en: Chapter I.
vi: Chapter 1
tr: Chapter I
es: CHAPTER 1

en: IT is a truth universally acknowledged, that a single man in possession of a good fortune must be in want of a wife.
vi: There is a truth universally acknowledged, that a single man in possession of a good fortune must be in want of a wife.
tr: It is a universally acknowledged truth that a single man in possession of a good fortune must be in want of a wife.
es: It is a truth universally acknowledged, that a single man in possession of a good fortune, must be in want of a wife.

en: However little known the feelings or views of such a man may be on his first entering a neighbourhood, this truth is so well fixed in the minds of the surrounding families, that he is considered as the rightful property of some one or other of their daughters.
vi: Even though very little is known about the feelings or views of such a man when he first moves into a neighborhood, this truth is so well fixed in the minds of the surrounding families that he is considered the rightful property of one or another of their daughters.
tr: No one knows what a man like this feels or thinks when he takes his first step into a new environment, but this fact is so ingrained in the minds of the families in the vicinity that they consider him the rightful property of one of their daughters.
es: However, little is known about the feelings or opinions of a man of such conditions when he becomes part of a neighborhood. This truth is so ingrained in the minds of some of the families around him, that some consider him their rightful property and others that of their daughters.

en: “My dear Mr. Bennet,” said his lady to him one day, “have you heard that Netherfield Park is let at last?”
vi: One day, Mrs. Bennet said to her husband: - My dear, do you know that someone has rented Netherfield Park?
tr: "Have you heard, Mr. Bennet, my dear," his wife said one day, "Netherfield Park is finally let."
es: ––My dear Mr. Bennet ––his wife said to him one day––, did you know that Netherfield Park has finally been rented?

en: Mr. Bennet replied that he had not.
vi: Mr. Bennet replied that he did not know yet.
tr: Mr. Bennet said he did not hear.
es: Mr. Bennet replied no.

en: “But it is,” returned she; “for Mrs. Long has just been here, and she told me all about it.”
vi: The wife continued: - Someone has already rented it. Mrs. Long went there and told me all about it.
tr: "But he is smitten," continued his wife; "Mrs. Long was here just now, she told me everything."
es: ––Well, that's how it is ––she insisted––; Mrs. Long was here a moment ago and told me everything.

en: Mr. Bennet made no answer.
vi: Mr. Bennet listened and did not reply.
tr: Mr. Bennet did not reply.
es: Mr. Bennet made no move to reply.

en: “Do not you want to know who has taken it?” cried his wife, impatiently.
vi: His wife, losing all patience, said: "Do you want to know who has just moved in?"
tr: "Aren't you curious who took it?" his wife shouted impatiently.
es: ––Don't you want to know who rented it? ––his wife grew impatient.

en: “You want to tell me, and I have no objection to hearing it.”
vi: - It is you who wants to tell me the story.
tr: "If you want to say it, I won't object."
es: ––You are the one who wants to tell me, and I have no problem listening to it.

en: This was invitation enough.
vi: That was enough encouragement for her to continue speaking.
tr: This many invitations were enough for him.
es: This suggestion was enough for him.

en: “Why, my dear, you must know, Mrs. Long says that Netherfield is taken by a young man of large fortune from the north of England; that he came down on Monday in a chaise and four to see the place, and was so much delighted with it that he agreed with Mr. Morris immediately; that he is to take possession before Michaelmas, and some of his servants are to be in the house by the end of next week.”
vi: - You must know, Mrs. Long has informed me that there is a young, wealthy gentleman from the North who has rented Netherfield. He arrived on Monday in a four-horse carriage. He likes the place very much and agreed immediately to Mr. Morris's price. And he is supposed to arrive before St. Michael's Day, but some of his servants will come ahead next week.
tr: "Well, darling, you must listen to this, Mrs. Long says that a young man from northern England, who is very wealthy, has bought Netherfield; he came on Sunday with a four-horse carriage to see the place and liked it so much that he immediately made an agreement with Mr. Morris; he will take over the property before Michaelmas, and some of his servants will be in the house by the end of next week.""
es: ––Well, you should know, dear, that Mrs. Long says that Netherfield has been rented by a very rich young man from the north of England; that he came on Monday in a four-horse landau to see the place; and that he was so delighted with it that he immediately came to an agreement with Mr. Morris; that he will come to occupy it before Michaelmas; and that some of his servants will be in the house by the end of next week.

en: “What is his name?”
vi: - So what is his name?
tr: "What is his/her name?""
es: ––What is your name?

en: “Bingley.”
vi: - Bingley.
tr: "Bingley.""
es: ––Bingley.

en: “Is he married or single?”
vi: - Is he married or still single?
tr: "Is he married or single?""
es: ––Are you married or single?

en: “Oh, single, my dear, to be sure! A single man of large fortune; four or five thousand a year. What a fine thing for our girls!”
vi: - Ah, he must still be single. A single man with a large income, four or five thousand pounds a year. That would be a good thing for our daughters!
tr: "Ah! Single, my dear, of course single! A very rich bachelor, earning four or five thousand a year. What a delightful thing for our daughters!"
es: ––Oh! Single, dear, of course. A single man of great fortune; four or five thousand pounds a year. What a good match for our daughters!

en: “How so? how can it affect them?”
vi: - So what? What does that have to do with our daughters?
tr: "What do you mean? What does it have to do with our daughters?"
es: ––And what? How can it affect them?

en: “My dear Mr. Bennet,” replied his wife, “how can you be so tiresome? You must know that I am thinking of his marrying one of them.”
vi: - Dear, you must understand that I am thinking about him marrying one of our children.
tr: "My dear Mr. Bennet," replied his wife, "how can you be so tiresome! You must have realized that I was thinking of marrying one of the girls to him."
es: ––My dear Mr. Bennet ––replied his wife––, how can you be so naive? You must know that I am thinking of marrying him to one of them.

en: “Is that his design in settling here?”
vi: - So, did that guy have such an intention when he came here?
tr: "Did he come here for this purpose?""
es: ––Is that the reason that brought you here?

en: “Design? Nonsense, how can you talk so! But it is very likely that he may fall in love with one of them, and therefore you must visit him as soon as he comes.”
vi: - Intention? How can you speak so recklessly? It's just that he might fall in love with one of our daughters, so you must visit him as soon as possible.
tr: "Did he come here for this purpose?"" "How can you talk like that! It's very likely that he has fallen in love with one of the girls; that's why you should visit him as soon as you arrive."
es: ––"Reason! Nonsense, how can you say that?" "It is very possible that he may fall in love with one of them, and that is why you must go visit him as soon as he arrives."

en: “I see no occasion for that. You and the girls may go—or you may send them by themselves, which perhaps will be still better; for as you are as handsome as any of them, Mr. Bingley might like you the best of the party.”
vi: - I don't see any opportunity at all. You and the kids can go, or let the kids go by themselves, that might be better. Because you are more beautiful than them, I'm afraid Mr. Bingley might like you more.
tr: "There is no reason for this. You can go with the girls, or you can send them on their own, in fact, this might be better because since you are not inferior to them in beauty, Mr. Bingley might choose you instead."
es: ––I don't see the reason for it. You can go with the girls or send them alone, which might be better; since you are as pretty as any of them, maybe Mr. Bingley will prefer you.

en: “My dear, you flatter me. I certainly have had my share of beauty, but I do not pretend to be anything extraordinary now. When a woman has five grown-up daughters, she ought to give over thinking of her own beauty.”
vi: - Oh sir, you are flattering me again. Surely, I once had my youthful days, but now I cannot consider myself special. When a woman has five grown daughters, she should no longer think about her own beauty.
tr: "You flatter me, darling. Of course, I've had my share of beauty, but I can no longer think highly of myself. A woman who has raised five daughters should stop thinking about her own beauty."
es: ––Dear, you flatter me. It is true that at one time I wasn't bad at all, but now I can't pretend to be anything out of the ordinary. When a woman has five grown daughters, she must stop thinking about her own beauty.

en: “In such cases, a woman has not often much beauty to think of.”
vi: - Well, only when that woman doesn't have any beauty worth thinking about.
tr: "In that case, there wouldn't be any beauty to think about anyway.""
es: ––In such cases, most women don't have much beauty left to think about.

en: “But, my dear, you must indeed go and see Mr. Bingley when he comes into the neighbourhood.”
vi: - But hey, you should go meet Mr. Bingley as soon as he arrives here.
tr: "Sweetheart, when he moves in, you really must go and see Mr. Bingley."
es: ––Well, dear, really, you have to go visit Mr. Bingley as soon as he settles in the neighborhood.

en: “It is more than I engage for, I assure you.”
vi: - To be honest, it's beyond my ability.
tr: "I can't promise that much, be sure of it."
es: ––I don't guarantee it.

en: “But consider your daughters. Only think what an establishment it would be for one of them. Sir William and Lady Lucas are determined to go, merely on that account; for in general, you know, they visit no new comers. Indeed you must go, for it will be impossible for us to visit him, if you do not.”
vi: You know... - But you have to think about the children. Just think that one of them might achieve something. Sir William and Lady Lucas are also determined to go for that very reason. You know they usually don't like visiting new people. In fact, you must go, otherwise, the children and I have no reason to go if you don't.
tr: "But think of your daughters. Look, what a great match for the girls. Sir William and Lady Lucas are determined to go, and just because of this, because you know they usually don't visit newcomers. You really must go, because if you don't go, it will be impossible for us to go."
es: ––But think of your daughters. Realize what a match it would be for one of them. Sir William and Lady Lucas are determined to go, and only for that purpose. You know they usually don't visit new neighbors. Really, you must go, because it will be impossible for us to visit him if you don't.

en: “You are over scrupulous, surely. I dare say Mr. Bingley will be very glad to see you; and I will send a few lines by you to assure him of my hearty consent to his marrying whichever he chooses of the girls—though I must throw in a good word for my little Lizzy.”
vi: - You are being overly cautious. I am sure that Mr. Bingley will be pleased to meet you, and I will send you with a few lines to let him know that I am willing to accept, if he chooses one of my daughters, although I will say little to praise Lizzy.
tr: "You are calculating things very precisely. I'm sure Mr. Bingley will be very happy to see you; I will also write a few lines and send them with you, saying that I am fine with whichever of the girls he chooses; but of course, I need to add something nice for my little Lizzy."
es: ––You are too modest. I am sure that Mr. Bingley will be very glad to see you; and you will take him a few lines from me to assure him that he has my most sincere consent to marry one of them; although I will put in a good word for my little Lizzy.

en: “I desire you will do no such thing. Lizzy is not a bit better than the others: and I am sure she is not half so handsome as Jane, nor half so good-humoured as Lydia. But you are always giving her the preference.”
vi: - I hope you won't do that. Lizzy is no better than the others, and I don't think she's half as beautiful as Jane, nor half as lively as Lydia, yet you always favor her the most!
tr: "I hope you don't do such a thing. Lizzy is not even a bit superior to the others; she is neither half as beautiful as Jane, nor half as good-natured as Lydia. But you always side with her."
es: ––I refuse to let you do such a thing. Lizzy is no better than the others, she is not half as pretty as Jane, nor half as cheerful as Lydia. But you always prefer her.

en: “They have none of them much to recommend them,” replied he: “they are all silly and ignorant like other girls; but Lizzy has something more of quickness than her sisters.”
vi: - So, do you think those kids have anything worth mentioning?
tr: "None of them have any remarkable qualities," replied Mr. Bennet; "they are all silly and ignorant like other girls; but Lizzy is smarter than her sisters."
es: ––None of the three are very recommendable ––he replied––. They are as silly and ignorant as the other girls; but Lizzy has a bit more sharpness than her sisters.

en: “Mr. Bennet, how can you abuse your own children in such a way? You take delight in vexing me. You have no compassion on my poor nerves.”
vi: - Mr. Bennet, how can you humiliate our children like that? You just tease me to get me upset for fun. You have no sympathy for my sensitive nerves at all!
tr: "Mr. Bennet, how can you belittle your own children like this? You take pleasure in vexing me. You have no compassion for my poor nerves."
es: ––Mr. Bennet! How can you speak like that about your daughters? You love to upset me. You have no compassion for my poor nerves.

en: “You mistake me, my dear. I have a high respect for your nerves. They are my old friends. I have heard you mention them with consideration these twenty years at least.”
vi: - You are mistaken. I have great respect for your nerves. At least for the past twenty years, I have heard you talk a lot about your nerves.
tr: "You misunderstood me, my dear. I have great respect for your nerves. Your nerves are my old friend. For at least twenty years, I have been persistently listening to you talk about your nerves."
es: ––You are mistaken, dear. I have a lot of respect for your nerves. They are old friends of mine. For at least twenty years, I have heard you mention them with much consideration.

en: “Ah, you do not know what I suffer.”
vi: - Hmph! You can't possibly know how much I've suffered...
tr: "How would you know what I've been through.""
es: ––You don't know how much I suffer!

en: “But I hope you will get over it, and live to see many young men of four thousand a year come into the neighbourhood.”
vi: - But I hope you will soon get over it, and continue to live to see many young men with four thousand pounds a year come to reside in this area.
tr: "You will get through it, live many more years, and see many young people who earn four thousand a year come here.""
es: ––But you will get well and live to see many young men with four thousand pounds a year come to this place.

en: “It will be no use to us, if twenty such should come, since you will not visit them.”
vi: - If twenty people like that come here but you refuse to meet them, it will be pointless.
tr: "Even if twenty come, it won't be of any use to us if you don't visit.""
es: ––It would be useless if those twenty young people came and you didn't go to visit them.

en: “Depend upon it, my dear, that when there are twenty, I will visit them all.”
vi: - When there are twenty people, I will go meet everyone.
tr: "Rest assured, my dear, if there are twenty, I will visit them all.""
es: ––If it depends on that, dear, as soon as the twenty are here, I will visit them all.

en: Mr. Bennet was so odd a mixture of quick parts, sarcastic humour, reserve, and caprice, that the experience of three-and-twenty years had been insufficient to make his wife understand his character. Her mind was less difficult to develope. She was a woman of mean understanding, little information, and uncertain temper. When she was discontented, she fancied herself nervous. The business of her life was to get her daughters married: its solace was visiting and news.
vi: Mr. Bennet's personality was a blend of cunning, sarcastic humor, reserve, and unpredictability, so much so that even after decades of living together, his wife still couldn't understand him. Her mind was simpler. She had a narrow-minded empathy, poor knowledge, and an erratic temperament. When things didn't go her way, she felt as if she were anxious. Her whole life revolved around finding husbands for her five daughters. Visiting and exchanging gossip were her ways of relieving boredom.
tr: Mr. Bennet was such a mixture of odd quick-wittedness, subtle sarcasm, coldness, and selfishness that twenty-three years of experience had not been enough for his wife to understand his character. Understanding his wife's temperament was less difficult. She was a woman of limited understanding, low education, and unpredictable reactions. When she was unhappy, she thought her nerves were disturbed. Her whole concern in life was to marry off her daughters; her solace was visits and news.
es: Mr. Bennet was such a rare mixture of witty, sarcastic, reserved, and capricious that twenty-three years of experience had not been enough for his wife to understand his character. However, hers was less difficult; she was a woman of little intelligence, rather uneducated, and of uneven temperament. Her goal in life was to marry off her daughters; her consolation, visits and gossip.

en: Mr. & Mrs. Bennet
vi: Pride and Prejudice Jane Austen
tr: Her whole concern in life was to marry off her daughters; her solace was visits and news.
es: Her goal in life was to marry off her daughters; her consolation, visits and gossip.

en: CHAPTER II.
vi: www. dtv-ebook. com Chapter 2
tr: Chapter II
es: CHAPTER II

en: MR. BENNET was among the earliest of those who waited on Mr. Bingley. He had always intended to visit him, though to the last always assuring his wife that he should not go; and till the evening after the visit was paid she had no knowledge of it. It was then disclosed in the following manner. Observing his second daughter employed in trimming a hat, he suddenly addressed her with,—
vi: Mr. Bennet was one of the earliest visitors to call on Bingley. He always intended to visit him, although he constantly told his wife that he did not want to go. It was not until the evening after the visit that his wife learned of it. While watching his second daughter trim a hat, he suddenly said to her: - Lizzy, I hope Mr. Bingley will like this hat.
tr: Mr. Bennet was one of the first to visit Mr. Bingley. Although he convinced his wife until the last moment that he would not go, he had intended to go from the beginning; he did not tell his wife about the visit until the evening. In the evening, he explained it in the following manner. While watching his second daughter decorate a hat, he suddenly said,
es: Mr. Bennet was one of the first to pay his respects to Mr. Bingley. He always intended to visit him, although, in the end, he always assured his wife that he would not; and until the evening after his visit, his wife knew nothing about it. The matter came to light in the following way: observing how his daughter was putting on a hat, Mr. Bennet said:

en: “I hope Mr. Bingley will like it, Lizzy.”
vi: While watching his second daughter trim a hat, he suddenly said to her: - Lizzy, I hope Mr. Bingley will like this hat.
tr: "I hope Mr. Bingley likes it, Lizzy," she said.
es: ––I hope Mr. Bingley likes it, Lizzy.

en: “We are not in a way to know what Mr. Bingley likes,” said her mother, resentfully, “since we are not to visit.”
vi: She was offended: - We cannot know what he likes because we do not visit him.
tr: "We have no way of knowing what Mr. Bingley likes," said her mother sorrowfully, "since we are not going to visit him."
es: ––How can we know what Mr. Bingley likes ––said his resentful wife–– if we haven't visited him yet?

en: “But you forget, mamma,” said Elizabeth, “that we shall meet him at the assemblies, and that Mrs. Long has promised to introduce him.”
vi: Elizabeth said: - Have you forgotten? We will meet him at the gathering, and Mrs. Long has promised to introduce us to him.
tr: "But you are forgetting, mother," said Elizabeth, "we will meet him at the ball; Mrs. Long promised to introduce us.""
es: ––You forget, mom ––said Elizabeth–– that we will see him at the parties, and that Mrs. Long has promised to introduce him to us.

en: “I do not believe Mrs. Long will do any such thing. She has two nieces of her own. She is a selfish, hypocritical woman, and I have no opinion of her.”
vi: - Mom doesn't believe Mrs. Long would do such a thing. She still has two granddaughters. She is a selfish, hypocritical, and untrustworthy person.
tr: "I don't think Mrs. Long will introduce him. She has her own two nieces. She's a selfish, hypocritical woman, I don't respect her."
es: ––I don't believe Mrs. Long would do such a thing. She has two nieces to think about; she is selfish and hypocritical and does not deserve my trust.

en: “No more have I,” said Mr. Bennet; “and I am glad to find that you do not depend on her serving you.”
vi: Mr. Bennet interjected - I don't believe it either, so I'm glad you have no intention of asking her for help.
tr: "Nor will I," said Mr. Bennet; "besides, I can gladly say that you do not need his help."
es: ––Nor is mine ––said Mr. Bennet–– and I am glad to know that you do not rely on her services.

en: Mrs. Bennet deigned not to make any reply; but, unable to contain herself, began scolding one of her daughters.
vi: Mrs. Bennet did not bother to reply, but unable to contain herself, she turned to scold her daughters.
tr: Mrs. Bennet did not deign to respond, but she couldn't help starting to scold one of her daughters.
es: Mrs. Bennet did not deign to reply; but unable to contain herself, she began to scold one of her daughters.

en: “Don’t keep coughing so, Kitty, for heaven’s sake! Have a little compassion on my nerves. You tear them to pieces.”
vi: - Kitty, don't keep coughing like that. You have to consider your mother's nerves a bit. My head is about to explode here.
tr: "For God's sake, Kitty, stop coughing like that! Have some pity on my nerves. You've shredded my nerves to pieces."
es: ––For the love of God, Kitty, stop coughing like that! Have mercy on my nerves. You are destroying them.

en: “Kitty has no discretion in her coughs,” said her father; “she times them ill.”
vi: The father interjected: - Kitty coughs without any discretion, coughing at inappropriate times.
tr: "Kitty is not careful about coughing at all," said her father; "she coughs at the wrong time."
es: ––Kitty is not at all discreet when coughing ––said her father––. She always does it at an inopportune moment.

en: “I do not cough for my own amusement,” replied Kitty, fretfully. “When is your next ball to be, Lizzy?”
vi: Kitty replied miserably: - I'm not happy enough to laugh like that. - When is your prom?
tr: "I'm not coughing for fun," Kitty replied irritably. "When is the first ball, Lizzy?"
es: ––I don't find coughing amusing ––complained Kitty. ––When is your next dance, Lizzy?

en: “To-morrow fortnight.”
vi: - Two more weeks.
tr: "Next week is tomorrow.""
es: ––In fifteen days from tomorrow.

en: “Ay, so it is,” cried her mother, “and Mrs. Long does not come back till the day before; so, it will be impossible for her to introduce him, for she will not know him herself.”
vi: The mother exclaimed in shock: - Ah, I see. Mrs. Long will only return the day before that, so she can't introduce him because she doesn't know him yet.
tr: "There you go," cried his mother, "Mrs. Long will only return a day before, and then she won't be able to introduce the man, because she herself wouldn't have met him yet."
es: ––Yes, that's right ––exclaimed the mother––. And Mrs. Long won't return until the day before; so it will be impossible for her to introduce us to Mr. Bingley, because she still won't know him.

en: “Then, my dear, you may have the advantage of your friend, and introduce Mr. Bingley to her.”
vi: - So you have an advantage over your friend, just introduce Mr. Bingley to the girl.
tr: "Then, my dear, take your friend's place and introduce Mr. Bingley to her.""
es: ––Then, Mrs. Bennet, you can get ahead of your friend and introduce him to her yourself.

en: “Impossible, Mr. Bennet, impossible, when I am not acquainted with him myself; how can you be so teasing?”
vi: - It's not possible, sir, it's not possible, as I still haven't gotten to know him. How can you joke like that?
tr: "Impossible, Mr. Bennet, impossible, I haven't even met the man yet; how can you be so exasperating?"
es: ––Impossible, Mr. Bennet, impossible, when I don't know him either. Why are you mocking me?

en: “I honour your circumspection. A fortnight’s acquaintance is certainly very little. One cannot know what a man really is by the end of a fortnight. But if we do not venture, somebody else will; and after all, Mrs. Long and her nieces must stand their chance; and, therefore, as she will think it an act of kindness, if you decline the office, I will take it on myself.”
vi: - I commend you for being cautious. Two weeks is too little time to get acquainted. We cannot know what someone we just met thinks after only two weeks, but if we are not bold, others will take the initiative. Anyway, Mrs. Long and her two nieces also want to try their luck. If we do not move forward, she will think we are yielding, and she will seize the opportunity.
tr: "I agree with your meticulousness. Fifteen days of acquaintance is certainly very little. A person cannot be known in fifteen days. But if we don't take action, someone else will; besides, Mrs. Long and her nieces will also try their luck; so, isn't the point courtesy? If you refuse the help, I can take on this task."
es: ––I commend your discretion. A friendship of fifteen days is truly very short. In reality, after only two weeks, one cannot really know what kind of man he is. But if we do not take the risk, others will. After all, Mrs. Long and her nieces can wait for their opportunity to present itself; but, nevertheless, as she will believe it to be an act of delicacy on her part to decline the attention, I will be the one to introduce him to you.

en: The girls stared at their father. Mrs. Bennet said only, “Nonsense, nonsense!”
vi: The girls stared at their father. Mrs. Bennet only said: - Nonsense, absolute nonsense!
tr: The girls looked at their father. Mrs. Bennet simply said, "You are being ridiculous!"
es: The girls stared at their father intently. Mrs. Bennet simply said: ––Nonsense, nonsense!

en: “What can be the meaning of that emphatic exclamation?” cried he. “Do you consider the forms of introduction, and the stress that is laid on them, as nonsense? I cannot quite agree with you there. What say you, Mary? For you are a young lady of deep reflection, I know, and read great books, and make extracts.”
vi: - What do you mean by that? Do you mean that the way of introduction and the tension in this matter are unreasonable? I cannot agree with you on this point. Mary, do you have any opinions? Dad knows you like to think carefully, enjoy reading good books, and often quote from them.
tr: "What could be the meaning of this harsh word?" cried Mr. Bennet. "Do you see the customs of acquaintance and the importance given to them as nonsense? I do not agree with you on that matter. What do you say, Mary, as a girl with deep thoughts, who reads big books and takes notes?"
es: "––What does that emphatic exclamation mean? ––asked Mr. Bennet––." "Do you consider the formalities of introduction as nonsense, given their importance?" "I do not agree with you on that." "What do you say, Mary?" "I know that you are a very thoughtful young woman, and that you read great books and summarize them."

en: Mary wished to say something very sensible, but knew not how.
vi: Mary wanted to say something reasonable, but couldn't think of anything.
tr: Mary wanted to say something very meaningful, but she couldn't manage it.
es: Mary wanted to say something sensible, but she didn't know how.

en: “While Mary is adjusting her ideas,” he continued, “let us return to Mr. Bingley.”
vi: He continued: - While Mary is gathering her thoughts, let's return to the story of Mr. Bingley.
tr: "While Mary gathers her thoughts," continued Mr. Bennet, "let us return to Mr. Bingley."
es: ––While Mary clarifies her thoughts ––he continued––, let's return to Mr. Bingley.

en: “I am sick of Mr. Bingley,” cried his wife.
vi: The wife raised her voice: - I'm too tired of this Bingley guy.
tr: "I'm tired of Mr. Bingley," cried his wife.
es: ––I'm fed up with Mr. Bingley! ––shouted his wife.

en: “I am sorry to hear that; but why did you not tell me so before? If I had known as much this morning, I certainly would not have called on him. It is very unlucky; but as I have actually paid the visit, we cannot escape the acquaintance now.”
vi: - I am sorry to hear you say that, but why didn't you say it earlier? If I had known this morning, I certainly wouldn't have gone to meet him. It's really unfortunate, but since I have met him, we can't avoid this acquaintance now.
tr: "I'm sorry to hear that; but why didn't you tell me earlier? If I had known this in the morning, I wouldn't have visited the man. It's a great misfortune; but since I went, we can't pretend we haven't met anymore."
es: ––I'm very sorry to hear that; why didn't you tell me earlier? If I had known this morning, I wouldn't have gone to their house. Bad luck! But since I have already visited them, we cannot give up their friendship now.

en: The astonishment of the ladies was just what he wished—that of Mrs. Bennet perhaps surpassing the rest; though when the first tumult of joy was over, she began to declare that it was what she had expected all the while.
vi: The astonishment of the girls was exactly what he desired; Mrs. Bennet herself was even more astonished than her daughters, yet after moments of agitation came joy; she believed that this was what she had always wished for.
tr: The ladies' astonishment was just as he wanted; in fact, Mrs. Bennet's surpassed the others; yet, as the first wave of joy subsided, Mrs. Bennet began to say that she had expected this all along.
es: The astonishment of the ladies was precisely what he desired; perhaps Mrs. Bennet's surpassed the rest; although once the commotion caused by the joy was over, she declared that deep down it was what she had always imagined.

en: “How good it was in you, my dear Mr. Bennet! But I knew I should persuade you at last. I was sure you loved your girls too well to neglect such an acquaintance. Well, how pleased I am! And it is such a good joke, too, that you should have gone this morning, and never said a word about it till now.”
vi: - My dear Mr. Bennet, how kind you are! But I know in the end I still have to persuade you. I know very well that you love the children very much, so you cannot overlook such an acquaintance. I'm so happy! It's quite amusing how you joked this morning, going without saying a word until now.
tr: "How good you are, dear Mr. Bennet! But I knew I would eventually convince you. I was sure you loved your daughters too much to neglect such an acquaintance. Oh, how pleased I am! Also, it's such a good joke, you go this morning, but don't say a word until this hour."
es: ––My dear Mr. Bennet, how good you are! But I knew that in the end I would convince you. I was sure that you love your daughters enough not to neglect this matter. How happy I am! And what a funny joke, that you went this morning and didn't tell us anything until now!

en: “Now, Kitty, you may cough as much as you choose,” said Mr. Bennet; and, as he spoke, he left the room, fatigued with the raptures of his wife.
vi: Mr. Bennet turned to Kitty and said, "Kitty, you may cough as much as you like now." He spoke as he walked out of the room, feeling tired from his wife's enthusiastic words.
tr: "Come now, Kitty, you can cough as much as you want," said Mr. Bennet; saying this, he left the room, exhausted from his wife's enthusiasm.
es: ––Now, Kitty, you may cough as much as you want ––said Mr. Bennet; and he left the room, tired by his wife's enthusiasm.

en: “What an excellent father you have, girls,” said she, when the door was shut. “I do not know how you will ever make him amends for his kindness; or me either, for that matter. At our time of life, it is not so pleasant, I can tell you, to be making new acquaintances every day; but for your sakes we would do anything. Lydia, my love, though you are the youngest, I dare say Mr. Bingley will dance with you at the next ball.”
vi: When the door of the room had closed, she told her children: "See, you have a wonderful father." "I don't understand how you will repay your father's care, even I don't know." "I don't mind telling you, at our age, making new acquaintances every day is not very pleasant, but we are willing to do everything for you." "Lydia, although you are the youngest, I am sure Mr. Bingley will dance with you at the upcoming ball."
tr: "You have a wonderful father, girls," said Mrs. Bennet, as the door closed. "I don't know how you will repay his efforts, or even mine. At our age, meeting someone new every day is not very pleasant; but we do everything for your sake. Lydia, my dear, you are the youngest, but I think Mr. Bingley will dance with you at the first ball."
es: ––What an excellent father you have, daughters! ––she said once the door was closed––. I don't know how you will ever be able to thank him for his kindness, nor do I, for that matter. At this point, I assure you that it is not pleasant to make new acquaintances every day. But for you, we would do anything. Lydia, dear, even though you are the youngest, I would bet that Mr. Bingley will dance with you at the next ball.

en: “Oh,” said Lydia, stoutly, “I am not afraid; for though I am the youngest, I’m the tallest.”
vi: Lydia said firmly: - I'm not afraid. Although I'm the youngest, I'm taller than my sisters.
tr: "Yo!" said Lydia, boldly, "I'm not afraid; I may be the youngest, but I'm the tallest."
es: ––I am calm ––said Lydia firmly––, because although I am the youngest, I am the tallest.

en: The rest of the evening was spent in conjecturing how soon he would return Mr. Bennet’s visit, and determining when they should ask him to dinner.
vi: And for the rest of the evening, they took turns guessing when Mr. Bingley would visit Mr. Bennet to return the courtesy, and discussed when they could invite him to dinner.
tr: The later hours of the evening were spent guessing when Mr. Bingley would return the visit and deciding when they could invite him to dinner.
es: The rest of the afternoon was spent making guesses about whether Mr. Bingley would soon return Mr. Bennet's visit, and deciding when they could invite him to dinner.

en: CHAPTER III.
vi: Chapter 3
tr: Chapter III
es: CHAPTER III

en: NOT all that Mrs. Bennet, however, with the assistance of her five daughters, could ask on the subject, was sufficient to draw from her husband any satisfactory description of Mr. Bingley. They attacked him in various ways, with barefaced questions, ingenious suppositions, and distant surmises; but he eluded the skill of them all; and they were at last obliged to accept the second-hand intelligence of their neighbour, Lady Lucas. Her report was highly favourable. Sir William had been delighted with him. He was quite young, wonderfully handsome, extremely agreeable, and, to crown the whole, he meant to be at the next assembly with a large party. Nothing could be more delightful! To be fond of dancing was a certain step towards falling in love; and very lively hopes of Mr. Bingley’s heart were entertained.
vi: However, through her husband, Mrs. Bennet could not learn much about Mr. Bingley, even with the assistance of their five daughters. They questioned him in every possible way, with every question, every marvelous conjecture, every vague assumption, but he evaded them all. In the end, they had to accept indirect information from their neighbor, Mrs. Lucas. The news she provided was very favorable. Sir William had a particular fondness for Mr. Bingley. He was a fairly young man, very handsome and extremely amiable, and most importantly, he intended to bring many people to the ball. Nothing could be more perfect. A fondness for dancing is the first step towards a romance, so everyone freely hoped for his heart.
tr: Despite Mrs. Bennet's persistent efforts with her five daughters, she couldn't manage to get a satisfactory description of Mr. Bingley from her husband. They attacked the poor man from all sides, with impudent questions, cunning guesses, and distant hints, but he deflected all these attempts; in the end, they had to settle for the second-hand information obtained by their neighbor Lady Lucas. Lady Lucas's report was quite positive. Sir William liked the man. He was very young, wonderfully handsome, extremely charming, and, to crown it all, he intended to attend the first ball with a large group of friends. Nothing could be more delightful! Loving to dance was an important step towards falling in love; pleasant hopes were entertained for Mr. Bingley's heart.
es: No matter how much Mrs. Bennet, with the help of her daughters, inquired about the matter, she could not get any satisfactory description of Mr. Bingley from her husband. They attacked him in various ways: with very clear questions, clever suppositions, and hints; but no matter how skillful they were, he evaded them all. And in the end, they were forced to accept second-hand information from their neighbor Lady Lucas. Her impression was very favorable, Sir William had been delighted with him. He was young, very handsome, extremely pleasant, and to top it off, he planned to attend the next ball with a group of friends. There could be nothing better. His fondness for dancing was truly an advantage when it came to falling in love; and thus, lively hopes were kindled to win Mr. Bingley's heart.

en: “If I can but see one of my daughters happily settled at Netherfield,” said Mrs. Bennet to her husband, “and all the others equally well married, I shall have nothing to wish for.”
vi: Mrs. Bennet said to her husband: - If I could just see one daughter having a happy life at Netherfield, and the other four having similar good fortunes, I would have no more wishes.
tr: "If I could see one of my daughters happily settled at Netherfield," said Mrs. Bennet to her husband, "and the others making such good marriages, I would not want anything else in the world."
es: ––If I could see one of my daughters living happily in Netherfield, and the others equally well married, I would desire nothing more in life––said Mrs. Bennet to her husband.

en: In a few days Mr. Bingley returned Mr. Bennet’s visit, and sat about ten minutes with him in his library. He had entertained hopes of being admitted to a sight of the young ladies, of whose beauty he had heard much; but he saw only the father. The ladies were somewhat more fortunate, for they had the advantage of ascertaining, from an upper window, that he wore a blue coat and rode a black horse.
vi: A few days later, Bingley returned Mr. Bennet's visit, and during the ten minutes he spent with him in the study, he hoped to be allowed to meet the girls, whom he had heard others praise for their beauty, but he only met the father. The girls were luckier, as they could observe him from the upstairs window, seeing him wearing a blue coat and riding a black horse.
tr: Within a few days, Mr. Bingley returned Mr. Bennet's visit and sat with him in the library for about ten minutes. He had hoped to be admitted to the presence of the young ladies whose beauty he had heard of, but he could only see the father. The ladies were a bit luckier; they had the opportunity to see from the upstairs window that he was wearing a blue coat and riding a black horse.
es: A few days later, Mr. Bingley returned Mr. Bennet's visit and spent ten minutes with him in his library. He had hoped to be allowed to see the young ladies whose beauty he had heard so much about; but he saw no one but the father. The ladies were a bit more fortunate, as they had the advantage of being able to observe from a high window that Mr. Bingley wore a blue coat and rode a black horse.

en: An invitation to dinner was soon afterwards despatched; and already had Mrs. Bennet planned the courses that were to do credit to her housekeeping, when an answer arrived which deferred it all. Mr. Bingley was obliged to be in town the following day, and consequently unable to accept the honour of their invitation, etc. Mrs. Bennet was quite disconcerted. She could not imagine what business he could have in town so soon after his arrival in Hertfordshire; and she began to fear that he might always be flying about from one place to another, and never settled at Netherfield as he ought to be. Lady Lucas quieted her fears a little by starting the idea of his
vi: Then came the invitation to dinner, and Mrs. Bennet hurriedly arranged many things before receiving a response. Mr. Bingley had business in London the next day and could not accept the invitation. Mrs. Bennet was disappointed. She could not imagine what important business he had in the city right after arriving in Hertfordshire. She began to worry that he might flit from place to place without settling down at Netherfield. Lady Lucas had to reassure her, suggesting that Bingley was only going to London to invite friends to the ball.
tr: The dinner invitation was conveyed to him immediately; Mrs. Bennet had just started planning meals that would bring prestige to her hosting when a reply came postponing everything. Mr. Bingley had to go to town the next day, so he regrettably could not accept their invitation, etc. Mrs. Bennet was very upset. She couldn't understand what business he could have in town right after arriving in Hertfordshire; she began to fear that he might be someone who constantly flits from place to place and would not properly settle in Netherfield. Lady Lucas somewhat eased her fears by suggesting that he had gone to London just to bring a large group of friends for the ball; soon, news arrived that Mr. Bingley would bring twelve ladies and seven gentlemen to the ball.
es: Shortly afterwards, they sent him an invitation to come to dinner. And when Mrs. Bennet had already planned the dishes that would credit her good housekeeping, they received a response that ruined everything. Mr. Bingley was obliged to go to town the next day, and consequently could not accept the honor of their invitation. Mrs. Bennet was quite disconcerted. She could not imagine what business called him to town so soon after his arrival in Hertfordshire; and she began to fear that he would always be flitting about without settling down properly and as expected at Netherfield. Lady Lucas somewhat allayed her fears by concluding that he was only going to London to gather a group of friends for the party.

en: being gone to London only to get a large party for the ball; and a report soon followed that Mr. Bingley was to bring twelve ladies and seven gentlemen with him to the assembly. The girls grieved over such a number of ladies; but were comforted the day before the ball by hearing that, instead of twelve, he had brought only six with him from London, his five sisters and a cousin. And when the party entered the assembly-room, it consisted of only five altogether: Mr. Bingley, his two sisters, the husband of the eldest, and another young man.
vi: Soon, there was news that Mr. Bingley would bring twelve ladies and seven gentlemen to the ball. The girls were distressed to hear of such a large number of women, but on the morning before the ball, they heard that instead of twelve, he would bring only six people from London, five sisters and a cousin. When the ball began, there were only five people: Mr. Bingley, his two sisters, the husband of the elder sister, and another young man.
tr: Lady Lucas somewhat eased her fears by suggesting that he had gone to London just to bring a large group of friends for the ball; soon, news arrived that Mr. Bingley would bring twelve ladies and seven gentlemen to the ball. The girls were worried at the thought of so many ladies; but they were relieved when they heard the day before the ball that he had brought only six ladies from London instead of twelve, five of whom were his sisters and one his cousin. Finally, when they entered the ballroom, the group consisted of only five people; Mr. Bingley, his two sisters, the elder sister's husband, and another young man.
es: And soon the rumor spread that Bingley was going to bring twelve ladies and seven gentlemen for the ball. The girls were distressed by such a number of ladies; but the day before the ball, they were consoled to hear that instead of twelve, he had brought only six, five sisters and a cousin. And when the day of the ball arrived and they entered the hall, there were only five in total: Mr. Bingley, his two sisters, the husband of the eldest, and another young man.

en: Mr. Bingley was good-looking and gentlemanlike: he had a pleasant countenance, and easy, unaffected manners. His sisters were fine women, with an air of decided fashion. His brother-in-law, Mr. Hurst, merely looked the gentleman; but his friend Mr. Darcy soon drew the attention of the room by his fine, tall person, handsome features, noble mien, and the report, which was in general circulation within five minutes after his entrance, of his having ten thousand a year. The gentlemen pronounced him to be a fine figure of a man, the ladies declared he was much handsomer than Mr. Bingley, and he was looked at with great admiration for about half the evening, till his manners gave a disgust which turned the tide of his popularity; for he was discovered to be proud, to be above his company, and above being pleased; and not all his large estate in Derbyshire could save him from having a most forbidding, disagreeable countenance, and being unworthy to be compared with his friend.
vi: Mr. Bingley had a handsome appearance and a graceful demeanor. His face was pleasant, his gestures leisurely and sincere. His two sisters looked mature, with a style of decisive conduct. His brother-in-law, Mr. Hurst, only appeared courteous. But his friend, named Darcy, soon attracted the attention of the entire room, due to his tall, handsome, and elegant figure; and within five minutes of his entrance, there was a murmur that his annual income amounted to ten thousand a year. The gentlemen considered him well-proportioned, while the ladies thought he was even more handsome than Bingley. For half the evening, everyone had a favorable opinion of him. Afterwards, his own behavior caused many to despise him. They thought he was proud, that he placed himself above his friends, and did not mingle and enjoy himself with everyone. Even with his large estate in Derbyshire, his face bore an unpleasant, disagreeable expression, unworthy of comparison to his friend.
tr: Mr. Bingley was handsome and kind; he had a pleasant face and easy, unpretentious manners. His sisters were elegant women and had a fashionable air about them. His brother-in-law, Mr. Hurst, looked like a gentleman, and that was all; but his friend Mr. Darcy, with his fine, tall figure, handsome face, noble demeanor, and the rumor of his ten thousand a year income circulating within five minutes of his entrance, quickly drew the room's attention. The gentlemen declared him to be a fine man, and the ladies proclaimed him much more handsome than Mr. Bingley, and he attracted admiring glances until halfway through the evening, when his manners caused displeasure and reversed his popularity; for it was understood that he was proud, saw himself as superior to those around him, and was generally discontented; at that point, even his vast estate in Derbyshire could not save him from being found disagreeable, unattractive, and unworthy of comparison to his friend.
es: Mr. Bingley was handsome, had the appearance of a gentleman, a pleasant countenance, and simple, unaffected manners. His sisters were beautiful women of undeniable elegance. His brother-in-law, Mr. Hurst, hardly had the appearance of a gentleman; but it was his friend Mr. Darcy who soon drew the attention of the room with his distinguished personality. He was a tall man, with handsome features and an aristocratic bearing. A few minutes after his entrance, a rumor was already circulating that his income was ten thousand pounds a year. The gentlemen declared that he was a man of great class; the ladies said he was much more handsome than Bingley, and he was admired for almost half the evening, until his manners caused such displeasure that they changed the course of his good reputation; it was discovered that he was a proud man, who pretended to be above everyone else and showed his dissatisfaction with the environment around him; not even his extensive estates in Derbyshire could save him from appearing odious and unpleasant, and from being considered worthless compared to his friend.

en: Mr. Bingley had soon made himself acquainted with all the principal people in the room: he was lively and unreserved, danced every dance, was angry that the ball closed so early, and talked of giving one himself at Netherfield. Such amiable qualities must speak for themselves. What a contrast between him and his friend! Mr. Darcy danced only once with Mrs. Hurst and once with Miss Bingley, declined being introduced to any other lady, and spent the rest of the evening in walking about the room, speaking occasionally to one of his own party. His character was decided. He was the proudest, most disagreeable man in the world, and everybody hoped that he would never come there again. Amongst the most violent against him was Mrs. Bennet, whose dislike of his general behaviour was sharpened into particular resentment by his having slighted one of her daughters.
vi: It wasn't long before Bingley had acquainted himself with everyone important in the room. He appeared lively and unpretentious, danced to every piece of music, expressed dissatisfaction when the ball ended too early, and announced that he would host another ball at Netherfield. Between him and his friend, they were indeed two extremes! Mr. Darcy danced only once with Mrs. Hurst and once with Miss Bingley, did not wish to be introduced to other women, and then just walked around, occasionally talking to a few people in the group. Everyone quickly recognized his character. In this world, he might be the most disagreeable person, the most disagreeable, and everyone hoped he would not return. Mrs. Bennet, in particular, had the strongest aversion; she felt annoyed because he had slighted one of her daughters.
tr: Mr. Bingley had introduced himself to all the prominent people in the drawing room in a short time; he was lively and sincere, participated in every dance, was upset that the ball ended so early, and talked about hosting a ball at Netherfield himself. Such friendly actions give an idea about him. How opposite he was to his friend! Mr. Darcy danced only once with Mrs. Hurst and once with Miss Bingley; he refused to be introduced to any other lady and spent the rest of the evening walking around the room, occasionally chatting with someone from his own group. A decision was made about his character. He was the proudest, most disagreeable man in the world; everyone wished he would never come there again. One of the most vehement in her reaction was Mrs. Bennet; her general displeasure with the man turned to anger when he slighted one of her daughters.
es: Mr. Bingley immediately made friends with the main people in the room; he was lively and frank, did not miss a single dance, regretted that the party ended so early, and spoke of giving one himself at Netherfield. Such pleasant qualities spoke for themselves. What a difference between him and his friend! Mr. Darcy danced only once with Mrs. Hurst and once with Miss Bingley, refused to be introduced to any other lady, and spent the rest of the night wandering around the room and occasionally talking to some of his companions. His character was definitively judged. He was the proudest and most disagreeable man in the world, and everyone hoped he would not return there again. Among those most offended by Darcy was Mrs. Bennet, whose displeasure at his behavior had intensified, turning into a personal offense for having slighted one of her daughters.

en: Elizabeth Bennet had been obliged, by the scarcity of gentlemen, to sit down for two dances; and during part of that time, Mr. Darcy had been standing near enough for her to overhear a conversation between him and Mr. Bingley, who came from the dance for a few minutes to press his friend to join it.
vi: Because there were more women than men, Elizabeth Bennet had to sit out for two dances, and during that time Darcy talked to Bingley while standing quite close to her, so she overheard. Mr. Bingley wanted to persuade his friend to dance more.
tr: Elizabeth Bennet had to sit out for two dances due to a shortage of men; at one point, Mr. Darcy was standing so close to Elizabeth that she overheard a conversation between Mr. Bingley and her friend, who was trying to persuade him to join the dance for a few minutes.
es: There were so few gentlemen that Elizabeth Bennet had been obliged to sit down during two dances; during that time, Darcy was close enough to her for the young lady to hear a conversation between him and Mr. Bingley, who left the dance for a few minutes to persuade his friend to join them.

en: “Come, Darcy,” said he, “I must have you dance. I hate to see you standing about by yourself in this stupid manner. You had much better dance.”
vi: - Hey Darcy, you must dance. I don't like seeing you stand here with such a dull demeanor. Dancing is fun with others.
tr: "Come on Darcy," said Mr. Bingley, "you need to dance. I hate seeing you standing there all alone. Come on, dance."
es: ––Come, Darcy ––she said to him––, you have to dance. I can't stand seeing you standing there alone with that stupid attitude. It's better if you dance.

en: “I certainly shall not. You know how I detest it, unless I am particularly acquainted with my partner. At such an assembly as this, it would be insupportable. Your sisters are engaged, and there is not another woman in the room whom it would not be a punishment to me to stand up with.”
vi: - I don't like it. You know I hate dancing, except with someone I know well. I can't stand these people. Your sisters have partners, and I find dancing with the other women in the room to be torture.
tr: "Never. You know I don't like it, I don't dance without knowing my partner well. In such a gathering, it's impossible. Your sisters are occupied, and there is no other woman in the hall whom I can ask to dance without it being a torment for me."
es: ––I don't intend to do it. You know how much I hate it, unless I personally know my partner. At a party like this, it would be impossible for me. Your sisters are engaged, and dancing with any other woman in this room would be like a punishment for me.

en: “I would not be so fastidious as you are,” cried Bingley, “for a kingdom! Upon my honour, I never met with so many pleasant girls in my life as I have this evening; and there are several of them, you see, uncommonly pretty.”
vi: - Tờ is not as picky as you. To be honest, in my life, I have never met such lovely people, with a few being absolutely beautiful.
tr: "If they gave me the world," cried Bingley, "I wouldn't be as fastidious as you! Honestly, I've never seen so many beautiful girls together in my life; there are a few who are extraordinarily charming."
es: ––You shouldn't be so demanding and fussy ––complained Bingley––. For heaven's sake! Honestly, I've never seen so many charming girls as tonight; and there are some who are especially pretty.

en: “You are dancing with the only handsome girl in the room,” said Mr. Darcy, looking at the eldest Miss Bennet.
vi: Darcy looked at the eldest daughter of the Bennet family: - You only dance with the beautiful girls in this room.
tr: "Of course you are dancing with the most beautiful girl in the room," said Mr. Darcy, looking at the eldest Miss Bennet.
es: ––You are dancing with the only pretty girl in the room ––said Mr. Darcy, looking at the eldest of the Bennet sisters.

en: “Oh, she is the most beautiful creature I ever beheld! But there is one of her sisters sitting down just behind you, who is very pretty, and I dare say very agreeable. Do let me ask my partner to introduce you.”
vi: - She is the most beautiful person I have ever met! But the very pretty, very cute girl sitting behind you is also lovely. Allow me to ask my dance partner to introduce her to you.
tr: "The most beautiful creature I have ever seen! But there is a sibling sitting right behind you, who is also very beautiful and very cute. Let me tell my spouse to introduce you."
es: ––Oh! She is the most beautiful creature I have ever seen in my life! But right behind you is sitting one of her sisters who is very pretty and I would bet very nice. Let me ask my partner to introduce you to her. ––What are you saying?

en: “Which do you mean?” and turning round, he looked for a moment at Elizabeth, till, catching her eye, he withdrew his own, and coldly said, “She is tolerable: but not handsome enough to tempt me; and I am in no humour at present to give consequence to young ladies who are slighted by other men. You had better return to your partner and enjoy her smiles, for you are wasting your time with me.”
vi: Darcy turned to look at Elizabeth for a moment, caught her gaze, then turned away and coldly said: - What do you mean? She looks okay, but not attractive enough to captivate me, and I don't like chasing after women who have been discarded by other men. You should go out with your dance partner, don't waste your time with me.
tr: "Which one do you mean?" and turned around to look at Elizabeth for a moment, when he caught her eyes, he averted his own and said coldly: "Well, she's not beautiful enough to tempt me; besides, I'm not in a position to care about girls who are scorned by other men right now. I think you should turn to your wife and enjoy her smiles, because you are wasting your time with me."
es: ––and, turning around, he looked at Elizabeth for a moment, until their gazes met, he immediately looked away and said coldly: ––She is not bad, although she is not pretty enough to tempt me; and I am not in the mood to pay attention to young women who have been turned down by others. It is better that you return to your partner and enjoy their smiles because you are wasting your time with me.

en: Mr. Bingley followed his advice. Mr. Darcy walked off; and Elizabeth remained with no very cordial feelings towards him. She told the story, however, with great spirit among her friends; for she had a lively, playful disposition, which delighted in anything ridiculous.
vi: Bingley followed his friend's advice. Darcy walked away; and Elizabeth sat still, without any friendly feelings towards him. But afterwards she cheerfully recounted the story to her friend, as she had a playful nature and took delight in all oddities.
tr: Mr. Bingley followed his friend's advice. Mr. Darcy walked away, and Elizabeth was left with feelings that were not at all pleasant towards him. Nevertheless, she recounted the story to her friends with all its cheerfulness; for she had a lively, playful spirit that took delight in everything ridiculous.
es: Mr. Bingley followed his advice. Mr. Darcy walked away; and Elizabeth was left there with her not very cordial feelings towards him. However, she recounted the story to her friends with much humor because it was funny and very cheerful, and she had a certain disposition to make ridiculous things amusing.

en: The evening altogether passed off pleasantly to the whole family. Mrs. Bennet had seen her eldest daughter much admired by the Netherfield party. Mr. Bingley had danced with her twice, and she had been distinguished by his sisters. Jane was as much gratified by this as her mother could be, though in a quieter way. Elizabeth felt Jane’s pleasure. Mary had heard herself mentioned to Miss Bingley as the most accomplished girl in the neighbourhood; and Catherine and Lydia had been fortunate enough to be never without partners, which was all that they had yet learnt to care for at a ball. They returned, therefore, in good spirits to Longbourn, the village where they lived, and of which they were the principal inhabitants. They found Mr. Bennet still up. With a book, he was regardless of time; and on the present occasion he had a good deal of curiosity as to the event of an evening which had raised such splendid expectations. He had rather hoped that all his wife’s views on the stranger would be disappointed; but he soon found that he had a very different story to hear.
vi: The Bennet family was pleased with the ball. Mrs. Bennet noticed that everyone in attendance liked her eldest daughter. Bingley had danced with her twice, and she stood out among her sisters. As a result, Jane felt as pleased as her mother, though in a quieter manner. Elizabeth sensed Jane's joy. Mary heard someone tell Mr. Bingley that Jane was the most perfect girl in the area. As for Catherine and Lydia, they were fortunate to always have someone to dance with, and that was all they hoped for at a ball. The whole family cheerfully returned to Longbourn, the village where they lived, where they were important residents. When they got home, they found Mr. Bennet still awake. All he needed was a book to lose track of time, and on this occasion, he was eager to hear about the evening that had created so much delightful anticipation for everyone. He had thought that all his wife's opinions about the stranger would be disappointed, but he heard a completely different story.
tr: The evening was enjoyable for the whole family. Mrs. Bennet had seen that her eldest daughter had won the deep admiration of the Netherfield group. Mr. Bingley had danced with her twice, and his sisters had treated her with special attention. Jane received this with as much pleasure as her mother, but more calmly. Elizabeth felt Jane's satisfaction. Mary had heard herself referred to as the most skillful girl in the neighborhood by Miss Bingley; and Catherine and Lydia were lucky enough never to be without partners, which was all they could think of when it came to the ball for now. Thus, they returned to Longbourn in high spirits; their home was in the village of Longbourn, and they were the landowners of the village. They found Mr. Bennet still awake. Mr. Bennet would lose track of time when he picked up a book, but now he was very curious about the news of the evening that had created such tremendous expectations. He had thought that all his wife's hopes regarding the stranger would come to nothing, but soon realized he was about to hear a different story.
es: In short, the evening passed pleasantly for the whole family. Mrs. Bennet saw how her eldest daughter had been admired by those from Netherfield. Mr. Bingley had danced with her twice, and his sisters were very attentive to her. Jane was as satisfied as, if not more than, her mother, but she kept it to herself. Elizabeth was happy for Jane. Mary had heard Miss Bingley say that she was the most cultured girl in the neighborhood. And Catherine and Lydia had the good fortune of never being without a partner, which, as they had been taught, was the only thing they should worry about at dances. So they returned happily to Longbourn, the village where they lived and of which they were the principal inhabitants. They found Mr. Bennet still up; with a book in front of him, he lost track of time; and on this occasion, he was very curious about the events of the night that had aroused so much expectation. He came to believe that his wife's opinion of the newcomer might be unfavorable; but he soon realized that what he was about to hear was quite the opposite.

en: “Oh, my dear Mr. Bennet,” as she entered the room, “we have had a most delightful evening, a most excellent ball. I wish you had been there. Jane was so admired, nothing could be like it. Everybody said how well she looked; and Mr. Bingley thought her quite beautiful, and danced with her twice. Only think of that, my dear: he actually danced with her twice; and she was the only creature in the room that he asked a second time. First of all, he asked Miss Lucas. I was so vexed to see him stand up with her; but, however, he did not admire her at all; indeed, nobody can, you know; and he seemed quite struck with Jane as she was going down the dance. So he inquired who she was, and got introduced, and asked her for the two next. Then, the two third he danced with Miss King, and the two fourth with Maria Lucas, and the two fifth with Jane again, and the two sixth with Lizzy, and the Boulanger——”
vi: When entering the room, the wife said: - Sir, my children and I had a really fun evening, a wonderful ball. I wish you could have come along, everyone adored Jane, it couldn't have been better. Everyone praised her for being pretty, and Mr. Bingley found her quite beautiful, dancing with her twice. I can only think about that: he danced with her twice, she was the only one invited to dance a second time. First, he invited Miss Lucas. I felt really annoyed then, but he didn't seem to like her at all. You know, actually, no one likes her. He was attracted to our Jane after dancing with her. So he inquired about her, got introduced to her, and then invited her to dance a second time. Then the third dance with Miss King, the fourth with Maria Lucas, the fifth with Jane again, the sixth with Lizzy, and then the Boulanger.
tr: "Ah dear Mr. Bennet," said his wife as she entered the room, "what a delightful evening we had, what a magnificent ball it was! If only you had come too. They absolutely adored Jane. Everyone said how wonderful she looked; Mr. Bingley also adored her, he danced with her twice. Imagine, my dear, he really danced with her twice; moreover, she was the only girl in the whole room he asked to dance a second time. First, he asked Miss Lucas. Though I was very upset to see them together, fortunately, he didn't like her: after all, who would; but once the dance started, he seemed completely smitten with Jane. Then he inquired who she was, introduced himself, and then asked her for the second dance. Then, the third dance was with Miss King, the fourth with Maria Lucas, the fifth again with Jane, and the sixth with Lizzy-"
es: ––Oh, my dear Mr. Bennet ––said his wife as she entered the room––. We had a delightful evening, the ball was splendid. I would have liked you to be there. Jane aroused such admiration, nothing like it had ever been seen. Everyone was commenting on how beautiful she looked, and Mr. Bingley found her gorgeous and danced with her twice. Just imagine, dear; he danced with her twice. She was the only one in the entire hall he asked to dance a second time. The first one he asked was Miss Lucas. It quite upset me to see him dance with her, but he didn't like it at all. Who could like her, don't you think? However, he seemed to be captivated by Jane when he saw her dance. So he asked who she was, they introduced her to him, and he asked her for the next dance. Then he danced the third with Miss King, the fourth with Maria Lucas, the fifth again with Jane, the sixth with Lizzy, and the boulanger...

en: “If he had had any compassion for me,” cried her husband impatiently, “he would not have danced half so much! For God’s sake, say no more of his partners. O that he had sprained his ancle in the first dance!”
vi: The husband impatiently interrupted: - If he had any pity for me, he should have danced only half as much! Oh Lord, please don't talk about those girls dancing with him anymore. Ah! Perhaps it's better to say that he sprained his ankle in the first round.
tr: "If she had a bit of compassion for me," her husband cried impatiently, "she wouldn't dance even half as much! For God's sake, stop talking about their wives. I wish she had twisted her ankle in the first dance!"
es: ––If she had had any compassion for me ––shouted the impatient husband–– she wouldn't have spent so much! For the love of God, don't talk to me anymore about her partners! I wish she had twisted an ankle at the first dance!

en: “Oh, my dear,” continued Mrs. Bennet, “I am quite delighted with him. He is so excessively handsome! and his sisters are charming women. I never in my life saw anything more elegant than their dresses. I dare say the lace upon Mrs. Hurst’s gown——”
vi: Mrs. Bennet continued: - I really like him. He is so handsome! His sisters are also attractive. In my life, I have never seen outfits as elegant as the ones they wear. I am sure the lace on Mrs. Hurst's dress...
tr: "But my dear," continued Mrs. Bennet, "I liked the man very much. Incredibly handsome! His sisters are also very charming women. I have never seen more elegant dresses in my life. I think the lace on Mrs. Hurst's gown-"
es: ––Oh, my dear! He has me fascinated, he is incredibly handsome, and his sisters are charming. They wore the most elegant dresses I have ever seen in my life. The lace on Mrs. Hurst's...

en: Here she was interrupted again. Mr. Bennet protested against any description of finery. She was therefore obliged to seek another branch of the subject, and related, with much bitterness of spirit, and some exaggeration, the shocking rudeness of Mr. Darcy.
vi: She was interrupted again. Mr. Bennet did not want to hear her talk about flashy fashion. So she had to change the subject, and with all bitterness, adding a bit of exaggeration, she told him about Mr. Darcy's rude attitude. She continued:
tr: Here, again, the speech was interrupted. Mr. Bennet objected to the description of the attire. Mrs. Bennet, therefore, had to seek another aspect of the topic and, with a heavy heart and a bit of exaggeration, recounted Mr. Darcy's incredible rudeness.
es: Here she was interrupted again. Mr. Bennet protested against any description of attire. Therefore, she was forced to move on to another chapter of the story, and recounted, with great bitterness and some exaggeration, the scandalous rudeness of Mr. Darcy.

en: “But I can assure you,” she added, “that Lizzy does not lose much by not suiting his fancy; for he is a most disagreeable, horrid man, not at all worth pleasing. So high and so conceited, that there was no enduring him! He walked here, and he walked there, fancying himself so very great! Not handsome enough to dance with! I wish you had been there, my dear, to have given him one of your set-downs. I quite detest the man.”
vi: - But rest assured, Lizzy doesn't lose anything by not fitting his tastes. He belongs to the most unlikable type of people, a disgusting person, not worth anyone's affection. He is so arrogant and haughty that no one can stand him. He just goes around strutting, acting like he's the best! And he's not even handsome! I wish you had been there to give him a piece of your mind! I hate him to the core.
tr: "But I assure you," he added, "Lizzy hasn't lost much by not pleasing him; because he is an extremely unpleasant, terrible man, not worth bothering with. So self-conceited, so arrogant that it's impossible to tolerate him! He wandered around as if he were something special! Not even handsome enough to dance! I wish you had been there, dear, to put him in his place. I truly hated the man."
es: ––But I can assure you ––he added–– that Lizzy doesn't lose much by not being his type, because he is the most unpleasant and horrible man that exists, and he doesn't deserve anyone's sympathy. He is so stiff and so conceited that there is no way to tolerate him. He did nothing but strut from one side to the other like a peacock. He's not even handsome enough to be worth dancing with. I would have liked you to have been there and given him a good lesson. I detest him.

en: CHAPTER IV.
vi: Chapter 4
tr: Chapter IV
es: CHAPTER IV

en: WHEN Jane and Elizabeth were alone, the former, who had been cautious in her praise of Mr. Bingley before, expressed to her sister how very much she admired him.
vi: When there was no one else around, Jane confided in Elizabeth about the feelings she had for Mr. Bingley, whereas before she had been somewhat cautious in her praise:
tr: When Jane and Elizabeth were alone, Jane, who had previously been cautious about praising Mr. Bingley, told her sister how much she admired him.
es: When Jane and Elizabeth were alone, the former, who had been cautious in praising Mr. Bingley, expressed to her sister how much she admired him.

en: “He is just what a young-man ought to be,” said she, “sensible, good-humoured, lively; and I never saw such happy manners! so much ease, with such perfect good breeding!”
vi: - Young people should indeed be like him, mature, cheerful, and lively. She had never met anyone like that! So relaxed, with a wonderful cultured demeanor!
tr: "A man should be exactly like this," she said, "smart, well-behaved, good-natured, lively; I have never seen such pleasant manners before! So relaxed, so polite!"
es: ––He is everything a young man should be ––she said––, sensible, cheerful, with a sense of humor; I had never seen such relaxed manners, so much naturalness with such perfect education.

en: “He is also handsome,” replied Elizabeth, “which a young man ought likewise to be if he possibly can. His character is thereby complete.”
vi: Elizabeth replied: - He is also a handsome man, that's how a young man should be. Truly an ideal person.
tr: "Handsome, as well," replied Elizabeth, "well, a man should also be handsome, if possible. So, he has everything perfectly."
es: ––And he is also handsome ––replied Elizabeth––, which is never a bad thing in a young man. So he is a complete man.

en: “I was very much flattered by his asking me to dance a second time. I did not expect such a compliment.”
vi: - She felt proud when he invited her to dance for the second time. She didn't expect that he would pay attention to her like that.
tr: "Him asking me to dance a second time really flattered my pride. I wasn't expecting such a compliment."
es: ––I felt very flattered when he asked me to dance for the second time. I didn't expect such a compliment.

en: “Did not you? I did for you. But that is one great difference between us. Compliments always take you by surprise, and me never. What could be more natural than his asking you again? He could not help seeing that you were about five times as pretty as every other woman in the room. No thanks to his gallantry for that. Well, he certainly is very agreeable, and I give you leave to like him. You have liked many a stupider person.”
vi: - Unexpected, huh! I actually think you deserve it. But that's the big difference between the two of us. You always feel surprised when you get attention, while I never do. It's only natural that he invited you to dance again. He must have noticed that you're more beautiful than the other girls in the room. There's no need to thank him for that. He's really a nice guy, and I have no intention of stopping you from liking him. You've liked much more foolish people before.
tr: "Is that so? I was waiting on your behalf. But this is another big difference between us. Compliments always surprise you, they never surprise me. What could be more natural than him proposing to you again? It was impossible for him not to see that you are five times more beautiful than every woman in the room. We don't owe this to his kindness. Yes, he is indeed very nice; I allow you to like him. You have liked much more foolish ones."
es: ––Didn't you expect it? I did. That is the big difference between us. Compliments always catch you by surprise, but never me. It was the most natural thing for him to ask you to dance for the second time. It couldn't have escaped his notice that you were five times more beautiful than all the other women in the room. Don't thank him for his gallantry because of that. Well, the truth is that he is very pleasant, I approve of you liking him. You have liked many stupid people.

en: “Dear Lizzy!”
vi: - Hey Lizzy!
tr: "Peace Lizzy!"
es: ––Lizzy, dear! ––Oh!

en: “Oh, you are a great deal too apt, you know, to like people in general. You never see a fault in anybody. All the world are good and agreeable in your eyes. I never heard you speak ill of a human being in my life.”
vi: - Do you know? You are very easily swayed by others. In your eyes, everyone is good and likable. I've never heard you criticize anyone in my life.
tr: "Well, you are generally very ready to like people. You don't see anyone's faults. According to you, the whole world is good and charming. I've never heard you speak ill of anyone in your life."
es: You know perfectly well that you have a certain tendency to like everyone. You never see a flaw in anyone. Everyone is good and pleasant in your eyes. I have never heard you speak ill of a human being in my life.

en: “I would wish not to be hasty in censuring anyone; but I always speak what I think.”
vi: - I don't want to hastily criticize others, but I always speak my mind truthfully.
tr: "I don't want to be quick to judge anyone; but I always say what I think.""
es: ––I would not want to be imprudent in criticizing someone; but I always say what I think.

en: “I know you do: and it is that which makes the wonder. With your good sense, to be so honestly blind to the follies and nonsense of others! Affectation of candour is common enough; one meets with it everywhere. But to be candid without ostentation or design,—to take the good of everybody’s character and make it still better, and say nothing of the bad,—belongs to you alone. And so, you like this man’s sisters, too, do you? Their manners are not equal to his.”
vi: - I know that. That's why you are a wonderful person. With your sincere heart, you cannot recognize the madness and recklessness of people. The attitude of pretending to be straightforward is everywhere. But being straightforward without any intention of showing off or pretense like you is truly rare. You only pay attention to people's good points to praise them and ignore the bad ones. And so, you also really like his two sisters, don't you? Their character is not as good as his.
tr: "I know you will say it; that's the strange part. To have your sense and be so sincerely blind to the foolishness and absurdities of others! Pretending to be sincere is common enough –you see it everywhere. But to be genuinely sincere without show or plan –to take the good side of everyone's character and make it better, and not to speak of the bad side –is unique to you. You must have liked this man's sisters too, right? Their demeanor is not like his."
