es: ––I already know; and that's what makes it amazing. To be so blind to the follies and foolishness of others, with the good sense you have. Pretending candor is quite common, you see it everywhere. But to be candid without ostentation or premeditation, to take the good from everyone, improve it even, and say nothing of the bad, only you do that. And you also like his sisters, don't you? Their manners are nothing like his.

en: “Certainly not, at first; but they are very pleasing women when you converse with them. Miss Bingley is to live with her brother, and keep his house; and I am much mistaken if we shall not find a very charming neighbour in her.”
vi: - Certainly not as good, at first she thought so. But after talking to them, she found them very likable. His sister will live with him and help manage the house. She was not wrong when she said that we would have a truly charming neighbor like her.
tr: "Of course not, at first. But when you talk to them, they are very pleasant women. Miss Bingley will stay with her brother and manage the house; if she doesn't turn out to be a very sweet neighbor for us, I would be quite mistaken."
es: ––At first, of course not, but when you talk to them, they are very kind. Miss Bingley is going to come live with her brother and take care of his house. And, unless I am very much mistaken, I am sure we will find in her a charming neighbor.

en: Elizabeth listened in silence, but was not convinced: their behaviour at the assembly had not been calculated to please in general; and with more quickness of observation and less pliancy of temper than her sister, and with a judgment, too, unassailed by any attention to herself, she was very little disposed to approve them. They were, in fact, very fine ladies; not deficient in good-humour when they were pleased, nor in the power of being agreeable where they chose it; but proud and conceited. They were rather handsome; had been educated in one of the first private seminaries in town; had a fortune of twenty thousand pounds; were in the habit of spending more than they ought, and of associating with people of rank; and were, therefore, in every respect entitled to think well of themselves and meanly of others. They were of a respectable family in the north of England; a circumstance more deeply impressed on their memories than that their brother’s fortune and their own had been acquired by trade.
vi: Elizabeth listened in silence, but she did not feel convinced. She found the behavior of Mr. Bingley's sisters to be far from amiable. With her keen observational skills, thoughts that were not easily swayed like her sister's, and an unshakable judgment, she found it difficult to accept them. In fact, these two women were quite good people; they were not lacking in wit when they were in good spirits and were quite capable of pleasing others when they wished to. But they were too proud and self-important. They were quite beautiful, educated in a city convent school, possessed a fortune of twenty thousand pounds, had extravagant spending habits, and enjoyed mingling with the upper class. Therefore, in every respect, they felt entitled to think highly of themselves and look down on others. They belonged to a reputable family in the North of England. This was an environment that left a deeper impression on their memories than their fortune and their brother's wealth, which had been accumulated through business.
tr: Elizabeth listened in silence, but she was not convinced; the ladies' behavior at the ball was not exactly pleasing to everyone; with a quicker observation skill than her sister, a less flexible nature, and a judgment unaffected by personal interest, Elizabeth was not inclined to approve of their behavior. In fact, they were quite elegant women; when they were in a good mood, they did not refrain from being polite, and when they wished, they could be charming; but they were proud and self-conceited. They could be considered beautiful, they had been educated at one of the best private schools in the city, they had a fortune of twenty thousand pounds, they had habits of spending more money than necessary and associating with people of high status, therefore, they had every right to see themselves as superior and to look down on others. They belonged to a respectable family from Northern England, and this fact was more deeply ingrained in their memories than the fact that both their brother's fortune and their own had been acquired through trade.
es: Elizabeth listened in silence, but she was not convinced. The behavior of Bingley's sisters had not been intended to please anyone. A better observer than her sister, with a less flexible temperament and a judgment less prone to being influenced by flattery, Elizabeth was unwilling to approve of the Bingleys. They were, indeed, very fine ladies, quite cheerful when not contradicted and, when they wanted to be, very pleasant; but proud and conceited. They were quite pretty; they had been educated at one of the best schools in the capital and possessed a fortune of twenty thousand pounds; they were accustomed to overspending and associating with people of rank, which made them believe they had the right to hold a good opinion of themselves and a poor opinion of others. They belonged to an honorable family from the north of England, a fact that was more deeply ingrained in their memory than the fact that both their fortune and their brother's had been made in trade.

en: Mr. Bingley inherited property to the amount of nearly a hundred thousand pounds from his father, who had intended to purchase an estate, but did not live to do it. Mr. Bingley intended it likewise, and sometimes made choice of his county; but, as he was now provided with a good house and the liberty of a manor, it was doubtful to many of those who best knew the easiness of his temper, whether he might not spend the remainder of his days at Netherfield, and leave the next generation to purchase.
vi: Mr. Bingley inherited from his father a fortune amounting to nearly one hundred thousand pounds. He had intended to purchase an estate, but he passed away before he could buy one. Mr. Bingley had a similar intention, and at one point had chosen a location, but now he has been provided with a spacious house along with an estate. Many people who are familiar with his character still cannot predict whether he will stay at Netherfield for life or not.
tr: Mr. Bingley had inherited an estate worth about one hundred thousand pounds from his father; his father had always wanted to buy a manor but had not lived long enough. –Mr. Bingley had intended the same and had chosen his region several times; but now that he had found a good house and hunting grounds, many who knew his easygoing nature well doubted that he would spend the rest of his life at Netherfield and leave the purchasing to the next generation.
es: Mr. Bingley inherited nearly one hundred thousand pounds from his father, who had already intended to buy a mansion but did not live to do so. Mr. Bingley thought the same way and sometimes seemed determined to make the choice within his county; but as he now had a good house and the freedom of a property owner, those who knew his calm character well doubted that he would not spend the rest of his days in Netherfield and leave the purchase for the next generation.

en: His sisters were very anxious for his having an estate of his own; but though he was now established only as a tenant, Miss Bingley was by no means unwilling to preside at his table; nor was Mrs. Hurst, who had married a man of more fashion than fortune, less disposed to consider his house as her home when it suited her. Mr. Bingley had not been of age two years when he was tempted, by an accidental recommendation, to look at Netherfield House. He did look at it, and into it, for half an hour; was pleased with the situation and the principal rooms, satisfied with what the owner said in its praise, and took it immediately.
vi: The sisters of the young man were eager for him to buy property of his own, but now, even though she was just a tenant, the younger sister did not hesitate to sit in the head chair at the dining table. Mrs. Hurst was the same, having married with more clothes than assets, whenever she wanted, she was always ready to consider her brother's house as her own place. Bingley happened to be introduced to the Netherfield house. He went to see it and after half an hour of inspecting inside and out, feeling pleased with the location of the house and its main rooms, agreed with the owner's praises, and consented immediately.
tr: His sisters were very eager for him to have his own estate; although he had only settled as a tenant now, Miss Bingley was not at all reluctant to manage his house; and Mrs. Hurst, who was married to a man of position rather than wealth, did not dislike seeing his house as her own whenever she pleased. Mr. Bingley had not yet been of age for two years when he was advised by chance to look at Netherfield Park. He spent half an hour looking inside and outside the house, liked its location and main rooms, was satisfied with the owner's praises, and immediately took the house.
es: His sisters were eager for him to have a mansion of his own. But although he was currently nothing more than a tenant, Miss Bingley was still eager to preside over his table; nor was Mrs. Hurst, who had married a man more elegant than wealthy, any less willing to consider her brother's house as her own whenever it suited her. Two short years after Mr. Bingley had come of age, a casual recommendation induced him to visit the Netherfield estate. He viewed it inside and out for half an hour and was satisfied with the owner's praises, renting it immediately.

en: Between him and Darcy there was a very steady friendship, in spite of a great opposition of character. Bingley was endeared to Darcy by the easiness, openness, and ductility of his temper, though no disposition could offer a greater contrast to his own, and though with his own he never appeared dissatisfied. On the strength of Darcy’s regard, Bingley had the firmest reliance, and of his judgment the highest opinion. In understanding, Darcy was the superior. Bingley was by no means deficient; but Darcy was clever. He was at the same time haughty, reserved, and fastidious; and his manners, though well bred, were not inviting. In that respect his friend had greatly the advantage. Bingley was sure of being liked wherever he appeared; Darcy was continually giving offence.
vi: Between him and Mr. Darcy, there is a very strong friendship, despite their opposing natures. Bingley is cherished by Darcy for his easy-going, open, and pliable nature, although there is no other circumstance that brings about a greater contrast than their inherent characters, but he never shows any dissatisfaction with himself. Bingley has a firm belief in Darcy's integrity and highly values his friend's judgment. In terms of knowledge, Darcy is somewhat superior to Bingley and appears to be wiser. Darcy is both proud and reserved, and his demeanor is not very engaging, although he is very well-educated. In this regard, Bingley is somewhat superior, as he is liked by everyone wherever he goes, while Darcy continually offends people.
tr: Despite the significant difference in character between Bingley and Darcy, there was a stable friendship. –Bingley had endeared himself to Darcy with his ease, openness, and gentleness, although no personality could be more opposite to his own, and he did not seem to be dissatisfied with his own personality. Bingley had immense confidence in the solidity of Darcy's opinions and held great respect for his judgment. Darcy's understanding was more profound. Not because Bingley was inadequate, but because Darcy was intelligent. At the same time, he was proud, distant, and meticulous, and his manners, though polite, were not inviting. In this respect, his friend was much more privileged. Bingley was confident that he would endear himself wherever he went, whereas Darcy constantly offended people.
es: Between him and Darcy, there existed a firm friendship despite having such opposite characters. Bingley had gained Darcy's sympathy due to his open and docile temperament and his naturalness, even though there was no way of being that offered a greater contrast to his own, and even though he seemed very satisfied with his character. Bingley knew the respect that Darcy had for him, which is why he trusted him completely, as well as his good judgment. He understood Darcy like no one else. Bingley was not at all foolish, but Darcy was much more intelligent. He was at the same time arrogant, reserved, and picky, and although he was very polite, his manners did not make him at all attractive. In this regard, his friend had all the advantage; Bingley was sure to be liked wherever he went, whereas Darcy was always offensive.

en: The manner in which they spoke of the Meryton assembly was sufficiently characteristic. Bingley had never met with pleasanter people or prettier girls in his life; everybody had been most kind and attentive to him; there had been no formality, no stiffness; he had soon felt acquainted with all the room; and as to Miss Bennet, he could not conceive an angel more beautiful. Darcy, on the contrary, had seen a collection of people in whom there was little beauty and no fashion, for none of whom he had felt the smallest interest, and from none received either attention or pleasure. Miss Bennet he acknowledged to be pretty; but she smiled too much.
vi: The way two people converse with each other at the ball clearly reflects their personalities. Bingley had never met a girl as charming and pretty as Jane in his life. Everyone was kind and considerate to him. Without being formal and stiff, he soon got acquainted with everyone in the room, but as for Jane Bennet, he felt no angel could be more beautiful. As for him, he found the whole crowd unremarkable, so he paid no attention to anyone, and no one paid attention to him either. He acknowledged that Jane was a beautiful girl, but he thought she smiled too much.
tr: The conversations about the Meryton ball also sufficiently revealed their personalities. Bingley had never encountered such pleasant people and such beautiful girls before; everyone had treated him with utmost kindness and care, there had been no formality or stiffness; he had soon felt acquainted with the entire room; as for Miss Bennet, he couldn't imagine a more beautiful angel. In contrast, Darcy had seen a crowd with little beauty and no manners; he hadn't felt the slightest closeness to anyone, nor had he received any attention or interest from anyone. Miss Bennet, he admitted, was beautiful, but she laughed too much.
es: The best example is the way they talked about the Meryton party. Bingley had never met more charming people or prettier girls in his life; everyone had been extremely kind and attentive to him, there had been no formalities or stiffness, and he soon became friends with the whole room; and as for Miss Bennet, he couldn't conceive of an angel who was more beautiful. On the contrary, Darcy had seen a collection of people in whom there was little beauty and no elegance, he had felt the slightest interest in none of them, and had received no attention or pleasure from any of them. He acknowledged that Miss Bennet was beautiful, but she smiled too much.

en: Mrs. Hurst and her sister allowed it to be so; but still they admired her and liked her, and pronounced her to be a sweet girl, and one whom they should not object to know more of. Miss Bennet was therefore established as a sweet girl; and their brother felt authorized by such commendation to think of her as he chose.
vi: Mrs. Hurst and her younger sister thought the same, but they still liked her, considering her a pleasant, gentle young woman, and were not hesitant to learn more about her. Thus, Jane was acknowledged by everyone as gentle, which allowed Bingley to feel free to think of her whenever he wished.
tr: Although Mrs. Hurst and her sister shared the same opinion, they admired and liked her; they said she was a sweet girl and they would not object to getting to know her better. Thus, Miss Bennet was accepted as a sweet girl, and their brother felt permitted to consider her if he wished.
es: Mrs. Hurst and her sister admitted it, but still liked and admired her, they said she was a very sweet girl and that they would not mind getting to know her better. It was established, then, that Miss Bennet was a very sweet girl and for this reason the brother felt authorized to think of her as and when he wanted.

en: CHAPTER V.
vi: Chapter 5
tr: Chapter V
es: CHAPTER V

en: WITHIN a short walk of Longbourn lived a family with whom the Bennets were particularly intimate. Sir William Lucas had been formerly in trade in Meryton, where he had made a tolerable fortune, and risen to the honour of knighthood by an address to the king during his mayoralty. The distinction had, perhaps, been felt too strongly. It had given him a disgust to his business and to his residence in a small market town; and, quitting them both, he had removed with his family to a house about a mile from Meryton, denominated from that period Lucas Lodge; where he could think with pleasure of his own importance, and, unshackled by business, occupy himself solely in being civil to all the world. For, though elated by his rank, it did not render him supercilious; on the contrary, he was all attention to everybody. By nature inoffensive, friendly, and obliging, his presentation at St. James’s had made him courteous.
vi: A short distance from Longbourn, there was a family well-acquainted with the Bennets. Sir William Lucas had previously conducted business in Meryton, building a considerable career and was knighted by the court when he held the position of mayor. Perhaps he felt this honor too intensely. He grew tired of business and his house in a small commercial town, so he abandoned both and moved his family to a house about a mile from Meryton. He named the house Lucas Lodge, where he could complacently consider himself an important person, unburdened by business matters, focusing solely on living up to the appearance of being a good citizen. He took pride in his knighthood but was not arrogant; on the contrary, he cared about everyone. With a nature that did not want to offend anyone, combined with his friendliness and accommodating disposition, his knighthood at St James's Palace had made him a courteous person.
tr: A family with whom the Bennets were very close lived a short walking distance from Longbourn. Sir William Lucas had once been a tradesman in Meryton; he had made a considerable fortune and had been knighted during his mayoralty by presenting his gratitude to the King. This privilege may have been felt too strongly. It had caused the man to become disenchanted with his business and home in a small market town; he then left both and moved with his family to a house about a mile from Meryton, which had since been called Lucas Lodge; here, free from the worries of business, he could contemplate his own importance with pleasure and occupy himself solely with being courteous to the world. If his title filled him with pride, it did not make him arrogant; on the contrary, he became a model of politeness to everyone. By nature, he was mild-mannered, friendly, and considerate; St. His presentation at St. James's had also made him a courtier.
es: A short distance from Longbourn lived a family with whom the Bennets had a special friendship. Sir William Lucas had previously been in business in Meryton, where he had made a modest fortune and had been elevated to the rank of knight by petition to the king during his mayoralty. This distinction had gone a bit to his head, and he began to dislike having to engage in business and live in a small commercial town; so, leaving both behind, he moved with his family to a house a mile from Meryton, henceforth called Lucas Lodge, where he could indulge in thinking with pleasure about his own importance, and, detached from his business, occupy himself solely with being kind to everyone. For although he was proud of his rank, he had not become conceited; on the contrary, he was all attentiveness to everyone. Of an inoffensive, sociable, and helpful nature, his presentation at St. James had also made him courteous.

en: Lady Lucas was a very good kind of woman, not too clever to be a valuable neighbour to Mrs. Bennet. They had several children. The eldest of them, a sensible, intelligent young woman, about twenty-seven, was Elizabeth’s intimate friend.
vi: Mrs. Lucas was a very gentle woman, not too wise, so she easily became a good neighbor to Mrs. Bennet. They had several children. Their eldest daughter, sensible and intelligent, about twenty-seven years old, was a close friend of Elizabeth.
tr: Lady Lucas was a very kind-hearted woman, but not clever enough to be a good neighbor to Mrs. Bennet. –She had several children. The eldest, a sensible and intelligent young woman of twenty-seven, was a close friend of Elizabeth.
es: Mrs. Lucas was a good woman, although not intelligent enough for Mrs. Bennet to consider her a valuable neighbor. They had several children. The eldest, an intelligent and sensible young woman of about twenty years, was Elizabeth's close friend.

en: That the Miss Lucases and the Miss Bennets should meet to talk over a ball was absolutely necessary; and the morning after the assembly brought the former to Longbourn to hear and to communicate.
vi: The meeting of the Bennet and Lucas daughters to gossip about the ball was absolutely necessary. The next morning, the Lucas girls went to Longbourn to hear the news and chat with each other.
tr: It was essential for the daughters of the Lucases and the Bennets to meet and discuss every ball; the morning after the ball, the Lucas daughters came to Longbourn to listen and share.
es: That the Lucases and the Bennets should gather to chat after a ball was absolutely necessary, and the morning after the party, the Lucases went to Longbourn to exchange impressions.

en: “You began the evening well, Charlotte,” said Mrs. Bennet, with civil self-command, to Miss Lucas. “You were Mr. Bingley’s first choice.”
vi: Mrs. Bennet said to Miss Lucas with an air of composure: - Hey Charlotte, you started the ball off well. You were Mr. Bingley's first choice.
tr: "You have started the evening well, Charlotte," said Mrs. Bennet to Miss Lucas, with polite solemnity. "You were Mr. Bingley's first choice."
es: ––You started the night well, Charlotte ––said Mrs. Bennet, feigning all possible kindness towards Miss Lucas––. You were the first one Mr. Bingley chose.

en: “Yes; but he seemed to like his second better.”
vi: - That's right, but it seems he prefers the second option.
tr: "Yes, but I think he liked his second choice more."" "Ah!
es: ––Yes, but she seemed to like the second one more. ––Oh!

en: “Oh, you mean Jane, I suppose, because he danced with her twice. To be sure that did seem as if he admired her—indeed, I rather believe he did—I heard something about it—but I hardly know what—something about Mr. Robinson.”
vi: - Ah, you think that you mean Jane – Because he danced with her twice. It seems like he likes her – in fact, I believed so – I heard about it, but I don't know anything about... something about Mr. Robinson.
tr: I suppose you mean Jane – because he danced with her twice. Of course, this makes one think he likes her – in fact, I believe he does – I've heard something about it – but exactly what, I don't know – something related to Mr. Robinson."
es: You mean Jane, I suppose, because he danced with her twice. Yes, it seems he liked her; yes, I think so.

en: “Perhaps you mean what I overheard between him and Mr. Robinson: did not I mention it to you? Mr. Robinson’s asking him how he liked our Meryton assemblies, and whether he did not think there were a great many pretty women in the room, and which he thought the prettiest? and his answering immediately to the last question, ‘Oh, the eldest Miss Bennet, beyond a doubt: there cannot be two opinions on that point.’”
vi: - Perhaps you think I overheard Mr. Bingley and Mr. Robinson talking to each other, have I told you about this? Mr. Robinson asked him what he thought of the Meryton ball, did he think there were many beautiful women in the room? He asked which lady he thought was the most beautiful. He immediately answered the last question – Ah! Surely the eldest Miss Bennet, indeed no one would disagree.
tr: "Maybe you mean the things I heard while talking to Mr. Robinson; didn't I tell you? Mr. Robinson asked him how he found our Meryton balls, whether he thought there were many beautiful women in the room, and which one he liked the most, to which he immediately replied to the last question – Oh! Miss Bennet undoubtedly, no one can say otherwise."
es: I heard something, I don't know, something about Mr. Robinson. ––Perhaps it refers to what I heard between him and Mr. Robinson, haven't I told you? Mr. Robinson asked him if he liked the Meryton parties, if he didn't think there were very beautiful girls in the hall, and which one seemed the prettiest of all to him. His answer to this last question was immediate: "The eldest of the Bennets, without a doubt. There can be only one opinion on that matter."

en: “Upon my word! Well, that was very decided, indeed—that does seem as if—but, however, it may all come to nothing, you know.”
vi: - So he had an intention, it seems like that... but it might not lead to anything, you know.
tr: "Wow! –Yes, this is indeed quite clear –it seems like –but still, all of this might not lead anywhere."
es: ––Don't tell me! It seems determined to... It's as if... But, in the end, everything could come to nothing.

en: “My overhearings were more to the purpose than yours, Eliza,” said Charlotte. “Mr. Darcy is not so well worth listening to as his friend, is he? Poor Eliza! to be only just tolerable.”
vi: Charlotte said: - Lizzy, the eavesdropping you did served a better purpose than my story, didn't it? Mr. Darcy's words aren't worth listening to, but your brother's words are, right? Poor Eliza, having to put up with it!
tr: "What I have heard is more meaningful than what you have heard, Eliza," said Charlotte. "Mr. Darcy is not as worthy of attention as his friend, is he? –Poor Eliza!
es: ––What I heard was better than what you heard, right, Elizabeth? ––said Charlotte––. It's more worthwhile to listen to Mr. Bingley than to Mr. Darcy, don't you think? Poor Eliza!

en: “I beg you will not put it into Lizzy’s head to be vexed by his ill-treatment, for he is such a disagreeable man that it would be quite a misfortune to be liked by him. Mrs. Long told me last night that he sat close to her for half an hour without once opening his lips.”
vi: - I hope you don't put that matter into Lizzy's head to cause annoyance because of his mistreatment. Because he is such an unpleasant person, if he likes someone, that person is truly unfortunate. Last night, Mrs. Long told me that he sat next to her for half an hour without saying a word.
tr: –he is hard to endure." "Please do not get into Lizzy's head, she shouldn't dwell on that man's rudeness; he is such an unpleasant man that being liked by him would be a complete misfortune. Mrs. Long told me last night that she sat next to him for half an hour and he didn't open his mouth even once."
es: To only say: "Not bad. " ––I beg you not to put it into Lizzy's head to be upset about Darcy. He is such an unpleasant man that it would be a misfortune to like him. Mrs. Long told me that he had been sitting next to her and hadn't opened his mouth.

en: “Are you quite sure, ma’am? Is not there a little mistake?” said Jane. “I certainly saw Mr. Darcy speaking to her.”
vi: Jane asked: - Mom, are you sure you're not mistaken? I clearly saw him talking to her.
tr: "Are you sure, ma'am? –isn't there a small mistake?" said Jane. "I clearly saw Mr. Darcy talking to her."
es: ––Are you sure, Mom? Aren't you mistaken? I saw Mr. Darcy talking to her.

en: “Ay, because she asked him at last how he liked Netherfield, and he could not help answering her; but she said he seemed very angry at being spoke to.”
vi: - Ah, that's because she asked him if he liked living at Netherfield, so he had to answer, but she said he seemed very annoyed that someone brought it up.
tr: "So – because in the end, he asked her how she found Netherfield, and she had to answer; but she said he seemed very angry about being spoken to."
es: ––Yes, of course; because she eventually asked him if he liked Netherfield, and he had no choice but to answer; but Mrs. Long said that he was not at all pleased that she spoke to him.

en: “Miss Bingley told me,” said Jane, “that he never speaks much unless among his intimate acquaintance. With them he is remarkably agreeable.”
vi: Jane said: - Miss Bingley told me that he never speaks much except with those he is very close to. With these people, he appears quite pleasant.
tr: "Miss Bingley told me that she does not speak if one is not among her close acquaintances," said Jane. "When she is with her acquaintances, she is quite friendly."
es: ––Miss Bingley told me ––commented Jane that he did not usually talk much, except with his close friends. With them, he is incredibly pleasant.

en: “I do not believe a word of it, my dear. If he had been so very agreeable, he would have talked to Mrs. Long. But I can guess how it was; everybody says that he is eat up with pride, and I dare say he had heard somehow that Mrs. Long does not keep a carriage, and had to come to the ball in a hack chaise.”
vi: - I find it hard to believe. If he were really that pleasant, he would have conversed with Mrs. Long. But I can guess why: everyone says it's because he's too proud, and somehow he heard that Mrs. Long's family doesn't have a carriage and had to rent an old one to go to the ball.
tr: "I don't believe a single word, my dear. If he were that friendly, he would have talked to Mrs. Long. I can imagine how it is; everyone says he is a pride maniac; I suppose he heard that Mrs. Long didn't have a carriage and came to the ball in a rented cab."
es: ––I don't believe a word of it, dear. If he were so pleasant, he would have talked to Mrs. Long. But I can already imagine what happened. Everyone says that his pride knows no bounds, and I would bet that he heard that Mrs. Long doesn't have a carriage and that she went to the ball in a rented one.

en: “I do not mind his not talking to Mrs. Long,” said Miss Lucas, “but I wish he had danced with Eliza.”
vi: Ms. Lucas said: - I don't care if he talks to Mrs.
tr: "I don't care if he doesn't talk to Mrs. Long," said Miss Lucas, "but I wish he had danced with Eliza.""
es: ––I don't mind that he didn't speak with Mrs. Long ––said Miss Lucas––, but I wish he had danced with Eliza.

en: “Another time, Lizzy,” said her mother, “I would not dance with him, if I were you.”
vi: Long or not, but I wish he would dance with Lizzy. The mother told Elizabeth: - Another time, Lizzy. If I were you, I wouldn't want to dance with him.
tr: "Next time, Lizzy," said her mother, "if I were you, I wouldn't dance with him either."
es: ––If I were you, Lizzy ––added the mother––, I would never dance with him again.

en: “I believe, ma’am, I may safely promise you never to dance with him.”
vi: - I swear to you, Mom, and I can promise you that I will never dance with him.
tr: "I believe, madam, that I can comfortably promise never to dance with him.""
es: ––I believe, mom, that I can promise you that I will never dance with him.

en: “His pride,” said Miss Lucas, “does not offend me so much as pride often does, because there is an excuse for it. One cannot wonder that so very fine a young man, with family, fortune, everything in his favour, should think highly of himself. If I may so express it, he has a right to be proud.”
vi: Ms. Lucas said: - His pride did not bother her, because there was some justifiable reason for it. We should not question why a young man who has so much: a noble family, immense wealth, would think of himself as noble. If she could say, he had the right to be proud.
tr: "The man's pride," said Miss Lucas, "does not bother me so much, because it has an explanation. There is nothing surprising in a young man who has family and wealth, who is so handsome, and who has everything complete, valuing himself. I can say he has the right to be proud."
es: ––Pride ––said Miss Lucas–– always offends, but his pride doesn't seem so offensive to me. He has an excuse. It is natural for an attractive man, with family, fortune, and everything in his favor to have a high opinion of himself. In a way, he has the right to be proud.

en: “That is very true,” replied Elizabeth, “and I could easily forgive his pride, if he had not mortified mine.”
vi: - That is very true, I can easily forgive his pride, if he does not insult my pride.
tr: "This is very true," replied Elizabeth, "I could easily forgive his pride, if he had not wounded mine."
es: ––It is very true ––replied Elizabeth––, I could easily forgive his pride if he had not mortified mine.

en: “Pride,” observed Mary, who piqued herself upon the solidity of her reflections, “is a very common failing, I believe. By all that I have ever read, I am convinced that it is very common indeed; that human nature is particularly prone to it, and that there are very few of us who do not cherish a feeling of self-complacency on the score of some quality or other, real or imaginary. Vanity and pride are different things, though the words are often used synonymously. A person may be proud without being vain. Pride relates more to our opinion of ourselves; vanity to what we would have others think of us.”
vi: Mary was still resentful of her sister's steadfast opinion: - I believe that pride is a very common flaw. From what I have read, I believe that this is very prevalent, human nature tends to lean towards this defect. Among us, very few people do not have a self-satisfied thought in one way or another, whether real or imagined. Vanity and pride are two different things, although people often consider them synonymous. A person can feel pride without being vain. Pride is when we have an opinion of ourselves, vanity is when we want others to think of us in a certain way.
tr: "Pride," Mary observed, taking pride as usual in the firmness of her opinions, "I think is a very common fault. From all the things I have read, I have come to believe that it is indeed very common; human nature is particularly inclined towards pride; there are very few people who do not feel some satisfaction with themselves for one real or imaginary attribute or another. Pride and vanity are different things, but they are often used synonymously. One can be proud without being vain. Pride relates more to our opinion of ourselves, while vanity is what we would have others think of us."
es: ––Pride ––observed Mary, who prided herself greatly on the solidity of her reflections––, is a very common defect. From all that I have read, I am convinced that it is indeed very frequent for human nature to be especially prone to it; there are very few who do not harbor a feeling of self-sufficiency for one reason or another, whether real or imagined. Vanity and pride are different things, although they are often used as synonyms. Pride relates to the opinion we have of ourselves; vanity, to what we would like others to think of us.

en: “If I were as rich as Mr. Darcy,” cried a young Lucas, who came with his sisters, “I should not care how proud I was. I would keep a pack of foxhounds, and drink a bottle of wine every day.”
vi: Lucas's younger sister exclaimed: - If I were as wealthy as Mr. Darcy, I wouldn't need to feel so proud. I would raise a pack of hunting dogs and drink a bottle of wine every day.
tr: "If I were as rich as Mr. Darcy," exclaimed one of the sons of the Lucases who came with their sisters, "I wouldn't care how proud I was. I would keep a pack of hounds and drink a bottle of wine every day."
es: ––If I were as rich as Mr. Darcy, exclaimed a young Lucas who had come with his sisters––, I wouldn't mind being proud. I would have a pack of hunting dogs, and I would drink a bottle of wine a day.

en: “Then you would drink a great deal more than you ought,” said Mrs. Bennet; “and if I were to see you at it, I should take away your bottle directly.”
vi: - Then you will drink too much, if I catch you, I will take your bottle of wine immediately...
tr: "Then you would drink too much," said Mrs. Bennet; "and I would take the bottle from your hand the moment I saw it.""
es: ––Well, you would drink much more than you should ––said Mrs. Bennet–– and if I saw you, I would take the bottle away from you immediately.

en: The boy protested that she should not; she continued to declare that she would; and the argument ended only with the visit.
vi: And the debate continued until parting ways.
tr: The boy objected, saying he couldn't get it; Mrs. Bennet kept insisting that she would, and the argument only ended with the visit.
es: The boy said he wouldn't dare, she said she would, and so they kept arguing until the visit was concluded.

en: CHAPTER VI.
vi: Chapter 6
tr: Chapter VI
es: CHAPTER VI

en: THE ladies of Longbourn soon waited on those of Netherfield. The visit was returned in due form. Miss Bennet’s pleasing manners grew on the good-will of Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley; and though the mother was found to be intolerable, and the younger sisters not worth speaking to, a wish of being better acquainted with them was expressed towards the two eldest. By Jane this attention was received with the greatest pleasure; but Elizabeth still saw superciliousness in their treatment of everybody, hardly excepting even her sister, and could not like them; though their kindness to Jane, such as it was, had a value, as arising, in all probability, from the influence of their brother’s admiration. It was generally evident, whenever they met, that he did admire her; and to her it was equally evident that Jane was yielding to the preference which she had begun to entertain for him from the first, and was in a way to be very much in love; but she considered with pleasure that it was not likely to be discovered by the world in general, since Jane united with great strength of feeling, a composure of temper and an uniform cheerfulness of manner, which would guard her from the suspicions of the impertinent. She mentioned this to her friend, Miss Lucas.
vi: Thus, it wasn't long before the women at Longbourn visited Netherfield. They were properly reciprocated with visits. Jane Bennet's amiable nature won over Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley. Despite their mother's unbearable attitude and her younger sisters being not worth mentioning, they all wanted to befriend the eldest sister. Jane felt very happy to be so well-regarded, but Elizabeth still noticed the arrogance of the other side in their treatment of everyone and even Jane, so she couldn't bring herself to like the two, although their kindness to Jane did influence Mr. Bingley's feelings. It was clear that whenever the two met, he genuinely showed his affection for her, and as for Jane, she liked him more as well, but she was glad that no one noticed this. She was a strong combination of calm temperament and enthusiastic demeanor, and these two traits concealed the suspicions of those who meddled in others' affairs. Elizabeth shared this with Charlotte Lucas.
tr: The ladies of Longbourn immediately visited Netherfield. The visit was duly returned. Miss Bennet's pleasant manners increased the admiration of Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley; although the mother was found unbearable and the younger sisters not worth talking about, the desire to get to know them better was expressed towards the two eldest daughters. This interest was accepted with great pleasure by Jane; but Elizabeth saw how they looked down on almost everyone, including her sister, and was unwilling to like them; yet the kindness shown to Jane, probably stemming from their brother's admiration for her, had some value. It was evident at every encounter that the man admired her; according to Elizabeth, it was clear that Jane was allowing herself to be carried away by the feelings she had initially started to harbor for the man, and would eventually be head over heels in love; but she was pleased to think that the world would not notice this, because Jane combined dignity and cheerfulness with great emotional strength, which protected her from the suspicions of indiscreet people. She told this to her friend Miss Lucas.
es: The ladies of Longbourn soon went to visit those of Netherfield, and the latter returned the visit as is customary. The charm of Miss Bennet increased the esteem that Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley felt for her; and although they found the mother intolerable and not worth speaking to the younger sisters, they expressed a desire to deepen their relations with them out of regard for the two eldest. This attention was received by Jane with pleasure, but Elizabeth continued to see arrogance in their treatment of everyone, except, with reservations, her sister; she could not like them. Although she valued their kindness to Jane, she knew it was probably due to the influence of the admiration the brother felt for her. It was evident, wherever they met, that Bingley admired Jane; and it was also evident to Elizabeth that in her sister increased the inclination she felt for him from the beginning, which predisposed her to fall in love with him; but she realized, with great satisfaction, that people could not notice it, since Jane would combine the strength of her feelings with moderation and a constant joviality, which would drive away the suspicions of the impertinent. She commented this to her friend, Miss Lucas.

en: “It may, perhaps, be pleasant,” replied Charlotte, “to be able to impose on the public in such a case; but it is sometimes a disadvantage to be so very guarded. If a woman conceals her affection with the same skill from the object of it, she may lose the opportunity of fixing him; and it will then be but poor consolation to believe the world equally in the dark. There is so much of gratitude or vanity in almost every attachment, that it is not safe to leave any to itself. We can all begin freely—a slight preference is natural enough; but there are very few of us who have heart enough to be really in love without encouragement. In nine cases out of ten, a woman had better show more affection than she feels. Bingley likes your sister undoubtedly; but he may never do more than like her, if she does not help him on.”
vi: Charlotte replied: - It might be a good thing to create such an impression for the public, but sometimes being too reserved can be disadvantageous. If a girl keeps hiding her feelings, she might miss the chance to make the guy notice her, and at that point, there's nothing left but to console herself when everyone else is just as clueless as she is. Almost every relationship requires a bit of appreciation or frivolity, to the extent that if everything is left to develop freely, there's no guarantee of anything. We can start comfortably – perhaps a gentle affection is natural, but very few of us can truly love without encouragement from the other side. In nine out of ten cases, a woman should express her admiration more than her feelings. Surely Bingley likes your sister, but he might stop there if she doesn't help him move forward.
tr: "In such a situation," Charlotte replied, "it may be pleasant to be dignified towards others; but being so well-guarded can sometimes be harmful. If a woman hides her love from the man she loves with the same skill, she may miss the opportunity to win him, and then believing that the world is unaware would be a weak consolation. In almost every relationship, there is so much gratitude or display of emotion that it is not safe to leave things to their own devices. We can all start freely – a slight inclination is quite natural, but very few of us have the heart to truly fall in love without encouragement. Nine times out of ten, the right thing for a woman is to show more love than she actually feels. Bingley undoubtedly likes your sister, but if your sister does not help him along, the man may not go beyond liking her."
es: ––Perhaps it is better in this case ––replied Charlotte–– to be able to escape people's curiosity; but sometimes it is bad to be so reserved. If a woman conceals her affection for its object, she may lose the opportunity to win him over; and then it is a poor consolation to think that others are equally ignorant. There is so much gratitude and vanity in almost all affections that it is not at all convenient to leave them adrift. Normally we all start with a slight preference, and that can simply be for no reason; but there are very few who have enough heart to fall in love without having been encouraged. In nine out of ten cases, a woman must show more affection than she feels. Bingley likes your sister, undoubtedly; but if she does not help him, it will go no further.

en: “But she does help him on, as much as her nature will allow. If I can perceive her regard for him, he must be a simpleton indeed not to discover it too.”
vi: - But in reality, Jane did show encouragement for him to advance further, within the limits that her dignity allowed. If you could sense her feelings, he would be a fool not to notice.
tr: "But she is helping, as much as she can. If I can perceive the interest she shows the man, he must be stupid not to understand it."
es: ––She helps him as much as his nature allows. If I can notice her affection towards him, he, certainly, would be foolish not to discover it.

en: “Remember, Eliza, that he does not know Jane’s disposition as you do.”
vi: - Eliza, remember that he doesn't understand Jane's temperament as well as you do.
tr: "Remember, Eliza, she doesn't know Jane's nature as well as you do."
es: ––Remember, Eliza, that he does not know Jane's character as you do.

en: “But if a woman is partial to a man, and does not endeavor to conceal it, he must find it out.”
vi: - But if a woman has special feelings for a man and does not intentionally hide them, he needs to understand clearly.
tr: "But if a woman likes a man and doesn't try to hide it, the man will notice."
es: ––But if a woman is interested in a man and does not try to hide it, he will eventually have to find out.

en: “Perhaps he must, if he sees enough of her. But though Bingley and Jane meet tolerably often, it is never for many hours together; and as they always see each other in large mixed parties, it is impossible that every moment should be employed in conversing together. Jane should therefore make the most of every half hour in which she can command his attention. When she is secure of him, there will be leisure for falling in love as much as she chooses.”
vi: - Maybe he needs to find out, if he knows a lot about her. But although Jane and Bingley met quite often, they never met for long. Because they always met in crowds, they couldn't talk much to each other. Therefore, Jane needed to seize every moment to capture his feelings. Once she was sure she had won his heart, she could leisurely enjoy love as she pleased.
tr: "It might make a difference, if he sees the woman enough. But even though Bingley and Jane see each other often, they don't spend much time alone; they always see each other in large, mixed groups, so it's impossible for them to spend every moment talking to each other. Therefore, Jane should make the most of every minute she can capture the man's attention. After securing the man, she will have plenty of time to fall in love."
es: ––Maybe so, if he sees her enough. But although Bingley and Jane are often together, it is never for long; and besides, since they only see each other at crowded parties, they cannot talk alone. So Jane should make the most of every minute she can catch his attention. And when she has him for sure, she will have time––to fall in love with him as much as she wants.

en: “Your plan is a good one,” replied Elizabeth, “where nothing is in question but the desire of being well married; and if I were determined to get a rich husband, or any husband, I dare say I should adopt it. But these are not Jane’s feelings; she is not acting by design. As yet she cannot even be certain of the degree of her own regard, nor of its reasonableness. She has known him only a fortnight. She danced four dances with him at Meryton; she saw him one morning at his own house, and has since dined in company with him four times. This is not quite enough to make her understand his character.”
vi: - Your plan is really good, there's nothing to doubt except for the desire to get married. If I were determined to marry a rich guy, or any guy for that matter, I would follow this way. But that's not Jane's feeling; she has no intention of acting. She is still unsure about her feelings, or whether this is reasonable or not. Jane has only known him for half a month. She has danced with him four times in Meryton, and only met him once at his house, and since then had dinner four times with him along with other people. These opportunities are not enough for Jane to understand much about him.
tr: "Your plan is sound," replied Elizabeth, "of course, if nothing else is at stake other than the desire to make a good marriage; if I were to seek a wealthy husband, or even just a husband, I would certainly follow your plan. But Jane's feelings are not like that; she is not acting according to a plan. She is not even sure of her own feelings yet, let alone whether it is wise or not. She has only known the man for fifteen days. She danced with him four times in Meryton; saw him at his house one morning, and since then they have met four times at dinner. This is not enough for her to understand the man's character."
es: ––Your plan is good ––replied Elizabeth––, when the matter is only about marrying well; and if I were determined to get a rich husband, or any husband, I can almost say that I would carry it out. But those are not Jane's feelings, she does not act with premeditation. She still cannot be sure to what extent she likes him, nor why. She has only known him for fifteen days. She danced with him four times in Meryton; saw him one morning at her house, and since then has dined in his company four times. This is not enough for her to know his character.

en: “Not as you represent it. Had she merely dined with him, she might only have discovered whether he had a good appetite; but you must remember that four evenings have been also spent together—and four evenings may do a great deal.”
vi: - You are right in the way you speak. If Jane simply had dinner with him, she could only know if he enjoyed his meal, but you should remember they have met for four evenings, and four evenings can create a lot of things.
tr: "It's not like you think. If he had only had a meal with her, he would have only learned whether she had a good appetite or not; but remember that four evenings were spent together – four evenings can make a big difference."
es: ––Not as you put it. If I had only had dinner with him, I wouldn't have discovered anything other than whether he has a good appetite or not; but you mustn't forget that they spent four evenings together; and four evenings can mean quite a lot.

en: “Yes: these four evenings have enabled them to ascertain that they both like Vingt-un better than Commerce, but with respect to any other leading characteristic, I do not imagine that much has been unfolded.”
vi: - Yes, during the four evenings they helped each other see what recreational activities they both enjoy, but regarding their temperaments, I think they didn't reveal much.
tr: "Yes, these four evenings gave them a chance to learn that they loved twenty-one more than conk; but I don't think much has come to light about other fundamental characteristics."
es: ––Yes; in those four evenings, all they could do was find out what kind of dances each one liked, but I don't think they were able to discover the really important things about their character.

en: “Well,” said Charlotte, “I wish Jane success with all my heart; and if she were married to him to-morrow, I should think she had as good a chance of happiness as if she were to be studying his character for a twelvemonth. Happiness in marriage is entirely a matter of chance. If the dispositions of the parties are ever so well known to each other, or ever so similar beforehand, it does not advance their felicity in the least. They always continue to grow sufficiently unlike afterwards to have their share of vexation; and it is better to know as little as possible of the defects of the person with whom you are to pass your life.”
vi: - Ah, I truly hope Jane's wishes come true, and if she gets married tomorrow, I believe she will certainly be as happy as if she had known him for twelve months. Happiness in marriage is entirely a matter of chance. If the two sides have mutual understanding beforehand, or if their temperaments are similar beforehand, it does not add to the happiness at all. They always plan to become entirely different people afterward, enough to annoy each other. Therefore, for the person with whom we are about to share our lives, it is best to know as little as possible about their flaws.
tr: "Honestly," said Charlotte, "I wish Jane all the success with all my heart; I believe that marrying her tomorrow would give as much chance of happiness as marrying her after examining her character for twelve months. Happiness in marriage is entirely a matter of chance. Even if the parties know each other very well, or are even very similar from the start, this does not contribute the slightest bit to their happiness. They always strive to change and get themselves into trouble; the less you know about the faults of the person you are going to spend your life with, the better."
es: ––Well ––said Charlotte––. I wholeheartedly wish that things go well for Jane; and if she were to marry him tomorrow, I believe she would have a better chance of being happy than if she spends twelve months studying his character. Happiness in marriage is only a matter of luck. The belief that a couple is equal or knows each other well beforehand is not going to bring them happiness at all. The differences become more and more pronounced until they become unbearable; it is always better to know as little as possible about the person with whom you are going to share your life.

en: “You make me laugh, Charlotte; but it is not sound. You know it is not sound, and that you would never act in this way yourself.”
vi: - You make me laugh, Charlotte, but what you're saying doesn't sound right at all. You must know it's not right, so I believe you would never act that way.
tr: "You make me laugh, Charlotte; but this is not sensible. You yourself wouldn't behave this way."
es: ––You make me laugh, Charlotte; it doesn't make sense. You know it doesn't make sense; besides, you would never act that way.

en: Occupied in observing Mr. Bingley’s attention to her sister, Elizabeth was far from suspecting that she was herself becoming an object of some interest in the eyes of his friend. Mr. Darcy had at first scarcely allowed her to be pretty: he had looked at her without admiration at the ball; and when they next met, he looked at her only to criticise. But no sooner had he made it clear to himself and his friends that she had hardly a good feature in her face, than he began to find it was rendered uncommonly intelligent by the beautiful expression of her dark eyes. To this discovery succeeded some others equally mortifying. Though he had detected with a critical eye more than one failure of perfect symmetry in her form, he was forced to acknowledge her figure to be light and pleasing; and in spite of his asserting that her manners were not those of the fashionable world, he was caught by their easy playfulness. Of this she was perfectly unaware: to her he was only the man who made himself agreeable nowhere, and who had not thought her handsome enough to dance with.
vi: While busy observing the relationship between Bingley and her sister, Elizabeth did not expect that she would be a noteworthy subject in the eyes of Mr. Bingley's friend. Darcy initially did not think she was beautiful; he had seen her at the ball without feeling any admiration for her. And afterward, he looked at her only to criticize. But not long after, once he clearly saw and told his friends that he could hardly see any beauty in her face, he began to perceive that her face exuded an unusual intelligence, through the beautiful expression of her dark eyes. This discovery was something that embarrassed him no less. Although through his critical eyes he saw her figure as less proportionate, he had to admit that her form exuded a graceful attractiveness; although he criticized her gestures as not belonging to the upper class, he was captivated by her playful nature. Regarding this, she was completely unaware – to her, he was just someone who never felt comfortable anywhere, the person who had deemed her not beautiful enough to be worth asking to dance.
tr: Elizabeth, who was busy observing the interest Mr. Bingley showed to her sister, was in no position to suspect that she herself was becoming the center of attention in the eyes of his friend. Mr. Darcy had not even admitted that she was beautiful at first; he had looked at her without admiration at the ball; in their next encounters, he had looked at her only to criticize. But it was almost immediate that, after telling himself and his friend that there was not a single beautiful feature in the girl's face, he began to see that the extraordinary expression in her dark eyes made that face unusually intelligent. This discovery was followed by others equally attentive. Though he found more than one symmetry flaw in her form when looking with a critical eye, he had to admit that her appearance was bright and refreshing; despite noting that her manners were not those of high society, he was intrigued by their ease. Elizabeth was unaware of these; –Darcy was just the man who could not endear himself to anyone anywhere and did not find her beautiful enough to dance with.
es: Occupied with observing Bingley's attentions towards her sister, Elizabeth was far from suspecting that she was also the object of interest in the eyes of Bingley's friend. At first, Mr. Darcy barely deigned to admit that she was pretty; he had shown no admiration for her at the ball; and the next time they met, he only noticed her to criticize her. But as soon as he made it clear to himself and to his friends that he barely liked her facial features, he began to realize that the beautiful expression of her dark eyes gave her an air of extraordinary intelligence. This discovery was followed by others equally mortifying. Although he detected with a critical eye more than one flaw in the perfect symmetry of her form, he had to acknowledge that her figure was graceful and slender; and despite claiming that her manners were not those of refined people, he felt attracted to her naturalness and cheerfulness. She had not the slightest idea of this matter. To her, Darcy was the man who made himself disagreeable wherever he went and the man who had not considered her beautiful enough to ask her to dance.

en: He began to wish to know more of her; and, as a step towards conversing with her himself, attended to her conversation with others. His doing so drew her notice. It was at Sir William Lucas’s, where a large party were assembled.
vi: He began to want to learn more about her. To take the first step towards conversing with her, he joined in on her conversations with others. This caught her attention. That was when the Lucas family organized a large gathering.
tr: Darcy wanted to get to know her better, and as a step to converse with her personally, he joined her conversations with others. By doing so, he caught Elizabeth's attention. This was happening at Sir William Lucas's; a large party was being held.
es: Darcy began to want to get to know her better. As a preliminary step to talking to her, he dedicated himself to listening to her talk with others. This fact caught Elizabeth's attention. It happened one day at Sir Lucas's house where a large group of people had gathered.

en: “What does Mr. Darcy mean,” said she to Charlotte, “by listening to my conversation with Colonel Forster?”
vi: Elizabeth said to Charlotte: - What did Mr. Darcy mean when he commented on the conversation I was having with Colonel Forster?
tr: "What does Mr. Darcy mean," said Elizabeth to Charlotte, "by listening to my conversation with Colonel Forster?"
es: ––What could Mr. Darcy want ––she said to Charlotte––, as he has been listening to my conversation with Colonel Forster?

en: “That is a question which Mr. Darcy only can answer.”
vi: - That is a question that only you can answer.
tr: "This is a question that only Mr. Darcy can answer.""
es: ––That is a question that only Mr. Darcy can answer.

en: “But if he does it any more, I shall certainly let him know that I see what he is about. He has a very satirical eye, and if I do not begin by being impertinent myself, I shall soon grow afraid of him.”
vi: - But if he does that again, I will definitely let him know what I think of him. He has a very mocking eye, if I don't start off rudely, I will become afraid of him.
tr: "But if he keeps this up, I will tell him that I understand what he's after. He has very piercing looks; if I don't start being rude first, he will quickly intimidate me."
es: ––If he does it again, I will let him know that I understand what he intends. He is very satirical, and if I don't start by being impertinent myself, I will end up being afraid of him.

en: “The entreaties of several”
vi: Immediately after that, the young man came over again, although he seemed reluctant to join the conversation.
tr: When they approached them a little later, although he did not seem inclined to talk, Miss Lucas cautioned her friend not to say such a thing; the admonition, provoking Elizabeth at that moment, made her turn to Darcy and say:
es: Shortly afterward, he approached them again, and although he did not seem to have any intention of speaking, Miss Lucas challenged her friend to bring up the subject, which immediately prompted Elizabeth, who turned to him and said:

en: On his approaching them soon afterwards, though without seeming to have any intention of speaking, Miss Lucas defied her friend to mention such a subject to him, which immediately provoking Elizabeth to do it, she turned to him and said,—
vi: Miss Lucas dared her friend to mention to him what they had just discussed. Thus, Elizabeth was challenged, she turned to the young man and said:
tr: When they approached them a little later, although he did not seem inclined to talk, Miss Lucas cautioned her friend not to say such a thing; the admonition, provoking Elizabeth at that moment, made her turn to Darcy and say:
es: Shortly afterward, he approached them again, and although he did not seem to have any intention of speaking, Miss Lucas challenged her friend to bring up the subject, which immediately prompted Elizabeth, who turned to him and said:

en: “Did not you think, Mr. Darcy, that I expressed myself uncommonly well just now, when I was teasing Colonel Forster to give us a ball at Meryton?”
vi: - Mr. Darcy, do you think I made a good remark when I teased Colonel Forster about organizing a ball in Meryton?
tr: "Don't you think I was expressing myself extraordinarily well, Mr. Darcy, while I was just now pestering Colonel Forster in Meryton to give us a ball?""
es: ––Don't you think, Mr. Darcy, that I expressed myself very well a moment ago when I insisted to Colonel Forster that he give us a ball in Meryton?

en: “With great energy; but it is a subject which always makes a lady energetic.”
vi: - I support it enthusiastically, but I think this is the topic that you ladies always support the most enthusiastically.
tr: "With tremendous energy too; –but this topic always makes a lady energetic."
es: ––With great energy; but that is a topic that always fills women with energy.

en: “You are severe on us.”
vi: - You are too strict with us.
tr: "You are cruel to us."
es: ––You are strict with us.

en: “It will be her turn soon to be teased,” said Miss Lucas. “I am going to open the instrument, Eliza, and you know what follows.”
vi: - Now it's your turn to be teased, Eliza. I'll play the opening music, and then you know how to continue.
tr: "Her turn to be vexed will come soon," said Miss Lucas. "I'm opening the piano, Eliza; you know what will follow.""
es: ––Now it's our turn to insist to you ––said Miss Lucas––. I'm going to open the piano and you know what comes next, Eliza.

en: “You are a very strange creature by way of a friend!—always wanting me to play and sing before anybody and everybody! If my vanity had taken a musical turn, you would have been invaluable; but as it is, I would really rather not sit down before those who must be in the habit of hearing the very best performers.” On Miss Lucas’s persevering, however, she added, “Very well; if it must be so, it must.” And gravely glancing at Mr. Darcy, “There is a very fine old saying, which everybody here is of course familiar with—‘Keep your breath to cool your porridge,’—and I shall keep mine to swell my song.”
vi: – Lucas interjected. - You are really strange compared to your friends – always wanting to sing and play music in front of everyone! If my frivolous nature has turned into music and poetry, it's because you have helped a lot. But I don't want to perform in front of people who expect to see the best performance. However, as Miss Lucas insisted, she continued, looking over at Darcy: - Alright, if it has to be that way, so be it. There is a very good proverb that everyone here knows: "Save your breath to cool the porridge," so I will save my breath to sing well.
tr: "You need a thousand witnesses to call you a friend! –you always want me to play and sing in front of people! If I were interested in showing off with music, you would be very useful; but as I am, I prefer not to perform in front of people who are used to listening to the best performers." Still, when Miss Lucas insisted, she added, "Alright, if you say so, let it be so." And giving Mr. Darcy a brave look, she said: "There is an old saying, everyone here knows it –'Save your breath to cool your porridge,' they say –so I'd better save my breath to sing my song."
es: ––What kind of friend are you? You always want me to sing and play in front of everyone. If God had called me to the path of music, you would be a friend of incalculable value; but since that is not the case, I would prefer not to play in front of people who must be used to listening to the best musicians ––but as Miss Lucas insisted, she added––: Very well, if it must be, it will be ––and looking coldly at Darcy, she said––: There is an old saying that everyone here knows very well, "save your breath to cool your soup," and I will save mine for my song.

en: Her performance was pleasing, though by no means capital. After a song or two, and before she could reply to the entreaties of several that she would sing again, she was eagerly succeeded at the instrument by her sister Mary, who having, in consequence of being the only plain one in the family, worked hard for knowledge and accomplishments, was always impatient for display.
vi: Her performance was cute, though nothing extraordinary. After one or two pieces and before she could respond to the request to continue, the prelude began from her sister Mary, the most unpretentious child in the family, diligent in her pursuit of knowledge and self-improvement, always eager to display her skills.
tr: Although the performance was not spectacular, it was sweet. After a few songs, before she could respond to the requests to sing again, her sister Mary eagerly sat down at the piano; Mary, being the most ordinary member of the family, worked very hard to gain knowledge and skills, and was always impatient to showcase what she had acquired.
es: Elizabeth's concert was pleasant, but not extraordinary. After one or two songs and before she could satisfy the requests of some who wanted her to sing again, she was replaced at the piano by her sister Mary, who, being the least brilliant of the family, worked hard to acquire knowledge and skills that she was always eager to demonstrate.

en: Mary had neither genius nor taste; and though vanity had given her application, it had given her likewise a pedantic air and conceited manner, which would have injured a higher degree of excellence than she had reached. Elizabeth, easy and unaffected, had been listened to with much more pleasure, though not playing half so well; and Mary, at the end of a long concerto, was glad to purchase praise and gratitude by Scotch and Irish airs, at the request of her younger sisters, who with some of the Lucases, and two or three officers, joined eagerly in dancing at one end of the room.
vi: Mary had neither genius nor taste, and though vanity had given her application, it had likewise given her a pedantic air and conceited manner, which would have injured a higher degree of excellence than she had reached. Elizabeth, easy and unaffected, had listened to her with much more pleasure, though not playing half so well herself. Mary, at the end of a long concerto, was glad to purchase praise and gratitude by Scotch and Irish airs, at the request of her younger sisters, who, with some of the Lucases and two or three officers, joined eagerly in dancing at one end of the room. The younger sisters were dancing at the other end of the room with the Miss Lucases and several of the officers.
tr: Mary had neither talent nor taste; the sense of show gave her the drive to work, just as it gave her a very knowing air and conceited manners, which would be repulsive even at a higher level of perfection than she had attained. Comfortable and unpretentious Elizabeth, although she played not even half as well, was listened to with much more pleasure; Mary received the praise and applause that would satisfy her at the end of a long concerto with the Scottish and Irish tunes she played at the request of her younger sisters; her younger sisters, along with a few of the Lucas girls and one or two officers, began a cheerful dance at the other end of the room.
es: Mary had neither talent nor taste; and although vanity had made her diligent, it had also given her a pedantic air and affected manners that would mar any brilliance superior to what she had achieved. Elizabeth, although she had played only half as well, had been listened to with more pleasure because of her ease and simplicity; Mary, at the end of her long concert, received no more than a few compliments for the Scottish and Irish melodies she had played at the request of her younger sisters who, along with some of the Lucases and two or three officers, were dancing merrily at one end of the room.

en: Mr. Darcy stood near them in silent indignation at such a mode of passing the evening, to the exclusion of all conversation, and was too much engrossed by his own thoughts to perceive that Sir William Lucas was his neighbour, till Sir William thus began:—
vi: Darcy stood in silent contempt of how to spend an evening like this, and withdrew from all conversation. He was so immersed in his own thoughts that he did not notice Sir William standing next to him until the latter spoke.
tr: Mr. Darcy, abandoning all conversation in the face of spending the evening in this manner, stood beside them with silent disdain; he was so lost in his thoughts that he did not notice Sir William Lucas approaching him as a neighbor until Sir William began to speak:
es: Darcy, who was indignant at that way of spending the evening, was silent and not in the mood to talk; he was so absorbed in his own thoughts that he did not notice Sir William Lucas was beside him until the latter addressed him.

en: “What a charming amusement for young people this is, Mr. Darcy! There is nothing like dancing, after all. I consider it as one of the first refinements of polished societies.”
vi: - Mr. Darcy, it is truly delightful for the young ones! There is nothing better than dancing. I consider dancing to be the first refined pleasure of elegant society.
tr: "What an attractive amusement for young people, Mr. Darcy! There's nothing like dancing, really. I consider it one of the first refinements of polite society."
es: ––What a delightful amusement for the youth, Mr. Darcy! When you look at it closely, there is nothing like dancing. I consider it one of the finest refinements of the most distinguished societies.

en: “Certainly, sir; and it has the advantage also of being in vogue amongst the less polished societies of the world: every savage can dance.”
vi: - Yes, sir. Dancing is also a popular trend in less refined societies around the world. All primitive people can dance.
tr: "Of course, sir; moreover, it also has the feature of being fashionable in the less polite societies of the world. Every savage can dance."
es: ––Certainly, sir, and it also has the advantage of being fashionable among the less distinguished societies of the world; all the savages dance.

en: Sir William only smiled. “Your friend performs delightfully,” he continued, after a pause, on seeing Bingley join the group; “and I doubt not that you are an adept in the science yourself, Mr. Darcy.”
vi: Sir William just smiled. - I applaud your friend's performance... He paused for a moment when he saw Bingley join the conversation group, then continued: - And I am certain that you are well-versed in the humanities, Mr. Darcy.
tr: Sir William just smiled. Seeing Bingley join the group, he paused for a moment and continued, "Your friend dances wonderfully; I have no doubt that you are also skilled in this art, Mr. Darcy."
es: Sir William sketched a smile. ––Your friend dances wonderfully ––she continued after a pause, seeing Bingley join the group–– and I do not doubt, Mr. Darcy, that you yourself are an expert in the matter.

en: “You saw me dance at Meryton, I believe, sir.”
vi: - I think you saw me dancing at Meryton.
tr: "Sir, you must have seen me dancing in Meryton."
es: ––He saw me dance in Meryton, I believe, sir.

en: “Yes, indeed, and received no inconsiderable pleasure from the sight. Do you often dance at St. James’s?”
vi: - Yes, that's right. I am extremely delighted with the view I witnessed. Do you often dance at St James's Palace?
tr: "Yes, of course; I quite enjoyed what I saw. Do you often dance at St. James?"
es: ––Of course, and it gave me great pleasure to see him. Do you often dance at Saint James?

en: “Never, sir.”
vi: - Never before, sir.
tr: "No, sir.""
es: ––Never, sir.

en: “Do you not think it would be a proper compliment to the place?”
vi: - Do you think that there should be proper praise for that place?
tr: "Don't you think that dancing is an appropriate expression of respect for that place?"
es: ––Don't you think it would be a compliment to that place?

en: “It is a compliment which I never pay to any place if I can avoid it.”
vi: - That is the praise I have never bestowed upon any other place, if I could avoid it.
tr: "It is a respect that I do not show to any place as long as I can avoid it.""
es: ––It is a compliment that I never give anywhere, if I can avoid it.

en: “You have a house in town, I conclude?”
vi: - I guess your house is in the city, is that right?
tr: "You have a house in the city, don't you?"
es: ––I believe he has a house in the capital.

en: Mr. Darcy bowed.
vi: Darcy just leaned over without saying anything.
tr: Mr. Darcy nodded.
es: Mr. Darcy nodded his head.

en: “I had once some thoughts of fixing in town myself, for I am fond of superior society; but I did not feel quite certain that the air of London would agree with Lady Lucas.”
vi: - There were times when I thought about settling down in the city because I enjoy high society, but it seems that the atmosphere in London does not suit Lady Lucas.
tr: "Once upon a time, I also considered settling in the city – I am interested in high society; but I was not sure if the air of London would be good for Lady Lucas.""
es: ––I sometimes thought about settling in the city, because I love high society; but I wasn't sure if the air of London would agree with Lady Lucas.

en: He paused in hopes of an answer: but his companion was not disposed to make any; and Elizabeth at that instant moving towards them, he was struck with the notion of doing a very gallant thing, and called out to her,—
vi: He stopped, waiting for an answer, but the young man was unwilling to say another word. Just then, Elizabeth was approaching them, and he suddenly had the idea to do something very chivalrous, so he called her:
tr: He paused in the hope of getting a response; but his friend was not inclined to reply; at that moment, seeing Elizabeth approaching them, he was seized with the idea of doing something bold and called out to her–
es: Sir William paused in the hope of a response, but his company was not willing to make any. Seeing Elizabeth approaching, it occurred to him to do something that seemed very gallant on his part, and he called her.

en: “My dear Miss Eliza, why are not you dancing? Mr. Darcy, you must allow me to present this young lady to you as a very desirable partner. You cannot refuse to dance, I am sure, when so much beauty is before you.” And, taking her hand, he would have given it to Mr. Darcy, who, though extremely surprised, was not unwilling to receive it, when she instantly drew back, and said with some discomposure to Sir William,—
vi: - Dear Eliza, why are you not dancing? Mr. Darcy, allow me to introduce this young lady to you as a most desirable dance partner. I am sure you cannot refuse, when such a wonderful beauty is before you. Then taking her hand, he should have led her to Darcy, who was very surprised but not entirely unwilling, but she immediately retreated and said with some embarrassment:
tr: "Dear Miss Eliza, why are you not dancing? –Mr. Darcy, you must allow me to present this young lady to you as a very suitable partner. With such beauty before you, I am sure you cannot refuse to dance." Just as he was about to take Elizabeth's hand and give it to the very surprised but not unwilling Mr. Darcy, Elizabeth quickly withdrew her hand and said to Sir William with some discomfort–
es: ––My dear Miss Eliza, why are you not dancing? Mr. Darcy, allow me to introduce you to this young lady who could be an excellent partner. I am sure you cannot refuse to dance when you have such beauty before you. He took Elizabeth by the hand with the intention of giving her to Darcy; who, although extremely surprised, was not going to refuse her; but Elizabeth turned her back on him and said to Sir William, somewhat disconcerted:

en: “Indeed, sir, I have not the least intention of dancing. I entreat you not to suppose that I moved this way in order to beg for a partner.”
vi: - Actually, sir, I have no intention of dancing at all. Please do not think that I came here to find a dance partner.
tr: "Truly, sir, I have no intention of dancing. I kindly ask you not to think that I came here to look for a partner."
es: ––Really, sir, I had no intention of dancing. I beg you not to assume that I came here to find a partner.
