tr: "Gladly; if Darcy sells it, I will buy Pemberley.""
es: ––Of course, I would do it. And I would buy Pemberley itself if Darcy were to sell it.

en: “I am talking of possibilities, Charles.”
vi: - Charles, I'm talking about possibilities.
tr: "I'm talking about possibilities, Charles."
es: ––I am talking about possibilities, Charles.

en: “Upon my word, Caroline, I should think it more possible to get Pemberley by purchase than by imitation.”
vi: - Caroline, I give you my word of honor that I believe it is more feasible to approach Pemberly by purchasing it than by imagining it.
tr: "Believe me, Caroline, I think it is more feasible to own Pemberley by purchasing it than by imitating it."
es: ––Honestly, Caroline, I would rather acquire Pemberley by purchasing it than by imitating it.

en: Elizabeth was so much caught by what passed, as to leave her very little attention for her book; and, soon laying it wholly aside, she drew near the card-table, and stationed herself between Mr. Bingley and his eldest sister, to observe the game.
vi: Elizabeth was so surprised by what was happening that she no longer focused on the book she was holding, and soon put it aside. She went to the card table, standing between Bingley and his sister to observe the game.
tr: The conversation intrigued Elizabeth so much that she couldn't focus on her book; soon she put the book aside entirely, moved closer to the table to watch the game, and placed herself between Mr. Bingley and her eldest sister.
es: Elizabeth was too absorbed in what was happening to pay the slightest attention to her book; she soon abandoned it, approached the game table, and positioned herself between Bingley and her older sister to observe the game.

en: “Is Miss Darcy much grown since the spring?” said Miss Bingley: “will she be as tall as I am?”
vi: Miss Bingley said: - Has Miss Darcy grown much since last spring? Is she as tall as I am?
tr: "Has Miss Darcy grown since the spring?" said Miss Bingley; "Is she as tall as I am?"
es: ––Has Miss Darcy grown since the spring? ––asked Miss Bingley––. Is she as tall as I am now?

en: “I think she will. She is now about Miss Elizabeth Bennet’s height, or rather taller.”
vi: - I think that maybe so. Now she is almost as tall as Miss Elizabeth, or maybe even taller.
tr: "It might work. Now, she is about the height of Miss Elizabeth Bennet, or maybe a bit taller."
es: ––I think so. Now she must be as tall as Miss Elizabeth Bennet, or even taller.

en: “How I long to see her again! I never met with anybody who delighted me so much. Such a countenance, such manners, and so extremely accomplished for her age! Her performance on the pianoforte is exquisite.”
vi: - I really want to meet her again. I have never met anyone as pleasant as her. Her face and gestures are truly adorable. Her piano playing is truly unique.
tr: "How much I would like to see her again! I haven't met anyone who made me so happy. Such a face, such grace! Extremely skillful for her age, moreover! Her piano playing is extraordinary."
es: ––How eager I am to see her again! I've never met anyone I like so much. What a figure, what manners, and what talent for her age! She plays the piano exquisitely.

en: “It is amazing to me,” said Bingley, “how young ladies can have patience to be so very accomplished as they all are.”
vi: Bingley said: - I am amazed at how young girls have enough perseverance to achieve so many talents; all of them are truly talented.
tr: "I don't understand how young ladies find the patience to be so skillful, and all of them at that," said Bingley.
es: ––It amazes me ––said Bingley–– that young women have so much patience to learn so much, and become as perfect as they all are.

en: “All young ladies accomplished! My dear Charles, what do you mean?”
vi: - Are all young girls talented? Dear Charles, what do you mean by that?
tr: "All young ladies are skillful! Dear Charles, what do you mean?"
es: ––All the young women are perfect! My dear Charles, what do you say?

en: “Yes, all of them, I think. They all paint tables, cover screens, and net purses. I scarcely know any one who cannot do all this; and I am sure I never heard a young lady spoken of for the first time, without being informed that she was very accomplished.”
vi: - That's right, I think all the girls are very talented. All of them can paint tables and chairs, hang curtains, and knit purses. I see that few people cannot do these things, and I am sure that the girls being mentioned are all talented.
tr: "Yes, all of them, I suppose. They paint, embroider, and knit bags. I have hardly ever met anyone who cannot do all these things; I am sure I have never heard a young lady mentioned without first being told how skillful she is."
es: ––Yes, all of them. They all paint, cover screens, and make mesh bags. I don't know any who can't do all these things, and I've never heard of a young lady for the first time without being informed that she was perfect.

en: “Your list of the common extent of accomplishments,” said Darcy, “has too much truth. The word is applied to many a woman who deserves it no otherwise than by netting a purse or covering a screen; but I am very far from agreeing with you in your estimation of ladies in general. I cannot boast of knowing more than half-a-dozen in the whole range of my acquaintance that are really accomplished.”
vi: Darcy said: - Your list of common talents is quite accurate. This world has many women who are only commendable for knitting purses or hanging curtains. But I don't quite agree with your way of evaluating women. Among all the people I know, I can't boast of knowing more than half a dozen women who are truly talented.
tr: "The skills you mentioned are indeed common," said Darcy, "very true. This word is also used for women who do not deserve it beyond sewing and embroidery. But I am far from accepting your general assessment of ladies. I cannot boast of having known more than half a dozen truly skilled ladies among all my acquaintances."
es: ––Your list of what those perfections commonly encompass ––said Darcy–– has much truth in it. The adjective is applied to women whose knowledge is no more than making mesh bags or covering screens. But I am far from agreeing with you regarding your estimation of ladies in general. Of all those I have known, I cannot boast of knowing more than half a dozen who are truly perfect.

en: “Nor I, I am sure,” said Miss Bingley.
vi: Miss Bingley added: - Me neither, I'm sure of it.
tr: "I am sure I feel the same way," said Miss Bingley.
es: ––Nor I, certainly ––said Miss Bingley.

en: “Then,” observed Elizabeth, “you must comprehend a great deal in your idea of an accomplished woman.”
vi: - Then, you must have a very thorough understanding of what it means to be an accomplished woman. – Elizabeth remarked.
tr: "In that case," observed Elizabeth, "your idea of an accomplished woman must be very comprehensive."
es: ––Then observed Elizabeth–– it must be that his concept of the perfect woman is very demanding.

en: “Yes; I do comprehend a great deal in it.”
vi: - Yes, indeed I know very well about this issue.
tr: "Yes, it is really comprehensive."" "Ah!
es: ––Yes, it is very demanding.

en: “Oh, certainly,” cried his faithful assistant, “no one can be really esteemed accomplished who does not greatly surpass what is usually met with. A woman must have a thorough knowledge of music, singing, drawing, dancing, and the modern languages, to deserve the word; and, besides all this, she must possess a certain something in her air and manner of walking, the tone of her voice, her address and expressions, or the word will be but half deserved.”
vi: Darcy's loyal assistant exclaimed: - Ah! That's right. No one can be considered complete if they do not overcome what they usually have to face. A woman must have a thorough understanding of music, vocals, dance, and foreign languages to be worthy of that title. And besides these aspects, she must also have something in her demeanor and posture when moving, the tone of her voice, the way she addresses and expresses herself, otherwise, she is only worthy of half the words.
tr: Of course," cried the loyal supporter, "no one can truly be considered skillful unless they have far surpassed the ordinary things encountered. A woman must be well-versed in music, singing, painting, and modern languages to deserve that word; moreover, there must be a certain something in her manner of walking, her air, the tone of her voice, her speech, her expressions, otherwise that word would seem out of place."
es: ––"Oh, of course!" exclaimed her faithful collaborator––. No one can truly consider themselves perfect if they do not far exceed what is normally found. A woman must have a deep knowledge of music, singing, drawing, dancing, and modern languages. And in addition to all this, she must possess a certain something in her air and manner of walking, in the tone of her voice, in her demeanor and way of expressing herself; otherwise, she would only deserve the title halfway.

en: “All this she must possess,” added Darcy; “and to all she must yet add something more substantial in the improvement of her mind by extensive reading.”
vi: Darcy added: - She must have all of these things, and in addition to that, she must have something substantial in the way of expanding her knowledge by reading a lot.
tr: "She must possess all this," added Darcy, "and to all this she must yet add something more substantial, in the improvement of her mind by extensive reading.""
es: ––She must possess all this ––added Darcy––, and to it must be added something more substantial in the development of her intelligence through abundant reading.

en: “I am no longer surprised at your knowing only six accomplished women. I rather wonder now at your knowing any.”
vi: - I am no longer surprised that you only know six perfect women. I want to know if you currently know any such woman?
tr: "I am no longer surprised that you have only known six skillful women. I would be surprised if you knew even one."
es: ––It doesn't surprise me now that I know only six perfect women. What surprises me is that I know any.

en: “Are you so severe upon your own sex as to doubt the possibility of all this?”
vi: - Are you too strict about your gender, thus doubting your ability to achieve all these talents?
tr: "Are you so cruel as to doubt that this is possible for your fellow beings?"
es: ––Are you so severe with your own sex that you doubt this is possible?

en: “I never saw such a woman. I never saw such capacity, and taste, and application, and elegance, as you describe, united.”
vi: - I have never met a woman like that. I have never had the honor of meeting such a talent, combined with taste, diligence, and the refined personality as you described, all in one person.
tr: "I have never seen a woman like this. I have never seen such a combination of capacity, taste, practice, and elegance as you described."
es: ––I have never seen a woman like that. I have never seen so much capability, so much taste, so much dedication, and so much elegance together as you describe.

en: Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley both cried out against the injustice of her implied doubt, and were both protesting that they knew many women who answered this description, when Mr. Hurst called them to order, with bitter complaints of their inattention to what was going forward. As all conversation was thereby at an end, Elizabeth soon afterwards left the room.
vi: Both Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley voiced their objections, claiming that she was being unfair in her doubts. While the two were arguing that they knew many women who fit that description, Mr. Hurst called for order with a bitter complaint that they had disregarded what they were supposed to be doing. Thus, all conversation ceased, and afterward, Elizabeth left the room.
tr: Miss Hurst and Miss Bingley reacted strongly to the injustice of the suspicion they harbored; they continued to argue by saying that they knew many women who fit this description, until Mr. Hurst bitterly complained that they were not paying attention to the game in front of them and brought them back in line. Since all conversation ended at that moment, Elizabeth immediately left the room afterward.
es: Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley protested against the injustice of his implicit doubt, asserting that they knew many women who fit that description, when Mr. Hurst called them to order, bitterly complaining that they were not paying attention to the game. As the conversation seemed to have ended, Elizabeth soon left the room.

en: “Eliza Bennet,” said Miss Bingley, when the door was closed on her, “is one of those young ladies who seek to recommend themselves to the other sex by undervaluing their own; and with many men, I daresay, it succeeds; but, in my opinion, it is a paltry device, a very mean art.”
vi: When the door had closed behind Elizabeth, Miss Bingley said: - Elizabeth Bennet is one of those girls who wants to introduce herself to others by undervaluing herself, and I am convinced that this works with many people. But in my opinion, it is a trick, a very poor art.
tr: "Eliza Bennet," said Miss Bingley, when the door had closed behind her, "is one of those women who disparage their own sex to appeal to the opposite sex; I suppose this works with many men. But in my opinion, it is a low method, very vulgar."
es: ––Elizabeth ––said Miss Bingley when the door had closed behind her–– is one of those girls who try to make themselves agreeable to the opposite sex by discrediting their own; I won't say it doesn't work with many men, but in my opinion, it's a vile trick, a bad habit.

en: “Undoubtedly,” replied Darcy, to whom this remark was chiefly addressed, “there is meanness in all the arts which ladies sometimes condescend to employ for captivation. Whatever bears affinity to cunning is despicable.”
vi: Darcy replied to her: - There is certainly an inadequacy in all the arts that you ladies occasionally use to win over men. Everything related to cunning is contemptible.
tr: "Undoubtedly," replied Darcy, as these words were essentially addressed to him, "there is vulgarity in all the methods that ladies sometimes use to attract attention. Everything close to cunning is simplicity."
es: ––Undoubtedly ––replied Darcy, to whom this observation was mainly directed–– there is baseness in all the arts that ladies sometimes lower themselves to employ to captivate men. Anything that has to do with cunning is despicable.

en: Miss Bingley was not so entirely satisfied with this reply as to continue the subject.
vi: Miss Bingley was not entirely satisfied with the answer to continue the subject.
tr: Miss Bingley was not satisfied enough with this remark to continue the subject.
es: Miss Bingley was not satisfied enough with the answer to continue with the topic.

en: Elizabeth joined them again only to say that her sister was worse, and that she could not leave her. Bingley urged Mr. Jones’s being sent for immediately; while his sisters, convinced that no country advice could be of any service, recommended an express to town for one of the most eminent physicians. This she would not hear of; but she was not so unwilling to comply with their brother’s proposal; and it was settled that Mr. Jones should be sent for early in the morning, if Miss Bennet were not decidedly better. Bingley was quite uncomfortable; his sisters declared that they were miserable. They solaced their wretchedness, however, by duets after supper; while he could find no better relief to his feelings than by giving his housekeeper directions that every possible attention might be paid to the sick lady and her sister.
vi: Elizabeth came in again just to say that her sister's condition had worsened, and she could not leave her side. Bingley urged them to call Mr. Jones, while the two sisters believed that the country doctor could not help and suggested urgently inviting a renowned doctor from the city. Elizabeth did not agree with the sisters, but she was not as reluctant with Bingley's suggestion. Everyone then agreed that if Jane did not get better, they would call Mr. Jones early in the morning. Bingley clearly appeared very restless, while the Bingley sisters claimed they felt very distressed upon hearing this news. However, after dinner, the two sisters amused themselves with duets, while Mr. Bingley could do nothing more than order the servants to do everything possible to care for the patient and her sister.
tr: Elizabeth returned to them only to say that her sister was getting worse and that she couldn't leave her side. Bingley insisted on calling Mr. Jones immediately; his sisters, thinking that provincial knowledge would be useless, suggested sending for one of the leading doctors from the city. Elizabeth did not entertain this idea; but she did not want to refuse Bingley's offer; it was decided that if there was no noticeable improvement in Miss Bennet, Mr. Jones would be called early in the morning. Bingley was quite distressed; his sisters also said they were devastated. But they alleviated their sorrow with duets after dinner; Bingley, on the other hand, found the only way to ease his mind was to instruct the steward to show every possible care to the sick lady and her sister.
es: Elizabeth rejoined them only to tell them that her sister was worse and that she could not leave her. Bingley decided to send someone immediately to fetch Dr. Jones; while his sisters, convinced that medical assistance in the countryside was useless, proposed sending someone to the capital to bring one of the most eminent doctors. Elizabeth did not want to hear of the latter, but she did not oppose doing what the brother suggested. So it was agreed to send for Dr. Jones early the next morning if Jane was not better. Bingley was quite worried and his sisters were very distressed. However, later they consoled themselves by singing some duets, while Bingley could find no better relief for his concern than giving orders to his housekeeper to pay all possible attention to the sick woman and her sister.

en: CHAPTER IX.
vi: Chapter 9
tr: Chapter IX
es: CHAPTER IX

en: ELIZABETH passed the chief of the night in her sister’s room, and in the morning had the pleasure of being able to send a tolerable answer to the inquiries which she very early received from Mr. Bingley by a housemaid, and some time afterwards from the two elegant ladies who waited on his sisters. In spite of this amendment, however, she requested to have a note sent to Longbourn, desiring her mother to visit Jane, and form her own judgment of her situation. The note was immediately despatched, and its contents as quickly complied with. Mrs. Bennet, accompanied by her two youngest girls, reached Netherfield soon after the family breakfast.
vi: Elizabeth spent the night in the same room as her sister. In the morning, the servants conveyed the regards of Mr. Bingley and his two sisters to them. And Eliza could be pleased because the doctor's response was not too pessimistic. Although Jane's condition had improved, she still requested that news be sent to Longbourn about her situation and expressed a desire for her mother to visit her. The letter was sent immediately and her mother responded at once. Mrs. Bennet and her two youngest daughters arrived at Netherfield just after breakfast.
tr: Elizabeth spent most of the night in her sister's room and took delight in giving a comforting answer to the questions Mr. Bingley had asked through his servant early in the morning, and a little later, to the two elegant ladies who visited her sister. Despite this improvement, she still requested that a letter be sent to Longbourn, asking her mother to come see Jane and assess her condition with her own eyes. The letter was sent immediately and was responded to with the same speed. Mrs. Bennet, accompanied by her two youngest daughters, arrived at Netherfield shortly after the family breakfast.
es: Elizabeth spent most of the night in her sister's room, and in the morning she had the pleasure of being able to send a satisfactory response to the numerous questions she had been receiving very early, through one of Bingley's servants; and also to those she later received from the two elegant ladies-in-waiting of the sisters. Despite the improvement, Elizabeth asked for a note to be sent to Longbourn, as she wanted her mother to come visit Jane so she could judge the situation for herself. The note was dispatched immediately and the response to its content was fulfilled with the same speed. Mrs. Bennet, accompanied by her two younger daughters, arrived at Netherfield shortly after the family's breakfast.

en: Had she found Jane in any apparent danger, Mrs. Bennet would have been very miserable; but being satisfied on seeing her that her illness was not alarming, she had no wish of her recovering immediately, as her restoration to health would probably remove her from Netherfield. She would not listen, therefore, to her daughter’s proposal of being carried home; neither did the apothecary, who arrived about the same time, think it at all advisable. After sitting a little while with Jane, on Miss Bingley’s appearance and invitation, the mother and three daughters all attended her into the breakfast parlour. Bingley met them with hopes that Mrs. Bennet had not found Miss Bennet worse than she expected.
vi: If Mrs. Bennet saw Jane in any obvious danger, she would feel extremely distressed. But upon arriving and being reassured that her illness was not serious, she did not wish for her to recover immediately, lest she have to leave Netherfield. Therefore, she did not heed her daughter's request to return home. The doctor felt the same way. After sitting with Jane, all four of them were invited by Miss Bingley into the breakfast room. Bingley met them with the hope that Mrs. Bennet did not think Jane's condition was worse than she initially feared. Mrs. Bennet said:
tr: If Mrs. Bennet found Jane's condition dangerous, she would have been devastated; but upon seeing that her illness was not frightening and feeling relieved, she no longer wished for her to recover quickly, as regaining her health would likely take her away from Netherfield. Therefore, she paid no attention to her daughter's wish to be taken home; the pharmacist who arrived at the same time also found this unwise. After sitting with Jane for a while, upon Miss Bingley's personal invitation, the mother and her three daughters all followed her to the breakfast room. Bingley greeted them by saying that he hoped Mrs. Bennet did not find Miss Bennet worse than she had expected.
es: If she had found Jane in apparent danger, Mrs. Bennet would have been very upset; but being satisfied to see that the illness was not alarming, she had no desire for her to recover quickly, as her cure would mean leaving Netherfield. For this reason, she refused to heed her daughter's request to be taken home, something that the doctor, who had arrived almost at the same time, also did not deem prudent. After sitting with Jane for a while, Miss Bingley appeared and invited them to the dining room. The mother and the three daughters followed her. Bingley received them and asked about Jane, hoping that Mrs. Bennet had not found her daughter worse than expected.

en: “Indeed I have, sir,” was her answer. “She is a great deal too ill to be moved. Mr. Jones says we must not think of moving her. We must trespass a little longer on your kindness.”
vi: - Actually, I fear Jane's illness is quite severe, so she cannot walk. Mr. Jones said we shouldn't let the girl move. We are forced to trouble your family for a little while longer.
tr: "Actually, I found it, sir," was the woman's reply. "He is too sick to move. Mr. Jones said don't move him. We have to rely on your kindness a little longer."
es: ––Well, truly, I have found her very unwell ––replied Mrs. Bennet––. So unwell that it is not possible to take her home. Doctor Jones says we must not think of moving her. We will have to impose a little more on your kindness.

en: “Removed!” cried Bingley. “It must not be thought of. My sister, I am sure, will not hear of her removal.”
vi: Bingley exclaimed: - Move! Don't think about this. I am sure that my sister doesn't want her to move.
tr: "Take her away!" cried Bingley. "Don't even think about it. My sister, I'm sure, would never agree to her leaving."
es: ––Move her! ––exclaimed Bingley––. Not a chance! I'm sure my sister will also oppose her going home.

en: “You may depend upon it, madam,” said Miss Bingley, with cold civility, “that Miss Bennet shall receive every possible attention while she remains with us.”
vi: - Madam, you can rely on us. Miss Bennet will be well taken care of during her stay here. – Miss Bingley said.
tr: "Rest assured, madam," said Miss Bingley with cold politeness, "Miss Bennet will receive every care while she stays with us.""
es: ––You can trust, madam ––replied Miss Bingley with cold courtesy––, that Miss Bennet will lack nothing while she is with us.

en: Mrs. Bennet was profuse in her acknowledgments.
vi: Mrs. Bennet thanked them warmly.
tr: Mrs. Bennet thanked profusely.
es: ––You can trust, madam ––replied Miss Bingley with cold courtesy––, that Miss Bennet will lack nothing while she is with us.

en: “I am sure,” she added, “if it was not for such good friends, I do not know what would become of her, for she is very ill indeed, and suffers a vast deal, though with the greatest patience in the world, which is always the way with her, for she has, without exception, the sweetest temper I ever met with. I often tell my other girls they are nothing to her. You have a sweet room here, Mr. Bingley, and a charming prospect over that gravel walk. I do not know a place in the country that is equal to Netherfield. You will not think of quitting it in a hurry, I hope, though you have but a short lease.”
vi: She added: - I am sure that if it weren't for such good friends, I don't know what would have happened to Jane. Because Jane has really weakened a lot and suffered a lot. Although Jane has enough perseverance to endure. She is the gentlest girl I have ever seen. I often tell my other girls that they cannot compare to their sister. Mr. Bingley, you have a really elegant room, with the charming exterior view through the gravel path out there. I have never seen a place as beautiful as Netherfield. I hope you don't intend to leave this place in a hurry, even though I know you are only renting it short-term.
tr: "I'm sure," she added, "if she didn't have such good friends, I don't know what would become of her, because she is really very ill and in great pain, but she is the most patient person in the world, she always is, because, without exception, she is the most good-natured girl I know. I often tell my other daughters that she is unique. You have a very lovely room, Mr. Bingley, and the view over that gravel path is wonderful. I don't know of any place around here that compares to Netherfield. I hope you won't leave here quickly, even though you've rented it for a short time."
es: ––I am sure ––she added–– that if it weren't for such good friends, I don't know what would have become of her, because she is very ill and suffers a lot; although, that said, with the greatest patience in the world, as she always does, because she has the sweetest character I know. I often tell my other daughters that they are worth nothing compared to her. What a beautiful room this is, Mr. Bingley, and what a lovely view it has of the garden paths! I have never seen a place in the whole country comparable to Netherfield. I hope you are not thinking of leaving it suddenly, even though you have rented it for a short time.

en: “Whatever I do is done in a hurry,” replied he; “and therefore if I should resolve to quit Netherfield, I should probably be off in five minutes. At present, however, I consider myself as quite fixed here.”
vi: - I decide everything quickly, so if I am determined to leave Netherfield, I could be on my way within five minutes. However, at this moment I want to settle here. – Bingley replied.
tr: "Whatever I do, I do quickly," replied Bingley; "so if I decide to leave Netherfield, I will probably be gone within five minutes. But for now, I feel quite settled here.""
es: ––I do everything suddenly ––replied Bingley––. So if I decided to leave Netherfield, I would probably be gone in five minutes. But, for now, I am fine here.

en: “That is exactly what I should have supposed of you,” said Elizabeth.
vi: Elizabeth exclaimed: - That is exactly what I guessed about you.
tr: "I would have expected this from you," said Elizabeth.
es: ––That is exactly what I expected from you ––said Elizabeth.

en: “You begin to comprehend me, do you?” cried he, turning towards her.
vi: - You are starting to understand me, aren't you? – He turned towards her and exclaimed.
tr: "You are beginning to know me, aren't you?" cried Bingley, turning towards her.
es: ––You are beginning to understand me, aren't you? ––exclaimed Bingley, turning towards her.

en: “Oh yes—I understand you perfectly.”
vi: - Ah yes, I think I understand you quite well.
tr: "Ah yes! –I understand you very well."
es: ––Oh, yes! I understand you perfectly.

en: “I wish I might take this for a compliment; but to be so easily seen through, I am afraid, is pitiful.”
vi: - I hope this is a compliment.
tr: "I wish I could see this as a compliment; but being understood this easily, I'm afraid, is a pitiable thing."
es: ––I would like to take it as a compliment; but I am afraid that being easily recognized is unfortunate.

en: “That is as it happens. It does not necessarily follow that a deep, intricate character is more or less estimable than such a one as yours.”
vi: But being seen through completely is really pitiful for me. - But this does not necessarily mean that a person with a deep and sophisticated personality like you has to make themselves appear more enigmatic.
tr: "There is no rule for this. A deep, complex character doesn't necessarily mean it will be more or less respectable than yours."
es: ––It is what it is. That does not necessarily mean that a deep and complex character is more or less estimable than his.

en: “Lizzy,” cried her mother, “remember where you are, and do not run on in the wild manner that you are suffered to do at home.”
vi: The mother exclaimed: - Lizzy, remember where you are, don't be as carefree as you are at home.
tr: "Lizzy," cried her mother, "do not forget where you are; at least do not continue the wild manners we tolerate at home here."
es: ––Lizzy ––exclaimed her mother––, remember where you are and stop behaving with that intolerable conduct that we are accustomed to at home.

en: “I did not know before,” continued Bingley, immediately, “that you were a studier of character. It must be an amusing study.”
vi: Bingley immediately continued: - I didn't know before that you often explore personalities. This must be an interesting field of study.
tr: "I didn't know you studied character," Bingley immediately continued. "It must be an amusing study."
es: ––I didn't know you were dedicated to studying people's character ––Bingley continued immediately––. It must be a fascinating study.

en: “Yes; but intricate characters are the most amusing. They have at least that advantage.”
vi: - Yes, the most enjoyable are the complex personalities, at least there's an advantage in that.
tr: "Yes, but complex characters are the most fun. At least they serve this purpose."
es: ––Yes; and complex characters are the most fascinating of all. At least, they have that advantage.

en: “The country,” said Darcy, “can in general supply but few subjects for such a study. In a country neighbourhood you move in a very confined and unvarying society.”
vi: - The entire country can only provide a few such individuals. In the countryside, we move within a very limited and unchanging society.
tr: "The countryside," said Darcy, "can offer very few subjects for such an examination. In the rural environment, you live within a very limited and monotonous society."
es: ––The countryside ––said Darcy–– cannot provide many subjects for such a study. In a village, one moves in an unchanging and very limited society.

en: “But people themselves alter so much, that there is something new to be observed in them for ever.”
vi: - But people themselves change so much that we can always observe something new in them.
tr: "But people themselves change so much that there is always something new to observe in them.""
es: ––But people change so much that there is always something new to observe in them.

en: “Yes, indeed,” cried Mrs. Bennet, offended by his manner of mentioning a country neighbourhood. “I assure you there is quite as much of that going on in the country as in town.”
vi: Mrs. Bennet said, with a look of displeasure because he had mentioned the countryside: - Yes, that's right. I assure you that many such things happen in the countryside as well as in the city.
tr: "Yes, of course," cried Mrs. Bennet, offended by the way the provincial environment was mentioned. "I assure you that there are as many events in the countryside as there are in the city."
es: ––Of course it does ––exclaimed Mrs. Bennet, offended by the way he had spoken about country folk––; I assure you that it happens the same in the country as in the city.

en: Everybody was surprised; and Darcy, after looking at her for a moment, turned silently away. Mrs. Bennet, who fancied she had gained a complete victory over him, continued her triumph,—
vi: Everyone was surprised. Darcy, after looking at her for a moment, silently turned away. Thinking she had overwhelmingly won against him, Mrs. Bennet continued her victorious momentum:
tr: Everyone was surprised; Darcy looked at her for a moment and then silently turned away. Believing she had achieved absolute victory over him, Mrs. Bennet continued her triumph.
es: Everyone was surprised. Darcy looked at her for a moment and then turned away without saying anything. Mrs. Bennet believed she had achieved a crushing victory over him and continued triumphantly:

en: “I cannot see that London has any great advantage over the country, for my part, except the shops and public places. The country is a vast deal pleasanter, is not it, Mr. Bingley?”
vi: As for me, I don't see any significant advantages that London has over the countryside, except for the shops and public facilities. The countryside is much more pleasant, isn't it, Mr. Bingley?
tr: "For my part, I do not think London is superior to the countryside, except for the shops and public places. The countryside is much more charming, isn't it, Mr. Bingley?"
es: ––For my part, I do not think that London has any advantage over the countryside, except for the shops and public places. The countryside is much more pleasant. Isn't that so, Mr. Bingley?

en: “When I am in the country,” he replied, “I never wish to leave it; and when I am in town, it is pretty much the same. They have each their advantages, and I can be equally happy in either.”
vi: - When I lived in the countryside, I never wanted to leave, and when I moved to the city, it was the same. Each place has its own advantages, so I find happiness wherever I am.
tr: "When I am in the countryside," replied Bingley, "I never want to leave; but the same thing happens when I am in the city. Both have their advantages; I can be equally happy in both."
es: ––When I am in the countryside ––he replied–– I do not wish to leave, and when I am in the city, the same thing happens to me. Each place has its advantages, and I feel equally comfortable in both.

en: “Ay, that is because you have the right disposition. But that gentleman,” looking at Darcy, “seemed to think the country was nothing at all.”
vi: - That's right, because you have a moderate temperament. But this friend here – she looked over at Mr. Darcy – seems to think that the countryside is nothing at all.
tr: "Yes –because your approach is correct. But this gentleman," looking at Darcy, "seems to think that the countryside is insignificant."
es: ––Of course, because you have a very good disposition. On the other hand, that gentleman ––she said looking at Darcy –does not seem to have a very good opinion of the countryside.

en: “Indeed, mamma, you are mistaken,” said Elizabeth, blushing for her mother. “You quite mistook Mr. Darcy. He only meant that there was not such a variety of people to be met with in the country as in town, which you must acknowledge to be true.”
vi: Elizabeth blushed because of her mother: - Mom! Actually, you misunderstood Mr. Darcy's point. He just meant that people living in the countryside are not as diverse as those in the city, you have to admit this.
tr: "You are truly mistaken, mother," said Elizabeth, blushing on behalf of her mother. "You misunderstood Mr. Darcy. He only meant that there isn't as much variety of people in the countryside as there is in the city, which you must admit is true."
es: ––Mom, you are very mistaken ––Elizabeth intervened, blushing at her mother's imprudence––, you misunderstand Mr. Darcy. He only meant to say that in the countryside you don't find as much variety of people as in the city. Which you must admit is true.

en: “Certainly, my dear, nobody said there were; but as to not meeting with many people in this neighbourhood, I believe there are few neighbourhoods larger. I know we dine with four-and-twenty families.”
vi: - That's right, my child, but regarding not meeting the people in this community, I think there aren't many communities larger than this place. We have had dinner with more than forty families.
tr: "Naturally, darling, no one said there was anyone here; but if you say you don't encounter many people in this neighborhood, I would say there are few neighborhoods larger than this one. I remember having dinner with twenty-four families."
es: ––Certainly, dear, no one said otherwise, but as for there not being many people in this neighborhood, I believe there are few as large as ours. I have dined with twenty-four families.

en: Nothing but concern for Elizabeth could enable Bingley to keep his countenance. His sister was less delicate, and directed her eye towards Mr. Darcy with a very expressive smile. Elizabeth, for the sake of saying something that might turn her mother’s thoughts, now asked her if Charlotte Lucas had been at Longbourn since her coming away.
vi: Only his concern for Elizabeth allowed Bingley to maintain a calm demeanor. His sister was less discreet, casting a meaningful glance towards Darcy. To divert her mother, Elizabeth asked if Charlotte Lucas had visited Longbourn since she had left.
tr: Bingley would not have been able to control his expression if he were not worried about Elizabeth. His sister was less kind and turned her eyes towards Mr. Darcy with a very meaningful smile. Elizabeth asked if Charlotte Lucas had come to Longbourn while she was away to change her mother's thoughts.
es: Nothing, if it weren't for his consideration for Elizabeth, could have made Bingley restrain himself. His sister was less delicate, and looked at Darcy with a very expressive smile. Elizabeth wanted to say something to change the conversation and asked her mother if Charlotte Lucas had been to Longbourn since she had left.

en: “Yes, she called yesterday with her father. What an agreeable man Sir William is, Mr. Bingley—is not he? so much the man of fashion! so genteel and so easy! He has always something to say to everybody. That is my idea of good breeding; and those persons who fancy themselves very important and never open their mouths quite mistake the matter.”
vi: - She went with her father. Sir William is really a pleasant person, isn't he, Mr. Bingley? He is a man of fashion, so gentle, so profound. He always has something to say to everyone. That is my idea of a well-bred person; those who consider themselves important and never open their mouths are greatly mistaken.
tr: "Yes, he stopped by with his father yesterday. What a charming man Sir William is, Mr. Bingley – isn't he? What a cultured man! So polite, so at ease! –He always has something to say to everyone. –This is what I call good upbringing; those who think they are very important and never open their mouths misunderstand the matter."
es: ––Yes, he visited us yesterday with his father. What a pleasant man Sir William is! Isn't he, Mr. Bingley? So distinguished, so gentle, and so simple! He always has a kind word for everyone. That is my idea of what good manners are; those people who think they are very important and never open their mouths have no idea of manners.

en: “Did Charlotte dine with you?”
vi: - Did Charlotte have a meal with her mother?
tr: "Did Charlotte stay for dinner?""
es: ––Did Charlotte have dinner with you?

en: “No, she would go home. I fancy she was wanted about the mince-pies. For my part, Mr. Bingley, I always keep servants that can do their own work; my daughters are brought up differently. But everybody is to judge for themselves, and the Lucases are a very good sort of girls, I assure you. It is a pity they are not handsome! Not that I think Charlotte so very plain; but then she is our particular friend.”
vi: - No, she wants to go home. Mother guesses the person she needs to see is the minced meat pie. As for me, Mr. Bingley, I always keep servants who can get the job done. My daughters are educated differently. But let everyone judge for themselves. Although the Lucas girls are very nice, believe me. But they are not beautiful, which is a pity. Not that I find Charlotte unattractive – but she is still a special friend of my family.
tr: "No, she went home. Probably needed to make an apple pie. For my part, Mr. Bingley, I always employ servants who can do their own work; my daughters were raised differently. But of course, everyone knows their own business; the Lucases are very good girls, I assure you. It's a pity they're not beautiful! Not that I find Charlotte very plain – but well, she is our dear friend."
es: ––No, she went home. I think they needed her to make the meatloaf. As for me, Mr. Bingley, I always have servants who know how to do their job. My daughters are educated differently. But everyone should judge for themselves. The Lucas girls are very good girls, I assure you. It's a pity they aren't pretty! It's not that I think Charlotte is very ugly; anyway, she is a very good friend of ours.

en: “She seems a very pleasant young woman,” said Bingley.
vi: Bingley said: - She seems to be very likable.
tr: "She seems like a very nice young lady," said Bingley.
es: ––She seems like a very pleasant young woman ––said Bingley.

en: “Oh dear, yes; but you must own she is very plain. Lady Lucas herself has often said so, and envied me Jane’s beauty. I do not like to boast of my own child; but to be sure, Jane—one does not often see anybody better looking. It is what everybody says. I do not trust my own partiality. When she was only fifteen there was a gentleman at my brother Gardiner’s in town so much in love with her, that my sister-in-law was sure he would make her an offer before we came away. But, however, he did not. Perhaps he thought her too young. However, he wrote some verses on her, and very pretty they were.”
vi: - Ah, that's right, but you have to admit that she is not beautiful. Lady Lucas herself often says so and feels envious of our Jane. I don't want to boast about my children, but it is certain that Jane is the most beautiful girl in the area. That is what everyone says. When she was fifteen, there was a young man living with Mr. Gardiner, my brother, in the city, who loved her so much that my sister-in-law thought he would propose to her. But in the end, he did not, perhaps because he thought she was too young. However, he wrote her some truly wonderful poems.
tr: "Yes, indeed; –but it must be admitted that it is very ordinary. Lady Lucas herself has often said so and envied me for Jane's beauty. I don't want to boast about my own child, but truly Jane –one can hardly see anyone more beautiful. Everyone says so. I'm not saying this just because she's my daughter. She was only fifteen, there was a gentleman at my brother Gardiner's in the city who was so in love with her that my sister-in-law was sure he would propose before we left. He didn't, however. Maybe he found her too young. However, he wrote her poems, and they were indeed beautiful poems."
es: ––Oh! Yes, but you must admit she is rather plain. Even Lady Lucas says so many times, and she envies me for Jane's beauty. I don't like to praise my own daughters, but the truth is that you don't often find someone as pretty as Jane. I can't be impartial, of course; but everyone says so. When she was only fifteen, there was a gentleman who lived at my brother Gardiner's house in the city, and he was so in love with Jane that my sister-in-law assured me he would propose before we left. But he didn't. He probably thought she was too young. However, he wrote her some verses, and they were quite beautiful.

en: “And so ended his affection,” said Elizabeth, impatiently. “There has been many a one, I fancy, overcome in the same way. I wonder who first discovered the efficacy of poetry in driving away love!”
vi: Elizabeth anxiously said: - So that's the end of his love. I guess many people also get over their sadness in the same way. I've wondered who discovered the power of poetry in dispelling love.
tr: "Thus, he exhausted his love," said Elizabeth, impatiently. "There have been many who have succumbed in the same way. I truly wonder who first discovered the ability of poetry to destroy love!"
es: ––And so ended his love ––said Elizabeth impatiently––. I believe there have been many who overcame it in the same way. I wonder who was the first to discover the efficacy of poetry in ending love.

en: “I have been used to consider poetry as the food of love,” said Darcy.
vi: - And yet I still think poetry is the food of love. – Darcy said.
tr: "I always thought of poetry as the nourishment of love," said Darcy.
es: ––I have always considered that poetry is the food of love ––said Darcy.

en: “Of a fine, stout, healthy love it may. Everything nourishes what is strong already. But if it be only a slight, thin sort of inclination, I am convinced that one good sonnet will starve it entirely away.”
vi: - It may be so for delicate, enduring, and healthy love. Everything can nurture what is already strong. But I believe that with a bit of fragile love, a short poem can make that love entirely starved.
tr: "It may be true for a healthy, strong, good love. Anything is good for something that is already strong. But if it is a weak, feeble inclination, a sweet sonnet will starve it to death."
es: ––From a great love, solid and strong, it can. Everything nourishes what is already strong by itself. But if it is only a slight inclination, without any foundation, a good sonnet would end up starving it to death.

en: Darcy only smiled; and the general pause which ensued made Elizabeth tremble lest her mother should be exposing herself again. She longed to speak, but could think of nothing to say; and after a short silence Mrs. Bennet began repeating her thanks to Mr. Bingley for his kindness to Jane, with an apology for troubling him also with Lizzy. Mr. Bingley was unaffectedly civil in his answer, and forced his younger sister to be civil also, and say what the occasion required. She performed her part, indeed, without much graciousness, but Mrs. Bennet was satisfied, and soon afterwards ordered her carriage. Upon this signal, the youngest of her daughters put herself forward. The two girls had been whispering to each other during the whole visit; and the result of it was, that the youngest should tax Mr. Bingley with having promised on his first coming into the country to give a ball at Netherfield.
vi: Darcy merely smiled, and the ensuing moment of silence made Elizabeth fear that her mother might once again expose her own shortsightedness. She wanted to say something but did not know how to begin. Then Mrs. Bennet began thanking Bingley for taking care of Jane, adding an apology for Lizzy's interruption. Bingley responded politely, and his sister was obliged to say a few polite words as well. Miss Bingley tried to fulfill her role without much grace, just enough to satisfy Mrs. Bennet. After that, she requested the carriage to be prepared. At this signal, the youngest daughter escorted her outside. The two had been whispering to each other throughout the visit, resulting in the youngest demanding that Bingley host a ball when he came over.
tr: Darcy merely smiled; the ensuing general silence made Elizabeth uneasy, fearing her mother would embarrass herself again. She wanted to speak but couldn't think of anything; after a brief silence, Mrs. Bennet began thanking Mr. Bingley again for his care of Jane, adding an apology for burdening him with Lizzy as well. Mr. Bingley responded with measured politeness, compelling his sister to be courteous and to speak as the situation required. His sister did her part without being overly generous, but Mrs. Bennet was satisfied and soon ordered her carriage. At this signal, the youngest daughter stepped forward. Throughout the visit, the two girls had been whispering to each other and had concluded that the youngest would remind Mr. Bingley of his promise to hold a ball at Netherfield upon his first arrival in the countryside.
es: Darcy merely smiled. A general silence followed, making Elizabeth fear that her mother might speak again. Mrs. Bennet wished to do so but did not know what to say, until after a brief pause she began to reiterate her gratitude to Mr. Bingley for his kindness to Jane and apologized for any inconvenience Lizzy might also be causing. Mr. Bingley was courteous in his response and obliged his younger sister to be polite and say what the occasion required. She played her part, though with little grace, but Mrs. Bennet was satisfied and shortly thereafter asked for her carriage. Upon hearing this, the youngest of her daughters stepped forward to say something. The two young girls had been whispering throughout the visit, and the result was that the youngest was to remind Mr. Bingley that when he first came to the countryside, he had promised to give a ball at Netherfield.

en: Lydia was a stout, well-grown girl of fifteen, with a fine complexion and good-humoured countenance; a favourite with her mother, whose affection had brought her into public at an early age. She had high animal spirits, and a sort of natural self-consequence, which the attentions of the officers, to whom her uncle’s good dinners and her own easy manners recommended her, had increased into assurance. She was very equal, therefore, to address Mr. Bingley on the subject of the ball, and abruptly reminded him of his promise; adding, that it would be the most shameful thing in the world if he did not keep it. His answer to this sudden attack was delightful to her mother’s ear.
vi: Lydia is a fifteen-year-old girl, sturdy, with fair skin and a cheerful face. She is her mother's darling, so her mother introduced her to social interactions at a very young age. She has a lively temperament and a self-important demeanor, which draws the attention of officers who often visit her uncle's house. Combined with her simple manners, these interactions have made her more confident. Therefore, she considers herself equal enough to talk to Bingley about organizing the ball and suddenly reminds him to keep his promise. She also adds that if he does not keep his word, it would be the most shameful thing in the world. His response made her mother very happy.
tr: Lydia was fifteen years old, a robust and well-developed girl; she had fair skin and a cheerful face; she was her mother's favorite; her mother's affection had brought her into society at a young age. She had an enthusiastic spirit and a natural ability to assert herself, which had turned into confidence by attracting the attention of officers thanks to her uncle's dinners and her own relaxed demeanor. Therefore, she was quite convincing when she addressed Mr. Bingley about the ball, reminded him of his promise with frankness, and even added that it would be the most embarrassing thing in the world if he did not keep his word. Bingley's response to this sudden attack delighted her mother–
es: Lydia was strong, very mature for being fifteen years old, she had a good figure and a very cheerful character. She was her mother's favorite, who, out of love for her, had introduced her to society at a very young age. She was very impulsive and gave herself a lot of importance, which had increased with the attentions she received from the officers, to which her aunt's dinners and her simple manners contributed. Therefore, she was the most suitable to approach Bingley and remind him of his promise; adding that it would be a shame before the world if he did not keep it. His response to this sudden attack was delightful to Mrs. Bennet's ears.

en: “I am perfectly ready, I assure you, to keep my engagement; and, when your sister is recovered, you shall, if you please, name the very day of the ball. But you would not wish to be dancing while she is ill?”
vi: - Please believe that I am very willing to keep my promise, and when your sister recovers, if you wish, you can set the date and time. But I believe you wouldn't want to dance while your sister is still weak.
tr: "I am ready with everything I have to fulfill my promise; when your sister gets better, you can choose the day of the ball if you wish. But you wouldn't want to dance while she is lying sick."
es: ––I assure you that I am willing to keep my commitment, as soon as your sister is well; you yourself, if you like, can set the date of the ball: You wouldn't want to be dancing while your sister is ill.

en: Lydia declared herself satisfied. “Oh yes—it would be much better to wait till Jane was well; and by that time, most likely, Captain Carter would be at Meryton again. And when you have given your ball,” she added, “I shall insist on their giving one also. I shall tell Colonel Forster it will be quite a shame if he does not.”
vi: - Ah yes. It would be better to wait until Jane is well, and by then Captain Carter might have returned to Meryton. And when he organizes the ball, I will insist that they hold a ball as well. I will tell Colonel Foster that it would be a shame if he refused.
tr: Lydia said that she got the answer she wanted. "Oh yes – it is better to wait until Jane gets better; by then Captain Carter will have returned to Meryton. After you give your own ball," she added, "I will insist that they give a ball as well. I will say it would be a great shame if they don't give it to Colonel Forster."
es: Lydia was satisfied: ––Oh! Yes, it will be much better to wait until Jane is well; and by then it is most likely that Captain Carter will be back in Meryton. And when you have given your ball ––she added––, I will insist that they give one too. I will tell Colonel Forster that it would be unfortunate if he did not.

en: Mrs. Bennet and her daughters then departed, and Elizabeth returned instantly to Jane, leaving her own and her relations’ behaviour to the remarks of the two ladies and Mr. Darcy; the latter of whom, however, could not be prevailed on to join in their censure of her, in spite of all Miss Bingley’s witticisms on fine eyes.
vi: Mrs. Bennet and her two daughters left, Elizabeth returned to Jane, leaving her mother's and two sisters' behavior to the judgment of the two women and Darcy. However, Darcy did not want to join the two in criticizing Mrs. Bennet, even though Miss Bingley had made some insinuations about her dark eyes.
tr: Then Mrs. Bennet and her daughters left; Elizabeth immediately returned to Jane, leaving her own and her family's behavior to be commented on by the two ladies and Mr. Darcy; however, despite all of Miss Bingley's pointed jokes about fine eyes, Mr. Darcy could not be persuaded to join in their disparagement.
es: Finally, Mrs. Bennet and her daughters left, and Elizabeth instantly returned to Jane, leaving the two ladies and Mr. Darcy to make their comments about her behavior and that of her family. However, Darcy could not share in the others' censure of Elizabeth, despite Miss Bingley's sharpness in making jokes about pretty eyes.

en: CHAPTER X.
vi: Chapter 10
tr: Chapter X
es: CHAPTER X

en: THE day passed much as the day before had done. Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley had spent some hours of the morning with the invalid, who continued, though slowly, to mend; and, in the evening, Elizabeth joined their party in the drawing-room. The loo table, however, did not appear. Mr. Darcy was writing, and Miss Bingley, seated near him, was watching the progress of his letter, and repeatedly calling off his attention by messages to his sister. Mr. Hurst and Mr. Bingley were at piquet, and Mrs. Hurst was observing their game.
vi: A day passed similarly to the previous one. Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley spent a few hours in the morning sitting with Jane, who was gradually recovering. In the evening, Elizabeth sat with them in the drawing room. Mr. Darcy was writing a letter, Miss Bingley sat beside him, constantly watching what he was doing, which distracted Darcy from writing the letter to his sister. Mr. Hurst and Bingley were playing cards, and Mrs. Hurst watched them play.
tr: That day passed almost like the previous one. Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley spent a few hours of the morning beside the patient, who continued to recover slowly; in the evening, Elizabeth joined their gathering in the sitting room. This time, the loo table was not brought out. Mr. Darcy was writing; Miss Bingley, who was sitting next to him, was observing the progress of his letter and frequently distracted him by sending messages to her sister. Mr. Hurst and Mr. Bingley were playing piquet; Mrs. Hurst was watching the game.
es: The day passed the same as the previous one. Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley had spent a few hours in the morning by the side of the sick woman, who was improving, though slowly. In the afternoon, Elizabeth joined them in the drawing room. But the usual card table was not set up. Darcy was writing, and Miss Bingley, sitting beside him, followed the course of the letter, repeatedly interrupting him with messages for her sister. Mr. Hurst and Bingley were playing piquet, and Mrs. Hurst was watching the game.

en: Elizabeth took up some needlework, and was sufficiently amused in attending to what passed between Darcy and his companion. The perpetual commendations of the lady either on his hand-writing, or on the evenness of his lines, or on the length of his letter, with the perfect unconcern with which her praises were received, formed a curious dialogue, and was exactly in unison with her opinion of each.
vi: Elizabeth was sitting and embroidering, but she also found it amusing to pay attention to what was happening between Darcy and Miss Bingley. The strange conversation between the two somewhat matched her observations about everyone. With Miss Bingley's compliments on his beautiful handwriting or the evenness of his lines, and the way he accepted her compliments with absolute indifference.
tr: Elizabeth took up her embroidery; she listened in on what was happening between Darcy and his friend and amused herself quite a bit. The girl's constant comments on either the handwriting, the neatness of the lines, or the length of the letter, combined with the absolute indifference with which her praises were met, created a strange dialogue that perfectly matched Elizabeth's opinions of the two.
es: Elizabeth dedicated herself to needlework and had enough entertainment attending to what was happening between Darcy and his company. The constant praises from the latter about Darcy's handwriting, the symmetry of his lines, or the length of the letter, as well as the absolute indifference with which they were received, constituted a curious dialogue that was exactly in line with Elizabeth's opinion of each of them.

en: “How delighted Miss Darcy will be to receive such a letter!”
vi: - Miss Darcy will surely be very pleased to receive your letter.
tr: "Receiving such a letter will make Miss Darcy so happy!"
es: ––How happy Miss Darcy will be when she receives this letter!

en: He made no answer.
vi: Darcy did not reply.
tr: The man did not respond.
es: He did not answer.

en: “You write uncommonly fast.”
vi: - You write unusually fast.
tr: "You are typing extraordinarily fast.""
es: ––You write faster than anyone.

en: “You are mistaken. I write rather slowly.”
vi: - You are mistaken, I write quite slowly.
tr: "You are mistaken. I am writing slowly."
es: ––You are mistaken. I write very slowly.

en: “How many letters you must have occasion to write in the course of a year! Letters of business, too! How odious I should think them!”
vi: - How many letters do you have the opportunity to write in a year! Including business letters. I hate such correspondence.
tr: "You must have to write so many letters throughout the year! Of course, there are business letters too! Who knows how disgusting they can be!"
es: ––How many letters you will have the chance to write by the end of the year! Including business letters. How I detest them!

en: “It is fortunate, then, that they fall to my lot instead of to yours.”
vi: - Then it is fortunate that those letters are tied to my fate instead of yours.
tr: "It seems you are lucky that the task of writing a business letter has fallen to me.""
es: ––It is fortunate, then, that it is I and not you who has to write them.

en: “Pray tell your sister that I long to see her.”
vi: - Please kindly tell her that I am very eager to see her again.
tr: "Please tell your brother, I really want to see him.""
es: ––I beg you to tell your sister that I very much wish to see her.

en: “I have already told her so once, by your desire.”
vi: - I already sent a message once according to your request.
tr: "I already told you once, as per your request."
es: ––I have already told him once, at his request.

en: “I am afraid you do not like your pen. Let me mend it for you. I mend pens remarkably well.”
vi: - I'm afraid you don't like that pen. Let me fix it for you. I'm quite good at fixing pens.
tr: "I'm afraid you didn't like your pen. Let me sharpen it for you. I am very good at sharpening pen tips."
es: ––I’m afraid your pen isn’t working well. Let me sharpen it for you, I do it incredibly well. ––Thank you, but I always sharpen my own pen.

en: “Thank you—but I always mend my own.”
vi: - Thank you, but I always treat myself.
tr: "Thank you – I always open it myself."
es: ––Thank you, but I always sharpen my own pen.

en: “How can you contrive to write so even?”
vi: - How did you come up with the way to write in such straight lines?
tr: "How do you manage to write so neatly?""
es: ––How can you achieve such uniform handwriting?

en: He was silent.
vi: Darcy was silent.
tr: No answer.
es: Darcy made no comment.

en: “Tell your sister I am delighted to hear of her improvement on the harp, and pray let her know that I am quite in raptures with her beautiful little design for a table, and I think it infinitely superior to Miss Grantley’s.”
vi: - Please tell your sister that I am pleased to hear she has made much progress with her music. Also let her know that I am very impressed with her small design for the table, and I think it is clearly better than Miss Grantley's.
tr: "Tell your brother that I am glad he is progressing with playing the harp; and please also tell him that I admired his beautiful table drawing, I think it is far superior to Miss Grantley's.""
es: ––Tell your sister that I am glad to know that she has made a lot of progress with the harp; and I also ask you to tell her that I am enthusiastic about the table design she made, and that I think it is infinitely superior to Miss Grantley's.

en: “Will you give me leave to defer your raptures till I write again? At present I have not room to do them justice.”
vi: - Can I postpone my infatuation with you until the next letter? Right now, I don't have enough paper to write.
tr: "Would you allow me to postpone expressing my admiration to the next letter? I don't have much space left now."
es: ––May I ask you to postpone your enthusiasm for another letter? In this one, I no longer have space for more compliments.

en: “Oh, it is of no consequence. I shall see her in January. But do you always write such charming long letters to her, Mr. Darcy?”
vi: - Ah! It's okay. I will meet her in January. But do you often write such long and captivating letters, Mr. Darcy?
tr: "Oh, it's not important. Anyway, I will see him in January. But do you always write such nice long letters to him, Mr. Darcy?"
es: ––Oh, it's not important. I will see her in January. But, do you always write such long and charming letters, Mr. Darcy?

en: “They are generally long; but whether always charming, it is not for me to determine.”
vi: - Usually, the letters I write are long, but whether they are captivating or not, I do not know.
tr: "They are usually long; but whether they are always beautiful or not, it's not for me to decide.""
es: ––Generally they are long; but whether they are charming or not, it is not for me to judge.

en: “It is a rule with me, that a person who can write a long letter with ease cannot write ill.”
vi: - I realized the rule that if a person writes a long letter easily, the content is always very engaging.
tr: "I think the rule is, someone who can comfortably write a long letter cannot write poorly."
es: ––For me, it's like a rule, when a person writes such long letters with such ease, they can't write poorly.

en: “That will not do for a compliment to Darcy, Caroline,” cried her brother, “because he does not write with ease. He studies too much for words of four syllables. Do not you, Darcy?”
vi: Bingley exclaimed: - Caroline, that's not the way to praise Darcy, because he doesn't write letters easily. He has learned quite a few vulgar words, hasn't he, my friend?
tr: "That is not a compliment for Darcy, Caroline," cried her brother – "because he does not write comfortably. He searches long and hard for a four-syllable word. Isn't that right, Darcy?"
es: ––That compliment does not apply to Darcy, Caroline ––interrupted her brother––, because he does not write easily. He studies the words too much. He always looks for complicated words with more than four syllables, isn't that right, Darcy?

en: “My style of writing is very different from yours.”
vi: - My writing style is completely different from yours.
tr: "My writing style is very different from yours."
es: ––My style is very different from yours.

en: “Oh,” cried Miss Bingley, “Charles writes in the most careless way imaginable. He leaves out half his words, and blots the rest.”
vi: - Ah! Charles writes in the most careless way imaginable. He leaves out half the words and smudges the rest. – Miss Bingley added.
tr: "Oo!" cried Miss Bingley, "Charles writes in the most careless manner imaginable. He forgets half the words and smudges the rest with ink."
es: ––Oh! ––exclaimed Miss Bingley––. Charles writes without any care. He eats up half the words and smudges the rest.

en: “My ideas flow so rapidly that I have not time to express them; by which means my letters sometimes convey no ideas at all to my correspondents.”
vi: - My ideas flow out so quickly that I don't have time to present them. In that manner, my letters often fail to convey what I want to the recipient.
tr: "My thoughts flow so quickly that I can't find the time to express them – that's why sometimes readers can't make sense of my letters."
es: ––Ideas come to me so quickly that I don't have time to express them; so, sometimes, my letters don't convey any idea to the recipient.

en: “Your humility, Mr. Bingley,” said Elizabeth, “must disarm reproof.”
vi: Elizabeth said: - Mr. Bingley, your modesty makes it impossible for anyone to criticize you.
tr: "You are so humble, Mr. Bingley," said Elizabeth, "that one cannot even think of finding fault with you."
es: ––Your humility, Mr. Bingley ––intervened Elizabeth––, must disarm all reproaches.

en: “Nothing is more deceitful,” said Darcy, “than the appearance of humility. It is often only carelessness of opinion, and sometimes an indirect boast.”
vi: - There is nothing more deceitful than the appearance of humility. Often it is carelessness in expressing opinions, sometimes it is even a way of indirect boasting. – Darcy said.
tr: "Nothing is more deceitful than the appearance of humility," said Darcy. "It is often only carelessness of opinion, and sometimes an indirect boast.""
es: ––Nothing is more deceptive ––said Darcy–– than the appearance of humility. Normally, it is nothing more than a lack of opinion, and sometimes it is an indirect form of boasting.

en: “And which of the two do you call my little recent piece of modesty?”
vi: - And what category do you think my little humility just now falls into?
tr: "So, which one do you think is my latest example of modesty?"
es: ––And which of those two adjectives do you apply to my recent act of modesty?

en: “The indirect boast; for you are really proud of your defects in writing, because you consider them as proceeding from a rapidity of thought and carelessness of execution, which, if not estimable, you think at least highly interesting. The power of doing anything with quickness is always much prized by the possessor, and often without any attention to the imperfection of the performance. When you told Mrs. Bennet this morning, that if you ever resolved on quitting Netherfield you should be gone in five minutes, you meant it to be a sort of panegyric, of compliment to yourself; and yet what is there so very laudable in a precipitance which must leave very necessary business undone, and can be of no real advantage to yourself or anyone else?”
vi: - That is a way of indirect boasting, because in fact, he is proud of his shortcomings when writing letters, as he sees these shortcomings as a result of quick thinking and clumsy presentation, he thinks at least that is an interesting point. Teachers often value the ability to do things quickly and usually do not pay attention to perfectionism. When he told Mrs. Bennet this morning that if he decided to leave Netherfield he would go within five minutes, that was a way of self-praise. However, what is praiseworthy about the hastiness that leaves all necessary work unfinished and benefits neither oneself nor anyone else? - No way!
tr: "Indirect boasting, because you are actually proud of the flaws in your writing, thinking they come from the speed of thought and the carelessness of execution, which, if not admirable, is at least quite interesting to you. The ability to do something quickly is always greatly appreciated by the person doing it, and the flaws in the work are hardly noticed. This morning, when you told Mrs. Bennet that if you decided to leave Netherfield, you would do so within five minutes, you said it as a kind of boast, like a compliment – whereas what is there to applaud in a hastiness that will leave many important tasks unfinished and be of no benefit to yourself or anyone else?"
es: ––An indirect way of boasting; because you, in reality, are proud of your flaws as a writer, since you attribute them to your quickness of thought and a lack of care in execution, something you consider, if not very estimable, at least very interesting. The ability to do anything quickly is always highly appreciated, and no attention is paid to the imperfection with which it is done. When you told Mrs. Bennet this morning that if you ever decided to leave Netherfield, you would leave in five minutes, it was a kind of self-praise; and yet, what is praiseworthy about leaving hastily, undoubtedly leaving matters unresolved, which cannot be beneficial for you or anyone else?

en: “Nay,” cried Bingley, “this is too much, to remember at night all the foolish things that were said in the morning. And yet, upon my honour, I believed what I said of myself to be true, and I believe it at this moment. At least, therefore, I did not assume the character of needless precipitance merely to show off before the ladies.”
vi: That's just too much. Remembering the foolish things said in the morning during the evening is truly unbearable. However, I can confirm with honor that I believe the things I said about myself are true; at that time, I believed so. Therefore, I have no intention of acting hastily just to show off to the girls.
tr: "Wow," cried Bingley, "this is too much, remembering all the foolish things said in the morning by the evening. Honestly, I still believed that what I said about myself was true, and I still do. At least I didn't pretend to be unnecessarily hasty just to show off to the ladies."
es: ––No! ––exclaimed Bingley––. It seems too much to remember at night the nonsense that is said in the morning. And I give you my word, I was convinced that what I said about myself was true, and I still am now. At least, I did not unnecessarily adopt a hasty character to show off in front of the ladies.

en: “I daresay you believed it; but I am by no means convinced that you would be gone with such celerity. Your conduct would be quite as dependent on chance as that of any man I know; and if, as you were mounting your horse, a friend were to say, ‘Bingley, you had better stay till next week,’ you would probably do it—you would probably not go—and, at another word, might stay a month.”
vi: - I know you believe in what you say, but I am also not convinced that you would leave in such a hurry, and if you are mounting your horse, a friend just needs to say “Bingley, you should stay another week,” and you might not go, and with further persuasion, you might stay a few more months.
tr: "You clearly believed in it, but I did not believe it would go that fast. Your behavior would be as dependent on chance as anyone I know; just as you were about to mount your horse, if a friend came up and said, 'Bingley, it would be good if you stayed until next week,' you would probably stay, you probably wouldn't go – if necessary, you would stay for a month."
es: ––Yes, I think you were convinced; but it is I who am not convinced that you would leave so hastily. Your behavior would depend on the circumstances, like that of any person. And if, already mounted on the horse, a friend were to say to you: "Bingley, stay until next week," you would probably do so, you probably wouldn't leave, and just one more word would be enough for you to stay a month.

en: “You have only proved by this,” cried Elizabeth, “that Mr. Bingley did not do justice to his own disposition. You have shown him off now much more than he did himself.”
vi: Elizabeth exclaimed: - By that, you only demonstrate that Mr. Bingley is not fair to his own temperament. You only show off for him more than he shows off himself.
tr: "With this," cried Elizabeth, "you have proven that Mr. Bingley has not done justice to his own nature. You have described him more thoroughly than he did himself."
es: ––With this, you have only proven ––said Elizabeth–– that Bingley did not do justice to his temperament. You have favored him more now than he had done.

en: “I am exceedingly gratified,” said Bingley, “by your converting what my friend says into a compliment on the sweetness of my temper. But I am afraid you are giving it a turn which that gentleman did by no means intend; for he would certainly think the better of me if, under such a circumstance, I were to give a flat denial, and ride off as fast as I could.”
vi: - I am very grateful that you turned my friend's words into a compliment about my gentle demeanor. But I fear that you have steered the issue in a different direction that my friend here might not necessarily follow, because he will surely think well of me again. If in such a case, I would straightforwardly refuse and leave as quickly as possible.
tr: "I am grateful," said Bingley, "that you have turned my friend's words into a compliment about my good nature. But I fear you are giving his words a meaning that this gentleman did not intend; because in such a situation, if I were to say no and ride off on a horse, he would like me even more."
es: ––I am enormously grateful ––said Bingley for turning what my friend says into a compliment. But I fear that you do not interpret it in the way my friend intended; because he would have a better opinion of me if, in that circumstance, I refused outright and left as quickly as possible.

en: “Would Mr. Darcy then consider the rashness of your original intention as atoned for by your obstinacy in adhering to it?”
vi: – Bingley smiled and said to Elizabeth. - Does Mr. Darcy consider the flaw of hastiness in his intentions to be rectifiable when he insists on maintaining his intentions?
tr: "Then does Mr. Darcy think that you balance the thoughtlessness of your initial intention with your stubbornness in sticking to it?"
es: ––Would Mr. Darcy then consider the imprudence of his first intention repaired by the obstinacy of maintaining it?

en: “Upon my word, I cannot exactly explain the matter—Darcy must speak for himself.”
vi: - I can't explain this issue exactly, Darcy himself has to say it. Darcy spoke up:
tr: "Well, I can't say for sure; let Darcy speak for himself.""
es: ––It is not I, but Darcy, who must explain it.

en: “You expect me to account for opinions which you choose to call mine, but which I have never acknowledged. Allowing the case, however, to stand according to your representation, you must remember, Miss Bennet, that the friend who is supposed to desire his return to the house, and the delay of his plan, has merely desired it, asked it without offering one argument in favour of its propriety.”
vi: - You want me to explain the opinion that you call my opinion, while I still haven't realized that it is my own. However, according to your presentation, dear Miss Bennet, you should remember that this friend only wants him to delay his plans, they only wish for that and do not intend to argue about the propriety of the behavior.
tr: "You expect me to explain views that you claim are mine but that I have not expressed." "But if we approach the matter as you have presented it, Miss Bennet, remember that the friend who wished for her to return home and delay the plan merely wished for it, without providing any justification.""
es: ––You want me to account for some opinions that you attribute to me, but that I have never acknowledged. Returning to the case, you must remember, Miss Bennet, that the supposed friend who wishes you to stay and delay your plan, simply desires it and asks it without offering any argument.

en: “To yield readily—easily—to the persuasion of a friend is no merit with you.”
vi: - Ready to compromise – to compromise easily – the persuasion of a friend seems to hold no value for him.
tr: "Being easily –readily– convinced by a friend is not a virtue according to you."
es: ––Yielding quickly and easily to a friend's persuasion has no merit for you.

en: “To yield without conviction is no compliment to the understanding of either.”
vi: - Conceding without having firm inner belief is not a commendation of understanding or trust in concession.
tr: "Being convinced without believing is not considered a compliment to the mind."
es: ––Yielding without conviction speaks little in favor of the intelligence of either.

en: “You appear to me, Mr. Darcy, to allow nothing for the influence of friendship and affection.
