A regard for the requester would often make one readily yield to a request, without waiting for arguments to reason one into it. I am not particularly speaking of such a case as you have supposed about Mr. Bingley. We may as well wait, perhaps, till the circumstance occurs, before we discuss the discretion of his behaviour thereupon. But in general and ordinary cases, between friend and friend, where one of them is desired by the other to change a resolution of no very great moment, should you think ill of that person for complying with the desire, without waiting to be argued into it?”
vi: - In my opinion, Mr. Darcy does not trust in the influence of friendship or affection. When we truly care for someone who asks us for something, we tend to comply without needing an explanation for the request. Perhaps we should wait until the situation actually arises before we discuss how he would behave. But generally, in ordinary circumstances between friends, when one wishes the other to change their mind, do you think ill of the person who goes along with their friend's wish without waiting for an explanation?
tr: "It seems to me, Mr. Darcy, that you do not allow for the influence of friendship and affection. The importance given to the person making the request often makes one accept that request immediately, without waiting for reasons to think it over. I am not exactly talking about a situation like the one you gave as an example for Mr. Bingley. Perhaps we should wait until such a situation arises before discussing what his behavior would be in that situation. But generally and normally, between two friends, if one asks the other to change a decision that is not very crucial, would you look down on that person for complying with the request without thinking it over?"
es: ––It seems to me, Mr. Darcy, that you never allow affection or friendship to influence you. Respect or esteem for the person making the request may lead us to comply without expecting any reason or argument. I am not speaking of the particular case you have mentioned regarding Mr. Bingley. Moreover, we should perhaps wait for the circumstance to arise to then discuss his behavior. But in general and in normal cases among friends, when one wants the other to change a decision, would you see it as wrong for that person to comply with the wish without expecting the other's reasons?

en: “Will it not be advisable, before we proceed on this subject, to arrange with rather more precision the degree of importance which is to appertain to this request, as well as the degree of intimacy subsisting between the parties?”
vi: Before we discuss, shouldn't we clarify the importance of the request and the level of closeness between the two people?
tr: "Wouldn't it be better to clarify the importance of this request and the degree of closeness between the parties before continuing with this topic?"
es: ––Wouldn't it be advisable, before continuing with the topic, to clarify more precisely the importance of the request and the intimacy between the friends?

en: “By all means,” cried Bingley; “let us hear all the particulars, not forgetting their comparative height and size, for that will have more weight in the argument, Miss Bennet, than you may be aware of. I assure you that if Darcy were not such a great tall fellow, in comparison with myself, I should not pay him half so much deference. I declare I do not know a more awful object than Darcy on particular occasions, and in particular places; at his own house especially, and of a Sunday evening, when he has nothing to do.”
vi: - Miss Bennet, indeed it is so, let us listen to every detail, do not forget the importance of the details, because through them the argument can be more weighty. I assure you that if Darcy were not taller than I am, my esteem for him would be less than half. I have never known anyone more imposing than Darcy, in certain circumstances and certain places, especially at his home, on Saturday evenings when he has nothing to do.
tr: "Absolutely," cried Bingley, "let's learn all the details, and don't forget their height and weight; because, Miss Bennet, this will play a bigger role in the discussion than you think. I assure you that if Darcy were not such a tall man compared to me, I would not show him half as much respect. In certain situations and certain places, especially in his own home, for instance when he has nothing to do on a Sunday evening, I would say there is nothing more dreadful than Darcy."
es: ––Perfectly ––said Bingley––, let's pay attention to all the details without forgetting to compare height and size; because that, Miss Bennet, may carry more weight in the discussion than it seems. I assure you that if Darcy were not so tall compared to me, I would not have half the respect for him that I do. I confess that I know nothing more imposing than Darcy on certain occasions and in certain places, especially in his house and on Sunday afternoons when he has nothing to do.

en: Mr. Darcy smiled; but Elizabeth thought she could perceive that he was rather offended, and therefore checked her laugh. Miss Bingley warmly resented the indignity he had received, in an expostulation with her brother for talking such nonsense.
vi: Darcy smiled, but Elizabeth could sense that he was quite offended, so she tried to stifle her laughter. Miss Bingley, upset by the insult he received, pointed out the wrongness of her brother's nonsensical talk.
tr: Mr. Darcy smiled; but Elizabeth felt as if he was a bit offended and held herself back, not laughing. Miss Bingley responded affectionately to the slight Darcy had endured by accusing her brother of talking nonsense.
es: Mr. Darcy smiled; but Elizabeth noticed that he was quite offended and held back her laughter. Miss Bingley was very upset by the offense made to Darcy and scolded her brother for saying such nonsense.

en: “I see your design, Bingley,” said his friend. “You dislike an argument, and want to silence this.”
vi: Your friend said: - I recognize your intention, Bingley. You hate arguing, so you want to quash it.
tr: "I understand your purpose, Bingley," said his friend. "You don't like arguments and you want to end this one."
es: ––I know your system, Bingley ––said his friend––. You don't like arguments and you want to end this one.

en: “Perhaps I do. Arguments are too much like disputes. If you and Miss Bennet will defer yours till I am out of the room, I shall be very thankful; and then you may say whatever you like of me.”
vi: - It could be so, arguing as well as debating. If you and Miss Bennet could postpone your debate until I leave the room, I would be very grateful, and then you can say whatever you want about me.
tr: "Maybe. There is no difference between an argument and a fight. I would be grateful if you and Miss Bennet could postpone your argument until I leave the room; then you can say whatever you want about me."
es: ––Maybe. Discussions are too much like disputes. If you and Miss Bennet postpone yours until I am not in the room, I will be very grateful; besides, that way you can say whatever you want about me.

en: “What you ask,” said Elizabeth, “is no sacrifice on my side; and Mr. Darcy had much better finish his letter.”
vi: - For me, it's nothing.
tr: "What you want," said Elizabeth, "would not be a great sacrifice on my part; it would be much better if Mr. Darcy finished his letter as well.""
es: ––For my part ––said Elizabeth––, I have no objection to doing what he asks, and it is better that Mr. Darcy finishes the letter.

en: Mr. Darcy took her advice, and did finish his letter.
vi: As for Mr. Darcy, he should finish writing his letter. Darcy followed her advice, and he completed the letter.
tr: Mr. Darcy followed this advice and finished his letter.
es: Darcy followed his advice and finished the letter.

en: When that business was over, he applied to Miss Bingley and Elizabeth for the indulgence of some music. Miss Bingley moved with alacrity to the pianoforte, and after a polite request that Elizabeth would lead the way, which the other as politely and more earnestly negatived, she seated herself.
vi: After finishing his work, he asked Miss Bingley and Elizabeth to indulge him by playing a few pieces of music. Miss Bingley eagerly went to the piano, politely asking Elizabeth to perform first, and she also politely and earnestly declined, so Bingley began to sit down and play.
tr: When the letter was finished, he turned to Miss Bingley and Elizabeth for a bit of musical enjoyment. Miss Bingley, as if she had been ready since yesterday, went to the piano and, after politely asking Elizabeth to start and Elizabeth declining the request with the same politeness but even greater enthusiasm, sat down at the piano.
es: Task completed, he approached Miss Bingley and Elizabeth to delight them with some music. Miss Bingley hurried to the piano, but before sitting down, she courteously invited Elizabeth to play first; the latter, with equal courtesy and complete sincerity, declined the invitation; then, Miss Bingley sat down and began the concert.

en: Mrs. Hurst sang with her sister; and while they were thus employed, Elizabeth could not help observing, as she turned over some music-books that lay on the instrument, how frequently Mr. Darcy’s eyes were fixed on her. She hardly knew how to suppose that she could be an object of admiration to so great a man, and yet that he should look at her because he disliked her was still more strange. She could only imagine, however, at last, that she drew his notice because there was something about her more wrong and reprehensible, according to his ideas of right, than in any other person present. The supposition did not pain her. She liked him too little to care for his approbation.
vi: Mrs. Hurst sang with her sister; and while Elizabeth was turning over the music books placed on the piano, she couldn't help but notice that Darcy's eyes occasionally fixed on her. She did not dare to think that she could be the object of affection for someone of his high social standing. Yet, the idea that he looked at her out of dislike seemed even stranger. In the end, she could only think that she attracted his attention because, in his view, she had something more wrong or blameworthy than the others in the room, according to his ideas of conduct. This thought did not offend her. She did not like him much, so she did not care whether he accepted her or not.
tr: Mrs. Hurst sang with her sister; while they were occupied with this, Elizabeth noticed that Mr. Darcy's eyes frequently fell upon her as she was browsing through the music books on the piano. She found it hard to believe that she could be an object of admiration for such a great man; on the other hand, it made no sense for him to look at her since he did not like her. Finally, she thought that, in his understanding, she must have something more wrong and reprehensible than the other people present, which caught his attention. This thought did not upset her. She cared so little for Darcy that she would not worry about his approval.
es: Mrs. Hurst sang with her sister, and while they were engaged in this activity, Elizabeth could not help but notice, each time she turned the pages of some music books that were on the piano, how frequently Darcy's eyes were fixed on her. It was difficult for her to suppose that she was an object of admiration to a man of such a rank; and it would be even stranger if he looked at her because she displeased him. Finally, she could only imagine that she caught his attention because there was something in her worse and more reprehensible, according to his concept of virtue, than in the rest of those present. This assumption did not sadden her. She liked him so little, that his opinion of her did not concern her.

en: After playing some Italian songs, Miss Bingley varied the charm by a lively Scotch air; and soon afterwards Mr. Darcy, drawing near Elizabeth, said to her,—
vi: After playing a few Italian pieces, Miss Bingley changed the enchantment with a lively Scottish tune. Shortly thereafter, Darcy approached her and said:
tr: After playing a few Italian songs, Miss Bingley changed the atmosphere with a lively Scottish tune; immediately afterward, Mr. Darcy approached Elizabeth and said-
es: After playing some Italian songs, Miss Bingley switched the repertoire to a more cheerful Scottish tune; and at that moment Mr. Darcy approached Elizabeth and said to her:

en: “Do you not feel a great inclination, Miss Bennet, to seize such an opportunity of dancing a reel?”
vi: - Miss Bennet, do you feel like taking this opportunity to dance a piece?
tr: "Don't you feel a great desire to take advantage of such an opportunity for a Scottish dance, Miss Bennet?"
es: ––Would you like to take this opportunity to dance a reel, Miss Bennet?

en: She smiled, but made no answer. He repeated the question, with some surprise at her silence.
vi: She smiled but did not respond. He repeated the question, with a bit of surprise at her silence.
tr: Elizabeth smiled, but did not answer. Darcy repeated the question, surprised by Elizabeth's silence.
es: She smiled and did not answer. He, somewhat surprised by her silence, repeated the question.

en: “Oh,” said she, “I heard you before; but I could not immediately determine what to say in reply. You wanted me, I know, to say ‘Yes,’ that you might have the pleasure of despising my taste; but I always delight in overthrowing those kind of schemes, and cheating a person of their premeditated contempt. I have, therefore, made up my mind to tell you that I do not want to dance a reel at all; and now despise me if you dare.”
vi: - Ah, I have heard you, but I don't yet know how to respond immediately. I know you want me to agree so you can look down on my recreational pleasures, but I take great pleasure in thwarting such schemes and countering the schemer. Therefore, I decided to tell you that I do not like dancing. And now you can despise me, if you dare.
tr: "I heard," she said, "but I couldn't immediately decide what to say. I know, you wanted me to say yes to enjoy the pleasure of belittling my taste; but I love to upset such plans and take away the chance of expected belittlement. Therefore, I decided, I don't want to dance – now, if you dare, belittle me."
es: ––Oh! ––she said––, I had already heard the question. I was pondering the answer. I know you would have liked me to say yes, and thus you would have had the pleasure of criticizing my tastes; but I love to thwart such traps and disappoint people who are premeditating a slight. Therefore, I have decided to tell you that I do not wish to dance at all. And now, slight me if you dare.

en: “Indeed I do not dare.”
vi: - Actually, I do not dare to underestimate you.
tr: "It's really not my place."
es: ––I don't dare, I assure you.

en: Elizabeth, having rather expected to affront him, was amazed at his gallantry; but there was a mixture of sweetness and archness in her manner which made it difficult for her to affront anybody, and Darcy had never been so bewitched by any woman as he was by her. He really believed that, were it not for the inferiority of her connections, he should be in some danger.
vi: Elizabeth actually intended to confront him, but she was surprised to see him act so generously. Her personality was a blend of sweetness and humor, making it difficult for her to confront anyone. And Darcy felt that he had never been so captivated by a woman like her. He truly thought that if it weren't for her low status, he would be in a dangerous situation.
tr: Elizabeth had hoped to upset him, but she admired the maturity he showed; although there was a mixture of sweetness and mischief in Elizabeth's behavior that made it difficult to upset people; and no woman had ever captivated Darcy like she did. If her relatives were not from the lower class, Darcy felt he would find himself in serious danger.
es: She, who believed she had offended him, was astonished by his gallantry. But there was such a mixture of sweetness and malice in Elizabeth's manners that it was difficult for her to offend anyone; and Darcy had never been so captivated by a woman as he was with her. He truly believed that if it were not for the inferiority of her family, he would be in danger.

en: Miss Bingley saw, or suspected, enough to be jealous; and her great anxiety for the recovery of her dear friend Jane received some assistance from her desire of getting rid of Elizabeth.
vi: Miss Bingley had seen enough, or had enough suspicion to become jealous. She had been impatient for Jane to recover, and now she was even more eager to get rid of Elizabeth.
tr: The things she saw or suspected were enough to make Miss Bingley jealous; her great concern for her dear friend Jane's health was further intensified by her desire to get rid of Elizabeth.
es: Miss Bingley saw or suspected enough to become jealous, and her anxiety for her dear friend Jane to recover increased with the desire to get rid of Elizabeth.

en: She often tried to provoke Darcy into disliking her guest, by talking of their supposed marriage, and planning his happiness in such an alliance.
vi: She often tried to provoke Darcy to look down on the guests by talking about an imaginary wedding or planning for his happiness in a family connection.
tr: By talking about the expected marriage and depicting the happiness such a union would bring to Darcy, he often tried to provoke Darcy to become disinterested in his guest.
es: He was trying to provoke Darcy into becoming disillusioned with the young woman, by talking to him about his supposed marriage to her and the happiness that such an alliance would bring him.

en: “I hope,” said she, as they were walking together in the shrubbery the next day, “you will give your mother-in-law a few hints, when this desirable event takes place, as to the advantage of holding her tongue; and if you can compass it, to cure the younger girls of running after the officers. And, if I may mention so delicate a subject, endeavour to check that little something, bordering on conceit and impertinence, which your lady possesses.”
vi: When walking with him in the garden the next day, she said: - When this highly anticipated event occurs, I hope that you will give your mother-in-law some hints to make her understand that she should keep her mouth shut. If possible, you should also correct your sisters-in-law who always follow the officers around. And, if I may address a very delicate matter, you should control that small, almost arrogant and insolent trait of your wife.
tr: "I hope," he said, as they walked through the heath the next day, "you give your mother-in-law a few hints so that when this long-awaited event happens, she understands the benefit of holding her tongue; and, if you can manage, save the little girls from the obsession of chasing after officers. –And, if you allow me to speak on such a delicate matter, try to control that little issue, that arrogance and impertinence, which your wife has a bit of."
es: ––I hope ––he said to her the next day while they were walking in the garden–– that when that desired event takes place, you will give your mother-in-law a few warnings to moderate her tongue; and if you can manage it, prevent the younger daughters from running after the officers. And, if you allow me to mention such a delicate subject, try to restrain that something, bordering on presumption and impertinence, that your lady possesses.

en: “No, no; stay where you are”
vi: And, if I may address a very delicate matter, you should control that small, almost arrogant and insolent trait of your wife.
tr: "Do you have any other suggestions for my family happiness?"
es: ––Do you have anything else to propose for my domestic happiness?

en: “Have you anything else to propose for my domestic felicity?”
vi: - Do you have any other suggestions for my family's happiness?
tr: "Do you have any other suggestions for my family happiness?"
es: ––Do you have anything else to propose for my domestic happiness?

en: “Oh yes. Do let the portraits of your uncle and aunt Philips be placed in the gallery at Pemberley. Put them next to your great-uncle the judge. They are in the same profession, you know, only in different lines. As for your Elizabeth’s picture, you must not attempt to have it taken, for what painter could do justice to those beautiful eyes?”
vi: - Ah! Yes. You should hang the portraits of your uncle and aunt Phillips along the hallway of the Pemberly estate's living room. Place it near your uncle's portrait, who used to be a judge. Both of them worked in the same field, only differing in their professions. As for Elizabeth's portrait, you shouldn't worry, because no artist can truly capture the beauty of her eyes.
tr: "Ah yes! –Hang the portraits of your Uncle Philips and Aunt in the gallery at Pemberley. Hang the portrait of your great-uncle the judge next to them. After all, they are in the same profession, just in different lines. As for the portrait of your Elizabeth, you shouldn't attempt that because which artist could do justice to those beautiful eyes?"
es: ––Oh, yes! Let the portraits of your uncles, the Phillips, be hung in the gallery of Pemberley. Place them next to your great-uncle, the judge. They are of the same profession, although of different ranks. As for the portrait of your Elizabeth, you must not allow it to be made, because what painter could do justice to her beautiful eyes?

en: “It would not be easy, indeed, to catch their expression; but their colour and shape, and the eyelashes, so remarkably fine, might be copied.”
vi: - That's right, it's not easy to capture what is expressed through the eyes, but colors and shapes can still be drawn.
tr: "Capturing the expression in those eyes is truly not easy, but the colors, shapes, and eyelashes are so beautiful that they can be copied."
es: ––Of course, it wouldn't be easy to capture her expression, but the color, the shape, and her pretty eyelashes could be reproduced.

en: At that moment they were met from another walk by Mrs. Hurst and Elizabeth herself.
vi: At that moment, they encountered Mrs. Hurst and Elizabeth, who were also out for a walk.
tr: At that moment, they encountered Mrs. Hurst and Elizabeth coming from another path.
es: At that moment, by another path in the garden, Mrs. Hurst and Elizabeth came across their way.

en: “I did not know that you intended to walk,” said Miss Bingley, in some confusion, lest they had been overheard.
vi: Miss Bingley seemed uneasy, fearing that her recent remarks had been overheard. - I didn't know you two were also taking a walk.
tr: "I didn't know you intended to walk," said Miss Bingley, confused, wondering if their conversation had been overheard.
es: ––I didn't know you were out walking ––said Miss Bingley, a little confused at the thought that they might have overheard them.

en: “You used us abominably ill,” answered Mrs. Hurst, “running away without telling us that you were coming out.”
vi: Mrs. Hurst said: - You two are so sneaky, slipping out without letting us know.
tr: "You deceived us badly," replied Mrs. Hurst, "you ran away without saying you were leaving.""
es: ––You have behaved very badly towards us ––Mrs. Hurst replied–– by not telling us that you were going out.

en: Then taking the disengaged arm of Mr. Darcy, she left Elizabeth to walk by herself. The path just admitted three. Mr. Darcy felt their rudeness, and immediately said,—
vi: Then she took hold of Darcy's free arm, and she walked away, leaving Elizabeth alone. The path was only wide enough for three people. Darcy, realizing their rudeness, turned back and said:
tr: Then, taking Mr. Darcy's freed arm, he left Elizabeth to walk on her own. The path only accommodated three people. Mr. Darcy sensed their rudeness and immediately intervened–
es: And, taking Mr. Darcy's free arm, she let Elizabeth walk alone. The path could only accommodate three. Mr. Darcy noticed such rudeness and immediately said:

en: “This walk is not wide enough for our party. We had better go into the avenue.”
vi: - This road is too narrow for our group. We should take the main road.
tr: "This road is narrow. Let's switch to the wide road."
es: ––This path is not wide enough for the four of us, let's go out to the avenue.

en: But Elizabeth, who had not the least inclination to remain with them, laughingly answered,—
vi: But Elizabeth did not want to join the crowd, she smiled and replied:
tr: Elizabeth, who did not feel the slightest desire to stay with them, replied with a laugh–
es: But Elizabeth, who had no intention whatsoever of continuing with them, replied with a big smile:

en: “No, no; stay where you are. You are charmingly grouped, and appear to uncommon advantage. The picturesque would be spoilt by admitting a fourth. Good-bye.”
vi: - No, no, you three go ahead. A group like that looks nice already. Adding a fourth person would ruin the scenery. I'll pass.
tr: "No no; stay where you are. You make a nice group, you look great. If a fourth person comes, the picture will be ruined. Goodbye."
es: ––No, no; stay where you are. You make a charming group, it's much better this way. A fourth person would spoil it. Goodbye.

en: She then ran gaily off, rejoicing, as she rambled about, in the hope of being at home again in a day or two. Jane was already so much recovered as to intend leaving her room for a couple of hours that evening.
vi: Then she skipped away, her heart light and carefree, hoping that she could return home in a few days. Jane had improved a lot, so she wanted to leave the bedroom that night.
tr: Then, she ran away joyfully, hopping and skipping with the hope of returning home within a day or two, feeling cheerful. Jane had already recovered enough that evening to intend to leave her room for a few hours.
es: He left cheerfully rejoicing at the thought, while walking, that in one or two more days he would be home. Jane was already so well that that very afternoon she intended to leave her room for a couple of hours.

en: CHAPTER XI.
vi: Chapter 11
tr: Chapter XI
es: CHAPTER XI

en: WHEN the ladies removed after dinner Elizabeth ran up to her sister, and seeing her well guarded from cold, attended her into the drawing-room, where she was welcomed by her two friends with many professions of pleasure; and Elizabeth had never seen them so agreeable as they were during the hour which passed before the gentlemen appeared. Their powers of conversation were considerable. They could describe an entertainment with accuracy, relate an anecdote with humour, and laugh at their acquaintance with spirit.
vi: After dinner, Elizabeth ran up to her sister's room, prepared a warm coat for her, and brought her to the living room. The two hostesses welcomed them with expressions of joy. In the hour before the gentlemen appeared, Elizabeth found the two women to be more pleasant than ever. Their conversational skills were truly excellent. They could accurately describe a party, humorously recount a story, and comfortably joke with their friends.
tr: After the ladies got up from the meal, Elizabeth ran to her sister, and seeing that she was well-protected from the cold, took her to the sitting room; her two friends greeted her with displays of joy; Elizabeth had never seen them as charming as they were during the hour before the gentlemen arrived. Their conversational skills were quite advanced. They could describe an event in detail, tell an anecdote with humor, and laugh joyfully at people they knew.
es: When the ladies got up from the table after dinner, Elizabeth went upstairs to visit her sister, and seeing that she was well wrapped up, accompanied her to the drawing room, where her friends welcomed her with great demonstrations of joy. Elizabeth had never seen them so amiable as in the hour that passed until the gentlemen arrived. They talked about everything. They described the party in great detail, told anecdotes with much grace, and made fun of their acquaintances with humor.

en: But when the gentlemen entered, Jane was no longer the first object; Miss Bingley’s eyes were instantly turned towards Darcy, and she had something to say to him before he had advanced many steps. He addressed himself directly to Miss Bennet with a polite congratulation; Mr. Hurst also made her a slight bow, and said he was “very glad;” but diffuseness and warmth remained for Bingley’s salutation. He was full of joy and attention. The first half hour was spent in piling up the fire, lest she should suffer from the change of room; and she removed, at his desire, to the other side of the fireplace, that she might be farther from the door. He then sat down by her, and talked scarcely to anyone else. Elizabeth, at work in the opposite corner, saw it all with great delight.
vi: But when the gentlemen appeared, Jane was no longer the important subject. Miss Bingley's eyes immediately turned to Darcy, saying something to him before he stepped forward. He greeted Jane with congratulations on her health. Mr. Hurst also slightly bowed to her and said he was "very pleased." But only Bingley was somewhat verbose and warm, expressing joy and care for her. For half an hour, they lit the fire and kept the fireplace hot for fear that Jane might be cold. Bingley suggested she sit by the fireplace and then sat down near her, not conversing much with others. Elizabeth sat in the opposite corner of the room, looking at the scene with delight.
tr: But when the gentlemen arrived, Jane ceased to be the main subject; Miss Bingley's eyes turned to Darcy at that moment, and as she prepared to say something to him, Darcy walked away quickly. He went straight to Miss Bennet, greeted her politely; Mr. Hurst also bowed slightly and said he was "glad"; but the excitement and warmth were left to Bingley's greeting. Bingley was full of joy and care. The first half hour was spent tending to the fire, so that Miss Bennet would not be disturbed by the change of room; then, at Bingley's request, she was moved to the other side of the fireplace, away from the door. Then Bingley sat beside her and did not talk much to anyone else. Elizabeth, who was occupied with her work in the opposite corner, watched all this with great pleasure.
es: But as soon as the gentlemen entered, Jane ceased to be the primary object of attention. Miss Bingley's eyes instantly turned towards Darcy, and she had not taken four steps before she had something to say to him. He went directly to Miss Bennet and courteously congratulated her. Mr. Hurst also gave her a slight nod, saying he was very glad; but the effusion and warmth were reserved for Bingley's greeting, who was very happy and full of attentions towards her. The first half hour he spent stoking the fire so that Jane would not notice the change from one room to another, and he asked her to sit by the fireplace, as far away from the door as possible. Then he sat next to her and hardly spoke to anyone else. Elizabeth, opposite, with her work, watched the scene with satisfaction.

en: When tea was over Mr. Hurst reminded his sister-in-law of the card-table—but in vain. She had obtained private intelligence that Mr. Darcy did not wish for cards, and Mr. Hurst soon found even his open petition rejected. She assured him that no one intended to play, and the silence of the whole party on the subject seemed to justify her. Mr. Hurst had, therefore, nothing to do but to stretch himself on one of the sofas and go to sleep. Darcy took up a book. Miss Bingley did the same; and Mrs. Hurst, principally occupied in playing with her bracelets and rings, joined now and then in her brother’s conversation with Miss Bennet.
vi: When they had finished their tea, Mr. Hurst reminded his sister about the card game, but no one was interested. She had guessed that Darcy did not like playing cards, so she refused Mr. Hurst. She explained to him that no one wanted to play cards, and their silence seemed to confirm her words. Therefore, with nothing else to do, Mr. Hurst had to lie down on the sofa and sleep. Darcy took out a book to read, Miss Bingley did the same, while Mrs. Hurst busied herself with her bracelets and rings, occasionally joining in the conversation with Jane.
tr: When the tea was finished, Mr. Hurst reminded his sister-in-law of the card table – but in vain. His sister-in-law had received secret intelligence and learned that Mr. Darcy did not want to play cards; Mr. Hurst soon saw that even his open invitation was declined. His sister-in-law assured him that no one wanted to play, and the others in the room, by remaining silent on the matter, proved her right. With nothing left to do, Mr. Hurst lay down on a sofa and fell asleep. Darcy picked up a book; Miss Bingley did the same; Mrs. Hurst, who was playing with her bracelets and rings, occasionally joined her brother's conversation with Miss Bennet.
es: When they finished having tea, Mr. Hurst reminded his sister-in-law about the card table, but it was in vain; she sensed that Darcy did not feel like playing, and Mr. Hurst saw his request immediately rejected. He assured her that no one felt like playing; the silence that followed his statement seemed to corroborate it. Therefore, Mr. Hurst had nothing left to do but lie down on a sofa and sleep. Darcy picked up a book, Miss Bingley picked up another, and Mrs. Hurst, mainly occupied with playing with her bracelets and rings, occasionally joined her brother's conversation with Miss Bennet.

en: Miss Bingley’s attention was quite as much engaged in watching Mr. Darcy’s progress through his book, as in reading her own; and she was perpetually either making some inquiry, or looking at his page. She could not win him, however, to any conversation; he merely answered her question and read on. At length, quite exhausted by the attempt to be amused with her own book, which she had only chosen because it was the second volume of his, she gave a great yawn and said, “How pleasant it is to spend an evening in this way! I declare, after all, there is no enjoyment like reading! How much sooner one tires of anything than of a book! When I have a house of my own, I shall be miserable if I have not an excellent library.”
vi: Miss Bingley both noticed Darcy engrossed in his book and read her own, occasionally asking a question or glancing at his pages. However, she could not engage him in conversation; he only answered her questions briefly and then continued reading intently. Eventually, she lost interest in her book, having chosen it merely because it was the second volume of the one he was reading. She yawned and said: - Experiencing an evening like this is truly delightful! I can say there's nothing more enjoyable than reading books. One can get bored with everything else, but never with books! When I have my own house, I will be miserable without a rich bookshelf.
tr: Miss Bingley's attention was as much focused on Mr. Darcy's progress in his book as on her own reading; she kept either asking a question or looking at his page. Yet she could not draw him into a conversation; Mr. Darcy contented himself with answering her question and continued his reading. Finally, exhausted from her attempt to occupy herself with her own book, which she had chosen only because it was the second volume of Mr. Darcy's, she gave a huge yawn and said: "How delightful it is to spend an evening in this way! Indeed, there is nothing as sweet as reading! Everything else tires one more quickly than a book! –I shall be miserable if I do not have an excellent library when I have a house of my own."
es: Miss Bingley paid more attention to Darcy's reading than to her own. She kept asking him questions or looking at the page he had in front of him. However, she did not manage to draw him into any conversation; he simply answered and continued reading. Finally, distressed by the idea of having to entertain herself with her book, which she had chosen only because it was the second volume of what Darcy was reading, she yawned broadly and exclaimed: ––How pleasant it is to spend an evening like this! All things considered, I think there's nothing as fun as reading. Anything else tires you quickly, but a book, never. When I have––my own house, I will be very unhappy if I don't have a large library.

en: No one made any reply. She then yawned again, threw aside her book, and cast her eyes round the room in quest of some amusement; when, hearing her brother mentioning a ball to Miss Bennet, she turned suddenly towards him and said,—
vi: No one answered, she yawned again, threw the book aside, and glanced around the room looking for something more entertaining. When she heard her brother mention a ball for Jane, she turned to him:
tr: Nobody answered. Then he yawned again, put his book aside, and let his eyes wander around the room in search of distraction; when he heard his brother mention the ball to Miss Bennet, he suddenly turned to him and said–
es: Nobody said anything. Then he yawned again, closed the book, and looked around the room for something to occupy his time; when, upon hearing his brother mention a ball to Miss Bennet, he suddenly turned to him and said:

en: “By the bye Charles, are you really serious in meditating a dance at Netherfield? I would advise you, before you determine on it, to consult the wishes of the present party; I am much mistaken if there are not some among us to whom a ball would be rather a punishment than a pleasure.”
vi: - Charles, by the way, do you really intend to organize the ball at Netherfield? Before you proceed, I advise you to seek the opinions of those around here. I might be mistaken, but I guess there are some among us who think of the ball as a torment rather than a pleasure.
tr: "By the way, Charles, are you serious about organizing a dance at Netherfield? –My advice to you is to learn the wishes of those here before making a decision; if I'm not mistaken, there are those among us who see the ball as torture rather than pleasure."
es: ––Do you seriously think about giving a ball at Netherfield, Charles? Before deciding, I would advise you to consult with those present, for either I am very mistaken or there is someone among us who would find a ball more of a punishment than an amusement.

en: “If you mean Darcy,” cried her brother, “he may go to bed, if he chooses, before it begins; but as for the ball, it is quite a settled thing, and as soon as Nicholls has made white soup enough I shall send round my cards.”
vi: - If you mean Darcy, if he wants, he can go to bed before the ball starts. The ball has been decided.
tr: "If you mean Darcy," said his sister, "he can go to bed and sleep before the ball starts if he wants – but the ball is already confirmed; as soon as Nicholls makes enough almond soup, I will send out my invitations."
es: ––If you mean Darcy ––his brother replied––, he can go to bed before it starts, if he prefers; but as for the dance, it's a done deal, and as soon as Nicholls has arranged everything, I will send the invitations.

en: “I should like balls infinitely better,” she replied, “if they were carried on in a different manner; but there is something insufferably tedious in the usual process of such a meeting. It would surely be much more rational if conversation instead of dancing made the order of the day.”
vi: - I would prefer the ball to be organized differently. Usually, in gatherings like this, there is something unbearably dull. Creating opportunities to converse with each other is better than dancing.
tr: "If it were done differently," replied Miss Bingley, "I would like balls much more; but there is something oddly boring about the usual course of such a ball. It would be much more sensible to have a conversation instead of dancing."
es: ––I would like dances much more ––replied her sister–– if they were different, but those kinds of gatherings are usually so tedious that they become unbearable. It would be more rational if the main focus in them were conversation and not dancing.

en: “Much more rational, my dear Caroline, I dare say; but it would not be near so much like a ball.”
vi: - Caroline, it's much better, you could say that, but then it wouldn't be a ball anymore.
tr: "Much wiser, dear Caroline, but then it wouldn't be called a ball."
es: ––Much more rational, yes, Caroline; but then it wouldn't resemble a dance at all.

en: Miss Bingley made no answer, and soon afterwards got up and walked about the room. Her figure was elegant, and she walked well; but Darcy, at whom it was all aimed, was still inflexibly studious. In the desperation of her feelings, she resolved on one effort more; and, turning to Elizabeth, said,—
vi: Miss Bingley did not reply; after a moment, she stood up and walked around the room. Her figure was truly splendid and her movements were graceful, all aimed at Darcy, but he remained engrossed in his book. In desperation, she tried another tactic. Turning to Elizabeth, she said:
tr: Miss Bingley did not reply; she immediately stood up and began to walk around the room. Her body was graceful, and she walked beautifully; –but all these efforts aimed at Darcy were still in vain as he remained engrossed in his work. In the hopelessness of her emotions, Miss Bingley made one more attempt and, turning to Elizabeth, said–
es: Miss Bingley did not reply; she got up shortly after and began to walk around the room. Her figure was elegant and her gait graceful; but Darcy, to whom everything was directed, remained engrossed in his reading. She, desperate, decided to make one more effort, and, turning to Elizabeth, said:

en: “Miss Eliza Bennet, let me persuade you to follow my example, and take a turn about the room. I assure you it is very refreshing after sitting so long in one attitude.”
vi: - Miss Lizzy, I want to persuade you to follow me, walk around the room. I assure you it will be quite pleasant after sitting in one place for so long.
tr: "Miss Eliza Bennet, come, take a turn about the room with me. –It is so refreshing after sitting so long in one attitude."
es: ––Miss Eliza Bennet, allow me to persuade you to follow my example and take a turn about the room. I assure you it is very beneficial after sitting for so long in the same position.

en: Elizabeth was surprised, but agreed to it immediately. Miss Bingley succeeded no less in the real object of her civility: Mr. Darcy looked up. He was as much awake to the novelty of attention in that quarter as Elizabeth herself could be, and unconsciously closed his book. He was directly invited to join their party, but he declined it, observing that he could imagine but two motives for their choosing to walk up and down the room together, with either of which motives his joining them would interfere. What could he mean? She was dying to know what could be his meaning—and asked Elizabeth whether she could at all understand him.
vi: Elizabeth was surprised, but she agreed to follow along. Miss Bingley had succeeded with her target. Darcy looked up. Like Elizabeth, he was startled by being drawn into this new method of attracting attention. He was invited to join but declined. He stated that he believed there were two motives for walking back and forth in the room together and that if he joined, he would hinder one of those motives. “What do you mean?” Miss Bingley was very eager to know what he was thinking – and asked Elizabeth if she understood what he meant. She replied: - I don't understand anything.
tr: Elizabeth was surprised, but she immediately accepted. Miss Bingley's courtesy achieved its true purpose; Mr. Darcy looked up. He was as aware of the striking innovations on the side as Elizabeth herself and closed his book without thinking. He was immediately invited to join the group but declined, saying that he saw only two reasons behind their walking up and down the room together, and if he joined them, he would interfere with either one or the other of those reasons. "What could he mean? She was dying to understand what he meant" –and asked Elizabeth if she could understand him.
es: Elizabeth was surprised, but she agreed immediately. Miss Bingley achieved what she had intended with her kindness; Mr. Darcy looked up. He was as astonished by the novelty of this invitation as Elizabeth herself could be; unconsciously, he closed his book. Then, they invited him to walk with them, to which he refused, explaining that there could only be two reasons for them to walk through the hall together, and if he joined them, he would interfere with both. “What does he mean?” Miss Bingley was dying to know what the meaning could be and asked Elizabeth if she could understand it.

en: “Not at all,” was her answer; “but, depend upon it, he means to be severe on us, and our surest way of disappointing him will be to ask nothing about it.”
vi: But through that, he has a strict attitude towards us, so the best way to disappoint him is to say nothing at all.
tr: "I don't understand," was Elizabeth's reply; "but believe me, he is trying to be cruel to us; the only way to surprise him is to ask nothing about it."
es: ––Not at all ––he replied––; but, whatever it is, it's certain that he wants to make us look bad, and the best way to disappoint him will be not to ask him anything.

en: Miss Bingley, however, was incapable of disappointing Mr. Darcy in anything, and persevered, therefore, in requiring an explanation of his two motives.
vi: However, Miss Bingley did not want to disappoint him in any way, so she insisted on asking him to explain the two motives he had thought of.
tr: However, Miss Bingley was incapable of surprising Mr. Darcy on any matter, and she stubbornly inquired about what those two reasons were.
es: However, Miss Bingley was unable to disappoint Darcy and therefore insisted on asking him to explain the two reasons.

en: “I have not the smallest objection to explaining them,” said he, as soon as she allowed him to speak. “You either choose this method of passing the evening because you are in each other’s confidence, and have secret affairs to discuss, or because you are conscious that your figures appear to the greatest advantage in walking: if the first, I should be completely in your way; and if the second, I can admire you much better as I sit by the fire.”
vi: He spoke, after she allowed him to speak: - I have no intention of hiding anything by not explaining. Either you two chose this way because you are close to each other and have secret matters to discuss, or you know that your appearance becomes most beautiful when you move. With the first motivation, I do not want to intrude on your private matters; with the second motivation, I can admire you both better when I sit by the fireplace.
tr: "I have no objection to the explanation," said Mr. Darcy, as soon as he was allowed to speak. "The reason you prefer to spend the evening this way is either because you have confidential matters to discuss, or you think your figure will be most effective while walking; –if it is the former, I will not hinder you, if it is the latter, I can admire you more from my seat by the fire."
es: ––I have not the slightest objection to explaining it ––he said as soon as she allowed him to speak––. You choose this way to pass the time either because you need to confide in each other or to talk about your secret affairs, or because you know that walking shows off your figure better; if it is the first, by going with you I would only be a nuisance; and if it is the second, I can admire you much better sitting by the fire.

en: “Oh, shocking!” cried Miss Bingley. “I never heard anything so abominable. How shall we punish him for such a speech?”
vi: - Hey! You have shocked me! I have never heard anything so peculiar. How can we punish you for this statement?
tr: "Oh! Surprising!" exclaimed Miss Bingley. "I have never heard such an impertinent thing. How shall we punish him for these words?"
es: ––What a horror! ––cried Miss Bingley––. I have never heard anything so abominable. How could we give him what he deserves?

en: “Nothing so easy, if you have but the inclination,” said Elizabeth. “We can all plague and punish one another. Tease him—laugh at him. Intimate as you are, you must know how it is to be done.”
vi: – Miss Bingley exclaimed. - It's not easy if you just want to punish him. We can all irritate or punish each other. You should tease him, laugh at him; you are close to him, so you should know this well.
tr: "It's very easy, just ask," said Elizabeth. "We can all punish each other. Mock, laugh. You are the one close to him, you should know how to do it."
es: ––Nothing so easy, if you are willing to do it ––said Elizabeth––. We all know how to annoy and mortify each other. Mock him, laugh at him. Being such a close friend of his, you will know very well how to do it.

en: “But upon my honour I do not. I do assure you that my intimacy has not yet taught me that. Tease calmness of temper and presence of mind! No, no; I feel he may defy us there. And as to laughter, we will not expose ourselves, if you please, by attempting to laugh without a subject. Mr. Darcy may hug himself.”
vi: - On my honor, I must say I do not know. Please believe that my closeness does not teach me to do such a thing. Teasing a calm temperament and wit? No, no, I think he might challenge us on this point. As for jesting, we should not expose ourselves by jesting without a subject. Mr. Darcy can praise himself.
tr: "But I really am not. My closeness has not yet taught me this. To mock someone so calm and sensible! No, no – there he can outdo us. When it comes to laughing, if you allow me, let's not make fools of ourselves when there is no one to laugh at. Mr. Darcy would be quite amused."
es: ––I don't know, I give you my word. I assure you that my great friendship with him has not taught me what his weak points are. Mocking a phlegmatic person, with such cold blood! And as for laughing at him just like that, we shouldn't expose ourselves; he could challenge us and we would be the ones to lose. ––We cannot laugh at Mr. Darcy!

en: “Mr. Darcy is not to be laughed at!” cried Elizabeth. “That is an uncommon advantage, and uncommon I hope it will continue, for it would be a great loss to me to have many such acquaintance. I dearly love a laugh.”
vi: Elizabeth exclaimed: - You shouldn't mock Mr. Darcy! It's a rare advantage, and I hope it remains rare, because I would be at a great disadvantage if there were many such relationships. I really enjoy joking.
tr: "Isn't Mr. Darcy laughable!" exclaimed Elizabeth. "This is a rare trait; I hope it continues, because having many acquaintances like him would be a great loss for me. I love to laugh."
es: ––exclaimed Elizabeth––. It is a very strange privilege, and I hope it remains strange; I wouldn't like to have many acquaintances like that. I love to laugh.

en: “Miss Bingley,” said he, “has given me credit for more than can be. The wisest and best of men,—nay, the wisest and best of their actions,—may be rendered ridiculous by a person whose first object in life is a joke.”
vi: He said: - Miss Bingley has elevated my reputation too high. The cleverest and the best of men, or rather the cleverest and the best of men's actions, can become ridiculous by someone who has spent their whole life first and foremost in jest.
tr: "Miss Bingley," said Mr. Darcy, "you have given me too much credit." "The wisest and best of men –nay, the wisest and best of their actions– may be rendered ridiculous by a person whose first object in life is a joke.""
es: ––Miss Bingley ––replied Darcy–– has given me more importance than I deserve. The wisest and best of men or the wisest and best of actions can be ridiculous in the eyes of a person who thinks of nothing in this life but laughing.

en: “Certainly,” replied Elizabeth, “there are such people, but I hope I am not one of them. I hope I never ridicule what is wise or good. Follies and nonsense, whims and inconsistencies, do divert me, I own, and I laugh at them whenever I can. But these, I suppose, are precisely what you are without.”
vi: Elizabeth replied: - That's right, there are people like that, but I hope I'm not one of them. I hope I'm not too frivolous. All the madness, impulsiveness, and inconsistency amuse me, I must admit, so I laugh at these things whenever I can. But I don't think you have that trait.
tr: "Of course," answered Elizabeth, "there are such people, but I hope I am not one of them. I hope I never make a mockery of something that is wise and good. Foolishness, nonsense, frivolity, inconsistency, these provoke me, truly, and I laugh at them at every opportunity. –But these, I believe, are things you will never be seen with."
es: ––I agree ––replied Elizabeth––, there are people like that, but I don't think I am among them. I hope I never come to ridicule what is good or wise. Foolishness, nonsense, whims, and inconsistencies are the things that truly amuse me, I confess, and I laugh at them whenever I can. But I suppose these are the things you lack.

en: “Perhaps that is not possible for anyone. But it has been the study of my life to avoid those weaknesses which often expose a strong understanding to ridicule.”
vi: - Maybe no one has. But I have learned to avoid the flaws that often manifest as notions that make others mock.
tr: "This may not be possible for anyone. But avoiding weaknesses that would make one look ridiculous in front of a sound mind has been the endeavor of my life."
es: ––Perhaps it is not possible for anyone, but I have spent my life striving to avoid these weaknesses that expose any intelligent person to ridicule.

en: “Such as vanity and pride.”
vi: - Flaws such as frivolity and pride.
tr: "Like ostentation and pride."
es: ––Like vanity and pride, for example.

en: “Yes, vanity is a weakness indeed. But pride—where there is a real superiority of mind—pride will be always under good regulation.”
vi: - Yes, frivolity is indeed a flaw. But pride – when one has a better mind than others, pride is always measured.
tr: "Yes, ostentation is indeed a weakness. But pride – if there is true intellectual superiority, pride will always be in safe hands."
es: ––Yes, indeed, vanity is a flaw. But pride, in the case of people with superior intelligence, I believe is valid.

en: Elizabeth turned away to hide a smile.
vi: Elizabeth turned away to hide a smile.
tr: Elizabeth turned to the other side to hide her smile.
es: Elizabeth had to turn away to hide a smile.

en: “Your examination of Mr. Darcy is over, I presume,” said Miss Bingley; “and pray what is the result?”
vi: Miss Bingley interjected:
tr: "I suppose your examination of Mr. Darcy is complete," said Miss Bingley, "tell me, what is the result?"
es: ––I suppose you have just finished examining Mr. Darcy ––said Miss Bingley, and I beg you to tell me what you have concluded.

en: “I am perfectly convinced by it that Mr. Darcy has no defect. He owns it himself without disguise.”
vi: - I think you have finished considering Mr. Darcy. Could you please tell me the result? - According to Mr. Darcy, I am fully convinced that he has no flaws. He has admitted it himself without any concealment.
tr: "I wholeheartedly believed that Mr. Darcy had no faults. He himself says so openly anyway."
es: ––I am fully convinced that Mr. Darcy has no faults. He himself clearly acknowledges it.

en: “No,” said Darcy, “I have made no such pretension. I have faults enough, but they are not, I hope, of understanding. My temper I dare not vouch for. It is, I believe, too little yielding; certainly too little for the convenience of the world. I cannot forget the follies and vices of others so soon as I ought, nor their offences against myself. My feelings are not puffed about with every attempt to move them. My temper would perhaps be called resentful. My good opinion once lost is lost for ever.”
vi: Darcy retorted: - No, I did not mean to boast like that. I have many flaws, but I hope these flaws are not due to my understanding. Regarding my temperament, I do not dare to flatter myself. I think my nature is not easily submissive - certainly not agreeable with others. I cannot quickly forget the bad habits of others, or the offenses they commit against me. My mind is not easily swayed. Perhaps it should be said that I am easily displeased. Once my good opinion is lost, it is considered irretrievable.
tr: "No" –said Darcy. "I make no such claim. I have my faults, but I hope they are not related to intellect. I will not defend my nature. –I suppose I am not very charming –not enough to please everyone. I cannot easily forget people's foolishness, their wickedness, or their rudeness towards me. No one can easily provoke my feelings. Perhaps you could call my nature resentful. –Once I cool towards someone, I cool forever."
es: ––No ––said Darcy––, I did not mean to say that. I have many faults, but they have nothing to do with intelligence. As for my character, I do not dare to vouch for it; I am too uncompromising, in fact, too uncompromising for what is convenient for people. I cannot forget as quickly as I should the foolishness and vices of others, nor the offenses committed against me. My feelings do not fade no matter how much effort is made to change them. Perhaps I can be accused of being resentful. When I lose the good opinion I have of someone, it is forever.

en: “That is a failing, indeed!” cried Elizabeth. “Implacable resentment is a shade in a character. But you have chosen your fault well. I really cannot laugh at it. You are safe from me.”
vi: Elizabeth exclaimed: - That is a flaw! The habit of being displeased that cannot be soothed is indeed a part of one's temperament. But you have chosen your flaw correctly – I truly cannot jest. You are safe with me.
tr: "This is a flaw indeed!" –cried Elizabeth. "Rigid vindictiveness is a shadow in the character. But you have chosen your fault well. I really cannot laugh at this. You are safe from me."
es: ––That is really a flaw ––replied Elizabeth––. Implacable resentment is truly a shadow on one's character. But you have chosen your flaw very well. I cannot laugh at it. As for me, you are safe.

en: “There is, I believe, in every disposition a tendency to some particular evil, a natural defect, which not even the best education can overcome.”
vi: - I think everyone has some flaw, a natural flaw that even the best education cannot erase.
tr: "I think there is a certain inclination towards evil in every creation – a natural flaw that even the best education cannot overcome."
es: ––I believe that in every individual there is a certain tendency towards a particular flaw, an innate defect, that not even the best education can overcome.

en: “And your defect is a propensity to hate everybody.”
vi: - And your flaw is the tendency to hate everyone.
tr: "Your flaw is the tendency to hate everyone."
es: ––And that flaw is the propensity to hate everyone.

en: “And yours,” he replied, with a smile, “is wilfully to misunderstand them.”
vi: - And her flaw is intentionally misunderstanding them.
tr: "Yours is," said Darcy, smiling, "willingly misunderstanding everyone."
es: ––And yours, he replied with a smile–– is to intentionally misinterpret everyone.

en: “Do let us have a little music,” cried Miss Bingley, tired of a conversation in which she had no share. “Louisa, you will not mind my waking Mr. Hurst.”
vi: Too bored with the conversation that she couldn't participate in, Miss Bingley dejectedly exclaimed: - Play some music for a while. Louisa, allow me to wake up Mr. Hurst.
tr: "Let's play some music," cried Miss Bingley, tired of the conversation she wasn't part of. "Louisa, could you please wake Mr. Hurst?"
es: ––Let's hear some music ––proposed Miss Bingley, tired of a conversation in which she took no part––. Louisa, would you mind if I wake up Mr. Hurst?

en: Her sister made not the smallest objection, and the pianoforte was opened; and Darcy, after a few moments’ recollection, was not sorry for it. He began to feel the danger of paying Elizabeth too much attention.
vi: The elder sister did not object, the piano was opened again, and Darcy, after a few moments of thought, began to regret this. He began to feel the danger of having paid too much attention to Elizabeth.
tr: His sister did not object at all; the piano was opened; after thinking about what had happened for a few minutes, Darcy did not regret it. He had begun to feel the danger of paying too much attention to Elizabeth.
es: His sister did not raise the slightest objection and opened the piano; Darcy, after a few moments of reflection, did not mind. He was beginning to feel the danger of paying too much attention to Elizabeth.

en: CHAPTER XII.
vi: Chapter 12
tr: Chapter XII
es: CHAPTER XII

en: IN consequence of an agreement between the sisters, Elizabeth wrote the next morning to her mother, to beg that the carriage might be sent for them in the course of the day. But Mrs. Bennet, who had calculated on her daughters remaining at Netherfield till the following Tuesday, which would exactly finish Jane’s week, could not bring herself to receive them with pleasure before. Her answer, therefore, was not propitious, at least not to Elizabeth’s wishes, for she was impatient to get home. Mrs. Bennet sent them word that they could not possibly have the carriage before Tuesday; and in her postscript it was added, that if Mr. Bingley and his sister pressed them to stay longer, she could spare them very well. Against staying longer, however, Elizabeth was positively resolved—nor did she much expect it would be asked; and fearful, on the contrary, of being considered as intruding themselves needlessly long, she urged Jane to borrow Mr. Bingley’s carriage immediately, and at length it was settled that their original design of leaving Netherfield that morning should be mentioned, and the request made.
vi: After the two sisters reached an agreement, Elizabeth wrote a letter to her mother requesting that a carriage be sent to bring them home. But Mrs. Bennet had planned for Jane to stay at Netherfield until Tuesday, exactly one week after Jane fell ill, so she was not pleased to hear this news. Therefore, her response did not align with Elizabeth's wishes. Mrs. Bennet stated that she could not send the carriage before Tuesday, and added that if Bingley and his sisters insisted, they could stay even longer. However, Elizabeth was determined not to stay any longer; she did not wish to accept their insistence. On the contrary, she was concerned that people might think she had intruded on their private lives for too long, so she urged Jane to ask to borrow Mrs. Hurst's carriage. Finally, the two sisters informed their hosts of their intention to leave Netherfield that morning and asked to borrow the carriage.
tr: According to the agreement between the sisters, Elizabeth wrote a letter to her mother the next morning, requesting that the carriage be sent during the day. But Mrs. Bennet, who calculated that her daughters should stay at Netherfield until the next Tuesday, that is, until Jane's week was up, was not willing to accept them before that day. Therefore, she did not give a positive response, at least according to Elizabeth, because Elizabeth was impatient to return home. Mrs. Bennet sent them a message saying that she could not arrange the carriage before Tuesday; she did not forget to add this note: if Mr. Bingley and his sister insisted on them staying longer, she had no objection. On the other hand, Elizabeth was determined not to stay any longer – she did not expect to be asked to stay; on the contrary, thinking that they were imposing themselves as unnecessary guests, she immediately urged Jane to borrow Mr. Bingley's carriage; finally, that morning, plans to leave Netherfield were discussed and the carriage was requested.
es: According to her sister, Elizabeth wrote to her mother the next morning, asking her to send the carriage that very day. But Mrs. Bennet had calculated that her daughters would stay at Netherfield until Tuesday, which would make it exactly a week since Jane had arrived there, and she was not willing for them to return before the stated date. Thus, her response was not very favorable or, at least, it was not the response that Elizabeth would have wished for, as she was eager to return home. Mrs. Bennet replied that it was not possible for her to send the carriage before Tuesday; in the postscript, she added that if Mr. Bingley and his sister insisted that they stay longer, they should not hesitate, as she could very well manage without them. However, Elizabeth was determined not to stay there no matter how much they asked; fearing, on the contrary, to be a nuisance by staying unnecessarily longer, she begged Jane to ask Bingley for the carriage immediately; and, finally, they decided to present their plan to leave Netherfield that very morning and ask to borrow the carriage.

en: The communication excited many professions of concern; and enough was said of wishing them to stay at least till the following day to work on Jane; and till the morrow their going was deferred. Miss Bingley was then sorry that she had proposed the delay; for her jealousy and dislike of one sister much exceeded her affection for the other.
vi: Everyone expressed a desire for them to leave the next day so that Jane could have more time to rest. The two sisters agreed. And Miss Bingley regretted having made the suggestion to postpone the date, as her jealousy towards Lizzy overshadowed her sympathy for Jane. Mr. Bingley was quite worried about letting the two leave too early, repeatedly persuading Miss Bingley that it was not safe for Jane—that she had not fully recovered.
tr: The news caused a commotion; it was insisted that they stay at least until the next day to look after Jane; thus, they postponed their departure to the following day. Then Miss Bingley regretted suggesting the delay, because the jealousy and hatred she felt for one sister surpassed the love she felt for the other.
es: The news caused many expressions of concern; they repeatedly expressed their desire for them to stay at least until the next day, and there was no choice but to delay the departure until then. Miss Bingley later regretted having proposed the delay, because the jealousy and antipathy she felt for one of the sisters was far greater than the affection she felt for the other.

en: The master of the house heard with real sorrow that they were to go so soon, and repeatedly tried to persuade Miss Bennet that it would not be safe for her—that she was not enough recovered; but Jane was firm where she felt herself to be right.
vi: But Jane was determined when she believed she was right.
tr: The master of the house was truly saddened to hear that they would leave so soon and often tried to convince Jane that it would not be safe for her to go frequently, that she had not yet recovered enough; but when Jane knew she was right, she was determined.
es: The master of the house was very saddened to learn that they were going to leave so soon, and he persistently tried to convince Jane that it would not be good for her, because she was not yet fully recovered; but Jane was firm when she knew she was acting as she should.

en: To Mr. Darcy it was welcome intelligence: Elizabeth had been at Netherfield long enough. She attracted him more than he liked; and Miss Bingley was uncivil to her and more teasing than usual to himself. He wisely resolved to be particularly careful that no sign of admiration should now escape him—nothing that could elevate her with the hope of influencing his felicity; sensible that, if such an idea had been suggested, his behaviour during the last day must have material weight in confirming or crushing it. Steady to his purpose, he scarcely spoke ten words to her through the whole of Saturday: and though they were at one time left by themselves for half an hour, he adhered most conscientiously to his book, and would not even look at her.
vi: For Darcy, this was rather good news – Elizabeth had stayed too long. And she attracted him more than he wanted, while Miss Bingley had been impolite to her and teased him more than usual. He had wisely resolved that he would not show any signs of affection towards her, and would not create any situation that might lead her to hope she could influence his happiness. Feeling that if this idea were to be revealed, his actions on the last day should be strong enough to either confirm or dispel it. Having decided to pursue his goal, he exchanged only a few words with her throughout Saturday. Even though there were times when they were alone together for half an hour, he focused on reading and did not look at her.
tr: Mr. Darcy received the news positively – Elizabeth had stayed at Netherfield long enough. She had attracted him more than he could accept – and Miss Bingley was treating Elizabeth poorly, which was also greatly annoying Darcy. Darcy was now determined not to show any signs of closeness that might lead Elizabeth to hope that he could affect her happiness; he was aware that even if such an impression had been made, his behavior throughout that last day would have the weight to either confirm or dispel this impression. He remained committed to his purpose and did not speak more than ten words to her all Saturday; at one point, they were alone for half an hour, but he did not even lift his head from his book to look at her.
es: The news seemed good to Darcy. Elizabeth had already been at Netherfield for quite some time. She attracted him more than he wanted, and Miss Bingley was rude to her and more annoying to him than ever. He resolved to be especially careful not to let any sign of admiration escape him, nor anything that might make Elizabeth believe she had any influence on his happiness. Aware that he might have suggested such an idea, his behavior during the last day had to be decisive in either confirming it or removing it from her mind. Firm in his purpose, he barely spoke ten words to her all Saturday, and despite being left alone for half an hour, he immersed himself in his book and did not even look at her.

en: On Sunday, after morning service, the separation, so agreeable to almost all, took place. Miss Bingley’s civility to Elizabeth increased at last very rapidly, as well as her affection for Jane; and when they parted, after assuring the latter of the pleasure it would always give her to see her either at Longbourn or Netherfield, and embracing her most tenderly, she even shook hands with the former. Elizabeth took leave of the whole party in the liveliest spirits.
vi: On Sunday, they said goodbye to each other, almost everyone had joy in their hearts. Miss Bingley quickly treated Elizabeth politely and showed affection towards Jane. She expressed a desire to see Jane again at Longbourn or Netherfield, then gently hugged Jane and shook hands with Elizabeth. As for Elizabeth, she felt the most uplifted in spirit.
tr: On Sunday, after the morning prayer, the much-desired departure that almost everyone wanted took place. Miss Bingley's kindness towards Elizabeth and her affection for Jane suddenly increased; as they were parting, after saying that she would always be delighted to see Jane at Longbourn or Netherfield and embracing her warmly, she even shook hands with Elizabeth. Elizabeth bid farewell to everyone with great joy.
es: On Sunday, after the morning religious service, the separation, so pleasant for almost everyone, took place. Miss Bingley's courtesy towards Elizabeth increased rapidly at the last moment, as did her affection for Jane. Upon saying goodbye, after assuring the latter of the pleasure it would always give her to see her both at Longbourn and at Netherfield and giving her a tender hug, she only shook hands with the former. Elizabeth bid farewell to everyone with a more cheerful spirit than ever.

en: They were not welcomed home very cordially by their mother. Mrs. Bennet wondered at their coming, and thought them very wrong to give so much trouble, and was sure Jane would have caught cold again. But their father, though very laconic in his expressions of pleasure, was really glad to see them; he had felt their importance in the family circle. The evening conversation, when they were all assembled, had lost much of its animation, and almost all its sense, by the absence of Jane and Elizabeth.
vi: Mrs. Bennet did not warmly welcome her two daughters. She was puzzled to see them return, thinking they had made a wrong decision and believing that it would cause Jane to fall ill again. But their father, although he only briefly expressed his joy, was genuinely delighted to see them again. He felt that the two daughters truly played a very important role in the family. In their absence, dinner conversations were much less lively and almost devoid of emotion.
tr: Their mother did not welcome them warmly at home. Mrs. Bennet was surprised by their arrival and was angry with them for causing so much trouble; she was sure that Jane would catch a cold again. –But their father was genuinely happy to see them, even though his expressions of joy were brief and to the point; he had felt the importance of his daughters within the family. When they were together, the evening conversation lost most of its cheerfulness and almost all of its meaning without Jane and Elizabeth.
es: The mother was not very cordial in welcoming them. She did not understand why they had returned so soon and told them that they were very wrong to cause her such distress; she was sure that Jane had caught a cold again. But the father, although very laconic in expressing joy, was truly happy to see them. He had realized the importance they had in the family circle. The evening gatherings, when everyone got together, had lost their animation and even their meaning with the absence of Jane and Elizabeth.

en: They found Mary, as usual, deep in the study of thorough bass and human nature; and had some new extracts to admire and some new observations of threadbare morality to listen to. Catherine and Lydia had information for them of a different sort. Much had been done, and much had been said in the regiment since the preceding Wednesday; several of the officers had dined lately with their uncle; a private had been flogged; and it had actually been hinted that Colonel Forster was going to be married.
vi: They noticed that Mary, as usual, was immersing herself in understanding human nature with some old-fashioned moral comments that she wanted everyone to hear. Catherine and Lydia had information on a different matter; since the previous Wednesday, many things had happened with the regiment, some officers had dined with their uncle, a private had been punished, and there was news that Colonel Foster was going to get married.
tr: They found Mary, as usual, immersed in her studies of harmony and human nature; she had gathered admirable new quotes and insightful new observations. However, Catherine and Lydia had different kinds of news to share with them. Since the previous Wednesday, much had been done and said in the regiment; a few officers had recently dined with their uncle, a soldier had been whipped, and it was openly talked about that Colonel Forster was going to get married.
es: They found Mary, as usual, deeply engrossed in the profound study of human nature; they had to admire her new summaries and listen to the observations she had recently made about a very unconvincing morality. What Catherine and Lydia had to tell them was very different. Many things had been done and said in the regiment since the previous Wednesday; several officers had recently dined with their uncle, a soldier had been flogged, and there was a rumor that Colonel Forster was going to get married.

en: CHAPTER XIII
vi: Chapter 13
tr: Chapter XIII
es: CHAPTER XIII

en: “I hope, my dear,” said Mr. Bennet to his wife, as they were at breakfast the next morning, “that you have ordered a good dinner to-day, because I have reason to expect an addition to our family party.”
vi: When the whole family was having breakfast together, Mr. Bennet said to his wife: - I hope you will prepare a delicious dinner tonight, as we will have guests visiting.
tr: "I hope, my dear," said Mr. Bennet to his wife, as they were having breakfast the next morning, "that you have ordered a good dinner today, for I have reasons to expect an addition to our family circle."
es: ––I hope, my dear ––Mr. Bennet said to his wife while they were having breakfast the next morning––, that you have prepared a good meal, because I have reason to believe that one more will join us at our table today.

en: “Who do you mean, my dear? I know of nobody that is coming, I am sure, unless Charlotte Lucas should happen to call in; and I hope my dinners are good enough for her. I do not believe she often sees such at home.”
vi: - What do you mean? I haven't heard anyone will come, except for Charlotte Lucas who might unexpectedly visit. But I hope our family's food is good enough to entertain her, I don't think she often gets to enjoy such dishes at home.
tr: "Who do you mean, my dear? There is no one coming; perhaps Charlotte Lucas might drop by – I hope my table is good enough for her. She doesn't get to see such things often even in her own home."
es: ––Who are you referring to, dear? I have no news of anyone coming, unless Charlotte Lucas decides to visit us, and I think my meals are good enough for her. I don't believe they are better at her house.

en: “The person of whom I speak is a gentleman and a stranger.”
vi: - The person I want to talk about is a strange man.
tr: "The person I mentioned is a man, moreover a foreigner.""
es: ––The person I am talking about is a gentleman and a stranger.

en: Mrs. Bennet’s eyes sparkled. “A gentleman and a stranger! It is Mr. Bingley, I am sure. Why, Jane—you never dropped a word of this—you sly thing! Well, I am sure I shall be extremely glad to see Mr. Bingley. But—good Lord! how unlucky! there is not a bit of fish to be got to-day. Lydia, my love, ring the bell. I must speak to Hill this moment.”
vi: Mrs. Bennet's eyes lit up: - A strange man? I believe you are referring to Mr. Bingley. Why, Jane? You never tell me anything! I would certainly be very happy to see him again. But, oh dear, what bad luck. There's no fish left today! Lydia, ring the bell. I need to see Hill right now.
tr: Mrs. Bennet's eyes sparkled. "A man, and a stranger at that! It must be Mr. Bingley! Oh Jane, why didn't you tell me, you naughty girl! Honestly, I will be very pleased to see Mr. Bingley. But –Oh dear! What luck! We have no fish today. Lydia, darling, ring the bell –I need to speak with Hill immediately."
es: Mrs. Bennet's eyes sparkled like sparks. ––A gentleman and a stranger? It's Mr. Bingley, no doubt. Why do you never say a word about these things, Jane? How sly you are! Well, I will be very glad to see him. But, my God, what bad luck! Today, it's impossible to get even a bit of fish. Lydia, dear, ring the bell; I need to speak with Hill immediately.

en: “It is not Mr. Bingley,” said her husband; “it is a person whom I never saw in the whole course of my life.”
vi: The husband said: - It is not Mr. Bingley. This is someone whom I have never met in my life.
tr: "Not Mr. Bingley," said her husband; "someone I have never seen in my life.""
es: ––It is not Mr. Bingley ––said her husband––; it is a person I have never seen in my life.

en: This roused a general astonishment; and he had the pleasure of being eagerly questioned by his wife and five daughters at once.
vi: He made everyone extremely surprised, and seemed delighted to see his wife and five daughters anxiously asking about this man.
