tr: This statement caused general astonishment; Mr. Bennet enjoyed the pleasure of being besieged by his wife and five daughters at the same time.
es: These words aroused general astonishment; and he had the pleasure of being anxiously questioned by his wife and his five daughters at once.

en: After amusing himself some time with their curiosity, he thus explained:—“About a month ago I received this letter, and about a fortnight ago I answered it; for I thought it a case of some delicacy, and requiring early attention. It is from my cousin, Mr. Collins, who, when I am dead, may turn you all out of this house as soon as he pleases.”
vi: After amusing himself for a while with his family's curiosity, he calmly explained: - About a month ago, I received this letter, and two weeks ago I replied, because I thought this was a delicate matter, so I needed to pay attention from the beginning. This is a letter from Mr. Collins, who, after I die, can evict everyone from this house if he wants to.
tr: After amusing himself with their curiosity for a while, he made the explanation– "I received this letter about a month ago; I replied about fifteen days ago, because I thought it was a delicate matter that needed to be handled carefully." "It is from my nephew Mr. Collins, you know, the man who can throw you all out of this house whenever he wants after I die.""
es: After having some fun, piquing their curiosity, he explained to them: ––A month ago I received this letter, and I replied to it about fifteen days ago, because I thought it was a very delicate matter and needed time to reflect. It is from my cousin, Mr. Collins, who, when I die, can throw you out of this house whenever he pleases.

en: “Oh, my dear,” cried his wife, “I cannot bear to hear that mentioned. Pray do not talk of that odious man. I do think it is the hardest thing in the world, that your estate should be entailed away from your own children; and I am sure, if I had been you, I should have tried long ago to do something or other about it.”
vi: The wife exclaimed in horror: - Oh! I can't bear to hear about this. Please don't say anything about that disgusting fellow. I think this is the most absurd thing in the world, your property being torn away from our children, and if I were you, I would have done something about it a long time ago.
tr: "Oh my God," cried his wife, "I can't even bear to hear you talk about him. Please don't mention that disgusting man. The most unbearable thing in the world is that his inheritance is mortgaged against his own children; if I were in his place, I would have definitely done something by now, one way or another."
es: ––Oh, dear! ––lamented his wife––. I can't bear to hear about the subject. Don't mention that hateful man. It's the worst thing that can happen in the world, that your daughters can't inherit your property. If I were you, I would have done something about it a long time ago.

en: Jane and Elizabeth attempted to explain to her the nature of an entail. They had often attempted it before: but it was a subject on which Mrs. Bennet was beyond the reach of reason; and she continued to rail bitterly against the cruelty of settling an estate away from a family of five daughters, in favour of a man whom nobody cared anything about.
vi: Jane and Elizabeth tried to explain to her the order of inheritance. The two had tried to explain many times before, but this was beyond her comprehension. She continued to rail against the cruelty of taking away the property of a family with five daughters to give it to a man who no one cared about.
tr: They tried to explain to Jane and Elizabeth what an entailment was. They had tried before, but it was a subject that Mrs. Bennet could not grasp, and once again she bitterly lamented the cruelty of taking a house away from a family with five daughters and giving it to a man whom no one knew.
es: Jane and Elizabeth tried to explain to her why the inheritance did not belong to them. They had tried many times, but it was a topic that made their mother completely lose her reason; and she continued to complain bitterly about the cruelty of disinheriting a family of five daughters in favor of a man who meant nothing to any of them.

en: “It certainly is a most iniquitous affair,” said Mr. Bennet; “and nothing can clear Mr. Collins from the guilt of inheriting Longbourn. But if you will listen to his letter, you may, perhaps, be a little softened by his manner of expressing himself.”
vi: Mr. Bennet admitted: - This is truly an unreasonable issue, nothing can erase Mr. Collins' guilt in inheriting Longbourn. But if you are willing to listen to me read this letter, you might feel relieved by the way he expresses himself.
tr: "Of course, it is an unjust situation," said Mr. Bennet, "and nothing can cover the shame of Mr. Collins inheriting Longbourn. But if you listen to his letter, perhaps his way of expressing himself might soften you."
es: ––Certainly, it is a very unfair matter ––said Mr. Bennet––, and there is nothing that can prove Mr. Collins' guilt for inheriting Longbourn. But if you listen to his letter, his way of expressing himself might calm you a bit.

en: “No, that I am sure I shall not: and I think it was very impertinent of him to write to you at all, and very hypocritical. I hate such false friends. Why could not he keep on quarrelling with you, as his father did before him?”
vi: - No, I will not feel relieved at all. I think he is really insolent to dare to write a letter to you, and hypocritical as well. I absolutely hate such deceitful people. Why doesn't he continue the dispute with you like his father did before?
tr: "No, I don't want to; I think it's inappropriate, even hypocritical, for him to write to you. I hate such fake friends. Why doesn't he fight with you like his father does?"
es: ––No, I won't listen to her; and besides, I find it impertinent that she writes to you, and hypocritical. I can't stand those false friends. Why doesn't she continue litigating with you like her father did?

en: “Why, indeed, he does seem to have had some filial scruples on that head, as you will hear.”
vi: - Oh right, why does he seem to have some hesitation about familial relationships, as you will hear below:
tr: "There seems to be something like a feeling of being adopted; listen.""
es: ––Because it seems to have some pangs of conscience, as you are about to hear:

en: “Hunsford, near Westerham, Kent, 15th October.
vi: "Huntsford, Westerham, Kent" October 15
tr: "Hunsford, near Westerham, Kent, October 15.
es: Hunsford, near Westerham, Kent, October 15.

en: “Dear Sir,
vi: Dear Uncle
tr: Dear Sir,
es: Dear Sir,

en: “The disagreement subsisting between yourself and my late honoured father always gave me much uneasiness; and, since I have had the misfortune to lose him, I have frequently wished to heal the breach: but, for some time, I was kept back by my own doubts, fearing lest it might seem disrespectful to his memory for me to be on good terms with anyone with whom it had always pleased him to be at variance.”—‘There, Mrs. Bennet.’—“My mind, however, is now made up on the subject; for, having received ordination at Easter, I have been so fortunate as to be distinguished by the patronage of the Right Honourable Lady Catherine de Bourgh, widow of Sir Lewis de Bourgh, whose bounty and beneficence has preferred me to the valuable rectory of this parish, where it shall be my earnest endeavour to demean myself with grateful respect towards her Ladyship, and be ever ready to perform those rites and ceremonies which are instituted by the Church of England. As a clergyman, moreover, I feel it my duty to promote and establish the blessing of peace in all families within the reach of my influence; and on these grounds I flatter myself that my present overtures of good-will are highly commendable, and that the circumstance of my being next in the entail of Longbourn estate will be kindly overlooked on your side, and not lead you to reject the offered olive branch. I cannot be otherwise than concerned at being the means of injuring your amiable daughters, and beg leave to apologize for it, as well as to assure you of my readiness to make them every possible amends; but of this hereafter. If you should have no objection to receive me into your house, I propose myself the satisfaction of waiting on you and your family, Monday, November 18th, by four o’clock, and shall probably trespass on your hospitality till the Saturday se’nnight following, which I can do without any inconvenience, as Lady Catherine is far from objecting to my occasional absence on a Sunday, provided that some other clergyman is engaged to do the duty of the day. I remain, dear sir, with respectful compliments to your lady and daughters, your well-wisher and friend,
vi: The long-standing discord between you and my esteemed father has always made me feel uneasy, so since my father's unfortunate passing, I have often wanted to mend this rift. However, for a time I thought it would be disrespectful to my father's memory if I were to have a conciliatory relationship with anyone who had been in conflict with him. Nevertheless, I have now made a decision on this matter because, after being ordained last Easter, I was particularly fortunate to be appointed by the council of Lady Catherine de Bourgh, widow of Sir Lewis de Bourgh, with generosity and kindness, to the precious position of vicar of this parish. Here, I will strive with all my might to act with grateful reverence towards the Lady and be ready to perform the rites of the Church. Furthermore, in my capacity as a clergyman, I feel it is my duty to promote and establish the grace of peace to all families within my sphere of influence. On this basis, I believe that opening my heart is very appropriate, and given my position as the heir apparent to the estate at Longbourn, which will be overlooked by the family, I hope you will not refuse my olive branch. I cannot be at ease because I have hurt the dear ladies of the house, and I also wish to apologize for this, as well as to ask you to understand that I am willing to reconcile with them – but I will mention this matter later. If you do not mind welcoming me into your home, I would like to visit the family on Monday, November 10th, at 4 PM. I will impose on the family's hospitality until the following Saturday, and there will be no hindrance to work, as Lady Catherine is willing to allow me to be absent on Sunday, provided another clergyman takes over the duties. With goodwill and affection, I respectfully send my regards to your wife and the ladies.
tr: The conflict between you and my late father has always troubled me; since I unfortunately lost my father, I have wanted to mend the disagreement many times; but for a while my doubts held me back, fearing that getting along well with someone he was quarrelsome with might seem disrespectful to his memory.- [Oh, Mrs. Bennet.] –However, I have made my decision regarding the matter; when I received my ordination certificate at Easter, I was fortunate to be taken under the patronage of the widow of Sir Lewis de Bourgh, the Honorable Lady Catherine de Bourgh; thanks to her generosity and benevolence, I was appointed as the vicar of that village; now, with all my gratitude, I will dedicate myself to the service of Her Ladyship and organize the rites and ceremonies prescribed by the Church of England. Additionally, as a clergyman, I aim to protect and strengthen the peace of all the families within my sphere of influence; therefore, I hope you will see this goodwill initiative as quite positive, overlook the fact that I am the first heir to the mortgage on Longbourn estate, and not reject the olive branch I extend. It would distress me to be considered a cause of harm to your dear daughters; with your permission, I want you to know that I am ready to apologize and make amends for this, –but we will discuss this later. If you have no objection to accepting me into your home, I wish to visit you and your family on Monday, November 18th around four o'clock and possibly seek your hospitality until the following Saturday, as Lady Catherine does not object to my occasional absences provided another clergyman handles the daily duties, bless her. –I extend my deepest respects to you and your daughters, sir. Your well-wisher and friend,
es: The ongoing disagreement between you and my recently deceased father has always made me feel somewhat uneasy, and since I had the misfortune of losing him, I have wished to settle the matter. However, for some time, I was held back by doubts, fearing it would be disrespectful to his memory to make amends with someone he was always at odds with, so soon after his death. But now I have made a decision on the matter, having been ordained at Easter, as I have been fortunate enough to be distinguished with the patronage of the very honorable Lady Catherine de Bourgh, widow of Sir Lewis de Bourgh, whose generosity and beneficence have chosen me to take charge of the esteemed rectory of her parish, where my firmest purpose will be to serve Her Ladyship with gratitude and respect, and to always be ready to perform the rites and ceremonies instituted by the Church of England. Moreover, as a clergyman, I believe it is my duty to promote and establish the blessing of peace in all the families within my influence; and based on this, I hope that my present intention of goodwill will be well received, and that the fact that I am the heir to Longbourn will be forgotten by you and will not lead you to reject the olive branch I offer. I cannot help but be concerned about causing harm to your pleasant daughters, and I beg to be excused for this. I also want to attest to my good disposition to make all possible amends from now on. If you do not object to receiving me in your home, I hope to have the satisfaction of visiting you and your family on Monday, November 18th at four o'clock, and I may take advantage of your hospitality until the following Saturday, which I can do without any inconvenience, as Lady Catherine de Bourgh will not object and would not even disapprove of my being absent fortuitously on Sunday, as long as there is another clergyman ready to fulfill the duties of that day. I send affectionate regards to your wife and daughters, your friend who wishes you all the best,

en: “William Collins.”
vi: William Collins
tr: William Collins."
es: William Collins.

en: “At four o’clock, therefore, we may expect this peace-making gentleman,” said Mr. Bennet, as he folded up the letter. “He seems to be a most conscientious and polite young man, upon my word; and, I doubt not, will prove a valuable acquaintance, especially if Lady Catherine should be so indulgent as to let him come to us again.”
vi: Mr. Bennet said, as he folded the letter: - So, at 4 o'clock, we will welcome this peace envoy. It seems that he is a conscientious and courteous person, so I think this will be a good relationship, especially if the Lady allows him to visit again.
tr: "So we can expect this peace-loving gentleman at four o'clock," said Mr. Bennet, folding the letter. "He truly seems like a conscientious and kind young man; I have no doubt he will be a valuable relative, especially if Lady Catherine allows him to visit us again."
es: ––Therefore, at four o'clock it is possible that this conciliatory gentleman will appear ––said Mr. Bennet while folding the letter––. He seems to be a well-mannered and attentive young man; I have no doubt that his friendship will be valuable to us, especially if Lady Catherine is indulgent enough to allow him to come visit us.

en: “There is some sense in what he says about the girls, however; and, if he is disposed to make them any amends, I shall not be the person to discourage him.”
vi: - There is some meaning when he talks about the girls, and if he is willing to make peace like that, then I will not stop him.
tr: "There is a reasonable tone in his words about the girls; if he wants to make amends with the girls, I won't stand in his way.""
es: ––You see, it seems that what he says about our daughters makes sense. If he is willing to make amends, I won't be the one to discourage him.

en: “Though it is difficult,” said Jane, “to guess in what way he can mean to make us the atonement he thinks our due, the wish is certainly to his credit.”
vi: Jane joined: - Although it is difficult to predict how he will make amends, he earned good points for expressing his intentions.
tr: "It's hard to guess how he intends to make the correction he thinks we deserve," said Jane, "but even this desire earns him points."
es: ––Although it is difficult ––observed Jane–– to guess what he means by that reparation he thinks we deserve, we must give credit to his intentions.

en: Elizabeth was chiefly struck with his extraordinary deference for Lady Catherine, and his kind intention of christening, marrying, and burying his parishioners whenever it were required.
vi: Elizabeth was particularly impressed with his exceptional respect for Lady Catherine, and the good ideas in the rituals of baptism, weddings, and burials for parishioners whenever requested.
tr: Elizabeth was particularly impressed by his extraordinary respect for Lady Catherine and his intention to baptize, marry, and bury the villagers when necessary.
es: Elizabeth was greatly impressed by that extraordinary deference towards Lady Catherine and that earnest intention to baptize, marry, and bury his parishioners whenever necessary.

en: “He must be an oddity, I think,” said she. “I cannot make him out. There is something very pompous in his style. And what can he mean by apologizing for being next in the entail? We cannot suppose he would help it, if he could. Can he be a sensible man, sir?”
vi: She said: - I think he seems strange. I can't figure out what kind of person he is. He seems somewhat ostentatious, and what did he mean by apologizing for being the heir by order? I can't expect him to help, even if he could. Is he a reasonable person, father?
tr: "There must be something strange about the man," he said. "I can't understand him. –There is something too fancy in his manner. –What does it mean to apologize for being the first during the inheritance? –Even if he could, we can't expect him to do anything. –Do you think he could be a reasonable man, sir?"
es: ––It must be a bit strange ––he said––. I can't imagine it. His style is somewhat pompous. And what does he mean by apologizing for being the heir of Longbourn? I suppose he wouldn't try to avoid it, if he could. Dad, could he be a cunning man?

en: “No, my dear; I think not. I have great hopes of finding him quite the reverse. There is a mixture of servility and self-importance in his letter which promises well. I am impatient to see him.”
vi: - I don't think so. I very much hope to meet someone who contradicts my thoughts. His letter seems both humble and arrogant, which says something. I am very eager to meet him.
tr: "No, darling; I don't think so. I have high hopes that the opposite is true. There is something both servile and boastful in his letter, which is quite meaningful. I can't wait to see him."
es: ––No, dear, I don't think so. I have great hopes that it will be the opposite. There is a mixture of servility and presumption in his letter that confirms it. I am eager to see him.

en: “In point of composition,” said Mary, “his letter does not seem defective. The idea of the olive branch perhaps is not wholly new, yet I think it is well expressed.”
vi: Mary commented: - Regarding the writing style, the letter has no flaws. The idea of the olive branch is not new, but I think he expressed it well.
tr: "In terms of writing," said Mary, "the letter doesn't seem flawed. The olive branch idea may not be very new, but I think it is well expressed."
es: ––As for the writing ––said Mary––, your letter doesn't seem to have any flaws. The olive branch part isn't very original, but even so, it is well expressed.

en: To Catherine and Lydia neither the letter nor its writer were in any degree interesting. It was next to impossible that their cousin should come in a scarlet coat, and it was now some weeks since they had received pleasure from the society of a man in any other colour. As for their mother, Mr. Collins’s letter had done away much of her ill-will, and she was preparing to see him with a degree of composure which astonished her husband and daughters.
vi: For Lydia and Catherine, neither the letter nor the letter writer was of any interest. Their cousin could not come in a red coat, and the period during which they were interested in people wearing other colors had passed several weeks ago. As for their mother, the letter had somewhat alleviated her aversion; she prepared to meet him with a calmness that surprised both her husband and her daughters.
tr: The letter and its author held no interest for Catherine and Lydia. It was almost impossible for their cousins to arrive in a red coat, and they had not enjoyed the presence of a man in any other color for several weeks. As for their mother, Mr. Collins' letter had taken away most of her bad thoughts, and she was preparing to receive the man with a calmness that surprised her husband and daughters.
es: Catherine and Lydia were not in the least interested in either the letter or its author. It was practically impossible for their cousin to show up in a scarlet coat, and it had been a few weeks since they had felt any fondness for any man dressed in another color. As for their mother, Mr. Collins's letter had extinguished her resentment, and she was prepared to receive him with such moderation that it would leave her husband and daughters perplexed.

en: Mr. Collins was punctual to his time, and was received with great politeness by the whole family. Mr. Bennet indeed said little; but the ladies were ready enough to talk, and Mr. Collins seemed neither in need of encouragement, nor inclined to be silent himself. He was a tall, heavy-looking young man of five-and-twenty. His air was grave and stately, and his manners were very formal. He had not been long seated before he complimented Mrs. Bennet on having so fine a family of daughters, said he had heard much of their beauty, but that, in this instance, fame had fallen short of the truth; and added, that he did not doubt her seeing them all in due time well disposed of in marriage. This gallantry was not much to the taste of some of his hearers; but Mrs. Bennet, who quarrelled with no compliments, answered most readily,—
vi: Mr. Collins arrived on time as promised and was received very politely by the whole family. Mr. Bennet spoke very little, but the daughters were always ready to converse; as for Mr. Collins, he neither needed encouragement to speak nor restraint to remain silent. He was quite tall and rather heavyset at the age of twenty-five. His demeanor was serious and formal, complemented by a very proper attitude. Soon after sitting down, he praised Mrs. Bennet for having such a wonderful family with five daughters, and said that he had heard much about them, but in this case, the reputation fell far short of the reality. He added that he was certain that before long, all the daughters would be happily settled. Some of the girls did not much like this flattery, but Mrs. Bennet, who enjoyed arguing but lacked for compliments, responded immediately:
tr: Mr. Collins adhered to the given time; he was received very politely by the whole family. Mr. Bennet spoke little; but the ladies were quite ready to talk; Mr. Collins, on the other hand, seemed neither to need encouragement nor to have any inclination to sit quietly. He was a twenty-five-year-old man, tall and heavy-looking. He had a serious and dignified air; his movements were very formal. He had not been seated long before he complimented Mrs. Bennet on her daughters; he said he had heard much about their beauty, but now saw that their reputation fell short of the reality, and added that he had no doubt they would all make good marriages in due time. This compliment did not quite suit the taste of some of the listeners; but Mrs. Bennet, who thought there was no such thing as a bad compliment, immediately responded.
es: Mr. Collins arrived punctually at the announced time and was received with great courtesy by the whole family. Mr. Bennet spoke little, but the ladies were very willing to talk, and Mr. Collins did not seem to need encouragement nor was he fond of silence. He was a man of twenty-five years of age, tall, with a deep gaze, a grave and static air, and ceremonious manners. Shortly after sitting down, he congratulated Mrs. Bennet on having such beautiful daughters; he said he had heard much about their beauty, but that the fame fell short compared to reality; and he added that he did not doubt he would see them all married in due time. The gallantry was not to the liking of all the listeners; but Mrs. Bennet, who was not one for formalities, replied immediately:

en: “You are very kind, sir, I am sure; and I wish with all my heart it may prove so; for else they will be destitute enough. Things are settled so oddly.”
vi: - You are truly kind, with all my heart I hope that it will come true, otherwise their fate will be very miserable. Life often creates many strange circumstances.
tr: "You are very kind, believe me; I hope it turns out that way, because otherwise they will be left homeless." Things are going very strangely.""
es: ––You are very kind, and I sincerely hope that it is as you say, because otherwise the poor ones would be quite helpless, given the strange way things are arranged.

en: “You allude, perhaps, to the entail of this estate.”
vi: - Maybe she was referring to inheritance by order.
tr: "I suppose you are referring to the mortgage on this property.""
es: ––Are you perhaps referring to the inheritance of this property?

en: “Ah, sir, I do indeed. It is a grievous affair to my poor girls, you must confess. Not that I mean to find fault with you, for such things, I know, are all chance in this world. There is no knowing how estates will go when once they come to be entailed.”
vi: - Ah! That's right! That is the matter that causes me to worry, I have to say so. I do not mean to imply that you are at fault, because I know that such things are merely by chance. We cannot know where our fortune will go when it is inherited in order.
tr: "Ah sir, of course. You must understand that this is a great torment for my daughters. Not that I find fault with you, because I know that these matters are a matter of luck in this world. I don't understand how an inheritance can be mortgaged away."
es: ––Ah! Indeed, sir. You cannot deny that it is a very distressing matter for my daughters. I do not blame you; you know that in this world these things are just a matter of luck. No one has any notion of what will happen with the properties once they have to be inherited.

en: “I am very sensible, madam, of the hardship to my fair cousins, and could say much on the subject, but that I am cautious of appearing forward and precipitate. But I can assure the young ladies that I come prepared to admire them. At present I will not say more, but, perhaps, when we are better acquainted——”
vi: - Madam, I deeply sympathize with the situation of your cousins and could say much more about this, only because I do not want to appear too eager and rash. But I can say that you can rest assured, I always care for them with a loving heart. At the moment, I cannot say more, but when we get to know each other better…
tr: "I am aware of the difficulty I have created for my dear cousins, madam, and I have much to say on the matter, but I do not wish to appear hasty and rushed. But I have come ready to admire the young ladies. I will not say more for now, but, perhaps, when we know each other better–"
es: ––I deeply regret the misfortune of your lovely daughters; but I will be cautious, I do not want to rush and seem hasty. What I can assure these young ladies is that I have come prepared to admire them. For now, I will say no more, but perhaps, when we get to know each other better...

en: He was interrupted by a summons to dinner; and the girls smiled on each other. They were not the only objects of Mr. Collins’s admiration. The hall, the dining-room, and all its furniture, were examined and praised; and his commendation of everything would have touched Mrs. Bennet’s heart, but for the mortifying supposition of his viewing it all as his own future property. The dinner, too, in its turn, was highly admired; and he begged to know to which of his fair cousins the excellence of its cookery was owing. But here he was set right by Mrs. Bennet, who assured him, with some asperity, that they were very well able to keep a good cook, and that her daughters had nothing to do in the kitchen. He begged pardon for having displeased her. In a softened tone she declared herself not at all offended; but he continued to apologize for about a quarter of an hour.
vi: He was interrupted by an invitation to dine, and the girls smiled at each other. The girls were not the only ones he fancied. He examined and praised the large living room, the dining room, and all the furnishings. His praise of the household items might have touched Mrs. Bennet's heart, but she was tormented by the thought that he was viewing everything as his future inheritance. He also lavishly praised the dinner and asked to know which lady had such excellent culinary skills. But Mrs. Bennet hastily corrected him, somewhat rudely, informing him that the family had their own cook and the girls had nothing to do with the kitchen. He apologized for offending her. She gently replied that she was not offended at all, but he continued to apologize for quite some time.
tr: The call to dinner interrupted the conversation; the girls smiled at each other. Mr. Collins' admiration was not solely directed at them. The drawing room, the dining room, and all the furniture were examined and praised; Mrs. Bennet's pride would have been flattered by his approval of everything if it weren't for the possibility that he saw it all as his future property. The dinner, in due course, also received its share of admiration; he wanted to know to which lovely cousin he owed thanks for the excellent cooking. But here Mrs. Bennet interrupted him and said rather sharply that they were well-off enough to hire a good cook, and that her daughters had no business in the kitchen. Mr. Collins apologized for having offended her. Although Mrs. Bennet explained in a gentle voice that she was not at all offended, the man continued to apologize for a quarter of an hour.
es: He was interrupted to be invited to the dining room; and the young ladies smiled at each other. Not only were they the object of Mr. Collins' admiration: he examined and praised the hall, the dining room, and all the furniture; and the praises he gave to everything would have touched Mrs. Bennet's heart, if it weren't for the fact that she was mortified thinking that Collins saw all of it as his future property. He also praised the dinner and begged to be told which of his beautiful cousins was responsible for preparing it. But here, Mrs. Bennet interrupted him bluntly, telling him that her means allowed her to have a good cook and that her daughters had nothing to do in the kitchen. He apologized for having bothered her, and she, in a very gentle tone, told him that she was not at all offended. But Collins continued apologizing for almost a quarter of an hour.

en: CHAPTER XIV
vi: Chapter 14
tr: Chapter XIV
es: CHAPTER XIV

en: DURING dinner, Mr. Bennet scarcely spoke at all; but when the servants were withdrawn, he thought it time to have some conversation with his guest, and therefore started a subject in which he expected him to shine, by observing that he seemed very fortunate in his patroness. Lady Catherine de Bourgh’s attention to his wishes, and consideration for his comfort, appeared very remarkable. Mr. Bennet could not have chosen better. Mr. Collins was eloquent in her praise. The subject elevated him to more than usual solemnity of manner; and with a most important aspect he protested that he had never in his life witnessed such behaviour in a person of rank—such affability and condescension, as he had himself experienced from Lady Catherine. She had been graciously pleased to approve of both the discourses which he had already had the honour of preaching before her. She had also asked him twice to dine at Rosings, and had sent for him only the Saturday before, to make up her pool of quadrille in the evening. Lady Catherine was reckoned proud by many people, he knew, but he had never seen anything but affability in her. She had always spoken to him as she would to any other gentleman; she made not the smallest objection to his joining in the society of the neighbourhood, nor to his leaving his parish occasionally for a week or two to visit his relations. She had even condescended to advise him to marry as soon as he could, provided he chose with discretion; and had once paid him a visit in his humble parsonage, where she had perfectly approved all the alterations he had been making, and had even vouchsafed to suggest some herself,—some shelves in the closets upstairs.
vi: Mr. Bennet spoke very little during the meal, but when all the servants had left the dining room, he thought it was time to talk to the guest. So he started with the topic he thought the young man excelled in, by remarking that he had been very fortunate to receive the patronage of the Lady, that Lady Catherine de Bourgh's interest in his work, along with her consideration in making his living arrangements more comfortable, was very unusual. Mr. Bennet could not have chosen a better topic for the young man. For Mr. Collins eloquently praised the Lady. And the topic elevated his solemn demeanor above the usual level, and with the most important appearance, he stated that he had never met anyone like her in the upper class – the kindness and condescension, as he had observed in Lady Catherine. She had been pleased to graciously review two of his sermons during her attendance. She had also twice invited him to dine at Rosings, and just the previous Saturday had invited him to fill in for a four-person card game in the evening. Many people he knew said that Lady Catherine was proud, but he saw nothing in her but affability. She always spoke to him as she would to any other upper-class person, she never hindered him from socializing with neighboring families, or when he left the parish to visit relatives. She even condescended to advise him to marry as soon as possible, provided he chose carefully, and had several times visited his humble abode, where she was absolutely pleased with all his arrangements, and she even gave him a few suggestions – a few shelves in the room upstairs.
tr: Mr. Bennet did not talk much during the meal; but when the servants withdrew, he thought it was time to converse with his guest and opened a topic in which he hoped he would show himself, saying that he seemed very fortunate in his patroness. Lady Catherine de Bourgh's attention to his wishes and care for his comfort was very impressive. Mr. Bennet could not have chosen a better topic. Mr. Collins could not stop praising the lady. As he spoke, he became more and more enthusiastic, speaking with the air of a very important man, "he had never in his life seen such behavior from someone of title – such sensitivity and generosity as Lady Catherine had shown him. She had approved with generous satisfaction both of the sermons he had had the honor of delivering in her presence. She had invited him to dine at Rosings twice, and just last Saturday had sent for him to complete the quartet at the quadrille table in the evening. Many people he knew thought Lady Catherine was proud, but he had seen nothing but sensitivity in her. She had always spoken to him as she would to any other gentleman; she had not objected in the slightest to his forming close relationships with the neighbors or to his leaving his parish for a week or two to visit his relatives occasionally. She had even shown her generosity by advising him to marry as soon as possible, provided he made a good choice, and had once visited him in his humble abode, fully approving of all the renovations he was making and even making some suggestions herself – such as adding a few shelves to the small rooms upstairs."
es: Mr. Bennet barely spoke during dinner; but when the servants had already withdrawn, he thought the opportune moment had arrived to converse with his guest. He began with a topic he believed would be to his liking, and told him that he had been very fortunate with his patroness. Lady Catherine de Bourgh's attention to his wishes and her concern for his well-being were extraordinary. Mr. Bennet could not have chosen anything better. Mr. Collins praised Lady Catherine with great eloquence. The subject elevated the usual solemnity of his manners, and, giving himself much importance, he asserted that he had never seen behavior like hers in a person of her rank, nor such affability and condescension. She had deigned to give her approval to the two sermons he had already had the honor of delivering in her presence; she had invited him to dine twice at Rosings, and just the previous Saturday had sent for him to complete her quadrille game during the evening. He knew many people who considered Lady Catherine to be proud, but he had never seen in her anything but affability. She always spoke to him as she would to any other gentleman; she did not object to his associating with the people of the neighborhood, nor to his leaving the parish for one or two weeks to visit his relatives. She always saw fit to recommend that he marry as soon as possible, provided he chose wisely, and she had visited him at his humble home, where she approved of all the changes he had made, even going so far as to suggest some herself, such as, for example, putting some shelves in the closets of the upstairs rooms.

en: “That is all very proper and civil, I am sure,” said Mrs. Bennet, “and I dare say she is a very agreeable woman. It is a pity that great ladies in general are not more like her. Does she live near you, sir?”
vi: Mrs. Bennet said: - All these actions are proper and polite, so I am sure she is a very pleasant woman. The unfortunate thing is that there aren't many such ladies. Does she live near you?
tr: "These are very appropriate and polite actions," said Mrs. Bennet, "it is clear that she is a very charming woman. It is a pity that more grand ladies are not like her. Does she live near you, sir?"
es: ––All that is very well and very courteous on her part ––commented Mrs. Bennet––. She must be a very pleasant woman. It's a pity that great ladies in general do not resemble her much. Does she live near you?

en: “The garden in which stands my humble abode is separated only by a lane from Rosings Park, her Ladyship’s residence.”
vi: - The garden outside my modest dwelling is separated from Lady Catherine's Rosings Park estate by only a road.
tr: "My humble abode's garden is separated from the lady's estate, Rosings Park, by only one road.""
es: ––Rosings Park, Her Ladyship's residence, is only separated by a road from the estate where my humble abode is situated.

en: “I think you said she was a widow, sir? has she any family?”
vi: - I think you said she was a widow. Does she have any relatives?
tr: "You said he was dull, didn't you? Does he have a family?"
es: ––I believe you said you were a widow. Do you have family?

en: “She has one only daughter, the heiress of Rosings, and of very extensive property.”
vi: - She has only one daughter, who is the heiress of Rosings and a vast fortune.
tr: "She has an only daughter, the heiress of Rosings and a vast estate.""
es: ––He has only one daughter, the heiress of Rosings and other vast estates.

en: “Ah,” cried Mrs. Bennet, shaking her head, “then she is better off than many girls. And what sort of young lady is she? Is she handsome?”
vi: Mrs. Bennet exclaimed, shaking her head: - Ah! So she is a wealthy person. So what kind of person is she? Does she look beautiful?
tr: "Ah!" cried Mrs. Bennet, shaking her head, "so she is better off than most girls. What kind of young lady is she? Is she beautiful?"
es: ––Oh! ––sighed Mrs. Bennet, shaking her head––. She is in a better situation than many other young women. What kind of girl is she? Is she pretty?

en: “She is a most charming young lady, indeed. Lady Catherine herself says that, in point of true beauty, Miss de Bourgh is far superior to the handsomest of her sex; because there is that in her features which marks the young woman of distinguished birth. She is unfortunately of a sickly constitution, which has prevented her making that progress in many accomplishments which she could not otherwise have failed of, as I am informed by the lady who superintended her education, and who still resides with them. But she is perfectly amiable, and often condescends to drive by my humble abode in her little phaeton and ponies.”
vi: - Actually, she is the most graceful young woman I have ever met. Lady Catherine herself said that, in terms of true beauty, Miss de Bourgh surpasses the most beautiful girls, as she has the expressions of a young woman of noble lineage. Unfortunately, her physical condition is too weak, which has hindered her success in many areas; otherwise, she would not fail in any field. But she is entirely amiable to everyone, often humbling herself to drive past my modest abode.
tr: "A very elegant young lady indeed. Lady Catherine herself says that in terms of true beauty, Miss de Bourgh is far superior to the most beautiful of her peers, because there is something in her face that shows she is a young woman of innate privilege. But unfortunately, she is always ill; according to the lady who oversees her education and still stays with them, this prevents her from developing many of her skills, otherwise why would she fall behind. But she is extremely amiable; she often shows the kindness of passing by my humble abode with her little phaeton and ponies."
es: ––She is truly a charming young lady. Lady Catherine herself says that, to be honest, in terms of beauty, she far surpasses the most beautiful of her sex; because there is something in her features that reveals her distinguished birth. Unfortunately, she is of a sickly constitution, which has prevented her from progressing in certain aspects of her education that, if not for this, would be very remarkable, according to the lady who directed her education and who still lives with them. But she is very kind and often has the goodness to stop by my humble residence with her little phaeton and her ponies.

en: “Has she been presented? I do not remember her name among the ladies at court.”
vi: - Has she been presented at court yet? I don't remember ever seeing her name among the women presented at the Court.
tr: "Was it presented?" "I don't remember hearing her name among the ladies in the palace.""
es: ––Has she been introduced to society yet? I don't remember hearing her name among the ladies of the court.

en: “Her indifferent state of health unhappily prevents her being in town; and by that means, as I told Lady Catherine myself one day, has deprived the British Court of its brightest ornament. Her Ladyship seemed pleased with the idea; and you may imagine that I am happy on every occasion to offer those little delicate compliments which are always acceptable to ladies. I have more than once observed to Lady Catherine, that her charming daughter seemed born to be a duchess; and that the most elevated rank, instead of giving her consequence, would be adorned by her. These are the kind of little things which please her Ladyship, and it is a sort of attention which I conceive myself peculiarly bound to pay.”
vi: - The sad thing is that her health condition does not allow her to enter the city. I myself told Lady Catherine the other day that this situation deprives the court of a splendid beauty. Lady Catherine seemed very pleased with my remark, and you can imagine that I am very delighted at every opportunity to offer subtle compliments that are always accepted by women. More than once, I have remarked to Lady Catherine that her charming daughter seems born to become a duchess, and the title is elevated by her rather than merely providing her with status. These are the little things that please Lady Catherine, and it is the special care that I remind myself to show in response to the favor she has shown me.
tr: "His poor health prevents him from coming to the city; therefore, one day I personally told Lady Catherine that he deprives the English court of its brightest ornament. Her Ladyship seemed to like this idea; you can guess that I always gladly express these little delicate compliments that women always find reasonable at every opportunity. I have told Lady Catherine several times that her beautiful daughter seems to be born to be a duchess, and that even the highest title would be honored by her rather than adding glory to her. –These are the kinds of little things that please Her Ladyship, and I consider it my duty to show such attention."
es: ––The poor state of his health has unfortunately not allowed him to go to the capital, and because of this, as I once told Lady Catherine, he has deprived the British court of its most radiant ornament. Her Ladyship seemed very flattered by this appreciation; and you can understand that I take pleasure in directing, whenever I have the chance, these small and delicate compliments that are usually pleasing to the ladies. More than once I have pointed out to Lady Catherine that her charming daughter seemed born to be a duchess and that the highest rank, instead of giving her importance, would be elevated by her. These kinds of little things are what please Her Ladyship and I consider myself especially obliged to have such attentions with her.

en: “You judge very properly,” said Mr. Bennet; “and it is happy for you that you possess the talent of flattering with delicacy. May I ask whether these pleasing attentions proceed from the impulse of the moment, or are the result of previous study?”
vi: Mr. Bennet said: - Your observation is very accurate; you have pleased others through your delicate manner. By the way, may I ask whether those gestures stem from the unfolding events, or are they the result of prior study.
tr: "A very sensible thought," said Mr. Bennet, "also, it is nice that you have the ability to make fine compliments. I wonder if these sweet words are born at the moment or if they are rehearsed beforehand."
es: ––You judge very well ––said Mr. Bennet––, and it is fortunate that you have the talent to flatter with delicacy. May I ask if those pleasant compliments occur to you spontaneously or if they are the result of prior study?

en: “They arise chiefly from what is passing at the time; and though I sometimes amuse myself with suggesting and arranging such little elegant compliments as may be adapted to ordinary occasions, I always wish to give them as unstudied an air as possible.”
vi: - Most of it is spontaneous according to the moment, although sometimes I do arrange small compliments depending on the situation. If possible, I always create the appearance of being unprepared.
tr: "They mostly come from things happening at the time; although sometimes I think of and come up with these kinds of delicate compliments that can be adapted to normal situations to keep myself entertained, I always want to say them with an air of spontaneity as much as possible."
es: ––Normally they come to me on the spot, and although sometimes I take the time to meditate and prepare these small and elegant compliments to be able to adapt them to the occasions that arise, I always try to give them a tone that is as unstudied as possible.

en: Mr. Bennet’s expectations were fully answered. His cousin was as absurd as he had hoped; and he listened to him with the keenest enjoyment, maintaining at the same time the most resolute composure of countenance, and, except in an occasional glance at Elizabeth, requiring no partner in his pleasure.
vi: But what Mr. Bennet had anticipated was satisfactorily answered. He was indeed as ridiculous as Mr. Bennet had thought; he listened to him tell stories with pleasure, maintaining a serious expression, and only seeking sympathy when he glanced over at Elizabeth.
tr: Mr. Bennet's predictions turned out to be entirely correct. His nephew was as foolish as he had anticipated; he listened to him with intelligent pleasure, maintaining a serious expression on his face and, except for occasionally glancing at Elizabeth, not seeking to share his enjoyment with anyone.
es: Mr. Bennet's assumptions had been confirmed. His cousin was as absurd as he believed. He listened to him with intense pleasure, maintaining, however, the most perfect composure; and, except for the occasional glance he cast at Elizabeth, no one else needed to share in his joy.

en: By tea-time, however, the dose had been enough, and Mr. Bennet was glad to take his guest into the drawing-room again, and when tea was over, glad to invite him
vi: At tea time, considering that the amount of amusement had been sufficient, Mr. Bennet cheerfully led the guest back into the drawing room, and after they had finished tea, he invited him to read to the ladies.
tr: Nevertheless, these sufficed for her until tea time; she took her guest back to the sitting room and, when tea was finished, invited him to read to the ladies.
es: However, by tea time he had had enough, and Mr. Bennet had the pleasure of taking his guest back to the drawing room.

en: “Protested
vi: Mr. Collins readily accepted, and a book was handed to him.
tr: Nevertheless, these sufficed for her until tea time; she took her guest back to the sitting room and, when tea was finished, invited him to read to the ladies.
es: When tea was over, he invited him to read something aloud to the ladies.

en: that he never read novels” H.T Feb 94
vi: But when he picked up the book, he apologized and said that he had never read novels – Kitty stared at him, while Lydia exclaimed in astonishment.
tr: Nevertheless, these sufficed for her until tea time; she took her guest back to the sitting room and, when tea was finished, invited him to read to the ladies.
es: When tea was over, he invited him to read something aloud to the ladies.

en: to read aloud to the ladies. Mr. Collins readily assented, and a book was produced; but on beholding it (for everything announced it to be from a circulating library) he started back, and, begging pardon, protested that he never read novels. Kitty stared at him, and Lydia exclaimed. Other books were produced, and after some deliberation he chose “Fordyce’s Sermons.” Lydia gaped as he opened the volume; and before he had, with very monotonous solemnity, read three pages, she interrupted him with,—
vi: But when he picked up the book, he apologized and said that he had never read novels – Kitty stared at him, while Lydia exclaimed in astonishment. Several other books were brought to him, and after some consideration, he chose Fordyce's Sermons; Lydia gaped as he opened the book, and before he could read in a solemn, monotonous tone, she interrupted:
tr: Nevertheless, these sufficed for her until tea time; she took her guest back to the sitting room and, when tea was finished, invited him to read to the ladies. Mr. Collins immediately accepted; a book was brought, but upon seeing the book (it was evident from every aspect that it had been borrowed from a public library), he recoiled and apologized, saying that he did not read novels. Kitty stared at him intently, and Lydia let out a cry of astonishment. Other books were brought, and after some deliberation, he chose Fordyce's Sermons. As Mr. Collins opened the book, Lydia yawned, and he had not read more than three pages in a monotonous seriousness before she stopped him-
es: When tea was over, he invited him to read something aloud to the ladies. Collins agreed immediately and they brought a book; but as soon as he saw it ––it was immediately noticeable that it was from a circulating library–– he stopped, asked for forgiveness, and said he never read novels. Kitty looked at him in surprise and Lydia let out an exclamation. They brought other volumes and after some hesitation he chose Fordyce's sermons. He had barely opened the book when Lydia began to yawn, and before Collins, with monotonous solemnity, had read three pages, the girl interrupted him saying:

en: “Do you know, mamma, that my uncle Philips talks of turning away Richard? and if he does, Colonel Forster will hire him. My aunt told me so herself on Saturday. I shall walk to Meryton to-morrow to hear more about it, and to ask when Mr. Denny comes back from town.”
vi: - Mom, do you know, Mr. Phillips intends to fire Richard, and if that happens, the colonel will take him in. Aunt told me so. I will go to Meryton tomorrow to get more details, and also to ask when Danny will return from the city.
tr: "You know, mom, Aunt Philips is talking about turning Richard away; then Colonel Forster will take him. My aunt said it herself on Saturday. Tomorrow I will go to Meryton to learn the rest, and I will also ask when Mr. Denny is returning from the city."
es: ––Do you know, Mom, that Uncle Phillips is talking about dismissing Richard? And if he does, Colonel Forster will hire him. Aunt told me on Saturday. I will go to Meryton tomorrow to find out more and to ask when Mr. Denny is coming from the city.

en: Lydia was bid by her two eldest sisters to hold her tongue; but Mr. Collins, much offended, laid aside his book, and said,—
vi: The two elder sisters demanded that she hold her tongue, but Mr. Collins, feeling deeply offended, put the book aside and began to speak:
tr: Her two older sisters told Lydia to be quiet; but Mr. Collins, who was very offended, put his book aside and said–
es: The two older sisters begged Lydia to be quiet, but Collins, very offended, put down the book and exclaimed:

en: “I have often observed how little young ladies are interested by books of a serious stamp, though written solely for their benefit. It amazes me, I confess; for certainly there can be nothing so advantageous to them as instruction. But I will no longer importune my young cousin.”
vi: - I often notice that young girls pay little attention to books with distinctive value, even though they are written specifically for them. I must say that I am very surprised, because I believe that this education is very necessary for them. But I do not want to bother the young ladies any further.
tr: "I have often observed that young ladies are not interested in serious books – yet these are written solely for their benefit. I must confess, it astonishes me; –because, after all, there is nothing as beneficial as education. But I will not bore my young cousin any longer."
es: ––I have often observed how little young women are interested in books on serious subjects, despite the fact that they were written for their benefit. I confess that it amazes me, for there can be nothing as advantageous for them as education. But I do not want to keep bothering my little cousin.

en: Then, turning to Mr. Bennet, he offered himself as his antagonist at backgammon. Mr. Bennet accepted the challenge, observing that he acted very wisely in leaving the girls to their own trifling amusements. Mrs. Bennet and her daughters apologized most civilly for Lydia’s interruption, and promised that it should not occur again, if he would resume his book; but Mr. Collins, after assuring them that he bore his young cousin no ill-will, and should never resent her behaviour as any affront, seated himself at another table with Mr. Bennet, and prepared for backgammon.
vi: Then he turned to Mr. Bennet and suggested they play chess. Mr. Bennet agreed, thinking that he had acted wisely by letting the girls amuse themselves with their trivial pursuits. Mrs. Bennet and the older daughters apologized to him in the politest terms for Lydia's interruption. But Mr. Collins reassured them that he did not mind the girl's actions and that he would never feel annoyed by her behavior. Then he sat down with Mr. Bennet at the chess table and prepared for the game.
tr: Then he turned to Mr. Bennet and offered to be his opponent in backgammon. Mr. Bennet accepted the offer, saying that he was wise to leave his daughters to their own trifling affairs. Mrs. Bennet and her daughters politely apologized for Lydia's interruption and promised it would not happen again if he wished to return to his book; but Mr. Collins, after assuring his young cousin that he was not offended by her action, settled at another table with Mr. Bennet and prepared for backgammon.
es: He approached Mr. Bennet and proposed a game of backgammon. Mr. Bennet accepted the challenge and found that he was acting very wisely by letting the girls amuse themselves with their frivolities. Mrs. Bennet and her daughters apologized profusely for Lydia's interruption and promised that it would not happen again if he wanted to continue reading. But Collins assured them that he was not angry with his cousin and that he could never interpret what she had done as an offense; and, sitting at another table with Mr. Bennet, he prepared to play backgammon.

en: CHAPTER XV.
vi: Chapter 15
tr: Chapter XV
es: CHAPTER XV

en: MR. COLLINS was not a sensible man, and the deficiency of nature had been but little assisted by education or society; the greatest part of his life having been spent under the guidance of an illiterate and miserly father; and though he belonged to one of the universities, he had merely kept the necessary terms without forming at it any useful acquaintance. The subjection in which his father had brought him up had given him originally great humility of manner; but it was now a good deal counteracted by the self-conceit of a weak head, living in retirement, and the consequential feelings of early and unexpected prosperity. A fortunate chance had recommended him to Lady Catherine de Bourgh when the living of Hunsford was vacant; and the respect which he felt for her high rank, and his veneration for her as his patroness, mingling with a very good opinion of himself, of his authority as a clergyman, and his right as a rector, made him altogether a mixture of pride and obsequiousness, self-importance and humility.
vi: Mr. Collins is an insensitive person, and neither education nor communication has helped to compensate for this deficiency. Most of his upbringing was under the tutelage of an uneducated and miserly father. Although he attended university, he only did the bare minimum and failed to form any useful relationships. The subjugation—imposed on him by his father—initially gave him a humble appearance, now neutralized by the conceit of a dull mind, an isolated life, and a sense of self-satisfaction from early and unexpected success. A stroke of luck introduced him to Lady Catherine De Bourgh when a preaching position became vacant. His respect for her title and the reverence he holds for her as his patron, combined with his high self-regard, the prestige of being a clergyman, and the rights of a parish rector, have all created in him a blend of pride and obsequiousness, of self-importance and humility.
tr: Chapter XV Mr. Collins was not a clever man; the flaws in his nature had not benefited from education or environment; most of his life had been spent under the control of an illiterate, miserable father; although he was a university graduate, he had only taken the compulsory courses and had not formed a useful connection with education. The treatment his father subjected him to had given him a great sense of inferiority from the start; but this inferiority was now considerably balanced by the illusions of a weak mind living far from everyone and the feelings provided by early and unexpected prosperity. A good coincidence had brought Lady Catherine de Bourgh into his life at a time when the Hunsford position was vacant; the respect he felt for the woman's high status, combined with the reverence he felt for her as his patron, and his great appreciation of his authority as a clergyman and his rights as a priest, had made him a man of mixed pride and servility, arrogance and inferiority.
es: Mr. Collins was not an intelligent man, and the deficiencies of his nature had not been helped at all by his education or his social life. He spent most of his life under the authority of an uneducated and miserly father; and although he went to university, he only stayed there for the merely necessary courses and did not acquire any truly useful knowledge. The subjection with which his father had raised him had initially given him great humility in his character, but this was now counteracted by a vanity obtained thanks to his limited intelligence, his reclusive life, and the feelings inherent to a sudden and unexpected prosperity. A fortunate chance had placed him under the patronage of Lady Catherine de Bourgh when the rectory of Hunsford became vacant, and his respect for the lady's high rank and the veneration she inspired in him for being his patroness, combined with a great self-concept, his authority as a clergyman, and his rights as rector, had turned him into a mixture of pride and servility, of presumption and modesty.

en: Having now a good house and a very sufficient income, he intended to marry; and in seeking a reconciliation with the Longbourn family he had a wife in view, as he meant to choose one of the daughters, if he found them as handsome and amiable as they were represented by common report. This was his plan of amends—of atonement—for inheriting their father’s estate; and he thought it an excellent one, full of eligibility and suitableness, and excessively generous and disinterested on his own part.
vi: Now with a spacious mansion and sufficient income, he intended to get married. When he planned to reconcile with the family at Longbourn, he aimed to marry one of the daughters, provided they were as beautiful and charming as he had heard. This was his plan for making amends – a way to atone – to inherit Mr. Bennet's estate. He thought this was a wonderful plan, that he was qualified and well-matched, coupled with boundless generosity, and without any self-interest on his part.
tr: Now that he had a good house and a very reasonable income, he had decided to marry; while seeking reconciliation with the Longbourn family, he had in mind to find a wife, because he wanted to choose one of the family's daughters, provided he found them as beautiful and charming as they were said to be. This was his plan to compensate – to rectify – inheriting their father's house, and he thought it was a wonderful plan, very clear and convenient, and moreover, extremely generous and selfless.
es: Since he now already owned a good house and more than sufficient income, Collins was thinking about getting married. In his reconciliation with the Longbourn family, he sought the possibility of realizing his plan, as he intended to choose one of the daughters, provided they were as beautiful and pleasant as was said. This was his plan of amendment, or reparation, for inheriting the father's properties, a plan that seemed excellent to him, as it was legitimate, very appropriate, and at the same time very generous and selfless on his part.

en: His plan did not vary on seeing them. Miss Bennet’s lovely face confirmed his views, and established all his strictest notions of what was due to seniority; and for the first evening she was his settled choice. The next morning, however, made an alteration; for in a quarter of an hour’s tête-à-tête with Mrs. Bennet before breakfast, a conversation beginning with his parsonage-house, and leading naturally to the avowal of his hopes, that a mistress for it might be found at Longbourn, produced from her, amid very complaisant smiles and general encouragement, a caution against the very Jane he had fixed on. “As to her younger daughters, she could not take upon her to say—she could not positively answer—but she did not know of any prepossession;—her eldest daughter she must just mention—she felt it incumbent on her to hint, was likely to be very soon engaged.”
vi: After meeting the ladies, his plan remained unchanged. Jane's beautiful face confirmed everyone's rumors and matched the strictest views regarding his status. On the first morning, Jane was his choice. However, the next morning there was an adjustment. While sitting and talking with Mrs. Bennet during breakfast, the conversation started from the parsonage and naturally led to a confession of his hopes that at Longbourn he might find someone who could be the mistress of his estate. Amidst kind smiles and encouragement were hints about Jane, whom he was interested in. But Mrs. Bennet had to mention that she might soon be engaged.
tr: His plan did not change upon seeing the girls. Miss Bennet's beautiful face confirmed his thoughts, and the requirements of being the eldest grounded his choice on solid foundations; his definite choice on the first evening was Jane. However, the situation changed the next morning; he had a fifteen-minute private conversation with Mrs. Bennet before breakfast; he began by talking about his own home, naturally leading to his hope of finding a lady in Longbourn, and in response, amidst polite smiles and encouraging words, he received a warning about Jane. "It was not her place to say anything about her younger daughters – she couldn't say anything definite – but as far as she knew, there was no engagement – as for her eldest daughter, she felt compelled to mention that an engagement was imminent."
es: His plan did not change at all upon seeing them. Jane's charming face confirmed his intentions and corroborated all his strict notions about the preference that should be given to the elder daughters; and thus, during the first evening, he definitively decided on her. However, the next morning he had to make an alteration; for before breakfast, he had a quarter-hour conversation with Mrs. Bennet. They began by talking about his parsonage, which naturally led him to confess his hopes of finding in Longbourn the one who was to be its mistress. Amidst complacent smiles and general encouragements, Mrs. Bennet gave him a warning about Jane: "As for the younger daughters, it was not for her to argue; she could not answer positively, though she did not know that anyone had made them proposals; but regarding Jane, she had to warn him, though, after all, it was something that concerned only her, that she might soon be engaged."

en: Mr. Collins had only to change from Jane to Elizabeth—and it was soon done—done while Mrs. Bennet was stirring the fire. Elizabeth, equally next to Jane in birth and beauty, succeeded her of course.
vi: Mr. Collins simply needed to change from Jane to Elizabeth, and this happened quickly, while Mrs. Bennet was still busy suggesting that Elizabeth was nearly equal to Jane in age and beauty.
tr: Mr. Collins only needed to change his mind from Jane to Elizabeth – and he did – while Mrs. Bennet was stirring the fire. Elizabeth, who was not inferior to Jane in beauty and virtue, immediately followed her.
es: Collins only had to replace Jane with Elizabeth; and, spurred on by Mrs. Bennet, he made the change quickly. Elizabeth, who followed Jane in age and beauty, was the new candidate.

en: Mrs. Bennet treasured up the hint, and trusted that she might soon have two daughters married; and the man whom she could not bear to speak of the day before, was now high in her good graces.
vi: Mrs. Bennet paid great attention to this insinuation, and believed that soon her two daughters would be engaged. The young man whom she could not stand to hear about two days ago was now being treated by her as an honored guest.
tr: Mrs. Bennet eagerly seized the opportunity, and soon believed she could marry off her two daughters; the man she couldn't even bear to hear about just yesterday had now become quite favorable in her eyes.
es: Mrs. Bennet took note of it, and she hoped that soon she would have two married daughters. The man she didn't even want to hear about the day before suddenly became the object of her highest esteem.

en: Lydia’s intention of walking to Meryton was not forgotten: every sister except Mary agreed to go with her; and Mr. Collins was to attend them, at the request of Mr. Bennet, who was most anxious to get rid of him, and have his library to himself; for thither Mr. Collins had followed him after breakfast, and there he would continue, nominally engaged with one of the largest folios in the collection, but really talking to Mr. Bennet, with little cessation, of his house and garden at Hunsford. Such doings discomposed Mr. Bennet exceedingly. In his library he had been always sure of leisure and tranquillity; and though prepared, as he told Elizabeth, to meet with folly and conceit in every other room in the house, he was used to be free from them there: his civility, therefore, was most prompt in inviting Mr. Collins to join his daughters in their walk; and Mr. Collins, being in fact much better fitted for a walker than a reader, was extremely well pleased to close his large book, and go.
vi: Lydia did not forget her intention to go to Meryton; her sisters, except for Mary, all agreed to go with her, and Mr. Collins would accompany them to look after them at Mr. Bennet's request. He only wanted to get rid of the man so he could read in peace, because after breakfast Mr. Collins had been following him around, ostensibly examining the large volumes in the collection, but incessantly talking to him about his house and garden at Huntsford. This behavior made Mr. Bennet extremely uncomfortable. In the reading room, he was always assured of quiet. As he had told Elizabeth, although he had to face folly and conceit elsewhere, in the reading room he was usually free from such annoyances. Therefore, he politely invited Mr. Collins to accompany his daughters. Mr. Collins also preferred going with the ladies to reading, and was very happy to close the thick book and join them.
tr: Lydia's intention to walk to Meryton was not forgotten; all the girls except Mary agreed to go with her; Mr. Collins would accompany them at the request of Mr. Bennet, who wanted to get rid of him and have the library to himself; the man had followed him to the library after breakfast and, pretending to browse one of the largest volumes in the collection, would once again relentlessly talk about his house and garden in Hunsford, giving Mr. Bennet no respite. Such actions greatly annoyed Mr. Bennet. He always desired absolute comfort and tranquility in his library; as he told Elizabeth, he was prepared to encounter foolishness and pretentiousness in every other room of the house, but he was accustomed to being free from them there; therefore, without losing a moment, he kindly invited Mr. Collins to join his daughters' walk; Mr. Collins, being more inclined to walk than to read, gladly closed the large book and went.
es: Lydia's plan to go to Meryton was still on. All the sisters, except Mary, agreed to go with her. Mr. Collins was going to accompany them at Mr. Bennet's request, who was eager to get rid of his relative and have the library all to himself; for Mr. Collins had followed him there after breakfast and would continue to do so, apparently occupied with one of the largest folios in the collection, though in reality, incessantly talking to Mr. Bennet about his house and garden at Hunsford. Such things greatly unsettled him. The library was the place where he knew he could enjoy his free time in peace. He was willing, as he told Elizabeth, to endure stupidity and conceit in any other room of the house, but in the library, he wanted to be free of all that. So he employed all his courtesy in inviting Collins to accompany his daughters on their walk; and Collins, who was much better at walking than reading, saw the heavens open. He closed the book and left.

en: In pompous nothings on his side, and civil assents on that of his cousins, their time passed till they entered Meryton. The attention of the younger ones was then no longer to be gained by him. Their eyes were immediately wandering up the street in quest of the officers, and nothing less than a very smart bonnet, indeed, or a really new muslin in a shop window, could recall them.
vi: With trivial displays and polite compliments, he accompanied the ladies to Meryton. At this point, the ladies no longer paid attention to him. Their eyes roamed the streets in search of officers, and only the sight of truly elegant hats or muslin goods could distract them.
tr: He swaggered idly, while his cousins nodded politely, and finally, they arrived in Meryton. By then, he could no longer attract the attention of the young people. The girls' eyes immediately started searching for the officers as they wandered the streets, and nothing could distract them except for a very flashy hat in a shop window or a brand new muslin.
es: And between pompous and insipid phrases on his part, and courteous nods on the part of his cousins, time passed until they reached Meryton. From then on, the younger sisters no longer paid him any attention. They had eyes only for seeking officers in the streets. And unless it was a truly elegant hat or a genuinely new muslin, nothing could distract them.

en: But the attention of every lady was soon caught by a young man, whom they had never seen before, of most gentlemanlike appearance, walking with an officer on the other side of the way. The officer was the very Mr. Denny concerning whose return from London Lydia came to inquire, and he bowed as they passed. All were struck with the stranger’s air, all wondered who he could be; and Kitty and Lydia, determined if possible to find out, led the way across the street, under pretence of wanting something in an opposite shop, and fortunately had just gained the pavement, when the two gentlemen, turning back, had reached the same spot. Mr. Denny addressed them directly, and entreated permission to introduce his friend, Mr. Wickham, who had returned with him the day before from town, and, he was happy to say, had accepted a commission in their corps. This was exactly as it should be; for the young man wanted only regimentals to make him completely charming. His appearance was greatly in his favour: he had all the best parts of beauty, a fine countenance, a good figure, and very pleasing address. The introduction was followed up on his side by a happy readiness of conversation—a readiness at the same time perfectly correct and unassuming; and the whole party were still standing and talking together very agreeably, when the sound of horses drew their notice, and Darcy and Bingley were seen riding down the street. On distinguishing the ladies of the group the two gentlemen came directly towards them, and began the usual civilities. Bingley was the principal spokesman, and Miss Bennet the principal object. He was then, he said, on his way to Longbourn on purpose to inquire after her. Mr. Darcy corroborated it with a bow, and was beginning to determine not to fix his eyes on Elizabeth, when they were suddenly arrested by the sight of the stranger; and Elizabeth happening to see the countenance of both as they looked at each other, was all astonishment at the effect of the meeting. Both changed colour, one looked white, the other red. Mr. Wickham, after a few moments, touched his hat—a salutation which Mr. Darcy just deigned to return. What could be the meaning of it? It was impossible to imagine; it was impossible not to long to know.
vi: But a young man appeared and caught the ladies' attention. He had a truly elegant appearance, walking in the opposite direction of an officer. The officer was Danny, the one who had returned from London that Lydia had mentioned. He bowed his head to greet them as everyone passed by. All the ladies were impressed by his demeanor and wondered who he was. Kitty and Lydia decided to find out who he was. The two led the way, crossing the street under the pretext of buying something from the shop opposite, and luckily arrived at the curb just as the two young men were returning to the same place. Danny greeted them and asked permission to introduce his friend to the ladies, Mr. Wickham, who had returned from the city with him and was also joining the same unit. Just the uniform alone made the young man completely captivating. Every aspect of his appearance was splendid; he had a delicate face, a perfect physique, and, in addition, a very charming way of speaking. Right after the introduction, there was a cheerful and naturally fluent conversation that was very proper. They were all chatting when they heard the sound of approaching horses, and they saw Darcy and Bingley riding up. Upon seeing the ladies, the two men approached and began the usual polite exchanges. Bingley was the main speaker, and Jane the main listener. He said he was on his way to Longbourn to inquire about her condition. Darcy confirmed his friend's words with a slight nod, and as he began to resolutely avoid staring at Elizabeth, he noticed the unfamiliar young man. Elizabeth managed to see the expressions on both their faces as they looked at each other, very surprised by the impact of the encounter. Both changed their complexion, one turning white, the other red. After a few moments, Wickham touched his hat to greet, and Darcy only awkwardly responded. What was that? Impossible to think of, impossible not to want to know?
tr: However, it wasn't long before a young man caught the attention of all the ladies, someone they had never seen before, very gentlemanly in appearance, walking with an officer on the other side of the road. The officer was Mr. Denny, whom Lydia had come to inquire about whether he had returned from London, and he nodded as they passed by. They were all struck by the stranger's demeanor, all curious about who he might be; Kitty and Lydia pretended to look at something in the shop across the street to find out if possible, and just as they stepped onto the sidewalk, by coincidence, they came face to face with the two gentlemen returning. Mr. Denny immediately began to speak, asking permission to introduce his friend: Mr. Wickham had come to town with him the previous day and, he was happy to say, had agreed to be an officer in their regiment. This was just as it should be; the young man's only missing element for perfect charm was his uniform. Every detail of his demeanor added something to him; everything about him was beautiful: a pleasant face, a well-formed body, and an engaging manner of speaking. After the introductions, the young man showed he was eager to talk – but it was a perfectly measured and easy eagerness; the whole group was standing and chatting sweetly when the sound of horses drew their attention, and they saw Darcy and Bingley coming down the street. As soon as the two gentlemen recognized the ladies in the group, they came directly to them and displayed their usual politeness. Bingley was the main speaker, and Miss Bennet was the main topic. At that moment, Bingley said, he was also on his way to Longbourn to inquire about her health.
