Mr. Darcy nodded to confirm this and was just beginning to struggle not to fix his eyes on Elizabeth when he noticed the stranger's presence and suddenly froze; Elizabeth saw that both their faces froze in astonishment at the encounter as they looked at each other. Both of their colors changed, one turning white, the other red. Mr. Wickham touched his hat a few seconds later – Darcy barely acknowledged this salute. What could this mean? –It was impossible to imagine; it was impossible not to be eager to find out.
es: But the attention of all the young ladies was instantly captured by a young man they had not seen before, who had the appearance of being quite the gentleman, and who was walking with an officer on the opposite side of the street. The officer was Mr. Denny himself, whose return from London Lydia had come to inquire about, and who bowed to greet them as he passed. They were all impressed by the stranger's bearing and wondered who he could be. Kitty and Lydia, determined to find out, crossed the street under the pretext that they wanted to buy something at the shop opposite, reaching the sidewalk so fortunately that, at that very moment, the two gentlemen, on their way back, arrived at exactly the same spot. Mr. Denny addressed them directly and asked if he might introduce his friend, Mr. Wickham, who had come from London with him the day before and had kindly accepted a position in the Corps. This was the last straw, for belonging to the regiment was the only thing he lacked to complete his charm. His appearance spoke highly in his favor; he was handsome and slender, with very affable manners. After the introduction, Mr. Wickham initiated a conversation with great ease, with the utmost correctness and without pretensions. They were all still standing there pleasantly chatting when the sound of horses drew their attention, and they saw Darcy and Bingley, on their mounts, coming down the street. Upon recognizing the young ladies in the group, the two gentlemen approached them and began the customary greetings. Bingley spoke more than anyone, and Jane was the main subject of his conversation. At that moment, he said, they were on their way to Longbourn to see how she was; Darcy confirmed this with a nod and was trying not to fix his gaze on Elizabeth when suddenly they were both paralyzed upon seeing the stranger. Elizabeth, who saw both their faces as they looked at each other, was very surprised by the effect the encounter had on them. Both changed color, one turned pale and the other red. After a slight hesitation, Wickham raised his hand to his hat, to which Darcy deigned to respond. What could that mean? It was impossible to imagine, but it was also impossible not to feel a great curiosity to know.

en: In another minute Mr. Bingley, but without seeming to have noticed what passed, took leave and rode on with his friend.
vi: Meanwhile, Bingley seemed unaware of what had happened, bid farewell, and rode off with his friend.
tr: Soon after, Mr. Bingley asked for leave without seeming to pay attention to what was happening and set off with his friend.
es: A moment later, Bingley, who seemed not to have noticed what had happened, said goodbye and continued on with his friend.

en: Mr. Denny and Mr. Wickham walked with the young ladies to the door of Mr. Philips’s house, and then made their bows, in spite of Miss Lydia’s pressing entreaties that they would come in, and even in spite of Mrs. Philips’s throwing up the parlour window, and loudly seconding the invitation.
vi: Mr. Danny and Wickham accompanied the ladies to Mr. Phillips' house, then bowed and took their leave, despite Lydia's pleas for them to come inside.
tr: Mr. Denny and Mr. Wickham walked with the young ladies to the door of Mr. Philips's house, then, despite Miss Lydia's insistent invitations to come inside and even Mrs. Philips raising the parlor window to support the invitation, they bowed and took their leave.
es: Denny and Wickham continued walking with the girls until they reached Mr. Philips' house door, where they made the appropriate bows and left despite Lydia's insistent pleas for them to come in and despite Mrs. Philips opening the vestibule window and leaning out to vocally support the invitation.

en: Mrs. Philips was always glad to see her nieces; and the two eldest, from their recent absence, were particularly welcome; and she was eagerly expressing her surprise at their sudden return home, which, as their own carriage had not fetched them, she should have known nothing about, if she had not happened to see Mr. Jones’s shopboy in the street, who had told her that they were not to send any more draughts to Netherfield, because the Miss Bennets were come away, when her civility was claimed towards Mr. Collins by Jane’s introduction of him. She received him with her very best politeness, which he returned with as much more, apologizing for his intrusion, without any previous acquaintance with her, which he could not help flattering himself, however, might be justified by his relationship to the young ladies who introduced him to her notice. Mrs. Philips was quite awed by such an excess of good breeding; but her contemplation of one stranger was soon put an end to by exclamations and inquiries about the other, of whom, however, she could only tell her nieces what they already knew, that Mr. Denny had brought him from London, and that he was to have a lieutenant’s commission in the ——shire. She had been watching him the last hour, she said, as he walked up and down the street,—and had Mr. Wickham appeared, Kitty and Lydia would certainly have continued the occupation; but unluckily no one passed the windows now except a few of the officers, who, in comparison with the stranger, were become “stupid, disagreeable fellows.” Some of them were to dine with the Philipses the next day, and their aunt promised to make her husband call on Mr. Wickham, and give him an invitation also, if the family from Longbourn would come in the evening. This was agreed to; and Mrs. Philips protested that they would have a nice comfortable noisy game of lottery tickets, and a little bit of hot supper afterwards. The prospect of such delights was very cheering, and they parted in mutual good spirits. Mr. Collins repeated his apologies in quitting the room, and was assured, with unwearying civility, that they were perfectly needless.
vi: Mrs. Phillips was delighted to see her nieces again. The two older girls, having been away for some time, received a special welcome. She was surprised by their sudden return home. Since they did not use the carriage, she would not have known they had returned if she had not accidentally met the shopkeeper who sold goods to Mr. Jones and informed her. Jane introduced Mr. Collins to her, and she received him with utmost politeness. He responded formally, apologizing for the intrusion as they had not been acquainted before, only through the ladies' introduction. Mrs. Phillips seemed concerned about receiving someone with such excessive politeness. But the welcome was interrupted by inquiries about the stranger, and about him, she only knew what the ladies had already been told. She promised to have her husband visit him and invite him for a meal, provided the Bennet family would also come in the evening. Everyone agreed, and they all left in high spirits, anticipating the upcoming pleasures. Mr. Collins repeated his apologies, but she reassured him that it was unnecessary.
tr: Mrs. Philips was always pleased to see her nieces; the two eldest girls were especially well received after their recent absence; Mrs. Philips was fervently expressing her surprise at their sudden return, saying that if she hadn't seen Mr. Jones's apprentice in the street, who told her they would no longer be sending syrup to Netherfield because the Miss Bennets had left, she wouldn't have known. At that moment, Jane stepped forward and introduced Mr. Collins, drawing her attention to him. Mrs. Philips greeted Mr. Collins in the most polite manner, and received the same courtesy in return; Mr. Collins apologized for being a guest without their prior acquaintance, but he believed that his proud connection with the young ladies who brought him there would excuse this situation. Mrs. Philips was delighted by such extreme politeness; but her observation of the stranger was soon interrupted by excited questions about another stranger, about whom she could tell her nieces what they already knew, namely that Mr. Denny had brought him from London and that he would be taking the rank of lieutenant in the -------shire regiment. She said she had been watching him for the past hour, walking up and down the street; if Mr. Wickham had appeared, Kitty and Lydia would certainly have continued to watch, but unfortunately, apart from a few officers who were "stupid, disagreeable fellows" compared to the stranger, no one else was passing by the windows. Some of them would be dining with the Philipses the next day; their aunt promised that if the Longbourn family came in the evening, she would send her husband to visit Mr. Wickham and invite him as well. They agreed; Mrs. Philips said they would play a delightful, easy, and boisterous game of lottery tickets, followed by something hot to eat. It was joyful to have such entertainments to look forward to; both parties were in high spirits as they parted. Mr. Collins repeated his apologies as he left the room and was assured with tireless politeness that there was no need for any apology.
es: Mrs. Philips was always delighted to see her nieces. The two eldest were especially well received due to their recent absence. She expressed her surprise at their quick return home, of which she would have known nothing, since they did not come back in their own carriage, had it not been for the chance encounter with Dr. Jones's young man, who told her that she no longer needed to send more medicines to Netherfield because the Miss Bennets had left. Then Jane introduced Mr. Collins to whom she dedicated all her attention. She welcomed him with the most exquisite courtesy, to which Collins responded with even more refinement, apologizing for having presented himself at her house without prior notice, although he felt proud that it was the relationship with her nieces that justified such an intrusion. Mrs. Philips was completely overwhelmed by such an excess of good manners. But she soon had to set aside this stranger, due to the exclamations and questions regarding the other. Mrs. Philips could not tell her nieces more than they already knew: that Mr. Denny had brought him from London and that he was going to stay at the county garrison with the rank of lieutenant. She added that she had been observing him while he walked down the street; and if Mr. Wickham had appeared then, both Kitty and Lydia would have also approached the window to watch him, but unfortunately, at that moment only a few officers passed by who, compared to the stranger, seemed "stupid and unpleasant fellows." Some of these officers were going to dine the next day with the Philips, and the aunt promised them that she would tell her husband to visit Wickham to invite him too, if the Longbourn family wanted to come in the evening. Thus it was agreed, and Mrs. Philips offered them to play the lottery and then have a hot dinner. The prospect of such delights was magnificent, and the girls left very happy. Collins apologized again upon leaving, and he was assured that it was unnecessary.

en: As they walked home, Elizabeth related to Jane what she had seen pass between the two gentlemen; but though Jane would have defended either or both, had they appeared to be wrong, she could no more explain such behaviour than her sister.
vi: On the way back, Elizabeth told Jane about Darcy's strange attitude. Although Jane could defend both of them if they had done something wrong, she couldn't explain to her sister the attitude of the two.
tr: While walking home, Elizabeth explained to Jane what had transpired between the two gentlemen; if they seemed to have made a mistake, Jane would have defended one or both of them, but she too could not make more sense of this behavior than her sister.
es: On the way home, Elizabeth told Jane what had happened between the two gentlemen, and although Jane would have defended them if she had noticed anything strange, in this case, like her sister, she could not explain such behavior.

en: Mr. Collins on his return highly gratified Mrs. Bennet by admiring Mrs. Philips’s manners and politeness. He protested that, except Lady Catherine and her daughter, he had never seen a more elegant woman; for she had not only received him with the utmost civility, but had even pointedly included him in her invitation for the next evening, although utterly unknown to her before. Something, he supposed, might be attributed to his connection with them, but yet he had never met with so much attention in the whole course of his life.
vi: Mr. Collins made Mrs. Bennet extremely grateful when he praised Mrs. Phillips' attitude and polite manners. He insisted that, except for Lady Catherine and her daughter, he had never met a more elegant woman, for she not only received him with the highest courtesy but also kindly invited him to visit the next evening, despite not having known him before. He could guess that it was due to his connection with the Bennet family, yet he was still very pleased because he had never been so noticed in his life.
tr: When they returned, Mr. Collins greatly pleased Mrs. Bennet by showering praises on Mrs. Philips's behavior and kindness. He said that, except for Lady Catherine and her daughter, he had never seen a more elegant lady in his life; she had not only received him with tremendous politeness but had also emphatically included him in the invitation for the following evening, even though she had never seen him before. Of course, their familial connection might have had some influence, but still, he had never received such attention in his life.
es: Collins praised Mrs. Bennet by commending the manners and education of Mrs. Philips. He assured that apart from Lady Catherine and her daughter, he had never seen a more elegant woman, for not only did she receive him with the utmost courtesy, but she also included him in the invitation for the next evening, despite being a complete stranger to her. Of course, he knew he should attribute it to his relationship with them, but nevertheless, he had never been treated with such kindness in his life.

en: CHAPTER XVI.
vi: Chapter 16
tr: Chapter XVI
es: CHAPTER XVI

en: AS no objection was made to the young people’s engagement with their aunt, and all Mr. Collins’s scruples of leaving  for a single evening during his visit were most steadily resisted, the coach conveyed him and his five cousins at a suitable hour to Meryton; and the girls had the pleasure of hearing, as they entered the drawing-room, that Mr. Wickham had accepted their uncle’s invitation, and was then in the house.
vi: Because no one objected to the girls gathering at their aunt's house, everyone opposed Mr. Collins' hesitation to leave Mr. and Mrs. Bennet during the visit, the carriage took him and his five cousins to Meryton. When they entered the living room, the girls were delighted to learn that Mr. Wickham had accepted their uncle's invitation and was currently in the house.
tr: Since there was no objection to the young people's agreement with their aunt, and Mr. Collins's complaints about not wanting to leave Mr. and Mrs. Bennet even for an evening were met with belief, the carriage took him and his five cousins to Meryton at a convenient time; as the girls entered the sitting room, they were delighted to learn that Mr. Wickham had accepted their uncle's invitation and was currently at home.
es: Since no objection was raised to the young women's commitment to their aunt and Mr. Collins's reservations about not leaving the Bennets for even a single evening during his visit were firmly rejected, at the appropriate time the carriage set off with him and his five cousins towards Meryton. Upon entering the Philips' drawing room, the girls had the satisfaction of learning that Wickham had accepted their uncle's invitation and was in the house.

en: When this information was given, and they had all taken their seats, Mr. Collins was at leisure to look around him and admire, and he was so much struck with the size and furniture of the apartment, that he declared he might almost have supposed himself in the small summer breakfast parlour at Rosings; a comparison that did not at first convey much gratification; but when Mrs. Philips understood from him what Rosings was, and who was its proprietor, when she had listened to the description of only one of Lady Catherine’s drawing-rooms, and found that the chimney-piece alone had cost eight hundred pounds, she felt all the force of the compliment, and would hardly have resented a comparison with the housekeeper’s room.
vi: When everyone had taken their seats, Mr. Collins gazed around absentmindedly and admired the surroundings, as he was quite impressed with the size and interior of the room, to the extent that he remarked he felt as if he were sitting in the summer dining room at Rosings.
tr: After this information was given and everyone was seated, Mr. Collins began to idly examine the surroundings; he was so impressed by the spaciousness and furnishing of the apartment that he almost declared he could mistake it for the small summer breakfast room at Rosings. Although this comparison did not initially garner much appreciation, once Mrs. Philips learned what Rosings was and who its owner was – upon hearing a description of just one of Lady Catherine's sitting rooms and that just the fireplace had cost eight hundred pounds – she felt the full force of the compliment, to the extent that she would no longer be offended even if it were compared to the servant's quarters.
es: After receiving this information, and when everyone had taken their seats, Collins was able to observe everything at his leisure; the dimensions and the furniture of the room caused him such admiration that he confessed to having believed he was in the summer dining room of Rosings.

en: In describing to her all the grandeur of Lady Catherine and her mansion, with occasional digressions in praise of his own humble abode, and the improvements it was receiving, he was happily employed until the gentlemen joined them; and he found in Mrs. Philips a very attentive listener, whose opinion of his consequence increased with what she heard, and who was resolving to retail it all among her neighbours as soon as she could. To the girls, who could not listen to their cousin, and who had nothing to do but to wish for an instrument, and examine their own indifferent imitations of china on the mantel-piece, the interval of waiting appeared very long. It was over at last, however. The gentlemen did approach: and when Mr. Wickham walked into the room, Elizabeth felt that she had neither been seeing him before, nor thinking of him since, with the smallest degree of unreasonable admiration. The officers of the ——shire were in general a very creditable, gentlemanlike set and the best of them were of the present party; but Mr, Wickham was as far beyond them all in person, countenance, air, and walk, as they were superior to the broad-faced stuffy uncle Philips, breathing port wine, who followed them into the room.
vi: At first, the comparison did not bring joy, but when Mrs. Philips understood where Rosings was and who owned it, when she heard him describe one of Lady Catherine's drawing rooms and learned that just the fireplace had cost eight hundred pounds, she immediately felt the full force of the compliment, and it would not have been bothersome if he had intended to compare it to the housekeeper's room. Until the young men arrived to sit with them, while describing all the splendor of Lady Catherine and her estate, occasionally digressing to praise his own humble Parsonage and its improvements, Mr. Collins found Mrs. Philips to be an attentive listener in conversation. The more she listened, the higher her impression of his status grew, and she intended to recount everything to her neighbors as soon as possible. For the young ladies, unable to hear him speak and with nothing to do but wait, the waiting time seemed excessively long. Finally, the young men arrived. When Mr. Wickham entered, Elizabeth felt as if she had either never met him before or had not thought of him since then, with a fleeting, inexplicable fondness. The officers were all reputable, elegant, and the best of them were present here; but Mr. Wickham stood out above all in person, face, manner, and bearing, just as they surpassed Mr. Philips, with his broad face, who at that moment was exhaling the scent of port wine as he followed them into the room.
tr: She was very happy to describe the splendor of Lady Catherine and her mansion, occasionally praising her own humble abode and the renovations she was undergoing, until the gentlemen joined them; Mrs. Philips was a very attentive listener for her; after hearing these, she found the young man even more important and decided to share this with her neighbors at the first opportunity. The girls, who couldn't listen to their cousins, lamented the lack of a piano, and had nothing to do but examine the fake porcelain they had decorated above the fireplace, found the waiting time very long. But it finally ended, of course. The gentlemen approached; when Mr. Wickham entered the room, Elizabeth felt that she was not at all wrong in her admiration for him when she had seen him before and since then. The officers of the -------shire regiment were generally very reasonable, gentlemanly men, and the best of them were at this party; but Mr. Wickham, with his appearance, face, demeanor, and walk, was far superior to all of them, just as the officers were superior to the broad-faced, dull, wine-breathed Mr. Philips who entered the room after them.
es: This comparison did not arouse any enthusiasm at first; but when Mrs. Philips heard from Collins' lips what Rosings was and who its owner was, when she heard the description of one of Lady Catherine's drawing rooms and learned that just the fireplace had cost eight hundred pounds, she appreciated the full value of that compliment and would hardly have been bothered if he had compared her drawing room to the housekeeper's room at the Bourghs'. Collins amused himself by telling Mrs. Philips all about Lady Catherine's grandeur and her mansion, occasionally mentioning his humble home and the improvements he was making to it, until the gentlemen arrived. Collins found in Mrs. Philips an attentive listener whose good opinion of the rector increased with everything he explained to her, and she was already thinking about telling her neighbors all about it as soon as possible. To the young ladies, who could not stand their cousin and had nothing else to do but wish for a musical instrument at hand and examine the china imitations on the mantelpiece, the wait was becoming too long. But finally, the gentlemen appeared. When Wickham entered the room, Elizabeth noticed that she had neither paid attention to him before nor remembered him afterward with sufficient admiration. The county garrison officers generally enjoyed extraordinary prestige; they were very handsome, and the best of them were now at the present gathering. But Wickham, with his gallantry, his ease, and his graceful walk, was as superior to them as they were to the stout Uncle Philips, who entered the room last, reeking of port wine.

en: “The officers of the ——shire”
vi: Mr. Wickham was the fortunate young man who caught the attention of almost all the ladies, while Elizabeth was the fortunate young woman who got to sit near him.
tr: The officers of the -------shire regiment were generally very reasonable, gentlemanly men, and the best of them were at this party; but Mr. Wickham, with his appearance, face, demeanor, and walk, was far superior to all of them, just as the officers were superior to the broad-faced, dull, wine-breathed Mr. Philips who entered the room after them.
es: Mr. Wickham was the fortunate man to whom almost all female eyes turned; and Elizabeth was the fortunate woman beside whom he decided to take a seat.

en: Mr. Wickham was the happy man towards whom almost every female eye was turned, and Elizabeth was the happy woman by whom he finally seated himself; and the agreeable manner in which he immediately fell into conversation, though it was only on its being a wet night, and on the probability of a rainy season, made her feel that the commonest, dullest, most threadbare topic might be rendered interesting by the skill of the speaker.
vi: His relaxed manner when he started a conversation, even if it was about a rainy night and with the potential of a rainy season, made her think that the most ordinary, boring, and old-fashioned topic could become interesting through a person with the gift of gab.
tr: Mr. Wickham was the lucky man who almost every woman's eyes were fixed upon, and Elizabeth soon became the lucky woman when the young man finally came and sat next to her; although he only talked about it being a rainy night and the possibility of a rainy season, the charm with which he started speaking immediately made Elizabeth think that even the most ordinary, most boring, most stale topic could become interesting with the speaker's skill.
es: Wickham initiated the conversation in such a pleasant manner, despite limiting himself to saying that the night was damp and that it would probably rain a lot throughout the season, that Elizabeth realized that the most common, trivial, and worn-out topics can be interesting if said skillfully.

en: With such rivals for the notice of the fair as Mr. Wickham and the officers, Mr. Collins seemed to sink into insignificance; to the young ladies he certainly was nothing; but he had still at intervals a kind listener in Mrs. Philips, and was, by her watchfulness, most abundantly supplied with coffee and muffin.
vi: With rivals like Mr. Wickham and the officers, Mr. Collins seemed to sink to a level of insignificance. To the young ladies, he was certainly nothing; but occasionally he had the polite Mrs. Philips to listen to him, and under her care, he was the guest most frequently invited for coffee and cake.
tr: When it came to attracting the attention of the fair sex, with rivals like Mr. Wickham and the officers, Mr. Collins began to sink into insignificance; he was already a nobody to the young ladies; nevertheless, Mrs. Philips occasionally became a good listener to him and, with her attentiveness, did not leave him without coffee and cake.
es: With rivals like Wickham and the other officers monopolizing the ladies' attention, Collins seemed to sink into insignificance. To the young women, he meant nothing. But Mrs. Philips still listened to him from time to time and made sure he never lacked coffee or pastries.

en: When the card tables were placed, he had an opportunity of obliging her, in return, by sitting down to whist.
vi: When the cards were laid out, he had the opportunity to respond to her invitation to join the whist game.
tr: When the game tables were set up, by sitting down to play whist, he also found an opportunity to express his feelings of gratitude towards her.
es: When the gaming tables were arranged, Collins saw an opportunity to return her attentions and sat down to play whist with her.

en: “I know little of the game at present,” said he, “but I shall be glad to improve myself; for in my situation of life——” Mrs. Philips was very thankful for his compliance, but could not wait for his reason.
vi: He said: - I don't know much about this way of playing, but I would be very happy to have the opportunity to learn more, given the circumstances of my life. Mrs. Philips thanked him for indulging her, but could not wait to hear his reason.
tr: "I know very little about the game yet," he said, "but I want to improve myself, because a person in my situation–" Mrs. Philips thanked him for his cooperation but did not want to hear the reason.
es: ––I know little about this game now ––he said to him––, but I would like to learn it better, due to my situation in life. Mrs. Philips thanked him for his condescension, but she could not understand those reasons.

en: Mr. Wickham did not play at whist, and with ready delight was he received at the other table between Elizabeth and Lydia. At first there seemed danger of Lydia’s engrossing him entirely, for she was a most determined talker; but being likewise extremely fond of lottery tickets, she soon grew too much interested in the game, too eager in making bets and exclaiming after prizes, to have attention for anyone in particular. Allowing for the common demands of the game, Mr. Wickham was therefore at leisure to talk to Elizabeth, and she was very willing to hear him, though what she chiefly wished to hear she could not hope to be told, the history of his acquaintance with Mr. Darcy. She dared not even mention that gentleman. Her curiosity, however, was unexpectedly relieved. Mr. Wickham began the subject himself. He inquired how far Netherfield was from Meryton; and, after receiving her answer, asked in a hesitating manner how long Mr. Darcy had been staying there.
vi: Mr. Wickham did not play whist, but was pleased to sit between Elizabeth and Lydia at the other table. At first, there was a risk that Lydia would monopolize his time because she talked incessantly, but since she was very fond of playing lottery tickets, she focused more on the game and paid no attention to anyone else. Thus, Mr. Wickham leisurely conversed with Elizabeth. She was willing to listen to him, although the main thing she wanted to hear, which was the reason for his acquaintance with Mr. Darcy, he did not mention. She did not even dare to mention his name. But soon, her curiosity was satisfied, as Mr. Wickham began the topic. He asked her how far Netherfield was from Meryton, and after hearing the answer, with a slight hesitation, he asked how long Mr. Darcy had been there. She replied:
tr: Mr. Wickham did not play whist and was gladly accepted between Elizabeth and Lydia at the other table. At first, there was a danger of Lydia overwhelming the man; she was a persistent talker; but since she was also extremely fond of lottery tickets, she soon got caught up in the game, investing money with such great enthusiasm that she couldn't pay attention to anyone else, and demanded her prize with loud cries. Thus, Mr. Wickham, adhering to the usual demands of the game, was free to talk to Elizabeth; Elizabeth was very eager to listen to him, but of course, what she most wanted to hear was something else – the story of his acquaintance with Mr. Darcy. She didn't even dare to mention it. Nevertheless, her curiosity was unexpectedly satisfied. Mr. Wickham brought up the subject himself. He asked how far Netherfield was from Meryton; after receiving Elizabeth's answer, he hesitated and then wanted to know how long Mr. Darcy had been staying there.
es: Wickham did not play whist and was received with genuine enthusiasm at the other table, between Elizabeth and Lydia. At first, it seemed there was a danger that Lydia would completely monopolize him, as she liked to talk incessantly, but since she was also very fond of the lottery, she soon focused all her interest on the game and was too busy betting and exclaiming when prizes were won to be distracted by anything else. As everyone was concentrated on the game, Wickham could dedicate his time to talking with Elizabeth, and she was eager to listen to him, although she had no hope that he would tell her what she most wanted to know, the story of his relationship with Darcy. She did not even dare to mention his name. However, her curiosity was unexpectedly satisfied. It was Mr. Wickham himself who brought up the subject. He asked how far it was from Meryton to Netherfield, and after hearing Elizabeth's response and a few seconds of hesitation, he also wanted to know how long Mr. Darcy had been there.

en: “About a month,” said Elizabeth; and then, unwilling to let the subject drop, added, “he is a man of very large property in Derbyshire, I understand.”
vi: - About a month. Then, not wanting the story to be left unfinished, she added: - I have been informed that he has a large estate in Derbyshire.
tr: "It has been about a month," said Elizabeth; then, to keep the matter from closing, she continued, "As far as I understand, he has a very large estate in Derbyshire."
es: ––About a month ––answered Elizabeth. And with eagerness that the topic wouldn't end there, he added: ––I believe that gentleman owns large estates in Derbyshire.

en: “Yes,” replied Wickham; “his estate there is a noble one. A clear ten thousand per annum. You could not have met with a person more capable of giving you certain information on that head than myself—for I have been connected with his family, in a particular manner, from my infancy.”
vi: Wickham replied: - Yes, his real estate is quite substantial. Up to ten thousand a year. You won't find anyone who can provide as much information about him as I can, because I have had a special relationship with his family since I was a child.
tr: "Yes," replied Wickham; – "he has a solid estate there. Ten thousand a year clear. You couldn't have come across anyone who could give you more information on that subject than me – because I have had a special relationship with his family since my childhood."
es: ––Yes ––replied Wickham––, his estate is significant, it provides him with ten thousand pounds annually. No one better than I could give you authentic information about Mr. Darcy, for I have been particularly connected with his family since my childhood.

en: Elizabeth could not but look surprised.
vi: Elizabeth could not hide her surprise.
tr: Elizabeth couldn't hide the astonishment on her face.
es: Elizabeth couldn't help but show her surprise.

en: “You may well be surprised, Miss Bennet, at such an assertion, after seeing, as you probably might, the very cold manner of our meeting yesterday. Are you much acquainted with Mr. Darcy?”
vi: - Elizabeth, you might be very surprised to hear me say this, after you must have noticed the cold attitude between the two of us when we met yesterday. Are you well acquainted with Mr. Darcy?
tr: "After seeing the cold atmosphere in our encounter yesterday, such a statement might certainly surprise you, Miss Bennet. –Do you know Mr. Darcy well?"
es: ––It will surprise you what I say, Miss Bennet, after having seen, as you probably did, the coldness of our meeting yesterday. Do you know Mr. Darcy well?

en: “As much as I ever wish to be,” cried Elizabeth, warmly. “I have spent four days in the same house with him, and I think him very disagreeable.”
vi: Elizabeth spoke harshly: - Close enough to the extent that I desire. I spent four days under the same roof with him, and because of that, I think he is a really unpleasant person.
tr: "Enough," cried Elizabeth in a warm voice. –"I spent four days in the same house with him and I find him quite unpleasant."
es: ––More than I would wish ––replied Elizabeth affectionately––. I have spent four days in the same house as him and I find him very unpleasant.

en: “I have no right to give my opinion,” said Wickham, “as to his being agreeable or otherwise. I am not qualified to form one. I have known him too long and too well to be a fair judge. It is impossible for me to be impartial. But I believe your opinion of him would in general astonish—and, perhaps, you would not express it quite so strongly anywhere else. Here you are in your own family.”
vi: Wickham said: - I do not have the right to give my opinion on whether he is pleasant or not. I am not qualified to give an opinion. I have known him for too long and too well to be impartial in judging him. I cannot remain unbiased. But I believe your opinion of him is surprisingly harsh – and perhaps elsewhere you would not speak so harshly. Here, you are with your family.
tr: "I have no right to state my opinion," said Wickham, "I cannot say whether she is charming or not. I am not authorized to give an opinion. I have known her for too long and too well to make a fair judgment. It is impossible for me to be impartial. But I believe that your opinion of her would surprise many people – though perhaps you would not express it so strongly elsewhere. After all, you are among family here."
es: ––I have no right to say whether he is or isn't disagreeable ––continued Mr. Wickham––. I am not the most suitable person for that. I have known him for too long and too well to be a fair judge. It would be impossible for me to be impartial. But I believe that the opinion you have of him would surprise anyone, and you might not express it so categorically anywhere else. Here you are among your own.

en: “Upon my word I say no more here than I might say in any house in the neighbourhood, except Netherfield. He is not at all liked in Hertfordshire. Everybody is disgusted with his pride. You will not find him more favourably spoken of by anyone.”
vi: - I assure you that here I am not exaggerating what I can say in any other house in the area, except at Netherfield. No one in Hertfordshire loves him. You will not find anyone who speaks well of him.
tr: "Well, I wouldn't say more about any house in this neighborhood than I would here, except for Netherfield. No one in Hertfordshire likes it. Everyone hates its pride. I don't think you'll hear anyone speaking well of it anywhere."
es: ––I give you my word that what I say here I would say in any other house in the neighborhood, except in Netherfield. Darcy has disgusted everyone with his pride. You will not find anyone who speaks well of him.

en: “I cannot pretend to be sorry,” said Wickham, after a short interruption, “that he or that any man should not be estimated beyond their deserts; but with him I believe it does not often happen. The world is blinded by his fortune and consequence, or frightened by his high and imposing manners, and sees him only as he chooses to be seen.”
vi: Wickham said: - I cannot pretend to regret that he or any other person should not be overestimated compared to their true worth, but with him, I believe this does not happen often. People are dazzled by his wealth and status, or intimidated by his elevated and dignified demeanor, so they see him the way he wants to be seen.
tr: "I can't say I'm sorry," said Wickham, after a brief hesitation, "no one should be given more credit than they deserve; but in his case, I suppose that's not happening. Anyone who sees him is blinded by his wealth and power, or they are intimidated by his arrogant, oppressive demeanor and see him only as he wants to be seen."
es: ––I cannot pretend that I am sorry ––said Wickham after a brief pause––. I do not feel that he or anyone else should be esteemed solely for their merits, but with Darcy, it usually does not happen that way. People are blinded by his fortune and his importance or fear him for his distinguished and haughty manners, and they see him only as he wishes to be seen.

en: “I should take him, even on my slight acquaintance, to be an ill-tempered man.”
vi: - Even though I don't know him well, I still consider him to be a person with a bad temper.
tr: "Even though I barely know him, I can say that he is a grumpy man."
es: ––Well, despite the little I know him, I consider him a bad person.

en: Wickham only shook his head.
vi: Wickham just shook his head.
tr: Wickham just nodded.
es: Wickham merely nodded his head.

en: “I wonder,” said he, at the next opportunity of speaking, “whether he is likely to be in this country much longer.”
vi: He said: - I wonder how long he will stay here.
tr: "I wonder," he said, when he got the chance to speak again, "if he will stay around here much longer?"
es: Then he added: "I wonder if he plans to stay in this county for long."

en: “I do not at all know; but I heard nothing of his going away when I was at Netherfield. I hope your plans in favour of the ——shire will not be affected by his being in the neighbourhood.”
vi: - I don't know anything, but when I was at Netherfield, I didn't hear anything about him leaving. I hope his presence around here won't affect your plans to join the unit here.
tr: "I have no idea; but I didn't hear anything about him leaving while I was at Netherfield. I hope your plans for ------shire won't change because of his presence in the area."
es: ––I have no idea; but I didn't hear anything about him leaving while he was at Netherfield. I hope Darcy's presence won't alter his plans to stay at the county garrison.

en: “Oh no—it is not for me to be driven away by Mr. Darcy. If he wishes to avoid seeing me he must go. We are not on friendly terms, and it always gives me pain to meet him, but I have no reason for avoiding him but what I might proclaim to all the world—a sense of very great ill-usage, and most painful regrets at his being what he is. His father, Miss Bennet, the late Mr. Darcy, was one of the best men that ever breathed, and the truest friend I ever had; and I can never be in company with this Mr. Darcy without being grieved to the soul by a thousand tender recollections. His behaviour to myself has been scandalous; but I verily believe I could forgive him anything and everything, rather than his disappointing the hopes and disgracing the memory of his father.”
vi: - Ah, no – it’s not that I will be shunned by Mr. Darcy. If he wants to avoid meeting me, he must leave. The two of us are not friends; I always feel uncomfortable when I see him, but I have no reason to avoid him except for what I can publicly declare: a sense of mistreatment, along with the sorrowful regret of seeing him in this situation. Miss Bennet, his father passed away, was one of the best men who ever lived on this earth, and also one of my most trusted confidants, so I cannot be close to this Mr. Darcy without my heart aching with a thousand tender memories. His attitude towards me is scandalous, but honestly, I believe that I can forgive him for everything, rather than let him disappoint all hopes and bring shame to his father's spirit.
tr: "No, never! –Mr. Darcy cannot send me away. If he wishes to avoid seeing me, he must be the one to go. We are not on good terms; seeing him always brings me pain, but I have no reason to avoid him, and I can tell the whole world why – a terrible sense of being wronged and agonizing remorse towards him. His father, Miss Bennet, the late Mr. Darcy, was one of the kindest men to ever walk the earth and was my truest friend in life; when I see this Mr. Darcy, countless tender memories pierce my heart. His behavior towards me is utterly disgraceful; believe me, I can forgive him for everything but never for shattering his father's hopes and tarnishing his memory."
es: ––Of course not. I will not be the one to leave because of Mr. Darcy, and it always saddens me to see him, but I have only one reason to avoid him and I can proclaim it in front of everyone: a painful regret for his mistreatment and for being the way he is. His father, Miss Bennet, the late Mr. Darcy, was the best of men and my best friend; I cannot speak with Darcy without my heart breaking with a thousand tender memories. His conduct towards me has been improper; but I sincerely confess that I would forgive him everything except that he has frustrated his father's hopes and dishonored his memory.

en: Elizabeth found the interest of the subject increase, and listened with all her heart; but the delicacy of it prevented further inquiry.
vi: Elizabeth felt more interested in the matter and listened with all her heart, but due to delicate reasons, she could not inquire further.
tr: Elizabeth felt that the matter was becoming even more interesting and listened with full attention; but the sensitivity of the subject prevented her from asking questions.
es: Elizabeth found that her interest was increasing and she listened with all her senses, but the delicate nature of the matter prevented her from asking more questions.

en: Mr. Wickham began to speak on more general topics, Meryton, the neighbourhood, the society, appearing highly pleased with all that he had yet seen, and speaking of the latter, especially, with gentle but very intelligible gallantry.
vi: Mr. Wickham began to talk about more general topics, Meryton, the surrounding area, through social interactions, revealing his appreciation for what he had observed; and with a charming and gentle manner that was very easy to understand, he particularly spoke about social relations.
tr: Mr. Wickham began to talk about more general subjects, Meryton, the surroundings, and the people; he seemed to be very impressed with what he had seen; he spoke of the people in particular with a courteous but very familiar compliment.
es: Wickham began to talk about more general topics: Meryton, the neighborhood, the society; and he seemed extremely pleased with what he already knew, speaking especially of the latter with gentle but understandable gallantry.

en: “It was the prospect of constant society, and good society,” he added, “which was my chief inducement to enter the ——shire. I know it to be a most respectable, agreeable corps; and my friend Denny tempted me further by his account of their present quarters, and the very great attentions and excellent acquaintance Meryton had procured them. Society, I own, is necessary to me. I have been a disappointed man, and my spirits will not bear solitude. I must have employment and society. A military life is not what I was intended for, but circumstances have now made it eligible. The church ought to have been my profession—I was brought up for the church; and I should at this time have been in possession of a most valuable living, had it pleased the gentleman we were speaking of just now.”
vi: He added: - It was precisely because I thought of stable social relations and good relationships that I joined the militia. I know this is the most respectable, most pleasant force, and my friend Denny further encouraged me through the way he spoke about the residential area, along with the utmost care and wonderful relationships in Meryton. I confess that I desire social relationships. I have been disappointed before, and my temperament cannot endure loneliness. I must have work and relationships. Military life was not something I aimed for before, but circumstances now make me qualified. The church should have been my professional environment. I was raised for the church; by now I would have had the most valuable life, if the person I just mentioned had accepted,
tr: "The main reason I joined this regiment," he added, "was that it promised a solid community of people, an elite environment. I knew it was a very respectable, reasonable regiment; when my friend Denny described their current headquarters, the close interest Meryton showed them, and the tremendous camaraderie, I was completely captivated. The environment is essential for me. I am a disappointed man; my soul cannot endure loneliness. I need work and friends. I did not aim for a military life, but circumstances led to it. My profession should have been the church – I was trained for the church and would now have the most valuable church, had the gentleman we mentioned been willing."
es: ––The main incentive for my joining the county garrison ––continued Wickham–– was the hope of being in constant contact with society, and people of good society. I knew it was a very respected and pleasant Corps, and my friend Denny tempted me further by describing his current residence and the great attentions and excellent friendships he has found in Meryton. I confess that I need a bit of social life. I am a disappointed man and my state of mind could not bear solitude. I need occupation and company. It was not my intention to join military life, but current circumstances made me choose it. The Church should have been my profession; I was educated for it and today I would be in possession of a valuable rectory if it had not been for the gentleman I was talking about a moment ago.

en: “Indeed!”
vi: - Really?
tr: "Really?""
es: ––Really?

en: “Yes—the late Mr. Darcy bequeathed me the next presentation of the best living in his gift. He was my godfather, and excessively attached to me. I cannot do justice to his kindness. He meant to provide for me amply, and thought he had done it; but when the living fell, it was given elsewhere.”
vi: - Yes: Darcy's late father gave me the highest ecclesiastical income among what he left for me. He was my godfather, very attached to me. I didn't know how to repay his kindness. He intended to provide me with ample means of living and thought he had accomplished this, but when the income was reduced, I did not receive it.
tr: "Yes – the late Mr. Darcy bequeathed to me the best parish under his administration, and I was to take charge of it when it became vacant. He was my godfather and was extremely attached to me. No amount of praise can do justice to his kindness. He wanted to provide me with a good livelihood, and he thought he had; but when the parish became vacant, it was given to someone else."
es: ––Yes; the late Mr. Darcy had arranged for me to be presented with the best ecclesiastical benefice on his estates. He was my godfather and loved me dearly. I can never do justice to his kindness. He wanted to leave me well situated, and he believed he had done so; but when the position became vacant, it was granted to someone else.

en: “Good heavens!” cried Elizabeth; “but how could that be? How could his will be disregarded? Why did not you seek legal redress?”
vi: Elizabeth exclaimed: - Oh no! How could this happen? How could people not follow the will? Why didn't you seek legal intervention?
tr: "Oh my God!" cried Elizabeth; "but how can this be? –How can the will be disregarded? –Why didn't you pursue legal action?"
es: ––My God! ––exclaimed Elizabeth––. But how could that be? How could they contradict his will? Why didn't you seek justice?

en: “There was just such an informality in the terms of the bequest as to give me no hope from law. A man of honour could not have doubted the intention, but Mr. Darcy chose to doubt it—or to treat it as a merely conditional recommendation, and to assert that I had forfeited all claim to it by extravagance, imprudence, in short, anything or nothing. Certain it is that the living became vacant two years ago, exactly as I was of an age to hold it, and that it was given to another man; and no less certain is it, that I cannot accuse myself of having really done anything to deserve to lose it. I have a warm unguarded temper, and I may perhaps have sometimes spoken my opinion of him, and to him, too freely. I can recall nothing worse. But the fact is, that we are very different sort of men, and that he hates me.”
vi: - There is one clause in the will that leaves me with no hope from the law. A man of honor cannot doubt the intention, but Mr. Darcy deliberately doubts, or considers it merely a conditional proposal, and asserts that I have forfeited all rights in it through reckless extravagance, something like that. What is certain is that the income was gone two years ago, at the time I came of age to benefit from it. This amount was assigned to someone else. It is also certain that I cannot convict myself of having actually done anything to deserve disinheritance. I have a hot temper, cannot restrain myself; perhaps I occasionally said something too loose about him, or to him. I do not remember doing anything worse. But the truth is, we belong to two very different types of people, and he hates me.
tr: "There was something unofficial in the conditions of the will, it didn't give me a chance in the eyes of the law. An honorable man couldn't doubt the intention here, but Mr. Darcy chose to doubt – or thought it was a conditional recommendation and claimed that I had renounced all my rights, saying I was extravagant, saying I was imprudent – whatever came to his mind. That church also became vacant two years ago, just when I was of age to take over, and it was given to someone else, that's certain; but it's also certain that I can't accuse myself of having done anything to deserve losing that church. I have a warm, unprotected nature; I may have sometimes spoken freely about my opinions of him, I may have even said something to him. I can't think of anything worse. But the truth is, we are very different kinds of people and he hates me."
es: ––There was so much informality in the terms of the legacy that the law would not have given me any hope. A man of honor would not have doubted the intention of those terms; but Darcy preferred to doubt it or take it as a merely conditional recommendation and asserted that I had lost all my rights due to my extravagance and imprudence; in short, either for one reason or another, the fact is that the rectory became vacant two years ago, just when I was old enough to occupy it, and it was given to someone else; and it is no less true that I cannot blame myself for having done anything to deserve losing it. I have a fiery temperament, I am indiscreet, and perhaps I have expressed my opinion about Darcy a few times, and even to him, with excessive frankness. I do not remember anything else I could be accused of. But the fact is that we are very different and that he hates me.

en: “This is quite shocking! He deserves to be publicly disgraced.”
vi: - It's terrible! He should have been publicly exposed.
tr: "I was shocked! –They deserve to be humiliated in front of everyone."
es: ––It's shameful! He deserves to be discredited in public.

en: “Some time or other he will be—but it shall not be by me. Till I can forget his father, I can never defy or expose him.”
vi: - One day you will be exposed, but not by me. As long as I cannot forget your father, I cannot challenge or accuse you.
tr: "It will eventually happen anyway – but I won't be the one to do it. I can't confront him until he can forget his father, I can't expose him."
es: ––One day or another his time will come, but it won't be me who discredits him. As long as I can't forget his father, I will never be able to challenge or unmask him.

en: Elizabeth honoured him for such feelings, and thought him handsomer than ever as he expressed them.
vi: Elizabeth respected him for these thoughts, thinking he looked more handsome when he expressed them.
tr: Elizabeth praised him for these feelings, and thought he looked more handsome than ever while expressing them.
es: Elizabeth honored him for such sentiments and found him more attractive than ever as he expressed them.

en: “But what,” said she, after a pause, “can have been his motive? what can have induced him to behave so cruelly?”
vi: After a moment of silence, she said: - But what is his motivation? What could make him act so ruthlessly?
tr: "Mom," he said, after a moment's hesitation, "what could be the reason? –what could have driven him to act so cruelly?"
es: ––But ––he continued after a pause––, what could be the reason? What could have induced him to act with such cruelty?

en: “A thorough, determined dislike of me—a dislike which I cannot but attribute in some measure to jealousy. Had the late Mr. Darcy liked me less, his son might have borne with me better; but his father’s uncommon attachment to me irritated him, I believe, very early in life. He had not a temper to bear the sort of competition in which we stood—the sort of preference which was often given me.”
vi: - He hates me intensely, and I believe it is due to jealousy. If the old man loved me less, his son might have treated me better. But I believe that the unusual attachment between the old man and me made him angry from the very beginning. He did not have enough composure to accept the rivalry between the two of us, to accept the favoritism shown towards me.
tr: "A deep, resolute hatred towards me – a hatred that I involuntarily attributed to a certain degree of jealousy. The late Mr. Darcy might have treated me better if his father had loved me less: but it seems to me that his father's extraordinary attachment to me disturbed him even as a child. He was not of a nature to endure the competition we were in – a competition in which I was always the preferred one."
es: ––A deep and energetic antipathy towards me that I can only attribute to jealousy to a certain extent. If the late Mr. Darcy had not been so fond of me, his son would have tolerated me better. But the extraordinary affection that his father felt for me irritated him, I believe, from his earliest childhood. He did not have the character to withstand the kind of rivalry in which we found ourselves, nor the preference that his father often showed me.

en: “I had not thought Mr. Darcy so bad as this—though I have never liked him, I had not thought so very ill of him—I had supposed him to be despising his fellow-creatures in general, but did not suspect him of descending to such malicious revenge, such injustice, such inhumanity as this!”
vi: - I did not think that Mr. Darcy could be so wicked; although I never liked him, I did not think too badly of him. I guessed that he just generally disliked others, but I did not expect him to stoop to such malicious revenge, such injustice, such inhumanity!
tr: "I never imagined Mr. Darcy could be so bad – although I never liked him, I did not expect him to be this bad. –I thought he generally looked down on people, but I never suspected he could stoop to such heartless vindictiveness, such injustice, such cruelty."
es: He did not have the character to withstand the kind of rivalry in which we found ourselves, nor the preference that his father often showed me.

en: After a few minutes’ reflection, however, she continued, “I do remember his boasting one day, at Netherfield, of the implacability of his resentments, of his having an unforgiving temper. His disposition must be dreadful.”
vi: After a few minutes of thinking, she continued: - Actually, at Netherfield the other day, I remember hearing him boast about his unappeasable irritability and his unwillingness to forgive. His temperament is truly dreadful.
tr: After thinking for a few minutes, he continued– "I remember, one day at Netherfield, he was boasting that he had an unforgiving nature, that his resentment never passed. He must be a terrible person."
es: ––I remember that one day, in Netherfield, he was boasting about the relentlessness of his feelings and having an unforgiving character. His way of being is dreadful.

en: “I will not trust myself on the subject,” replied Wickham; “I can hardly be just to him.”
vi: Wickham replied: - I am not confident enough to talk about this. I find it difficult to be impartial in judging him.
tr: "I cannot trust myself on this matter," replied Wickham; "it is difficult for me to be fair to him."
es: ––I must not speak of this topic, replied Wickham––; I find it difficult to be fair with him.

en: Elizabeth was again deep in thought, and after a time exclaimed, “To treat in such a manner the godson, the friend, the favourite of his father!” She could have added, “A young man, too, like you, whose very countenance may vouch for your being amiable.” But she contented herself with—“And one, too, who had probably been his own companion from childhood, connected together, as I think you said, in the closest manner.”
vi: Elizabeth sank deep into thought again, and after a moment she exclaimed: - To treat someone in such a manner, the godson, the friend, the one favored by the father! She could have added: "A young man, like you, with a face that could be called charming," but she only said: - And perhaps also a close companion from his youth, the closest relationship, as he said.
tr: Elizabeth once again fell into deep thoughts and after a while couldn't hold herself back: "To treat a godson, a friend, someone his father loved in such a way!" –She was about to add, "and to a young man like you, whose beauty is proof of his goodness," –but she settled for saying, "and to someone who is probably your childhood friend, with whom you have close ties according to what you say!"
es: Elizabeth reflected again and after a few moments exclaimed: ––To treat the godson, the friend, the father's favorite in that way! He could have added: "To a young man, moreover, like you, whose face alone offers ample proof of your kindness." But he limited himself to saying: ––To a man who was surely the companion of his childhood and with whom, as I believe you have said, he had close ties.

en: “We were born in the same parish, within the same park; the greatest part of our youth was passed together: inmates of the same house, sharing the same amusements, objects of the same parental care. My father began life in the profession which your uncle, Mr. Philips, appears to do so much credit to; but he gave up everything to be of use to the late Mr. Darcy, and devoted all his time to the care of the Pemberley property. He was most highly esteemed by Mr. Darcy, a most intimate, confidential friend. Mr. Darcy often acknowledged himself to be under the greatest obligations to my father’s active superintendence; and when, immediately before my father’s death, Mr. Darcy gave him a voluntary promise of providing for me, I am convinced that he felt it to be as much a debt of gratitude to him as of affection to myself.”
vi: - We were born in the same parish, in the same garden, living together for most of our childhood; we stayed in the same dormitory, shared the same pleasures, and were cared for by the same parents. My father started his life with the same profession as your uncle Philips, but he gave it all up to work for Mr. Darcy, dedicating all his time to taking care of the Pemberly estate. He was greatly respected by Mr. Darcy, and he was also the closest and most trustworthy person in his household. Mr. Darcy often acknowledged that he owed a deep debt of gratitude for my father's diligent care. Just before my father passed away, Mr. Darcy voluntarily promised him that it was both out of a sense of deep debt to him and affection for me.
tr: "We were born in the same village, under the same grove; much of our youth was spent together; we were people of the same house, shared the same amusements, and experienced the same parental love. My father started in the same profession that I believe your brother-in-law Mr. Philips is now pursuing with great success – but he left everything to be of service to the late Mr. Darcy and dedicated all his time to managing the Pemberley estate. He was held in high esteem by Mr. Darcy, being his close friend and confidant. Mr. Darcy often said himself how much he felt indebted to my father's active management; just before my father's death, when Mr. Darcy voluntarily promised to look after me, I believed it was as much out of gratitude to my father as it was out of affection for me."
es: ––We were born in the same parish, on the same estate; we spent most of our youth together, living in the same house, sharing games, and being the object of the same parental care. My father started in the profession in which it seems his uncle, Mr. Philips, has achieved so much prestige; but he left it all to serve Mr. Darcy and dedicated all his time to managing the Pemberley estate. Mr. Darcy held him in high esteem and he was his trusted man and closest friend. Mr. Darcy himself often acknowledged that he owed much to my father's active supervision, and when, shortly before he died, Mr. Darcy spontaneously promised to take care of me, I am convinced he did so to repay my father a debt of gratitude as well as out of the affection he had for me.

en: “How strange!” cried Elizabeth. “How abominable! I wonder that the very pride of this Mr. Darcy has not made him just to you. If from no better motive, that he should not have been too proud to be dishonest,—for dishonesty I must call it.”
vi: Elizabeth exclaimed: - How strange! How disgusting! I wonder if it was pride that made him treat you like that. If not for a greater motive, I think he wouldn't have been too proud to become dishonest – because I must call it dishonesty.
tr: "How strange!" cried Elizabeth. "How abominable! –This Mr. Darcy's pride prevented him from being fair to you! –Even if not driven by a better impulse, his pride should not have allowed him to act so basely –because I call what he did base."
es: ––How strange! ––exclaimed Elizabeth––. How abominable! It astonishes me that Mr. Darcy's own pride hasn't compelled him to be just with you. Because, even if only for that reason, he is too proud not to be honorable; and dishonesty is what I must call what he has done to you.

en: “It is wonderful,” replied Wickham; “for almost all his actions may be traced to pride; and pride has often been his best friend. It has connected him nearer with virtue than any other feeling. But we are none of us consistent; and in his behaviour to me there were stronger impulses even than pride.”
vi: Wickham replied: - That is wonderful, because almost all of his actions stem from pride, and pride is often his closest friend. It has connected him closer to virtue than any other feeling. But none of us are consistent; and in his attitude towards me, there are stronger motives than pride.
tr: "Great," answered Wickham, "because almost all of his actions can be attributed to pride; – and pride is often his best friend. His pride has made him closer to virtue than to other feelings. But none of us are consistent; in his behavior towards me, there were impulses even stronger than pride."
es: It's curious ––answered Wickham––, because almost all of his actions have been guided by pride, which has often been his best advisor. For him, it is more connected to virtue than any other feeling. But neither of us are consistent; and in his behavior towards me, there were impulses even stronger than pride.

en: “Can such abominable pride as his have ever done him good?”
vi: - Could it be that such disgusting pride has ever helped him do good work?
tr: "I wonder if he ever saw any benefit from such a vile pride?"" "Yes.
es: ––Is it possible that such a detestable pride as his has ever led him to do some good?

en: “Yes; it has often led him to be liberal and generous; to give his money freely, to display hospitality, to assist his tenants, and relieve the poor. Family pride, and filial pride, for he is very proud of what his father was, have done this. Not to appear to disgrace his family, to degenerate from the popular qualities, or lose the influence of the Pemberley House, is a powerful motive. He has also brotherly pride, which, with some brotherly affection, makes him a very kind and careful guardian of his sister; and you will hear him generally cried up as the most attentive and best of brothers.”
vi: - Yes, of course. Pride often makes him generous and chivalrous – to freely distribute money, to demonstrate hospitality, to support tenants, to help the poor. Pride in his family, pride in filial piety drove these actions, because he is very proud of his father. Not revealing it in a way that would disgrace the family, such as degrading common values, or diminishing the influence of the Pemberley house, all these are strong motivations. He is also proud of his kinship which, with a certain brotherly love, has made him a very kind and careful guardian of his sister. You could hear people praising him as the most caring and best brother among his siblings.
tr: That pride often makes him tolerant and generous, –he spends his money lavishly, shows hospitality, supports his tenants, and feeds the poor. It was family pride, and the pride of being a son that did this –because he was very proud of his father. Not doing anything to disgrace his family, not deviating from popular traits, not losing the influence of Pemberley Manor, this is a strong impulse. There is also the pride of being a brother, which, combined with brotherly love, has made him a tender and attentive guardian of his sister; you hear from everyone that he is the most sensitive, the best brother."
es: ––Yes; it has often led him to be liberal and generous, to give his money freely, to be hospitable, to help his tenants, and to aid the poor. Family pride, his pride as a son, because he is very proud of what his father was, has made him act in this way. The desire to show that he did not fall short of his own, that he was no less esteemed than they were, and that he did not diminish the influence of the house of Pemberley, was a powerful motive for him. He also has a brotherly pride which, combined with some fraternal affection, has made him a most kind and solicitous guardian of Miss Darcy, and you will often hear it said that he is considered the most attentive and best of brothers.

en: “What sort of a girl is Miss Darcy?”
vi: - And what kind of person is Miss Darcy?
tr: "What kind of girl is Miss Darcy?""
es: ––What kind of girl is Miss Darcy?

en: He shook his head. “I wish I could call her amiable. It gives me pain to speak ill of a Darcy; but she is too much like her brother,—very, very proud. As a child, she was affectionate and pleasing, and extremely fond of me; and I have devoted hours and hours to her amusement. But she is nothing to me now. She is a handsome girl, about fifteen or sixteen, and, I understand, highly accomplished. Since her father’s death her home has been London, where a lady lives with her, and superintends her education.”
vi: He shook his head: -I wish I could say she was charming. I feel sad speaking ill of a member of the Darcy family. But she is just like her brother, proud, very proud. When she was a child, she was affectionate and pleasant, and she was very fond of me; I spent a lot of time playing with her. But now, to her, I am nothing. She is a pretty girl, about fifteen or sixteen, and as far as I know, she has quite a few talents. Since her father passed away, she has been living in London, with a lady who stays with her and acts as her governess.
tr: He nodded his head. –"I wish I could call her cute. It pains me to speak ill of a Darcy. But she is just like her brother, –very, very proud. As a child, she was friendly, sweet, and very fond of me; I spent hours entertaining her. But now she means nothing to me. A beautiful girl, fifteen or sixteen years old, and from what I understand, quite talented. Since her father's death, her home has been in London, where a lady stays with her and oversees her education."
es: Wickham nodded. ––I wish I could say she is charming. It pains me to speak ill of a Darcy. But now she resembles her brother too much, she is very proud. As a child, she was very affectionate and accommodating and had great affection for me. Oh, the hours I have spent entertaining her! But now she is indifferent to me. She is a beautiful girl of fifteen or sixteen years, I believe very well-educated. Since her father's death, she has been living in London with a governess.

en: After many pauses and many trials of other subjects, Elizabeth could not help reverting once more to the first, and saying,—
vi: After many moments of silence and several attempts to change the subject, Elizabeth couldn't help but return to the original topic. She said:
tr: After many hesitations and trying many other topics, Elizabeth couldn't help but return to the first topic once again:
es: After many pauses and many attempts to talk about other topics, Elizabeth could not help but return to the first subject, and said:

en: “I am astonished at his intimacy with Mr. Bingley. How can Mr. Bingley, who seems good-humour itself, and is, I really believe, truly amiable, be in friendship with such a man? How can they suit each other? Do you know Mr. Bingley?”
vi: - I am surprised by the friendship between Darcy and Mr. Bingley! How can Mr. Bingley, who seems quite cheerful and genuinely friendly, as I believe, be friends with someone like Darcy? Do you know anything about Mr. Bingley?
tr: "I am surprised at his intimacy with Mr. Bingley! How can Mr. Bingley, who seems to be a good-natured and truly charming person, be friends with such a man? How can they be compatible with each other? –Do you know Mr. Bingley?"
es: ––What amazes me is his friendship with Mr. Bingley. How can Mr. Bingley, who is the very embodiment of good humor, and is, I am convinced, truly kind, have anything to do with a man like Mr. Darcy? How can they get along? Do you know Mr. Bingley?

en: “Not at all.”
vi: - Absolutely not.
tr: "No."
es: ––No, I don't know him.

en: “He is a sweet-tempered, amiable, charming man. He cannot know what Mr. Darcy is.”
vi: - He is a young man with a gentle, charming, and captivating personality. He cannot understand what kind of person Darcy is.
tr: "He is a sweet, charming, polite man. She must not have recognized Mr. Darcy."
es: ––He is a charming man, kind, with a sweet disposition. You must not know what Mr. Darcy is really like.

en: “Probably not; but Mr. Darcy can please where he chooses. He does not want abilities. He can be a conversible companion if he thinks it worth his while. Among those who are at all his equals in consequence, he is a very different man from what he is to the less prosperous. His pride never deserts him; but with the rich he is liberal-minded, just, sincere, rational, honourable, and, perhaps, agreeable,—allowing something for fortune and figure.”
vi: - It may be so, but Mr. Darcy can please others when he wants to. He is not very likely to. He can be a companion to socialize with if he thinks it benefits him. Among those of his own status, he becomes a completely different person compared to when he associates with those of lower status. He is always proud, but with the wealthy, he has a liberal, fair, honest, just, straightforward, and perhaps pleasant demeanor – this is in addition to his wealth and appearance.
tr: "Probably; but Mr. Darcy can be pleasant when he chooses to be. He is not without talent. If he thinks it worth his time, he can be quite engaging. Among those whose fortunes are equal to his own, he is a very different person than he is among the poor. His pride never leaves him: but when he is with the wealthy, he is liberal-minded, fair, sincere, sensible, honest, and perhaps even charming – of course, one must give credit where credit is due."
es: ––Probably not; but Mr. Darcy knows how to please when he feels like it. He doesn't need to make an effort. He can be a pleasant conversationalist if he thinks it's worth his while. Among people of his own rank, he is very different from how he is with those of lower status. Pride never leaves him, but with the wealthy, he adopts a liberal mindset; he is fair, sincere, reasonable, honorable, and perhaps even pleasant, partly due to his fortune and good looks.

en: The whist party soon afterwards breaking up, the players gathered round the other table, and Mr. Collins took his station between his cousin Elizabeth and Mrs. Philips. The usual inquiries as to his success were made by the latter. It had not been very great; he had lost every point; but when Mrs. Philips began to express her concern thereupon, he assured her, with much earnest gravity, that it was not of the least importance; that he considered the money as a mere trifle, and begged she would not make herself uneasy.
vi: The whist card game table then dispersed, and the card players gathered around another table, with Mr. Collins sitting between Elizabeth and Mrs. Philips. He lost every point, but when Mrs. Philips expressed concern, he solemnly reassured her that it did not matter at all, that he regarded money as a trivial matter, and asked her not to worry. He said:
tr: The whist party ended shortly after; the players gathered around the other table; Mr. Collins took his place between his cousin Elizabeth and Mrs. Philips. Mrs. Philips asked the usual questions about his success. It had not gone very well; he had lost every point; but when Mrs. Philips began to express her regrets, he said with dignity that it did not matter at all, that he did not value money, and asked her not to feel uncomfortable.
es: Shortly after, the whist game ended and the players gathered around the other table. Collins positioned himself between his cousin Elizabeth and Mrs. Philips. The latter asked him the usual questions about the outcome of the game. It was not much; he had lost all the points. But when Mrs. Philips began to tell him how sorry she was, Collins assured her with the utmost seriousness that it did not matter and that money was the least of his concerns, begging her not to worry about it.

en: “I know very well, madam,” said he, “that when persons sit down to a card table they must take their chance of these things,—and happily I am not in such circumstances as to make five shillings any object. There are, undoubtedly, many who could not say the same; but, thanks to Lady Catherine de Bourgh, I am removed far beyond the necessity of regarding little matters.”
vi: - Madam, I am well aware that when one sits down at a card table, they must accept the risks involved, and I am fortunate not to be in circumstances where I have to count every penny. Surely, many would disagree, but thanks to Lady Catherine de Bourgh, I do not have to worry about such trivial matters.
tr: "I know this very well, madam," he said, "when people sit at the gambling table, they try their luck – thankfully, I am not in a position to bet five shillings. Undoubtedly, there are many who cannot say the same, but thanks to Lady Catherine de Bourgh, I do not need to concern myself with such small matters."
es: ––I know very well, madam ––he said––, that when one sits at a gaming table, one must submit to chance, and fortunately I am not in circumstances to have to worry about five shillings. Undoubtedly there are many who cannot say the same, but thanks to Lady Catherine de Bourgh, I am far from having to give importance to such trifles.

en: Mr. Wickham’s attention was caught; and after observing Mr. Collins for a few moments, he asked Elizabeth in a low voice whether her relations were very intimately acquainted with the family of De Bourgh.
vi: The remark caught Mr. Wickham's attention. After observing Mr. Collins for a while, he quietly asked Elizabeth about the relationship between Mr. Collins and the De Bourgh family.
tr: Mr. Wickham's eyes fell on Mr. Collins; after watching him for a few seconds, he asked Elizabeth in a low voice if her relative was well acquainted with the de Bourgh family.
es: Wickham caught his attention, and after watching Collins for a few minutes, he quietly asked Elizabeth if her relative was a friend of the Bourgh family.

en: “Lady Catherine de Bourgh,” she replied, “has very lately given him a living. I hardly know how Mr. Collins was first introduced to her notice, but he certainly has not known her long.”
vi: She replied: - Lady Catherine de Bourgh recently provided him with an ecclesiastical income. I am not sure how he was first introduced to her, but he certainly hasn't known her for long.
tr: "Lady Catherine de Bourgh," answered Elizabeth, "has recently given him a church. I don't know how Mr. Collins was introduced to her, but it's clear he hasn't known her for long."
es: Lady Catherine de Bourgh has recently given him a rectory ––he replied––. I don't know very well who introduced them, but he hasn't known her for very long.
