en: “You know of course that Lady Catherine de Bourgh and Lady Anne Darcy were sisters; consequently that she is aunt to the present Mr. Darcy.”
vi: - Surely you know that Lady Catherine de Bourgh and Lady Anne Darcy are sisters, so she is Mr. Darcy's aunt.
tr: "Of course you must know, Lady Catherine de Bourgh and Lady Anne Darcy were sisters; that is, the current Mr. Darcy's aunts.""
es: ––I suppose you know that Lady Catherine de Bourgh and Lady Anne Darcy were sisters, and that, consequently, Lady Catherine is the aunt of the current Mr. Darcy.

en: “No, indeed, I did not. I knew nothing at all of Lady Catherine’s connections. I never heard of her existence till the day before yesterday.”
vi: - Actually, I don't know. I don't know anything about Mrs. Catherine's relationships. I only heard about her the day before yesterday.
tr: "No, I truly didn't know. –I have no knowledge about Lady Catherine's relatives. Until the day before, I was unaware of their existence."
es: ––No, no idea; I didn't know anything about Lady Catherine's family. I had no notion of her existence until two days ago.

en: “Her daughter, Miss de Bourgh, will have a very large fortune, and it is believed that she and her cousin will unite the two estates.”
vi: - Your daughter, Miss De Bourgh, will have a very large fortune, and it is believed that she and her cousin, Mr. Darcy, will unite the two estates.
tr: "It is believed that Miss de Bourgh, who will inherit a large fortune, is intended to unite her wealth with that of her cousin.""
es: ––Her daughter, Miss de Bourgh, will inherit a vast fortune, and it is said that she and her cousin will unite the two estates.

en: This information made Elizabeth smile, as she thought of poor Miss Bingley. Vain indeed must be all her attentions, vain and useless her affection for his sister and her praise of himself, if he were already self-destined to another.
vi: This information made Elizabeth smile, as she thought of poor Miss Bingley. All of her attentions would be in vain; her feelings for his sister and her respect for him would also be futile and useless if he had already been designated for someone else. Elizabeth said:
tr: This information made Elizabeth smile, thinking of poor Miss Bingley. All her interest was in vain, the closeness she showed to his sister and the compliments she paid him were in vain and useless, since he had already chosen another girl.
es: This news made Elizabeth smile at the thought of poor Miss Bingley. In vain were all her attentions, in vain and useless all her affection for Darcy's sister and all the praises she lavished on him if he was already destined for another.

en: “Mr. Collins,” said she, “speaks highly both of Lady Catherine and her daughter; but, from some particulars that he has related of her Ladyship, I suspect his gratitude misleads him; and that, in spite of her being his patroness, she is an arrogant, conceited woman.”
vi: - Mr. Collins praised both Lady Catherine and her daughter, but from some details he mentioned about her, I think his appreciation has made him delusional. Although she is his patroness, she is an arrogant, conceited woman.
tr: "Mr. Collins," said Elizabeth, "You speak highly of both Lady Catherine and her daughter; but from some of your words about her ladyship, I think your gratitude has misled you; though she is your patron, she is, in my opinion, an arrogant and conceited woman.""
es: ––Mr. Collins ––said Elizabeth–– speaks very well of Lady Catherine and her daughter; but from some details he has shared about Her Ladyship, I suspect that gratitude blinds him and that, despite being his protector, she is an arrogant and vain woman.

en: “I believe her to be both in a great degree,” replied Wickham; “I have not seen her for many years; but I very well remember that I never liked her, and that her manners were dictatorial and insolent. She has the reputation of being remarkably sensible and clever; but I rather believe she derives part of her abilities from her rank and fortune, part from her authoritative manner, and the rest from the pride of her nephew, who chooses that everyone connected with him should have an understanding of the first class.”
vi: Wickham replied: - I believe she possesses both flaws to a severe degree. For many years I did not see her, but I still remember very clearly that I never liked her; I also remember her domineering and arrogant attitude. She had a reputation for being reasonable and shrewd, but I believe her abilities were partly due to her status and wealth, partly from her authoritative manner, and the rest from the pride of her nephew, who always wanted those associated with him to have the discernment of the upper class.
tr: "Absolutely so," replied Wickham; "I haven't seen him for years, but I remember that I never liked him; his manner was dictatorial and condescending. He was famous for being very intelligent and clever; but I think he derived his abilities partly from his position and wealth, partly from his authoritative demeanor, and the rest from his nephew's pride; his nephew believes that everyone related to him possesses a first-rate intellect."
es: ––I believe it is both, and to a high degree ––Wickham replied––. I haven't seen her for many years, but I remember that I never liked her and that her manners were authoritarian and insolent. She has a reputation for being judicious and intelligent; but I get the feeling that part of her qualities derive from her rank and fortune; another part, from her despotism, and the rest, from the pride of her nephew who believes that everyone related to him must possess superior intelligence.

en: Elizabeth allowed that he had given a very rational account of it, and they continued talking together with mutual satisfaction till supper put an end to cards, and gave the rest of the ladies their share of Mr. Wickham’s attentions. There could be no conversation in the noise of Mrs. Philips’s supper party, but his manners recommended him to everybody. Whatever he said, was said well; and whatever he did, done gracefully. Elizabeth went away with her head full of him. She could think of nothing but of Mr. Wickham, and of what he had told her, all the way home; but there was not time for her even to mention his name as they went, for neither Lydia nor Mr. Collins were once silent. Lydia talked incessantly of lottery tickets, of the fish she had lost and the fish she had won; and Mr. Collins, in describing the civility of Mr. and Mrs. Philips, protesting that he did not in the least regard his losses at whist, enumerating all the dishes at supper, and repeatedly fearing that he crowded his cousins, had more to say than he could well manage before the carriage stopped at Longbourn House.
vi: Elizabeth thought that he had analyzed it reasonably. The two continued to converse with each other harmoniously until the dinner ended the card game and allowed other women to pay attention to him. During the noisy meal, no one could talk much, but everyone admired his demeanor. Everything he said was reasonable; everything he did was elegant. Elizabeth went home with her mind filled only with thoughts of him. On the way back, she could think of nothing but Mr. Wickham and what he had told her. But she could not even mention his name, because both Lydia and Mr. Collins did not stop talking. Lydia chattered on about lottery tickets, about the cards she won and lost. Mr. Collins talked about everything, describing the politeness of Mr. and Mrs. Philips, insisting that he did not care about the money lost at the whist game, naming and praising every dish, repeatedly saying that he took up the cousins' seats, and he still wanted to say more when the carriage stopped at Longbourn.
tr: Elizabeth acknowledged that she had given a very reasonable explanation of the situation; they continued their conversation happily until the dinner call ended the card game and gave the other ladies a chance to share in Mr. Wickham's kindness. At Mrs. Philips' dinner party, the noise made conversation impossible, but Mr. Wickham's manners won everyone's admiration. Whatever he said was well said; whatever he did was done wonderfully. Elizabeth left the place with her mind full of him. All the way home, she could think of nothing but Mr. Wickham and what he had told her; but she found no time to mention his name, as neither Lydia nor Mr. Collins stopped talking for a moment. Lydia kept talking about lottery tickets, the ticket she lost, and the ticket she won; Mr. Collins went on about Mr. and Mrs. Philips' kindness, said he didn't mind his loss at whist in the least, listed all the dishes on the table, repeatedly asked if he had been a bother to his cousins, and when the carriage stopped at Longbourn House, he still hadn't finished telling everything he wanted to say.
es: Elizabeth recognized that he had portrayed her very well, and they continued chatting together until dinner ended the game and allowed the other ladies to partake in Wickham's attentions. A conversation could not be started due to the noise made by Mr. Philips' guests; but his manners charmed everyone. Everything he said was well said and everything he did was well done. Elizabeth was captivated by him. On the way back home, she could think of nothing but Mr. Wickham and everything he had told her; but throughout the journey, she was not given a chance to even mention his name, as neither Lydia nor Mr. Collins stopped talking for a second. Lydia kept talking about the lottery, what she had lost, what she had won; and Collins, with praising the hospitality of the Philips, assuring that he didn't mind his losses in whist, listing all the dinner dishes, and constantly repeating that he feared his cousins were cramped because of him, had more to say than he could before the carriage stopped in front of the Longbourn house.

en: CHAPTER XVII.
vi: Chapter 17
tr: Chapter XVII
es: CHAPTER XVII

en: ELIZABETH related to Jane, the next day, what had passed between Mr. Wickham and herself. Jane listened with astonishment and concern: she knew not how to believe that Mr. Darcy could be so unworthy of Mr. Bingley’s regard; and yet it was not in her nature to question the veracity of a young man of such amiable appearance as Wickham. The possibility of his having really endured such unkindness was enough to interest all her tender feelings; and nothing therefore remained to be done but to think well of them both, to defend the conduct of each, and throw into the account of accident or mistake whatever could not be otherwise explained.
vi: Elizabeth recounted to Jane the things she had discussed with Mr. Wickham, and Jane listened with astonishment and anxiety. She did not know how to believe that Mr. Darcy was not worthy of Mr. Bingley's esteem. However, her nature could not doubt the sincerity of someone as charming as Mr. Wickham. The fact that he had truly endured such cruel actions was enough to stir tender feelings within her. Therefore, there was nothing left to do but to think well of both men, justify their characters, and consider the possibility of unfortunate circumstances or misunderstandings—anything that could not be explained in any other way.
tr: Elizabeth told Jane what had happened between her and Wickham the next day. Jane listened with astonishment and concern; she did not know how to believe that Mr. Darcy was not as worthy of the esteem Mr. Bingley had shown him; yet, it was not in her nature to question the integrity of someone as pleasant-looking as Wickham. The possibility that Wickham had truly been subjected to such wrongs was enough to stir her compassionate feelings; therefore, there was nothing left to do but to think well of both, to defend each one's behavior, and in cases that could not be otherwise explained, to suggest an accident or mistake as the explanation.
es: The next day Elizabeth told Jane everything that she and Wickham had talked about. Jane listened with astonishment and interest. She could not believe that Darcy was so unworthy of Bingley's esteem; and yet, she did not dare to doubt the veracity of a man with such an affable appearance as Wickham. The mere possibility that he had suffered such cruelty was enough to stir her most tender feelings; so she had no choice but to think ill of neither, defend the conduct of both, and attribute to chance or error what otherwise could not be explained.

en: “They have both,” said she, “been deceived, I dare say, in some way or other, of which we can form no idea. Interested people have perhaps misrepresented each to the other. It is, in short, impossible for us to conjecture the causes or circumstances which may have alienated them, without actual blame on either side.”
vi: She said: - You could say that both of them were deceived in one way or another – the exact way we do not know. Perhaps one person misunderstood the other. In short, we cannot speculate on the reasons or circumstances that caused them to drift apart, so we cannot blame either of them.
tr: "Both of them," he said, "were deceived, I think, in a way that we cannot understand. The relevant parties might have misrepresented one to the other. In short, it is impossible for us to guess the reasons or conditions that alienated them from each other without blaming either side."
es: ––I have the impression ––he said–– that both have been let down, they are people, somehow disappointed by something that we cannot guess. Perhaps it was people interested in distorting things who set them against each other. In any case, we cannot speculate on the causes or circumstances that have separated them without either being at fault.

en: “Very true, indeed; and now, my dear Jane, what have you got to say in behalf of the interested people who have probably been concerned in the business? Do clear them, too, or we shall be obliged to think ill of somebody.”
vi: - Actually, that's true. Now, Jane, what can you say on behalf of those who might be concerned about the matter? We should consider that neither is to blame, otherwise we would have to think badly of someone.
tr: "Very true indeed; –now dear Jane, what can you say on behalf of the concerned individuals who might have been involved in the matter? –Let's clear them too, otherwise we will have to sacrifice someone."
es: ––You are very right; and tell me, my dear Jane: What do you have to say in favor of those interested people who probably had something to do with the matter? Defend them too, otherwise we will be forced to speak ill of someone.

en: “Laugh as much as you choose, but you will not laugh me out of my opinion. My dearest Lizzy, do but consider in what a disgraceful light it places Mr. Darcy, to be treating his father’s favourite in such a manner,—one whom his father had promised to provide for. It is impossible. No man of common humanity, no man who had any value for his character, could be capable of it. Can his most intimate friends be so excessively deceived in him? Oh no.”
vi: - You can laugh freely, but you cannot mock my opinion. Lizzy, just think about how Mr. Darcy will be disgraced, after having treated so poorly the person whom his father favored, the person his father promised to take care of. It cannot be, no one with ordinary humanity, no one with any value of character, could do such a thing. Could it be that his best friend was so greatly deceived? It cannot be!
tr: "Laugh as much as you want, but you can't change my mind by laughing. Dear Lizzy, think about how unpleasant it makes Mr. Darcy look to behave this way towards someone her father promised to look after, someone her father cares for. No one with a shred of humanity, no one who values their character even a little, could do this, it's beyond them. Could his closest friends have been so mistaken about him? –no! absolutely not."
es: ––Laugh at me all you want, but you won't make me change my mind. Dear Lizzy, consider what a dishonorable position it places Mr. Darcy in; to treat the favorite of his father this way, someone to whom he had promised a future. It is impossible. No one even moderately good, who values their conduct at all, is capable of doing it. Is it possible that his closest friends are so deceived about him? Oh, no!

en: “I can much more easily believe Mr. Bingley’s being imposed on than that Mr. Wickham should invent such a history of himself as he gave me last night; names, facts, everything mentioned without ceremony. If it be not so, let Mr. Darcy contradict it. Besides, there was truth in his looks.”
vi: - I can believe that Mr. Bingley was deceived more easily than that Mr. Wickham fabricated the story as he told me last night; the names, the events, everything was mentioned in a natural manner. If it were not so, let Mr. Darcy refute it. Moreover, Mr. Darcy's manner somewhat speaks the truth.
tr: "It is much easier for me to believe that Mr. Bingley was misled than to believe that Mr. Wickham fabricated a story about himself as he told me last night; names, facts, everything was told sincerely. If it is not so, let Mr. Darcy object. Moreover, there was truth in his gaze."
es: ––I believe it is easier for Mr. Bingley's friendship to be imposed than for Mr. Wickham to have invented such a story with names, facts, and to tell it so naturally. And if it is not so, let Mr. Darcy be the one to deny it. Besides, there was sincerity in his eyes.

en: “It is difficult, indeed—it is distressing. One does not know what to think.”
vi: - It's really hard to think, really sad. People don't know what to think.
tr: "It's hard, really –annoying. You don't know what to think."
es: ––It's really difficult, it's unfortunate. One doesn't know what to think.

en: “I beg your pardon;—one knows exactly what to think.”
vi: - Sorry, ma'am, people know exactly what to think.
tr: You don't know what to think."
es: ––Excuse me; one knows exactly what to think.

en: But Jane could think with certainty on only one point,—that Mr. Bingley, if he had been imposed on, would have much to suffer when the affair became public.
vi: But Jane could only be sure of one thing – that Mr. Bingley, if truly deceived, would suffer greatly when the matter became public.
tr: Jane could believe only one thing – Mr. Bingley, if he was truly misled, would suffer greatly when the matter came to light.
es: The two young women were chatting in the garden when they were informed of the arrival of some of the people they were just talking about.

en: The two young ladies were summoned from the shrubbery, where this conversation passed, by the arrival of some of the very persons of whom they had been speaking; Mr. Bingley and his sisters came to give their personal invitation for the long expected ball at Netherfield, which was fixed for the following Tuesday. The two ladies were delighted to see their dear friend again, called it an age since they had met, and repeatedly asked what she had been doing with herself since their separation. To the rest of the family they paid little attention; avoiding Mrs. Bennet as much as possible, saying not much to Elizabeth, and nothing at all to the others. They were soon gone again, rising from their seats with an activity which took their brother by surprise, and hurrying off as if eager to escape from Mrs. Bennet’s civilities.
vi: The two ladies were called into the house because there were guests – the very people they had just mentioned. He and his sisters came to deliver invitations for the ball at Netherfield on the following Tuesday. The two Bingley women were delighted to see their dear friend Jane again, feeling it had been a long time since they last met, and repeatedly asked her what she had been doing for herself since their parting. The two ladies paid little attention to the other family members, avoided Mrs. Bennet if possible, spoke little to Elizabeth, and said nothing to the other girls.
tr: Two young ladies were called from the shrubbery where this conversation was taking place; some of the people they had been talking about had arrived: Mr. Bingley and his sisters had come in person to extend an invitation for the long-awaited ball at Netherfield; the ball was to be held the following Tuesday. The two ladies were delighted to see their dear friends again, –they said it had been ages since they last met, and repeatedly asked what they had been up to since their last meeting. They paid little attention to the other members of the family; they kept as far away from Mrs. Bennet as possible, said very little to Elizabeth, and nothing at all to the others. They soon left, rising from their seats with a speed that caught their brother unprepared, and rushed to the door as if to escape Mrs. Bennet's offerings.
es: Mr. Bingley and his sisters were coming to personally invite them to the much-anticipated Netherfield ball that had been scheduled for the following Tuesday. The Bingley sisters were very happy to see their dear friend; it seemed to them that a century had passed since they had been together, and they continually asked her what had happened to her since their separation. They paid little attention to the rest of the family; they avoided Mrs. Bennet as much as they could, spoke very little with Elizabeth, and did not even address the others. They left immediately, rising from their seats with a speed that astonished their brother; they exited so quickly that they seemed eager to escape Mrs. Bennet's attentions.

en: The prospect of the Netherfield ball was extremely agreeable to every female of the family. Mrs. Bennet chose to consider it as given in compliment to her eldest daughter, and was particularly flattered by receiving the invitation from Mr. Bingley himself, instead of a ceremonious card. Jane pictured to herself a happy evening in the society of her two friends, and the attentions of their brother; and Elizabeth thought with pleasure of dancing a great deal with Mr. Wickham, and of seeing a confirmation of everything in Mr. Darcy’s look and behaviour. The happiness anticipated by Catherine and Lydia depended less on any single event, or any particular person; for though they each, like Elizabeth, meant to dance half the evening with Mr. Wickham, he was by no means the only partner who could satisfy them, and a ball was, at any rate, a ball. And even Mary could assure her family that she had no disinclination for it.
vi: Everyone in the family was eagerly looking forward to the ball. Mrs. Bennet saw this as an event for her eldest daughter, particularly proud to receive a personal invitation from Mr. Bingley himself, instead of a formal card. Jane imagined she would have a happy evening with her two friends, along with the attention of her cousin. Elizabeth thought of the joy of dancing many dances with Mr. Wickham, and seeing everything proven through Mr. Darcy's attitude and gestures. The joy that Catherine and Lydia anticipated did not depend much on any particular event or person, for although they liked dancing with Mr. Wickham, they did not focus solely on him, and after all, a ball was just a ball. Even Mary reassured the family that she would not be reluctant to attend.
tr: The fact that a ball was to be held at Netherfield made every woman in the family extremely happy. Mrs. Bennet preferred to think that the ball was given as a compliment to her eldest daughter and took particular pride in receiving the invitation personally from Mr. Bingley rather than through a formal card. Jane imagined a happy evening in the company of her two friends and under the attention of their brothers; Elizabeth, in her delight, thought of dancing a lot with Mr. Wickham and seeing everything in Mr. Wickham's gaze and posture confirmed. The happiness Catherine and Lydia anticipated was not so dependent on a single event or person; although they, like Elizabeth, wanted to dance with Mr. Wickham, Mr. Wickham was not the only partner who could satisfy them, besides, a ball was always a ball. Even Mary told her family that she did not look unfavorably upon the ball.
es: The prospect of the Netherfield ball was extraordinarily appealing to all the female members of the family. Mrs. Bennet took it as a compliment to her eldest daughter and felt particularly flattered to have received the invitation from Mr. Bingley in person rather than through a ceremonious card. Jane imagined a happy evening in the company of her two friends and with the attentions of the brother, and Elizabeth thought with delight of dancing the whole time with Mr. Wickham and of seeing the entire story confirmed in Mr. Darcy's looks and behavior. The happiness that Catherine and Lydia anticipated depended less on a single fact or a particular person, because, although both, like Elizabeth, thought of dancing half the night with Wickham, he was by no means the only partner who could satisfy them, and, after all, a ball was a ball. Even Mary went so far as to assure her family that she did not dislike the idea of going either.

en: “While I can have my mornings to myself,” said she, “it is enough. I think it is no sacrifice to join occasionally in evening engagements. Society has claims on us all; and I profess myself one of those who consider intervals of recreation and amusement as desirable for everybody.”
vi: She said: - As long as you have your own mornings, that is enough. Occasionally, you can participate in evening parties without feeling forced. Society has bound everyone, but you are one of those who believe that everyone occasionally desires entertainment and enjoyment that everyone wishes for.
tr: "If I reserve my mornings for myself," he said, "that will be enough for me – I suppose missing the occasional evening gathering isn't a great loss. Society has expectations of us as well; I see myself as one of those who believe that breaks given for entertainment and relaxation are beneficial for everyone."
es: ––As long as I can have the mornings for myself ––he said––, that's enough for me. It doesn't require any sacrifice on my part to occasionally accept evening commitments. We all owe something to society, and I confess that I am one of those who believe that intervals of recreation and relaxation are advisable for everyone.

en: Elizabeth’s spirits were so high on the occasion, that though she did not often speak unnecessarily to Mr. Collins, she could not help asking him whether he intended to accept Mr. Bingley’s invitation, and if he did, whether he would think it proper to join in the evening’s amusement; and she was rather surprised to find that he entertained no scruple whatever on that head, and was very far from dreading a rebuke, either from the Archbishop or Lady Catherine de Bourgh, by venturing to dance.
vi: Elizabeth's spirits were so high that, although she did not like conversing with Mr. Collins unless absolutely necessary, she could not help but ask if he intended to accept Mr. Bingley's invitation and, if he did, whether he thought it proper to attend an evening of enjoyment. She was quite surprised to hear him say that his mind harbored no such scruples; he was not afraid of being reprimanded by the Archbishop or Lady Catherine de Bourgh for daring to participate in the dance. He said:
tr: Elizabeth was so delighted at the mention of the ball that, despite usually avoiding conversation with Mr. Collins unless necessary, she couldn't help but ask if he was considering accepting Mr. Bingley's invitation and, if so, whether he found it appropriate to attend the evening festivities. She was surprised to see that he harbored no reservations and was far from fearing any rebuke from the Archbishop or Lady Catherine de Bourgh.
es: Elizabeth was so excited about the occasion that, despite usually only speaking to Collins when necessary, she couldn't help but ask him if he intended to accept Mr. Bingley's invitation and, if so, whether he thought it appropriate to attend evening parties. Elizabeth was surprised when he replied that he had no objections in this regard and that he did not fear that the archbishop or Lady Catherine de Bourgh would censure him for venturing to the dance.

en: “I am by no means of opinion, I assure you,” said he, “that a ball of this kind, given by a young man of character, to respectable people, can have any evil tendency; and I am so far from objecting to dancing myself, that I shall hope to be honoured with the hands of all my fair cousins in the course of the evening; and I take this opportunity of soliciting yours, Miss Elizabeth, for the two first dances especially; a preference which I trust my cousin Jane will attribute to the right cause, and not to any disrespect for her.”
vi: - I do not intend to view this type of ball, organized by a person of standing for respectable attendees, as potentially having an unhealthy tendency. I do not wish to refuse to participate in the dance, so that I may have the honor of the hands of my beautiful cousins, and I will take this opportunity to request the hand of Miss Elizabeth, especially for the first two dances – a preference which I believe Miss Jane will understand is not due to any lack of respect for her.
tr: "My opinion is," he said, "that a ball given by a man of good character to respectable people cannot harbor ill tendencies; I have no personal objection to dancing, and I even hope to have the honor of holding my lovely cousins' hands throughout the evening; and indeed, while we're on the subject, Miss Elizabeth, I would especially like to request you for the first two dances, –I believe my cousin Jane will understand my preference and will not consider it disrespectful.""
es: ––I assure you that I absolutely do not believe ––he said–– that a ball like this, organized by a man of distinction for respectable people, could have anything wrong with it. I have no objection to dancing and I hope to have the honor of doing so with all my beautiful cousins. I take this opportunity to ask you, specifically you, Miss Elizabeth, for the first two dances, a preference which I trust my cousin Jane will attribute to the proper cause, and not to any disregard for her.

en: Elizabeth felt herself completely taken in. She had fully proposed being engaged by Wickham for those very dances; and to have Mr. Collins instead!—her liveliness had been never worse timed. There was no help for it, however. Mr. Wickham’s happiness and her own was perforce delayed a little longer, and Mr. Collins’s proposal accepted with as good a grace as she could. She was not the better pleased with his gallantry, from the idea it suggested of something more. It now first struck her, that she was selected from among her sisters as worthy of being the mistress of Hunsford Parsonage, and of assisting to form a quadrille table at Rosings, in the absence of more eligible visitors. The idea soon reached to conviction, as she observed his increasing civilities towards herself, and heard his frequent attempt at a compliment on her wit and vivacity; and though more astonished than gratified herself by this effect of her charms, it was not long before her mother gave her to understand that the probability of their marriage was exceedingly agreeable to her. Elizabeth, however, did not choose to take the hint, being well aware that a serious dispute must be the consequence of any reply. Mr. Collins might never make the offer, and, till he did, it was useless to quarrel about him.
vi: Elizabeth felt completely awkward. She had hoped to dance with Mr. Wickham for the first two dances, but instead, it was Mr. Collins! Never had her lively personality been so poorly scheduled! But there was no other way. The joy of Mr. Wickham and hers would have to be postponed a bit; she accepted Mr. Collins' invitation with the most cheerful attitude she could muster. She was no happier with his flattering manner, thinking it indicated something. Now she suddenly realized that, among her sisters, he had chosen her to be the mistress of the Hunsford Parsonage, and also to fill a seat at the card table at Rossings in the absence of any more qualified guest. The thought gradually turned into conviction as she noticed him becoming increasingly courteous to her, especially when she heard him praise her intelligence and liveliness. Although feeling more surprised than pleased, it wasn't long before her mother hinted that she was very happy about the possibility of a wedding between the two. However, Elizabeth did not want to acknowledge the implication, knowing that any response would lead to a heated argument. Mr. Collins might never propose, so there was no point in arguing about him at this moment.
tr: Elizabeth felt that she was caught badly. She had assumed she would be paired with Mr. Wickham for the dances; now, instead, Mr. Collins! –he couldn't have chosen a worse time to be mischievous. However, there was nothing to be done. Her happiness with Mr. Wickham was necessarily postponed for a while, and Mr. Collins's proposal was accepted with all the courtesy that could be mustered. What really bothered her about the man's assertiveness was the underlying idea it expressed. –Now, for the first time, she realized that she had been deemed worthy among her sisters to be the lady of Hunsford Parsonage, to form the quartet at the card table in Rosings when there were no more distinguished guests. The idea quickly turned into belief as she observed the man's increasing interest in her, listened to the compliments he showered on her intelligence and vivacity; although the effect of her charm surprised her more than it honored her, it wasn't long before her mother made it clear that she was quite warm to the possibility of their marriage. However, Elizabeth refused to acknowledge her mother's insinuation because she knew well that her response would result in a serious disagreement. Mr. Collins might never make the proposal, and until he did, it was pointless to quarrel over it.
es: Elizabeth was completely disillusioned. She had intended to dedicate those two very special dances to Mr. Wickham! And now she had to dance them with Mr. Collins! She had chosen the wrong moment to become so happy. Well, what could she do? She had no choice but to postpone her happiness and Wickham's for a little later and accept Collins' proposal with the best possible attitude. She found no pleasure in his gallantry because there was something more hidden behind it. For the first time, it occurred to her that she was the chosen one among all her sisters to be the lady of the parsonage at Hunsford and to attend the quadrille parties at Rosings in the absence of more select visitors. This idea soon turned into conviction when she observed Collins' increasing attentions towards her and heard his frequent attempts to praise her wit and vivacity. Although the effect her charms had in this case left her more astonished than pleased, her mother soon made it clear that the possibility of that marriage pleased her excessively. However, Elizabeth preferred to ignore it, because she was sure that any reply would result in a serious argument. Probably Mr. Collins would never make such a proposal, and until he did, it was a waste of time to argue about him.

en: If there had not been a Netherfield ball to prepare for and talk of, the younger Miss Bennets would have been in a pitiable state at this time; for, from the day of the invitation to the day of the ball, there was such a succession of rain as prevented their walking to Meryton once. No aunt, no officers, no news could be sought after; the very shoe-roses for Netherfield were got by proxy. Even Elizabeth might have found some trial of her patience in weather which totally suspended the improvement of her acquaintance with Mr. Wickham; and nothing less than a dance on Tuesday could have made such a Friday, Saturday, Sunday, and Monday endurable to Kitty and Lydia.
vi: If it weren't for the Netherfield ball to prepare for and discuss, the Bennet sisters would surely feel miserable, as the continuous rain from the day they were invited until the ball prevented them from going to Meryton. Unable to visit their aunt, unable to meet the officers, no new news, they had to substitute with Netherfield. Even Elizabeth felt her patience being tested, as her efforts to strengthen her acquaintance with Mr. Wickham were completely stalled. As for Kitty and Lydia, if it weren't for the ball on Tuesday, there would be nothing else to help them endure Friday, Saturday, Sunday, and Monday.
tr: If there were no ball to be prepared and talked about at Netherfield, the young Miss Bennets would be in a pitiable state at that time, because the continuous rain from the day of the invitation to the day of the ball prevented them from going to Meryton. No aunt, no officers, no news – even the pink shoes for Netherfield were ordered by mail. Even Elizabeth had her patience tested by the weather that prevented her from furthering her acquaintance with Mr. Wickham; such a Friday, Saturday, Sunday, and Monday would have been difficult for Kitty and Lydia if there were no dance on Tuesday.
es: If they had not had to make preparations for the Netherfield ball, the younger Bennets would have reached a pitiable state, since from the day of the invitation until the day of the ball, the rain did not stop for a moment, preventing them from going to Meryton even once. No aunt, no officers, no gossip to share. Even the rose arrangements for the Netherfield ball had to be made to order. Elizabeth herself saw her patience tested by that bad weather which completely suspended the progress of her friendship with Wickham. Only the Tuesday ball could make a Friday, Saturday, Sunday, and Monday like those bearable for Catherine and Lydia.

en: CHAPTER XVIII.
vi: Chapter 18
tr: Chapter XVIII
es: CHAPTER XVIII

en: TILL Elizabeth entered the drawing-room at Netherfield, and looked in vain for Mr. Wickham among the cluster of red coats there assembled, a doubt of his being present had never occurred to her. The certainty of meeting him had not been checked by any of those recollections that might not unreasonably have alarmed her. She had dressed with more than usual care, and prepared in the highest spirits for the conquest of all that remained unsubdued of his heart, trusting that it was not more than might be won in the course of the evening. But in an instant arose the dreadful suspicion of his being purposely omitted, for Mr. Darcy’s pleasure, in the Bingleys’ invitation to the officers; and though this was not exactly the case, the absolute fact of his absence was pronounced by his friend Mr. Denny, to whom Lydia eagerly applied, and who told them that Wickham had been obliged to go to town on business the day before, and was not yet returned; adding, with a significant smile,—
vi: Elizabeth never doubted that Mr. Wickham would be absent from the ball, until she entered the drawing room at Netherfield and searched for him in vain among the men in red coats. She had been so sure he would be there, that she did not review her memories for any event that might have alerted her. She had dressed more carefully than usual, and prepared with the greatest eagerness to conquer all that remained unconquered in his heart, thinking that it could be achieved in just one evening. But suddenly, she had the dreadful thought that he had been deliberately excluded from Mr. Bingley's guest list to please Mr. Darcy. Although this was not entirely true, Mr. Denny conveyed the news of his absence when Lydia spoke with him. Denny reported that Wickham had to attend to business in town the day before and had not yet returned. He added, with a suggestive smile:
tr: It had never occurred to Elizabeth that there was any chance of Mr. Wickham not being present until she entered the sitting room at Netherfield and looked in vain among the cluster of redcoats gathered there. The belief that she would encounter him had not been tested by memories that might justifiably have made her uneasy. She had dressed with more than usual care, prepared with all her cheerfulness to conquer everything that remained unconquered in the man's heart, confident that there was not much left unconquered throughout the evening. But for a moment, she was seized by the suspicion that the Bingleys had deliberately omitted the officers from their invitations to please Mr. Darcy; although this was not the case, the fact of his absence was confirmed by his friend Mr. Denny, who, when approached by the curious Lydia, explained that Wickham had been obliged to go to town on business the previous day and had not yet returned, adding with a meaningful smile:
es: Until Elizabeth entered the Netherfield drawing-room and searched in vain among the group of red coats gathered there for Wickham, it did not occur to her that he might not be among the guests. The certainty of finding him had made her forget what would have rightly alarmed her. She had groomed herself with more care than usual and was prepared with a very high spirit to conquer whatever remained untamed in her heart, trusting that it was the best reward she could achieve during the evening. But in an instant, the horrible suspicion came over her that Wickham might have been omitted from Bingley's list of invited officers to please Darcy. That was not exactly the case. His absence was definitively confirmed by Mr. Denny, whom Lydia anxiously approached, and who told them that Mr. Wickham had been obliged to go to the capital to resolve some matters the day before and had not yet returned. And with a significant smile, he added:

en: “I do not imagine his business would have called him away just now, if he had not wished to avoid a certain gentleman here.”
vi: - I can't imagine any job that would make him leave at this moment, unless he wants to avoid someone here.
tr: "If she didn't want to avoid a certain gentleman here, she wouldn't care about work or anything else right now.""
es: ––I don't believe those matters would have detained him today, unless he wanted to avoid meeting a certain gentleman here.

en: This part of his intelligence, though unheard by Lydia, was caught by Elizabeth; and, as it assured her that Darcy was not less answerable for Wickham’s absence than if her first surmise had been just, every feeling of displeasure against the former was so sharpened by immediate disappointment, that she could hardly reply with tolerable civility to the polite inquiries which he directly afterwards approached to make. Attention, forbearance, patience with Darcy, was injury to Wickham. She was resolved against any sort of conversation with him, and turned away with a degree of ill-humour which she could not wholly surmount even in speaking to Mr. Bingley, whose blind partiality provoked her.
vi: Although Lydia did not notice, Elizabeth heard it. Though this news reassured her that Darcy was not much involved in Wickham's absence as she had initially suspected, all her resentment towards Darcy grew even more intense due to her disappointment, to the extent that she could not respond with the minimal courtesy to his polite questions. She thought that showing interest, tolerance, and patience towards Darcy would hurt Wickham. She resolved not to speak to Darcy anymore, turning away with a bit of irritation that she could not entirely suppress even when conversing with Mr. Bingley, and was further provoked by his blind partiality.
tr: Although this part of the explanation escaped Lydia's attention, it did not escape Elizabeth's, and even if her initial guess was not correct, it convinced her that the reason for Wickham's absence was Darcy; the coldness she felt towards Darcy hardened so much with her current disappointment that she had difficulty responding with reasonable politeness to Darcy's courteous questions when he approached her shortly after. Showing interest, patience, and understanding to Darcy meant insulting Wickham. She was determined not to speak to him in any way and turned her back with a certain petulance; her petulance did not fully subside even while talking to Mr. Bingley; she was also angry with him for not being impartial.
es: Lydia did not hear these words, but Elizabeth did; although her initial suspicion had not been true, Darcy was equally responsible for Wickham's absence, her antipathy towards the former was so exacerbated that she could barely respond politely to the kind questions Darcy asked her when he approached her shortly after. Any attention or tolerance towards Darcy meant an injury to Wickham. She decided not to have any conversation with Darcy and put herself in such a mood that she could not even conceal it when talking to Bingley, as his blind partiality irritated her.

en: But Elizabeth was not formed for ill-humour; and though every prospect of her own was destroyed for the evening, it could not dwell long on her spirits; and, having told all her griefs to Charlotte Lucas, whom she had not seen for a week, she was soon able to make a voluntary transition to the oddities of her cousin, and to point him out to her particular notice. The two first dances, however, brought a return of distress: they were dances of mortification. Mr. Collins, awkward and solemn, apologizing instead of attending, and often moving wrong without being aware of it, gave her all the shame and misery which a disagreeable partner for a couple of dances can give. The moment of her release from him was ecstasy.
vi: However, Elizabeth's personality did not hold onto resentment for long. Although all her hopes for the evening had faded away, her spirits gradually became comfortable again. After sharing all her feelings with Charlotte Lucas, whom she had not seen in a week, she soon willingly moved on to the peculiarities of her cousin, telling her friend about him. However, the first two dances brought about sorrow; they were two torturous pieces. Mr. Collins, clumsy and miserable, apologized instead of attending to her, often stepping out of rhythm without realizing it, bringing her all the shame and misery of an unpleasant dance partner. She was delighted to be rid of him.
tr: Aunt Elizabeth was not made for sulking; although all the dreams she had for the evening were shattered, the sulking did not last long; after pouring out all her sorrows to Charlotte Lucas, whom she hadn't seen for a week, she became willing to transition to her cousin's oddities and pointed her finger at Charlotte. However, the first two dances brought back her boredom; they were no different from a death dance. Clumsy and solemn Mr. Collins, instead of doing what was necessary, apologized and frequently took wrong steps unknowingly, giving Elizabeth all the embarrassment and discomfort that a terrible partner could give during several dances. The moment of getting rid of the man was wonderful.
es: But bad humor was not made for Elizabeth, and despite all her plans for the night being ruined, it soon passed. After telling her sorrows to Charlotte Lucas, whom she hadn't seen for a week, she soon found herself in the mood to tolerate all her cousin's oddities and approached him. However, the first two dances brought back her distress; they were like a penance. Mr. Collins, clumsy and solemn, apologizing instead of keeping to the rhythm, and losing the step without realizing it, gave her all the pity and embarrassment that an unpleasant partner can give in a couple of dances. Getting rid of him was like reaching ecstasy.

en: She danced next with an officer, and had the refreshment of talking of Wickham, and of hearing that he was universally liked. When those dances were over, she returned to Charlotte Lucas, and was in conversation with her, when she found herself suddenly addressed by Mr. Darcy, who took her so much by surprise in his application for her hand, that, without knowing what she did, she accepted him. He walked away again immediately, and she was left to fret over her own want of presence of mind: Charlotte tried to console her.
vi: She danced the next set with an officer, feeling happy to hear about Wickham and knowing that everyone adored him. After the music ended, she returned to Charlotte Lucas. While they were conversing, Mr. Darcy suddenly approached her. He surprised her by asking her to dance. Without thinking, she accepted. He immediately turned and walked away; she was left feeling irritated at her own lack of judgment. Charlotte tried to console her.
tr: Then she danced with an officer and had the pleasure of hearing everyone speak well of Wickham. When these dances ended, she turned to Charlotte Lucas; they had just started conversing when suddenly she found Mr. Darcy standing beside her, saying something; she was so caught off guard that when Mr. Darcy asked her to dance, she accepted without realizing it. Mr. Darcy left as quickly as he had come, and Elizabeth was left to lament her foolishness; Charlotte tried to console her.
es: Then she had the relief of dancing with an officer with whom she could talk about Mr. Wickham, learning that everyone appreciated him. When this dance ended, she returned to Charlotte Lucas, and they were chatting when she suddenly realized that Mr. Darcy had approached her and was asking for the next dance; she was so surprised that, without knowing what she was doing, she accepted. Darcy left immediately, and she, having become very nervous, stayed there wishing to regain her composure. Charlotte tried to console her.

en: “I dare say you will find him very agreeable.”
vi: - I think you will find him very likable.
tr: "I think you will like him/her a lot.""
es: ––Maybe you'll find it charming.

en: “Heaven forbid! That would be the greatest misfortune of all! To find a man agreeable whom one is determined to hate! Do not wish me such an evil.”
vi: - How miserable! That would be the most unfortunate thing for everyone! To see someone you deliberately hate being so likable! Don't wish me such a malicious thing.
tr: "God forbid! –It would be the epitome of misfortune! –Liking someone you are determined to hate! –Don't wish such bad things for me."
es: ––May God forbid it! That would be the greatest of all misfortunes. To find charming a man who must be hated! Do not wish me such ill.

en: When the dancing recommenced, however, and Darcy approached to claim her hand, Charlotte could not help cautioning her, in a whisper, not to be a simpleton, and allow her fancy for Wickham to make her appear unpleasant in the eyes of a man often times his consequence. Elizabeth made no answer, and took her place in the set, amazed at the dignity to which she was arrived in being allowed to stand opposite to Mr. Darcy, and reading in her neighbours’ looks their equal amazement in beholding it. They stood for some time without speaking a word; and she began to imagine that their silence was to last through the two dances, and, at first, was resolved not to break it; till suddenly fancying that it would be the greater punishment to her partner to oblige him to talk, she made some slight observation on the dance. He replied, and was again silent. After a pause of some minutes, she addressed him a second time, with—
vi: However, when the dance music started and Darcy returned to take her hand, Charlotte couldn't help but whisper in her ear not to foolishly dream of Wickham and become unpleasant in the eyes of someone ten times higher in status. Elizabeth did not reply, accepted the dance with him, feeling surprised at how her own dignity had changed to allow her to face Mr. Darcy, and read in the eyes of the other dancing couples an equal surprise at seeing the two of them together. For a long while, neither of them spoke a word; she began to imagine that their silence would last throughout the two dances. At first, she had no intention of breaking the silence, until she suddenly thought that the heaviest punishment for him would be to make him speak, so she made some idle remarks about the ball. He replied, then fell silent again. A moment later, she spoke again for the second time.
tr: Still, when the dance resumed and Darcy approached to ask her for a dance, Charlotte couldn't help but warn her: she whispered not to act childishly and not to let her fantasies about Wickham make her appear unattractive in the eyes of a man ten times richer. Elizabeth did not reply and took her place on the dance floor, marveling at the respectability she gained from the chance to stand opposite Mr. Darcy, and saw the same amazement on the faces of their observing neighbors. They stood without speaking for a while; Elizabeth thought their silence would last until the end of the two dances and initially decided not to break it, but then suddenly considered that forcing him to talk would be a greater punishment and made a few observations about the dance. Mr. Darcy replied, then fell silent again. After a few minutes of hesitation, Elizabeth spoke to him a second time – "It is now your turn to say something, Mr. Darcy.
es: When the dance resumed, Darcy approached her to take her hand, and Charlotte couldn't help but whisper in her ear not to be foolish and not to let her infatuation with Wickham make her appear unpleasant in the eyes of a man who was worth ten times more than him. Elizabeth did not reply. She took her place on the dance floor, astonished by the dignity bestowed upon her by standing face to face with Darcy, reading in the eyes of all her neighbors the same astonishment at witnessing the event. They were silent for a while; Elizabeth began to think that the silence would last until the end of the two dances. At first, she was determined not to break it, when suddenly she thought that the worst punishment for her partner would be to force him to talk, and she made a small remark about the dance. Darcy replied and fell silent again. After a pause of a few minutes, Elizabeth spoke for the second time and said to him:

en: “It is your turn to say something now, Mr. Darcy. I talked about the dance, and you ought to make some kind of remark on the size of the room, or the number of couples.”
vi: - Mr. Darcy, it's your turn to say something. I've talked about the ball, now you must make some remarks about the size of the room, or the number of dancing couples.
tr: After a few minutes of hesitation, Elizabeth spoke to him a second time – "It is now your turn to say something, Mr. Darcy. I talked about the dance, you could, for instance, say something about the dimensions of the room, or how many couples there are.""
es: ––Now it's your turn to say something, Mr. Darcy. I've already talked about the dance, and you should make some comment about the size of the hall and the number of couples.

en: He smiled, and assured her that whatever she wished him to say should be said.
vi: He smiled, assuring her that he would say anything she wanted him to say.
tr: Mr. Darcy smiled and assured her that he would say whatever she wished.
es: He smiled and assured her that he would say everything she wished to hear.

en: “Very well; that reply will do for the present. Perhaps, by-and-by, I may observe that private balls are much pleasanter than public ones; but now we may be silent.”
vi: - Very good. That answer is sufficient for now. Perhaps gradually I can observe that family dances are more enjoyable than public dances. But now we can be silent.
tr: "Very good. This answer is sufficient for now. Maybe in a bit, I'll say that private balls are more pleasant than public balls. But now we must be silent."
es: ––Very well. That response isn't bad for now. Maybe little by little I'll be convinced that private dances are more pleasant than public ones; but for now, we can remain silent.

en: “Do you talk by rule, then, while you are dancing?”
vi: - Do you often talk while you are dancing?
tr: "Do you talk about rules while dancing?"
es: ––Do you usually talk while you dance?

en: “Sometimes. One must speak a little, you know. It would look odd to be entirely silent for half an hour together; and yet, for the advantage of some, conversation ought to be so arranged as that they may have the trouble of saying as little as possible.”
vi: - Sometimes. People need to chat a little, you know. It does look odd if we stay silent with each other for half an hour, but for some people, it is necessary to arrange the conversation in such a way that they can be bothered to speak as much as possible.
tr: "Sometimes. A person should talk a little, of course. Sitting in silence together for half an hour seems strange; but the conversation should be arranged in such a way that they can speak as little as possible to suit some people."
es: ––Sometimes. It's necessary to talk a little, don't you think? It would be strange to be together for half an hour without saying a word. But out of consideration for some, you have to steer the conversation so that they don't feel compelled to say more than necessary.

en: “Are you consulting your own feelings in the present case, or do you imagine that you are gratifying mine?”
vi: - Are you probing your own feelings in this case, or do you think you are probing mine?
tr: "Are you expressing your own feelings right now, or do you think you are responding to mine?"
es: ––Are you referring to yourself or are you saying it about me?

en: “Both,” replied Elizabeth archly; “for I have always seen a great similarity in the turn of our minds. We are each of an unsocial, taciturn disposition, unwilling to speak, unless we expect to say something that will amaze the whole room, and be handed down to posterity with all the éclat of a proverb.”
vi: Elizabeth replied mischievously: - Both, because I realized there is a similarity in the way both of us shift our thoughts. Both of us have a difficult temperament, sullen, unwilling to speak, except when we want to say something that surprises the whole room, to be passed down to future generations with all the glory of a proverb.
tr: "Both," answered Elizabeth mischievously; "I have always seen a great similarity in our ways of thinking. We are both unsociable, stubborn, we do not like to talk, unless we hope to say something that will enchant the whole room and be passed down to future generations with proverbial grandeur."
es: ––For both ––replied Elizabeth coquettishly––, for I have found a great similarity in our ways of being. We are both unsociable, taciturn, and averse to speaking unless we expect to say something that will dazzle everyone present and go down in history with all the brilliance of a proverb.

en: “This is no very striking resemblance of your own character, I am sure,” said he. “How near it may be to mine, I cannot pretend to say. You think it a faithful portrait, undoubtedly.”
vi: - This is not at all like your nature, I am sure of it. I dare not say how it aligns with my nature. Surely you think it is a true portrait.
tr: "This is a picture that does not resemble your character at all," said Mr. Darcy. "I cannot say how close it is to mine either. But evidently, you think it is a faithful portrait.""
es: ––I am sure that you are not like that. As for me, I wouldn't know what to say. You, without a doubt, believe that you have made a faithful portrait of me.

en: “I must not decide on my own performance.”
vi: - I should not conclude about my nature.
tr: "It is not for me to judge my own skill.""
es: ––I cannot judge my own work.

en: He made no answer; and they were again silent till they had gone down the dance, when he asked her if she and her sisters did not very often walk to Meryton. She answered in the affirmative; and, unable to resist the temptation, added, “When you met us there the other day, we had just been forming a new acquaintance.”
vi: He did not answer. The two fell into silence again until near the end of the piece, when he asked her whether she and her sisters often went to Meryton. She said yes and, unable to resist the temptation, added: - When you met us the other day, we had just gotten to know someone new.
tr: Mr. Darcy did not reply, and they did not speak again until the dance was over; then Mr. Darcy asked if they often walked to Meryton with their sisters. Elizabeth said yes, and unable to resist the provocation, added, "When you met us there the other day, we were just making a new acquaintance."
es: He did not answer, and it seemed that they would not open their mouths again until the dance ended, when he asked her if she and her sisters often went to Meryton. Elizabeth answered affirmatively and, unable to resist the temptation, added: ––When you found us the other day, we had just met a new friend.

en: The effect was immediate. A deeper shade of hauteur overspread his features, but he said not a word; and Elizabeth, though blaming herself for her own weakness, could not go on. At length Darcy spoke, and in a constrained manner said,—
vi: He had an immediate reaction. A profound arrogance spread across his face, but he did not say a word. Elizabeth, though blaming herself for being too weak, could not continue. Finally, Darcy spoke, restraining himself:
tr: The effect of the words was seen immediately. A darker shadow of arrogance spread across his face, but he did not utter a single word; although Elizabeth blamed herself for her weakness, she could not continue the subject. Finally, Mr. Darcy spoke, and in a tense manner, said, "Mr. Wickham has such charming manners that he quickly makes friends – but I am not sure if he can keep them."
es: The effect was immediate. An intense shadow of arrogance darkened Darcy's countenance. But he did not say a word; Elizabeth, though reproaching herself for her weakness, preferred not to continue. Finally, Darcy spoke and said in a forced manner:

en: “Mr. Wickham is blessed with such happy manners as may insure his making friends; whether he may be equally capable of retaining them, is less certain.”
vi: - Mr. Wickham is fortunate to be endowed with a cheerful demeanor that makes it easy for him to make friends; whether he has the ability to maintain those friendships, I am not sure.
tr: Finally, Mr. Darcy spoke, and in a tense manner, said, "Mr. Wickham has such charming manners that he quickly makes friends – but I am not sure if he can keep them."
es: ––Mr. Wickham is endowed with such pleasant manners that he can certainly make friends easily. What is less certain is that he is equally capable of keeping them.

en: “He has been so unlucky as to lose your friendship,” replied Elizabeth, with emphasis, “and in a manner which he is likely to suffer from all his life.”
vi: Elizabeth replied: - He was unfortunate because he lost his friendship with you. She emphasized further: - And in the way that he might suffer for a lifetime.
tr: "Losing your friendship has been a great misfortune," replied Elizabeth emphatically, "and he will suffer from it for the rest of his life."
es: ––He has had the misfortune of losing his friendship ––said Elizabeth emphatically––, in such a way that he will suffer for it all his life.

en: Darcy made no answer, and seemed desirous of changing the subject. At that moment Sir William Lucas appeared close to them, meaning to pass through the set to the other side of the room; but, on perceiving Mr. Darcy, he stopped, with a bow of superior courtesy, to compliment him on his dancing and his partner.
vi: Darcy did not reply, seemingly wanting to change the subject. At that moment, Sir William Lucas appeared near them, but upon seeing Darcy, he bowed with the courtesy of an elder to compliment him on his dance steps and his dance partner.
tr: Darcy did not respond; he seemed to want to change the subject. At that moment, Sir William Lucas appeared nearby; he intended to cross the room from the middle of the dance floor, but upon noticing Mr. Darcy, he stopped and bowed with superior courtesy, complimenting him on the dance and his partner.
es: Darcy did not answer and it was noticeable that he was eager to change the subject. At that moment, Sir William Lucas was passing near them as he crossed the dance floor with the intention of going to the other end of the hall, and upon seeing Mr. Darcy, he stopped and made a bow with all courtesy to congratulate him on his way of dancing and his partner.

en: “I have been most highly gratified, indeed, my dear sir; such very superior dancing is not often seen. It is evident that you belong to the first circles. Allow me to say, however, that your fair partner does not disgrace you: and that I must hope to have this pleasure often repeated, especially when a certain desirable event, my dear Miss Eliza (glancing at her sister and Bingley), shall take place. What congratulations will then flow in! I appeal to Mr. Darcy;—but let me not interrupt you, sir. You will not thank me for detaining you from the bewitching converse of that young lady, whose bright eyes are also upbraiding me.”
vi: - I am very pleased, sir. One rarely sees such dancing artistry. Obviously, you belong to the upper class. However, allow me to say that your beautiful dance partner does not make you ashamed, and I wish to often have such joy, especially when a happy event is about to take place. So many congratulations will pour in! I ask Mr. Darcy not to let me interrupt you, sir. You will not thank me for pulling you away from the enchanting conversation of this young lady with bright eyes who also seems to blame me.
tr: "I am truly very impressed, sir. Such an exceptional dance is rarely seen. It is clear that you belong in the front ranks. But allow me to say, your lovely wife is not inferior to you; I hope for the frequent repetition of this pleasure, dear Miss Eliza, (glancing towards her sister and Bingley) especially when that happy day arrives. Then you will see the real congratulations! My request to Mr. Darcy: –but I won't keep you, sir. –If I deprive you of this young lady's conversation, you won't thank me, and her bright eyes are already scolding me.""
es: ––I am extremely pleased, my esteemed sir, such an excellent way of dancing is not often seen. It is evident that you belong to the most distinguished circles. Allow me to say, however, that your beautiful partner is in no way inferior to you, and I hope to enjoy this pleasure again, especially when a certain much-desired event, dear Elizabeth (looking at Jane and Bingley), takes place. How many congratulations there will be then! I appeal to Mr. Darcy. But I do not want to interrupt you, sir. You will thank me for not depriving you further of the captivating conversation of this young lady whose beautiful eyes are also reproaching me.

en: “Such very superior dancing is not
vi: You will not thank me for pulling you away from the enchanting conversation of this young lady with bright eyes who also seems to blame me.
tr: –If I deprive you of this young lady's conversation, you won't thank me, and her bright eyes are already scolding me.""
es: You will thank me for not depriving you further of the captivating conversation of this young lady whose beautiful eyes are also reproaching me.

en: often seen.”
vi: Darcy did not clearly hear the end of this speech, but Sir William's insinuations seemed to strike him deeply.
tr: Darcy barely heard the second half of these words, but Sir William's insinuation about his friend struck him; with a very serious expression, he turned his eyes to Bingley and Jane, who were dancing together.
es: Darcy barely heard this last part of her speech, but the allusion to his friend seemed to impress him greatly, and with a grave expression, he directed his gaze towards Bingley and Jane who were dancing together.

en: The latter part of this address was scarcely heard by Darcy; but Sir William’s allusion to his friend seemed to strike him forcibly, and his eyes were directed, with a very serious expression, towards Bingley and Jane, who were dancing together. Recovering himself, however, shortly, he turned to his partner, and said,—
vi: His eyes, with a very serious expression, turned towards Bingley and Jane, who were dancing together at that moment. But he quickly regained his composure, turned to his dance partner, and said:
tr: Darcy barely heard the second half of these words, but Sir William's insinuation about his friend struck him; with a very serious expression, he turned his eyes to Bingley and Jane, who were dancing together. Nevertheless, he quickly composed himself and turned to his companion, saying, "When Sir William interrupted, I forgot what we were talking about."
es: Darcy barely heard this last part of her speech, but the allusion to his friend seemed to impress him greatly, and with a grave expression, he directed his gaze towards Bingley and Jane who were dancing together. Nevertheless, he quickly recovered and, turning to Elizabeth, said:

en: “Sir William’s interruption has made me forget what we were talking of.”
vi: - Sir William interrupted, making me forget what we were talking about.
tr: Nevertheless, he quickly composed himself and turned to his companion, saying, "When Sir William interrupted, I forgot what we were talking about."
es: ––Sir William's interruption has made me forget what we were talking about.

en: “I do not think we were speaking at all. Sir William could not have interrupted any two people in the room who had less to say for themselves. We have tried two or three subjects already without success, and what we are to talk of next I cannot imagine.”
vi: - I don't think we are talking about anything at all. Sir William cannot interrupt two people in this room when they have nothing to say to each other. We have tried two or three topics without success, so I cannot think of what we will talk about next.
tr: "I don't think we talked. Sir William couldn't have found two people who speak less to interrupt. We already tried two or three topics, it didn't work; I don't know what we will talk about now."
es: ––I don't think we were talking. Sir William could not have interrupted another couple in the entire room who had less to say to each other. We have already tried two or three topics without success. I have no idea what we can talk about now.

en: “What think you of books?” said he, smiling.
vi: He said, smiling: - What do you think about books? - Books? Oh!
tr: "What do you think about books?" he said, smiling. "Books –No! absolutely not.
es: ––What do you think about books? ––he asked her, smiling. ––The books!

en: “Books—oh no!—I am sure we never read the same, or not with the same feelings.”
vi: No, I'm sure we never read the same kind of books, or read with the same feelings.
tr: –I'm sure we don't read the same books, and I'm also sure we don't read them with the same feelings."
es: Oh, no! I'm sure we never read the same ones or, at least, we don't get the same impressions.

en: “I am sorry you think so; but if that be the case, there can at least be no want of subject. We may compare our different opinions.”
vi: - It's a pity that you think so, but if that's the case, at least we won't lack topics. We can compare different viewpoints.
tr: "I am sorry you feel that way; but if that's the case, at least we won't run out of topics. –We can compare our different views."
es: ––I regret that you think that; but if that were the case, anyway, we would not lack a topic. We can compare our various opinions.

en: “No—I cannot talk of books in a ball-room; my head is always full of something else.”
vi: - No, I cannot talk about books in a ballroom; my mind is always filled with other things.
tr: "No – I cannot talk about books in a ballroom; my mind is always filled with other things."
es: ––No, I can't talk about books in a ballroom. My mind is occupied with other things.

en: “The present always occupies you in such scenes—does it?” said he, with a look of doubt.
vi: He asked, with a doubtful look: - The present always preoccupies you in these settings, doesn't it? - Yes, always like that.
tr: "The current you is always preoccupied with such scenes – isn't it?" said Darcy, with a doubtful look.
es: ––In these places, one thinks only of the present, right? ––he said with a doubtful look.

en: “Yes, always,” she replied, without knowing what she said; for her thoughts had wandered far from the subject, as soon afterwards appeared by her suddenly exclaiming, “I remember hearing you once say, Mr. Darcy, that you hardly ever forgave;—that your resentment, once created, was unappeasable. You are very cautious, I suppose, as to its being created?”
vi: She answered without knowing what she was saying, as her thoughts had wandered off the subject, but then suddenly appeared: - Mr. Darcy, I remember the other day, you mentioned that you rarely forgive, and once you are offended, nothing can soothe you. I suppose you are very cautious about becoming offended in the first place.
tr: "Yes, always," answered Elizabeth, not knowing what she was saying; her thoughts had wandered away from the subject; it became apparent a moment later when she suddenly spoke: "I remember you saying once, Mr. Darcy, that you do not forgive easily, that once you are offended, your resentment does not pass. I suppose you are very cautious not to be offended."
es: ––Yes, always ––she replied without knowing what she was saying, as her thoughts had wandered elsewhere, as she suddenly demonstrated by exclaiming––: I remember hearing you say once that you rarely forgave; that when you had conceived a resentment, it was impossible for you to appease it. I suppose, therefore, that you are very cautious in conceiving resentments...

en: “I am,” said he, with a firm voice.
vi: He spoke firmly: - That's right.
tr: "Indeed," said Darcy in a firm voice.
es: ––Indeed ––replied Darcy with a firm voice.

en: “And never allow yourself to be blinded by prejudice?”
vi: - And you never allow yourself to be blinded by prejudice, do you?
tr: "But wouldn't there be times when you let prejudice blind you?""
es: ––And do you never let yourself be blinded by prejudice?

en: “I hope not.”
vi: - I hope so.
tr: "I hope not."
es: ––I hope not.

en: “It is particularly incumbent on those who never change their opinion, to be secure of judging properly at first.”
vi: - Those who never change their opinions must possess this virtue to ensure sound judgment from the very beginning.
tr: "It is especially necessary for those who never change their opinions to arrive at the correct judgment in the first place.""
es: ––Those who never change their opinion must make sure before judging.

en: “May I ask to what these questions tend?”
vi: - May I ask, what are you aiming for?
tr: "May I ask where these questions are leading to?"
es: ––Can I ask you what the intention of these questions is?

en: “Merely to the illustration of your character,” said she, endeavouring to shake off her gravity. “I am trying to make it out.”
vi: She said, trying to be gentle: - It's just an illustration of your nature. I'm trying to figure out what that nature is like.
tr: "I am merely trying to reveal your character," said Elizabeth, trying to shake off the weight on her. "I am trying to understand."
es: ––To know his character, simply ––said Elizabeth, trying to conceal her seriousness––. I am trying to decipher it.

en: “And what is your success?”
vi: - And how did she realize it?
tr: "Did you at least understand?"
es: ––And what conclusions have you reached?

en: She shook her head. “I do not get on at all. I hear such different accounts of you as puzzle me exceedingly.”
vi: She shook her head: - I don't understand anything. I hear different things about you that make me very confused.
tr: Elizabeth nodded, "I haven't made any progress at all. I hear such different things about you that it confuses me greatly."
es: ––None ––he said, shaking his head––. I've heard such different things about you that I can't make sense of it.

en: “I can readily believe,” answered he, gravely, “that reports may vary greatly with respect to me; and I could wish, Miss Bennet, that you were not to sketch my character at the present moment, as there is reason to fear that the performance would reflect no credit on either.”
vi: He replied, sternly: - I can readily believe that what people say about me varies greatly. Miss Bennet, I hope you will not hastily sketch out my character at this moment, for there is reason to fear that doing so correctly or incorrectly will not be properly reflected.
tr: "I believe that," Darcy replied seriously, "reports about me can vary greatly; I wish, Miss Bennet, that you would not attempt to sketch my character at this moment, for I have reasons to fear that your effort would not do justice to either side."
es: ––I acknowledge ––he replied gravely–– that opinions about me may vary greatly; and I would wish, Miss Bennet, that you do not sketch my character at this moment, because I have reasons to fear that the result would not reflect the truth.

en: “But if I do not take your likeness now, I may never have another opportunity.”
vi: - But if I don't try to create a portrait of you now, I might never have another chance.
tr: "But if I don't get an idea about you now, I might not have another chance.""
es: ––But if I don't do it now, I might not have another chance.

en: “I would by no means suspend any pleasure of yours,” he coldly replied. She said no more, and they went down the other dance and parted in silence; on each side dissatisfied, though not to an equal degree; for in Darcy’s breast there was a tolerably powerful feeling towards her, which soon procured her pardon, and directed all his anger against another.
vi: He said coldly: - I have no intention of stopping you if you like it. She said nothing more. The two continued with another piece of music and then parted in silence. Each felt a sense of resentment, though to different degrees, for within Darcy there was already a strong feeling towards her, allowing him to forgive her and direct all his anger towards someone else.
tr: "Then I shall not spoil your enjoyment," replied Darcy. Elizabeth said nothing more; they finished the other dance and parted in silence; neither was satisfied, though not equally; for there was a rather strong feeling in Darcy's chest towards her, which allowed him to quickly forgive her and direct all his anger towards someone else.
es: ––By no means would I wish to prevent any of your satisfactions ––he replied coldly. Elizabeth did not speak further, and when the dance ended, they parted in silence, both dissatisfied, though to different degrees, for in Darcy's heart there was a powerful feeling of tolerance towards her, which soon led him to forgive her and focus all his anger on another.

en: They had not long separated when Miss Bingley came towards her, and, with an expression of civil disdain, thus accosted her,—
vi: They parted ways not long before Miss Bingley arrived, her face disdainful.
tr: It hadn't been long since they parted when Miss Bingley came towards Elizabeth and, with a measured expression of disdain on her face, harassed her as follows: –"I heard, Miss Eliza, that you are quite fond of George Wickham!
es: It wasn't long after they had parted ways when Miss Bingley approached Elizabeth and, with an expression of both kindness and disdain, said to her:

en: “So, Miss Eliza, I hear you are quite delighted with George Wickham? Your sister has been talking to me about him, and asking me a thousand questions; and I find that the young man forgot to tell you, among his other communications, that he was the son of old Wickham, the late Mr. Darcy’s steward. Let me recommend you, however, as a friend, not to give implicit confidence to all his assertions; for, as to Mr. Darcy’s using him ill, it is perfectly false: for, on the contrary, he has been always remarkably kind to him, though George Wickham has treated Mr. Darcy in a most infamous manner.
