I do not know the particulars, but I know very well that Mr. Darcy is not in the least to blame; that he cannot bear to hear George Wickham mentioned; and that though my brother thought he could not well avoid including him in his invitation to the officers, he was excessively glad to find that he had taken himself out of the way. His coming into the country at all is a most insolent thing, indeed, and I wonder how he could presume to do it. I pity you, Miss Eliza, for this discovery of your favourite’s guilt; but really, considering his descent, one could not expect much better.”
vi: - Ah, Miss Eliza, I heard that you are quite fond of George Wickham! Your sister has told me about him and asked me a thousand questions. I see that the young man forgot to tell you that he is the son of old Mr. Wickham, the late Mr. Darcy's steward. However, as a friend, I advise you not to believe everything he says. The notion that Mr. Darcy treated him poorly is completely wrong, for on the contrary, Mr. Darcy has always been very kind to him, even though George Wickham has treated Mr. Darcy in the most shameful manner. I do not know the details, but I know very clearly that Mr. Darcy is not to blame at all, and he does not want to hear anyone speak of George Wickham. Although my brother could not help but invite him to the ball, he was very glad to see him voluntarily absent. His moving to this area was indeed an insolent act; I wonder how he could have the audacity to do so. I pity you, Eliza, for discovering the wrongdoings of the person you admire, but considering his decline, no one could expect anything better.
tr: It hadn't been long since they parted when Miss Bingley came towards Elizabeth and, with a measured expression of disdain on her face, harassed her as follows: –"I heard, Miss Eliza, that you are quite fond of George Wickham! Your sister mentioned him to me, she kept asking a thousand questions; I realized that young man forgot to tell you some things, for instance, that he is old Wickham's son, that is, the late Mr. Darcy's steward. However, as a friend, my advice to you is not to believe everything he says immediately; as for Mr. Darcy having wronged him, that's a blatant lie; quite the contrary, he has always treated him very well, even though George Wickham has done everything possible to harm him. I don't know the details, but I do know that Mr. Darcy is not at fault in the slightest, and that he can't even bear to hear George Wickham's name; also, my brother thought he couldn't avoid inviting the officers, but he was very pleased to see him withdraw. His coming to the countryside is really a great impertinence; I truly wonder how he dared. I pity you for learning about your favorite's fault in this way, Miss Eliza; but honestly, considering the man's downfall, nothing better could be expected."
es: ––So, Miss Eliza, you are delighted with Mr. Wickham. I have learned from your sister who has spoken to me about him and asked me a thousand questions. It seems to me that this young man forgot to tell you, among many other things, that he is the son of old Wickham, the last steward of Mr. Darcy. Let me advise you, as a friend, not to trust too much in everything he tells you, because the idea that Mr. Darcy treated him badly is completely false; on the contrary, he has always been extraordinarily kind to him, although George Wickham has behaved towards Mr. Darcy in the most infamous manner. I do not know the details, but I know very well that Mr. Darcy is in no way to blame, that he cannot bear to even hear the name of George Wickham, and that, although my brother considered that he could not avoid including him in the list of invited officers, he was greatly relieved to see that he himself had stepped aside. The mere fact that he has come here to the countryside is a true insolence, and I cannot understand how he dared to do so. I pity you, Miss Eliza, for this discovery of the guilt of your favorite; but in reality, considering his origin, nothing better could be expected.

en: “His guilt and his descent appear, by your account, to be the same,” said Elizabeth, angrily; “for I have heard you accuse him of nothing worse than of being the son of Mr. Darcy’s steward, and of that, I can assure you, he informed me himself.”
vi: Elizabeth angrily: - According to what she said, his wrongdoing and his decline seemed to be one and the same, because I heard her condemn him for nothing worse than being the son of Mr. Darcy's steward, but I inform you that he himself told me about this.
tr: "His crime and his fall seem to be the same as in your story," said Elizabeth angrily; "because I haven't heard you accuse him of anything worse than being Mr. Darcy's steward's son, and rest assured, he himself had already told me as much.""
es: ––His guilt and his origin seem to be the same thing to you ––Elizabeth said angrily––; because the worst thing I have heard you accuse him of is being the son of Mr. Darcy's steward, and I can assure you, he had already informed me of that.

en: “I beg your pardon,” replied Miss Bingley, turning away with a sneer. “Excuse my interference; it was kindly meant.”
vi: I'm sorry for interfering. I only had good intentions.
tr: "Excuse me," replied Miss Bingley, turning up her nose as she walked away. "Pardon my interference; I said it with good intentions."
es: ––I beg you to excuse me ––replied Miss Bingley, turning away with disdain––. Forgive my intrusion; it was with the best intention.

en: “Insolent girl!” said Elizabeth to herself. “You are much mistaken if you expect to influence me by such a paltry attack as this. I see nothing in it but your own wilful ignorance and the malice of Mr. Darcy.” She then sought her eldest sister, who had undertaken to make inquiries on the same subject of Bingley. Jane met her with a smile of such sweet complacency, a glow of such happy expression, as sufficiently marked how well she was satisfied with the occurrences of the evening. Elizabeth instantly read her feelings; and, at that moment, solicitude for Wickham, resentment against his enemies, and everything else, gave way before the hope of Jane’s being in the fairest way for happiness.
vi: Miss Bingley turned away, sneering. Elizabeth whispered: "You are the one who is being insolent! You are greatly mistaken if you think you can influence me with such vile words. I see nothing in this but your deliberate ignorance and Mr. Darcy's malice." Then she went to find her eldest sister; her sister had already inquired Mr. Bingley about the same subject. Jane met her younger sister with a sweet, satisfied smile, her face glowing with happiness, clearly showing she had enjoyed the evening very much. Elizabeth immediately understood her sister's feelings.
tr: "Arrogant thing!" said Elizabeth to herself. "If you think you can affect me with such pitiful attacks, you are very mistaken. I see nothing in this but your deliberate ignorance and Mr. Darcy's malice." Then she looked for her sister; Jane had begun to probe Bingley on the same matter. She greeted her with such a sweet smile of happiness, such a joyful glow, that it spoke volumes about how pleased she was with what had happened that evening. Elizabeth understood her feelings at that moment, and in that instant, her solidarity with Wickham, her anger towards Wickham's enemies, and everything else faded away in the face of the hope that Jane was on the most beautiful path to happiness.
es: “Insolent!” said Elizabeth to herself. “You are very mistaken if you think you will influence me with such a petty attack. I see nothing in it but your stubborn ignorance and Darcy's malice.” Then she looked at her older sister who had dared to question Bingley about the same matter. Jane returned her gaze with such a sweet smile, with an expression of happiness and so much satisfaction that it clearly indicated she was very pleased with what had happened during the evening. Elizabeth instantly read her feelings; and in a moment all her concern for Wickham, her hatred towards his enemies, and everything else disappeared before the hope that Jane was on the best path to her happiness.

en: “I want to know,” said she, with a countenance no less smiling than her sister’s, “what you have learnt about Mr. Wickham. But perhaps you have been too pleasantly engaged to think of any third person, in which case you may be sure of my pardon.”
vi: She asked, with a smile as bright as her sister's: - I want to know what you have found out about Mr. Wickham. But perhaps you are too happy to think about a third person, in which case I apologize to you.
tr: "Tell me," she said with a face no less smiling than her sister's, "what did you learn about Mr. Wickham? But perhaps you were too occupied with happy things to think of a third person; if so, I apologize."
es: "I want to know," said Elizabeth as smiling as her sister, "what you have heard about Mr. Wickham." "But perhaps you have been too busy with more pleasant things to think about a third person..." "If that has been the case, you can be sure that I forgive you."

en: “No,” replied Jane, “I have not forgotten him; but I have nothing satisfactory to tell you. Mr. Bingley does not know the whole of his history, and is quite ignorant of the circumstances which have principally offended Mr. Darcy; but he will vouch for the good conduct, the probity and honour, of his friend, and is perfectly convinced that Mr. Wickham has deserved much less attention from Mr. Darcy than he has received; and I am sorry to say that by his account, as well as his sister’s, Mr. Wickham is by no means a respectable young man. I am afraid he has been very imprudent, and has deserved to lose Mr. Darcy’s regard.”
vi: Jane replied: - No, I haven't forgotten him, but I have nothing good to say to you about him. Mr. Bingley does not know everything about his past, and he is almost unaware of the circumstances that offended Mr. Darcy, but he can vouch for his friend's good conduct, honesty, and honor. He firmly believes that Mr. Wickham does not deserve Mr. Darcy's attention. I regret to say that, according to him and his sister, Mr. Wickham is not a respectable person. I fear that Wickham is too reckless and that Mr. Darcy's dislike of him is justified.
tr: "No," said Jane, "I haven't forgotten him; but there is nothing proper to tell you. Mr. Bingley doesn't know the whole story; he also doesn't know what originally angered Mr. Darcy; but he vouches for his friend's moral conduct, honor, and integrity; moreover, he is certain that Mr. Wickham has been treated better than he deserves by Mr. Darcy; I'm sorry to say that from what I've heard from him and his sister, Mr. Wickham is not a very reputable young man. I'm afraid he has behaved too recklessly and deserved to lose Mr. Darcy's trust."
es: ––No ––answered Jane––, I have not forgotten him, but I have nothing pleasant to tell you. Mr. Bingley does not know the whole story and is unaware of the circumstances that have so offended Mr. Darcy, but he vouches for the good conduct, integrity, and honesty of his friend, and is firmly convinced that Mr. Wickham has received more attention from Mr. Darcy than he deserved; and I regret to say that, according to Mr. Bingley and his sister, Mr. Wickham is far from being a respectable young man. I fear he has been imprudent and well deserves to have lost Mr. Darcy's consideration.

en: “Mr. Bingley does not know Mr. Wickham himself.”
vi: - Mr. Bingley doesn't know Mr. Wickham?
tr: "Does Mr. Bingley not know Mr. Wickham personally?""
es: ––Does Mr. Bingley not know Mr. Wickham personally?

en: “No; he never saw him till the other morning at Meryton.”
vi: - No; I only met him this morning at Meryton.
tr: "No; she had never seen him before last morning in Meryton.""
es: ––No, I had never seen him before the other day in Meryton.

en: “This account then is what he has received from Mr. Darcy. I am perfectly satisfied. But what does he say of the living?”
vi: - So, what you know is through Mr. Darcy. I am completely satisfied. But what did he say about the church income?
tr: "Then the things they know are what Mr. Darcy taught them. I am quite satisfied. So what does he say about the church?"
es: ––So what you know is what Mr. Darcy has told you. I am satisfied. And what does he say about the rectory?

en: “He does not exactly recollect the circumstances, though he has heard them from Mr. Darcy more than once, but he believes that it was left to him conditionally only.”
vi: - He does not remember anything about this matter, although more than once he has heard from Mr. Darcy, but he believes that this amount was left conditionally for Wickham.
tr: "She has heard from Mr. Darcy a few times but does not remember the events well, yet believes that the church was left to him conditionally."
es: ––He doesn't remember exactly how it was, although he has heard his friend tell it more than once; but he believes it was bequeathed to him only conditionally.

en: “I have not a doubt of Mr. Bingley’s sincerity,” said Elizabeth warmly, “but you must excuse my not being convinced by assurances only. Mr. Bingley’s defence of his friend was a very able one, I dare say; but since he is unacquainted with several parts of the story, and has learnt the rest from that friend himself, I shall venture still to think of both gentlemen as I did before.”
vi: Elizabeth said warmly: - I have no doubt about Mr. Bingley's sincerity, but you must forgive me if I am not convinced by his assurances. I can acknowledge that Mr. Bingley's defense of his friend has some basis, but since he is unaware of certain parts of the story and only knows the rest through his friend, I still think of Wickham and Darcy as I did before.
tr: "I have no doubt of Mr. Bingley's sincerity," said Elizabeth warmly: "but do not expect me to be convinced merely by suggestions. It is quite normal for Mr. Bingley to defend his friend; but since he does not know every aspect of the story and has learned the other sides from his friend, I believe I will continue to think the same about both gentlemen as before."
es: ––I do not doubt Mr. Bingley's sincerity ––said Elizabeth heatedly––, but forgive me if his assertions do not convince me. He does well to defend his friend; but since he is unaware of some parts of the story and the only thing he knows is what he has been told, I will continue to think of the two gentlemen the same as I did before.

en: She then changed the discourse to one more gratifying to each, and on which there could be no difference of sentiment. Elizabeth listened with delight to the happy though modest hopes which Jane entertained of Bingley’s regard, and said all in her power to heighten her confidence in it. On their being joined by Mr. Bingley himself, Elizabeth withdrew to Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last partner she had scarcely replied, before Mr. Collins came up to them, and told her with great exultation, that he had just been so fortunate as to make a most important discovery.
vi: Then she changed the conversation to a topic that everyone felt more comfortable with and that did not cause emotional conflict. Elizabeth happily listened to the modest hopes for happiness that Jane harbored about Bingley, and did her best to reinforce her sister's belief. When Mr. Bingley arrived, she returned to find Miss Lucas but gave brief answers to her questions about her recent dance partner before Mr. Collins approached. He cheerfully told her that he had just been fortunate to discover something important.
tr: Then he moved on to a topic that both would enjoy more and would not disagree on. He listened with pleasure to Jane's happy but modest hopes regarding Bingley's intentions and said everything he could to boost Jane's confidence. When Mr. Bingley came over, Elizabeth withdrew to Miss Lucas's side; before Miss Lucas could answer whether she liked her last husband, Mr. Collins came over and, in a state of rapture, said he had just made a very important discovery.
es: Having said this, both sisters started another conversation much more pleasant for both of them. Elizabeth listened delightedly to the happy yet modest hopes that Jane harbored regarding Bingley, and she said everything she could to encourage her confidence. When Mr. Bingley joined them, Elizabeth withdrew and went to talk with Miss Lucas, who asked her if she had liked her last partner. Elizabeth hardly had time to answer, because Collins presented himself to them, enthusiastically saying that he had been fortunate enough to make a very important discovery.

en: “I have found out,” said he, “by a singular accident, that there is now in the room a near relation to my patroness. I happened to overhear the gentleman himself mentioning to the young lady who does the honours of this house the names of his cousin Miss De Bourgh, and of her mother, Lady Catherine. How wonderfully these sort of things occur! Who would have thought of my meeting with—perhaps—a nephew of Lady Catherine de Bourgh in this assembly! I am most thankful that the discovery is made in time for me to pay my respects to him, which I am now going to do, and trust he will excuse my not having done it before. My total ignorance of the connection must plead my apology.”
vi: - I happened to learn that there is currently someone in the room who has a close relationship with my benefactor. I accidentally overheard him mentioning the name of this hostess, who is his cousin, Miss De Bourgh, and the name of her mother, Lady Catherine. It is wonderful to know this. Who could have guessed that I would meet Lady Catherine's nephew here! I am very pleased to have learned this just in time to greet him, and I believe he will forgive me for not knowing about this relationship, which can serve as an excuse for my apology.
tr: "I learned by accident," he said, "that there is a close relative of my boss in the room right now. I happened to overhear the gentleman personally telling the young lady of the house, Miss de Bourgh, and her mother, Lady Catherine's names. What wonderful things happen in life! Who would have thought that I might meet a nephew of Lady Catherine de Bourgh in this gathering! I am grateful to have learned this in time, so I can go and pay my respects now; I hope they will excuse me for not having gone earlier. My excuse is my ignorance of the relationship."
es: ––I have learned ––he said––, by a singular chance, that there is in this room a close relative of my benefactress. I had the pleasure of hearing the gentleman himself mention to the lady who hosts this house the names of his cousin, Miss de Bourgh, and her mother, Lady Catherine. How wonderfully these things happen! Who would have told me that I would find a nephew of Lady Catherine de Bourgh at this gathering! I am very glad to have made this discovery in time to pay my respects, which I will do right now. I trust you will forgive me for not having done so earlier, but my total ignorance of this relationship excuses me.

en: “You are not going to introduce yourself to Mr. Darcy?”
vi: - You don't intend to introduce yourself to Mr. Darcy, do you?
tr: "You will not introduce yourself to Mr. Darcy!""
es: ––Aren't you going to introduce yourself to Mr. Darcy?

en: “Indeed I am. I shall entreat his pardon for not having done it earlier. I believe him to be Lady Catherine’s nephew. It will be in my power to assure him that her Ladyship was quite well yesterday se’nnight.”
vi: - Actually, I intended to do so. I will ask for your forgiveness for not doing this sooner. I believe you are Lady Catherine's nephew. I will do my best to assure you that the lady is still in good health.
tr: "Of course, I will introduce you. I will also apologize for not introducing you earlier. I believe you are Lady Catherine's niece. I will tell her that until last night, her Ladyship was in good health and spirits."
es: ––Of course! I will ask him to excuse me for not having done it earlier. Don't you see that he is Lady Catherine's nephew? I will be able to tell him that Her Ladyship was very well the last time I saw her.

en: Elizabeth tried hard to dissuade him from such a scheme; assuring him that Mr. Darcy would consider his addressing him without introduction as an impertinent freedom, rather than a compliment to his aunt; that it was not in the least necessary there should be any notice on either side, and that if it were, it must belong to Mr. Darcy, the superior in consequence, to begin the acquaintance. Mr. Collins listened to her with the determined air of following his own inclination, and when she ceased speaking, replied thus,—
vi: Elizabeth tried to persuade him to abandon the idea, making him understand that Mr. Darcy would consider his approaching to start a conversation without an introduction as an improper and presumptuous attitude rather than a friendly inquiry about his aunt; that there was no need for them to recognize each other; that if necessary, Mr. Darcy should be the one to take the initiative to get acquainted due to his higher status. Mr. Collins listened to her with a determined look, still wanting to keep his intention, and when she finished speaking, he replied:
tr: Elizabeth tried very hard to dissuade him from the plan, saying that she would consider it an impertinent liberty rather than a compliment to her aunt for Mr. Darcy to speak to her without an introduction, that neither party needed such communication, and that even if they did, the right to initiate the acquaintance belonged to Mr. Darcy, who was superior in rank. Mr. Collins listened to her with a determined air of knowing better, and when she had finished speaking, he replied: "Dear Miss Elizabeth, I have great respect for your immense judgment in all matters within your understanding; but allow me to say, there is a great difference between the established rules of conduct among worldly men and those governing clergymen; permit me also to express that I see the religious office as equal in sanctity to the highest position in the kingdom – of course, maintaining humble behavior.
es: Elizabeth tried to dissuade him from doing such a thing by assuring him that Mr. Darcy would consider addressing him without a prior introduction as an impertinence and a boldness, rather than a compliment to his aunt; that there was no need to make himself known, and if there were, it would be up to Mr. Darcy, due to the superiority of his rank, to take the initiative. Collins listened to her, determined to follow his own impulses, and when Elizabeth stopped speaking, he replied:

en: “My dear Miss Elizabeth, I have the highest opinion in the world of your excellent judgment in all matters within the scope of your understanding, but permit me to say that there must be a wide difference between the established forms of ceremony amongst the laity and those which regulate the clergy; for, give me leave to observe that I consider the clerical office as equal in point of dignity with the highest rank in the kingdom—provided that a proper humility of behaviour is at the same time maintained. You must, therefore, allow me to follow the dictates of my conscience on this occasion, which lead me to perform what I look on as a point of duty. Pardon me for neglecting to profit by your advice, which on every other subject shall be my constant guide, though in the case before us I consider myself more fitted by education and habitual study to decide on what is right than a young lady like yourself;” and with a low bow he left her to attack Mr. Darcy, whose reception of his advances she eagerly watched, and whose astonishment at being so addressed was very evident. Her cousin prefaced his speech with a solemn bow, and though she could not hear a word of it, she felt as if hearing it all, and saw in the motion of his lips the words “apology,” “Hunsford,” and “Lady Catherine de Bourgh.” It vexed her to see him expose himself to such a man. Mr. Darcy was eyeing him with unrestrained wonder; and when at last Mr. Collins allowed him to speak, replied with an air of distant civility. Mr. Collins, however, was not discouraged from speaking again, and Mr. Darcy’s contempt seemed abundantly increasing with the length of his second speech; and at the end of it he only made him a slight bow, and moved another way: Mr. Collins then returned to Elizabeth.
vi: - Dear Miss Elizabeth, I have the utmost respect for your excellent judgment on all matters within your understanding, but allow me to say that there is a significant difference between the manners of the secular world and the rituals of the clergy. I must say that I regard the institution of the clergy with the same dignity as the highest titles in the kingdom – provided that proper humility is maintained in conduct. Therefore, you must allow me to follow the call of my conscience in this situation, so that I may perform what I consider to be a duty. Forgive me for not taking advantage of your advice, which would be a guiding star for me in other areas, although in the present case, I consider myself to have more understanding than a young lady like you, due to my education and constant learning, to decide what is right. He bent down and then went to meet Mr. Darcy. She eagerly watched how Mr. Darcy greeted him, clearly seeing that Mr. Darcy was very surprised to be approached. Her cousin began with a formal bow, though she couldn't hear what he said, she had the impression she heard everything clearly, watching his lips form the words "apology," "Hunsford," and "Lady Catherine de Bourgh." Her heart fluttered seeing him expose himself to such a person. Mr. Darcy looked at him with undisguised astonishment, and when Mr. Collins finally stopped speaking, he responded with little politeness. However, Mr. Collins was not discouraged and said a few more words, and Mr. Darcy's attitude seemed even more disdainful of what he heard. Finally, Mr. Collins bowed slightly and returned to Elizabeth.
tr: Mr. Collins listened to her with a determined air of knowing better, and when she had finished speaking, he replied: "Dear Miss Elizabeth, I have great respect for your immense judgment in all matters within your understanding; but allow me to say, there is a great difference between the established rules of conduct among worldly men and those governing clergymen; permit me also to express that I see the religious office as equal in sanctity to the highest position in the kingdom – of course, maintaining humble behavior. Therefore, allow me to do what my conscience tells me to do in this situation; my conscience urges me to do what I see as a duty. Forgive me for neglecting to take advantage of your advice; in every other matter, your advice will be my guide, but in the present issue, I consider myself more qualified than a young lady like you to decide what is right due to my education and occupation." And with a slight bow, he left her to approach Mr. Darcy; Elizabeth watched with curiosity as Mr. Darcy received him: it was very clear that he was surprised to be approached in such a manner. Her cousin began his speech with a slight bow: although Elizabeth could not hear a single word, she felt as if she heard everything; she saw the words "apology," "Hunsford," and "Lady Catherine de Bourgh" in the movement of his lips. It annoyed her to see him make a fool of himself to such a man. Mr. Darcy was looking at him with boundless astonishment; when Mr. Collins finally allowed him to speak, he replied with an air of distant politeness. Nevertheless, Mr. Collins's courage to speak again was not broken; the length of the second speech increased Mr. Darcy's disdain, and in the end, he merely gave a slight bow and walked away in the other direction. Mr. Collins turned back to Elizabeth.
es: ––My dear Miss Elizabeth, I have the highest opinion in the world of your excellent judgment in all kinds of matters, as befits your intelligence; but allow me to tell you that there must be a great difference between the established forms of courtesy for laypeople and those accepted for clergymen; let me warn you that the office of clergyman is, in terms of dignity, equivalent to the highest rank in the kingdom, provided that those who hold it behave with the appropriate humility. So allow me to follow the dictates of my conscience which on this occasion lead me to do what I consider a duty. Excuse me, then, for not following your advice which in all other matters will constantly serve as my guide, but I believe that in this case I am more qualified, due to my education and habitual study, than a young lady like you, to decide what is proper. Collins made a bow and walked away to greet Darcy. Elizabeth did not lose sight of him to see Darcy's reaction, whose astonishment at being approached in such a manner was evident. Collins began his speech with a solemn bow, and, although she could not hear him, it was as if she could, for she could read the words "apologies," "Hunsford," and "lady Catherine de Bourgh" on his lips. It irritated her that he would make a fool of himself in front of a man like Darcy. Darcy observed him without suppressing his astonishment, and when Collins allowed him to speak, he responded with distant courtesy. However, Collins was not discouraged and continued speaking. Darcy's disdain grew with the length of his second speech, and, in the end, he only made a slight bow and went elsewhere. Collins then turned back to Elizabeth.

en: “I have no reason, I assure you,” said he, “to be dissatisfied with my reception. Mr. Darcy seemed much pleased with the attention. He answered me with the utmost civility, and even paid me the compliment of saying, that he was so well convinced of Lady Catherine’s discernment as to be certain she could never bestow a favour unworthily. It was really a very handsome thought. Upon the whole, I am much pleased with him.”
vi: He said: - I have no reason to be dissatisfied with the audience. Mr. Darcy seemed very pleased with my interest. He responded to me very politely, and even complimented me by saying that he had great faith in Lady Catherine's judgment, knowing that she would never bestow favors on someone unworthy. That was a very generous thought. Overall, I am very satisfied with him.
tr: "I assure you," he said, "I have no complaints about the way I was received. Mr. Darcy seemed very pleased with the attention I showed. He gave extremely kind responses and even paid a compliment, saying that he trusted Lady Catherine's decisions so much that he knew she would never do a favor to someone undeserving. It was indeed a very nice thought. As a result, I was very pleased with him."
es: ––I assure you ––he said to her–– that I have no reason to be dissatisfied with the reception Mr. Darcy has given me. My attention has pleased him greatly and he has responded with the utmost politeness, even doing me the honor of stating that he was so convinced of Lady Catherine's good judgment that he took it for granted she would never bestow a favor unless it was deserved. It was truly a very beautiful phrase. In short, I am very pleased with him.

en: As Elizabeth had no longer any interest of her own to pursue, she turned her attention almost entirely on her sister and Mr. Bingley; and the train of agreeable reflections which her observations gave birth to made her perhaps almost as happy as Jane. She saw her in idea settled in that very house, in all the felicity which a marriage of true affection could bestow; and she felt capable, under such circumstances, of endeavouring even to like Bingley’s two sisters. Her mother’s thoughts she plainly saw were bent the same way, and she determined not to venture near her, lest she might hear too much. When they sat down to supper, therefore, she considered it a most unlucky perverseness which placed them within one of each other; and deeply was she vexed to find that her mother was talking to that one person (Lady Lucas) freely, openly, and of nothing else but of her expectation that Jane would be soon married to Mr. Bingley. It was an animating subject, and Mrs. Bennet seemed incapable of fatigue while enumerating the advantages of the match. His being such a charming young man, and so rich, and living but three miles from them, were the first points of self-gratulation; and then it was such a comfort to think how fond the two sisters were of Jane, and to be certain that they must desire the connection as much as she could do. It was, moreover, such a promising thing for her younger daughters, as Jane’s marrying so greatly must throw them in the way of other rich men; and, lastly, it was so pleasant at her time of life to be able to consign her single daughters to the care of their sister, that she might not be obliged to go into company more than she liked. It was necessary to make this circumstance a matter of pleasure, because on such occasions it is the etiquette; but no one was less likely than Mrs. Bennet to find comfort in staying at home at any period of her life. She concluded with many good wishes that Lady Lucas might soon be equally fortunate, though evidently and triumphantly believing there was no chance of it.
vi: Since Elizabeth no longer cared about anything else, she paid close attention to her sister and Mr. Bingley. The sight of the two being close to each other made her feel a joy almost as great as what Jane was experiencing. She imagined her sister living in this very house with all the happiness that a marriage based on love could bring, and in this context, she thought she could even grow fond of Bingley's two sisters. She clearly saw that her mother's intentions were aligned with the same feelings, so she decided not to go near her for fear of hearing too much. Thus, when they sat down to eat, she found the unfortunate circumstance that had placed her and her mother close to each other, and she was very uneasy to see her mother talking comfortably and openly with Lady Lucas, discussing nothing but her expectations of seeing Jane soon married to Mr. Bingley. It was a lively topic, and Mrs. Bennet seemed tireless in listing the advantages of the marriage. The first points she boasted about were a charming, wealthy young man living only three miles away; and then it was truly comforting to see that his two sisters also liked Jane, being sure that they too desired the match as much as she did. Moreover, this was a promising situation for the younger siblings, as Jane's wedding and such a brother-in-law would bring them closer to other wealthy men, and finally, it was a relief in this stage of her life to be able to entrust the care of her unmarried daughters to their elder sister, so when they went out to socialize, she wouldn't have to follow them more closely than she wished. In this situation, it was necessary to accept and find joy, due to the social etiquette of such occasions, although she did not feel as comfortable as everyone else being confined indoors at any stage of life. She concluded with many good wishes for Lady Lucas to soon be as fortunate as she was, although she confidently believed with a sense of triumph that her friend would have no such luck.
tr: When Elizabeth had no business of her own to attend to, she immediately turned all her attention to her sister and Mr. Bingley; the train of thoughts that emerged from her observations made her almost as happy as Jane. She imagined Jane settled in the same house with all the happiness that a true love marriage could bring; and under those circumstances, she felt that she could even try to love Bingley's two sisters. She could clearly see that her mother's thoughts were in the same direction and decided not to approach her for fear of hearing too much. When they sat down to dinner, she saw that by a stroke of bad luck she was seated next to her; and her spirits sank even further when she saw her mother freely and openly conversing with Lady Lucas on her other side, constantly talking about how she hoped Jane would soon marry Mr. Bingley. – It was an exciting topic, and Mrs. Bennet seemed tireless in enumerating the advantages of that union. The most significant sources of joy were that the man was so charming, so rich, and lived only three miles away from them; then, seeing how fond Bingley's two sisters were of Jane, and how much they desired the union as much as she did, was a great comfort. Moreover, it was a promising thing for her younger sisters as well, because Jane making such a great marriage would pave the way for them to find wealthy men; and finally, knowing that at her age, she could place her unmarried daughters under their sister's protection and not have to go out into society unless she wanted to was a source of happiness. This situation had to be turned into a source of pleasure because etiquette required it; but no one could enjoy staying at home less than Mrs. Bennet at any period of her life. She ended her words with wishes for Lady Lucas to be as fortunate as she was, although she clearly and joyfully believed that this was not possible.
es: Elizabeth, who had no interest whatsoever in continuing to talk with Collins, devoted her attention almost entirely to her sister and Bingley; the multitude of pleasant thoughts that her observations gave rise to made her almost as happy as Jane. She imagined her settled in that great house with all the happiness that a marriage for true love can provide, and felt so delighted that she even believed that Bingley's two sisters might come to like her. It was not difficult for her to guess that her mother's thoughts followed the same path, and she decided not to risk approaching her to avoid hearing her comments. Unfortunately, at dinner time, they had to sit next to each other. Elizabeth was very upset to see how her mother kept talking to Lady Lucas, freely and openly, about her hope that Jane would soon marry Bingley. The topic was captivating, and Mrs. Bennet seemed never to tire of enumerating the advantages of that alliance. Just considering the youth of the groom, his attractiveness, his wealth, and the fact that he lived only three miles from Longbourn, made Mrs. Bennet happy. But in addition, one had to take into account how delighted Bingley's two sisters were with Jane, who would undoubtedly be as pleased with the union as she herself was. Moreover, Jane's marriage to someone of such high status was very promising for her younger daughters, who would thus have more opportunities to meet wealthy men. Finally, it was a relief, at her age, to be able to entrust her single daughters to the care of their sister, and not have to accompany them herself except when she felt like it. There was no choice but to take this circumstance as a reason for satisfaction, for in such cases, etiquette demands it; but there was no one who liked staying comfortably at home more at any time in her life. She concluded by wishing Lady Lucas that she would soon be as fortunate as she was, though triumphantly thinking that there was not much hope.

en: In vain did Elizabeth endeavour to check the rapidity of her mother’s words, or persuade her to describe her felicity in a less audible whisper; for to her inexpressible vexation she could perceive that the chief of it was overheard by Mr. Darcy, who sat opposite to them. Her mother only scolded her for being nonsensical.
vi: Elizabeth tried in vain to curb her mother's incessant chatter or persuade her not to be so loud in expressing her happiness, for in an indescribable agitation, she could see Mr. Darcy, sitting opposite them, had overheard most of the conversation. Her mother only scolded her for being unreasonable.
tr: Elizabeth tried in vain to control the speed of her mother's words, to persuade her to recount her happiness in a less audible whisper; she was extremely annoyed to see that most of her mother's words were reaching the ears of Mr. Darcy, who was sitting opposite. Her mother contented herself with scolding her, saying she was being foolish.
es: Elizabeth tried in vain to repress her mother's words and to convince her to express her joy a little more quietly; because, to her greater annoyance, she noticed that Darcy, who was sitting opposite them, was hearing almost everything. The only thing her mother did was scold her for being so foolish.

en: “What is Mr. Darcy to me, pray, that I should be afraid of him? I am sure we owe him no such particular civility as to be obliged to say nothing he may not like to hear.”
vi: - What is Mr. Darcy to you that makes you afraid of him? You know very well that you don't need to be so polite to him that you dare not say something he might not like to hear.
tr: "What do I care about Mr. Darcy, for heaven's sake, why should I be afraid of him? I'm sure we don't owe him the courtesy of not saying things he wouldn't like to hear."
es: ––What does Mr. Darcy mean to me? Tell me, why should I be afraid of him? We don't owe him any special attention to feel obliged not to say anything that might upset him.

en: “For heaven’s sake, madam, speak lower. What advantage can it be to you to offend Mr. Darcy? You will never recommend yourself to his friend by so doing.”
vi: - Mom, please, I beg you to speak softly. What good does it do to insult Mr. Darcy? His friends will never think well of you if you keep doing that.
tr: "Please, mother, speak softly. What can offending Mr. Darcy gain you? –You cannot make him speak well of you to his friend by acting this way."
es: ––For the love of God, mom, speak more quietly! What do you gain by offending Mr. Darcy? The only thing you'll achieve, if you do, is to look bad in front of his friend.

en: Nothing that she could say, however, had any influence. Her mother would talk of her views in the same intelligible tone. Elizabeth blushed and blushed again with shame and vexation. She could not help frequently glancing her eye at Mr. Darcy, though every glance convinced her of what she dreaded; for though he was not always looking at her mother, she was convinced that his attention was invariably fixed by her. The expression of his face changed gradually from indignant contempt to a composed and steady gravity.
vi: However, her words had no effect. The mother still blatantly voiced her opinions. Elizabeth kept blushing out of embarrassment and unease. She couldn't help but occasionally glance at Mr. Darcy, seeing exactly what she had feared; for although he seldom looked at her, she believed he was still attentively listening. His expression gradually changed from contemptuous indignation to sternness and calmness.
tr: Nothing he said worked. His mother continued to voice her thoughts in the same audible tone. Elizabeth blushed repeatedly in shame and discomfort. She often couldn't resist glancing at Mr. Darcy, and each time she realized her worst fear had come true; even if Mr. Darcy wasn't always looking at her mother, Elizabeth felt his attention was constantly fixed on her mother. The expression on his face gradually shifted from a haughty disdain to a calm and steady seriousness.
es: But nothing he said had any effect. The mother continued to express her opinion with the same nonchalance. Elizabeth was becoming more and more flushed with embarrassment and displeasure. She couldn't stop looking at Darcy frequently, although each glance convinced her more of what she was fearing. Darcy rarely fixed his eyes on the mother, but Elizabeth had no doubt that his attention was on what was being said. The expression on his face gradually shifted from disdain and indignation to an unperturbed seriousness.

en: At length, however, Mrs. Bennet had no more to say; and Lady Lucas, who had been long yawning at the repetition of delights which she saw no likelihood of sharing, was left to the comforts of cold ham and chicken. Elizabeth now began to revive. But not long was the interval of tranquillity; for when supper was over, singing was talked of, and she had the mortification of seeing Mary, after very little entreaty, preparing to oblige the company. By many significant looks and silent entreaties did she endeavour to prevent such a proof of complaisance,—but in vain; Mary would not understand them; such an opportunity of exhibiting was delightful to her, and she began her song. Elizabeth’s eyes were fixed on her, with most painful sensations; and she watched her progress through the several stanzas with an impatience which was very ill rewarded at their close; for Mary, on receiving amongst the thanks of the table the hint of a hope that she might be prevailed on to favour them again, after the pause of half a minute began another. Mary’s powers were by no means fitted for such a display; her voice was weak, and her manner affected. Elizabeth was in agonies. She looked at Jane to see how she bore it; but Jane was very composedly talking to Bingley. She looked at his two sisters, and saw them making signs of derision at each other, and at Darcy, who continued, however, impenetrably grave. She looked at her father to entreat his interference, lest Mary should be singing all night. He took the hint, and, when Mary had finished her second song, said aloud,—
vi: In the end, Mrs. Bennet had nothing more to say. Lady Lucas, having yawned at the long-winded accounts of joys she saw no chance of sharing, was left in peace to enjoy the ham and chicken. Elizabeth began to recover. But the tranquility did not last long, for when the meal ended, a suggestion was made for singing, and she felt tormented seeing Mary, after a little encouragement, preparing to contribute to the entertainment. She tried to prevent such indulgence with many suggestive and pleading glances, but to no avail. Mary did not care to understand; such an opportunity to perform was her delight, and she began her song. Elizabeth's eyes were fixed on her sister with the most wretched feelings; and she restlessly watched her through several not very well-received musical passages as they concluded. Upon receiving thanks, Mary also perceived the implied wish for her to sing another song, so she began again. Mary's talents were not suited for such a style of performance; she had a weak voice and overly affected mannerisms. Elizabeth fell into despair. She looked over at Jane to see how her sister was enduring it, but Jane was calmly conversing with Bingley. She looked at her two younger sisters, seeing them making mocking gestures at each other. She looked at Darcy, seeing him still stern and reserved. She glanced at her father to implore him to intervene, lest Mary sing all night. He understood, and when Mary finished her second song, he spoke loudly:
tr: Finally, Mrs. Bennet had nothing more to say; Lady Lucas, who had begun to yawn from repeatedly hearing the pleasures that Mrs. Bennet deemed impossible to share, was left with the taste of cold ham and chicken. Elizabeth then began to come to her senses. However, the silence did not last long; after the meal, there was talk of singing, and she saw that Mary was preparing to respond to the requests after very little insistence. She tried to prevent such an indiscretion with meaningful looks and silent pleas, but in vain; Mary did not understand these; she liked the opportunity to show off; she began her song. Elizabeth's eyes were fixed on her in agony, she watched impatiently as Mary progressed through several verses, but as the verses ended, she saw that it was not worth the patience, because when Mary seemed to receive a signal for another song among the table's thanks, she started a new song after a half-minute pause. Mary's talents were not suited for such a display; her voice was weak, her manner affected. Elizabeth was in pain. She looked at Jane to see how she was enduring it; but Jane was calmly talking to Bingley. She looked at her two sisters, saw that they were making signs of disdain to each other; she looked at Darcy, but he maintained his incomprehensibly serious demeanor. She looked at her father, hoping he would intervene so that Mary would not sing all night. Her father got the signal, and when Mary finished her second song, he said loudly, "You sang wonderfully, my dear.
es: However, there came a moment when Mrs. Bennet had nothing more to say, and Lady Lucas, who had long been yawning at the repetition of delights in which she saw no possibility of participating, indulged in the pleasures of chicken and ham. Elizabeth breathed a sigh of relief. But this interval of tranquility did not last long; after dinner, there was talk of singing, and she had to endure the ordeal of seeing Mary, after very little persuasion, prepare to treat those present with her singing. With significant looks and silent pleas, Elizabeth tried to prevent this display of condescension, but it was useless. Mary could not understand what she meant. Such an opportunity to showcase her talent captivated her, and she began her song. Elizabeth kept watching her with a painful sensation, observing the progress of the concert with an impatience that was not rewarded in the end, for Mary, upon receiving a slight hint to continue among the expressions of gratitude from her audience, after a minute's pause, began another song. Mary's abilities were not the most suitable for such an exhibition; she had little voice and an affected style. Elizabeth endured a true agony. She looked at Jane to see how she was bearing it, but she was talking calmly with Bingley. She looked at his sisters and saw that they were making mocking gestures to each other, and at Darcy, who remained serious and unperturbed. Finally, she looked at her father, imploring his intervention to prevent Mary from singing all night. He took the hint and when Mary finished her second song, he said loudly:

en: “That will do extremely well, child. You have delighted us long enough. Let the other young ladies have time to exhibit.”
vi: - That's good enough, my daughter. You have entertained enough. Let the other young ladies have their time to perform.
tr: Her father got the signal, and when Mary finished her second song, he said loudly, "You sang wonderfully, my dear. You have made us all happy enough. Let some other young ladies show themselves now."
es: ––Girl, that's enough. You've done very well, you've delighted us quite enough; now let the other young ladies shine.

en: Mary, though pretending not to hear, was somewhat disconcerted; and Elizabeth, sorry for her, and sorry for her father’s speech, was afraid her anxiety had done no good. Others of the party were now applied to.
vi: Although pretending not to hear, Mary felt somewhat disappointed. Elizabeth pitied Mary, pitied her father, but feared that worrying would still not help. The others were encouraged to show their talents.
tr: Although Mary pretended not to hear, she was a bit upset; Elizabeth, who was worried for her and for her father's words, feared that her concern was in vain. Then the other members of the group were consulted.
es: Mary, although she pretended not to hear, was a little disconcerted. Elizabeth felt sorry for her and regretted that her father had said that. She realized that due to her uneasiness, she had not acted well at all. Now it was someone else's turn to sing.

en: “If I,” said Mr. Collins, “were so fortunate as to be able to sing, I should have great pleasure, I am sure, in obliging the company with an air; for I consider music as a very innocent diversion, and perfectly compatible with the profession of a clergyman. I do not mean, however, to assert that we can be justified in devoting too much of our time to music, for there are certainly other things to be attended to. The rector of a parish has much to do. In the first place, he must make such an agreement for tithes as may be beneficial to himself and not offensive to his patron. He must write his own sermons; and the time that remains will not be too much for his parish duties, and the care and improvement of his dwelling, which he cannot be excused from making as comfortable as possible. And I do not think it of light importance that he should have attentive and conciliatory manners towards everybody, especially towards those to whom he owes his preferment. I cannot acquit him of that duty; nor could I think well of the man who should omit an occasion of testifying his respect towards anybody connected with the family.” And with a bow to Mr. Darcy, he concluded his speech, which had been spoken so loud as to be heard by half the room. Many stared—many smiled; but no one looked more amused than Mr. Bennet himself, while his wife seriously commended Mr. Collins for having spoken so sensibly, and observed, in a half-whisper to Lady Lucas, that he was a remarkably clever, good kind of young man.
vi: Mr. Collins said: - If I were fortunate enough to have a good singing voice, I would be very honored to contribute to the enjoyment, as I consider music a healthy pastime and entirely compatible with a clergyman. However, I do not mean to say that we have a legitimate reason to spend much time on music, as there are certainly other tasks that need to be done. A pastor managing a parish has many tasks to handle. First and foremost, he must arrange with the higher powers to be effective in his duties without offending his patron. He must write his own sermons, and the remaining time cannot be so extensive that it neglects parish duties. He also has to take care of and improve his living quarters without being condemned for extravagance. I consider it equally important that he must have an attitude of care and reconciliation with everyone, especially those who have elevated him. I cannot exempt him from these duties, just as I cannot think well of someone who has missed the opportunity to show respect to anyone related to the family. He leaned towards Mr. Darcy as he concluded his speech, which was delivered loudly enough for half the room to hear clearly. Many people stared at him intently. Many people smiled, but no one appeared as interested as Mr. Bennet, while his wife enthusiastically praised Mr. Collins for his heartfelt words, whispering to Mrs. Lucas that he was a particularly virtuous and wise young man.
tr: "If I were fortunate enough to be able to sing," said Mr. Collins, "I would take great pleasure in entertaining this assembly with a song; I see music as a very innocent occupation, perfectly in harmony with the profession of clergy. –However, I do not say we should devote too much time to music, because there are other things that need attention. A village parson has many duties to attend to. –For one, he must make a contribution agreement that will be beneficial to himself and not disturb his patron. He must write his own sermons; the remaining time is barely enough for church duties and the maintenance and repair of his home, and it would be inexcusable not to make his home as comfortable as possible. Moreover, I find it very important that he should have a careful and conciliatory attitude towards everyone, especially towards those to whom he owes his appointment. I cannot absolve him from this duty; in fact, let me say, I would not look kindly on him missing an opportunity to show his respect to anyone connected with the family. " And he concluded his speech by bowing to Mr. Darcy; he had spoken so loudly that half the room had heard him. –Many people stared –many people smiled; but no one seemed more amused than Mr. Bennet; at that moment his wife was seriously engaged in praising Mr. Collins for making such a meaningful speech: in a half-whisper she was telling Lady Lucas that he was quite an intelligent, well-bred young man.
es: ––If I ––said Collins then–– had the good fortune to be apt for singing, I would very much like to entertain the audience with a romance. I consider music to be an innocent distraction and completely compatible with the clerical profession. By this, I do not mean to say that it is right to devote too much time to music, for there are, of course, other things to attend to. The rector of a parish has a lot of work. First of all, he has to make an adjustment of the tithes that is beneficial to him and not burdensome to his patron. He has to write the sermons, and the time left is never enough for the parish duties and for the care and improvement of his parishioners whose lives he is obliged to make as bearable as possible. And I consider it of great importance that he be attentive and conciliatory with everyone, especially with those to whom he owes his position. I consider this indispensable and cannot hold in good esteem the man who would waste the opportunity to pay his respects to anyone related to the family of his benefactors. And with a bow to Mr. Darcy, he concluded his speech, spoken so loudly that half the room heard it. Many stared at him intently, many smiled, but no one was as amused as Mr. Bennet, while his wife seriously praised Collins for having spoken so sensibly, and whispered to Lady Lucas that he was a very good person and extremely clever.

en: To Elizabeth it appeared, that had her family made an agreement to expose themselves as much as they could during the evening, it would have been impossible for them to play their parts with more spirit, or finer success; and happy did she think it for Bingley and her sister that some of the exhibition had escaped his notice, and that his feelings were not of a sort to be much distressed by the folly which he must have witnessed. That his two sisters and Mr. Darcy, however, should have such an opportunity of ridiculing her relations was bad enough; and she could not determine whether the silent contempt of the gentleman, or the insolent smiles of the ladies, were more intolerable.
vi: For Elizabeth, it seemed as though her family had conspired together to showcase themselves as prominently as possible on this occasion; they could not have played their roles with higher spirits or better results. She thought Mr. Bingley and her sister were truly fortunate that he did not notice some of the performances, and his feelings were not too distressed by the ridiculous actions he had witnessed. However, she found it unfortunate that Mr. Bingley’s sisters and Mr. Darcy had the opportunity to mock her relatives, and she was unsure whether Mr. Darcy's silent arrogance or the sisters' disdainful smiles were more bearable.
tr: It seemed to Elizabeth as if her entire family had conspired to disgrace themselves throughout the evening; they could not have played their roles more sincerely or with greater success; she was glad for Bingley and her sister that he had missed some of the disgrace; fortunately, Bingley's feelings were not the kind to be troubled by the foolishness he must have witnessed. However, it was bad enough that her two sisters had found an opportunity to mock Mr. Darcy's relatives, and Elizabeth could not decide whether Mr. Darcy's silent disdain or the two ladies' insolent smiles were more unbearable.
es: To Elizabeth, it seemed that if her family had agreed to make themselves as ridiculous as possible that night, they could not have done it better nor achieved such success; and she was very glad that Bingley and his sister had not witnessed most of the spectacle and that Bingley was not the kind of person who cared about or was bothered by the madness he might have witnessed. It was bad enough that the sisters and Darcy had the opportunity to mock her family; and she did not know what she found more intolerable: Darcy's silent contempt or the ladies' insolent smirks.

en: The rest of the evening brought her little amusement. She was teased by Mr. Collins, who continued most perseveringly by her side; and though he could not prevail with her to dance with him again, put it out of her power to dance with others. In vain did she entreat him to stand up with somebody else, and offered to introduce him to any young lady in the room. He assured her that, as to dancing, he was perfectly indifferent to it; that his chief object was, by delicate attentions, to recommend himself to her; and that he should therefore make a point of remaining close to her the whole evening. There was no arguing upon such a project. She owed her greatest relief to her friend Miss Lucas, who often joined them, and good-naturedly engaged Mr. Collins’s conversation to herself.
vi: She did not feel any joy in the remaining time. Mr. Collins teased her, persistently clinging to her; and although he could not dance with her again, he found ways to prevent her from dancing with others. She earnestly asked him to dance with someone else and offered to introduce him to any young lady in the room, but he refused. He reassured her that he did not like dancing at all, that his main purpose was the delicate attentions he wanted to bestow upon her, and thus he wanted to make his intentions clear by staying close to her for the rest of the time. There was no arguing about this. She felt greatly relieved whenever Miss Lucas came over to them and cheerfully started a conversation with Mr. Collins.
tr: The rest of the evening brought very little amusement. She was weary of Mr. Collins, who stubbornly stood by her side; although he could not persuade her to dance again, he also did not allow her to dance with others. Elizabeth tried in vain to get rid of him; she even offered to introduce him to one of the young ladies in the room. The man said that he did not care in the least about dancing, that his main aim was to win her favor by showing delicate attention, and therefore he insisted on staying by her side all evening. There was no arguing with such a project. Her friend Miss Lucas often came over to them and meekly took over the task of listening to Mr. Collins' conversation, which allowed Elizabeth to feel somewhat at ease.
es: The rest of the night passed for her without the slightest interest. Collins drove her crazy with his insistence on not leaving her side. Although he did not manage to convince her to dance with him again, he prevented her from dancing with others. It was useless for her to beg him to go chat with other people and to offer to introduce him to some young ladies at the party. Collins assured her that dancing did not matter to him and that his main desire was to make himself agreeable to her with delicate attentions, so he had decided to stay by her side all night. There was nothing to argue about such a plan. Her friend Miss Lucas was the only one who consoled her by frequently sitting by her side and diverting Collins' conversation towards her.

en: She was at least free from the offence of Mr. Darcy’s further notice: though often standing within a very short distance of her, quite disengaged, he never came near enough to speak. She felt it to be the probable consequence of her allusions to Mr. Wickham, and rejoiced in it.
vi: At least she no longer had to endure the annoyance of Mr. Darcy paying her any more attention. Although he often stayed a short distance away, somewhat unburdened, he never came close enough to converse. She thought it might be because she had hinted at Mr. Wickham, and she was glad about this.
tr: At least she did not have to endure the boredom that Mr. Darcy could cause; although he was often very close and standing by himself, he never came close enough to talk. Elizabeth felt that this might be the result of his implications regarding Mr. Wickham, and she was pleased.
es: At least in this way she was free of Darcy, who, although sometimes found himself at a short distance from them completely unoccupied, did not approach to speak to them. Elizabeth attributed it to the result of her allusions to Wickham and was glad of it.

en: The Longbourn party were the last of all the company to depart; and by a manœuvre of Mrs. Bennet had to wait for their carriage a quarter of an hour after everybody else was gone, which gave them time to see how heartily they were wished away by some of the family. Mrs. Hurst and her sister scarcely opened their mouths except to complain of fatigue, and were evidently impatient to have the house to themselves. They repulsed every attempt of Mrs. Bennet at conversation, and, by so doing, threw a languor over the whole party, which was very little relieved by the long speeches of Mr. Collins, who was complimenting Mr. Bingley and his sisters on the elegance of their entertainment, and the hospitality and politeness which had marked their behaviour to their guests. Darcy said nothing at all. Mr. Bennet, in equal silence, was enjoying the scene. Mr. Bingley and Jane were standing together a little detached from the rest, and talked only to each other. Elizabeth preserved as steady a silence as either Mrs. Hurst or Miss Bingley; and even Lydia was too much fatigued to utter more than the occasional exclamation of “Lord, how tired I am!” accompanied by a violent yawn.
vi: The Longbourn family left the ball last. With Mrs. Bennet's arrangements, they had to wait for their carriage for 15 minutes after everyone else had gone. This gave them enough time to see how warmly some members of the host family bid them farewell. Mrs. Hurst and her sister barely spoke except to complain of tiredness, clearly wanting to see the guests off as quickly as possible. The two did not want to continue conversing with Mrs. Bennet, despite her attempts to start a conversation, and this created an awkward atmosphere for everyone. Mr. Collins did not help matters by going on at length praising Mr. Bingley and his two sisters for their elegance in manners, as well as their outstanding hospitality and courtesy towards the guests. Darcy said nothing. Mr. Bennet, also in silence, amused himself by observing the scene around him. Mr. Bingley and Jane stood together, slightly apart from everyone else, speaking only to each other. Even Lydia was too tired to say anything more than “Oh my, I am so tired!” accompanied by a long yawn.
tr: The Longbourn group was the last to leave; due to Mrs. Bennet's maneuver, they had to wait fifteen minutes after everyone else had left for their carriage, which gave them the opportunity to see how heartily some members of the family wished for their departure. Mrs. Hurst and her sister hardly opened their mouths except to complain of fatigue; it was clear that they wanted the house to themselves. They repelled every attempt Mrs. Bennet made to start a conversation, thereby creating a severe silence over the whole group; Mr. Collins' long speeches, full of compliments about the elegance of the entertainment arranged by Mr. Bingley and his sisters, and their hospitality and kindness as a mark of their treatment of their guests, did nothing to ease them. Darcy said nothing. Mr. Bennet, in the same silence, was enjoying the scene. Mr. Bingley and Jane stood a little apart from the others, talking only to each other. Elizabeth also maintained her steady silence with Mrs. Hurst or Miss Bingley; even Lydia, except for occasionally exclaiming "My God, how tired I am!" with a violent yawn, was too exhausted to say anything else.
es: The Longbourn family was the last to leave. Mrs. Bennet managed to make them wait for the carriages for a quarter of an hour after everyone else had left, which allowed them to notice how eager some members of the Bingley family were for them to disappear. Mrs. Hurst and her sister barely opened their mouths except to complain of fatigue; they were visibly impatient to be alone in the house. They rejected all of Mrs. Bennet's attempts at conversation and the liveliness dwindled, despite Collins' long speeches congratulating Bingley and his sisters on the elegance of the party and the hospitality and finesse with which they had treated their guests. Darcy said absolutely nothing. Mr. Bennet, as silent as he, enjoyed the scene. Bingley and Jane were together and a little apart from the others, talking to each other. Elizabeth maintained the same silence as Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley. Even Lydia was too exhausted to say more than "Good heavens! How tired I am!" amid great yawns.

en: When at length they arose to take leave, Mrs. Bennet was most pressingly civil in her hope of seeing the whole family soon at Longbourn; and addressed herself particularly to Mr. Bingley, to assure him how happy he would make them, by eating a family dinner with them at any time, without the ceremony of a formal invitation. Bingley was all grateful pleasure; and he readily engaged for taking the earliest opportunity of waiting on her after his return from London, whither he was obliged to go the next day for a short time.
vi: Finally, when they bid each other farewell, Mrs. Bennet, with the most constrained politeness, expressed her desire to welcome the entire family to Longbourn, specifically telling Mr. Bingley that everyone would be very happy if he could come for an informal meal with the family at any time, instead of a formal invitation. Bingley cheerfully accepted, willing to take advantage of the earliest opportunity to visit her after he returned from London, as he had to leave the next day for a short period.
tr: When they finally rose to leave, Mrs. Bennet, in her most polite manner, expressed her hope of seeing the entire family at Longbourn as soon as possible. Addressing Mr. Bingley specifically, she mentioned that there was no need for formalities between them and that they would be very happy if he and his family came to dinner without waiting for an invitation. Bingley was very pleased and promised to visit them as soon as he returned from London, where he had to go for a short while the next day.
es: When they finally got up to say goodbye, Mrs. Bennet insisted very courteously on her desire to soon see the whole family at Longbourn. She specifically addressed Bingley to tell him that they would be very honored if one day he came to their house to have lunch with them as a family, without the formality of a formal invitation. Bingley thanked her delightedly and immediately committed to taking the first opportunity that presented itself to visit them upon his return from London, where he had to go the next day, although he would not be long in coming back.

en: Mrs. Bennet was perfectly satisfied; and quitted the house under the delightful persuasion that, allowing for the necessary preparations of settlements, new carriages, and wedding clothes, she should undoubtedly see her daughter settled at Netherfield in the course of three or four months. Of having another daughter married to Mr. Collins she thought with equal certainty, and with considerable, though not equal, pleasure. Elizabeth was the least dear to her of all her children; and though the man and the match were quite good enough for her, the worth of each was eclipsed by Mr. Bingley and Netherfield.
vi: Mrs. Bennet was completely satisfied, leaving with the joy that, after preparing for the settlement of living arrangements, new carriages, and wedding dresses, she would surely see her daughter settled at Netherfield within three to four months. Thinking about another daughter marrying Mr. Collins also brought her great joy, though not to the same extent. Among the daughters, she loved Elizabeth the least, although the second suitor and match were good enough for her, the value of Mr. Bingley and Netherfield still surpassed them.
tr: Mrs. Bennet was quite satisfied; if she allowed some time for the necessary preparations, new carriages, and wedding clothes, it was certain that within three or four months she would see her daughter settled at Netherfield; she left the house in this delight. She thought with the same conviction and, if not the same, considerable pleasure that another of her daughters would marry Mr. Collins. Among her children, she was the least fond of Elizabeth; both the man and the marriage were quite suitable for Elizabeth, but of course, Mr. Bingley and Netherfield were much more valuable than them.
es: Mrs. Bennet was beside herself with joy and left the house convinced that, accounting for the necessary time for the celebration preparations, purchase of new carriages and wedding dresses, she would see her daughter settled in Netherfield within three or four months. With the same certainty and with considerable, though not equal, pleasure, she expected to soon have another daughter married to Collins. Elizabeth was the one she loved the least of all her daughters, and although the suitor and the wedding were more than enough for her, they were overshadowed by Bingley and by Netherfield.

en: CHAPTER XIX.
vi: Chapter 19
tr: Chapter XIX
es: CHAPTER XIX

en: THE next day opened a new scene at Longbourn. Mr. Collins made his declaration in form. Having resolved to do it without loss of time, as his leave of absence extended only to the following Saturday, and having no feelings of diffidence to make it distressing to himself even at the moment, he set about it in a very orderly manner, with all the observances which he supposed a regular part of the business. On finding Mrs. Bennet, Elizabeth, and one of the younger girls together, soon after breakfast, he addressed the mother in these words,—
vi: A new scene unfolded at Longbourn the next day. Mr. Collins had solemnly expressed his intentions. Having decided not to waste time since he could only take leave until Saturday, and feeling no shyness to be troubled even at this moment, he began in a very orderly manner, adhering to all the formalities of the matter. After breakfast, with Mrs. Bennet, Elizabeth, and one of her sisters present, he spoke to the mother:
tr: The next day opened a new scene at Longbourn. Mr. Collins formally made his proposal. Determined not to waste any time since his leave was only until the following Saturday, and feeling no shyness that would turn the matter into a tension for him at that moment, he set to work in a very orderly manner, adhering to all the rules he considered a usual part of the business. When he found Mrs. Bennet, Elizabeth, and one of the younger girls together immediately after breakfast, he addressed the mother with these words: "Madam, may I hope to obtain your approval if I request the honor of a private audience with your fair daughter Elizabeth this morning?"
es: The next day, there was another event at Longbourn. Collins formally proposed. He resolved to do it without delay, as his leave was expiring the following Saturday; and having full confidence in his success, he undertook the task methodically and with all the formalities he deemed necessary in such cases. Shortly after breakfast, he found Mrs. Bennet, Elizabeth, and one of the younger daughters together, and addressed the mother with these words:

en: “May I hope, madam, for your interest with your fair daughter Elizabeth, when I solicit for the honour of a private audience with her in the course of this morning?”
vi: - Madam, for the love you bear your beautiful daughter Elizabeth, could you grant me the honor of a private conversation with her this morning?
tr: When he found Mrs. Bennet, Elizabeth, and one of the younger girls together immediately after breakfast, he addressed the mother with these words: "Madam, may I hope to obtain your approval if I request the honor of a private audience with your fair daughter Elizabeth this morning?"
es: ––May I expect, madam, given your interest in your beautiful daughter Elizabeth, that I will be granted the honor of a private interview with her, during the course of this very morning?

en: Before Elizabeth had time for anything but a blush of surprise, Mrs. Bennet instantly answered,—
vi: While Elizabeth had not yet had time to react except to blush, Mrs. Bennet quickly replied:
tr: Elizabeth, her face flushed with astonishment, before she could find an opportunity to say anything, Mrs. Bennet immediately replied, "Oh my God!
es: Before Elizabeth had time to do anything more than blush with surprise, Mrs. Bennet instantly replied:

en: “Oh dear! Yes, certainly. I am sure Lizzy will be very happy—I am sure she can have no objection. Come, Kitty, I want you upstairs.” And gathering her work together, she was hastening away, when Elizabeth called out,—
vi: - Ah, yes, certainly, I'm sure Lizzy will be very happy. I'm sure the girl won't refuse. Come here, Kitty, I want you to go upstairs. As she was hurrying along, Elizabeth called after her:
tr: –Yes –of course. I am sure Lizzy will be very happy –I am sure she will not object. Come, Kitty, I need you upstairs." As she gathered her things and hurried away, Elizabeth called after her,
es: ––Oh, dear! That was the last thing missing! I'm sure Elizabeth will be delighted and won't have any objections. Come, Kitty, I need you upstairs. And gathering her work, she hurried to leave them alone. Elizabeth called her, saying:

en: “Dear ma’am, do not go. I beg you will not go. Mr. Collins must excuse me. He can have nothing to say to me that anybody need not hear. I am going away myself.”
vi: - Mom, please don't go. I beg you, don't go. Please forgive me, Mr. Collins. He has nothing to say to me that others don't need to hear. I'm about to leave as well.
tr: "Mother, don't go. I beg you, don't go. Mr. Collins must excuse me. He cannot have anything to say to me that no one else should hear. I am going myself."
es: ––Mom, dear, don't go. I beg you, don't go. Mr. Collins will excuse me; but he has nothing to say to me that everyone can't hear. It's me who is leaving.

en: “No, no, nonsense, Lizzy. I desire you will stay where you are.” And upon Elizabeth’s seeming really, with vexed and embarrassed looks, about to escape, she added, “Lizzy, I insist upon your staying and hearing Mr. Collins.”
vi: - No, no, don't be unreasonable, Lizzy. Your mother wants you to sit back down there. And when she saw Elizabeth with a frustrated and embarrassed expression as if wanting to hide, she added: - Lizzy, your mother wants you to stay and listen to Mr. Collins.
tr: "No, no, don't be ridiculous, Lizzy. Please stay where you are." And when he realized that Elizabeth was indeed about to flee with a troubled and anxious face, he added, "Lizzy, I insist that you sit and listen to Mr. Collins."
es: ––No, don't be silly, Lizzy. Stay where you are. And seeing that Elizabeth, upset and agitated, was about to leave, he added: ––Lizzy, I order you to stay and listen to Mr. Collins.

en: Elizabeth would not oppose such an injunction; and a moment’s consideration making her also sensible that it would be wisest to get it over as soon and as quietly as possible, she sat down again, and tried to conceal, by incessant employment, the feelings which were divided between distress and diversion. Mrs. Bennet and Kitty walked off, and as soon as they were gone, Mr. Collins began,—
vi: Elizabeth could not resist this command. A moment of consideration helped her think that the wisest course was to resolve the matter as quickly and smoothly as possible. She sat down, trying to conceal her mixed feelings of distress and distraction. Mrs. Bennet and Kitty walked away, and soon after, Mr. Collins began.
tr: Elizabeth could not resist such coercion – after a moment's thought, she decided that the wisest course was to get through this quickly and quietly, and she sat down again; she tried to mask her feelings, torn between discomfort and patience, with the work in her hand. Mrs. Bennet and Kitty went outside; as soon as they left, Mr. Collins began to speak.
es: Elizabeth could not disobey such a command. For a moment, she reconsidered and thought it wiser to end all of this as soon as possible in peace and tranquility. She sat down again and tried hard to conceal, on one hand, the feeling of discomfort, and on the other, how amusing she found the matter. Mrs. Bennet and Kitty left, and then Collins began:
