en: “Believe me, my dear Miss Elizabeth, that your modesty, so far from doing you any disservice, rather adds to your other perfections. You would have been less amiable in my eyes had there not been this little unwillingness; but allow me to assure you that I have your respected mother’s permission for this address. You can hardly doubt the purport of my discourse, however your natural delicacy may lead you to dissemble; my attentions have been too marked to be mistaken. Almost as soon as I entered the house I singled you out as the companion of my future life. But before I am run away with by my feelings on this subject, perhaps it will be advisable for me to state my reasons for marrying—and, moreover, for coming into Hertfordshire with the design of selecting a wife, as I certainly did.”
vi: - Dear Miss Elizabeth, please believe that your humility so far has not harmed you at all; on the contrary, it complements your perfections. In my eyes, you might be less charming if you had not shown such modesty, but I assure you that your esteemed mother has permitted me to converse with you in this manner. Surely you do not doubt my intentions, although your innate delicacy might make you ignore them; my feelings are too clear to be mistaken. From the moment I entered this house, I chose you as my companion for my future life. But before I stray too far from the subject due to my emotions in this matter, perhaps I should state the reasons for marriage when I came to Hertfordshire with the intention of finding a wife, for indeed I had this intention.
tr: "Believe me, dear Elizabeth, your modesty, far from doing you any disservice, adds perfection to your perfection. If it were not for this little unwillingness, you would appear less admirable in my eyes; but allow me to assure you, I have obtained your venerable mother's permission for this conversation. You cannot doubt the purpose of my words, but your natural delicacy may cause your mind to be confused; the interest I have shown was too evident to be disregarded. As soon as I entered the house, I chose you as my future life partner. But before my feelings on the subject take over my senses, it might be appropriate to state my reasons for marriage – indeed, the reason for my coming to Hertfordshire with the intention of choosing a wife."
es: ––Believe me, my dear Miss Elizabeth, that your modesty, instead of harming you, adds to your other perfections. I would have found you less adorable if you had not shown that little resistance. But allow me to assure you that your mother has given me permission for this interview. You must already know the object of my discourse; although your natural delicacy leads you to conceal it; my intentions have been too evident to be mistaken. Almost from the moment I set foot in this house, I chose you as the future companion of my life. But before expressing my feelings, it might be advisable to explain the reasons I have for marrying, and why I came to Hertfordshire with the idea of finding a wife precisely here.

en: The idea of Mr. Collins, with all his solemn composure, being run away with by his feelings, made Elizabeth so near laughing that she could not use the short pause he allowed in any attempt to stop him farther, and he continued,—
vi: The idea of Mr. Collins, in all his calm solemnity, about straying from the subject due to his emotions, made Elizabeth almost burst into laughter to the point where she couldn't seize the opportunity when he paused to stop him. He continued.
tr: Looking at his solemn demeanor, the thought that Mr. Collins's feelings could sweep him off his feet almost made Elizabeth laugh; therefore, she couldn't use the brief pause to prevent the man from going further; Mr. Collins continued:–
es: Elizabeth almost burst into laughter at the thought of him expressing his feelings; and she couldn't take advantage of the brief pause he made to prevent him from continuing. Collins continued:

en: “My reasons for marrying are, first, that I think it a right thing for every clergyman in easy circumstances (like myself) to set the example of matrimony in his parish; secondly, that I am convinced it will add very greatly to my happiness; and, thirdly, which perhaps I ought to have mentioned earlier, that it is the particular advice and recommendation of the very noble lady whom I have the honour of calling patroness. Twice has she condescended to give me her opinion (unasked too!) on this subject; and it was but the very Saturday night before I left Hunsford,—between our pools at quadrille, while Mrs. Jenkinson was arranging Miss De Bourgh’s footstool,—that she said, ‘Mr. Collins, you must marry. A clergyman like you must marry. Choose properly, choose a gentlewoman for my sake, and for your own; let her be an active, useful sort of person, not brought up high, but able to make a small income go a good way. This is my advice. Find such a woman as soon as you can, bring her to Hunsford, and I will visit her.’ Allow me, by the way, to observe, my fair cousin, that I do not reckon the notice and kindness of Lady Catherine de Bourgh as among the least of the advantages in my power to offer. You will find her manners beyond anything I can describe; and your wit and vivacity, I think, must be acceptable to her, especially when tempered with the silence and respect which her rank will inevitably excite. Thus much for my general intention in favour of matrimony; it remains to be told why my views were directed to Longbourn instead of my own neighbourhood, where I assure you there are many amiable young women. But the fact is, that being, as I am, to inherit this estate after the death of your honoured father (who, however, may live many years longer), I could not satisfy myself without resolving to choose a wife from among his daughters, that the loss to them might be as little as possible when the melancholy event takes place—which, however, as I have already said, may not be for several years. This has been my motive, my fair cousin, and I flatter myself it will not sink me in your esteem. And now nothing remains for me but to assure you in the most animated language of the violence of my affection. To fortune I am perfectly indifferent, and shall make no demand of that nature on your father, since I am well aware that it could not be complied with; and that one thousand pounds in the 4 per cents., which will not be yours till after your mother’s decease, is all that you may ever be entitled to. On that head, therefore, I shall be uniformly silent: and you may assure yourself that no ungenerous reproach shall ever pass my lips when we are married.”
vi: - My reasons for marriage are, first, I think every clergyman, when in favorable circumstances, should set a good example of married life in his parish. Second, I believe that married life will bring me boundless happiness; and third, which I should have mentioned first, due to the advice of the noble lady whom I have the honor to call my patroness. Twice she has condescended to give me her opinion on this matter, and only last Saturday before I left Hunsford, she said: “Mr. Collins, you must marry. A clergyman like you must marry. Choose carefully, select a good woman for me, and for yourself; she must be active and useful, not necessarily high-born but should be capable of managing household finances. That is my advice. Find such a woman as soon as possible, bring her to Hunsford, and I will visit her. ” By the way, my dear, allow me to remark that I consider Lady Catherine de Bourgh's concern and advice among my favorable circumstances. You will find her character far surpasses what I have described; your wit and vivacity will please her, especially when tempered with the silence and respect that her position inevitably commands. While I have intentions of marriage, I must also explain why I am inclined towards Longbourn rather than the area where I currently reside, which also has many charming young ladies. I will inherit this estate after your esteemed father passes away, and I would not be at ease if I did not choose one of his daughters as my spouse, so that they would suffer less when that unfortunate event occurs, although, as I have said, it will not happen for many years. My dear, that is my motivation, which I hope will not make you think less of me. Now, I have nothing more to say except to confirm to you, in the most vivid terms, my ardent affection. I am completely indifferent to money, and will not ask your father for anything in this regard because I know well that he cannot provide, and that you will only inherit a sum of one thousand pounds at four percent, which you will only receive after your mother's death. Therefore, on this matter, I will remain entirely silent. You can trust that I will not be so narrow-minded as to utter any complaints once we are married.
tr: "My reasons for getting married are as follows; first, I think it is right for a clergyman with comfortable conditions (like myself) to set an example of marriage in his village; second, I believe my happiness will greatly increase; third – and perhaps I should have mentioned this first, it is the special advice and recommendation of that noble lady whom I have the honor to call my patroness. She gave me her opinion on this matter twice (unsolicited); it was the Saturday night before I left Hunsford – between the quadrilles, Mrs. Jenkinson was adjusting Miss de Bourgh's footstool, and she said, 'Mr. Collins, you must marry. A clergyman like you must marry. –Make a suitable choice, select a young lady for my sake; for your own sake, she should be lively, useful, not overly pampered, but able to manage a small income. That is my advice. Find such a woman as soon as possible, bring her to Hunsford, and I will visit.' Meanwhile, my dear cousin, allow me to mention that I do not consider the privilege of being able to present you with Lady Catherine de Bourgh's interest and kindness as the least of my advantages. You will find her manners beyond anything I can describe; your intelligence and liveliness, I believe, will be acceptable to her, especially when tempered with the awe her rank will inspire. That is enough explanation for my intention to consider marriage; now it remains to explain why my thoughts have directed me to Longbourn instead of my own neighborhood; believe me, there are many beautiful young women in my own neighborhood. But the truth is, after the death of your esteemed father (may he live long), this estate will pass to me, and I would not feel at ease unless I chose one of his daughters as my wife to lessen the loss they would suffer, which I repeat, may it be long delayed. That was my reason, dear cousin; I believe this will not lower me in your eyes. Now it only remains to convince you of the intensity of my feelings in the most colorful language. I have no concern about a dowry; I will not make such a demand from your father, as I am aware it is impossible to meet; the only thing you may have a right to is that thousand-pound bond at 4 percent interest, which will not come to you until after your mother's death. I will not say a word about this; and rest assured, when we are married, not a single ungenerous complaint will ever escape my lips."
es: ––The reasons I have for marrying are: first, that the obligation of a clergyman in favorable circumstances like mine is to set an example of marriage in his parish; second, that I am convinced that it will contribute greatly to my happiness; and third, something that perhaps I should have mentioned first, that it is the particular advice and recommendation of the most noble lady whom I have the honor to call my patroness. Twice she has deigned to suggest it to me, even without my hinting at it, and on the very Saturday night before I left Hunsford and during our game of quadrille, while Mrs. Jenkinson was adjusting Miss de Bourgh's chair, she said to me: "Mr. Collins, you must marry. A clergyman like you must be married. Choose well, choose thinking of me and yourself; make sure she is an active and useful person, not highly educated, but capable of making the most of small incomes. This is my advice. Find that woman as soon as possible, bring her to Hunsford, and let me see her." Allow me, by the way, to say, fair cousin, that I do not consider as the least of the advantages I can offer you, the acquaintance and enjoyment of the kindness of Lady Catherine de Bourgh. Her manners will seem to you far above anything I can describe, and your liveliness and wit will seem very acceptable to her, especially when moderated by the discretion and respect that her high rank inevitably imposes. This is all regarding my general intentions in favor of marriage; I have nothing more to say except the reason why I have directed myself directly to Longbourn instead of seeking in my own locality, where, I assure you, there are many charming young ladies. But it is the case that being as I am the heir of Longbourn upon the death of your honorable father, whom I hope will live many years, I would not be satisfied if I did not choose a wife from among his daughters, to mitigate as much as possible the loss they will suffer upon the occurrence of such a sad event which, as I have already told you, I wish will not happen for many years. This has been the reason, fair cousin, and I hope it will not lower me in your esteem. And now I have only to express to you, in the most emphatic words, the strength of my affection. As for your dowry, it is absolutely indifferent to me, and I will not ask your father for anything that I know he cannot fulfill; so you will only have to bring the thousand pounds at four percent that will come to you upon your mother's death. But I will not be demanding and you can be assured that no interested reproach will come from my lips once we are married.

en: It was absolutely necessary to interrupt him now.
vi: It was absolutely necessary to interrupt the guy now.
tr: It was now necessary to stop him.
es: It was absolutely necessary to interrupt him immediately.

en: “You are too hasty, sir,” she cried. “You forget that I have made no answer. Let me do it without further loss of time. Accept my thanks for the compliment you are paying me. I am very sensible of the honour of your proposals, but it is impossible for me to do otherwise than decline them.”
vi: She exclaimed: - Sir, you have been too hasty. You forgot that I have not yet answered. I will answer immediately to avoid wasting more time. I thank you for your compliments. I am very touched by your proposal, but I can do nothing other than decline.
tr: "You are in too much of a hurry," cried Elizabeth. "You forget that I have not answered. Let me answer without wasting time. Accept my thanks for your compliments. I appreciate the sincerity of your proposal, but there is nothing I can do except say no."
es: ––You are going too fast ––exclaimed Elizabeth––. You forget that I have not answered you. Let me do so without further ado. I appreciate your attention and the honor that your proposal signifies, but I cannot help but decline it.

en: “I am not now to learn,” replied Mr. Collins, with a formal wave of the hand, “that it is usual with young ladies to reject the addresses of the man whom they secretly mean to accept, when he first applies for their favour; and that sometimes the refusal is repeated a second or even a third time. I am, therefore, by no means discouraged by what you have just said, and shall hope to lead you to the altar ere long.”
vi: Mr. Collins replied, with a ceremonious wave of his hand: - Until now, I have always known that when a young man proposes for the first time, young women often refuse while inwardly they are inclined to accept, and that they may refuse two or even three times. Therefore, I was not discouraged by what you just said, but rather hopeful that I would soon be married to you.
tr: "I do not wish to learn immediately," Mr. Collins replied, waving his hand formally, "it is normal for young ladies to reject the proposal of a man they intend to accept at first; sometimes a second, or even a third refusal may occur. Therefore, your words never discourage me; I hope to soon lead you to the altar.""
es: ––I know full well ––replied Collins with a grave gesture of his hand–– that among young women it is very common to reject the proposals of the man whom, deep down, they intend to accept, when he asks for their preference for the first time, and that the refusal is repeated a second or even a third time. For this reason, what you have just told me does not discourage me at all, and I hope to lead you to the altar soon.

en: “Upon my word, sir,” cried Elizabeth, “your hope is rather an extraordinary one after my declaration. I do assure you that I am not one of those young ladies (if such young ladies there are) who are so daring as to risk their happiness on the chance of being asked a second time. I am perfectly serious in my refusal. You could not make me happy, and I am convinced that I am the last woman in the world who would make you so. Nay, were your friend Lady Catherine to know me, I am persuaded she would find me in every respect ill qualified for the situation.”
vi: Elizabeth exclaimed: - Sir, I must say that your hope is quite unusual after I have explained everything to you. Please believe that I am not among those young women who dare to gamble their happiness on the chance of a second proposal. I am entirely serious in my refusal. You cannot bring happiness to me, and I am certain I am not the last woman in this world who could make you happy. No, if Lady Catherine truly understood me, I believe she would see that I do not meet any of her standards.
tr: "Believe me, sir," cried Elizabeth, "it is very strange that you still have hope after my explanation. I assure you, I am not one of those girls who would risk their happiness by expecting a second proposal (if such girls even exist). I am extremely serious in my refusal. You cannot make me happy, and I am certain that I am the last woman in the world who could make you happy. Moreover, if your friend Lady Catherine knew me, I know she would find me inadequate in every respect."
es: ––Good heavens, sir! ––exclaimed Elizabeth––. I don't know what hopes you could have left after my response! I assure you that I am not one of those women, if such women even exist, so reckless as to risk their happiness on the chance of being asked a second time. My refusal is very serious. You could not make me happy, and I am convinced that I am the last woman in the world who could make you happy. Moreover, if your friend Lady Catherine knew me, I have a feeling she would think that I am, in every respect, the least suitable for you.

en: “Were it certain that Lady Catherine would think so,” said Mr. Collins, very gravely—“but I cannot imagine that her Ladyship would at all disapprove of you. And you may be certain that when I have the honour of seeing her again I shall speak in the highest terms of your modesty, economy, and other amiable qualifications.”
vi: Mr. Collins said, very solemnly: - If Lady Catherine truly thinks that way, I cannot imagine that she would completely reject you. And please believe that when I have the honor of meeting her again, I will tell her in the most beautiful words about your humility, household economy skills, along with your other charming virtues.
tr: "Even if Lady Catherine is certain to think so," said Mr. Collins seriously, "I don't think she will object to you. You can be sure that when I have the honor of seeing her again, I will speak highly of your humility, modesty, and other positive qualities."
es: ––If it were true that Lady Catherine thought so... ––said Collins with the utmost seriousness–– but I am sure Her Ladyship would approve. And believe me ––when I have the honor of seeing her again, I will speak in the most commendatory terms of your modesty, your economy, and your other good qualities.

en: “Indeed, Mr. Collins, all praise of me will be unnecessary. You must give me leave to judge for myself, and pay me the compliment of believing what I say. I wish you very happy and very rich, and by refusing your hand, do all in my power to prevent your being otherwise. In making me the offer, you must have satisfied the delicacy of your feelings with regard to my family, and may take possession of Longbourn estate whenever it falls, without any self-reproach. This matter may be considered, therefore, as finally settled.” And rising as she thus spoke, she would have quitted the room, had not Mr. Collins thus addressed her,—
vi: - Mr. Collins, in fact, all your praises of me will be unnecessary. You should let me judge myself, and respect me by believing what I say. I wish you much happiness and wealth; by refusing you, I have done my best to prevent you from falling into the opposite situation. When you proposed to me, you must have satisfied your delicate feelings towards my family, so you can take possession of the Longbourn estate whenever possible without any self-reproach. Therefore, this matter can be considered concluded here. As she spoke, she stood up and might have left the room if Mr. Collins had not continued speaking:
tr: "Believe me, Mr. Collins, it will not be necessary for you to praise me. Allow me to evaluate myself; and please be kind enough to believe what I say. I wish you happiness and wealth, and by rejecting your proposal, I have done my utmost to prevent you from being otherwise. By proposing to me, you must have satisfied your kind feelings towards my family; you can take the Longbourn estate without any pangs of conscience when it becomes available. Therefore, this matter should be considered closed." As she said this, she stood up and was leaving the room when Mr. Collins spoke again:
es: ––Please, Mr. Collins, all the compliments you give me are unnecessary. Let me judge for myself and grant me the honor of believing what I say. I wish you to be very happy and very rich, and by rejecting your hand I am doing everything in my power to ensure it is so. In making me this proposal, you must consider the delicacy of your feelings towards my family satisfied, and when the time comes, you can take possession of the Longbourn inheritance without any pangs of conscience. Therefore, let us consider this matter definitively settled. While he was finishing saying this, he stood up and was about to leave the room, when Collins insisted again:

en: “When I do myself the honour of speaking to you next on the subject, I shall hope to receive a more favourable answer than you have now given me; though I am far from accusing you of cruelty at present, because I know it to be the established custom of your sex to reject a man on the first application, and, perhaps, you have even now said as much to encourage my suit as would be consistent with the true delicacy of the female character.”
vi: - When I have the honor of discussing this matter with you again, I hope to receive a more satisfactory answer than now; although I have no intention of accusing you of being cruel because I know it is customary for ladies to refuse a man the first time, perhaps; true to the delicacy of women, right now you have the intention of encouraging me to plead.
tr: "I hope that when I have the honor of discussing the matter with you next time, you will give me a more positive answer than you have now; I will not accuse you of cruelty at this moment, because I know it is customary for women to reject men at the first proposal; perhaps even now you have said enough to encourage me within the true delicacy of the female character.""
es: ––The next time I have the honor of speaking to you about this topic again, I hope to receive a more favorable response than the one you have given me now; although I am far from believing that you are cruel to me, for I already know that it is an incorrigible custom of women to reject men the first time they declare themselves, and you may have said all that just to make my request more consistent as befits the true delicacy of the female character.

en: “Really, Mr. Collins,” cried Elizabeth, with some warmth, “you puzzle me exceedingly. If what I have hitherto said can appear to you in the form of encouragement, I know not how to express my refusal in such a way as may convince you of its being one.”
vi: Elizabeth exclaimed, with little gentleness: - Mr. Collins, you have indeed put me in a most awkward position. If anything I have said so far has implied that I encouraged you, then I do not know how to refuse in a way that you would believe to be sincere.
tr: "Well, Mr. Collins," cried Elizabeth, beginning to get angry, "you astonish me greatly. If what I have said so far seems like a promise to you, I don't know how else to say no to convince you."
es: ––Really, Mr. Collins ––exclaimed Elizabeth somewhat heatedly–– you confuse me exceedingly. If you interpret everything I have said so far as encouragement, I do not know how to express my repulsion to convince you completely.

en: “You must give me leave to flatter myself, my dear cousin, that your refusal of my addresses are merely words of course. My reasons for believing it are briefly these:—It does not appear to me that my hand is unworthy your acceptance, or that the establishment I can offer would be any other than highly desirable. My situation in life, my connections with the family of De Bourgh, and my relationship to your own, are circumstances highly in my favour; and you should take it into further consideration that, in spite of your manifold attractions, it is by no means certain that another offer of marriage may ever be made you. Your portion is unhappily so small, that it will in all likelihood undo the effects of your loveliness and amiable qualifications. As I must, therefore, conclude that you are not serious in your rejection of me, I shall choose to attribute it to your wish of increasing my love by suspense, according to the usual practice of elegant females.”
vi: - My dear, you must allow me to feel gratified that your refusal is merely a matter of course. The reasons for my belief are quite simple. There seems to be no indication that I am unworthy of your acceptance, or that my status is insufficient. My circumstances, my connections with the De Bourgh family, and my relationship with your family are all highly advantageous for me; and you should also consider that although you have many charms, it is not certain that you will receive another proposal. Unfortunately, your dowry is too small for your beauty and other amiable qualities to have much effect. Since I must conclude that you are not serious in rejecting me, I can only believe that you wish for my love to grow deeper in suspense, as is often the way with elegant women.
tr: "Allow me to give myself some credit, dear cousin; your refusal of my offer is merely in words. Here are my reasons for believing so: –It does not seem to me that I am unworthy of you, and the life I offer is quite attractive. My position in life, my connections with the De Bourgh family, our kinship, all these are in my favor; if you think more thoroughly, despite your many charms, it appears you have not received any other marriage proposals so far. Unfortunately, your income is so small that it surely diminishes the effect of your beauty and charming qualities. Therefore, I conclude that you are not serious in rejecting me; as a reason for your refusal, I see that, as is customary for polite ladies, you wish to increase my love by making me wait."
es: ––You must let me presume, my dear cousin, that your rejection has been merely verbal. The reasons I have for believing this are as follows: I do not believe that my hand is unworthy of being accepted by you, nor that the position I offer is anything less than highly desirable. My situation in life, my connection with the Bourgh family, and my kinship with you are important circumstances in my favor. Consider, moreover, that despite your many attractions, it is not certain that you will receive another marriage proposal. Your fortune is so meager that it will unfortunately nullify the effects of your beauty and good qualities. Therefore, as I cannot deduce from all this that you have sincerely rejected me, I will choose to attribute it to your desire to increase my love with suspense, in accordance with the customary practice among elegant women.

en: “I do assure you, sir, that I have no pretensions whatever to that kind of elegance which consists in tormenting a respectable man. I would rather be paid the compliment of being believed sincere. I thank you again and again for the honour you have done me in your proposals, but to accept them is absolutely impossible. My feelings in every respect forbid it. Can I speak plainer? Do not consider me now as an elegant female intending to plague you, but as a rational creature speaking the truth from her heart.”
vi: - Sir, I beg you to believe that I had no intention of acting in such a refined manner when it truly only torments the spirit of a respectable man. Instead, I wish to be praised as a sincere person. I thank you and thank you again for the honor of your proposal, but I absolutely cannot accept it. My feelings in every aspect forbid this. Could I possibly be clearer than that? Now, please do not see me as a refined woman intending to distress you, but merely as a rational being who has spoken the truth from her heart.
tr: "Believe me, sir, I have no such courtesies as to torture a respectable man. I would be more pleased if my sincerity is believed. Thank you again and again for the honor you have given me with your offer, but it is impossible for me to accept your offer. My feelings forbid it in every respect. Could I be more clear? Now, think of me not as a polite woman trying to stall you, but as a sensible person speaking the truth from her heart."
es: ––I assure you, sir, that I do not find it at all elegant to torment a respectable man. I would prefer that you do me the courtesy of believing me. I thank you a thousand times for the honor you have done me with your proposal, but it is absolutely impossible for me to accept it. My feelings, in every respect, prevent me from doing so. Could I be any clearer? Do not consider me as an elegant woman who intends to torture you, but as a rational being who speaks from the heart.

en: “You are uniformly charming!” cried he, with an air of awkward gallantry; “and I am persuaded that, when sanctioned by the express authority of both your excellent parents, my proposals will not fail of being acceptable.”
vi: He exclaimed, with a clumsy attempt at flattery: - You are truly charming! I am convinced that when your dear parents agree, my proposal will be accepted.
tr: "You are extremely charming!" exclaimed Mr. Collins, with an air of awkward flirtation; "I believe that my proposal will be accepted once it is clearly approved by both of your parents.""
es: ––She is always charming! ––he exclaimed with coarse gallantry––. I cannot doubt that my proposal will be accepted when it is sanctioned by the authority of her excellent parents.

en: To such perseverance in wilful self-deception Elizabeth would make no reply, and immediately and in silence withdrew; determined, that if he persisted in considering her repeated refusals as flattering encouragement, to apply to her father, whose negative might be uttered in such a manner as must be decisive, and whose behaviour at least could not be mistaken for the affectation and coquetry of an elegant female.
vi: Elizabeth did not respond to such deliberate self-deception and immediately walked away. She had firmly resolved that if the gentleman persisted in interpreting her refusals as encouragements and then felt compelled to appeal to her father, her father's rejection would be unequivocal, and his demeanor would at least not be misinterpreted as the emotional and affected manner of a refined lady.
tr: Faced with such a stubbornness of self-deception, Elizabeth could not find an answer to give and immediately and quietly withdrew; if he insisted on interpreting her no as a promise of hope, she decided to appeal to her father; her father would say no in such a way that it would be understood as final; her father's behavior could not be mistaken for the coquetry or coyness of a polite woman.
es: Given such an effort to deceive himself, Elizabeth did not reply and left immediately without saying a word, determined that, if Collins persisted in considering her repeated refusals as a frivolous system of encouragement, she would turn to her father, whose rejection would be formulated in such a way that it would be unappealable and whose attitude, at least, could not be mistaken for the affectation and coquetry of an elegant lady.

en: CHAPTER XX.
vi: Chapter 20
tr: Chapter XX
es: CHAPTER XX

en: MR. COLLINS was not left long to the silent contemplation of his successful love; for Mrs. Bennet, having dawdled about in the vestibule to watch for the end of the conference, no sooner saw Elizabeth open the door and with quick step pass her towards the staircase, than she entered the breakfast-room, and congratulated both him and herself in warm terms on the happy prospect of their nearer connection. Mr. Collins received and returned these felicitations with equal pleasure, and then proceeded to relate the particulars of their interview, with the result of which he trusted he had every reason to be satisfied, since the refusal which his cousin had steadfastly given him would naturally flow from her bashful modesty and the genuine delicacy of her character.
vi: Mr. Collins was not allowed to remain quiet for long to contemplatively appreciate his successful courtship. Mrs. Bennet had been lingering in the hallway to see the conclusion of the conversation, and as soon as she saw Elizabeth open the door and walk out, quickly passing her towards the stairs, she entered the breakfast room and congratulated him and herself with gentle words on the prospect of a closer relationship between them. Mr. Collins received and reciprocated the congratulations with equal joy, then recounted to her the spirit of his exchange with Elizabeth, with the result that he believed he had every reason to be satisfied, as her refusal was merely a natural reaction of the true modesty, shyness, and delicacy in her character.
tr: Mr. Collins could not remain alone with his dreams of successful love for long; Mrs. Bennet, who had been lingering in the hall waiting for the conversation to end, entered the breakfast room when she saw Elizabeth open the door and pass by her quickly to go up the stairs, and warmly congratulated both Mr. Collins and herself on the possibility of becoming closer relatives. Mr. Collins accepted these congratulations and responded with equal pleasure; then he proceeded to recount the details of the meeting; he believed he had every reason to be satisfied with the outcome of the conversation, as his cousin's persistent refusal stemmed from her shy modesty and genuine elegance of character.
es: CHAPTER XX Collins was not left much time to silently ponder the success of his love; because Mrs. Bennet, who had stayed in the hallway waiting for the conversation to end, as soon as she saw Elizabeth open the door and head quickly towards the stairs, entered the dining room and congratulated Collins, rejoicing over the fortunate prospect of the imminent union. After accepting and returning those congratulations with the same enthusiasm, Collins proceeded to explain the details of the interview, with which he was satisfied, as his cousin's firm refusal could naturally only stem from her shy modesty and the delicacy of her character.

en: This information, however, startled Mrs. Bennet: she would have been glad to be equally satisfied that her daughter had meant to encourage him by protesting against his proposals, but she dared not believe it, and could not help saying so.
vi: However, his words surprised Mrs. Bennet. She should have felt as happy as he did, believing that her daughter's refusal was meant to encourage him further, but she did not dare to believe this and had to speak out.
tr: This information still surprised Mrs. Bennet; –she would have been equally pleased if her daughter had opposed the proposal with the intention of encouraging him, but she did not dare to believe it, and could not help but say that she did not dare.
es: But her news startled Mrs. Bennet. She too would have liked to believe that her daughter had only tried to encourage Collins by rejecting his proposals; but she did not dare to admit it, and thus she conveyed it to Collins.

en: “But depend upon it, Mr. Collins,” she added, “that Lizzy shall be brought to reason. I will speak to her about it myself directly. She is a very headstrong, foolish girl, and does not know her own interest; but I will make her know it.”
vi: - Mr. Collins, but according to this matter, Lizzy needs to be explained. I will speak to her directly. She is a very stubborn and foolish girl who does not see the benefits for her; but I will make her see.
tr: "But rest assured, Mr. Collins," she added, "Lizzy will come to her senses. I will speak to her personally. She is a very stubborn, foolish girl who doesn't know her own interest, but I will make sure she understands."
es: ––The important thing ––he added–– is that Lizzy comes to her senses. I will personally talk to her about this matter. She is a very stubborn and crazy girl and doesn't know what's good for her, but I'll make sure she understands.

en: “Pardon me for interrupting you, madam,” cried Mr. Collins; “but if she is really headstrong and foolish, I know not whether she would altogether be a very desirable wife to a man in my situation, who naturally looks for happiness in the marriage state. If, therefore, she actually persists in rejecting my suit, perhaps it were better not to force her into accepting me, because, if liable to such defects of temper, she could not contribute much to my felicity.”
vi: - I apologize for interrupting you, but if she truly is stubborn and foolish, I am not sure if she would be an ideal wife for someone in my situation, who seeks happiness in marriage. Therefore, if she genuinely rejects me, it might be better not to force her to accept me, because if she is against it, she cannot bring complete happiness to me.
tr: "Forgive me for interrupting, madam," cried Mr. Collins; "but if she is truly stubborn and foolish, I am not sure if she would be a reasonable wife for a man like me who naturally seeks happiness in marriage. If she persists in rejecting my proposal, it would be better not to force her to accept me, because if she has such flaws, she would not contribute much to my happiness."
es: ––Excuse me for interrupting ––exclaimed Collins––, but if she is indeed stubborn and crazy, I don't know if, all things considered, she is a desirable wife for a man in my situation, who naturally seeks happiness in marriage. Therefore, if she insists on rejecting my proposal, it might be better not to force her to accept me, because if she has those flaws, she wouldn't contribute much to my happiness.

en: “Sir, you quite misunderstand me,” said Mrs. Bennet, alarmed. “Lizzy is only headstrong in such matters as these. In everything else she is as good-natured a girl as ever lived. I will go directly to Mr. Bennet, and we shall very soon settle it with her, I am sure.”
vi: Mrs. Bennet said, worried: - Brother, you have misunderstood me. Lizzy is only stubborn in matters like this. In everything else, she is the most obedient. I will speak directly with her father, we will sort it out with her soon, I am sure of it.
tr: "Sir, you misunderstood," said Mrs. Bennet, becoming frightened. "Lizzy is only stubborn about matters like this. In every other matter, she is the most good-natured girl in the world. I will go straight to Mr. Bennet and take Elizabeth to settle the matter, I am sure."
es: ––You have misunderstood me ––said Mrs. Bennet alarmed––. Lizzy is stubborn only in these matters. In everything else, she is the most reasonable girl in the world. I will go directly to Mr. Bennet, and I have no doubt that we will soon come to an agreement with her.

en: She would not give him time to reply, but hurrying instantly to her husband, called out, as she entered the library,—
vi: She did not give him time to answer, hurriedly went to find her husband, and exclaimed as she entered the study:
tr: Without giving the man time to respond, she immediately hurried to her husband, calling out as she entered the library, "Oh, Mr. Bennet, you are urgently needed; we are in great distress.
es: Without giving him time to answer, she flew to meet her husband and upon entering the library exclaimed: "Oh, Mr. Bennet!"

en: “Oh, Mr. Bennet, you are wanted immediately; we are all in an uproar. You must come and make Lizzy marry Mr. Collins, for she vows she will not have him; and if you do not make haste he will change his mind and not have her.”
vi: - Dear, I need you right now, we are in turmoil. You must come and advise Lizzy to marry Mr. Collins, because she is determined not to marry him, and if you don't hurry, he will change his mind and won't want to marry her.
tr: Without giving the man time to respond, she immediately hurried to her husband, calling out as she entered the library, "Oh, Mr. Bennet, you are urgently needed; we are in great distress. You must come and make Lizzy marry Mr. Collins; she is insisting she won't, and if you don't hurry, the man will change his mind about taking her."
es: We need you urgently. We are in a predicament. You must go and convince Elizabeth to marry Collins, for she has sworn she will not and if you don't hurry, Collins will change his mind and won't want her anymore.

en: Mr. Bennet raised his eyes from his book as she entered, and fixed them on her face with a calm unconcern, which was not in the least altered by her communication.
vi: Mr. Bennet looked up from his book when she entered, gazing at her calmly without any sign of concern and without changing his demeanor as she spoke.
tr: As she entered, Mr. Bennet lifted his eyes from his book and fixed them on his wife's face with a calm indifference that was unaffected by what he heard.
es: When his wife entered, Mr. Bennet lifted his eyes from the book and fixed them on her face with a calm indifference that the news did not alter in the slightest.

en: “I have not the pleasure of understanding you,” said he, when she had finished her speech. “Of what are you talking?”
vi: When she finished speaking, he said: - I don't understand what you mean. What are you talking about?
tr: "I haven't had the pleasure of understanding you," he said when his wife finished speaking. "What are you talking about?"
es: ––I have not had the pleasure of understanding you ––he said when she finished her tirade––. What are you talking about?

en: “Of Mr. Collins and Lizzy. Lizzy declares she will not have Mr. Collins, and Mr. Collins begins to say that he will not have Lizzy.”
vi: - The matter of Mr. Collins and Elizabeth. Lizzy declared that she would not accept Mr. Collins, and Mr. Collins began to say that he would not want to marry Lizzy.
tr: "From Mr. Collins and Lizzy. Lizzy says she doesn't want Mr. Collins, and Mr. Collins is about to say he doesn't want Lizzy."
es: ––About Mr. Collins and Lizzy. Lizzy says she will not marry Mr. Collins, and Mr. Collins is beginning to say he will not marry Lizzy.

en: “And what am I to do on the occasion? It seems a hopeless business.”
vi: - What should I do in this situation? It seems like a hopeless matter.
tr: "So what should I do? –The situation looks hopeless."
es: ––And what am I going to do? It seems to me that there's no solution.

en: “Speak to Lizzy about it yourself. Tell her that you insist upon her marrying him.”
vi: - You must personally talk to Lizzy. Tell her that you want her to marry Mr. Collins.
tr: "You talk to Lizzy. Tell her that you insisted on marrying the man."
es: ––Talk to Lizzy. Tell her you want her to marry him.

en: “Let her be called down. She shall hear my opinion.”
vi: - Call the little one down here. It will follow my opinion.
tr: "Let them come. Let them learn my opinion."
es: ––Tell him to come down. He will hear my opinion.

en: Mrs. Bennet rang the bell, and Miss Elizabeth was summoned to the library.
vi: Mrs. Bennet rang the bell, and Miss Elizabeth was summoned to the study.
tr: Mrs. Bennet rang the bell; Miss Elizabeth was called to the library.
es: Mrs. Bennet rang the bell and Elizabeth was called to the library.

en: “Come here, child,” cried her father as she appeared. “I have sent for you on an affair of importance. I understand that Mr. Collins has made you an offer of marriage. Is it true?”
vi: He called out as she appeared: Come here, my child. Your father is calling you because there is something important. Your father heard that Mr. Collins has proposed to you. Is that true?
tr: "Come here, my child," said her father when Elizabeth appeared at the door. "I called you for an important matter. I heard that Mr. Collins has proposed to you. Is it true?"
es: ––Come, my daughter ––said her father as soon as the young woman entered––. I have sent for you regarding an important matter. They say that Collins has made you a marriage proposal, is it true?

en: Elizabeth replied that it was.
vi: Elizabeth answered that it was true:
tr: Elizabeth said it was true.
es: Elizabeth said yes.

en: “Very well—and this offer of marriage you have refused?”
vi: - Very well, and you turned down the proposal, didn't you?
tr: "Alright – did you also reject the marriage proposal?"
es: ––Very well; and they say that you have rejected them.

en: “I have, sir.”
vi: - Yes, father.
tr: "Yes, sir.""
es: ––That's right, Dad.

en: “Very well. We now come to the point. Your mother insists upon your accepting it. Is it not so, Mrs. Bennet?”
vi: - Very well. Now let's get to the point. Your mother wants you to agree. Isn't that right, dear?
tr: "Alright. Now we get to the point. Your mother insists that you accept. Isn't that right, Mrs. Bennet?"
es: ––Well. Now let's get to the point. Your mother wishes you to accept it. Isn't that right, Mrs. Bennet?

en: “Yes, or I will never see her again.”
vi: - That's right, otherwise I would never see its face again.
tr: "Yes, otherwise I won't look at your face again.""
es: Yes, or otherwise I don't want to see her anymore.

en: “An unhappy alternative is before you, Elizabeth. From this day you must be a stranger to one of your parents. Your mother will never see you again if you do not marry Mr. Collins, and I will never see you again if you do.”
vi: - So, there is an unfortunate choice before you. Elizabeth. From this day forward, you will become a stranger to either your father or your mother. Your mother will never see you again if you do not marry Mr. Collins, and your father will never see you again if you do.
tr: "You have an unhappy choice before you, Elizabeth. From this day onward, you must be a stranger to one of your parents. Your mother says she will never see you again if you do not marry Mr. Collins, and I will never see you again if you do."
es: ––You have a sad alternative before you, Elizabeth. From this day forward, you will have to renounce one of your parents. Your mother does not want to see you again if you do not marry Collins, and I do not want to see you again if you marry him.

en: Elizabeth could not but smile at such a conclusion of such a beginning; but Mrs. Bennet, who had persuaded herself that her husband regarded the affair as she wished, was excessively disappointed.
vi: Elizabeth could not suppress a smile upon hearing such a conclusion right at the beginning. But Mrs. Bennet was deeply disappointed because she had believed that her husband would agree with her.
tr: Elizabeth couldn't help but smile at such a beginning leading to such an end; but Mrs. Bennet, who believed that her husband would handle the matter as she wished, was very surprised.
es: Elizabeth could not help but smile at such a beginning; but Mrs. Bennet, who was convinced that her husband would advocate for that marriage, was disappointed.

en: “What do you mean, Mr. Bennet, by talking in this way? You promised me to insist upon her marrying him.”
vi: - What do you mean by saying that? You promised me you would force the girl to marry him.
tr: "What do you mean by talking this way, Mr. Bennet? You promised me that you would insist on her marrying him."
es: ––What does that way of speaking mean, Mr. Bennet? You had promised me that you would force her to marry Mr. Collins.

en: “My dear,” replied her husband, “I have two small favours to request. First, that you will allow me the free use of my understanding on the present occasion; and, secondly, of my room. I shall be glad to have the library to myself as soon as may be.”
vi: - Ma'am, I request two small favors from you. First: allow me the freedom to use my understanding of the matter, and second: to use the reading room. I would be very happy to continue reading as soon as possible.
tr: "My dear," replied her husband, "I am asking for two favors. First, allow me to use my mind freely on this matter, and then my room. The sooner my library is left to me, the happier I will be."
es: ––My dear ––replied her husband––, I have to ask you for two small favors: first, that you let me use my understanding freely in this matter, and second, that you let me enjoy my library alone as soon as you can.

en: Not yet, however, in spite of her disappointment in her husband, did Mrs. Bennet give up the point. She talked to Elizabeth again and again; coaxed and threatened her by turns. She endeavoured to secure Jane in her interest, but Jane, with all possible mildness, declined interfering; and Elizabeth, sometimes with real earnestness, and sometimes with playful gaiety, replied to her attacks. Though her manner varied, however, her determination never did.
vi: However, despite being disappointed in her husband, she still did not give up her intention. She spoke with Elizabeth again, alternately advising and threatening her. She wanted Jane to side with her, but Jane refused with all possible gentleness, and Elizabeth responded to her attacks sometimes with genuine seriousness, sometimes with playful banter. Although her attitude varied, she always remained resolute.
tr: Even though she was disappointed in her husband, Mrs. Bennet did not give up easily. She repeatedly talked to Elizabeth; sometimes she tried to flatter her, sometimes she threatened her. She also tried to get Jane on her side; but Jane, with all her mildness, avoided getting involved; Elizabeth responded to her mother's attacks sometimes with genuine excitement, sometimes with cheerful jesting. Though her style changed from time to time, her determination did not.
es: However, Mrs. Bennet, despite the disappointment she had with her husband, still did not give up. She spoke to Elizabeth again and again, flattering and threatening her alternately. She tried to get Jane on her side; but Jane, with all possible gentleness, preferred not to get involved. Elizabeth, sometimes with true seriousness, and other times jokingly, responded to her attacks; and although her mood changed, her determination remained unshakable.

en: Mr. Collins, meanwhile, was meditating in solitude on what had passed. He thought too well of himself to comprehend on what motive his cousin could refuse him; and though his pride was hurt, he suffered in no other way. His regard for her was quite imaginary; and the possibility of her deserving her mother’s reproach prevented his feeling any regret.
vi: Meanwhile, Mr. Collins was alone, pondering over what had happened. He thought too highly of himself to understand what could have motivated his cousin to reject him. Although his pride was wounded, he did not feel any other kind of distress. His feelings for her were merely the result of much imagination, and her situation of being scolded by her mother prevented any sense of regret in him.
tr: Meanwhile, Mr. Collins had fallen into solitary contemplation over what had transpired. He thought too highly of himself to understand why his cousin might reject him; although his pride was wounded, he felt no other pain. He had a very fanciful interest in Elizabeth; the possibility of deserving his mother's scoldings prevented him from feeling any regret.
es: Collins, meanwhile, silently pondered everything that had happened. He had too high a regard for himself to understand what reasons his cousin might have for rejecting him, and although his pride was wounded, he did not suffer in the least. His interest in his cousin was merely imaginary; the possibility that she might be deserving of her mother's reproaches prevented him from feeling any regret.

en: While the family were in this confusion, Charlotte Lucas came to spend the day with them. She was met in the vestibule by Lydia, who, flying to her, cried in a half whisper, “I am glad you are come, for there is such fun here! What do you think has happened this morning? Mr. Collins has made an offer to Lizzy, and she will not have him.”
vi: While the family was still bustling, Charlotte Lucas came to visit them. In the hall, she met Lydia, who approached her and whispered: - I'm glad to see you, because there's something amusing happening here. Do you know what happened this morning? Mr. Collins proposed to Elizabeth, and she did not accept.
tr: While the family was in this turmoil, Charlotte Lucas came to spend the day with them. She was met in the hall by Lydia; Lydia threw herself at her and exclaimed in a half-whisper, "I'm glad you came, because there's some strange fun here! –Guess what happened this morning? –Mr. Collins proposed to Lizzy, and Lizzy said she didn't want to."
es: While this confusion reigned in the family, Charlotte Lucas arrived, who was coming to spend the day with them. She met Lydia in the hall, who ran to her to quietly tell her what was happening. ––I'm glad you came, because there's a commotion here...! What do you think happened this morning? Mr. Collins proposed to Elizabeth and she turned him down.

en: “they entered the breakfast room”
vi: While Charlotte did not have time to respond, Kitty went to inform her of the news.
tr: Before Charlotte could respond, Kitty also came over to share the same news; as soon as they entered the breakfast room where Mrs. Bennet was sitting alone, Mrs. Bennet brought up the subject and asked Miss Lucas to take pity on their situation and persuade her friend Lizzy to comply with the wishes of the entire family.
es: Before Charlotte had time to answer, Kitty appeared, coming to give her the same news.

en: Charlotte had hardly time to answer before they were joined by Kitty, who came to tell the same news; and no sooner had they entered the breakfast-room, where Mrs. Bennet was alone, than she likewise began on the subject, calling on Miss Lucas for her compassion, and entreating her to persuade her friend Lizzy to comply with the wishes of her family. “Pray do, my dear Miss Lucas,” she added, in a melancholy tone; “for nobody is on my side, nobody takes part with me; I am cruelly used, nobody feels for my poor nerves.”
vi: As soon as they entered the breakfast room, where Mrs. Bennet was sitting alone, she also began with the same matter, hoping Miss Lucas would sympathize with her, earnestly asking her to persuade her friend Lizzy to comply with the family's wishes. She added, with a sorrowful voice: - Miss Lucas, please help me because no one agrees with me, no one is on my side, I am being treated cruelly, no one sympathizes with my nerves.
tr: Before Charlotte could respond, Kitty also came over to share the same news; as soon as they entered the breakfast room where Mrs. Bennet was sitting alone, Mrs. Bennet brought up the subject and asked Miss Lucas to take pity on their situation and persuade her friend Lizzy to comply with the wishes of the entire family. "Please speak, my dear Miss Lucas," she added in a sorrowful tone, "no one is on my side, no one supports me, they are being cruel to me, no one considers my nerves."
es: And as soon as they entered the dining room, where Mrs. Bennet was alone, she also began to talk to her about the matter. She begged her to have compassion and to try to convince Lizzy to yield to the wishes of the whole family. ––I beg you to intercede, dear Charlotte ––he added in a melancholic tone––, since no one is on my side, they treat me cruelly, no one sympathizes with my poor nerves.

en: Charlotte’s reply was spared by the entrance of Jane and Elizabeth.
vi: While Charlotte had not yet had time to respond, Jane and Elizabeth both walked in.
tr: Charlotte's response was interrupted by Jane and Elizabeth's entrance.
es: Charlotte saved herself the response, for at that moment Jane and Elizabeth entered.

en: “Ay, there she comes,” continued Mrs. Bennet, “looking as unconcerned as may be, and caring no more for us than if we were at York, provided she can have her own way. But I tell you what, Miss Lizzy, if you take it into your head to go on refusing every offer of marriage in this way, you will never get a husband at all—and I am sure I do not know who is to maintain you when your father is dead. I shall not be able to keep you—and so I warn you. I have done with you from this very day. I told you in the library, you know, that I should never speak to you again, and you will find me as good as my word. I have no pleasure in talking to undutiful children. Not that I have much pleasure, indeed, in talking to anybody. People who suffer as I do from nervous complaints can have no great inclination for talking. Nobody can tell what I suffer! But it is always so. Those who do not complain are never pitied.”
vi: Mrs. Bennet continued: - Ah, the young lady has arrived, it seems she doesn't care and no longer pays attention to us, as long as she can live her own way. But Miss Lizzy, let me tell you, if you keep stubbornly rejecting every proposal like this, you will never find a husband – and I don't know who will take care of you when your father passes away. I will not be able to take care of you – and I warn you about that. From today onwards, I will have nothing to do with you anymore. I told you in the reading room, you know, that I will never speak to you again, and you will see that I will do exactly as I said. I do not like talking to disobedient children. In fact, I do not like talking to anyone. People who are nervous wrecks like me do not like talking at all. No one can understand how much I suffer. But it is always like that. Those who do not complain are never understood.
tr: "Oh, here he comes," continued Mrs. Bennet, "look, he doesn't care at all; as if we were in York and he couldn't see us, doing whatever he pleases. –But let me tell you, Miss Lizzy –if you keep rejecting every suitor like this, you'll never find a husband –who do you think will take care of you when your father dies? –I certainly won't be able to take care of you –so I'm warning you. –From this day forward, I have nothing more to do with you. –Didn't I tell you in the library that I wouldn't speak to you again, see how I'm keeping my word. I don't speak to ungrateful children. –If it were up to me, I wouldn't speak to anyone. People with nervous complaints like mine are not inclined to talk. Only I know what I have suffered. They say those who don't express their troubles have no one to pity them."
es: ––There he is ––continued Mrs. Bennet––, as if nothing happened, he doesn't care about us at all, he disengages from everything just to get his way. I'll tell you one thing: if you get it into your head to keep rejecting all the marriage proposals you receive, you'll end up an old maid; and I don't know who will support you when your father dies. I won't be able to, I warn you. From today, I'm done with you forever. I told you in the library that I would never speak to you again; and what I say, I mean. I don't find any pleasure in talking to disobedient daughters. Nor with anyone. People like me who suffer from nerves are not fond of chatting. No one knows what I suffer! But it's always the same. Those who don't complain, no one pities them.

en: Her daughters listened in silence to this effusion, sensible that any attempt to reason with or soothe her would only increase the irritation. She talked on, therefore, without interruption from any of them till they were joined by Mr. Collins, who entered with an air more stately than usual, and on perceiving whom, she said to the girls,—
vi: In silence, the girls listened to their mother pouring out, knowing that any attempt to reason with or soothe her would only make her more upset. Therefore, she continued without pause until Mr. Collins entered, looking more solemn than ever. As soon as she saw him, she said:
tr: The girls listened to this plea in silence, knowing that trying to talk to her or calm her down would only increase her discomfort. Mrs. Bennet kept complaining, and no one intervened until Mr. Collins came to join them; seeing Mr. Collins enter with an even more pompous air than usual, Mrs. Bennet told the girls, "Now all of you hold your tongues and let me have a little chat with Mr. Collins alone.""
es: The daughters listened in silence to their mother's laments. They knew that if they tried to reason with her or calm her down, they would only succeed in irritating her more. So she continued speaking without anyone interrupting her, until Collins entered with a more solemn air than usual. Upon seeing him, Mrs. Bennet said to the girls:

en: “Now, I do insist upon it, that you, all of you, hold your tongues, and let Mr. Collins and me have a little conversation together.”
vi: - Now, I want all of you to keep quiet so that Mr. Collins and I can have a little conversation.
tr: Mrs. Bennet kept complaining, and no one intervened until Mr. Collins came to join them; seeing Mr. Collins enter with an even more pompous air than usual, Mrs. Bennet told the girls, "Now all of you hold your tongues and let me have a little chat with Mr. Collins alone.""
es: ––Now I ask you to shut your mouths and leave Mr. Collins and me so we can talk for a while.

en: Elizabeth passed quietly out of the room, Jane and Kitty followed, but Lydia stood her ground, determined to hear all she could; and Charlotte, detained first by the civility of Mr. Collins, whose inquiries after herself and all her family were very minute, and then by a little curiosity, satisfied herself with walking to the window and pretending not to hear. In a doleful voice Mrs. Bennet thus began the projected conversation:—
vi: Elizabeth silently stepped out of the room, Jane and Kitty following behind, but Lydia remained there, determined to hear everything. Charlotte stayed, firstly because Mr. Collins had politely inquired in detail about her and her family, and secondly out of a bit of curiosity, so she moved to the window and pretended not to be listening attentively. With a sorrowful voice, she began:
tr: Elizabeth quietly left the room, followed by Jane and Kitty, but Lydia remained in place, determined to hear everything she could; Charlotte stayed there first because of Mr. Collins' interest, who inquired thoroughly about her and her family's well-being, and then out of a little curiosity, she walked to the window and pretended not to hear while satisfying her curiosity. In a distressed voice, Mrs. Bennet began the anticipated conversation: –"Oh, Mr. Collins dear!"
es: Elizabeth left the room in silence; Jane and Kitty followed her, but Lydia did not move, determined to listen to everything she could. Charlotte, held back by Mr. Collins's courtesy, whose questions about her and her family followed one after another without interruption, and also a bit by curiosity, merely approached the window pretending not to listen. In a sad voice, Mrs. Bennet thus began her conversation:

en: “Oh, Mr. Collins!”
vi: - Oh, Mr. Collins!
tr: "Dear madam," replied Mr. Collins, "let us forever maintain our silence on this matter.
es: ––Oh, Mr. Collins!

en: “My dear madam,” replied he, “let us be for ever silent on this point. Far be it from me,” he presently continued, in a voice that marked his displeasure, “to resent the behaviour of your daughter. Resignation to inevitable evils is the duty of us all: the peculiar duty of a young man who has been so fortunate as I have been, in early preferment; and, I trust, I am resigned. Perhaps not the less so from feeling a doubt of my positive happiness had my fair cousin honoured me with her hand; for I have often observed, that resignation is never so perfect as when the blessing denied begins to lose somewhat of its value in our estimation. You will not, I hope, consider me as showing any disrespect to your family, my dear madam, by thus withdrawing my pretensions to your daughter’s favour, without having paid yourself and Mr. Bennet the compliment of requesting you to interpose your authority in my behalf. My conduct may, I fear, be objectionable in having accepted my dismission from your daughter’s lips instead of your own; but we are all liable to error. I have certainly meant well through the whole affair. My object has been to secure an amiable companion for myself, with due consideration for the advantage of all your family; and if my manner has been at all reprehensible, I here beg leave to apologize.”
vi: He replied: - Madam, let us remain silent about this matter forever. But he continued, with a dissatisfied tone: - I am not at all disappointed by your daughter's attitude. We have a duty to endure the unavoidable misfortunes; it is an unusual duty for a young man as fortunate as I am to have achieved success early, and I believe I can endure it. Perhaps no less is the doubt about my happiness if your beautiful daughter agreed to marry me; because I often find that we cannot fully endure when a chance, after being rejected, starts to lose a bit of its value in the way we perceive it. Madam, I hope you will not see me as having a disrespectful attitude towards your family when I withdraw my intentions towards your daughter, when I do not ask you and your husband to use your authority to intervene for me. I am concerned that my manner might be unpleasant when I accept your daughter's refusal instead of yours. But we all can make mistakes. Surely, I have had good intentions throughout this matter. My aim was to seek a charming life partner for myself with all considerations beneficial to your family, and if my attitude was blameworthy, I now ask you to forgive me.
tr: "Dear madam," replied Mr. Collins, "let us forever maintain our silence on this matter. It is not my place," he continued immediately after, in a voice that emphasized his displeasure, "to condemn your daughter's behavior. It is our duty to face unexpected disasters with resignation; it is especially the duty of a young man like myself, who has had the fortune to rise at a young age; and I have indeed resigned myself. It is not because I doubted the happiness I would feel if my beautiful cousin had granted me the honor of taking my hand; I have often observed that resignation takes on a marvelous quality when the beauty we are deprived of begins to lose its value in our eyes. I hope you do not think I have disrespected your family by withdrawing my claims regarding your daughter without showing the courtesy of asking you and Mr. Bennet to use your influence in my favor. I fear it may not be pleasant that I accepted the rejection from your daughter rather than from you. But we can all make mistakes. Throughout the whole matter, I was certainly very well-intentioned. My aim was to find a compassionate life partner for myself while also ensuring the benefit of your entire family; if I have behaved inappropriately, I apologize to you."
es: ––My dear madam ––he replied––, not another word on this matter. I am very far ––he continued with an accent that denoted his indignation–– from harboring any resentment towards your daughter's attitude. It is everyone's duty to resign themselves to inevitable misfortunes; and it is especially a duty for me, who has had the fortune of seeing myself so young in such an elevated position; I trust I will know how to resign myself. It may be that my beautiful cousin, by not wanting to honor me with her hand, has not diminished my positive happiness. I have often observed that resignation is never as perfect as when the denied happiness begins to lose some value in our estimation. I hope you do not suppose that I am disrespecting your family, my dear madam, by withdrawing my plans regarding your daughter without asking you and Mr. Bennet to interpose your authority on my behalf. I fear that my conduct, by accepting my rejection from your daughter's lips and not from yours, may be censurable. But we are all capable of making mistakes. I am sure I have acted with the best intention in this matter. My objective was to procure myself a kind companion with due consideration to the advantages this would bring to your entire family. If my conduct has been reproachable, I beg you to forgive me.

en: CHAPTER XXI.
vi: Chapter 21
tr: Chapter XXI
es: CHAPTER XXI

en: THE discussion of Mr. Collins’s offer was now nearly at an end, and Elizabeth had only to suffer from the uncomfortable feelings necessarily attending it, and occasionally from some peevish allusion of her mother. As for the gentleman himself, his feelings were chiefly expressed, not by embarrassment or dejection, or by trying to avoid her, but by stiffness of manner and resentful silence. He scarcely ever spoke to her; and the assiduous attentions which he had been so sensible of himself were transferred for the rest of the day to Miss Lucas, whose civility in listening to him was a seasonable relief to them all, and especially to her friend.
vi: The debate over Mr. Collins' proposal had now nearly reached its conclusion, and Elizabeth felt miserable due to her discomfort in participating in the discussion, sometimes exacerbated by her mother's irritable insinuations. As for the gentleman, his feelings were expressed not so much through confusion or disappointment, or by avoiding her, but through a rigid and silently frustrated demeanor. He spoke very little to her, and subsequently, his diligent attentions were redirected to Miss Lucas. Her polite attentiveness in listening to him relieved everyone, especially her friend.
tr: The discussion regarding Mr. Collins' proposal was now considered over; Elizabeth only had to endure the boredom that naturally arose from the argument and her mother's occasional irritable scoldings. As for the gentleman himself, his feelings were expressed not in shame or sorrow or attempts to avoid Elizabeth, but in cold manners and angry silence. He hardly spoke to Elizabeth; the determined praises he was well aware of were directed towards Miss Lucas for the rest of the day; Miss Lucas's kindness in listening to him greatly relieved everyone, especially her friend.
es: The discussions about Collins' offer were coming to an end; Elizabeth no longer had to endure more than that uncomfortable feeling, which inevitably derives from such situations, and, from time to time, some pointed allusions from her mother. As for the gentleman, he did not show himself to be disturbed, nor dejected, nor did he try to avoid Elizabeth, but expressed his feelings with an attitude of rigidity and a resentful silence. He hardly spoke to her; and those assiduous attentions so appreciated on his part, he dedicated all day to Miss Lucas who listened to him kindly, providing everyone and especially her friend Elizabeth with great relief.

en: The morrow produced no abatement of Mrs. Bennet’s ill humour or ill health. Mr. Collins was also in the same state of angry pride. Elizabeth had hoped that his resentment might shorten his visit, but his plan did not appear in the least affected by it. He was always to have gone on Saturday, and to Saturday he still meant to stay.
vi: The days did not help alleviate Mrs. Bennet's vexation or her poor health. Mr. Collins shared the same prideful anger. Elizabeth had hoped that his distress would shorten his visit, but this did not affect his plans at all. He had always intended to leave on Saturday, so he decided to stay until Saturday.
tr: The next morning brought no relief to Mrs. Bennet's discomfort or illness. Mr. Collins was in the same state of angry arrogance. Elizabeth had hoped that his anger might shorten his visit, but his plans seemed unaffected in any way. He had kept saying he would leave on Saturday, and he still intended to stay until Saturday.
es: The next morning, Mrs. Bennet's bad mood and poor health had not subsided. Mr. Collins also suffered from the wound to his pride. Elizabeth thought that his resentment would shorten his visit; but Mr. Collins's plans did not seem to be altered in the slightest. He had initially planned to leave on Saturday and intended to stay until Saturday.

en: After breakfast, the girls walked to Meryton, to inquire if Mr. Wickham were returned, and to lament over his absence from the Netherfield ball. He joined them on their entering the town, and attended them to their aunt’s, where his regret and vexation and the concern of everybody were well talked over. To Elizabeth, however, he voluntarily acknowledged that the necessity of his absence had been self-imposed.
vi: After breakfast, the daughters walked to Meryton to see if Mr. Wickham had returned, and also to lament his absence at the Netherfield ball. He met them as they entered the town and accompanied them to their aunt's house. He spoke very eloquently about his regrets, his troubles, and the concern of everyone. However, with Elizabeth, he was willing to admit that he had felt it necessary to be absent. He said:
tr: After breakfast, the girls walked to Meryton to ask if Mr. Wickham had returned and to lament his absence at the Netherfield ball. Mr. Wickham joined them as they entered the town and accompanied them to their aunt's house; at home, Mr. Wickham's sorrow and grief, and everyone's curiosity were discussed in detail. –Only, he explained to Elizabeth, it was his own decision not to attend.
es: After lunch, the girls went to Meryton to find out if Wickham had returned, and to lament his absence at the Netherfield ball. They found him upon entering the town and he accompanied them to their aunt's house, where they talked at length about his absence and misfortune and the consternation it had caused everyone. But in front of Elizabeth, he willingly admitted that his absence had been premeditated.

en: “I found,” said he, “as the time drew near, that I had better not meet Mr. Darcy;—that to be in the same room, the same party with him for so many hours together, might be more than I could bear, and that scenes might arise unpleasant to more than myself.”
vi: - When that day approached, I thought that I should not meet Mr. Darcy, that being present in the same room, at the same gathering for many hours with him was something I could not endure, while others might also be affected by the discomfort.
tr: "As the time approached," she said, "I felt it would be better not to encounter Mr. Darcy; –being in the same room, in the same company with him for so many hours could be more than I could bear, scenes that could disturb others more than myself might occur."
es: ––As the moment approached ––he said–– it seemed to me that it would be better not to meet Darcy, for being together in a room for so many hours would have been beyond my strength and the situation could have become unpleasant, moreover, for other people.

en: She highly approved his forbearance; and they had leisure for a full discussion of it, and for all the commendations which they civilly bestowed on each other, as Wickham and another officer walked back with them to Longbourn, and during the walk he particularly attended to her. His accompanying them was a double advantage: she felt all the compliment it offered to herself; and it was most acceptable as an occasion of introducing him to her father and mother.
vi: Accepting his endurance, and the two had leisurely time to discuss this matter in depth, also to compliment each other politely. When Wickham and another officer accompanied the ladies to Longbourn, he paid special attention to her. His accompanying had two advantages: she felt all the affection he had for her, and it was an opportunity for her to introduce him to her father and mother.
tr: Elizabeth regarded the cautious behavior very positively; on the return journey, as Wickham and another officer accompanied them to Longbourn, they found ample time to discuss the matter in detail and exchange numerous compliments; during the walk, Wickham paid her special attention. Their accompaniment was doubly delightful; firstly, Elizabeth felt that this act was a compliment directed at her, and secondly, it was a good opportunity to introduce Wickham to her parents.
es: Elizabeth fully approved of Wickham's conduct and they discussed it extensively, exchanging mutual praises as they headed towards Longbourn, where Wickham and another officer accompanied the young ladies. During the walk, Wickham devoted himself entirely to Elizabeth, providing her with a double satisfaction: receiving his compliments and having the opportunity to introduce him to her parents.

en: “Walked back with them”
vi: His accompanying had two advantages: she felt all the affection he had for her, and it was an opportunity for her to introduce him to her father and mother.
tr: Immediately after their return, a letter arrived for Miss Bennet; it was from Netherfield and was opened at once.
es: Shortly after arriving, they brought a letter for Jane.

en: Soon after their return, a letter was delivered to Miss Bennet; it came from Netherfield, and was opened immediately. The envelope contained a sheet of elegant, little, hot-pressed paper, well covered with a lady’s fair, flowing hand; and Elizabeth saw her sister’s countenance change as she read it, and saw her dwelling intently on some particular passages. Jane recollected herself soon; and putting the letter away, tried to join, with her usual cheerfulness, in the general conversation: but Elizabeth felt an anxiety on the subject which drew off her attention even from Wickham; and no sooner had he and his companion taken leave, than a glance from Jane invited her to follow her upstairs. When they had gained their own room, Jane, taking out her letter, said, “This is from Caroline Bingley: what it contains has surprised me a good deal. The whole party have left Netherfield by this time, and are on their way to town; and without any intention of coming back again. You shall hear what she says.”
vi: Not long after they returned, a letter from Netherfield was brought to Miss Bennet: she opened it immediately. The letter was written on a small, elegant piece of paper, with soft, feminine handwriting. Elizabeth noticed her sister's expression change as she read, and saw her read several passages over and over. Jane quickly returned to normal, put away the letter, and tried to join the conversation with her usual cheerfulness, but Elizabeth felt worried, which made her pay less attention even to Mr. Wickham. As soon as he and his friend took their leave, Jane's glance made her follow her sister up the stairs. When they entered her room, Jane took out the letter and said: - This is a letter from Caroline Bingley; its contents have greatly surprised me.
