The whole family has now left Netherfield, on their way to the city, with no intention of returning. You will hear what she has to say.
tr: Immediately after their return, a letter arrived for Miss Bennet; it was from Netherfield and was opened at once. Inside the envelope was a polite, small, high-quality piece of paper, covered with a lady's careful, flowing handwriting; as Elizabeth read the letter, she sensed her sister's face changing and saw her getting stuck at certain points. Jane soon composed herself, put the letter away, and tried to join the conversation with her usual cheerfulness; but Elizabeth felt a concern that distracted her even from Wickham; as soon as Wickham and his friend left, Jane, with her eyes, called her to follow upstairs. When they entered their room, Jane took out the letter and said, "It is from Caroline Bingley; what she wrote surprised me a lot. They have all left Netherfield and are going to the city –and they have no intention of returning. Listen to what she says."
es: It came from Netherfield, and the young woman opened it immediately. The envelope contained a very elegant and glossy sheet of paper, covered with the handwriting of a beautiful and agile woman's hand. Elizabeth noticed that her sister's expression changed as she read and that she lingered over certain paragraphs. Jane quickly composed herself; she put down the letter and tried to join in the conversation with her usual cheerfulness; but Elizabeth was so curious that she even stopped paying attention to Wickham. And as soon as he and his companion left, Jane invited her with a look to accompany her upstairs. Once in her room, Jane showed her the letter and said: ––It is from Caroline Bingley; its content has surprised me greatly. Everyone in the house has left Netherfield and at this hour they are on their way to the capital, from where they do not plan to return. Listen to what it says.

en: She then read the first sentence aloud, which comprised the information of their having just resolved to follow their brother to town directly, and of their meaning to dine that day in Grosvenor Street, where Mr. Hurst had a house. The next was in these words:—“‘I do not pretend to regret anything I shall leave in Hertfordshire except your society, my dearest friend; but we will hope, at some future period, to enjoy many returns of that delightful intercourse we have known, and in the meanwhile may lessen the pain of separation by a very frequent and most unreserved correspondence. I depend on you for that.’” To these high-flown expressions Elizabeth listened with all the insensibility of distrust; and though the suddenness of their removal surprised her, she saw nothing in it really to lament: it was not to be supposed that their absence from Netherfield would prevent Mr. Bingley’s being there; and as to the loss of their society, she was persuaded that Jane must soon cease to regard it in the enjoyment of his.
vi: Then she read the letter, the content of which said that they had just decided to follow Mr. Bingley to the city, and would have dinner that evening on Grosvernor Street, where Mr. Hurst had a house. The next section read as follows: "I do not want to pretend to regret anything when leaving Hertfordshire, except for the relationship with you, my dearest friend, but my family hopes that in the future it will be compensated by the friendship between us. For now, the pain of separation can be alleviated by frequent and heartfelt correspondence." "I hope you will agree to this." Elizabeth listened to such passionate words with indifference due to suspicion, and although surprised by their sudden departure, she did not find this event tragic. It should not be assumed that their absence from Netherfield would prevent Mr. Bingley from staying. Regarding the loss of their acquaintance, she believed that soon Jane would no longer think about it, and then he would be happy about this. Elizabeth said, after a few moments of thought:
tr: He read the first sentence aloud; it was announcing that they had immediately decided to go to the city after their siblings and that they planned to have dinner that evening on Grosvenor Street, where Mr. Hurst resided. The rest was described with these words: "I don't think I will miss anything I left behind in Hertfordshire except your friendship; but I hope that we will enjoy our pleasant companionship again and again in the future, and in the meantime, we can lessen the pain of separation with frequent and sincere letters. I trust you on this matter." Elizabeth listened to these generous expressions with a calm filled with doubt; although the suddenness of their departure surprised her, she saw nothing to lament in their wake: their absence from Netherfield did not necessarily mean Mr. Bingley would not be there; as for losing their friendship, she believed that Jane should stop thinking about it and focus on Mr. Bingley's companionship.
es: Jane read aloud the first paragraph where it was stated that they had decided to go to London with her brother and that they intended to eat that same day on Grosvenor Street, where Mr. Hurst had his house. The following was written as follows: "I do not regret leaving Hertfordshire except for you, dearest friend; but I hope to enjoy again later the delightful moments we spent together and in the meantime we can lessen the sorrow of separation with very frequent and effusive letters. I count on your correspondence." Elizabeth listened to all these grand expressions with impassivity due to the distrust they inspired in her. She was surprised by the haste with which they had left, but in reality, she saw no reason to regret it. It could not be supposed that the fact that they were not in Netherfield would prevent Bingley from coming; and as for the absence of the ladies, she was sure that Jane would console herself with the presence of the brother.

en: “It is unlucky,” said she, after a short pause, “that you should not be able to see your friends before they leave the country. But may we not hope that the period of future happiness, to which Miss Bingley looks forward, may arrive earlier than she is aware, and that the delightful intercourse you have known as friends will be renewed with yet greater satisfaction as sisters? Mr. Bingley will not be detained in London by them.”
vi: - The unfortunate thing is that you couldn't meet your friends before they left. But can we hope, then, that the happy time Miss Bingley is expecting will come sooner? And the friendship between friends will quickly turn into a sister-in-law relationship? Mr. Bingley will not be detained by them in London.
tr: "Bad luck," he said after a brief silence, "it would have been good if you could see your friends before leaving. But can't we hope that the day Miss Bingley is expecting will come sooner than predicted, and that the companionship you enjoyed as friends will be renewed more firmly as sisters? They cannot keep Mr. Bingley in London."
es: ––It's a shame ––he said to her after a brief pause–– that you couldn't see your friends before they left. But can't we hope that this "later on" of future happiness that your friend so desires will come sooner than she thinks and that this wonderful relationship you had as friends will be renewed with greater satisfaction as sisters? They are not going to detain Mr. Bingley in London.

en: “Caroline decidedly says that none of the party will return into Hertfordshire this winter. I will read it to you.
vi: - Caroline made it clear that no one in the family would return to Herfordshire this winter. She will read it to you:
tr: "Caroline insists that no one from the family will return to Hertfordshire this winter. Let me read it to you:–
es: ––Caroline says that decidedly none of them will return to Hertfordshire this winter.

en: “‘When my brother left us yesterday, he imagined that the business which took him to London might be concluded in three or four days; but as we are certain it cannot be so, and at the same time convinced that when Charles gets to town he will be in no hurry to leave it again, we have determined on following him thither, that he may not be obliged to spend his vacant hours in a comfortless hotel. Many of my acquaintance are already there for the winter: I wish I could hear that you, my dearest friend, had any intention of making one in the crowd, but of that I despair. I sincerely hope your Christmas in Hertfordshire may abound in the gaieties which that season generally brings, and that your beaux will be so numerous as to prevent your feeling the loss of the three of whom we shall deprive you.’
vi: "When my brother left yesterday, he thought that the job in London might be finished in three or four days, but we couldn't believe it. At the same time, we thought that once Charles was in the city, he wouldn't be in a hurry to leave, so we decided to follow him, so he wouldn't be alone in the uncomfortable hotel room." "Many of my acquaintances have gone there for the winter; I wish you, my closest friend, could join the crowd, but I'm not sure." "I sincerely wish you a Merry Christmas in Herfordshire, and you will have many suitors to help you forget the three of us."
tr: " ‘My brother, when leaving us yesterday, thought that the business requiring him to go to London could be handled within three or four days; but now that we know this is not possible, and also believing that Charles will not return once he gets to the city, we decided to follow him so that he wouldn't have to spend his idle hours in an uncomfortable hotel. Most of my acquaintances have already come there for the winter; I wish you too, my dear friend, would consider joining us – but I am not hopeful about this. With all my heart, I wish that Christmas brings joy to Hertfordshire and to you as it always does, and that your admirers prevent you from feeling the loss of the three friends we have deprived you of.' "
es: I will read it to you: «When my brother left us yesterday, he imagined that the matters calling him to London could be handled in three or four days; but as we know that this will not be the case and convinced, at the same time, that when Charles goes to the capital he is in no hurry to return, we have decided to go with him so that he does not have to spend his free hours in a hotel, without any comfort. Many of our acquaintances are already there to spend the winter; I would like to know if you, dearest friend, plan to do the same; but I don't think it possible. I sincerely wish that Christmas in Hertfordshire is bountiful in the joys typical of these festivities, and that your suitors are so numerous that they prevent you from feeling the loss of the three gentlemen we are taking away from you.»

en: “It is evident by this,” added Jane, “that he comes back no more this winter.”
vi: Jane added: - Clearly, he will not return this winter.
tr: "It is clear," added Jane, "that he will not return this winter.""
es: ––Therefore, it is evident ––added Jane–– that Mr. Bingley is not coming back this winter.

en: “It is only evident that Miss Bingley does not mean he should.”
vi: - I only see a clear intention that Miss Bingley implies he should not return.
tr: "The only certain thing is, Miss Bingley is not saying she will return."
es: ––The only thing that is evident is that Miss Bingley is the one who says he is not coming back.

en: “Why will you think so? It must be his own doing; he is his own master. But you do not know all. I will read you the passage which particularly hurts me. I will have no reserves from you. ‘Mr. Darcy is impatient to see his sister; and to confess the truth, we are scarcely less eager to meet her again. I really do not think Georgiana Darcy has her equal for beauty, elegance, and accomplishments; and the affection she inspires in Louisa and myself is heightened into something still more interesting from the hope we dare to entertain of her being hereafter our sister. I do not know whether I ever before mentioned to you my feelings on this subject, but I will not leave the country without confiding them, and I trust you will not esteem them unreasonable. My brother admires her greatly already; he will have frequent opportunity now of seeing her on the most intimate footing; her relations all wish the connection as much as his own; and a sister’s partiality is not misleading me, I think, when I call Charles most capable of engaging any woman’s heart. With all these circumstances to favour an attachment, and nothing to prevent it, am I wrong, my dearest Jane, in indulging the hope of an event which will secure the happiness of so many?’ What think you of this sentence, my dear Lizzy?” said Jane, as she finished it. “Is it not clear enough? Does it not expressly declare that Caroline neither expects nor wishes me to be her sister; that she is perfectly convinced of her brother’s indifference; and that if she suspects the nature of my feelings for him she means (most kindly!) to put me on my guard. Can there be any other opinion on the subject?”
vi: - Why do you think that? This is something I have to decide for myself. He is the master of his own life. But you don't know everything. I will read to you the part of the letter that broke my heart. I won't hide anything from you. “Mr. Darcy is eager to see his sister again, and to be honest, we are just as impatient to meet her. I truly think no one can compare to Georgiana Darcy in terms of appearance, elegance, and talent, and her affection for Louisa and me has grown into something more, in my bold hope that she will become my sister-in-law. I don't remember if I have mentioned my feelings about this to you before, but I will not leave without confiding in you, and I hope you won't find this too forward. My brother is very fond of her, and now he will have many opportunities to see her in the most intimate circumstances. Both her relatives and ours desire this relationship, and I believe that the partiality of a sister does not lead me astray in thinking that Charles has the ability to win the heart of any woman. With all such favorable circumstances for an attachment and nothing to prevent it, dear Jane, am I wrong to expect an event that ensures the happiness of many people?” Jane said, when she finished reading: - What do you think about this, Lizzy? Is the meaning clear enough? Does it mean that Caroline neither expects nor hopes that you will become her sister-in-law? That she is certain he is indifferent to you? And if she has guessed your feelings towards him, would she intend to warn you? Do you have any thoughts?
tr: "Why do you think that way? It should be his decision. The man is his own master. But you haven't heard everything yet. I will read you the part that especially hurt me. I have nothing to hide from you. " 'Mr. Darcy is eager to see his sister; to be honest, we are no less eager to see her than Mr. Darcy himself. In my opinion, there is no one who can match Georgiana Darcy in beauty, grace, and talent; the affection she has inspired in Louisa and me has become even more interesting because we hope she will soon become our sister. I don't know if I have mentioned my feelings on this matter to you before; but I will not leave here without opening up to you about my feelings, and I am sure you will find them reasonable. My brother already admires her immensely; now he will have the chance to see her often in the closest of settings; her relatives, just like us, desire this union; not because he is my brother, but Charles is someone who could win any woman's heart. When all circumstances are in favor of a relationship, and there is no obstacle, could I be wrong in hoping for an event that will ensure the happiness of many people, dear Jane?' "What do you say to this sentence, dear Lizzy?" said Jane, as she finished the letter. "Isn't it quite clear? Doesn't Caroline plainly say that she neither wants nor hopes for me as her sister-in-law? She is quite certain of her brother's indifference; even if she suspects my feelings for him, she (kindly!) warns me to be cautious. Can there be any other interpretation of this matter?"
es: ––Why do you believe that? It must be Mr. Bingley's doing: It doesn't depend on anyone. But you don't know everything yet. I'm going to read you the passage that hurts me the most. I don't want to hide anything from you. «Mr. Darcy is eager to see his sister, and the truth is that we are no less eager to see her. I believe that Georgina Darcy has no equal in beauty, elegance, and talent, and the affection she inspires in Louisa and me increases with the hope we harbor that she will be our sister in the future. I don't know if I have ever expressed to you my feelings on this matter; but I don't want to leave without confiding it to you, and I imagine you will find it very reasonable. My brother already feels great admiration for her, and now he will have frequent opportunities to see her with the greatest intimacy. Georgina's family desires this union as much as we do, and I don't think I am blinded by sisterly passion in believing that Charles is very capable of winning any woman's heart. With all these circumstances in favor of this relationship and nothing to prevent it, I cannot be mistaken, dearest Jane, if I hope for the event that would bring happiness to so many people.» ––What do you think of this paragraph, Lizzy? ––asked Jane after finishing reading––. Isn't it quite clear? Doesn't it clearly express that Caroline neither expects nor desires that I be her sister, that she is completely convinced of her brother's indifference, and that if she suspects the nature of my feelings towards him, she intends, with all kindness, of course, to warn me? Can this matter be interpreted in any other way?

en: “Yes, there can; for mine is totally different. Will you hear it?”
vi: - Yes, because my opinion is completely different. Do you want to hear it?
tr: "Yes, it could be; because mine is completely different. –Will you listen?"
es: ––Yes, it can be done. I interpret it very differently. Do you want to know how?

en: “Most willingly.”
vi: - Of course, I want to.
tr: "With great enthusiasm."
es: ––Of course.

en: “You shall have it in a few words. Miss Bingley sees that her brother is in love with you and wants him to marry Miss Darcy. She follows him to town in the hope of keeping him there, and tries to persuade you that he does not care about you.”
vi: - You can listen briefly. Miss Bingley thought that her brother was in love with you, while she wanted him to marry Miss Darcy. She followed him in hopes of keeping him there, trying to convince you that he didn't care about you.
tr: "I will say it in a few words. Miss Bingley sees that her brother is in love with you and wants to marry him to Miss Darcy. She is going to the city after him with the intention of keeping him there, and wants to convince you that the man does not care about you."
es: ––I will tell you in a few words. Miss Bingley has realized that her brother is in love with you and she wants him to marry Miss Darcy. She has gone to the capital after him, hoping to keep him there, and is trying to convince you that Bingley does not care about you at all.

en: Jane shook her head.
vi: Jane shook her head.
tr: Jane nodded her head.
es: Jane shook her head.

en: “Indeed, Jane, you ought to believe me. No one who has ever seen you together can doubt his affection; Miss Bingley, I am sure, cannot: she is not such a simpleton. Could she have seen half as much love in Mr. Darcy for herself, she would have ordered her wedding clothes. But the case is this:—we are not rich enough or grand enough for them; and she is the more anxious to get Miss Darcy for her brother, from the notion that when there has been one inter-marriage, she may have less trouble in achieving a second; in which there is certainly some ingenuity, and I dare say it would succeed if Miss de Bourgh were out of the way. But, my dearest Jane, you cannot seriously imagine that, because Miss Bingley tells you her brother greatly admires Miss Darcy, he is in the smallest degree less sensible of your merit than when he took leave of you on Tuesday; or that it will be in her power to persuade him that, instead of being in love with you, he is very much in love with her friend.”
vi: - Actually, Jane, you should trust me. No one who has ever seen the two of you together would doubt his feelings for you. I'm sure Miss Bingley doesn't either. She's not foolish. If she could recognize that Mr. Darcy loved her even half as much, she would have already ordered her wedding dress. But here's the issue. We are neither wealthy nor have any status for them to look forward to; while her sister keeps trying to pair Miss Darcy with him, with the idea that once there is a marriage between the two families, she could easily secure a second marriage. This calculation is quite clever; I'm sure it could succeed if not for Lady De Bourgh's interference. But, dear Jane, you shouldn't seriously imagine that just because Miss Bingley tells you he admires Miss Darcy, he will think less of you than he did when he left on Tuesday, or that she has the ability to persuade him to love her friend instead of you.
tr: "Truly, Jane, you must believe me. –No one who has seen you together can doubt his affection. I am sure Miss Bingley cannot doubt it either. She cannot be that foolish. If she could see that Mr. Darcy was half as in love with her, she would have ordered her wedding dress by now. But the situation is this: –We are not rich enough or grand enough for them; she wants to marry Miss Darcy to her brother because she thinks that once there is one marriage, achieving a second one will be easier, which she may be partly right about, and she might even succeed if it weren't for the obstacle of Miss de Bourgh. But, dear Jane, just because Miss Bingley told you that her brother admires Miss Darcy very much, you cannot believe that Mr. Bingley values your superiority any less than he did at your parting on Tuesday, or that her influence could make him fall in love with her friend instead of you."
es: ––That's right, Jane; you must believe me. No one who has seen you together can doubt Bingley's affection. His sister doesn't doubt it either, she's not that foolish. If she had seen half of that affection in Darcy towards her, she would have already ordered the wedding dress. But the thing is this: we are neither rich enough nor distinguished enough for them. If Miss Bingley is so eager to marry Miss Darcy to her brother, it's because it would make it easier for her to marry Darcy himself; which seems a bit naive on her part. But I would dare to believe that she would achieve her desires if Miss de Bourgh were not in the way. However, you can't seriously think that just because Miss Bingley tells you that her brother likes Miss Darcy, he is less in love with you than he was on Thursday when he said goodbye; nor that it is possible for his sister to convince him to love Miss Darcy instead of you.

en: “If we thought alike of Miss Bingley,” replied Jane, “your representation of all this might make me quite easy. But I know the foundation is unjust. Caroline is incapable of wilfully deceiving anyone; and all that I can hope in this case is, that she is deceived herself.”
vi: Jane replied: - If we had the same thoughts as Miss Bingley, everything you said might help put my mind at ease. But I think that is unfounded. Caroline cannot be capable of deceiving anyone; in this matter, all I can hope is that she has merely deceived herself.
tr: "If we had similar thoughts about Miss Bingley," Jane replied, "these explanations would greatly relieve me. But I know there is a fundamental mistake. Even Caroline cannot deliberately deceive anyone; in this case, all I can hope for is that she is deceiving herself."
es: ––If our opinion of Miss Bingley were the same ––replied Jane––, your explanation would reassure me. But I know that you are being unfair to her. Caroline is incapable of deceiving anyone; the only thing I can hope for in this case is that she is deceiving herself.

en: “That is right. You could not have started a more happy idea, since you will not take comfort in mine: believe her to be deceived, by all means. You have now done your duty by her, and must fret no longer.”
vi: - That's right. You can't think of anything better to make you happy, because you can't be happy with my words. Believe that she has deceived herself. As for you, it's over with her, you shouldn't be sad anymore.
tr: "That's true. –You couldn't have come up with a better idea, since my idea didn't comfort you. Whatever happens, believe that he is deceiving himself. You have done your duty towards him; don't be sad anymore."
es: ––That's right. You couldn't have come up with a better idea, since mine doesn't comfort you. Suppose she's mistaken. That way you'll be in good standing with her and you'll see that you have nothing to worry about.

en: “But, my dear sister, can I be happy, even supposing the best, in accepting a man whose sisters and friends are all wishing him to marry elsewhere?”
vi: - But, my dear, can I be happy, even in the best case, to accept a young man whose siblings and friends all want him to marry someone else?
tr: "But my dear brother, can I be happy even in the best case by accepting a man whom all my sisters and friends wish to marry someone else?""
es: ––But Lizzy, can I be happy, even assuming the best, by accepting a man whose sisters and friends wish him to marry another?

en: “You must decide for yourself,” said Elizabeth; “and if, upon mature deliberation, you find that the misery of disobliging his two sisters is more than equivalent to the happiness of being his wife, I advise you, by all means, to refuse him.”
vi: Elizabeth said: - You must decide for yourself, and if after careful consideration, you find that the distress of displeasing the two sisters outweighs the happiness of being his wife, I advise you by all means to refuse him.
tr: "The decision is up to you," said Elizabeth; "if, after careful consideration, the sorrow of disappointing your two sisters outweighs the happiness of being his wife, then I advise you to reject him.""
es: ––You must decide that for yourself ––said Elizabeth––, if after mature reflection you find that the misfortune of displeasing his sisters is more than equivalent to the happiness of being his wife, I advise you, of course, to reject Bingley. ––What things you say!

en: “How can you talk so?” said Jane, faintly smiling; “you must know, that, though I should be exceedingly grieved at their disapprobation, I could not hesitate.”
vi: Jane smiled softly: - How can you say that? You must know that although I might be very sad because they don't accept me, I cannot hesitate.
tr: "How can you talk like that?" said Jane, with a faint smile. "You know that if they don't approve, I would be very upset, but I wouldn't hesitate for a minute."
es: said Jane with a slight smile––. You must know that although their disapproval would sadden me greatly, I would not hesitate.

en: “I did not think you would; and that being the case, I cannot consider your situation with much compassion.”
vi: - I didn't think you would hesitate, and in such a case, I cannot have compassion for your situation.
tr: "I don't think you deserve it either; if that's the case, your situation isn't that dire.""
es: ––I already figured as much, and being so, I don't think I can sympathize with your situation.

en: “But if he returns no more this winter, my choice will never be required. A thousand things may arise in six months.”
vi: - But if he doesn't come back in the winter, you will never have to choose anything at all. Thousands of things can happen in six months.
tr: "But if he doesn't come back this winter, I won't need to make a choice. A thousand things can happen in six months!"
es: ––But if he doesn't come back all winter, my choice will be useless. So many things can happen in six months!

en: The idea of his returning no more Elizabeth treated with the utmost contempt. It appeared to her merely the suggestion of Caroline’s interested wishes; and she could not for a moment suppose that those wishes, however openly or artfully spoken, could influence a young man so totally independent of everyone.
vi: The thought that he would not return made Elizabeth utterly contemptuous. She thought that it seemed merely to be Caroline's self-serving wish; she did not believe that these wishes, whether expressed bluntly or subtly, could influence a man as independent as he was.
tr: Elizabeth never took seriously the thought of him not returning again. She believed that this was merely an implication of Caroline's self-serving wishes, and she did not for a moment think that such wishes, whether expressed openly or subtly, could influence a young man who seemed so independent of everyone.
es: Elizabeth rejected the idea that Bingley would not return; it seemed to her simply a suggestion born of Caroline's self-interested wishes, and she could not suppose for a moment that such wishes, whether expressed openly or covertly, would influence the mind of a man so independent.

en: She represented to her sister, as forcibly as possible, what she felt on the subject, and had soon the pleasure of seeing its happy effect. Jane’s temper was not desponding; and she was gradually led to hope, though the diffidence of affection sometimes overcame the hope, that Bingley would return to Netherfield, and answer every wish of her heart.
vi: She expressed her feelings as strongly as she could, immediately seeing that her sister was very happy. Jane's attitude was not one of discouragement, and she gradually began to hope that Bingley would return to Netherfield and reciprocate her feelings.
tr: Elizabeth explained her thoughts on the matter to her sister with all her persuasiveness and soon had the pleasure of seeing the happy effect she had created. Jane's nature was not inclined to remain sorrowful; although occasional doubts of affection hindered her hope, she increasingly believed that Bingley would return to Netherfield and fulfill all the desires of her heart.
es: He explained to his sister as eloquently as he could his point of view, and soon observed the good effect of his words. Jane was by nature an optimist, which gradually led her to hope that Bingley would return to Netherfield and fulfill all the desires of her heart, although doubt occasionally assailed her.

en: They agreed that Mrs. Bennet should only hear of the departure of the family, without being alarmed on the score of the gentleman’s conduct; but even this partial communication gave her a great deal of concern, and she bewailed it as exceedingly unlucky that the ladies should happen to go away just as they were all getting so intimate together. After lamenting it, however, at some length, she had the consolation of thinking that Mr. Bingley would be soon down again, and soon dining at Longbourn; and the conclusion of all was the comfortable declaration, that, though he had been invited only to a family dinner, she would take care to have two full courses.
vi: The two sisters agreed to inform Mrs. Bennet about the family's departure without alarming her about the young man's attitude, but even this news caused her considerable worry, and she lamented her misfortune excessively, as if they were her close relatives. However, she soon consoled herself with the thought that Mr. Bingley would return shortly and would come to dine at Longbourn. Everyone felt happy, even though they were inviting him to a regular family meal, but she would prepare a lavish feast.
tr: They decided to only tell Mrs. Bennet about the family's departure, so as not to cause her to panic over the man's behavior; but even this partial information greatly distressed Mrs. Bennet. She kept lamenting that it was a great misfortune for the ladies to leave just when they had gotten so close. Nevertheless, after her complaints subsided, she soon consoled herself with the thought that Mr. Bingley would be coming very soon and would be dining at Longbourn in the near future; as a result, she cheered up by saying that she would need to prepare a double menu, even though he was only invited to a family dinner.
es: They agreed that they would only inform Mrs. Bennet about the family's departure, so she wouldn't be too alarmed; but she was quite alarmed anyway; and lamented the tremendous misfortune that the ladies had left just when they had become so close. She was very upset about it, but consoled herself by thinking that Bingley would soon return to dine at Longbourn, and ended up declaring that despite having invited him to a family dinner, she would make sure to prepare two first-rate dishes for that day.

en: CHAPTER XXII.
vi: Chapter 22
tr: Chapter XXII
es: CHAPTER XXII

en: THE Bennets were engaged to dine with the Lucases; and again, during the chief of the day, was Miss Lucas so kind as to listen to Mr. Collins. Elizabeth took an opportunity of thanking her. “It keeps him in good humour,” said she, “and I am more obliged to you than I can express.”
vi: The Bennet family was invited to dine with the Lucas family, and once again Miss Charlotte Lucas spent most of the time politely listening to Mr. Collins. Elizabeth took the opportunity to express her gratitude to her. - You have made him happy, thank you very much.
tr: The Bennets had promised to dine with the Lucases; throughout most of the day, Miss Lucas showed kindness by listening to Mr. Collins. Elizabeth thanked her when she found an opportunity. "He is being kept occupied thanks to you," she said, "I am grateful to you for that."
es: The Bennets were invited to dine with the Lucases, and once again Miss Lucas had the kindness to listen to Collins for most of the day. Elizabeth took the first opportunity to thank her. ––This puts him in a good mood. I am more grateful to you than you can imagine ––she said to him.

en: Charlotte assured her friend of her satisfaction in being useful, and that it amply repaid her for the little sacrifice of her time. This was very amiable; but Charlotte’s kindness extended farther than Elizabeth had any conception of:—its object was nothing less than to secure her from any return of Mr. Collins’s addresses, by engaging them towards herself. Such was Miss Lucas’s scheme; and appearances were so favourable, that when they parted at night, she would have felt almost sure of success if he had not been to leave Hertfordshire so very soon. But here she did injustice to the fire and independence of his character; for it led him to escape out of Longbourn House the next morning with admirable slyness, and hasten to Lucas Lodge to throw himself at her feet. He was anxious to avoid the notice of his cousins, from a conviction that, if they saw him depart, they could not fail to conjecture his design, and he was not willing to have the attempt known till its success could be known likewise; for, though feeling almost secure, and with reason, for Charlotte had been tolerably encouraging, he was comparatively diffident since the adventure of Wednesday. His reception, however, was of the most flattering kind. Miss Lucas perceived him from an upper window as he walked towards the house, and instantly set out to meet him accidentally in the lane. But little had she dared to hope that so much love and eloquence awaited her there.
vi: Charlotte reassured her friend that she was happy to be of help, thinking she had used her time meaningfully. This was truly sweet, but Charlotte's kindness had gone beyond what Elizabeth imagined – her goal was nothing less than to gain Mr. Collins' attention. That was her intention, and everything appeared so favorable that when they parted that night, she could almost certainly think she had succeeded if he did not have to leave Hertfordshire soon. But in this matter, she had not accurately assessed his courage and self-control, for he left Longbourn the next morning, hastily heading to Lucas Lodge to court her. He did not want his cousins to see him, fearing that if they saw him leave, they would immediately guess his intention, which he did not want anyone to know until he was certain of the outcome. He was right to be worried, for although Charlotte had encouraged him to proceed, he lacked confidence after the adventure on Wednesday. However, the way she welcomed him made him truly satisfied. As he was approaching the house, Miss Lucas had seen him from an upstairs window, immediately went outside, pretending to meet him by chance on the path. But she did not dare hope that so much affection and eloquence awaited her there.
tr: Charlotte reassured her friend by saying she was happy to be of use and that she had been more than rewarded for spending a little time. This was very friendly; but Charlotte's kindness went further than Elizabeth thought; –her aim was to draw Mr. Collins' attention to herself, thus sparing Elizabeth from having to reciprocate. This was Miss Lucas's plan, and it seemed to work so well that by the time they parted at night, Miss Lucas would have been almost certain of her success if Mr. Collins were not to leave Hertfordshire so soon. But at this point, she did not account for Mr. Collins' passionate and independent character; for his character led him to escape from Longbourn House the next morning with admirable secrecy and throw himself at Miss Lucas's feet at Lucas Lodge. He had taken care not to be seen by his cousins, as he thought they would guess his purpose if they saw him leave, and he did not want his attempt to be known until his success was certain; though he felt almost secure, as he had a right to, because Charlotte had been quite encouraging, but he was relatively shy after Wednesday's adventure. Nevertheless, he was received in a very flattering manner. As he walked towards the house, Miss Lucas saw him from an upstairs window and immediately went out to meet him on the road, pretending it was a coincidence. But she could not dare to hope that such a strong love and such beautiful words awaited her there.
es: Charlotte assured her that she was glad to be able to do something for her, and that it compensated her for the small sacrifice of dedicating her time. It was very kind of her, but Charlotte's kindness went further than Elizabeth could suspect: her goal was none other than to prevent Collins from directing his compliments to her friend again, attracting them to herself instead. This was Charlotte's plan, and appearances were so favorable to her that upon parting that night, she could almost have taken success for granted, if Collins did not have to leave Hertfordshire so soon. But in conceiving this doubt, she did not do justice to Collins' fiery and independent character; the next morning he slipped away from Longbourn with admirable stealth and ran to the Lucas' house to surrender at her feet. He wanted to conceal his departure from his cousins because if they had seen him, they would have discovered his intention, and he did not want to announce it until he was sure of success; although he felt almost certain of it, for Charlotte had encouraged him enough, but since his adventure on Wednesday, he was a little lacking in confidence. Nevertheless, he received a very flattering welcome. Miss Lucas saw him arriving from a window, and immediately went out to the path to meet him as if by chance. But little could she imagine how much love and eloquence awaited her.

en: In as short a time as Mr. Collins’s long speeches would allow, everything was settled between them to the satisfaction of both; and as they entered the house, he earnestly entreated her to name the day that was to make him the happiest of men; and though such a solicitation must be waived for the present, the lady felt no inclination to trifle with his happiness. The stupidity with which he was favoured by nature must guard his courtship from any charm that could make a woman wish for its continuance; and Miss Lucas, who accepted him solely from the pure and disinterested desire of an establishment, cared not how soon that establishment were gained.
vi: In the short period of time that Mr. Collins' lengthy speeches allowed, everything was arranged to the satisfaction of both parties. When the two entered the house, he warmly asked her to set a date that would make him the happiest young man. Although she could not give an answer at that moment, the young lady did not want to downplay his delight. His naturally foolish demeanor made his courtship lack the compelling force that women wish to continue. Miss Lucas, having accepted him with pure and selfless intentions regarding the relationship, did not care how quickly the relationship was established.
tr: During the short intervals allowed by Mr. Collins' long speeches, everything between them was settled in a manner satisfactory to both; as they entered the house, Mr. Collins asked her to set the day that would make him the happiest man in the world; although there was no need to rush such a decision, the young lady had no intention of playing with his happiness. The foolishness nature had bestowed upon him had protected his courtship style from any charm that might make a woman want it to continue; Miss Lucas, who accepted him out of a pure and selfless desire for marriage, did not mind how quickly that marriage was obtained.
es: In the short span of time left by Collins' endless speeches, everything was arranged between them to mutual satisfaction. Upon entering the house, Collins earnestly begged her to name the day when she would make him the happiest of men; and although such a request had to be postponed for the moment, the lady did not wish to play with his happiness. The stupidity with which nature had endowed her deprived her courtship of the charms that might incline a woman to prolong it; Miss Lucas, who had accepted him solely out of the pure and selfless desire to marry, did not care how soon this event would take place.

en: Sir William and Lady Lucas were speedily applied to for their consent; and it was bestowed with a most joyful alacrity. Mr. Collins’s present circumstances made it a most eligible match for their daughter, to whom they could give little fortune; and his prospects of future wealth were exceedingly fair. Lady Lucas began directly to calculate, with more interest than the matter had ever
vi: They quickly expressed to Mr. Williams and Lady Lucas, both of whom accepted with the most eager cheerfulness. Mr. Collins's current situation made him the most eligible match for their daughter, as they could only provide her with a small fortune, and his future prospects were very bright. Lady Lucas began to calculate with unprecedented attention the number of years Mr. Bennet would still live.
tr: Sir William and Lady Lucas were quickly visited to obtain their approval; the approval was given with joyful promptness. Mr. Collins' current circumstances made him a very suitable husband for their daughters, who could not expect much of a dowry; besides, his future prospects of wealth were quite high. Lady Lucas immediately began to calculate how many more years Mr. Bennet might live with more interest than the matter had previously aroused; Sir William also expressed his firm opinion that it would be quite appropriate for both him and his wife to make an appearance at St. James's once Mr. Collins became the owner of the Longbourn estate.
es: They quickly informed Sir William and Lady Lucas to obtain their consent, which was granted with the greatest promptness and joy. Collins' situation made him a very desirable match for their daughter, to whom they could leave only a small fortune, and the prospects of future well-being were too tempting. Lady Lucas immediately began to calculate with more interest than ever how many more years Mr. Bennet might live, and Sir William expressed his opinion that when Collins became the owner of Longbourn, it would be very convenient for him and his wife to make their appearance at St. James.

en: “So much love and eloquence”
vi: Sir William decided that when Mr. Collins inherited the Longbourn estate, both he and his wife would appear at St. James's Court.
tr: Lady Lucas immediately began to calculate how many more years Mr. Bennet might live with more interest than the matter had previously aroused; Sir William also expressed his firm opinion that it would be quite appropriate for both him and his wife to make an appearance at St. James's once Mr. Collins became the owner of the Longbourn estate.
es: Lady Lucas immediately began to calculate with more interest than ever how many more years Mr. Bennet might live, and Sir William expressed his opinion that when Collins became the owner of Longbourn, it would be very convenient for him and his wife to make their appearance at St. James.

en: excited before, how many years longer Mr. Bennet was likely to live; and Sir William gave it as his decided opinion, that whenever Mr. Collins should be in possession of the Longbourn estate, it would be highly expedient that both he and his wife should make their appearance at St. James’s. The whole family in short were properly overjoyed on the occasion. The younger girls formed hopes of coming out a year or two sooner than they might otherwise have done; and the boys were relieved from their apprehension of Charlotte’s dying an old maid. Charlotte herself was tolerably composed. She had gained her point, and had time to consider of it. Her reflections were in general satisfactory. Mr. Collins, to be sure, was neither sensible nor agreeable: his society was irksome, and his attachment to her must be imaginary. But still he would be her husband. Without thinking highly either of men or of matrimony, marriage had always been her object: it was the only honourable provision for well-educated young women of small fortune, and, however uncertain of giving happiness, must be their pleasantest preservative from want. This preservative she had now obtained; and at the age of twenty-seven, without having ever been handsome, she felt all the good luck of it. The least agreeable circumstance in the business was the surprise it must occasion to Elizabeth Bennet, whose friendship she valued beyond that of any other person. Elizabeth would wonder, and probably would blame her; and though her resolution was not to be shaken, her feelings must be hurt by such a disapprobation. She resolved to give her the information herself; and therefore charged Mr. Collins, when he returned to Longbourn to dinner, to drop no hint of what had passed before any of the family. A promise of secrecy was of course very dutifully given, but it could not be kept without difficulty; for the curiosity excited by his long absence burst forth in such very direct questions on his return, as required some ingenuity to evade, and he was at the same time exercising great self-denial, for he was longing to publish his prosperous love.
vi: Sir William decided that when Mr. Collins inherited the Longbourn estate, both he and his wife would appear at St. James's Court. The whole family seemed delighted. The younger daughters hoped they might come out a year or two sooner than expected, while the sons were relieved that Charlotte would not die an old maid. Charlotte herself was quite composed. She had achieved her goal and had time to think about it. Her reflections were all satisfactory. It was evident that Mr. Collins was neither sensible nor agreeable; his manners were awkward, and his attachment to her was imaginary. But still, he would be her husband. Not thinking highly of men or matrimony, marriage had always been her objective. It was the most dignified provision for well-educated young women of small fortune; and though uncertain of bringing happiness, it was the most pleasant preservative from want. Now that this preservative was secured, and at the age of twenty-seven, without being handsome, she felt fortunate. The most uncomfortable feeling was Elizabeth Bennet's surprise, whose friendship she valued more than any other person's. Elizabeth might wonder, perhaps reproach her; and though her opinion was resolute, she might feel hurt by her friend's disapproval. Charlotte decided to inform her friend herself, so when Mr. Collins returned to Longbourn for dinner, she requested him to withhold the news. Of course, he promised secrecy, but it was not easy, as everyone was curious about his absence and questioned him directly. He had to be very skillful in evading, while he himself was eager to announce his prosperous love affair.
tr: Lady Lucas immediately began to calculate how many more years Mr. Bennet might live with more interest than the matter had previously aroused; Sir William also expressed his firm opinion that it would be quite appropriate for both him and his wife to make an appearance at St. James's once Mr. Collins became the owner of the Longbourn estate. In short, this event filled the entire family with joy. The younger girls hoped that they might come out a year or two earlier than would otherwise have been possible; the boys were relieved of the fear that Charlotte would remain unmarried. Charlotte, however, was more composed. She had achieved her goal and had had time to consider it. Her thoughts were generally satisfactory. Mr. Collins, of course, was neither sensible nor agreeable; his conversation was dreadful; his attachment to her must be imaginary. But still, he would be her husband. Without indulging in great expectations regarding men or the marital bond, she had always aimed for marriage; marriage was the only honorable provision for well-educated young women of small fortune, and though it might not ensure happiness, it must be their most eligible protection against want. She had now secured that protection; at twenty-seven, with no beauty to recommend her, she knew it to be a fortunate chance. The most unpleasant part of the affair was the possibility of surprising Elizabeth Bennet, whose friendship she valued more than any other. Elizabeth would be astonished and probably would reproach her; her decision would not be altered, but it would hurt her feelings to face such a surprise. She decided to give the news to her herself and enjoined Mr. Collins not to say a word to anyone in the family about what had happened when he returned to Longbourn for dinner. Of course, the promise of secrecy was given with all his heart, but it would not be easy to keep; the curiosity aroused by his long absence would lead to such direct questions on his return that it would require considerable dexterity to avoid answering; moreover, he was burning with the desire to proclaim his triumphant love, so he had to struggle hard with himself.
es: Lady Lucas immediately began to calculate with more interest than ever how many more years Mr. Bennet might live, and Sir William expressed his opinion that when Collins became the owner of Longbourn, it would be very convenient for him and his wife to make their appearance at St. James. In short, the whole family rejoiced greatly at the news. The younger daughters hoped to be presented in society a year or two earlier than they would have been otherwise due to this circumstance. The sons were relieved of the fear that Charlotte might remain single. Charlotte was calm. She had won the game and had time to consider it. Her reflections were generally satisfactory. To tell the truth, Collins was neither intelligent nor pleasant, his company was tedious, and his affection for her must have been imaginary. But, after all, he would be her husband. Although Charlotte did not have a high opinion of men or marriage, she had always desired it because it was the only honorable position for a well-educated young woman with little fortune, and, although it could not be guaranteed to be a source of happiness, it would always be the most agreeable resource against need. This resource was what she had just obtained, for at twenty-seven years of age, never having been pretty, it was a real stroke of luck for her. The least pleasant part of all was the surprise that Elizabeth Bennet would receive, whose friendship she valued more than that of any other person. Elizabeth would be astonished and probably would not approve; and, although the decision was already made, Elizabeth's disapproval would hurt her greatly. She resolved to tell her herself, so she recommended to Collins, when he returned to Longbourn for dinner, not to say anything about what had happened. Naturally, he duly promised to keep the secret; but it was difficult for him, because the curiosity aroused by his long absence burst upon his return in such direct questions that it required great skill to evade them; moreover, it represented a real self-denial for Collins, as he was impatient to proclaim his romantic success to the four winds.

en: As he was to begin his journey too early on the morrow to see any of the family, the ceremony of leave-taking was performed when the ladies moved for the night; and Mrs. Bennet, with great politeness and cordiality, said how happy they should be to see him at Longbourn again, whenever his other engagements might allow him to visit them.
vi: Because he would leave too early the next day to say goodbye to anyone, they had a farewell ceremony that night. With utmost politeness and warmth, Mrs. Bennet said she would be very pleased to welcome him again at Longbourn whenever he had the chance to visit.
tr: Since he would leave so early in the morning that he wouldn't see any of the family, the farewell ceremony was held as the ladies retired for the night; Mrs. Bennet, with great politeness and generosity, said how happy they would be to see him at Longbourn again whenever his duties allowed.
es: The next day he had to leave, but since he had to set off too early to see any member of the family, the farewell ceremony took place when the ladies went to bed. Mrs. Bennet, with great courtesy and warmth, told him that she would be very happy to see him in Longbourn again when his other commitments allowed him to visit them.

en: “My dear madam,” he replied, “this invitation is particularly gratifying, because it is what I have been hoping to receive; and you may be very certain that I shall avail myself of it as soon as possible.”
vi: He replied: - Madam, I am very excited to be invited, as I have always hoped to receive such an invitation, and you can be sure that I will accept it as soon as possible.
tr: "Dear madam," he replied, "this invitation is especially honorable, because I was also expecting it; you can be sure that I will respond to your invitation at the first opportunity.""
es: ––My dear lady ––replied Collins––, I particularly appreciate this invitation because I very much wanted to receive it; rest assured that I will take advantage of it as soon as possible.

en: They were all astonished; and Mr. Bennet, who could by no means wish for so speedy a return, immediately said,—
vi: The whole family was surprised. They never thought there would be such a quick response. Mr. Bennet immediately said:
tr: They were all surprised; not wanting such a quick turn of events, Mr. Bennet immediately spoke up–
es: Everyone was astonished, and Mr. Bennet, who in no way desired such a quick return, hastened to say:

en: “But is there not danger of Lady Catherine’s disapprobation here, my good sir? You had better neglect your relations than run the risk of offending your patroness.”
vi: - But will Lady Catherine object, dear? Should you forget your own relatives instead of displeasing your benefactor?
tr: "But isn't there a danger of offending Lady Catherine here, sir?" "It is better to neglect your relatives than to risk offending your patron.""
es: ––But, isn't there a danger that Lady Catherine will disapprove this time? It is better to be negligent with his relatives than to risk offending his patroness.

en: “My dear sir,” replied Mr. Collins, “I am particularly obliged to you for this friendly caution, and you may depend upon my not taking so material a step without her Ladyship’s concurrence.”
vi: Mr. Collins replied: - Sir, I am particularly very pleased that you have reminded me so sincerely, and please believe me that I will not do anything without the lady's approval.
tr: "Dear sir," replied Mr. Collins, "I am particularly grateful for this friendly advice; you can be assured that I would not take such an important step without first obtaining permission from her ladyship."
es: ––Dear sir ––replied Collins––, I am very grateful to you for this friendly warning, and you can be assured that I will not take a single step that is not authorized by His Lordship.

en: “You cannot be too much on your guard. Risk anything rather than her displeasure; and if you find it likely to be raised by your coming to us again, which I should think exceedingly probable, stay quietly at home, and be satisfied that we shall take no offence.”
vi: - Anyway, you should be more careful. You can afford to lose everything, but you should not offend the lady. I believe you might want to visit us again, but if this matter displeases her, I think you should not come, and please rest assured, we will not hold it against you.
tr: "You can never be too careful. Just don't upset him, and do whatever you want; if you see that coming back to us will be risky, which I think it will be, just stay quietly at home, and be assured that we won't be offended."
es: ––All precautions are few. Risk anything except inconveniencing her, and if you believe that your visits to our house could cause that, which I consider more than possible, stay quietly in yours and console yourself thinking that we will not be offended.

en: “Believe me, my dear sir, my gratitude is warmly excited by such affectionate attention; and, depend upon it, you will speedily receive from me a letter of thanks for this as well as for every other mark of your regard during my stay in Hertfordshire. As for my fair cousins, though my absence may not be long enough to render it necessary, I shall now take the liberty of wishing them health and happiness, not excepting my cousin Elizabeth.”
vi: - Sir, please believe me, I am deeply grateful for such heartfelt concern, and I will write you a thank-you letter for this concern, as well as for what I received during my stay in Hertfordshire. As for my lovely cousins, although my absence will not be long and there is no need for many well-wishes, I still wish them health and happiness, including Miss Elizabeth.
tr: "Believe me, dear sir, my gratitude has increased manifold with your kind concern; for this and for all the understanding you have shown during my stay in Hertfordshire, you can be sure that you will receive a thank-you letter from me immediately. As for my lovely cousins, although my absence will not be long enough to necessitate it, I wish them health and happiness, including my cousin Elizabeth."
es: ––Believe me, my dear sir, my gratitude increases with your affectionate advice, so I warn you that you will soon receive a letter of thanks for the same and for all the other proofs of consideration that you have given me during my stay in Hertfordshire. As for my beautiful cousins, although my absence will not be so long as to make it necessary, I will take the liberty of wishing them health and happiness, not excluding my cousin Elizabeth.

en: With proper civilities, the ladies then withdrew; all of them equally surprised to find that he meditated a quick return. Mrs. Bennet wished to understand by it that he thought of paying his addresses to one of her younger girls, and Mary might have been prevailed on to accept him. She rated his abilities much higher than any of the others: there was a solidity in his reflections which often struck her; and though by no means so clever as herself, she thought that, if encouraged to read and improve himself by such an example as hers, he might become a very agreeable companion. But on the following morning every hope of this kind was done away. Miss Lucas called soon after breakfast, and in a private conference with Elizabeth related the event of the day before.
vi: With all due politeness, the women went outside; everyone was surprised to see that he planned to return soon. From this, Mrs. Bennet hoped he would want to get acquainted with one of her young daughters, and Mary in particular might be willing to accept him. She had rated him higher than the other girls did. She often had a good impression of his way of thinking, which she considered mature. Although he was not as wise as she was, she thought that if he were encouraged to read more and be as self-improving as she was, he could become a pleasant life partner. But the next morning, all hopes were dashed. Miss Lucas visited after breakfast, and during a private conversation with Elizabeth, recounted the events of the previous day.
tr: After the necessary courtesies, the ladies withdrew; since they thought she would return quickly, they were all equally surprised. Mrs. Bennet preferred to conclude that she intended to turn to one of her younger daughters; Mary might be persuaded to accept her. Mary had valued her qualities more than the others; there was a solidity in her thoughts that Mary found interesting, and although she did not consider her as intelligent as herself, she thought she could take her as a model, encourage her to read, improve herself, and become a very reasonable life partner. But the next morning, all such hopes vanished. Immediately after breakfast, Miss Lucas called and, while they were sitting alone, told Elizabeth what had happened the previous day.
es: After the customary pleasantries, the ladies withdrew. They were all equally surprised to see that he intended to return soon. Mrs. Bennet wanted to attribute it to his intention of courting one of her younger daughters, so she decided to convince Mary to accept him. Indeed, Mary appreciated Collins more than the others; she found a solidity in his reflections that often dazzled her, and although she did not consider him as intelligent as herself, she believed that if he were encouraged to read and to follow an example like hers, he could become a very pleasant companion. But the next morning, the entire plan fell apart, for Miss Lucas came to visit them just after lunch and in a private conversation with Elizabeth, she recounted the events of the previous day.

en: The possibility of Mr. Collins’s fancying himself in love with her friend had once occurred to Elizabeth within the last day or two: but that Charlotte could encourage him seemed almost as far from possibility as that she could encourage him herself; and her astonishment was consequently so great as to overcome at first the bounds of decorum, and she could not help crying out,—
vi: The possibility that Mr. Collins might fall for her friend had crossed Elizabeth's mind in the past few days, but the idea that Charlotte could encourage him seemed as unlikely as she herself encouraging him. Therefore, she was so extremely surprised that she forgot all manners and couldn't help but exclaim:
tr: The possibility that Mr. Collins might think himself in love with her friend had crossed Elizabeth's mind in the last few days; but the idea that Charlotte would encourage him seemed as unlikely as her encouraging him herself; thus, the astonishment she felt was so great that it surpassed the bounds of etiquette, and she involuntarily exclaimed–
es: The possibility that Collins might believe himself in love with her friend had already occurred to Elizabeth one or two days before, but that Charlotte would encourage him seemed as impossible as if she herself would do it. Her astonishment, therefore, was so great that it exceeded all bounds of decorum and she could not refrain from shouting at her:

en: “Engaged to Mr. Collins! my dear Charlotte, impossible!”
vi: - Engaged to Mr. Collins! Dear Charlotte, that cannot be!
tr: "Are you engaged to Mr. Collins! Dear Charlotte, –impossible!"
es: ––Engaged to Mr. Collins! How is that possible, Charlotte?

en: The steady countenance which Miss Lucas had commanded in telling her story gave way to a momentary confusion here on receiving so direct a reproach; though, as it was no more than she expected, she soon regained her composure, and calmly replied,—
vi: The calm expression on Miss Lucas's face as she recounted her story gave way to confusion due to such a straightforward reaction, although it was not unexpected. But she quickly composed herself and replied:
tr: Miss Lucas's calm face while telling her story took on a temporary disheartenment when faced with such a direct reproach; however, it was not more than she had expected, so she quickly recovered and replied calmly–
es: Charlotte had told the story with much serenity, but now she felt momentarily confused for having received such a direct reproach; although it was what she had expected. But she recovered quickly and said calmly:

en: “Why should you be surprised, my dear Eliza? Do you think it incredible that Mr. Collins should be able to procure any woman’s good opinion, because he was not so happy as to succeed with you?”
vi: - Dear Elizabeth, why are you surprised? Do you think it is unbelievable that Mr. Collins could win over another woman because he was not happy after failing to win you?
tr: "Why are you surprised, dear Eliza? –Do you think Mr. Collins cannot win any woman's favor just because he couldn't win yours?""
es: ––What are you surprised about, Elizabeth? Does it seem incredible to you that Mr. Collins was able to gain the esteem of a woman just because he was not fortunate with you?

en: But Elizabeth had now recollected herself; and, making a strong effort for it, was able to assure her, with tolerable firmness, that the prospect of their relationship was highly grateful to her, and that she wished her all imaginable happiness.
vi: But Elizabeth had calmed down, trying her best to reassure her friend that she was very happy to see the prospect of a union between the two, and she wished them all happiness.
tr: But now Elizabeth had composed herself, and with a serious effort, she managed to convincingly assure Miss Lucas that she found their relationship very gratifying and wished her all the happiness imaginable.
es: But, in the meantime, Elizabeth had regained her composure, and with a tremendous effort, she was able to assure him with enough firmness that she was delighted by the idea of their kinship and wished him all the happiness in the world.

en: “I see what you are feeling,” replied Charlotte; “you must be surprised, very much surprised, so lately as Mr. Collins was wishing to marry you. But when you have had time to think it all over, I hope you will be satisfied with what I have done. I am not romantic, you know. I never was. I ask only a comfortable home; and, considering Mr. Collins’s character, connections, and situation in life, I am convinced that my chance of happiness with him is as fair as most people can boast on entering the marriage state.”
vi: Charlotte replied: - I understand what you are thinking. You must be surprised, very surprised to hear that Mr. Collins wants to marry me. But when you have had time to think, I hope you will be satisfied with my decision. I have never been imprudent, you know. I just want a comfortable home; and considering Mr. Collins' character, connections, and social status, I am confident that I will be happy with him, as most people entering into marriage can boast.
tr: "I understand how you feel," replied Charlotte, "you must be surprised, very surprised – just the other day Mr. Collins wanted to marry you. But when you have time to think it all over, I hope you will be as happy with my decision as I am. You know I'm not romantic; I never have been. All I want is a comfortable home; considering Mr. Collins' character, connections, and life circumstances, I believe my chances of being happy with him are as high as anyone entering into marriage could boast."
es: ––I know how you feel ––replied Charlotte––. You must be surprised, very surprised, considering how little Mr. Collins wanted to marry you. But when you have had time to think it over, I hope you will understand what I have done. You know I am not romantic. I never have been. I seek nothing more than a comfortable home, and considering Collins' character, his connections, and his position, I am convinced that I have as much chance of being happy with him as most people have when they marry.

en: Elizabeth quietly answered “undoubtedly;” and, after an awkward pause, they returned to the rest of the family. Charlotte did not stay much longer; and Elizabeth was then left to reflect on what she had heard. It was a long time before she became at all reconciled to the idea of so unsuitable a match. The strangeness of Mr. Collins’s making two offers of marriage within three days was nothing in comparison of his being now accepted. She had always felt that Charlotte’s opinion of matrimony was not exactly like her own; but she could not have supposed it possible that, when called into action, she would have sacrificed every better feeling to worldly advantage. Charlotte, the wife of Mr. Collins, was a most humiliating picture! And to the pang of a friend disgracing herself, and sunk in her esteem, was added the distressing conviction that it was impossible for that friend to be tolerably happy in the lot she had chosen.
vi: Elizabeth replied gently: - Certainly. After a moment of confusion, both of them went back in with the family. Charlotte did not stay much longer, and Elizabeth had time to think about what she had heard. It took her a while to come to terms with the idea of such an ill-matched marriage. That Mr. Collins proposed twice in three days was odd, but even odder was that he was accepted. She had always thought Charlotte's views on marriage were exactly like her own, but she could not imagine that when it came to a decision, her friend would sacrifice all feelings to gain worldly advantage. Charlotte, the wife of Mr. Collins, was indeed a humiliating image! In the pain of seeing a friend degrade herself and lose respect, there was also the sorrow from the certain thought that her friend could not be happy with the man she had chosen.
tr: Elizabeth calmly replied, "Undoubtedly," – and after an awkward silence, they returned to the other members of the family. Charlotte did not stay long; Elizabeth was lost in thoughts about what she had heard. It took her a long time to come to terms with the idea of such an inappropriate marriage. The strangeness of Mr. Collins making two marriage proposals within three days was nothing compared to the fact that it had now been accepted. Elizabeth had always sensed that Charlotte's idea of marriage was quite different from her own, but she could never believe that all good feelings would be sacrificed for worldly comfort when it came to making a decision. Charlotte, the wife of Mr. Collins, what a degrading picture! –And to the pain of a friend who had diminished herself and fallen from grace was added the sorrow of knowing that this friend could not be truly happy in the life she had chosen.
es: Elizabeth answered sweetly: ––It is undeniable. And after a somewhat awkward pause, they went to join the rest of the family. Charlotte left immediately, and Elizabeth stayed behind, pondering what she had just heard. It took her a long time to come to terms with such a ludicrous marriage. The oddity of Collins having made two marriage proposals in three days was nothing compared to the fact that he had been accepted. She always believed that Charlotte's theories about marriage were not exactly like hers, but she never supposed that in putting them into practice, she would sacrifice her best feelings to worldly matters. And to the pain caused by seeing how her friend had discredited herself and lost much of the esteem she had for her, was added the distressing conviction that it would be impossible for her to be happy with the fate she had chosen.

en: CHAPTER XXIII.
vi: Chapter 23
tr: Chapter XXIII
es: CHAPTER XXIII

en: ELIZABETH was sitting with her mother and sisters, reflecting on what she had heard, and doubting whether she was authorized to mention it, when Sir William Lucas himself appeared, sent by his daughter to announce her engagement to the family. With many compliments to them, and much self-gratulation on the prospect of a connection between the houses, he unfolded the matter,—to an audience not merely wondering, but incredulous; for Mrs. Bennet, with more perseverance than politeness, protested he must be entirely mistaken; and Lydia, always unguarded and often uncivil, boisterously exclaimed,—
vi: While Elizabeth was sitting with her mother and siblings, thinking about what she had heard and wondering if she was allowed to reveal this matter As it happened, Sir William Lucas appeared, having been sent by his daughter to announce her engagement. With congratulations for them and greater self-satisfaction about an alliance between the two families, he proclaimed the news. Everyone was not only puzzled but also found it hard to believe. Out of stubbornness rather than politeness, Mrs. Bennet insisted that he must be mistaken. Lydia, always unreserved and seldom polite, exclaimed loudly:
tr: Elizabeth was sitting with her mother and sisters, thinking about what she had heard and trying to decide whether she had the authority to explain it, when Sir William Lucas himself arrived; he had been sent by his daughter to inform the family of her engagement. Due to the possibility of kinship between the families, he opened the matter with compliments to them and with pride in himself – to an audience that was not only astonished but also could not believe their ears; so much so that Mrs. Bennet, with an insistence that went beyond politeness, said he must be mistaken; and Lydia, who was always tactless and often behaved rudely, shouted at the top of her lungs–
es: Elizabeth was sitting with her mother and sisters, pondering over what she had heard and unsure whether to tell it or not, when Sir William Lucas himself appeared, sent by his daughter, to announce the engagement to the family. Amid many compliments and congratulating the union of the two houses, he revealed the matter to an audience not only astonished but also incredulous, as Mrs. Bennet, with more obstinacy than courtesy, insisted that he must be completely mistaken, and Lydia, always indiscreet and often ill-mannered, exclaimed boisterously:

en: “Good Lord! Sir William, how can you tell such a story? Do not you know that Mr. Collins wants to marry Lizzy?”
vi: - My God! Mr. Williams, how could you tell such a story? Do you know that Mr. Collins wants to marry Lizzy?
tr: "My God! Sir William, how can you make up such a story? Don't you know that Mr. Collins wants to marry Lizzy?"
es: ––Holy God! What are you saying, Sir William? Don't you know that Mr. Collins wants to marry Elizabeth?

en: Nothing less than the complaisance of a courtier could have borne without anger such treatment: but Sir William’s good-breeding carried him through it all; and though he begged leave to be positive as to the truth of his information, he listened to all their impertinence with the most forbearing courtesy.
vi: Only the magnanimity of a nobleman could restrain the anger from such a statement. But Sir William's good education helped him overcome it; and although he confirmed that the news was true, he still listened to all their insolence with the utmost polite forbearance.
tr: Nothing less than courtly politeness could endure this treatment without anger; but Sir William's manners enabled him to withstand it all; he did not consent to confirm the accuracy of the information he provided, but he listened to all their rudeness with very patient nobility.
es: Only the condescension of a courtier could have endured that behavior without getting angry; but Sir William's good manners were above all. He begged to be allowed to guarantee the truth of what he said, but he listened to all those impertinences with the utmost correctness.

en: Elizabeth, feeling it incumbent on her to relieve him from so unpleasant a situation, now put herself forward to confirm his account, by mentioning her prior knowledge of it from Charlotte herself; and endeavoured to put a stop to the exclamations of her mother and sisters, by the earnestness of her congratulations to Sir William, in which she was readily joined by Jane, and by making a variety of remarks on the happiness that might be expected from the match, the excellent character of Mr. Collins, and the convenient distance of Hunsford from London.
vi: Elizabeth thought she needed to help him get out of the uncomfortable situation. She confirmed his words by recounting what she had heard Charlotte announce. She tried to end her mother's and sisters' complaints with warm congratulations to Sir William, which Jane also joined in, and with a few remarks about the happiness the union would bring, the excellent character of Mr. Collins, and the convenient distance between Hunsford and London.
tr: Feeling that it was her duty to rescue the poor man from such an awkward situation, Elizabeth stepped forward and confirmed the news by saying that Charlotte had previously informed her; in an effort to put an end to her mother and sisters' cries of astonishment, she warmly expressed her congratulations to Sir William; Jane immediately joined her and they spoke various words about the happiness promised by the marriage, Mr. Collins' wonderful character, and the proximity of Hunsford to London.
es: Elizabeth felt compelled to help him out of such an awkward situation, and confirmed his words, revealing what she knew from Charlotte herself. She tried to put an end to the exclamations of her mother and sisters warmly congratulating Sir William, in which she was soon seconded by Jane, and commenting on the happiness that could be expected from the event, given Mr. Collins's excellent character and the convenient distance from Hunsford to London.

en: Mrs. Bennet was, in fact, too much overpowered to say a great deal while Sir William remained; but no sooner had he left them than her feelings found a rapid vent. In the first place, she persisted in disbelieving the whole of the matter; secondly, she was very sure that Mr. Collins had been taken in; thirdly, she trusted that they would never be happy together; and, fourthly, that the match might be broken off. Two inferences, however, were plainly deduced from the whole: one, that Elizabeth was the real cause of all the mischief; and the other, that she herself had been barbarously used by them all; and on these two points she principally dwelt during the rest of the day. Nothing could console and nothing appease her. Nor did that day wear out her resentment. A week elapsed before she could see Elizabeth without scolding her: a month passed away before she could speak to Sir William or Lady Lucas without being rude; and many months were gone before she could at all forgive their daughter.
vi: Mrs. Bennet was too overwhelmed to say much in Sir William's presence; but as soon as he took his leave, she poured out her feelings. First, she still stubbornly refused to believe the entire affair; second, she was convinced that Mr. Collins had been ensnared; third, she believed that the two would not be happy together; and fourth, the marriage could fall apart.
