However, she drew two conclusions: first, Elizabeth was the sole cause of all the turmoil; and second, she herself had been cruelly exploited by them. She carried these two points in her mind throughout the entire day. Nothing could console her and nothing could reason with her. Her frustration did not subside in a day. It took a week before she stopped scolding Elizabeth every time she saw her. It took a month before she could speak to Sir William or Mrs. Lucas without rudeness, and many months before she could forgive their daughter.
tr: Mrs. Bennet was actually too overwhelmed to say much as long as Sir William was there; but as soon as he left, her emotions quickly poured out. First, she insisted on not believing the matter in the slightest; then, she decided that Mr. Collins had been deceived; next, she argued that they could never be happy together; finally, she said that the engagement could be broken off. In fact, two things emerged from all she said: first, the root cause of all the abomination was Elizabeth; second, everyone had personally treated her, Mrs. Bennet, barbarically: she dwelled on these two points for the rest of the day. Nothing could calm her down or console her. Her grief did not end when the day ended. It took a week for her to look at Elizabeth without scolding, a month to speak to Sir William or Lady Lucas without rudeness, and months to forgive her daughters.
es: Mrs. Bennet was certainly too overwhelmed to speak much while Sir William remained in the house; but as soon as he left, she quickly vented. First, she insisted on not believing a word; second, she was sure that Collins had been deceived; third, she trusted that they would never be happy together; and fourth, the wedding would not take place. However, two things clearly emerged from all this: that Elizabeth was the true cause of all the misfortune, and that she, Mrs. Bennet, had been treated in a barbaric manner by everyone. The rest of the day was spent ranting, and there was nothing that could console or calm her. A week had to pass before she could see Elizabeth without reprimanding her; a month, before she spoke to Sir William or Lady Lucas without being rude; and much longer, before she forgave Charlotte.

en: Mr. Bennet’s emotions were much more tranquil on the occasion, and such as he did experience he pronounced to be of a most agreeable sort; for it gratified him, he said, to discover that Charlotte Lucas, whom he had been used to think tolerably sensible, was as foolish as his wife, and more foolish than his daughter!
vi: Mr. Bennet was more composed, as this matter amused him to see Charlotte Lucas, whom he had thought to have quite a bit of judgment, turn out to be as foolish as his wife, and even more foolish than his own daughter!
tr: Mr. Bennet's feelings on the matter were much more subdued; as far as he could see, it was quite a reasonable situation; he said that it pleased him to see that Charlotte Lucas, whom he thought to be a sensible person, was as foolish as his wife and even more foolish than his daughter!
es: Mr. Bennet's mood upon hearing the news was calmer; moreover, he was even pleased, because in this way he could confirm, as he said, that Charlotte Lucas, whom he never considered very smart, was as foolish as his wife, and much more so than his daughter.

en: Jane confessed herself a little surprised at the match: but she said less of her astonishment than of her earnest desire for their happiness; nor could Elizabeth persuade her to consider it as improbable. Kitty and Lydia were far from envying Miss Lucas, for Mr. Collins was only a clergyman; and it affected them in no other way than as a piece of news to spread at Meryton.
vi: In her heart, Jane was somewhat surprised by the marriage, but she spoke more about her wishes for the couple's happiness than about her own surprise; and Elizabeth could not convince her sister that this could not happen. Kitty and Lydia had nothing to envy Miss Lucas for, as Mr. Collins was merely a clergyman; this marriage only served as gossip material for them in Meryton.
tr: Jane admitted that she was a bit surprised by the engagement; but she spoke of her sincere wishes for their happiness rather than her astonishment; even Elizabeth could not convince her to find the matter impossible. Kitty and Lydia were far from being jealous of Miss Lucas, because Mr. Collins was just a clergyman; the matter only interested them as a morsel of news to spread in Meryton.
es: Jane confessed that she had been surprised; but she spoke less of her astonishment than of her sincere wishes that both would be happy, not even Elizabeth managed to make her see that such happiness was unlikely. Catherine and Lydia were far from envying Miss Lucas, for Collins was nothing more than a clergyman and the event held no more interest for them than that of being able to spread it around Meryton.

en: Lady Lucas could not be insensible of triumph on being able to retort on Mrs. Bennet the comfort of having a daughter well married; and she called at Longbourn rather oftener than usual to say how happy she was, though Mrs. Bennet’s sour looks and ill-natured remarks might have been enough to drive happiness away.
vi: Lady Lucas could not avoid feeling a sense of triumph when she retaliated against Mrs. Bennet by having her daughter secure a good marriage. She visited Longbourn more frequently than before to express her joy, even though the bitter looks and nasty remarks should have been strong enough to dispel her happiness.
tr: Lady Lucas did not refrain from savoring the feeling of triumph by rubbing in Mrs. Bennet's face the pleasure of her daughter's good marriage; she visited Longbourn more frequently than ever to say how happy she was, even though Mrs. Bennet's sour looks and grumpy replies were enough to destroy her happiness.
es: Lady Lucas could not resist the joy of being able to get back at Mrs. Bennet by expressing the comfort she felt in having a married daughter; she went to Longbourn more frequently than usual to tell how happy she was, although Mrs. Bennet's unfriendly looks and malicious comments could have ended all that happiness.

en: Between Elizabeth and Charlotte there was a restraint which kept them mutually silent on the subject; and Elizabeth felt persuaded that no real confidence could ever subsist between them again. Her disappointment in Charlotte made her turn with fonder regard to her sister, of whose rectitude and delicacy she was sure her opinion could never be shaken, and for whose happiness she grew daily more anxious, as Bingley had now been gone a week, and nothing was heard of his return.
vi: Elizabeth and Charlotte showed restraint, causing both to remain silent about the matter; Elizabeth, in particular, realized that they could no longer share intimate thoughts with each other. The disappointment in Charlotte made her turn back to feeling compassion for her sister. Her thoughts on her sister's propriety and sensitivity had not changed; she grew increasingly worried about her sister's happiness, as Mr. Bingley had been gone for a week without any news.
tr: There was a tension between Elizabeth and Charlotte that kept both of them silent on the subject; Elizabeth felt that there could never be true trust between them again. The disappointment regarding Charlotte made her look at her sister with more affection; she was certain that her views on her sister's honesty and taste would never be shaken, and she worried more and more each day for her sister's happiness, as it had been a week since Bingley had left and there was no news of his return.
es: Between Elizabeth and Charlotte, there was a barrier that made them remain silent on the subject, and Elizabeth had the impression that true trust would never exist between them again. The disappointment she had felt from Charlotte made her turn to her sister with more affection and admiration than ever; her sister's integrity and delicacy guaranteed that her opinion of her would never change, and her happiness concerned her more each day, as it had been a week since Bingley had left and nothing was known about his return.

en: Jane had sent Caroline an early answer to her letter, and was counting the days till she might reasonably hope to hear again. The promised letter of thanks from Mr. Collins arrived on Tuesday, addressed to their father, and written with all the solemnity of gratitude which a twelve-month’s abode in the family might have prompted. After discharging his conscience on that head, he proceeded to inform them, with many rapturous expressions, of his happiness in having obtained the affection of their amiable neighbour, Miss Lucas, and then explained that it was merely with the view of enjoying her society that he had been so ready to close with their kind wish of seeing him again at Longbourn, whither he hoped to be able to return on Monday fortnight; for Lady Catherine, he added, so heartily approved his marriage, that she wished it to take place as soon as possible, which he trusted would be an unanswerable argument with his amiable Charlotte to name an early day for making him the happiest of men.
vi: Jane sent a reply letter to Caroline, waiting each day to receive more news. The thank-you letter that Mr. Collins had promised arrived on the third day, signed by his father, expressing gratitude as if he had stayed with them for the past 12 months. After settling his conscience on this matter, with fervent words he continued to write about his happiness at being favored by their charming neighbor, Miss Lucas. He explained that it was only because he wanted to be near her that he would accept their kind wish to see him again at Longbourn. He hoped to return the following Monday, as Lady Catherine had warmly approved the marriage and wished for it to proceed as soon as possible, so he believed his dear Charlotte would agree to set a date so that he could soon become the happiest young man.
tr: Jane had immediately replied to Caroline's letter and was waiting for the time to pass so she could hope to receive another letter. The promised thank-you letter from Mr. Collins arrived on Tuesday; it was addressed to their father and written with a serious gratitude as if he had stayed with the family for twelve months. Thus, after easing his conscience, he expressed with enthusiastic words the happiness he felt from having won the heart of their dear neighbor Miss Lucas, and then explained that he was ready to accept the kind invitation they had extended to him, solely with the aim of seeing her again, hoping to return the following Monday; Lady Catherine, he continued, had so wholeheartedly approved of his marriage that she wanted it to be completed as soon as possible, and he believed that his dear Charlotte would have no objection to choosing an earlier day to make him the happiest man in the world.
es: Jane immediately replied to Caroline Bingley's letter, and she was calculating the days it might take to receive the response. The promised letter from Collins arrived on Tuesday, addressed to the father and written with all the solemnity of gratitude that only a year of living with the family could have justified. After apologizing at the beginning, he proceeded to inform him, with much grandiloquence, of his happiness for having obtained the affection of his charming neighbor Miss Lucas, and then expressed that it was only with the intention of enjoying her company that he had felt so inclined to accede to their kind wishes to see him again in Longbourn, where he hoped to return on Monday in a fortnight; for Lady Catherine, he added, so cordially approved of his marriage that she wished it to be celebrated as soon as possible, something he trusted would be an irrefutable argument for his dear Charlotte to set the day when she would make him the happiest of men.

en: Mr. Collins’s return into Hertfordshire was no longer a matter of pleasure to Mrs. Bennet. On the contrary, she was as much disposed to complain of it as her husband. It was very strange that he should come to Longbourn instead of to Lucas Lodge; it was also very inconvenient and exceedingly troublesome. She hated having visitors in the house while her health was so indifferent, and lovers were of all people the most disagreeable. Such were the gentle murmurs of Mrs. Bennet, and they gave way only to the greater distress of Mr. Bingley’s continued absence.
vi: Mr. Collins's return to Hertfordshire was no longer a joy for Mrs. Bennet. On the contrary, she constantly complained just like he did. It was strange, inconvenient, and extremely bothersome that he came to Longbourn instead of Lucas Lodge. She hated having guests in the house when her health was not good, and she found that among humanity, those in love were the hardest to endure. These were her whispered complaints, made even more miserable by Mr. Bingley's prolonged absence.
tr: Mr. Collins's return to Hertfordshire was no longer a source of pleasure for Mrs. Bennet. On the contrary, she began to complain about it like her husband. –It was very strange for him to come to Longbourn instead of going to Lucas Lodge; moreover, it was very inappropriate and extremely inconvenient. –She hated having a guest at home when her health was so fickle; besides, lovers were the most irritable people in the world. Thus Mrs. Bennet murmured her complaints, and her grumbling was only subdued by the greater distress caused by Mr. Bingley's prolonged absence.
es: Mrs. Bennet no longer found Collins's return to Hertfordshire a cause for satisfaction. On the contrary, she deplored it more than her husband: "It was very odd that Collins came to Longbourn instead of going to the Lucas's house; it was very inconvenient and extremely embarrassing. She hated having visitors given her poor health, and engaged couples were the most unbearable beings in the world." These were Mrs. Bennet's constant murmurs, which only ceased in the face of an even greater distress: Mr. Bingley's long absence.

en: Neither Jane nor Elizabeth were comfortable on this subject. Day after day passed away without bringing any other tidings of him than the report which shortly prevailed in Meryton of his coming no more to Netherfield the whole winter; a report which highly incensed Mrs. Bennet, and which she never failed to contradict as a most scandalous falsehood.
vi: Both Jane and Elizabeth felt uneasy about this absence. Each day passed without any encouraging news about him, except for the rumor at Netherfields that he would not return throughout the winter. Mrs. Bennet was extremely angry about this news, constantly refuting it as the most malicious falsehood.
tr: Neither Jane nor Elizabeth were comfortable about this. Days chased days without bringing any news from him; only a rumor emerged in Meryton that he would not come to Netherfield again throughout the winter; this rumor drove Mrs. Bennet mad, she ranted that such a lie could not be.
es: Neither Jane nor Elizabeth were calm about this matter. The days passed without any more news except for what soon spread through Meryton: that the Bingleys would not return for the entire winter. Mrs. Bennet was indignant and did not stop denying it, asserting that it was the most atrocious falsehood one could hear.

en: Even Elizabeth began to fear—not that Bingley was indifferent—but that his sisters would be successful in keeping him away. Unwilling as she was to admit an idea so destructive to Jane’s happiness, and so dishonourable to the stability of her lover, she could not prevent its frequently recurring. The united efforts of his two unfeeling sisters, and of his overpowering friend, assisted by the attractions of Miss Darcy and the amusements of London, might be too much, she feared, for the strength of his attachment.
vi: Even Elizabeth had begun to fear – not that Mr. Bingley was indifferent – but that his sisters might have succeeded in keeping him away. Even though she did not want to accept such a harmful idea for Jane's happiness and such a disgraceful one for her sister's suitor's constancy, the idea still lingered in her mind. She feared that the unfeeling efforts of the two sisters and the strong-willed friend, along with the charming allure of Miss Darcy and the pleasures of London, might exceed the strength of his affections.
tr: Elizabeth even began to fear—not that Bingley was indifferent—but that his sisters would succeed in keeping him away. Though she was unwilling to accept the idea, which would be so destructive to Jane's happiness and damaging to her lover's reliability, she could not prevent it from frequently arising. She feared that the combined efforts of Bingley's two unfeeling sisters and his discouraging friend, along with the allure of Miss Darcy and the entertainments of London, might overpower the strength of his attachment.
es: Even Elizabeth began to fear, not that Bingley had forgotten Jane, but that his sisters might succeed in separating him from her. Despite not wanting to admit such a disastrous idea for Jane's happiness and so unworthy of her lover's firmness, Elizabeth could not help but frequently think of it. She feared that the combined effort of his heartless sisters and his influential friend, along with the attractions of Miss Darcy and the pleasures of London, could be too many things at once against Bingley's affection.

en: As for Jane, her anxiety under this suspense was, of course, more painful than Elizabeth’s: but whatever she felt she was desirous of concealing; and between herself and Elizabeth, therefore, the subject was never alluded to. But as no such delicacy restrained her mother, an hour seldom passed in which she did not talk of Bingley, express her impatience for his arrival, or even require Jane to confess that if he did not come back she should think herself very ill-used. It needed all Jane’s steady mildness to bear these attacks with tolerable tranquillity.
vi: As for Jane, her anxiety in uncertainty was even more painful than the fear in Elizabeth. But no matter what she thought, she still wanted to hide it, so she and Elizabeth never brought up the issue. However, such delicacy could not restrain their mother. Not an hour passed without her mentioning Mr. Bingley, expressing eagerness to see him return, or even forcing Jane to acknowledge that if he did not come back, she should consider herself used. Jane had to muster all her gentle firmness to calmly withstand these attacks.
tr: When it came to Jane, her fear under this uncertainty was, of course, more painful than Elizabeth's; but she wished to conceal her feelings; therefore, the subject was never touched upon between her and Elizabeth. But since such sensitivity did not affect her mother, not an hour passed without her mentioning Bingley, expressing her impatience for his return, or even pressing Jane to admit that she would feel deceived if he did not come back. Jane had to use all her gentleness to remain calm in the face of these attacks.
es: As for Jane, the anxiety that this doubt caused her was, naturally, more painful than Elizabeth's; but no matter what she felt, she wanted to hide it, and therefore the matter was never mentioned between her and her sister. Her mother, however, was not restrained by the same delicacy and not an hour passed without her talking about Bingley, expressing her impatience for his arrival or insisting that Jane confess that if he did not return, they would have been treated in the most indecorous manner. It took all of Jane's gentleness to endure these attacks with tolerable calmness.

en: Mr. Collins returned most punctually on the Monday fortnight, but his reception at Longbourn was not quite so gracious as it had been on his first introduction. He was too happy, however, to need much attention; and, luckily for the others, the business of love-making relieved them from a great deal of his company. The chief of every day was spent by him at Lucas Lodge, and he sometimes returned to Longbourn only in time to make an apology for his absence before the family went to bed.
vi: Mr. Collins returned on Monday as announced, but Longbourn did not welcome him as warmly as the first time. However, he was too delighted to feel the need for much attention, and fortunately for the others, his preoccupations with seeking love spared them from the burden of his close presence. He spent most of each day at Lucas Lodge; sometimes he returned to Longbourn only to apologize for his absence before the household went to bed.
tr: Mr. Collins returned the next Monday as he had said, but this time he was not received with the same attention at Longbourn as during his first visit. However, he was too happy to seek much attention; and fortunately for the others, the courtship business largely spared them from having to endure Mr. Collins. Mr. Collins spent most of each day at Lucas Lodge and sometimes returned to Longbourn so late that he barely had time to apologize for his absence before the family went to bed.
es: Collins returned promptly on Monday in fifteen days; the reception he received at Longbourn was not as cordial as the first time. But the man was too happy for anything to affect him, and fortunately for everyone, he was so busy with his courtship that they were free of his company for much of the time. He spent most of the day at the Lucas house, and sometimes returned to Longbourn just in time to excuse his absence before the family went to bed.

en: “Whenever she spoke in a low voice”
vi: He spent most of each day at Lucas Lodge; sometimes he returned to Longbourn only to apologize for his absence before the household went to bed.
tr: Mr. Collins spent most of each day at Lucas Lodge and sometimes returned to Longbourn so late that he barely had time to apologize for his absence before the family went to bed.
es: He spent most of the day at the Lucas house, and sometimes returned to Longbourn just in time to excuse his absence before the family went to bed.

en: Mrs. Bennet was really in a most pitiable state. The very mention of anything concerning the match threw her into an agony of ill-humour, and wherever she went she was sure of hearing it talked of. The sight of Miss Lucas was odious to her. As her successor in that house, she regarded her with jealous abhorrence. Whenever Charlotte came to see them, she concluded her to be anticipating the hour of possession; and whenever she spoke in a low voice to Mr. Collins, was convinced that they were talking of the Longbourn estate, and resolving to turn herself and her daughters out of the house as soon as Mr. Bennet was dead. She complained bitterly of all this to her husband.
vi: Mrs. Bennet was truly in the most pitiable situation. Just a mention of the marriage was enough to cause her agony, and wherever she went, she heard talk of it. She loathed the presence of Miss Lucas, who would inherit the house. Whenever Charlotte visited, she thought she was preparing to take over the house; whenever she whispered with Mr. Collins, she believed they were discussing the Longbourn estate, determined to expel her and her daughters from the house as soon as Mr. Bennet passed away. She bitterly complained about this to her husband.
tr: Mrs Bennet was truly in a pitiable state. Every mention of marriage left her in agony, and wherever she went, she inevitably heard it being talked about. Even seeing Miss Lucas was repulsive to her. She watched her with jealous disgust as her successor in that house. Whenever Charlotte came to visit them, she was convinced that she was calculating when she would move in; whenever she whispered with Mr. Collins, she believed they were talking about the Longbourn estate and had decided to evict her and her daughters from the house as soon as Mr. Bennet died. She bitterly complained about all this to her husband.
es: Mrs. Bennet was truly in a lamentable state. The mere mention of anything concerning the wedding would put her in a bad mood, and wherever she went, she could be sure to hear about the event. Seeing Miss Lucas unsettled her. She looked at her with horror and jealousy, imagining her as her successor in that house. Whenever Charlotte came to visit them, Mrs. Bennet concluded that she was anticipating the time of taking possession, and every time she whispered something to Collins, she was convinced they were talking about the inheritance of Longbourn and planning to throw her and her daughters out as soon as Mr. Bennet passed away. She complained about it bitterly to her husband.

en: “Indeed, Mr. Bennet,” said she, “it is very hard to think that Charlotte Lucas should ever be mistress of this house, that I should be forced to make way for her, and live to see her take my place in it!”
vi: - Actually, sir, it is hard to believe that Charlotte Lucas would become the mistress of this house, that I would have to give up my place to her, and then live to see her take over my position.
tr: "Really, Mr. Bennet," she was saying, "it's very hard for me to think that Charlotte Lucas will be the mistress of this house; it's very hard for me to think that they will force me to give my home to her, that she will come and take my place!"
es: ––The truth is, Mr. Bennet ––she said to him––, it is very hard to think that Charlotte Lucas will one day be the mistress of this house, and that I will be forced to yield my place to her and live seeing her in my position.

en: “My dear, do not give way to such gloomy thoughts. Let us hope for better things. Let us flatter ourselves that I may be the survivor.”
vi: - Ma'am, you shouldn't harbor such dark thoughts. We should hope for better things. We should boast that I might be the one who survives.
tr: "My dear, don't succumb to such sorrowful thoughts. Let's hope for better things. For instance, let's do ourselves a favor and think that the one who survives will be me."
es: ––Dear, don't think about sad things. Let's have hope for better things. Let's cheer up with the idea that I can outlive you.

en: This was not very consoling to Mrs. Bennet; and, therefore, instead of making any answer, she went on as before.
vi: This did not appease Mrs. Bennet, so instead of replying, she continued:
tr: These did not comfort Mrs. Bennet; therefore, instead of replying, she continued as she knew best.
es: It was not very comforting, to say the least, for Mrs. Bennet; however, instead of replying, she continued:

en: “I cannot bear to think that they should have all this estate. If it was not for the entail, I should not mind it.”
vi: - I can't bear the thought that they will take all of this property. If it weren't for the inheritance, I wouldn't care at all.
tr: "I can't bear the thought of them taking all this property. If it weren't for the mortgage, I wouldn't care at all."
es: ––I can't bear the thought of them becoming the owners of all this property. If it weren't for the inheritance, I wouldn't care.

en: “What should not you mind?”
vi: - She doesn't care about anything?
tr: "Wouldn't it be in his lifetime?"
es: ––What is it that you couldn't care less about?

en: “I should not mind anything at all.”
vi: - I don't care about anything.
tr: "I wouldn't care about anything."
es: ––I wouldn't care about absolutely anything.

en: “Let us be thankful that you are preserved from a state of such insensibility.”
vi: - Grandma, if you are as healthy as that, then we should be happy.
tr: "Then let's be glad that you don't have to be subjected to such insensitivity.""
es: ––Let's give thanks, then, that they save you from such a state of insensitivity.

en: “I never can be thankful, Mr. Bennet, for anything about the entail. How anyone could have the conscience to entail away an estate from one’s own daughters I cannot understand; and all for the sake of Mr. Collins, too! Why should he have it more than anybody else?”
vi: - I never rejoice over an inheritance. How can a person with a conscience want to inherit and take away the property of their own daughters is something I cannot understand, all because of Mr. Collins. Why does he get more than others?
tr: "I cannot be pleased with anything regarding the mortgage, Mr. Bennet. How can one, in good conscience, leave a house to anyone other than their own daughters, I do not understand; especially to Mr. Collins – Why should he get it and not someone else?"
es: ––I will never be able to give thanks for anything related to the inheritance. I will never understand how someone can have a clear conscience disinheriting their own daughters. And to top it off, the heir has to be Mr. Collins! Why him, and not anyone else?

en: “I leave it to yourself to determine,” said Mr. Bennet.
vi: - I will leave it to you to answer.
tr: "The decision is up to you," said Mr. Bennet.
es: ––I leave it to your own consideration.

en: CHAPTER XXIV.
vi: Chapter 24
tr: Second Book Chapter I
es: CHAPTER XXIV

en: MISS BINGLEY’S letter arrived, and put an end to doubt. The very first sentence conveyed the assurance of their being all settled in London for the winter, and concluded with her brother’s regret at not having had time to pay his respects to his friends in Hertfordshire before he left the country.
vi: Miss Bingley's letter ended all doubts. In the very first sentence, she confirmed that they would stay in London, and the concluding sentence expressed that her brother regretted not having had the time to visit his friends in Hertfordshire before leaving.
tr: Miss Bingley's letter arrived and put an end to the doubt. The first sentence confirmed that they had settled in London for the winter and ended by saying how sorry her brother was for leaving without finding time to say goodbye to his friends in Hertfordshire.
es: The letter from Miss Bingley arrived and put an end to all doubts. The first sentence already conveyed that everyone had settled in London for the winter, and at the end, it expressed the brother's regret for not having had time, before leaving the countryside, to pay his respects to his friends in Hertfordshire.

en: Hope was over, entirely over; and when Jane could attend to the rest of the letter, she found little, except the professed affection of the writer, that could give her any comfort. Miss Darcy’s praise occupied the chief of it. Her many attractions were again dwelt on; and Caroline boasted joyfully of their increasing intimacy, and ventured to predict the accomplishment of the wishes which had been unfolded in her former letter. She wrote also with great pleasure of her brother’s being an inmate of Mr. Darcy’s house, and mentioned with raptures some plans of the latter with regard to new furniture.
vi: Hope had vanished, completely vanished. When Jane read the rest of the letter, she found little more to comfort her, except for the affection the writer had wished to express. The letter praised Miss Darcy a lot, about her attractive features. Caroline cheerfully talked about the growing bond between the two, predicting that the hopes mentioned in the previous letter might come true. She enthusiastically wrote about her brother becoming close with the Darcy family, excitedly mentioning some issues regarding the interior upgrades in this family.
tr: Hope was gone, completely gone; when Jane could look at the rest of the letter, she found little to comfort her besides the author's supposed affection. A large part of the letter was devoted to praising Miss Darcy. Again, many virtues were emphasized; Caroline, boasting joyfully of their increasing closeness, ventured to predict that the wishes expressed in her previous letter would come true. Once more, she wrote with great pleasure that her brother was staying at Mr. Darcy's house and spoke enthusiastically about Mr. Darcy's plans to buy new furniture.
es: There was no hope, it had completely vanished. Jane continued reading, but found few things, aside from the expressions of affection from her author, that could provide her any relief. The rest of the letter was almost entirely dedicated to praising Miss Darcy. It insisted again on her many charms, and Caroline boasted very happily about her growing intimacy with her, venturing to predict the fulfillment of the wishes she had already expressed in the first letter. She also joyfully recounted that her brother was close to the Darcy family, and enthusiastically mentioned certain plans of the latter, related to the new furniture.

en: Elizabeth, to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this, heard it in silent indignation. Her heart was divided between concern for her sister and resentment against all others. To Caroline’s assertion of her brother’s being partial to Miss Darcy, she paid no credit. That he was really fond of Jane, she doubted no more than she had ever done; and much as she had always been disposed to like him, she could not think without anger, hardly without contempt, on that easiness of temper, that want of proper resolution, which now made him the slave of his designing friends, and led him to sacrifice his own happiness to the caprice of their inclinations. Had his own happiness, however, been the only sacrifice, he might have been allowed to sport with it in whatever manner he thought best; but her sister’s was involved in it, as she thought he must be sensible himself. It was a subject, in short, on which reflection would be long indulged, and must be unavailing. She could think of nothing else; and yet, whether Bingley’s regard had really died away, or were suppressed by his friends’ interference; whether he had been aware of Jane’s attachment, or whether it had escaped his observation; whichever were the case, though her opinion of him must be materially affected by the difference, her sister’s situation remained the same, her peace equally wounded.
vi: Elizabeth listened to this in silent disdain. Her mind was torn between worry for her sister and resentment towards everyone else. She did not believe Caroline's words about her brother falling for Miss Darcy. She did not doubt that he genuinely admired Jane. Although she always liked him, she could not help but feel a mix of anger and slight contempt for such an easy-going nature, for the lack of decisiveness that made him a slave to his scheming relatives, causing him to sacrifice his own happiness to please them. However, if his happiness was the only sacrifice, he could be allowed to be generous in the way he thought best; but since this involved her sister, she thought he ought to have been more sensitive. This was what troubled her; she could think of nothing else. Yet whether his feelings had faded or were suppressed by the interference of others, whether he could understand that Jane loved him or he did not recognize this affection, in any case—though her opinion of him varied accordingly, her sister's situation remained the same, her own peace was equally disturbed.
tr: Jane summarized the letter to Elizabeth shortly after; Elizabeth listened to it in silent fury. Her heart was divided between the concern she felt for her sister and the anger she felt towards the others. She did not believe Caroline's claim that her brother was interested in Miss Darcy. She still did not doubt that Jane genuinely felt close to her; although she had always been inclined to like Mr. Bingley, she could not think of the weakness, that indecisiveness that made him a slave to his meddlesome friends and caused him to sacrifice his own happiness to their spoiled preferences, without feeling anger, even hatred. Moreover, if only his own happiness were being sacrificed, no one could object to him doing as he pleased, but her sister's happiness was also at stake, and he needed to consider that. In short, the matter was not something that could be resolved by thinking. Elizabeth could think of nothing else; had Bingley's interest truly waned, or was it suppressed by his friends' interference, was he aware of Jane's attachment or had it escaped his notice; whatever the answer, although her opinion of Bingley would change significantly depending on the answer, her sister's situation remained the same, and her own peace of mind was equally damaged.
es: Elizabeth, to whom Jane immediately communicated the most important parts of the news, listened in silence and with great indignation. Her heart wavered between concern for her sister and hatred for everyone else. She did not believe Caroline's assertion that her brother was interested in Miss Darcy. She never doubted, as she had never doubted before, that Bingley was in love with Jane; but Elizabeth, who had always had so much sympathy for him, could not think without anger, and even without contempt, of that weakness of character and lack of decision that made him a slave to his scheming friends and led him to sacrifice his own happiness to the whims of their desires. If he were only sacrificing his own happiness, he could play with it as he pleased; but it also involved Jane's happiness, and she thought he should take that into account. In the end, it was one of those things that it is useless to break one's head over. Elizabeth could think of nothing else; and whether Bingley's interest had truly died, or had been hindered by the interference of his friends; whether Bingley was aware of Jane's affection, or it had gone unnoticed by him; in any case, and although Elizabeth's opinion of Bingley might vary depending on the differences, Jane's situation remained the same and her peace had been disturbed.

en: A day or two passed before Jane had courage to speak of her feelings to Elizabeth; but at last, on Mrs. Bennet’s leaving them together, after a longer irritation than usual about Netherfield and its master, she could not help saying,—
vi: After a few days and only when the Bennet family allowed the two to be alone following a series of frustrations about Netherfield, Jane finally had the courage to confide in Elizabeth.
tr: A few days passed before Jane could find the strength to talk about her feelings to Elizabeth; but finally, after Mrs. Bennet left them alone and following an unusually long discomfort regarding Netherfield and its owner, Jane couldn't hold back and said,
es: A day or two passed before Jane had the courage to confess her feelings to her sister; but finally, in a moment when Mrs. Bennet had left them alone after becoming more irritated than usual with the subject of Netherfield and its owner, the young woman could not resist and exclaimed:

en: “O that my dear mother had more command over herself! she can have no idea of the pain she gives me by her continual reflections on him. But I will not repine. It cannot last long. He will be forgot, and we shall all be as we were before.”
vi: - Ah! The fact that our mother couldn't keep her composure, she doesn't understand that she has caused you so much pain by constantly bringing him up. But you won't be upset. It won't last long, you will forget him and we will go back to how we were before.
tr: "If only my mother could manage herself a little! She doesn't know how much she hurts me by constantly talking about her. But I won't let it bother me. It won't last long anyway. I will forget her and we will all be as we were before."
es: ––If my dear mother had more self-control! You cannot imagine how much her constant comments about Mr. Bingley hurt me. But I will not be sad. It cannot last long. I will forget it and we will all be as we were before.

en: Elizabeth looked at her sister with incredulous solicitude, but said nothing.
vi: Elizabeth looked at her sister with incredible concern, but said nothing.
tr: Elizabeth looked at her sister with a suspicious concern, but said nothing.
es: Elizabeth, solicitous and incredulous, looked at her sister, but said nothing.

en: “You doubt me,” cried Jane, slightly colouring; “indeed, you have no reason. He may live in my memory as the most amiable man of my acquaintance but that is all. I have nothing either to hope or fear, and nothing to reproach him with. Thank God I have not that pain. A little time, therefore—I shall certainly try to get the better——”
vi: Jane exclaimed, her face slightly flushed: - I suspect you; in fact, I have no reason to suspect you. He may reign in your thoughts as the most charming person among those you know, but that's all. You have nothing to hope for or worry about, and nothing to blame him for. Thank God! You haven't felt such pain. Just a short time, and you will feel better.
tr: "You don't believe me," cried Jane, her color slightly changing, "but there is no reason for you not to believe. He may live in my memories as the nicest man I have known, but that's all. I have nothing to hope for or fear, and nothing that requires me to condemn him. Thank goodness! I don't suffer that kind of pain. So a little time will be enough. –Of course, I will try to get better."
es: ––Do you doubt it? ––asked Jane, slightly blushing––. You have no reason to. I will always remember him as the best man I have ever known, that's all. I have nothing to hope for nor to fear, and I have nothing to reproach him for. Thank God, I am spared that sorrow. So, in a short time, I will be much better.

en: With a stronger voice she soon added, “I have this comfort immediately, that it has not been more than an error of fancy on my side, and that it has done no harm to anyone but myself.”
vi: Raising her voice, she added: - You have the immediate consolation that all of this is due to your small share of arbitrariness, but this does not harm anyone except yourself.
tr: Immediately after, he added in a stronger voice, "In this respect, I am at ease; from my perspective, it was merely a mistake of imagination, and it harmed no one but myself."
es: In a louder voice, he added afterwards: ––I have the consolation of thinking that it was nothing more than an error of imagination on my part and that it has harmed no one but myself.

en: “My dear Jane,” exclaimed Elizabeth, “you are too good. Your sweetness and disinterestedness are really angelic; I do not know what to say to you. I feel as if I had never done you justice, or loved you as you deserve.”
vi: Elizabeth exclaimed: - Sister Jane! You are so kind. You are gentle and carefree like an angel. I don't know how to express this to you. I feel that I have misunderstood you, or have not loved you as you deserve to be loved.
tr: "Dear Jane!" cried Elizabeth, "you are so good. Your sweetness and nobility are truly worthy of angels; I don't know what else to say to you. I feel like I have never treated you fairly or loved you as much as you deserve."
es: ––Dear Jane! ––exclaimed Elizabeth––. You are too good. Your sweetness and selflessness are truly angelic. I don't know what to say to you. I feel as if I have never done you justice, or as if I have not loved you as much as you deserve.

en: Miss Bennet eagerly disclaimed all extraordinary merit, and threw back the praise on her sister’s warm affection.
vi: Jane refused to accept any compliments and instead complimented her sister.
tr: Miss Bennet persistently denied all these extraordinary qualities and attributed the praise to her sister's kindness.
es: Jane vehemently denied having any extraordinary merit and rejected her sister's praises, which were only a product of her great affection.

en: “Nay,” said Elizabeth, “this is not fair. You wish to think all the world respectable, and are hurt if I speak ill of anybody. I only want to think you perfect, and you set yourself against it. Do not be afraid of my running into any excess, of my encroaching on your privilege of universal good-will. You need not. There are few people whom I really love, and still fewer of whom I think well. The more I see of the world the more am I dissatisfied with it; and every day confirms my belief of the inconsistency of all human characters, and of the little dependence that can be placed on the appearance of either merit or sense. I have met with two instances lately: one I will not mention, the other is Charlotte’s marriage. It is unaccountable! in every view it is unaccountable!”
vi: Elizabeth said: - No, that's not fair at all. You want to think well of everyone and feel hurt if I think badly of someone. I just want to think of you as a perfect person, but you have denied it. Don't worry that I will go astray, or that I will infringe on your privilege of goodwill. You don't have to worry. The number of people I truly care about is very few; the number of people I think well of is even fewer. The more I look at the world, the more dissatisfied I feel. Each passing day reinforces my belief in the indomitable nature of human character, and that value or personal consciousness depends on outward appearances. Later, I encountered two cases; one doesn't need to be mentioned, the other is Charlotte's marriage. It cannot be justified! From every angle, it cannot be justified!
tr: "No," said Elizabeth, "this is not fair. You want to believe that the whole world is moral, and you get hurt when I speak ill of someone. I just want to think that you are perfect, and you object to this. Do not fear my going to extremes, my getting too caught up in your absolute goodwill. There is no need. There are very few people I truly love; even fewer people I respect. The more I know the world, the more my discontent grows; every day my belief in the inconsistency of human character and that even those who seem intelligent and sensitive cannot be trusted strengthens. Recently, I have encountered two examples; I will not mention one; the other is Charlotte's marriage. It is not understandable! From whichever angle you look, it is not understandable!"
es: ––No ––said Elizabeth––, that is not right. Everyone seems respectable to you and you get offended if I speak ill of someone. You are the only one I find perfect and you don't want me to tell you that either. Do not fear that I will exceed by appropriating your privilege of universal kindness. There is no danger. I truly care for very few people, and I have a good opinion of very few. The more I know the world, the more it displeases me, and time confirms my belief in the inconsistency of human character, and in how little one can trust the appearances of goodness or intelligence. Lately, I have had two examples: one that I do not want to mention, and the other, Charlotte's wedding. It's incredible! No matter how you look at it, it's incredible!

en: “My dear Lizzy, do not give way to such feelings as these. They will ruin your happiness. You do not make allowance enough for difference of situation and temper. Consider Mr. Collins’s respectability, and Charlotte’s prudent, steady character. Remember that she is one of a large family; that as to fortune it is a most eligible match; and be ready to believe, for everybody’s sake, that she may feel something like regard and esteem for our cousin.”
vi: - Dear Lizzy, you shouldn't be so extreme in your feelings like that, otherwise you won't be happy. You haven't tolerated the difference between reality and emotions. Consider the respectable position of Mr. Collins and the prudent, steadfast character of Charlotte. Think about it; she is the daughter in a large family, materially this is a suitable marriage. For everyone's sake, you should believe that she has some feelings, such as affection and respect for our cousin.
tr: "My dear Lizzy, do not give in to such feelings. You will be unhappy. You are not giving enough consideration to the differences in rank and temperament. Think of Mr. Collins's respectability and Charlotte's sensible, steady character. Remember that Charlotte belongs to a large family; she is a financially suitable choice; and, for the good of everyone, you must believe that you can feel some respect and warmth for our cousin."
es: ––Dear Lizzy, you must not have those feelings, they will end your happiness. You do not take into consideration the different situations and the nature of people. Keep in mind the respectability of Mr. Collins and the firm and prudent character of Charlotte. Remember that she belongs to a large family, and as far as fortune is concerned, it is a very desirable marriage. You must believe, for God's sake, that she might feel some affection and esteem for our cousin.

en: “To oblige you, I would try to believe almost anything, but no one else could be benefited by such a belief as this; for were I persuaded that Charlotte had any regard for him, I should only think worse of her understanding than I now do of her heart. My dear Jane, Mr. Collins is a conceited, pompous, narrow-minded, silly man: you know he is, as well as I do; and you must feel, as well as I do, that the woman who marries him cannot have a proper way of thinking. You shall not defend her, though it is Charlotte Lucas. You shall not, for the sake of one individual, change the meaning of principle and integrity, nor endeavour to persuade yourself or me, that selfishness is prudence, and insensibility of danger security for happiness.”
vi: - To please you, I will try to believe almost everything, but no one else benefits from such belief, because I know if Collins loves her, I would despise her understanding even more than I currently disregard her feelings. Jane, Collins is an arrogant, ostentatious, narrow-minded, foolish person; you know this as well as I do. You must also think as I do, that any woman who wants to marry him cannot have sound judgment. You should not defend anyone, even if it is Charlotte Lucas. You should not change the meaning of principles and integrity for the sake of an individual, nor should you try to convince yourself or me that selfishness means prudence, and indifference to danger means the pursuit of happiness.
tr: "I would try to believe almost anything to please you, but such a belief would benefit no one; if I were convinced that Charlotte respected him, his mind would fall as low in my estimation as his heart. Dear Jane, Mr. Collins is a conceited, boastful, selfish, foolish man; you know this as well as I do; you must also be able to guess as well as I can that any woman who marries him must be out of her mind. Even if it were Charlotte Lucas, you cannot defend such a woman. You are not going to try to change the meaning of principle and honor for the sake of one person, or try to convince yourself or me that selfishness is common sense, or that insensitivity to danger is a guarantee of happiness."
es: ––To please you, I would try to believe what you say, but no one would benefit, because if I suspected that Charlotte had any interest in Mr. Collins, I would think less of her intelligence than I currently do of her heart. Dear Jane, Mr. Collins is a conceited, pedantic, stubborn, and foolish man; you know this as well as I do; and you must also know, as I do, that the woman who marries him cannot be in her right mind. Do not defend her just because she is Charlotte Lucas. For the sake of one person, you should not distort the meaning of principle and integrity, nor try to convince yourself or me that selfishness is prudence or that insensitivity to danger is a guarantee of happiness.

en: “I must think your language too strong in speaking of both,” replied Jane; “and I hope you will be convinced of it, by seeing them happy together. But enough of this. You alluded to something else. You mentioned two instances. I cannot misunderstand you, but I entreat you, dear Lizzy, not to pain me by thinking that person to blame, and saying your opinion of him is sunk. We must not be so ready to fancy ourselves intentionally injured. We must not expect a lively young man to be always so guarded and circumspect. It is very often nothing but our own vanity that deceives us. Women fancy admiration means more than it does.”
vi: Jane replied: - I think you have gone too far in your thoughts about the two people; I hope you truly believe me by seeing them live in happiness. But that is enough. You are alluding to something else. You are talking about two cases. I cannot misunderstand you, but I beg you, dear Lizzy, please do not break my heart by reproaching that person and by thinking lowly of them. We should not dwell on the thought that we are hurt intentionally. We cannot expect a young, lively man to always be meticulous and cautious. Very often, it is our own frivolity that has deceived us. Women often speculate about love more than its true nature.
tr: "If you ask me, you are using harsh language when talking about them," Jane replied; "and I hope you will believe it when you see that they are happy together. But let's leave this aside now. You mentioned something else. You spoke of two examples. There is no way I can misunderstand you, but I beg you, my dear Lizzy, do not cause me pain by thinking that person is guilty and saying that your impression of him is terrible. We should not be so ready to see ourselves as people who are intentionally hurt. We should not expect a cheerful young man to be so careful and cautious at all times. Often it is nothing but our own pride that deceives us. Women think admiration means more than it does."
es: ––You speak of both with too much harshness ––replied Jane––, and I hope you will admit it when you see that they are happy together. But let's leave this aside. You alluded to something else. You mentioned two examples. I know what it's about, but I beg you, dear Lizzy, not to make me suffer by blaming that person and saying that you have lost the good opinion you had of him. We should not be so inclined to imagine that we have been intentionally hurt. We cannot expect a young and so vital man to always be so circumspect and restrained. Often what deceives us is only our own vanity. We women believe that admiration means more than it actually does.

en: “And men take care that they should.”
vi: - And men want us to be like that.
tr: "Men are also working to make it meaningless.""
es: ––And men make sure that it is so.

en: “If it is designedly done, they cannot be justified; but I have no idea of there being so much design in the world as some persons imagine.”
vi: - If it's true, then this is precisely the reason you can't justify yourself; but you don't know that there are many schemes in this world as some people have imagined.
tr: "If it is done deliberately, it cannot be justified; but I don't think there are as many plans in the world as some people think."
es: ––If they do it deliberately, they have no justification; but it seems to me that there is not as much premeditation in the world as many people imagine.

en: “I am far from attributing any part of Mr. Bingley’s conduct to design,” said Elizabeth; “but, without scheming to do wrong, or to make others unhappy, there may be error and there may be misery. Thoughtlessness, want of attention to other people’s feelings, and want of resolution, will do the business.”
vi: Elizabeth said: - I do not attribute any part of Mr. Bingley's attitude to malice, but even without the intention to do harm or cause distress, it can still be a mistake, it can still be painful. Everything could be due to thoughtlessness, or a lack of consideration for others' feelings, or a lack of resolve.
tr: "I do not intend to attribute any part of Mr. Bingley's actions to a plan," said Elizabeth; "but mistakes can be made and sorrow can be caused without the intention of making mistakes or making others unhappy. Thoughtlessness, insensitivity to the feelings of others, and indecision can achieve the same result."
es: ––I do not mean to attribute Mr. Bingley's conduct to premeditation; but without intending to do wrong or cause others to suffer, one can make mistakes and do a great deal of harm. Inattention, disregard for the feelings of others, and indecision are responsible for that.

en: “And do you impute it to either of those?”
vi: - And you want to blame one of these things, don't you?
tr: "Is this one of the reasons for you?""
es: ––Do you attribute what happened to any of that?

en: “Yes; to the last. But if I go on I shall displease you by saying what I think of persons you esteem. Stop me, whilst you can.”
vi: - That's right, for the last thing. But if you continue, you will upset me by saying what you think about the people I value. Please stop me here.
tr: "Yes; the last one. But if I continue, I will upset you by telling you what I think about the people you respect. Stop me while you have the chance."
es: ––Yes, at the end. But if I keep talking, I will upset you by saying what I think of people you hold in high regard. It's better if you try to make me stay quiet.

en: “You persist, then, in supposing his sisters influence him?”
vi: - So you still think that his sisters influence him, don't you?
tr: "You still think that his sisters influence him, do you?""
es: Do you still suppose, then, that the sisters influence him?

en: “Yes, in conjunction with his friend.”
vi: - Yes, in collusion with his friend.
tr: "Yes, in partnership with his friend.""
es: ––Yes, along with his friend.

en: “I cannot believe it. Why should they try to influence him? They can only wish his happiness; and if he is attached to me no other woman can secure it.”
vi: - She couldn't believe it. Why did they have to try so hard to influence him? They just wanted him to be happy, and if he stayed with her, no woman could be happy with him.
tr: "I can't believe this. Why would they want to influence him? They just want him to be happy; if he's passionate about me, no other woman can make him happy."
es: ––I can't believe it. Why would he do it? They can only wish for his happiness; and if he loves me, no other woman will be able to provide it.

en: “Your first position is false. They may wish many things besides his happiness: they may wish his increase of wealth and consequence; they may wish him to marry a girl who has all the importance of money, great connections, and pride.”
vi: - Your first argument is incorrect. They may desire many things besides happiness. They may want you to be wealthier, to have more status; they may want you to marry a girl with high financial standing, elite connections, and pride.
tr: "Your first assumption is wrong. They want other things besides happiness; they want their wealth and power to increase; they want to marry a girl with money, important relatives, and ostentation."
es: Your first assumption is false. They may desire many things besides their happiness; they may desire to increase their wealth, with all that it brings; they may desire for you to marry a girl who has all the importance that money, great families, and pride can give.

en: “Beyond a doubt they do wish him to choose Miss Darcy,” replied Jane; “but this may be from better feelings than you are supposing. They have known her much longer than they have known me; no wonder if they love her better. But, whatever may be their own wishes, it is very unlikely they should have opposed their brother’s. What sister would think herself at liberty to do it, unless there were something very objectionable? If they believed him attached to me they would not try to part us; if he were so, they could not succeed. By supposing such an affection, you make everybody acting unnaturally and wrong, and me most unhappy. Do not distress me by the idea. I am not ashamed of having been mistaken—or, at least, it is slight, it is nothing in comparison of what I should feel in thinking ill of him or his sisters. Let me take it in the best light, in the light in which it may be understood.”
vi: Jane replied: - Certainly. They all want you to choose Miss Darcy, but perhaps this is out of goodwill rather than what I guess. They have known her for a longer time than they have known you; it's not surprising if they like her more. But, whatever their intentions might be, there is no reason they would go against your brother's wishes. What sibling would think they have the full right to do so, except if there is something very reprehensible? If they still believed that he cared for you, they would not try to separate you; if he truly loved you, they could not succeed. When I assume such love, I make everyone's actions seem abnormal and wrong, which makes you the saddest. Don't make yourself sad with this thought. I'm not ashamed of having been mistaken – or at least this mistake is minor, not comparable to thinking ill of him or his sisters. Let me endure it in the best way, a way that everyone can sympathize with.
tr: "No doubt, they would prefer Miss Darcy," replied Jane; "but this might be due to better feelings than you think. They have known her for a longer time than they have known me; it is not surprising that they love her more. But regardless of their own wishes, it is unlikely that they would oppose their brother's desire. Which sister would see herself with this right, if there is nothing much to object to? If they believed he was attached to me, they would not try to separate us; because if he were attached, they would not succeed. By searching for such an intention, you make everyone behave unnaturally and wrongly, and you make me very unhappy. Do not upset me with this idea. I am not ashamed of being mistaken – or whatever, it does not matter, not at all compared to the feelings I would have if I thought badly of him or his sisters. Let me see the matter from the best perspective, that is, the one that can be understood."
es: ––So, you mean that they want me to choose Miss Darcy ––replied Jane––; but perhaps they are driven by better intentions than you think. They have spent much more time with her than with me, it's logical that they would like her more. But whatever their wishes may be, it is very unlikely that they have opposed their brother's. What sister would believe she has the right to do so, unless there was something very serious to object to? If they had seen that he was very interested in me, they would not have tried to separate us; and if he were indeed that interested, all their efforts would be useless. By assuming that he loves me, you only manage to attribute bad behavior and a wrong attitude to everyone and make me suffer even more. I am not ashamed of having been wrong, and if I were ashamed, my suffering would be nothing compared to the pain that thinking ill of Bingley or his sisters would cause me. Let me interpret it in the best possible way, in the way that makes it most understandable.

en: Elizabeth could not oppose such a wish; and from this time Mr. Bingley’s name was scarcely ever mentioned between them.
vi: Elizabeth could not resist such a desire, and from this moment on they rarely mentioned the name Bingley.
tr: Elizabeth could not object to such a request; from that moment on, Mr. Bingley's name was never mentioned between them again.
es: Elizabeth could not oppose such wishes; and from then on, the name of Bingley was seldom mentioned between them.

en: Mrs. Bennet still continued to wonder and repine at his returning no more; and though a day seldom passed in which Elizabeth did not account for it clearly, there seemed little chance of her ever considering it with less perplexity. Her daughter endeavoured to convince her of what she did not believe herself, that his attentions to Jane had been merely the effect of a common and transient liking, which ceased when he saw her no more; but though the probability of the statement was admitted at the time, she had the same story to repeat every day. Mrs. Bennet’s best comfort was, that Mr. Bingley must be down again in the summer.
vi: Mrs. Bennet continued to worry and fret about him not returning, although there wasn't a day that Elizabeth didn't notice this, it seemed she had little chance to think and be less bewildered. Her eldest daughter tried to persuade her of something she herself didn't believe, that when he paid attention to her, it was merely the result of ordinary and temporary admiration, which would fade away when he no longer saw her. Although she also recognized that this might be true, she still had only one thing to repeat every day. Mrs. Bennet's only consolation was that Mr. Bingley would return in the summer.
tr: Mrs. Bennet continued to be amazed and saddened by the fact that he would not be returning anymore; although not a single day passed without Elizabeth explaining the situation, it seemed almost impossible to get Mrs. Bennet to handle the situation more calmly. Her daughter tried to make her believe something she did not want to believe, that his interest in Jane was nothing more than a normal and temporary liking, and that his interest ceased once he stopped seeing her; however, even if the explanation was accepted as possibly true at the time, she repeated the same story every day. Mrs. Bennet's only consolation was that Mr. Bingley would come there again in the summer.
es: Mrs. Bennet was still puzzled and murmuring upon seeing that Bingley did not return; and although not a day went by without Elizabeth clearly showing her what was happening, it seemed that the mother could not stop being puzzled. Her daughter tried to convince her of what she herself did not believe, telling her that Bingley's attentions towards Jane had been the result of a common and fleeting whim that ceased once he stopped seeing her; but although Mrs. Bennet did not hesitate to admit that possibility, she could not help but repeat the same story every day. The only thing that consoled her was that Bingley had to return in the summer.

en: Mr. Bennet treated the matter differently. “So, Lizzy,” said he, one day, “your sister is crossed in love, I find. I congratulate her. Next to being married, a girl likes to be crossed in love a little now and then. It is something to think of, and gives her a sort of distinction among her companions. When is your turn to come? You will hardly bear to be long outdone by Jane. Now is your time. Here are officers enough at Meryton to disappoint all the young ladies in the country. Let Wickham be your man. He is a pleasant fellow, and would jilt you creditably.”
vi: Mr. Bennet viewed the matter differently. One day, he said: - So, Lizzy, I see your sister has encountered a setback in love. I'm glad for her. Apart from marriage, a young woman likes to occasionally face obstacles in love. This is something to ponder, making her distinct from others. When will it be your turn? You can hardly stand for your sister Jane to surpass you. Now it's your turn. There are enough officers in Meryton to disappoint every girl in the area. Choose Wickham as your man. He is charming and will reliably let you down.
tr: Mr. Bennet approached the matter differently. "So, Lizzy," he said one day, "your sister has lost in love. I congratulate her. Every girl likes to lose in love once in a while as much as she likes to get married. It gives her something to think about and a sort of distinction among her friends. When is it going to be your turn? You can't stand being left behind Jane for too long. Your time has come. There are enough officers in Meryton to disappoint all the women in the country. Let yours be Wickham. A charming man, he will leave you nicely."
es: Mr. Bennet saw the matter in a very different light. So, Lizzy ––he said one day––, your sister has had a romantic failure. I congratulate her. Before getting married, it's good for a girl to have some failure; it gives her something to think about, and it gives her a certain distinction among her friends. And you, when is it your turn? You wouldn't want to be less than Jane. Take advantage now. There are enough officers in Meryton to deceive all the girls in the area. Choose Wickham. He is a pleasant fellow, and he is sure to reject you.

en: “Thank you, sir, but a less agreeable man would satisfy me. We must not all expect Jane’s good fortune.”
vi: - Thank you, Dad, but a less pleasant person would also make me happy. None of us should rely on luck like Jane.
tr: "Thank you, sir, but a less charming man will suffice for me." "We cannot all hope to be as fortunate as Jane.""
es: ––Thank you, Dad, but I would be satisfied with a less pleasant man. Not all of us can expect to be as lucky as Jane.

en: “True,” said Mr. Bennet; “but it is a comfort to think that, whatever of that kind may befall you, you have an affectionate mother who will always make the most of it.”
vi: - That's right, but there's some comfort in thinking that, no matter what happens to you, you still have a loving mother who always knows how to take advantage of the situation.
tr: "True," said Mr. Bennet, "but whatever may come to her, it is comforting to know that she has a loving mother who knows how to make the best of the situation."
es: ––It is true ––said Mr. Bennet––, but it is a comfort to think that, whatever happens, you have a loving mother who will always help you.

en: Mr. Wickham’s society was of material service in dispelling the gloom which the late perverse occurrences had thrown on many of the Longbourn family. They saw him often, and to his other recommendations was now added that of general unreserve. The whole of what Elizabeth had already heard, his claims on Mr. Darcy, and all that he had suffered from him, was now openly acknowledged and publicly canvassed; and everybody was pleased to think how much they had always disliked Mr. Darcy before they had known anything of the matter.
vi: The relationship with Mr. Wickham had the effect of dispelling any gloom in the Longbourn household. They often met with him. Now, additional impressions of him included his unreserved attitude. Everything Elizabeth had heard, the things he told about Darcy, and all that he had to endure because of Darcy, were now openly discussed and acknowledged; everyone was happy to think that they had always had a dislike for Mr. Darcy even before they knew about any issues between the two of them.
tr: Mr. Wickham's presence was quite effective in dispelling the sorrow caused by recent misfortunes among many members of the Longbourn family. They saw him frequently, and now a general frankness was added to his other qualities. The things Elizabeth had already heard, the claims about Mr. Darcy, the sufferings caused by him were now openly spoken of, publicly declared; even before everyone learned everything, she took pleasure in thinking about how much she hated Mr. Darcy.
es: Wickham's company was of great utility in dispelling the sadness that the recent unfortunate events had caused several members of the Longbourn family. They saw him often, and on that occasion, he added to his other virtues that of absolute frankness. Everything Elizabeth had heard, his complaints against Darcy and the grievances he had inflicted upon him, became public knowledge; everyone delighted in recalling how disagreeable Darcy had always been, even before knowing any of this.

en: Miss Bennet was the only creature who could suppose there might be any extenuating circumstances in the case unknown to the society of Hertfordshire: her mild and steady candour always pleaded for allowances, and urged the possibility of mistakes; but by everybody else Mr. Darcy was condemned as the worst of men.
vi: Mrs. Bennet was still the only creature who thought that there might be mitigating circumstances in the matter that the people of Hertfordshire were unaware of. Her gentle and steadfast frankness always called for forgiveness and tried to persuade a possibility of misunderstanding – but to everyone else, Mr. Darcy was still condemned as the worst person.
tr: Miss Bennet was the only person who could think that there might be mitigating circumstances in the matter unknown to the people of Hertfordshire; her moderate and steady sincerity always allowed room for tolerance, seeking the possibility of error – but everyone else cursed Mr. Darcy as the most heartless man in the world.
es: Jane was the only one capable of supposing that there might be some mitigating circumstance in this case unknown to the neighbors of Hertfordshire. Her sweet and unwavering candor constantly called for indulgence and proposed the possibility of a mistake; but everyone considered Darcy to be the worst of men.

en: CHAPTER XXV.
vi: Chapter 25
tr: Chapter II
es: CHAPTER XXV

en: AFTER a week spent in professions of love and schemes of felicity, Mr. Collins was called from his amiable Charlotte by the arrival of Saturday. The pain of separation, however, might be alleviated on his side by preparations for the reception of his bride, as he had reason to hope, that shortly after his next return into Hertfordshire, the day would be fixed that was to make him the happiest of men. He took leave of his relations at Longbourn with as much solemnity as before; wished his fair cousins health and happiness again, and promised their father another letter of thanks.
vi: After a week of expressing affection and contemplating happiness, Mr. Collins was called back on Sunday. However, the sadness of parting this time could be alleviated for him by the preparations for welcoming the bride. He had reason to hope that, upon his next return to Hertfordshire, they would set a date for him to become the happiest young man in the world. He bid farewell to his relatives at Longbourn with the same formal words as before; he wished his lovely cousins health and happiness, and promised Mr. Bennet to send a thank-you letter.
tr: After a week filled with vows of love and dreams of happiness, Mr. Collins had to part from his dear Charlotte with the arrival of Saturday. But the pain of separation was alleviated for him by the preparations being made for his bride's arrival; he had reasons to hope that the day which would make him the happiest man in the world would be set immediately upon his next return to Hertfordshire. He bade farewell to his relatives at Longbourn with the same solemnity as before; he once again wished his beautiful cousins health and happiness and promised their father a new letter of thanks.
es: After a week spent between promises of love and plans of happiness, Collins had to bid farewell to his beloved Charlotte to arrive on Saturday at Hunsford. But the sorrow of the separation was alleviated for Collins by the preparations he had to make for the reception of his fiancée; for he had reasons to believe that shortly after his next return to Hertfordshire, the day would be set that would make him the happiest of men. He bid farewell to his relatives at Longbourn with the same solemnity as before; once again wished his beautiful cousins health and happiness, and promised the father another letter of gratitude.

en: On the following Monday, Mrs. Bennet had the pleasure of receiving her brother and his wife, who came, as usual, to spend the Christmas at Longbourn. Mr. Gardiner was a sensible, gentlemanlike man, greatly superior to his sister, as well by nature as education. The Netherfield ladies would have had difficulty in believing that a man who lived by trade, and within view of his own warehouses, could have been so well-bred and agreeable. Mrs. Gardiner, who was several years younger than Mrs. Bennet and Mrs. Philips, was an amiable, intelligent, elegant woman, and a great favourite with her Longbourn nieces. Between the two eldest and herself especially, there subsisted a very particular regard. They had frequently been staying with her in town.
vi: On the following day, Mrs. Bennet joyfully welcomed her brother and his wife to stay at Longbourn for Christmas. Mr. Gardiner was a sensitive, refined man, surpassing his sister in both character and education. The ladies of Netherfield might find it hard to believe that someone who made his living through commerce and lived near warehouses could possess such a level of sophistication and pleasant demeanor. Mrs. Gardiner, a few years younger than Mrs. Bennet and Mrs. Philips, was a charming, intelligent, and elegant woman, dearly loved by all the young ladies of Longbourn. There was a very special affection between the two sisters and Mrs. Gardiner. They often stayed with her in the city.
tr: The following Monday, Mrs. Bennet joyfully welcomed her brother and his wife, who, as usual, had come to spend Christmas at Longbourn. Mr. Gardiner was a sensible, gentlemanly man; in both nature and education, he was far superior to his sister. The ladies at Netherfield found it hard to believe that a man who made his living through trade and whose house was within sight of his shop could be so polite and charming. Mrs. Gardiner, who was a few years younger than Mrs. Bennet and Mrs. Philips, was a pleasant, intelligent, and graceful woman; she was the favorite of all her nieces and nephews at Longbourn. She had a particularly special bond with her two eldest nieces. When they went to town, they often stayed with her.
es: On the following Monday, Mrs. Bennet had the pleasure of receiving her brother and his wife, who came, as usual, to spend Christmas at Longbourn. Mr. Gardiner was an intelligent and gentlemanly man, far superior to his sister by nature and education. The ladies of Netherfield would have found it difficult to believe that this man, who lived off commerce and was always involved in his warehouse, could be so well-educated and pleasant. Mrs. Gardiner, much younger than Mrs. Bennet and Mrs. Philips, was a charming and elegant woman, adored by her nieces at Longbourn. Especially the two eldest, with whom she had a particular friendship. Elizabeth and Jane had often been to her house in the capital.

en: The first part of Mrs. Gardiner’s business, on her arrival, was to distribute her presents and describe the newest fashions. When this was done, she had a less active part to play. It became her turn to listen. Mrs. Bennet had many grievances to relate, and much to complain of. They had all been very ill-used since she last saw her sister. Two of her girls had been on the point of marriage, and after all there was nothing in it.
vi: The first thing Mrs. Gardiner did upon arrival was to distribute the gifts and describe the new fashion styles. Once finished, she didn't have much else to do; it was her turn to listen. Mrs. Bennet had many things to complain about. Everyone had been treated poorly since the last time the sisters met. The two daughters had come close to marriage, but in the end, they got nothing.
tr: Mrs. Gardiner's first task upon arrival was to distribute her gifts and discuss the latest fashion trends. After this task was completed, she had a less active role. It was her turn to listen. Mrs. Bennet had a lot of grievances and many complaints to share. Since the last time she had seen her aunt, everything had gone wrong for everyone. Two of her daughters had come to the brink of marriage but had remained there.
es: The first thing Mrs. Gardiner did upon arriving was to distribute her gifts and describe the new fashions. Once this was done, she ceased to lead the conversation; now it was her turn to listen. Mrs. Bennet had to tell her about her many misfortunes and complaints. She had suffered many humiliations since the last time she saw her sister-in-law. Two of her daughters had been on the verge of getting married, but then everything had come to nothing.

en: “I do not blame Jane,” she continued, “for Jane would have got Mr. Bingley if she could. But, Lizzy! Oh, sister! it is very hard to think that she might have been Mr. Collins’s wife by this time, had not it been for her own perverseness. He made her an offer in this very room, and she refused him. The consequence of it is, that Lady Lucas will have a daughter married before I have, and that Longbourn estate is just as much entailed as ever. The Lucases are very artful people, indeed, sister. They are all for what they can get. I am sorry to say it of them, but so it is.
