It makes me very nervous and poorly, to be thwarted so in my own family, and to have neighbours who think of themselves before anybody else. However, your coming just at this time is the greatest of comforts, and I am very glad to hear what you tell us of long sleeves.”
vi: Mrs. Bennet continued: - I do not blame Jane, for Jane would have taken Mr. Bingley if she could. But Lizzy! Oh! It is so distressing to think that she could have been Mr. Collins's wife by now, if she had not been so headstrong. He proposed to her right in this room, but she refused. As a result, Lady Lucas will have a daughter married before mine, and the Longbourn estate will continue to be inherited as before. The Lucases are really very cunning people, my dear. They want to seize everything they can. I regret to speak of them this way, but it is the truth. This makes me very anxious and unwell, being thwarted in my own family, and having neighbors who think only of themselves first. However, you coming at this moment is a great comfort to me, and I am very glad to hear your opinion.
tr: "I don't blame Jane," she continued, "because if Jane could, she would have won over Mr. Bingley. But Lizzy! oh, my sister! by now she would have already been Mr. Collins's wife if she hadn't been so perverse. The man proposed to her in this very room, and she refused. The result is clear, Lady Lucas will be the mother of a married daughter before me; and the Longbourn estate is still mortgaged as ever. The Lucases are indeed very clever people, my sister. They take whatever they can get. I'm sorry to speak about them this way, but it's the truth. Being pushed around within my own family like this irritates me, it makes me miserable; especially when you have neighbors who think of themselves before anyone else. Nevertheless, your coming at such a time is the greatest consolation; I really enjoyed what you said about the long sleeves."
es: ––I do not blame Jane, he continued––, because she would have married Mr. Bingley if she could; but Elizabeth... Ah, my sister! It is very hard to think that at this hour she could be Mrs. Collins if it hadn't been for her stubbornness. He proposed to her in this very room and she rejected him. As a consequence, Lady Lucas will have a married daughter before I do, and the Longbourn inheritance will pass into their hands. The Lucases are very shrewd, they always take advantage of what they can. I regret having to speak of them in this way but it is the truth. It makes me very nervous and sick that my own family contradicts me in this way, and to have neighbors who think only of themselves. At least having you here at this very moment comforts me greatly; I love what you tell us about the long sleeves.

en: Mrs. Gardiner, to whom the chief of this news had been given before, in the course of Jane and Elizabeth’s correspondence with her, made her sister a slight answer, and, in compassion to her nieces, turned the conversation.
vi: Through Jane and Elizabeth's letters, Mrs. Gardiner had some knowledge of the matter. She only responded briefly, and out of compassion for her nieces, she steered the conversation in a different direction.
tr: Mrs. Gardiner, who had learned the essence of these news during her correspondence with Jane and Elizabeth, responded lightly to her sister-in-law, then, feeling sorry for her nieces, changed the subject.
es: Mrs. Gardiner, who had already heard about the matter through the correspondence she maintained with Jane and Elizabeth, gave a brief response, and out of compassion for her nieces, changed the subject.

en: When alone with Elizabeth afterwards, she spoke more on the subject. “It seems likely to have been a desirable match for Jane,” said she. “I am sorry it went off. But these things happen so often! A young man, such as you describe Mr. Bingley, so easily falls in love with a pretty girl for a few weeks, and, when accident separates them, so easily forgets her, that these sort of inconstancies are very frequent.”
vi: When sitting alone with Elizabeth, she further discussed the matter. She said: - It seems that Jane could have had a desirable marriage. Your aunt feels very sad because this did not happen. But such things are common! A young man, as you described Mr. Bingley, falls in love with a beautiful girl so easily within a few weeks, and when an incident forces him to be away from her, he forgets her just as easily.
tr: Later, when he was alone with Elizabeth, he talked a little more about this subject. "It seems like it would have been an ideal marriage for Jane," he said. "I'm sorry it didn't happen. But such things happen a lot! If Mr. Bingley is the kind of man you described, who easily falls in love with a pretty girl for a few weeks and then forgets her just as easily when circumstances separate them, it means he often engages in such infidelity."
es: When he was alone later with Elizabeth, he brought up the matter again: ––It seems that it would have been a good match for Jane ––he said––. I regret that it has been ruined. But these things happen so often! A young man like Bingley, as you describe him to me, easily falls in love with a pretty girl for a few weeks and, if by chance they part, he forgets her just as easily.

en: “Offended two or three young ladies”
vi: Such inconsistencies happen very often.
tr: If Mr. Bingley is the kind of man you described, who easily falls in love with a pretty girl for a few weeks and then forgets her just as easily when circumstances separate them, it means he often engages in such infidelity."
es: Such inconstancies are very common.

en: “An excellent consolation in its way,” said Elizabeth; “but it will not do for us. We do not suffer by accident. It does not often happen that the interference of friends will persuade a young man of independent fortune to think no more of a girl whom he was violently in love with only a few days before.”
vi: Elizabeth said: - You are very good at comforting, but it doesn't help us. We are not suffering because of the incident. It is not common for close relatives to intervene to persuade a young man with independent means to completely forget a girl he passionately loved just a few days before.
tr: "A perfect solace on its own," said Elizabeth, "but it doesn't work for us. We are not suffering by chance. That a friend's intervention convinces a young man with his own income to forget a girl he was passionately in love with just a few days ago, this is not something that happens often."
es: ––If that had been the case, it would be a great comfort ––said Elizabeth––, but our situation is different. What happened to us was not by chance. It is not so common for friends to intervene and convince an independent young man to stop thinking about a girl he was madly in love with just a few days before.

en: “But that expression of ‘violently in love’ is so hackneyed, so doubtful, so indefinite, that it gives me very little idea. It is as often applied to feelings which arise only from a half hour’s acquaintance, as to a real, strong attachment. Pray, how violent was Mr. Bingley’s love?”
vi: - But the phrase "intense love" is too nonsensical, too suspicious, too vague, so there's not much to say about it. It usually refers to emotions stemming from interactions lasting half an hour, as well as true love. Try asking yourself, how intense is Mr. Bingley's love?
tr: "But this expression 'violently in love' is so clichéd, so doubtful, so vague that it gives me very little idea. It can apply to feelings born from half an hour's acquaintance as well as to real, strong attachments. Please, can you tell me how intense Mr. Bingley's love was?"
es: ––But that expression, "madly in love," is so overused, so ambiguous and so vague, that it tells me nothing. The same applies to feelings born half an hour after meeting, as to a strong and true affection. Explain to me what Mr. Bingley's love was like.

en: “I never saw a more promising inclination; he was growing quite inattentive to other people, and wholly engrossed by her. Every time they met, it was more decided and remarkable. At his own ball he offended two or three young ladies by not asking them to dance; and I spoke to him twice myself without receiving an answer. Could there be finer symptoms? Is not general incivility the very essence of love?”
vi: - I have never seen such a promising affection. He hardly pays attention to anyone else, completely captivated by my sister. Each time they meet, their feelings seem more determined and vivid. At the ball he hosted, he offended two or three young ladies by not inviting them to dance, and I myself spoke to him twice without receiving a response. Could there be a clearer sign?
tr: "I have never seen a more promising interest; gradually, he became oblivious to other people; he was so captivated by Jane. Whenever they met, this became more apparent, more definite. At his own ball, he offended several ladies by not asking them to dance; I spoke to him twice, but received no reply. Could there be clearer signs? Isn't indifference to others the essence of love?"
es: ––I have never seen a more promising attraction. When he was with Jane, he paid no attention to anyone else, he devoted himself entirely to her. Every time they saw each other, it became more certain and evident. At his own ball, he snubbed two or three young ladies by not asking them to dance, and I spoke to him twice without getting a response. Could there be clearer symptoms? Isn't rudeness to everyone else the very essence of love?

en: “Oh, yes! of that kind of love which I suppose him to have felt. Poor Jane! I am sorry for her, because, with her disposition, she may not get over it immediately. It had better have happened to you, Lizzy; you would have laughed yourself out of it sooner. But do you think she would be prevailed on to go back with us? Change of scene might be of service—and perhaps a little relief from home may be as useful as anything.”
vi: - Ah, that's right! I do think it's his feelings. Poor Jane! I feel for her because with her temperament, she can't get over it quickly. This should have happened to you, Lizzy; soon you would be able to joke about such a thing. But do you think your sister can overcome herself to return to us? A change of scenery, or being away from home for a while, might be beneficial for anything else.
tr: "Ah yes! –the kind of love I thought he felt. Poor Jane! I feel sorry for her; someone of her character cannot get over it quickly. I wish it had happened to you, Lizzy; you would laugh it off more quickly. But do you think we can persuade Jane to come back with us? A change of air might help –and perhaps just being away from home would be a relief in itself."
es: ––Of that kind of love that I imagine Bingley felt, yes. Poor Jane! I feel sorry for her, because given her nature, she won't forget so easily. It would have been better if it had happened to you, Lizzy; you would have resigned yourself sooner. But, do you think we can convince her to come with us to London? A change of air would do her good, and maybe a little rest away from home would be better for her than anything else.

en: Elizabeth was exceedingly pleased with this proposal, and felt persuaded of her sister’s ready acquiescence.
vi: Elizabeth was very pleased with such a proposal, confident that her sister would agree.
tr: Elizabeth was extremely pleased with the offer; she said she believed her sister was more than willing from the start.
es: Elizabeth found this proposition wonderful and did not doubt that her sister would accept it.

en: “I hope,” added Mrs. Gardiner, “that no consideration with regard to this young man will influence her. We live in so different a part of town, all our connections are so different, and, as you well know, we go out so little, that it is very improbable they should meet at all, unless he really comes to see her.”
vi: Mrs. Gardiner added: - I hope your sister won't be influenced by any thoughts about that young man. As you know, our family lives in a secluded part of the city, and we rarely go out, so it's unlikely that the two of them will meet. Unless he intentionally comes to find your sister.
tr: "I hope," added Mrs. Gardiner, "that her concerns about this young man do not affect her. We live in a very different part of the city, all our associations are very different, and as you know, we seldom go out; so it is almost impossible for them to encounter us, unless the man comes to see her.""
es: ––I suppose ––he added–– that thinking she might meet that young man won't stop her. We live in opposite parts of the city, all our friends are so different and, as you know, we go out so little, that it's very unlikely to happen, unless he comes expressly to see her.

en: “And that is quite impossible; for he is now in the custody of his friend, and Mr. Darcy would no more suffer him to call on Jane in such a part of London! My dear aunt, how could you think of it? Mr. Darcy may, perhaps, have heard of such a place as Gracechurch Street, but he would hardly think a month’s ablution enough to cleanse him from its impurities, were he once to enter it; and, depend upon it, Mr. Bingley never stirs without him.”
vi: - This is unlikely to happen because he is still being held by his friend, Mr. Darcy will not allow him to meet Jane in that area of London! My dear, how could you come up with such a thing? Mr. Darcy might have heard of a place like Gracechurch Street, but he should not think that a month of baptism is enough to cleanse all the stains from his person if he comes here, and consequently, Mr. Bingley never acts without him.
tr: "There is no way; because now he is under the watchful eye of his friend; Mr. Darcy cannot tolerate him visiting Jane in such a neighborhood of London! My dear aunt, how could such a thing cross your mind? Mr. Darcy may have heard of a place called Gracechurch Street, but once he sets foot there, he would think he couldn't rid himself of its grime even if he scrubbed for a month; rest assured, Mr. Bingley won't move an inch without him."
es: ––And that is impossible, because now he is under the custody of his friend, and Mr. Darcy would not allow him to visit Jane in such a part of London. Dear aunt, what do you think? Darcy might have heard of a place like Gracechurch Street, but he would believe that not even the ablutions of a whole month would be enough to cleanse him of all its impurities, if he ever deigned to enter that street. And you can be sure that Bingley would not take a step without him.

en: “So much the better. I hope they will not meet at all. But does not Jane correspond with his sister? She will not be able to help calling.”
vi: - Then all the better. She hopes the two of you will never meet again. But Jane will correspond with her sister, won't she? She won't be able to resist visiting.
tr: "All the better." "I hope they never meet." "But isn't Jane corresponding with the man's sister?" "She can't ignore that.""
es: ––Much better. I hope they never meet. But, doesn't Jane write to her sister? Then, Miss Bingley will have no excuse not to visit her.

en: “She will drop the acquaintance entirely.”
vi: - My sister will sever all relationships.
tr: "He will end the friendship permanently."
es: ––He will completely break off their friendship.

en: But, in spite of the certainty in which Elizabeth affected to place this point, as well as the still more interesting one of Bingley’s being withheld from seeing Jane, she felt a solicitude on the subject which convinced her, on examination, that she did not consider it entirely hopeless. It was possible, and sometimes she thought it probable, that his affection might be re-animated, and the influence of his friends successfully combated by the more natural influence of Jane’s attractions.
vi: But although Elizabeth spoke firmly about this, as well as about Mr. Bingley being detained and unable to visit her sister, she still cared deeply about the matter, leading her to believe that not all hope was lost. She thought it very possible that his love would rekindle, and the natural influence of Jane's charm would overcome the influence of those around him.
tr: Although Elizabeth seemed very confident when describing this point and the even more intriguing fact that Bingley was being kept from seeing Jane, a doubt about the matter crept into her mind, and upon reflection, it convinced her that the situation was not entirely hopeless. It was possible, even quite possible, that Bingley's affection could be rekindled and that the influence of his friends could be overcome by the more natural effect of Jane's charm.
es: But, despite Elizabeth being so sure about this point, and, what was even more interesting, despite Bingley being prevented from seeing Jane, Mrs. Gardiner was convinced, after examining it well, that there was still hope. It was possible, and sometimes she believed even beneficial, that Bingley's affection could be rekindled and fight against the influence of his friends under the more natural influence of Jane's charms.

en: Miss Bennet accepted her aunt’s invitation with pleasure; and the Bingleys were no otherwise in her thoughts at the same time than as she hoped, by Caroline’s not living in the same house with her brother, she might occasionally spend a morning with her, without any danger of seeing him.
vi: Jane happily accepted her aunt's invitation. The Bingley household no longer occupied her thoughts with the idea that she might occasionally spend a morning with Caroline without having to see him, as she did not live in the same house as her brother.
tr: Miss Bennet gladly accepted her sister-in-law's invitation; her only thought about the Bingleys was Caroline; since she did not live in the same house as her brother, she hoped to spend a morning with Caroline now and then without the danger of seeing him.
es: Jane gladly accepted her aunt's invitation, without thinking about the Bingleys, although she hoped that, since Caroline did not live in the same house as her brother, she might spend a morning with her without the danger of encountering him.

en: The Gardiners stayed a week at Longbourn; and what with the Philipses, the Lucases, and the officers, there was not a day without its engagement. Mrs. Bennet had so carefully provided for the entertainment of her brother and sister, that they did not once sit down to a family dinner. When the engagement was for home, some of the officers always made part of it, of which officers Mr. Wickham was sure to be one; and on these occasions Mrs. Gardiner, rendered suspicious by Elizabeth’s warm commendation of him, narrowly observed them both. Without supposing them, from what she saw, to be very seriously in love, their preference of each other was plain enough to make her a little uneasy; and she resolved to speak to Elizabeth on the subject before she left Hertfordshire, and represent to her the imprudence of encouraging such an attachment.
vi: The Gardiners stayed at Longbourn for a week. With the Philipses, the Lucases, and the officers, there was not a day without social engagements. Mrs. Bennet was so considerate in entertaining her brother and sister-in-law that they had no time to sit down for meals with the family. When there were social gatherings at the house, the officers were always present, among whom was certainly Mr. Wickham. On these occasions, Mrs. Gardiner noticed Elizabeth's warm demeanor towards him, so she carefully observed the two. She did not think they were deeply in love, but felt uneasy seeing them clearly affectionate towards each other. She decided to talk to Elizabeth about this before leaving Hertfordshire, explaining to her the need to be cautious in encouraging such an attachment.
tr: The Gardiners stayed at Longbourn for a week; with the Philipses, the Lucases, and the officers, not a single day passed without entertainment. Mrs. Bennet tried so hard to ensure her brother and sister-in-law had fun that they couldn't even sit down for a family dinner once. When the entertainment was at home, some officers were always present – Mr. Wickham, of course, was one of them; once, Mrs. Gardiner became suspicious after Elizabeth spoke warmly of him and decided to keep a close watch on the two. From what she observed, she did not seriously conclude that they were in love, but the obvious interest they showed in each other disturbed her a bit, and before leaving Hertfordshire, she decided to talk to Elizabeth about it and advise her that continuing such a closeness would be unwise.
es: The Gardiners stayed in Longbourn for a week; and among the Philipses, the Lucases, and the officers, there was not a day without an engagement. Mrs. Bennet had taken such care to prepare everything so that her brother and sister-in-law would have a good time, that not once could they enjoy a family meal. When the gathering was at home, there were always some officers present among whom Wickham could not be absent. On these occasions, Mrs. Gardiner, who was curious about the many praises Elizabeth bestowed upon him, observed the two of them closely. Realizing, from what she saw, that they were not seriously in love; their mutual preference was too evident. She did not feel very at ease, so before leaving Hertfordshire she decided to speak with Elizabeth about the matter, warning her of her imprudence in encouraging that relationship.

en: To Mrs. Gardiner, Wickham had one means of affording pleasure, unconnected with his general powers. About ten or a dozen years ago, before her marriage, she had spent a considerable time in that very part of Derbyshire to which he belonged. They had, therefore, many acquaintance in common; and, though Wickham had been little there since the death of Darcy’s father, five years before, it was yet in his power to give her fresher intelligence of her former friends than she had been in the way of procuring.
vi: For Mrs. Gardiner, Wickham had a way of enjoying pleasures that had nothing to do with his abilities. About ten years ago, before she got married, she had lived for a long time in Derbyshire, Wickham's hometown. Therefore, she and Wickham had mutual friends. Although Wickham had seldom visited the area since Mr. Darcy's father passed away five years ago, it was through his abilities that she received new information about old acquaintances.
tr: Mrs. Gardiner found Wickham interesting not only because of his general characteristics. Ten or twelve years ago, when she was still single, she had spent quite some time in the part of Derbyshire where Wickham was from. Therefore, they had many mutual acquaintances; although Wickham had not visited there much since Darcy's father died five years ago, Mrs. Gardiner had more recent information about their old friends than he could provide.
es: Wickham, aside from his qualities, knew how to please Mrs. Gardiner. Before getting married, ten or twelve years ago, she had spent quite some time in the same part of Derbyshire where Wickham was born. They therefore had many mutual friends; and although Wickham left shortly after the death of Darcy's father, which occurred five years ago, he could still tell her things about their old friends, more recent than what she knew.

en: Mrs. Gardiner had seen Pemberley, and known the late Mr. Darcy by character perfectly well. Here, consequently, was an inexhaustible subject of discourse. In comparing her recollection of Pemberley with the minute description which Wickham could give, and in bestowing her tribute of praise on the character of its late possessor, she was delighting both him and herself. On being made acquainted with the present Mr. Darcy’s treatment of him, she tried to remember something of that gentleman’s reputed disposition, when quite a lad, which might agree with it; and was confident, at last, that she recollected having heard Mr. Fitzwilliam Darcy formerly spoken of as a very proud, ill-natured boy.
vi: Mrs. Gardiner had come to Pemberley and knew very well about old Mr. Darcy's character. Therefore, this was a topic for endless conversation. When comparing what she remembered about Derbyshire with what Mr. Wickham described in detail, and when praising the character of the late master, both she and he found joy. Upon learning about how Darcy treated him, she tried to recall something about Darcy's youth that matched his story, and eventually, she remembered hearing Mr. Fitzwilliam Darcy talk about a very proud and ill-tempered boy.
tr: Mrs. Gardiner had seen Pemberley and had heard much about the late Mr. Darcy's reputation. Here was an inexhaustible topic of conversation. Comparing what she remembered of Pemberley with the detailed description given by Wickham, and speaking in praise of the late owner's character, she made both Wickham and herself happy. Upon hearing what the current Mr. Darcy had done to him, she tried to recall something that would match the reputation of that gentleman in his childhood, and finally she was sure that she remembered hearing Mr. Fitzwilliam Darcy described as an excessively proud, mischievous child even then.
es: Mrs. Gardiner had been to Pemberley and had known the late Mr. Darcy perfectly. This was, therefore, an inexhaustible topic of conversation. She compared her memories of Pemberley with the detailed description Wickham gave, and by praising the character of its last owner, they both delighted in it. Upon learning of Darcy's behavior with Wickham, Mrs. Gardiner believed she remembered something of the bad reputation he had when he was still a boy, which fit this case; finally, she confessed that she remembered that even then young Fitzwilliam Darcy was spoken of as a bad and proud boy.

en: CHAPTER XXVI.
vi: Chapter 26
tr: Chapter III
es: CHAPTER XXVI

en: MRS. GARDINER’S caution to Elizabeth was punctually and kindly given on the first favourable opportunity of speaking to her alone: after honestly telling her what she thought, she thus went on:—
vi: Mrs. Gardiner took the opportunity to speak privately with Elizabeth to gently caution her. After honestly telling her what she thought, she added:
tr: Mrs. Gardiner firmly and kindly warned Elizabeth at the first opportunity they had to speak alone; after sharing her thoughts, she continued: –
es: Mrs. Gardiner gave Elizabeth the aforementioned warning promptly and kindly, at the first opportunity she had to speak with her alone. After having honestly told her what she thought, she added:

en: “You are too sensible a girl, Lizzy, to fall in love merely because you are warned against it; and, therefore, I am not afraid of speaking openly. Seriously, I would have you be on your guard. Do not involve yourself, or endeavour to involve him, in an affection which the want of fortune would make so very imprudent. I have nothing to say against him: he is a most interesting young man; and if he had the fortune he ought to have, I should think you could not do better. But as it is—you must not let your fancy run away with you. You have sense, and we all expect you to use it. Your father would depend on your resolution and good conduct, I am sure. You must not disappoint your father.”
vi: - Lizzy, you are mature enough not to fall in love just because you are warned against it. Therefore, I will not hesitate to speak frankly. I need to caution you, and I am serious about this. You should not get entangled with him in a relationship where material desires might make love reckless. I have nothing against him; he is someone worthy of our attention; and if he had the wealth he should have inherited, I could say there would be nothing better for you. You are sensible, and everyone expects you to use your sense. I believe your father will rely on your steadfastness and virtue. You should not disappoint your father.
tr: "You are a very sensible girl, Lizzy, you won't fall in love with anyone just because you were warned; so I am not afraid to speak openly with you. Seriously, I advise you to protect yourself. Do not enter into or try to force a relationship that would be impossible due to lack of money. I have nothing against him; he is a very interesting young man; if he had the fortune he deserved, I would say you couldn't do better. But in his current state, you must not let yourself get carried away by dreams. You have common sense, and we all want to see you use it. Your father trusts your decisions and actions, I am sure. You must not disappoint your father."
es: ––You are a girl too sensible, Lizzy, to fall in love just because you were warned not to; and for that reason, I dare to speak to you openly. Seriously, be careful. Do not commit yourself, nor let him get involved in an affection that the lack of fortune can turn into imprudence. I have nothing to say against him; he is a very interesting young man, and if he had the position he should have, he would seem unbeatable to me. But as things stand, you cannot blind yourself. You have a lot of sense, and we all expect you to use it. Your father trusts in your firmness and good conduct. Do not disappoint him.

en: “My dear aunt, this is being serious indeed.”
vi: - Auntie, what you said is really serious.
tr: "My dear sister-in-law, this matter is getting very serious.""
es: ––Dear aunt, this is really serious.

en: “Yes, and I hope to engage you to be serious likewise.”
vi: - That's right, and I hope you will be that serious.
tr: "Yes, and I invite you to be serious in the same way."
es: ––Yes, and I hope you take it seriously too.

en: “Well, then, you need not be under any alarm. I will take care of myself, and of Mr. Wickham too. He shall not be in love with me, if I can prevent it.”
vi: - In that case, you shouldn't worry. I know how to take care of myself, and of Mr. Wickham too. He wouldn't love me if I could prevent it.
tr: "Well then; there's no need for you to worry. I will take care of myself, and of course, Mr. Wickham too. He will not fall in love with me, if I can help it."
es: ––Well, don't be alarmed. I will take care of Wickham. If I can avoid it, he will not fall in love with me.

en: “Elizabeth, you are not serious now.”
vi: - Elizabeth, now you are being unserious.
tr: "Elizabeth, you are not serious right now.""
es: ––Elizabeth, you can't be serious.

en: “I beg your pardon. I will try again. At present I am not in love with Mr. Wickham; no, I certainly am not. But he is, beyond all comparison, the most agreeable man I ever saw—and if he becomes really attached to me—I believe it will be better that he should not. I see the imprudence of it. Oh, that abominable Mr. Darcy! My father’s opinion of me does me the greatest honour; and I should be miserable to forfeit it. My father, however, is partial to Mr. Wickham. In short, my dear aunt, I should be very sorry to be the means of making any of you unhappy; but since we see, every day, that where there is affection young people are seldom withheld, by immediate want of fortune, from entering into engagements with each other, how can I promise to be wiser than so many of my fellow-creatures, if I am tempted, or how am I even to know that it would be wiser to resist? All that I can promise you, therefore, is not to be in a hurry. I will not be in a hurry to believe myself his first object. When I am in company with him, I will not be wishing. In short, I will do my best.”
vi: - I'm sorry, aunt. Let me clarify further. Right now, I don't love Mr. Wickham, I truly don't. But in every respect, he is the most charming person I have ever met, and if he sincerely loves me, I believe it would be better if he didn't. I feel the need to be cautious. Oh dear! That dreadful Mr. Darcy! My father's opinion of me has given me a great honor, so I would be distressed to lose this honor. However, my father is not fair to Mr. Wickham. In short, dear aunt, I would be very sorry to make my loved ones unhappy, but as we see every day, when it comes to matters of love, young people rarely lack material desires, how can I promise to be much wiser than many friends if I am tempted, or how can I know that I must be wise to restrain myself? Therefore, I can only promise not to be hasty. I will not hastily believe in his initial intentions. When I meet him, I will not have any expectations. In short, I will do everything possible.
tr: "Excuse me; I will try again. At present, I am not in love with Mr. Wickham; no, not at all. But he is the most charming man I have ever seen – if he truly attaches himself to me – I think it would be better if he did not. I can see the impossibility of it. –Oh! that scoundrel Mr. Darcy! – My father's opinion of me honors me; if I lose it, I would be devastated. My father, meanwhile, likes Mr. Wickham. In short, my dear aunt, I am very sorry to have made you unhappy; but we see every day that when there is love, young people get engaged without worrying about money; in this situation, how can I promise to be wiser than so many of my peers when I am about to be tempted, or even know that it would be wise to resist? Therefore, all I can promise you is not to rush. I will not be in a hurry to believe that I am his first choice. I will not be eager when I am with him. In short, I will do my best."
es: ––Forgive me. I will try again. For now, I am not in love with Wickham; it's true, I am not. But he is, without comparison, the most pleasant man I have ever seen; so much so, that I wouldn't mind if he felt attracted to me. I know it is imprudent. Oh, that abominable Darcy! The opinion my father has of me honors me; and it would grieve me greatly to lose it. However, my father is a supporter of Mr. Wickham. In short, dear aunt, I would be very sorry to make any of you suffer; but when we see daily that young people, if they are in love, usually disregard the lack of fortune when committing, how could I promise to be wiser than so many of my peers if I found myself tempted? Or how would I know that I would act wisely if I resist? So the only thing I can promise you is that I will not rush. I will not hasten to believe that I am the woman of his dreams. When I am by his side, I will not show him that I like him. In other words, I will behave as best as I can.

en: “Perhaps it will be as well if you discourage his coming here so very often. At least you should not remind your mother of inviting him.”
vi: - It might also be a good idea if you advise him not to come here often. At the very least, you shouldn't remind your mother to invite him.
tr: "Maybe you can also prevent him from coming here so often. At least you won't remind your mother to invite him."
es: ––Maybe you would achieve it, if you try to make sure he doesn't come here so often. At the very least, you shouldn't remind your mother to invite him.

en: “As I did the other day,” said Elizabeth, with a conscious smile; “very true, it will be wise in me to refrain from that. But do not imagine that he is always here so often. It is on your account that he has been so frequently invited this week. You know my mother’s ideas as to the necessity of constant company for her friends. But really, and upon my honour, I will try to do what I think to be wisest; and now I hope you are satisfied.”
vi: Elizabeth gave a conscious smile. - As I reminded you that day. That's right, you should be wise and not do this. But you shouldn't think he always comes here. You noticed that this week he has often been invited. You know, my mother's idea is to always have her loved ones close by. But honestly, I swear on my honor that I will try to do what I believe is the wisest. And now, I think you are reassured.
tr: "Like I did the other day," said Elizabeth with a meaningful smile: "very true, I should give it up." But don't think it happens that often. This week, thanks to you, I've been invited so frequently. You know my mother always wants company. But really, I give you my word, I will do what seems most sensible to me; now I hope you are satisfied.""
es: ––As I did the other day ––replied Elizabeth with a malicious smile––. It's true, it would be the most appropriate. But don't go imagining that he comes so often. If we've invited him so much this week, it's because you were here. You know my mother's obsession with having her guests constantly accompanied. But truly, I give you my word that I will always try to do what I believe is most sensible. I hope you are happier now.

en: Her aunt assured her that she was; and Elizabeth, having thanked her for the kindness of her hints, they parted,—a wonderful instance of advice being given on such a point without being resented.
vi: Aunt reassured her niece that she was satisfied, and Elizabeth thanked her for her kind advice. The two parted ways, after a situation where advice was accepted without causing offense..
tr: Her sister-in-law said she was satisfied, and after Elizabeth thanked her for her courtesy in the warnings, they parted ways; an unusual example of giving advice on such a matter without causing offense.
es: Her aunt assured her that she was; Elizabeth thanked her for her kind warnings, and they left. Their conversation had been an admirable example of how to give advice without causing resentment.

en: Mr. Collins returned into Hertfordshire soon after it had been quitted by the Gardiners and Jane; but, as he took up his abode with the Lucases, his arrival was no great inconvenience to Mrs. Bennet. His marriage was now fast approaching; and she was at length so far resigned as to think it inevitable, and even repeatedly to say, in an ill-natured tone, that she “wished they might be happy.” Thursday was to be the wedding-day, and on Wednesday Miss Lucas paid her farewell visit; and when she rose to take leave, Elizabeth, ashamed of her mother’s ungracious and reluctant good wishes, and sincerely affected herself, accompanied her out of the room. As they went down stairs together, Charlotte said,—
vi: Mr. Collins returned to Hertfordshire shortly after Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner and Jane left, but since he stayed at the Lucas house, his presence did not bother Mrs. Bennet much. His marriage was being hastily arranged, and in the end, she had to accept the inevitable, even though she often said in a displeased tone that she "hoped the two could be happy." The wedding was to be held on Thursday, and on Wednesday Miss Lucas came to say goodbye. As she stood up to leave, embarrassed by her mother's reluctant well-wishes, Elizabeth escorted her out of the room. As the two walked down the stairs, Charlotte said:
tr: Right after Jane left with the Gardiners, Mr. Collins returned to Hertfordshire; but since he stayed with the Lucases, his arrival did not cause much inconvenience for Mrs. Bennet. His marriage was now rapidly approaching; Mrs. Bennet had finally been forced to accept that this matter was inevitable, and even repeatedly said, in a malicious tone, "I hope they can be happy." The wedding was to be on Thursday; on Wednesday, Miss Lucas came for a farewell visit; when she rose to leave, Elizabeth, embarrassed by her mother's sour-faced, reluctant good wishes and sincerely moved on her own behalf, accompanied her out of the room. As they descended the stairs together, Charlotte said–
es: Shortly after the Gardiners and Jane had left, Collins returned to Hertfordshire; but since he went to the Lucas house, Mrs. Bennet was not bothered by his arrival. The wedding was approaching, and Mrs. Bennet had resigned herself so much that she already considered it inevitable and even repeated, albeit in a bad mood, that she wished them to be happy. The wedding was to be held on Thursday, and on Wednesday Miss Lucas came to make her farewell visit. When the young woman got up to leave, Elizabeth, sincerely moved and embarrassed by her mother's inattentive attitude and feigned good wishes, left the room with her and accompanied her to the door. As they were going down the stairs, Charlotte said:

en: “I shall depend on hearing from you very often, Eliza.”
vi: - Eliza, I hope you will keep in touch with me often.
tr: "I believe I will hear from you often, Eliza."
es: ––I trust that I will hear from you very often, Eliza.

en: “That you certainly shall.”
vi: - This is definitely doable.
tr: "Of course you will get it.""
es: ––You will have them.

en: “And I have another favour to ask. Will you come and see me?”
vi: - And she also asked for another job. Can you come visit her?
tr: "I have one more request. Would you come and see me?"
es: ––And I want to ask you another favor. Will you come to see me?

en: “We shall often meet, I hope, in Hertfordshire.”
vi: - I think we will often meet each other, in Hertfordshire.
tr: "I hope we often meet in Hertfordshire.""
es: ––We will see each other often in Hertfordshire, I hope.

en: “I am not likely to leave Kent for some time. Promise me, therefore, to come to Hunsford.”
vi: - It is possible that for a while, I will not leave Kent. Therefore, please promise to visit me in Hunsford.
tr: "It doesn't seem possible for me to leave Kent for a while. So promise to come to Hunsford."
es: ––It seems to me that I won't be able to leave Kent for a while. Therefore, promise me to come to Hunsford.

en: Elizabeth could not refuse, though she foresaw little pleasure in the visit.
vi: Elizabeth could not refuse, although she foresaw no pleasure in the visit.
tr: Elizabeth did not like the idea of the visit, but she could not say no.
es: Despite how little she liked the visit, Elizabeth could not refuse Charlotte's invitation.

en: “My father and Maria are to come to me in March,” added Charlotte, “and I hope you will consent to be of the party. Indeed, Eliza, you will be as welcome to me as either of them.”
vi: Charlotte added: - Your father and Maria will visit you in March, at that time I hope you will agree to go with them. Eliza, in fact, I wish to welcome you just as much as I look forward to seeing those two again.
tr: "My father and Maria will come to visit me in March," added Charlotte, "I hope you will join them as well. Honestly, Eliza, your arrival would make me as happy as theirs."
es: ––My father and María will come to see me in March ––––added Charlotte–– and I would like you to accompany them. I assure you, Eliza, that you will be as well received as they are.

en: The wedding took place: the bride and bridegroom set off for Kent from the church door, and everybody had as much to say or to hear on the subject as usual. Elizabeth soon heard from her friend, and their correspondence was as regular and frequent as it ever had been: that it should be equally unreserved was impossible. Elizabeth could never address her without feeling that all the comfort of intimacy was over; and, though determined not to slacken as a correspondent, it was for the sake of what had been rather than what was. Charlotte’s first letters were received with a good deal of eagerness: there could not but be curiosity to know how she would speak of her new home, how she would like Lady Catherine, and how happy she would dare pronounce herself to be; though, when the letters were read, Elizabeth felt that Charlotte expressed herself on every point exactly as she might have foreseen. She wrote cheerfully, seemed surrounded with comforts, and mentioned nothing which she could not praise. The house, furniture, neighbourhood, and roads, were all to her taste, and Lady Catherine’s behaviour was most friendly and obliging. It was Mr. Collins’s picture of Hunsford and Rosings rationally softened; and Elizabeth perceived that she must wait for her own visit there, to know the rest.
vi: The wedding ceremony was held. The bride and groom left the church to go to Kent, and everyone had something to say or listen to as usual. Soon, Elizabeth received news from her friend, the two still corresponded regularly as before. Every time she wrote to her, Elizabeth couldn't help but think that the comfortable friendliness was gone. Although she still wanted to keep in touch, it was because of their past rather than the present. She eagerly received Charlotte's first letters. Of course, there was the curious thought of wanting to know how she spoke about her new home, how she liked Lady Catherine, how she confidently claimed to be happy, even though Elizabeth felt Charlotte described everything exactly as Elizabeth had predicted. Charlotte's words in the letters were cheerful, seemingly wrapped in comfort, without touching on things she couldn't praise. The house, the interior, the neighbors, the roads, all were to her liking, and Lady Catherine was very friendly and accommodating. This was Mr. Collins' image of Hunsford and Rosings toned down to some extent, and Elizabeth felt she would have to wait until she visited them to know the other details.
tr: The marriage was solemnized: the bride and groom left the church and set off towards Kent; as always, there was much to tell or listen to about the event. Elizabeth soon received news from her friend; they were corresponding as frequently and regularly as before, but it was impossible for it to be as intimate. Elizabeth couldn't write to her without feeling that all sense of closeness had ended, and although she was determined not to neglect writing letters, she was writing them for the sake of past things, not present ones. Charlotte's first letters were received with considerable excitement; there was natural curiosity about how she would describe her new home, whether she liked Lady Catherine, and if she was happy; however, when the letters were read, Elizabeth felt that Charlotte expressed herself exactly as she had expected in every way. She wrote cheerfully, seemed comfortable, and mentioned nothing that she couldn't praise. The house, the furniture, the neighborhood, the roads, all were to her liking, and Lady Catherine's demeanor was extremely friendly and kind. The picture Mr. Collins painted of Hunsford and Rosings was only smartly softened; Elizabeth realized she would have to wait for her own visit to learn the rest.
es: The wedding took place; the groom and the bride departed for Kent from the church door, and everyone had some comment to make or hear on the matter, as usual. Elizabeth soon received a letter from her friend, and their correspondence was as regular and frequent as ever. But no longer as frank. It was impossible for Elizabeth to address Charlotte without noticing that all her former confidence had disappeared, and although she did not want to interrupt the correspondence, she did so more for what their friendship had been than for what it actually was now. Charlotte’s first letters were received with much impatience; she was very curious to see what she would say about her new home, to know if she would have liked Lady Catherine and to what extent she would dare to confess that she was happy. But upon reading those letters, Elizabeth observed that Charlotte expressed herself exactly as she had anticipated. She wrote cheerfully, seemed to be surrounded by comforts, and did not mention anything that was not worthy of praise. The house, the furniture, the neighborhood, and the roads, everything was to her liking, and Lady Catherine could not be more sociable and attentive. It was the same portrait of Hunsford and Rosings that Mr. Collins had made, although reasonably mitigated. Elizabeth understood that she would have to wait for her own visit to learn the rest.

en: Jane had already written a few lines to her sister, to announce their safe arrival in London; and when she wrote again, Elizabeth hoped it would be in her power to say something of the Bingleys.
vi: Jane wrote a few lines to inform that she had arrived in London safely. Elizabeth hoped that her sister's next letter would tell something about the Bingley household.
tr: Jane had already informed her sister with a few lines that they had arrived safely in London; she believed that when she wrote again, she would be able to say something about the Bingleys.
es: Jane had already sent a few lines to her sister announcing her happy arrival in London; and when she wrote to her again, Elizabeth hoped that she would be able to tell her something about the Bingleys.

en: Her impatience for this second letter was as well rewarded as impatience generally is. Jane had been a week in town, without either seeing or hearing from Caroline. She accounted for it, however, by supposing that her last letter to her friend from Longbourn had by some accident been lost.
vi: Jane's impatience for the second letter was compensated, as she had been living in the city for a week without seeing or hearing from Caroline. However, she explained that the last letter to her friend might have been lost.
tr: His impatience for this second letter, like every impatience, received its reward. Jane had been in the city for a week and had neither seen Caroline nor heard from her. But she attributed this to the possibility that the last letter she wrote to her friend from Longbourn had been accidentally lost.
es: Her impatience for this second letter received the usual reward for all impatience: Jane had been in the capital for a week without having seen or heard anything from Caroline. However, she explained it by assuming that the last letter she sent to her friend from Longbourn must have been lost.

en: “My aunt,” she continued, “is going to-morrow into that part of the town, and I shall take the opportunity of calling in Grosvenor Street.”
vi: She continued writing that her aunt would be going to the area they were residing in the next day, and she would have the opportunity to visit Grosvenor Street.
tr: "My sister-in-law," he continued, "is going to that part of the city tomorrow; I will also have the opportunity to stop by Grosvenor Street."
es: “My aunt,” he continued, “will go to that part of the city tomorrow, and I will have the opportunity to visit Caroline on Grosvenor Street.”

en: She wrote again when the visit was paid, and she had seen Miss Bingley. “I did not think Caroline in spirits,” were her words, “but she was very glad to see me, and reproached me for giving her no notice of my coming to London. I was right, therefore; my last letter had never reached her. I inquired after their brother, of course. He was well, but so much engaged with Mr. Darcy that they scarcely ever saw him. I found that Miss Darcy was expected to dinner: I wish I could see her. My visit was not long, as Caroline and Mrs. Hurst were going out. I dare say I shall soon see them here.”
vi: She wrote the letter after the visit. “I didn't think Caroline was a sentimental person, but she was very happy to see me again and scolded me for not letting her know sooner that I had arrived in London. Therefore, I guessed correctly that my recent letter did not reach her. Of course, I inquired about her brother. He is still the same, but very busy with Mr. Darcy, so they rarely see him. I saw that they were waiting for Miss Darcy to have dinner. I hope to meet her. I couldn't stay long because Caroline and Mrs. Hurst were about to go out. I believe it won't be long before I see them here again.”
tr: After the visit, he wrote again; he had seen Miss Bingley. "I found Caroline unwell," he wrote, "but she was very happy to see me; she was upset that I hadn't informed her of my arrival in London. So I was right; my last letter did not reach her. Of course, I asked about her siblings. They are well, but she is so occupied with Mr. Darcy that they rarely see her. I learned that Miss Darcy is expected for dinner. I wish I could see her. I couldn't stay long; Caroline and Mrs. Hurst were about to go out. I think I will see them here soon."
es: After the mentioned visit, in which she saw Miss Bingley, Jane wrote again: "Caroline was not in a good mood, but she was very happy to see me and reproached me for not notifying her of my arrival in London. Therefore, I was right: she had not received my letter. Naturally, I asked her about her brother. She told me he was well, but that he is so busy with Mr. Darcy that she barely sees him. They were expecting Miss Darcy for lunch by chance; I would like to see her. My visit was not long, as Caroline and Mrs. Hurst had to go out. I suppose they will come to see me soon."

en: Elizabeth shook her head over this letter. It convinced her that accident only could discover to Mr. Bingley her sister’s being in town.
vi: Elizabeth shook her head as she read the letter. It convinced her that only a chance opportunity could let Mr. Bingley know that her sister was currently in the city.
tr: Elizabeth read the letter, shaking her head. So, Mr. Bingley could only have learned that his sister was in town by chance.
es: Elizabeth shook her head as she read the letter. She saw clearly that only by chance could Bingley discover that Jane was in London.

en: Four weeks passed away, and Jane saw nothing of him. She endeavoured to persuade herself that she did not regret it; but she could no longer be blind to Miss Bingley’s inattention. After waiting at home every morning for a fortnight, and inventing every evening a fresh excuse for her, the visitor did at last appear; but the shortness of her stay, and, yet more, the alteration of her manner, would allow Jane to deceive herself no longer. The letter which she wrote on this occasion to her sister will prove what she felt:—
vi: Four weeks passed, Jane did not see him at all. She told herself she had nothing to be upset about regarding this, but she couldn't help but notice Miss Bingley's indifference. After expecting every morning for two weeks, and every evening thinking of all sorts of reasons to excuse her friend, she finally came. But the brief visit and, moreover, her friend's changed attitude, made it impossible for Jane to deceive herself any longer. She wrote to Elizabeth about this:
tr: Four weeks passed and Jane did not see Mr. Bingley. She tried to convince herself that she was not upset about this; but she could no longer ignore Miss Bingley's indifference. After waiting at home every morning for fifteen days, and making excuses for him every evening, the visitor finally appeared; but his short stay, moreover the change in his demeanor, did not allow Jane to deceive herself any longer. The letter she wrote to her sister about this will show how she felt.
es: Four weeks passed without Jane knowing anything about him. She tried to convince herself that she did not regret it; but what she could no longer be blind to was Miss Bingley's indifference. After waiting for her at home every morning for fifteen days and inventing an excuse for her every afternoon, she finally received her visit; but the brevity of it and, moreover, her strange attitude did not allow Jane to continue deceiving herself. The letter she then wrote to her sister demonstrated what she felt:

en: “My dearest Lizzy will, I am sure, be incapable of triumphing in her better judgment, at my expense, when I confess myself to have been entirely deceived in Miss Bingley’s regard for me. But, my dear sister, though the event has proved you right, do not think me obstinate if I still assert that, considering what her behaviour was, my confidence was as natural as your suspicion. I do not at all comprehend her reason for wishing to be intimate with me; but, if the same circumstances were to happen again, I am sure I should be deceived again. Caroline did not return my visit till yesterday; and not a note, not a line, did I receive in the meantime. When she did come, it was very evident that she had no pleasure in it; she made a slight, formal apology for not calling before, said not a word of wishing to see me again, and was, in every respect, so altered a creature, that when she went away I was perfectly resolved to continue the acquaintance no longer. I pity, though I cannot help blaming, her. She was very wrong in singling me out as she did; I can safely say, that every advance to intimacy began on her side. But I pity her, because she must feel that she has been acting wrong, and because I am very sure that anxiety for her brother is the cause of it. I need not explain myself farther; and though we know this anxiety to be quite needless, yet if she feels it, it will easily account for her behaviour to me; and so deservedly dear as he is to his sister, whatever anxiety she may feel on his behalf is natural and amiable. I cannot but wonder, however, at her having any such fears now, because if he had at all cared about me, we must have met long, long ago. He knows of my being in town, I am certain, from something she said herself; and yet it would seem, by her manner of talking, as if she wanted to persuade herself that he is really partial to Miss Darcy. I cannot understand it. If I were not afraid of judging harshly, I should be almost tempted to say, that there is a strong appearance of duplicity in all this. I will endeavour to banish every painful thought, and think only of what will make me happy, your affection, and the invariable kindness of my dear uncle and aunt. Let me hear from you very soon. Miss Bingley said something of his never returning to Netherfield again, of giving up the house, but not with any certainty. We had better not mention it. I am extremely glad that you have such pleasant accounts from our friends at Hunsford. Pray go to see them, with Sir William and Maria. I am sure you will be very comfortable there.
vi: “My dear Lizzy, you must be proud of having outshone me in judgment, as I admit I was completely deceived by Miss Bingley. But, my dear, although the event proves you right, do not think me stubborn if I say that my trust in him was as natural as your suspicion. I do not understand her reasons for being so friendly with me, but if similar situations arise, I am sure I will be deceived again. It was only yesterday that Caroline visited me in return, and she had not written a single word to me before that. When she came, it was clear she took no pleasure in the visit. She offered a superficial, solemn apology for not visiting sooner, without expressing any desire to see me again. Her demeanor had changed so completely that when she left, I resolved not to continue the acquaintance. I pity her, though I cannot help but blame her. She was entirely mistaken in targeting me. I can rightly say that all the beginnings of our acquaintance were initiated by her. But I pity her, for she must realize she was wrong, and I am convinced that the reason for this is her concern for her brother. I need not explain further; although we all know there is no need for such anxiety, if she is worried, it easily explains her attitude towards me. Any concern for her brother is natural and endearing, as he deserves such care from his sister. However, she still worried about her fear, because if he still cared about her, he could have met her many days ago. From her sister's words, she was certain that he knew she was currently residing in the city. Yet, from the way she talked, it seemed he truly leaned towards Miss Darcy. She couldn't understand this. If she didn't fear being judged harshly, she could clearly say there was an ambivalent attitude in everything. But she would try to dispel all sorrowful thoughts, only thinking about things that made her happy, about her sister's love, about the kindness of their uncle and aunt. Write to me soon. Miss Bingley mentioned something about him never returning to Netherfield, about giving up the house, but it is not certain. It is better not to mention this matter. I am very glad to know that you are on good terms with our friends at Hunsford. Go visit them, with Sir William and Maria. I believe you will feel comfortable there.
tr: "I am sure, my dear Lizzy, that Miss Bingley will not derive any pleasure from being proven right in her judgments against me when I admit to myself that I was entirely mistaken about her regard for me. But, my dear sister, although events have proven you right, I hope you do not think me stubborn if I continue to say that, considering Miss Bingley's behavior, my confidence was as natural as your doubt. I cannot understand why she wanted to be close to me; but if the same things were to happen again, I am sure I would be deceived once more. Caroline only returned my visit yesterday; during the intervening time, I received neither a note nor a single line from her. When she did come, it was clear she did not enjoy it; she made a light, formal apology for not having called earlier, said nothing about wanting to see me again, and in every way was so changed that I resolved not to continue our acquaintance after she left. I pity her, but I cannot help blaming her. She made a great mistake in singling me out; I can safely say that all the advances came from her. But I pity her, because she must feel she has acted wrongly, and I am sure it is her concern for her brother that is the cause. I need not explain myself further; we know that this concern is entirely unnecessary, but if she is worried, it easily explains her behavior towards me; since she is justly so fond of her brother, any concern on his behalf is natural and reasonable. However, I cannot help being surprised that she should feel such fears now, because if Mr. Bingley cared about me, we would have met a very, very long time ago. He knows I am in town, I gathered that from something Miss Bingley said; yet it was evident from the way she spoke that she wanted to convince herself that Mr. Bingley really admired Miss Darcy. I cannot understand it. If I were not afraid of making a harsh judgment, I would say there is a strong appearance of duplicity in all this. But I will try to keep every painful thought at bay and think only of what will make me happy, your love, the unfailing kindness of my dear uncle and aunt. I wish to hear from you as soon as possible. Miss Bingley said something about not returning to Netherfield and leaving the house, but she was not definite. It is best not to speak of it. I am very glad to hear that you have received pleasant news from our friends at Hunsford. Please go and see them, with Sir William and Maria. I am sure you will be very comfortable there.
es: I am sure, my dearest Lizzy, that you will be unable to boast at my expense about your good judgment when I confess that I have been completely disillusioned with Miss Bingley's affection. Anyway, although the facts have proven you right, do not think me obstinate if I still assert that, given her behavior towards me, my trust was as natural as your suspicions. Despite everything, I cannot understand why she wanted to be my friend; but if things were to happen again, I have no doubt that I would be deceived once more. Caroline did not return my visit until yesterday, and in the meantime, I did not receive a single note or line from her. When she came, it was quite clear that it was against her will; she gave a slight, merely formal excuse for not having come earlier; she did not say a word about when we would see each other again and was so upset that, when she left, I firmly decided to put an end to our relationship. I feel sorry, although I cannot help but blame her. She was wrong to choose me as a friend. But I can safely say that it was she who took the first step to become close to me. Anyway, I pity her because she must understand that she has behaved very badly, and because I am sure that her concern for her brother was the cause of everything. And although we know that this concern is unnecessary, the fact of feeling it justifies her attitude towards me, and since he fully deserves his sister's adoration, all the anxiety he inspires in her is natural and appreciable. But I cannot help but wonder why she continues to have these fears, for if he had been interested in me, we would have seen each other a long time ago. He knows that I am in the city; I deduce this from something she herself said; and still, it seemed, by her way of speaking, that she needed to convince herself that Bingley is really interested in Miss Darcy. I do not understand it. If I did not fear judging harshly, I would almost say that there is more to this than meets the eye. But I will try to dispel all these painful thoughts and think only of what makes me happy: your affection and the unalterable kindness of our dear uncles. Write to me soon. Miss Bingley spoke of never returning to Netherfield and of getting rid of the house, but not with much certainty. It is better not to mention these things. I am very glad that you have had such good news from our friends in Hunsford. Please go to see them with Sir William and Maria. I am sure you will be well there.

en: “Yours, etc.”
vi: My older sister
tr: –With love."
es: Yours,

en: This letter gave Elizabeth some pain; but her spirits returned, as she considered that Jane would no longer be duped, by the sister at least. All expectation from the brother was now absolutely over. She would not even wish for any renewal of his attentions. His character sunk on every review of it; and, as a punishment for him, as well as a possible advantage to Jane, she seriously hoped he might really soon marry Mr. Darcy’s sister, as, by Wickham’s account, she would make him abundantly regret what he had thrown away.
vi: Elizabeth felt somewhat pained when reading the letter, but she calmed herself with the thought that Jane would no longer be deceived, at least by the sister. All expectations from the brother had completely vanished. She did not even hope to rekindle his affections. His character had diminished in every respect. She sincerely hoped he would marry Miss Darcy, as a punishment for him and a benefit for Jane, because according to Mr. Wickham, she would make him deeply regret what he had thrown away.
tr: This letter upset Elizabeth a little; but at least she felt better thinking that Jane could no longer be deceived by that sister. Expectations regarding the brother were now definitely over. She didn't even want his interest to revive. With every examination, his character became a little more unpleasant; punishing him and giving Jane a possible advantage, she seriously hoped that he would soon truly marry Mr. Darcy's sister, because according to Wickham, the girl was the kind who would make him regret the things he had thrown away a thousand times over.
es: Jane Elizabeth felt a bit sorry about this letter, but she regained her spirits by thinking that at least she would no longer be fooled by Miss Bingley. All hope regarding the brother had completely vanished. She didn't even wish for their relationship to be renewed. Every time she thought of him, his character disappointed her more. And as a punishment for him and for Jane's benefit, Elizabeth wished he would marry Mr. Darcy's sister as soon as possible, for, according to what Wickham said, she would make him regret greatly what he had scorned.

en: Mrs. Gardiner about this time reminded Elizabeth of her promise concerning that gentleman, and required information; and Elizabeth had such to send as might rather give contentment to her aunt than to herself. His apparent partiality had subsided, his attentions were over, he was the admirer of some one else. Elizabeth was watchful enough to see it all, but she could see it and write of it without material pain. Her heart had been but slightly touched, and her vanity was satisfied with believing that she would have been his only choice, had fortune permitted it. The sudden acquisition of ten thousand pounds was the most remarkable charm of the young lady to whom he was now rendering himself agreeable; but Elizabeth, less clear-sighted perhaps in this case than in Charlotte’s, did not quarrel with him for his wish of independence. Nothing, on the contrary, could be more natural; and, while able to suppose that it cost him a few struggles to relinquish her, she was ready to allow it a wise and desirable measure for both, and could very sincerely wish him happy.
vi: Around this time, Mrs. Gardiner reminded Elizabeth of her promise to interact with that young man, and inquired about the news. Elizabeth had to comply to put her aunt at ease. He no longer paid exclusive attention to her; his attentions were gone, he was fond of someone else. Elizabeth observed carefully so she knew everything, but she could look and write about it without feeling sorrow. Her heart had only slightly fluttered; her vanity was satisfied with the thought that she could have been his only choice, if circumstances had allowed. The fact that he unexpectedly received ten thousand pounds was the most attractive thing about the girl he was pursuing. But Elizabeth, perhaps in this case not as farsighted as Charlotte, did not argue with him about his desire for independence. On the contrary, nothing could be more natural. While guessing that he had to go through some mental struggle to part from her, she was ready to wish him happiness.
tr: Around the same days, Mrs. Gardiner reminded Elizabeth of her promise regarding that gentleman and asked for information; Elizabeth had such information that would please her aunt more than herself. Wickham's evident admiration had passed, his interest had ended; he was now infatuated with someone else. Elizabeth was perceptive enough to see it all, but she could see and write about it without feeling significant pain. She wasn't very hurt; her pride was satisfied when she believed that she would be his only choice if his financial situation allowed it. The most striking charm of the young lady he was now trying to impress was that she had suddenly come into possession of ten thousand pounds; but perhaps because Elizabeth, who showed more understanding to Wickham than she did to Charlotte, wanted to be free, she did not quarrel with him. On the contrary, nothing could be more natural; while she guessed that Wickham had to struggle a bit to leave her, she was ready to accept that it was a wise and suitable solution for both of them and sincerely wished him happiness.
es: Meanwhile, Mrs. Gardiner reminded Elizabeth of her promise regarding Wickham and wanted to know how things were going. Elizabeth's news was more favorable for her aunt than for herself. Wickham's apparent interest had disappeared, as had his attentions. Now it was another whom he admired. Elizabeth was observant enough to notice everything, but she saw it and wrote about it without much sorrow. It had not made much of an impression on her heart, and her vanity was satisfied with believing that she would have been his favorite if her fortune had allowed it. The sudden acquisition of ten thousand pounds was the most notable charm of the young woman to whom Wickham now paid his attention. But Elizabeth, perhaps less perceptive in this case than in Charlotte's, did not blame him for his desire for independence. On the contrary, it seemed the most natural thing in the world to her, and as she presumed it cost him some effort to give her up, she was willing to consider it the wisest and most desirable measure for both, and could sincerely wish him much happiness.

en: All this was acknowledged to Mrs. Gardiner; and, after relating the circumstances, she thus went on:—“I am now convinced, my dear aunt, that I have never been much in love; for had I really experienced that pure and elevating passion, I should at present detest his very name, and wish him all manner of evil. But my feelings are not only cordial towards him, they are even impartial towards Miss King. I cannot find out that I hate her at all, or that I am in the least unwilling to think her a very good sort of girl. There can be no love in all this. My watchfulness has been effectual; and though I should certainly be a more interesting object to all my acquaintance, were I distractedly in love with him, I cannot say that I regret my comparative insignificance. Importance may sometimes be purchased too dearly. Kitty and Lydia take his defection much more to heart than I do. They are young in the ways of the world, and not yet open to the mortifying conviction that handsome young men must have something to live on as well as the plain.”
vi: She explained everything to Mrs. Gardiner, and continued: “Dear aunt, now I am sure that I have never been in love, because if I had truly experienced that pure and noble feeling, I would now detest even his name and wish all sorts of ill upon him. But my feelings towards him are not only kind but also indifferent towards Miss King. I do not hate her at all, and I am willing to acknowledge that she is a good example of a fine young lady. There could not have been any love in this matter. My vigilance has paid off. Although I would certainly become the subject of everyone's attention if I foolishly fell in love with him, I do not regret becoming unimportant. Sometimes one can pay a high price to become important. Kitty and Lydia are more concerned than I am about his distancing himself from me. They are still young, not yet ready to accept the embarrassing reality that handsome young men must have something to rely on to live.”
tr: All this was told to Mrs. Gardiner; after recounting the events, Elizabeth continued: – "Now I believe, my dear aunt, that I was not too much in love; for if I had experienced that pure and intoxicating passion, I would now be cursing his name and wishing him ill. But I have good feelings towards him, and I am indifferent to Miss King. I don't even feel like hating him or refusing to think that she is a very good girl. There can be no love in all this. Being alert has helped me; if I were madly in love with him, I would certainly be a more interesting person to all my acquaintances, but I can't say that I regret my relative insignificance. Importance can sometimes be bought at a very high price. Kitty and Lydia are much more troubled by this betrayal than I am. They are still young in the ways of the world; they are not yet open to believing that handsome young men can be as concerned with making a living as ordinary men."
es: She communicated all this to Mrs. Gardiner; and after recounting all the details, she added: "I am convinced, dear aunt, that I have never been truly in love, for if I had really felt that pure and elevated passion of love, I would detest even his name and wish him the greatest misfortunes. But not only do I still appreciate him, I do not feel any aversion towards Miss King. I do not hate her, I do not want to believe she is a bad girl. This cannot be love. My precautions have been effective; and although my friends would worry much more about me if I were madly in love with him, I cannot say that I regret my relative insignificance. Importance is sometimes paid for too dearly. Kitty and Lydia take Wickham's betrayal more to heart than I do. They are still too young to see the reality of the world and to acquire the humiliating conviction that handsome men must have something to live on, just like the ugly ones."

en: CHAPTER XXVII.
vi: Chapter 27
tr: Chapter IV
es: CHAPTER XXVII/h3>

en: WITH no greater events than these in the Longbourn family, and otherwise diversified by little beyond the walks to Meryton, sometimes dirty and sometimes cold, did January and February pass away. March was to take Elizabeth to Hunsford. She had not at first thought very seriously of going thither; but Charlotte, she soon found, was depending on the plan, and she gradually learned to consider it herself with greater pleasure as well as greater certainty. Absence had increased her desire of seeing Charlotte again, and weakened her disgust of Mr. Collins. There was novelty in the scheme; and as, with such a mother and such uncompanionable sisters, home could not be faultless, a little change was not unwelcome for its own sake. The journey would, moreover, give her a peep at Jane; and, in short, as the time drew near, she would have been very sorry for any delay. Everything, however, went on smoothly, and was finally settled according to Charlotte’s first sketch. She was to accompany Sir William and his second daughter. The improvement of spending a night in London was added in time, and the plan became as perfect as plan could be.
vi: February and March passed without any events of greater importance at Longbourn, with little variation through visits to Meryton, sometimes muddy, sometimes cold. In March, Elizabeth visited Huntsford. At first, she had no serious intention of going there, but she learned that Charlotte was eagerly awaiting her, and she gradually thought of the trip with joy and more determination. Their absence had made her eager to see Charlotte again and less resentful of Mr. Collins. There was a bit of novelty in the plan, for with such a mother and sisters who could not be close, the family setting inevitably became unpleasant, so a little change of scenery was good for her. The trip could also give her a brief insight into Jane's situation. As the day of departure approached, she would have regretted any delay. However, everything went smoothly, finally arranged according to Charlotte's outline. She would accompany Sir William and his second daughter. They decided to spend the night in London, and thus the plan became perfect.
tr: The months of January and February passed for the Longbourn family without any events of greater significance, or without much color aside from occasional walks to Meryton, sometimes in the mud, sometimes in the cold. In March, Elizabeth was to go to Hunsford. Initially, she was not very serious about going; but soon she realized that Charlotte valued the plan, and gradually she learned to think about it with both greater pleasure and greater determination. In their absence, her desire to see Charlotte again had increased, and her displeasure towards Mr. Collins had diminished. Life demanded novelty; a home with such a mother and such unbearable sisters could not be considered perfect; a small change, even for her own sake, would not be bad at all. Moreover, the journey would give her the opportunity to see Jane; in short, as the time approached, she began to worry that there might be a delay or something. But everything went smoothly and was arranged according to Charlotte's initial plan. Sir William would accompany her along with his second daughter. The plan became perfect with the addition of the idea of spending the night in London.
es: Without any significant events in the Longbourn family, and with no more variation than walks to Meryton, sometimes muddy and sometimes cold, the months of January and February passed. March was the month in which Elizabeth would go to Hunsford. At first, she did not seriously think of going. But she saw that Charlotte took it for granted, and little by little she became pleasantly accustomed to the idea until she decided to go. With the absence, her desire to see Charlotte had increased and her aversion to Collins had diminished. The project involved a certain novelty, and since with such a mother and such unbearable sisters, her home was not a very pleasant place, she could not disregard this change of scenery. The trip also provided her with the pleasure of going to give Jane a hug; so much so that when the date approached, she would have regretted having to postpone it. But everything went smoothly and the trip was carried out according to Charlotte's plans. Elizabeth would accompany Sir William and his second daughter. And to top it off, they decided to spend a night in London; the plan was so perfect that nothing more could be asked for.

en: The only pain was in leaving her father, who would certainly miss her, and who, when it came to the point, so little liked her going, that he told her to write to him, and almost promised to answer her letter.
