vi: The only thing that worried her was having to leave her father, who would surely miss her, had asked her to write letters home and almost promised to reply, even though he didn't want to see her go.
tr: Her only sorrow was parting from her father; her father would miss her very much, so when the time came, he was not very supportive of her leaving, told her to write to him, and almost promised to reply to her letter.
es: The only thing that saddened Elizabeth was parting from her father, because she knew he would miss her, and when the time came to leave, he became so sad that he asked his daughter to write to him and even promised to reply to her letter.

en: The farewell between herself and Mr. Wickham was perfectly friendly; on his side even more. His present pursuit could not make him forget that Elizabeth had been the first to excite and to deserve his attention, the first to listen and to pity, the first to be admired; and in his manner of bidding her adieu, wishing her every enjoyment, reminding her of what she was to expect in Lady Catherine de Bourgh, and trusting their opinion of her—their opinion of everybody—would always coincide, there was a solicitude, an interest, which she felt must ever attach her to him with a most sincere regard; and she parted from him convinced, that, whether married or single, he must always be her model of the amiable and pleasing.
vi: Both she and Mr. Wickham showed the utmost friendliness when they parted; even he appeared more friendly. The affection he currently pursued could not make him forget that Elizabeth had been the first to awaken feelings in him and deserved those feelings, the first to listen to him and pity him, the first to be admired by him. In the way he bid her farewell, when he wished her all happiness, reminded her of what Lady Catherine de Bourgh was like, and when he believed that their opinions of this lady – their opinions of everyone – always coincided, there was a desire, a concern that she felt must always bind her to him with the sincerest respect. Then she bid him farewell, believing that whether he was married or still single, he would always be to her the epitome of a charming person.
tr: The farewell with Mr. Wickham was quite amicable, especially from Wickham's perspective. His current objective had not allowed him to forget that Elizabeth was the first woman to catch his interest and deserve it, the first to listen and sympathize, the first to be admired; there was a closeness, an interest in his manner while saying goodbye, wishing her good times, reminding her what to expect from Lady Catherine de Bourgh, and saying that he believed they would be in agreement about her – about everyone – and because of this, Elizabeth felt she would remain forever sincerely attached to Wickham; when she parted from him, whether married or single, she believed he would always be the model of a charming and delightful man for her.
es: The farewell between Wickham and Elizabeth was very cordial, even more so on Wickham's part. Although at that moment he was occupied with other things, he could not forget that she was the first to excite and deserve his attention, the first to listen to him and sympathize with him, and the first to please him. And in his manner of saying goodbye, wishing her well, reminding her of what Lady Catherine de Bourgh seemed like to him, and repeating that his opinions about her and everyone else would always coincide, there was such solicitude and interest that Elizabeth felt filled with the most sincere affection towards him and left convinced that she would always consider Wickham, single or married, as a model of sympathy and simplicity.

en: Her fellow-travellers the next day were not of a kind to make her think him less agreeable. Sir William Lucas, and his daughter Maria, a good-humoured girl, but as empty-headed as himself, had nothing to say that could be worth hearing, and were listened to with about as much delight as the rattle of the chaise. Elizabeth loved absurdities, but she had known Sir William’s too long. He could tell her nothing new of the wonders of his presentation and knighthood; and his civilities were worn out, like his information.
vi: Her companions were not the kind of people who made her think he was less pleasant. Sir William Lucas and his daughter Maria, a cheerful girl but as empty-headed as her father, had nothing worth listening to. She listened to them with as much interest as she would to the clattering of a horse-drawn carriage. Elizabeth enjoyed hearing nonsense, but she had known Sir William for too long. He could no longer tell her anything new about his audience with the king or his knighthood, and his politeness was running thin with his repetitive stories.
tr: The passengers accompanying him the next day were not the type to make Wickham fall out of favor. Sir William Lucas and his daughter Maria, a polite but as empty-headed girl as her father, did not have anything worth listening to; listening to them was no more enjoyable than listening to the creaking of the carriage. Elizabeth liked oddities, but she had known Sir William's for too long. He could not tell her anything new about the wonders of his presentation at court and his knighthood; his polite manners, like his stories, had worn out.
es: Her travel companions for the next day were not the most suitable for Elizabeth to remember Wickham with less displeasure. Sir William and his daughter Maria, a cheerful girl but as empty-headed as her father, said nothing worth listening to; so hearing them was the same for Elizabeth as hearing the rattling of the carriage. Elizabeth was amused by the nonsense, but she had known Sir William for too long and he could tell her nothing new about the wonders of his presentation at court and his title of "Sir," and his courtesies were as stale as his news.

en: It was a journey of only twenty-four miles, and they began it so early as to be in Gracechurch Street by noon. As they drove to Mr. Gardiner’s door, Jane was at a drawing-room window watching their arrival: when they entered the passage, she was there to welcome them, and Elizabeth, looking earnestly in her face, was pleased to see it healthful and lovely as ever. On the stairs were a troop of little boys and girls, whose eagerness for their cousin’s appearance would not allow them to wait in the drawing-room, and whose shyness, as they had not seen her for a twelvemonth, prevented their coming lower. All was joy and kindness. The day passed most pleasantly away; the morning in bustle and shopping, and the evening at one of the theatres.
vi: The trip was only twenty-four miles, and the three of them set out early to reach Gracechurch Street by noon. As they entered Mrs. Gardiner's house, Jane was in the drawing-room watching them come in, and she stepped out to greet them. Elizabeth looked intently and was delighted to see that her sister was still as healthy and pretty as ever. On the stairs was a group of children, eager to meet their cousin but not allowed into the drawing-room, and too shy to approach because they hadn't seen her in twelve months. Everyone was cheerful and kind. They enjoyed each other's company all day; during the day they bustled around and went shopping, and in the evening they went to see a musical.
tr: It was a twenty-four-mile journey; they set out early and arrived at Gracechurch Street by noon. As they approached Mr. Gardiner's door, Jane was at the sitting room window, waiting for their arrival; when they entered the courtyard, she came down to greet them; Elizabeth, who looked eagerly at her face, was happy to see her looking as healthy and charming as ever. There was a group of girls and boys on the stairs; their curiosity to see their cousins had not allowed them to wait in the sitting room, and their shyness, having not seen her for twelve months, had not allowed them to come down. Everything was cheerful and sweet. Most of the day passed pleasantly; bustling and shopping in the morning, theater in the evening.
es: The journey was only twenty-four miles, and they set out so early that by noon they were already on Gracechurch Street. As they approached the Gardiners' door, Jane was at the sitting room window watching their arrival; when they entered the hall, she was already there to welcome them. Elizabeth examined her anxiously and was pleased to find her as healthy and charming as ever. On the stairs, there was a throng of boys and girls too impatient to see their cousin to wait for her in the sitting room, but their shyness kept them from fully descending and going to meet her, as it had been more than a year since they last saw her. Everything was joy and attentions. The day passed pleasantly; in the afternoon, they strolled around and visited the shops, and in the evening, they went to a theater.

en: Elizabeth then contrived to sit by her aunt. Their first subject was her sister; and she was more grieved than astonished to hear, in reply to her minute inquiries, that though Jane always struggled to support her spirits, there were periods of dejection. It was reasonable, however, to hope that they would not continue long. Mrs. Gardiner gave her the particulars also of Miss Bingley’s visit in Gracechurch Street, and repeated conversations occurring at different times between Jane and herself, which proved that the former had, from her heart, given up the acquaintance.
vi: Then Elizabeth managed to sit with her aunt. The first topic of conversation between the aunt and niece was the elder sister. Elizabeth felt more sorrow than surprise after inquiring thoroughly and hearing that Jane had periods of despondency despite always struggling mentally to lift herself up. However, there was reason to hope that this condition would not last long. Mrs. Gardiner also mentioned Miss Bingley's visit, recounting the things the two ladies discussed, showing that Jane sincerely wanted to abandon the relationship.
tr: Elizabeth made an adjustment and sat down next to her aunt. Their first topic was her sister; as detailed questions were answered, she felt more pain than surprise upon hearing that Jane always struggled to be cheerful but also went through periods of depression. Fortunately, it was possible to hope that it wouldn't last long. Mrs. Gardiner also gave her the details of Miss Bingley's visit to Gracechurch Street and repeated the details of the conversations that took place between her and Jane at different times; it was understood that Miss Bingley had ended the friendship from her own perspective.
es: Elizabeth then managed to sit next to her aunt. The first topic of conversation was Jane; after hearing the answers to the detailed questions she asked about her sister, Elizabeth was more saddened than surprised to learn that Jane, although always striving to keep her spirits high, was going through moments of great despondency. Nevertheless, it was reasonable to expect that they would not last long. Mrs. Gardiner also told her details of Miss Bingley's visit to Gracechurch, and repeated some conversations she had later with Jane that showed the latter had ended their friendship.

en: Mrs. Gardiner then rallied her niece on Wickham’s desertion, and complimented her on bearing it so well.
vi: Then Mrs. Gardiner inquired of her niece about Mr. Wickham's departure from her, praising her for enduring it very well.
tr: Mrs. Gardiner then pressed her niece about Wickham's misconduct and congratulated her for enduring it so well.
es: Mrs. Gardiner consoled her niece for Wickham's betrayal and congratulated her on how well she had taken it.

en: “But, my dear Elizabeth,” she added, “what sort of girl is Miss King? I should be sorry to think our friend mercenary.”
vi: She added: - But, Elizabeth dear, what kind of person is Miss King? You would regret it if you thought she was opportunistic.
tr: "But, dear Elizabeth," he added, "what kind of girl is Miss King? It is sad to think that our friend is a gold-digger."
es: ––But tell me, dear Elizabeth ––he added––, what kind of girl is Miss King? I would be very sorry to think that our friend is a fortune hunter.

en: “Pray, my dear aunt, what is the difference in matrimonial affairs, between the mercenary and the prudent motive? Where does discretion end, and avarice begin? Last Christmas you were afraid of his marrying me, because it would be imprudent; and now, because he is trying to get a girl with only ten thousand pounds, you want to find out that he is mercenary.”
vi: - Aunt, could you please explain the difference between opportunism and prudence in matters of marriage? Where does prudence begin and where does greed end? Last Christmas, you were afraid I would marry him because it would be reckless, but now because he wants to marry a girl with only ten thousand pounds, you want to think he is greedy.
tr: "Please tell me, dear aunt, what is the difference between being greedy and being prudent in matters of marriage? Where do emotions end and greed begin? Last Christmas you were afraid of him marrying me because you thought it would be foolish; but now you want to think he is greedy just because he is trying to win a girl who only has ten thousand pounds."
es: ––Let's see, dear aunt, what is the difference in matrimonial matters between selfish motives and prudent ones? Where does discretion end and greed begin? Last Christmas you feared he would marry me because it would have been imprudent, and now because he is seeking a young woman with only ten thousand pounds of income, you assume he is a fortune hunter.

en: “If you will only tell me what sort of girl Miss King is, I shall know what to think.”
vi: - If you just tell me what kind of person she is, I will know what to think.
tr: "If you tell me what kind of girl Miss King is, I will decide what to think."
es: ––Just tell me what kind of person Miss King is, and I will be able to form a judgment.

en: “She is a very good kind of girl, I believe. I know no harm of her.”
vi: - I believe she is a very good girl. I don't think badly of her.
tr: "She is a very good girl, in my opinion. I haven't seen any harm from her."
es: ––I think she is a good girl. I haven't heard anything bad about her.

en: “But he paid her not the smallest attention till her grandfather’s death made her mistress of this fortune?”
vi: - But he didn't pay any attention to her, not until she inherited that sum of money.
tr: "But he never showed any interest in the girl until he inherited this fortune after his grandfather's death.""
es: ––But he didn't pay her the slightest attention until her grandfather's death made her the owner of that fortune...

en: “No—why should he? If it were not allowable for him to gain my affections, because I had no money, what occasion could there be for making love to a girl whom he did not care about, and who was equally poor?”
vi: - That's right, but why did you have to pay attention to her first? If he is not allowed to win your affection because you have no money, what chance does he have to confess his feelings to a girl he doesn't care about and who is also poor?
tr: "No –why should he show it? If he doesn't care about winning my heart because I have no money, what sense does it make for him to court a girl who is equally penniless?"
es: ––Of course, why would he do it? If he couldn't afford to win me over because I had no money, what reason would he have to court a girl who meant nothing to him and was as poor as I was?

en: “But there seems indelicacy in directing his attentions towards her so soon after this event.”
vi: - But it seems he lacked tact when he paid attention to her right after she inherited.
tr: "But there's something crude about immediately turning his attention to her right after this incident."
es: ––But it seems improper for him to direct his attentions to her so soon after that event.

en: “A man in distressed circumstances has not time for all those elegant decorums which other people may observe. If she does not object to it, why should we?”
vi: - A young man in distressing circumstances does not have time for all the formalities that others might adhere to. If she does not oppose, why should we oppose?
tr: "A man in distress does not have the time to devote to all those elegant customs that others might observe." If the girl does not object, why should we?"
es: ––A man who is in a bad situation does not have time, like others, to observe those elegant delicacies. Besides, if she does not reproach him, why should we reproach him?

en: “Her not objecting does not justify him. It only shows her being deficient in something herself—sense or feeling.”
vi: - Her lack of resistance cannot justify him. It only shows that she lacks either awareness or feelings.
tr: "The girl's lack of objection does not justify the man. It only shows a deficiency within the girl herself – either emotion or sensitivity."
es: ––The fact that she doesn't care doesn't justify Wickham. It only shows that this young lady lacks sense or sensitivity.

en: “Well,” cried Elizabeth, “have it as you choose. He shall be mercenary, and she shall be foolish.”
vi: Elizabeth exclaimed: - Alright, it's up to you to think. He is greedy, and she is foolish.
tr: "Well," cried Elizabeth, "say whatever you like. Let the man be greedy, and the girl be foolish."
es: ––Well ––exclaimed Elizabeth––, as you wish. Let's say he is a fortune hunter and she is a fool.

en: “No, Lizzy, that is what I do not choose. I should be sorry, you know, to think ill of a young man who has lived so long in Derbyshire.”
vi: - No, Lizzy, it's not up to you to think whatever you want. You know, I feel sad thinking badly about a young man who has lived in Derbyshire for a long time.
tr: "No, Lizzy, that's not what I meant. It would truly upset me to think badly of a young man who has lived in Derbyshire for so long."
es: ––No, Elizabeth, that's what I don't want. You know it would hurt me to think badly of a young man who lived so long in Derbyshire.

en: “Oh, if that is all, I have a very poor opinion of young men who live in Derbyshire; and their intimate friends who live in Hertfordshire are not much better. I am sick of them all. Thank heaven! I am going to-morrow where I shall find a man who has not one agreeable quality, who has neither manners nor sense to recommend him. Stupid men are the only ones worth knowing, after all.”
vi: - Oh dear! If that's all, I have a very poor opinion of the young men living in Derbyshire, and their friends in Hertfordshire are no better. I'm fed up with all of them. Thank God! Tomorrow I will go to a place where I can find a man who has no agreeable qualities, no dignity, or sense worth mentioning. After all, only fools are worth getting to know.
tr: "Oh! If that's the issue, I have no regard for the young men living in Derbyshire; their close friends living in Hertfordshire are no better. I'm tired of all of them. Thank God! Tomorrow, I'm going to a place where I'll meet a man who has not a single charming aspect, neither inside nor out. In my opinion, foolish men are the only ones worth knowing."
es: ––Ah! Well, if that's the case, I have a very poor opinion of the young men who live in Derbyshire, whose close friends, who live in Hertfordshire, are not much better. I'm fed up with all of them. Thank God, tomorrow I'm going to a place where I'll meet a man who has no pleasant qualities, who has neither manners nor the ability to be likable. After all, stupid men are the only ones worth knowing.

en: “Take care, Lizzy; that speech savours strongly of disappointment.”
vi: - Be careful, Lizzy, such words clearly show disappointment.
tr: "Oh dear, Lizzy; there's a strong sense of disappointment in this conversation."
es: ––Watch out, Lizzy! Those words sound too much like disappointment.

en: Before they were separated by the conclusion of the play, she had the unexpected happiness of an invitation to accompany her uncle and aunt in a tour of pleasure which they proposed taking in the summer.
vi: Before they parted ways with a playful concluding remark, she had the unexpected pleasure of being invited to join her uncle and aunt on their summer trip.
tr: Before parting ways at the end of the game, with unexpected joy, they received an invitation to accompany their uncle and aunt on the trip they were planning to take in the summer.
es: Before parting ways after finishing the work, Elizabeth had the unexpected joy of being invited by her uncles to accompany them on a trip they were planning to take in the summer.

en: “We have not quite determined how far it shall carry us,” said Mrs. Gardiner; “but perhaps, to the Lakes.”
vi: Mrs. Gardiner said: - Aunt and uncle haven't decided how far they will go, but they might go to the Lake District.
tr: "We haven't decided exactly how far we will go yet," said Mrs. Gardiner, "perhaps we might go as far as the Lake District."
es: ––We still don't know how far we will go ––said Mrs. Gardiner––, but we might reach the Lakes.

en: No scheme could have been more agreeable to Elizabeth, and her acceptance of the invitation was most ready and grateful. “My dear, dear aunt,” she rapturously cried, “what delight! what felicity! You give me fresh life and vigour. Adieu to disappointment and spleen. What are men to rocks and mountains? Oh, what hours of transport we shall spend! And when we do return, it shall not be like other travellers, without being able to give one accurate idea of anything. We will know where we have gone—we will recollect what we have seen. Lakes, mountains, and rivers, shall not be jumbled together in our imaginations; nor, when we attempt to describe any particular scene, will we begin quarrelling about its relative situation. Let our first effusions be less insupportable than those of the generality of travellers.”
vi: No other plan could make Elizabeth as happy. She exclaimed enthusiastically: - My dear aunt, that's wonderful! So exciting! You give me joy and new vitality! Farewell to all disappointment and melancholy. Compared to rocks and mountains, what are men? Oh my! I have so much time to explore! And when we return, we won't be like other tourists who can't give accurate opinions about anything. We will know where we have been, we will remember what we have seen. The rivers, lakes, and mountains will not be jumbled in our imagination; and when we try to describe a certain scene, we won't have to argue about its related circumstances. Let our initial overflowing emotions be more pleasant than the general feelings of other tourists...
tr: No offer could be more appealing to Elizabeth; she accepted the invitation immediately and gratefully. "My dear, beloved aunt," she exclaimed with enthusiasm, "what joy! what happiness! You have given me new life and energy. Goodbye to disappointment and sorrow. What are men compared to mountains and rocks? Oh! just think of the hours we will spend on the roads! When we return, we will not be like other travelers; we will be able to describe everything in detail. We will know where we went – we will remember what we saw. Lakes, mountains, rivers will not get mixed up in our minds; when we try to describe a particular scene, we will not start arguing about what was near and what was far. Even our hastily told stories will be more convincing than most travelers' accounts."
es: No other project could be as pleasing to Elizabeth. She accepted the invitation instantly, extremely grateful. ––Dear, dearest aunt, she exclaimed enthusiastically––, what a delight!, what happiness! You make me come alive again, this gives me strength. Goodbye to disappointment and resentment! What are men compared to rocks and mountains? Oh, what hours of escape we will have! And when we return, we will not be like those travelers who are unable to give an accurate idea of anything. We will know where we have gone, and we will remember what we have seen. The lakes, the rivers, and the mountains will not be confused in our memory, nor will we argue about their relative positions when we want to describe a specific landscape. Let our first outpourings not be like those of most travelers!

en: CHAPTER XXVIII.
vi: Chapter 28
tr: Chapter V
es: CHAPTER XXVIII

en: EVERY object in the next day’s journey was new and interesting to Elizabeth; and her spirits were in a state of enjoyment; for she had seen her sister looking so well as to banish all fear for her health, and the prospect of her northern tour was a constant source of delight.
vi: Everything on the next day's journey was new and exciting for Elizabeth. Her spirits were high because she had seen her sister in good health and had no worries, and the prospect of the trip to the North was a source of endless joy.
tr: Everything Elizabeth saw on the journey the next day was new and interesting to her; she was in a cheerful mood because she had seen her sister well enough to dispel all her fears about her health, and the possibility of taking a northern tour was a constant source of joy for her.
es: The next day everything was new and interesting for Elizabeth. She was determined to have a good time and was very cheerful, as she had found her sister in very good health, and all the fears she had about her health had vanished. Moreover, the prospect of a trip to the North was for her a constant source of joy.

en: When they left the high road for the lane to Hunsford, every eye was in search of the Parsonage, and every turning expected to bring it in view. The paling of Rosings park was their boundary on one side. Elizabeth smiled at the recollection of all that she had heard of its inhabitants.
vi: When they turned off the main road to go to Huntsford, every eye was searching for the Parsonage, which everyone thought could be seen after every turn, with the boundary of Rosings Park on one side. Elizabeth smiled as she recalled what she had heard about the inhabitants of this place.
tr: When they left the main road and turned onto the Hunsford road, all eyes began to search for the Parsonage, expecting it to appear after every bend. The fence of Rosings Park marked their boundaries on one side. Elizabeth smiled as she remembered all that she had heard about the inhabitants of the estate.
es: When they left the main road to enter the Hunsford path, everyone's eyes searched for the parsonage and at every turn they thought they were going to see it. On one side of the path ran the fence of the Rosings estate. Elizabeth smiled as she remembered everything she had heard about its inhabitants.

en: At length the Parsonage was discernible. The garden sloping to the road, the house standing in it, the green pales and the laurel hedge, everything declared they were arriving. Mr. Collins and Charlotte appeared at the door, and the carriage stopped at the small gate, which led by a short gravel walk to the house, amidst the nods and smiles of the whole party. In a moment they were all out of the chaise, rejoicing at the sight of each other. Mrs. Collins welcomed her friend with the liveliest pleasure, and Elizabeth was more and more satisfied with coming, when she found herself so affectionately received. She saw instantly that her cousin’s manners were not altered by his marriage: his formal civility was just what it had been; and he detained her some minutes at the gate to hear and satisfy his inquiries after all her family. They were then, with no other delay than his pointing out the neatness of the entrance, taken into the house; and as soon as they were in the parlour, he welcomed them a second time, with ostentatious formality, to his humble abode, and punctually repeated all his wife’s offers of refreshment.
vi: Finally, the Parish Priest's Residence appeared. The garden sloped down to the road, the house lay within the fence and hedge, everything indicated they had reached their destination. Mr. Collins and Charlotte appeared at the doorway, and the carriage stopped before a small gate leading to a short gravel path, amidst nods and smiles from the group. In a moment, the three of them got off the carriage, happy to see each other again. Mrs. Collins welcomed her friend with the liveliest joy, and Elizabeth grew increasingly pleased with the visit as the couple treated her with great affection. She immediately noticed that her cousin's manner had not changed after marriage. His formal politeness remained the same, and he kept her for a few minutes by the gate to inquire about her family. After showing the three guests the intricate details of the entrance, he invited them in, and as soon as they reached the hall, with deliberately ostentatious words, he once again welcomed them to his humble abode and reiterated his wife's invitation for refreshments.
tr: Finally, the lodgings were chosen. The garden sloping towards the road, the house within it, the green posts, the laurel bushes, everything announced their arrival. Mr. Collins and Charlotte appeared at the door; the carriage stopped at a small gate; a short gravel path led up from the gate to the house; everyone's satisfaction was evident on their faces. Soon they all got out of the carriage, looking at each other with joy. Mrs. Collins greeted her friend with enthusiastic delight; seeing how warmly she was welcomed, Elizabeth was even more pleased to have come. She immediately noticed that her cousin's behavior had not changed after marriage; his formal politeness was just as it had been, and he detained Elizabeth at the door for a few minutes, inquiring about the health of each member of her family. Then, without any delay except to draw their attention to the neatness of the entrance, they were taken inside; as soon as they entered the parlor, he welcomed them to his humble abode with grand formality for the second time, and repeated all of his wife's offers of refreshments verbatim.
es: At last, they caught sight of the parsonage. The garden that extended to the road, the house that stood in the middle, the green palisade, and the laurel hedge indicated that they had arrived. Collins and Charlotte appeared at the door, and the carriage stopped at a small entrance that led to the house through a gravel path, amidst general greetings and smiles. In a moment, everyone got down from the landau, mutually rejoicing at seeing each other. Mrs. Collins welcomed her friend with the sincerest pleasure, and Elizabeth, being received with such affection, was increasingly glad she had come. She immediately observed that her cousin's manners had not changed with marriage; his rigid courtesy was exactly the same as before, and he kept her at the door for several minutes to ask questions about the entire family. Without further delay than Collins's remarks to his guests about the neatness of the entrance, they entered the house. Once in the hall, Collins, with bombastic formality, welcomed them to his humble abode for the second time, repeating point by point his wife's offer to serve them a refreshment.

en: Elizabeth was prepared to see him in his glory; and she could not help fancying that in displaying the good proportion of the room, its aspect, and its furniture, he addressed himself particularly to her, as if wishing to make her feel what she had lost in refusing him. But though everything seemed neat and comfortable, she was not able to gratify him by any sigh of repentance; and rather looked with wonder at her friend, that she could have so cheerful an air with such a companion. When Mr. Collins said anything of which his wife might reasonably be ashamed, which certainly was not seldom, she involuntarily turned her eye on Charlotte. Once or twice she could discern a faint blush; but in general Charlotte wisely did not hear. After sitting long enough to admire every article of furniture in the room, from the sideboard to the fender, to give an account of their journey, and of all that had happened in London, Mr. Collins invited them to take a stroll in the garden, which was large and well laid out, and to the cultivation of which he attended himself. To work in his garden was one of his most respectable pleasures; and Elizabeth admired the command of countenance with which Charlotte talked of the healthfulness of the exercise, and owned she encouraged it as much as possible. Here, leading the way through every walk and cross walk, and scarcely allowing them an interval to utter the praises he asked for, every view was pointed out with a minuteness which left beauty entirely behind. He could number the fields in every direction, and could tell how many trees there were in the most distant clump. But of all the views which his garden, or which the country or the kingdom could boast, none were to be compared with the prospect of Rosings, afforded by an opening in the trees that bordered the park nearly opposite the front of his house. It was a handsome modern building, well situated on rising ground.
vi: Elizabeth had prepared herself to meet him again in his glory; she couldn't help but imagine that in the display of most of the room, its layout, and its furnishings, he particularly wanted to speak to her privately, as if wanting her to think about how much she had lost by refusing him. But although everything was neat and comfortable, she could not satisfy him with a single sigh expressing regret. Instead, she looked at her friend and wondered about such cheerfulness, with such a husband. When Mr. Collins said something that might embarrass his wife, she involuntarily turned to look at Charlotte. A couple of times she could detect a faint blush, but usually, Charlotte wisely ignored it as if she hadn't heard. After everyone had had time to admire the furnishings in the room, recount their journey and the events in London, Mr. Collins invited everyone to take a walk in the garden, which was quite large and meticulously arranged, tended by his own hands. Gardening was one of his respectable pleasures, and Elizabeth admired Charlotte's composed expression when her friend spoke about the health benefits of gardening; Elizabeth thought her friend intended to encourage this as much as possible. He led the three companions around, rarely giving them time to express any praise, pointing out every trivial detail, leaving the beauty completely behind. He could count the garden plots on every side and tell how many trees were in the farthest grove. But for all the beauty that his garden, or the entire region, or even the entire kingdom, could boast, nothing compared to the view of the Rosings estate, seen through a gap in the foliage surrounding the garden near the front of the Parsonage. This was a magnificent, modern mansion, situated on a small elevated piece of land.
tr: Elizabeth was prepared to see him display his triumph; while drawing attention to the dimensions, atmosphere, and furniture of the room, she couldn't help but think that it was specifically addressing her: as if it wanted to make her feel what she had lost by rejecting him. However, although everything appeared to be in place and comfortable, Elizabeth couldn't detect any sign of regret that would please her; on the contrary, she looked at her friend with some amazement for being able to capture such a cheerful atmosphere with such a life partner. Whenever Mr. Collins said something that his wife might be embarrassed by, which was evidently not infrequent, Elizabeth couldn't help but fix her eyes on Charlotte. Once or twice she thought she detected a slight blush; but Charlotte was wise, mostly pretending not to hear. After sitting long enough to admire every piece of furniture in the room, from the display cabinet to the fireplace grate, and to recount their travels and what had happened in London, Mr. Collins invited them for a walk in the garden; the garden was large, well-arranged, and he personally took care of its maintenance. Working in his garden was one of his most esteemed pleasures; Elizabeth admired Charlotte's ability to control her facial expressions while she spoke about the benefits of exercise and her great encouragement in this matter. Falling ahead of them on every path, without giving them a second to utter the praises he expected, he pointed out the details of the scenery with a speed that made them forget every beauty. He could count the fields in every direction and tell how many trees were in the most distant grove. But among all the landscapes that his garden, or the country, or the kingdom could boast of, Rosings was incomparable, as seen through the clearing among the trees surrounding the grove facing the front of his house. It was a beautiful, modern building; built on a rising ground.
es: Elizabeth was prepared to see him now in his environment, and she couldn't help but think that by showing them the good proportions of the room, its appearance, and its furnishings, Collins was addressing her specifically, as if he wanted to make her feel what she had lost by rejecting him. But although everything seemed bright and comfortable, Elizabeth could not gratify him with any sign of regret; rather, she marveled that her friend could appear so cheerful with such a companion. When Collins said something that must have embarrassed his wife, which happened quite often, Elizabeth involuntarily turned her eyes towards Charlotte. Once or twice she could see that Charlotte blushed slightly; but, for the most part, Charlotte pretended not to hear him. After sitting for a while, long enough to admire each and every piece of furniture, from the sideboard to the fireplace grate, and to recount the journey and everything that had happened in London, Mr. Collins invited them to take a walk in the garden, which was large and well laid out and which he personally took care of. Working in the garden was one of his most respected pleasures; Elizabeth admired the seriousness with which Charlotte spoke of how healthy it was for Collins and confessed that she herself encouraged him to do it whenever possible. Guiding them through all the paths and corners and barely giving them time to express the praises he demanded, he pointed out all the views with a meticulousness that far exceeded their beauty. He enumerated the fields that could be seen in all directions and said how many trees were in each one. But of all the views that his garden, or the countryside, or the entire kingdom could boast of, there was none that could compare to that of Rosings, which was revealed through a clearing in the trees that bordered the estate on the side opposite to the front of his house. The mansion was pretty, modern, and very well situated, on an elevation of the land.

en: From his garden, Mr. Collins would have led them round his two meadows; but the ladies, not having shoes to encounter the remains of a white frost, turned back; and while Sir William accompanied him, Charlotte took her sister and friend over the house, extremely well pleased, probably, to have the opportunity of showing it without her husband’s help. It was rather small, but well built and convenient; and everything was fitted up and arranged with a neatness and consistency, of which Elizabeth gave Charlotte all the credit. When Mr. Collins could be forgotten, there was really a great air of comfort throughout, and by Charlotte’s evident enjoyment of it, Elizabeth supposed he must be often forgotten.
vi: From his garden, Mr. Collins wanted to take them to his two meadows, but the women were not wearing suitable shoes, so they turned back. While Sir William followed him, Charlotte led her sister and friend back, perhaps very happy to have the opportunity to introduce the residence without needing her husband's accompaniment. The residence was quite small, but it was built in a complete and convenient manner. Everything was arranged and equipped in an orderly and consistent way that Elizabeth attributed to Charlotte's efforts. When they could forget about Mr. Collins, there was clearly a comfortable atmosphere prevailing, and from Charlotte's cheerful demeanor, Elizabeth guessed that he was often forgotten.
tr: After the garden, Mr. Collins was going to show them his two lawns, but the ladies turned back as their shoes were not suitable for the remnants of frost on the ground; while Sir William accompanied him, Charlotte took her sister and friend back to the house, seemingly very delighted to have the opportunity to show the house without her husband's help. It was a small house, but well-built and functional; everything was matched with a care and harmony that Elizabeth attributed to Charlotte. When Mr. Collins was forgotten, there was an air of great comfort everywhere and Charlotte's enjoyment of it; Elizabeth thought that the man must often be forgotten.
es: From the garden, Collins would have liked to take them to tour his two meadows, but the ladies were not properly shod to walk on the still frozen grass and they declined. Sir William was the only one who accompanied him. Charlotte returned to the house with her sister and Elizabeth, probably extremely happy to be able to show it to them without her husband's help. It was small but well laid out, everything was arranged with order and cleanliness, a merit that Elizabeth attributed to Charlotte. When one could forget Collins, the house had a more pleasant atmosphere; and from her friend's evident satisfaction, Elizabeth thought she should forget him more often.

en: She had already learnt that Lady Catherine was still in the country. It was spoken of again while they were at dinner, when Mr. Collins joining in, observed,—
vi: She had heard that Lady Catherine was still staying in the area. They talked more about this at the dinner table, when Mr. Collins added his comments:
tr: He had previously learned that Lady Catherine was still in the countryside. This was mentioned again at dinner; Mr. Collins joined the conversation and said-
es: They had already told him that Lady Catherine was still in the country. She was mentioned again while they were dining, and Collins, joining the conversation, said:

en: “Yes, Miss Elizabeth, you will have the honour of seeing Lady Catherine de Bourgh on the ensuing Sunday at church, and I need not say you will be delighted with her. She is all affability and condescension, and I doubt not but you will be honoured with some portion of her notice when service is over. I have scarcely any hesitation in saying that she will include you and my sister Maria in every invitation with which she honours us during your stay here. Her behaviour to my dear Charlotte is charming. We dine at Rosings twice every week, and are never allowed to walk home. Her Ladyship’s carriage is regularly ordered for us. I should say, one of her Ladyship’s carriages, for she has several.”
vi: - Yes, Miss Elizabeth, you will have the honor of meeting Lady Catherine de Bourgh next Sunday at church, and I need not say that you will be very pleased with this opportunity. She is full of grace and sociable with those of lower status, and I am sure you will have the honor of being noticed by her a little when the service ends. I am certain that during your stay here, the Lady will invite you and my sister Maria to attend every gathering organized for us. Her attitude towards my dear Charlotte is truly captivating. We dine at her house twice a week, and we are never allowed to walk back. The Lady's carriage is often called for us to use. I must say, one of the carriages, because the Lady has several.
tr: "Yes, Miss Elizabeth, you will have the honor of seeing Lady Catherine de Bourgh in church next Sunday; I don't even need to tell you that you will be delighted with her. She is a paragon of kindness and magnanimity; I have no doubt that you will receive a certain amount of her attention once the service is over. I can say without hesitation that during your stay here, she will include you and my sister-in-law Maria in every invitation she honors us with. Her behavior towards my dear Charlotte is simply charming. We dine at Rosings twice a week and are not allowed to walk home. Her ladyship's carriage is regularly called for us. One of her carriages, I should say, because she has several."
es: ––Yes, Elizabeth; you will have the honor of seeing Lady Catherine de Bourgh next Sunday at church, and I don't need to tell you how much you will enjoy it. She is all affability and condescension, and I have no doubt that she will honor you by speaking to you as soon as the service is over. I also almost have no doubt that you and my sister-in-law Maria will be included in all the invitations with which she honors us during your stay here. Her attitude towards my dear Charlotte is most kind. We dine at Rosings twice a week and she never allows us to walk back. She always requests her carriage to take us, or rather, one of her carriages, because she has several.

en: “Lady Catherine is a very respectable, sensible woman, indeed,” added Charlotte, “and a most attentive neighbour.”
vi: Charlotte added: - Madam is truly a very respectable person, who knows right from wrong, and is the most considerate neighbor.
tr: "Lady Catherine is indeed a very respectable, understanding woman," added Charlotte, "and a very considerate neighbor."
es: ––Lady Catherine is really a very respectable and affectionate lady ––added Charlotte––, and a very attentive neighbor.

en: “Very true, my dear, that is exactly what I say. She is the sort of woman whom one cannot regard with too much deference.”
vi: - That's right, my dear, this is exactly what I said. She is the kind of woman whom people respect no matter what.
tr: "That's right, my dear, I say the same thing. She is such a woman that no matter how much respect you show, it is never enough."
es: ––Very true, dear; it is exactly what I say: she is a woman who can never be considered with enough deference.

en: The evening was spent chiefly in talking over Hertfordshire news, and telling again what had been already written; and when it closed, Elizabeth, in the solitude of her chamber, had to meditate upon Charlotte’s degree of contentment, to understand her address in guiding, and composure in bearing with, her husband, and to acknowledge that it was all done very well. She had also to anticipate how her visit would pass, the quiet tenour of their usual employments, the vexatious interruptions of Mr. Collins, and the gaieties of their intercourse with Rosings. A lively imagination soon settled it all.
vi: In the evening, they sat together mainly talking about the news in Hertfordshire and recounting what they had exchanged through letters. When they finished, Elizabeth sat alone in the room designated for her, contemplating Charlotte's contented appearance, to understand more about the cleverness in guiding and enduring her husband, and to acknowledge that her friend had behaved well in all matters. Previously, she had anticipated what this trip would be like, with the daily routines, the annoying interjections of Mr. Collins, and their enthusiasm in their relationship with Rosings. A rich imagination soon delineated everything.
tr: The evening mostly passed by talking about Hertfordshire news and recounting things that had already been written; when the evening ended, Elizabeth, in the solitude of her room, had to reflect on how content Charlotte was with her life, understand her ability to guide and endure her husband, and accept that everything was going quite well. She also had to anticipate how her visit would go, the calm flow of her daily activities, Mr. Collins' tedious interventions, and the amusements in their interactions with Rosings. A vivid imagination soon resolved everything.
es: During the evening, there was almost constant talk about Hertfordshire, and what had already been said in writing was repeated. Upon retiring, Elizabeth, in the solitude of her room, reflected on Charlotte's well-being and her skill and discretion in making the best of and enduring her husband, acknowledging that she did it very well. She also thought about how her visit would go, what they would do, the tedious interruptions from Collins, and how much she would enjoy dealing with the Rosings family. Her vivid imagination planned it all at once.

en: About the middle of the next day, as she was in her room getting ready for a walk, a sudden noise below seemed to speak the whole house in confusion; and, after listening a moment, she heard somebody running upstairs in a violent hurry, and calling loudly after her. She opened the door, and met Maria in the landing-place, who, breathless with agitation, cried out,—
vi: In the middle of the next day, as she was preparing to go out for a walk, a sudden noise seemed to throw the entire house into chaos. After listening for a moment, she heard the hurried footsteps of someone running up the stairs and loudly calling her name. She opened the door and met Maria on the stairs, who breathlessly exclaimed:
tr: By the middle of the next day, while preparing for a walk in his room, a sudden noise from downstairs seemed to turn the whole house upside down; after listening for a moment, he heard someone running up the stairs in a wild rush and shouting at him. He opened the door and saw Maria on the landing; out of breath from excitement, she was shouting-
es: The next day, around noon, she was in her room getting ready to go out for a walk, when she heard a sudden noise downstairs that seemed to throw the whole house into confusion. She listened for a moment and noticed that someone was hurriedly coming up the stairs and calling out to her loudly. She opened the door and in the hallway she found María, very agitated and out of breath, who exclaimed:

en: “In Conversation with the ladies”
vi: She opened the door and met Maria on the stairs, who breathlessly exclaimed:
tr: He opened the door and saw Maria on the landing; out of breath from excitement, she was shouting-
es: She opened the door and in the hallway she found María, very agitated and out of breath, who exclaimed:

en: “Oh, my dear Eliza! pray make haste and come into the dining-room, for there is such a sight to be seen! I will not tell you what it is. Make haste, and come down this moment.”
vi: - Hey, Eliza! Please hurry to the dining room, because there's something you need to see! I won't tell you what it is. Quickly, please come down right away.
tr: "Ah dear Eliza! Please hurry, come to the dining room, there's a sight to see! I won't tell you what it is. Hurry up, come down immediately."
es: ––Oh, dear Elizabeth! Hurry up, come down to the dining room and you'll see! I can't tell you what it is. Run, come at once!

en: Elizabeth asked questions in vain; Maria would tell her nothing more; and down they ran into the dining-room which fronted the lane, in quest of this wonder; it was two ladies, stopping in a low phaeton at the garden gate.
vi: Elizabeth asked but there was no answer; Maria refused to say anything more. They ran down to the dining room to look out onto the street. Two women arrived in a four-wheeled carriage, stopping in front of the garden gate, Elizabeth exclaimed:
tr: Elizabeth asked questions in vain; Maria was not going to say anything else; they ran together down to the dining room; the dining room faced the road, and the marvel they were pursuing was right in front of them! Two ladies were standing in a low carriage at the garden gate.
es: Elizabeth asked in vain what was happening. Maria did not want to tell her more; both went to the dining room, whose windows faced the road, to see the marvel. This consisted simply of two ladies who were standing at the garden gate in a low phaeton.

en: “And is this all?” cried Elizabeth. “I expected at least that the pigs were got into the garden, and here is nothing but Lady Catherine and her daughter!”
vi: - Is that all? I thought at least a few pigs had run into the garden, but here there are only Lady Catherine and her daughter!
tr: "Is that all?" cried Elizabeth. "I had at least hoped that the pigs had gotten into the garden, but there's nothing here except Lady Catherine and her daughter!"
es: ––And is that all? ––exclaimed Elizabeth––. I was at least expecting the pigs to have invaded the garden, and all I see is Lady Catherine and her daughter!

en: “La! my dear,” said Maria, quite shocked at the mistake, “it is not Lady Catherine. The old lady is Mrs. Jenkinson, who lives with them. The other is Miss De Bourgh. Only look at her. She is quite a little creature. Who would have thought she could be so thin and small!”
vi: Maria was quite surprised by the mistake: - No, ma'am. That is Mrs. Jenkinson, who lives with them. The other one is Miss De Bourgh. Look at her. She is quite small. Who could think she is so thin and small.
tr: "Oh, my dear," said Maria, bewildered by the mistake, "this is not Lady Catherine. The elderly lady is Mrs. Jenkinson, who lives with them; the other one is Miss de Bourgh. Look at her. What a cute thing. Who would have thought she was so slim and small!"
es: ––Oh, dear! ––replied María, extremely surprised by the mistake––. It is not Lady Catherine. The older one is Mrs. Jenkinson, who lives with them. The other one is Miss de Bourgh. Look at her closely. She is a little creature. Who would have believed she was so small and so thin!

en: “She is abominably rude to keep Charlotte out of doors in all this wind. Why does she not come in?”
vi: - She was indeed rude to make Charlotte go outside in this wind. Why doesn't she come inside? - Ah!
tr: "It's very rude to keep Charlotte outside in this wind. Why isn't she coming inside?"
es: ––It is rude to have Charlotte at the door with the wind blowing like this. Why doesn't that young lady come in?

en: “Oh, Charlotte says she hardly ever does. It is the greatest of favours when Miss De Bourgh comes in.”
vi: Charlotte says she rarely agrees to come inside. If Miss De Bourgh agrees, it is the greatest favor.
tr: "Charlotte says she rarely comes in. Miss de Bourgh's entrance is the greatest compliment."
es: ––Charlotte says she almost never does it. It would be the greatest of favors if Miss de Bourgh were to enter the house.

en: “I like her appearance,” said Elizabeth, struck with other ideas. “She looks sickly and cross. Yes, she will do for him very well. She will make him a very proper wife.”
vi: Elizabeth said: - She likes her figure. Suddenly, Elizabeth had a new thought. "She looks weak and irritable. Yes, she will suit him. She will be a very fitting wife for him."
tr: "I liked his appearance," said Elizabeth, her mind occupied with other thoughts. "He looks sick and irritable. Yes, it will do him good. She would make a very suitable wife for him."
es: ––I like her appearance ––said Elizabeth, thinking about other things––. She looks sick and ill-tempered. Yes, she is the right woman for him, she suits him well.

en: Mr. Collins and Charlotte were both standing at the gate in conversation with the ladies; and Sir William, to Elizabeth’s high diversion, was stationed in the doorway, in earnest contemplation of the greatness before him, and constantly bowing whenever Miss De Bourgh looked that way.
vi: Mr. Collins and Charlotte are standing by the gate talking to two women. Sir William is standing by the door frame, which distracts Elizabeth. He is solemnly observing the scene before him and always bows whenever Miss De Bourgh looks his way.
tr: Mr. Collins and Charlotte were standing at the door, talking to the ladies; Sir William, in a manner that would surprise Elizabeth, was positioned in front of the door, eagerly watching the noble person before him, and every time Miss de Bourgh looked that way, he kept bowing his head in greeting.
es: Collins and his wife were conversing with the two ladies at the garden gate, and Elizabeth was greatly amused watching Sir William at the entrance door, absorbed in the contemplation of the grandeur before him and bowing every time Miss de Bourgh glanced in his direction.

en: At length there was nothing more to be said; the ladies drove on, and the others returned into the house. Mr. Collins no sooner saw the two girls than he began to congratulate them on their good fortune, which Charlotte explained by letting them know that the whole party was asked to dine at Rosings the next day.
vi: In the end, they had nothing left to say. The two women drove away, and the others went into the house. As soon as he saw the two ladies, Mr. Collins hurriedly congratulated them both, and Charlotte explained that everyone was invited to dinner at Rosings the next day.
tr: Finally, there was nothing left to say; the ladies continued on their way, and the others returned home. As soon as Mr. Collins saw the two girls, he began to congratulate them on their fortune, and Charlotte explained what the fortune was: the whole group had been invited to dinner at Rosings the next day.
es: Once the conversation ended, the ladies continued on their way, and the others entered the house. Collins, as soon as he saw the two girls, congratulated them on their good fortune.

en: “Lady Catherine, said she, you have given me a treasure.”
vi: As soon as he saw the two ladies, Mr. Collins hurriedly congratulated them both, and Charlotte explained that everyone was invited to dinner at Rosings the next day.
tr: As soon as Mr. Collins saw the two girls, he began to congratulate them on their fortune, and Charlotte explained what the fortune was: the whole group had been invited to dinner at Rosings the next day.
es: This good fortune, as Charlotte clarified, was that they were all invited to dine at Rosings the next day.

en: CHAPTER XXIX.
vi: Chapter 29
tr: Chapter VI
es: CHAPTER XXIX

en: MR. COLLINS’S triumph, in consequence of this invitation, was complete. The power of displaying the grandeur of his patroness to his wondering visitors, and of letting them see her civility towards himself and his wife, was exactly what he had wished for; and that an opportunity of doing it should be given so soon was such an instance of Lady Catherine’s condescension as he knew not how to admire enough.
vi: The triumph of Mr. Collins after they received such an invitation was complete. The opportunity to present to the guests, who were astonished, the influence of his patroness and her courteous attitude towards him and his wife, was exactly what he had hoped for. Such an opportunity came quite quickly, demonstrating the Lady's affability towards her subordinates, which he did not know how to admire adequately.
tr: With this invitation, Mr. Collins' success was complete. The opportunity to showcase his patroness's splendor to curious guests and to have them witness the kindness shown to him and his wife was exactly what he desired; that this opportunity was given so quickly was such a rare example of Lady Catherine's generosity that no amount of gratitude would be sufficient.
es: Collins's satisfaction with this invitation was complete. There was nothing that delighted him more than being able to showcase the grandeur of his patroness to his admired guests and to make them see the courtesy with which this lady treated him and his wife; and the fact that he was given an opportunity to do so so soon was an example of Lady Catherine's condescension that he wouldn't know how to thank.

en: “I confess,” said he, “that I should not have been at all surprised by her Ladyship’s asking us on Sunday to drink tea and spend the evening at Rosings. I rather expected, from my knowledge of her affability, that it would happen. But who could have foreseen such an attention as this? Who could have imagined that we should receive an invitation to dine there (an invitation, moreover, including the whole party) so immediately after your arrival?”
vi: He said: - I must confess that I should not have been surprised by Lady Catherine inviting us this Sunday for tea and dinner at Rosings. Given what I know about Lady Catherine's kindness, this was bound to happen. But who could have anticipated such kindness? Who could have imagined that we would receive a dinner invitation as soon as you arrived!
tr: "I must confess," he said, "I wouldn't have been surprised if her ladyship had invited us to Rosings for tea and to spend Sunday evening together. Knowing how humble she is, I was expecting this. But who would have thought that we would be invited to dine there immediately after your arrival, and all of us at that!"
es: ––I confess ––he said–– that I would not have been surprised if His Lordship had invited us on Sunday to have tea and spend the afternoon at Rosings. In fact, I was expecting it, because I know his affability. But who could have imagined such an attention as this? Who could have imagined that we would receive an invitation to dinner; an invitation, moreover, extended to everyone in the house, so very shortly after you arrived?

en: “I am the less surprised at what has happened,” replied Sir William, “from that knowledge of what the manners of the great really are, which my situation in life has allowed me to acquire. About the court, such instances of elegant breeding are not uncommon.”
vi: Sir William replied: - I am less surprised by what happened, as the circumstances of my life have helped me understand the true nature of the upper class. Speaking of the court, such cases of refined upbringing are not uncommon.
tr: "I wasn't that surprised," replied Sir William, "if you ask why, it's because I know the manners of great people, my position in life has allowed me to acquire that style. Such refinements are not uncommon in the court circles."
es: ––I am not surprised ––replied Sir William––, because my position in life has allowed me to know the true nature of the great. In the court, such examples of elegant manners are very common.

en: Scarcely anything was talked of the whole day or next morning but their visit to Rosings. Mr. Collins was carefully instructing them in what they were to expect, that the sight of such rooms, so many servants, and so splendid a dinner, might not wholly overpower them.
vi: All that day and the next morning, they hardly talked about anything other than the upcoming visit to Rosings. Mr. Collins carefully instructed the three guests on what they would encounter, so that the grandeur of the rooms, the numerous servants, and the splendid dinner would not overwhelm them.
tr: All day and the next morning, little was talked about other than the visit to Rosings. Mr. Collins was carefully warning them about what to expect, so that the sight of such rooms, so many servants, and such a magnificent table would not completely overwhelm them.
es: All day long and the following morning, hardly anything else was talked about except the visit to Rosings. Collins carefully instructed them on what they were going to see, so that the sight of those rooms, so many servants, and such splendid food would not leave them open-mouthed.

en: When the ladies were separating for the toilette, he said to Elizabeth,—
vi: He spoke privately to Elizabeth:
tr: While the ladies withdrew to dress, Elizabeth was told-
es: When the ladies went to get dressed, he said to Elizabeth:

en: “Do not make yourself uneasy, my dear cousin, about your apparel. Lady Catherine is far from requiring that elegance of dress in us which becomes herself and daughter. I would advise you merely to put on whatever of your clothes is superior to the rest—there is no occasion for anything more. Lady Catherine will not think the worse of you for being simply dressed. She likes to have the distinction of rank preserved.”
vi: - My dear sister. You should not be anxious about your appearance. The lady does not require us to dress elegantly, so both she and her daughter dress plainly. I suggest that you simply wear the outfit that looks better than the others, nothing more. Lady Catherine will not think ill of you if you dress simply. She wants everyone to maintain the distinctiveness of their own class.
tr: "Do not feel uncomfortable about your attire, dear cousin. Lady Catherine does not expect us to wear dresses that match her and her daughter's elegance. My advice is to wear whichever of your clothes is superior to the others – nothing more is needed. Lady Catherine will not think ill of you for being plainly dressed. She likes to maintain the difference in status."
es: ––Do not worry about your attire, dear cousin. Lady Catherine is far from demanding from us the elegance in dressing that befits her and her daughter. I would only like to advise you to wear the best outfit you have; there is no need for more. Lady Catherine will not think ill of you for being dressed simply. She likes to be reserved the distinction due to her rank.

en: While they were dressing, he came two or three times to their different doors, to recommend their being quick, as Lady Catherine very much objected to be kept waiting for her dinner. Such formidable accounts of her Ladyship, and her manner of living, quite frightened Maria Lucas, who had been little used to company; and she looked forward to her introduction at Rosings with as much apprehension as her father had done to his presentation at St. James’s.
vi: While they were getting ready, he went to each room two or three times to urge them to hurry, as the Lady greatly disliked having to wait for her dinner. Maria Lucas was horrified by such dreadful details about the Lady and her way of life. Unaccustomed to socializing, she prepared for the party at Rosings with as much anxiety as her father had when he was knighted at St. James's Palace.
tr: While they were getting dressed, he came to their door several times, urging them to hurry, saying that Lady Catherine did not like to be kept waiting for dinner. Such grand pronouncements about Her Ladyship and her way of life intimidated Maria Lucas, who was not accustomed to such crowds, and she began to await her introduction at Rosings with the same anxiety as she had awaited her father's introduction at St. James's.
es: While they were getting dressed, Collins went two or three times to knock on the various doors, to recommend that they hurry up, as Lady Catherine was very uncomfortable having to wait to eat. Such formidable reports about Her Ladyship and her way of living had intimidated Maria Lucas, who was not used to social life, and awaited her entrance into Rosings with the same apprehension that her father had experienced when being presented at St. James.

en: As the weather was fine, they had a pleasant walk of about half a mile across the park. Every park has its beauty and its prospects; and Elizabeth saw much to be pleased with, though she could not be in such raptures as Mr. Collins expected the scene to inspire, and was but slightly affected by his enumeration of the windows in front of the house, and his relation of what the glazing altogether had originally cost Sir Lewis de Bourgh.
vi: Because of the good weather, they leisurely walked about half a mile, through a grove of trees. Each garden had its own unique beauty and distinctive panorama. Elizabeth enjoyed the scenery, though she did not show the excitement that Mr. Collins hoped the view would evoke in her. She absentmindedly listened to him talk about the number of windows on the mansion's facade and the cost of polishing that Sir Lewis De Bourgh had to incur.
tr: Because the weather was nice, they took a pleasant half-mile walk in the grove. Each grove has its own beauty and characteristics; Elizabeth saw many things she liked, but she still did not feel as much enthusiasm as Mr. Collins hoped the scene would inspire, nor was she very impressed by his counting the windows on the front facade of the house and telling her how much the glass had originally cost Sir Lewis de Bourgh.
es: Since the weather was good, the half-mile walk through the Rosings estate was very pleasant. All estates have their beauty and views, and Elizabeth was delighted with everything she saw, although she did not show the enthusiasm that Collins expected, and listened with little interest to his enumeration of the windows on the facade, and the account of what the stained glass had cost Sir Lewis de Bourgh.

en: When they ascended the steps to the hall, Maria’s alarm was every moment increasing, and even Sir William did not look perfectly calm. Elizabeth’s courage did not fail her. She had heard nothing of Lady Catherine that spoke her awful from any extraordinary talents or miraculous virtue, and the mere stateliness of money and rank she thought she could witness without trepidation.
vi: As they ascended the steps leading to the vestibule, Maria became increasingly alarmed, and even Sir William could not remain completely calm. Elizabeth's courageous temperament did not abandon her. She had not heard anything about Lady Catherine that suggested extraordinary talents or miraculous virtues. As for the grandeur stemming from wealth and status, she thought she could witness it without fear.
tr: As they ascended the stairs, Maria's anxiety increased with each passing moment; even Sir William did not appear very calm. Elizabeth's courage did not fail her. She had not heard Lady Catherine praised for extraordinary talents or miraculous virtues, and she thought she could observe the usual splendor of money and rank without feeling intimidated.
es: As they ascended the staircase leading to the lobby, María's excitement was increasing, and even Sir William was not entirely at ease. Elizabeth, on the other hand, did not lack courage. She had not heard anything about Lady Catherine that made her believe she possessed any extraordinary talents or miraculous virtues, and she knew that the mere majesty of money and lineage would not make her lose her composure.

en: From the entrance hall, of which Mr. Collins pointed out, with a rapturous air, the fine proportion and finished ornaments, they followed the servants through an antechamber to the room where Lady Catherine, her daughter, and Mrs. Jenkinson were sitting. Her Ladyship, with great condescension, arose to receive them; and as Mrs. Collins had settled it with her husband that the office of introduction should be hers, it was performed in a proper manner, without any of those apologies and thanks which he would have thought necessary.
vi: From the foyer, where Mr. Collins enthusiastically pointed out the harmonious proportions and decorative patterns, they followed the servant through the antechamber and then entered a room where Lady Catherine, her daughter, and Mrs. Jenkinson were seated. The lady, with a formally humble demeanor, stood up to greet them. Since Mrs. Collins had agreed with her husband that the introductions should be entirely her responsibility, she carried them out in the proper manner, without the apologies and thanks that her husband might have thought necessary.
tr: They followed the servants from the entrance hall, which Mr. Collins, in a state of rapture, pointed out for its vast dimensions and perfect adornments, through a waiting room, and entered the room where Lady Catherine, her daughter, and Mrs. Jenkinson were seated. Her Ladyship rose with great condescension to receive them; Mrs. Collins, having previously arranged with her husband that the duty of introduction should fall to her, performed the introduction accordingly, without any of the apologies and thanks the man might have deemed necessary.
es: From the entrance hall, whose harmonious proportions and delicate ornamentation Collins enthusiastically pointed out, the servants led them, through an antechamber, to the room where Lady Catherine, her daughter, and Mrs. Jenkinson were. Her Ladyship rose with great kindness to receive them. And as Mrs. Collins had agreed with her husband that she would make the introductions, they took place normally, without the excuses or expressions of gratitude that he would have deemed necessary.

en: In spite of having been at St. James’s, Sir William was so completely awed by the grandeur surrounding him, that he had but just courage enough to make a very low bow, and take his seat without saying a word; and his daughter, frightened almost out of her senses, sat on the edge of her chair, not knowing which way to look. Elizabeth found herself quite equal to the scene, and could observe the three ladies before her composedly. Lady Catherine was a tall, large woman, with strongly-marked features, which might once have been handsome. Her air was not conciliating, nor was her manner of receiving them such as to make her visitors forget their inferior rank. She was not rendered formidable by silence: but whatever she said was spoken in so authoritative a tone as marked her self-importance, and brought Mr. Wickham immediately to Elizabeth’s mind; and, from the observation of the day altogether, she believed Lady Catherine to be exactly what he had represented.
vi: Although present at St. James's Palace, Sir William still felt completely awed by the magnificent surroundings, to the point where he only had the courage to bow very low and then sit down without being able to say a word. His daughter, terrified to the extent of almost losing all her senses, sat on the edge of her seat, not knowing which way to turn. Elizabeth felt herself quite at ease with the setting, able to calmly observe the three women in front of her. Lady Catherine was tall and large, with strong features that might have once been beautiful. Her manner and gestures of greeting did not aim to win affection, such as helping the guests forget their lower status. When silent, she did not seem terrifying, but every word she spoke carried an authoritative tone as if to assert her position. She immediately reminded Elizabeth of Mr. Wickham, and from what she had observed, Elizabeth believed she was exactly the type of person he had described.
tr: Although he had previously been to St. James, Sir William was so astonished by the surrounding splendor that he could only muster the courage to bow deeply and sit down without uttering a word; his daughter, almost fainting from fear, sat on the edge of her seat, not knowing where to look. Elizabeth felt quite at ease and was able to calmly observe the three ladies in front of her. –Lady Catherine was a tall, large woman with stern features that might have been beautiful once. Her demeanor was not conciliatory, and the way she received them did not make her visitors forget their lower status. When silent, she was not intimidating; but she spoke in such an authoritative voice that demonstrated her self-importance, which immediately reminded Elizabeth of Mr. Wickham; after observing her all day, Elizabeth concluded that Lady Catherine was exactly as he had described.
es: Despite having been to St. James, Sir William was so overwhelmed by the grandeur surrounding him that he barely had the courage to make a deep bow and sat down without saying a word. His daughter, frightened and beside herself, also sat on the edge of a chair, not knowing where to look. Elizabeth was as usual, and was able to calmly observe the three ladies in front of her. Lady Catherine was a very tall and stout woman, with extremely pronounced features that must have been beautiful in her youth. She had an air of sufficiency, and her manner of receiving them was not the most appropriate to make her guests forget their inferior rank. When she was silent, she was not at all terrible; but when she spoke, she did so in such an authoritative tone that her importance became overwhelming. Elizabeth remembered Wickham, and her observations during the evening confirmed that Lady Catherine was exactly as he had described her.

en: When, after examining the mother, in whose countenance and deportment she soon found some resemblance of Mr. Darcy, she turned her eyes on the daughter, she could almost have joined in Maria’s astonishment at her being so thin and so small. There was neither in figure nor face any likeness between the ladies. Miss de Bourgh was pale and sickly: her features, though not plain, were insignificant; and she spoke very little, except in a low voice, to Mrs. Jenkinson, in whose appearance there was nothing remarkable, and who was entirely engaged in listening to what she said, and placing a screen in the proper direction before her eyes.
vi: After examining the mother, whose face and gestures vaguely resembled Mr. Darcy, she turned to look at the daughter. She found Maria's surprise understandable, as the girl was too slender and too short. The mother and daughter bore no resemblance to each other in terms of stature or face. Miss De Bourgh had a pale, sickly complexion; her features were unremarkable, though not unattractive. She spoke very little except when addressing Mrs. Jenkinson, in a soft voice. The latter had nothing distinctive in appearance, paying attention only to what Miss De Bourgh said.
tr: After examining the mother, in whom she immediately found a resemblance to Mr. Darcy in her face and posture, and then turning her eyes to the girl, she seemed to share Maria's astonishment at finding her so thin and petite. There was neither stature nor facial similarity among the ladies. Miss de Bourgh looked pale and sickly; her facial features, if not ordinary, were expressionless; she spoke very little and in a low voice only to Mrs. Jenkinson; there was nothing remarkable about Mrs. Jenkinson's appearance, and she was entirely occupied with listening to her and aligning the screen so that the light from the fireplace would not hurt her eyes.
es: After examining the mother, in whose countenance and behavior he immediately found a certain resemblance to Darcy, he turned his eyes towards the daughter, and was almost as astonished as Maria to see her so thin and so small. Both her figure and her face had nothing to do with her mother. Miss de Bourgh was pale and sickly; her features, although not ugly, were insignificant; she spoke little and only whispered to Mrs. Jenkinson, whose appearance was unremarkable and who did nothing but listen to what the girl said to her and place a screen in the right direction to protect her eyes from the sun.

en: After sitting a few minutes, they were all sent to one of the windows to admire the view, Mr. Collins attending them to point out its beauties, and Lady Catherine kindly informing them that it was much better worth looking at in the summer.
vi: After sitting for a few minutes, they were led to a window to enjoy the view. Mr. Collins followed to point out the beauties, and Lady Catherine politely mentioned that the scenery was more beautiful in the summer.
tr: After sitting for a few minutes, they were all sent to the window to enjoy the view; Mr. Collins accompanied them to point out the beauties of the scenery, and Lady Catherine remarked that it should really be seen in the summer.
es: After sitting for a few minutes, they were taken to one of the windows to admire the view; Mr. Collins accompanied them to properly point out its beauty, and Lady Catherine kindly informed them that in summer the view was much better.

en: The dinner was exceedingly handsome, and there were all the servants, and all the articles of plate which Mr. Collins had promised; and, as he had likewise foretold, he took his seat at the bottom of the table, by her Ladyship’s desire, and looked as if he felt that life could furnish nothing greater. He carved and ate and praised with delighted alacrity; and every dish was commended first by him, and then by Sir William, who was now enough recovered to echo whatever his son-in-law said, in a manner which Elizabeth wondered Lady Catherine could bear. But Lady Catherine seemed gratified by their excessive admiration, and gave most gracious smiles, especially when any dish on the table proved a novelty to them. The party did not supply much conversation.
