Elizabeth was ready to speak whenever there was an opening, but she was seated between Charlotte and Miss de Bourgh—the former of whom was engaged in listening to Lady Catherine, and the latter said not a word to her all the dinnertime. Mrs. Jenkinson was chiefly employed in watching how little Miss de Bourgh ate, pressing her to try some other dish and fearing she was indisposed. Maria thought speaking out of the question, and the gentlemen did nothing but eat and admire.
vi: The dinner was exceedingly sumptuous. All the servants and every piece of glassware and dishware that Mr. Collins had mentioned were present. As he had been forewarned, he sat down at the end of the table; according to the Lady's wishes, and acting as if nothing in life could be greater for him, he carved the food, eating and praising with all his quick words. Every dish was praised, first through his words, then through Sir William's, who had recovered enough to echo every word his son-in-law said, in a manner that made Elizabeth wonder if Lady Catherine could endure it. But Lady Catherine seemed pleased with the excessive praise, smiling very graciously, especially when there was a dish that was new to them. They did not converse much with each other. Elizabeth was ready to respond whenever spoken to, but she sat between Charlotte and Miss De Bourgh – the former only focused on listening to Lady Catherine, and the latter did not say a word throughout the meal. Mrs. Jenkinson primarily concerned herself with overseeing Miss De Bourgh's eating, urging her to try various dishes; worried she wasn't eating well. Maria could not say anything; the men only ate and praised.
tr: The meal was extremely delightful, and all those servants and all that tableware Mr. Collins had promised were there; as he had mentioned beforehand, he took his place at the other end of the table at the behest of her ladyship, and he looked like someone who thought life could offer no more. He cut up his food, ate, and praised it with delightful care; each dish was complimented separately, first by him, then by Sir William; Sir William had by then recovered enough to repeat everything his son-in-law said, in a manner that Elizabeth could not understand how Lady Catherine could endure. But Lady Catherine seemed to take pleasure in their excessive admiration and distributed generous smiles, especially when a dish appeared that they seemed not to have tasted before. The company was not very talkative. Elizabeth was ready to speak whenever she found a gap, but she was seated between Charlotte and Miss de Bourgh – the former was busy listening to Lady Catherine, and the latter did not say a single word to her throughout the meal. Mrs. Jenkinson was mostly occupied with observing how little Miss de Bourgh ate, insisting she try another dish, and fearing she had no appetite. Maria thought that conversation was out of the question, while the gentleman did nothing but eat and admire.
es: The dinner was excellent, and all the servants and the silverware that Collins had promised were brought out; and just as he had predicted, he took a seat at the head of the table at Her Ladyship's request, making it seem as if life had nothing more important to offer him. He carved, ate, and praised everything with delight and alacrity. Each dish was first praised by him and then by Sir William, who had recovered enough to echo everything his son-in-law said, so much so that Elizabeth couldn't understand how Lady Catherine could tolerate them. But Lady Catherine seemed pleased with such excessive admiration and smiled kindly, especially when a dish was new to them. The others said almost nothing. Elizabeth was ready to speak as soon as she was given the opportunity; but she was seated between Charlotte and Miss de Bourgh, and the former was busy listening to Lady Catherine, while the latter did not open her mouth throughout the meal. Miss Jenkinson's main occupation was to watch over the little that Miss de Bourgh ate, insistently asking her to take another dish, fearing all the time that she was unwell. Maria thought it best not to speak, and the gentlemen did nothing but eat and praise.

en: When the ladies returned to the drawing-room, there was little to be done but to hear Lady Catherine talk, which she did without any intermission till coffee came in, delivering her opinion on every subject in so decisive a manner as proved that she was not used to have her judgment controverted. She inquired into Charlotte’s domestic concerns familiarly and minutely, and gave her a great deal of advice as to the management of them all; told her how everything ought to be regulated in so small a family as hers, and instructed her as to the care of her cows and her poultry. Elizabeth found that nothing was beneath this great lady’s attention which could furnish her with an occasion for dictating to others. In the intervals of her discourse with Mrs. Collins, she addressed a variety of questions to Maria and Elizabeth, but especially to the latter, of whose connections she knew the least, and who, she observed to Mrs. Collins, was a very genteel, pretty kind of girl. She asked her at different times how many sisters she had, whether they were older or younger than herself, whether any of them were likely to be married, whether they were handsome, where they had been educated, what carriage her father kept, and what had been her mother’s maiden name? Elizabeth felt all the impertinence of her questions, but answered them very composedly. Lady Catherine then observed,—
vi: When the women returned to the living room, they did nothing more than listen to Lady Catherine speak. She spoke incessantly until the servants brought out the coffee. She gave her opinion on every subject with a decisive manner as if to demonstrate that she was not accustomed to being contradicted. She inquired knowledgeably and meticulously about the concerns in Charlotte's family life, giving her much advice on managing everything; she told her how to coordinate everything in a small household; she instructed her on how to take care of her cattle and poultry. Elizabeth noticed that nothing escaped her attention, giving her the opportunity to impose her opinions on others. Between conversations with Mrs. Collins, Lady Catherine asked many questions of Maria and Elizabeth, especially Elizabeth. She knew the least about Elizabeth and remarked to Mrs. Collins that Elizabeth was a gentle and pretty young woman. She asked her many questions, how many sisters she had, if any were about to get married, whether they were beautiful, how educated they were, what kind of carriage her father had, and what her mother's maiden name was. Elizabeth found all her questions irrelevant but calmly answered them. Then Lady Catherine remarked:
tr: When the ladies returned to the sitting room, there was little to do but listen to Lady Catherine's conversation; she talked incessantly until the coffee arrived, expressing her opinions on every subject with such a definitive manner that it was clear she was not accustomed to having her judgments questioned. She closely and meticulously inquired into Charlotte's household affairs and gave her plenty of advice on how to manage everything; she explained how everything should be organized in a small family like hers, and gave lessons on the care of her cows and chickens. Elizabeth noticed that nothing was beneath this grand lady's interest, as long as it provided her with the opportunity to give instructions to others. In the midst of her conversation with Mrs. Collins, she directed various questions to Maria and Elizabeth, but especially to Elizabeth; she did not know her relatives and told Mrs. Collins that she was a very elegant and beautiful girl. At different times, she asked Elizabeth how many sisters she had, whether they were older or younger than her, whether any of them were likely to get married, whether they were beautiful, where they were educated, what kind of carriages her father had, and her mother's maiden name. –Elizabeth, though she felt the impertinence of her questions, answered quite calmly. –Lady Catherine then made this observation,
es: When the ladies returned to the drawing room, they had nothing else to do but listen to Lady Catherine, who spoke without interruption until coffee was served, expressing her opinion on all kinds of matters in such a decided manner that it was clear she was not used to being contradicted. She questioned Charlotte minutely and with great familiarity about her domestic affairs, giving her a multitude of advice; she told her that everything should be very well organized in a family as small as hers, and instructed her even in the care of the cows and chickens. Elizabeth saw that there was nothing under the attention of this great lady that did not offer her the opportunity to dictate orders to others. In the intervals of her discourse to Mrs. Collins, she directed several questions to Maria and Elizabeth, but especially to the latter, about whose family she knew nothing, and who, as she told Mrs. Collins, seemed to her a very gentle and pretty girl. She asked her, on various occasions, how many sisters she had, whether they were older or younger than her, if any of them were about to be married, if they were pretty, where they had been educated, what kind of carriage her father had, and what her mother's maiden name had been. Elizabeth noticed the impertinence of her questions, but answered all of them with composure. Lady Catherine then observed:

en: “Your father’s estate is entailed on Mr. Collins, I think? For your sake,” turning to Charlotte, “I am glad of it; but otherwise I see no occasion for entailing estates from the female line. It was not thought necessary in Sir Lewis de Bourgh’s family. Do you play and sing, Miss Bennet?”
vi: - Her father's estate is to be inherited by Mr. Collins in order, as I heard. Then she turned to Charlotte: - I am happy for you, but on the other hand, I do not see the opportunity to pass on the inheritance through the female line. In the family of Mr. Lewis De Bourgh, this is considered unnecessary. Do you pursue music and vocal arts, Miss Bennet?
tr: "Your father's estate is mortgaged to Mr. Collins, I believe. From your perspective," he turned to Charlotte, "this is fortunate; but in fact, mortgaging the estate to anyone other than the daughters is not acceptable. –In Sir Lewis de Bourgh's family, this has not been deemed necessary. Do you know how to play the piano, sing, Miss Bennet?"
es: ––I understand that your father's property is to be inherited by Mr. Collins. I congratulate you ––he said, turning to Charlotte––; but I see no reason to bequeath the possessions outside the female line. In Sir Lewis de Bourgh's family, it was not done that way. Do you play and sing, Miss Bennet?

en: “A little.”
vi: - Just a little.
tr: "A little." "Ah!
es: ––A little. ––Ah!

en: “Oh then—some time or other we shall be happy to hear you. Our instrument is a capital one, probably superior to —— you shall try it some day. Do your sisters play and sing?”
vi: - Ah! Then at some point, we would be delighted to hear you perform. Our musical instruments are of good quality, even better. You should try them someday. Do your sisters study these arts as well?
tr: Then we would be happy to listen to you sometime. Our piano is one of the best, probably better than yours– You should try it one day. Do your siblings also play and sing?"
es: Then we will have the pleasure of hearing you at some point. Our piano is excellent, probably better than... One day you will try it. And your sisters, do they play and sing as well?

en: “One of them does.”
vi: - There is a person.
tr: "One of them."
es: ––One of them, yes.

en: “Why did not you all learn? You ought all to have learned. The Miss Webbs all play, and their father has not so good an income as yours. Do you draw?”
vi: - Why don't all of you study? All of you need to study. The Webb sisters all study, while their father doesn't have as much income as your father. Do you study painting?
tr: "Why didn't all of you learn? –All of you should have learned. All the Webblers know, and their father's income isn't as good as yours. –Will you draw a picture?"
es: ––And why not all of them? All of them should have learned. The Misses Webb all play, and their parents are not as rich as yours. Do you draw?

en: “No, not at all.”
vi: - No, no one is studying.
tr: "No, never."
es: ––No, nothing.

en: “What, none of you?”
vi: - What, no one?
tr: "What do you mean, none of you?""
es: ––How? None of you?

en: “Not one.”
vi: - No one.
tr: "None of us."
es: ––None.

en: “That is very strange. But I suppose you had no opportunity. Your mother should have taken you to town every spring for the benefit of masters.”
vi: - That's really strange. But I guess you girls didn't have the chance. Your mother should have taken you to the city every spring to study with renowned artists.
tr: "This is very strange. But you probably haven't had the opportunity. Your mother should have taken you to the city every spring to benefit from the teachers."
es: ––It's very strange. I suppose they haven't had the opportunity. Their mother must have taken them to the city every spring to have good teachers.

en: “My mother would have no objection, but my father hates London.”
vi: - Our mother surely wouldn't object, but our father hates London.
tr: "My mother wouldn't object, but my father hates London."
es: ––My mother wouldn't have objected, but my father hates London.

en: “Has your governess left you?”
vi: - Has your tutor quit already?
tr: "Did your governess leave you?"
es: ––And is your governess still with you?

en: “We never had any governess.”
vi: - We have never had a tutor.
tr: "We never had a governess."
es: ––We have never had a governess.

en: “No governess! How was that possible? Five daughters brought up at home without a governess! I never heard of such a thing. Your mother must have been quite a slave to your education.”
vi: - No governess! How can that be? Five daughters brought up in the house without a governess! I have never heard of such a thing. Your mother must have been a slave to your education.
tr: "Not at all! How is that possible? Raising five girls at home without a governess! I've never heard of such a thing. Your mother must have worked like a slave for your education."
es: ––They have never had a governess! How is that possible? Five daughters educated at home without a governess! I've never seen anything like it. Their mother must have been a true slave to their education.

en: Elizabeth could hardly help smiling, as she assured her that had not been the case.
vi: Elizabeth couldn't help but smile as she explained that it wasn't like that.
tr: Elizabeth couldn't help but smile as she said that wasn't the case.
es: Elizabeth could hardly suppress a smile as she assured him that it had not been so.

en: “Then who taught you? who attended to you? Without a governess, you must have been neglected.”
vi: - Then, who teaches you? Who takes care of you? Without a tutor, you must have been neglected.
tr: "So, who educated you? Who looked after you? You must have been neglected without a governess."
es: ––So, who educated them? Who took care of them? Without a governess, they must have been neglected.

en: “Compared with some families, I believe we were; but such of us as wished to learn never wanted the means. We were always encouraged to read, and had all the masters that were necessary. Those who chose to be idle certainly might.”
vi: - Compared to other families, I believe we were neglected, but if we wanted to learn, we were not lacking in resources. We were always encouraged to read books, and had tutors for all subjects when necessary. Those who wanted leisure could have leisure.
tr: "According to some families, I'm sure we were privileged; but those of us who wanted to learn were never deprived of the necessary means. We were always encouraged to read and had all the necessary teachers. But those who chose idleness were also free to choose it."
es: ––In comparison with some families, I'm not saying otherwise; but for those of us who wanted to learn, we never lacked the means. We were always encouraged to read, and we had all the teachers we needed. It is true that those who preferred to be idle, could be.

en: “Ay, no doubt: but that is what a governess will prevent; and if I had known your mother, I should have advised her most strenuously to engage one. I always say that nothing is to be done in education without steady and regular instruction, and nobody but a governess can give it. It is wonderful how many families I have been the means of supplying in that way. I am always glad to get a young person well placed out. Four nieces of Mrs. Jenkinson are most delightfully situated through my means; and it was but the other day that I recommended another young person, who was merely accidentally mentioned to me, and the family are quite delighted with her. Mrs. Collins, did I tell you of Lady Metcalfe’s calling yesterday to thank me? She finds Miss Pope a treasure. ‘Lady Catherine,’ said she, ‘you have given me a treasure.’ Are any of your younger sisters out, Miss Bennet?”
vi: - Ah, that's right, but a tutor can prevent this. If I had known your mother, I could have urgently advised her to have a tutor. I always say that nothing can be achieved in education without long-term and regular teaching, and only a tutor can accomplish this. It's quite wonderful to think about how many families I've had the opportunity to assist in this way. I'm always delighted to support a young person to achieve a good position. Four of Mrs. Jenkinson's nephews have been arranged in the best manner through my means. Just recently, I recommended a young person who was only mentioned to me by someone else, and the family is very happy with her. Mrs. Collins, did I tell you about Lady Metcalfe visiting me yesterday to thank me? She considers Miss Pope a treasure. She said: “Lady Catherine, you have given me a treasure.” Miss Bennet, have any of your sisters ever been out in society?
tr: "Yes, undoubtedly; but that is precisely what a governess is for; if I knew your mother, I would insistently advise her to hire one. I always say, nothing can be achieved in education without continuous and regular lessons, and only a governess can provide those lessons. You would be amazed if you knew how many families' needs I have met in this regard. I am always pleased to place a young person in a good position. Thanks to me, Mrs. Jenkinson's four nieces have secured very good positions; just the other day, I recommended another young girl who was mentioned to me by chance, and the family was very pleased with her. Mrs. Collins, did I tell you that Lady Metcalfe came to thank me yesterday? Miss Pope was a treasure for her. 'Lady Catherine,' she said, 'you have given me a treasure.' Have your younger sisters been presented to society, Miss Bennet?"
es: ––Yes, I don't doubt it! And that is what a governess can prevent, and if I had known your mother, I would have insisted with all my might that she take one. I always maintain that in matters of education, nothing is achieved without solid and orderly instruction, and only a governess can provide that. You should see the number of families I have guided in this regard! I love to see girls well-placed. Four nieces of Mrs. Jenkinson were very well placed thanks to me, and just the other day I recommended another young woman whom I heard about by chance, and the family is very happy with her. Mrs. Collins, did I tell you that Lady Metcalfe was here yesterday to thank me? She assures that Miss Pope is a treasure. “Lady Catherine,” she said to me, “you have given me a treasure.” Have any of your younger sisters been presented to society yet, Miss Bennet?

en: “Yes, ma’am, all.”
vi: - Yes, Madam, all of it.
tr: "Yes, sir, all of them."
es: ––Yes, ma'am, all of them.

en: “All! What, all five out at once? Very odd! And you only the second. The younger ones out before the elder are married! Your younger sisters must be very young?”
vi: - All of them! What, all five girls at once? How strange! And you are only the second child in the family. The younger sisters are socializing before the eldest gets married! Your younger sisters must be very young?!
tr: "All of you! –All five of you at once? Very strange! –Moreover, you are only the second one. –The younger ones are coming out before the older ones get married! –Are your siblings very young?"
es: ––All of them! How! All five at once? How strange! And you are only the second. The younger ones presented in society before the older ones get married! Your sisters must be very young...

en: “Yes, my youngest is not sixteen. Perhaps she is full young to be much in company. But really, ma’am, I think it would be very hard upon younger sisters that they should not have their share of society and amusement, because the elder may not have the means or inclination to marry early. The last born has as good a right to the pleasures of youth as the first. And to be kept back on such a motive! I think it would not be very likely to promote sisterly affection or delicacy of mind.”
vi: - Yes, the youngest one is not yet sixteen. Perhaps she is still too young to socialize widely. But, madam, I truly think it is too harsh for the younger sisters if they are not allowed to socialize and enjoy themselves just because the eldest sister is not yet in a position or does not intend to marry soon. I believe the youngest child also has the right to enjoy the pleasures of youth like the eldest. And being so restrained, I think it is difficult to foster sisterly bonds or develop the subtlety of the soul.
tr: "Yes, our youngest is not even sixteen. Maybe too young to be among too many people. But really, sir, it would be very sad if the young ones were deprived of gatherings and entertainments just because the elders do not have the means or desire to marry early. The youngest has as much right to enjoy the pleasures of youth as the firstborn. To be kept closed for such a reason! I don't think it would be very helpful in developing a sense of brotherhood or understanding."
es: ––Yes; the youngest is not yet sixteen years old. Perhaps she is too young to have been introduced to society. But in reality, madam, I believe it would be very unfair for the younger sisters to be unable to enjoy society and its amenities, just because the older ones do not have the means or desire to marry soon. The youngest daughter has as much right to the pleasures of youth as the first. Delaying them for that reason, I believe, would not be the most appropriate way to foster fraternal affection and delicacy of thought. ––"Goodness!" ––said His Lordship––.

en: “Upon my word,” said her Ladyship, “you give your opinion very decidedly for so young a person. Pray, what is your age?”
vi: - You have quite a decisive opinion for someone young. May I ask, how old are you?
tr: "Honestly," said the lady, "you express your opinions very decisively for someone so young. For God's sake, how old are you?"
es: For being so young, you express your opinions very decisively. Tell me, how old are you?

en: “With three younger sisters grown up,” replied Elizabeth, smiling, “your Ladyship can hardly expect me to own it.”
vi: Elizabeth smiled: - With three younger sisters who have grown up, Madam can hardly expect me to reveal my age publicly.
tr: "Since my three younger sisters are grown," replied Elizabeth with a smile, "I suppose her ladyship cannot expect me to state my age."
es: ––With three grown-up sisters behind me ––replied Elizabeth, smiling––, Your Lordship cannot expect me to confess it.

en: Lady Catherine seemed quite astonished at not receiving a direct answer; and Elizabeth suspected herself to be the first creature who had ever dared to trifle with so much dignified impertinence.
vi: Lady Catherine seemed quite surprised not to receive a direct answer, and Elizabeth guessed she was the first creature to dare to disregard such an intrusion into personal matters!
tr: Lady Catherine seemed very surprised not to receive a direct answer; Elizabeth suspected that she was the first person to dare to take such dignified impudence lightly.
es: Lady Catherine was astonished not to have received a direct response; and Elizabeth suspected that she was the first person who had dared to mock such majestic impertinence.

en: “You cannot be more than twenty, I am sure,—therefore you need not conceal your age.”
vi: - I'm sure you're not yet twenty, so you don't need to hide your age.
tr: "You can't be more than twenty, I'm sure, –so there's no need to hide your age."
es: ––You can't be more than twenty, I'm sure; so you don't need to hide your age.

en: “I am not one-and-twenty.”
vi: - I am not yet twenty-one.
tr: "I haven't turned twenty-one yet.""
es: ––I haven't turned twenty-one yet.

en: When the gentlemen had joined them, and tea was over, the card tables were placed. Lady Catherine, Sir William, and Mr. and Mrs. Collins sat down to quadrille; and as Miss De Bourgh chose to play at cassino, the two girls had the honour of assisting Mrs. Jenkinson to make up her party. Their table was superlatively stupid. Scarcely a syllable was uttered that did not relate to the game, except when Mrs. Jenkinson expressed her fears of Miss De Bourgh’s being too hot or too cold, or having too much or too little light. A great deal more passed at the other table. Lady Catherine was generally speaking—stating the mistakes of the three others, or relating some anecdote of herself. Mr. Collins was employed in agreeing to everything her Ladyship said, thanking her for every fish he won, and apologizing if he thought he won too many. Sir William did not say much. He was storing his memory with anecdotes and noble names.
vi: When they joined the group and had finished their tea, they set up the card tables. Lady Charlotte, Sir William, and Mr. and Mrs. Collins sat down to play a four-person card game. Since Miss De Bourgh wanted to play a different game, the two young ladies had the honor of forming a table with Mrs. Jenkinson. This group was extremely dull. Hardly a word was spoken that did not pertain to the game, except when Mrs. Jenkinson expressed concern that Miss De Bourgh might be too hot or too cold, or that there was too much or too little light. The other table had more going on. Lady Catherine talked more – pointing out the faults of the other three, or recounting some anecdotes about herself. Mr. Collins agreed with everything Lady Catherine said, thanked her whenever he scored points, and apologized when he thought he was winning too much. Sir William did not say much. His mind was busy remembering the anecdotes and the names of the aristocratic figures.
tr: When the gentlemen joined them, and the tea was finished, the game tables were set up. Lady Catherine, Sir William, and Mr. and Mrs. Collins sat down to quadrille; since Miss de Bourgh preferred to play cassino, the two girls supported Mr. Jenkinson to form a group with her. The tables were extraordinarily dull. Not a single syllable unrelated to the game came out of anyone's mouth; only Mrs. Jenkinson expressed her concerns about whether Miss de Bourgh was too hot or too cold, whether her clothing was too thick or too thin. More was happening at the other table. Lady Catherine was generally speaking – pointing out the mistakes of the other three people or telling an anecdote about herself. Mr. Collins was busy approving everything her ladyship said, thanking her for every chip he won, and apologizing if he thought he had won too much. Sir William did not say much. He was storing anecdotes and noble names in his memory.
es: When the gentlemen entered and finished having tea, the game tables were set up. Lady Catherine, Sir William, and the Collinses sat down to play a game of quadrille, and as Miss de Bourgh preferred to play casino, Elizabeth and Maria had the honor of helping Mrs. Jenkinson complete her table, which was supremely boring. Hardly a syllable was uttered that did not pertain to the game, except when Mrs. Jenkinson expressed her fears that Miss de Bourgh might be too hot or too cold, too much light or too little. The other table was much more lively. Lady Catherine almost never stopped talking, highlighting the mistakes of her fellow players or recounting some anecdote about herself. Collins did nothing but affirm everything Her Ladyship said, thanking her every time he won and apologizing when he thought his winnings were excessive. Sir William did not say much. He devoted himself to recalling in his memory all those anecdotes and so many illustrious names.

en: When Lady Catherine and her daughter had played as long as they chose, the tables were broken up, the carriage was offered to Mrs. Collins, gratefully accepted, and immediately ordered. The party then gathered round the fire to hear Lady Catherine determine what weather they were to have on the morrow. From these instructions they were summoned by the arrival of the coach; and with many speeches of thankfulness on Mr. Collins’s side, and as many bows on Sir William’s, they departed. As soon as they had driven from the door, Elizabeth was called on by her cousin to give her opinion of all that she had seen at Rosings, which, for Charlotte’s sake, she made more favourable than it really was. But her commendation, though costing her some trouble, could by no means satisfy Mr. Collins, and he was very soon obliged to take her Ladyship’s praise into his own hands.
vi: When Lady Catherine and her daughter decided it was enough, they put away the card tables, Mrs. Collins was offered the carriage and she gladly accepted. Then the whole group sat around the fireplace to hear Lady Catherine decide what the weather would be like the next day. Then they were informed that the carriage had arrived, with many expressions of gratitude from Mr. Collins along with many bows from Sir William, they bid each other farewell. As soon as they left, Mr. Collins asked Elizabeth about her impressions of Rosings. To please Charlotte, she made more favorable comments than she truly felt. But her words of praise, though they made her somewhat uncomfortable, still could not satisfy Mr. Collins, so he had to add more of his own to further extol Lady Catherine.
tr: After Lady Catherine and her daughter played until they were bored, the tables were cleared, a carriage was offered to Mrs. Collins, the offer was gratefully accepted, and the carriage was immediately ordered. Then the group gathered around the fire to listen to Lady Catherine decide what the weather would be like the next day. With the arrival of the carriage, they bid farewell to these observations; they departed with Mr. Collins's numerous expressions of gratitude and Sir William's endless salutations. As soon as the carriage left the door, Elizabeth was invited by her cousin to comment on what they had seen at Rosings; for Charlotte's sake, Elizabeth made a more favorable comment than she actually felt. But the praises she struggled so hard to fabricate did not satisfy Mr. Collins in any way, and soon Mr. Collins had to take the task of praising her ladyship into his own hands.
es: When Lady Catherine and her daughter grew tired of playing, the tables were cleared, and they offered the carriage to Mrs. Collins, who accepted it very gratefully, and immediately gave orders to bring it. The gathering then congregated by the fire to hear Lady Catherine predict what the weather would be like the next day. At that moment, they were informed that the carriage was at the door, and with many bows from Sir William and many expressions of gratitude from Mr. Collins, they took their leave. As soon as they left the hallway behind, Mr. Collins invited Elizabeth to express her opinion on what she had seen at Rosings, to which she agreed, only for Charlotte's sake, exaggerating it more than she felt. But no matter how hard she tried, her praise did not satisfy Mr. Collins, who soon found himself obliged to take on the task of praising Her Ladyship himself.

en: CHAPTER XXX.
vi: Chapter 30
tr: Chapter VII
es: CHAPTER XXX

en: SIR WILLIAM stayed only a week at Hunsford; but his visit was long enough to convince him of his daughter’s being most comfortably settled, and of her possessing such a husband and such a neighbour as were not often met with. While Sir William was with them, Mr. Collins devoted his mornings to driving him out in his gig, and showing him the country: but when he went away, the whole family returned to their usual employments, and Elizabeth was thankful to find that they did not see more of her cousin by the alteration; for the chief of the time between breakfast and dinner was now passed by him either at work in the garden, or in reading and writing, and looking out of window in his own book room, which fronted the road. The room in which the ladies sat was backwards. Elizabeth at first had rather wondered that Charlotte should not prefer the dining parlour for common use; it was a better sized room, and had a pleasanter aspect: but she soon saw that her friend had an excellent reason for what she did, for Mr. Collins would undoubtedly have been much less in his own apartment had they sat in one equally lively; and she gave Charlotte credit for the arrangement.
vi: Sir William stayed in Huntsford for only a week, but it was enough for him to believe that his daughter was settled in the most satisfactory manner, that she had a husband and neighbors that were not easy to find. While Sir William was staying there, Mr. Collins spent every morning driving him out into the countryside. When he left, the whole family returned to their usual routine. Elizabeth was pleased to see that they seldom saw him, for in the time between breakfast and dinner, he was either working in the garden or reading and writing, sitting in his own study at the front of the house looking out the window, while the women's gathering room was at the back of the house. At first, Catherine was puzzled that Charlotte did not want to use the dining room for everyone to gather in, as it was quite spacious and had a better view, but soon she saw that her friend had a very good reason, for if they used the large room, Mr. Collins would seldom be in his own study.
tr: Sir William stayed in Hunsford for only a week, but his visit was long enough to convince him that his daughter had made an extraordinary marriage, and that she had a rare husband and neighbor. While Sir William was with them, Mr. Collins devoted his mornings to taking him around the countryside in his one-horse carriage; but after he left, the whole family returned to their usual routines; Elizabeth was glad that she did not have to see her cousin more often due to the change; Mr. Collins spent most of the time between breakfast and dinner either working in the garden or reading and writing, or watching the outside from the window of his reading room facing the front road. The room where the ladies sat was at the back. Elizabeth was initially surprised that Charlotte had not chosen the dining room for everyday use; it was a larger room and had a more pleasant view; but she soon saw that her friend had an excellent reason for doing so, because if they sat in an equally beautiful room, Mr. Collins would undoubtedly spend less time in his own room; Elizabeth appreciated Charlotte for this arrangement.
es: Sir William spent no more than a week in Hunsford, but it was enough to convince him that his daughter was very well situated and that a husband like that and a neighborhood like that were not often found. While he was there, Collins dedicated the morning to taking him around in his carriage to show him the countryside; but as soon as he left, the family returned to their usual occupations. Elizabeth was grateful that with the change in routine, she no longer had to see her cousin so frequently, as most of the time between lunch and dinner, Collins spent working in the garden, reading, writing, or looking out the window of his study, which faced the road. The room where the ladies usually stayed faced the back of the house. At first, it surprised Elizabeth that Charlotte did not prefer to be in the dining room, which was a larger and more pleasant-looking room. But soon she saw that her friend had excellent reasons for acting this way, as Collins would have undoubtedly spent less time in his room if they had enjoyed one as large as his. And Elizabeth approved of Charlotte's attitude.

en: From the drawing-room they could distinguish nothing in the lane, and were indebted to Mr. Collins for the knowledge of what carriages went along, and how often especially Miss De Bourgh drove by in her phaeton, which he never failed coming to inform them of, though it happened almost every day. She not unfrequently stopped at the Parsonage, and had a few minutes’ conversation with Charlotte, but was scarcely ever prevailed on to get out.
vi: From the living room, they couldn't distinguish anything on the road, and they remembered Mr. Collins telling them what kind of carriage was passing by, especially how often Miss De Bourgh would come by in her four-wheeled carriage, which he always informed them of in advance even though she came almost every day. She often stopped in front of the Parsonage and chatted for a few minutes with Charlotte but almost never stepped out of the carriage.
tr: While they were in the living room, they were unaware of what was happening on the road; they could only learn which cars passed by thanks to Mr. Collins, who would promptly inform them of Miss de Bourgh's every passing, even though she passed almost every day. Occasionally, he would stop at the lodge and talk to Charlotte for a few minutes, but he was reluctant to get out of the car.
es: From the living room, they couldn't see the road, so it was always Collins who informed them about the passing cars and especially about how often Miss de Bourgh crossed in her phaeton, something he never failed to report even though it happened almost every day. Miss de Bourgh usually stopped at the house to chat with Charlotte for a few minutes, but it was difficult to convince her to get out of the carriage.

en: Very few days passed in which Mr. Collins did not walk to Rosings, and not many in which his wife did not think it necessary to go likewise; and till Elizabeth recollected that there might be other family livings to be disposed of, she could not understand the sacrifice of so many hours. Now and then they were honoured with a call from her Ladyship, and nothing escaped her observation that was passing in the room during these visits. She examined into their employments, looked at their work, and advised them to do it differently; found fault with the arrangement of the furniture, or detected the housemaid in negligence; and if she accepted any refreshment, seemed to do it only for the sake of finding out that Mrs. Collins’s joints of meat were too large for her family.
vi: There were very few days when Mr. Collins did not go to Rosings, and there were also many days when his wife thought it unnecessary to do so. Elizabeth could not understand the need to sacrifice so much time until she remembered that there might be other family activities that needed to be excluded. Occasionally, they had the honor of being visited by the Lady, and nothing that happened during these visits escaped her observation. She would scrutinize the couple's lifestyle, look into their work and advise them to do it differently, criticize the arrangement of the furniture, or notice the servants' negligence. If she accepted to have refreshments, it seemed she did so only to find out that Mrs. Collins's portions of meat were too large for the family.
tr: Few days passed without Mr. Collins walking to Rosings, and his wife also deemed it necessary to go as well; Elizabeth did not understand the sacrifice of so many hours until she realized there might be other church parishes to be distributed. Occasionally, they were honored by a visit from her ladyship; during these visits, nothing that happened in the room escaped her notice. She examined their occupations, looked at the work they produced, and advised them to do it differently; she found fault with the arrangement of the furniture or detected the servant's neglect; if she accepted to eat or drink something, it seemed she did so only to see that Mrs. Collins's meat allowance was too much for her family.
es: Few days passed without Collins taking a walk to Rosings, and his wife often felt it her duty to do the same; Elizabeth, until she remembered that there might be other families willing to do the same, did not understand the sacrifice of so many hours. From time to time, he honored them with a visit, during which nothing that happened in the drawing room escaped his notice. Indeed, he paid attention to what they were doing, looked at their work and advised them to do it differently, found faults in the arrangement of the furniture or discovered negligence in the maid; if he accepted any refreshment, it seemed he did so only to point out that the meat portions were too large for them.

en: Elizabeth soon perceived, that though this great lady was not in the commission of the peace for the county, she was a most active magistrate in her own parish, the minutest concerns of which were carried to her by Mr. Collins; and whenever any of the cottagers were disposed to be quarrelsome, discontented, or too poor, she sallied forth into the village to settle their differences, silence their complaints, and scold them into harmony and plenty.
vi: Elizabeth soon learned that, although this Lady did not hold any civil office for the local county, she was the most active magistrate in her parish, and every minor issue was reported to her by Mr. Collins. When the local residents quarreled with each other, expressed dissatisfaction, or fell into distress, she would come to resolve the disagreements, quell the complaints, and reprimand them to bring them into a state of harmony and prosperity.
tr: Elizabeth soon realized that although this great lady was not a member of the provincial peace committee, she was very active as a judge in her own village; Mr. Collins would bring her detailed reports, and whenever one of the villagers fought, got into trouble, or became very poor, she would immediately go to the village, resolve disputes, silence complaints, and give them a scolding while calling for unity and solidarity.
es: Elizabeth soon realized that although the peace of the county was not entrusted to that great lady, she was an active magistrate in her own parish, whose details were communicated to her by Collins.

en: “he never failed to inform them”
vi: They were invited to dine at Rosings about twice a week.
tr: Elizabeth soon realized that although this great lady was not a member of the provincial peace committee, she was very active as a judge in her own village; Mr. Collins would bring her detailed reports, and whenever one of the villagers fought, got into trouble, or became very poor, she would immediately go to the village, resolve disputes, silence complaints, and give them a scolding while calling for unity and solidarity.
es: Whenever any of the villagers were about to cause trouble or felt discontented or helpless, Lady Catherine would personally go to the required place to settle the differences and reprimand them, restoring harmony or ensuring abundance.

en: The entertainment of dining at Rosings was repeated about twice a week; and, allowing for the loss of Sir William, and there being only one card-table in the evening, every such entertainment was the counterpart of the first. Their other engagements were few, as the style of living of the neighbourhood in general was beyond the Collinses’ reach. This, however, was no evil to Elizabeth, and upon the whole she spent her time comfortably enough: there were half hours of pleasant conversation with Charlotte, and the weather was so fine for the time of year, that she had often great enjoyment out of doors. Her favourite walk, and where she frequently went while the others were calling on Lady Catherine, was along the open grove which edged that side of the park, where there was a nice sheltered path, which no one seemed to value but herself, and where she felt beyond the reach of Lady Catherine’s curiosity.
vi: After Mr. William had left and there was only one card table, each dining opportunity was no longer as enjoyable as the first evening. They had little chance to interact with anyone else, as the lifestyle of the neighbors did not suit the Collins family. This did not bother Elizabeth. During this time, she felt quite comfortable. She had half-hour conversations with Charlotte each time. The weather was very pleasant for this time of year, so she often enjoyed being outdoors. The path she liked to walk the most, especially when others were invited to Rosings, was the shaded trail along the garden fence that seemed to be favored only by her, where she felt she could escape Lady Catherine's prying eyes.
tr: The evening entertainment at Rosings was repeated twice a week; since Sir William's place was vacant and only one game table was set up throughout the evening, each of these entertainments was a copy of the first. They had very few other occupations, as the lifestyle of the neighborhood generally exceeded Mr. Collins' means. Nevertheless, Elizabeth was not bothered by this and mostly spent her time quite pleasantly; there were sweet half-hour conversations with Charlotte, and the weather was so beautiful for that time of year that she often spent cheerful hours outdoors. When the others went to visit Lady Catherine, she often went for a walk; she had a favorite route; there was a sheltered, beautiful path along the open plain adjacent to that side of the grove that seemed to matter to no one else, and here she felt herself in a place where Lady Catherine's curiosity could not reach.
es: The invitation to dine at Rosings was repeated a couple of times a week, and since Sir William's departure, as there was only one game table during the evening, the entertainment was always the same. They did not have many other commitments, because the lifestyle of the rest of the neighbors was below that of the Collinses. Elizabeth did not mind; she was comfortable with it, spending long periods chatting pleasantly with Charlotte; and since the weather was wonderful, despite the time of year, she amused herself by going out for walks. Her favorite walk, which she often took while the others visited Lady Catherine, was the avenue that bordered one side of the estate where there was a very beautiful and sheltered path that no one but her seemed to appreciate, and on which she was out of Lady Catherine's curious reach.

en: In this quiet way the first fortnight of her visit soon passed away. Easter was approaching, and the week preceding it was to bring an addition to the family at Rosings, which in so small a circle must be important. Elizabeth had heard, soon after her arrival, that Mr. Darcy was expected there in the course of a few weeks; and though there were not many of her acquaintance whom she did not prefer, his coming would furnish one comparatively new to look at in their Rosings parties, and she might be amused in seeing how hopeless Miss Bingley’s designs on him were, by his behaviour to his cousin, for whom he was evidently destined by Lady Catherine, who talked of his coming with the greatest satisfaction, spoke of him in terms of the highest admiration, and seemed almost angry to find that he had already been frequently seen by Miss Lucas and herself.
vi: The first two weeks of Elizabeth's visit passed in this manner. Easter was approaching, and a week before that, a notable person was expected to visit the Rosings family, which, in such a small household, would be a significant event. Elizabeth had heard that Mr. Darcy would be coming. Although there were few people she did not like, his presence would add a new subject for observation within the Rosings family. She might be interested in seeing how Miss Bingley's schemes regarding him would become futile, by examining his attitude towards his cousin, as it was clear that Lady Catherine had decided his fate with her. She had announced his imminent arrival with great satisfaction, speaking of him in terms of admiration, and seemed almost angry upon learning that Miss Lucas and Elizabeth herself had often met him.
tr: The first fifteen days of her visit passed quickly in this tranquility. Easter was approaching, and the week before it, there would be a new addition to the family at Rosings, which must have been significant for such a small circle. Elizabeth had heard shortly after her arrival that Mr. Darcy was expected to come there within a few weeks; although there were few acquaintances she liked less, his arrival would have added someone relatively new to the parties at Rosings; moreover, by observing his behavior towards her cousin, she could amuse herself by seeing how hopeless Miss Bingley's plans regarding him were; Lady Catherine was clearly considering him for her daughter; she spoke of his arrival with great joy, praised him endlessly, and was almost furious when she learned that Miss Lucas and Elizabeth had already seen him many times.
es: With this tranquility, the first fortnight of her stay in Hunsford quickly passed. Easter was approaching, and the week before it was going to bring an addition to the family at Rosings, which, in such a small circle, had to be very important. Shortly after her arrival, Elizabeth heard that Darcy was going to arrive in a few weeks, and although she would have preferred any other of his acquaintances, the truth was that his presence could bring a bit of variety to the evenings at Rosings and that she could amuse herself by seeing the little foundation of Miss Bingley's hopes while observing Darcy's attitude towards Miss de Bourgh, to whom Lady Catherine evidently intended him. Her Ladyship spoke of his coming with enormous satisfaction, and of him, in terms of the highest admiration; and it seemed to bother her that Miss Lucas and Elizabeth had already seen him frequently before.

en: His arrival was soon known at the Parsonage; for Mr. Collins was walking the whole morning within view of the lodges opening into Hunsford Lane, in order to have
vi: Not long after, the entire Parish House knew about his impending visit, because Mr. Collins had spent the entire morning walking around Huntsford spreading the news.
tr: Mr. Darcy's arrival at the parsonage was immediately noticed, because Mr. Collins had spent the entire morning walking within the view of the outbuildings that opened onto Hunsford Road in order to detect the exact moment of his arrival, and after bowing as the carriage turned into the Grove, he had rushed back to the house with the great news.
es: Their arrival was known immediately, for Collins had been strolling all morning with his eyes fixed on the pavilions at the entrance to the Hunsford road; as soon as he saw the carriage enter the estate, he made his corresponding bow, and ran home to deliver the grand news.

en: “The gentlemen accompanied him.”
vi: Not long after, the entire Parish House knew about his impending visit, because Mr. Collins had spent the entire morning walking around Huntsford spreading the news.
tr: Mr. Darcy's arrival at the parsonage was immediately noticed, because Mr. Collins had spent the entire morning walking within the view of the outbuildings that opened onto Hunsford Road in order to detect the exact moment of his arrival, and after bowing as the carriage turned into the Grove, he had rushed back to the house with the great news.
es: Their arrival was known immediately, for Collins had been strolling all morning with his eyes fixed on the pavilions at the entrance to the Hunsford road; as soon as he saw the carriage enter the estate, he made his corresponding bow, and ran home to deliver the grand news.

en: the earliest assurance of it; and, after making his bow as the carriage turned into the park, hurried home with the great intelligence. On the following morning he hastened to Rosings to pay his respects. There were two nephews of Lady Catherine to require them, for Mr. Darcy had brought with him a Colonel Fitzwilliam, the younger son of his uncle, Lord ——; and, to the great surprise of all the party, when Mr. Collins returned, the gentlemen accompanied him. Charlotte had seen them from her husband’s room, crossing the road, and immediately running into the other, told the girls what an honour they might expect, adding,—
vi: After bowing at Rosings Park, he hurried home with the most important news. The next morning, he rushed to Rosings to pay his respects. He needed to greet Lady Catherine's two nephews, as Mr. Darcy had brought along a Colonel Fitzwilliam, the younger son of his uncle. When Mr. Collins returned, the two men followed him. From her husband's room, Charlotte saw them crossing the road. She quickly ran in to inform the women and added:
tr: Mr. Darcy's arrival at the parsonage was immediately noticed, because Mr. Collins had spent the entire morning walking within the view of the outbuildings that opened onto Hunsford Road in order to detect the exact moment of his arrival, and after bowing as the carriage turned into the Grove, he had rushed back to the house with the great news. The next morning, he hurried to Rosings to pay his respects. Lady Catherine had two nephews who commanded respect; Mr. Darcy had brought along Colonel Fitzwilliam, the younger son of his uncle Lord --------, and as Mr. Collins returned home, the two gentlemen accompanied him, causing great astonishment to everyone. Charlotte had seen them from her husband's room, crossing the road; she immediately ran to the other room to tell the girls what an honor awaited them, and added–
es: Their arrival was known immediately, for Collins had been strolling all morning with his eyes fixed on the pavilions at the entrance to the Hunsford road; as soon as he saw the carriage enter the estate, he made his corresponding bow, and ran home to deliver the grand news. The next morning he flew to Rosings to pay his respects. But there was someone else to whom he had to present them, for there he found two of Lady Catherine's nephews. Darcy had come with Colonel Fitzwilliam, the younger son of his uncle Lord; and to the great surprise of the whole house, when Collins returned, both gentlemen accompanied him. Charlotte saw them from her husband's room as they crossed the path, and rushed to the other room to inform the two girls of the great honor that awaited them, and added:

en: “I may thank you, Eliza, for this piece of civility. Mr. Darcy would never have come so soon to wait upon me.”
vi: - She thanks Eliza for this courteous action. Mr. Darcy would never have visited her so quickly.
tr: "I owe you thanks, Eliza, for this kind gesture. Mr. Darcy would not have come to visit me so quickly."
es: ––Elizabeth, it is you whom I must thank for this display of courtesy. Mr. Darcy would not have come to visit me so soon.

en: Elizabeth had scarcely time to disclaim all right to the compliment before their approach was announced by the door-bell, and shortly afterwards the three gentlemen entered the room. Colonel Fitzwilliam, who led the way, was about thirty, not handsome, but in person and address most truly the gentleman. Mr. Darcy looked just as he had been used to look in Hertfordshire, paid his compliments, with his usual reserve, to Mrs. Collins; and whatever might be his feelings towards her friend, met her with every appearance of composure. Elizabeth merely courtesied to him, without saying a word.
vi: Elizabeth had barely had time to decline the praise before the doorbell announced their arrival, and a moment later, three people entered the room. Colonel Fitzwilliam led the way. He was about thirty, not handsome, but his demeanor and speech indicated he was a gentleman. Mr. Darcy looked the same as when he was in Hertfordshire. He greeted Mrs. Collins with his usual reserve. No matter what feelings he had for her friend, he remained composed. Elizabeth merely inclined her head to him, without saying a word.
tr: Before Elizabeth could say that she did not deserve this compliment at all, the doorbell announced their arrival, and shortly after, three gentlemen entered the room. Leading the way, Colonel Fitzwilliam was in his thirties, unpretentious, but a true gentleman in both his actions and speech. Mr. Darcy looked just as he had in Hertfordshire – with his usual reserved demeanor, he complimented Mrs. Collins and, regardless of what he felt towards his friend, looked at her with perfect composure. Elizabeth greeted with a mere bend of her knees, without uttering a single word.
es: Elizabeth barely had time to deny her right to such a compliment, for immediately the bell rang announcing the arrival of the two gentlemen, who shortly after entered the room. Colonel Fitzwilliam was ahead; he was about thirty years old, not handsome, but in his manner and person, he distinguished himself as a gentleman. Darcy was the same as in Hertfordshire; he greeted Mrs. Collins with his usual reserve, and whatever his feelings towards Elizabeth were, he greeted her with apparent impassivity. Elizabeth merely bowed without saying a word.

en: Colonel Fitzwilliam entered into conversation directly, with the readiness and ease of a well-bred man, and talked very pleasantly; but his cousin, after having addressed a slight observation on the house and garden to Mrs. Collins, sat for some time without speaking to anybody. At length, however, his civility was so far awakened as to inquire of Elizabeth after the health of her family. She answered him in the usual way; and, after a moment’s pause, added,—
vi: Colonel Fitzwilliam started the conversation directly with the fluency and ease of a well-educated person, speaking very pleasantly. But his cousin, after making a few remarks to Mrs. Collins about the house and garden, did not say another word to anyone. However, after a while, his politeness awakened, prompting him to inquire Elizabeth about the health of her family members. She answered him in the usual manner, and after a moment, added:
tr: Colonel Fitzwilliam entered into conversation directly with the energy and ease of a well-bred man and spoke sweetly; but his cousin, after expressing a slight observation to Mrs. Collins about the house and garden, sat for a while without speaking to anyone. Yet, in the end, his politeness prevailed, and he asked Elizabeth about her family's health. Elizabeth answered in the usual manner and, after a moment's pause, said–
es: Colonel Fitzwilliam took part in the conversation with the ease and fluency of a well-educated man, he was very pleasant; but his cousin, after making a few brief remarks to Mrs. Collins about the garden and the house, sat for a long time without speaking to anyone. Finally, however, his courtesy extended to asking Elizabeth how her family was. She replied in the usual terms, and after a moment of silence, added:

en: “My eldest sister has been in town these three months. Have you never happened to see her there?”
vi: - My eldest sister has been living in the city for three months now. Have you met her?
tr: "My brother has been in the city for three months. Haven't you ever run into him there?"
es: ––My older sister has spent these three months in London. Haven't you seen her by any chance?

en: She was perfectly sensible that he never had: but she wished to see whether he would betray any consciousness of what had passed between the Bingleys and Jane; and she thought he looked a little confused as he answered that he had never been so fortunate as to meet Miss Bennet. The subject was pursued no further, and the gentlemen soon afterwards went away.
vi: She had the impression that he had indeed met her, but she wanted to see if he would reveal any knowledge about what had happened between the Bingleys and Jane. She thought he seemed a bit confused when he replied that he had not had the good fortune to meet Miss Bennet again. No one said anything more about the matter, and shortly after, the gentlemen took their leave.
tr: Elizabeth knew very well that she had not met them, but she wanted to see if she would reveal that she knew what had transpired between the Bingleys and Jane, and she thought she seemed a bit surprised while answering that she had not had the chance to see Miss Bennet. The subject was not prolonged; the gentlemen left shortly after.
es: He knew perfectly well that he had not seen her, but he wanted to see if any gesture would betray him and reveal that he was aware of what had happened between the Bingleys and Jane; and it seemed to him that he was a bit embarrassed when he replied that he had never had the luck to meet Miss Bennet. Nothing more was said about the matter, and shortly after, the gentlemen left.

en: CHAPTER XXXI.
vi: Chapter 31
tr: Chapter VIII
es: CHAPTER XXXI

en: COLONEL FITZWILLIAM’S manners were very much admired at the Parsonage, and the ladies all felt that he must add considerably to the pleasure of their engagements at Rosings. It was some days, however, before they received any invitation thither, for while there were visitors in the house they could not be necessary; and it was not till Easter-day, almost a week after the gentlemen’s arrival, that they were honoured by such an attention, and then they were merely asked on leaving church to come there in the evening. For the last week they had seen very little of either Lady Catherine or her daughter. Colonel Fitzwilliam had called at the Parsonage more than once during the time, but Mr. Darcy they had only seen at church.
vi: Everyone in the Parsonage admired Colonel Fitzwilliam's demeanor, and the women in particular thought he would make the gatherings at Rosings more enjoyable. However, they were only invited over for Easter because there were many other guests, and they were asked to come only in the evening after attending church services. During this week, they rarely saw Lady Catherine or her daughter. Colonel Fitzwilliam visited the Parsonage a couple of times, but they only saw Mr. Darcy at church.
tr: Colonel Fitzwilliam's behavior was much appreciated at the parsonage; all the ladies felt that he would add pleasure to their activities at Rosings. However, it took a few days for them to receive any invitation from there – because when there were guests at the house, they were not needed; they did not receive such attention until Easter day, that is, a week after the gentlemen's arrival; even then, they were only asked to come in the evening as they were leaving the church. They had seen very little of Lady Catherine or her daughter during the past week. The Colonel had come to the parsonage several times during that period, but they had only seen Mr. Darcy at church.
es: Colonel Fitzwilliam was highly praised and all the ladies considered that his presence would be an additional charm to the gatherings at Rosings. But a few days passed without receiving any invitation, as if, having guests in the house, the Collinses were no longer needed. Until Easter day, a week after the arrival of the two gentlemen, they were not honored with such attention and even then, upon leaving the church, they were advised not to go until the very late afternoon. During the previous week, they saw very little of Lady Catherine and her daughter. Colonel Fitzwilliam visited the Collins' house more than once, but they only saw Darcy at church.

en: The invitation was accepted, of course, and at a proper hour they joined the party in Lady Catherine’s drawing-room. Her Ladyship received them civilly, but it was plain that their company was by no means so acceptable as when she could get nobody else; and she was, in fact, almost engrossed by her nephews, speaking to them, especially to Darcy, much more than to any other person in the room.
vi: Mrs. Catherine received them in the living room. Her attitude remained polite, but it was clear that she only accepted their presence when she couldn't invite anyone else. In fact, she almost exclusively focused on her two nephews; she conversed with them, especially with Mr. Darcy, more than with anyone else.
tr: The invitation was, of course, accepted; at a suitable hour, they joined the group in Lady Catherine's drawing room. Her Ladyship received them politely, but it was clear that their presence was not as welcome as when she could find no one else; indeed, she was almost enraptured with her nephews and spoke to them, especially Darcy, more than to anyone else in the room.
es: The invitation, naturally, was accepted, and at the appropriate time, the Collinses presented themselves in Lady Catherine's drawing room. Her Ladyship received them attentively, but it was quite clear that their company was no longer as pleasing to her as when she was alone; indeed, she was focused on her nephews and spoke with them, especially with Darcy–– much more than with any other person in the room.

en: Colonel Fitzwilliam seemed really glad to see them: anything was a welcome relief to him at Rosings; and Mrs. Collins’s pretty friend had, moreover, caught his fancy very much. He now seated himself by her, and talked so agreeably of Kent and Hertfordshire, of travelling and staying at home, of new books and music, that Elizabeth had never been half so well entertained in that room before; and they conversed with so much spirit and flow as to draw the attention of Lady Catherine herself, as well as of Mr. Darcy. His eyes had been soon and repeatedly turned towards them with a look of curiosity; and that her Ladyship, after a while, shared the feeling, was more openly acknowledged, for she did not scruple to call out,—
vi: Colonel Fitzwilliam seemed pleased to meet the family of his host; whatever the case, he was warmly welcomed at Rosings. The beautiful friend of Mrs. Collins particularly caught his attention. Now he was sitting next to her, engaging in pleasant conversation about Kent and Hertfordshire, about traveling and staying at home, about new books and music, to the extent that Elizabeth had never felt so entertained. The two of them chatted so animatedly and cheerfully together that even Lady Catherine took notice, as did Mr. Darcy. His eyes frequently turned towards the two with curiosity. The lady shared the same sentiment and did not hesitate to exclaim:
tr: Colonel Fitzwilliam seemed genuinely pleased to see them; everything at Rosings was a pleasant diversion for him, and Mrs. Collins' beautiful friend had quite caught his interest. He sat next to her and spoke so sweetly about Kent and Hertfordshire, about traveling and staying at home, about new books and music, that Elizabeth had never enjoyed herself half as much in that room before; they conversed so cheerfully and fluently that they even attracted the attention of both Lady Catherine and Mr. Darcy. Mr. Darcy's eyes soon and repeatedly turned to them with a curious gaze; Her Ladyship, after a while, also openly expressed her shared sentiment by calling out to them without any hesitation–
es: Colonel Fitzwilliam seemed genuinely pleased to see them; in Rosings, anything seemed like a relief to him, and besides, Mrs. Collins's pretty friend had captivated him. He sat next to Elizabeth and they chatted so pleasantly about Kent and Hertfordshire, their travels and the time spent at home, new books and music, that Elizabeth had never enjoyed herself so much in that parlor; they spoke with such ease and animation that they attracted the attention of Lady Catherine and Darcy. The latter had already looked at them several times with curiosity. Her Ladyship soon shared the same sentiment, and it was clearly seen, for she did not hesitate to ask:

en: “What is that you are saying, Fitzwilliam? What is it you are talking of? What are you telling Miss Bennet? Let me hear what it is.”
vi: - What are you talking about, Fitzwilliam? What are you telling Miss Bennet? Let me hear it too.
tr: "What are you talking about, Fitzwilliam? What are you saying like that? What are you telling Miss Bennet? Tell me, I want to listen too."
es: ––What are you saying, Fitzwilliam? What are you talking about? What are you telling Miss Bennet? Let me hear it.

en: “We were talking of music, madam,” said he, when no longer able to avoid a reply.
vi: He said, when he could no longer avoid it: - We are talking about music, aunt.
tr: "We are talking about music, madam," said Fitzwilliam, when he could no longer avoid answering.
es: ––We are talking about music, madam ––declared the colonel when he saw that he couldn't avoid the response.

en: “Of music! Then pray speak aloud. It is of all subjects my delight. I must have my share in the conversation, if you are speaking of music. There are few people in England, I suppose, who have more true enjoyment of music than myself, or a better natural taste. If I had ever learnt, I should have been a great proficient. And so would Anne, if her health had allowed her to apply. I am confident that she would have performed delightfully. How does Georgiana get on, Darcy?”
vi: - About music? Then you should speak up. Among the arts, my favorite is music. I must join the conversation if you are talking about music. I don't think there are many people in England who appreciate music more than I do, or have a higher taste for it than I do. If I had the opportunity to study, I could master it. And so could Ann, if her health permitted. I believe she could perform wonderfully. What about Georgiana, Darcy?
tr: "From music! In that case, please speak loudly. It is my favorite subject. If you are talking about music, I should have my share of the conversation too. In England, there are few as keen music listeners as myself, even fewer with as natural a taste, in my opinion. If I had learned, I would have been a great artist. Oh look, Anne too, if her health had allowed her to work. I'm sure she would have done extraordinarily well. How is Georgiana doing, Darcy?"
es: ––About music! Well, do me the favor of speaking loudly. Of all the topics of conversation, it is the one I enjoy the most. I must take part in the conversation if you are talking about music. I believe there are few people in England more fond of music than I am or who possess better natural taste. If I had studied, I would have become a great disciple. The same would happen to Anne if her health permitted it; I am sure she would have played delightfully. How is Georgiana, Darcy?

en: Mr. Darcy spoke with affectionate praise of his sister’s proficiency.
vi: Mr. Darcy lovingly praised his sister's proficiency.
tr: Mr. Darcy spoke with emotional praise about his sister's talent.
es: Darcy made a cordial compliment about how advanced his sister was.

en: “I am very glad to hear such a good account of her,” said Lady Catherine; “and pray tell her from me, that she cannot expect to excel, if she does not practise a great deal.”
vi: Lady Catherine said: - Auntie is very happy to hear you talk about her, and please convey Auntie's message to her that she cannot become outstanding if she does not practice a lot.
tr: "I am very glad to hear that," said Lady Catherine; "please tell her that she will never succeed unless she practices a great deal.""
es: ––I am very glad that you give me such good news ––said Lady Catherine––, and I beg you to tell her on my behalf that if she does not practice a lot, she will not improve at all.

en: “I assure you, madam,” he replied, “that she does not need such advice. She practises very constantly.”
vi: He replied: - Xin Di believes that she did not wait until she received such advice. She practiced continuously.
tr: "Rest assured, madam," replied Mr. Darcy, "he has no need of such advice. He practices constantly."
es: ––I assure you that he doesn't need to be warned. He practices constantly.

en: “So much the better. It cannot be done too much; and when I next write to her, I shall charge her not to neglect it on any account. I often tell young ladies, that no excellence in music is to be acquired without constant practice. I have told Miss Bennet several times, that she will never play really well, unless she practises more; and though Mrs. Collins has no instrument, she is very welcome, as I have often told her, to come to Rosings every day, and play on the pianoforte in Mrs. Jenkinson’s room. She would be in nobody’s way, you know, in that part of the house.”
vi: - That's good. No amount of practice is ever enough. When I write to her, I will insist that she must not be distracted for any reason. I often tell young girls that to excel in music, they must practice regularly. I have often told Miss Bennet several times that she can never play well unless she practices more. Even though Mrs. Collins does not have a piano, I often tell her that we are ready to let her practice at Rosings and use the piano in Mrs. Jenkinson's room. You know, in that room, she won't disturb anyone.
tr: "The more, the better. There is no end to it; when I write to her again, I will urge her never to neglect this matter. I often tell young ladies that perfection in music is not achieved without constant practice. I have also told Miss Bennet several times that she will never play really well unless she practices more; Mrs. Collins does not have a piano, but how many times have I told her that she can easily come to Rosings every day and play the piano in Mrs. Jenkinson's room. It wouldn't interfere with anyone, after all, it's on that side of the house."
es: ––Better. That is never too much; and the next time I write to her, I will make sure she does not neglect it. I often tell young ladies that in music, nothing is achieved without constant practice. I have often told Miss Bennet that she will never play truly well if she does not practice more; and although Mrs. Collins does not have a piano, Miss Bennet will be very welcome, as I have often told her, if she comes to Rosings every day to play the piano in Mrs. Jenkinson's room. In that part of the house, she will not bother anyone.

en: Mr. Darcy looked a little ashamed of his aunt’s ill-breeding, and made no answer.
vi: Mr. Darcy seemed a bit embarrassed by his aunt's demeanor but did not reply.
tr: Mr. Darcy was a bit embarrassed by his aunt's rudeness and did not respond.
es: Darcy seemed a little embarrassed by his aunt's rudeness, and did not reply.

en: When coffee was over, Colonel Fitzwilliam reminded Elizabeth of having promised to play to him; and she sat down directly to the instrument. He drew a chair near her. Lady Catherine listened to half a song, and then talked, as before, to her other nephew; till the latter walked away from her, and moving with his usual deliberation towards the pianoforte, stationed himself so as to command a full view of the fair performer’s countenance. Elizabeth saw what he was doing, and at the first convenient pause turned to him with an arch smile, and said,—
vi: When they had finished their coffee, Colonel Fitzwilliam reminded Elizabeth of her promise to play the piano for him, and she sat down in front of the instrument. He pulled a chair over to sit beside her. Lady Catherine listened to half the piece, then resumed her conversation with Mr. Darcy as before; until he disengaged himself from her, walking with his usual leisurely gait towards the piano. He positioned himself where he could observe Elizabeth's entire face. She noticed, and during the pause between two pieces, said:
tr: When the coffee was finished, Colonel Fitzwilliam reminded Elizabeth of her promise to play the piano for him; Elizabeth sat down at the piano immediately. Fitzwilliam also pulled up a chair next to her. Lady Catherine listened to half a song, then, as before, talked to her other nephew; until her nephew moved away from her and, with his usual determination, approached the piano and positioned himself where he could fully see the beautiful pianist's face. Elizabeth saw what he was doing and, at the first suitable pause, turned to him with a mocking smile and said–
es: When they finished their coffee, Colonel Fitzwilliam reminded Elizabeth that she had promised to play, and the young woman immediately sat down at the piano. The colonel placed his chair beside her. Lady Catherine listened to half of the song and then continued talking, as before, to her other nephew, until Darcy left her and, cautiously approaching the piano, positioned himself so that he could see the face of the beautiful performer. Elizabeth noticed what he was doing and at the first opportune pause turned to him with a broad smile and said:

en: “You mean to frighten me, Mr. Darcy, by coming in all this state to hear me. But I will not be alarmed, though your sister does play so well. There is a stubbornness about me that never can bear to be frightened at the will of others. My courage always rises with every attempt to intimidate me.”
vi: - Mr. Darcy, are you trying to overwhelm me by standing here listening to me play? I will not worry about the fact that your sister indeed plays music well. I have a stubborn nature that never fears the will of others. I always gain more courage with each threat.
tr: "Are you trying to frighten me by coming to listen to me in this state, Mr. Darcy? But I will not be alarmed because your sister plays so well. I have a stubbornness that does not accept being intimidated by others. Any attempt to frighten me only increases my courage."
es: ––Do you intend to frighten me by coming to listen to me with such seriousness? I am not scared, even though your sister plays so well. There is a kind of stubbornness in me that never allows anyone to intimidate me. On the contrary, my courage grows when someone tries to intimidate me.

en: “I shall not say that you are mistaken,” he replied, “because you could not really believe me to entertain any design of alarming you; and I have had the pleasure of your acquaintance long enough to know, that you find great enjoyment in occasionally professing opinions which, in fact, are not your own.”
vi: He replied: - I don't want to say you're mistaken, because I can't believe that I have any intention of intimidating you. I have had the pleasure of knowing you for a long time, so I understand that you occasionally find it amusing to express thoughts that are not really yours.
tr: "I will not say that you are mistaken," replied Mr. Darcy, "because you cannot really believe that I plan to frighten you; I have known you long enough to know that you take great pleasure in occasionally adopting views that are not actually your own."
es: ––I will not tell you that you are mistaken ––replied Darcy–– because you do not sincerely believe that I had any intention of alarming you; and I have had the pleasure of knowing you well enough to know that you sometimes take pleasure in holding opinions that are not actually yours.

en: Elizabeth laughed heartily at this picture of herself, and said to Colonel Fitzwilliam, “Your cousin will give you a very pretty notion of me, and teach you not to believe a word I say. I am particularly unlucky in meeting with a person so well able to expose my real character, in a part of the world where I had hoped to pass myself off with some degree of credit.
