Indeed, Mr. Darcy, it is very ungenerous in you to mention all that you knew to my disadvantage in Hertfordshire—and, give me leave to say, very impolitic too—for it is provoking me to retaliate, and such things may come out as will shock your relations to hear.”
vi: Elizabeth laughed joyfully at the description of herself, and said to Colonel Fitzwilliam: - Your cousin will show you a very beautiful side of me, and teach you clearly not to believe my words. I am unfortunate to encounter someone who can clearly reveal my true self, in a part of the world where I hoped to be judged favorably. Mr. Darcy, you lack generosity when you say you know all about me in Hertfordshire, allow me to say, you were also too rude, for you provoked me to retaliate, and if this happens, your relatives will be shocked to hear what I say.
tr: Elizabeth laughed heartily at this picture and said to Colonel Fitzwilliam, "Your cousin will give you a very pleasant idea of me and will advise you not to believe a single word I say. It is truly unfortunate that in a place where I hoped to make myself a little liked, I have encountered someone who reveals my true character so well. Indeed, Mr. Darcy, it is very cruel of you to speak of everything you learned against me in Hertfordshire – and allow me to say, very imprudent – because it provokes me to take revenge; things that could shock your relatives might come to light."
es: Elizabeth laughed openly at that description of herself, and said to Colonel Fitzwilliam: ––Your cousin aims to give you a poor impression of me by teaching you not to believe a word I say. It dismays me to encounter someone so eager to uncover my true nature in a place where I had hoped to pass for better than I am. Really, Mr. Darcy, it is very ungenerous of you to reveal the bad things you learned about me in Hertfordshire, and allow me to say that it is also very indiscreet, for this might lead me to retaliate and bring to light things that would scandalize your relatives.

en: “I am not afraid of you,” said he, smilingly.
vi: He smiled: - I'm not afraid of you.
tr: "I am not afraid of you," said Mr. Darcy, smiling.
es: ––I'm not––afraid ––he said, smiling.

en: “Pray let me hear what you have to accuse him of,” cried Colonel Fitzwilliam. “I should like to know how he behaves among strangers.”
vi: Colonel Fitzwilliam exclaimed: - Please let me hear what you accuse him of. I need to know how he treats others.
tr: "Please tell me what you are accusing him of," cried Colonel Fitzwilliam. "I want to know how he behaves among strangers."
es: ––Tell me, please, what you accuse him of ––exclaimed Colonel Fitzwilliam––. I would like to know how he behaves among strangers.

en: “You shall hear, then—but prepare for something very dreadful. The first time of my ever seeing him in Hertfordshire, you must know, was at a ball—and at this ball, what do you think he did? He danced only four dances! I am sorry to pain you, but so it was. He danced only four dances, though gentlemen were scarce; and, to my certain knowledge, more than one young lady was sitting down in want of a partner. Mr. Darcy, you cannot deny the fact.”
vi: - Then you will listen, but be prepared to hear something dreadful. The first time I met him was in Hertfordshire, you know, at a ball, and at this ball, do you know what he did? He only danced four dances! Sorry to break your heart, but that's the truth. He only danced four dances, even though young men were scarce, and I know for a fact that there was a young girl who had to sit out because there were not enough dance partners. Mr. Darcy, you cannot deny the fact.
tr: "Listen then –but prepare yourself for something very dreadful. When I first saw him in Hertfordshire, we were at a ball –and guess what he did at this ball? He danced only four times! I apologize for upsetting you –but that's how it was. Only four dances, despite the lack of men; and I know very well that many ladies were left sitting due to the absence of partners. Mr. Darcy, you cannot deny what you did."
es: ––I will tell you, but prepare yourself to hear something very dreadful. You must know that the first time I saw him was at a ball, and at that ball, what do you think he did? Well, he only danced four pieces, despite the scarcity of gentlemen, and more than one lady was left sitting for lack of a partner. Mr. Darcy, you cannot deny it.

en: “I had not at that time the honour of knowing any lady in the assembly beyond my own party.”
vi: - At that time, I did not have the honor of knowing any lady outside of my group.
tr: "At that time, I had not had the honor of meeting any lady outside of my own group."
es: ––I did not have the honor of knowing any of the ladies at the gathering, except for those who accompanied me.

en: “True; and nobody can ever be introduced in a ball-room. Well, Colonel Fitzwilliam, what do I play next? My fingers wait your orders.”
vi: - That's right, and no one has ever been introduced at a ball. So, Colonel Fitzwilliam, what should I play next? My fingers are awaiting your command.
tr: "That's right; no one can meet anyone at the ball anyway. So, Colonel Fitzwilliam, what shall I play now? My fingers are awaiting your orders."
es: ––True, and at a ball there is never a chance to be introduced... Well, Colonel Fitzwilliam, what shall I play now? My fingers are awaiting your orders.

en: “Perhaps,” said Darcy, “I should have judged better had I sought an introduction, but I am ill-qualified to recommend myself to strangers.”
vi: Darcy said: - Perhaps I should consider more carefully if I seek an introduction, but I am not qualified to introduce myself to strangers.
tr: "Perhaps," said Darcy, "I would behave differently if I sought the opportunity to meet; but I am inept at introducing myself to strangers."
es: ––Perhaps you would have judged me better ––added Darcy–– if I had requested an introduction. But I am not good at making myself known to strangers.

en: “Shall we ask your cousin the reason of this?” said Elizabeth, still addressing Colonel Fitzwilliam. “Shall we ask him why a man of sense and education, and who has lived in the world, is ill-qualified to recommend himself to strangers?”
vi: Elizabeth still spoke directly to Colonel Fitzwilliam: - Should we ask your cousin about the reason for this? Should we ask how a conscious and educated person, who has lived in this social class, could be unfit to introduce to strangers?
tr: "Shall we ask your cousin the reason for this?" said Elizabeth, still addressing Colonel Fitzwilliam. "Why would an intelligent, educated man, someone who has seen the world, be inept at introducing himself to strangers, shall we ask?"
es: ––Let's ask his cousin why he is like that ––said Elizabeth, addressing no one but Colonel Fitzwilliam––. Shall we ask him how it is possible that a talented and well-educated man, who has lived in high society, is not capable of attending to strangers?

en: “I can answer your question,” said Fitzwilliam, “without applying to him. It is because he will not give himself the trouble.”
vi: Fitzwilliam said: - I can answer your question without needing him. It's just because he isn't diligent.
tr: "I can answer your question," said Fitzwilliam, "there is no need for you to consult him. Because it won't cause any trouble."
es: ––I can answer this question myself ––replied Fitzwilliam–– without asking Darcy. That's because he doesn't want to bother.

en: “I certainly have not the talent which some people possess,” said Darcy, “of conversing easily with those I have never seen before. I cannot catch their tone of conversation, or appear interested in their concerns, as I often see done.”
vi: Darcy said: - I certainly don't have the talent that some people possess, to easily converse with someone they've never met before. I can't join in their conversations or show interest in their issues, as I often see them do.
tr: "I don't have the talent that some people possess," said Darcy, "the ability to comfortably talk to people I haven't met before. I can't catch the tone of their conversations like others do, I can't seem to show interest in the things they talk about."
es: ––I acknowledge ––said Darcy–– that I do not have the ability that others possess to converse easily with people I have never seen. I cannot engage in those conversations and pretend to be interested in their affairs as is customary.

en: “My fingers,” said Elizabeth, “do not move over this instrument in the masterly manner which I see so many women’s do. They have not the same force or rapidity, and do not produce the same expression. But then I have always supposed it to be my own fault—because I would not take the trouble of practising. It is not that I do not believe my fingers as capable as any other woman’s of superior execution.”
vi: Elizabeth said: - My fingers are not as skillful on this instrument as many other girls', because they lack the same strength or dexterity, and do not express the same emotions. But then I always considered it my fault – because I did not practice diligently. It's not that I don't believe my fingers have the same potential as any woman who plays better than me.
tr: "My fingers," said Elizabeth, "do not skillfully glide over this instrument like the fingers of many women. They do not have the same strength, the same speed, nor do they create the same expression. But I always thought that this was my own fault – because I did not endure the trouble of practicing. Not because I believed that my fingers could not possess the superior skill like another woman's fingers."
es: ––My fingers ––replied Elizabeth–– do not move over this instrument in the masterful way I have seen other women's fingers move; they do not have the same strength or agility, and they cannot produce the same impression. But I have always believed it was my fault, for not wanting to take the trouble to do exercises. Not because my fingers are not capable, like those of any other woman, of playing perfectly.

en: Darcy smiled and said, “You are perfectly right. You have employed your time much better. No one admitted to the privilege of hearing you can think anything wanting. We neither of us perform to strangers.”
vi: Darcy smiled: - You are absolutely right. You have used your time much more beneficially. No one who has the privilege of hearing you play can think there is any weakness. Neither of us performs for strangers.
tr: Darcy smiled and said, "You are very right. You have used your time much better. No one who has had the privilege of listening to you can find any fault. We both do not play for strangers."
es: Darcy smiled and said to her: ––You are absolutely right. You have used your time much better. No one who has the privilege of listening to you will be able to find fault. None of us perform in front of strangers.

en: Here they were interrupted by Lady Catherine, who called out to know what they were talking of. Elizabeth immediately began playing again. Lady Catherine approached, and, after listening for a few minutes, said to Darcy,—
vi: They were interrupted by Lady Catherine, who called out to ask what they were talking about. Elizabeth immediately began to play music. Lady Catherine approached, and after listening for a while, said to Mr. Darcy:
tr: Lady Catherine interrupted here: she called out and asked what they were talking about. Elizabeth immediately started to play. Lady Catherine approached, and after listening for a few minutes, she said to Darcy–
es: Lady Catherine interrupted them by asking what they were talking about. Elizabeth began to play again. Lady Catherine approached and after listening to her for a few minutes, said to Darcy:

en: “Miss Bennet would not play at all amiss if she practised more, and could have the advantage of a London master. She has a very good notion of fingering, though her taste is not equal to Anne’s. Anne would have been a delightful performer, had her health allowed her to learn.”
vi: - Miss Bennet's performance was flawless, if she practices more and gets a teacher in London. Her playing is quite skillful, although her taste is not as refined as Ann's. Ann could perform wonderfully if her health allowed her to practice.
tr: "If Miss practiced more and could benefit from a teacher from London, she would never play incorrectly. Her finger technique is very good, but of course, her taste is not as refined as Anne's. Anne would have been an extraordinary pianist if her health had allowed her to learn."
es: ––Miss Bennet would not play badly if she practiced more and had enjoyed the advantages of a good teacher from London. She knows what it is to play the keys, although her taste is not like Anne's. Anne would have been a wonderful pianist if her health had allowed her to learn.

en: Elizabeth looked at Darcy, to see how cordially he assented to his cousin’s praise: but neither at that moment nor at any other could she discern any symptom of love; and from the whole of his behaviour to Miss De Bourgh she derived this comfort for Miss Bingley, that he might have been just as likely to marry her, had she been his relation.
vi: Elizabeth looked at Darcy to see how he would respond to his aunt's praise of his cousin, but at that moment and at any other time, she did not detect any sign of affection. From the way he treated Miss De Bourgh, she felt reassured about her sister that Mr. Bingley could have married her if she had been related to him.
tr: Elizabeth looked at Darcy to see how he would react to the praise about his cousin; but neither at that moment nor at any other time did she see any sign of affection; from his overall behavior towards Miss de Bourgh, Elizabeth drew this consolation on behalf of Miss Bingley: he could have married her too, if she had been his relative.
es: Elizabeth looked at Darcy to observe his cordial assent to the praise given to his cousin, but neither then nor at any other time did she discover any sign of love; and from his attitude towards Miss de Bourgh, Elizabeth deduced something consoling in favor of Miss Bingley: that Darcy would have married her if she had belonged to his family.

en: Lady Catherine continued her remarks on Elizabeth’s performance, mixing with them many instructions on execution and taste. Elizabeth received them with all the forbearance of civility; and at the request of the gentlemen remained at the instrument till her Ladyship’s carriage was ready to take them all home.
vi: Lady Catherine continued to comment on Elizabeth's level of performance, mixing in advice on how to perform and appreciate music. Elizabeth accepted it with all the patience that politeness demanded, and at the request of the gentlemen, she remained at the piano until the carriage was ready to take them home.
tr: Lady Catherine continued to express her opinions about Elizabeth's performance, adding lessons of practice and taste to her remarks. Elizabeth received these words with all the fortitude of politeness and continued to play the piano at the gentlemen's request until her ladyship's carriage was ready to take them home.
es: Lady Catherine continued making observations about Elizabeth's manner of playing, mixed with numerous instructions on execution and taste. Elizabeth endured them with all the patience that courtesy demands, and at the gentlemen's request, she continued playing until Her Ladyship's carriage was ready and took everyone home.

en: CHAPTER XXXII.
vi: Chapter 32
tr: Chapter IX
es: CHAPTER XXXII

en: ELIZABETH was sitting by herself the next morning, and writing to Jane, while Mrs. Collins and Maria were gone on business into the village, when she was startled by a ring at the door, the certain signal of a visitor. As she had heard no carriage, she thought it not unlikely to be Lady Catherine; and under that apprehension was putting away her half-finished letter, that she might escape all impertinent questions, when the door opened, and to her very great surprise Mr. Darcy, and Mr. Darcy only, entered the room.
vi: The next morning, while sitting alone writing a letter to Jane as Mrs. Collins and Maria had business in the village, Elizabeth was surprised to hear the doorbell signaling a visitor. Since she did not hear a carriage, she thought it could not be Lady Catherine. She set the unfinished letter aside. When the door opened, she was surprised to see Mr. Darcy, and only Mr. Darcy, walk in.
tr: Elizabeth was sitting alone the next morning, writing a letter to Jane; Mrs. Collins and Maria had gone to the village on an errand; at one point, Elizabeth was startled by the ringing of the doorbell, clearly indicating a visitor. Since she did not hear the sound of a carriage, she thought it might be Lady Catherine and, with that thought, she was putting away her half-finished letter to avoid being subjected to impertinent questions when the door opened and, leaving Elizabeth in great astonishment, Mr. Darcy entered, and it was only Mr. Darcy.
es: The next morning, Elizabeth was alone writing to Jane, while Mrs. Collins and Maria had gone shopping in town, when she was startled by the ringing of the doorbell, an unmistakable sign of a visitor. Although she had not heard any carriage, she thought it might be Lady Catherine, and hurried to hide the half-written letter to avoid impertinent questions. But to her great surprise, the door opened, and Mr. Darcy entered the room. Darcy alone.

en: He seemed astonished too on finding her alone, and apologized for his intrusion, by letting her know that he had understood all the ladies to be within.
vi: He also showed surprise to see her alone, and apologized for being abrupt, saying he had assumed all women would be at home.
tr: He also seemed surprised to find Elizabeth alone and apologized for his unannounced visit, saying that he thought all the ladies were at home.
es: He seemed surprised to find her alone and apologized for his intrusion, saying that he believed all the ladies were in the house.

en: They then sat down, and when her inquiries after Rosings were made, seemed in danger of sinking into total silence. It was absolutely necessary, therefore, to think of something; and in this emergency recollecting when she had seen him last in Hertfordshire, and feeling curious to know what he would say on the subject of their hasty departure, she observed,—
vi: Then the two sat down, and when she asked him about Rosings, it seemed there was a risk they would lapse into silence. Therefore, needing to think of something else, in this urgent moment she recalled the last time she met him in Hertfordshire, and wondered what he thought about their hasty departure. She remarked:
tr: Then they sat down; after Elizabeth's questions about Rosings were asked, the danger of falling into silence arose. So it was necessary to think of something, and in this urgent situation, she began to speak, recalling the last time she saw him in Hertfordshire and wondering what he would say about their hasty departure–
es: They both sat down and, after the obligatory questions about Rosings, it seemed they were going to remain silent. Therefore, it was absolutely necessary to think of something, and Elizabeth, faced with this necessity, recalled the last time they had seen each other in Hertfordshire and felt curious to see what he would say about his hasty departure.

en: “How very suddenly you all quitted Netherfield last November, Mr. Darcy! It must have been a most agreeable surprise to Mr. Bingley to see you all after him so soon; for, if I recollect right, he went but the day before. He and his sisters were well, I hope, when you left London?”
vi: - All of you left Netherfield quite suddenly, Mr. Darcy! Mr. Bingley must have been pleasantly surprised to see you again so soon, because if I am not mistaken, he only left the day before. I hope he and his sisters were well when you left London.
tr: "How suddenly you left Netherfield last November, Mr. Darcy! Mr. Bingley must have been very surprised and pleased to see you all come right after him; if I remember correctly, he had left the day before. I hope both he and his sisters were in good health when you left London."
es: ––How suddenly you left Netherfield last November, Mr. Darcy! ––she said––. It must have been a very pleasant surprise for Mr. Bingley to see you so soon by his side, because, if I remember correctly, he had left a day earlier. I suppose both he and his sisters were well when you left London.

en: “Perfectly so, I thank you.”
vi: - Everything is normal, thank you.
tr: "They were very good, thank you."
es: ––Perfectly. Thank you.

en: She found that she was to receive no other answer; and, after a short pause, added,—
vi: She saw that she would not have any other answer, so after a moment, she continued:
tr: Elizabeth realized she could not get another answer, and after a short silence, she continued–
es: Elizabeth warned that she was not going to answer him anymore and, after a brief silence, added:

en: “I think I have understood that Mr. Bingley has not much idea of ever returning to Netherfield again?”
vi: - I have been informed that Mr. Bingley has no intention of returning to Netherfield, is that correct?
tr: "I think they said Mr. Bingley would not return to Netherfield again."
es: ––I understand that Mr. Bingley does not intend to return to Netherfield.

en: “I have never heard him say so; but it is probable that he may spend very little of his time there in future. He has many friends, and he is at a time of life when friends and engagements are continually increasing.”
vi: - I have never heard him say that, but maybe in the future, he will live less in that place. He has many friends, he is in a phase where friends and gatherings are continuously increasing.
tr: "I didn't hear him say such a thing; but it is likely that he won't stay there for long in the future. He has many friends, and he is at an age where both his friendships and relationships are constantly increasing."
es: ––I have never heard him say such a thing; but it is likely that he will not spend much time there in the future. He has many friends and is at a stage in life where friends and commitments continuously increase.

en: “If he means to be but little at Netherfield, it would be better for the neighbourhood that he should give up the place entirely, for then we might possibly get a settled family there. But, perhaps, Mr. Bingley did not take the house so much for the convenience of the neighbourhood as for his own, and we must expect him to keep or quit it on the same principle.”
vi: - If he intends to rarely stay at Netherfield, it might be better for the neighbors if he returns the house entirely, because then we could have a family permanently settled there. But perhaps Mr. Bingley uses the house not for the convenience of the neighbors but for his own convenience, and we think he will keep or return the house based on that same principle.
tr: "If he does not intend to stay long at Netherfield, it would be better for the neighborhood if he left it altogether, because then a family could settle there. But perhaps Mr. Bingley has rented the house not for the benefit of the neighborhood, but for himself; and he will probably keep it or leave it for the same reason."
es: ––If you intend to stay for a short time at Netherfield, it would be better for the neighborhood if you left it completely, and thus possibly another family could settle there. But perhaps Mr. Bingley has taken the house not so much for the convenience of the neighborhood as for his own, and it is to be hoped that he will keep it or leave it based on that same principle.

en: “I should not be surprised,” said Darcy, “if he were to give it up as soon as any eligible purchase offers.”
vi: - I wouldn't be surprised if he returns as soon as someone comes to rent.
tr: "If he leaves as soon as a place to buy comes up," said Darcy, "I wouldn't be surprised."
es: ––It wouldn't surprise me ––added Darcy–– if he got rid of it as soon as he was offered an acceptable purchase.

en: Elizabeth made no answer. She was afraid of talking longer of his friend; and, having nothing else to say, was now determined to leave the trouble of finding a subject to him.
vi: Elizabeth did not answer. She did not want to talk much about his friend. Since there was nothing else to discuss, she decided to let him choose the topic.
tr: Elizabeth did not respond. She was afraid to talk more about her friend; since she had nothing else to say, she decided to leave the trouble of finding a new topic to him.
es: Elizabeth did not answer. She feared speaking too much about her friend, and since she had nothing else to say, she decided to let Darcy find another topic of conversation. He understood it and said immediately:

en: He took the hint and soon began with, “This seems a very comfortable house. Lady Catherine, I believe, did a great deal to it when Mr. Collins first came to Hunsford.”
vi: I understand the idea, starting: - This house seems very comfortable. I think Lady Catherine had contributed a lot here before Mr. Collins first came to Huntsford.
tr: Darcy received the signal and soon began to speak, "This place looks like a very comfortable home. When Mr. Collins first came to Hunsford, I believe Lady Catherine did a lot here."
es: ––This house seems very comfortable. I believe Lady Catherine improved it a lot when Mr. Collins first came to Hunsford.

en: “I believe she did—and I am sure she could not have bestowed her kindness on a more grateful object.”
vi: - I think that's right, I believe you cannot bestow a favor in a more precious way.
tr: "He must have done it – he couldn't have shown his kindness better for someone who knows how to thank better.""
es: ––It seems so, and I am sure that he could not have given a better proof of his kindness.

en: “Mr. Collins appears very fortunate in his choice of a wife.”
vi: - Mr. Collins seems to be fortunate in choosing his wife.
tr: "Mr. Collins seems very fortunate in his choice of wife.""
es: ––Mr. Collins seems to have been very fortunate in the choice of his wife.

en: “Yes, indeed; his friends may well rejoice in his having met with one of the very few sensible women who would have accepted him, or have made him happy if they had. My friend has an excellent understanding—though I am not certain that I consider her marrying Mr. Collins as the wisest thing she ever did. She seems perfectly happy, however; and, in a prudential light, it is certainly a very good match for her.”
vi: - Yes, that's right. His relatives will be very happy to see him meet one of the rare women who is very knowledgeable and accepts him, or brings him happiness once they accept him. My friend has an excellent understanding – although I am not sure she made the wisest decision in agreeing to marry Mr. Collins. However, she seems completely happy, and from a cautious perspective, she has a very suitable marriage.
tr: "Indeed it is so; her friends may rejoice that she has met one of the rare, sensible women who can accept her, even make her happy. My friend has a flawless intellect –though I am not sure marrying Mr. Collins was the wisest thing she has ever done. Nevertheless, she seems quite happy; and from a common-sense perspective, he is a rather suitable match for her."
es: ––That's right. His friends can rejoice that he found one of the few intelligent women who would have accepted him or who would have made him happy after accepting him. My friend is very sensible, although her marriage to Collins seems to me the least sensible of her actions. However, she seems completely happy: from a prudent point of view, this was a good match for her.

en: “It must be very agreeable to her to be settled within so easy a distance of her own family and friends.”
vi: - It's quite a relief that she has stabilized her life within a very convenient distance from her family and friends.
tr: "He liked settling in a place so close to his family and friends."
es: ––It must be very pleasant for Mrs. Collins to live so close to her family and friends.

en: “An easy distance do you call it? It is nearly fifty miles.”
vi: - Do you think this is a very convenient distance? It's nearly fifty miles.
tr: "Are you saying it's close to here?" "It's almost fifty miles.""
es: ––Do you call that a short distance? It's about fifty miles.

en: “And what is fifty miles of good road? Little more than half a day’s journey. Yes, I call it a very easy distance.”
vi: - And what if the fifty miles are good roads? It would only take a little more than half a day. Yes, I think this is a very convenient distance.
tr: "Once the road is good, what is fifty miles? A little more than half a day's journey, that's all. Yes, I think it's very close."
es: ––And what are fifty miles of good road? Just over half a day's journey. Yes, I call that a short distance.

en: “I should never have considered the distance as one of the advantages of the match,” cried Elizabeth. “I should never have said Mrs. Collins was settled near her family.”
vi: Elizabeth exclaimed: - I have never considered distance to be an advantage in marriage. I have never said that Mrs. Collins has settled near her family.
tr: "I wouldn't really consider proximity as one of the advantages of marriage," exclaimed Elizabeth. "I wouldn't say Mrs. Collins settled close to her family."
es: ––I would never have considered that distance was one of the advantages of the match, exclaimed Elizabeth, and it would never have occurred to me that Mrs. Collins lived close to her family.

en: “It is a proof of your own attachment to Hertfordshire. Anything beyond the very neighbourhood of Longbourn, I suppose, would appear far.”
vi: - This is evidence of your attachment to Herfordshire. I suppose any place outside of Longbourn seems distant.
tr: "This is proof of your attachment to Hertfordshire. Everywhere else seems evidently distant to you except the vicinity of Longbourn."
es: ––That shows the attachment you have to Hertfordshire. Everything beyond Longbourn must already seem far away to you.

en: As he spoke there was a sort of smile, which Elizabeth fancied she understood; he must be supposing her to be thinking of Jane and Netherfield, and she blushed as she answered,—
vi: When he spoke, it seemed he smiled slightly, and Elizabeth thought she understood his implication. He must have guessed she was thinking about Jane and Netherfield, and her face flushed as she replied:
tr: While Darcy was speaking, there was a kind of smile on his face, and Elizabeth thought she understood it; she must have assumed he was thinking of Netherfield with Jane; her face turned red as she replied–
es: While speaking, he smiled in a way that Elizabeth thought she could interpret: Darcy must have assumed she was thinking about Jane and Netherfield; and she replied somewhat blushing:

en: “I do not mean to say that a woman may not be settled too near her family. The far and the near must be relative, and depend on many varying circumstances. Where there is fortune to make the expense of travelling unimportant, distance becomes no evil. But that is not the case here. Mr. and Mrs. Collins have a comfortable income, but not such a one as will allow of frequent journeys—and I am persuaded my friend would not call herself near her family under less than half the present distance.”
vi: - I do not mean to say that a woman should not settle too close to her family. Far or near is only relative, depending on various circumstances. When conditions make travel costs not an issue, distance means nothing. But that is not the case here. Mr. and Mrs. Collins have a comfortable income, but still not enough to travel frequently – and I believe my friend would not consider herself close to her family even if the distance were halved.
tr: "I do not mean to say that a woman may not settle too near her family. Distance and nearness are relative; they depend on many varying circumstances. When there is fortune to make the expenses of traveling unimportant, distance becomes no evil. But that is not the case here. Mr. and Mrs. Collins have a comfortable income, but not enough to allow for frequent journeys – I think my friend would not consider herself near her family unless she lived at half that distance."
es: ––I don't mean to say that a woman cannot live far from her family. Far and near are relative things and depend on very different circumstances. If one has the fortune not to worry about travel expenses, the distance is the least of it. But this is not the case. The Collinses do not live in straitened circumstances, but they are not so wealthy as to afford frequent travel; I am sure my friend would not say she lives close to her family unless she were at half this distance.

en: Mr. Darcy drew his chair a little towards her, and said, “You cannot have a right to such very strong local attachment. You cannot have been always at Longbourn.”
vi: Mr. Darcy pulled the chair he was sitting on a little closer to her and said: - You cannot be so attached to your place like that. You cannot live with Longbourn forever.
tr: Mr. Darcy pulled his chair a little towards her and said, "You do not have the right to such strong attachment to your country." "You cannot always live in Longbourn.""
es: Darcy moved his seat a little closer to Elizabeth's and said: ––You have no right to be so attached to your residence. You will not always be in Longbourn.

en: Elizabeth looked surprised. The gentleman experienced some change of feeling; he drew back his chair, took a newspaper from the table, and, glancing over it, said, in a colder voice,—
vi: Elizabeth was surprised. The young man felt some change in his feelings. He pulled the chair back, picked up a newspaper from the table, and glanced through it, speaking in a cold voice:
tr: Elizabeth seemed surprised. Mr. Darcy changed his mind; he pulled back his chair, took the newspaper from the table, and, looking over the top of the newspaper, said in a cold voice–
es: Elizabeth seemed to be surprised, and the gentleman thought he should change the conversation. He put his chair back where it was, took a newspaper from the table, and glancing over it, asked coldly:

en: “Are you pleased with Kent?”
vi: - Do you like Kent?
tr: "Did you like the city?"
es: ––Do you like Kent?

en: A short dialogue on the subject of the country ensued, on either side calm and concise—and soon put an end to by the entrance of Charlotte and her sister, just returned from their walk. The tête-à-tête surprised them. Mr. Darcy related the mistake which had occasioned his intruding on Miss Bennet, and, after sitting a few minutes longer, without saying much to anybody, went away.
vi: A short conversation followed on the topic of the countryside, with each side calm and proper, until Charlotte and her sister walked in after a stroll. They were surprised to see the two facing each other. Mr. Darcy recounted how he had been mistaken and abrupt with Miss Bennet, and after sitting for a few more minutes without much conversation with anyone, he took his leave.
tr: A brief discussion about the region followed, with both sides being calm and measured – it was soon interrupted by the entrance of Charlotte and her sister returning from their walk. They were surprised to see the two of them alone. Mr. Darcy explained to Miss Bennet the mistake that caused him to be an uninvited guest, and after sitting for a few more minutes without saying much to anyone, he left.
es: This was followed by a short dialogue on the subject of the countryside, concise and moderate on both sides, which soon ended, as Charlotte and her sister entered, having just returned from their walk. The tête-à-tête left them stunned. Darcy explained the misunderstanding that had led to his visit to the house; he remained seated for a few more minutes, not talking much to anyone, and then left.

en: “Accompanied by their aunt”
vi: Mr. Darcy recounted how he had been mistaken and abrupt with Miss Bennet, and after sitting for a few more minutes without much conversation with anyone, he took his leave.
tr: Mr. Darcy explained to Miss Bennet the mistake that caused him to be an uninvited guest, and after sitting for a few more minutes without saying much to anyone, he left.
es: ––What does this mean?

en: “What can be the meaning of this?” said Charlotte, as soon as he was gone. “My dear Eliza, he must be in love with you, or he would never have called on us in this familiar way.”
vi: Charlotte said right after he walked away: - What does that mean? Dear Eliza, he has fallen in love with you; otherwise, he would never visit you so intimately like this!
tr: "What could this mean?" said Charlotte, as soon as she left. "My dear Eliza, he must be in love with you, otherwise he would never come to us so unceremoniously."
es: ––asked Charlotte as soon as he left––. Dear Elizabeth, he must be in love with you, for otherwise, he would never have come to see us with such familiarity.

en: But when Elizabeth told of his silence, it did not seem very likely, even to Charlotte’s wishes, to be the case; and, after various conjectures, they could at last only suppose his visit to proceed from the difficulty of finding anything to do, which was the more probable from the time of year. All field sports were over. Within doors there was Lady Catherine, books, and a billiard table, but gentlemen cannot be always within doors; and in the nearness of the Parsonage, or the pleasantness of the walk to it, or of the people who lived in it, the two cousins found a temptation from this period of walking thither almost every day. They called at various times of the morning, sometimes separately, sometimes together, and now and then accompanied by their aunt. It was plain to them all that Colonel Fitzwilliam came because he had pleasure in their society, a persuasion which of course recommended him still more; and Elizabeth was reminded by her own satisfaction in being with him, as well as by his evident admiration, of her former favourite, George Wickham; and though, in comparing them, she saw there was less captivating softness in Colonel Fitzwilliam’s manners, she believed he might have the best informed mind.
vi: But when Elizabeth spoke of his silence, everyone felt it didn't seem to be the case, even Charlotte had a wish. After speculating on everything, they finally thought he visited just because he had nothing else to do, and that might be true for this time of year. All outdoor sports had ended. Inside was Lady Catherine, books, billiards table, but the young men couldn't be confined within four walls forever. Next door was the Parsonage, either the pleasure of walking there or because of the people living there, the two cousins found pleasure in walking there almost every day. The two came at different morning hours, sometimes separately, sometimes together, occasionally with their aunt. Everyone clearly saw that Colonel Fitzwilliam came because he enjoyed their company; this thought made them like him even more. Elizabeth felt comfortable near him as well as seeing him like her, seeing him like Mr. George Wickham whom she once admired; and though in comparing the two, she found Colonel Fitzwilliam's gentle manners less captivating, she believed he might have higher knowledge.
tr: When Elizabeth mentioned Miss Darcy's silence, it became clear, despite Charlotte's wishes, that the situation was not quite as she had hoped; after various speculations, they finally assumed that her visit stemmed from the difficulty of finding something to do, which was very possible for that time of year. All outdoor sports had ended. Inside, there were only Lady Catherine, books, and a billiard table, but men cannot stay indoors all the time; soon, the parsonage, or the walk there, or the pleasantness of the people there, enticed the two cousins to walk there almost every day thereafter. In the mornings, at different times, sometimes separately, sometimes together, they visited, and sometimes their aunt accompanied them. Everyone understood that Colonel Fitzwilliam came because he enjoyed their conversation, which made them like him even more; Elizabeth, thinking about the pleasure she took in his company, especially the admiration he showed her, was reminded of her former favorite, George Wickham; comparing the two, she found that Colonel Fitzwilliam's manners had less of a heart-winning softness, but she decided he was better educated.
es: But when Elizabeth recounted how quiet he had been, it didn't seem very likely, despite Charlotte's good wishes; and after several conjectures, they limited themselves to supposing that his visit had been due to the difficulty of finding something to do, which was very natural at that time of year. All the sports had ended. At Lady Catherine's house, there were books and a billiard table, but the gentlemen were frustrated by always being cooped up indoors, and whether it was because the Collins' residence was so close, or because the walk was pleasant, or because of the people who lived there, the two cousins felt tempted to visit them every day. They would show up at different times in the morning, sometimes separately and other times together, and occasionally accompanied by their aunt. It was evident that Colonel Fitzwilliam came because he felt comfortable with them, which naturally made him even more pleasant. The pleasure Elizabeth derived from his company and Fitzwilliam's evident admiration for her made her remember her first favorite, George Wickham. Comparing them, Elizabeth found that the Colonel's manners were less attractive and sweet than Wickham's, but Fitzwilliam seemed to her to be a more cultured man.

en: But why Mr. Darcy came so often to the Parsonage it was more difficult to understand. It could not be for society, as he frequently sat there ten minutes together without opening his lips; and when he did speak, it seemed the effect of necessity rather than of choice—a sacrifice to propriety, not a pleasure to himself. He seldom appeared really animated. Mrs. Collins knew not what to make of him. Colonel Fitzwilliam’s occasionally laughing at his stupidity proved that he was generally different, which her own knowledge of him could not have told her; and as she would have liked to believe this change the effect of love, and the object of that love her friend Eliza, she set herself seriously to work to find it out: she watched him whenever they were at Rosings, and whenever he came to Hunsford; but without much success. He certainly looked at her friend a great deal, but the expression of that look was disputable. It was an earnest, steadfast gaze, but she often doubted whether there were much admiration in it, and sometimes it seemed nothing but absence of mind.
vi: But why Mr. Darcy often went to the Parsonage was more difficult to understand. It was not due to a fondness for socializing, as he would often sit for a full ten minutes without saying a word, and when he did speak, it seemed more out of necessity than spontaneity – a sacrifice to propriety rather than personal inclination. He was rarely lively. Mrs. Collins could not discern his character. Colonel Fitzwilliam sometimes joked about his peculiar manners, suggesting he was different, but Mrs. Collins could not make anything of it. When she wanted to believe that this change was due to love, the object of this love, her friend Eliza, would sit solemnly alone for him to observe. She watched him whenever they visited Rosings and whenever he came to Huntsford, but she could not understand his feelings. It was evident that he often looked at her friend, but the expression in his gaze was unfathomable. It was a serious, intent look; but she often wondered if there was any affection in it, and sometimes she saw nothing but indifference.
tr: It was hard to understand why Mr. Darcy came to the lodge so often. It couldn't be for friendship, because he would come, sit for ten minutes, and leave without opening his mouth; and when he did speak, it seemed out of necessity rather than desire – not for pleasure, but to avoid rudeness. He rarely appeared cheerful. Mrs. Collins didn't know what to make of it. Colonel Fitzwilliam's occasional amusement at his absent-mindedness indicated that he was normally a different person, otherwise, she didn't know Mr. Darcy well enough to decide for herself; she seriously dedicated herself to finding out, because she liked to believe that this change was due to the effect of love, and that the object of his affection was her friend Elizabeth. She observed him every time they went to Rosings or whenever he came to Hunsford, but she didn't achieve much success. He looked at her friend a lot, but the expression of that gaze was debatable. It was a determined, steady gaze, but she wasn't sure if it contained much admiration and sometimes it just seemed like absent-mindedness.
es: But understanding why Darcy came to the house so often was more difficult. It couldn't be to seek company, as he would sit for ten minutes without opening his mouth, and when he spoke, it seemed more out of obligation than pleasure, as if it were a sacrifice rather than a delight. He was rarely truly animated. Mrs. Collins didn't know what to think of him. Since Colonel Fitzwilliam sometimes laughed at Darcy's foolishness, Charlotte understood that he must not always be like that, something her limited acquaintance with the gentleman would not have allowed her to guess; and as she wished to believe that this change was the work of love and that the object of that love was Elizabeth, she set out to discover it. When they were at Rosings and whenever Darcy came to her house, Charlotte observed him attentively, but she couldn't make anything of it. It was true that he looked at her friend a lot, but the expression of those looks was ambiguous. It was a fixed and deep gaze, but Charlotte sometimes doubted that it was enthusiastic, and at times it simply seemed that he was distracted.

en: She had once or twice suggested to Elizabeth the possibility of his being partial to her, but Elizabeth always laughed at the idea; and Mrs. Collins did not think it right to press the subject, from the danger of raising expectations which might only end in disappointment; for in her opinion it admitted not of a doubt, that all her friend’s dislike would vanish, if she could suppose him to be in her power.
vi: A few times, she let Elizabeth know that there was a possibility his feelings were leaning towards her, but Elizabeth always laughed off the idea. Mrs. Collins thought it best not to say more about this matter, as there was a risk of creating false hopes that would end in despair.
tr: Once or twice, she mentioned to Elizabeth the possibility that Mr. Darcy might be in love with her, but every time Elizabeth laughed it off, Mrs. Collins decided it was not right to insist on the matter too much, as there was a danger of raising hopes that could only end in disappointment, because it seemed to her that the moment her friend believed Mr. Darcy was in love with her, all her coldness towards him would disappear.
es: Two or three times he told Elizabeth that he might be in love with her, but Elizabeth would laugh, and Mrs. Collins thought it more prudent not to insist on it to avoid the danger of fostering impossible hopes, for she had no doubt that all of Elizabeth's aversion to Darcy would dissipate with the belief that he loved her.

en: In her kind schemes for Elizabeth, she sometimes planned her marrying Colonel Fitzwilliam. He was, beyond comparison, the pleasantest man: he certainly admired her, and his situation in life was most eligible; but, to counterbalance these advantages, Mr. Darcy had considerable patronage in the church, and his cousin could have none at all.
vi: With good intentions for Elizabeth, sometimes she intended to help her marry Colonel Fitzwilliam. Obviously, he was the most amiable person, certainly liked her, and was fully qualified; but in return, with these advantages, Mr. Darcy had considerable patronage from the church, while his cousin had none.
tr: While making sweet plans for Elizabeth, he sometimes imagined her marrying Colonel Fitzwilliam. He was a more charming man than anyone else; he was clearly enamored with Elizabeth; his means were extremely ample; however, despite these advantages, Mr. Darcy was also a significant patron of the church, whereas his cousin had no connection to the church.
es: In the good and affectionate plans that Charlotte made regarding Elizabeth, sometimes marrying her to Colonel Fitzwilliam was included. He was, without comparison, the most pleasant of all. He felt genuine admiration for Elizabeth and his position was excellent. But Darcy had considerable patronage in the Church, and his cousin had none.

en: “On looking up.”
vi: Obviously, he was the most amiable person, certainly liked her, and was fully qualified; but in return, with these advantages, Mr. Darcy had considerable patronage from the church, while his cousin had none.
tr: He was a more charming man than anyone else; he was clearly enamored with Elizabeth; his means were extremely ample; however, despite these advantages, Mr. Darcy was also a significant patron of the church, whereas his cousin had no connection to the church.
es: CHAPTER XXXIII

en: CHAPTER XXXIII.
vi: Chapter 33
tr: Chapter X
es: CHAPTER XXXIII

en: MORE than once did Elizabeth, in her ramble within the park, unexpectedly meet Mr. Darcy. She felt all the perverseness of the mischance that should bring him where no one else was brought; and, to prevent its ever happening again, took care to inform him, at first, that it was a favourite haunt of hers. How it could occur a second time, therefore, was very odd! Yet it did, and even the third. It seemed like wilful ill-nature, or a voluntary penance; for on these occasions it was not merely a few formal inquiries and an awkward pause and then away, but he actually thought it necessary to turn back and walk with her. He never said a great deal, nor did she give herself the trouble of talking or of listening much; but it struck her in the course of their third rencounter that he was asking some odd unconnected questions—about her pleasure in being at Hunsford, her love of solitary walks, and her opinion of Mr. and Mrs. Collins’s happiness; and that in speaking of Rosings, and her not perfectly understanding the house, he seemed to expect that whenever she came into Kent again she would be staying there too. His words seemed to imply it. Could he have Colonel Fitzwilliam in his thoughts? She supposed, if he meant anything, he must mean an allusion to what might arise in that quarter. It distressed her a little, and she was quite glad to find herself at the gate in the pales opposite the Parsonage.
vi: A couple of times while wandering in the garden, Elizabeth happened to meet Mr. Darcy. She felt that unfortunate irony had led him to a place where no one else bothered to go. To prevent this from happening again, she informed him in advance that this path was her favorite. How this happened a second time was truly strange! Nevertheless, it happened, and it happened a third time. It seemed like a deliberate bad habit, or a voluntary act of remorse, because on these occasions, it wasn't just a few customary greetings and a moment of awkwardness before moving on, but rather he turned back to walk with her. He never said much, and she didn't bother to talk or listen much either, but she noticed during the third walk that he asked strange questions, unrelated to the conversation – about her impressions of staying at Huntsford, her thoughts on walking alone, her opinion on the happiness of Mr. and Mrs. Collins. When talking about Rosings, her lack of understanding about this residence, it seemed he intended that whenever she came to Kent, she would also stay there. His words carried this implication. Could he be thinking of Colonel Fitzwilliam in his thoughts? She guessed, if he had any intention, he must be hinting at the possibility of it happening that way. This made her a bit uncomfortable, and she was glad to see that she had reached the gate of the garden opposite the Parsonage.
tr: While Elizabeth was walking around, she unexpectedly encountered Mr. Darcy several times. –She felt all the discomfort of the unfortunate coincidence that brought him to a place where no one else came, and to prevent it from happening again, she immediately told him that it was her favorite refuge. –However, it was very strange for this to happen a second time! –But it did, and in fact, it happened once more after that. It was actually no different from a deliberate mischief or a voluntary ordeal, because in these situations, it wasn't just about asking a few formal questions, awkwardly hesitating, and then leaving; on the contrary, Mr. Darcy found it really necessary to turn back and walk with her. He didn't talk much; Elizabeth also didn't bother to talk or listen to him much; but during their third encounter, she was intrigued by some odd, unrelated questions he asked –whether she liked being in Hunsford, her solitary walks, her views on Mr. and Mrs. Collins' happiness; then, when Elizabeth mentioned Rosings and that she didn't know the house well, Mr. Darcy spoke as if he hoped she would stay there during her next visit to Kent. His words implied this. Could he have been thinking of Colonel Fitzwilliam? Elizabeth thought that if he meant anything, he might be hinting in that direction. This bothered her a bit, and she was glad when she found herself at the gate of the fence opposite the lodge.
es: During her walks through the grove within the estate, Elizabeth had more than once unexpectedly encountered Darcy. The first time, she was not at all pleased that bad luck had brought him precisely to a place where no one else usually went, and to prevent it from happening again, she was careful to indicate that it was her favorite spot. Consequently, it was rare for the encounter to happen again, and yet, it occurred even a third time. It seemed as if he did it with intentional malice or as a penance, because it wasn't just limited to the usual questions or a simple and annoying stop; Darcy would turn back and walk with her. He never talked much nor bothered her by making her talk or listen too much. But at the third encounter, Elizabeth was astonished by the oddity of the questions he asked: if she liked being in Hunsford, if she enjoyed solitary walks, and what her opinion was of the happiness of the Collins' marriage; but the strangest thing was that when talking about Rosings and her limited knowledge of the house, it seemed that he assumed that, upon returning to Kent, Elizabeth would also reside there. Was he thinking about Colonel Fitzwilliam? The young woman thought that if he meant anything, it had to be an allusion in that direction. This unsettled her a bit, and she was glad to find herself at the gate of the fence that was right in front of the Collins' house.

en: She was engaged one day, as she walked, in re-perusing Jane’s last letter, and dwelling on some passages which proved that Jane had not written in spirits, when, instead of being again surprised by Mr. Darcy, she saw, on looking up, that Colonel Fitzwilliam was meeting her. Putting away the letter immediately, and forcing a smile, she said,—
vi: One day, while she was walking and pondering over Jane's latest letter, preoccupied with some passages that indicated Jane had not written with a calm mind, instead of being surprised once again by Mr. Darcy, she looked up and saw Colonel Fitzwilliam approaching. She quickly hid the letter and tried to smile:
tr: One day, while walking and rereading Jane's last letter, her mind got stuck on a part that showed Jane wrote without cheer, and instead of being surprised by Mr. Darcy again, she looked up and saw Colonel Fitzwilliam coming towards her. She immediately put the letter away and, with difficulty smiling, said–
es: One day, while walking, she was rereading Jane's last letter and focusing on a passage that denoted the sadness with which it had been written, when, instead of running into Darcy again, she looked up and found herself face to face with Colonel Fitzwilliam. She quickly hid the letter and, feigning a smile, said:

en: “I did not know before that you ever walked this way.”
vi: - I didn't know beforehand that you also liked walking along this path.
tr: "I didn't know you were walking this path."
es: ––I never knew until now that you walked this path.

en: “I have been making the tour of the park,” he replied, “as I generally do every year, and intended to close it with a call at the Parsonage. Are you going much farther?”
vi: He replied: - I am making a round around the campus as per my annual habit, intending to conclude with a visit to the Parish Priest's Residence. Are you going any further?
tr: "I was walking through the grove," answered Colonel Fitzwilliam, "I do it every year; I was going to end the walk by stopping by the lodge. Are you going any further?"
es: ––I have been making the full round of the estate ––replied the colonel––, something I usually do every year. And I was thinking of finishing it with a visit to the parish priest's house. Are you going to continue walking?

en: “No, I should have turned in a moment.”
vi: - No, I intend to come back a little later.
tr: "No, I was about to leave too."
es: ––No; I was going to return.

en: And accordingly she did turn, and they walked towards the Parsonage together.
vi: Accordingly, she turned back, and the two of them walked together towards the Parish House.
tr: She turned around; they started walking towards the lodging together.
es: Indeed, he turned around and together they headed towards the parish house.

en: “Do you certainly leave Kent on Saturday?” said she.
vi: She asked: - Are you sure you intend to leave Kent on Saturday?
tr: "Are you really leaving Kent on Saturday?" said Elizabeth.
es: ––Are you definitely leaving Kent on Saturday? ––asked Elizabeth.

en: “Yes—if Darcy does not put it off again. But I am at his disposal. He arranges the business just as he pleases.”
vi: - Yes, if Darcy doesn't postpone it again. But I depend on him. He arranges his work as he pleases.
tr: "Yes – if Darcy doesn't postpone again. But I am subject to him. He arranges things as he pleases."
es: ––Yes, if Darcy doesn't postpone the trip again. I am at his disposal; he arranges things as he sees fit. ––And if he does not like things, at least he takes great pleasure in being able to arrange them as he pleases.

en: “And if not able to please himself in the arrangement, he has at least great pleasure in the power of choice. I do not know anybody who seems more to enjoy the power of doing what he likes than Mr. Darcy.”
vi: - If he doesn't get things arranged to his liking, at least he will like having the right to decide. I have never known anyone who likes having the right to do as they please more than Mr. Darcy.
tr: "If she is not pleased with the arrangement, at least she can be satisfied with having had the choice. I have never seen anyone who loves having the power to do as they wish more than Mr. Darcy."
es: ––And if he does not like things, at least he takes great pleasure in being able to arrange them as he pleases. I do not know anyone who seems to enjoy the power to do what he wants more than Mr. Darcy.

en: “He likes to have his own way very well,” replied Colonel Fitzwilliam. “But so we all do. It is only that he has better means of having it than many others, because he is rich, and many others are poor. I speak feelingly. A younger son, you know, must be inured to self-denial and dependence.”
vi: Colonel Fitzwilliam replied: - He likes to do things his own way. But we all do. It's just that he has more means than others because he is rich, and many others are poor. I'm speaking emotionally. A young man must learn to get used to self-restraint and dependence.
tr: "He loves to do as he pleases," answered Colonel Fitzwilliam. "But of course, we all do. He just has more means to do so, because he is rich and many others are poor. I am speaking of myself. Being the younger son, I am accustomed to sacrifice and dependency."
es: ––He likes to have his own way, replied Colonel Fitzwilliam––. But we all like that. It's just that he has more means to do it than many others, because he is rich and others are poor. I say what I feel. You know that younger children have to get used to dependency and give up many things.

en: “In my opinion, the younger son of an earl can know very little of either. Now, seriously, what have you ever known of self-denial and dependence? When have you been prevented by want of money from going wherever you chose or procuring anything you had a fancy for?”
vi: - In my opinion, the young son of an Earl might know very little about many things. Now, seriously, what do you know about self-restraint and dependence? Have you ever been unable to go where you wanted or buy what you liked because of a lack of money?
tr: "I don't think the younger son of a count knows either of them very well. Seriously, do you know what sacrifice and dependency are? When has a lack of money ever stopped you from going wherever you wanted or buying something you desired?"
es: ––I believe that the youngest son of a count doesn't have it as bad as you say. Let's see, honestly, what do you know about renunciations and dependencies? When have you been deprived, due to lack of money, of going where you wanted or getting something you fancied?

en: “These are home questions—and perhaps I cannot say that I have experienced many hardships of that nature. But in matters of greater weight, I may suffer from the want of money. Younger sons cannot marry where they like.”
vi: - These are questions about family matters – and perhaps I have never experienced such hardships. But in more significant matters, I might still be lacking money. Young men cannot just marry whoever they want.
tr: "These are valid questions –perhaps I can't say I've faced too much difficulty of that kind. But I might face financial difficulties in more important matters. Young sons cannot marry the person they want."
es: ––Those are insignificant matters, and perhaps I can acknowledge that I haven't suffered many deprivations of that nature. But in matters of greater importance, I am subject to a lack of money. The younger children cannot marry whenever they please.

en: “Unless where they like women of fortune, which I think they very often do.”
vi: - Unless they like to marry wealthy women, and I think they often do.
tr: "If they don't want wealthy women, of course; I suppose they do this very often.""
es: ––Unless they like rich women, which I think happens often.

en: “Our habits of expense make us too dependent, and there are not many in my rank of life who can afford to marry without some attention to money.”
vi: - Our spending habits make us too dependent; not many people in my social class can get married without worrying about money.
tr: "Our spending habits make us quite dependent; there aren't many people in my position in life who can afford to get married without giving some importance to money."
es: ––Our habit of spending makes us too dependent, and there are not many of my rank who marry without paying a little attention to money.

en: “Is this,” thought Elizabeth, “meant for me?” and she coloured at the idea; but, recovering herself, said in a lively tone, “And pray, what is the usual price of an earl’s younger son? Unless the elder brother is very sickly, I suppose you would not ask above fifty thousand pounds.”
vi: Elizabeth thought, "Is this remark aimed at me?" and she blushed at the idea. But she composed herself and cheerfully said: - Could you please tell me, what is the usual price for a young son of an Earl? Unless your cousin is ill, I guess you wouldn't ask for more than fifty thousand pounds.
tr: "I wonder," thought Elizabeth, "is he referring to me with this?" and the thought made her blush; but, pulling herself together, she said in a cheerful voice, "For God's sake, can you tell me, what is the usual price for the younger son of an earl? If his elder brother is not very ill, surely you wouldn't ask for more than fifty thousand pounds."
es: "Could this be referring to me?" thought Elizabeth, blushing. But recovering, she replied in a jovial tone: ––And tell me, what is the usual price for the younger son of an earl? Unless the elder brother is very ill, you wouldn't ask for more than fifty thousand pounds...

en: He answered her in the same style, and the subject dropped. To interrupt a silence which might make him fancy her affected with what had passed, she soon afterwards said,—
vi: He replied to her in a joking manner, and they stopped there. To break the silence that might make him think she was affected by the recent words, she said:
tr: He responded in the same manner, and the matter was dropped. Elizabeth immediately said the following to avoid a silence that might suggest she was affected by the conversation–
es: He responded in the same tone and the topic was exhausted. To prevent a silence that might make the colonel think that what was said had affected her, Elizabeth spoke shortly after:

en: “I imagine your cousin brought you down with him chiefly for the sake of having somebody at his disposal. I wonder he does not marry, to secure a lasting convenience of that kind. But, perhaps, his sister does as well for the present; and, as she is under his sole care, he may do what he likes with her.”
vi: - I imagine your cousin brought you here mainly to have someone to boss around. I think he doesn't want to get married in order to enjoy this kind of freedom for a long time. But, perhaps his sister feels the same way, and since she is under his protection, he can do whatever he wants with her.
tr: "I think your cousin brought you along to have someone at his command. I'm surprised he hasn't married to have this kind of comfort all the time. But maybe for now his sister is enough; since he is her guardian, he can manage her as he wishes."
es: ––I imagine that his cousin brought him along mainly to have someone at his disposal. It surprises me that he doesn't get married, as that way he would have someone constantly subject to him. Although it may be that his sister suffices for that, for the moment, since as she is under his exclusive custody, he must be able to command her as he pleases.

en: “No,” said Colonel Fitzwilliam, “that is an advantage which he must divide with me. I am joined with him in the guardianship of Miss Darcy.”
vi: Colonel Fitzwilliam replied: - No, this is an advantage that he has to share with me. I, along with him, protect Miss Darcy.
tr: "No," said Colonel Fitzwilliam, "this is a privilege that should be shared with me. I am a partner with him in Miss Darcy's guardianship."
es: ––No ––said Colonel Fitzwilliam––, that advantage must be shared with me. I am entrusted, along with him, with the guardianship of his sister.

en: “Are you, indeed? And pray what sort of a guardian do you make? Does your charge give you much trouble? Young ladies of her age are sometimes a little difficult to manage; and if she has the true Darcy spirit, she may like to have her own way.”
vi: - Really? And may I ask, how do you protect her? Does she cause you any trouble? Young ladies at her age can sometimes be difficult to manage, so if she truly has the Darcy temperament, she might want to do things her own way.
tr: "Is that really so? God knows what kind of saints you have become? Does the young lady upset you a lot? It is a bit difficult to manage young girls at that age; especially if she has the true Darcy spirit, she may want to do as she pleases."
es: ––Really? And tell me, what kind of tutelage do you provide? Does it keep you very busy? Girls of her age can sometimes be a bit difficult to manage, and if she has the same character as Mr. Darcy, she must also like to have her own way.

en: As she spoke, she observed him looking at her earnestly; and the manner in which he immediately asked her why she supposed Miss Darcy likely to give them any uneasiness, convinced her that she had somehow or other got pretty near the truth. She directly replied,—
vi: When she spoke, she noticed that he was watching her intently, and the way he immediately asked her how she guessed that Miss Darcy might cause trouble for them made her think that somehow she had come close to the truth. She answered frankly:
tr: Elizabeth noticed that Colonel Fitzwilliam was looking at her with curiosity while she was speaking, and the way he immediately asked her why Miss Darcy might upset them convinced Elizabeth that she was quite close to the truth from one angle. He immediately replied,
es: While she was speaking, Elizabeth noticed that the colonel was looking at her very seriously, and the way he immediately asked how she supposed Miss Darcy could cause them any trouble convinced Elizabeth that, to some extent, she had come close to the truth. The young woman answered his question directly:

en: “You need not be frightened. I never heard any harm of her; and I dare say she is one of the most tractable creatures in the world. She is a very great favourite with some ladies of my acquaintance, Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley. I think I have heard you say that you know them.”
vi: - You don't need to worry. I have never heard anyone speak ill of her, and I am even certain that she is one of the most manageable creatures in the world. Many women I know, such as Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley, are very fond of her. I think I heard that you know them.
tr: "You don't need to be afraid. I haven't heard anything bad about him; in fact, I think he is one of the most charming people in the world. He is a favorite of some ladies I know, Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley. If I'm not mistaken, you mentioned that you know them."
es: ––Don't be alarmed. I've never heard anything bad about her and I would almost assure you that she is one of the best creatures in the world. She is the favorite of certain ladies I know: Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley. I believe you told me that you also knew them.

en: “I know them a little. Their brother is a pleasant, gentlemanlike man—he is a great friend of Darcy’s.”
vi: - I am somewhat acquainted with them. Their younger brother is a pleasant person – he is close friends with Mr. Darcy.
tr: "I know him a little. His brothers are pleasant gentlemen – Darcy's close friend."
es: ––Something, yes. Her brother is a very pleasant gentleman, an intimate friend of Darcy.

en: “Oh yes,” said Elizabeth drily—“Mr. Darcy is uncommonly kind to Mr. Bingley, and takes a prodigious deal of care of him.”
vi: Elizabeth is dry: - Ah! Yes. Mr. Darcy is unusually kind to Mr. Bingley and takes great care of him.
tr: "Indeed," said Elizabeth in a dry tone – "Mr. Darcy is extremely kind to Mr. Bingley; he looks after him as if he were his child."
es: ––Oh, yes! ––said Elizabeth dryly––. Mr. Darcy is incredibly kind to Mr. Bingley and takes care of him in an extraordinary way.

en: “Care of him! Yes, I really believe Darcy does take care of him in those points where he most wants care. From something that he told me in our journey hither, I have reason to think Bingley very much indebted to him. But I ought to beg his pardon, for I have no right to suppose that Bingley was the person meant. It was all conjecture.”
vi: - Take care of him! Yes, I believe that Darcy truly takes care of him in the matters he needs the most attention. According to what Darcy told me during this trip, I have reason to believe that Bingley owes him a lot. But I must apologize to him, for I should not assume that Bingley is the subject. It is all conjecture.
tr: "He looks out for him, right! Yes, I think Darcy looks out for him when needed. From something he told me on the way here, I got the impression that Bingley owes him. But forgive me, I have no right to think that the person in question is Bingley. It's all my assumption."
es: ––Does he take care of him? Yes, really, I think he takes care of him precisely in what requires the most care. From something he told me when we were coming here, I presume that Bingley owes him a lot. But I must ask you to forgive me, because I have no right to assume that Bingley was the person Darcy was referring to. They are just conjectures.

en: “What is it you mean?”
vi: - What do you mean?
tr: "What do you mean?"
es: ––What does it mean?

en: “It is a circumstance which Darcy of course could not wish to be generally known, because if it were to get round to the lady’s family it would be an unpleasant thing.”
vi: - This is a situation that Darcy naturally does not want everyone to know about, because if Lady's family finds out, it will be unpleasant.
tr: "A situation Darcy doesn't want to spread around; if it reaches the lady's family, it would be very unpleasant."
es: ––It is something that Darcy would not want to be disclosed, for if it reached the ears of the lady's family, it would be very unpleasant.

en: “You may depend upon my not mentioning it.”
vi: - You can trust me not to reveal it.
tr: "You can be sure that I won't tell anyone.""
es: Don't worry, I won't disclose it.

en: “And remember that I have not much reason for supposing it to be Bingley. What he told me was merely this: that he congratulated himself on having lately saved a friend from the inconveniences of a most imprudent marriage, but without mentioning names or any other particulars; and I only suspected it to be Bingley from believing him the kind of young man to get into a scrape of that sort, and from knowing them to have been together the whole of last summer.”
vi: - You should remember that I have little reason to guess that it was Mr. Bingley. What Darcy told me was simply this: he praised himself for having saved a friend from the troubles of a reckless marriage, but Darcy did not specify the name of the person or any other details. I only suspected it was Bingley because I believe Bingley is the type of young man who would behave foolishly like that, and because I know the two have been close throughout the past summer.
tr: "But remember, I have little reason to believe it was Bingley. All he told me was that he recently congratulated himself for saving a friend from making an unwise marriage, without giving any names or details. I only suspected it was Bingley because he is the kind of man who would be influenced in that way, and also because I knew they were together all last summer."
es: ––Keep in mind that I lack evidence to suppose that it is Bingley. What Darcy told me is that he was glad to have recently saved a friend from a very imprudent marriage; but he did not mention names or details, and I suspected that the friend was Bingley only because he seems to me a young man very suitable for such a case, and because I know they were together all summer.

en: “Did Mr. Darcy give you his reasons for this interference?”
vi: - Did Mr. Darcy tell you any reason why he wanted to get involved like that?
tr: "Did Mr. Darcy tell you the reasons for his intervention?"
es: ––Did Mr. Darcy tell you the reasons he had for interfering in the matter?

en: “I understood that there were some very strong objections against the lady.”
vi: - I think the girl faced a lot of strong opposition.
tr: "There were some very strong objections against the lady.""
es: ––I understood that there were some significant objections against the young lady.

en: “And what arts did he use to separate them?”
vi: - And what technique did he use to separate the two people?
tr: "So, what skills did he use to separate them?""
es: ––And what tricks did he use to separate them?

en: “He did not talk to me of his own arts,” said Fitzwilliam, smiling. “He only told me what I have now told you.”
vi: Fitzwilliam smiled: - He didn't tell me about his techniques. I told you everything he told me.
tr: "He didn't tell me about his own skills," said Fitzwilliam, smiling. "He only told me what I told you."
es: ––He didn't speak of his tricks ––said Fitzwilliam, smiling––. He only told me what I just told you.

en: Elizabeth made no answer, and walked on, her heart swelling with indignation. After watching her a little, Fitzwilliam asked her why she was so thoughtful.
vi: Elizabeth did not reply, continued walking, her mind filled with indignation. Watching her for a moment, Fitzwilliam asked why she seemed pensive.
tr: Elizabeth did not answer; she continued walking, her heart swelling with anger. After watching her for a while, Fitzwilliam asked why she was so pensive.
es: Elizabeth made no comment and continued walking with her heart swollen with indignation. After observing her for a bit, Fitzwilliam asked her why she was so thoughtful.

en: “I am thinking of what you have been telling me,” said she. “Your cousin’s conduct does not suit my feelings. Why was he to be the judge?”
vi: She said: - I am thinking about what you told me. Your cousin's behavior does not align with my feelings. Why does he want to be a judge?
tr: "I am thinking about what you told me," said Elizabeth. "Your cousin's behavior does not align with my feelings. Why would he be a judge?"
es: ––I am thinking about what you have told me ––Elizabeth replied––. Your cousin's behavior does not seem right to me at all. Why did he have to be the judge?

en: “You are rather disposed to call his interference officious?”
vi: - Do you mean that his interference is a nuisance?
tr: "It seems you found his intervention meddlesome."
es: ––Does that mean your intervention was indiscreet?

en: “I do not see what right Mr. Darcy had to decide on the propriety of his friend’s inclination; or why, upon his own judgment alone, he was to determine and direct in what manner that friend was to be happy. But,” she continued, recollecting herself, “as we know none of the particulars, it is not fair to condemn him. It is not to be supposed that there was much affection in the case.”
vi: - I think Mr. Darcy has no right to judge whether his friend's feelings are right or wrong, or why he should determine and dictate how his friend should find happiness based solely on his own judgment. She continued, calming down: - But, since we don't know any details, condemning him is unfair. We cannot assume that there are many emotions involved in this case.
tr: "What right does Mr. Darcy have to decide whether his friend's wish is appropriate, or how does he determine and direct what will make his friend happy, I don't understand." "But," he continued, collecting himself, "it would not be fair to condemn him as we do not know the details. Clearly, there was no significant affection involved."
es: ––I don't see what right Mr. Darcy has to decide on his friend's inclination and why he should be the one to direct and determine, in his judgment, how his friend should be happy. But ––he continued, composing himself––, not knowing the details, it is not right to criticize him. One must believe that love had little to do with this case.

en: “That is not an unnatural surmise,” said Fitzwilliam; “but it is lessening the honour of my cousin’s triumph very sadly.”
vi: Fitzwilliam said: - This is not a forced guess, but it sadly diminishes the glory of my cousin's victory.
tr: "This is not an incorrect assumption," said Fitzwilliam, "but it sadly diminishes the grandeur of my cousin's triumph."
es: It is to be supposed ––said Fitzwilliam––, but that very sadly diminishes my cousin's triumph.
