About a year ago, she was taken from school, and an establishment formed for her in London; and last summer she went with the lady who presided over it to Ramsgate; and thither also went Mr. Wickham, undoubtedly by design; for there proved to have been a prior acquaintance between him and Mrs. Younge, in whose character we were most unhappily deceived; and by her connivance and aid he so far recommended himself to Georgiana, whose affectionate heart retained a strong impression of his kindness to her as a child, that she was persuaded to believe herself in love and to consent to an elopement. She was then but fifteen, which must be her excuse; and after stating her imprudence, I am happy to add, that I owed the knowledge of it to herself. I joined them unexpectedly a day or two before the intended elopement; and then Georgiana, unable to support the idea of grieving and offending a brother whom she almost looked up to as a father, acknowledged the whole to me. You may imagine what I felt and how I acted. Regard for my sister’s credit and feelings prevented any public exposure; but I wrote to Mr. Wickham, who left the place immediately, and Mrs. Younge was of course removed from her charge. Mr. Wickham’s chief object was unquestionably my sister’s fortune, which is thirty thousand pounds; but I cannot help supposing that the hope of revenging himself on me was a strong inducement. His revenge would have been complete indeed. This, madam, is a faithful narrative of every event in which we have been concerned together; and if you do not absolutely reject it as false, you will, I hope, acquit me henceforth of cruelty towards Mr. Wickham. I know not in what manner, under what form of falsehood, he has imposed on you; but his success is not perhaps to be wondered at, ignorant as you previously were of everything concerning either. Detection could not be in your power, and suspicion certainly not in your inclination. You may possibly wonder why all this was not told you last night. But I was not then master enough of myself to know what could or ought to be revealed. For the truth of everything here related, I can appeal more particularly to the testimony of Colonel Fitzwilliam, who, from our near relationship and constant intimacy, and still more as one of the executors of my father’s will, has been unavoidably acquainted with every particular of these transactions. If your abhorrence of me should make my assertions valueless, you cannot be prevented by the same cause from confiding in my cousin; and that there may be the possibility of consulting him, I shall endeavour to find some opportunity of putting this letter in your hands in the course of the morning. I will only add, God bless you.
vi: "Last night you accused me of two charges of entirely different nature and unequal magnitude. The first charge is that, regardless of the feelings of each party, I separated Mr. Bingley from your sister; the other charge is that I ruined Mr. Wickham's immediate prosperity and shattered all his prospects, in defiance of all appeals, in defiance of honor and humanity. Deliberately and obstinately denying the friend of my youth, whom my father loved, a young man who had no other refuge than our patronage, who was raised to fend for himself. This is an unparalleled vile act, separating two young men whose affection could blossom in just a few weeks. “But from the severe condemnation declared so liberally last evening, for each case, I hope in the future you will believe me, if you read through the explanations below about my behavior and motivations. If while explaining, I mention feelings that might upset you, I can only ask for your forgiveness. But I need to mention them, and if further apologies are unreasonable. “When I first came to reside at Netherfield, like everyone else, I noticed that Mr. Bingley had more affection for your eldest sister than for any other young woman in the area. But it was only at the Netherfield ball that I realized the seriousness of his feelings. I have often seen him in love before. At that ball, while I had the honor of dancing with you, for the first time through Sir William Lucas, I learned that Mr. Bingley's attentions to your sister had raised hopes of a marriage between the two. He spoke of it as if it were a certainty, with only the date and time yet to be determined. “From that moment, I paid close attention to my friend's behavior, and noticed that Bingley's feelings towards your sister exceeded anything I had ever witnessed in him. I also observed your sister. Her demeanor and gestures remained open, cheerful, and graceful as always, but there was no particular sign of affection, and after a thorough examination that evening, I believed that although she was happy to be noticed by him, she did not invite his attention by revealing any sentiments. If you are not mistaken here, I could be mistaken. You understand her better than I do, so I could be mistaken. If that is the case, if I am mistaken, and it causes her distress, you have every right to be angry. But I do not hesitate to assert that, regardless of how amiable her disposition may be, her feelings are not easily swayed, judging by the calmness in her expression and demeanor that a sensitive observer can detect. I sincerely want to believe that she is indifferent, but I must boldly add that my hopes or fears do not usually influence my understanding and decisions. It is not that I believe she is indifferent because I wish it so. I believe this based on impartial observation; as truly as if I had reason to wish otherwise. I oppose the marriage not merely for the sake of opposition, and last night I realized that it would take the strongest emotions to set aside these objections, in my case; if lacking, the relationship would not be bad for him but very bad for me. “But the aversion has other causes that I myself want to forget because they are not apparent to me, although they still exist, and exist to the same degree in both Mr. Bingley's and my cases. I need to briefly mention these causes, though succinctly. Your family's circumstances, although uncomfortable, are insignificant compared to the material desires often manifested through your mother, your three younger sisters, and sometimes even your father. I apologize to you, I feel pained if I offend you. But when you and your sister show hesitation about the shortcomings of your relatives and displeasure at the manifestation of these shortcomings, please take comfort in knowing that your attitudes have avoided the criticism that others have faced, and have even earned you much praise, as well as making both your awareness and temperament worthy of respect. “I can only add that, from what happened that evening, my opinion of everyone was determined, and I was further compelled to act to protect my friend from an unhappy marriage. As you may recall, I am sure, the next day he left Netherfield for London with the intention of returning soon. Now I will explain my actions. Both his sister and I were concerned, and soon we both realized this coincidence, both of us were aware that no time should be wasted in separating him, so we decided to go to London with him. There, I tried my best to point out to my friend the disadvantages of such a choice. I tried to persuade him earnestly. But even if this reproach might have caused him to hesitate or delay his decision, I do not believe it would have prevented the marriage, if not for your sister's indifferent attitude. Previously, he believed that she would reciprocate his feelings with sincere interest, if not equally. But Bingley is inherently shy, and he relied on my judgment more than his own. Therefore, convincing him that he had deceived himself was easy. Once I had made him believe it, urging him not to return to Hertfordshire was not difficult. “I cannot blame myself for having acted to such an extent. In the entire matter, there is only one action of mine that I am dissatisfied with when I recall it, and that is that I lowered myself to use the art of concealing from you the fact that your sister was in town at that time. I knew this information, Miss Bingley knew it too, but Mr. Bingley did not know at all. It is possible that the two might meet without any harmful consequences, but I deemed that his feelings had not yet been entirely extinguished, so there was still a disadvantage in their meeting. Perhaps this concealment and disguise went against my nature. However, I did it, and did it in the hope of achieving the best outcome. On this matter, I have nothing more to say, no further apologies to offer. If I have caused your sister any pain, it was beyond my intention; and although the motives that guided me may not seem sufficient justification to you, I do not know how to condemn these motives. “Regarding the heavier accusation, that I have harmed Mr. Wickham, I can only refute it by explaining to you all the relations he has had with my family. He particularly accuses me of ignorance, but according to the truth I will present, I can call upon witnesses whose honesty is beyond dispute. Mr. Wickham is the son of a very respectable man, who for many years managed all the estates at Pemberley, and due to his virtue in his work, he was highly trusted, so naturally my father helped him. As for George Wickham, my father was very kind to him, as he was practically his adopted son. My father supported his education up to Cambridge University. This support was even more important because his father was poor due to his wife's extravagant lifestyle and could not afford to educate him properly. My father not only cherished his always engaging company but also held him in high regard, hoping he would have a career in the church, so he intended to support him in this direction. As for me, it was only after many, many years that I began to think of him differently. The lowly talents and lack of principles that he carefully concealed from his closest friend could not escape the observation of someone nearly his age, who had opportunities to see him in unguarded moments. Here, once again, I am causing you pain, to what extent only you can know. But whatever feelings Mr. Wickham has stirred in you, the doubt about the nature of these feelings cannot prevent me from exposing his true character. “I have another motivation as well. My father passed away about five years ago, and his affection for him remained so steadfast that in his will, which he specifically conveyed to me, it was stated that he would support the advancement that his profession allowed, and if he took holy orders, he would be given a substantial allowance from the family. There was also a legacy of one thousand pounds. His father passed away shortly after mine, within a year, and Mr. Wickham wrote to inform me that he had finally decided not to take holy orders, and he hoped I could consider providing him with financial assistance immediately rather than waiting until he was appointed. He added that he intended to study law, and I had to admit that one thousand pounds would not be sufficient for him. I wished, rather than believed, that he was sincere. But in any case, I was willing to comply with his request. I knew that Mr. Wickham should not become a clergyman. Therefore, the matter was settled shortly thereafter. He declared that he would renounce any future claims to church support that he might be entitled to, and instead, he received three thousand pounds. All relations between us now seem to be dissolved. I thought so little of him that I did not want to invite him to Pemberley, nor associate with him in the city. I believe he lives mainly in the city, but studying law was just an excuse, and now free from all restraints, he lives idly and extravagantly. "For about three years, I heard little news about him, but when the allowance he received ran out, he wrote to me asking for more. He persuaded me, and I had no difficulty believing him that he was in need. He found studying law to be unprofitable; now he was determined to be ordained, if I would transfer the remaining part of the allowance to him. He believed he was entitled to this because he knew I did not need to support anyone else, and I surely could not forget my grandfather's intentions. You cannot blame me for refusing his plea, or for rejecting all subsequent repeated requests. His resentment was as intense as his material deprivation, and surely he spoke ill of me to others as fiercely as he reproached me. “After this period, all outward appearances of the relationship between the two of us were discarded. I do not know how he managed to live. But last summer, he again forced me to pay painful attention to him. Now I must mention an event that I myself wish to forget, only because I am now compelled to reveal it. In such a lengthy manner, I think I can trust you to keep this matter confidential. My sister Georgiana, who is more than ten years younger than I, was entrusted to the guardianship of my mother's nephew, Colonel Fitzwilliam, and myself. About a year ago, she left school, a residence was established for her in London, and she, along with the manager of this residence, went to Ramsgate, from where she sought out Mr. Wickham. Surely this was premeditated, as he and Mrs. Younge had known each other previously. She deceived us sadly; through her collusion and assistance, he courted Georgiana. My sister's tender heart was strongly impressed by his kindness to a child, to the point that she was persuaded she loved him and agreed to elope with him. At that time, she was only fifteen, so this was an excuse to run away, and after mentioning her imprudence, I am pleased to add that I learned of this through her. I met the two of them one or two days before they planned to elope. Georgiana, not wanting to cause her brother, whom she also viewed as a father, distress and offense, confessed everything to me. You can imagine what I thought and how I acted. For the sake of my sister's dignity and feelings, I kept the matter confidential, but I wrote to Mr. Wickham, and of course, Mrs. Younge was dismissed. Surely Mr. Wickham's aim was my sister's fortune, about thirty thousand pounds, but I cannot help but guess that a desire for revenge against me was also a strong motivating factor. Indeed, his revenge could have been complete. "Miss, I have recounted every event truthfully that pertains to both of us. If you do not dismiss the story as falsehood, I hope you will retract your accusation of my cruel treatment towards Mr. Wickham. I am not sure how he has influenced you, with what deceitful words, but it is likely that he has succeeded. Previously, you knew nothing of these matters, you had no means to investigate, and certainly, you had no inclination to doubt. You may wonder why I did not recount all these events last night. But at that time, I could not maintain the composure to know what could or should be said. Regarding the truth behind what I have recounted here, I can call upon Colonel Fitzwilliam as a witness. As he is closely related and lives in proximity to us, still being an executor of my father's will, he could not help but be well aware of all the details. If you despise me so bitterly that all my explanations are worthless, you can still confide in my cousin, and since you may have the opportunity to seek his opinion, I have endeavored to find a chance to deliver this letter to you this morning. “I only have one more thing to say: may God bless you.”
tr: "Last night, you accused me of two evils of very different natures and varying degrees of importance. The first was that I separated Mr. Bingley from your sister without regard for either of their feelings, and the second was that I hindered Mr. Wickham's prosperity and darkened his future by rejecting various claims, disregarding honor and humanity. –To deliberately and irresponsibly cast aside a childhood friend, known to be my father's favorite, who had no means of subsistence outside our protection and was raised to expect to benefit from our patronage, would have been a deprivation incomparable to the separation of children with only a few weeks of shared feelings. –But when the following explanation of my actions and reasons is read, I hope to be spared from the severity of the accusations so unreservedly directed at me last night in both matters. –If I feel compelled to explain emotions that may seem repulsive to you while doing so, I can only apologize for it. –I must comply with this obligation –to apologize further would be absurd. –It wasn't long after I arrived in Hertfordshire that I, like others, saw that Bingley preferred your sister over all the other girls in the countryside. But it wasn't until the dance evening at Netherfield that I realized he had serious attachment. –I had seen him in love many times before. –At that ball, while I was dancing with you, a casual remark by Sir William Lucas made me realize for the first time that Bingley's interest in your sister had created expectations of marriage in everyone. Sir William spoke of it as if it were a certain event, with only the date left to be determined. From that moment, I observed my friend's actions carefully; and it was only then that I understood his attachment to Miss Bennet was beyond what I had seen before. I also watched your sister. –Her demeanor was as open, cheerful, and charming as ever, but there were no signs of special interest; from my observations that evening, I concluded that while Miss Bennet accepted Bingley's interest with pleasure, she did not invite it with any shared feelings. –If you are not mistaken on this point, then I was wrong. Your better knowledge of your sister strengthens the second possibility. –If so, if I made a mistake that caused her pain, your resentment would not be unjust. But I will say without hesitation that the seriousness in your sister's face and demeanor was such that even the most careful observer would think she was someone who, while friendly, was not easily accessible to the heart. –It is true that I wanted to believe in her indifference, –but I can say that my investigations and decisions are generally not influenced by my hopes or fears. –I did not believe in your sister's indifference because I wanted it to be so; –I believed it with impartial conviction, and with the same sincerity. –My objections to the marriage were not the matters I confessed last night could be overcome by a great passion on my part; the issue of relatives was not as great an obstacle for my friend as it was for me. –But there were other annoying circumstances; –although they still exist, and even if they exist to the same extent for both of us, they are not constantly in front of me, so I personally try to forget them. –These reasons also need to be briefly mentioned. –The situation of your mother's family, though repulsive, is insignificant compared to the absolute vulgarity almost always displayed by her, your three younger sisters, and even occasionally your father. –Forgive me. –It pains me to offend you. However, despite the discomfort you feel because of the faults of your closest relatives and the displeasure you will feel at their being described in this way, you may find consolation in knowing that the praise of your and your sister's intelligence and sensitivity, which prevents you from sharing in a similar judgment, is frequently expressed as you deserve. –Lastly, I must say that what happened that evening confirmed my views on everyone and strengthened my desire to protect my friend from a connection I found very unpleasant without further delay. –The next day, as you surely know, he went to London from Netherfield, intending to return soon. –Now it's time to explain the role I played. –His sisters' discomfort was no less than mine; we soon realized we shared the same thought; and believing that we should not waste time in separating their brother, we immediately decided to go to London to join him. –We went –there I began to explain to my friend the certain disadvantages of such a choice. –I did not just describe them, I proved them. –This intervention could have accelerated or delayed his decision, but in my opinion, it would not have prevented the marriage in the end if I had not mentioned your sister's indifference, which I did without hesitation. Until then, he believed he had received sincere reciprocation of feelings, if not to the same extent as his own. –But Bingley has a tremendous natural humility; he trusts my judgments more than his own. –It was not difficult to convince him that he was deceiving himself. After giving him this belief, persuading him not to return to Hertfordshire was a moment's work. –I cannot blame myself for what I did. There is one aspect of my behavior in the whole matter that I do not like to remember; that is, I stooped so low as to scheme to keep from him the fact that your sister was in town. I knew, Miss Bingley knew, but her brother still does not know. –It is possible that they could have met without bad consequences; –but it seemed to me that his feelings had not yet faded enough for him to see her safely. –Perhaps these secretive, devious actions did not suit me. –But I did it once, and I did it with good intentions. –I have nothing more to say on this matter, no other excuse to offer. If I hurt your sister's feelings, it was unknowingly; the reasons that guided me may naturally seem insufficient to you, but I have not yet learned to reject them. –As for the more serious accusation, the accusation that I harmed Mr. Wickham, I can refute it by revealing his entire connection with my family. I do not know exactly what he accuses me of; but I can present more than one witness whose reliability is beyond doubt regarding the truth of what I will tell. Mr. Wickham is the son of a very respectable man who managed all the Pemberley estates; his father's good conduct in his duties naturally inspired my father with a desire to be beneficial to him, and he showed his affection for his godson George Wickham with all his generosity. My father supported him at school, and later at Cambridge –significantly, because his own father, condemned to poverty by his wife's extravagance, was not in a position to provide him with a gentleman's education. My father not only valued the friendship of this young man, who always had pleasant manners, but also held high hopes for him and decided to provide him with a means of livelihood by hoping he would choose the church as his profession. For my part, I began to think differently about him years, long years ago. He was careful to hide his immoral tendencies and indecency from his closest friend, but these did not escape the notice of a young man almost the same age as him, who had the opportunity to catch him in unguarded moments, unlike Mr. Darcy. Here I will upset you again –only you can know how much. But whatever feelings Mr. Wickham has aroused, my doubts about their nature will not prevent me from revealing his true face. There is another reason. My kind-hearted father died five years ago; his attachment to Mr. Wickham continued until the end; so much so that in his will, he specifically instructed me to assist him in advancing in his profession as much as possible, and if he qualified for the clergy, to give him a valuable family living as soon as it became vacant. There was also a sum of one thousand pounds. His father did not outlive mine by much; six months after these events, Mr. Wickham wrote to me saying he had decided to give up his religious education, and hoped I would not find it inappropriate to expect some financial assistance instead of a church appointment that would be of no use to him. He also added that he intended to study law; he assumed I would understand that the interest on a thousand pounds would not be enough to support him there. Although I did not believe he was sincere, I wished he were; but in any case, I was ready to accept his proposal. I knew Mr. Wickham should not be a clergyman. The matter was quickly settled. He renounced all financial rights he could have received from the church and accepted three thousand pounds in return. Thus, all relations between us seemed to be over. My thoughts about him were so negative that I neither invited him to Pemberley nor allowed him to appear to me in town. I believe he mostly lived in town, but the study of law was merely a lie; once free of all obstacles, his life became one of complete idleness and vagabondage. For three years, I heard little from him; but upon the death of the clergyman intended for him, he again approached me for the letter of appointment. He wanted me to believe he was in very bad condition, which I found easy to believe. He had seen that law was a non-lucrative profession and had now definitely decided to take the clergy, provided I gave him the said living –he had no doubt about it, and besides, who else did I have to look after, and I could not have forgotten my dear father's intention. You cannot blame me for refusing this attempt or resisting its repetition. His resentment was proportional to the harshness of his circumstances –his complaints to others were as intense as the insults he directed at me. After this period, all signs of acquaintance were abandoned. I do not know how he lived. But last summer, he entered my life again in a very painful way. I must now speak of an event I wish I could forget and which no force other than the current matter would compel me to reveal to anyone. I am telling you this because I have no doubt you know how to keep a secret. My sister, who is at least ten years younger than me, was left under the guardianship of my mother's nephew, Colonel Fitzwilliam, and myself. About a year ago, she was taken from school and a house was opened for her in London; last summer, she went to Ramsgate with the lady managing the house; Mr. Wickham also went there, undoubtedly with intent; for it turned out he had a prior acquaintance with Mrs. Younge, which we had been quite mistaken about her character; with her arrangement and assistance, he managed to ingratiate himself with Georgiana; my sister, whose sensitive heart had been filled with affectionate memories of him since childhood, was convinced she was in love with him and agreed to elope with him. She was only fifteen at the time; this must be her excuse; after expressing her imprudence, I am also pleased to add that I learned of the matter from her. A few days before the planned elopement, I unexpectedly joined them; at that time, Georgiana could no longer bear the idea of subjecting a brother she saw as a father to such distress and insult, and she told me everything as it was. You can imagine what I felt and how I acted. My concern for my sister's reputation and feelings prevented the matter from becoming public; but my writing to Mr. Wickham and his immediate departure were simultaneous; Mrs. Younge was, of course, dismissed from her position. Mr. Wickham's main goal was undoubtedly my sister's thirty thousand-pound fortune; on the other hand, I cannot help but think that the hope of taking revenge on me was also a strong motivating factor. This, madam, is an honest explanation of every event between us; if you do not reject it as a lie, I hope you will retract the accusation that I have been cruel to Mr. Wickham. I do not know what style or lies he used to influence you; but perhaps his success should not be surprising, as you had no prior knowledge of these matters. You could not have learned these things yourself; doubting them was naturally not in your nature. You may wonder why all this was not told to you last night. But at that time, I was not in a state to decide how much could be explained. Regarding the truth of everything told here, I can particularly recommend the testimony of Colonel Fitzwilliam; due to our close relationship and constant confidences, and as one of the executors of my father's will, he has inevitably been involved in every detail of these transactions. If your contempt for me makes my explanations worthless, there is no reason to prevent you from consulting my cousin; I will try to find an opportunity to give you this letter this morning so that you can consult him. All I can wish is, may God protect you.
es: Yesterday you accused me of two offenses of very different nature and magnitude. The first was having separated Mr. Bingley from his sister, without consideration for the feelings of either; and the other, that despite certain rights and ignoring honor and humanity, I ruined Mr. Wickham's immediate prosperity and destroyed his future. To have abandoned ruthlessly and intentionally the companion of my youth and my father's favorite, a young man who had almost no other future than that of our rectory and who had been educated for its practice, would be a depravity that could not be compared to the separation of two young people whose affection had been the result of only a few weeks. But I hope you will withdraw the severe censure you so openly directed at me last night, when you have read the following account of my actions regarding these two circumstances and their motives. If in the explanation that I cannot help but give, I am forced to express feelings that offend you, I can only say that I regret it. One must submit to necessity and any apology would be absurd. It wasn't long after I arrived in Hertfordshire that I noticed, like everyone else, that Mr. Bingley favored your eldest sister much more than any of the other young ladies in the locality; but until the night of the Netherfield ball, I did not see that his affection was formal. I had seen him in love several times before. At that ball, while I had the honor of dancing with you, I learned for the first time, through a casual remark from Sir William Lucas, that Bingley's attentions towards your sister had given rise to hopes of marriage; he spoke of it as a settled matter with only the date to be fixed. From that moment, I carefully observed my friend's behavior and noticed that his inclination towards Miss Bennet was greater than any he had felt before. I also studied your sister. Her appearance and manners were as frank, cheerful, and attractive as ever, but they did not reveal any particular regard. My observations that evening left me convinced that, despite the pleasure with which she received my friend's attentions, she did not reciprocate his feelings. If you were not mistaken about this, then I must have been in error. Since you know your sister better, it is more likely the latter; and if so, if driven by that error I have caused her suffering, your resentment is not unfounded. But I do not hesitate to assert that your sister's appearance and demeanor could have given even the most astute observer the assurance that, despite her affectionate nature, her heart did not seem to have been affected. It is true that I wished to believe in her indifference, but I assure you that my studies and conclusions are not usually influenced by my hopes or fears. I did not believe her indifferent because it suited me to believe so; I believed it with absolute impartiality. My objections to that marriage were not exactly those I acknowledged last night could only be overcome by the force of passion, as in my own case; the disparity in rank would not be as serious for my friend as it would be for me; but there were other obstacles that, despite existing in both my friend's case and mine, I would have tried to forget since they did not affect me directly. I must say what they were, though I will do so briefly. The position of your mother's family, though questionable, was nothing compared to the absolute impropriety so often, almost constantly, displayed by that lady, by her three younger sisters, and occasionally even by her father. Forgive me, it pains me to offend you; but amid the concerns about the faults of your closest relatives and your displeasure at my mentioning them, take comfort in knowing that the fact that both you and your sister conduct yourselves in such a way that no similar reproaches can be made against you, elevates you even more in the esteem you deserve. I will only say that what happened that night confirmed all my suspicions and increased the reasons that might have already prompted me to preserve my friend from what I considered an unfortunate union. Bingley left for London the next day, as you will recall, with the intention of returning very soon. Now it remains to explain my involvement in the matter. The displeasure of his sisters had also intensified, and we soon discovered that we agreed in our assessments. We saw that there was no time to lose if we wanted to separate Bingley from his sister, and we decided to go with him to London. We moved there, and immediately I set about making my friend understand the dangers of his choice. I listed and described them to him with diligence. But, although this might have caused his determination to waver or be postponed, I do not believe it would have ultimately prevented the marriage, except for the conviction I managed to instill in him of his sister's indifference. Until then, Bingley had believed that she reciprocated his affection with sincere, though not equal, interest. But Bingley possesses great natural modesty and, moreover, genuinely believes that my sagacity is greater than his. Even so, it was not easy to convince him that he had been mistaken. Once convinced, making him decide not to return to Hertfordshire was a matter of an instant. I see nothing in all this that is reprehensible against me. One thing alone in all I did seems reproachable to me: having agreed to take the necessary measures to keep Bingley unaware of his sister's presence in the city. I knew she was in London, and Miss Bingley knew it too; but my friend has not found out yet. Perhaps if they had met, nothing would have happened; but it did not seem to me that his affection had extinguished enough for him to see her again without any danger. Maybe this concealment is unworthy of me, but I believed it my duty to do so. I have nothing more to say on this matter nor any further apology to offer. If I have hurt his sister's feelings, it has been unintentionally, and although my motives may seem insufficient to her, I do not find them so condemnable. Regarding the other more important accusation of having wronged Mr. Wickham, I can only counter it by explaining in detail the relationship of that gentleman with my family. I am unaware of what he may have specifically accused me of, but there is more than one reliable witness who can corroborate the truth of what I am about to tell you. Mr. Wickham is the son of a most respectable man who was in charge of managing all the Pemberley estates for many years, and whose excellent conduct inclined my father to favor him, as was natural; my father's affection was therefore generously manifested in George Wickham, who was his godson. He funded his education at a school and then at Cambridge, for his father, constantly impoverished by his wife's extravagances, would not have been able to give him a gentleman's education. My father not only enjoyed the boy's company, who was always very charming, but also formed the highest opinion of him and believed that the Church could be his profession, so he sought to provide him with the means for it. I, on the other hand, began to have a very different opinion of Wickham many years ago. The propensity for vices and the lack of principles that he took care to hide from his best friend could not escape the observation of a boy almost his age who had the chance to catch him in moments of carelessness that Mr. Darcy did not see. Now I will have to sadden you again to a degree that only you can calculate, but whatever feelings Mr. Wickham may have awakened in you, this suspicion will not prevent me from unmasking him; on the contrary, it will be an additional incentive for me. My excellent father died five years ago, and his affection for Mr. Wickham remained so constant until the end that in his will he recommended that I support him in the best way that his profession would allow; if he were ordained a priest, my father wished for him to be granted a benefice capable of supporting a family, at the first vacancy. He also bequeathed him a thousand pounds. Wickham's father did not survive mine by much. And half a year after his death, the young Wickham wrote to me informing me that he had finally resolved not to be ordained, and that, in exchange for the benefice he was not to enjoy, he hoped I would give him some more immediate pecuniary advantage. He added that he intended to pursue a career in law, and that I should understand that the interest on a thousand pounds could not suffice for that. More than believing him sincere, I wished he were; but in any case, I agreed to his proposal. I knew that Mr. Wickham was not suited to be a clergyman; so I arranged the matter. He renounced all claims to assistance regarding the clerical profession, even if he might find himself in a position to adopt it, and accepted three thousand pounds. Everything seemed settled between us. I had too poor an opinion of him to invite him to Pemberley or admit his company in the capital. I believe he lived mostly in London, but his law studies were nothing but a pretext, and as there was nothing to hold him, he freely indulged in idleness and dissipation. I knew almost nothing of him for three years, but upon the death of the holder of the rectory that had been intended for him, he sent me a letter asking me to grant it to him. He told me, and it was not difficult for me to believe, that he was in very poor circumstances, opined that the law career was not profitable, and was completely decided to be ordained if I granted him the rectory in question, something he did not doubt I would do, as he knew I had no one else to occupy it and on the other hand, I could not forget the wishes of my venerable father. I believe you cannot blame me for having refused to comply with this demand and preventing it from being repeated. Wickham's resentment was proportional to the calamitousness of his circumstances, and he undoubtedly spoke of me to people with the same violence with which he directly insulted me. After this, all relations between him and me were broken off. I do not know how he lived. But last summer I received very unpleasant news about him. I have to tell you something now that I myself would like to forget and that no other circumstance than the present one could induce me to reveal to any human being. I have no doubt that you will keep my secret. My sister, who is ten years younger than I am, was left under the guardianship of my mother's nephew, Colonel Fitzwilliam, and myself. About a year ago, she left school and settled in London. Last summer, she went with her governess to Ramsgate, where Mr. Wickham also went expressly, with complete certainty, for we later learned that Mrs. Younge and he had been in contact. We had, unfortunately, been deceived about the character of the governess. With her complicity and help, Wickham set about seducing Georgiana, whose affectionate heart was strongly impressed by his attentions; she was only a child and, believing herself to be in love, consented to elope. She was then only fifteen years old, which serves as an excuse. After confessing her imprudence, I have the satisfaction of adding that I learned of that plan from her herself. I went to Ramsgate and surprised them a day or two before the planned elopement, and then Georgiana, unable to distress and offend her brother whom she almost loved as a father, told me everything. You can imagine how I felt and how I acted. Out of consideration for my sister's honor and feelings, I did not make a public scandal, but I wrote to Mr. Wickham, who left immediately. Mrs. Younge, naturally, was dismissed on the spot. Mr. Wickham's main objective was undoubtedly my sister's fortune, which amounts to thirty thousand pounds, but I cannot help but suspect that his desire for revenge against me was also part of his purpose. It really would have been a complete revenge. This is, miss, the faithful narration of what happened between him and me; and if you do not reject it as absolutely false, I hope that henceforth you will withdraw the accusation of having behaved cruelly towards Mr. Wickham. I do not know in what way or with what falsehood he has deceived you; but it is not surprising that he has succeeded, for you were unaware of all these matters. It was impossible for you to find them out and you were not inclined to suspect them. You may wonder why I did not tell you everything last night, but at that time I was not in control of myself and did not know what I could or should reveal to you. Regarding the truth of everything I have narrated to you, I can appeal to the testimony of Colonel Fitzwilliam, who, due to our close relationship and constant interaction, and even more so for being one of the executors of my father's will, has had to become fully aware of everything that has happened. If the hatred you feel towards me invalidates my assertions, you may consult with my cousin, against whom you will have no reason for distrust; and to make this possible, I will try to find the opportunity to get this letter into your hands this very morning. I only have to add: May God bless you.

en: “Fitzwilliam Darcy.”
vi: Fitzwilliam Darcy
tr: FITZWILLIAM DARCY"
es: Fitzwilliam Darcy.

en: CHAPTER XXXVI.
vi: Chapter 36
tr: Chapter XIII
es: CHAPTER XXXVI

en: ELIZABETH, when Mr. Darcy gave her the letter, did not expect it to contain a renewal of his offers, she had formed no expectation at all of its contents. But such as they were, it may be well supposed how eagerly she went through them, and what a contrariety of emotion they excited. Her feelings as she read were scarcely to be defined. With amazement did she first understand that he believed any apology to be in his power; and steadfastly was she persuaded, that he could have no explanation to give, which a just sense of shame would not conceal. With a strong prejudice against everything he might say, she began his account of what had happened at Netherfield. She read with an eagerness which hardly left her power of comprehension; and from impatience of knowing what the next sentence might bring, was incapable of attending to the sense of the one before her eyes. His belief of her sister’s insensibility she instantly resolved to be false; and his account of the real, the worst objections to the match, made her too angry to have any wish of doing him justice. He expressed no regret for what he had done which satisfied her; his style was not penitent, but haughty. It was all pride and insolence.
vi: When Mr. Darcy handed her the letter, Elizabeth had not expected him to propose to her again, nor could she anticipate its contents. But she eagerly read it, and the letter caused conflicting emotions within her. She could not clearly define her thoughts as she read through the letter. At first, she was surprised to understand that he believed he had the ability to apologize to her, and she remained firmly convinced that he had no explanation that could justify his shameful behavior. With a strong prejudice against everything he might say, she began with the explanation of what had happened at Netherfield. She eagerly read, but in her impatience to know what the next sentence said, she could not clearly grasp what she was reading. She immediately assumed that his belief in her sister's indifference was wrong, and his explanation of the strong objections made her too angry to consider him impartially. He did not show any regret for what he had done; his manner was not repentant but arrogant. It was all pride and insolence.
tr: When Mr. Darcy gave her the letter, although Elizabeth did not expect it to reiterate his marriage proposal, she had no idea what it might be about. But given what it explained, it is easy to imagine how eagerly she read the letter and the complex emotions she experienced. What she felt while reading is indescribable. First, she saw with astonishment that Mr. Darcy believed he could somehow manage to apologize; whereas Elizabeth firmly believed that there was no explanation Mr. Darcy could give without blushing from shame. With a strong prejudice against everything he might say, she began reading his words about what happened at Netherfield. She read with an excitement that did not leave her mind at ease, and due to her impatience to learn what the next sentence might bring, she could not manage to pay attention to the meaning of the sentence before her. She immediately dismissed Mr. Darcy's belief in her sister's indifference as wrong; the most real, the worst objections against the marriage angered her so much that she could not remain impartial. She found it understandable that he said he did not regret what he had done; there was no remorse in his tone, there was arrogance. From beginning to end, it was proud and disrespectful.
es: Elizabeth did not expect, when Darcy gave her the letter, that he would repeat his proposal in it, but she had no idea what it might contain. Upon discovering it, one can well imagine how quickly she read it and what conflicting emotions it aroused in her. It would have been difficult to define her feelings. At first, she believed with astonishment that Darcy would want to apologize as best he could, but she immediately became firmly convinced that he could not offer any explanation that the most basic sense of dignity would not advise concealing. With great prejudice against everything he might say, she began to read his account of what had happened at Netherfield. Her eyes skimmed the paper with such anxiety that she barely had time to comprehend, and her impatience to know what the next sentence said prevented her from understanding the meaning of the one she was reading. She instantly assumed that Darcy's belief in her sister's indifference was false, and the worst objections he raised to that marriage angered her too much to be able to do him justice. She was pleased that he expressed no regret for what he had done; his style revealed no contrition, but arrogance. In his lines, she saw nothing but pride and insolence.

en: But when this subject was succeeded by his account of Mr. Wickham—when she read, with somewhat clearer attention, a relation of events which, if true, must overthrow every cherished opinion of his worth, and which bore so alarming an affinity to his own history of himself—her feelings were yet more acutely painful and more difficult of definition. Astonishment, apprehension, and even horror, oppressed her. She wished to discredit it entirely, repeatedly exclaiming, “This must be false! This cannot be! This must be the grossest falsehood!”—and when she had gone through the whole letter, though scarcely knowing anything of the last page or two, put it hastily away, protesting that she would not regard it, that she would never look in it again.
vi: But when he mentioned Mr. Wickham, as she read more attentively, the events, if true, would surely dispel all her good feelings about his worth. Her feelings became more painful and harder to define. She was extremely surprised, worried, even horrified. She wanted to reject everything, constantly shouting: "This is not right! It can't be like this! This is nonsense!" And when she had finished reading the letter, though she remembered nothing of the last one or two pages, she hurriedly folded the letter, convinced that she should not believe it, that she would never read it again.
tr: But when the explanation regarding Mr. Wickham followed this subject, if it were true, it should have shattered every good thought she had about Mr. Wickham, and as she read the explanation of events that bore a very disturbing similarity to the story he had told with a bit more clear attention, she felt an even more intense and indescribable pain. She was left in astonishment, anxiety, even horror. She wanted to oppose it all, repeatedly cried out, "Lies! It cannot be true! The utmost of lies!" – when she finished reading the letter, although she understood very little from the last one or two pages, she hastily folded and put it away, saying she would not believe what was written and would not look at it again.
es: But when she came to the part concerning Wickham, she read with greater attention. Faced with that account of events which, if true, would destroy all her good opinion of the young man, and which bore an alarming similarity to what Wickham himself had told her, her feelings became even more distressing and harder to define; confusion, suspicion, and even horror overwhelmed her. She wanted to deny it all and repeatedly exclaimed: "That must be false, it can't be true! It must be the greatest of lies!" She finished reading the letter, and without having taken in the last one or two pages, she quickly put it away, complaining to herself that she would not look at it again, that she did not want to know anything about it.

en: In this perturbed state of mind, with thoughts that could rest on nothing, she walked on; but it would not do: in half a minute the letter was unfolded again; and collecting herself as well as she could, she again began the mortifying perusal of all that related to Wickham, and commanded herself so far as to examine the meaning of every sentence. The account of his connection with the Pemberley family was exactly what he had related himself; and the kindness of the late Mr. Darcy, though she had not before known its extent, agreed equally well with his own words. So far each recital confirmed the other; but when she came to the will, the difference was great. What Wickham had said of the living was fresh in her memory; and as she recalled his very words, it was impossible not to feel that there was gross duplicity on one side or the other, and, for a few moments, she flattered herself that her wishes did not err. But when she read and re-read, with the closest attention, the particulars immediately following of Wickham’s resigning all pretensions to the living, of his receiving in lieu so considerable a sum as three thousand pounds, again was she forced to hesitate. She put down the letter, weighed every circumstance with what she meant to be impartiality—deliberated on the probability of each statement—but with little success. On both sides it was only assertion. Again she read on. But every line proved more clearly that the affair, which she had believed it impossible that any contrivance could so represent as to render Mr. Darcy’s conduct in it less than infamous, was capable of a turn which must make him entirely blameless throughout the whole.
vi: In such a state of mental turmoil, with intentions not knowing where to cling, she continued to walk. But she could not control herself, opened the letter again, trying to calm herself in her distressed state, and read everything about Wickham again, examining the meaning in each sentence. The letter's account of Mr. Wickham's relationship with the Pemberly family was just as he had told. The kindness of the late Mr. Darcy was also as he had said, though she had not known it well before. Up to this point, everything matched, but when she read the part about the will, there was a significant difference. She still remembered the allowance that Wickham mentioned, and when pondering each word he said, she couldn't help but think that either one or the other had behaved deceitfully, and for a moment she was proud that she had not been mistaken. But as she continued to read, then carefully reread, the subsequent details about Wickham renouncing all claims to the support, instead accepting a sum of three thousand pounds, made her uneasy. She put the letter down, considering every situation she thought was fair – cautious about the assumptions in each sentence – but she could not reach a conclusion. Each side was adamant about what they said. She read on. But each line showed more clearly that the matter, which she had believed no scheme could present in such a way as to make Mr. Darcy appear not too bad, had taken a step or made him completely innocent.
tr: In this shaken state of mind, he continued to walk with scattered thoughts; but it didn't work; half a minute later, the letter was opened again; he tried to collect himself as best as he could and began to read all those things about Wickham again in shame, forcing himself to examine the meaning of each sentence. The connection with the Pemberley family was exactly as he had described; although he did not know the extent of it until then, the kindness of the late Mr. Darcy matched his own words exactly. Up to that point, both statements corroborated each other: but when it came to the will, the difference was significant. What Wickham had said about the church was still fresh in his memory; remembering his words, it was impossible not to feel that there was a heavy lie on one side or the other; for a few minutes, he complimented himself by saying that his instincts would not mislead him. But upon closer reading, upon re-reading, the details behind Wickham's relinquishment of all claims to the church and instead receiving a substantial sum of three thousand pounds made him hesitate again. He put the letter aside, trying to weigh every possibility in his mind impartially – he pondered and considered the likelihood of every word, but he was unsuccessful. Both statements were merely claims. He read it again. But each line more clearly revealed that although he did not believe the matter had been falsified to make Mr. Darcy's behavior appear vile, it was also open to an interpretation that would show him completely innocent from the beginning to the end of the story.
es: In such a state of perturbation, assaulted by a thousand confused thoughts, she continued walking; but it was of no use; after half a minute she took out the letter again and, overcoming herself as best she could, began once more the mortifying reading of what referred to Wickham, mastering herself enough to examine the meaning of each phrase. His relationship with the Pemberley family was exactly as he had said, and the kindness of the old Mr. Darcy, although Elizabeth had not known until now how far it had gone, also coincided with what Wickham himself had indicated. Therefore, one account confirmed the other, but when it came to the matter of the will, it was very different. Everything he had said about his ecclesiastical benefice was fresh in the young woman's memory, and recalling his words, she had to acknowledge that there was double intention on one side or the other, and for a few moments she believed that her wishes were not deceiving her. But when she read and reread everything that had happened after Wickham had refused the rectory, in exchange for which he had received a sum as considerable as three thousand pounds, she could not help but doubt again. She folded the letter and weighed all the circumstances with her supposed impartiality, meditating on the probabilities of sincerity of each account, but she made no progress; from both sides she found nothing but assertions. She began to read again, but each line proved more clearly that the matter, which she had not believed could be explained in any way other than as an infamy to the detriment of Darcy's conduct, could be exposed in such a way that left Darcy completely free of blame.

en: The extravagance and general profligacy which he scrupled not to lay to Mr. Wickham’s charge exceedingly shocked her; the more so, as she could bring no proof of its injustice. She had never heard of him before his entrance into the ——shire militia, in which he had engaged at the persuasion of the young man, who, on meeting him accidentally in town, had there renewed a slight acquaintance. Of his former way of life, nothing had been known in Hertfordshire but what he told
vi: The extravagance and liberality that he had unhesitatingly accused Mr. Wickham of shocked her, even more so because she saw no evidence of any injustice. She had never heard of Mr. Wickham before he joined the military at the persuasion of her young brother, who had rekindled a superficial acquaintance upon meeting him again in the city. No one in Hertfordshire knew anything about his previous life except for what he himself had said.
tr: The accusation of excess and general immorality that he did not hesitate to direct at Mr. Wickham shook him deeply; it shook him even more as he could not find any evidence to disprove the accusation. He had heard nothing about him before he joined the -------shire Regiment; he had joined this regiment on the recommendation of a young man he had met by chance in the city and quickly renewed his friendship with. Nothing was known about his previous lifestyle except for what he had told in Hertfordshire.
es: The vices and prodigality that Darcy did not hesitate to attribute to Wickham outraged her excessively, all the more so because she had no evidence to refute Darcy's testimony. Elizabeth had never heard of Wickham before his joining the county garrison, which had been prompted by his casual encounter in London with a young man she only knew superficially. Of his former life, nothing was known in Hertfordshire except what he himself had told.

en: “Meeting accidentally in Town”
vi: No one in Hertfordshire knew anything about his previous life except for what he himself had said.
tr: Nothing was known about his previous lifestyle except for what he had told in Hertfordshire.
es: Of his former life, nothing was known in Hertfordshire except what he himself had told.

en: himself. As to his real character, had information been in her power, she had never felt a wish of inquiring. His countenance, voice, and manner, had established him at once in the possession of every virtue. She tried to recollect some instance of goodness, some distinguished trait of integrity or benevolence, that might rescue him from the attacks of Mr. Darcy; or at least, by the predominance of virtue, atone for those casual errors, under which she would endeavour to class what Mr. Darcy had described as the idleness and vice of many years’ continuance. But no such recollection befriended her. She could see him instantly before her, in every charm of air and address, but she could remember no more substantial good than the general approbation of the neighbourhood, and the regard which his social powers had gained him in the mess. After pausing on this point a considerable while, she once more continued to read. But, alas! the story which followed, of his designs on Miss Darcy, received some confirmation from what had passed between Colonel Fitzwilliam and herself only the morning before; and at last she was referred for the truth of every particular to Colonel Fitzwilliam himself—from whom she had previously received the information of his near concern in all his cousin’s affairs and whose character she had no reason to question. At one time she had almost resolved on applying to him, but the idea was checked by the awkwardness of the application, and at length wholly banished by the conviction that Mr. Darcy would never have hazarded such a proposal, if he had not been well assured of his cousin’s corroboration.
vi: No one in Hertfordshire knew anything about his previous life except for what he himself had said. She never wanted to inquire about his true character. His face, voice, and gestures all immediately confirmed every virtue of his. She tried to recall a few virtues, a few unique traits of integrity or benevolence that could help defend him against Mr. Darcy's accusations, or at least could excuse the common faults, as she thought, that Mr. Darcy had described as laziness and long-standing vices. But she could not remember anything like that. She could see him right before her, every manner and word captivating, but she could not recall any substantial point of his virtues, except for the approval of neighbors and the affection due to his social skills among the guests. After a moment of pondering this point, she continued reading. But, alas! The subsequent story about his intentions towards Miss Darcy, partially confirmed by the conversation she had with Colonel Fitzwilliam the previous morning, and finally substantiated in every detail by Colonel Fitzwilliam himself – who had informed her of his concerns about his cousin's actions, a man whose integrity she had no reason to doubt. For a moment she decided she would ask him about it, but the intention wavered because she felt awkward bringing it up. Ultimately, she dismissed the idea altogether, convinced that Mr. Darcy would never risk making such a proposal unless he was certain his cousin would corroborate his account.
tr: If he had learned something about his true character, he would not have felt the desire to investigate. Thanks to his face, voice, and demeanor, he had immediately established himself as a very virtuous person. Elizabeth tried to remember an example of goodness, a sign of evident honesty or humanity that could save him from Mr. Darcy's attacks or at least help classify the faults Mr. Darcy described as long-standing idleness and wickedness as mere ordinary mistakes through his inherent morality, but she could not recall anything more tangible than the general positive opinion in the village and the reputation his sociability had earned him among his fellow soldiers. After dwelling on this point for a while, she continued reading once again. But alas! The next story described his plans regarding Miss Darcy and was somewhat confirmed by the conversations she had had with Colonel Fitzwilliam earlier that morning; in the end, every detail was referred to Colonel Fitzwilliam for verification, from whom she had already learned about his close interest in all his cousin's affairs and had no reason to question his character. At one point, she almost decided to consult him but realized it would seem odd and gave up; in the end, she dismissed the idea entirely, thinking that Mr. Darcy would not risk making such an offer unless he was quite sure of his cousin's cooperation.
es: Of his former life, nothing was known in Hertfordshire except what he himself had told. As for his true character, despite Elizabeth having the opportunity to analyze it, she never felt the desire to do so; his appearance, voice, and manners instantly endowed him with all virtues. She tried to recall some noble trait, some special gesture of integrity or kindness that could shield him from Darcy's attacks, or at least that the predominance of good qualities would compensate for those casual errors, which was how she insisted on labeling what Darcy branded as laziness and immorality ingrained in him from the beginning. She imagined Wickham in front of her and remembered him with all the charm of his demeanor, but apart from the general approval he enjoyed in the locality and the consideration he had gained among his comrades for his sympathy, Elizabeth could find nothing more in his favor. After having reflected for a long time on this point, she resumed reading. But what followed about the adventure with Miss Darcy was partly confirmed by the conversation Elizabeth had had the previous morning with Colonel Fitzwilliam; and, at the end of the letter, Darcy appealed, to prove the truth of everything, to the colonel himself, whose involvement in all his cousin's affairs Elizabeth knew in advance, and whose veracity she had no reason to doubt. She was about to turn to him, but restrained herself at the thought of how awkward it would be to take that step; dismissing it in the end, convinced that Darcy would never have risked proposing it without being absolutely certain that his cousin would corroborate his statements.

en: She perfectly remembered everything that had passed in conversation between Wickham and herself in their first evening at Mr. Philips’s. Many of his expressions were still fresh in her memory. She was now struck with the impropriety of such communications to a stranger, and wondered it had escaped her before. She saw the indelicacy of putting himself forward as he had done, and the inconsistency of his professions with his conduct. She remembered that he had boasted of having no fear of seeing Mr. Darcy—that Mr. Darcy might leave the country, but that he should stand his ground; yet he had avoided the Netherfield ball the very next week. She remembered, also, that till the Netherfield family had quitted the country, he had told his story to no one but herself; but that after their removal, it had been everywhere discussed; that he had then no reserves, no scruples in sinking Mr. Darcy’s character, though he had assured her that respect for the father would always prevent his exposing the son.
vi: She clearly remembered everything that was exchanged between Wickham and her on the evening they first met at Mr. Phillips' house. Many of his words were still vividly imprinted in her memory. Now she was startled to think that speaking in such a manner to a stranger was improper, and she wondered why she hadn't realized this before. She thought he lacked tact when presenting himself in that way, and his statements and actions were inconsistent. She remembered that he had boasted that he was not afraid to meet Mr. Darcy, that Mr. Darcy could leave but he would stay; yet, he had avoided the ball at Netherfield the following week. She also remembered that, until the Netherfield family left, he had only told his story to her and no one else, but after they left, the story was discussed everywhere. She thought he had not hesitated at all, not even for a moment, to seek to undermine Mr. Darcy's character, even though he had reassured her that out of respect for the late gentleman, he would never expose the son.
tr: Mr. Philips remembered everything that was said during his conversations with Wickham very well. Most of his words remained fresh in his memory. Now, he was disturbed by the impropriety of making such revelations to a stranger and was amazed that he had overlooked this until now. He saw the indiscretion in revealing oneself in such a manner and that his words did not align with his actions. He recalled Wickham boasting that he was not afraid of seeing Mr. Darcy – that Mr. Darcy could leave the village if he wanted, but he would not budge from his place, yet he avoided the ball at Netherfield the following week. He remembered that Wickham did not tell his story to anyone else until the family at Netherfield left the village, but after they were gone, the story was talked about everywhere, and despite saying that his respect for his father would not allow him to disgrace his son in public, he ceaselessly criticized Mr. Darcy.
es: She perfectly remembered everything Wickham told her when they first spoke at Mr. Philips' house; many of his expressions were still entirely in her memory. Now she realized the impropriety of such confidences to a stranger and was amazed that she had not noticed it before. She saw the lack of delicacy involved in exposing oneself in that way, and the inconsistency of his statements with his behavior. She remembered that he boasted of not fearing to see Darcy and that Darcy would have to leave, but that he would not move, which did not prevent him from evading the Netherfield ball the following week. She also remembered that until the Netherfield family had left the county, he told his story only to her, but after their departure, the said story spread from mouth to mouth, and Wickham had no scruples about ruining Darcy's reputation, despite previously assuring Elizabeth that respect for the father would always prevent him from offending the son.

en: How differently did everything now appear in which he was concerned! His attentions to Miss King were now the consequence of views solely and hatefully mercenary; and the mediocrity of her fortune proved no longer the moderation of his wishes, but his eagerness to grasp at anything. His behaviour to herself could now have had no tolerable motive: he had either been deceived with regard to her fortune, or had been gratifying his vanity by encouraging the preference which she believed she had most incautiously shown. Every lingering struggle in his favour grew fainter and fainter; and in further justification of Mr. Darcy, she could not but allow that Mr. Bingley, when questioned by Jane, had long ago asserted his blamelessness in the affair;—that, proud and repulsive as were his manners, she had never, in the whole course of their acquaintance—an acquaintance which had latterly brought them much together, and given her a sort of intimacy with his ways—seen anything that betrayed him to be unprincipled or unjust—anything that spoke him of irreligious or immoral habits;—that among his own connections he was esteemed and valued;—that even Wickham had allowed him merit as a brother, and that she had often heard him speak so affectionately of his sister as to prove him capable of some amiable feeling;—that had his actions been what Wickham represented them, so gross a violation of everything right could hardly have been concealed from the world; and that friendship between a person capable of it and such an amiable man as Mr. Bingley was incomprehensible.
vi: Everything related to him has now changed! His attention to Miss King is now merely a consequence of pure greed and a desire for revenge, and her meager fortune indicates that his aspirations are no longer moderate but driven by a keen eagerness to seize anything. His attitude towards her now cannot be motivated by anything acceptable; either he is disappointed by her poor fortune, or his vanity has been satisfied after he aroused the affection that she believed she had shown imprudently. All ideas of justifying him are gradually fading away. Through Mr. Darcy's explanation, she had to accept that Mr. Bingley, when asked by Jane, had long believed he was not at fault in the matter. She realized that, throughout the time Mr. Darcy and she had a relationship that eventually brought them closer and allowed her to know his lifestyle well, although he was proud and unpleasant, she had never seen anything that indicated he lacked principles or fairness. Anything that indicated irreligious or immoral habits. In his social interactions, he was respected and highly regarded – even Wickham had considered him a brother; she had often heard him speak affectionately about his sister; all of which indicated he had some amiable sentiments. If his actions were as Wickham described, a blatant violation of all that is right could hardly be concealed from anyone, and the friendship between a person capable of forming bonds and someone as charming as Mr. Bingley; all of it was incomprehensible.
tr: How different everything related to Wickham seemed now! His interest in Miss King was now only the result of his low and selfish inclinations; the modesty of the girl's fortune no longer proved the ordinariness of Wickham's desires, but his desire to cling to whatever he could find. There was now no understandable reason for his behavior towards Elizabeth; either he was mistaken about her wealth, or he was feeding his own vanity by encouraging the intimacy he believed Elizabeth had shown so imprudently. As her last efforts to defend him weakened and further justified Mr. Darcy, she couldn't help but agree with Mr. Bingley's assertion of his innocence in response to Jane's question long ago; although his behavior was so proud and repulsive, throughout their acquaintance, which had recently brought them together frequently and made her familiar with his manner, she had never seen anything that revealed him to be unprincipled or unjust – nothing that suggested he had impious or immoral habits. He was respected and complimented among their acquaintances – even Wickham had admitted he was valuable as a brother, and Elizabeth had often witnessed him speaking of his sister with great affection, so much so that she thought he was capable of feeling closeness in his own way. If his actions were as Wickham described, such a grave disregard for everything right would be hard to hide from the world; a friendship between a person capable of this and a man as extremely kind-hearted as Mr. Bingley would be inconceivable.
es: How different everything related to Wickham seemed to her now! His attentions towards Miss King were now solely and exclusively the consequence of his odious fortune-hunting prospects, and the mediocrity of the young lady's fortune was no longer proof of the moderation of his ambitions, but rather his eagerness to cling to anything. His attitude towards Elizabeth could no longer have an acceptable motive: either he had been mistaken at first about her wealth, or he had tried to flatter his own vanity by nurturing the preference she had unwittingly shown him. All the efforts she made to defend him were progressively weakening. And to further justify Darcy, she could not help but recognize that Bingley, when questioned by Jane, had long ago proclaimed Darcy's innocence in that matter; that no matter how proud and repellent he was, never, in the entire course of their relationship ––a relationship that had recently brought them much closer, allowing her to know his character more deeply––, had she seen him do anything ignoble or unjust, nothing for which he could be accused of being irreligious or immoral; that among his friends he was appreciated and loved, and even Wickham himself had acknowledged that he was a good brother. She had also heard him speak of his sister with such affection that it demonstrated he had good feelings. If he had been as Wickham painted him, capable of such a violation of all rights, it would have been difficult for no one to know, and the friendship between such a being and a man as amiable as Bingley would have been incomprehensible.

en: She grew absolutely ashamed of herself. Of neither Darcy nor Wickham could she think, without feeling that she had been blind, partial, prejudiced, absurd.
vi: She felt completely ashamed of herself. She could not think of Darcy or Wickham without the idea that she had been blind, prejudiced, unjust, foolish.
tr: In the end, she was terribly ashamed of herself. –She couldn't think of Darcy or Wickham without feeling blind, biased, prejudiced, and ridiculous.
es: She came to be ashamed of herself. She could not think of Darcy or Wickham without acknowledging that she had been biased, absurd, blind, and full of prejudice.

en: “How despicably have I acted!” she cried. “I, who have prided myself on my discernment! I, who have valued myself on my abilities! who have often disdained the generous candour of my sister, and gratified my vanity in useless or blameless distrust. How humiliating is this discovery! Yet, how just a humiliation! Had I been in love, I could not have been more wretchedly blind. But vanity, not love, has been my folly. Pleased with the preference of one, and offended by the neglect of the other, on the very beginning of our acquaintance, I have courted prepossession and ignorance, and driven reason away where either were concerned. Till this moment, I never knew myself.”
vi: She exclaimed: "I have acted in such a despicable manner! I have been proud of my own awareness! I have overestimated my own abilities! I have looked down on my sister's genuine and generous nature, satisfying my own vanity with useless or condemnable suspicion. How shameful it is to have realized this! Indeed, it is only shame! If I had known love, I could not have been so miserably blind! But vanity, not love, has always been my folly. Moved by one person's kindness and offended by another's indifference, from the very beginning of my acquaintance with him, I have been full of prejudices, foolishness, always rejecting all reason. From the start until now, I have never truly recognized my own self."
tr: "I acted disgracefully!" he shouted. –"I, who used to take pride in my intuition! –I, who used to admire my talents! I would belittle my sister's boundless goodwill, and in a shameful and meaningless skepticism, I would constantly admire myself. –How humiliating it is to realize this! –How utterly humiliating! –If I had been in love, I couldn't have been in a more wretched blindness than this. But my foolish mistake was not love, it was pride. As soon as we met, I liked being someone's choice, and I was offended by being neglected by the other; I acted prejudiced and ignorantly about both, setting reason aside. It turns out I didn't know myself until this moment."
es: “How despicably I have acted,” she thought, “I, who prided myself on my discernment!” “I, who have boasted of my talent, who have scorned my sister’s generous candor, and have flattered my vanity with useless or blameworthy suspicions!” “How humiliating all this is, but how I deserve this humiliation!” If I had been in love with Wickham, I would not have acted with such lamentable blindness. But vanity, not love, has been my folly. Pleased with the preference of one and offended by the disdain of the other, I have from the beginning given myself up to presumption and ignorance, avoiding reason whenever it concerned either of them. Until this moment, I did not know myself.”

en: From herself to Jane, from Jane to Bingley, her thoughts were in a line which soon brought to her recollection that Mr. Darcy’s explanation there had appeared very insufficient; and she read it again. Widely different was the effect of a second perusal. How could she deny that credit to his assertions, in one instance, which she had been obliged to give in the other? He declared himself to have been totally unsuspicious of her sister’s attachment; and she could not help remembering what Charlotte’s opinion had always been. Neither could she deny the justice of his description of Jane. She felt that Jane’s feelings, though fervent, were little displayed, and that there was a constant complacency in her air and manner, not often united with great sensibility.
vi: From herself to Jane, from Jane to Bingley, her thoughts all converged to remind her that what Mr. Darcy explained here seemed to lack many things, so she read the letter again. This time the effect was very different – how could she dismiss his words in one situation, while believing them in another? He said he knew nothing of her sister's feelings, while she could not forget the remark about her sister that Charlotte still held in her mind. Nor could she dismiss his description of Jane. She thought that her sister expressed very little emotion even though her feelings were deep, and that her sister's attitude and gestures always exuded a sense of self-satisfaction, not well aligned with extreme sensitivity.
tr: From herself to Jane – from Jane to Bingley, her thoughts progressed in a line and soon brought to mind that Mr. Darcy's explanation there seemed quite inadequate; she read the letter once more. The effect of the second reading was very different. –How could she accept part of his explanations as true while rejecting the other part? –He had said that he never considered the possibility that her sister was interested; –Elizabeth couldn't help but recall Charlotte's opinion. –She couldn't deny that his observations about Jane were also correct. – Elizabeth felt that Jane's feelings, even if passionate, were seldom displayed, that there was a constant contentment in her demeanor and manner rarely accompanied by great sensitivity.
