es: From herself to Jane and from Jane to Bingley, her thoughts traveled a path that soon led her to remember that the explanation Darcy had given about their matter had seemed very insufficient to her, and she read it again. The effect of this second reading was very different. How could she not give credit to what Darcy said about one of the points, if she had been forced to give it to him on the other? Darcy declared that he had always suspected that Jane felt no love for Bingley, and Elizabeth remembered what Charlotte's opinion had been. Nor could she dispute the accuracy of his description of Jane; Elizabeth knew that her sister's feelings, though fervent, had been little expressed; and that the constant complacency in her air and manners often did not go hand in hand with great sensitivity.

en: When she came to that part of the letter in which her family were mentioned, in tones of such mortifying, yet merited, reproach, her sense of shame was severe. The justice of the charge struck her too forcibly for denial; and the circumstances to which he particularly alluded, as having passed at the Netherfield ball, and as confirming all his first disapprobation, could not have made a stronger impression on his mind than on hers.
vi: When she read the part about her family, with its reproachful but justified tone, she felt even more ashamed. The impartial comment struck her consciousness so heavily that she could not deny it. The situations he specifically alluded to, such as what happened at the Netherfield ball, seemed to confirm everything he disapproved of, leaving a stronger impression on her mind than on his.
tr: When the letter reached his family with such a humiliating but justified reproach, he felt intense shame. The justification of the accusation shook him so severely that he could not object; the events at the Netherfield ball, which Darcy particularly mentioned and which confirmed all his initial suspicions, could not have been more strongly imprinted in his mind than they were in Elizabeth's.
es: When she reached the part of the letter where Darcy mentioned her family in terms of such humiliating yet deserved reproaches, Elizabeth felt truly ashamed. The justice of his accusations seemed too evident for her to deny, and the circumstances he particularly alluded to as having occurred at the Netherfield ball could not have impressed him more than they had embarrassed her.

en: The compliment to herself and her sister was not unfelt. It soothed, but it could not console her for the contempt which had been thus self-attracted by the rest of her family; and as she considered that Jane’s disappointment had, in fact, been the work of her nearest relations, and reflected how materially the credit of both must be hurt by such impropriety of conduct, she felt depressed beyond anything she had ever known before.
vi: She did not overlook his praise for her and her sister. This helped her feel soothed, but it could not console her for the disdain towards the rest of the family. When she considered that Jane had been disappointed solely because of the attitude of their dearest relatives, and when she thought about how the reputation of those two had been harmed by such improper conduct, she felt a sorrow she had never experienced before.
tr: The compliments directed at her and her sister were not ignored. The compliments soothed the pain of the disgrace caused by her other family members, but they couldn't erase it; –while thinking that Jane's disappointment was actually the work of her closest relatives and how such vulgarity must have greatly damaged the dignity of both, she felt a distress heavier than anything she had ever experienced before.
es: The praise that Darcy bestowed upon her and her sister did not go unnoticed. It flattered her, but she could not console herself for the disdain it implied for the rest of the family; and upon considering that Jane's troubles had actually been caused by their own family, and reflecting on how the reputation of both would suffer due to such improper conduct, she felt a despondency she had never known before.

en: After wandering along the lane for two hours, giving way to every variety of thought, reconsidering events, determining probabilities, and reconciling herself, as well as she could, to a change so sudden and so important, fatigue, and a recollection of her long absence, made her at length return home; and she entered the house with the wish of appearing cheerful as usual, and the resolution of repressing such reflections as must make her unfit for conversation.
vi: After wandering along the path for two hours, indulging in every thought, reviewing events, determining possibilities, and trying to reconcile herself with the sudden and significant upheaval, fatigue and the sudden realization that she had been absent for quite a while made her turn back. She entered the house with the desire to appear cheerful as usual, and the firm intention to suppress the thoughts that made it difficult for her to converse with anyone.
tr: After walking on the path for two hours, getting caught up in all sorts of thoughts, reconsidering events, determining possibilities, and reconciling as best as he could with such a sudden and significant change, the fatigue and his long absence made him head home; he entered the house with the desire to appear cheerful as usual and with the decision to suppress thoughts that might cause him to become silent in the presence of others.
es: After walking for two hours along the road, turning over the diversity of her thoughts, reconsidering the events, determining possibilities, and gradually getting used to such a sudden and significant change, fatigue and the memory of how long she had been away made her return to the house. She entered with the intention of feigning her usual cheerfulness and resolved to suppress the thoughts that besieged her, as otherwise, she would not be able to maintain any conversation.

en: She was immediately told, that the two gentlemen from Rosings had each called during her absence; Mr. Darcy, only for a few minutes, to take leave, but that Colonel Fitzwilliam had been sitting with them at least an hour, hoping for her return, and almost resolving to walk after her till she could be found. Elizabeth could but just affect concern in missing him; she really rejoiced at it. Colonel Fitzwilliam was no longer an object. She could think only of her letter.
vi: She was informed that the two gentlemen from Rosings had visited while she was away. Mr. Darcy stayed only a few minutes, but Colonel Fitzwilliam had sat down for at least an hour, hoping she would return in time, almost wanting to go find her. Elizabeth could only feel concerned that she would miss him; in fact, she was happy about it. Colonel Fitzwilliam was no longer the subject, she could only think about the letter.
tr: As soon as she entered, they told her that while she was out, two gentlemen from Rosings had called separately; Mr. Darcy had stopped by for just a few minutes to say goodbye, but Colonel Fitzwilliam had sat with them for at least an hour in the hope of Elizabeth's return, and had even attempted to walk after her to find her. Elizabeth pretended to be sorry she had missed him, but inwardly she was glad. Colonel Fitzwilliam no longer interested her. Now she could think of nothing but the letter in her hand.
es: They told her that the two gentlemen from Rosings had been there during her absence; Darcy only for a brief moment, to say goodbye; but that Colonel Fitzwilliam had stayed for at least an hour, to see if she arrived and almost ready to go in search of her. Elizabeth was hardly affected by the colonel's departure; in fact, she was glad. She could only think about Darcy's letter.

en: CHAPTER XXXVII.
vi: Chapter 37
tr: Chapter XIV
es: CHAPTER XXXVII

en: THE two gentlemen left Rosings the next morning; and Mr. Collins having been in waiting near the lodges, to make them his parting obeisance, was able to bring home the pleasing intelligence of their appearing in very good health, and in as tolerable spirits as could be expected, after the melancholy scene so lately gone through at Rosings. To Rosings he then hastened to console Lady Catherine and her daughter; and on his return brought back, with great satisfaction, a message from her Ladyship, importing that she felt herself so dull as to make her very desirous of having them all to dine with her.
vi: The two young men left Rosings the next morning. After arriving at the place where the two were staying to bid farewell, Mr. Collins returned and happily reported to everyone that they were still in good health and in as good spirits as could be expected after the recent sorrowful events at Rosings. Then he hurried to Rosings to comfort Lady Catherine and her daughter. When he returned, with a look of complete satisfaction, he conveyed Lady Catherine's message that she felt quite lonely and was very eager to invite everyone to dinner.
tr: The two gentlemen left Rosings the next morning; Mr. Collins, who was waiting near the outbuildings to bid them farewell, came back to the house with this pleasant news: both of them appeared to be in very good health, and despite the sad scene that had just occurred at Rosings, they were in quite good spirits. Then he hurried to Rosings to console Lady Catherine and her daughter; upon his return, he brought a message from Lady Catherine with great satisfaction; she felt so sorrowful that she wanted to see them all at dinner with her.
es: Both gentlemen left Rosings the next morning. Collins was waiting near the entrance gates to bid them farewell, and brought home the pleasant news that they seemed to be well and in a passable mood, as was to be expected after the melancholy scene that must have taken place at Rosings. Collins then hurried to Rosings to console Lady Catherine and her daughter, and upon returning, he brought with great satisfaction a message from Her Ladyship, who was very sad and wished for everyone to dine with her.

en: Elizabeth could not see Lady Catherine without recollecting that, had she chosen it, she might by this time have been presented to her as her future niece; nor could she think, without a smile, of what her Ladyship’s indignation would have been. “What would she have said? how would she have behaved?” were the questions with which she amused herself.
vi: Elizabeth could not meet Lady Catherine without the thought that, if she wished, this time she could come to see her as her future niece-in-law. And she could not avoid the thought, with a smile, of her indignant reaction. She found it amusing to ask herself: “What would she say? How would she behave?”
tr: Elizabeth could not look at Lady Catherine without thinking that she might have already been presented to her as her future niece; nor could she think, without smiling, of how her ladyship's anger would be. "What would she say? –how would she behave?" she amused herself with these questions.
es: Elizabeth could not see Lady Catherine without remembering that, if she had wanted, she would have been introduced to her as her future niece; nor could she think, without smiling, about how indignant she would have been. What would she have said? What would she have done? It amused her to wonder about all these things.

en: Their first subject was the diminution of the Rosings’ party. “I assure you, I feel it exceedingly,” said Lady Catherine; “I believe nobody feels the loss of friends so much as I do. But I am particularly attached to these young men; and know them to be so much attached to me! They were excessively sorry to go! But so they always are. The dear Colonel rallied his spirits tolerably till just at last; but Darcy seemed to feel it most acutely—more, I think, than last year. His attachment to Rosings certainly increases.”
vi: Their first topic was the event that the two people had missed. Lady Catherine said: - I hope you understand that I feel very deeply. I believe that no one feels the separation from loved ones as I do. But I am particularly attached to these two young men, and I know they are also attached to me! They are infinitely sad to say goodbye. But they have always been like that. The Colonel tried to stay cheerful until the last moment, but Darcy seemed somewhat sadder; I think he is sadder than last year. Surely he has felt more attached to Rosings.
tr: The first topic was the reduced group at Rosings. –"Believe me, I feel it immensely," said Lady Catherine; "I'm sure no one feels the loss of their friends as much as I do. But I am particularly fond of these young men; I know they are equally fond of me! –How sorry they were to leave! They always are. Dear Colonel kept his spirits up until the last moment; but Darcy seemed very upset, even more than last year, it seemed. His attachment to Rosings is clearly growing."
es: The first thing that was discussed was the decline suffered in the gatherings at Rosings. ––I assure you that I am very sorry ––said Lady Catherine––; I believe that no one laments the loss of friends as much as I do. But, moreover, I love those boys so much and they love me so much! They were very sad when they left, as always when we part. The colonel remained firm until the end, but Darcy's sorrow was much more acute, more than last year, in my opinion. I do not doubt that his affection for Rosings is increasing.

en: Mr. Collins had a compliment and an allusion to throw in here, which were kindly smiled on by the mother and daughter.
vi: Mr. Collins offered words of praise and added a hint, causing the mother and daughter to smile gently.
tr: Mr. Collins made a compliment here and also hinted at something, receiving a polite smile from both the mother and the daughter.
es: Collins had a compliment and an allusion to the matter, which mother and daughter received with a kind smile.

en: Lady Catherine observed, after dinner, that Miss Bennet seemed out of spirits; and immediately accounting for it herself, by supposing that she did not like to go home again so soon, she added,—
vi: After the meal, Lady Catherine remarked that Miss Bennet seemed depressed, and immediately assumed that she did not want to return home too early. She added:
tr: Lady Catherine said that Miss Bennet looked unwell after dinner, and then immediately stated the reason; because she did not want to return home so quickly; and continued,
es: After the meal, Lady Catherine observed that Miss Bennet seemed to be low in spirits. She immediately explained it in her own way, assuming that the idea of returning so soon to her parents' house did not appeal to her, and said:

en: “But if that is the case, you must write to your mother to beg that you may stay a little longer. Mrs. Collins will be very glad of your company, I am sure.”
vi: - If that's true, you must immediately write a letter to your mother asking her to allow you to stay a little longer. I am sure Mrs. Collins will be very happy to have your company.
tr: "But if that's the case, write to your mother and ask for permission to stay a bit longer. Mrs. Collins would be very happy for you to stay, I think."
es: ––If that is the case, write to your mother to ask her to let you stay a little longer. I'm sure Mrs. Collins will be happy to have you by her side.

en: “I am much obliged to your Ladyship for your kind invitation,” replied Elizabeth; “but it is not in my power to accept it. I must be in town next Saturday.”
vi: Elizabeth replied: - I greatly appreciate the Lady's kind invitation, but I cannot accept. I have to return to the city next Saturday.
tr: "I am grateful to Her Ladyship for the kind invitation," replied Elizabeth, "but it is not possible for me to accept it. –I must be in the city next Saturday."
es: ––I greatly appreciate Your Lordship's kind invitation ––replied Elizabeth––, but I cannot accept it. I have to be in London next Saturday.

en: “Why, at that rate, you will have been here only six weeks. I expected you to stay two months. I told Mrs. Collins so before you came. There can be no occasion for your going so soon. Mrs. Bennet could certainly spare you for another fortnight.”
vi: - That way, you will only be able to stay here for six weeks. I had hoped you could stay for two months. I told Mrs. Collins that before you came here. There can't be anything that makes you leave in such a hurry. Mrs. Bennet will surely allow you to stay for another two weeks.
tr: "But if that's the case, you will have only stayed here for six weeks. I was expecting you to stay for two months. That's what I told Mrs. Collins before you arrived. There can be no reason for you to leave so soon. Mrs. Bennet can certainly give you another fifteen days."
es: ––What! Then you have only been here for six weeks. I expected you to stay for two months; I told Mrs. Collins so before you arrived. There is no reason for you to leave so soon. Mrs. Bennet will not mind if you stay another fortnight.

en: “But my father cannot. He wrote last week to hurry my return.”
vi: - But my father does not allow it. Last week he wrote me a letter, telling me I must return in time.
tr: "But my father can't give it. – Last week, he wrote and told me to return quickly."
es: ––But my father, yes; he wrote to me last week asking me to come back soon.

en: “Dawson”
vi: - Ah!
tr: "Oh, come on!
es: ––If your mother can do without you, your father will be able to as well.

en: “Oh, your father, of course, may spare you, if your mother can. Daughters are never of so much consequence to a father. And if you will stay another month complete, it will be in my power to take one of you as far as London, for I am going there early in June, for a week; and as Dawson does not object to the barouche-box, there will be very good room for one of you—and, indeed, if the weather should happen to be cool, I should not object to taking you both, as you are neither of you large.”
vi: Your father will certainly allow you, if your mother has already agreed. Daughters are never important to fathers. If you stay for a whole month, I will have the opportunity to take you all the way to London, because I will be going there in June and staying for a week. If Dawson agrees, one of you will have a comfortable room. In fact, if the weather turns cold, I wouldn't mind taking both of you, since you are both quite petite.
tr: If your mother allows it, your father will definitely allow it too. –Girls are not that important to fathers. If you stay for another month, I'll take one of you to London; I'm going at the beginning of June; since Dawson didn't object to the big car, there will be plenty of room for one of you –and if the weather is cool, I wouldn't say no to taking both of you, after all, neither of you are fat."
es: ––If your mother can do without you, your father will be able to as well. Daughters are never as necessary to fathers as they are to mothers. And if you would like to stay here another month, I could take you to London, because I have to go there at the beginning of June for a week; and since Danson won't mind traveling on the coachman's seat, there will be room for one of you, and if the weather is cool, I wouldn't mind taking both of you, as neither of you is stout.

en: “You are all kindness, madam; but I believe we must abide by our original plan.”
vi: - Madam, you are really kind, but we have to follow the planned schedule.
tr: "You are very kind, Madam; but it would be best to stick to our plan."
es: You are very kind, ma'am; but I believe we will have no choice but to do what we had originally planned.

en: Lady Catherine seemed resigned. “Mrs. Collins, you must send a servant with them. You know I always speak my mind, and I cannot bear the idea of two young women travelling post by themselves. It is highly improper. You must contrive to send somebody. I have the greatest dislike in the world to that sort of thing. Young women should always be properly guarded and attended, according to their situation in life. When my niece Georgiana went to Ramsgate last summer, I made a point of her having two men-servants go with her. Miss Darcy, the daughter of Mr. Darcy of Pemberley, and Lady Anne, could not have appeared with propriety in a different manner. I am excessively attentive to all those things. You must send John with the young ladies, Mrs. Collins. I am glad it occurred to me to mention it; for it would really be discreditable to you to let them go alone.”
vi: Lady Catherine seemed to have to accept it. - Mrs. Collins, you must send a servant to accompany the two girls. You know, I always speak my mind, and I cannot bear the thought of just two young girls going together. That is not proper at all. I do not like to see this at all. Young women should always have someone to protect and care for them, depending on their circumstances. When my niece Georgiana went to Ramsgate last year, I pointed out that two servants should go with her. Miss Darcy, the daughter of Mr. Darcy of Pemberly, and Lady Ann cannot go out properly in any other way. I am very attentive to this matter. Mrs. Collins, you need to send John with the girls. I am glad to remember to remind you of this, for you will lose your reputation if you let the two girls go alone.
tr: Lady Catherine seemed to be giving up. "Mrs. Collins, you must give them a servant. You know, I always say what's on my mind; I can't bear the thought of two young ladies traveling alone in a hired carriage. It's very improper. Find someone, send them. This is the kind of thing I detest the most in the world. –Young ladies should always have a companion, a protector, according to their status. When my niece Georgiana went to Ramsgate last summer, I insisted on having two footmen with her. –Miss Darcy, the daughter of Mr. Darcy of Pemberley and Lady Anne, could not appear otherwise, it would be unbecoming. –I pay extreme attention to such matters. You must send John with the young ladies, Mrs. Collins. I'm glad it occurred to me to say it; if you had sent them alone, you would have done something truly unforgivable."
es: Lady Catherine seemed to resign herself. ––Mrs. Collins, you will have to send a servant with them. You know that I always say what I feel, and I cannot bear the idea of two young ladies traveling alone in the coach. It is not proper. Find a way to have someone accompany them. There is nothing I dislike as much as that. Young ladies must always be guarded and attended to according to their position. When my niece Georgiana went to Ramsgate last summer, I insisted that two male servants go with them; otherwise, it would be improper for Miss Darcy, the daughter of Mr. Darcy of Pemberley and Lady Anne. I am very careful about these things. Send John with the young ladies, Mrs. Collins. I am glad it occurred to me, for it would be disgraceful for you to send them alone.

en: “My uncle is to send a servant for us.”
vi: - My uncle will send a servant to pick us up.
tr: "My uncle will send a servant for us.""
es: ––My uncle will send us a servant.

en: “Oh! Your uncle! He keeps a man-servant, does he? I am very glad you have somebody who thinks of those things. Where shall you change horses? Oh, Bromley, of course. If you mention my name at the Bell, you will be attended to.”
vi: - Ah! Your uncle! He has a male servant, doesn't he? I am very pleased that you ladies have thought of this. Where will you change horses? Ah, Bromley, of course. If you mention my name at Bell, they will take care of you.
tr: "Ha, your uncle! –He has a child, does he? –I'm glad you have a relative who thinks about these kinds of things. Where will you change the horses? –Ah, Bromley of course. –If you give my name at the Bell Inn, they will serve you well."
es: ––Ah! An uncle of yours! So you have a servant? I'm glad you have someone who thinks about these things. Where will you change horses? Oh! In Bromley, of course. If you mention my name at "The Bell," they will take good care of you.

en: Lady Catherine had many other questions to ask respecting their journey; and as she did not answer them all herself attention was necessary—which Elizabeth believed to be lucky for her; or, with a mind so occupied, she might have forgotten where she was. Reflection must be reserved for solitary hours: whenever she was alone, she gave way to it as the greatest relief; and not a day went by without a solitary walk, in which she might indulge in all the delight of unpleasant recollections.
vi: Mrs. Catherine asked many more questions about the journey of the two ladies, and since Elizabeth could not answer all the questions herself, she had to pay attention, and she found herself fortunate. Because, with a mind full of worries, she almost forgot where she was. Thoughts should be reserved for solitary moments; whenever she was alone, she considered this the best solace. Every day she had a solitary walk, during which she could indulge in the pleasure of not-so-pleasant recollections.
tr: Lady Catherine had many more questions to ask about her travels, and it was necessary to pay attention because she did not answer all the questions herself, which pleased Elizabeth, otherwise, she might forget where she was while her mind was so occupied. Reflection should be reserved for solitary hours; whenever she was alone, she gave herself up to thought with great relief; not a single day passed without her taking a solitary walk and indulging in all the pleasure of her troubling memories.
es: Lady Catherine had many other questions to ask about the trip, and since not all of them were answered by her, Elizabeth had to pay attention to her; it was fortunate, for otherwise, with her head so occupied, she would have forgotten where she was. She had to reserve her meditations for her solitary hours; when she was alone, she indulged in them as her greatest relief; not a day passed without her going for a walk to immerse herself in the delight of her unpleasant memories.

en: Mr. Darcy’s letter she was in a fair way of soon knowing by heart. She studied every sentence; and her feelings towards its writer were at times widely different. When she remembered the style of his address, she was still full of indignation: but when she considered how unjustly she had condemned and upbraided him, her anger was turned against herself; and his disappointed feelings became the object of compassion. His attachment excited gratitude, his general character respect: but she could not approve him; nor could she for a moment repent her refusal, or feel the slightest inclination ever to see him again. In her own past behaviour, there was a constant source of vexation and regret: and in the unhappy defects of her family, a subject of yet heavier chagrin. They were hopeless of remedy. Her father, contented with laughing at them, would never exert himself to restrain the wild giddiness of his youngest daughters; and her mother, with manners so far from right herself, was entirely insensible of the evil. Elizabeth had frequently united with Jane in an endeavour to check the imprudence of Catherine and Lydia; but while they were supported by their mother’s indulgence, what chance could there be of improvement? Catherine, weak-spirited, irritable, and completely under Lydia’s guidance, had been always affronted by their advice; and Lydia, self-willed and careless, would scarcely give them a hearing. They were ignorant, idle, and vain. While there was an officer in Meryton, they would flirt with him; and while Meryton was within a walk of Longbourn, they would be going there for ever.
vi: Before long, she had memorized Mr. Darcy's letter. She pondered over each sentence, and her feelings towards the writer changed greatly over time. When she recalled his manner of speaking, she was still full of indignation. But when she thought of how unjustly she had condemned and scolded him, she was angry at herself; his feelings became an object of her compassion. She was glad that he loved her; she respected his character, but could not accept him; and at no time did she regret rejecting him, nor did she have any fleeting desire to see him again. In her past behavior, there were always sources of annoyance and regret; and the shortcomings of her family were a matter that caused her even more distress. She felt hopeless to remedy it. Her father only wanted to joke and never restrained the frivolity of the young daughters. Her mother, with attitudes that were still improper, was completely insensitive to the harm. Elizabeth often tried with Jane to control the impulsiveness of Catherine and Lydia, but while their mother indulged them, what chance was there for the two to improve? Catherine, with her weak and irritable nature, always being led by Lydia, was always displeased with her sisters' advice. Lydia, with her self-willed and careless disposition, rarely listened to them. Both were foolish, lazy, and empty-headed. As long as there were officers in Meryton, the two would continue to flirt with them; as long as Meryton was just a walk away from Longbourn, they would always go there.
tr: At this rate, she would memorize Mr. Darcy's letter. She examined every sentence; her feelings towards the author of the letter frequently changed. When she remembered the writing style, she was still filled with anger; but when she thought about how unjustly she had accused and condemned him, her anger turned towards herself; she began to pity Mr. Darcy for his unrequited feelings. The man's interest evoked gratitude, his character respect; yet Elizabeth still could not accept him, she did not even regret rejecting him for a moment; she did not even feel like seeing him again. Within her past behaviors, there was a constant source of distress and regret, and in the sad mistakes of her family, an even heavier subject of unhappiness. Their situation was hopeless. Their father, who consoled himself by laughing at them, did not make any effort to restrain the wild recklessness of his younger daughters; their mother, with actions far from propriety, was unaware of the vulgarity at hand. Elizabeth often joined hands with Jane, trying to control the instability of Catherine and Lydia; but how could they possibly improve as long as they were supported by their mother's obsession? Weak-willed, uneasy, and having taken Lydia as her complete role model, Catherine was offended by their advice; ambitious and indifferent Lydia did not even hear them. They were ignorant, idle, and headstrong. As long as there were officers in Meryton, they would flirt with them; as long as Meryton was within walking distance of Longbourn, they would go there forever.
es: She almost knew Darcy's letter by heart. She studied its phrases one by one, and her feelings towards its author were sometimes extremely conflicted. When she focused on the tone in which he addressed her, she was filled with indignation, but when she considered how unjustly she had condemned and vilified him, her anger turned against herself and she pitied Darcy's disillusionment. His love for her stirred her gratitude, and his general demeanor, her respect; but she could not accept him and never for a moment regretted having rejected him nor felt the slightest desire to see him again. The way she had behaved filled her with constant shame and regret, and the unfortunate flaws of her family caused her horrible discomfort. There was no remedy. Her father merely mocked her younger sisters, but never attempted to curb their impetuous recklessness; and her mother, whose manners were so far from any decorum, was completely insensitive to the danger. Elizabeth had often conspired with Jane to curb Catherine and Lydia's imprudence, but as long as they had their mother's indulgence, what hope was there that they would be corrected? Catherine, weak and irritable in character and absolutely submissive to Lydia's direction, had always rebelled against their warnings; and Lydia, capricious and carefree, paid them no heed. Both were ignorant, lazy, and vain. As long as there was an officer in Meryton, they would flirt with him, and as long as Meryton was so close to Longbourn, nothing could prevent them from going there all their lives.

en: Anxiety on Jane’s behalf was another prevailing concern; and Mr. Darcy’s explanation, by restoring Bingley to all her former good opinion, heightened the sense of what Jane had lost. His affection was proved to have been sincere, and his conduct cleared of all blame, unless any could attach to the implicitness of his confidence in his friend. How grievous then was the thought that, of a situation so desirable in every respect, so replete with advantage, so promising for happiness, Jane had been deprived, by the folly and indecorum of her own family!
vi: Another concern was worrying about Jane. Mr. Darcy's explanation, by restoring Bingley to her good graces, made her understand what Jane had lost. His feelings were proven to be sincere, his behavior showed nothing to criticize, except that he might be faulted for relying too much on his friend's opinion. She felt even more compassion when she thought that, with a situation favorable in every way, full of advantages, full of promises of happiness, Jane was deprived of it all, just because her own family had been too foolish and impolite!
tr: Another source of her unhappiness was the worry she felt for Jane; Mr. Darcy's explanation had revived all her former positive opinions about Bingley, making her feel the magnitude of Jane's loss even more. Bingley's love had proven to be genuine, his behavior free from blame, unless one finds fault in his unquestioning trust in his friend. How painful it was that Jane, in every way so perfect, so satisfying, so promising of happiness, had lost such a match due to her own family's foolishness and lack of manners!
es: The anxiety for Jane's fate was another of her predominant concerns. Darcy's explanation, by restoring Bingley to the good opinion she previously had of him, made her better realize what Jane had lost. Bingley's affection was sincere and his conduct had been impeccable, except for his blind trust in his friend. How sad, then, it was to think that Jane had been deprived of such a desirable position in every sense, so full of advantages and so promising in happiness, due to the folly and lack of decorum of her own family!

en: When to these recollections was added the development of Wickham’s character, it may be easily believed that the happy spirits which had seldom been depressed before were now so much affected as to make it almost impossible for her to appear tolerably cheerful.
vi: When Wickham's true nature was added to this recollection, the previously seldom suppressed happy sentiments were now so heavily affected that she could hardly even pretend to be relatively cheerful.
tr: When the emergence of Wickham's character was added to these thoughts, it can easily be believed that it made it impossible for her to appear even somewhat cheerful, whereas she had previously rarely been in a dark mood.
es: When to all this was added the discovery of Wickham's true personality, it was easily understood that Elizabeth's jovial spirit, which had rarely felt depressed, had now declined to such an extent that it was almost impossible for her to feign even a little joy.

en: Their engagements at Rosings were as frequent during the last week of her stay as they had been at first. The very last evening was spent there; and her Ladyship again inquired minutely into the particulars of their journey, gave them directions as to the best method of packing, and was so urgent on the necessity of placing gowns in the only right way, that Maria thought herself obliged, on her return, to undo all the work of the morning, and pack her trunk afresh.
vi: The social gatherings at Rosings remained frequent during the last week of her stay, just as frequent as during the first week. On the evening of the last day, they went to the Lady's residence, where she once again inquired thoroughly about the two girls' journey and gave instructions on how to arrange their luggage. She spoke urgently about the necessity of arranging evening dresses in the only way she deemed correct, to the extent that Maria thought she would unpack all her luggage to rearrange it upon returning.
tr: During the last week of her visit, the invitations at Rosings were as frequent as they were in the first week. The last evening was also spent there; Her Ladyship once again inquired in detail about their travels, gave instructions on the best methods for packing, and insisted so much on the only correct way to arrange clothes that Maria felt compelled to undo all her work from the morning and repack her trunk from scratch when they returned home.
es: Invitations to Rosings were as frequent during the last week of their stay in Hunsford as they were at the beginning. The last evening was spent there, and Her Ladyship once again asked meticulous questions about the details of the trip, gave them instructions on the best way to pack the trunks, and insisted so much on the necessity of arranging the dresses in the only way she deemed proper, that when they returned to the house, Maria felt obliged to undo all her morning's work and had to repack.

en: When they parted, Lady Catherine, with great condescension, wished them a good journey, and invited them to come to Hunsford again next year; and Miss de Bourgh exerted herself so far as to courtesy and hold out her hand to both.
vi: When they bid farewell, Lady Catherine, with extreme humility, wished the two ladies a pleasant journey and invited them to visit Huntsford again the following year. As for Miss De Bourgh, she merely nodded and shook hands with the two ladies.
tr: When they parted, Lady Catherine deigned to wish them a good journey and invited them to come to Hunsford again next year; Miss de Bourgh also made an effort to curtsy and extended her hand to both of them.
es: When they left, Lady Catherine deigned to wish them a pleasant journey and invited them to return to Hunsford the following year. Miss de Bourgh extended her effort to the courtesy of shaking hands with both of them.

en: CHAPTER XXXVIII.
vi: Chapter 38
tr: Chapter XV
es: CHAPTER XXXVIII

en: ON Saturday morning Elizabeth and Mr. Collins met for breakfast a few minutes before the others appeared; and he took the opportunity of paying the parting civilities which he deemed indispensably necessary.
vi: On Saturday morning, Elizabeth and Mr. Collins met for a few minutes before the others appeared, and he took the opportunity to express a few polite words of farewell that he thought were very necessary. He said:
tr: On Saturday morning, Elizabeth and Mr. Collins met at breakfast a few minutes before the others arrived; Mr. Collins seized the opportunity to say the polite words he deemed absolutely necessary for a farewell.
es: On Saturday morning, Elizabeth and Collins met at breakfast a few minutes before the others appeared; and he took the opportunity to offer her the farewell compliments he considered absolutely necessary.

en: “I know not, Miss Elizabeth,” said he, “whether Mrs. Collins has yet expressed her sense of your kindness in coming to us; but I am very certain you will not leave the house without receiving her thanks for it. The favour of your company has been much felt, I assure you. We know how little there is to tempt anyone to our humble abode. Our plain manner of living, our small rooms, and few domestics, and the little we see of the world, must make Hunsford extremely dull to a young lady like yourself; but I hope you will believe us grateful for the condescension, and that we have done everything in our power to prevent you spending your time unpleasantly.”
vi: - Miss Elizabeth, I am not sure if Mrs. Collins has expressed her feelings about your kind visit to us, but I am certain she will thank you when you leave. Please believe that we are very touched by your group's visit to us. We think our humble abode has nothing attractive to visitors. Our simple way of living, the small rooms, few servants; and since we seldom go out to explore the outside world, all of this surely makes Huntsford completely boring for a young lady like you. But I hope you will believe that we have been very happy to humble ourselves, and we have done everything we can to make your time here pleasant.
tr: "I don't know, Miss Elizabeth," he said, "perhaps Mrs. Collins has not yet expressed her own feelings about the kindness you have shown by coming to us, but I am quite sure that you will not leave this house without receiving her thanks. Rest assured, the happiness your presence has brought is deeply felt. We know that there is very little in our humble abode to make it appealing to people. Our simple life, small rooms, few servants, and limited means must make Hunsford extremely dull for a young lady like yourself; but we hope you will believe that we are grateful for your condescension in coming, and that we have done everything in our power to prevent you from being bored during your stay here."
es: ––I am unaware, Miss Elizabeth ––he said––, whether Mrs. Collins has expressed to you how grateful she is for your kindness in coming; but I am sure she will do so before you leave this house. We have greatly appreciated the favor of your company. We know how unappealing it can be for anyone to come to our humble abode. Our simple way of living, our small rooms, our few servants, and our isolation must make Hunsford an extremely dreary place for a young lady like yourself. But I hope you believe in our gratitude for your condescension and that we have done everything within our power to prevent you from being bored.

en: Elizabeth was eager with her thanks and assurances of happiness. She had spent six weeks with great enjoyment; and the pleasure of being with Charlotte, and the kind attention she had received, must make her feel the obliged. Mr. Collins was gratified; and with a more smiling solemnity replied,—
vi: Elizabeth eagerly responded with thanks and reassured him that she was satisfied. She had spent six weeks in happiness and was pleased to have Charlotte's company; the attentions given to her made her very appreciative. Mr. Collins was delighted, and with a more solemn yet cheerful demeanor, he replied:
tr: Elizabeth thanked eagerly, wanting them to be sure that she was happy. She had spent six weeks with great pleasure; the joy of being with Charlotte, and the close attention shown to her, made her the one who should be truly grateful. Mr. Collins was very pleased and replied with a more smiling solemnity,
es: Elizabeth thanked her effusively and said she was very happy. She had spent six very happy weeks; and the pleasure of being with Charlotte and the kind attentions she had received had left her very satisfied. Collins celebrated it solemnly, but with a more smiling demeanor, he replied:

en: “It gives me the greatest pleasure to hear that you have passed your time not disagreeably. We have certainly done our best; and most fortunately having it in our power to introduce you to very superior society, and from our connection with Rosings, the frequent means of varying the humble home scene, I think we may flatter ourselves that your Hunsford visit cannot have been entirely irksome. Our situation with regard to Lady Catherine’s family is, indeed, the sort of extraordinary advantage and blessing which few can boast. You see on what a footing we are. You see how continually we are engaged there. In truth, I must acknowledge, that, with all the disadvantages of this humble parsonage, I should not think anyone abiding in it an object of compassion, while they are sharers of our intimacy at Rosings.”
vi: - I am very pleased to hear that your stay here has not been too unpleasant. We certainly did our best; fortunately, we had the circumstances to introduce you to a very distinguished society, and from our relationship with Rosings, which provides a change of atmosphere compared to our humble home, I think we can be satisfied that your visit to Huntsford was not too dull. Our circumstances in relation to Lady Catherine's family are indeed an exceptional advantage and fortune that few possess. You have seen what our status is like. You have seen how frequently we interact with them. Honestly, I must admit that, with the disadvantages of the humble Parsonage here, I did not dare to think that anyone would be kind enough to come to this place, while on the contrary, they are eager to share in our private moments at Rosings.
tr: "I am very glad to hear that you did not spend your time badly. Of course, we did our best; fortunately, we were also able to introduce you to very high-ranking individuals; I think we can take some pride in our connection with Rosings, which often brings liveliness to our humble home atmosphere, if your visit to Hunsford was not entirely dull. Our situation with Lady Catherine's family is indeed a very exceptional privilege, an honor that very few people can attain. You see what friends we have. You see how we are constantly invited. In fact, I must confess that despite all the flaws of this modest parsonage, no one living in it would be pitiable as long as they share our closeness with Rosings."
es: ––It gives me the greatest pleasure to know that you have spent your time pleasantly. Everything that could be done has indeed been done; we have had the supreme luck of being able to introduce you to the highest society, and the frequent means of varying the humble domestic scene that our relations with Rosings have facilitated, allow us to hope that your visit has been pleasant. Our dealings with Lady Catherine's family are truly an extraordinary advantage and a blessing that few can boast of. You have seen the situation we are in at Rosings, how many times we have been invited there. I must sincerely acknowledge that, with all the disadvantages of this humble parsonage, no one who comes here can pity themselves as long as they can share our intimacy with the Bourgh family.

en: Words were insufficient for the elevation of his feelings; and he was obliged to walk about the room, while Elizabeth tried to unite civility and truth in a few short sentences.
vi: Words could never suffice to elevate his ideas, so he had to pace around the room while Elizabeth tried to blend politeness and truth into a few short sentences.
tr: Words failed in the face of the intensity of his emotions; he had to pace around the room; meanwhile, Elizabeth was trying to politely condense the truth into a few short sentences.
es: Words were insufficient to express the elevation of his feelings, and he found himself compelled to pace the room, while Elizabeth tried to combine truth with courtesy in brief phrases.

en: “You may, in fact, carry a very favourable report of us into Hertfordshire, my dear cousin. I flatter myself, at least, that you will be able to do so. Lady Catherine’s great attentions to Mrs. Collins you have been a daily witness of; and altogether I trust it does not appear that your friend has drawn an unfortunate—but on this point it will be as well to be silent. Only let me assure you, my dear Miss Elizabeth, that I can from my heart most cordially wish you equal felicity in marriage. My dear Charlotte and I have but one mind and one way of thinking. There is in everything a most remarkable resemblance of character and ideas between us. We seem to have been designed for each other.”
vi: He continued: - My dear cousin, in fact, you can tell Herfordshire all the favorable things about us. I take pride in the fact that at least you can do this. Every day you have witnessed Lady Catherine paying special attention to Mrs. Collins, and generally, I believe your friend does not seem to be without troubles, but we should remain silent about this. My dear Elizabeth, I just want to assure you that deep down I sincerely wish you the utmost happiness in marriage. My beloved Charlotte and I share the same sentiments and thoughts. In everything, we are extraordinarily compatible with each other in both character and feelings. It seems as if we were born to live for each other.
tr: "Of course, you can take a very favorable report about us back to Hertfordshire, my dear cousin. At least being able to do that would make me proud. You have witnessed day by day the great kindness Lady Catherine has shown to Mrs. Collins; finally, I hope your friend is not so unfortunate a – but anyway, it is best to remain silent on this matter. Just believe, dear Miss Elizabeth, that I sincerely and wholeheartedly wish you such a happy marriage. My dear Charlotte and I have become of one mind and one soul. There is a magnificent similarity of feeling and thought between us in everything. It is as if we were made for each other."
es: ––So, then, you will be able to bring good news from us to Hertfordshire, dear cousin. At least this is my hope. You have been a daily witness to Lady Catherine's great attentions towards Mrs. Collins, and I trust it has not seemed to you that your friend is unhappy. But regarding this point, it is better that I remain silent. Allow me only to assure you, dear Miss Elizabeth, that I wholeheartedly wish you the same happiness in your marriage. My dear Charlotte and I have but one will and one way of thinking. There exist between us very notable similarities of character and ideas; we seem made for each other.

en: Elizabeth could safely say that it was a great happiness where that was the case, and with equal sincerity could add, that she firmly believed and rejoiced in his domestic comforts. She was not sorry, however, to have the recital of them interrupted by the entrance of the lady from whom they sprang. Poor Charlotte! it was melancholy to leave her to such society! But she had chosen it with her eyes open; and though evidently regretting that her visitors were to go, she did not seem to ask for compassion. Her home and her housekeeping, her parish and her poultry, and all their dependent concerns, had not yet lost their charms.
vi: Elizabeth said moderately that it was a great happiness in such a situation, with the same sincere tone, she added that she firmly believed and was glad about the comforts in his family. However, she did not regret seeing the account of these comforts interrupted because the person they were talking about stepped in. Poor Charlotte! It was indeed sad to let her live among such people! But she had chosen this with a clear intention, and obviously, she was sad because the guests were about to leave, as if she did not want anyone to pity her. Her house and her housekeeping, her parish and her flock of chickens, and all their dependent relationships, had not yet lost their charm.
tr: Elizabeth could easily say that this situation was a great happiness; with the same sincerity, she managed to add that she wholeheartedly believed in and rejoiced in her familial peace. However, she was not at all sorry that their conversation was interrupted by the entrance of the lady they were talking about. Poor Charlotte! –how sad it was to leave her to such a life! –But she had chosen this herself, knowingly; she was obviously sorry to see her guests leave, but she did not have an air of expecting pity. Her house and household chores, her church and chickens, and all the concerns related to these had not yet lost their charm.
es: Elizabeth could truly say that it was a great joy that it was so, and with the same sincerity, she added that she firmly believed it and was glad for her domestic well-being; however, she did not regret that the description of it was interrupted by the arrival of the lady in question. Poor Charlotte! It was sad to leave her in such company! But she had chosen it consciously. It was clear that she was pained by the departure of her guests, but she did not seem to want to be pitied. Her home and domestic chores, her parish, her chicken coop, and all the other associated tasks had not yet lost their charm for her.

en: At length the chaise arrived, the trunks were fastened on, the parcels placed within, and it was pronounced to be ready. After an affectionate parting between the friends, Elizabeth was attended to the carriage by Mr. Collins; and as they walked down the garden, he was commissioning her with his best respects to all her family, not forgetting his thanks for the kindness he had received at Longbourn in the winter, and his compliments to Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner, though unknown. He then handed her in, Maria followed, and the door was on the point of being closed, when he suddenly reminded them, with some consternation, that they had hitherto forgotten to leave any message for the ladies of Rosings.
vi: Finally, the carriage arrived, the luggage was securely tied to the vehicle, the packages were loaded in the middle, and then it was announced that everything was ready. After heartfelt goodbyes, Mr. Collins escorted Elizabeth to the carriage. As they passed through the flower garden, he sent his most respectful regards to her family, not forgetting to thank them for the kindness he received during the winter at Longbourn, and extended his greetings to Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner, even though he had not yet met them. Then he helped Elizabeth into the carriage, with Maria following behind, and just as the door was about to close, he suddenly, with some anxiety, reminded the two ladies that they had forgotten to send their regards to the women at Rosings.
tr: Finally, the car arrived, the crates were tied, the packages were placed inside, and it was announced that it was ready to move. After an emotional farewell among friends, Mr. Collins escorted Elizabeth to the car; as they walked down the garden, Mr. Collins was asking her to convey his deepest respects to her family, his thanks for the hospitality he received at Longbourn during the winter, and his regards to Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner, even though he did not know them. Then he took her hand and helped her get in, Maria followed her, and just as the door was about to close, he suddenly remembered with a certain concern that they had forgotten to leave a message for the ladies at Rosings.
es: Finally, the stagecoach arrived; the trunks were loaded, the packages were arranged, and they were informed that everything was ready. The two friends said their affectionate goodbyes, and Collins accompanied Elizabeth to the carriage. As they crossed the garden, he asked her to convey his warm regards to the entire family and to repeat his gratitude for the kindnesses they had shown him during his stay in Longbourn last winter, and he urged her to also greet the Gardiners even though he did not know them. He helped her into the carriage and, after her, Maria. Just as he was about to close the doors, Collins, distressed, reminded them that they had forgotten to ask him to convey something to the ladies of Rosings.

en: “They had forgotten to leave any message”
vi: He added:
tr: Then he took her hand and helped her get in, Maria followed her, and just as the door was about to close, he suddenly remembered with a certain concern that they had forgotten to leave a message for the ladies at Rosings.
es: Just as he was about to close the doors, Collins, distressed, reminded them that they had forgotten to ask him to convey something to the ladies of Rosings.

en: “But,” he added, “you will of course wish to have your humble respects delivered to them, with your grateful thanks for their kindness to you while you have been here.”
vi: - But of course, she will send them humble respects to thank them for their kindness during her time here.
tr: "But," he added, "of course you would like your deepest respects and your heartfelt thanks for the kindness they have shown during your stay here to be conveyed to them."
es: ––But ––he added–– surely they would want us to convey their humble respects along with their gratitude for your kindness towards them.

en: Elizabeth made no objection: the door was then allowed to be shut, and the carriage drove off.
vi: Elizabeth agreed, then the door closed, and the car drove away.
tr: Elizabeth did not object; –then the door was allowed to close and the carriage set off.
es: Elizabeth did not object; the door closed and the carriage departed.

en: “Good gracious!” cried Maria, after a few minutes’ silence, “it seems but a day or two since we first came! and yet how many things have happened!”
vi: Maria exclaimed, after a few moments of silence: - My goodness! It seems like we've only been here for a few days! And yet so many things have happened!
tr: "Oh my God!" cried Maria after a few minutes of silence, "it feels like we just arrived a day or two ago! –but so much has happened!"
es: ––My God! ––exclaimed María after a few minutes of silence––. It seems like it was just yesterday when we arrived and yet, so many things have happened!

en: “A great many indeed,” said her companion, with a sigh.
vi: Elizabeth sighed: - Indeed, many things have happened.
tr: "A lot has really happened," said his travel companion with a sigh.
es: ––Many, it's true ––replied her companion with a sigh.

en: “We have dined nine times at Rosings, besides drinking tea there twice! How much I shall have to tell!”
vi: - We have dined at Rosings nine times, besides having tea twice! I will have so many stories to tell.
tr: "We had dinner at Rosings nine times, and we also had tea three times! –I have so much to tell!"
es: ––We have dined at Rosings nine times, and we have had tea there twice. How much I have to tell!

en: Elizabeth privately added, “And how much I shall have to conceal!”
vi: In her heart, Elizabeth added: "And you will have so many more things to keep secret."
tr: "I also have so many things to hide," said Elizabeth to herself.
es: Elizabeth added to herself: "And I, how many things I have to keep to myself!"

en: Their journey was performed without much conversation, or any alarm; and within four hours of their leaving Hunsford they reached Mr. Gardiner’s house, where they were to remain a few days.
vi: The two ladies spoke little to each other during the trip. Within four hours, they arrived at Mr. Gardiner's house, where they stayed for a few days.
tr: They didn't talk much along the way; there were no mishaps either; four hours after leaving Hunsford, they reached Mr. Gardiner's house; they would stay there for a few days.
es: The journey passed without much conversation and without any incident, and four hours after leaving Hunsford, they arrived at the Gardiners' house, where they were going to spend a few days.

en: Jane looked well, and Elizabeth had little opportunity of studying her spirits, amidst the various engagements which the kindness of her aunt had reserved for them. But Jane was to go home with her, and at Longbourn there would be leisure enough for observation.
vi: Jane appeared to be in good health, but amidst the gatherings that their aunt organized for them, Elizabeth had little opportunity to understand her sister's feelings. However, Jane would return home with her, and at Longbourn, there would be plenty of time to observe.
tr: Jane looked well; Elizabeth did not find time to examine her among the various entertainments her aunt had prepared for them. But Jane would also be returning home with her, and there would be plenty of free time to observe at Longbourn.
es: Jane looked very well, and Elizabeth hardly had a chance to examine her state of mind, as her aunt had prepared countless invitations for them. But Jane was going to return to Longbourn with her sister, and once there, there would be plenty of time to observe her.

en: It was not without an effort, meanwhile, that she could wait even for Longbourn, before she told her sister of Mr. Darcy’s proposals. To know that she had the power of revealing what would so exceedingly astonish Jane, and must, at the same time, so highly gratify whatever of her own vanity she had not yet been able to reason away, was such a temptation to openness as nothing could have conquered, but the state of indecision in which she remained as to the extent of what she should communicate, and her fear, if she once entered on the subject, of being hurried into repeating something of Bingley, which might only grieve her sister further.
vi: But while waiting, with a little effort, Elizabeth told her sister about Mr. Darcy's proposal. Knowing that she had the ability to reveal something that would astonish Jane greatly, while simultaneously making her pleased with her own frivolity which she could not yet explain – this was what prompted her to confide in her sister, except for the hesitation about how much to reveal and her fear of acting rashly like Bingley, which would cause her sister further distress.
tr: Meanwhile, even waiting for Longbourn to tell her sister about Mr. Darcy's proposal required a considerable effort. Knowing that she had the power to reveal something that would astonish Jane to such a degree and at the same time flatter the pride she had not yet managed to rid herself of, tempted her so much that she could only resist this temptation thanks to her indecision about how much to reveal and the fear that if she started to tell, she might inadvertently repeat something about Bingley that could cause her sister even more pain.
es: Elizabeth barely managed to restrain herself from telling her until then about Darcy's proposals. What a surprise she was going to get, and how gratifying it would be for the vanity that Elizabeth still could not master! It was such a strong temptation that she would not have been able to resist it if it were not for the indecision she found herself in, the extent of what she had to communicate, and the fear that if she started talking, she would be forced to mention Bingley, which would only succeed in making her sister even sadder.

en: CHAPTER XXXIX.
vi: Chapter 39
tr: Chapter XVI
es: CHAPTER XXXIX

en: IT was the second week in May, in which the three young ladies set out together from Gracechurch Street for the town of ——, in Hertfordshire; and, as they drew near the appointed inn where Mr. Bennet’s carriage was to meet them, they quickly perceived, in token of the coachman’s punctuality, both Kitty and Lydia looking out of a dining-room upstairs. These two girls had been above an hour in the place, happily employed in visiting an opposite milliner, watching the sentinel on guard, and dressing a salad and cucumber.
vi: In the second week of May, three young girls traveled together from Gracechurch Street to Hertfordshire. As they approached an inn that served as a meeting point where Mr. Bennet's carriage would pick them up, they saw Kitty and Lydia looking down from the dining room upstairs. The two had arrived more than an hour earlier, delighting in shopping at a hat store, watching the guards on duty, and enjoying a vinegar-dressed salad.
tr: In the second week of May, three young ladies set out from Gracechurch Street towards the town of ------- in Hertfordshire; as they approached the inn where Mr. Bennet's carriage was to meet them, thanks to the punctuality of the coachman, they caught sight of Kitty and Lydia looking out from one of the upper-floor dining rooms. These two girls had been there for over an hour, had paid a pleasant visit to a draper across the street, watched the soldiers on guard, and made a curly lettuce and cucumber salad.
es: In the second week of May, the three girls set off together from Gracechurch Street, heading towards the town of X, in Hertfordshire. Upon arriving near the inn where Mr. Bennet's carriage was supposed to wait for them, they immediately saw, as proof of the coachman's punctuality, Catherine and Lydia who were on the lookout in the upper floor dining room. They had spent almost an hour at the place happily occupied with visiting the hat shop across the street, watching the guard on duty, and preparing a cucumber salad.

en: After welcoming their sisters, they triumphantly displayed a table set out with such cold meat as an inn larder usually affords, exclaiming, “Is not this nice? is not this an agreeable surprise?”
vi: After the greetings, the two girls proudly presented a table already set with cold food, exclaiming, "Looks delicious, doesn't it?" "Aren't you surprised and delighted?"
tr: After welcoming their sisters, they proudly showed the table prepared with cold meat that a pantry could offer; "isn't it nice? isn't it a lovely surprise?" they exclaimed.
es: After welcoming their sisters, they triumphantly showed them a table set with all the cold cuts that can normally be found in the pantry of an inn and exclaimed: ––Isn't it wonderful? Isn't it a pleasant surprise?

en: “And we mean to treat you all,” added Lydia; “but you must lend us the money, for we have just spent ours at the shop out there.” Then showing her purchases,—“Look here, I have bought this bonnet. I do not think it is very pretty; but I thought I might as well buy it as not. I shall pull it to pieces as soon as I get home, and see if I can make it up any better.”
vi: Lydia added. - We will treat you, but you have to lend us money because we spent all our money at the shop over there. Then she showed some items: - Look here, I bought this hat. I think it's not very pretty, but it's better to buy it than not. I'll fix it when I get home, to see if it looks better.
tr: "We are thinking of treating you all to a feast," Lydia added; "but you must lend us some money, because we spent all our money in this shop." Then she showed what she had bought: "Look, I bought this bonnet. It's not very nice, but I bought it just for the sake of it. When I get home, I'll take it apart to see if I can make something out of it."
es: ––We want to invite all of you ––added Lydia––; but you will have to lend us the money, because we just spent ours in the store out there. And, showing her purchases, she added: ––Look at the hat I bought. I don't think it's very pretty, but I thought it was the same to buy it or not; I'll take it apart as soon as we get home and see if I can improve it a bit.

en: And when her sisters abused it as ugly, she added, with perfect unconcern, “Oh, but there were two or three much uglier in the shop; and when I have bought some prettier-coloured satin to trim it with fresh, I think it will be very tolerable. Besides, it will not much signify what one wears this summer, after the ——shire have left Meryton, and they are going in a fortnight.”
vi: When the older sisters had words of criticism, she indifferently continued: - Ah! But there are a few that are much worse. When I bought some satin fabric to make the trim, I thought it looked okay. Moreover, it won't matter this summer, after the militia unit leaves Meryton, they will be gone in two weeks.
tr: When her sisters called it ugly, she nonchalantly added, "There were only two or three hats in the shop uglier than this one; if I take a more nicely colored satin and decorate it again, it will be quite good. Anyway, what people wear this summer is not that important, the --------shire regiment has left Meryton, they are leaving within fifteen days."
es: The sisters found him very ugly, but Lydia, not giving it any importance, replied: ––Well, there were two or three much uglier ones in the shop. And when I buy a satin of a prettier color, I'll fix it up and I think it won't look too bad at all. Besides, it hardly matters what we wear this summer, because the county garrison is leaving Meryton in fifteen days.

en: “Are they, indeed?” cried Elizabeth, with the greatest satisfaction.
vi: Elizabeth exclaimed, in utmost satisfaction: - Are they really going to go?
tr: "Really?" cried Elizabeth, with great satisfaction.
es: ––Really? ––exclaimed Elizabeth very satisfied.

en: “They are going to be encamped near Brighton; and I do so want papa to take us all there for the summer! It would be such a delicious scheme, and I dare say would hardly cost anything at all. Mamma would like to go, too, of all things! Only think what a miserable summer else we shall have!”
vi: - They will camp near Brington; I really want papa to take all of us there this summer! It will be a wonderful plan, and I am sure it won't cost much. Mother will also want to go for any reason. Elizabeth thought: "Indeed, this will be a wonderful plan, making everyone happy at once."
tr: "They are going to camp near Brighton; I want my father to take all of us there so much this summer! What a fun plan it would be; and it’s not even a major expense. My mother would want to go the most! Otherwise, just imagine what a boring summer we will have!"
es: ––They are going to camp near Brighton. Let's see if Dad takes us there this summer. It would be a great plan and would cost very little. Mom wants to go more than anything else. Imagine, otherwise, what a sad summer awaits us!

en: “Yes,” thought Elizabeth; “that would be a delightful scheme, indeed, and completely do for us at once. Good Heaven! Brighton and a whole campful of soldiers, to us, who have been overset already by one poor regiment of militia, and the monthly balls of Meryton!”
vi: Elizabeth thought: "Indeed, this will be a wonderful plan, making everyone happy at once." My God! Brington, adding a military camp to those already shaken by a miserable regiment and the monthly balls at Meryton."
tr: "Yes," thought Elizabeth, "this would indeed be an amusing plan, we would all be ruined at once. Oh my God! Brighton, a whole camp full of soldiers and us, already a scattered poor militia regiment because of Meryton's monthly balls."
es: “Yes,” thought Elizabeth, “it would be a truly splendid plan and very fitting for us. That’s all we would need. Brighton and a whole camp of soldiers, with how disrupted we already are by a mere regiment and the monthly Meryton balls.”

en: “Now I have got some news for you,” said Lydia, as they sat down to table. “What do you think? It is excellent news, capital news, and about a certain person that we all like.”
vi: Lydia said, as the sisters sat down at the dining table: - Now I have some news for you all. Try to guess! This is extremely good news, important news, related to a person we all cherish.
tr: "Now I have news for you," said Lydia, as they sat down at the table. "Guess what! Wonderful news, extraordinary news, and it's about someone we all love."
es: ––I have some news to share with you ––said Lydia as they sat down at the table—. What do you think? It's the most sensational thing you can imagine; something very important about a certain person we all like.

en: Jane and Elizabeth looked at each other, and the waiter was told that he need not stay. Lydia laughed, and said,—
vi: Jane and Elizabeth looked at each other, the waiter had been told not to attend to them closely. Lydia laughed, and said:
tr: Jane and Elizabeth looked at each other; they told the waiter he didn't need to stay. Lydia laughed and said,
es: Jane and Elizabeth looked at each other and told the servant that they no longer needed him. Lydia laughed and said:

en: “Ay, that is just like your formality and discretion. You thought the waiter must not hear, as if he cared! I dare say he often hears worse things said than I am going to say. But he is an ugly fellow! I am glad he is gone. I never saw such a long chin in my life. Well, but now for my news: it is about dear Wickham; too good for the waiter, is not it? There is no danger of Wickham’s marrying Mary King—there’s for you! She is gone down to her uncle at Liverpool; gone to stay. Wickham is safe.”
vi: - Ah, both sisters are still serious and cautious. The two sisters think it’s not necessary to let the servant know, as if he really wants to know! I think surely he often hears worse news than what I’m about to reveal. But he is so ugly! I’m glad he’s gone. In my life, I’ve never seen anyone with such a long chin. Alright, now here’s the news I want to announce; it’s about Mr. Wickham, too good for him, isn’t it? There’s no danger of Wickham marrying Miss Mary King. He’s yours! She has gone with her uncle to Liverpool and will stay there permanently. Wickham is safe.
tr: "Ah, your formality and tight-lipped nature, don't you see. You didn't want the waiter to hear, as if he cared! He probably hears worse things than what I'm about to tell you. But what an ugly fellow! Good thing he left. I've never seen such a long chin in my life. Anyway, let's get to my news: about dear Wickham; too good for the waiter, isn't it? There's no danger of Wickham marrying Mary King. How's that for news! The girl has gone to her uncle in Liverpool; she's gone to stay. Wickham is safe now."
es: ––Ah! That reveals your formality and discretion. Do you think the servant was going to listen? As if he cared! I would bet he often hears things much worse than what I'm going to tell you. But he's a very ugly fellow; I'm glad he's gone; I've never seen such a long chin. Well, now let's get to the news; it concerns our dear Wickham; it's too good for the servant, isn't it? There's no danger of Wickham marrying Mary King. We'll keep it to ourselves. Mary King has gone to Liverpool, to her aunt's house, and she won't be coming back. Wickham is safe!

en: “And Mary King is safe!” added Elizabeth; “safe from a connection imprudent as to fortune.”
vi: Elizabeth added: - And Mary King is safe! Safe from a reckless marriage in terms of fortune.
tr: "Mary King is safe!" added Elizabeth; "she has escaped a financially imprudent marriage.""
es: ––And Mary King is safe too ––added Elizabeth––, safe from an imprudent marriage for her happiness.

en: “She is a great fool for going away, if she liked him.”
vi: - She was foolish to leave if she liked him.
tr: "Leaving was a big mistake if he loved her.""
es: ––Well, she’s quite foolish for leaving if she loves him.

en: “But I hope there is no strong attachment on either side,” said Jane.
vi: Jane said: - But she hopes that neither side remains attached.
tr: "But I guess there isn't a strong commitment on either side," said Jane.
es: ––But I suppose there wouldn't be much love between them ––said Jane.

en: “I am sure there is not on his. I will answer for it, he never cared three straws about her. Who could about such a nasty little freckled thing?”
vi: - I'm sure he doesn't have any attachment. You can answer about this, that he doesn't care about her. Who would care about such a freckled and ugly person!
tr: "I'm sure he's not in Wickham. I don't think he cared about the girl at all. Who would care about such a pesky, freckled, insignificant girl?"
es: ––As for him, I'm sure he doesn't; Mary never mattered to him at all. Who could be interested in something so disgusting and so full of freckles?

en: Elizabeth was shocked to think that, however incapable of such coarseness of expression herself, the coarseness of the sentiment was little other than her own breast had formerly harboured and fancied liberal!
vi: Elizabeth was shocked to think that, although she did not have the ability to express such rudeness, the rudeness in her feelings in this way was no different than if her breasts were freely exposed!
tr: Elizabeth was stunned, and although she could not bring herself to use such coarse expressions, she thought about how she had once harbored such coarse feelings in her own heart and had found them reasonable!
es: Elizabeth was scandalized to think that, although she was incapable of expressing such vulgarity, the sentiment was not very different from what she herself had once harbored and admitted as liberal.

en: As soon as all had ate, and the elder ones paid, the carriage was ordered; and, after some contrivance, the whole party, with all their boxes, workbags, and parcels, and the unwelcome addition of Kitty’s and Lydia’s purchases, were seated in it.
vi: After they had finished eating and the older sisters had paid, they called the driver and loaded all the luggage, boxes, bags, along with the items Kitty and Lydia had bought that no one liked.
tr: After everyone finished their meal and the sisters paid the bill, the car was summoned; after a bit of effort, they all settled into the car along with all the boxes, craft bags, and packages, and the annoying addition of Kitty and Lydia's shopping.
es: As soon as they had eaten and the older ones had paid, they called for the carriage and, after organizing themselves a bit, all the girls, with their boxes, their work bags, their packages, and the poorly received addition of Catherine and Lydia's purchases, settled into the vehicle.

en: “How nicely we are crammed in!” cried Lydia. “I am glad I brought my bonnet, if it is only for the fun of having another band-box! Well, now let us be quite comfortable and snug, and talk and laugh all the way home. And in the first place, let us hear what has happened to you all since you went away. Have you seen any pleasant men? Have you had any flirting? I was in great hopes that one of you would have got a husband before you came back. Jane will be quite an old maid soon, I declare. She is almost three-and-twenty! Lord! how ashamed I should be of not being married before three-and-twenty! My aunt Philips wants you so to get husbands you can’t think. She says Lizzy had better have taken Mr. Collins; but I do not think there would have been any fun in it. Lord! how I should like to be married before any of you! and then I would chaperon you about to all the balls. Dear me! we had such a good piece of fun the other day at Colonel Forster’s! Kitty and me were to spend the day there, and Mrs. Forster promised to have a little dance in the evening; (by-the-bye, Mrs. Forster and me are such friends!) and so she asked the two Harringtons to come: but Harriet was ill, and so Pen was forced to come by herself; and then, what do you think we did? We dressed up Chamberlayne in woman’s clothes, on purpose to pass for a lady,—only think what fun! Not a soul knew of it, but Colonel and Mrs. Forster, and Kitty and me, except my aunt, for we were forced to borrow one of her gowns; and you cannot imagine how well he looked! When Denny, and Wickham, and Pratt, and two or three more of the men came in, they did not know him in the least. Lord! how I laughed! and so did Mrs. Forster. I thought I should have died. And that made the men suspect something, and then they soon found out what was the matter.”
vi: Lydia exclaimed: - How wonderful it is to stack them up! I'm glad I bought the hat, not just because I got an extra box! Now let's be comfortable and cozy, feel free to chat and laugh along the way back. First of all, please tell me what has happened since you left home. Did you meet any nice gentlemen? Did anyone try to court you? I had hoped one of you would have a husband before returning. I can say that Jane will soon become an old maid. She's almost twenty-three. Goodness, I would be so ashamed if I didn't get married before twenty-three! Aunt Phillips really wants you to get married, you don't know that. She said Lizzy should have married Mr. Collins, but I think that wouldn't have been any good. Oh, I wish I could get married before you all, then I could accompany you to all the balls. Goodness! The other day we had such a fun time at Colonel Forster's house. Kitty and I planned to visit for a day, and Mrs. Forster promised to hold a dance in the evening, so she invited the Harrington sisters, but Harriet was sick and Pen had to go alone. And then, guess what we did? We dressed Chamberlayne in women's clothes, to disguise him as a girl – just for fun. No one else knew except Mr. and Mrs. Forster, Kitty and I, and the aunt, because we had to borrow her dress, you can't imagine how much he looked like a girl!
