When Denny, Wickham, and Pratt along with a few other guys walked in, they had no idea it was him. Oh my, I laughed so hard! So did Mrs. Forster. I thought I might faint. And that made the guys suspicious, and soon they found out the truth.
tr: "How nicely we fit!" cried Lydia. "I'm so glad I brought my bonnet, it's worth it just for the box! Now let's make ourselves comfortable, talk and laugh all the way home. Tell me what happened since you left. Did you see any handsome men? Did you have any flirtations? I was saying that at least one of you wouldn't return without finding a husband. Jane will soon be left on the shelf. She's almost twenty-three! God, how embarrassed I would be if I weren't married before twenty-three! You can't imagine how much Aunt Philips wants us to find husbands. She says Lizzy should have accepted Mr. Collins; but I think that wouldn't have been fun. God! How I wish to get married before you; then I would play matchmaker for you at all the balls. Honestly, we had such fun at Colonel Forster's the other day! Kitty and I were going to spend the day there, and Mrs. Forster promised a little dance in the evening; (by the way, we became close friends with Mrs. Forster!) then she invited the Harringtons, but Harriet was sick, so Pen had to come alone; and guess what we did? We dressed Chamberlayne in women's clothes and passed him off as a maid – imagine how much fun we had! Only Colonel and Mrs. Forster, Kitty and I, and my aunt knew about it; we told my aunt to borrow her dress; you can't imagine how great it was! Denny, Wickham, Pratt, and a few others came, and they didn't recognize him. God! How I laughed! Mrs. Forster laughed so much too. I was dying of laughter. The men got suspicious because of this, and then they figured it out anyway."
es: ––How tightly packed we are! ––exclaimed Lydia––. I'm glad I bought the hat, if only for the pleasure of having another hatbox! Well, let's get comfortable and chat and laugh all the way home. First, let's hear what has happened to you since you left. Have you met any interesting men? Have you had any flirts? I had high hopes that one of you would catch a husband before coming back. Jane is soon going to get old. She is almost twenty-three years old! Lord, how ashamed I would be if I didn't get married before twenty-three...! You can't imagine how much Aunt Philips wants you to get married. She says Lizzy would have done better to accept Collins; but I think it would have been very boring. Lord, how I would love to get married before you! Then I would be the one to accompany you to the balls. How much fun we had the other day at the Forsters'! Catherine and I went to spend the day there, and Mrs. Forster promised us she would give a small dance in the evening. Since Mrs. Forster and I are such good friends! So she invited the Harringtons, but since Harriet was sick, Pen had to come alone; and then, what do you think we did? We dressed Chamberlayne as a woman so he could pass as a lady. Can you imagine the laughter? Nobody knew, only the colonel, Mrs. Forster, Catherine, and I, apart from my aunt, because we had to borrow one of her dresses; you can't imagine how well he looked. When Denny, Wickham, Pratt, and two or three other gentlemen arrived, they didn't recognize him at all. Oh, how I laughed! And how Mrs. Forster laughed! I thought I was going to die of laughter. And then, that made them suspect something and they soon discovered the joke.

en: With such kind of histories of their parties and good jokes did Lydia, assisted by Kitty’s hints and additions, endeavour to amuse her companions all the way to Longbourn. Elizabeth listened as little as she could, but there was no escaping the frequent mention of Wickham’s name.
vi: With the stories about the ball and such jokes, along with Kitty's embellishments, Lydia tried to entertain her sisters all the way back to Longbourn. Elizabeth wanted to hear as little as possible, but she could not avoid hearing Wickham's name.
tr: By recounting the stories of their parties and sweet jokes, Lydia, with Kitty's help and additions, tried to entertain their companions all the way to Longbourn. Elizabeth listened as little as possible, but she couldn't help noticing Wickham's name being mentioned frequently.
es: With similar stories of parties and jokes, Lydia tried, with the help of Catherine's directions, to entertain her sisters and Maria all the way until they reached Longbourn. Elizabeth tried to listen to her as little as possible, but the frequent allusions to Wickham did not escape her.

en: Their reception at home was most kind. Mrs. Bennet rejoiced to see Jane in undiminished beauty; and more than once during dinner did Mr. Bennet say voluntarily to Elizabeth,——
vi: They were warmly welcomed at home. Mrs. Bennet was delighted to see that Jane was still as beautiful as before. More than once during dinner, Mr. Bennet said to Elizabeth:
tr: They were warmly welcomed at home. Mrs. Bennet was very happy to see that Jane's beauty was still intact; during the meal, Mr. Bennet said to Elizabeth several times, "I'm glad you're back, Lizzy," with affection.
es: At home, they were received with all the affection. Mrs. Bennet rejoiced to see Jane as beautiful as ever, and Mr. Bennet, during the meal, more than once said to Elizabeth with all his heart:

en: “I am glad you are come back, Lizzy.”
vi: - Dad is happy to see you back, Lizzy.
tr: Mrs. Bennet was very happy to see that Jane's beauty was still intact; during the meal, Mr. Bennet said to Elizabeth several times, "I'm glad you're back, Lizzy," with affection.
es: ––I'm glad you're back, Lizzy.

en: Their party in the dining-room was large, for almost all the Lucases came to meet Maria and hear the news; and various were the subjects which occupied them: Lady Lucas was inquiring of Maria, across the table, after the welfare and poultry of her eldest daughter; Mrs. Bennet was doubly engaged, on one hand collecting an account of the present fashions from Jane, who sat some way below her, and on the other, retailing them all to the younger Miss Lucases; and Lydia, in a voice rather louder than any other person’s, was enumerating the various pleasures of the morning to anybody who would hear her.
vi: The gathering in the dining room had many people, as most of the Lucas household came to meet Maria and hear her news, asking about everything. Lady Lucas asked Maria about her health and the chickens of her eldest daughter. Mrs. Bennet was doubly busy, on one hand asking Jane about the current fashion, and on the other talking to the Lucas sister. Lydia, with a voice that drowned out everyone else, recounted her morning amusements to anyone who would listen.
tr: There was a large crowd in the dining room; almost all the Lucases had come to welcome Maria and hear the news; everyone was occupied with a different matter; Lady Lucas was asking Maria about her eldest daughter's well-being and her chickens from across the table; Mrs. Bennet was engaged in two tasks at once, receiving the latest fashion news from Jane, who was sitting a little further away, and relaying this information to the younger Lucas girls; Lydia, in a voice louder than anyone else's, was recounting her morning's amusements to the room, for anyone who cared to listen.
es: The gathering in the dining room was large, as most of the Lucases had come to pick up Maria and hear the news. Many things were discussed. Lady Lucas was questioning Maria from across the table about the well-being and the pen of her eldest daughter; Mrs. Bennet was doubly occupied in finding out about the London fashions that her daughter Jane was explaining to her on one side, and in conveying the information to the younger Lucases on the other. Lydia, shouting louder than anyone, detailed what they had enjoyed that morning to all who would listen.

en: “Oh, Mary,” said she, “I wish you had gone with us, for we had such fun! as we went along Kitty and me drew up all the blinds, and pretended there was nobody in the coach; and I should have gone so all the way, if Kitty had not been sick; and when we got to the George, I do think we behaved very handsomely, for we treated the other three with the nicest cold luncheon in the world, and if you would have gone, we would have treated you too. And then when we came away it was such fun! I thought we never should have got into the coach. I was ready to die of laughter. And then we were so merry all the way home! we talked and laughed so loud, that anybody might have heard us ten miles off!”
vi: - Hey! Maria, I wish you were with us, it was so much fun! On the way, Kitty and I pulled down all the curtains, pretending there was no one on the bus. I could go the whole way like that, but Kitty felt uncomfortable. When we got to George, I think we behaved well, because we treated your dad to the best ham in the world; if you leave and come back, we will treat you the same way. And it was really fun when everyone was on the bus. I thought all of us sisters couldn't fit on the bus. I laughed so hard I almost died. And then all of us sisters were happy on the way back. We talked so loudly that everyone could hear us from ten miles away!
tr: "Ah, Mary," he was saying, "I wish you had come with us, we had so much fun! On the way, Kitty and I opened all the curtains, pretending there was no one else in the car; if Kitty hadn't gotten nauseous, I would have gone the whole way like that; when we arrived at George's inn, I think we acted very chic and offered these three people the best cold dishes in the world, if you had come, we would have offered them to you too. Our return was just as fun! I thought we would never get into the car. I was laughing so hard I almost died. And such joy on the way back! What a laugh, they must have heard us from miles away."
es: ––Oh, Mary! ––he exclaimed––. How much I would have liked you to come with us! We had so much fun! When Catherine and I were alone, we closed all the windows to make it look like the car was empty, and we would have gone like that the whole way if Catherine hadn't gotten sick. When we arrived at the "George" we were so generous! We treated the three of us to the most amazing appetizer in the world, and if you had come, we would have invited you too. And what a blast on the way back! I thought we wouldn't fit in the car. I almost died laughing. And the whole way we had a great time; we talked and laughed so loudly that we could have been heard ten miles away.

en: To this, Mary very gravely replied, “Far be it from me, my dear sister, to depreciate such pleasures. They would doubtless be congenial with the generality of female minds. But I confess they would have no charms for me. I should infinitely prefer a book.”
vi: Mary replied, solemnly: - She does not underestimate such pleasures, which are clearly in line with the temperament of women. But to be honest, she does not crave these pleasures. She definitely prefers reading books.
tr: Mary answered this seriously, "Oh, keep it away from me, sister, such pleasures are not for me." Most women like such things. But they are not attractive to me at all. I prefer to read books."
es: Mary replied gravely: ––Far be it from me, dear sister, to disdain those pleasures. They are undoubtedly suitable for the majority of women. But I confess that they do not amuse me at all; I would have preferred a book a thousand times over.

en: But of this answer Lydia heard not a word. She seldom listened to anybody for more than half a minute, and never attended to Mary at all.
vi: But Lydia did not want to hear a word of the reply. She rarely listened to anyone for more than half a minute, and never wanted to hear Mary.
tr: Aunt Lydia did not hear a single word of this answer. She rarely listened to anyone for more than half a minute, and she didn't even listen to Mary for that long.
es: But Lydia did not hear a word of her remark. She rarely listened to anyone for more than half a minute, and she never paid any attention to Mary.

en: In the afternoon Lydia was urgent with the rest of the girls to walk to Meryton, and see how everybody went on; but Elizabeth steadily opposed the scheme. It should not be said, that the Miss Bennets could not be at home half a day before they were in pursuit of the officers. There was another reason, too, for her opposition. She dreaded seeing Wickham again, and was resolved to avoid it as long as possible. The comfort to her, of the regiment’s approaching removal, was indeed beyond expression. In a fortnight they were to go, and once gone, she hoped there could be nothing more to plague her on his account.
vi: In the afternoon, Lydia eagerly joined the other girls to go to Meryton and see what everyone was doing, but Elizabeth stubbornly resisted. It should not be said that the Bennet girls could not stay at home for half a day without chasing after the officers. She resisted for another reason. She was fed up with seeing Wickham again and was determined to avoid this for as long as possible. The consolation for her, that the regiment would be moving, was truly hard to describe. They would depart in two weeks, and after they were gone, she hoped there would be nothing left to trouble her about him.
tr: In the afternoon, Lydia insisted on walking to Meryton with the other girls to see what everyone was up to; but Elizabeth stubbornly opposed the plan. It should not be said that the Miss Bennets were chasing after officers without even spending half a day at home. There was another reason for her opposition. The thought of seeing Wickham again was terrifying to her, and she was determined to avoid it as much as possible. The proximity of the regiment's departure gave her an indescribable comfort. They would be gone within fifteen days; and once they were gone, she hoped she would no longer be troubled because of Wickham.
es: In the afternoon, Lydia insisted that they all go to Meryton to see how everyone was; but Elizabeth vehemently opposed. She did not want it to be said that the Bennet ladies could not stay at home for half a day without running after the officers. She had another reason for opposing: she feared seeing Wickham again, something she wanted to avoid at all costs. The satisfaction she felt at the regiment's departure was beyond what could be expressed. In fifteen days they would no longer be there, and she hoped that this way she would be rid of Wickham forever.

en: She had not been many hours at home, before she found that the Brighton scheme, of which Lydia had given them a hint at the inn, was under frequent discussion between her parents. Elizabeth saw directly that her father had not the smallest intention of yielding; but his answers were at the same time so vague and equivocal, that her mother, though often disheartened, had never yet despaired of succeeding at last.
vi: Just a few hours after arriving home, she realized that her parents often discussed the plan about Brington that Lydia had mentioned at the inn. Elizabeth immediately saw that her father did not want to comply, but his answers were both vague and ambiguous; while her mother was not worried about failure, even though she often felt discouraged.
tr: She had not been home for long when she saw that the Brighton plan Lydia had mentioned at the inn was a frequent topic of discussion between her mother and father. She immediately understood that her father had no intention of going; but his responses were so vague and evasive that, although her mother often lost hope, she had not yet lost her belief that she would eventually succeed.
es: She hadn't been home for many hours when she realized that the Brighton plan Lydia had informed them about at the inn was often discussed by her parents. Elizabeth understood that Mr. Bennet had no intention of giving in, but his replies were so vague and equivocal that her mother, although sometimes discouraged, did not lose hope of eventually getting her way.

en: CHAPTER XL.
vi: Chapter 40
tr: Chapter XVII
es: CHAPTER XL

en: ELIZABETH’S impatience to acquaint Jane with what had happened could no longer be overcome; and at length resolving to suppress every particular in which her sister was concerned, and preparing her to be surprised, she related to her the next morning the chief of the scene between Mr. Darcy and herself.
vi: Jane no longer wanted to satisfy Elizabeth's eagerness to know about what had happened. Eventually, Elizabeth did not mention her sister's situation. The next morning, she wanted to surprise her sister; she recounted what had happened between Mr. Darcy and herself.
tr: Elizabeth could no longer resist the impatience she felt to tell Jane what had happened; finally, deciding to withhold the details concerning her sister and asking her to be prepared for a surprise, she recounted to her the majority of what had transpired between her and Mr. Darcy the next morning.
es: Elizabeth could no longer contain her impatience to tell Jane everything that had happened. Finally, she decided to omit everything related to her sister, and after preparing her for the surprise, she recounted the most important parts of her scene with Darcy the next morning.

en: Miss Bennet’s astonishment was soon lessened by the strong sisterly partiality which made any admiration of Elizabeth appear perfectly natural; and all surprise was shortly lost in other feelings. She was sorry that Mr. Darcy should have delivered his sentiments in a manner so little suited to recommend them; but still more was she grieved for the unhappiness which her sister’s refusal must have given him.
vi: Miss Bennet's surprise did not last long due to the sisterly affection that made her admire her sister's natural composure, then she sank into other thoughts. She regretted that Mr. Darcy had proposed in an inappropriate manner, but she was even more saddened by his misfortune of being rejected by her sister. She said:
tr: Miss Bennet's astonishment did not last long, as she found it quite natural that Elizabeth should be admired, due to her strong sisterly partiality; indeed, soon there was no astonishment left at all. She was upset that Mr. Darcy had expressed his feelings in a rather ungracious manner; but she was more upset by the unhappiness that her sister's rejection must have caused him.
es: The great affection that Jane felt for Elizabeth diminished her astonishment, for anything that was admiration for her seemed perfectly natural. Her feelings were different. It hurt her that Darcy had expressed himself in such a way that was so little suitable to make himself agreeable, but it pained her even more to think of the unhappiness that her sister's refusal would have caused him.

en: “His being so sure of succeeding was wrong,” said she, “and certainly ought not to have appeared; but consider how much it must increase his disappointment.”
vi: - He made a mistake by being too confident that he would succeed, he shouldn't have expressed it in that way, but I think this only makes him more disappointed.
tr: "It was a mistake to be so sure it would be accepted," he said, "it shouldn't have looked that way; but just think, how much it must have increased his disappointment."
es: ––It was a mistake to be so sure of success ––he said–– and of course he shouldn't have given himself away; but just imagine how much he must regret it and how bad he must feel now!

en: “Indeed,” replied Elizabeth, “I am heartily sorry for him; but he has other feelings which will probably soon drive away his regard for me. You do not blame me, however, for refusing him?”
vi: Elizabeth replied: - That's right, I pity him, but you have other thoughts that might dispel your feelings for me. However, you don't blame me for rejecting him, do you?
tr: "Of course," replied Elizabeth, "I really feel sorry for him; but he has other feelings that will extinguish his interest in me. Still, you don't blame me for rejecting him, do you?"
es: ––It is true ––replied Elizabeth––, I truly feel sorry for him; but his pride is so great that it won't take long for him to forget me. Do you think it was wrong for me to reject him?

en: “Blame you! Oh, no.”
vi: - Blame you? Oh, no.
tr: "Blame you! No, not at all."
es: ––Do I mind? Not at all.

en: “But you blame me for having spoken so warmly of Wickham?”
vi: - But you blame me for speaking so warmly about Wickham.
tr: "But you blame me for speaking so sympathetically about Wickham."
es: ––But you must not have liked that I spoke to him with such emphasis about Wickham.

en: “No—I do not know that you were wrong in saying what you did.”
vi: - No. Based on what you told me about your reaction, I don't think you were wrong.
tr: "No – I don't know if I made a mistake by saying them."
es: ––I don't know if you did wrong by speaking to him the way you did.

en: “But you will know it, when I have told you what happened the very next day.”
vi: - But you will think, after I tell you about the next day.
tr: "But you will know when I tell you what happened the next day.""
es: ––Well, you will know when I have told you what happened the next day.

en: She then spoke of the letter, repeating the whole of its contents as far as they concerned George Wickham. What a stroke was this for poor Jane, who would willingly have gone through the world without believing that so much wickedness existed in the whole race of mankind as was here collected in one individual! Nor was Darcy’s vindication, though grateful to her feelings, capable of consoling her for such discovery. Most earnestly did she labour to prove the probability of error, and seek to clear one, without involving the other.
vi: Then she recounted the letter, repeating even the part about George Wickham. It was indeed a shock for poor Jane! She was always willing to endure all the ups and downs of life without believing that all the malice of humanity could be gathered in one individual. Even Darcy's explanation could not console her for this discovery, though her mind was somewhat eased. She was eager to prove the possibility of a mistake and wanted to exonerate one person without affecting another.
tr: Then she spoke about the letter, repeating all the parts concerning George Wickham. These were a great blow to poor Jane! She could have spent her whole life believing that such baseness did not exist in any one person among the entire human race. Even though Darcy's exoneration pleased her, it could not lessen the pain of such a discovery. She searched with all her might for the possibility of a mistake and tried to find one innocent without implicating the other.
es: Then Elizabeth spoke to her about the letter, repeating all its contents as far as they related to George Wickham. It was a hard blow for poor Jane. She would have traveled around the world without suspecting that such perversity could exist in all of humanity as was contained in that single individual. Not even Darcy's justification, however pleasing it was to her, was enough to console her from such a revelation. She tried with all her might to maintain that there could be some mistake, attempting to defend one without incriminating the other.

en: “This will not do,” said Elizabeth; “you never will be able to make both of them good for anything. Take your choice, but you must be satisfied with only one. There is but such a quantity of merit between them; just enough to make one good sort of man; and of late it has been shifting about pretty much. For my part, I am inclined to believe it all Mr. Darcy’s, but you shall do as you choose.”
vi: Elizabeth said: - It can't be done. You can never make both people good at anything. You should choose, but you should be content with just one person. There is only one value between them that is enough to help one person become good, and recently, this value has been transferred back and forth quite a lot. As for me, I can trust Mr. Darcy completely, but it's up to you to decide.
tr: "It's no use," said Elizabeth. "You can't do a good thing with both of them at the same time. Make your choice, but you must be content with just one. Even if you take all their virtues, it would only be enough to make one good man; besides, he has been changing sides a lot lately. For my part, I am inclined to believe Mr. Darcy, but you must make your own choice."
es: ––It will be of no use to you ––Elizabeth told him––; you will never be able to say that both are good. Choose as you wish; but either you stay with one or the other. Between the two, they do not gather more than just enough merits for one decent man. We have already deceived ourselves enough lately. For my part, I am inclined to believe everything Darcy says; you will see what you decide.

en: It was some time, however, before a smile could be extorted from Jane.
vi: However, it took Jane a while before she could muster a smile.
tr: It still took some time for Jane to be able to smile.
es: It took a long time before Jane could smile.

en: “I do not know when I have been more shocked,” said she. “Wickham so very bad! It is almost past belief. And poor Mr. Darcy! dear Lizzy, only consider what he must have suffered. Such a disappointment! and with the knowledge of your ill opinion too! and having to relate such a thing of his sister! It is really too distressing, I am sure you must feel it so.”
vi: She said: - I have never been so shocked like this. Wickham is really terrible! It's almost unbelievable. Poor Mr. Darcy! Lizzy, just thinking about how much he has suffered. It must be so disappointing for him to know that you thought badly of him! To have to recount the story of his sister like that! It’s truly painful! I am sure you feel the same way.
tr: "I don't remember being more surprised," she said. "Wickham being so bad! It's an incredible thing. Poor Mr. Darcy! Imagine the agony he must have endured, my dear Lizzy. Such a disappointment! and knowing your negative opinions as well! To have to tell such a thing about his sister! It's truly very distressing. I'm sure you feel the same way."
es: ––I don't know what has surprised me more ––she said at last––. That Wickham is so wicked! It's almost unbelievable. And poor Darcy! Dear Elizabeth, just think of what he must have suffered. What a disappointment! And on top of that, confessing the bad opinion you had of him! And having to tell such things about his sister! It is truly dreadful. Don't you think so?

en: “Oh no, my regret and compassion are all done away by seeing you so full of both. I know you will do him such ample justice, that I am growing every moment more unconcerned and indifferent. Your profusion makes me saving; and if you lament over him much longer, my heart will be as light as a feather.”
vi: - Oh, no! When I see you carrying heavy regret and pity, I no longer feel regret and pity. I know you will judge him fairly, so I worry less. Your heavy heart makes mine lighter. If you lament for him more, my heart will be as light as a feather.
tr: "No, no! My chances of regret or pity are disappearing, while you have both in abundance. I know you will treat him quite fairly, so I am becoming more indifferent, more detached by the minute. Your generosity makes me frugal; if you complain about him a little more, my heart will feel as light as a feather."
es: ––Oh, no! All my sorrow and compassion have left me upon seeing that you feel them for both. I know that as long as you do justice, it is enough. I know I can become more and more unconcerned and indifferent. Your abundance of lamentations saves me. And if you continue to pity him for a long time, my heart will become as insensitive as a rock.

en: “Poor Wickham! there is such an expression of goodness in his countenance! such an openness and gentleness in his manner.”
vi: - Poor Wickham! His face shows a kind expression. His gestures are all open and graceful.
tr: "Poor Wickham; goodness radiates from his face! His manners are so charming, so kind.""
es: ––Poor Wickham! He seems so good, so frank! ––Yes, it's true; there must have been a misdirection in the education of these two young men; one took all the kindness and the other all the good appearances.

en: “There certainly was some great mismanagement in the education of those two young men. One has got all the goodness, and the other all the appearance of it.”
vi: - There is certainly some trouble in the educational foundation of you two. One person absorbs all the good things; the other only shows all the good things on the surface.
tr: "It is clear that a great mistake was made in the education of these two young men. Goodness is in one of them, and in the appearance of the other."
es: ––Yes, it's true; there must have been a misdirection in the education of these two young men; one took all the kindness and the other all the good appearances.

en: “I never thought Mr. Darcy so deficient in the appearance of it as you used to do.”
vi: - I never thought Mr. Darcy was as lacking in appearance as you often think.
tr: "I never thought there was any goodness in Mr. Darcy's appearance, unlike you."
es: ––I never considered that Darcy's appearances were as bad as you said.

en: “And yet I meant to be uncommonly clever in taking so decided a dislike to him, without any reason. It is such a spur to one’s genius, such an opening for wit, to have a dislike of that kind. One may be continually abusive without saying anything just; but one cannot be always laughing at a man without now and then stumbling on something witty.”
vi: - And yet, previously you had determined to appear extraordinarily wise by hating me without any reason at all. This is the natural instinct of a human being, the act of opening a keen mind to have such hatred in this way. People can continue to insult without bothering to say anything fair, but they cannot keep mocking someone without occasionally touching on something witty.
tr: "Still, I thought I was being incredibly smart by feeling an unfounded coldness towards him. This kind of coldness stimulates one's genius, opens up one's intellect. A person can continuously harass someone without saying a single justified word; but a person cannot laugh at someone forever without occasionally saying something clever."
es: ––Well, you see, I thought I was very clever when I found him so unpleasant for no reason at all. Feeling that kind of antipathy is like a stimulus for intelligence, it's like a sign of wit. You can keep talking badly about someone without ever saying anything accurate; but it's impossible to always laugh at a person without hitting the mark at least once.

en: “Lizzy, when you first read that letter, I am sure you could not treat the matter as you do now.”
vi: - Lizzy, I'm sure that when you first read the letter, you didn't think about the matter as you do now.
tr: "Lizzy, I'm sure you couldn't evaluate the matter the same way when you first read that letter as you do now.""
es: ––I am sure, Elizabeth, that when you first read Darcy's letter, you did not think so.

en: “Indeed, I could not. I was uncomfortable enough, I was very uncomfortable—I may say unhappy. And with no one to speak to of what I felt, no Jane to comfort me, and say that I had not been so very weak, and vain, and nonsensical, as I knew I had! Oh, how I wanted you!”
vi: - Actually, at that time, I couldn't think about anything. I was too disturbed. I was very disturbed, you could say I was miserable. And there was no one to talk to about what I was thinking, no Jane to comfort me and tell me that I had never been so weak, empty, and unreasonable! Oh! I needed you so much!
tr: "Of course not. I am very disturbed. I can say I am quite disturbed, even unhappy. There is no one to talk to about what I feel, no Jane to comfort me and tell me that I am not acting as weak, brainless, and heartless as I think! Oh! how I have missed you!"
es: ––I wouldn't have been able to, it's true. I was so upset, or rather, so sad. And the worst part of all was that I had no one to confide my sorrow in. To have no one to talk to about what I felt, no Jane to console me and tell me that I hadn't been as fragile, as vain, and as foolish as I thought I was! How much I missed you!

en: “How unfortunate that you should have used such very strong expressions in speaking of Wickham to Mr. Darcy, for now they do appear wholly undeserved.”
vi: - It is truly regrettable that you used such strong expressions when speaking to Mr. Darcy about Wickham, as neither of them is entirely deserving of such praise or criticism.
tr: "It was unfortunate that you used such strong expressions when talking to Mr. Darcy about Wickham; now it turns out he didn't deserve it at all.""
es: ––To have attacked Darcy in that way to defend Wickham, and now to think that he didn't deserve it!

en: “Certainly. But the misfortune of speaking with bitterness is a most natural consequence of the prejudices I had been encouraging. There is one point on which I want your advice. I want to be told whether I ought, or ought not, to make our acquaintance in general understand Wickham’s character.”
vi: - Certainly so. But the bitter way of speaking is the most inevitable consequence of the prejudices you keep pursuing. There is one thing I need your advice on. I want you to tell me whether or not I should inform the people we know so that they understand Wickham's true nature.
tr: "Absolutely. But the misfortune of speaking harsh words is the natural result of the prejudices I have nurtured within me. There is a point where I need your advice. You need to tell me whether I should or should not speak about Wickham's character to others."
es: ––It's true; but she was embittered by the prejudices she had been nurturing. I need you to advise me on something. Should I or should I not disclose what I have learned about Wickham?

en: Miss Bennet paused a little, and then replied, “Surely there can be no occasion for exposing him so dreadfully. What is your own opinion?”
vi: Ms. Bennet hesitated for a moment, then replied: - There's certainly no chance to expose him in such a terrible way. What do you think?
tr: After a moment's hesitation, Miss Bennet replied, "There is no reason to disgrace the poor man in front of everyone." "What is your opinion?""
es: Jane meditated for a while and then said: ––I don't think there's any reason to put him in such a bad light. What do you think?

en: “That it ought not to be attempted. Mr. Darcy has not authorized me to make his communication public. On the contrary, every particular relative to his sister was meant to be kept as much as possible to myself; and if I endeavour to undeceive people as to the rest of his conduct, who will believe me? The general prejudice against Mr. Darcy is so violent, that it would be the death of half the good people in Meryton, to attempt to place him in an amiable light. I am not equal to it. Wickham will soon be gone; and, therefore, it will not signify to anybody here what he really is. Some time hence it will be all found out, and then we may laugh at their stupidity in not knowing it before. At present I will say nothing about it.”
vi: - I think you shouldn't. Mr. Darcy hasn't given me permission to tell the world about what he said. Moreover, all details concerning his sister need to be kept confidential. If I try to tell everyone about other matters, who will believe me? The prejudices against Mr. Darcy are so intense that if he were portrayed in a good light, half the people in Meryton would faint. Wickham will soon leave, so no one will care to know what kind of person he really is. After some time, people will find out, and then we can mock them for being ignorant and not recognizing it earlier. Right now, I don't want to say anything about this matter.
tr: "I think it is best not to do it. Mr. Darcy did not allow me to explain what he had told me. On the contrary, he instructed me to keep every detail about his sister to myself as much as possible; if I try to correct people's misconceptions about his other behaviors, who would believe me? The prejudice against Mr. Darcy is so strong that to make him appear likable, one would have to kill half the people in Meryton. I can't manage that much. Wickham will be leaving soon; therefore, his true nature will not mean anything to anyone. One day in the future, it will be known, and then we will laugh at their foolishness for not having learned it earlier. For now, I will not say anything about it."
es: ––That you are right. Darcy has not authorized me to disclose what he has revealed to me. On the contrary, he has made it clear that I must keep the matter of his sister as confidential as possible. And, on the other hand, even if I wanted to open people's eyes to his conduct in other matters, who would believe me? The prejudice against Darcy is so strong that half of the good people of Meryton would rather die than have to put him on a pedestal. I am not suited for that. Wickham will leave soon, and it is better that I keep quiet. In some time, everything will be discovered and then we can laugh at people's foolishness for not having known it earlier. For now, I will say nothing.

en: “You are quite right. To have his errors made public might ruin him for ever. He is now, perhaps, sorry for what he has done, and anxious to re-establish a character. We must not make him desperate.”
vi: - I think you're absolutely right. If we expose all his mistakes, we could ruin his entire life. Maybe now he's regretting what he did and wants to rebuild himself. We shouldn't make him lose hope.
tr: "You are absolutely right. Revealing his flaws could ruin his life. Maybe he regrets what he has done and is trying to become a better person again. Let's not crush his hopes."
es: ––It seems very good to me. If you spread his defects, you could ruin him forever. Maybe he regrets what he did and wants to make amends. We should not push him to despair.

en: The tumult of Elizabeth’s mind was allayed by this conversation. She had got rid of two of the secrets which had weighed on her for a fortnight, and was certain of a willing listener in Jane, whenever she might wish to talk again of either. But there was still something lurking behind, of which prudence forbade the disclosure. She dared not relate the other half of Mr. Darcy’s letter, nor explain to her sister how sincerely she had been valued by his friend. Here was knowledge in which no one could partake; and she was sensible that nothing less than a perfect understanding between the parties could justify her in throwing off this last encumbrance of mystery. “And then,” said she, “if that very improbable event should ever take place, I shall merely be able to tell what Bingley may tell in a much more agreeable manner himself. The liberty of communication cannot be mine till it has lost all its value!”
vi: Elizabeth's troubled mind returned to peace thanks to this conversation. She had confided two deep secrets that had weighed heavily on her mind for the past two weeks, certain that Jane would be willing to listen, even if she might not want to discuss the matter again. But there was still something lingering in the background that her cautious nature prevented her from revealing. She did not dare to mention the other half of Mr. Darcy's letter, nor did she dare to explain how honestly his friend had judged her sister. This was a sentiment that no one could share; she realized that only perfect empathy between the two sides could dispel this mysterious burden. She told herself, "And then, if this unlikely situation were to actually occur, I would just have to say that Bingley could have spoken in a gentler manner. I cannot divulge everything until the moment of revelation has lost all significance!”
tr: The storm within Elizabeth calmed with this conversation. She had rid herself of two of the secrets that had burdened her for fifteen days, and she knew that Jane would be a willing listener if she ever wanted to talk about them again. But there was still something lurking in the background, something that common sense did not allow to be explained. She did not dare to tell the other half of Mr. Darcy's letter, to explain to her sister how sincerely her friend was valued by him. This was knowledge that no one could share, and Elizabeth knew that it would not be right to rid herself of this final burden of secrecy without complete mutual understanding between the two parties. "Then," she thought, "if this impossible situation happens, I will tell what Bingley himself could explain much more pleasantly. I cannot have the right to tell it until this information loses all its value."
es: The tumult in Elizabeth's mind was calmed by this conversation. She had unburdened herself of one of the two secrets that had weighed on her soul for fifteen days, and she knew that Jane would always listen willingly whenever she wanted to talk about it. But she still concealed something that prudence prevented her from revealing. She did not dare to disclose to her sister the other half of Darcy's letter, nor to tell her how sincerely she had been loved by his friend. It was a secret of hers that she could share with no one, and she knew that only an agreement between Jane and Bingley would justify her confession. «And even then ––she told herself–– I could only tell her what Bingley himself deemed appropriate to share. I will not have the freedom to reveal this secret until it has lost all its value.»

en: She was now, on being settled at home, at leisure to observe the real state of her sister’s spirits. Jane was not happy. She still cherished a very tender affection for Bingley. Having never even fancied herself in love before, her regard had all the warmth of first attachment, and from her age and disposition, greater steadiness than first attachments often boast; and so fervently did she value his remembrance, and prefer him to every other man, that all her good sense, and all her attention to the feelings of her friends, were requisite to check the indulgence of those regrets which must have been injurious to her own health and their tranquillity.
vi: Now she had time to observe the true state of her sister's spirit. Jane was not happy. Her sister still harbored very tender feelings for Mr. Bingley. Previously, she had never thought that she knew love, but her mind was now filled with the warmth of first love. Due to her age and status, she was calmer than in other first loves. She cherished and respected her memories of him and leaned towards him more than anyone else, to the extent that all her good sense and all her care for the feelings of her loved ones were necessary to prevent her from indulging in regrets that were not beneficial to her health and peace of mind.
tr: Now that she had settled at home, she had time to observe her sister's true state of mind. Jane was not happy. She still harbored a deep affection for Bingley. Since she had never imagined herself in love before, her feelings carried all the warmth of a first attachment, and, due to her age and temperament, with a greater solidity than first attachments usually possess; she valued Bingley's memory so passionately and regarded him as superior to everyone else that, if she did not use all her sensitivity and attention to avoid hurting her friends, it would be easy for her to succumb to these sorrows, compromising her own health and the peace of those around her.
es: Since she was at home all day, she had the opportunity to study her sister's true state of mind. Jane was not happy; she still tenderly loved Bingley. She had never been in love before, and her affection had all the fire of a first love, but her age and character gave it a firmness that first loves usually lack. She could think of nothing but Bingley, and it required all her good sense and attention to her family to moderate those memories that could ruin her health and the tranquility of those around her.

en: “Well, Lizzy,” said Mrs. Bennet, one day, “what is your opinion now of this sad business of Jane’s? For my part, I am determined never to speak of it again to anybody. I told my sister Philips so the other day. But I cannot find out that Jane saw anything of him in London. Well, he is a very undeserving young man—and I do not suppose there is the least chance in the world of her ever getting him now. There is no talk of his coming to Netherfield again in the summer; and I have inquired of everybody, too, who is likely to know.”
vi: One day, Mrs. Bennet asked: - So, Lizzy, what do you now think about Jane's miserable situation? As for me, I have decided never to speak of this matter to anyone again. I told your Aunt Phillips so the other day. But I cannot know if Jane has met him at all in London. He is a young man of no worth at all. And I think there is now no chance for Jane to marry him. No one has mentioned anything about him returning to Netherfield this summer; I have also inquired from everyone who might know about him.
tr: "Well, Lizzy," said Mrs. Bennet one day, "what do you say now about Jane's sad business? As for myself, I am determined never to speak of it to anyone again. I told my sister Philips so the other day. But how is it that Jane never sees him in London, I do not understand. Well, he turned out to be a worthless man – surely now there is no chance of her marrying him. There is no talk of him coming to Netherfield in the summer either; I asked everyone who might know."
es: ––Well, Elizabeth ––said Mrs. Bennet one day––, tell me now what your opinion is on the sad matter of Jane. I am determined not to speak of it again. That's what I told my sister Philips the other day. But I can't believe that Jane hasn't seen Bingley in London. Really, he is heartless and I don't think there's the slightest chance of her succeeding. There's no talk of him returning to Netherfield this summer, and I've asked everyone who might be informed.

en: “I am determined never to speak of it again”
vi: No one has mentioned anything about him returning to Netherfield this summer; I have also inquired from everyone who might know about him.
tr: "I don't think he will live at Netherfield again.""
es: ––I don't think he will return to Netherfield anymore.

en: “I do not believe that he will ever live at Netherfield any more.”
vi: - I don't think he will live at Netherfield anymore.
tr: "I don't think he will live at Netherfield again.""
es: ––I don't think he will return to Netherfield anymore.

en: “Oh, well! it is just as he chooses. Nobody wants him to come; though I shall always say that he used my daughter extremely ill; and, if I was her, I would not have put up with it. Well, my comfort is, I am sure Jane will die of a broken heart, and then he will be sorry for what he has done.”
vi: - Oh, is that so! It's up to him to decide. No one wants him to come back. Although mother always says that he treated her daughter badly, if she were Jane, she wouldn't have to endure it. Mother finds comfort in believing that if Jane were to die of heartbreak, he would regret what he had done.
tr: "It's up to him." "Oh, as if anyone wants him to come." "I always say he treats my daughter badly, but if I were in my daughter's place, I couldn't bear it." "My only consolation is that Jane will die of a broken heart, and then the man will suffer for what he has done.""
es: ––Very well. It's better this way. There's no need. Although I will always say that he has behaved terribly with my daughter, and if I were her, I wouldn't have tolerated it. My only consolation is that Jane will die of a broken heart and then Bingley will regret what he has done.

en: But as Elizabeth could not receive comfort from any such expectation she made no answer.
vi: But since Elizabeth did not feel comforted by such a prospect, she did not reply.
tr: Elizabeth, unable to find solace in such an expectation, did not respond.
es: But Elizabeth, who could not console herself with those hopes, remained silent.

en: “Well, Lizzy,” continued her mother, soon afterwards, “and so the Collinses live very comfortable, do they? Well, well, I only hope it will last. And what sort of table do they keep? Charlotte is an excellent manager, I dare say. If she is half as sharp as her mother, she is saving enough. There is nothing extravagant in their housekeeping, I dare say.”
vi: The mother continued: - Hey, Lizzy, and then the Collins family lives very comfortably, right? Alright, alright, I just hope the couple continues to be like that. And how is their dining table? I'm sure Charlotte is an excellent housekeeper. If she is only half as thrifty as her mother, she could save enough money. I'm sure there is nothing wasteful in the management of their household.
tr: "Well, Lizzy," her mother continued shortly after, "the Collinses live quite comfortably, don't they? Well, I hope they live long. How is their table? Charlotte understands household management well, I think. If she is half as frugal as her mother, she will save quite a bit. I don't think they ever go to excess in their home."
es: ––Tell me ––continued the mother––, the Collins live very well, don't they? Well, well, I hope it lasts a long time for them. And how do they eat? I'm sure Charlotte is an excellent manager. If she is half as sharp as her mother, she will save a lot. I don't think they indulge much.

en: “No, nothing at all.”
vi: - No, no waste at all.
tr: "No, not at all.""
es: ––No, not at all.

en: “A great deal of good management, depend upon it. Yes, yes. They will take care not to outrun their income. They will never be distressed for money. Well, much good may it do them! And so, I suppose, they often talk of having Longbourn when your father is dead. They look upon it quite as their own, I dare say, whenever that happens.”
vi: - Management must be very skillful. Yes, that's right. They will be careful not to spend more than their income. They will never be short of money. Ah, so many good things for them! And so, I guess the two often talk about taking over Longbourn when your father passes away. I'm sure they consider it theirs once that happens.
tr: "He is very frugal, very, trust my word. Truly. They are careful to spend only as much as they earn. That's why they never have money troubles. Well, may God accept it! Then, I think, they often talk about inheriting Longbourn when your father dies. They see this place as their own property, I suppose, eventually."
es: ––Good administration depends on it. Yes, yes; they will be very careful not to squander their salary. They will never have money troubles. Good for them! And I imagine they often talk about acquiring Longbourn when your father dies, and that they already consider it theirs as soon as that happens.

en: “It was a subject which they could not mention before me.”
vi: - They don't talk about this in front of the child.
tr: "This was a topic they couldn't talk about in front of me."
es: ––They never mentioned this topic in front of me.

en: “No; it would have been strange if they had. But I make no doubt they often talk of it between themselves. Well, if they can be easy with an estate that is not lawfully their own, so much the better. I should be ashamed of having one that was only entailed on me.”
vi: - That's right. If they say so, it is indeed strange. But I no longer have any doubts. They often talk about that with each other. Well, if they can feel comfortable with a property that is not legally theirs, then that's fine. I would be ashamed to have a property that I only inherited by order.
tr: "Indeed. It would be strange if they talked. But I have no doubt, they often talk about this among themselves. Well, if they will feel at ease by settling in a house that doesn't legally belong to them, it's their choice. If such an inheritance were to come to me, I would be ashamed to claim it."
es: ––Of course, it wouldn't have been appropriate; but I have no doubt that they talk about it many times among themselves. Well, if they are content with a possession that legally isn't theirs, that's their problem. It would embarrass me.

en: CHAPTER XLI.
vi: Chapter 41
tr: Chapter XVIII
es: CHAPTER XLI

en: THE first week of their return was soon gone. The second began. It was the last of the regiment’s stay in Meryton, and all the young ladies in the neighbourhood were drooping apace. The dejection was almost universal. The elder Miss Bennets alone were still able to eat, drink, and sleep, and pursue the usual course of their employments. Very frequently were they reproached for this insensibility by Kitty and Lydia, whose own misery was extreme, and who could not comprehend such hard-heartedness in any of the family.
vi: They have been back home for two weeks. This is the last week the regiment will stay in Meryton. All the young girls were downcast; all were disheartened. Only the two eldest Bennet daughters could eat, sleep, and continue their daily routines. Very often, Kitty and Lydia reproached them for their indifferent attitude. The two younger girls felt too miserable to understand such stony-heartedness within the family. They often bitterly exclaimed:
tr: The first week of their return passed quickly. The second one began. It was the last week the regiment would spend in Meryton, and all the young ladies in the vicinity were swooning. Sorrow had enveloped almost everyone. Only the elder Miss Bennets were still able to eat, drink, sleep, and continue their daily activities. They were often scolded by Kitty and Lydia for this insensitivity; those two were in deep mourning and could not accept such heartlessness in the family.
es: The first week of the return passed quickly, and they entered the second, which was the last week of the regiment's stay in Meryton. The young women of the locality languished; the sadness was almost general. Only the elder Bennet daughters were capable of eating, drinking, and sleeping as if nothing was happening. Catherine and Lydia often reproached them for their insensitivity. They were very dejected and could not understand such hardness of heart in members of their own family.

en: “Good Heaven! What is to become of us? What are we to do?” would they often exclaim in the bitterness of woe. “How can you be smiling so, Lizzy?”
vi: - Good heavens! What will become of us? What will we do? How can you still smile like that, Lizzy?
tr: "For God's sake! What will happen to us!" "What will we do!" they often lamented in a bitter voice. "How can you smile like that, Lizzy?"
es: ––My God! What is going to become of us? What are we going to do? ––they exclaimed desolately––. How can you smile like that, Elizabeth?

en: Their affectionate mother shared all their grief; she remembered what she had herself endured on a similar occasion five-and-twenty years ago.
vi: The loving mother shared their pain. She remembered that she had gone through a similar situation twenty years ago. She said:
tr: Their loving mothers shared in all their pain; she too remembered facing a similar situation, twenty-five years ago.
es: Her loving mother shared her sorrow and remembered what she herself had suffered on a similar occasion twenty-five years ago.

en: “I am sure,” said she, “I cried for two days together when Colonel Miller’s regiment went away. I thought I should have broke my heart.”
vi: - I'm sure I will cry for two days with you when Colonel Millar's regiment leaves. I think my heart might break. - I am sure my heart will be broken.
tr: "Believe me," she said, "when Colonel Millar's regiment left, I cried for exactly two days. I thought I was done for."
es: ––I remember ––he said–– that I cried for two days straight when Colonel Miller's regiment left, I thought my heart was going to break.

en: “I am sure I shall break mine,” said Lydia.
vi: She remarked:
tr: "But I am really exhausted," said Lydia.
es: ––Mine will also fall to pieces ––said Lydia.

en: “If one could but go to Brighton!” observed Mrs. Bennet.
vi: - I just wish I could go to Brington!
tr: "Oh, if only we could go to Brighton!" said Mrs. Bennet.
es: ––If only we could go to Brighton! ––sighed Mrs. Bennet.

en: “Oh yes!—if one could but go to Brighton! But papa is so disagreeable.”
vi: - Ah, really, I wish I could go to Brington! But papa is too difficult!
tr: "Ah yes! –If only we could go to Brighton! But my father is so stubborn."
es: ––Oh, yes! If only we could go to Brighton! But father is so unaccommodating!

en: “A little sea-bathing would set me up for ever.”
vi: - Swimming in the sea a little is enough for you forever.
tr: "Going to the sea used to make me feel so good."
es: ––A few sea baths would make me feel like new.

en: “And my aunt Philips is sure it would do me a great deal of good,” added Kitty.
vi: Kitty added: - And Aunt Phillips will certainly be able to help you a lot.
tr: "Aunt Philips says it will be especially good for me," added Kitty.
es: ––And Aunt Philips says they would do me a lot of good too ––added Catherine.

en: Such were the kind of lamentations resounding perpetually through Longbourn House. Elizabeth tried to be diverted by them; but all sense of pleasure was lost in shame. She felt anew the justice of Mr. Darcy’s objections; and never had she before been so much disposed to pardon his interference in the views of his friend.
vi: This is the kind of lamentation that always echoes in the Longbourn house. Elizabeth tried to make this a diversion, but all feelings of joy vanished in shame. Once again, she felt that Mr. Darcy's opposition was justified, and never before had she felt such a desire to forgive his interference in his friend's views.
tr: Such pleas echoed incessantly in the Longbourn estate. Elizabeth tried to distract herself with them; but all sense of pleasure vanished in shame. She felt the validity of Mr. Darcy's objections once again; never before had she been so inclined to forgive his interference in his friend's opinions.
es: These lamentations continually echoed in the Longbourn house. Elizabeth tried to keep herself isolated, but she could not avoid the shame. She once again recognized the justice of Darcy's observations, and she had never felt so willing to forgive him for opposing his friend's plans.

en: But the gloom of Lydia’s prospect was shortly cleared away; for she received an invitation from Mrs. Forster, the wife of the colonel of the regiment, to accompany her to Brighton. This invaluable friend was a very young woman, and very lately married. A resemblance in good-humour and good spirits had recommended her and Lydia to each other, and out of their three months’ acquaintance they had been intimate two.
vi: But the gloom in Lydia's prospects was dispelled, for she received an invitation from Mrs. Forster, the wife of the Colonel in the regiment, to accompany her to Brington. This dear friend was a very young woman, and had only recently been married. A similar sense of humor and high spirits had brought the two women together, and in three months of acquaintance, they had become close in two months.
tr: But Lydia's sorrow was soon alleviated; she received an invitation from Mrs. Forster, the wife of the regiment's Colonel, to accompany her to Brighton. This dear friend was a very young woman, newly married. The similarity in their temperaments and their fondness for amusement had drawn her and Lydia close to each other, and during their three months of acquaintance, Lydia had become like a member of the family.
es: But Lydia's melancholy did not take long to dissipate, for she received an invitation from Mrs. Forster, the wife of the regiment's colonel, to accompany her to Brighton. This invaluable friend of Lydia was very young and had recently married. Since both were equally cheerful and lively, they got along perfectly and within three months of meeting, they were already close friends.

en: The rapture of Lydia on this occasion, her adoration of Mrs. Forster, the delight of Mrs. Bennet, and the mortification of Kitty, are scarcely to be described. Wholly inattentive to her sister’s feelings, Lydia flew about the house in restless ecstasy, calling for everyone’s congratulations, and laughing and talking with more violence than ever; whilst the luckless Kitty continued in the parlour repining at her fate in terms as unreasonable as her accent was peevish.
vi: Lydia's delight, her affection for Mrs. Forster, Mrs. Bennet's cheerfulness, and Kitty's humiliation were all difficult to describe. Completely oblivious to her sister's feelings, Lydia wandered around the house in a state of ecstatic restlessness, calling on everyone to congratulate her, chattering away, while the unfortunate Kitty expressed her irritation in nonsensical words. She said to her sisters:
tr: The joy Lydia felt in this situation, the love she felt for Mrs. Forster, Mrs. Bennet's satisfaction, and Kitty's sorrow were indescribable. Lydia, who was completely indifferent to her sister's feelings, ran around the house in a state of ecstasy, wanting everyone to congratulate her, laughed louder than ever, and spoke; meanwhile, the unfortunate Kitty continued to grumble about her fate in the living room with a grumpy voice and equally unreasonable expressions.
es: Lydia's enthusiasm and the adoration she felt for Mrs. Forster, Mrs. Bennet's satisfaction, and Catherine's mortification were almost indescribable. Without the slightest concern for her sister's displeasure, Lydia ran around the house completely ecstatic, asking everyone to congratulate her, laughing and talking more energetically than ever, while poor Catherine remained in the living room lamenting her bad luck in unreasonable terms and in a foul mood.

en: “I cannot see why Mrs. Forster should not ask me as well as Lydia,” said she, “though I am not her particular friend. I have just as much right to be asked as she has, and more too, for I am two years older.”
vi: - I can't understand why Mrs. Forster invited Lydia and not me. Even though I'm not a special friend of hers, I still have the right to be invited just as much as she does. Even more so, because I am two years older than she is.
tr: "I may not be a close friend," she said, "but I don't understand why Mrs. Forster doesn't invite me instead of Lydia. I have as much right to be invited as she does, even more; I am two years older."
es: ––I don't see why Mrs. Forster doesn't invite me as well ––she said––, even though Lydia is her particular friend. I have the same right as she does to be invited, and even more so, because I am older.

en: In vain did Elizabeth attempt to make her reasonable, and Jane to make her resigned. As for Elizabeth herself, this invitation was so far from exciting in her the same feelings as in her mother and Lydia, that she considered it as the death-warrant of all possibility of common sense for the latter; and detestable as such a step must make her, were it known, she could not help secretly advising her father not to let her go. She represented to him all the improprieties of Lydia’s general behaviour, the little advantage she could derive from the friendship of such a woman as Mrs. Forster, and the probability of her being yet more imprudent with such a companion at Brighton, where the temptations must be greater than at home. He heard her attentively, and then said,—
vi: Elizabeth could not make her understand more, and Jane could not make her resign. As for Elizabeth, this invitation did not excite her as much as it did her mother and Lydia, to the extent that she saw it as a death sentence for any possibility of Lydia having a conscience. She made a decision that might be despised if not kept secret; she could not help but advise her father not to let Lydia go. She presented to him all of Lydia's improper behavior, the unbeneficial relationship with Mrs. Forster, the possibility that Lydia would become even more reckless with such a companion at Brington, where the temptations might be stronger than near home. He listened to her attentively, then said:
tr: Elizabeth tried to persuade Jane to be reasonable and give up, but it was in vain. As for Elizabeth herself, this invitation did not evoke the same feelings in her as it did in her mother and Lydia; she saw the invitation as the death knell for any chance of her sister behaving sensibly; knowing that learning of the trip would put her in a difficult position, Elizabeth couldn't help but secretly speak to her father to prevent her from going. She explained to her father all the impropriety of Lydia's general behavior, that a woman like Mrs. Forster would be of no benefit to her, and that in a place full of traps like Brighton, she was likely to get even more out of control with such a friend. After listening to her carefully, her father said,
es: In vain did Elizabeth try to make her see reason, and in vain did Jane try to make her resign herself. The happy invitation awakened in Elizabeth feelings quite different from those of Lydia and her mother; she clearly understood that there was no longer any hope that Mrs. Bennet would show any sign of common sense. She could not help but ask her father not to let Lydia go to Brighton, as such a step could have dire consequences. She pointed out to him Lydia's unsuitability, the few advantages her friendship with Mrs. Forster could bring, and the danger that, with such company, Lydia's imprudence in Brighton, where temptations would be greater, would be redoubled. Mr. Bennet listened attentively to his daughter and said to her:

en: “Lydia will never be easy till she has exposed herself in some public place or other, and we can never expect her to do it with so little expense or inconvenience to her family as under the present circumstances.”
vi: - Lydia will never be at peace until she can socialize in public or somewhere else. And we can never expect her to socialize in such a way with less expense or trouble for the family under the current circumstances.
tr: "Lydia will not be at ease until she has shown herself to the public in one community or another; and we cannot expect her to do this with so little expense or inconvenience to her family.""
es: ––Lydia will not be at ease until she makes a fool of herself in public at one place or another, and we can never expect her to do it with so little expense and sacrifice to her family as on this occasion.

en: “If you were aware,” said Elizabeth, “of the very great disadvantage to us all, which must arise from the public notice of Lydia’s unguarded and imprudent manner, nay, which has already arisen from it, I am sure you would judge differently in the affair.”
vi: Elizabeth said: - If father knew about the severe disadvantages for all of us when people notice Lydia's lack of tact and recklessness, which they already have, I think he would consider the matter differently.
tr: "If you knew the discomfort Lydia's imprudent and careless appearance to the public would cause us all," said Elizabeth, "or even the discomfort it has already caused; I am sure you would then evaluate the matter differently.""
es: ––If you knew ––replied Elizabeth–– the great harm that the indiscreet and improper behavior of Lydia can bring upon all of us, and the harm it has already caused us, I am sure you would think very differently.

en: “Already arisen!” repeated Mr. Bennet. “What! has she frightened away some of your lovers? Poor little Lizzy! But do not be cast down. Such squeamish youths as cannot bear to be connected with a little absurdity are not worth a regret. Come, let me see the list of the pitiful fellows who have been kept aloof by Lydia’s folly.”
vi: - Noticed?! What, has she already driven away a few of your suitors? Poor Lizzy! But don't be discouraged. Any young people who are so restless that they can't bear to engage with a bit of absurdity aren't worth our regret. Come here, let me see the list of those poor boys who have been kept away by that crazy Lydia.
tr: "Already created, ha!" repeated Mr. Bennet. "What, did she scare away her suitors? Poor Lizzy! Don't worry. It's not worth feeling sorry for young men who can't stand being related to a few oddballs. Come on, count the poor souls scared away by Lydia's foolishness."
es: ––"It has already caused us trouble!" ––exclaimed Mr. Bennet––. "Has it scared away any of your suitors? Poor Lizzy!" "But don't be distressed." "Those delicate young men who cannot endure such nonsense are not worth it." "Come, tell me who are the finicky suitors that Lydia's madness has driven away."

en: “Indeed, you are mistaken. I have no such injuries to resent. It is not of peculiar, but of general evils, which I am now complaining. Our importance, our respectability in the world, must be affected by the wild volatility, the assurance and disdain of all restraint which mark Lydia’s character. Excuse me,—for I must speak plainly. If you, my dear father, will not take the trouble of checking her exuberant spirits, and of teaching her that her present pursuits are not to be the business of her life, she will soon be beyond the reach of amendment. Her character will be fixed; and she will, at sixteen, be the most determined flirt that ever made herself and her family ridiculous;—a flirt, too, in the worst and meanest degree of flirtation; without any attraction beyond youth and a tolerable person; and, from the ignorance and emptiness of her mind, wholly unable to ward off any portion of that universal contempt which her rage for admiration will excite. In this danger Kitty is also comprehended. She will follow wherever Lydia leads. Vain, ignorant, idle, and absolutely uncontrolled! Oh, my dear father, can you suppose it possible that they will not be censured and despised wherever they are known, and that their sisters will not be often involved in the disgrace?”
vi: - Actually, father was mistaken. I don't feel hurt or upset. I am complaining about bad habits in general, not any specific bad habit. The status of our family and the respect others have for us will certainly be affected by the impulsiveness, decisiveness, and disregard for all restraint, which are Lydia's characteristics. Sorry, father, for speaking frankly. Dear father, if you do not take the trouble to control her exuberant temperament and if you do not teach her that she should not make her current pursuits of pleasure her daily life's work, she will soon be beyond correction. Her character will become fixed; then at sixteen, she will become so wanton that she herself and the whole family will be a laughingstock. A girl who indulges in the worst and most base kind of wantonness, with nothing to attract people except youth, and a person barely tolerable. With a foolish and empty mind, she cannot withstand contempt while she herself desires to be admired. In this danger, Kitty is also a concern. She will imitate all of Lydia's bad habits. Oh, father, can you think that they will not be criticized and despised everywhere they are known, and that their sisters will not be humiliated by association?
tr: "You are truly mistaken. I don't have those kinds of wounds that you worry about. I'm not afraid of any specific thing, but rather of general dangers. Because of Lydia's character trait of wild variability, her tendency to break all rules and disregard them, our importance and respect in the world will be damaged. Forgive me – because I must speak openly. If you, dear father, do not take the trouble to curb her rebellious spirit and teach her that she cannot spend her life chasing such fantasies, she will soon become uncontrollable. Her character will settle, and at sixteen, she will become a complete disgrace to herself and her family. And a disgrace of the worst, most vulgar kind; someone who has no charm beyond her youth and physique; due to her ignorance and stupidity, while she struggles to be admired, she will not be able to prevent everyone from despising her. This danger applies to Kitty as well. Wherever Lydia goes, she follows. Foolish, ignorant, idle, and completely uncontrolled! Oh! Dear father, don't you see that they will be condemned and scorned wherever they are known, and their sisters will also share in this shame?"
es: ––You don't understand me. I'm not complaining about that. I'm not denouncing specific dangers, but general ones. Our prestige and our respectability in front of people will be harmed by Lydia's extreme frivolity, disdain, and recklessness. Forgive me, but I have to speak to you clearly. If you, dear father, do not take the trouble to curb her euphoria, to teach her that she should not devote her life to her current pastimes, soon it will be too late for her to amend. Her character will be set, and at sixteen she will be an incorrigible flirt who will not only make a fool of herself but also of her entire family; a flirt, moreover, in the worst and most insignificant degree of flirtation, with no more attraction than her youth and her average physical traits; ignorant and empty-headed, incapable of noticing the slightest bit of the general contempt that her desire to be admired will provoke. Catherine is in the same danger, because she will go where Lydia leads her; vain, ignorant, lazy, and absolutely uncontrollable. Father, can you believe that they will not be criticized and despised wherever they go, and that they will not drag the other sisters into their disgrace?

en: Mr. Bennet saw that her whole heart was in the subject; and, affectionately taking her hand, said, in reply,—
vi: Mr. Bennet saw that she was deeply invested in the matter, and affectionately took her hand, he said:
tr: Mr. Bennet understood that Elizabeth was speaking with all her heart; he lovingly took her hand and replied,
es: Mr. Bennet realized that Elizabeth was speaking from the heart. He took her hand affectionately and replied:

en: “Do not make yourself uneasy, my love. Wherever you and Jane are known, you must be respected and valued; and you will not appear to less advantage for having a couple of—or I may say, three—very silly sisters. We shall have no peace at Longbourn if Lydia does not go to Brighton. Let her go, then. Colonel Forster is a sensible man, and will keep her out of any real mischief; and she is luckily too poor to be an object of prey to anybody. At Brighton she will be of less importance even as a common flirt than she has been here. The officers will find women better worth their notice. Let us hope, therefore, that her being there may teach her her own insignificance. At any rate, she cannot grow many degrees worse, without authorizing us to lock her up for the rest of her life.”
vi: - Don't let yourself be anxious, my dear. Everywhere people know you and Jane, you both will be respected and appreciated, and you won't seem disadvantaged if you have two – or three – foolish siblings. We won't be able to have peace at Longbourn if Lydia doesn't go to Brington. Let her go. Colonel Forster is a sensible person and will help her avoid all sorts of trouble, and fortunately, she is too poor to be prey for anyone. In Brington, she will become less playful than she is here. The officers there will find women more worthy of their attention. Therefore, we should believe that the girl will learn a lesson about her own insignificance. Anyway, she can't become any worse, unless she wants me to confine her to the house for the rest of her life.
tr: "Don't be upset, my dear. Wherever you and Jane are known, you will be met with respect and love; having one or two, how should I say, quite foolish sisters does not diminish your worth. If Lydia does not go to Brighton, we will not see peace at Longbourn. Therefore, let her go. Colonel Forster is a reasonable man, he will not allow her to get into serious trouble; fortunately, she is too poor to be preyed upon by anyone. As an ordinary floozy in Brighton, she will be less significant than she is here. The officers will find more useful women. So let us hope that going there teaches her her own insignificance. After all, she cannot go worse than she is now, otherwise it would mean we have to keep her locked up for the rest of her life."
es: ––Don't be troubled, my love. You and Jane will always be respected and loved everywhere, and you won't seem less advantaged for having two or perhaps three very foolish sisters. There will be no peace in Longbourn if Lydia does not go to Brighton. Let her go. Colonel Forster is a sensible man and will watch over her. And she is fortunately too poor to be the target of anyone's predation. Her flirtation will be of less importance in Brighton than here, as the officers will find more attractive women there. So it will serve to make her understand her own insignificance. In any case, she can't get much worse, and if she does, we would then have sufficient reason to lock her up for the rest of her life.

en: With this answer Elizabeth was forced to be content; but her own opinion continued the same, and she left him disappointed and sorry. It was not in her nature, however, to increase her vexations by dwelling on them. She was confident of having performed her duty; and to fret over unavoidable evils, or augment them by anxiety, was no part of her disposition.
vi: With this answer, Elizabeth was forced to be satisfied, but she still held onto her opinion in disappointment and frustration. However, she did not have the temperament to remain upset forever over the matter. She was content that she had fulfilled her duty, and did not have the tendency to stay upset over unpleasant matters, which were inevitable, and thus cause herself more worry.
tr: Elizabeth was forced to find solace in this answer; but her own view remained the same, and she left her father's side feeling disappointed and sad. Nevertheless, she did not have the habit of increasing her troubles by dwelling on them. She was confident that she had done her duty; it was not in her nature to worry about inevitable disasters or to magnify them with anxiety.
es: Elizabeth had to be content with this answer; but her opinion remained the same, and she parted from her father sorrowful and disappointed. But her character prevented her from increasing her troubles by dwelling on them. She believed she had fulfilled her duty and was not willing to consume herself thinking about inevitable evils or to increase them with her anxiety.

en: Had Lydia and her mother known the substance of her conference with her father, their indignation would hardly have found expression in their united volubility. In Lydia’s imagination, a visit to Brighton comprised every possibility of earthly happiness. She saw, with the creative eye of fancy, the streets of that gay bathing-place covered with officers. She saw herself the object of attention to tens and to scores of them at present unknown. She saw all the glories of the camp: its tents stretched forth in beauteous uniformity of lines, crowded with the young and the gay, and dazzling with scarlet; and, to complete the view, she saw herself seated beneath a tent, tenderly flirting with at least six officers at once.
vi: If Lydia and her mother knew about the conversation she had with her father, their outrage would be difficult to put into words given their quick tempers. In Lydia's imagination, a trip to Brington encompassed every possibility of earthly happiness. With a fanciful eye, she envisioned streets crowded with officers, and herself as the object of attention for dozens of strange young men. She saw all the glory of the barracks; the rows of tents neatly lined up, bustling with young and lively men in bright red; and to complete the scene, she even saw herself sitting under a tent, playfully flirting with at least six officers at once.
