tr: If her mother and Lydia knew the subject of the conversation she had with her father, they would join forces and say everything they could out of anger. In Lydia's imagination, the trip to Brighton encompassed every possibility of earthly happiness. She saw the streets of the cheerful seaside resort, filled with officers, through the creative eye of dreams. She saw herself as an object of attention for dozens, even scores, of men she had yet to meet. She envisioned all the splendor of the military camp; rows of tents stretched out beautifully, filled with young and cheerful men in dazzling red; and to complete the scene, she saw herself sitting under a canopy, playfully flirting with at least six officers.
es: If Lydia or her mother had known what Elizabeth had been talking about with her father, their indignation would have known no bounds. A visit to Brighton was for Lydia the epitome of earthly happiness. With her enormous imagination, she saw the streets of that cheerful coastal town teeming with officers; she saw herself attracting the gazes of dozens and dozens of them whom she had yet to meet. She imagined herself in the middle of the camp, with its tents laid out in the beautiful uniformity of their lines, filled with cheerful and dazzling young men in their crimson uniforms; and to complete the picture, she imagined herself sitting next to one of those tents and tenderly flirting with no fewer than six officers at once.

en: “Tenderly flirting”
vi: She saw all the glory of the barracks; the rows of tents neatly lined up, bustling with young and lively men in bright red; and to complete the scene, she even saw herself sitting under a tent, playfully flirting with at least six officers at once.
tr: She envisioned all the splendor of the military camp; rows of tents stretched out beautifully, filled with young and cheerful men in dazzling red; and to complete the scene, she saw herself sitting under a canopy, playfully flirting with at least six officers.
es: She imagined herself in the middle of the camp, with its tents laid out in the beautiful uniformity of their lines, filled with cheerful and dazzling young men in their crimson uniforms; and to complete the picture, she imagined herself sitting next to one of those tents and tenderly flirting with no fewer than six officers at once.

en: Had she known that her sister sought to tear her from such prospects and such realities as these, what would have been her sensations? They could have been understood only by her mother, who might have felt nearly the same. Lydia’s going to Brighton was all that consoled her for the melancholy conviction of her husband’s never intending to go there himself.
vi: If you knew that your sister had tried to pull you out of such visions and realities, what would you think? Only your mother could understand these thoughts, because she had the same feelings. Lydia going to Brington was the only comfort for her melancholy, as her husband never intended to go there.
tr: What would his reaction be if he knew that his sister was trying to separate him from these opportunities and these realities? Only his mother could understand this, because she might have felt more or less the same things. Lydia going to Brighton was her mother's only consolation against the sorrow caused by her husband's reluctance to go.
es: If she had known that her sister intended to take away all those dreams, all those realities, what would have happened? Only her mother would have been able to understand it, as she almost felt the same as her. Lydia's trip to Brighton was the only thing that consoled her from her melancholic conviction that she would never manage to take her husband there.

en: But they were entirely ignorant of what had passed; and their raptures continued, with little intermission, to the very day of Lydia’s leaving home.
vi: But they knew nothing about what had happened, remaining eager until the day of departure.
tr: But they were completely unaware of what had happened; their joy continued uninterrupted until the day Lydia left the house.
es: But neither of them suspected what had happened, and their enthusiasm continued until the very day Lydia left home.

en: Elizabeth was now to see Mr. Wickham for the last time. Having been frequently in company with him since her return, agitation was pretty well over; the agitations of former partiality entirely so. She had even learnt to detect, in the very gentleness which had first delighted her, an affectation and a sameness to disgust and weary. In his present behaviour to herself, moreover, she had a fresh source of displeasure; for the inclination he soon testified of renewing those attentions which had marked the early part of their acquaintance could only serve, after what had since passed, to provoke her. She lost all concern for him in finding herself thus selected as the object of such idle and frivolous gallantry; and while she steadily repressed it, could not but feel the reproof contained in his believing, that however long, and for whatever cause, his attentions had been withdrawn, her vanity would be gratified, and her preference secured, at any time, by their renewal.
vi: Elizabeth is now preparing to meet Mr. Wickham for the last time. Since her return, she had met him frequently, and the agitation in her mind had greatly diminished; the agitation from her initial feelings had completely disappeared. She had realized that, in the same gentle demeanor that had once delighted her, there was now a sense of absurdity and something akin to disgust and weariness. Moreover, in his current manner towards her, she had additional reasons for dissatisfaction because he seemed to want to rekindle their old feelings as if nothing had happened, which only made her more infuriated after all that had transpired. She lost all interest in him when she saw herself being chosen as an object for such pointless and frivolous flirtation. While she rebuffed him, she had the impression that he was still confident that no matter how long he had neglected her and for whatever reason, he could satisfy her vanity and could win her back at any time.
tr: Elizabeth was now going to see Mr. Wickham for the last time. Since she had been in his company frequently since his return, her excitement had considerably diminished; the excitement caused by their former intimacy had entirely vanished. She had even learned to detect a tiresome, wearisome falseness and sameness in the politeness that had once pleased her so much. Moreover, she found a new source of dissatisfaction in Wickham's current behavior towards her because his attempt to restore the intimacy that had characterized the first part of their relationship, after all that had happened in between, only served to irritate Elizabeth. Seeing herself chosen as the object of such idle and spurious flirtation, she had lost all interest in him; while resolutely resisting Wickham's advances, she could not help but feel the condescension underlying his belief that he would flatter her pride and win her heart by rekindling an interest she had long since and for known reasons ceased to have.
es: Elizabeth was now going to see Wickham for the last time. She had often been in his company since she returned from Hunsford, and her agitation had greatly subsided; her former interest in him had completely vanished. She had learned to discern in that kindness which initially attracted her a certain affectation that now repelled her. Moreover, Wickham's attitude towards her had just displeased her, as the young man showed a desire to renew his courtship, and after all that had happened, Elizabeth could not help but feel indignant. She firmly restrained his vain and frivolous attentions, while still feeling the offense implied by Wickham's belief that no matter how long he had neglected her and whatever the cause of his neglect, he would flatter and win her over again just by seeking her out once more.

en: On the very last day of the regiment’s remaining in Meryton, he dined, with others of the officers, at Longbourn; and so little was Elizabeth disposed to part from him in good-humour, that, on his making some inquiry as to the manner in which her time had passed at Hunsford, she mentioned Colonel Fitzwilliam’s and Mr. Darcy’s having both spent three weeks at Rosings, and asked him if he were acquainted with the former.
vi: On the last day of the Meryton regiment, he attended a dinner with other officers at Longbourn. Elizabeth was not at all prepared to bid him farewell cheerfully, so much so that when he asked about her stay in Hentsford, she mentioned that both Colonel Fitzwilliam and Mr. Darcy would be staying at Rosings for three weeks, and asked if he was acquainted with the colonel.
tr: On the last day of the regiment's stay in Meryton, Wickham dined at Longbourn with other officers; Elizabeth was so reluctant to part on bad terms with him that when Wickham asked how she had spent her time in Hunsford, she mentioned that Colonel Fitzwilliam and Mr. Darcy had spent three weeks at Rosings and asked if he had met the former.
es: On the last day of the regiment's stay in Meryton, Wickham dined at Longbourn with other officers. Elizabeth was so unwilling to endure him that when Wickham asked her how she had spent her time in Hunsford, she replied that Colonel Fitzwilliam and Darcy had spent three weeks in Rosings, and she wanted to know if he knew the former.

en: He looked surprised, displeased, alarmed; but, with a moment’s recollection, and a returning smile, replied, that he had formerly seen him often; and, after observing that he was a very gentlemanlike man, asked her how she had liked him. Her answer was warmly in his favour. With an air of indifference, he soon afterwards added, “How long did you say that he was at Rosings?”
vi: He showed a look of surprise, dissatisfaction, and worry, but quickly calmed himself, and with a smile, replied that he often met the Colonel; and after noting that he was a refined person, he asked her what she thought of him. Her answer warmed his heart. With a cold demeanor, he then asked: - How long did she tell him to stay at Rosings?
tr: Wickham appeared surprised, bored, and flustered; but after a moment's thought, his smile returned, and he replied that he had often seen him before; after stating that he was a very gentlemanly man, he asked Elizabeth whether she liked him. Elizabeth's response was very positive. Wickham added shortly after, in an indifferent manner, "How long did you say he stayed at Rosings?"
es: Wickham seemed surprised, upset, and alarmed; but he quickly recovered and with a smile replied that he used to see him often. He said that he was quite a gentleman and asked if she had liked him. Elizabeth responded enthusiastically that she had. But then Wickham added, with an indifferent air: ––How long did you say the colonel was at Rosings?

en: “Nearly three weeks.”
vi: - Nearly three weeks.
tr: "About three weeks."
es: ––About three weeks.

en: “And you saw him frequently?”
vi: - And do you meet him often?
tr: "Did you see him often?"
es: ––And did you see him often?

en: “Yes, almost every day.”
vi: - Yes, almost every day.
tr: "Yes, almost every day.""
es: Almost every day.

en: “His manners are very different from his cousin’s.”
vi: - His character is completely different from his cousin's.
tr: "His/her behavior is different from his/her cousin's."
es: ––He is very different from his cousin.

en: “Yes, very different; but I think Mr. Darcy improves on acquaintance.”
vi: - Yes, very different. But I think Mr. Darcy has learned to communicate better.
tr: "Yes, very much. But I think Mr. Darcy becomes more likable as you get to know him."
es: ––Yes, indeed. But I think Mr. Darcy improves a lot upon acquaintance.

en: “Indeed!” cried Wickham, with a look which did not escape her. “And pray may I ask—” but checking himself, he added, in a gayer tone, “Is it in address that he improves? Has he deigned to add aught of civility to his ordinary style? for I dare not hope,” he continued, in a lower and more serious tone, “that he is improved in essentials.”
vi: Wickham exclaimed with an expression that did not escape her observation: - Really? But he calmed down and added: - May I ask, does he communicate better through spoken words? Or does he just want to add more politeness to his usual manner? He continued in a lower and more solemn tone: - Because I do not dare to hope that he has changed his essential nature.
tr: "What do you say!" cried Wickham, with a look that did not escape Elizabeth's notice. "Well, may I ask?" but collecting himself, he added in a more cheerful voice, "Did you like the way of speaking? Does he condescend to add other things to his usual manner? because," he continued in a lower and more serious voice, "I don't think you would like him at heart."
es: ––Wow! ––exclaimed Wickham with a look that did not go unnoticed by Elizabeth––. In what? ––but, restraining himself, he continued in a more jovial tone––: In manners? Has he deigned to behave more correctly than usual? Because I cannot believe ––he continued in a lower and more serious voice–– that he has improved in the essential.

en: “Oh, no!” said Elizabeth. “In essentials, I believe, he is very much what he ever was.”
vi: Elizabeth said: - Ah, no. I believe that in his essential qualities, he is still much the same as before.
tr: "No, no!" said Elizabeth. "I think he is what he is at his core.""
es: ––Oh, no! In essence, he is still the same as always.

en: While she spoke, Wickham looked as if scarcely knowing whether to rejoice over her words or to distrust their meaning. There was a something in her countenance which made him listen with an apprehensive and anxious attention, while she added,—
vi: While she spoke, Wickham seemed unsure whether to be pleased by her words or to distrust their meaning. There was something in her expression that made him listen with anxious attention as she continued:
tr: While Elizabeth was speaking, Wickham could not decide whether to be pleased by her words or to doubt their meaning. There was something in Elizabeth's face that compelled him to listen with an uneasy and anxious attention as she said the following words,
es: Wickham did not know whether to be pleased with her words or to distrust their meaning. There was something in Elizabeth's demeanor that made him listen with anxious attention and suspicion to what she said next:

en: “When I said that he improved on acquaintance, I did not mean that either his mind or manners were in a state of improvement; but that, from knowing him better, his disposition was better understood.”
vi: - When I said he communicated better, I didn't mean that his speech or gestures had improved. I just meant that, if we knew more about him, we could understand him better.
tr: "When I said 'he becomes more pleasant as you get to know him,' I didn't mean that his thoughts or behaviors undergo a pleasant change, but rather that as you get to know him better, his temperament is better understood."
es: ––By saying that he benefits from the interaction, I do not mean to imply that his character or manners have improved, but rather that by getting to know him better, it is easier to understand his attitude.

en: Wickham’s alarm now appeared in a heightened complexion and agitated look; for a few minutes he was silent; till, shaking off his embarrassment, he turned to her again, and said in the gentlest of accents,—
vi: The worried look on Wickham's face now seemed to have added confusion. For a few minutes, he remained silent until he shook off all confusion, then turned back to her and spoke very gently:
tr: Wickham's agitation now appeared with a tense face and an excited look; he was silent for a few minutes; finally, shaking off his discomfort, he turned to her again and said in a very gentle voice,
es: Wickham's alarm then betrayed itself through his blush and the agitation in his gaze; he remained silent for a few moments until he managed to overcome his embarrassment and, addressing Elizabeth again, said in the kindest tone:

en: “You, who so well know my feelings towards Mr. Darcy, will readily comprehend how sincerely I must rejoice that he is wise enough to assume even the appearance of what is right. His pride, in that direction, may be of service, if not to himself, to many others, for it must deter him from such foul misconduct as I have suffered by. I only fear that the sort of cautiousness to which you, I imagine, have been alluding, is merely adopted on his visits to his aunt, of whose good opinion and judgment he stands much in awe. His fear of her has always operated, I know, when they were together; and a good deal is to be imputed to his wish of forwarding the match with Miss de Bourgh, which I am certain he has very much at heart.”
vi: - Since you have understood very well my feelings about Mr. Darcy, you must understand how sincerely happy I was when he was wise enough to create a proper appearance. In this way, his pride will be beneficial if not to him then to others, as it will prevent him from committing the vile acts that caused me so much misery. I only fear that he adopts a cautious attitude, which I guess you have observed, only when he visits his aunt, whose opinions and judgments he greatly respects. I know he is always afraid of her when they are together, largely because of his intention to marry Miss De Bourgh, whom I am sure he is very fond of.
tr: "You, who know well my feelings towards Mr. Darcy, can imagine how sincerely I am glad that he is wise enough to assume the appearance of truthfulness, even if only in form. His pride can be beneficial in that respect, if not to himself, then to many others; thus preventing the wrongs done to me from being inflicted on others. My only fear is that the prudence you mentioned only manifests during his visits to his aunt; he cares greatly about how she perceives him. I know that he is always afraid of her when they are together; and considerable weight should also be given to his desire to expedite his marriage to Miss de Bourgh, which I am sure is always on his mind."
es: ––You, who know so well my resentment against Mr. Darcy, will understand how sincerely I must rejoice that he is astute enough to at least assume an outward correction. With that system, his pride can be useful, if not to him; to many others, for it will keep him away from the bad behavior of which I was a victim. But I very much fear that the kind of prudence to which you seem to allude is employed only during his visits to his aunt, as it does not suit him to misbehave in her presence. I know very well that he has always cared about appearances in front of her with the desire to bring to fruition his marriage with Miss de Bourgh, in which he puts all his effort.

en: Elizabeth could not repress a smile at this, but she answered only by a slight inclination of the head. She saw that he wanted to engage her on the old subject of his grievances, and she was in no humour to indulge him. The rest of the evening passed with the appearance, on his side, of usual cheerfulness, but with no further attempt to distinguish Elizabeth; and they parted at last with mutual civility, and possibly a mutual desire of never meeting again.
vi: Elizabeth couldn't suppress a smile when she heard this, but she only responded with a slight nod. She sensed that he wanted to bring her back to the old topic of his complaints, but she no longer had the inclination to follow his lead. Throughout the rest of the evening, outwardly he tried to maintain his usual cheerful demeanor, but he no longer wanted to pay attention to her amidst the crowd. Finally, the two politely parted ways, perhaps both wishing never to see each other again.
tr: Elizabeth couldn't help but smile when she heard these words, but she only responded with a slight nod of her head. She realized that Wickham wanted to draw her back to the old topic, to his sufferings, but she was not in a state to comply now. The rest of the evening passed with Wickham's usual appearance of cheerfulness; he made no further attempt towards Elizabeth; eventually, they parted with mutual politeness and possibly a desire never to meet again.
es: Elizabeth couldn't suppress a smile upon hearing this; but she only responded with a slight nod of her head. She noticed that Wickham was about to return to the old topic of his misfortunes, and she was not in the mood to allow it. For the rest of the evening, Wickham pretended his usual cheerfulness, but he no longer attempted to court Elizabeth. In the end, they parted with mutual courtesy and also probably with the mutual desire never to see each other again.

en: When the party broke up, Lydia returned with Mrs. Forster to Meryton, from whence they were to set out early the next morning. The separation between her and her family was rather noisy than pathetic. Kitty was the only one who shed tears; but she did weep from vexation and envy. Mrs. Bennet was diffuse in her good wishes for the felicity of her daughter, and impressive in her injunctions that she would not miss the opportunity of enjoying herself as much as possible,—advice which there was every reason to believe would be attended to; and, in the clamorous happiness of Lydia herself in bidding farewell, the more gentle adieus of her sisters were uttered without being heard.
vi: When everyone had left, Lydia went with Mrs. Forster to Meryton, from where they would set off the next morning. The farewell between her and the family was more noisy than touching. Only Kitty shed tears, but it was out of displeasure and jealousy. Mrs. Bennet was lengthy in her blessings for her fortunate daughter, impressing upon her through her instructions that she should not miss any opportunity to enjoy herself as much as possible. In the noisy delight, Lydia bid farewell, unable to hear the gentle goodbyes of her sisters.
tr: As the meeting dispersed, Lydia went to Meryton with Mrs. Forster; they would set off from there early the next morning. Her farewell with the family was not sorrowful but noisy. Only Kitty shed tears; the reason for her crying was boredom and jealousy. Mrs. Bennet wished her daughter plenty of happiness and sternly advised her not to miss any opportunity to have fun; it was evident that this advice would be followed; amidst Lydia's boisterous happiness while bidding farewell, the more polite farewell words of her sisters went unheard.
es: When the gathering ended, Lydia went to Meryton with Mrs. Forster, from where they were to depart early the next morning. Her farewell to the family was more noisy than pathetic. Catherine was the only one who cried, although out of humiliation and envy. Mrs. Bennet wished her daughter to have as much fun as possible, advice that the girl was willing to follow to the letter. And her clamor upon leaving was so loud that she didn't even hear the gentle goodbyes from her sisters.

en: CHAPTER XLII.
vi: Chapter 42
tr: Chapter XIX
es: CHAPTER XLII

en: HAD Elizabeth’s opinion been all drawn from her own family, she could not have formed a very pleasing picture of conjugal felicity or domestic comfort. Her father, captivated by youth and beauty, and that appearance of good-humour which youth and beauty generally give, had married a woman whose weak understanding and illiberal mind had very early in their marriage put an end to all real affection for her. Respect, esteem, and confidence had vanished for ever; and all his views of domestic happiness were overthrown. But Mr. Bennet was not of a disposition to seek comfort for the disappointment which his own imprudence had brought on in any of those pleasures which too often console the unfortunate for their folly or their vice. He was fond of the country and of books; and from these tastes had arisen his principal enjoyments. To his wife he was very little otherwise indebted than as her ignorance and folly had contributed to his amusement. This is not the sort of happiness which a man would in general wish to owe to his wife; but where other powers of entertainment are wanting, the true philosopher will derive benefit from such as are given.
vi: If Elizabeth's thoughts were all derived from her family, she could not have formed a very favorable impression of married life or a harmonious family. Her father, attracted by youth, beauty, and the outward cheerfulness that youth and beauty bring, had married a woman of weak understanding and narrow mind, and from the very beginning of the marriage, he had lost all real affection for her. Respect, esteem, and confidence had vanished forever; all his views of domestic happiness were overthrown. But Mr. Bennet was not of a disposition to seek comfort for his disappointment in his own imprudence, so he did not resort to those pleasures which might have soothed the unfortunate who had acted foolishly or wickedly. He loved the countryside and books, and found enjoyment in them. As for his wife, he owed her little gratitude except for the amusement her folly and nonsense provided him. This was not the sort of happiness that makes a man grateful to his wife, but when he had no ability to indulge in other diversions, the true philosopher must derive benefit from whatever is available.
tr: If Elizabeth's views had come from her family, she might not have been able to paint a very pleasant picture of a happy marriage or a comfortable home life. Her father, captivated by youth and beauty, and the cheerful appearance that youth and beauty generally bring, had married a woman who was lacking in both sense and manners, and had lost all real affection for her soon after their marriage began. Respect, reverence, and trust had vanished forever; all hopes for family happiness were shattered. But Mr. Bennet was not the kind of man to seek solace in the pleasures that other unfortunate people, who had acted foolishly or wickedly, might resort to in their disappointment caused by their own imprudence. He was fond of the countryside and books; his main enjoyment came from these pleasures. He owed very little to his wife, except for the amusement her ignorance and foolishness provided him. This is not usually the kind of happiness a man wishes to owe to his wife; but when there are no other means of distraction, a true philosopher makes do with what he has.
es: If Elizabeth's opinion were derived from what she saw in her own family, she could not have formed a very pleasant idea of marital happiness and domestic well-being. Her father, captivated by youth and beauty, and the apparent illusion and joy that both entail, had married a woman whose weak understanding and petty spirit had put an end to all affection at the very beginning of their marriage. Respect, esteem, and trust had vanished forever; and all of Mr. Bennet's prospects of happiness within the home had collapsed. But he was not one of those men who seek comfort for the effects of their own imprudence in the pleasures that often console those who have become unhappy through their follies and vices. He loved the countryside and books, and they constituted the source of his main joys. From his wife, he owed nothing more than the laughter that her ignorance and folly provided him from time to time. That is not the kind of happiness a man would wish to owe to his wife; but in the absence of... The good philosopher only takes benefit from where it exists.

en: Elizabeth, however, had never been blind to the impropriety of her father’s behaviour as a husband. She had always seen it with pain; but respecting his abilities, and grateful for his affectionate treatment of herself, she endeavoured to forget what she could not overlook, and to banish from her thoughts that continual breach of conjugal obligation and decorum which, in exposing his wife to the contempt of her own children, was so highly reprehensible. But she had never felt so strongly as now the disadvantages which must attend the children of so unsuitable a marriage, nor ever been so fully aware of the evils arising from so ill-judged a direction of talents—talents which, rightly used, might at least have preserved the respectability of his daughters, even if incapable of enlarging the mind of his wife.
vi: However, Elizabeth had never ignored his improper behaviors as a husband. She was always distressed to see him like that, but out of respect for his abilities and happiness at being cherished by him, she tried to forget what she could not overlook and pushed out of her mind the sad actions when he showed irresponsibility or lacked the spirit of marital decorum by exposing his wife to the contempt of their children. But she had never deeply felt the disadvantages for the daughters in such a discordant marriage, nor had she ever recognized the harms of misusing talents – talents that, if properly harnessed, could at least earn the daughters respect from others, if not broaden the mind of their mother.
tr: However, Elizabeth had never been blind to her father's inappropriate behavior as a husband. She had always watched these with pain; but because she respected her father's abilities and was grateful for the love he showed her, she tried not to think about the extremely unpleasant act of constantly violating the duties and decorum of marriage, such as belittling his wife at every opportunity in front of their children. But never had she felt so strongly the troubles that children of such an incompatible marriage had to endure; never had she understood so well the harm caused by talents directed at the wrong targets – talents that, if used correctly, could at least have preserved her daughters' dignity, even if they failed to improve her wife's mind.
es: Elizabeth, nevertheless, had never ceased to recognize the impropriety of her father's conduct as a husband. She had always observed it with sorrow, but she respected his talent and was grateful for his affection, so she tried to forget what she could not ignore and to put out of her mind his continuous breach of marital duties and the decorum that, by exposing his wife to the contempt of her own daughters, was so exceedingly reprehensible. But she had never felt as she did then the harm that a discordant marriage can cause to the children, nor had she ever so clearly realized the dangers inherent in the misdirection of talent, talent that, if well employed, although it might not have been enough to enhance his wife's intelligence, could at least have preserved the respectability of the daughters.

en: When Elizabeth had rejoiced over Wickham’s departure, she found little other cause for satisfaction in the loss of the regiment. Their parties abroad were less varied than before; and at home she had a mother and sister, whose constant repinings at the dulness of everything around them threw a real gloom over their domestic circle; and, though Kitty might in time regain her natural degree of sense, since the disturbers of her brain were removed, her other sister, from whose disposition greater evil might be apprehended, was likely to be hardened in all her folly and assurance, by a situation of such double danger as a watering-place and a camp. Upon the whole, therefore, she found, what has been sometimes found before, that an event to which she had looked forward with impatient desire, did not, in taking place, bring all the satisfaction she had promised herself. It was consequently necessary to name some other period for the commencement of actual felicity; to have some other point on which her wishes and hopes might be fixed, and by again enjoying the pleasure of anticipation, console herself for the present, and prepare for another disappointment. Her tour to the Lakes was now the object of her happiest thoughts: it was her best consolation for all the uncomfortable hours which the discontentedness of her mother and Kitty made inevitable; and could she have included Jane in the scheme, every part of it would have been perfect.
vi: While Elizabeth was glad that Wickham would be leaving, she saw no other reason to be satisfied with the loss of the militia regiment. Social gatherings at other people's houses became more monotonous than before; and at home, she had a mother and a sister who were always irritable because everything around them had become boring, creating a gloomy atmosphere in the family. Although Kitty gradually regained her natural sense because those who disturbed her mind were absent, the other sister, whom everyone feared would encounter worse, might plunge deeper into her foolish self-confidence. Thus, as before, she thought that an event she eagerly awaited, when it happened, did not satisfy her as she had hoped. As a result, it was necessary to identify another time period to truly begin to be happy. There needed to be a milestone to which all wishes and hopes could be connected. Through this, feeling pleasure in anticipation, comforting her for the present, and preparing for another disappointment. Her trip to the Lake District had now become a happy thought. This was the best consolation for the frustrating moments caused by her mother and Kitty. If Jane could join in this plan, everything would become wonderful.
tr: While Elizabeth Wickham was happy to be gone, she couldn't find any other consoling aspect in losing the regiment. The parties outside were duller than before; at home, her mother and sister, who constantly complained about the monotony of everything around them, cast a gloom over their family life; with the things that troubled her mind now distant, Kitty might eventually regain her former common sense, but her other sister, from whom greater mischief could be expected, seemed likely to harden all her foolishness and stubbornness in a situation that involved the double danger of the seaside and the military camp. In the end, as she had seen a few times before, she realized that an event she had been waiting for with impatient anticipation did not bring the joy Elizabeth had promised her when it finally happened. Another date would have to be set for true happiness to begin, another turning point where her wishes and hopes could be realized; and once again, she would console herself for the time being with the pleasure of anticipation, and prepare for another disappointment. The trip to the Lake District now formed her happiest thoughts; it was her strongest consolation against all those distressing hours made inevitable by her mother and Kitty; if she could include Jane in the plan, everything would be perfect.
es: While it is true that Elizabeth was glad of Wickham's absence, it cannot be said that she rejoiced at the regiment's departure. Her outings were less frequent than before, and the constant complaints of her mother and sister about the boredom they had fallen into saddened the house. And although Catherine might have regained the common sense lost with the departure of those who caused her disturbance, her other sister, from whose behavior all calamities could be expected, was in danger of affirming her madness and brazenness, for being near a beach and a camp, her situation was doubly threatening. In short, she now saw what she had already realized at other times, that an eagerly awaited event could not, upon happening, bring her all the satisfaction that was to be expected. It was necessary, therefore, to open another period for the beginning of her happiness, to set another goal for the achievement of her desires and hopes, which by cheering her with another anticipated pleasure, would console her for the present and prepare her for another disappointment. Her trip to the Lakes became the object of her happiest thoughts and constituted her best refuge in the unpleasant hours that her mother's and Catherine's discontent made inevitable. And if she could have included Jane in the plan, everything would have been perfect.

en: “But it is fortunate,” thought she, “that I have something to wish for. Were the whole arrangement complete, my disappointment would be certain. But here, by carrying with me one ceaseless source of regret in my sister’s absence, I may reasonably hope to have all my expectations of pleasure realized. A scheme of which every part promises delight can never be successful; and general disappointment is only warded off by the defence of some little peculiar vexation.”
vi: She thought: "It's fortunate that I still have something to wish for. If everything had been arranged perfectly, I would surely be disappointed. But here, by harboring an endless source of regret while my sister is absent, I can hope that all my wishes will come true. A plan in which everything promises to bring joy never succeeds; one can only avoid disappointment by making excuses for a few peculiar inconveniences."
tr: "But luckily," she thought, "I have something to wish for. If all the arrangements had been made, I would certainly be disappointed. But here, while my sister is not around, I can carry a continuous source of sorrow with me and hope for all my joy expectations to come true. A plan that promises pleasure in every part can never succeed; the only way to prevent a great disappointment is to defend a small inconvenience."
es: ––"It's a stroke of luck," he thought, "to have something to desire. If everything were complete, there would undoubtedly be something that would disappoint me. But now, carrying with me that source of longing which will be Jane's absence, I can reasonably think that all my expectations of pleasure will be fulfilled. A plan that in all its parts promises happiness never turns out well; and you can't avoid some mishap if you don't have a small setback."

en: When Lydia went away she promised to write very often and very minutely to her mother and Kitty; but her letters were always long expected, and always very short. Those to her mother contained little else than that they were just returned from the library, where such and such officers had attended them, and where she had seen such beautiful ornaments as made her quite wild; that she had a new gown, or a new parasol, which she would have described more fully, but was obliged to leave off in a violent hurry, as Mrs. Forster called her, and they were going to the camp; and from her correspondence with her sister there was still less to be learnt, for her letters to Kitty, though rather longer, were much too full of lines under the words to be made public.
vi: When Lydia left, she promised to write letters regularly and in great detail to her mother and Kitty; but her letters were always delayed and always very short. The letters to her mother said little more than that they had just returned from the library with some officers who were doting on them, about the shops where they saw jewelry that captivated them; that she had just bought a new maxi dress, or a new umbrella that she should have described in detail, but had to hastily end because Mrs. Forster was calling, and they were preparing to go to the barracks. Communication with her sister provided even less news, the letters to Kitty, though longer, contained too many things that could not be shared with others.
tr: Lydia had promised her mother and Kitty that she would write to them often and at length; but her letters always arrived very late and were always very short. The letters she wrote to her mother contained little more than the fact that they had just returned from the bookstore, that such and such officers had accompanied them there, that she had seen some trinkets that had taken her breath away, or that she had bought a new dress or a new umbrella that she would describe in detail but couldn't because Mrs. Forster had called and they were about to go to the camp; –even less could be learned from the letters she wrote to her sister –because although the letters to Kitty were somewhat longer, they were filled with underlined sentences not to be told to anyone else.
es: Lydia, upon leaving, promised to write very often and in great detail to her mother and Catherine, but her letters were always long overdue and all were brief. The ones addressed to her mother said little more than that they had just returned from the reading room where they had been greeted by such and such officers, that the decoration of the room was so beautiful that it had taken her breath away, that she had a new dress or a new parasol that she would describe more extensively, but that she couldn't because Mrs. Forster was waiting for her to go to the camp together... From the correspondence addressed to her sister, even less could be known, for her letters to Catherine, although long, had many underlined lines that could not be made public.

en: After the first fortnight or three weeks of her absence, health, good-humour, and cheerfulness began to reappear at Longbourn. Everything wore a happier aspect. The families who had been in town for the winter came back again, and summer finery and summer engagements arose. Mrs. Bennet was restored to her usual querulous serenity; and by the middle of June Kitty was so much recovered as to be able to enter Meryton without tears,—an event of such happy promise as to make Elizabeth hope, that by the following Christmas she might be so tolerably reasonable as not to mention an officer above once a day, unless, by some cruel and malicious arrangement at the War Office, another regiment should be quartered in Meryton.
vi: After Lydia had been gone for two or three weeks, a cheerful atmosphere returned to Longbourn. Everything brought a more uplifting spirit. Families who had gone to the city during the winter returned, and springtime interactions began again. Mrs. Bennet reverted to her usual quiet grumbling. By mid-June, Kitty had calmed down enough to go to Meryton without shedding tears; an event promising much good, leading Elizabeth to hope that by the next Christmas season, her younger sister might become sensible enough not to mention an officer more than once a day, unless, through the malicious arrangements of the defense department, another regiment was stationed in Meryton.
tr: After the first two or three weeks of his absence, health, cheerfulness, and liveliness returned to Longbourn. Everything took on a happier appearance. Families who had gone to the city for the winter returned, and summer clothes and summer invitations emerged. Mrs. Bennet resumed her usual fretful solemnity; by mid-June, Kitty had recovered enough to go to Meryton without shedding tears – which was such a happy event in Elizabeth's eyes that she hoped Kitty might normalize to the point of not mentioning an officer's name more than once a day until the next Christmas, provided, of course, that the war office did not cruelly and ominously decide to station a new regiment in Meryton.
es: After the two or three weeks of Lydia's absence, health and good humor began to reign in Longbourn. Everything looked better. Families who had spent the winter in the capital were returning, and the summer festivities and invitations were reemerging. Mrs. Bennet recovered from her complaining state, and by mid-June, Catherine was already consoled enough to enter Meryton without tears. This fact was so promising that Elizabeth believed that by the next Christmas, Catherine would be so reasonable that she wouldn't mention an officer even once a day, unless by some cruel and malicious order of the War Office, a new regiment was quartered in Meryton.

en: The time fixed for the beginning of their northern tour was now fast approaching; and a fortnight only was wanting of it, when a letter arrived from Mrs. Gardiner, which at once delayed its commencement and curtailed its extent. Mr. Gardiner would be prevented by business from setting out till a fortnight later in July, and must be in London again within a month; and as that left too short a period for them to go so far, and see so much as they had proposed, or at least to see it with the leisure and comfort they had built on, they were obliged to give up the Lakes, and substitute a more contracted tour; and, according to the present plan, were to go no farther northward than Derbyshire. In that county there was enough to be seen to occupy the chief of their three weeks; and to Mrs. Gardiner it had a peculiarly strong attraction. The town where she had formerly passed some years of her life, and where they were now to spend a few days, was probably as great an object of her curiosity as all the celebrated beauties of Matlock, Chatsworth, Dovedale, or the Peak.
vi: The time to start the Northern excursion is approaching quickly. With only two weeks left, a letter from Mrs. Gardiner arrives, causing the trip to be postponed and the journey to be shortened. Mrs. Gardiner is busy with work until July and has to go to London for a month. The time is not sufficient for them to travel far to see much, or at least to see leisurely and comfortably as planned. They are forced to cancel the trip to the Lake District, replacing it with a closer itinerary. According to the new plan, they will only go as far as Derbyshire. This region has enough variety for them to explore over three weeks and is particularly appealing to Mrs. Gardiner. The town where she lived for a few years before, and where they plan to stay for a few days, is of special interest to her.
tr: The start date of the northern travels was rapidly approaching; only fifteen days were left when a letter from Mrs. Gardiner both postponed the start date of the trip and narrowed its scope. Mr. Gardiner's work would not allow him to leave until mid-July, and he had to be back in London within a month; this left them so little time that they would not be able to go as far as they wanted or visit every place they wished, or at least not comfortably; therefore, they had to give up the Lake District and settle for a more limited tour; according to the current plan, they would not go further north than Derbyshire. There were enough places to visit and see in that county to keep them occupied for three weeks; it was particularly appealing to Mrs. Gardiner. The city where she had spent a few years of her life in the past and where she would now stay for a few days was probably as much of a curiosity for her as famous places like Matlock, Chatsworth, Dovedale, or the Peak.
es: The appointed time for the excursion to the North was already approaching; only two weeks were left, when a letter was received from Mrs. Gardiner postponing the date of the trip and, at the same time, shortening its duration. Mr. Gardiner's business prevented him from leaving until two weeks after the beginning of July, and he had to be back in London within a month; and since this reduced the time too much to go so far and see all the things they had planned, or to see them with enough rest and comfort, there was no choice but to give up the Lakes and think of a more limited excursion, in view of which they would not go beyond Derbyshire. In that region, there were enough things worth seeing to fill most of the time they had available, and, moreover, Mrs. Gardiner felt a very special attraction for Derbyshire. The town where she had spent several years of her life might be as interesting to her as all the famous beauties of Matlock, Chatsworth, Dovedale, or the Peak.

en: Elizabeth was excessively disappointed: she had set her heart on seeing the Lakes; and still thought there might have been time enough. But it was her business to be satisfied—and certainly her temper to be happy; and all was soon right again.
vi: Elizabeth was very disappointed; she had hoped to visit the Lake District and thought there might still be enough time. But her nature was easily contented with what she had, so she was willing to accept the new circumstances.
tr: Elizabeth was greatly disappointed; she had very much wanted to see the Lake District; yet she thought there might still be time. But her task was to be content – of course, her inclination was also to be happy; soon everything was fine.
es: Elizabeth felt very disappointed; she was very excited about going to the Lakes, and she believed there would have been plenty of time for it. But, in any case, she should be satisfied, they would surely have a good time, and it didn't take long for her to come to terms with it.

en: With the mention of Derbyshire, there were many ideas connected. It was impossible for her to see the word without thinking of Pemberley and its owner. “But surely,” said she, “I may enter his county with impunity, and rob it of a few petrified spars, without his perceiving me.”
vi: Many thoughts are evoked by the name Derbyshire. She could not visit the area without thinking of Pemberley estate and its owner. She told herself, "But surely I can enter the region where he resides with a peaceful mind and bring back some mineral crystals without his knowledge."
tr: The mention of Derbyshire brought many ideas to mind. It was impossible to see that word without thinking of Pemberley and its owner. "What if," she said, "I secretly enter his homeland and steal a few florid stones without being seen by him."
es: For Elizabeth, the name of Derbyshire was connected to many other things. It made her think of Pemberley and its owner. "But," she said to herself, "I can enter his county with impunity and steal a few stones without him noticing."

en: The period of expectation was now doubled. Four weeks were to pass away before her uncle and aunt’s arrival. But they did pass away, and Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner, with their four children, did at length appear at Longbourn. The children, two girls of six and eight years old, and two younger boys, were to be left under the particular care of their cousin Jane, who was the general favourite, and whose steady sense and sweetness of temper exactly adapted her for attending to them in every way—teaching them, playing with them, and loving them.
vi: The waiting time has now doubled, four weeks before the uncle and aunt arrive. The children, including two girls aged six and eight and two younger boys, were entrusted to Jane's care. The children adored Jane, and with her calm and sweet nature, she proved to be suitable for taking care of them, teaching them, playing with them, and loving them.
tr: The waiting period had now doubled. Four more weeks would pass before her uncle and aunt arrived. But it passed; finally, Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner appeared at Longbourn with their four children. The children, two girls aged six and eight and two younger boys, were to be entrusted specifically to their cousin Jane; Jane was their favorite cousin, and with her calm speech and affectionate behavior, she was able to look after them in every way – educating them, entertaining them, and loving them.
es: The wait then felt doubly long to her. There were four weeks left until her uncles arrived. But, finally, the time passed and Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner arrived in Longbourn with their four children. The children ––two little girls aged six and eight respectively, and two younger boys–– were to be under the special care of their cousin Jane, the favorite of all, whose sweet and calm temperament was ideal for teaching them, playing with them, and loving them.

en: The Gardiners stayed only one night at Longbourn, and set off the next morning with Elizabeth in pursuit of novelty and amusement. One enjoyment was certain—that of suitableness as companions; a suitableness which comprehended health and temper to bear inconveniences—cheerfulness to enhance every pleasure—and affection and intelligence, which might supply it among themselves if there were disappointments abroad.
vi: Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner stayed at Longbourn for only one night, then set off the next day with Elizabeth to seek new and delightful experiences. Surely the three of them would find much enjoyment, as they had suitable companions; the harmony in both body and mind to endure any inconveniences, the optimism to fully appreciate every pleasure, along with the love and intelligence to cope with any disappointments when away from home.
tr: The Gardiners stayed at Longbourn for only one night and set out the next morning with Elizabeth in search of novelty and amusement. There was a certain pleasure – they were well-suited as travel companions; both mentally and physically capable of enduring hardships – they had a cheerfulness that would enhance every happiness, and a love and intelligence that would compensate for any possible disappointments in their journey.
es: The Gardiners slept at Longbourn that night and the next morning they set off with Elizabeth in search of news and amusement. They had assured pleasure: the three of them were excellent travel companions, which meant they had the health and character to endure inconveniences, the cheerfulness to enhance all kinds of happiness, and the affection and intelligence to overcome any setbacks.

en: It is not the object of this work to give a description of Derbyshire, nor of any of the remarkable places through which their route thither lay—Oxford, Blenheim, Warwick, Kenilworth, Birmingham, etc., are sufficiently known. A small part of Derbyshire is all the present concern. To the little town of Lambton, the scene of Mrs. Gardiner’s former residence, and where she had lately learned that some acquaintance still remained, they bent their steps, after having seen all the principal wonders of the country; and within five miles of Lambton, Elizabeth found, from her aunt, that Pemberley was situated. It was not in their direct road; nor more than a mile or two out of it. In talking over their route the evening before, Mrs. Gardiner expressed an inclination to see the place again. Mr. Gardiner declared his willingness, and Elizabeth was applied to for her approbation.
vi: No need to describe Derbyshire or the famous places along the way in detail, just focus on a small region of Derbyshire. When they arrived at the small town of Lambton, where Mrs. Gardiner used to reside and where she recently learned that some acquaintances still remained, they turned onto another road, and after traveling five miles, Mrs. Gardiner informed Elizabeth that they had reached Pemberley. It was not directly on their route, but no more than one or two miles off the road. On the previous evening, while discussing the next day's journey, Mrs. Gardiner had expressed a desire to visit this place again. Mr. Gardiner agreed, and Elizabeth was consulted. Mrs. Gardiner said:
tr: Describing Derbyshire or the notable places along the way is not the purpose of this book; Oxford, Blenheim, Warwick, Kenilworth, and Birmingham are well known enough. Now, we are only concerned with a small part of Derbyshire. After seeing the main wonders of the countryside, they turned their steps towards the small town of Lambton, where Mrs. Gardiner used to live and recently learned that a few of her acquaintances still resided; Elizabeth learned from her aunt that Pemberley was located about five miles from Lambton. It was not directly on their way, but it was not more than a mile or two off the road either. While discussing their route the previous evening, Mrs. Gardiner mentioned that she wanted to see the place again. Mr. Gardiner also expressed his desire, so they turned to Elizabeth for approval.
es: We are not going to describe Derbyshire here, nor any of the notable places they passed through: Oxford, Blenheim, Warwick, Kenilworth, Birmingham, and all the others, are well known. We will only refer to a small part of Derbyshire. Towards the small town of Lambton, the scene of Mrs. Gardiner's youth, where she had recently learned that some acquaintances still resided, the travelers directed their steps after having seen the main wonders of the region. Elizabeth learned from her aunt that Pemberley was about five miles from Lambton. It was not on their way, but they only had to deviate one or two miles to visit it. While discussing their route the previous evening, Mrs. Gardiner expressed a desire to see Pemberley again. Mr. Gardiner did not object and sought Elizabeth's approval.

en: “My love, should not you like to see a place of which you have heard so much?” said her aunt. “A place, too, with which so many of your acquaintance are connected. Wickham passed all his youth there, you know.”
vi: - Child, do you want to go see the place you've heard so much about? The place where a few people you know are. Wickham lived here when he was a child, you know.
tr: "Sweetie, wouldn't you like to see a place you've heard so much about?" said her aunt. "A place with connections to many of your friends, moreover. Wickham spent all his youth there."
es: ––Dear ––her aunt said to her––, wouldn’t you like to see a place you’ve heard so much about and that is connected with so many of your acquaintances? You know that Wickham spent all his youth there.

en: Elizabeth was distressed. She felt that she had no business at Pemberley, and was obliged to assume a disinclination for seeing it. She must own that she was tired of great houses: after going over so many, she really had no pleasure in fine carpets or satin curtains.
vi: Elizabeth felt sorrowful. She thought she had nothing to do with Pemberley, wanting to appear uninterested in going there. She stated that she was too tired of looking at large houses; after having seen so many of them, she no longer found any pleasure in seeing beautiful carpets or satin curtains.
tr: Elizabeth was bored. She felt that she had no business at Pemberley; she was inwardly inclined to object to seeing the place. She had to admit that she was tired of large houses; she had seen so many that she no longer truly enjoyed silk carpets or satin curtains.
es: Elizabeth was distressed. She felt that she had nothing to do at Pemberley and was forced to say that she was not interested. She had to confess that she was tired of large houses, after having seen so many; and that she found no pleasure in seeing exquisite carpets and satin curtains.

en: Mrs. Gardiner abused her stupidity. “If it were merely a fine house richly furnished,” said she, “I should not care about it myself; but the grounds are delightful. They have some of the finest woods in the country.”
vi: Mrs. Gardiner criticized her ignorance: - If there were only elaborately decorated houses, I wouldn't bother going there; but this land is truly wonderful. It has the most beautiful forests in the country.
tr: Mrs. Gardiner was annoyed by the indifference. "If it were just a beautifully furnished house," she said, "I wouldn't care; but the land is magnificent. Some of the finest woods in the area are there."
es: Mrs. Gardiner censured her foolishness. ––If it were just a richly furnished house ––he said–– I wouldn't be interested either; but the estate is a marvel. It contains one of the most beautiful forests in the country.

en: Elizabeth said no more; but her mind could not acquiesce. The possibility of meeting Mr. Darcy, while viewing the place, instantly occurred. It would be dreadful! She blushed at the very idea; and thought it would be better to speak openly to her aunt, than to run such a risk. But against this there were objections; and she finally resolved that it could be the last resource, if her private inquiries as to the absence of the family were unfavourably answered.
vi: Elizabeth said nothing more, but inwardly she did not agree. The possibility of meeting Mr. Darcy again upon going there immediately came to her mind. How dreadful! She blushed at the thought, considering that she should speak frankly to her aunt rather than take the risk. But her aunt objected. In the end, she would decide after discreetly inquiring about the family's absence.
tr: Elizabeth did not object any further – but it wasn't coming from her heart. As she was walking around, the possibility of encountering Mr. Darcy suddenly crossed her mind. It would be dreadful! The mere thought of it was enough to make her blush; she thought it would be better to speak openly with her aunt rather than face such a danger. But there were obstacles to this as well; finally, she decided that this would be the last resort, in case a secret investigation about whether the family was there or not yielded an unpleasant result.
es: Elizabeth did not speak any more, but she no longer had any peace of mind. The possibility of encountering Darcy while visiting Pemberley instantly crossed her mind. It would be horrible! Just thinking about it made her blush, and she thought it would be better to speak clearly to her aunt than to expose herself to such a risk. But this decision had its drawbacks, and she resolved that she would only adopt it if her inquiries about the absence of the property owner's family were negative.

en: Accordingly, when she retired at night, she asked the chambermaid whether Pemberley were not a very fine place, what was the name of its proprietor, and, with no little alarm, whether the family were down for the summer? A most welcome negative followed the last question; and her alarms being now removed, she was at leisure to feel a great deal of curiosity to see the house herself; and when the subject was revived the next morning, and she was again applied to, could readily answer, and with a proper air of indifference, that she had not really any dislike to the scheme.
vi: In that manner, in the evening, she asked the chambermaid whether the Pemberley estate was worth visiting, who the owner was, and she calmly inquired whether the owner had arrived to enjoy the summer yet. The chambermaid replied that he had not. Now with nothing to worry about, she was curious to see the house. When asked for her opinion again the next morning, she calmly replied that she actually had no objections to the couple's plan.
tr: Accordingly, when she retired to her room at night, she asked the servant whether Pemberley was a beautiful place, who its owner was, and, quite anxiously, whether the family was at the summer house. The answer to the last question was a very reassuring no – with her anxiety thus relieved, she had the opportunity to feel a great curiosity to see the house; when the subject was brought up again the next morning and she was asked, her answer was ready; she said, with a very indifferent air, that she had no objection to the plan.
es: Consequently, upon retiring that night, she asked the maid if Pemberley was a very beautiful place, what the name of its owner was, and finally, with no small amount of concern, if the family was spending the summer there. The negative response to this last question was the most welcome in the world. With her anxiety now gone, she felt great curiosity even about the house itself, and when the plan was proposed again the next morning and she was consulted, she instantly replied, with an evident air of indifference, that she did not dislike the idea.

en: To Pemberley, therefore, they were to go.
vi: Therefore, the three people set off for Pemberley.
tr: So, they were going to Pemberley. Third Book
es: Therefore, they set out for Pemberley.

en: CHAPTER XLIII.
vi: End of episode 2 Chapter 43
tr: Chapter I
es: CHAPTER XLIII

en: ELIZABETH, as they drove along, watched for the first appearance of Pemberley Woods with some perturbation; and when at length they turned in at the lodge, her spirits were in a high flutter.
vi: On the way, Elizabeth anxiously watched the Pemberley garden come into view, but as they entered the estate, her spirits lifted again.
tr: Elizabeth watched the first glimpses of Pemberley Woods from the carriage with some unease; by the time they entered through the lodge, she was quite discomposed.
es: Elizabeth glimpsed the woods of Pemberley with some unease, and when they finally arrived at the gate, her heart was beating strongly.

en: The park was very large, and contained great variety of ground. They entered it in one of its lowest points, and drove for some time through a beautiful wood stretching over a wide extent.
vi: The garden was really spacious and varied. They entered through one of the low areas, then drove a long way along a lush forest.
tr: The grove was very large; the terrain was filled with various elevations. They entered the grove from one of its lowest points and proceeded for a while through a beautiful forest that stretched far to both sides.
es: The estate was enormous and comprised a great variety of lands. They entered through one of the lowest points and strolled for a long time through a beautiful forest that extended over its wide surface.

en: Elizabeth’s mind was too full for conversation, but she saw and admired every remarkable spot and point of view. They gradually ascended for half a mile, and then found themselves at the top of a considerable eminence, where the wood ceased, and the eye was instantly caught by Pemberley House, situated on the opposite side of the valley, into which the road with some abruptness wound. It was a large, handsome stone building, standing well on rising ground, and backed by a ridge of high woody hills; and in front a stream of some natural importance was swelled into greater, but without any artificial appearance. Its banks were neither formal nor falsely adorned. Elizabeth was delighted. She had never seen a place for which nature had done more, or where natural beauty had been so little counteracted by an awkward taste. They were all of them warm in their admiration; and at that moment she felt that to be mistress of Pemberley might be something!
vi: Elizabeth's mind was too busy for conversation, but she observed every scene and angle. They walked half a mile up a gentle slope, then reached a high ground where the woodland ended, and they immediately saw Pemberley House, situated on the opposite side of the valley, with the road suddenly turning into it. It was a large, grand building, built of stone, standing prominently on high ground, backed by a range of hills covered with woods. In front was a stream that widened out but did not appear artificial; the banks were not in straight lines but did not seem overly embellished. Elizabeth enjoyed the view. She had never seen a place so favored by nature, or one where natural beauty was so little marred by coarse taste. All three felt a warmth in their hearts as they admired it, and at that moment she thought that being the mistress of this estate must be something indeed!
tr: Elizabeth's mind was too full to speak, but she saw and admired every remarkable detail and view. They climbed about half a mile up the slope, then found themselves on a rather high hill; the forest had ended, and in an instant, her eyes were caught by Pemberley Manor; the Manor rose on the opposite side of a valley into which the road suddenly wound down. It was a large, beautiful stone building; set on the slope, backed by the ridges of high wooded hills; –in front, a river of natural significance swelled, but without creating an artificial appearance, it joined a larger river. The banks of the river were neither formal nor artificially adorned. Elizabeth was delighted. She had never seen a place where nature had been more generous or where natural beauty had been less marred by tastelessness in her life. They all stood in awe; and at that moment, Elizabeth felt that being the mistress of Pemberley might mean something!
es: Elizabeth's mind was too busy to converse; but she observed and admired all the notable spots and all the views. For half a mile, they climbed a slope that led them to a considerable hill where the forest broke off and from where they immediately saw Pemberley House, situated on the other side of the valley through which a somewhat steep path wound. It was a stone building, spacious and beautiful, well situated on a knoll that stood out in front of a chain of high, forest-covered hills, and it had in front a rather copious stream that ran increasingly powerful, completely natural and wild. Its banks were neither regular nor falsely adorned with gardening works. Elizabeth was amazed. She had never seen a place more favored by nature or where natural beauty was less marred by poor taste. Everyone was full of admiration, and Elizabeth then understood what it might mean to be the mistress of Pemberley.

en: They descended the hill, crossed the bridge, and drove to the door; and, while examining the nearer aspect of the house, all her apprehension of meeting its owner returned. She dreaded lest the chambermaid had been mistaken. On applying to see the place, they were admitted into the hall; and Elizabeth, as they waited for the housekeeper, had leisure to wonder at her being where she was.
vi: They went down the hillside, crossed a bridge, and drove the carriage through the gate. While observing the mansion up close, all her worries about meeting the owner returned to her mind. She feared that the butler might be mistaken. They asked for permission and were invited into the hall. While waiting for the steward, Elizabeth idly thought about her presence there.
tr: They went down the slope, crossed the bridge, and arrived at the door; while Elizabeth was examining the house more closely, the possibility of encountering its owner again crossed her mind. She was seized by the fear that the servant might have been mistaken. When they knocked on the door to see the house, they were taken into the hall; while waiting for the steward to come, Elizabeth was surprised to find herself there.
es: They went down the hill, crossed a bridge, and continued to the door. While they examined the appearance of the house up close, Elizabeth again feared encountering the owner. What if the maid had been mistaken? After asking for permission to see the mansion, they were led into the vestibule. While they waited for the housekeeper, Elizabeth had time to marvel at finding herself in such a place.

en: The housekeeper came; a respectable looking elderly woman, much less fine, and more civil, than she had any notion of finding her. They followed her into the dining-parlour. It was a large, well-proportioned room, handsomely fitted up. Elizabeth, after slightly surveying it, went to a window to enjoy its prospect. The hill, crowned with wood, from which they had descended, receiving increased abruptness from the distance, was a beautiful object. Every disposition of the ground was good; and she looked on the whole scene, the river, the trees scattered on its banks, and the winding of the valley, as far as she could trace it, with delight. As they passed into other rooms, these objects were taking different positions; but from every window there were beauties to be seen. The rooms were lofty and handsome, and their furniture suitable to the fortune of their proprietor; but Elizabeth saw, with admiration of his taste, that it was neither gaudy nor uselessly fine,—with less of splendour, and more real elegance, than the furniture of Rosings.
vi: The housekeeper came, a respectable-looking, elderly woman, somewhat coarse but more polite than she had thought. They followed her into the dining room. It was a spacious, well-proportioned room, decorated with elegance. After a brief glance around, Elizabeth walked to a window to admire the view outside. The hill covered by the canopy of trees where they had descended was suddenly interrupted by a steep slope, creating a magnificent landscape. Everything on the ground was harmoniously arranged; and she delighted in the panoramic view, the river, the scattered trees along its banks, and the winding valley stretching as far as the eye could see. As they passed through other rooms, these scenes shifted position, but each window revealed its own unique beauty. The rooms were all high and spacious, with elegant furnishings befitting the wealth of the owner; but Elizabeth admired his taste, as there was nothing gaudy or excessively meticulous; less opulent yet more refined than the furnishings in the Rosings estate.
tr: The housekeeper arrived; she was an elderly woman with a dignified appearance, less ornate but more elegant than Elizabeth had imagined. Following her, they entered the dining room. It was a large, well-proportioned, beautifully furnished room. After briefly examining the room, Elizabeth went to the window to see the view. The hill they had descended was crowned with forest, appearing even more steep and magnificent from a distance. The garden was well-kept; Elizabeth looked with pleasure at the entire view, the river, the scattered trees along its banks, and the valley rising in winding curves. As they moved to the other rooms, these views took on different perspectives; but there was beauty to be seen from every window. The rooms were grand and beautiful; the furniture was fitting for the owner's wealth; but Elizabeth, admiring the owner's taste, saw that they were neither gaudy nor unnecessarily simple; they had a more genuine elegance than the furniture at Rosings.
es: The housekeeper was an elderly woman, of respectable appearance, much less stiff and much more courteous than Elizabeth had imagined. She led them to the dining room. It was a well-proportioned and elegantly furnished room. Elizabeth glanced at it briefly and went to one of the windows to take in the view. The hill crowned with forest they had descended, from a distance, appeared more abrupt and more beautiful. The entire layout of the land was good; she looked at the landscape with delight: the stream, the trees along the banks, and the curve of the valley as far as the eye could see. As they moved to other rooms, the landscape appeared from different angles, but magnificent views could be seen from all the windows. The rooms were tall and beautiful, and their furnishings were in harmony with the fortune of their owner. Elizabeth noted, admiring his taste, that there was nothing flashy or tacky and that there was less pomp but more elegance than at Rosings.

en: “And of this place,” thought she, “I might have been mistress! With these rooms I might have now been familiarly acquainted! Instead of viewing them as a stranger, I might have rejoiced in them as my own, and welcomed to them as visitors my uncle and aunt. But, no,” recollecting herself, “that could never be; my uncle and aunt would have been lost to me; I should not have been allowed to invite them.”
vi: She thought: "I could be the mistress of this place! Now I can start getting familiar with these rooms. Instead of looking at everything like a stranger, I can delight in seeing it as mine, and I can welcome my uncle and aunt as if they were two close relatives visiting." She calmed herself: "But no, it can never be like that; my uncle and aunt will never know what happened to me; I shouldn't invite them."
tr: "And I," she thought, "could have been the mistress of this place! I could have known these rooms very well by now! Instead of looking at them as a stranger, I could have enjoyed them as mine and could have invited my uncle and aunt as guests. –But no," –she pulled herself together, – "it wouldn't be like that: I would have lost my uncle and aunt: I wouldn't have been allowed to invite them."
es: "And to think," she said to herself, "that I could have been the mistress of all this! These rooms could now be mine! Instead of visiting them as a stranger, I could enjoy them and receive my uncles here! But no," she replied, recovering herself, "it would not have been possible, I would have had to give up my uncles; I would not have been allowed to invite them."

en: This was a lucky recollection—it saved her from something like regret.
vi: This is a fortunate calmness – it helps her escape from something almost like regret.
tr: This was a fortunate recollection – it prevented him from feeling something like regret.
es: This revived her and saved her from something akin to regret.

en: She longed to inquire of the housekeeper whether her master were really absent, but had not courage for it. At length, however, the question was asked by her uncle; and she turned away with alarm, while Mrs. Reynolds replied, that he was; adding, “But we expect him to-morrow, with a large party of friends.” How rejoiced was Elizabeth that their own journey had not by any circumstance been delayed a day!
vi: She very much wanted to ask the housekeeper whether the master was truly absent or not, but she did not have the courage. However, eventually her uncle asked, and she turned away in panic, while Mrs. Reynolds replied that he was away, and added: "But we are preparing to welcome him back tomorrow, with a large group of his friends." Elizabeth was delighted to feel that their trip had not been delayed by a day!
tr: The butler wanted to ask if the landlord was really traveling, but he didn't dare. Still, in the end, his uncle asked the question; while Elizabeth turned away in fear, Mrs. Reynolds said he was traveling and added, "but we expect him to come tomorrow, many of his friends will also come." How glad Elizabeth was that their own travels were not delayed by a day for any reason!
es: He wanted to find out from the housekeeper if his master was truly absent, but he lacked the courage. Finally, it was his uncle who asked the question, and Elizabeth turned frightened when Mrs. Reynolds said yes, adding: ––But we expect him tomorrow. He is going to come with many friends. Elizabeth was glad that her trip had not been postponed by a day for any reason.

en: Her aunt now called her to look at a picture. She approached, and saw the likeness of Mr. Wickham, suspended, amongst several other miniatures, over the mantel-piece. Her aunt asked her, smilingly, how she liked it. The housekeeper came forward, and told them it was the picture of a young gentleman, the son of her late master’s steward, who had been brought up by him at his own expense. “He is now gone into the army,” she added; “but I am afraid he has turned out very wild.”
vi: Aunt now called her to see a painting. She approached and saw Wickham's portrait hanging above the fireplace, among other miniatures. Aunt smiled and asked her what she thought. The housekeeper stepped forward and informed them that it was a picture of the old gentleman's adopted son, who had been supported by him, and added: "He has joined the army, but I fear he has become too wayward."
tr: Her aunt called her to look at a picture at that moment. When Elizabeth approached, she saw Mr. Wickham's likeness among several miniatures above the fireplace. Her aunt asked with a smile how she found it. The housekeeper approached and said that the picture belonged to the son of her late master's steward, and that the young man had been raised by her master. –"He is in the army now," she added, "but I'm afraid he has become quite a rascal."
es: Her aunt called her to see a painting. Elizabeth approached and saw a portrait of Wickham above the mantelpiece among other miniatures. Her aunt asked her with a smile what she thought of it. The housekeeper came to tell them that he was a young son of the last steward of her lord, educated by him at his own expense. ––Now he has joined the army ––––he added–– and I think he is a lost cause.

en: Mrs. Gardiner looked at her niece with a smile, but Elizabeth could not return it.
vi: Mrs. Gardiner looked at her and smiled, but she could not respond.
tr: Mrs. Gardiner smiled at her niece, but Elizabeth could not respond.
es: Mrs. Gardiner looked at her niece with a smile, but Elizabeth remained very serious.

en: “And that,” said Mrs. Reynolds, pointing to another of the miniatures, “is my master—and very like him. It was drawn at the same time as the other—about eight years ago.”
