es: ––Of course, he is not as handsome as Wickham ––replied the aunt––; or rather, he is not as well-built, but his features are perfect. How could you tell us he was so unpleasant, Lizzy?

en: Elizabeth excused herself as well as she could: said that she had liked him better when they met in Kent than before, and that she had never seen him so pleasant as this morning.
vi: Elizabeth tried to justify herself; she said that she liked him more when they met in Kent than before; and that she had never found him as pleasant as this morning.
tr: Elizabeth tried her best to excuse herself; she said that she liked him more than before when they met in Kent, and that he had never seemed as charming as he did that morning.
es: Elizabeth apologized as best she could; she said that upon seeing him in Kent, she had liked him more than before and had never found him as agreeable as that morning.

en: “But perhaps he may be a little whimsical in his civilities,” replied her uncle. “Your great men often are; and therefore I shall not take him at his word about fishing, as he might change his mind another day, and warn me off his grounds.”
vi: Uncle answered: - But perhaps he has a somewhat erratic nature when it comes to politeness. All of your friends are like that, so you wouldn't truly believe his invitation to go fishing, because one day he might change his mind and forbid you from coming near.
tr: "But maybe his politeness is a bit of a coincidence," his uncle replied. "Great men are like that; so I won't take his words about fishing seriously, because he might forget what he said and fire me the day after tomorrow."
es: ––He might be a bit whimsical in his courtesy ––replied the uncle––; those very haughty gentlemen tend to be like that. That's why I won't take his word regarding the fishing, in case he changes his mind another day and throws me off the estate.

en: Elizabeth felt that they had entirely mistaken his character, but said nothing.
vi: Elizabeth thought the couple were completely mistaken about his character, but she remained silent.
tr: She felt that they were completely wrong about Elizabeth's character, but she said nothing.
es: Elizabeth realized that they were completely wrong about her character, but she said nothing.

en: “From what we have seen of him,” continued Mrs. Gardiner, “I really should not have thought that he could have behaved in so cruel a way by anybody as he has done by poor Wickham. He has not an ill-natured look. On the contrary, there is something pleasing about his mouth when he speaks. And there is something of dignity in his countenance, that would not give one an unfavourable idea of his heart. But, to be sure, the good lady who showed us the house did give him a most flaming character! I could hardly help laughing aloud sometimes. But he is a liberal master, I suppose, and that, in the eye of a servant, comprehends every virtue.”
vi: Mrs. Gardiner continued: - From what we see, honestly, you shouldn't have thought he could behave cruelly towards anyone, as Wickham said. He doesn't look like a bad person. On the contrary, there is something pleasant in his words. And there is a certain dignity in his face that does not indicate he has a bad heart. But surely the lady who took us to see the house spoke very highly of him! At times, you almost couldn't help but laugh. But I think he is a generous master, and this, in the eyes of a servant, is enough to encompass all virtues.
tr: "As far as we can see," continued Mrs. Gardiner, "I can't imagine anyone treating poor Wickham as cruelly as he did. He doesn't have the appearance of a bad-hearted person. On the contrary, when he speaks, a pleasant air emanates from his words. There is such nobility in his face that one cannot think there could be evil in his heart. But of course, the lovely woman showing us the house exaggerated him a lot! At one point, I held myself back from laughing. But he must be a generous master for his servant to think he possesses every virtue."
es: ––After having seen him now, I would never have believed that he could behave as badly as he did with Wickham ––continued Mrs. Gardiner––, he doesn't seem heartless. On the contrary, he has a very pleasant expression when he speaks. And there is also a dignity in his face that would make no one think he doesn't have a good heart. But, to tell the truth, the good woman who showed us the house exaggerated his character a bit. There were times when I almost burst out laughing. The thing is, he must be a very generous master and that, in the eyes of a servant, equals all virtues.

en: Elizabeth here felt herself called on to say something in vindication of his behaviour to Wickham; and, therefore, gave them to understand, in as guarded a manner as she could, that by what she had heard from his relations in Kent, his actions were capable of a very different construction; and that his character was by no means so faulty, nor Wickham’s so amiable, as they had been considered in Hertfordshire. In confirmation of this, she related the particulars of all the pecuniary transactions in which they had been connected, without actually naming her authority, but stating it to be such as might be relied on.
vi: Elizabeth felt the need to say something to vindicate his attitude towards Wickham. In the most cautious words possible, she explained to them that from what she had heard from his relatives in Kent, his actions could be explained differently, that his character was not as flawed as they thought, and that Wickham was not as amiable as the people in Hertfordshire believed. To confirm this, she recounted all the details of the strange relations between the two young men without specifying who said what, only indicating that these events could be trusted.
tr: Elizabeth felt the need to say something corrective about her behavior towards Wickham and, as limited as possible, told them that, according to what she had heard from relatives in Kent, his actions were open to a very different interpretation, his character was not at all flawed, and on the other hand, Wickham was not as good as they thought in Hertfordshire. To confirm this, without specifying the source but stating that it was reliable, she explained all the details of the financial transactions that concerned them all.
es: Upon hearing this, Elizabeth believed she should say something in defense of Darcy's conduct with Wickham. With all the care she could muster, she tried to hint that, based on what she had heard from her relatives in Kent, his actions could be interpreted very differently, and that neither his character was as bad nor Wickham's as good as had been believed in Hertfordshire. To confirm what she had said, she recounted the details of all the financial transactions that had taken place between them, without mentioning how she had come to know them, but asserting that it was strictly true.

en: Mrs. Gardiner was surprised and concerned: but as they were now approaching the scene of her former pleasures, every idea gave way to the charm of recollection; and she was too much engaged in pointing out to her husband all the interesting spots in its environs, to think of anything else. Fatigued as she had been by the morning’s walk, they had no sooner dined than she set off again in quest of her former acquaintance, and the evening was spent in the satisfactions of an intercourse renewed after many years’ discontinuance.
vi: Mrs. Gardiner felt surprised and concerned, but when she arrived at the scene she had enjoyed in the past, all thoughts gave way to enchanting memories, and she was too busy pointing out interesting spots in the area to her husband to think of anything else. Although tired from the morning walk, after dinner she visited old acquaintances, and she was pleased with the relationships rekindled after many years of interruption.
tr: Mrs. Gardiner was surprised and worried; but as they approached the places of her old happy days, these thoughts gave way to the charm of memories; she became so engrossed in pointing out the interesting places in the vicinity to her husband that she couldn't think of anything else. Although she was tired from the morning walk, she immediately set out to search for old acquaintances as soon as the meal was over; the evening passed in the pleasure of a relationship renewed after a long separation.
es: Mrs. Gardiner was surprised and curious about the topic, but as they were approaching the scene of her former pleasures, she yielded to the charm of her memories and only pointed out to her husband all the interesting places and their surroundings. Despite being tired from the morning walk, as soon as they had dinner, they went out in search of old acquaintances, and the evening passed with the satisfaction of relationships renewed after many years of interruption.

en: The occurrences of the day were too full of interest to leave Elizabeth much attention for any of these new friends; and she could do nothing but think, and think with wonder, of Mr. Darcy’s civility, and, above all, of his wishing her to be acquainted with his sister.
vi: The events of the day occupied Elizabeth's mind entirely, so she could do nothing but think, and think with amazement, about Mr. Darcy's courteous behavior, especially about his desire for her to become acquainted with his sister.
tr: The events of that day were so intriguing to Elizabeth that she could not focus on these new friends; she could not stop thinking about Mr. Darcy's politeness and, most of all, his desire to introduce her to his sister, and she was astonished by it.
es: The events of that day had been too overwhelming for Elizabeth to pay much attention to any of those new friends, and she could only think with admiration of Darcy's kindnesses, and especially of his desire for her to meet his sister.

en: CHAPTER XLIV.
vi: Chapter 44
tr: Chapter II
es: CHAPTER XLIV

en: ELIZABETH had settled it that Mr. Darcy would bring his sister to visit her the very day after her reaching Pemberley; and was, consequently, resolved not to be out of sight of the inn the whole of that morning. But her conclusion was false; for on the very morning after their own arrival at Lambton these visitors came. They had been walking about the place with some of their new friends, and were just returned to the inn to dress themselves for dining with the same family, when the sound of a carriage drew them to a window, and they saw a gentleman and lady in a curricle driving up the street. Elizabeth, immediately recognizing the livery, guessed what it meant, and imparted no small degree of surprise to her relations, by acquainting them with the honour which she expected. Her uncle and aunt were all amazement; and the embarrassment of her manner as she spoke, joined to the circumstance itself, and many of the circumstances of the preceding day, opened to them a new idea on the business. Nothing had ever suggested it before, but they now felt that there was no other way of accounting for such attentions from such a quarter than by supposing a partiality for their niece. While these newly-born notions were passing in their heads, the perturbation of Elizabeth’s feelings was every moment increasing. She was quite amazed at her own discomposure; but, amongst other causes of disquiet, she dreaded lest the partiality of the brother should have said too much in her favour; and, more than commonly anxious to please, she naturally suspected that every power of pleasing would fail her.
vi: Elizabeth guessed that Mr. Darcy would bring his sister to visit her on the very day she arrived at Pemberley, so she planned not to stray far from the inn that entire morning. But she was mistaken, for the very morning after they arrived in Lambton, their two guests came. The three had strolled around the area with a few new friends; just as they returned to the inn to change clothes for a meal with these friends' family, they heard the sound of a carriage, and through the window, they saw a man and a woman driving a two-wheeled carriage along the road. Immediately, Elizabeth recognized the noble attire, expressing her surprise to her uncle and aunt about the honor their guests were bestowing upon her. The uncle and aunt were equally astonished. The awkwardness when she spoke to them, combined with the current situation and many past situations, led them to a new thought. Nothing had been said about this before, but now they thought there was no other way to explain such attentions from the upper class, except for the affection they had for their niece. While these ideas passed through their minds, Elizabeth's state of anxiety grew higher and higher. She found it strange that she was losing her composure, but among the reasons for her agitation, she feared that his feelings for her might have spoken too highly of her to his sister. More than the anxiety of wanting to please, she feared that she no longer had the ability to please anyone at all.
tr: Elizabeth had arranged for Mr. Darcy to bring his sister to visit the day after they arrived at Pemberley; therefore, she decided not to leave the inn's vicinity throughout the morning. But her assumption was wrong; because these visitors came the morning after they themselves arrived in Lambton. They were touring the surroundings with some of their new friends; they had returned to the inn to change their clothes to go dine with the same family when they heard the sound of a carriage and went to the window; they saw a gentleman and a lady coming up the street in an open carriage. Elizabeth immediately recognized the coachman's uniform, guessed its meaning, and surprised her relatives just as much by announcing the expected visit. Her uncle and aunt were astonished; their discomfort in their movements while speaking, combined with the situation itself and the events of the previous day, sparked a new idea about the matter in their minds. Nothing had suggested this possibility before, but now they felt that the only explanation for such attention from such a place could be an interest in their niece. As these new thoughts passed through their minds, the confusion of Elizabeth's feelings increased every moment. She was surprised at her own agitation; but among other reasons for discomfort, she most feared that the brother had praised her too much; she wanted to appear pleasing, but she was afraid that nothing she did would be enough to achieve that.
es: Elizabeth had calculated that Darcy would bring his sister to visit her the day after their arrival at Pemberley, and consequently, she resolved not to lose sight of the inn all that morning. But she was mistaken, for she received the visit the very day they arrived. The Gardiners and Elizabeth had been walking around the town with some of their new friends, and were returning at that moment to the inn to dress and go to lunch with them, when the noise of a carriage made them look out the window and they saw a gentleman and a young lady in a cabriolet coming up the street. Elizabeth instantly recognized the livery of the footmen, guessed what it meant, and left her uncles astonished by informing them of the honor that awaited them. They were frightened; that visit, Elizabeth's bewilderment, and the circumstances of the previous day made them form a new idea of the matter. There had been nothing to suggest it before, but now they realized that there was no other way to explain Darcy's attentions than by supposing him interested in their niece. While they were thinking about all this, Elizabeth's agitation increased by the moment. She was alarmed by her own bewilderment, and among the other causes of her unease was the idea that Darcy, in his enthusiasm, might have spoken of her to his sister with too much praise. She wanted to please more than ever, but suspected that she would not be able to achieve it.

en: She retreated from the window, fearful of being seen; and as she walked up and down the room, endeavouring to compose herself, saw such looks of inquiring surprise in her uncle and aunt as made everything worse.
vi: She stepped away from the window, afraid of being seen; and as she paced back and forth in the room trying to stay calm, she saw the surprised looks of her uncle and aunt, which made her even more agitated.
tr: He pulled back from the window, afraid of being seen; while trying to compose himself, he saw the bewildered looks filled with questions from his uncle and aunt, and his task became even more difficult.
es: She withdrew from the window for fear of being seen, and, while pacing back and forth in the room, the questioning looks from her uncles made her even more nervous.

en: Miss Darcy and her brother appeared, and this formidable introduction took place. With astonishment did Elizabeth see that her new acquaintance was at least as much embarrassed as herself. Since her being at Lambton, she had heard that Miss Darcy was exceedingly proud; but the observation of a very few minutes convinced her that she was only exceedingly shy. She found it difficult to obtain even a word from her beyond a monosyllable.
vi: Miss Darcy and her brother appeared, and the introduction – the dreadful introduction in her mind – took place. Elizabeth was surprised to notice that the younger sister was just as flustered as she was. Since arriving in Lambton, she had heard that Miss Darcy was extremely proud, but after only a few minutes of observation, Elizabeth was convinced that she was merely excessively shy. The younger sister could hardly complete a sentence, only uttering a few short words.
tr: Miss Darcy and her brother arrived, and the intimidating introduction took place. Elizabeth was surprised to see that her new acquaintance was at least as uncomfortable as she was. Since coming to Lambton, she had heard that Miss Darcy was extremely proud; but a few minutes of observation convinced her that she was extremely shy. It was difficult to get a single word out of her, except for monosyllables.
es: Finally, Miss Darcy and her brother appeared, and the grand introduction took place. Elizabeth noticed with astonishment that her new acquaintance was at least as disturbed as she was. Since arriving in Lambton, she had heard that Miss Darcy was extremely proud, but after observing her for a few minutes, she was convinced that she was only extremely shy. She could hardly get a word out of her, except for a few monosyllables.

en: Miss Darcy was tall, and on a larger scale than Elizabeth; and, though little more than sixteen, her figure was formed, and her appearance womanly and graceful. She was less handsome than her brother, but there was sense and good-humour in her face, and her manners were perfectly unassuming and gentle. Elizabeth, who had expected to find in her as acute and unembarrassed an observer as ever Mr. Darcy had been, was much relieved by discerning such different feelings.
vi: Miss Darcy is tall and somewhat larger than Elizabeth. Although she is just over sixteen, she already has the figure of a graceful and mature woman. She is not as handsome as her brother, but her face shows a sense of propriety and cheerfulness, and her demeanor is entirely gentle and unpretentious. Previously, Elizabeth had thought she might be someone with keen and sharp observational skills, but now she felt relieved to realize the opposite.
tr: Miss Darcy was tall, larger than Elizabeth; although she was only sixteen, she had matured well; her appearance was feminine and graceful. She was not as beautiful as her brother, but there was sensitivity and kindness in her face; her manners were modest and polite. Elizabeth, who expected to find in her as sharp and bold an observer as Mr. Darcy, was quite relieved to distinguish such different feelings.
es: Miss Darcy was taller than Elizabeth and, although she was only sixteen years old, her body was already developed and her appearance was very feminine and graceful. She was not as beautiful as her brother, but her face revealed intelligence and good character, and her manners were very simple and gentle. Elizabeth, who had feared that she might be as sharp and outgoing an observer as Darcy, felt great relief to see how different she was.

en: They had not been long together before Darcy told her that Bingley was also coming to wait on her; and she had barely time to express her satisfaction, and prepare for such a visitor, when Bingley’s quick step was heard on the stairs, and in a moment he entered the room. All Elizabeth’s anger against him had been long done away; but had she still felt any, it could hardly have stood its ground against the unaffected cordiality with which he expressed himself on seeing her again. He inquired in a friendly, though general, way, after her family, and looked and spoke with the same good-humoured ease that he had ever done.
vi: They only managed to exchange a few words when Darcy informed her that Bingley was also coming to visit her. Before she had time to express her joy and prepare for the new guest, she heard footsteps coming up the stairs, and then he entered. All of Elizabeth's anger towards him had long since dissipated, but now, even if any remnants remained, they completely vanished due to his friendly and unpretentious demeanor when he met her again. He inquired warmly, though generally, about her family's health, looking and speaking with the same natural and cheerful manner as before.
tr: It hadn't been long since they had come together when Darcy told her that Bingley would also be visiting her; and before Elizabeth could express her pleasure and prepare herself for such a visitor, Bingley's quick steps were heard on the stairs, and in a moment he entered the room. Elizabeth's anger towards him had long passed; but if any remained, it vanished in the face of Bingley's humble closeness as he expressed how delighted he was to see her again. In a friendly but impartial manner, he inquired about her family's health and moved and spoke with his usual cheerful ease.
es: They had been conversing for only a short while when Darcy told Elizabeth that Bingley would also be coming to visit her, and she had barely had time to express her satisfaction and prepare to receive him when they heard Bingley's hurried steps on the stairs, and he immediately entered the room. All of Elizabeth's indignation against him had long since disappeared, but if any resentment had remained, she could not have resisted the frank cordiality that Bingley showed her upon seeing her again. He inquired about her family in a caring, albeit general, manner, and behaved and spoke with his usual good humor.

en: To Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner he was scarcely a less interesting personage than to herself. They had long wished to see him. The whole party before them, indeed, excited a lively attention. The suspicions which had just arisen of Mr. Darcy and their niece, directed their observation towards each with an earnest, though guarded, inquiry; and they soon drew from those inquiries the full conviction that one of them at least knew what it was to love. Of the lady’s sensations they remained a little in doubt; but that the gentleman was overflowing with admiration was evident enough.
vi: For Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner, Mr. Bingley was a character worth paying attention to just as much as their niece. They had long wanted to meet him. In fact, the entire group of guests before them had sparked lively attention. Their suspicions about Mr. Darcy and their niece directed their attention to each guest with eager yet cautious inquiries, and soon from these inquiries, they were convinced that at least one of the two knew what love was. They had doubts about their niece's feelings, but it was clear to them that the other was overflowing with affection.
tr: He was just as interesting to Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner. They had wanted to see him for some time. The entire group in front of them was exciting. The doubts they had just heard about Mr. Darcy and his nieces directed their attention to the two with curious but covert scrutiny; soon they concluded from their observation that at least one of them knew what love was. They had little doubt about the girl's feelings; but the boy was evidently burning with admiration.
es: The Gardiners welcomed Bingley with the same interest as Elizabeth. They had long wanted to meet him. In truth, all those present inspired the liveliest curiosity in them. The suspicions they had just conceived about Darcy and his niece led them to focus their attention on them, examining them closely, though discreetly, and very soon they realized that at least one of them was very much in love. Elizabeth's feelings were somewhat doubtful, but it was evident that Darcy was overflowing with admiration in every way.

en: Elizabeth, on her side, had much to do. She wanted to ascertain the feelings of each of her visitors, she wanted to compose her own, and to make herself agreeable to all; and in the latter object, where she feared most to fail, she was most sure of success, for those to whom she endeavoured to give pleasure were pre-possessed in her favour. Bingley was ready, Georgiana was eager, and Darcy determined, to be pleased.
vi: As for Elizabeth, she had many things to do. She wanted to understand the thoughts of each guest, she wanted to remain calm, and she wanted to appear pleasant to everyone. Regarding the last task, which she feared failing the most, she was confident she would succeed, because everyone she wanted to please had a favorable opinion of her. Bingley was willing, Georgiana was eager, and Darcy was intentionally pleased.
tr: Elizabeth had a lot to do on her own behalf. She wanted to be sure of the feelings of each of her guests, to calm her own mood, and to make herself appear charming to everyone; the chance of success for her second goal, which she feared she would fail at most, was certain because the people she was trying to please were already on her side. Bingley was ready, Georgiana was willing, and Darcy was determined to be pleased.
es: Elizabeth, for her part, had a lot to do. She had to guess the feelings of each of her visitors and at the same time had to contain her own and make herself pleasant to everyone. It is true that the last part, which was what scared her the most, was what she could achieve most confidently, as the interested parties were already very predisposed in her favor. Bingley was ready, Georgiana desired it, and Darcy was completely decided.

en: “To make herself agreeable to all”
vi: When she met Mr. Bingley again, her thoughts naturally turned to her sister, and she was eager to know what was on his mind.
tr: Upon seeing Bingley, her thoughts naturally turned to her sister; oh, how she wished she knew if his thoughts were directed to the same place!
es: Upon seeing Bingley, Elizabeth's thoughts naturally flew to her sister, and she diligently observed whether any of his thoughts were going in the same direction.

en: In seeing Bingley, her thoughts naturally flew to her sister; and oh! how ardently did she long to know whether any of his were directed in a like manner. Sometimes she could fancy that he talked less than on former occasions, and once or twice pleased herself with the notion that, as he looked at her, he was trying to trace a resemblance. But, though this might be imaginary, she could not be deceived as to his behaviour to Miss Darcy, who had been set up as a rival to Jane. No look appeared on either side that spoke particular regard. Nothing occurred between them that could justify the hopes of his sister. On this point she was soon satisfied; and two or three little circumstances occurred ere they parted, which, in her anxious interpretation, denoted a recollection of Jane, not untinctured by tenderness, and a wish of saying more that might lead to the mention of her, had he dared. He observed to her, at a moment when the others were talking together, and in a tone which had something of real regret, that it “was a very long time since he had had the pleasure of seeing her;” and, before she could reply, he added, “It is above eight months. We have not met since the 26th of November, when we were all dancing together at Netherfield.”
vi: When she met Mr. Bingley again, her thoughts naturally turned to her sister, and she was eager to know what was on his mind. Sometimes she imagined that he was less talkative than in previous encounters, and occasionally she was pleased to notice that when he looked at her, he was searching for similarities between the two sisters. But, although this might have been mere imagination, she could not be deceived by his attitude towards Miss Darcy, who had been presented as Jane's rival. Neither of them showed any signs of affection. Nothing occurred between the two that could justify Miss Darcy's hopes. She felt immediately satisfied on this point, and there were a few small incidents before they parted, which, in her eager interpretation, indicated that he had fleeting recollections of Jane, marked by a gentle demeanor and a desire to inquire further about something that might lead to mentioning Jane, if he dared. While the others were conversing, he spoke to her in a voice tinged with regret, saying that it had been a long time since he last saw Jane, and before she could respond, he added that it had been over eight months since the 26th of October when they danced together at Netherfield.
tr: Upon seeing Bingley, her thoughts naturally turned to her sister; oh, how she wished she knew if his thoughts were directed to the same place! Sometimes it seemed to her that Bingley spoke less than he used to; indeed, once or twice she was delighted by the thought that he was trying to find traces of resemblance while looking at her. These could be mere figments of her imagination, but she could not be mistaken about his behavior towards Miss Darcy, who was set up as a rival to Jane. Neither party's looks indicated any special interest. There was nothing between them that could justify her sisters' hopes. She was quickly satisfied on this point; indeed, before their departure, there were a few small incidents which, according to Elizabeth's eager interpretation, showed that he remembered Jane and wanted to say something more that could lead to her being mentioned, but did not dare to. At a moment when the others were talking among themselves, he said to Elizabeth in a voice filled with genuine regret, "It has been a very long time since I had the pleasure of seeing her;" and before Elizabeth could respond, he added, "It has been over eight months. We have not met since the 26th of November, the day we danced at Netherfield."
es: Upon seeing Bingley, Elizabeth's thoughts naturally flew to her sister, and she diligently observed whether any of his thoughts were going in the same direction. She deluded herself into thinking that he spoke less than on other occasions, and once or twice she took pleasure in the idea that, when he looked at her, Bingley was trying to find a resemblance. But, even if all that were just her fantasies, she could not be mistaken about his behavior towards Miss Darcy, who had been spoken of as Jane's presumed rival. She did not notice a single glance from either of them that could justify the hopes of Bingley's sister. Regarding this matter, she was completely satisfied. Before they left, she still noticed from two or three small details that Bingley remembered Jane tenderly and seemed to want to say something more but did not dare. At a moment when the others were conversing, he said it in a sorrowful tone: ––How long it has been since I had the pleasure of seeing you! And, before Elizabeth had time to respond, he added: ––About eight months ago. We hadn't seen each other since the twenty-sixth of November when we all danced together at Netherfield.

en: Elizabeth was pleased to find his memory so exact; and he afterwards took occasion to ask her, when unattended to by any of the rest, whether all her sisters were at Longbourn. There was not much in the question, nor in the preceding remark; but there was a look and a manner which gave them meaning.
vi: Elizabeth was pleased to see that his memory was so accurate, and then taking advantage of the opportunity when no one was standing next to them, he asked her if all her sisters were at Longbourn. The question was not much, just like the previous one, but with an attitude and gesture that conveyed some meaning.
tr: Elizabeth was pleased to see that her memory was so strong; later, finding an opportunity when the others were not around, she asked if all her sisters were at Longbourn. There was nothing much in the question, nor in the answer that came, but there was a look and a manner that gave them meaning.
es: Elizabeth was glad to see that her memory did not fail her. Then, taking advantage of the others being distracted, she asked him if all his sisters were at Longbourn. Neither the question nor the previous memory were important, but Bingley's look and gesture were very significant.

en: It was not often that she could turn her eyes on Mr. Darcy himself; but whenever she did catch a glimpse she saw an expression of general complaisance, and in all that he said, she heard an accent so far removed from hauteur or disdain of his companions, as convinced her that the improvement of manners which she had yesterday witnessed, however temporary its existence might prove, had at least outlived one day. When she saw him thus seeking the acquaintance, and courting the good opinion of people with whom any intercourse a few months ago would have been a disgrace; when she saw him thus civil, not only to herself, but to the very relations whom he had openly disdained, and recollected their last lively scene in Hunsford Parsonage, the difference, the change was so great, and struck so forcibly on her mind, that she could hardly restrain her astonishment from being visible. Never, even in the company of his dear friends at Netherfield, or his dignified relations at Rosings, had she seen him so desirous to please, so free from self-consequence or unbending reserve, as now, when no importance could result from the success of his endeavours, and when even the acquaintance of those to whom his attentions were addressed, would draw down the ridicule and censure of the ladies both of Netherfield and Rosings.
vi: She did not often look at Mr. Darcy, but whenever she glanced at him, she always noticed a kind demeanor, and in every word he spoke, she detected a tone that no longer seemed arrogant or disdainful. This convinced her that the improvement in his character, which she had noticed before, had lasted for more than just two days. When she saw him wanting to get acquainted and win the approval of people he had not wanted to associate with a few months ago, when she saw him being polite not only to her but also to those he had previously openly scorned, and recalled the vivid scene at the Huntsford Parsonage; the differences, the changes were so great, striking her consciousness so strongly, that she could hardly contain her expression of astonishment. Never, even when he was among his close friends at Netherfield, or his noble relatives at Rosings, had she seen him so eager to please others, so devoid of arrogance, or as comfortable as he was now, while gaining no significant benefit from this attitude, even though this interaction would cause the ladies at Netherfield and Rosings to mock and criticize him.
tr: She could not often turn her eyes towards Mr. Darcy; but whenever she did catch a glimpse of him, she saw a general expression of politeness, and in everything he said, she heard a tone of voice that was far removed from arrogance or disdain towards his companions, which convinced her that the improvement in his behavior she had witnessed yesterday, even if temporary, had lasted for more than just a day. Seeing him seek opportunities to meet people he would have been ashamed to encounter a few months ago, and trying to win their approval, and observing him being courteous not only to her but also to the relatives he had previously openly scorned, and recalling the last lively scenes at the parsonage in Hunsford, the difference and change seemed so great and made such a strong impression on her mind that she could not help but show her astonishment. She had never seen him so eager to be liked, whether among his dear friends at Netherfield or his noble relatives at Rosings, and so far removed from self-importance or pretentiousness, even though his efforts would bring him no benefit and his acquaintance with the people he was showing kindness to would lead to the mockery and disapproval of the ladies at Netherfield and Rosings.
es: Elizabeth did not look at Darcy very often; but when she did, she saw in him an expression of contentment and in what he said she perceived a tone that erased all disdain or haughtiness towards his companions, and convinced her that the improvement in his character that she had witnessed the previous day, even if fleeting, had lasted, at least, until now. Seeing him trying to be sociable, seeking the good opinion of those present, with whom having any dealings a few months ago would have meant disgrace for him; seeing him so courteous, not only with her, but with the very relatives he had despised, and remembering the violent scene at the parsonage in Hunsford, the difference, the change was so great, that she could barely prevent her astonishment from becoming visible. Never, neither in the company of his dear friends at Netherfield, nor in that of his haughty relatives at Rosings, had she found him so eager to please, so devoid of self-importance or reserve, as now when no vanity could be gained from the success of his endeavor, and when dealing with those he showered with attentions would have been censured and ridiculed by the ladies of Netherfield and Rosings.

en: Their visitors stayed with them above half an hour; and when they arose to depart, Mr. Darcy called on his sister to join him in expressing their wish of seeing Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner, and Miss Bennet, to dinner at Pemberley, before they left the country. Miss Darcy, though with a diffidence which marked her little in the habit of giving invitations, readily obeyed. Mrs. Gardiner looked at her niece, desirous of knowing how she, whom the invitation most concerned, felt disposed as to its acceptance, but Elizabeth had turned away her head. Presuming, however, that this studied avoidance spoke rather a momentary embarrassment than any dislike of the proposal, and seeing in her husband, who was fond of society, a perfect willingness to accept it, she ventured to engage for her attendance, and the day after the next was fixed on.
vi: The three people stayed for just over half an hour. When they stood up to say goodbye, Mr. Darcy asked his sister to join him in inviting Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner and Miss Bennet to dine at Pemberley before their departure. Miss Darcy readily obeyed, though with a lack of confidence in extending the invitation, due to her nature. Mrs. Gardiner looked at her niece, as she was the main subject of the invitation, to see how she would respond, but Elizabeth had turned away. However, she guessed that this was due to shyness rather than a desire to refuse; and seeing that her husband enjoyed socializing, she suggested that her niece accept, and they arranged to meet two days later.
tr: The guests stayed with them for more than half an hour; when they got up to leave, Mr. Darcy turned to his sister and asked her to join him in expressing the desire to see Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner and Miss Bennet again for dinner at Pemberley before they left the area. Miss Darcy, though shyly indicating her lack of habit in making invitations, complied with the request. Mrs. Gardiner looked at her niece to see if she, the person most concerned with the invitation, was inclined to accept, but Elizabeth had turned her head away. However, assuming that this eager avoidance indicated momentary discomfort rather than displeasure with the offer, and seeing in her husband a complete willingness to accept, she accepted the invitation; the next day was agreed upon.
es: The visit lasted about half an hour, and when they stood up to say goodbye, Darcy asked his sister to support the invitation to the Gardiners and Miss Bennet, so that they would come to dine at Pemberley before leaving the area. Miss Darcy, although with a shyness that revealed her little habit of making invitations, obeyed immediately. Mrs. Gardiner looked at her niece to see how she, to whom the invitation was directed, would receive it; but Elizabeth had turned her head away. She presumed, however, that her studied evasion meant more a momentary confusion than displeasure at the proposition, and seeing her husband, who was very fond of social life, eager to accept, she ventured to accept on behalf of the three; and the date was set for two days later.

en: Bingley expressed great pleasure in the certainty of seeing Elizabeth again, having still a great deal to say to her, and many inquiries to make after all their Hertfordshire friends. Elizabeth, construing all this into a wish of hearing her speak of her sister, was pleased; and on this account, as well as some others, found herself, when their visitors left them, capable of considering the last half hour with some satisfaction, though while it was passing the enjoyment of it had been little. Eager to be alone, and fearful of inquiries or hints from her uncle and aunt, she stayed with them only long enough to hear their favourable opinion of Bingley, and then hurried away to dress.
vi: Bingley expressed genuine joy at the prospect of seeing Elizabeth again, as he still had many things he wanted to discuss with her and many questions to ask about his friends at Netherfield. Elizabeth was pleased, thinking he wanted to hear her talk about her sister. When the guests had left, Elizabeth reflected on the recent events and felt satisfied. Desiring privacy and wary of her uncle and aunt's questions or insinuations, she lingered only a moment to hear them praise Bingley, then excused herself to go change her clothes.
tr: Bingley said that he was very happy to see Elizabeth again, that he still had much to tell her and many questions to ask about their friends in Hertfordshire. Elizabeth, attributing all this to his desire to hear news about her sister, was pleased; therefore, and for some other reasons as well, she found that she could think back on the last half hour with a certain satisfaction after the guests had left, even though it had not seemed very enjoyable at the time. She wanted to be alone, fearing questions or insinuations from her uncle and aunt, and stayed with them just long enough to learn their positive opinions about Bingley, then hurriedly went to change her clothes.
es: Bingley expressed his delight at knowing he would see Elizabeth again, as he still had many things to tell her and many questions to ask about all the friends in Hertfordshire. Elizabeth believed she understood that he wished to hear her speak of her sister, and she was very pleased. This and some other details of the visit left her inclined, as soon as their friends had left, to recall it with pleasure, even though she had felt a bit uncomfortable during the visit. Eager to be alone and fearful of her uncles' questions or suppositions, she stayed with them just long enough to hear their favorable comments about Bingley, and then hurried to get dressed.

en: But she had no reason to fear Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner’s curiosity; it was not their wish to force her communication. It was evident that she was much better acquainted with Mr. Darcy than they had before any idea of; it was evident that he was very much in love with her. They saw much to interest, but nothing to justify inquiry.
vi: But she had no reason to fear Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner's curiosity; they did not want to press her to disclose anything. They clearly saw that she was more acquainted with Mr. Darcy than they had thought; and it was also evident that he loved her deeply. They had noticed many things worthy of their attention, but there was nothing that needed to be asked.
tr: However, there was no reason for Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner to fear their curiosity; they did not intend to force her to talk. It was clear that Elizabeth knew Mr. Darcy much better than they had previously realized; it was also clear that Mr. Darcy was deeply in love with her. They were seeing interesting things, but there was no need to ask questions.
es: But she was very wrong to fear the curiosity of the Gardiners, who had no intention of making her talk. It was evident that her relationship with Darcy was much more serious than they had believed, and it was clearer than water that he was deeply in love with her. They had seen many things that interested them, but they did not justify their inquiry.

en: Of Mr. Darcy it was now a matter of anxiety to think well; and, as far as their acquaintance reached, there was no fault to find. They could not be untouched by his politeness; and had they drawn his character from their own feelings and his servant’s report, without any reference to any other account, the circle in Hertfordshire to which he was known would not have recognized it for Mr. Darcy. There was now an interest, however, in believing the housekeeper; and they soon became sensible that the authority of a servant, who had known him since he was four years old, and whose own manners indicated respectability, was not to be hastily rejected. Neither had anything occurred in the intelligence of their Lambton friends that could materially lessen its weight. They had nothing to accuse him of but pride; pride he probably had, and if not, it would certainly be imputed by the inhabitants of a small market town where the family did not visit. It was acknowledged, however, that he was a liberal man, and did much good among the poor.
vi: Regarding Mr. Darcy, this is a matter of concern that requires her to think clearly. According to the acquaintance they have just established, the couple did not find anything lacking. They could not be indifferent to his courteous demeanor, and if they judged him based on their feelings combined with the housekeeper's affection but disregarded other opinions, those who knew him in Hertfordshire would not recognize this as Mr. Darcy. However, now is the time to consider whether to trust the housekeeper or not. They realized that it would not be wise to hastily dismiss the opinion of a respectable servant who had known him since he was four. They also did not hear their friends in Lambton speak ill of him. These people had nothing to accuse him of except pride. Perhaps he is proud, or it could be that those living in a small town who are less acquainted with him said so. However, they acknowledged that he was a generous person who had done many good deeds for the poor.
tr: Thinking well of Mr. Darcy was now a matter of concern; throughout their acquaintance, they had seen no fault in him. It was impossible not to be impressed by his politeness; if they had drawn his character from their own feelings and the words of his servant without resorting to anyone else's expression, the Hertfordshire community who knew him could not recognize this Mr. Darcy. However, there was also meaning in believing the steward; they realized that the testimony of a servant who had known him since he was four years old and whose own behavior exuded respectability could not be easily disregarded. There was nothing known by their friends in Lambton that could significantly lessen the weight of this. They could not accuse him of anything other than pride; he was probably proud, but even if he were not, the residents of a small market town that the family did not visit would somehow attach that label to him. On the other hand, it was accepted that he was a generous man, and that he did much good for the poor and needy.
es: The important thing now was that Darcy was a good boy. As far as they could have appreciated, he had no faults. His kindnesses had moved them, and if they had had to describe his character according to their own opinion and according to the reports of their maid, disregarding any other reference, they would have done so in such a way that the Hertfordshire circle who knew him would not have recognized him. They now wished to give credit to the housekeeper and soon agreed that the testimony of a maid who had known him since he was four years old and who seemed so respectable, could not be questioned. On the other hand, there was nothing in what his friends from Lambton said that could diminish the weight of that testimony. They accused him of nothing more than pride; proud he may have been, but even if he had not been, the inhabitants of that small commercial town, where the Pemberley family never went, would have attributed the label to him just the same. But they said he was very generous and did a lot of good among the poor.

en: With respect to Wickham, the travellers soon found that he was not held there in much estimation; for though the chief of his concerns with the son of his patron were imperfectly understood, it was yet a well-known fact that, on his quitting Derbyshire, he had left many debts behind him, which Mr. Darcy afterwards discharged.
vi: As for Wickham, the couple did not think highly of him. Although they did not fully understand what he complained about regarding the son of the patron who took care of him, they knew one thing for sure: when he left Derbyshire, he left behind many debts that Mr. Darcy had to settle afterward.
tr: As for Wickham, the travelers learned that he was not held in high regard there; although most of his troubles, particularly those involving his master's son, were not well known, it was a well-known fact that he had left behind a considerable amount of debt when he departed from Derbyshire, and that these debts were later paid off by Mr. Darcy.
es: As for Wickham, the travelers soon saw that he was not held in high regard there; the main details of his relationship with his master's son were unknown, but it was well known that upon leaving Derbyshire he had left behind a multitude of debts that Darcy had paid.

en: As for Elizabeth, her thoughts were at Pemberley this evening more than the last; and the evening, though as it passed it seemed long, was not long enough to determine her feelings towards one in that mansion; and she lay awake two whole hours, endeavouring to make them out. She certainly did not hate him. No; hatred had vanished long ago, and she had almost as long been ashamed of ever feeling a dislike against him, that could be so called. The respect created by the conviction of his valuable qualities, though at first unwillingly admitted, had for some time ceased to be repugnant to her feelings; and it was now heightened into somewhat of a friendlier nature by the testimony so highly in his favour, and bringing forward his disposition in so amiable a light, which yesterday had produced. But above all, above respect and esteem, there was a motive within her of good-will which could not be overlooked. It was gratitude;—gratitude, not merely for having once loved her, but for loving her still well enough to forgive all the petulance and acrimony of her manner in rejecting him, and all the unjust accusations accompanying her rejection. He who, she had been persuaded, would avoid her as his greatest enemy, seemed, on this accidental meeting, most eager to preserve the acquaintance; and without any indelicate display of regard, or any peculiarity of manner, where their two selves only were concerned, was soliciting the good opinion of her friends, and bent on making her known to his sister. Such a change in a man of so much pride excited not only astonishment but gratitude—for to love, ardent love, it must be attributed; and, as such, its impression on her was of a sort to be encouraged, as by no means unpleasing, though it could not be exactly defined. She respected, she esteemed, she was grateful to him, she felt a real interest in his welfare; and she only wanted to know how far she wished that welfare to depend upon herself, and how far it would be for the happiness of both that she should employ the power, which her fancy told her she still possessed, of bringing on the renewal of his addresses.
vi: As for Elizabeth, her thoughts about Pemberley tonight were even more complicated than the day before. Although the evening seemed to pass slowly, it was not slow enough for her to determine her feelings for a certain resident of that estate, and she lay awake for two hours trying to find an answer. Surely, she did not hate him. No, the thought of hatred had long vanished, and for a long time, she had felt ashamed of having harbored such thoughts, one might say. The respect born from her belief in his noble qualities, although initially she did not want to admit it, no longer conflicted with her feelings. Now, that respect had grown to a more intimate level, through her good opinions of him, making him more likable, as past events had shown. But above all, above respect and affection, there was in her a driving force of goodwill that could not be ignored. It was emotion. Emotion not just because someone loved her, but because he loved her so deeply that he forgave all her impulsiveness and sharpness when rejecting his proposal, and forgave all the unjust accusations that followed the rejection. She had thought he would avoid her like the worst enemy; but when he unexpectedly met her again, he seemed to want to maintain a relationship with her. Without any lack of tact or odd gestures, he had won the good opinion of her relatives and even wanted his sister to become acquainted with her. Such a change in a very proud man not only astonished her but also moved her – for this was due to love, deep love. Therefore, the impression within her was something that should be encouraged, certainly not unpleasant, though it could not be clearly defined. She respected him, liked him, was moved by him. She genuinely cared about his happiness. She only wanted to know how much she desired that his happiness depended on her and how much she would use her abilities for the happiness of both. She thought she still had the ability to lead him to propose to her again.
tr: Elizabeth's thoughts this evening were even more focused on Pemberley than the previous evening; the evening hours seemed long as they passed, but not long enough for her to understand her feelings for someone at that estate; she lay awake for two hours trying to make sense of her emotions. Of course, she did not hate him. No; the hatred had passed long ago, and Elizabeth had almost been ashamed of the coldness she had felt towards him since then. The respect that his superior qualities had aroused, though initially accepted reluctantly, had for some time ceased to be repulsive to her; moreover, thanks to the praise spoken about him, he now appeared in a more friendly light, and his character was shown in a very charming light that had emerged yesterday. But more than anything, more than respect and trust, there was a feeling of goodwill within Elizabeth that she could not ignore. It was gratitude. –Not just gratitude for once loving him, but gratitude for loving him enough to forgive all the rudeness and irritability in her manner of rejecting him, and all the unjust accusations that accompanied them. When she should have seen him as her greatest enemy and avoided him, he had shown willingness to maintain their friendship when they met by chance, had tried to win the hearts of her friends without the discourtesy of limiting his attention to her, and had decided to introduce her to his sister. Such a change in a man so proud not only aroused astonishment but also gratitude –for it must have been because of love, passionate love; thus, the effect on Elizabeth was not irritating but rather of a kind that sought encouragement, though it was not clear exactly what it was. She felt respect, appreciation, and gratitude towards him, and sincerely wished for his well-being; she just wanted to know to what extent she wished that well-being to be tied to herself, Elizabeth, and to what extent her imagination, which still told her she had the power, would take their happiness if he used the power to renew his proposal.
es: Elizabeth thought about Pemberley that night even more than the previous one. It seemed very long to her, but not long enough to determine her feelings towards one of the inhabitants of the mansion. After going to bed, she stayed awake for two hours trying to decipher them. She did not hate him, no; the hatred had vanished long ago, and for almost all that time she had been ashamed of having felt a dislike towards that person that could bear such a name. The respect due to his valuable qualities, although admitted at first against her will, had contributed to the cessation of the hostility of her feelings, and these had evolved into affectionate ones in light of the significant testimony in his favor that she had heard and the good disposition he himself had shown the previous day. But above all that, above respect and esteem, Elizabeth felt another impulse of benevolence towards Darcy that could not be overlooked. It was gratitude; gratitude not only for having loved her, but for still loving her enough to forget all the petulance and sharpness of her rejection and all the unjust accusations that accompanied it. He, who should consider her ––so Elizabeth supposed–– as his greatest enemy, upon meeting her by chance seemed eager to maintain her friendship, and without any display of indelicacy or affectation in his manner, in a matter that only concerned the two of them, sought the good opinion of her friends and decided to introduce her to his sister. Such a change in a man so proud not only had to inspire astonishment, but also gratitude, for it had to be attributed to love, to a passionate love. But, although this impression was encouraging and very contrary to dislike, she could not define it precisely. She respected him, esteemed him, was grateful to him, and earnestly wished for his happiness. She only needed to know to what extent she wished that happiness to depend on her, and to what extent it would result in the happiness of both if she used the power she imagined she still possessed to induce him to renew his proposal.

en: It had been settled in the evening, between the aunt and niece, that such a striking civility as Miss Darcy’s, in coming to them on the very day of her arrival at Pemberley—for she had reached it only to a late breakfast—ought to be imitated, though it could not be equalled, by some exertion of politeness on their side; and, consequently, that it would be highly expedient to wait on her at Pemberley the following morning. They were, therefore, to go. Elizabeth was pleased; though when she asked herself the reason, she had very little to say in reply.
vi: In the evening, the aunt and the niece agreed that according to the standards of etiquette on their part, they needed to return the visit to Miss Darcy, who had been extremely courteous when she visited them immediately upon returning to Pemberley, even though their return visit could not be equivalent. They decided they needed to visit her at Pemberley the next morning. Thus, the aunt and niece went together. Elizabeth felt happy, though when she silently asked herself the reason for her happiness, she could not provide much of an answer.
tr: The aunt and the niece decided that evening that it was necessary to respond to Miss Darcy's tremendous kindness, that is, the kindness she showed by getting up to visit them on the day she arrived at Pemberley, even though she arrived at breakfast time, with a response that, even if not as exquisite, should be close to it; as a result, they agreed that it would be very appropriate to visit her at Pemberley the next morning. They would go, that is. –Elizabeth was happy, but when she asked herself why she was happy, she couldn't find much of an answer.
es: In the afternoon, the aunt and niece agreed that such an extraordinary attention as the visit from Miss Darcy on the very day of her arrival at Pemberley—where she had arrived shortly after breakfast—should be reciprocated, if not with something equivalent, at least with some special courtesy. Therefore, they decided to visit her at Pemberley the next morning. Elizabeth felt happy, although when she asked herself why, she couldn't find an answer.

en: Mr. Gardiner left them soon after breakfast. The fishing scheme had been renewed the day before, and a positive engagement made of his meeting some of the gentlemen at Pemberley by noon.
vi: Mr. Gardiner left after breakfast. The day before, he had once again been invited to go fishing and had agreed to meet some people at Pemberley in the afternoon.
tr: Mr. Gardiner left them immediately after breakfast. The invitation to go fishing had been repeated the previous day, and it was arranged to meet a few gentlemen at Pemberley around noon.
es: After breakfast, Mr. Gardiner left them. The offer to go fishing had been renewed the previous day, and he had been assured that one of the gentlemen from Pemberley would accompany him at noon.

en: CHAPTER XLV.
vi: Chapter 45
tr: Chapter III
es: CHAPTER XLV

en: CONVINCED as Elizabeth now was that Miss Bingley’s dislike of her had originated in jealousy, she could not help feeling how very unwelcome her appearance at Pemberley must be to her, and was curious to know with how much civility on that lady’s side the acquaintance would now be renewed.
vi: Elizabeth was now convinced that Miss Bingley disliked her purely out of jealousy. She wondered how Miss Bingley would receive her at Pemberley, curious to know how this young woman would treat her once her relationship with Mr. Darcy was rekindled.
tr: Elizabeth, now thoroughly convinced that Miss Bingley's dislike for her stemmed from jealousy, couldn't help but think about how uncomfortable it must be for her to appear at Pemberley; indeed, she wondered how much courtesy that lady would show while renewing their acquaintance.
es: Elizabeth was now convinced that Miss Bingley's antipathy towards her stemmed from jealousy. She understood, therefore, how unpleasant it must be for her to see her appear at Pemberley and wondered with curiosity how much courtesy she would muster to resume their relations.

en: On reaching the house, they were shown through the hall into the saloon, whose northern aspect rendered it delightful for summer. Its windows, opening to the ground, admitted a most refreshing view of the high woody hills behind the house, and of the beautiful oaks and Spanish chestnuts which were scattered over the intermediate lawn.
vi: When they arrived at the mansion, the two were led through the foyer to enter the great hall, which opened to the north and looked beautiful in the summer. The windows extended to the ground, revealing a refreshing view of the forest-covered hills behind the mansion, with oaks and chestnuts scattered across the adjacent lawn.
tr: When they arrived at the house, they were taken from the hall to the living room; its north-facing aspect made the living room a pleasant place for summer. The windows opening to the garden displayed the refreshing view of the high wooded hills behind the house and the magnificent oak and chestnut trees rising in the grassy area just in front.
es: Upon arriving at the house, they crossed the vestibule and entered the living room, whose northward orientation made it delightful in summer. The wide-open windows offered a refreshing view of the tall, forested hills behind the building, and of the beautiful oaks and chestnut trees of Spain scattered across the meadow that stretched out in front of the house.

en: In this room they were received by Miss Darcy, who was sitting there with Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley, and the lady with whom she lived in London. Georgiana’s reception of them was very civil, but attended with all that embarrassment which, though proceeding from shyness and the fear of doing wrong, would easily give to those who felt themselves inferior the belief of her being proud and reserved. Mrs. Gardiner and her niece, however, did her justice, and pitied her.
vi: They were received by Miss Darcy; she was sitting with Mrs. Hunts and Miss Bingley, along with a lady who lived with her in London. Georgiana was very polite in receiving the two, but with a confused manner due to shyness and the fear of making mistakes, which could make someone of lower class mistakenly think that she was proud and fastidious. However, Mrs. Gardiner and Elizabeth thought rightly of her, feeling sorry for her.
tr: They were greeted in this room by Miss Darcy; Miss Darcy was sitting there with Mrs. Hurst, Miss Bingley, and a lady from London. Georgiana greeted them very politely; but there was no lack of that discomfort stemming from shyness and the fear of making mistakes, which could make those who felt inferior to her think she was proud and distant. Nevertheless, Mrs. Gardiner and her niece gave her credit and felt sorry for her.
es: In that room, they were received by Miss Darcy, who was waiting for them along with Mrs. Hurst, Miss Bingley, and her companion. Georgiana's welcome was very courteous, but dominated by that shyness due to her timidity and the fear of doing things wrong, which had given her a reputation of being proud and reserved among her inferiors. But Mrs. Gardiner and her niece understood and sympathized with her.

en: By Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley they were noticed only by a courtesy; and on their being seated, a pause, awkward as such pauses must always be, succeeded for a few moments. It was first broken by Mrs. Annesley, a genteel, agreeable-looking woman, whose endeavour to introduce some kind of discourse proved her to be more truly well-bred than either of the others; and between her and Mrs. Gardiner, with occasional help from Elizabeth, the conversation was carried on. Miss Darcy looked as if she wished for courage enough to join in it; and sometimes did venture a short sentence, when there was least danger of its being heard.
vi: Mrs. Hunts and Miss Bingley only inclined their heads to greet them. After everyone sat down, there was an awkward moment, broken by Mrs. Annesley. She was a gentle, pleasant woman; when she wanted to start a conversation, she demonstrated that she was truly better educated than the others. The conversation took place between her and Mrs. Gardiner, with Elizabeth occasionally joining in. It seemed that Miss Darcy needed to muster enough courage to contribute, and she occasionally added a short sentence when there was the least risk of being overheard by others.
tr: Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley greeted them only with a slight bend of the knee; once seated, there was a silence, the kind of awkward silence that can occur in such a situation, and it lasted for a few minutes. The first to break the silence was Mrs. Annesley; she appeared to be a kind and amiable woman, and her attempt to start a conversation showed that she was better bred than the other two; the conversation continued between her and Mrs. Gardiner, with occasional help from Elizabeth. Miss Darcy seemed to be gathering the courage to join the conversation and sometimes dared to say a brief word when the risk of being heard was at its lowest.
es: Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley made a simple bow and sat down. An extremely awkward silence ensued, lasting for a few moments. It was interrupted by Mrs. Annesley, a kind and pleasant person who, in attempting to break the ice, showed better manners than any of the other ladies. The conversation continued between her and Mrs. Gardiner, with some contributions from Elizabeth. Miss Darcy seemed to wish she had the confidence to take part in the conversation, and occasionally ventured a short sentence when there was the least danger of being overheard.

en: Elizabeth soon saw that she was herself closely watched by Miss Bingley, and that she could not speak a word, especially to Miss Darcy, without calling her attention. This observation would not have prevented her from trying to talk to the latter, had they not been seated at an inconvenient distance; but she was not sorry to be spared the necessity of saying much: her own thoughts were employing her. She expected every moment that some of the gentlemen would enter the room: she wished, she feared, that the master of the house might be amongst them; and whether she wished or feared it most, she could scarcely determine. After sitting in this manner a quarter of an hour, without hearing Miss Bingley’s voice, Elizabeth was roused by receiving from her a cold inquiry after the health of her family. She answered with equal indifference and brevity, and the other said no more.
vi: Elizabeth immediately realized that Miss Bingley was observing her closely. This would not have prevented her from joining the conversation if she were not in an inconvenient position, but she did not regret having to speak less. She was preoccupied with the thought that at any moment some gentlemen would enter the room. She both wished for and feared the presence of the master of the estate among them, and she could not discern whether she wished or feared it more. After sitting for a while without hearing Miss Bingley, Elizabeth heard her coldly inquiring about her family's health. She responded with the same coldness and brevity, and Miss Bingley said nothing more.
tr: Elizabeth soon realized that she was under the close watch of Miss Bingley and that she couldn't speak a single word to Miss Darcy without drawing her attention. This observation did not prevent her from trying to talk to her, but there was an inconvenient distance between their seats; however, she was not upset as she was relieved from the obligation of much conversation. Her thoughts were already occupying her. She was expecting some of the gentlemen to enter the room at any moment. She wanted the master of the house to be among them, feared he would be, and couldn't decide whether she wanted it or feared it. After sitting for a quarter of an hour in this manner without hearing Miss Bingley's voice, Elizabeth was startled when a cold question about her family's health came from her. She replied with the same indifference and brevity, and the other said nothing more.
es: Elizabeth immediately realized that Miss Bingley was closely watching her and that she couldn't say a word, especially to Miss Darcy, without the other sharpening her ears. However, her tenacious observation would not have prevented her from speaking with Georgiana if they hadn't been so distant from each other; but she was not distressed by not being able to speak much, as it allowed her to think more freely. She both wished for and feared the arrival of the master of the house, and she could hardly clarify whether she feared it more than she desired it. After being like this for a quarter of an hour without hearing Miss Bingley's voice, Elizabeth blushed when the latter asked her how her family was. She replied with the same indifference and brevity, and the other said nothing more.

en: The next variation which their visit afforded was produced by the entrance of servants with cold meat, cake, and a variety of all the finest fruits in season; but this did not take place till after many a significant look and smile from Mrs. Annesley to Miss Darcy had been given, to remind her of her post. There was now employment for the whole party; for though they could not all talk, they could all eat; and the beautiful pyramids of grapes, nectarines, and peaches, soon collected them round the table.
vi: The servants brought in cold meats, pastries, and some of the finest seasonal fruits; this was only after Mrs. Annesley had repeatedly glanced and smiled at Miss Darcy to remind her of her position. Now they had something to do, for if they could not talk, they could eat, and they gathered around the table adorned with fresh grapes, tangerines, and peaches.
tr: The second movement during the visit occurred with the entrance of the servants; they brought cold cuts, cake, and various seasonal fruits; but for this movement to happen, Mrs. Annesley had to make numerous gestures to Miss Darcy to remind her of her duty. Now there was something for everyone to occupy themselves with; they couldn't all talk, but they could all eat; seeing the grapes, nectarines, and peaches arranged in marvelous pyramids, they soon gathered around the table.
es: The first variety of the visit consisted of the appearance of some servants who brought cold cuts, pastries, and some of the best fruits of the season, but this happened after many significant looks from Mrs. Annesley to Georgiana to remind her of her duties. This distracted the gathering, for, although not all the ladies could talk, at least all could eat. The beautiful pyramids of grapes, apricots, and peaches immediately gathered them around the table.

en: While thus engaged, Elizabeth had a fair opportunity of deciding whether she most feared or wished for the appearance of Mr. Darcy, by the feelings which prevailed on his entering the room; and then, though but a moment before she had believed her wishes to predominate, she began to regret that he came.
vi: At that moment, Elizabeth had the opportunity to determine whether she wished for or feared Mr. Darcy's appearance more, through the emotions that arose within her as he entered. Just a moment ago, she believed she wished for it more, but now she began to regret that he had come.
tr: In the midst of this occupation, was Elizabeth afraid of Mr. Darcy's arrival, or did she want him to come? She had the opportunity to truly decide when Mr. Darcy entered the room; then, she began to feel upset that he had come, even though she thought she wanted it just a minute before.
es: While they were engaged in this, Elizabeth began to ponder whether she feared or desired Darcy's arrival due to the effect his presence would have on her; and although a moment before she believed she rather desired it, she now began to think the opposite.

en: He had been some time with Mr. Gardiner, who, with two or three other gentlemen from the house, was engaged by the river; and had left him only on learning that the ladies of the family intended a visit to Georgiana that morning. No sooner did he appear, than Elizabeth wisely resolved to be perfectly easy and unembarrassed;—a resolution the more necessary to be made, but perhaps not the more easily kept, because she saw that the suspicions of the whole party were awakened against them, and that there was scarcely an eye which did not watch his behaviour when he first came into the room. In no countenance was attentive curiosity so strongly marked as in Miss Bingley’s, in spite of the smiles which overspread her face whenever she spoke to one of its objects; for jealousy had not yet made her desperate, and her attentions to Mr. Darcy were by no means over. Miss Darcy, on her brother’s entrance, exerted herself much more to talk; and Elizabeth saw that he was anxious for his sister and herself to get acquainted, and forwarded, as much as possible, every attempt at conversation on either side. Miss Bingley saw all this likewise; and, in the imprudence of anger, took the first opportunity of saying, with sneering civility,—
vi: He was standing by the river with Mr. Gardiner and a few of his friends when he was informed that there were guests. As soon as he appeared, Elizabeth wisely resolved that she needed to appear completely at ease and not flustered. Thinking it was easy but doing it could be difficult, because when he entered, she felt all the curiosity was focused on the two of them, with every eye keenly observing his demeanor. Miss Bingley's face showed the most attentive curiosity although she always smiled when talking, because jealousy had not yet made her desperate, she had not ceased to pay attention to Mr. Darcy. When she saw her brother enter, Miss Darcy spoke more, and Elizabeth noticed that he wanted her and his sister to become more acquainted, so he tried to draw the two into the conversation. Miss Bingley also knew this, and in a rash moment of anger, she seized the first opportunity to speak, with a polite mocking tone:
tr: Mr. Darcy had been with Mr. Gardiner for a while; Mr. Gardiner was busy at the river with a few gentlemen who were guests at the house, and Mr. Darcy had only left him alone upon learning that the ladies of the family were planning to visit Georgiana that morning. As soon as she entered the room, Elizabeth decided to appear quite at ease and natural – a necessary decision but perhaps not so easy to adhere to, because she saw that the suspicions of everyone in the room were aroused against the two of them and that there was not a single eye that did not follow Mr. Darcy's behavior when he first entered. No one else's face bore such a strongly fixed look of attentive curiosity as Miss Bingley's, even though her face lit up with smiles while speaking to one of the two people who aroused her curiosity; jealousy had not yet exhausted all her hopes, and she had not given up showing interest in Mr. Darcy. Miss Darcy forced herself to talk more upon her brother's arrival; Elizabeth saw that Mr. Darcy wanted his sister and herself to become closer and that he supported every attempt at conversation from both sides as much as he could. Miss Bingley also saw all this and, in the carelessness of her anger, said with a contemptuous interest at the first opportunity,
es: Darcy had been with Mr. Gardiner, who was fishing in the river with two or three other gentlemen, but upon learning that the ladies of his family planned to visit Georgiana that very morning, he went home. Upon seeing him enter, Elizabeth resolved to appear as natural as possible, a necessary but difficult task, as she was aware that the entire gathering was focused on them, and as soon as Darcy arrived, all eyes turned to examine him. But no face showed curiosity as strongly as Miss Bingley's, despite the smiles she lavished while speaking with anyone; however, her jealousy had not reached the point of making her desist from her attentions to Darcy––. Georgiana, as soon as her brother entered, made more effort to speak, and Elizabeth understood that Darcy wanted the two to become close, for which he encouraged all attempts at conversation from both sides. Miss Bingley also noticed this and with the imprudence typical of her anger, seized the first opportunity to say with mocking finesse:

en: “Pray, Miss Eliza, are not the ——shire militia removed from Meryton? They must be a great loss to your family.”
vi: - Miss Elizabeth, has the militia regiment moved away from Meryton? This must be a great loss for your family.
tr: "May I ask, Miss Eliza, hasn't the -------shire regiment withdrawn from Meryton? It must have been a great loss for your family."
es: ––Tell me, Miss Elizabeth, is it true that the Meryton garrison has been relocated? It must have been a great loss for your family.

en: In Darcy’s presence she dared not mention Wickham’s name: but Elizabeth instantly comprehended that he was uppermost in her thoughts; and the various recollections connected with him gave her a moment’s distress; but, exerting herself vigorously to repel the ill-natured attack, she presently answered the question in a tolerably disengaged tone.
