Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner had returned in a hurry, assuming from the servant's statement that their niece had suddenly fallen ill; –but she reassured them on that account and explained the reason for their urgent summons, reading both letters aloud with trembling energy and emphasizing the note in the second one. –Although Lydia was not their favorite niece, Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner couldn't help but feel deep sorrow. The matter concerned not just Lydia, but everyone; after the initial cries of shock and horror, Mr. Gardiner promised to do all he could to help. –Elizabeth thanked him with tears of gratitude, although she expected no less; since all three were in the same state of mind, all the travel details were quickly settled. They would set out at the first opportunity. "But what about Pemberley?" cried Mrs. Gardiner. "When John called us, he said Mr. Darcy was here; –was he here?"
es: She couldn't wait to be home to see, hear, and be there, and to share with Jane the care that such a troubled family required, with the father absent and the mother incapable of any effort and needing constant attention. Although she was almost convinced that nothing could be done for Lydia, her uncle's help seemed of utmost importance to her, so until she saw him enter the room, she endured the torment of an impatient wait. Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner returned hurriedly and alarmed, believing, from what the servant had told them, that their niece had suddenly fallen ill. Elizabeth reassured them on this point and immediately informed them of the reason for her call by reading them the two letters and insisting on the postscript with trembling energy. Although Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner had never been very fond of Lydia, the news deeply affected them. The misfortune affected not only Lydia but everyone. After the initial exclamations of surprise and horror, Mr. Gardiner offered all the help he could. Elizabeth expected no less and thanked them with tears in her eyes. Moved by the same spirit, the three of them quickly arranged everything for the trip. ––And what shall we do about Pemberley? ––asked Mrs. Gardiner––. John has told us that Mr. Darcy was here when you sent him to fetch us. Is it true?

en: “Yes; and I told him we should not be able to keep our engagement. That is all settled.”
vi: - Yes; I told Mr. Darcy that we would not be able to keep our promise. This matter has been settled.
tr: "Yes; I told him that we wouldn't be able to keep our promise. Everything is settled."
es: ––Yes; I told him that we were not in a position to fulfill our commitment. That's already been settled.

en: “What is all settled?” repeated the other, as she ran into her room to prepare. “And are they upon such terms as for her to disclose the real truth? Oh, that I knew how it was!”
vi: The aunt repeated, as she ran into the room to prepare: "This matter has been arranged." And I don't know how close the two of you are for the niece to reveal the truth! Oh, if only I had known what the situation was like!”
tr: "Everything is taken care of," repeated the other, darting to their room to get ready. "I wonder if they are close enough to reveal the truth! Oh, I wish I knew!"
es: ––That's already been settled ––repeated Mrs. Gardiner as she ran to the other room to get ready–. Are they on such close terms as to have revealed the truth to him? How I would love to find out what has happened!

en: But wishes were vain; or, at best, could serve only to amuse her in the hurry and confusion of the following hour. Had Elizabeth been at leisure to be idle, she would have remained certain that all employment was impossible to one so wretched as herself; but she had her share of business as well as her aunt, and amongst the rest there were notes to be written to all their friends at Lambton, with false excuses for their sudden departure. An hour, however, saw the whole completed; and Mr. Gardiner, meanwhile, having settled his account at the inn, nothing remained to be done but to go; and Elizabeth, after all the misery of the morning, found herself, in a shorter space of time than she could have supposed, seated in the carriage, and on the road to Longbourn.
vi: But all wishes were futile, or at least only helped her feel better in the rush and confusion of the next hour. If Elizabeth had been at leisure, she would have been convinced that she could not accomplish anything while in such distress; but she had as much to do as her aunt, including writing letters to inform everyone in Lambton, with a fabricated reason for their sudden departure. However, within an hour, everything was settled. After a miserable morning, Elizabeth found that she could return to Longbourn sooner than she had thought.
tr: It was not a time for wishes; or if there were any, they would only serve to distract her in the rush and hurry of the next hour. If Elizabeth had the chance to be idle, she would believe that it was impossible for someone as miserable as herself to engage in any activity, but she had as much work to do as her aunt; it fell to her to write notes to all their friends in Lambton, making up false excuses for their sudden departure. Yet within an hour, all the work was completed; in the meantime, Mr. Gardiner settled the inn's account and there was nothing left to do but leave. After all the morning's misery, Elizabeth found herself settled in the carriage and on the way to Longbourn sooner than she had expected.
es: But her curiosity was useless. At most, it served to entertain her in the rush and confusion of the next hour. If Elizabeth could have stayed idle, she would have believed that someone as miserable as she was incapable of any work, but she was as busy as her aunt and, to top it off, she had to write cards to all the friends in Lambton to explain their sudden departure with false excuses. Everything was dispatched within an hour. Meanwhile, Mr. Gardiner settled the inn's bill, and all that was left was to depart. After the sadness of the morning, Elizabeth found herself, in less time than she had supposed, seated in the carriage and heading towards Longbourn.

en: CHAPTER XLVII.
vi: Chapter 47
tr: Chapter V
es: CHAPTER XLII

en: “I HAVE been thinking it over again, Elizabeth,” said her uncle, as they drove from the town; “and really, upon serious consideration, I am much more inclined than I was to judge as your eldest sister does of the matter. It appears to me so very unlikely that any young man should form such a design against a girl who is by no means unprotected or friendless, and who was actually staying in his Colonel’s family, that I am strongly inclined to hope the best. Could he expect that her friends would not step forward? Could he expect to be noticed again by the regiment, after such an affront to Colonel Forster? His temptation is not adequate to the risk.”
vi: When they drove out of town, the uncle said to her: - Elizabeth, you have thought over the matter, and after serious consideration, now you can truly be ready to judge the matter better, just as your sister has judged. You think there is no reason why a young man would intend to marry a girl with no guaranteed fortune and no friends, while she is actually staying with his colonel's family. Can he rely on his friends to help him? After confronting Colonel Forster, does he think he will be reprimanded by the regiment? His actions are not worth taking such risks.
tr: "I keep thinking about it, Elizabeth," said her uncle, as they moved away from the town; "and the more I think, the more inclined I am to view the matter as your sister does. It seems highly unlikely to me that a young man would make such a plan against a girl who is not unprotected, not without guardians, and who is a guest of his colonel's family; so much so that I am inclined to hope for the best outcome. Can this young man expect that the girl's relatives will not emerge? Can he expect to be accepted into the regiment after such an insult to Colonel Forster? The reasons do not outweigh the risks."
es: I've been thinking about it again, Elizabeth," her uncle said to her as they were leaving the city, "and finally, after serious consideration, I feel inclined to adopt your elder sister's opinion. It seems unlikely to me that Wickham would want to harm a girl who is not without protection or friends and who was living with the Forster family. He wouldn't assume that the girl's friends would stand idly by, nor that he would be readmitted to the regiment after such a grave offense to his colonel. The temptation is not proportional to the risk.

en: “Do you really think so?” cried Elizabeth, brightening up for a moment.
vi: Elizabeth exclaimed, her face momentarily lighting up with joy: - Do you really believe that?
tr: "Do you really think so?" cried Elizabeth, coming to life for a moment.
es: ––Do you really believe that? ––asked Elizabeth, brightening up for a moment.

en: “Upon my word,” said Mrs. Gardiner, “I begin to be of your uncle’s opinion. It is really too great a violation of decency, honour, and interest, for him to be guilty of it. I cannot think so very ill of Wickham. Can you, yourself, Lizzie, so wholly give him up, as to believe him capable of it?”
vi: Mrs. Gardiner said: - Honestly, I am beginning to think like your uncle. This is too grave an error in terms of propriety, honor, and rights, not deserving of him being accused. I cannot believe Wickham could be that bad. Lizzy, you yourself, can you believe he is capable of doing such a thing?
tr: "Absolutely," said Mrs. Gardiner, "I am beginning to think like your uncle. He cannot risk being guilty of such a great abuse in so many matters of decorum, honor, and profession. I cannot think so badly of Wickham. Have you, yourself, Lizzy, lost hope in him enough to think he could do this?"
es: ––I am also beginning to share your uncle's opinion ––said Mrs. Gardiner––. It is too great a violation of decency, honor, and self-interest to have acted so lightly. I cannot admit that Wickham is so foolish. And you yourself, Elizabeth, do you hold him in such low regard to believe him capable of such madness?

en: “Not perhaps of neglecting his own interest. But of every other neglect I can believe him capable. If, indeed, it should be so! But I dare not hope it. Why should they not go on to Scotland, if that had been the case?”
vi: - Perhaps he won't overlook your rights, but I believe he can overlook everything else. But why didn't they go to Scotland if that's the case?
tr: "Maybe not to the extent of thinking he neglected his own interests. But I expect every other kind of neglect from him. What if it is so! I hope it isn't. Then why didn't they go to Scotland?"
es: ––I don't believe he's capable of forgetting his own convenience, but he is capable of forgetting everything that doesn't pertain to it. I wish it were as you say! I don't dare to hope for it. And if not, why haven't they gone to Scotland?

en: “In the first place,” replied Mr. Gardiner, “there is no absolute proof that they are not gone to Scotland.”
vi: Mr. Gardiner replied: - First of all, there is no conclusive evidence that they did not go to Scotland.
tr: "For one thing," replied Mr. Gardiner, "there is no definite proof that they did not go to Scotland."
es: ––First of all ––replied Mr. Gardiner––, there is no evidence that they haven't gone.

en: “Oh, but their removing from the chaise into a hackney coach is such a presumption! And, besides, no traces of them were to be found on the Barnet road.”
vi: - Ah! But the fact that they switched from a horse-drawn carriage to a rented vehicle allows us to infer that. And furthermore, no trace of the two was found along Barnet Street.
tr: "But that means they switched to the city car! Besides, no traces of them were found on Barnet Road."
es: ––What better proof than having left the post chaise and taken a hired carriage? Besides, they did not go through the Barnet road.

en: “Well, then,—supposing them to be in London—they may be there, though for the purpose of concealment, for no more exceptionable purpose. It is not likely that money should be very abundant on either side; and it might strike them that they could be more economically, though less expeditiously, married in London, than in Scotland.”
vi: - Alright, then suppose they are in London. They might be there for the purpose of hiding, not for any other exceptional reason. Each person might not have much money, and they think they can get married more cheaply, though slowly, in London than in Scotland.
tr: "Alright – let's assume they are in London. They might be there to hide, but there can't be any other exceptional reason. It's unlikely that both sides are swimming in money; they might have thought that getting married in London would be more economical, if not more urgent, than in Scotland."
es: ––Well, suppose they are in London. They may have done it only for the purpose of hiding. It is not likely that either of them has plenty of money, and they might have thought it would be cheaper to get married in London than in Scotland, even if it is more difficult for them.

en: “But why all this secrecy? Why any fear of detection? Why must their marriage be private? Oh, no, no—this is not likely. His most particular friend, you see by Jane’s account, was persuaded of his never intending to marry her. Wickham will never marry a woman without some money. He cannot afford it. And what claims has Lydia, what attractions has she beyond youth, health, and good humour, that could make him for her sake forego every chance of benefiting himself by marrying well? As to what restraint the apprehensions of disgrace in the corps might throw on a dishonourable elopement with her, I am not able to judge; for I know nothing of the effects that such a step might produce. But as to your other objection, I am afraid it will hardly hold good. Lydia has no brothers to step forward; and he might imagine, from my father’s behaviour, from his indolence and the little attention he has ever seemed to give to what was going forward in his family, that he would do as little and think as little about it, as any father could do, in such a matter.”
vi: - But why keep it a secret? Why be afraid of being discovered? Why must the marriage be kept secret? Oh, no, no, it makes no sense. His closest friend, according to Jane, believes that he never had any intention of marrying. Wickham would never marry someone without money. He does not have the financial means to do so. And what does Lydia have, what attractive qualities beyond youth, health, and cheerfulness, that could make him give up every opportunity for a wealthy marriage? As for his fear of being despised by the army for eloping in disgrace, I cannot judge, because I do not know the consequences of this situation. As for your argument, I fear it has no basis. Lydia has no brothers to hope for help from, and from my father's attitude, his laziness, and his lack of attention to what is happening in the family, one could think that he would do as little as possible and think as little as possible about this matter, like any other father.
tr: "But why this secrecy? Why are they afraid of being found? Why must their marriage be secret? Oh! No, no, it's not possible. From what Jane told us, we saw that his closest friend says he has no intention of marrying her. Wickham would never marry a woman without money. His means do not allow it. But what does Lydia have, besides youth, health, and cheerfulness, that would make him ruin his chance of a good marriage for her sake? I don't know how the fear of losing reputation in the army could prevent him from eloping so disgracefully with Lydia; because I know nothing about the consequences of such a step. But as for your other objection, I'm not sure it will work. Lydia has no brothers to come forward; and Wickham might have concluded from my father's behavior, his laziness, and his apparent indifference to what happens in his family, that he would not trouble himself like any other father would in such a matter."
es: ––But why the secrecy? Why do they have to marry in secret? You know from Jane that Wickham's closest friend assures that he never thought of marrying Lydia. Wickham will never marry a woman who doesn't have money, because he can't afford the expenses of a marriage. And what merits does Lydia have, what attractions, aside from her health, her youth, and her good humor, for Wickham to give up the possibility of making a good match for her? I can't accurately assess to what extent a dishonorable elopement will harm him in the Corps, as I am unaware of the measures taken in such cases, but as for your other objections, it seems difficult for them to hold up. Lydia has no brothers to intervene; and given my father's character, his indolence, and the little attention he has always paid to his family, Wickham might have believed he wouldn't take it too seriously.

en: “But can you think that Lydia is so lost to everything but love of him, as to consent to live with him on any other terms than marriage?”
vi: - But can you think that Lydia would lose so much except for your love, that she would be willing to live with you in any way other than marriage?
tr: "But can you imagine that Lydia is so blindly in love that she would agree to live a life outside of marriage, not seeing anything else?"
es: ––But how do you suppose that Lydia is so inconsiderate about everything except loving him, that she would agree to live with him in any other way than as his legitimate wife?

en: “It does seem, and it is most shocking, indeed,” replied Elizabeth, with tears in her eyes, “that a sister’s sense of decency and virtue in such a point should admit of doubt. But, really, I know not what to say. Perhaps I am not doing her justice. But she is very young: she has never been taught to think on serious subjects; and for the last half year, nay, for a twelvemonth, she has been given up to nothing but amusement and vanity. She has been allowed to dispose of her time in the most idle and frivolous manner, and to adopt any opinions that came in her way. Since the ——shire were first quartered in Meryton, nothing but love, flirtation, and officers, have been in her head. She has been doing everything in her power, by thinking and talking on the subject, to give greater—what shall I call it?—susceptibility to her feelings; which are naturally lively enough. And we all know that Wickham has every charm of person and address that can captivate a woman.”
vi: Elizabeth replied, her eyes filled with tears: - It seems, and this is the most astonishing thing, that the conscience of an elder sister regarding propriety and morality should consider herself doubtful. But, truly, I don't know what to say. Perhaps I am not being fair to my sister. But she is still too young; she has never been taught how to think about serious matters; for the past six months, no, for the past twelve months, she has cared for nothing but fun and frivolity. She has been allowed to spend her time in the laziest and most frivolous manner, and to follow every opinion she has picked up. Since the regiment arrived at Meryton, her mind has been filled with love, amusement, and the officers. She has done everything in her power to think and talk about this subject, to create – what should I call it? To create a sensitivity in her mind, a mind naturally quite lively. And we all know Wickham has all the appearances and words to captivate a woman.
tr: "It appears, quite bitterly," replied Elizabeth, with tears in her eyes, "that one must accept that a sister's sense of virtue and honor is questionable at such a point. But I really don't know what to say. Perhaps I am not being fair to her. But she is very young; she was not taught to think about serious matters; for the last six months, even a year, she has been encouraged in nothing but pleasure and display. She was allowed to spend her time in the most idle and superficial manner, adopting every idea that came her way. Since the --------shire regiment settled in Meryton, nothing has occupied her mind but love, flirtation, and officers. She did everything she could to, how shall I say, further inflame her already lively feelings by thinking and talking about this subject. And we all know that Wickham's appearance and speech possess every charm to captivate a woman."
es: ––It seems so ––replied Elizabeth with her eyes full of tears––, and it is dreadful to have to doubt the decency and virtue of a sister. But in reality, I don't know what to say. Perhaps I judge her wrongly, but she is very young, she has never been accustomed to thinking about serious matters, and for the last half year, or rather for an entire year, she has done nothing but chase after diversions and vanity. She has been allowed to indulge in idleness and frivolity and to do nothing but what she fancied. Since the county garrison was quartered in Meryton, she has thought of nothing but love, flirting, and the officers. She did everything she could to excite, how should I put it?, the susceptibility of her feelings, which are already quite lively by nature. And we all know that Wickham possesses in his person and manners all the charms that can captivate a woman.

en: “But you see that Jane,” said her aunt, “does not think so ill of Wickham, as to believe him capable of the attempt.”
vi: Auntie said: - But don't you see that Jane doesn't think too badly of Wickham, so she doesn't believe he is capable of doing such a thing? - Does
tr: "But you see," said her aunt, "she doesn't think so badly of Jane Wickham, she doesn't believe she would attempt such a thing."
es: ––But you see ––insisted her aunt–– that your sister does not believe Wickham capable of such an offense.

en: “Of whom does Jane ever think ill? And who is there, whatever might be their former conduct, that she would believe capable of such an attempt, till it were proved against them? But Jane knows, as well as I do, what Wickham really is. We both know that he has been profligate in every sense of the word; that he has neither integrity nor honour; that he is as false and deceitful as he is insinuating.”
vi: Jane think ill of anyone? And does she believe that anyone is capable, regardless of their character, until there is proof? But like you, Jane knows what Wickham's true nature is. We both know he has been dissolute in every sense of the word. He has no integrity or honor. He likes deceit and deception.
tr: "Who would Jane think badly of? No matter what his past behavior was, who does she believe could attempt such a thing, until events prove otherwise? But Jane knows as well as I do what Wickham really is. We both know that he is a bad person in every sense of the word. That he knows neither honor nor integrity. That he is as deceitful as he is a liar and a fraud."
es: ––Jane never believes anything bad about anyone. Much less when it comes to something like this, until it has been proven to her. But Jane knows as well as I do who Wickham is. We both know that he is a libertine in every sense of the word, lacking integrity and honor, and that he is as false and deceitful as he is attractive.

en: “And do you really know all this?” cried Mrs. Gardiner, whose curiosity as to the mode of her intelligence was all alive.
vi: Mrs. Gardiner exclaimed, surprised at how she gathered information: - And you really know all these things??
tr: "Do you really know all this?" cried Mrs. Gardiner; her curiosity about where this information came from was thoroughly aroused.
es: ––Are you sure? ––asked Mrs. Gardiner, who was burning with the desire to know the source of her niece's information.

en: “I do, indeed,” replied Elizabeth, colouring. “I told you the other day of his infamous behaviour to Mr. Darcy; and you, yourself, when last at Longbourn, heard in what manner he spoke of the man who had behaved with such forbearance and liberality towards him. And there are other circumstances which I am not at liberty—which it is not worth while to relate; but his lies about the whole Pemberley family are endless. From what he said of Miss Darcy, I was thoroughly prepared to see a proud, reserved, disagreeable girl. Yet he knew to the contrary himself. He must know that she was as amiable and unpretending as we have found her.”
vi: Elizabeth blushed: - I really know. The other day I told my aunt about his scandalous behavior towards Mr. Darcy; it was my aunt who, during her last visit to Longbourn, heard him speak about Mr. Darcy, who had treated him with tolerance and generosity. And there are other instances that I cannot... instances not worth mentioning; but he has continuously lied about the Pemberley family. From what he said about Miss Darcy, I thought she was a proud, fastidious, and unpleasant girl. Yet he knew the opposite was true. He must have known that she is as sweet and humble as we have seen.
tr: "Of course I know," replied Elizabeth, blushing. "The other day I told you about the villainy he did to Mr. Darcy; you yourself heard how he spoke about the man who treated him so patiently and generously when he last came to Longbourn. There are also other incidents that I am not authorized to tell – I mean, not worth mentioning; but his lies about the entire Pemberley family are countless. From what he said about Miss Darcy, I was prepared to see a proud, cold, unpleasant girl. But he knew very well that the opposite was true. He knew that she was a pleasant and unassuming girl, as we found her to be."
es: ––Absolutely sure ––replied Elizabeth, blushing––. I already told you the other day about his infamous behavior towards Mr. Darcy, and you yourself heard the last time in Longbourn how he spoke about the man who has treated him with such indulgence and generosity. And there is yet another circumstance that I am not authorized... that is not worth mentioning. The truth is that his lies about the Pemberley family are endless. From what he had told us about Miss Darcy, I believed she would be a haughty, reserved, and unpleasant girl. However, he knew that she was quite the opposite. He must know very well, as we have observed, how affectionate and simple she is.

en: “But does Lydia know nothing of this? can she be ignorant of what you and Jane seem so well to understand?”
vi: - But Lydia didn't know anything at all? Could it be that she doesn't know what you and Jane seem to understand so well?
tr: "But doesn't Lydia know these things?" "How could she not know the things that you and Jane seem to know so well?""
es: ––And Lydia isn't aware of any of this? How does she not know what Jane and you know?

en: “Oh, yes!—that, that is the worst of all. Till I was in Kent, and saw so much both of Mr. Darcy and his relation Colonel Fitzwilliam, I was ignorant of the truth myself. And when I returned home the ——shire was to leave Meryton in a week or fortnight’s time. As that was the case, neither Jane, to whom I related the whole, nor I, thought it necessary to make our knowledge public; for of what use could it apparently be to anyone, that the good opinion, which all the neighbourhood had of him, should then be overthrown? And even when it was settled that Lydia should go with Mrs. Forster, the necessity of opening her eyes to his character never occurred to me. That she could be in any danger from the deception never entered my head. That such a consequence as this should ensue, you may easily believe was far enough from my thoughts.”
vi: - Yes, exactly like that! And this is the worst part. I myself was not clear about the truth until I went to Kent and met Mr. Darcy and his cousin, Colonel Fitzwilliam. When I returned home, the regiment was preparing to leave Meryton in a week or two. Because of this, both Jane and I thought it unnecessary to make it public, as what good would it do to disrupt everyone's positive impression of him? And even when the family agreed to let Lydia go with Mrs. Forster, I never thought it necessary to enlighten her about his character. I never suspected she could be deceived. I did not foresee such consequences, while you could have easily thought of them.
tr: "Ah yes! –and that's the worst part of it anyway. Until I went to Kent and got to know Mr. Darcy and his cousin Colonel Fitzwilliam well, I didn't know the truth either. When I returned home, the --------shire regiment was about to leave within a week or two. Given the situation, neither Jane nor I felt it necessary to explain these things to everyone; because what good would it do to shatter the positive opinions the whole community had of him? Even when it was decided that Lydia would go with Mrs. Forster, it didn't occur to me to warn her about his true nature. I never considered the possibility that she could be in danger of being deceived. Believe me, the thought of such an outcome never even crossed my mind."
es: ––You are right. Until I was in Kent and met Mr. Darcy and his cousin Colonel Fitzwilliam, I did not know either. When I arrived home, the county garrison was set to leave Meryton within three weeks, so neither Jane, whom I informed of everything, nor I thought it necessary to disclose it; because what use would it be to ruin the good opinion they had of him in Hertfordshire? And when it was decided that Lydia would go with the Forsters to Brighton, it never occurred to me to reveal Wickham's true character to her, as it never crossed my mind that she would be in any danger of that kind. You can understand that I was far from suspecting that such disastrous consequences would ensue.

en: “When they all removed to Brighton, therefore, you had no reason, I suppose, to believe them fond of each other?”
vi: - So, you think there's no reason for you to believe that when they went to Brighton, they had feelings for each other, right?
tr: "When they all went to Brighton together, there was no reason for you to think that they were interested in each other."
es: ––When they moved the garrison to Brighton, did you have any idea that there was something between them?

en: “Not the slightest. I can remember no symptom of affection on either side; and had anything of the kind been perceptible, you must be aware that ours is not a family on which it could be thrown away. When first he entered the corps, she was ready enough to admire him; but so we all were. Every girl in or near Meryton was out of her senses about him for the first two months: but he never distinguished her by any particular attention; and, consequently, after a moderate period of extravagant and wild admiration, her fancy for him gave way, and others of the regiment, who treated her with more distinction, again became her favourites.”
vi: - I don't see any reason at all. I don't remember seeing any signs of affection between the two. When he first joined the militia, she already liked him, but so did all of us. Every girl in Meryton and around there was infatuated with him for the first two months, but he never treated her with any special attention. Therefore, after the phase of crazy infatuation, she no longer liked him, and since others in the regiment treated her more specially, she liked them more.
tr: "There was no reason at all. I saw no sign of any intimacy on either side; you know that if I had sensed the slightest thing, our family is not one to overlook such matters. When Wickham first joined the regiment, Lydia was quite ready to admire him; but so were we all. Every girl in Meryton and the surrounding area was crazy about him for the first two months; but he showed no special interest in Lydia; eventually, after a brief period of exaggerated and wild admiration, she stopped dreaming about Wickham and began to occupy herself with other officers who paid her more attention." -------------------------------
es: ––Not the slightest bit. I don't remember noticing any sign of affection from either one of them. If there had been anything, my family is certainly sharp enough to have noticed it! When Wickham joined the Corps, Lydia liked him a lot, but no more than the rest of us did. All the girls in Meryton and the surrounding areas went crazy over him during the first two months, but he never paid Lydia any special attention, so after a period of extravagant and unrestrained admiration, she forgot about him and turned her attention to other officers who paid her more attention.

en: It may be easily believed, that however little of novelty could be added to their fears, hopes, and conjectures, on this interesting subject by its repeated discussion, no other could detain them from it long, during the whole of the journey. From Elizabeth’s thoughts it was never absent. Fixed there by the keenest of all anguish, self-reproach, she could find no interval of ease or forgetfulness.
vi: Even though there wasn't much new to add to the worries, hopes, and speculations, no one could dismiss these thoughts for long throughout the journey. Elizabeth's mind was always preoccupied. Tormented by all the distress and self-blame, she never felt comfortable or temporarily forgot the incident.
tr: Although it could easily be anticipated that nothing new could be added by repeatedly talking about their fears, hopes, and wishes on this important matter, no other topic could distract them from it for long throughout the entire journey. It never left Elizabeth's thoughts. It had firmly settled there with all its torment and pangs of conscience, not allowing her a moment's peace or forgetfulness.
es: Although few new things could be added to their fears, hopes, and conjectures about such an interesting matter, the travelers debated it throughout the entire journey. Elizabeth could not think of anything else. The sharpest of all agonies, self-reproach, prevented her from finding the slightest interval of relief or forgetfulness.

en: They travelled as expeditiously as possible; and sleeping one night on the road, reached Longbourn by dinnertime the next day. It was a comfort to Elizabeth to consider that Jane could not have been wearied by long expectations.
vi: The three people moved as quickly as possible, and after spending the night on the road, they arrived back at Longbourn by dinner time the next day. Elizabeth was reassured that Jane must not have been anxious due to the long wait.
tr: They traveled as fast as they could; they slept on the road one night and reached Longbourn the next day at mealtime. It comforted Elizabeth to think that Jane had not kept her eyes on the road for a long time.
es: They walked as quickly as they could, spent the night at an inn, and arrived at Longbourn the next day at lunchtime. Elizabeth's only consolation was that she would not have kept Jane waiting too long.

en: The little Gardiners, attracted by the sight of a chaise, were standing on the steps of the house, as they entered the paddock; and when the carriage drove up to the door, the joyful surprise that lighted up their faces and displayed itself over their whole bodies, in a variety of capers and frisks, was the first pleasing earnest of their welcome.
vi: The Gardiner children were standing on the doorstep when they drove in, and as the car reached the threshold, the children's faces lit up, jumping excitedly to greet them.
tr: When they saw the car, the little Gardiners, who had eagerly climbed the steps as the car entered the lawn, were waiting; as the car approached the door, the joyful astonishment that lit up their faces and spread through their entire bodies, making them jump and bounce, was the first sign of the excitement caused by their arrival.
es: The little Gardiners, drawn by the sight of a carriage, stood on the steps of the house as it made its way up the driveway. When the carriage stopped at the door, the joyful surprise that shone on their faces and made them jump around was the prelude to their welcome.

en: Elizabeth jumped out; and after giving each of them a hasty kiss, hurried into the vestibule, where Jane, who came running downstairs from her mother’s apartment, immediately met her.
vi: Elizabeth jumped down from the carriage, quickly kissed each child, and ran into the front hall while Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner were busy with their children and Jane was running down the stairs from their parents' room.
tr: Elizabeth rushed outside; after hastily kissing each one, she darted to the hall; Jane came running out of her mother's room and immediately greeted her.
es: Elizabeth gave each one a kiss and ran to the hall, where she met Jane who was hurrying down from their mother's room.

en: Elizabeth, as she affectionately embraced her, whilst tears filled the eyes of both, lost not a moment in asking whether anything had been heard of the fugitives.
vi: Elizabeth affectionately hugged her sister, tears streaming down but not wasting a moment. She asked if there was any news of the two who had run away.
tr: As Elizabeth embraced him with love, while tears filled both of their eyes, she asked without losing a moment if there was any news about the fugitives.
es: They embraced warmly, with eyes full of tears, and Elizabeth asked without wasting a second if there had been any news of the fugitives.

en: “Not yet,” replied Jane. “But now that my dear uncle is come, I hope everything will be well.”
vi: Jane replied: - Not yet. But now that you are here, I hope everything will be fine.
tr: "Not yet," Jane replied. "But now that my uncle is here, I hope everything will be alright.""
es: ––Not yet ––replied Jane––, but now that our dear uncle has arrived, I hope everything goes well.

en: “Is my father in town?”
vi: - Has Dad gone to the city?
tr: "Is my father in the city?"
es: ––Is Dad in the capital?

en: “Yes, he went on Tuesday, as I wrote you word.”
vi: - Yes, he left on Tuesday as you mentioned in the letter.
tr: "Yes, he went on Tuesday, while I was writing you a letter."
es: ––Yes, he left on Tuesday, as I wrote to you.

en: “And have you heard from him often?”
vi: - And have you heard from Dad often?
tr: "Have you heard from him often?""
es: ––And what news have you had of him?

en: “We have heard only once. He wrote me a few lines on Wednesday, to say that he had arrived in safety, and to give me his directions, which I particularly begged him to do. He merely added, that he should not write again, till he had something of importance to mention.”
vi: - The family only received news once. Dad wrote a few lines to my sister on Wednesday, saying that he had arrived safely. He only added that he would not send any more letters unless there was important news.
tr: "I received it once. He wrote a few lines on Wednesday, saying he arrived safely, and gave his address, which I had specifically requested. He said he wouldn't write again unless he had something important to say."
es: ––Few. On Wednesday, he sent me a few lines saying that he had arrived safely and giving me his address, as I had asked him to. He only added that he wouldn't write again until he had something important to tell us.

en: “And my mother—how is she? How are you all?”
vi: - And mother, how is she? How is the whole family?
tr: "And my mother – How is she? How are you all?"
es: ––And mom, how is she? How are all of you?

en: “My mother is tolerably well, I trust; though her spirits are greatly shaken. She is upstairs, and will have great satisfaction in seeing you all. She does not yet leave her dressing-room. Mary and Kitty, thank Heaven! are quite well.”
vi: - Mother is enduring quite well, I believe; although her spirit is in crisis. She is lying upstairs, and will be very happy to see everyone again. Mary and Kitty, thank God, are both normal.
tr: "My mother is doing fairly well; her morale is very low though. She is upstairs; she will be happy to see you. She hasn't come out of her room yet. Mary and Kitty, thank goodness, are very well."
es: ––Mom is fine, as far as I can see, although very downcast. She is upstairs and will have great satisfaction in seeing you all. She still hasn't left her room. Mary and Catherine are perfectly well, thank God.

en: “But you—how are you?” cried Elizabeth. “You look pale. How much you must have gone through!”
vi: Elizabeth exclaimed: - But what about you, how are you? You look pale. You've had to go through so much suffering?
tr: "Well, you – How are you?" cried Elizabeth. "You look pale. Who knows what you've been through!"
es: ––And you, how are you feeling? ––asked Elizabeth––. You look pale. You must have gone through so much!

en: Her sister, however, assured her of her being perfectly well; and their conversation, which had been passing while Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner were engaged with their children, was now put an end to by the approach of the whole party. Jane ran to her uncle and aunt, and welcomed and thanked them both, with alternate smiles and tears.
vi: But the older sister reassured that she was completely healthy, their conversation was interrupted when the uncle and aunt entered. Jane ran to them, greeted and thanked them with smiles mixed with tears.
tr: However, her sister assured her that she was quite well; the conversation that was taking place among them ended as Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner were occupied with their children and all approached together. Jane ran to her uncle and aunt, greeted them, and oscillating between tears and smiles, thanked them both.
es: But Jane assured her that she was very well. Meanwhile, Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner, who had been busy with their children, arrived and put an end to the conversation between the two sisters. Jane ran to her aunt and uncle and welcomed and thanked them with tears and smiles.

en: When they were all in the drawing-room, the questions which Elizabeth had already asked were of course repeated by the others, and they soon found that Jane had no intelligence to give. The sanguine hope of good, however, which the benevolence of her heart suggested, had not yet deserted her; she still expected that it would all end well, and that every morning would bring some letter, either from Lydia or her father, to explain their proceedings, and, perhaps, announce the marriage.
vi: When everyone had entered the living room, the couple repeated the same questions as Elizabeth, and found that Jane had no news. However, the optimistic hope from her gentle heart remained; she still hoped that everything would end well, and each morning she expected to receive a letter, either from Lydia or from her father, to explain what the two had done and perhaps to announce a wedding.
tr: When they gathered in the living room, the questions Elizabeth asked were naturally repeated by the others, and they saw that Jane had no news to share. Nevertheless, the hope inspired by the innocence in her heart had not yet abandoned her; she still hoped that everything would end well, that every morning would bring a letter either from Lydia or her father explaining what had happened and perhaps announcing the marriage.
es: Once gathered in the living room, the questions asked by Elizabeth were repeated by the others, and they saw that poor Jane had no new information. But her ardent confidence that everything would end well had not abandoned her; she still hoped that one of these mornings a letter from Lydia or her father would arrive explaining the events and perhaps announcing the marriage.

en: Mrs. Bennet, to whose apartment they all repaired, after a few minutes’ conversation together, received them exactly as might be expected; with tears and lamentations of regret, invectives against the villainous conduct of Wickham, and complaints of her own sufferings and ill-usage; blaming everybody but the person to whose ill-judging indulgence the errors of her daughter must be principally owing.
vi: After a few minutes of conversation, they went together to Mrs. Bennet's room. She received them in the manner they had anticipated, with tears and lamentations, insults to Wickham's character, and complaints about the suffering and mistreatment she was enduring. She blamed everyone while the less knowledgeable had indulged the faults of the daughter who should have blamed herself.
tr: After talking privately for a few minutes, they went up to Mrs. Bennet's room, where she received them exactly as expected: with tears of regret and pleas, curses directed at Wickham's vile behavior, complaints about her own suffering and misfortune, and blaming everyone except the one responsible for the neglect that was the main cause of her daughter's mistakes.
es: Mrs. Bennet, to whose room they all went up after their brief conversation, received them as expected: with tears and lamentations, reproaches against Wickham's villainous conduct, and complaints about her own sufferings, blaming everyone except the one who, due to her tolerance and poor judgment, was mainly responsible for her daughter's mistakes.

en: “If I had been able,” said she, “to carry my point in going to Brighton with all my family, this would not have happened: but poor dear Lydia had nobody to take care of her. Why did the Forsters ever let her go out of their sight? I am sure there was some great neglect or other on their side, for she is not the kind of girl to do such a thing, if she had been well looked after. I always thought they were very unfit to have the charge of her; but I was over-ruled, as I always am. Poor, dear child! And now here’s Mr. Bennet gone away, and I know he will fight Wickham, wherever he meets him, and then he will be killed, and what is to become of us all? The Collinses will turn us out, before he is cold in his grave; and if you are not kind to us, brother, I do not know what we shall do.”
vi: She said: - If everyone had listened to my opinion and all gone to Brighton, this wouldn't have happened; but poor little Lydia had no one to look after her. Why didn't the Forsters take care of her? I'm sure they were negligent or something, because the girl wouldn't have done such a thing if she had been properly cared for. I've always thought they weren't capable of looking after the girl, but no one ever listens to me, as always. Poor little girl! And now Mr. Bennet is away, I know he will confront Wickham wherever he meets him, and then he will be killed, and what will become of all of us? The Collinses will throw us out before his grave is even green, dear brother, if you are not kind to us, I don't know how we will survive.
tr: "If only I could," she said, "if I had carried out my plan to go to Brighton with my whole family, none of this would have happened; but there was no one to keep an eye on poor Lydia. Why did the Forsters take their eyes off her? I think they must have been greatly negligent in some way or another, otherwise Lydia is not the kind of girl to do such a thing; they did not keep a good eye on her, that's why this happened. I always knew they were not capable of taking responsibility for her, but who listens to me, when did they ever listen anyway. Oh, my poor girl! Now Mr. Bennet has gone; I know he will fight Wickham when he sees him, then he will be killed, and what will happen to us then? The Collinses will throw us out of the house before his body is even cold in the grave; if you don't reach out to us, brother, God knows what will become of us."
es: ––If I had been able ––he said–– to carry out my plan of going to Brighton with my whole family, this would not have happened; but poor Lydia had no one to look after her. The Forsters should not have lost sight of her. If they had watched her closely, she would not have done such a thing, Lydia is not that kind of girl. I always knew that the Forsters were very unsuitable to take care of her, but no one listened to me, as always. My poor girl! And now Bennet has gone and I suppose he will challenge Wickham wherever he finds him, and since he will die in the duel, what will become of us? The Collins will throw us out of here before he is cold in his grave, and if you, my brother, do not assist us, I don't know what we will do.

en: They all exclaimed against such terrific ideas; and Mr. Gardiner, after general assurances of his affection for her and all her family, told her that he meant to be in London the very next day, and would assist Mr. Bennet in every endeavour for recovering Lydia.
vi: They all refuted such terrible opinions; Mr. Gardiner reassured her about his feelings for her and for her entire family, then he told her he planned to go to London the next day, and would try to help Mr. Bennet in every way to find Lydia.
tr: They all objected to such pessimistic thoughts in unison; after Mr. Gardiner expressed how fond he was of her and her entire family, he mentioned that he was considering going to London the next day and would assist Mr. Bennet in every way to find Lydia.
es: Everyone protested against such terrifying ideas. Mr. Gardiner assured her that they would not lack his support and said that he planned to be in London the next day to help Mr. Bennet with all his efforts to find Lydia.

en: “Do not give way to useless alarm,” added he: “though it is right to be prepared for the worst, there is no occasion to look on it as certain. It is not quite a week since they left Brighton. In a few days more, we may gain some news of them; and till we know that they are not married, and have no design of marrying, do not let us give the matter over as lost. As soon as I get to town, I shall go to my brother, and make him come home with me to Gracechurch Street, and then we may consult together as to what is to be done.”
vi: He added: - Please don't panic as it won't do any good; although we should prepare for the worst-case scenario, we shouldn't think that it will definitely happen like that. The two people left Brighton less than a week ago. In the next few days, we hope to receive some news about them, and since we don't know if they have married or intend to marry, we shouldn't think that all is lost. When I get to the city, I will immediately go see my brother and invite him to go with me to Gracechurch Street, then we will discuss together what to do.
tr: "Don't panic unnecessarily," he added, "it's right to be prepared for the worst, but there's no point in seeing it as a done deal. It hasn't even been a week since they left Brighton. Let's wait a few more days, we'll hear from them; until we learn that they haven't married and aren't planning to marry, let's not consider the matter lost. As soon as I get to the city, I'll find my uncle, take him to Gracechurch Street, to our house; then we'll sit down and discuss what we should do."
es: ––Do not alarm yourselves needlessly ––he added––; although it is good to prepare for the worst, it should not be taken for granted. It has not even been a week since they left Brighton. In a few more days we will find out something; and until we know that they are not married and have no intentions of being so, let us not consider the matter lost. As soon as I arrive in London, I will pick up my brother and take him to Gracechurch Street; together we will deliberate on what needs to be done.

en: “Oh, my dear brother,” replied Mrs. Bennet, “that is exactly what I could most wish for. And now do, when you get to town, find them out, wherever they may be; and if they are not married already, make them marry. And as for wedding clothes, do not let them wait for that, but tell Lydia she shall have as much money as she chooses to buy them, after they are married. And, above all things, keep Mr. Bennet from fighting. Tell him what a dreadful state I am in—that I am frightened out of my wits; and have such tremblings, such flutterings all over me, such spasms in my side, and pains in my head, and such beatings at my heart, that I can get no rest by night nor by day. And tell my dear Lydia not to give any directions about her clothes till she has seen me, for she does not know which are the best warehouses. Oh, brother, how kind you are! I know you will contrive it all.”
vi: Mrs. Bennet replied: - Oh! My dear brother, this is exactly what I long for. And please, when you get to the city and find them, wherever they may be, if they are not yet married, help advise them to get married. Regarding the wedding dress, tell them not to wait, but please tell Lydia she will have the money she wants to shop after the wedding. Above all, keep Mr. Bennet away from any conflicts. Tell him about my miserable state – that I am so terrified I can't think straight, I am trembling, speaking incoherently, having spasms on both sides, headaches, rapid heartbeat, to the point that I cannot rest day or night. Please tell Lydia not to rush into buying clothes before seeing me again, as she doesn't know where to buy at a cheap price. Oh, my dear brother, you are so kind! I know you will take care of everything.
tr: "Ah my dear brother," replied Mrs. Bennet, "I was just saying the same thing. When you go to the city, find them, wherever they are; if they haven't married, make them marry. They shouldn't wait for wedding dresses or anything; tell Lydia to just get married first, and then we can buy whatever dress she wants, no matter the cost. But most importantly, don't involve Mr. Bennet in any fights. Tell him how terribly I am, –say that I've lost my mind from fear, that I'm trembling, having convulsions, suffering from chest pains, headaches, my heart is pounding, and I'm in such a state that I have neither night nor day. Also tell my sweet Lydia not to get into the matter of clothes until she sees me because she doesn't know which shop is good. Oh brother, how kind you are! You can handle all of this."
es: ––Oh, my dear brother! exclaimed Mrs. Bennet––, that is precisely my greatest wish. When you get to London, find them wherever they are, and if they are not married, make them get married. Do not allow them to delay the wedding for the bridal gown, tell Lydia that she will have all the money she wants to buy it afterwards. And above all, prevent Bennet from dueling with Wickham. Tell him the horrible state I am in: shattered, distraught, with such trembling and agitation, such convulsions in my side, such headaches and such palpitations that I cannot rest either day or night. And tell my dear Lydia not to order her dresses until she has seen me, for she does not know which are the best stores. Oh, brother! How good you are! I know you will sort everything out.

en: But Mr. Gardiner, though he assured her again of his earnest endeavours in the cause, could not avoid recommending moderation to her, as well in her hopes as her fears; and after talking with her in this manner till dinner was on table, they left her to vent all her feelings on the housekeeper, who attended in the absence of her daughters.
vi: But Mr. Gardiner, despite reassuring three more times that he would try, still wanted to advise her to remain calm in both hope and fear. They tried to console her in this way until dinner time, then they left her to pour out all her thoughts to the housekeeper who came to take care of her while the daughters had their meal.
tr: Although Mr. Gardiner expressed that he would do his best for that purpose, he could not refrain from advising him to be moderate in both his fears and hopes; after talking to him in this way until dinner was served, they left his side so that he could vent all his emotions to the butler who had taken over his daughter's duties in her absence.
es: Mr. Gardiner repeated to her that he would do everything he could and advised her to moderate her hopes and fears. He conversed with her in this manner until the meal was on the table, and left her to vent with the housekeeper who assisted her in the absence of her daughters.

en: Though her brother and sister were persuaded that there was no real occasion for such a seclusion from the family, they did not attempt to oppose it; for they knew that she had not prudence enough to hold her tongue before the servants, while they waited at table, and judged it better that one only of the household, and the one whom they could most trust, should comprehend all her fears and solicitude on the subject.
vi: Even though the younger brother and sister-in-law believed there was no reason to isolate her from the family like that, they did not object because they knew she was not careful enough to keep her mouth shut with the servants when they served at the table. So it was better to have only one servant, the most trusted one, who knew about all her tears and worries regarding the matter.
tr: His brother and sister-in-law thought there was no reason to hide it from the family, but they did not try to oppose it either, because they knew he did not have the common sense to hold his tongue in front of the servants while waiting at the table, and they decided that it would be appropriate for just one person among the servants, the one they trusted the most, to witness his fears and concerns about the matter.
es: Although his brother and sister-in-law were convinced that there was no reason for him not to come down to eat, they did not dare ask him to sit with them at the table, because they feared his imprudence in front of the servants and thought it preferable that only one of them, the one they could trust the most, should learn of his troubles.

en: In the dining-room they were soon joined by Mary and Kitty, who had been too busily engaged in their separate apartments to make their appearance before. One came from her books, and the other from her toilette. The faces of both, however, were tolerably calm; and no change was visible in either, except that the loss of her favourite sister, or the anger which she had herself incurred in the business, had given something more of fretfulness than usual to the accents of Kitty. As for Mary, she was mistress enough of herself to whisper to Elizabeth, with a countenance of grave reflection, soon after they were seated at table,—
vi: Mary and Kitty came to dine together after being busy in their respective rooms, one occupied with books, the other preoccupied with makeup. However, both appeared quite calm, with no noticeable changes, except that Kitty seemed more irritable than usual, due to the loss of her beloved younger sibling and the anger she had caused within the family. As for Mary, she had matured enough to whisper to Elizabeth with a serious expression.
tr: Mary and Kitty, who had been too busy to appear earlier in their own rooms, joined them in the dining room. One came from her books, the other from her dressing table. Both of their faces were quite calm; apart from the loss of their beloved sister or the unusual annoyance in Kitty's manner of speaking caused by the anger she had gathered because of it, there was no visible change. As for Mary, she was composed enough to whisper to Elizabeth with a face full of serious thought right after sitting at the table,
es: In the dining room appeared Mary and Catherine, who had been too busy in their rooms to show up earlier. One had just put down her books and the other her vanity. But both were very calm and did not seem upset. Only the latter had a more irate tone than usual, whether due to the loss of the favorite sister or the anger of not finding herself in her place. Shortly after sitting at the table, Mary, very sure of herself, whispered to Elizabeth with an air of gravity in her reflection:

en: “This is a most unfortunate affair, and will probably be much talked of. But we must stem the tide of malice, and pour into the wounded bosoms of each other the balm of sisterly consolation.”
vi: - This is the most unfortunate event, and it will probably be talked about the most. But we must strive to overcome malice, and pour into each wounded heart the comfort of sisterly love.
tr: "A very unfortunate situation; it will probably be talked about a lot. But we must stop the winds of evil and apply the balm of brotherhood's consolation to each other's wounded chests."
es: It is a very unfortunate matter and will probably be much talked about; but we must overcome the wave of malice and pour the balm of fraternal comfort over our wounded hearts.

en: Then perceiving in Elizabeth no inclination of replying, she added, “Unhappy as the event must be for Lydia, we may draw from it this useful lesson:—that loss of virtue in a female is irretrievable, that one false step involves her in endless ruin, that her reputation is no less brittle than it is beautiful, and that she cannot be too much guarded in her behaviour towards the undeserving of the other sex.”
vi: Then, noticing that Elizabeth had no intention of replying, she added: - Although the event was unfortunate for Lydia, we can draw a useful lesson from it, which is: a single misstep can cause immense ruin, reputation is as fragile as beauty, and maintaining propriety in one's attitude towards ordinary boys cannot be overemphasized.
tr: Then, seeing that Elizabeth had no intention of replying, he added, "Although it is a grievous incident for Lydia, we must derive a useful lesson from it; a woman's loss of honor is irreparable – a single misstep can darken a woman's world – a woman's virtue is as beautiful as it is fragile – her behavior towards the worthless members of the opposite sex can never be too cautious.""
es: Upon arriving here, he noticed that Elizabeth did not feel like answering, and added: ––Although it may be a misfortune for Lydia, for us it can be a valuable lesson: the loss of virtue in a woman is irreparable; a single misstep carries within it the final ruin; her reputation is no less fragile than her beauty, and she can never be cautious enough in her behavior towards the indignities of the other sex.

en: Elizabeth lifted up her eyes in amazement, but was too much oppressed to make any reply. Mary, however, continued to console herself with such kind of moral extractions from the evil before them.
vi: Elizabeth looked up in astonishment, but her mind was too heavy for her to respond. However, Mary continued to console herself with quotes from books on ethics.
tr: Elizabeth raised her eyes in astonishment, but she was too distressed to respond. Nevertheless, Mary continued to occupy herself with making such moral inferences from the disaster ahead of them.
es: Elizabeth, astonished, raised her eyes, but she was too distressed to respond. Mary continued consoling herself with moral lessons of the sort drawn from the misfortune before them.

en: In the afternoon, the two elder Miss Bennets were able to be for half an hour by themselves; and Elizabeth instantly availed herself of the opportunity of making any inquiries which Jane was equally eager to satisfy. After joining in general lamentations over the dreadful sequel of this event, which Elizabeth considered as all but certain, and Miss Bennet could not assert to be wholly impossible, the former continued the subject by saying, “But tell me all and everything about it which I have not already heard. Give me further particulars. What did Colonel Forster say? Had they no apprehension of anything before the elopement took place? They must have seen them together for ever.”
vi: In the afternoon, the two eldest Bennet sisters had some time to sit alone together, and Elizabeth immediately inquired about many things, with Jane willing to respond amidst lamentations about the dreadful consequences of the affair. Elizabeth asked: - But please tell me all the details that I haven't heard yet. What did Colonel Forster say? Did they notice any signs before the two ran away? They must have seen the two of them always together?
tr: In the afternoon, the two eldest Miss Bennets managed to stay alone together for about half an hour; Elizabeth seized the opportunity and immediately asked many questions, and Jane answered with equal eagerness. According to Elizabeth, the only certain thing about this event was the dreadful conclusion that Miss Bennet could not quite deny as impossible. After lamenting over it together, Elizabeth continued: "Tell me everything about this that I haven't heard yet, one by one. Give me more details. What did Colonel Forster say? Didn't they notice anything before they ran away? They must have seen the two of them together all the time."
es: In the afternoon, the two eldest Bennet daughters were able to be alone for half an hour, and Elizabeth immediately took the opportunity to ask some questions that Jane was equally eager to answer. After lamenting together about the terrible consequences of the event, which Elizabeth took for granted and the other could not assure were impossible, the former said: Tell me everything I don't know. Give me more details. What did Colonel Forster say? Didn't he have any suspicion about the escape? They must have always seen them together.

en: “Colonel Forster did own that he had often suspected some partiality, especially on Lydia’s side, but nothing to give him any alarm. I am so grieved for him. His behaviour was attentive and kind to the utmost. He was coming to us, in order to assure us of his concern, before he had any idea of their not being gone to Scotland: when that apprehension first got abroad, it hastened his journey.”
vi: - Colonel Forster said he suspected the two had feelings for each other, especially on Lydia's part, but didn't see anything to worry about. She felt sorry for him. His attitude was very attentive and kind. He was coming here to express his concerns before he knew they weren't going to Scotland. As soon as he got the news, he hurried on his way.
tr: "Colonel Forster admitted that he often suspected from close proximity, especially regarding Lydia, but nothing had happened to alarm him. I felt very sorry for him. He behaved extremely close and concerned. He was coming to us to make sure of his interest before the idea that they hadn't gone to Scotland occurred to him, and that idea hastened his journey."
es: ––Colonel Forster confessed that he once noticed some interest, especially on Lydia's part, but he saw nothing that alarmed him. I feel sorry for him. He was most attentive and kind. He was planning to come see us before knowing they hadn't gone to Scotland, and when it was presumed they were in London, he hastened his trip.

en: “And was Denny convinced that Wickham would not marry? Did he know of their intending to go off? Had Colonel Forster seen Denny himself?”
vi: - And does Danny firmly believe that Wickham will refuse to get married? Does he know anything about the two eloping? Did Colonel Forster meet Danny?
tr: "So, you believe that Denny will not marry Wickham? Did he know that they were planning to elope? Did Colonel Forster see Denny himself?"
es: ––And Denny, was he convinced that Wickham would not get married? Did he know they were going to elope? Has Colonel Forster seen Denny?

en: “Yes; but when questioned by him, Denny denied knowing anything of their plan, and would not give his real opinion about it. He did not repeat his persuasion of their not marrying, and from that I am inclined to hope he might have been misunderstood before.”
vi: - Yes, but when he was questioned by him, he said he didn't know anything about their plan and didn't give any opinion on the matter. He didn't repeat what he believed, that they wouldn't get married, and from this, she hoped he had previously misunderstood.
tr: "Yes; but when questioned, Denny denied knowing about the plans and did not reveal his true opinion on the matter. He did not repeat that he thought they would not marry – from this, I hope that he might have been previously misunderstood."
es: ––Yes, but when he was questioned, Denny said he wasn't aware of anything and refused to give his true opinion on the matter. He didn't repeat his conviction that they wouldn't get married, and that's why I think he might have misunderstood it.

en: “And till Colonel Forster came himself, not one of you entertained a doubt, I suppose, of their being really married?”
vi: - Do you think that before Colonel Forster came here, no one in the family suspected that they would actually get married, right?
tr: "Until Colonel Forster came in person, none of you really doubted that they would get married, did you?"
es: ––I suppose that until Colonel Forster came, no one in the house doubted that they were married.

en: “How was it possible that such an idea should enter our brains? I felt a little uneasy—a little fearful of my sister’s happiness with him in marriage, because I knew that his conduct had not been always quite right. My father and mother knew nothing of that; they only felt how imprudent a match it must be. Kitty then owned, with a very natural triumph on knowing more than the rest of us, that in Lydia’s last letter she had prepared her for such a step. She had known, it seems, of their being in love with each other many weeks.”
vi: - How could such a thought have entered our minds! She felt a little worried – a little fearful about the happiness of the girl in her marriage with him, because she knew his character was not always proper. Both father and mother knew nothing about this; they only thought that the marriage was too hasty. Then, with the pride of knowing more than others, Kitty revealed that in Lydia's last letter, the girl had prepared her sister for this matter. It seemed that Kitty had known for weeks that they had feelings for each other.
tr: "But how could such a thing even cross our minds! I was a bit uneasy – I was slightly afraid that she would marry him and be unhappy, because I knew that the man's behavior was not always proper. My parents didn't know this; they just thought it was an imprudent marriage. Then Kitty, with the rightful pride of knowing more than us, confessed in Lydia's last letter that she was preparing to take such a step. Apparently, she knew they had been in love for weeks."
es: ––How could such a thing occur to us? I felt sad because I know it is difficult for my sister to be happy marrying Wickham due to his terrible background. Our parents knew nothing of this, but they realized the imprudence of such a wedding. Then Catherine confessed, very satisfied to know more than us, that Lydia's last letter already hinted at what they were plotting. It seems that she said they had been in love for a few weeks.

en: “But not before they went to Brighton?”
vi: - But not from before they went to Brighton, right?
tr: "Not until I go to Brighton.""
es: ––But not before going to Brighton.

en: “No, I believe not.”
vi: - That's right.
tr: "No, I don't think so."
es: ––I don't think so.

en: “And did Colonel Forster appear to think ill of Wickham himself? Does he know his real character?”
vi: - And it seems that Colonel Forster himself had a poor opinion of Wickham, didn't he? Did he know Wickham's true nature?
tr: "Was Colonel Forster blaming Wickham? Does he know his true character?"
es: ––And Colonel Forster, does he have a bad opinion of Wickham? Does he know what he is really like?

en: “I must confess that he did not speak so well of Wickham as he formerly did. He believed him to be imprudent and extravagant; and since this sad affair has taken place, it is said that he left Meryton greatly in debt: but I hope this may be false.”
vi: - You must admit that he doesn't speak about Wickham as favorably as he did before. Since this unfortunate incident occurred, it is said that he has many debts in Meryton, but I hope this is not true.
tr: "I must admit that I do not speak as well of Wickham as I used to. He is believed to be indifferent and frivolous. It is said that he left a lot of debt when he departed from Meryton since that unfortunate incident, but I hope it is not true."
es: ––I must confess that he did not speak as well of him as before. He considers him imprudent and a spendthrift. And it is said that he has left great debts in Meryton, but I hope it is not true.

en: “Oh, Jane, had we been less secret, had we told what we knew of him, this could not have happened!”
vi: - Oh, Jane, if we hadn't been so secretive, if we had told everyone what we knew about him, this wouldn't have happened!
tr: "Ah Jane, if we had kept fewer secrets and told you what we knew about you, none of this might have happened."
es: ––Oh, Jane! If we hadn't been so reserved and had said what we knew about Wickham, this wouldn't have happened.

en: “Perhaps it would have been better,” replied her sister.
vi: - Maybe it would be better.
tr: "Maybe it would have been better," her sister replied.
es: ––Maybe it would have been better ––replied her sister––, but it is not fair to publish a person's past mistakes, ignoring whether they have corrected them.

en: “But to expose the former faults of any person, without knowing what their present feelings were, seemed unjustifiable.”
vi: But exposing someone's past mistakes without knowing their current state of mind seems unfair.
tr: "But it might seem unjust to reveal a person's past mistakes without knowing their current feelings.
es: ––Maybe it would have been better ––replied her sister––, but it is not fair to publish a person's past mistakes, ignoring whether they have corrected them.

en: “We acted with the best intentions.”
vi: We acted with the best intentions.
tr: We acted with good intentions."
es: We acted in good faith.

en: “Could Colonel Forster repeat the particulars of Lydia’s note to his wife?”
vi: - Did Colonel Forster mention anything about the contents of Lydia's letter to his wife?
tr: "Did Colonel Forster explain the details of the letter he wrote to Lydia's wife?""
es: ––Did Colonel Forster repeat the details of the note that Lydia left for his wife?

en: “He brought it with him for us to see.”
vi: - You brought that letter here for the household to read.
tr: "He brought it along so we could see.""
es: ––He brought it with him to show it to us.

en: Jane then took it from her pocket-book, and gave it to Elizabeth. These were the contents:—
vi: Then Jane took out the letter and handed it to Elizabeth. The content of the letter was as follows:
tr: Jane took the letter out of her notebook and gave it to Elizabeth. The content of the letter was as follows:
es: Jane took it out of her purse and gave it to Elizabeth. This was its content:

en: “My dear Harriet,
vi: "Dear Harriet,
tr: "Dear Harriet,
es: Dear Harriet,

en: “You will laugh when you know where I am gone, and I cannot help laughing myself at your surprise to-morrow morning, as soon as I am missed. I am going to Gretna Green, and if you cannot guess with who, I shall think you a simpleton, for there is but one man in the world I love, and he is an angel. I should never be happy without him, so think it no harm to be off. You need not send them word at Longbourn of my going, if you do not like it, for it will make the surprise the greater when I write to them, and sign my name Lydia Wickham. What a good joke it will be! I can hardly write for laughing. Pray make my excuses to Pratt for not keeping my engagement, and dancing with him to-night. Tell him I hope he will excuse me when he knows all, and tell him I will dance with him at the next ball we meet with great pleasure. I shall send for my clothes when I get to Longbourn; but I wish you would tell Sally to mend a great slit in my worked muslin gown before they are packed up. Good-bye. Give my love to Colonel Forster. I hope you will drink to our good journey.
vi: You will laugh when you know that I am about to leave, and I cannot help but laugh when I think of your surprise tomorrow morning, right after I am absent. I intend to go to Gretna Green, and if you cannot guess who I am going with, I will think you are foolish, because there is only one person in the world whom I love, he is an angel. I will never be happy without him, so please do not worry about me. If you do not accept my departure, please do not inform Longbourn about this, because I want to give them a bigger surprise when I write to them and sign as Lydia Wickham. What a joke! I will probably laugh so hard that I cannot write. Please apologize to Mr. Pratt for me, tell him I will be very happy to dance with him at the first ball I see him again. I will ask for my clothes to be sent to me when I get to Longbourn; but please tell Sally to mend the tear in the muslin dress before sending it. Goodbye. Please send my regards to Colonel Forster, I hope you will drink to my journey.
tr: When you learn that I have gone, you will laugh; I cannot help but laugh myself when I think of how surprised you will be when you cannot find me tomorrow. I am going to Gretna Green; if you cannot guess with whom, I will call you a fool, because there is only one man in the world that I love, and he is an angel. I can never be happy without him, so I see no harm in going. You need not inform those at Longbourn of my departure, if you do not wish to, because the surprise will be greater when I write to them and sign my name as Lydia Wickham. What a delightful joke it will be! I cannot write for laughing. Please make up something for Pratt on my behalf, as I cannot go to the dance with him tonight. Say that I hope he will forgive me when he learns everything, and also say that I will dance with him with great pleasure at the first ball when we meet again. When I go to Longbourn, I will send for my clothes; but I wish you would tell Sally to mend the large tear in my embroidered muslin dress before it is packed. Goodbye. Give my love to Colonel Forster; I hope you will raise a glass to wish us a good journey.
es: You will laugh when you find out where I have gone, and I can't stop laughing myself thinking about the fright you will get tomorrow when you don't find me. I'm going to Gretna Green, and if you don't guess with whom, I will think you're a fool, because he is the only man I love in the world, so I don't think I'm doing anything foolish by going with him. If you don't want to, don't tell my family, as it will be a bigger surprise when I write to them and sign as Lydia Wickham. It will be a great joke! I can hardly write from laughing. I beg you to excuse me with Pratt for not fulfilling my commitment to dance with him tonight; tell him I hope he will forgive me when he knows everything, and also that I will gladly dance with him at the first ball we meet. I will send for my dresses when I go to Longbourn, but tell Sally to fix the cut of the muslin dress from home before you pack it. Goodbye. Give my regards to Colonel Forster. I hope you will toast to our happy journey.

en: “Your affectionate friend,
vi: Grandma's little friend.
tr: Your friend who loves you,
es: Affectionate greetings from your friend,

en: “Lydia Bennet.”
vi: Lydia Bennet
tr: Lydia Bennet."
es: Lydia Bennet

en: “Oh, thoughtless, thoughtless Lydia!” cried Elizabeth when she had finished it. “What a letter is this, to be written at such a moment! But at least it shows that she was serious in the object of her journey. Whatever he might afterwards persuade her to, it was not on her side a scheme of infamy. My poor father! how he must have felt it!”
vi: Elizabeth exclaimed after reading the letter: - Oh! Foolish, that foolish Lydia! What kind of letter is this, written at this time. But at least it shows that she was serious about the purpose of the trip. Even if he later persuaded her in some other way, for her part, it was not a disgraceful intention. Poor father! I wonder what he was thinking!
tr: "Oh, foolish, foolish Lydia!" cried Elizabeth as she finished the letter. What a letter, to be written at such a time. But at least it shows she was serious about the journey. Whatever Wickham convinced her of later, Lydia did not have an immoral plan in mind. Poor father! Who knows how terrible he must feel!"
es: ––Oh, Lydia, how thoughtless! How thoughtless! ––exclaimed Elizabeth after finishing reading––. What a letter to be written at such a moment!
