es: ––Yes, yes, they must get married. There is no other option. But there are two points I want to clarify: first, how much money your uncle has advanced to resolve this, and second, how I am going to pay him back.

en: “Money! my uncle!” cried Jane, “what do you mean, sir?”
vi: Jane exclaimed: - Money! Your uncle! What do you mean, Dad?
tr: "Money! To my uncle!" Jane shouted, "what do you mean, sir?"
es: ––Money, my uncle? ––asked Jane––. What do you mean?

en: “I mean that no man in his proper senses would marry Lydia on so slight a temptation as one hundred a year during my life, and fifty after I am gone.”
vi: - Dad means that no one, like him, would want to marry Lydia just because he is tempted by one hundred pounds a year while Dad is still alive, and five thousand pounds after that.
tr: "What I mean is that no one in their right mind would marry Lydia for a flimsy reason like a hundred pounds a year while I'm alive, and fifty pounds a year after I'm gone."
es: ––I say that no man in his right mind would marry Lydia for such a slight temptation as one hundred pounds annually during my life and fifty when I die.

en: “That is very true,” said Elizabeth; “though it had not occurred to me before. His debts to be discharged, and something still to remain! Oh, it must be my uncle’s doings! Generous, good man, I am afraid he has distressed himself. A small sum could not do all this.”
vi: Elizabeth said: - That's right, although I didn't think of this. All his debts have been paid off, and there's even a little money left! Oh, this is arranged by your son! A generous, kind person, I'm afraid he has to suffer losses. A small amount of money can't do all this.
tr: "This is very true," said Elizabeth; "it hadn't occurred to me before. The debts will be paid off, and there will be something left over! Oh! It must be my uncle's doing! What a generous, kind-hearted man; I fear he has put himself in difficulty. These things couldn't have been done with little money."
es: ––It is very true ––said Elizabeth––; it hadn't occurred to me. Paid off his debts and still something left! That must be my uncle's doing. What a good and generous man! I fear he is in trouble, for with a small amount, you can't do all that.

en: “No,” said her father. “Wickham’s a fool if he takes her with a farthing less than ten thousand pounds: I should be sorry to think so ill of him, in the very beginning of our relationship.”
vi: - That's right. Wickham is a fool if he agrees to marry the girl for less than ten thousand pounds. Father regrets having to think badly of him when his relationship with the family has just begun.
tr: "No," said her father, "I would say Wickham is a fool if he accepts the girl for less than ten thousand pounds. It would upset me to think so badly of him at the beginning of our relationship."
es: ––No ––said Mr. Bennet––, Wickham is a fool if he accepts Lydia for less than ten thousand pounds. I would regret judging him so poorly when we are about to become relatives.

en: “Ten thousand pounds! Heaven forbid! How is half such a sum to be repaid?”
vi: - Ten thousand pounds! My God! How can one repay even half of such an amount?
tr: "Ten thousand pounds! God forbid! How can even half of such an amount be paid?"
es: ––Ten thousand pounds! God forbid! When could we ever pay half of that amount?

en: Mr. Bennet made no answer; and each of them, deep in thought, continued silent till they reached the house. Their father then went to the library to write, and the girls walked into the breakfast-room.
vi: Mr. Bennet did not reply, and each person, lost in their own thoughts, walked back home. The father went into the study to write a reply letter, while the two girls went into the breakfast room.
tr: Mr. Bennet did not reply; each walked in silence, deep in thought, all the way home. Their father went to the library to write, and the girls went to the breakfast room.
es: Mr. Bennet did not reply, and, absorbed in their thoughts, they continued in silence until they reached the house. The father went into the library to write, and the girls went to the dining room.

en: “And they are really to be married!” cried Elizabeth, as soon as they were by themselves. “How strange this is! and for this we are to be thankful. That they should marry, small as is their chance of happiness, and wretched as is his character, we are forced to rejoice! Oh, Lydia!”
vi: Elizabeth exclaimed, when only the two sisters were left alone: - And they are really going to get married! How strange! And we will be happy about this. We must be happy because they are getting married, no matter how slim their chances of happiness are, no matter how bad his character is. Oh, Lydia!
tr: "So they are really going to get married!" cried Elizabeth when they were alone. "How strange! Moreover, we have to be grateful for this. We have to be happy that they are getting married, even though their chances of happiness are low and the man's character is vile! Oh, Lydia!"
es: ––Are they really going to get married? ––exclaimed Elizabeth as soon as they were alone––. How strange! And we shall have to give thanks yet. Despite the slim chances of happiness in that marriage and Wickham's perfidy, we will still have to rejoice. Oh, Lydia!

en: “I comfort myself with thinking,” replied Jane, “that he certainly would not marry Lydia, if he had not a real regard for her. Though our kind uncle has done something towards clearing him, I cannot believe that ten thousand pounds, or anything like it, has been advanced. He has children of his own, and may have more. How could he spare half ten thousand pounds?”
vi: Jane replied: - She took comfort in thinking that he certainly wouldn't marry Lydia if he didn't truly love the girl. Although our kind uncle did something to untangle things for him, she didn't believe ten thousand pounds, or something like that, had been spent. Our uncle had children, and could have more. How could he possibly spend even half of the ten thousand pounds?
tr: "This is how I comfort myself," replied Lydia, "if he didn't really feel close, he would never have married Lydia." "Even if our kind-hearted uncle did something to clear his debts, I can't believe that ten thousand pounds or something similar has been paid." "He has his own children, and there could be more." "How could he set aside even half of ten thousand pounds?""
es: ––I console myself by thinking ––replied Jane–– that he surely wouldn't marry Lydia if he didn't love her. Although our kind uncle may have done something to save him, I can't believe he advanced ten thousand pounds or anything like that. He has children and may have more. He wouldn't be able to save even half of that amount.

en: “If we are ever able to learn what Wickham’s debts have been,” said Elizabeth, “and how much is settled on his side on our sister, we shall exactly know what Mr. Gardiner has done for them, because Wickham has not sixpence of his own. The kindness of my uncle and aunt can never be requited. Their taking her home, and affording her their personal protection and countenance, is such a sacrifice to her advantage as years of gratitude cannot enough acknowledge. By this time she is actually with them! If such goodness does not make her miserable now, she will never deserve to be happy! What a meeting for her, when she first sees my aunt!”
vi: Elizabeth said: - If we can find out about Wickham's debts and how much the payment is, we can know exactly how much Mr. Gardiner had to spend, because Wickham doesn't have a penny to his name. We can never repay the kindness of our uncle and aunt adequately. The fact that they took Lydia into their home and cared for her is a huge sacrifice that many years of gratitude cannot fully acknowledge. At this moment, the girl is already at their house! If this kindness does not make her feel remorseful now, she will never deserve happiness! I wonder how the meeting will go when she first sees our aunt!
tr: "If we can find out how much debt Wickham has," said Elizabeth, "and how much was settled on his behalf by our uncle, we will know exactly what Mr. Gardiner has done for them, because Wickham doesn't have a penny to his name. My uncle and aunt's kindness can never be repaid. Taking him into their home, giving him personal protection and support are such great sacrifices that years of thanks would not suffice. He is really with them right now! If such kindness doesn't make him feel terrible now, he will never deserve to be happy! How surprised he must have been when he first saw my aunt!"
es: ––If we could find out how much Wickham's debts amount to ––said Elizabeth–– and what dowry Uncle Gardiner is giving our sister, we would know exactly what he has done for them, since Wickham doesn't have a single shilling. We will never be able to repay Uncle's kindness. Taking her into his home and placing her under his personal care and protection is a sacrifice we can never thank him enough for. He must be with them now. If such kindness doesn't make her feel miserable, she will never deserve to be happy. What a shame for her to face our aunt!

en: “We must endeavour to forget all that has passed on either side,” said Jane: “I hope and trust they will yet be happy. His consenting to marry her is a proof, I will believe, that he is come to a right way of thinking. Their mutual affection will steady them; and I flatter myself they will settle so quietly, and live in so rational a manner, as may in time make their past imprudence forgotten.”
vi: Jane said: - We must try to forget what happened to both sides. I hope and believe that the two of you will be happy. I think his willingness to marry the girl is proof that he has thought things through properly. The love between the two of them will help them stay steadfast, and I am satisfied to see them settling into a quiet and proper life; over time, their past impulsiveness will be overlooked.
tr: "We must try to forget what happened on both sides," said Jane: "Still, I believe and trust that they will be happy. Her agreeing to marry is, in my opinion, proof that she has started to think correctly. Their mutual love will put them in order; my belief is that they will settle down calmly and lead a sensible life, and time will make them forget their past mistakes."
es: ––We must all try to forget what happened ––said Jane––: I hope they will still be happy. In my view, the fact that Wickham has agreed to marry is proof that he has taken the right path. Their mutual affection will make them settle down, and I trust it will make them so reasonable that, in time, they will make us forget their past imprudence:

en: “Their conduct has been such,” replied Elizabeth, “as neither you, nor I, nor anybody, can ever forget. It is useless to talk of it.”
vi: Elizabeth replied: - Their behavior was so terrible that you, or I, or anyone else, cannot forget it. There is no use in talking about this.
tr: "Your actions," replied Elizabeth, "can neither be forgotten by you, nor by me, nor by anyone else. It is useless to talk about it."
es: ––They have behaved in such a way ––replied Elizabeth–– that neither you, nor I, nor anyone will ever be able to forget it. It's useless to talk about it.

en: It now occurred to the girls that their mother was in all likelihood perfectly ignorant of what had happened. They went to the library, therefore, and asked their father whether he would not wish them to make it known to her. He was writing, and, without raising his head, coolly replied,—
vi: Now the two sisters realized that their mother still didn't know anything about what had happened. They went to the study and asked their father if he wanted them to inform their mother. The father, busy writing, did not look up and only replied:
tr: Then the girls realized that their mother was unaware of what had happened. So they went to the library and asked their father if he wanted to tell their mother about the development. Their father was writing and answered coldly without lifting his head,
es: It then occurred to the girls that their mother was completely unaware of all this. They went to the library and asked their father if he wanted them to tell her. Mr. Bennet was writing and, without raising his head, replied coldly:

en: “Just as you please.”
vi: - Up to you.
tr: "As you wish."
es: ––As you wish.

en: “May we take my uncle’s letter to read to her?”
vi: - Can we read your letter to mom?
tr: "Can we take my uncle's letter and read it to him?""
es: ––Can we show him Uncle Gardiner's letter?

en: “Take whatever you like, and get away.”
vi: - Do anything you want, and go outside.
tr: "Take whatever you want and leave.""
es: ––Teach him whatever you want and leave.

en: Elizabeth took the letter from his writing-table, and they went upstairs together. Mary and Kitty were both with Mrs. Bennet: one communication would, therefore, do for all. After a slight preparation for good news, the letter was read aloud. Mrs. Bennet could hardly contain herself. As soon as Jane had read Mr. Gardiner’s hope of Lydia’s being soon married, her joy burst forth, and every following sentence added to its exuberance. She was now in an irritation as violent from delight as she had ever been fidgety from alarm and vexation. To know that her daughter would be married was enough. She was disturbed by no fear for her felicity, nor humbled by any remembrance of her misconduct.
vi: Elizabeth took the letter placed on her father's writing desk, and they went upstairs together. Both Mary and Kitty were sitting in Mrs. Bennet's room, so it was only necessary to inform everyone once. Jane opened the letter to read. Mrs. Bennet could hardly contain herself. As soon as Jane read the part where Mr. Gardiner hoped Lydia would soon be married, she burst into joy, and each subsequent sentence added to her happiness. Knowing that her daughter would be married – that was all she needed. She did not worry whether her daughter would be happy, nor did she feel ashamed recalling her daughter's misdeeds.
tr: Elizabeth took the letter from the writing desk and they went upstairs together. Mary and Kitty were with Mrs. Bennet: telling it once would be enough for everyone. After a brief preparation for the good news, the letter was read aloud. Mrs. Bennet could barely contain herself. As soon as Jane read Mr. Gardiner's hope that Lydia would soon be married, her joy overflowed, and every subsequent sentence added to her happiness. As much as she had been distressed by fear and anxiety, she was now intensely excited by pleasure. Knowing that her daughter would soon be married was enough. She no longer feared for her daughter's happiness, nor did recalling her daughter's mistakes dampen her spirits.
es: Elizabeth picked up the letter from the desk and the two sisters went up to their mother's room. Mary and Catherine were with Mrs. Bennet, and therefore, they had to find out as well. After a slight preparation for the good news, the letter was read aloud. Mrs. Bennet could hardly contain herself, and as soon as Jane reached Mr. Gardiner's hopes that Lydia would soon be married, her joy burst forth, and every subsequent phrase increased it. The jubilation now produced an exaltation in her that anguish and sorrow had not caused. The main thing was that her daughter would get married; the fear that she might not be happy did not concern her in the least, nor did it humiliate her to think of her bad behavior.

en: “My dear, dear Lydia!” she cried: “this is delightful indeed! She will be married! I shall see her again! She will be married at sixteen! My good, kind brother! I knew how it would be—I knew he would manage everything. How I long to see her! and to see dear Wickham too! But the clothes, the wedding clothes! I will write to my sister Gardiner about them directly. Lizzy, my dear, run down to your father, and ask him how much he will give her. Stay, stay, I will go myself. Ring the bell, Kitty, for Hill. I will put on my things in a moment. My dear, dear Lydia! How merry we shall be together when we meet!”
vi: She exclaimed: - Oh my dear Lydia, my beloved daughter! This is such wonderful news! My little girl is getting married! I will see her again! She will be married at sixteen! And my kind, good brother! I knew how this would turn out – I knew he would take care of everything. I am so eager to see my little girl again! And to see dear Wickham too! But what about the outfits, the wedding outfits! I will write to Mrs. Gardiner about this. Lizzy, run down and find your father, ask him how much he will give your sister. Stay, stay here, I will go ask him. Kitty, ring the bell for Mrs. Hill. I will change my outfit. Lydia, my dear! How happy we will all be to see each other again!
tr: "Ah my dearest Lydia!" she exclaimed: "What delightful news! –She is going to get married! –I will see her again! –She will get married at sixteen! –Oh my kind-hearted sister! –I knew it would be like this –I knew you would sort everything out. How I long to see my daughter! And dear Wickham too! But the clothes, the wedding clothes! I must urgently write to my Aunt Gardiner about this. Lizzy, my dear, run to your father immediately, ask him how much he will give Lydia. Wait, wait, I'll go myself. Ring the bell, Kitty, let Hill come. Let me get dressed at once. Oh my dearest Lydia! –How happy we will all be when we are together!"
es: ––My dear, my beloved Lydia! ––he exclaimed––. It's wonderful! She will get married! I will see her again! Married at sixteen! Oh, how good and loving you are, my brother! I knew it would be like this, that everything would be sorted out! How eager I am to see her, and also dear Wickham! But, what about the dresses? And the wedding dress? I will write to my sister-in-law about that right now. Lizzy, my dear, run to see your father and ask him how much he is going to give. Wait, wait, I will go myself. Ring the bell, Catherine, so Hill can come. I will get dressed in a moment. My dear, my Lydia of my soul! How happy we will both be when we see each other!

en: Her eldest daughter endeavoured to give some relief to the violence of these transports, by leading her thoughts to the obligations which Mr. Gardiner’s behaviour laid them all under.
vi: The eldest daughter tried to curb her mother's intense pleasure by directing her thoughts to the family's gratitude for Mr. Gardiner's kindness.
tr: The eldest daughter tried to somewhat reduce the intensity of these outbursts by drawing attention to Mr. Gardiner's behavior and the obligations it imposed on everyone.
es: The older sister tried to moderate the violence of her excitement a little and to make her mother think about the obligations that Mr. Gardiner's behavior imposed on all of them.

en: “For we must attribute this happy conclusion,” she added, “in a great measure to his kindness. We are persuaded that he has pledged himself to assist Mr. Wickham with money.”
vi: She added: - We need to acknowledge that the good outcome is largely due to his kindness. We are certain he promised to support Mr. Wickham financially.
tr: "We owe this happy outcome," he added, "largely to his kindness. We believe he put himself forward by providing financial assistance to Mr. Wickham."
es: ––Well, we must attribute this happy outcome, he added–– to his generosity. We are convinced that he has helped Wickham with his money.

en: “Well,” cried her mother, “it is all very right; who should do it but her own uncle? If he had not had a family of his own, I and my children must have had all his money, you know; and it is the first time we have ever had anything from him except a few presents. Well! I am so happy. In a short time, I shall have a daughter married. Mrs. Wickham! How well it sounds! And she was only sixteen last June. My dear Jane, I am in such a flutter, that I am sure I can’t write; so I will dictate, and you write for me. We will settle with your father about the money afterwards; but the things should be ordered immediately.”
vi: The mother exclaimed: - Ah, that's great! If it's not you, who else would do this? Do you know, if he didn't have a family, your mother and you would receive all his money, and this is the first time our family has received anything from him, not counting a few gifts before. Ah, I feel so happy. Soon, I will have a daughter getting married. Mrs. Wickham! Sounds delightful. And she's only just turned sixteen. Last June. Jane, I'm too excited to write; I'll dictate and you write for me. Later we will discuss money matters with your father; but we should order the necessary items right away.
tr: "Oh," cried her mother, "what's the big deal; isn't he her uncle, of course he will do it! If he didn't have his own family, all his money would have gone to my children; besides, this is the first time we're seeing something from him, except for a few gifts. Honestly, I'm quite happy. Very soon, I will have a married daughter. Mrs. Wickham! How nice it sounds. And she just turned sixteen last June. Jane dear, I'm so flustered that I can't write; I'll tell you, and you write. We'll sort out the money issue with your father later; right now there are things that need to be ordered urgently."
es: ––Well ––exclaimed the mother––, it is very natural. Who else would have done it, but your uncle? If he hadn't had children, we would have inherited his fortune, you know, and this is the first time he has done something for us, apart from a few gifts. How happy I am! Soon I will have a married daughter: Mrs. Wickham! How well that sounds! And she just turned sixteen last June. Dear Jane, I am so excited that I won't be able to write; so I will dictate and you will write for me. Then we will determine with your father what to do about the money, but the other things must be arranged right now.

en: She was then proceeding to all the particulars of calico, muslin, and cambric, and would shortly have dictated some very plentiful orders, had not Jane, though with some difficulty, persuaded her to wait till her father was at leisure to be consulted. One day’s delay, she observed, would be of small importance; and her mother was too happy to be quite so obstinate as usual. Other schemes, too, came into her head.
vi: Then she went into detail about the fabric samples for making clothes, and might have read a long list of items to buy if Jane hadn't persuaded her, though with some difficulty, that she should wait to consult her father. Jane said that a delay of one day wouldn't matter, and her mother, being so overjoyed, was not as stubborn as usual. Other plans began to creep into her mind. She said:
tr: Then she started listing the details of linen, muslin, and calico, and was about to write down a full order when Jane, with difficulty, managed to convince her to wait for a suitable time to consult her father. One day's delay wouldn't matter, she said; her mother was too happy to be stubborn as usual. Other plans also came to her mind.
es: She was about to deal with all the particulars about silks, muslins, and batistes, and would have immediately given some orders if Jane had not convinced her, though with some difficulty, that she should first consult her husband. She made her understand that a day's delay would not have the slightest importance, and Mrs. Bennet was too happy to be as obstinate as always. Besides, other plans had already occurred to her:

en: “I will go to Meryton,” said she, “as soon as I am dressed, and tell the good, good news to my sister Philips. And as I come back, I can call on Lady Lucas and Mrs. Long. Kitty, run down and order the carriage. An airing would do me a great deal of good, I am sure. Girls, can I do anything for you in Meryton? Oh! here comes Hill. My dear Hill, have you heard the good news? Miss Lydia is going to be married; and you shall all have a bowl of punch to make merry at her wedding.”
vi: - I will go to Meryton as soon as I finish getting ready, to inform your Aunt Philips of the good news. And on the way back, I will stop by Lady Lucas and Mrs. Long. Kitty, run down and tell them to prepare the carriage. I think a little fresh air will do me good. Children, do you want me to buy anything in Meryton? Oh, look! Mrs. Hill has arrived. Mrs. Hill, have you heard the good news? Miss Lydia is getting married, and you will get to drink to your heart's content to celebrate her wedding day.
tr: "I am going to Meryton," she said, "as soon as I am dressed; I will give my sister Philips the good news. On my way back, I will call on Lady Lucas and Mrs. Long. Kitty, go down and order the carriage. A little fresh air will do me a lot of good, I am sure. Girls, can I do anything for you in Meryton? Oh, here comes Hill. Dear Hill, have you heard the good news? Miss Lydia is getting married, and you will make a bowl of punch and celebrate at the wedding."
es: ––I will go to Meryton as soon as I get dressed, to share such excellent news with my sister Philips. And on the way back I can visit Lady Lucas and Mrs. Long. Catherine, run downstairs and call for the carriage! I am sure that getting some fresh air will do me good. Girls, do you need anything from Meryton? Oh, here comes Hill. Dear Hill, have you heard the good news yet? Miss Lydia is going to get married, and to toast her wedding, you will have some punch.

en: Mrs. Hill began instantly to express her joy. Elizabeth received her congratulations amongst the rest, and then, sick of this folly, took refuge in her own room, that she might think with freedom. Poor Lydia’s situation must, at best, be bad enough; but that it was no worse, she had need to be thankful. She felt it so; and though, in looking forward, neither rational happiness, nor worldly prosperity could be justly expected for her sister, in looking back to what they had feared, only two hours ago, she felt all the advantages of what they had gained.
vi: Mrs. Hill immediately expressed her joy. Elizabeth, along with the others, also received her congratulations, and then, weary of this lively affair, she returned to her room so she could think freely. The plight of poor little Lydia was bad, to put it mildly, but it couldn't get any worse, she should be glad. She felt this, although when thinking about the future, she couldn't expect her sister to be moderately happy or materially well-off; when thinking about what they had feared just two hours ago, she felt all the advantages they had just gained.
tr: Mrs. Hill immediately began to express her joy. Elizabeth accepted her congratulations among the others, then, overwhelmed by this foolishness, she retreated to her room to think comfortably. Even at best, poor Lydia's situation must have been quite bad; but she should be grateful that it wasn't worse. She felt this way; looking ahead, neither a sensible happiness nor worldly prosperity could be hoped for her sister; but looking back, she felt all the goodness of what they had obtained compared to the things they had feared just two hours ago.
es: Mrs. Hill expressed her satisfaction and gave her congratulations to everyone. Elizabeth, dizzy from all the madness, took refuge in her room to freely indulge her thoughts. The situation of poor Lydia was to be, even in the best case, quite bad; but that was not the worst; she had to be grateful, for although looking to the future her sister could not expect any reasonable happiness or any prosperity in the world, looking back, to what only two hours earlier Elizabeth had feared so much, it could not be denied that she had still been lucky.

en: CHAPTER L.
vi: Chapter 50
tr: Chapter VIII
es: CHAPTER L

en: MR. BENNET had very often wished, before this period of his life, that, instead of spending his whole income, he had laid by an annual sum, for the better provision of his children, and of his wife, if she survived him. He now wished it more than ever. Had he done his duty in that respect, Lydia need not have been indebted to her uncle for whatever of honour or credit could now be purchased for her. The satisfaction of prevailing on one of the most worthless young men in Great Britain to be her husband might then have rested in its proper place.
vi: In the past, Mr. Bennet had often wished that instead of spending all his income, he would save a portion each year to later provide for his children and his wife, should she outlive him. Now he wished for this more than ever. If he had fulfilled his duty in this way, Lydia would not have to be indebted to her uncle for having to buy any honor or reputation for her. Thus, the satisfaction of having persuaded one of the most worthless men in England to marry his daughter might have been rightly placed.
tr: Mr. Bennet, before this period of his life, often wanted to set aside a sum of money each year to ensure a better life for his children and wife after his death, instead of spending all his income. He now wished he had done this more than ever. Had he fulfilled this duty, Lydia would not be indebted to her uncle for the respectability or credibility that could now be bought for her. The satisfaction of having persuaded one of the most worthless young men in England to be her husband could then be felt in the right place.
es: Previously, Mr. Bennet had often wanted to save a certain annual amount to improve the fortune of his daughters and his wife, if she survived him, instead of spending all his income. And now he regretted not having done so. This would have prevented Lydia from indebting herself to her uncle for everything he now had to do for her, both in terms of honor and money. Moreover, he could have had the pleasure of tempting any of the brightest young men in Great Britain to marry her.

en: He was seriously concerned that a cause of so little advantage to anyone should be forwarded at the sole expense of his brother-in-law; and he was determined, if possible, to find out the extent of his assistance, and to discharge the obligation as soon as he could.
vi: He seriously worried about his brother-in-law having to bear the costs, and he intended, if possible, to find out the amount his brother-in-law had supported, so that he could repay the debt as soon as possible.
tr: He was seriously upset that the entire cost of such a purpose, which was of little benefit to anyone, had fallen on his brother-in-law; if possible, he was determined to find out the amount of his help and to settle the debt at the first opportunity.
es: He was seriously dismayed that for a matter which offered so few advantages for anyone, his brother-in-law had to make so many sacrifices, and he wanted to find out the amount of his donation in order to repay him when possible.

en: When first Mr. Bennet had married, economy was held to be perfectly useless; for, of course, they were to have a son. This son was to join in cutting off the entail, as soon as he should be of age, and the widow and younger children would by that means be provided for. Five daughters successively entered the world, but yet the son was to come; and Mrs. Bennet, for many years after Lydia’s birth, had been certain that he would. This event had at last been despaired of, but it was then too late to be saving. Mrs. Bennet had no turn for economy; and her husband’s love of independence had alone prevented their exceeding their income.
vi: When Mr. Bennet had just gotten married, the couple did not need to think about frugality because, of course, they would have a son, they believed so. This son would inherit the estate as soon as he came of age, and the widowed mother and the sisters would be provided for from this inheritance. The five daughters were born one after another without a son, while Mrs. Bennet, many years after giving birth to Lydia, still believed she would have a son. Eventually, this became hopeless, but it was too late to save up. Mrs. Bennet was not frugal and her husband liked to be free and easy, so for this reason alone they could not prevent overspending their income.
tr: When Mr. Bennet first got married, saving money seemed utterly unnecessary; because surely they would have a son. This son, as soon as he came of age, would remove the mortgage, and his widow and younger children would not suffer from financial difficulties thanks to him. Five daughters came into the world one after another, but still no son; Mrs. Bennet was confident that a son would come even years after Lydia was born. When hope was finally lost for this event, it was too late to start saving. Mrs. Bennet had no understanding of saving, and it was only thanks to her husband's love of independence that they managed not to spend more than they earned.
es: In the early days of Mr. Bennet's marriage, it was considered that there was no need for economy, as it was assumed that a male heir would be born and that he would inherit the estate upon reaching the appropriate age, thus ensuring the widow and daughters would be provided for. But five daughters were born in succession, and the male heir did not appear. Years after Lydia's birth, Mrs. Bennet still believed that the heir would come, but eventually, she gave up hope. Now it was too late to save: Mrs. Bennet had no aptitude for economy, and her husband's love of independence was the only thing that prevented them from overspending.

en: Five thousand pounds was settled by marriage articles on Mrs. Bennet and the children. But in what proportions it should be divided amongst the latter depended on the will of the parents. This was one point, with regard to Lydia at least, which was now to be settled, and Mr. Bennet could have no hesitation in acceding to the proposal before him. In terms of grateful acknowledgment for the kindness of his brother, though expressed most concisely, he then delivered on paper his perfect approbation of all that was done, and his willingness to fulfil the engagements that had been made for him. He had never before supposed that, could Wickham be prevailed on to marry his daughter, it would be done with so little inconvenience to himself as by the present arrangement. He would scarcely be ten pounds a year the loser, by the hundred that was to be paid them; for, what with her board and pocket allowance, and the continual presents in money which passed to her through her mother’s hands, Lydia’s expenses had been very little within that sum.
vi: The marriage terms specified a sum of five thousand pounds for Mrs. Bennet and the children. But how this sum would be divided depended on the will of both Mr. and Mrs. Bennet. Now it was necessary to settle the inheritance finances, at least for Lydia, and Mr. Bennet did not hesitate to meet the immediate demands placed before him. Accompanied by sincere words of gratitude for his brother-in-law's kindness, though concisely expressed, he wrote down his complete approval of all the arrangements made, confirming that he would meet the demands placed upon him. Previously, he had never thought that persuading Wickham to marry his daughter would be so inexpensive for him under the current arrangement. By providing an annual allowance of one hundred pounds for his daughter, he would only spend about ten pounds a year, because with the living expenses and pocket money plus the amounts given by her mother, all the costs for his daughter were now almost equal to that allowance.
tr: As per the conditions of the marriage, five thousand pounds were allocated to Mrs. Bennet and the children. But the proportion of how the money would be divided among the children was to be decided by the parents. Now, at least regarding Lydia, this point needed to be resolved, and Mr. Bennet could not hesitate to accept the proposal before him. In terms of appreciating his brother-in-law's kindness, he acknowledged on paper, albeit briefly, that he fully approved of everything that had been done and agreed to fulfill the commitments made on his behalf. It had never occurred to him before that if Wickham could be persuaded to marry his daughter, it could be done without causing him any inconvenience, as stated in the agreement before him. The hundred pounds to be paid to them would either cost him ten pounds a year or not; because with her food, drink, pocket money, and the constant financial support from her mother, Lydia's expenses would only just be covered by that amount.
es: In the marriage settlements, five thousand pounds were secured for Mrs. Bennet and her daughters; but the distribution depended on the will of the parents. Finally, this point was to be decided concerning Lydia, and Mr. Bennet did not hesitate to agree to the proposal. In terms of gratitude for his brother-in-law's kindness, though expressed very concisely, he entrusted to paper his approval of everything done and his desire to fulfill the commitments made in his name. He would never have believed that Wickham would consent to marry Lydia at the cost of so few inconveniences as those resulting from that arrangement. Ten pounds annually was the most he was going to lose by giving the hundred he had to give them, for between the fixed ordinary expenses, the loose money he gave Lydia, and the continuous cash gifts her mother made to her, little less than that amount was spent on Lydia.

en: That it would be done with such trifling exertion on his side, too, was another very welcome surprise; for his chief wish at present was to have as little trouble in the business as possible. When the first transports of rage which had produced his activity in seeking her were over, he naturally returned to all his former indolence. His letter was soon despatched; for though dilatory in undertaking business, he was quick in its execution. He begged to know further particulars of what he was indebted to his brother; but was too angry with Lydia to send any message to her.
vi: He was also pleased to see that he didn't have to put much effort into such arrangements, as his main desire now was to be disturbed as little as possible. When the initial fierce words that prompted him to search for his daughter had subsided, he naturally reverted to his lazy habits. The letter was quickly sent, because although he was slow to start a task, he often finished it swiftly. In the letter, he earnestly wanted to know how much he owed his brother-in-law, but he was too angry with Lydia to write anything to her.
tr: The fact that the matter was resolved with such an insignificant effort from his perspective was another pleasant surprise; his current main goal was to cause as few problems as possible in the matter. After the initial fits of anger that led him to go searching for him subsided, he naturally returned to his old occupations. The letter was sent immediately; although he was slow to start the task, he was quick to finish it. He also wanted to know in detail what he owed his brother-in-law; but he was so angry with Lydia that he did not send her any message.
es: Another thing that pleasantly surprised him was that everything was done with such insignificant trouble for him, as his main desire was always to be left alone. After the initial burst of anger that motivated him to seek out his daughter, he returned, as expected, to his usual indolence. He quickly dispatched the letter, though he took a long time to start things, he was quick to execute them. In the letter, he asked for more details about what he owed his brother-in-law, but he was too resentful towards Lydia to send her any message.

en: The good news quickly spread through the house; and with proportionate speed through the neighbourhood. It was borne in the latter with decent philosophy. To be sure, it would have been more for the advantage of conversation, had Miss Lydia Bennet come upon the town; or, as the happiest alternative, been secluded from the world in some distant farm-house. But there was much to be talked of, in marrying her; and the good-natured wishes for her well-doing, which had proceeded before from all the spiteful old ladies in Meryton, lost but little of their spirit in this change of circumstances, because with such a husband her misery was considered certain.
vi: The good news spread quickly within the house, and just as quickly in the surrounding area. The neighbors added a bit of serious philosophy. Conversations would certainly be more interesting if Lydia Bennet had fallen into the mire of society, or in a more favorable way, if she were isolated from the public, confined in a remote rustic house. But there was still much to discuss about her wedding; and the kind wishes for her well-being, which every spiteful old lady in Meryton had previously expressed, remained similar in this changed circumstance, as people thought that with such a husband, she would surely suffer.
tr: The good news spread quickly at home; it spread around just as fast. The people around received the news reasonably. Of course, the gossip would have been more enjoyable if Miss Lydia Bennet had fallen into the city streets, or better yet, retreated to a distant farmhouse. But she was getting married, and there was still much to talk about; all the old ladies in Meryton who had previously wished her well did not lose any of their enthusiasm when the situation changed, because they knew that with such a husband, that girl would never reform.
es: The good news spread quickly throughout the house and, with proportional promptness, through the neighborhood. It is true that it would have caused more talk if Lydia Bennet had come to town, and it would have been even better if they had confined her to some distant farm; but there was already enough to gossip about regarding her marriage, and the well-intentioned wishes for her happiness that the spiteful old women of Meryton had previously expressed lost only a little of their liveliness in this change of circumstances, for with such a husband Lydia's misfortune was considered certain.

en: It was a fortnight since Mrs. Bennet had been down stairs, but on this happy day she again took her seat at the head of her table, and in spirits oppressively high. No sentiment of shame gave a damp to her triumph. The marriage of a daughter, which had been the first object of her wishes since Jane was sixteen, was now on the point of accomplishment, and her thoughts and her words ran wholly on those attendants of elegant nuptials, fine muslins, new carriages, and servants. She was busily searching through the neighbourhood for a proper situation for her daughter; and, without knowing or considering what their income might be, rejected many as deficient in size and importance.
vi: It has been two weeks since Mrs. Bennet recovered from her illness and came downstairs to join the household, but on this happy day, she was once again sitting at the head of the dining table, her spirits suddenly uplifted. There was no thought of shame to dampen her triumphant feelings. Having a daughter get married was one of her earliest wishes since Jane turned sixteen, and now it was about to come true. Her thoughts and words always revolved around grand wedding ceremonies, fine fabrics, new carriages, and servants. She was busily searching the area for a house for her daughter, and without considering the family's income, she had rejected many houses of moderate size and appearance.
tr: It had been fifteen days since Mrs. Bennet had set foot on the ground floor, but on this happy day, she took her place at the head of the table once again, with a cheerfulness that would drive everyone crazy. No sense of shame could tarnish her victory in the slightest. Since Jane had turned sixteen, her greatest dream had been to marry off one of her daughters, and now she was on the verge of achieving it; all her thoughts and conversations revolved around elegant weddings, high-quality muslins, new carriages, and servants. She was looking for a suitable house in the vicinity for her daughter, turning her nose up at many because their size and location were not adequate, without knowing or caring what their income would be.
es: It had been fifteen days since Mrs. Bennet had come down from her rooms, but in order to celebrate such joyous events, she once again took her radiant place at the head of the table. In her triumph, there was not the slightest feeling of shame. The marriage of a daughter, which had been her main desire since Jane turned sixteen, was now about to take place. She thought and spoke of nothing but elegant weddings, fine muslins, new servants, and new carriages. She was very busy looking for a suitable house for the couple in the neighborhood, and without knowing or considering what their income would be, she rejected many for lack of space or luxury.

en: “Haye Park might do,” said she, “if the Gouldings would quit it, or the great house at Stoke, if the drawing-room were larger; but Ashworth is too far off. I could not bear to have her ten miles from me; and as for Purvis Lodge, the attics are dreadful.”
vi: She said: - Haye-Park would be acceptable if the Gouldings would move, or the big house at Stoke would do if the drawing-room were larger, but Ashworth is too far away! I could not bear it if it lived ten miles away from me, and Purvis Lodge with its upper floor is dreadfully dull.
tr: "It could be Haye-Park," he said, "if the Gouldings leave it; the large house at Stoke could also work, if the sitting room were larger; but Ashworth is too far! I can't bear it being more than ten miles away from me; as for Purvis Lodge, its attic is terrible."
es: ––Haye Park ––he said–– would do very well if the Gouldings would let it; or the house at Stoke, if the drawing-room were larger; but Asworth is too far away! I could not bear to have her live ten miles away. As for Purvis Lodge, the attics are dreadful.

en: Her husband allowed her to talk on without interruption while the servants remained. But when they had withdrawn, he said to her, “Mrs. Bennet, before you take any, or all of these houses, for your son and daughter, let us come to a right understanding. Into one house in this neighbourhood they shall never have admittance. I will not encourage the imprudence of either, by receiving them at Longbourn.”
vi: The husband let his wife speak without interruption when there were servants around. But when they withdrew, he said to her: - Mrs. Bennet, before you choose any house, or all the houses for your son-in-law and daughter, we need to understand each other properly. They will never set foot in a house in this area. I will not encourage the recklessness of the others by receiving them at Longbourn.
tr: He allowed her to speak without interference while the servants were there. When the servants withdrew, he said to her, "Mrs. Bennet, before you take any of these houses, or all of them, for your son or daughter, let us come to an agreement on one matter. They shall never enter a single house in this neighborhood. I will not reward their immorality by accepting them at Longbourn."
es: Her husband let her speak without interrupting her while the servants were present. But when they left, he said to her: ––Mrs. Bennet, before taking any of those houses or all of them for your daughter, let's make things clear. There is a house in this neighborhood where they will never be admitted. I will not encourage the impudence of either of them by receiving them at Longbourn.

en: A long dispute followed this declaration; but Mr. Bennet was firm: it soon led to another; and Mrs. Bennet found, with amazement and horror, that her husband would not advance a guinea to buy clothes for his daughter. He protested that she should receive from him no mark of affection whatever on the occasion. Mrs. Bennet could hardly comprehend it. That his anger could be carried to such a point of inconceivable resentment as to refuse his daughter a privilege, without which her marriage would scarcely seem valid, exceeded all that she could believe possible. She was more alive to the disgrace, which her want of new clothes must reflect on her daughter’s nuptials, than to any sense of shame at her eloping and living with Wickham a fortnight before they took place.
vi: Two people argued with each other after his statement, but Mr. Bennet remained steadfast, and soon the argument shifted to another topic. Mrs. Bennet felt surprised and horrified to learn that her husband would not spend a penny on clothing for his daughter. He also declared that on the wedding day, he would not show any sign of affection towards his daughter. Mrs. Bennet could hardly understand. She could not comprehend how his anger could lead to such unimaginable resentment, to the point of not wanting to grant his daughter a favor, making the wedding seem hardly legitimate. She was more worried that her daughter would be humiliated by the lack of new clothes at the wedding than feeling ashamed of her running away and living with Wickham, just two weeks before the wedding was to take place.
tr: This statement was followed by a long dispute; but Mr. Bennet was resolute: another dispute ensued; Mrs. Bennet learned with astonishment and horror that her husband would not give a single penny for their daughter's dress. Mr. Bennet said he would not show the slightest sign of affection regarding the wedding. Mrs. Bennet could not comprehend these things. His refusal to do such a kindness for his daughter would take the wedding out of the realm of weddings; it was inconceivable that his anger had reached such an unimaginable point of resentment. Mrs. Bennet cared less about the shame of her daughter eloping and living with Wickham just fifteen days ago than she did about the new dresslessness staining the wedding.
es: This declaration was followed by a long dispute, but Mr. Bennet remained firm. The discussion moved from this point to another, and Mrs. Bennet watched with astonishment and horror as her husband refused to advance even a guinea to buy their daughter’s wedding dress. He assured that she would not receive any proof of affection from him regarding that matter. Mrs. Bennet could not comprehend it; it was beyond the possibilities of her imagination that her husband's resentment could reach the point of denying their daughter a privilege without which her marriage would scarcely seem valid. She was more sensitive to the misfortune of her daughter not having a wedding dress to wear than to the shame of her having eloped and lived with Wickham for fifteen days before the wedding took place.

en: Elizabeth was now most heartily sorry that she had, from the distress of the moment, been led to make Mr. Darcy acquainted with their fears for her sister; for since her marriage would so shortly give the proper termination to the elopement, they might hope to conceal its unfavourable beginning from all those who were not immediately on the spot.
vi: Elizabeth now regretted that in a moment of sorrow she had revealed to Mr. Darcy the family's fears regarding her youngest sister; for with her sister's wedding bringing a proper conclusion to the elopement, the family could hope to conceal the initial scandal from those living far away.
tr: Elizabeth was now very upset for having given in to the despair of the moment and told Mr. Darcy about the fears they had for his sister; they could hope to conceal the distressing beginning from everyone who was not present at that moment, as the matter of the elopement would soon be properly resolved.
es: Elizabeth regretted more than ever having informed Darcy, driven by the pain of the moment, of her sister's action, for since the wedding was going to cover the scandal of the elopement, it was to be assumed that the ungrateful preliminaries would be hidden from all those who could be unaware of them.

en: She had no fear of its spreading farther, through his means. There were few people on whose secrecy she would have more confidently depended; but at the same time there was no one whose knowledge of a sister’s frailty would have mortified her so much. Not, however, from any fear of disadvantage from it individually to herself; for at any rate there seemed a gulf impassable between them. Had Lydia’s marriage been concluded on the most honourable terms, it was not to be supposed that Mr. Darcy would connect himself with a family, where to every other objection would now be added an alliance and relationship of the nearest kind with the man whom he so justly scorned.
vi: She was not afraid that Mr. Darcy would spread the news of the incident further. There were few people she could trust more regarding discretion; but at the same time, there was no one else whose knowledge of her sister's susceptibility would cause her such humiliation. However, this was not a fear of personal disadvantage, as there was already an insurmountable chasm between them. Even if Lydia's wedding were conducted with the utmost honor, it was not to be thought that Mr. Darcy would wish to associate with her family, as there was an additional obstacle: his justified disdain for a person he had rightly despised.
tr: He did not fear that the situation would spread further through Mr. Darcy. There were very few people whose confidentiality he could trust more than him; but at the same time, no one else's knowledge of his sister's weakness could upset him more. Not because he would be personally harmed by it; because, in any case, there seemed to be an insurmountable chasm between them. Even if Lydia's marriage had been handled in the most respectable manner, it was unimaginable that Mr. Darcy would want to be related to a family that added the closest and most intimate relationship with a man he rightfully despised to its other negative aspects.
es: He did not fear Darcy's indiscretion; few people inspired more confidence in him than Darcy; but it mortified him that he knew his sister's weakness. And not out of fear that it would cause her any harm, because the chasm that seemed to separate them was insurmountable anyway. Even if Lydia's marriage had been arranged in the most honorable way, it could not be supposed that Darcy would want to ally himself with a family that, to all its other drawbacks, would now add the most intimate connection with the man whom Darcy so justly despised.

en: From such a connection she could not wonder that he should shrink. The wish of procuring her regard, which she had assured herself of his feeling in Derbyshire, could not in rational expectation survive such a blow as this. She was humbled, she was grieved; she repented, though she hardly knew of what. She became jealous of his esteem, when she could no longer hope to be benefited by it. She wanted to hear of him, when there seemed the least chance of gaining intelligence. She was convinced that she could have been happy with him, when it was no longer likely they should meet.
vi: From such a relationship, she had no doubt that he would withdraw. The desire to win her affection, as she had clearly seen in Derbyshire, could not survive such a disaster. She felt inferior, she felt sorrowful, she felt regretful, although she was not sure about what. She envied his respectable status, when she no longer had any hope of benefiting from it. She wanted to receive news of him, when it seemed there was the least chance of hearing from him. She believed she could be happy with him when they might never meet again.
tr: There was nothing surprising in wanting to stay away from such a kinship. She had felt that she was trying to win his favor in Derbyshire, but after such a blow, no one in their right mind could expect her to continue. Elizabeth was humiliated, she was suffering; she was repenting, though she didn't know for what. She was jealous of his love, even though she could no longer hope to feel it. She wanted to hear from him, even though there was no way to reach him. She believed she could be happy with him, even though it now seemed impossible for them to be together.
es: In the face of such a thing, it was natural for Darcy to retreat. The desire to win Elizabeth's affection, which she had sensed in him in Derbyshire, could not survive such a blow. Elizabeth felt humiliated, saddened, and filled with vague remorse. She longed for his affection when she could no longer hope to obtain it. She wanted to hear from him when there was not the slightest chance of receiving news from him. She was convinced that she could have been happy with him, when it was likely that they would not see each other again.

en: What a triumph for him, as she often thought, could he know that the proposals which she had proudly spurned only four months ago would now have been gladly and gratefully received! He was as generous, she doubted not, as the most generous of his sex. But while he was mortal, there must be a triumph.
vi: She often thought, it would indeed be a victory for him if he knew that now she could accept the feelings she had proudly rejected just four months ago! She still believed he had the most generous nature of any man. But because he was only human, he could still feel intoxicated by the triumph.
tr: How victorious he would have been, he often thought, if only he had known that the offers he had proudly rejected just four months ago would now be accepted with such great joy and gratitude! There was no doubt that he was a noble man, and one of the noblest at that. But at the same time, he was human and could feel a sense of victory.
es: "What a triumph for him," she thought, "if he knew that the proposals I so proudly rejected just four months ago, I would now gladly accept." He did not doubt that he was as generous as anyone, but as long as he lived, that had to be a triumph for him.

en: She began now to comprehend that he was exactly the man who, in disposition and talents, would most suit her. His understanding and temper, though unlike her own, would have answered all her wishes. It was an union that must have been to the advantage of both: by her ease and liveliness, his mind might have been softened, his manners improved; and from his judgment, information, and knowledge of the world, she must have received benefit of greater importance.
vi: Now she began to realize that he was the person most suited to her, in terms of temperament and talent. His understanding and character, although different from hers, met all her desires. This was a mutually beneficial combination: through her simplicity and liveliness, his character could become more gentle, his behavior more measured; while from his maturity and knowledge, she could learn many more important things.
tr: Now she was beginning to realize that he was the most suitable man for her, with his personality and abilities. Even though his mind and nature were not similar to hers, he fulfilled all her wishes. This was a relationship that would make both of them happy; Elizabeth's ease and liveliness could soften his character and improve his behavior; his judgment, knowledge, and experience would teach Elizabeth more important things.
es: Then she began to understand that Darcy was exactly, by his way of being and his talent, the man who would have suited her best. Darcy's understanding and character, although not similar to hers, would have fulfilled all her desires. Their union would have been advantageous for both: with her ease and liveliness, his temperament would have softened and his manners would have improved. And the judgment, culture, and knowledge of the world that he possessed would have brought her significant benefits.

en: But no such happy marriage could now teach the admiring multitude what connubial felicity really was. An union of a different tendency, and precluding the possibility of the other, was soon to be formed in their family.
vi: But such a happy marriage cannot teach people what true marital happiness really is. The combination of one distinct personality, and the rejection of the other personality, will soon occur in their family.
tr: But such a happy marriage would not be able to teach the crowd around them what true marital happiness really was. A union of a different nature, which would eliminate the possibility of the other within their families, was about to be established.
es: But that ideal marriage could no longer teach the admiring crowds what conjugal happiness was; the union that was about to take place in Elizabeth's family was very different and excluded the possibility of the former.

en: How Wickham and Lydia were to be supported in tolerable independence she could not imagine. But how little of permanent happiness could belong to a couple who were only brought together because their passions were stronger than their virtue, she could easily conjecture.
vi: She could not imagine how Wickham and Lydia would manage to support themselves even relatively independently. But she could easily guess how short-lived their happiness would be for a couple brought together by infatuation rather than by virtue.
tr: Wickham could not imagine how Lydia and he would manage to live more or less independently. However, he could easily predict how little lasting happiness could be possible in the life of a couple who came together only because their passions were stronger than their virtues.
es: They could not imagine how Wickham and Lydia would manage to live with a passable independence; but it was not difficult to conjecture how unstable the happiness of a couple united solely because their passions were stronger than their virtue would be.

en: Mr. Gardiner soon wrote again to his brother. To Mr. Bennet’s acknowledgments he briefly replied, with assurances of his eagerness to promote the welfare of any of his family; and concluded with entreaties that the subject might never be mentioned to him again. The principal purport of his letter was to inform them, that Mr. Wickham had resolved on quitting the militia.
vi: Mr. Gardiner had written another letter to his brother-in-law. With Mr. Bennet's words of thanks, he only replied briefly to affirm his earnest desire to bring happiness to any member of the family and asked Mr. Bennet not to mention gratitude anymore. The purpose of his letter was to inform the family that Mr. Wickham had decided to resign from the militia.
tr: ------------------------ Mr. Gardiner soon wrote back to his brother-in-law. He briefly acknowledged Mr. Bennet's thanks, expressed his readiness to ensure the well-being of every member of the family, and concluded by requesting that the matter not be mentioned to him again. The main purpose of his letter was to inform them that Wickham had decided to leave the Militia.
es: Mr. Gardiner soon wrote back to his brother-in-law. He briefly responded to Mr. Bennet's gratitude by saying that his greatest wish was to contribute to the well-being of the entire family and concluded by asking that the matter not be discussed any further. The main purpose of the letter was to inform him that Wickham had decided to leave the regiment.

en: “It was greatly my wish that he should do so,” he added, “as soon as his marriage was fixed on. And I think you will agree with me, in considering a removal from that corps as highly advisable, both on his account and my niece’s. It is Mr. Wickham’s intention to go into the Regulars; and, among his former friends, there are still some who are able and willing to assist him in the army. He has the promise of an ensigncy in General——’s regiment, now quartered in the north. It is an advantage to have it so far from this part of the kingdom. He promises fairly; and I hope among different people, where they may each have a character to preserve, they will both be more prudent. I have written to Colonel Forster, to inform him of our present arrangements, and to request that he will satisfy the various creditors of Mr. Wickham in and near Brighton with assurances of speedy payment, for which I have pledged myself. And will you give yourself the trouble of carrying similar assurances to his creditors in Meryton, of whom I shall subjoin a list, according to his information? He has given in all his debts; I hope at least he has not deceived us. Haggerston has our directions, and all will be completed in a week. They will then join his regiment, unless they are first invited to Longbourn; and I understand from Mrs. Gardiner that my niece is very desirous of seeing you all before she leaves the south. She is well, and begs to be dutifully remembered to you and her mother.—Yours, etc.
vi: He added: "I earnestly hope that he should proceed with this matter as soon as he has decided on the wedding. And I think you will agree with me that this is the right thing to do, considering his circumstances and my niece's. Mr. Wickham intends to join the regular army, among his old friends there are still some who are capable and willing to help him enlist. He has been promised assistance by an officer in a regiment currently stationed in the North. There is an advantage to him serving in a unit stationed so far away, I hope that when they live with others, they will become more cautious, in a place where each person still retains some good qualities. I have written to Colonel Forster to inform him of our arrangements, and I have asked him to notify Mr. Wickham's creditors in Brighton and the surrounding area that the debts will be paid promptly, as I have committed myself. And please kindly inform his creditors in Meryton similarly, I enclose a list provided by him. He has declared all his debts; I hope at least he is not deceiving us. Haggerston has received my instructions, and everything will be settled within a week. Then the two will go to live with the regiment, except when they are invited to Longbourn. As I have learned from Mrs. Gardiner, my niece is very eager to see the whole family again before leaving the South. She is well and hopes you will kindly think of her. Respectfully yours
tr: "Once the marriage is finalized," he added, "I wanted him to do so as well. I believe you will agree that it would be beneficial for both him and my niece to leave the regiment. Mr. Wickham's intention is to enlist in the regular army; there are still some of his old friends who are willing and able to support him in the army. He has been promised a corporal position in the unit of General ---------, who is currently stationed in the North. Being so far from this part of the kingdom is also an advantage. He promises reasonably; I hope they will act more prudently among different people where they can present themselves as new individuals. I wrote a letter to Colonel Forster informing him of our agreement, asking him to reassure Mr. Wickham's creditors in and around Brighton by promising quick payment under my personal guarantee. I also ask you to kindly give the same assurance to the creditors in Meryton; I will send you the list according to the information he provided me. He listed all his debts; I hope at least he has not deceived us. Haggerston has received our instructions; everything will be settled within a week. Then they will join their unit, unless they are invited to Longbourn beforehand; from what Mrs. Gardiner has told me, my niece is very eager to see you all before she leaves the South. She is well; she sends her love to you and your mother.
es: He was very eager for him to do it ––he added when we finalized the marriage; and I believe you will agree with me that his departure from that Corps is highly beneficial both for him and for my niece. Mr. Wickham's intention is to join the regular Army, and among his old friends, there are those who can and want to help him achieve it. He has been promised the rank of ensign in General X's regiment, currently stationed in the North. It is much better for him to move away from this part of the kingdom. He firmly promises, and I hope it will be so, that being among other people before whom they should not discredit themselves, the two will be more prudent. I have written to Colonel Forster informing him of our arrangements and requesting that he tell Mr. Wickham's various creditors in Brighton and its surroundings that they will be paid immediately under my responsibility. Would you mind taking the trouble to give the same assurances to the creditors in Meryton, of whom I am sending you a list according to what Mr. Wickham has indicated to me? He has confessed all his debts to us and I hope that at least in this he has not deceived us. Haggerston already has instructions and within a week everything will be ready. Then Mr. Wickham will join his regiment, unless he is first invited to go to Longbourn, for my wife tells me that Lydia is very eager to see you all before leaving the South. She is very well and humbly asks you and her mother to remember her. Yours,

en: “E. Gardiner.”
vi: E. Gardiner
tr: E. Gardiner."
es: E. Gardiner.

en: Mr. Bennet and his daughters saw all the advantages of Wickham’s removal from the ——shire, as clearly as Mr. Gardiner could do. But Mrs. Bennet was not so well pleased with it. Lydia’s being settled in the north, just when she had expected most pleasure and pride in her company, for she had by no means given up her plan of their residing in Hertfordshire, was a severe disappointment; and, besides, it was such a pity that Lydia should be taken from a regiment where she was acquainted with everybody, and had so many favourites.
vi: Just like Mr. Gardiner, Mr. Bennet and his daughters clearly saw all the advantages when Mr. Wickham requested to leave the militia. But Mrs. Bennet was not very pleased. She was deeply disappointed to see Lydia having to settle in the North, just when she wished to have her close in happiness and pride. She had not yet given up the idea of having the two stay in Hertfordshire, and moreover, it was rather pitiful for Lydia to be separated from the militia regiment where she knew everyone and where she was fond of many people.
tr: Mr. Bennet and his daughters found Wickham's departure from the ---------shire regiment to be as favorable as Mr. Gardiner did. But Mrs. Bennet was not as pleased about it. Just when she was about to take great pleasure and pride in his presence, Lydia's move to the North was a heavy disappointment for her, because she had not yet given up on the plan of them living in Hertfordshire, and it was truly a pity that Lydia had to leave a regiment where she knew everyone and had many loved ones.
es: Mr. Bennet and his daughters understood the advantages of Wickham leaving the county garrison as clearly as Mr. Gardiner; but Mrs. Bennet was not as satisfied as they were. She was very displeased that Lydia was to settle in the North precisely when she had been looking forward with pleasure and pride to enjoying her company, for she had not given up her illusion that Lydia would reside in Hertfordshire. And besides, it was a pity that Lydia would be separated from a regiment where everyone knew her and where she had so many admirers.

en: “She is so fond of Mrs. Forster,” said she, “it will be quite shocking to send her away! And there are several of the young men, too, that she likes very much. The officers may not be so pleasant in General——’s regiment.”
vi: She said: - The little girl loves Mrs. Forster very much; it would be a shock if she had to be sent away! And there are a few young men that she is also very fond of. The officers in the new regiment might not be as pleasant.
tr: "She is very fond of Mrs. Forster," he said, "sending her away will be a complete shock! Besides, there are plenty of young people she likes very much there. It is impossible for the officers in General ---------'s unit to be so pleasant."
es: ––She is so fond of Mrs. Forster that it will be very hard for her to leave her. And, besides, there are several boys she likes. It may be that the officers of General X's regiment are not as nice.

en: His daughter’s request, for such it might be considered, of being admitted into her family again, before she set off for the north, received at first an absolute negative. But Jane and Elizabeth, who agreed in wishing, for the sake of their sister’s feelings and consequence, that she should be noticed on her marriage by her parents, urged him so earnestly, yet so rationally and so mildly, to receive her and her husband at Longbourn, as soon as they were married, that he was prevailed on to think as they thought, and act as they wished. And their mother had the satisfaction of knowing, that she should be able to show her married daughter in the neighbourhood, before she was banished to the north. When Mr. Bennet wrote again to his brother, therefore, he sent his permission for them to come; and it was settled, that, as soon as the ceremony was over, they should proceed to Longbourn. Elizabeth was surprised, however, that Wickham should consent to such a scheme; and, had she consulted only her own inclination, any meeting with him would have been the last object of her wishes.
vi: Lydia's plea to be accepted back into the family before she went to the North initially met with a completely negative reaction. But Jane and Elizabeth thought about their sister's feelings and position. The two sisters earnestly pleaded with their father, both reasonably and emotionally, to accept the couple at Longbourn after their marriage. They hoped their father would think as they did and act as they wished. Their mother would be satisfied if she had the chance to show her neighbors that her daughter was married before she was sent to the North. Therefore, Mr. Bennet wrote to his brother-in-law that he allowed the couple to come, agreeing that immediately after the wedding, they should go straight to Longbourn. However, Elizabeth was surprised to learn that Wickham agreed to this plan. If she only considered her own feelings, she did not want to see him at all.
tr: The request of her daughter to be accepted back into the family before going North, because she seemed to have made such a request, was initially met with absolute opposition. But for the sake of their sisters' feelings and reputation, Jane and Elizabeth, who accepted the request for her marriage to be recognized by their mother and father, so persistently but so wisely and moderately pressured Mr. Bennet to accept Lydia and her husband at Longbourn as soon as they got married that he was finally convinced to think like them and act as they wished. Thus, their mother was also pleased, thinking she could show her daughter around before she was exiled to the North. When Mr. Bennet wrote to his brother-in-law again, he thus allowed them to come; it was decided that they would proceed to Longbourn immediately after the ceremony. However, Elizabeth was surprised that Wickham consented to such a plan; if it were up to her, encountering Wickham would be the last thing she would want in life.
es: The plea ––for such it had to be considered from his daughter to be readmitted into the family before departing for the North was at first roundly denied; but Jane and Elizabeth, for the sake of their sister's feelings and future, wished that she would notify her parents of her marriage in person, and insisted with such interest, gentleness, and sweetness that Mr. Bennet agreed to receive her and her husband at Longbourn after the wedding, that they convinced him. Thus, Mrs. Bennet had the satisfaction of knowing that they could present their married daughter to the neighborhood before she was banished to the North. Consequently, when Mr. Bennet wrote back to his brother-in-law, he gave permission for the couple to come, and it was determined that after the ceremony they would leave for Longbourn. Elizabeth complained that Wickham accepted this plan, and if she had been guided only by her own desires, Wickham would be the last person she would want to meet.

en: CHAPTER LI.
vi: Chapter 51
tr: Chapter IX
es: CHAPTER LI

en: THEIR sister’s wedding-day arrived; and Jane and Elizabeth felt for her probably more than she felt for herself. The carriage was sent to meet them at——, and they were to return in it by dinnertime. Their arrival was dreaded by the elder Miss Bennets—and Jane more especially, who gave Lydia the feelings which would have attended herself, had she been the culprit, and was wretched in the thought of what her sister must endure.
vi: The wedding day of their younger sister had arrived, and perhaps Jane and Elizabeth felt more for their sister than she felt for herself. The family sent a carriage to pick them up, and the two would arrive home by dinner time. The two older sisters, especially Jane, were terrified for their younger sister about the return journey of the two. Jane thought of Lydia through the emotions she attributed to herself, as if she were the guilty one, and thus she sorrowfully contemplated what her sister would have to endure.
tr: The wedding day of their sisters arrived; Jane and Elizabeth were probably more anxious on her behalf than she was herself. A carriage was sent to meet them at ----------; they would have returned by mealtime. The elder Miss Bennets were gripped by the fear of their arrival; especially Jane, who was distressed thinking about what her sister had to endure, as she felt the emotions Lydia would have if she had been the one to make the mistake.
es: The day of Lydia's wedding arrived, and Jane and Elizabeth were probably more interested in it than she was herself. The carriage was sent to fetch them from X, and it would return with them at lunchtime. Jane and Elizabeth dreaded their arrival, especially Jane, who attributed to Lydia the same feelings that would have overwhelmed her if she had been the guilty one, and she tormented herself thinking about what Lydia must be suffering.

en: They came. The family were assembled in the breakfast-room to receive them. Smiles decked the face of Mrs. Bennet, as the carriage drove up to the door; her husband looked impenetrably grave; her daughters, alarmed, anxious, uneasy.
vi: Two people have arrived. The whole family gathered in the breakfast room to welcome them. Smiles adorned Mrs. Bennet's face as the carriage pulled up to the doorstep; her husband bore a serious expression, revealing nothing of his thoughts; the daughters, on the other hand, were anxious, restless, and uneasy.
tr: They arrived. The family gathered in the breakfast room to greet them. As the car approached the door, Mrs. Bennet's face lit up with smiles; her husband appeared impenetrably serious; their daughters were anxious, worried, and tense.
es: They arrived. The family was gathered in the sitting room waiting for them. A smile adorned Mrs. Bennet's face when the carriage stopped in front of the door; her husband was impenetrably serious, and her daughters were alarmed, anxious, and restless.

en: Lydia’s voice was heard in the vestibule; the door was thrown open, and she ran into the room. Her mother stepped forwards, embraced her, and welcomed her with rapture; gave her hand with an affectionate smile to Wickham, who followed his lady; and wished them both joy, with an alacrity which showed no doubt of their happiness.
vi: The whole family heard Lydia's voice from the hall; the door was wide open, and she ran in. Her mother stepped forward, embraced her, excitedly welcoming her. She extended her hand to Wickham with a tender smile and wished them both happiness, in a lively tone that showed she believed they were happy.
tr: Lydia's voice was heard in the hallway; the door opened quickly and she ran into the room. Her mother stepped forward, embraced her, and greeted her warmly; with a loving smile, she gave her hand to Wickham, who was following his wife, and with an enthusiasm that left no doubt about their happiness, she wished them both eternal bliss.
es: The voice of Lydia was heard in the hall; the door opened and the newlywed entered the room.
