Her mother stood up, hugged her, and enthusiastically welcomed her, extending her hand to Wickham who followed his wife, wishing them both the greatest happiness, with a promptness that demonstrated her conviction that they would undoubtedly be happy.

en: Their reception from Mr. Bennet, to whom they then turned, was not quite so cordial. His countenance rather gained in austerity; and he scarcely opened his lips. The easy assurance of the young couple, indeed, was enough to provoke him.
vi: The two turned towards Mr. Bennet, but his reception was not as warm as the mother's. His face showed a stern expression, and he scarcely parted his lips. In fact, their confident demeanor was enough to provoke him.
tr: Then they turned to Mr. Bennet; the reception they received from him was not very friendly. A cold expression settled on his face, and he hardly opened his mouth. The carefree ease of the young couple was enough to provoke him.
es: The reception of Mr. Bennet, to whom they then turned, was no longer so cordial. He reaffirmed his seriousness and barely opened his lips. The tranquility of the young couple was really enough to provoke him.

en: Elizabeth was disgusted, and even Miss Bennet was shocked. Lydia was Lydia still; untamed, unabashed, wild, noisy, and fearless. She turned from sister to sister, demanding their congratulations; and when at length they all sat down, looked eagerly round the room, took notice of some little alteration in it, and observed, with a laugh, that it was a great while since she had been there.
vi: Elizabeth felt disdain, even Miss Bennet was shocked. Lydia was still the same old Lydia; unruly, shameless, reckless, loud, and fearless. She looked from one sister to another, hoping they would congratulate her. When finally everyone sat down, she glanced around the room, noting a few small changes, and laughed loudly as she remarked that she had been away from this place for quite a while.
tr: Elizabeth was disgusted; even Miss Bennet was shaken. Lydia was still Lydia; mischievous, shameless, wild, boisterous, and fearless. She turned from one sister to another, demanding their congratulations; finally, when they all sat together, she looked around the room curiously, noticed a few changes, and laughingly said that a lot of time had passed since she was last there.
es: Elizabeth was embarrassed and even Jane was scandalized. Lydia remained Lydia: untamed, shameless, foolish, loud, and daring. She went from sister to sister asking them to congratulate her, and when they all finally sat down, she looked eagerly around the room, noticing that there had been a small change, and, bursting into laughter, said that it had been a long time since she had been there.

en: Wickham was not at all more distressed than herself; but his manners were always so pleasing, that, had his character and his marriage been exactly what they ought, his smiles and his easy address, while he claimed their relationship, would have delighted them all. Elizabeth had not before believed him quite equal to such assurance; but she sat down, resolving within herself to draw no limits in future to the impudence of an impudent man. She blushed, and Jane blushed; but the cheeks of the two who caused their confusion suffered no variation of colour.
vi: Wickham did not appear more distressed than she did. On the contrary, his demeanor was always pleasant, so much so that if his character and his wedding were as the family wished, his smiles and easy conversation when confirming their relationship would have pleased them. Elizabeth did not think he could be so brazen; but she sat down, resolute in her heart to never accept any shameless actions from a shameless person in the future. She blushed, Jane blushed; but the cheeks of the two, though embarrassed in different ways, were equally red.
tr: Wickham was not more troublesome than before, but his actions were so pleasant at every moment that if his personality and marriage were as they wished, his smile and easy conversation while expecting intimacy would give them all pleasure. Elizabeth had not previously believed that he could possess such confidence; but she sat down, resolving within herself that in the future she would set no limits to the shamelessness of a shameless man. Her face turned red, Jane's face turned red, but the color on the cheeks of the two people who upset them did not even flicker.
es: Wickham did not seem less pleased than she was; but his manners remained so pleasant that if his behavior and his marriage had been as they should, his smiles and his easy gestures in claiming the recognition of his kinship from his sisters-in-law would have charmed them all. Elizabeth never believed he was capable of such impudence, but she sat determined not to set limits henceforth to the shamelessness of a shameless person. Both Jane and she were blushing, but the cheeks of those who caused their embarrassment remained unchanged.

en: There was no want of discourse. The bride and her mother could neither of them talk fast enough; and Wickham, who happened to sit near Elizabeth, began inquiring after his acquaintance in that neighbourhood, with a good-humoured ease, which she felt very unable to equal in her replies. They seemed each of them to have the happiest memories in the world. Nothing of the past was recollected with pain; and Lydia led voluntarily to subjects which her sisters would not have alluded to for the world.
vi: No one wants her to perform lengthy speeches. The bride and the mother could not speak any faster. Wickham unintentionally sat close to Elizabeth, starting to inquire about the people he knew in the area with a cheerful and relaxed attitude, which she could not match in her responses. It seemed as if everyone had the best memories in the world. Nothing was recalled in sorrow; and Lydia herself steered the conversation to the incident that the older sisters did not want to mention to the public. Lydia exclaimed:
tr: There was no lack of conversation. Both the bride and her mother kept talking; Wickham, who was sitting close to Elizabeth, began to ask about acquaintances in the area with a cheerful ease; Elizabeth felt that she was having quite a hard time responding in the same manner. Both seemed to possess the happiest memories in the world. Nothing from the past was remembered with pain; Lydia willingly brought up topics that her sisters would never want to be mentioned in the world.
es: The conversation was not lacking. The bride and the mother talked without pause, and Wickham, who sat next to Elizabeth, began to ask about their acquaintances in the neighborhood with a cheerfulness and good humor that she could not have matched in her responses. Both Lydia and Wickham seemed to have wonderful memories. They remembered everything from the past without any regret, and she willingly spoke of things that her sisters would not have mentioned for anything in the world.

en: “Only think of its being three months,” she cried, “since I went away: it seems but a fortnight, I declare; and yet there have been things enough happened in the time. Good gracious! when I went away, I am sure I had no more idea of being married till I came back again! though I thought it would be very good fun if I was.”
vi: - Just thinking about the past three months since you left, it feels like it's only been two weeks, yet so much has happened. My God! When you left, you had no thoughts of marriage until you returned! Although I would be really happy if that’s truly what you thought.
tr: "Just imagine," he exclaimed, "it’s only been three months since I left; yet it feels like fifteen days to me; but so much has happened in that time. Oh my God! When I left, the idea of getting married never crossed my mind until I returned! Still, I thought that if I got married, it would be a lot of fun."
es: ––It's already been three months since I left! ––she exclaimed––. And it seems like it was only fifteen days ago! And yet, how many things have happened! My God! When I left, I had no idea that when I returned I would be married; although I thought it would be hilarious if that were the case.

en: Her father lifted up his eyes, Jane was distressed, Elizabeth looked expressively at Lydia; but she, who never heard nor saw anything of which she chose to be insensible, gaily continued,—
vi: The father raised his eyes. Jane felt uneasy. Elizabeth looked at Lydia meaningfully, but her sister, who never listened to or looked at anything she didn't like, cheerfully continued:
tr: Her father raised his eyes. Jane was bored, overwhelmed.
es: Her father raised his eyes; Jane was distressed; Elizabeth looked at Lydia significantly, but she, who never saw or heard what did not interest her, continued cheerfully:

en: “Oh, mamma, do the people hereabouts know I am married to-day? I was afraid they might not; and we overtook William Goulding in his curricle, so I was determined he should know it, and so I let down the side glass next to him, and took off my glove and let my hand just rest upon the window frame, so that he might see the ring, and then I bowed and smiled like anything.”
vi: - Oh, Ma-man! Do the people around here know that I got married today? I fear they don't, so when we passed by William Goulding's carriage, I lowered the window, took off my glove, and placed my hand on the window sill so he could see the wedding ring, then I bowed my head and smiled.
tr: Elizabeth looked meaningfully at Lydia; but Lydia, who preferred to be oblivious to the things she chose to ignore, continued cheerfully, "Oh, mother, do people know I got married today? I was afraid they might not know; we caught up with William Goulding on the road, in his carriage, I wanted him to see and find out, so I lowered the window on his side, took off my glove, and placed my hand on the window sill so he could see my ring, then I bowed my head and smiled calmly."
es: ––Mom, do the people around here know that I got married? I was afraid they didn't, and that's why, when we passed William Goulding's carriage, I wanted him to find out; I lowered the window on his side, took off my glove, and rested my hand on the window frame so he could see the ring. Then I greeted him and smiled as if nothing had happened.

en: Elizabeth could bear it no longer. She got up and ran out of the room; and returned no more, till she heard them passing through the hall to the dining-parlour. She then joined them soon enough to see Lydia, with anxious parade, walk up to her mother’s right hand, and hear her say to her eldest sister,—
vi: Elizabeth could not endure it any longer. She stood up, ran out of the room, and did not return until she heard them going to the dining room. She arrived just in time to see Lydia, with the intention of showing off, walk to her mother's right side and say to her eldest sister: - Ah!
tr: Elizabeth couldn't bear it any longer. She got up, ran out of the room, and didn't return until she heard them passing through the corridor to the dining room. Then she immediately went inside and, pretending to be worried, approached her mother on the right side and heard Lydia say to her eldest sister, "Well Jane, I'm taking your place now, your turn has passed, because I'm now a married woman.""
es: Elizabeth couldn't take it anymore. She got up and went to her room and didn't come down until she heard them passing through the hall towards the dining room. She arrived in time to see Lydia, strutting, taking her place at the table on their mother's right side and saying to her older sister:

en: “Ah, Jane, I take your place now, and you must go lower, because I am a married woman.”
vi: Sister Jane, I now take your place and you have to move down, because now I am a married woman.
tr: Then she immediately went inside and, pretending to be worried, approached her mother on the right side and heard Lydia say to her eldest sister, "Well Jane, I'm taking your place now, your turn has passed, because I'm now a married woman.""
es: ––Jane, now it is my turn to take your place. You move to second place, because I am a married woman.

en: It was not to be supposed that time would give Lydia that embarrassment from which she had been so wholly free at first. Her ease and good spirits increased. She longed to see Mrs. Philips, the Lucases, and all their other neighbours, and to hear herself called “Mrs. Wickham” by each of them; and in the meantime she went after dinner to show her ring and boast of being married to Mrs. Hill and the two housemaids.
vi: Do not assume that time would make Lydia embarrassed, so at first she was completely at ease. She became even more comfortable and cheerful. She expressed a desire to see Mrs. Philips, the Lucas family, and all the other neighbors, to hear each of them call her "Mrs. Wickham," and in the meantime, she showed Mrs. Hill and two other servants her ring and boasted to them that she was married.
tr: It was inconceivable that time would give Lydia a sense of shame that she initially lacked. Her comfort and cheerfulness increased. She wanted to see Mrs. Philips, the Lucases, and all the other neighbors, to hear each of them call her "Mrs. Wickham"; meanwhile, after dinner, she went to show her ring and boast about being married to Mrs. Hill and the two servants.
es: It was not to be supposed that time would give Lydia that composure which she had always lacked. Her peace of mind and her ease were increasing. She was eager to see Mrs. Philips, the Lucases, and all the other neighbors, to hear them call her "Mrs. Wickham." Meanwhile, after lunch, she went to show her wedding ring to Mrs. Hill and the two maids to boast about being married.

en: “Well, mamma,” said she, when they were all returned to the breakfast-room, “and what do you think of my husband? Is not he a charming man? I am sure my sisters must all envy me. I only hope they may have half my good luck. They must all go to Brighton. That is the place to get husbands. What a pity it is, mamma, we did not all go!”
vi: When they returned to the breakfast room, she said to her mother: - Hey, ma-man, what do you think about my husband? Is he a likable person? I am sure my sisters are all jealous of me. I just wish they had half the luck I have. The sisters should go to Brighton. This is the place to find a husband. Ma-man, it's a pity that we all didn't go together.
tr: "Honestly, mom," she said, as they all returned to the breakfast room, "what do you think about my husband? Isn't he a charming man? I'm sure all my sisters are jealous of me. I hope they are at least half as lucky as I am. They should all go to Brighton. That's the place to find a husband. It's a pity, mom, that we didn't all go together."
es: ––Well, Mom ––she said when everyone returned to the sitting room––, what do you think of my husband? Isn't he charming? I'm sure all my sisters envy me; I only wish they have half the luck I do. They should go to Brighton; it's an ideal place to find a husband. What a pity we all didn't go!

en: “Very true; and if I had my will we should. But, my dear Lydia, I don’t at all like your going such a way off. Must it be so?”
vi: - That's right, and if mother had the authority, all of us would have gone together. But dear Lydia, mother doesn't want you to go so far away. Is it necessary to go that far?
tr: "You are absolutely right; if they listened to me, we would have gone. But my dear Lydia, I don't like you going so far away. Is it necessary?"
es: ––It's true. If I were in charge, we would have gone. Lydia, my dear, I don't like it at all that you are going so far away. Does it have to be this way?

en: “Oh, Lord! yes; there is nothing in that. I shall like it of all things. You and papa, and my sisters, must come down and see us. We shall be at Newcastle all the winter, and I dare say there will be some balls, and I will take care to get good partners for them all.”
vi: - Oh, my God, I have to go – it's nothing. I will be happy with everything. Mom and dad and the sisters should come visit us. We will spend the winter in Newcastle; I dare say there will be some balls, and I will find dance partners for everyone.
tr: "Oh my God! yes; –there's nothing wrong with that. I like it. You, my father, my sisters will come and see me. We will be in Newcastle all winter; I'm sure there will be balls, I will make sure to find good partners for all of them."
es: ––Oh, Lord! Yes, there is no other choice. But I will like it a lot. You, dad, and my sisters have to come see us. We will be in Newcastle all winter, and there will surely be some dances; I will try to get good partners for everyone.

en: “I should like it beyond anything!” said her mother.
vi: The mother said: - Mom would like that more than anything else.
tr: "I want it more than anything!" said her mother.
es: ––That's what I would like the most! ––sighed her mother.

en: “And then when you go away, you may leave one or two of my sisters behind you; and I dare say I shall get husbands for them before the winter is over.”
vi: Elizabeth said:
tr: "And then, when you leave, you can leave a couple of my sisters with me; I'm sure I'll find them husbands before the winter ends.""
es: ––And when you return, let one or two of my sisters stay with us, and I am sure I will have found them a husband before the winter is over:

en: “I thank you for my share of the favour,” said Elizabeth; “but I do not particularly like your way of getting husbands.”
vi: - I appreciate your good intentions, but I particularly dislike the way you are looking for a husband for me.
tr: "Thanks, I'll pass," said Elizabeth; "I don't quite like your way of finding a husband."
es: ––I appreciate the intention ––replied Elizabeth––, but I don't quite like, to say the least, your way of getting a husband.

en: Their visitors were not to remain above ten days with them. Mr. Wickham had received his commission before he left London, and he was to join his regiment at the end of a fortnight.
vi: The two people stayed for no more than ten days. Mr. Wickham had completed the enlistment procedures before he left London, and he needed to report to the regiment within two weeks.
tr: The guests would not stay with them for more than ten days. Mr. Wickham had received his assignment before leaving London and would join his unit in fifteen days.
es: The guests were going to stay at Longbourn for only ten days. Wickham had received his assignment before leaving London and had to join his regiment within a fortnight.

en: No one but Mrs. Bennet regretted that their stay would be so short; and she made the most of the time by visiting about with her daughter, and having very frequent parties at home. These parties were acceptable to all; to avoid a family circle was even more desirable to such as did think than such as did not.
vi: Except for Mrs. Bennet, no one expressed regret that the two stayed for such a short time. She made the most of the time by taking her daughter to visit various people and often organizing gatherings at home. Everyone accepted these gatherings at home; the thought of avoiding family reunions was better than not thinking at all.
tr: No one but Mrs. Bennet was upset that they would stay so briefly; Mrs. Bennet made good use of the time, visiting friends and acquaintances with her daughter, and frequently hosting parties at home. These parties seemed reasonable to everyone; in fact, those troubled by family matters enjoyed escaping the family atmosphere more than those who were not troubled.
es: Nobody, except Mrs. Bennet, felt that their stay was too short. Most of the time was spent making visits accompanied by her daughter and organizing parties at the house. The parties were pleasant for everyone; avoiding the family circle was even more desirable for those who thought than for those who did not think.

en: Wickham’s affection for Lydia was just what Elizabeth had expected to find it; not equal to Lydia’s for him. She had scarcely needed her present observation to be satisfied, from the reason of things, that their elopement had been brought on by the strength of her love rather than by his; and she would have wondered why, without violently caring for her, he chose to elope with her at all, had she not felt certain that his flight was rendered necessary by distress of circumstances; and if that were the case, he was not the young man to resist an opportunity of having a companion.
vi: The feelings of Wickham towards Lydia were exactly as Elizabeth had thought: not as strong as Lydia's feelings for him. According to her own reasoning, she did not need to observe much to understand that the elopement was more due to her sister's love than his. She could have wondered why, if he did not love her sister much, he wanted to elope with her. This was simply because she believed that he surely needed to do so due to his dire circumstances, and if that were the case, he was not a young man who would pass up the opportunity to find himself a companion.
tr: Wickham's interest in Lydia was exactly as Elizabeth had predicted; it was not equal to the interest Lydia showed him. It did not need to be confirmed that their elopement stemmed from the strength of Lydia's love rather than Wickham's; even though he did not have a strong desire for Lydia, he might have wondered why he agreed to run away with her if he were not sure that the hopelessness of his circumstances necessitated it; and even in that situation, he was not a man who could resist the opportunity to have a companion by his side.
es: Wickham's affection for Lydia was exactly as Elizabeth had imagined it, and very different from Lydia's affection for him. Elizabeth needed only to observe her sister a little to realize that the elopement had been driven more by Lydia's love for him than by his love for her. She would have been surprised that Wickham had eloped with a woman towards whom he felt no special attraction, if she had not been certain that his dire situation had forced that action upon him, and he was not the kind of man, in such a case, to pass up the opportunity of having a companion.

en: Lydia was exceedingly fond of him. He was her dear Wickham on every occasion; no one was to be put in competition with him. He did everything best in the world; and she was sure he would kill more birds on the first of September than anybody else in the country.
vi: Lydia loved him dearly. In every circumstance, he was always her beloved Mr. Wickham; no one could take him away from her. He was everything good in the world, and she was certain that on the first day of September, he would shoot more birds than anyone else in the country.
tr: Lydia was extremely fond of him. He was her dear Wickham in every situation; no one could compare to him. He did everything in the world better than anyone else; Lydia was sure he would kill more birds than anyone else in the village one September.
es: Lydia was crazy about him; her "dear Wickham" was always on her lips, he was the most perfect man in the world and everything he did was well done. She assured that at the beginning of September Wickham would kill more birds than anyone in the region.

en: One morning, soon after their arrival, as she was sitting with her two elder sisters, she said to Elizabeth,—
vi: One morning, not long after the two arrived, while Lydia was sitting and talking with her two older sisters, she said to Elizabeth:
tr: Shortly after their arrival, one morning while sitting with her two sisters, Elizabeth said,
es: One morning, shortly after her arrival, while she was sitting with her older sisters, Lydia said to Elizabeth:

en: “Lizzy, I never gave you an account of my wedding, I believe. You were not by, when I told mamma, and the others, all about it. Are not you curious to hear how it was managed?”
vi: - Lizzy, you have never told me about your wedding. When you talk to mom and others, I am not comfortable with it. Do you wonder how the event was organized?
tr: "Lizzy, I don't think I told you about my wedding. You weren't there when I was telling my mom and others. Aren't you curious about how it was?"
es: ––I don't think I've told you yet how my wedding was. You weren't there when I explained it to mom and the others. Aren't you interested in knowing?

en: “No, really,” replied Elizabeth; “I think there cannot be too little said on the subject.”
vi: Elizabeth replied: - She is not exactly puzzled.
tr: "I do not believe it," replied Elizabeth; "the less we know, the better.""
es: ––Really, no ––replied Elizabeth––; you shouldn't talk much about that matter.

en: “La! You are so strange! But I must tell you how it went off. We were married, you know, at St. Clement’s, because Wickham’s lodgings were in that parish. And it was settled that we should all be there by eleven o’clock. My uncle and aunt and I were to go together; and the others were to meet us at the church.
vi: She thinks that talking about the incident could go on forever. - There, you are so strange! But I need to tell you. You know, we got married at St. Clement's Church because Wickham resided in that parish. And we decided to go there at eleven o'clock. My uncle, aunt, and I will go together, while the others will meet us at the church.
tr: "Oh my God! You are so strange!" "But I will tell you anyway." "As you know, we got married at St. Clement's because Wickham's house was in that neighborhood." "It was decided that everyone would be there by eleven o'clock." "My uncle, aunt, and I were going to go together; the others would meet us at the church."
es: ––Oh, how strange you are! But I want to tell you about it. You already know that we got married in San Clemente because Wickham's lodging belonged to that parish. We had agreed to all be there at eleven. My uncles and I had to go together and meet the others at the church.

en: “Well, Monday morning came, and I was in such a fuss! I was so afraid, you know, that something would happen to put it off, and then I should have gone quite distracted. And there was my aunt, all the time I was dressing, preaching and talking away just as if she was reading a sermon. However, I did not hear above one word in ten, for I was thinking, you may suppose, of my dear Wickham. I longed to know whether he would be married in his blue coat.
vi: And well, Monday morning came, I was so nervous! You know, I was very afraid that something might happen to cancel the wedding, and then I would be in a mess. And with my aunt here, I was getting dressed, she was pleading and talking incessantly as if she were preaching. However, I could only catch bits and pieces, because I was thinking about, you can guess, my dear Wickham. I wanted to know if he would wear the blue coat for the wedding ceremony or not.
tr: "Honestly, when Monday morning came, I panicked so much!" "I was so scared that something would come up and prevent it, and I would go crazy again." "Especially my aunt, while I was getting dressed, she kept preaching, talking continuously like she was reciting a prayer." "But I could only hear one out of ten of her words, because, you understand, my mind was on my dear Wickham." "I was wondering if he would wear his blue jacket at the wedding."
es: Well, Monday morning arrived and I was beside myself. You know? I was so afraid that something would happen to ruin everything, I would have gone crazy! While I was getting dressed, my aunt kept preaching to me non-stop as if she were reading me a sermon. But I didn't hear even a tenth of her words because, as you can imagine, I was thinking about my dear Wickham, and whether he would wear his blue suit for the wedding.

en: “Well, and so we breakfasted at ten as usual: I thought it would never be over; for, by the bye, you are to understand that my uncle and aunt were horrid unpleasant all the time I was with them. If you’ll believe me, I did not once put my foot out of doors, though I was there a fortnight. Not one party, or scheme, or anything! To be sure, London was rather thin, but, however, the Little Theatre was open.
vi: "Ah, and then everyone had breakfast at ten o'clock as usual; I thought the meal would never end, because, by the way, you will know, my uncle and aunt are terribly unpleasant whenever they are near me. If you can believe me, I haven't stepped out the door in the entire two weeks I've been here. No gatherings, plans, or anything. London is actually quite dull, but there is a theater performing.
tr: "Then, as usual, we had breakfast at ten; I thought it would never end because, you know, my uncle and aunt were terribly unpleasant while I was there. Believe it or not, I didn't even step outside the door, even though I stayed there for fifteen days. No parties, no plans, nothing. Although London was also dull, at least the Little Theater was open.
es: "Well, we had breakfast at ten, as usual." "I thought it would never end, because you should know that my uncles were extremely annoying with me the whole time I spent with them." "Believe me, I didn't set foot outside the house in fifteen days; no parties, no excursions, nothing!" "The truth is that London wasn't very lively; but the Little Theatre was open."

en: “Well, and so, just as the carriage came to the door, my uncle was called away upon business to that horrid man Mr. Stone. And then, you know, when once they get together, there is no end of it. Well, I was so frightened I did not know what to do, for my uncle was to give me away; and if we were beyond the hour we could not be married all day. But, luckily, he came back again in ten minutes’ time, and then we all set out. However, I recollected afterwards, that if he had been prevented going, the wedding need not be put off, for Mr. Darcy might have done as well.”
vi: Ah, and when a carriage came to the doorstep, my uncle was called away to do some work for that annoying Mr. Stone. And then, you know, whenever the two meet, they can't seem to part. Ah, I was so worried that I didn't know what to do, because my uncle was supposed to take me to the wedding, and if we were late, we couldn't get married. But, fortunately, ten minutes later he returned, and then everyone went together. However, I later remembered, if my uncle couldn't go, there was no need to postpone the wedding, because Mr. Darcy could help."
tr: Oh, just as the car was pulling up to the door, didn't that awful man, Mr. Stone, call my uncle for work. You know, when those two get together, it never ends. I was so scared I didn't know what to do because my uncle was supposed to give me away; moreover, if we missed the time, we couldn't get married all day. But luckily, he came back in ten minutes, and we all set off together. But then it occurred to me that even if he couldn't come, the wedding wouldn't have to be postponed because Mr. Darcy could also perform his duties."
es: "As soon as the car arrived at the door, my uncle had to attend to that horrible Mr. Stone for some matter." "And you know that as soon as they meet, it takes a long time." "Well, I was so scared that I didn't know what to do, because my uncle was going to be the best man, and if we arrived late, we wouldn't be able to get married that day." "But fortunately, my uncle was ready in two minutes and we left for the church." "But then I remembered that if Uncle Gardiner hadn't been able to go to the wedding, it wouldn't have been canceled anyway, because Mr. Darcy could have taken his place."

en: “Mr. Darcy!” repeated Elizabeth, in utter amazement.
vi: Elizabeth repeated, astonished: - Mr. Darcy!
tr: "Mr. Darcy!" repeated Elizabeth, in horror.
es: Mr. Darcy! ––repeated Elizabeth in complete astonishment.

en: “Oh, yes! he was to come there with Wickham, you know. But, gracious me! I quite forgot! I ought not to have said a word about it. I promised them so faithfully! What will Wickham say? It was to be such a secret!”
vi: - Ah, that's right! He will come with Wickham, you know. But poor me! I forgot! I shouldn't have said a word about this. I had sincerely promised them. What will Wickham say? This is a secret!
tr: "Oh yes! –he was going to come with Wickham. Oh my God! I completely forgot! I wasn't supposed to mention this. I had given them my word of honor! What will Wickham say now? It was supposed to remain a secret!"
es: Of course! He was accompanying Wickham, you know. But alas, I had forgotten! I shouldn't have said it. I promised faithfully. What will Wickham say? It was a secret!

en: “If it was to be a secret,” said Jane, “say not another word on the subject. You may depend upon my seeking no further.”
vi: Jane said: - If it's a secret, don't say anything more. The two of us won't want to know more.
tr: "If it was meant to remain a secret," said Jane, "don't say another word. You can be sure that I don't want to hear anything else."
es: ––If it was a secret ––said Jane–– don't say another word. I don't want to know.

en: “Oh, certainly,” said Elizabeth, though burning with curiosity; “we will ask you no questions.”
vi: Elizabeth said, though restless with curiosity: - Ah, that's right, you two won't ask anything.
tr: "Oh, of course," said Elizabeth, even though she was burning with curiosity; "we won't ask you any questions."
es: ––Naturally ––added Elizabeth, even though she was dying of curiosity––, we won't ask you anything.

en: “Thank you,” said Lydia; “for if you did, I should certainly tell you all, and then Wickham would be so angry.”
vi: Lydia said: - Thank you both, because if you had asked, I would have certainly told you everything, and then Wickham would have been furious.
tr: "Thank you," said Lydia, "because if you had asked, I would have told you everything, and Wickham would have blushed."
es: ––Thank you ––said Lydia––, because if you asked me, I would tell you everything and Wickham would get angry.

en: On such encouragement to ask, Elizabeth was forced to put it out of her power, by running away.
vi: With such encouragement to ask questions, Elizabeth was forced to avoid it by running away.
tr: Upon such an invitation to ask a question, Elizabeth ran outside and had to restrain herself.
es: With such an incentive to coax him, Elizabeth refrained from doing so and to avoid the temptation, she left.

en: But to live in ignorance on such a point was impossible; or at least it was impossible not to try for information. Mr. Darcy had been at her sister’s wedding. It was exactly a scene, and exactly among people, where he had apparently least to do, and least temptation to go. Conjectures as to the meaning of it, rapid and wild, hurried into her brain; but she was satisfied with none. Those that best pleased her, as placing his conduct in the noblest light, seemed most improbable. She could not bear such suspense; and hastily seizing a sheet of paper, wrote a short letter to her aunt, to request an explanation of what Lydia had dropped, if it were compatible with the secrecy which had been intended.
vi: But she found it difficult to live without knowing about such matters, or at least difficult not to want to find out. Mr. Darcy had attended her sister’s wedding. Clearly, it was precisely such a setting and precisely such people that he did not want to attend and did not want to meet. Speculations about the meaning of this arose wildly in her mind, but she was not satisfied with any of them. The speculation that pleased her the most, placing him in the highest regard, seemed impossible to be true. She could not bear such intense thoughts, so she hurriedly grabbed a piece of paper and wrote a short letter to her aunt to ask her to explain the matter Lydia had just brought up, to see if this matched the secretive nature they had identified.
tr: However, it was impossible to live without knowing something about such a point; or at least, it was impossible not to try to gain information. Mr. Darcy had attended his sister's wedding. This was a scene and a group of people in which he had the least interest and the least desire to go. Quick and frantic guesses about its meaning swarmed his mind, but none were satisfactory. The ones he liked the most, that is, those which placed his behavior in the noblest light, seemed the most impossible. He could not bear this tension; he hastily took paper and pen and wrote a short letter to his aunt, asking for an explanation about the things Lydia had not mentioned, if the situation allowed for confidentiality.
es: But ignoring that was impossible or, at the very least, it was impossible not to try to find out. Darcy had attended Lydia's wedding. Both the event and its protagonists seemed precisely the least likely for Darcy to get involved with them. Quick and confused conjectures about what that meant crossed her mind, but none seemed acceptable to her. The ones that pleased her the most, because they exalted Darcy, were apparently improbable. She could not bear such uncertainty, so she hurried and grabbed a sheet of paper to write a brief letter to her aunt asking her to clarify what Lydia had let slip, if it was compatible with the secrecy of the matter.

en: “You may readily comprehend,” she added, “what my curiosity must be to know how a person unconnected with any of us, and, comparatively speaking, a stranger to our family, should have been amongst you at such a time. Pray write instantly, and let me understand it—unless it is, for very cogent reasons, to remain in the secrecy which Lydia seems to think necessary; and then I must endeavour to be satisfied with ignorance.”
vi: She added: "You can immediately understand my eagerness to know how someone who has no relation to anyone in our family, a stranger to the family, could attend such a ceremony." "Please write back to me immediately and help me understand – except for the reason that Lydia thinks it necessary to keep it secret, after which I will be at ease and not want to know anything more."
tr: "As you might imagine," he added, "I was extremely curious to see someone among you who has no ties to any of us, a stranger to our family (relatively speaking, I mean) at such a moment. Please write immediately so that I can understand – of course, if Lydia does not need to maintain secrecy for very credible reasons; in that case, I will have to try to live without knowing."
es: "You will understand," he added, "that I need to know why a person who has nothing to do with us and who, properly speaking, is a stranger to our family, was with you at that moment." "I beg you to reply by return mail and explain it to me, unless there are powerful reasons that impose the secrecy Lydia mentions, in which case I will have to try to resign myself to ignorance."

en: “Not that I shall, though,” she added to herself, and she finished the letter; “and, my dear aunt, if you do not tell me in an honourable manner, I shall certainly be reduced to tricks and stratagems to find it out.”
vi: She thought, upon finishing the letter: "Although you won't feel at ease, dear aunt, if you don't let me know in an honorable manner, I will certainly resort to tricks to find out."
tr: "But it won't be necessary, of course," he added to himself, as he finished the letter; "and, my dear aunt, if you don't explain it to me clearly, I will have no choice but to resort to some tricks to find out.""
es: “But I will not do it,” she said to herself upon finishing the letter; “and dear aunt, if you do not tell me, I will be forced to resort to tricks and stratagems to find out.”

en: Jane’s delicate sense of honour would not allow her to speak to Elizabeth privately of what Lydia had let fall; Elizabeth was glad of it:—till it appeared whether her inquiries would receive any satisfaction, she had rather be without a confidante.
vi: Jane's delicate and honorable nature did not allow her to speak privately with Elizabeth about what Lydia had revealed. Elizabeth was pleased about this – until her inquiries were satisfactorily answered, she had to endure the situation without a confidant.
tr: Jane's delicate sense of honor would not allow her to secretly discuss with Elizabeth what Lydia had let slip; Elizabeth was pleased with this; she preferred to be without a confidante until her questions were answered.
es: Jane's delicate sense of honor prevented her from speaking alone with Elizabeth about what had slipped out to Lydia. Elizabeth was glad, although in this way, if her inquiries were successful, she would not be able to have a confidant.

en: CHAPTER LII.
vi: Chapter 52
tr: Chapter X
es: CHAPTER LII

en: ELIZABETH had the satisfaction of receiving an answer to her letter as soon as she possibly could. She was no sooner in possession of it, than hurrying into the little copse, where she was least likely to be interrupted, she sat down on one of the benches, and prepared to be happy; for the length of the letter convinced her that it did not contain a denial.
vi: Elizabeth was pleased to receive a reply to her letter as quickly as she had hoped. As soon as she received the letter, she hurried to a grove in the garden where she was least likely to be disturbed, sat on a bench, and prepared for the pleasure, as the letter looked quite long, indicating that there was no secrecy being kept from her.
tr: Elizabeth received a reply to her letter as quickly as possible. As soon as the letter reached her hands, she hurried to the small grove, the place where she would be least disturbed, sat on one of the benches, and prepared to be happy; because the letter was too long to be dismissive.
es: Elizabeth had the satisfaction of receiving an immediate response to her letter. She ran with it to the grove, where there was less chance of being disturbed, sat on a bench, and prepared to be happy, as the length of the letter convinced her that it did not contain a refusal.

en: “Gracechurch Street, Sept. 6.
vi: "Gracechurch Street, September 6,
tr: "Gracechurch Street, September 6"
es: Gracechurch Street, September 8.

en: “My dear Niece,
vi: My dear niece/nephew,
tr: Dear Nephew,
es: My dear niece: I have just received your letter and I am going to dedicate the whole morning to answering it, as I believe that in a few words I will not be able to tell you all that I have to share with you.

en: “I have just received your letter, and shall devote this whole morning to answering it, as I foresee that a little writing will not comprise what I have to tell you. I must confess myself surprised by your application; I did not expect it from you. Don’t think me angry, however, for I only mean to let you know, that I had not imagined such inquiries to be necessary on your side. If you do not choose to understand me, forgive my impertinence. Your uncle is as much surprised as I am; and nothing but the belief of your being a party concerned would have allowed him to act as he has done. But if you are really innocent and ignorant, I must be more explicit. On the very day of my coming home from Longbourn, your uncle had a most unexpected visitor. Mr. Darcy called, and was shut up with him several hours. It was all over before I arrived; so my curiosity was not so dreadfully racked as yours seems to have been. He came to tell Mr. Gardiner that he had found out where your sister and Mr. Wickham were, and that he had seen and talked with them both—Wickham repeatedly, Lydia once. From what I can collect, he left Derbyshire only one day after ourselves, and came to town with the resolution of hunting for them. The motive professed was his conviction of its being owing to himself that Wickham’s worthlessness had not been so well known as to make it impossible for any young woman of character to love or confide in him. He generously imputed the whole to his mistaken pride, and confessed that he had before thought it beneath him to lay his private actions open to the world. His character was to speak for itself. He called it, therefore, his duty to step forward, and endeavour to remedy an evil which had been brought on by himself. If he had another motive, I am sure it would never disgrace him. He had been some days in town before he was able to discover them; but he had something to direct his search, which was more than we had; and the consciousness of this was another reason for his resolving to follow us. There is a lady, it seems, a Mrs. Younge, who was some time ago governess to Miss Darcy, and was dismissed from her charge on some cause of disapprobation, though he did not say what. She then took a large house in Edward Street, and has since maintained herself by letting lodgings. This Mrs. Younge was, he knew, intimately acquainted with Wickham; and he went to her for intelligence of him, as soon as he got to town. But it was two or three days before he could get from her what he wanted. She would not betray her trust, I suppose, without bribery and corruption, for she really did know where her friend was to be found. Wickham, indeed, had gone to her on their first arrival in London; and had she been able to receive them into her house, they would have taken up their abode with her. At length, however, our kind friend procured the wished-for direction. They were in —— Street. He saw Wickham, and afterwards insisted on seeing Lydia. His first object with her, he acknowledged, had been to persuade her to quit her present disgraceful situation, and return to her friends as soon as they could be prevailed on to receive her, offering his assistance as far as it would go. But he found Lydia absolutely resolved on remaining where she was. She cared for none of her friends; she wanted no help of his; she would not hear of leaving Wickham. She was sure they should be married some time or other, and it did not much signify when. Since such were her feelings, it only remained, he thought, to secure and expedite a marriage, which, in his very first conversation with Wickham, he easily learnt had never been his design. He confessed himself obliged to leave the regiment on account of some debts of honour which were very pressing; and scrupled not to lay all the ill consequences of Lydia’s flight on her own folly alone. He meant to resign his commission immediately; and as to his future situation, he could conjecture very little about it. He must go somewhere, but he did not know where, and he knew he should have nothing to live on. Mr. Darcy asked why he did not marry your sister at once. Though Mr. Bennet was not imagined to be very rich, he would have been able to do something for him, and his situation must have been benefited by marriage. But he found, in reply to this question, that Wickham still cherished the hope of more effectually making his fortune by marriage, in some other country. Under such circumstances, however, he was not likely to be proof against the temptation of immediate relief. They met several times, for there was much to be discussed. Wickham, of course, wanted more than he could get; but at length was reduced to be reasonable. Everything being settled between them, Mr. Darcy’s next step was to make your uncle acquainted with it, and he first called in Gracechurch Street the evening before I came home. But Mr. Gardiner could not be seen; and Mr. Darcy found, on further inquiry, that your father was still with him, but would quit town the next morning. He did not judge your father to be a person whom he could so properly consult as your uncle, and therefore readily postponed seeing him till after the departure of the former. He did not leave his name, and till the next day it was only known that a gentleman had called on business. On Saturday he came again. Your father was gone, your uncle at home, and, as I said before, they had a great deal of talk together. They met again on Sunday, and then I saw him too. It was not all settled before Monday: as soon as it was, the express was sent off to Longbourn. But our visitor was very obstinate. I fancy, Lizzy, that obstinacy is the real defect of his character, after all. He has been accused of many faults at different times; but this is the true one. Nothing was to be done that he did not do himself; though I am sure (and I do not speak it to be thanked, therefore say nothing about it) your uncle would most readily have settled the whole. They battled it together for a long time, which was more than either the gentleman or lady concerned in it deserved. But at last your uncle was forced to yield, and instead of being allowed to be of use to his niece, was forced to put up with only having the probable credit of it, which went sorely against the grain; and I really believe your letter this morning gave him great pleasure, because it required an explanation that would rob him of his borrowed feathers, and give the praise where it was due. But, Lizzy, this must go no further than yourself, or Jane at most. You know pretty well, I suppose, what has been done for the young people. His debts are to be paid, amounting, I believe, to considerably more than a thousand pounds, another thousand in addition to her own settled upon her, and his commission purchased. The reason why all this was to be done by him alone, was such as I have given above. It was owing to him, to his reserve and want of proper consideration, that Wickham’s character had been so misunderstood, and consequently that he had been received and noticed as he was. Perhaps there was some truth in this; though I doubt whether his reserve, or anybody’s reserve can be answerable for the event. But in spite of all this fine talking, my dear Lizzy, you may rest perfectly assured that your uncle would never have yielded, if we had not given him credit for another interest in the affair. When all this was resolved on, he returned again to his friends, who were still staying at Pemberley; but it was agreed that he should be in London once more when the wedding took place, and all money matters were then to receive the last finish. I believe I have now told you everything. It is a relation which you tell me is to give you great surprise; I hope at least it will not afford you any displeasure. Lydia came to us, and Wickham had constant admission to the house. He was exactly what he had been when I knew him in Hertfordshire; but I would not tell you how little I was satisfied with her behaviour while she stayed with us, if I had not perceived, by Jane’s letter last Wednesday, that her conduct on coming home was exactly of a piece with it, and therefore what I now tell you can give you no fresh pain. I talked to her repeatedly in the most serious manner, representing to her the wickedness of what she had done, and all the unhappiness she had brought on her family. If she heard me, it was by good luck, for I am sure she did not listen. I was sometimes quite provoked; but then I recollected my dear Elizabeth and Jane, and for their sakes had patience with her. Mr. Darcy was punctual in his return, and, as Lydia imformed you, attended the wedding. He dined with us the next day, and was to leave town again on Wednesday or Thursday. Will you be very angry with me, my dear Lizzy, if I take this opportunity of saying (what I was never bold enough to say before) how much I like him? His behaviour to us has, in every respect, been as pleasing as when we were in Derbyshire. His understanding and opinions all please me; he wants nothing but a little more liveliness, and that, if he marry prudently, his wife may teach him. I thought him very sly; he hardly ever mentioned your name. But slyness seems the fashion. Pray forgive me, if I have been very presuming, or at least do not punish me so far as to exclude me from P. I shall never be quite happy till I have been all round the park. A low phaeton with a nice little pair of ponies would be the very thing. But I must write no more. The children have been wanting me this half hour.
vi: Auntie just received your letter, and she spent the entire morning writing a reply, because she anticipated that if she wrote briefly, it wouldn't be enough to convey everything she wants to say to you. I must say that Auntie was surprised when she received your request; she didn't think such a request would come from you. However, don't think that Auntie is upset, because she just wants you to understand that she thinks you don't need to inquire in such a manner. If you don't want to understand Auntie, she apologizes for digressing. Your uncle was just as surprised as Auntie. He did those things only because he thought you were involved. But if you are truly unaware and innocent, Auntie needs to clarify further. "On the very day you returned home from Longbourn, your uncle received an unexpected guest. Mr. Darcy came to visit, and the two talked for many hours. By the time you arrived, they had finished; therefore, your curiosity was not as tormenting as mine. Mr. Darcy came to inform Mr. Gardiner that he had found the place where your sister and Mr. Wickham were hiding, and he had met and talked with both of them, several times with Wickham, and once with Lydia. If I remember correctly, he left Derbyshire just one day after we returned, and went to the city with the determination to find them. He explained that his motivation in this was because he thought that due to him, not many people were aware of Wickham's true character, otherwise he could have prevented respectable young women from mistakenly falling in love with him. Mr. Darcy blamed his misplaced pride for the entire affair, confessing that he previously thought it beneath him to expose the private actions of the other man to everyone. Therefore, he felt it was his duty to act and try to rectify the mistake he had caused. If Mr. Darcy had any other motivation, I think it would not cause him any shame. “He came to the city and within just a few days found two people, because he had some clues that we didn't have, and his awareness of this was another reason why he was determined to help you search. It seems there was a woman, Mrs. Younge, who was previously a governess for Miss Darcy, but was later dismissed for some reason that Mr. Darcy did not disclose. She moved to a large house on Edward Street, and since then has been living by renting out rooms. Mr. Darcy knew this woman was close to Wickham, so as soon as he arrived in the city, he went to find her to inquire. But it took one or two days for her to give him any information. I think this woman didn't want to betray Wickham's trust unless there was money involved, because she really knew where her friend was staying. In fact, Wickham went to find her as soon as the two of them arrived in London, and if she had the means to accommodate them, they would have stayed at her place. However, in the end, our kind friend Mr. Darcy managed to get the information. He went to meet Wickham, and then insisted on meeting Lydia. Mr. Darcy said his purpose was to persuade her to get out of the disgraceful situation, to return to her family as soon as they showed willingness to take her back and support her. But he found Lydia determined to stay where they were hiding. She didn't care about her family, she didn't want him to help her, she didn't want to hear about leaving Wickham. She was convinced that she and Wickham would get married someday, but didn't specify when that would be. "Mr. Darcy thought that given her feelings, the only thing left to do was to expedite the wedding, although in his first conversation with Wickham, Mr. Darcy clearly saw that this was never in his intentions. Wickham only talked about resigning from the militia due to pressing debts of honor, without considering the negative consequences of Lydia's elopement, which were solely due to her own foolishness. He intended to resign as an officer immediately, and as for his future, he had no concrete plans. He had to go somewhere but did not know where, and he was well aware that he had no income to live on. Mr. Darcy asked him why he did not marry your sister right away. Although no one thought Mr. Bennet was wealthy, he could still do something for him, and his situation would improve thanks to the marriage. But from Wickham's response, Mr. Darcy realized that he still harbored hopes of securing a better fortune through marriage elsewhere. However, given the circumstances, he still wanted to quickly escape his current difficulties. The two met several times as there were many matters to discuss. Of course, Wickham wanted more than what he could receive, but in the end, the two reached a reasonable agreement. "Everything was agreed upon by the two of them. Next, Mr. Darcy intended to explain his plan clearly to your uncle, and he went to Gracechurch Street one evening before your aunt returned home. But he did not meet Mr. Gardiner, and upon further inquiry, Mr. Darcy found out that your father was with him, but would be leaving the city the next morning. He thought your father was not someone he could consult as effectively as your uncle, so he waited until your father left before meeting your uncle. He did not leave his name, so until the next day, everyone only knew that a gentleman wanted to discuss business matters. He returned on Saturday. By then, your father had left, your uncle was at home, and as your aunt mentioned above, they talked for a long time. They met again on Sunday; that was when your aunt also met him. It wasn't until Monday that they agreed on everything, and immediately after, your uncle sent an urgent letter to Longbourn. “But Mr. Darcy is very stubborn, Lizzy, I think this stubbornness is truly a flaw of Mr. Darcy. At different times, he must have been condemned for different faults, but this is the real flaw. Nothing can be done unless he takes charge himself, although I am sure your uncle is willing to take care of everything. They kept arguing with each other for a long time, longer than two young people deserve to be concerned about. But in the end, your uncle was forced to yield, and instead of being allowed to act to help his niece, he only received credit for the arrangement. This goes against his nature, and I truly think your letter made him infinitely happy; this explanatory letter helped him remove the false mask of gratitude and place the benefactor in his rightful position. But, Lizzy, you should not reveal this to anyone, at most only to Jane. I think you already know quite well how they arranged things for the two young people. I believe the amount of money to cover his debts was more than a thousand pounds, plus another thousand pounds for her in addition to what she received from her family, and the cost for him to join the army. The reason why Mr. Darcy wanted to do all this, I mentioned above. Mr. Darcy thinks that because of him, due to his reserve and lack of prudent judgment, others did not understand Wickham's character, hence the incident occurred. There may be some truth in this, but I am not sure whether to blame his reserve or the reserve of anyone else. “But despite having such a clever way of speaking, my dear Lizzy, you can rest assured that your uncle would never have conceded if he and your aunt did not believe that Mr. Darcy had another interest in arranging this matter. Once they had agreed on everything, he returned to his friends who were still staying at Pemberley, but they agreed that he would return to London once more on the wedding day, at which time all the financial matters would be settled. "I think I have now told you everything clearly. The relationship you mentioned to me will surprise and delight you; I hope at least it does not bother you. Lydia is staying with us, and Wickham often visits. He is still the same person I understood him to be in Hertfordshire. As for Lydia, I wouldn't want to tell you that I am not very pleased with her attitude if I hadn't realized, through Jane's letter last Wednesday, that her behavior when visiting home would be the same, so now saying it won't cause you any more pain. I often speak to her in the most serious manner, showing her all the harm her actions have caused and all the suffering she has brought to the family. If she happens to hear what I say, it is by luck, because I am certain she does not listen. Sometimes I get annoyed, but I think of dear Jane and Elizabeth, and for their sake, I try to endure her. “Mr. Darcy returned as promised, and as Lydia informed you, he attended the wedding. The next day, he dined with the family, and he will leave the city on Wednesday or Thursday. My dear, you may be very angry with me if I take this opportunity to say that I am very fond of him. In every aspect, his demeanor is as pleasant as when we were in Derbyshire. All his knowledge and opinions please me; he only lacks a bit of liveliness, but his wife could influence him in this regard, if he chooses his spouse carefully. I think he is quite reserved – he almost never mentions your name. But discretion seems to be a fashionable trait. Forgive me if I have any undue thoughts, or at least do not punish me by forbidding me from coming to P. I will never be satisfied until I have the opportunity to take a full tour around the garden. A four-wheeled carriage with a pair of small horses is sufficient. But I cannot write any more. My children have been clamoring for me for half an hour now.
tr: I just received your letter; since I anticipate that a short writing will not suffice to explain everything I need to tell you, I will dedicate the entire morning to replying. I must confess that I am surprised by your request; I did not expect this from you. Do not think that I am angry, but I want you to know that I did not think you would need to ask such questions. If you are having difficulty understanding me, please excuse my intervention. Your uncle was as surprised as I was – he would never have acted this way if he believed you were aware of the matter. But if you are truly unaware, then I must be more explicit. The day I returned home from Longbourn, your uncle received an unexpected visitor. Mr. Darcy came, and they locked themselves in a room for several hours. Everything was over before I arrived; therefore, my curiosity was not as agonizing as yours. Mr. Darcy came to tell Mr. Gardiner that he had found out where your sister and Mr. Wickham were, had seen them, had spoken with Wickham frequently, and with Lydia once. As far as I can understand, he left Derbyshire a day after us and came to the city with the aim of finding them. The reason for his action was that he felt responsible for the fact that Wickham's villainy was not sufficiently known; if it were known, it would be impossible for well-bred girls to love or trust him. He found all the blame in his own faulty pride; he admitted that he did not consider it appropriate to reveal private matters to the public. Therefore, he felt it his duty to come forward and make an effort to remedy a wrong he had caused. If there is another reason, I am sure it is not one that would embarrass him. He spent a few days in the city until he found them; unlike us, he knew where to direct his search; knowing this was another reason he decided to follow us. It appears there is a lady, someone named Mrs. Younge, who was Miss Darcy's governess for a while; he did not say exactly what happened, but she was dismissed for some reason. The lady then rented a large house on Edward Street and has been making a living by renting rooms since then. He knew that Mrs. Younge was well acquainted with Wickham and went to her for information as soon as he arrived in the city. But it took two or three days to get what he wanted from her. Apparently, he had to bribe her to betray Wickham because she really knew where her friend was. Wickham had actually gone to her first when he came to London; if she could have accommodated him, they would have stayed with her. But in the end, our kind-hearted friend got the address he wanted. They were on ------- street. He saw Wickham and then insisted on seeing Lydia. His initial aim regarding Lydia was to persuade her to end that disgraceful situation and return to her relatives, as soon as they were willing to accept her, and he offered to help as much as he could to achieve this. But he saw that Lydia was determined to stay where she was. She did not care about her relatives, did not want his help, and would not even hear of leaving Wickham. At some point, she was sure they would marry, and the timing did not matter much. Given her feelings, he thought the only thing left was to secure and hasten the marriage; in his first conversation with Wickham, he easily learned that he had no such intention. Wickham himself admitted that he had to leave the regiment due to some urgent gambling debts; he did not hesitate to attribute all the bad consequences of Lydia's elopement solely to her foolishness. He intended to leave the regiment immediately; he had no clear idea of what he would do in the future. He had to go somewhere, but he did not know where; he also did not know how he would make a living. Mr. Darcy asked him why he did not marry your sister immediately. Although Mr. Bennet was not very wealthy, he could do something for him, and his situation could improve through marriage. But in response to this question, Mr. Darcy learned that Wickham still held out hope of making a more substantial fortune through marriage in another region. However, it was not easy for him to resist the temptation of immediate relief. They met several times because there was much to discuss. Of course, Wickham wanted more than he could get, but eventually, he agreed to a reasonable amount. Once everything was settled between them, Mr. Darcy's next step was to inform your uncle of the situation; he visited Gracechurch Street the evening before my first arrival. But Mr. Gardiner was not around; after doing some more research, Mr. Darcy learned that your father was with him but would leave the city the next day. Thinking he could not speak as comfortably with your father as with your uncle, he postponed the meeting until your father left. He did not leave his name; until the next day, all that was known was that a gentleman had called on business. He came again on Saturday. Your father was gone, your uncle was home, and as I said, they talked extensively in private. They met again on Sunday, and that was when I saw him. Everything was settled by Monday: a courier was immediately sent to Longbourn. But our guest was very stubborn. It seems to me, my dear Lizzy, that stubbornness is his true character flaw. He has been found to have many faults at different times; but this is the real flaw. He did not allow anything to be done that he did not do himself; yet I am sure (I am not saying this to expect thanks, so do not say anything) your uncle would have wholeheartedly handled the entire matter. They struggled over this for a long time, much more than the gentleman or lady involved deserved. But in the end, your uncle had to agree; he had to be content with the probable reputation of being truly helpful to his niece rather than actually being so, which he could not bear at all; therefore, I believe your letter this morning pleased him greatly because it asked for an explanation that would free your uncle from his borrowed crown and return the praise to where it belonged. However, my dear Lizzy, no one should know about this except you and perhaps Jane. I believe you know very well what was done for the young couple. Wickham's debts, which I believe exceed a thousand pounds, will be paid, and another thousand will be added to Lydia's own money in her name, and Wickham's rank in the army will be purchased. All this was done solely by him for the reason I mentioned above. It was Mr. Darcy's fault, negligence, and thoughtlessness that Wickham's character was so misunderstood and consequently accepted by society. There may be some truth in this; but I doubt that the reason was his or anyone else's negligence. Nevertheless, despite all these fine words, my dear Lizzy, rest assured, your uncle would not have agreed if he did not think there was another reason related to this matter. When all this was decided, Mr. Darcy returned to his friends still staying at Pemberley; but it was agreed that he would come to London once more for the wedding; all financial matters would be finalized then. I believe I have now told you everything. You said this explanation would surprise you greatly; I hope at least it will not upset you. Lydia came to us; Wickham was allowed to come and go as he pleased. Wickham was just as he was when we knew him in Hertfordshire; I was not going to tell you how repulsive I found Lydia's behavior while she stayed with us, but from Jane's letter last Wednesday, I understand that her behavior when she arrived home was the same; so what I will now tell you will not cause you new pain. I spoke to Lydia very seriously and repeatedly, explaining the immorality of what she had done and how much she had made her family unhappy. If she heard me, it was by chance, because I am sure she did not listen. Sometimes I felt like I was losing control, but then I remembered my dear Elizabeth and Jane and showed patience for their sake. Mr. Darcy returned without delay and, as Lydia told you, attended the wedding. He had dinner with us the next day; he was to leave the city again on Wednesday or Thursday. If I take this opportunity to tell you how much I admire him (I had not found the courage to say this before), will you be angry with me, my dear Lizzy? His behavior towards us was as pleasant in every way as it was in Derbyshire. I like his intelligence and opinions; all he needs is a bit more liveliness, which, if he makes a wise marriage, his wife can teach him. I found him very tight-lipped; – he hardly mentioned your name. But being tight-lipped must be in fashion these days. If I have been building castles in the air, please forgive me, or at least do not punish me so severely as to ban me from Pemberley. I will never be happy until I thoroughly explore the grove. A small carriage with a pair of beautiful ponies will suffice and more. But I cannot continue any longer. The children have been calling me for half an hour.
es: My dear niece: I have just received your letter and I am going to dedicate the whole morning to answering it, as I believe that in a few words I will not be able to tell you all that I have to share with you. I must confess that your question surprised me, as I did not expect it from you. Do not be upset, I only wish you to know that I did not think such clarifications were necessary on your part. If you do not want to understand me, forgive my impertinence. Your uncle is as surprised as I am, and only because of the belief that you are an interested party has he allowed himself to act as he has. But in case you are indeed innocent and know nothing at all, I will have to be more explicit. The same day I arrived from Longbourn, your uncle had a very unexpected visit. Mr. Darcy came and was locked up with him for several hours. When I returned, everything was already settled; so my curiosity did not suffer as much as yours. Darcy came to tell Gardiner that he had discovered the hiding place of Wickham and your sister, and that he had seen and spoken to both of them: to Wickham several times, to your sister only once. From what I can deduce, Darcy left Derbyshire the day after we did and came to London with the idea of finding them. The reason he gave is that he felt guilty for not having made Wickham's infamy sufficiently known to prevent a decent girl from loving or trusting him. He generously attributed it all to his blind pride, saying that he had previously deemed it unworthy of him to publish his private affairs. His conduct would speak for him. Therefore, he believed it his duty to intervene and remedy a wrong that he himself had caused. If he had another motive, I am sure it was not dishonorable... He had spent several days in the capital without being able to find them, but he had a lead that could guide him and that was more important than all of ours and that, moreover, was another reason that prompted him to come see us. It seems that there is a lady, a certain Mrs. Younge, who some time ago was Miss Darcy's governess, and had to be dismissed from her position for some reprehensible reason that he did not tell us. Upon leaving the Darcy family, Mrs. Younge took a large house on Edwards Street and since then made a living by renting out rooms. Darcy knew that this Mrs. Younge had close ties with Wickham, and he went to her for news of him as soon as he arrived in the capital. But two or three days went by without being able to obtain from that lady what he needed. I suppose she did not want to speak until she was bribed, for, in reality, she knew from the beginning where her friend was. Wickham, in fact, went to her upon his arrival in London, and if there had been room in her house, he would have stayed there. But, finally, our good friend obtained the address he was looking for. They were on X Street. He saw Wickham and then wanted to see Lydia. He confessed to us that his first intention was to convince her to leave that unfortunate situation and return to her family's bosom if it could be arranged for them to receive her, and he offered his help in everything within his reach. But he found Lydia absolutely determined to stay as she was. She did not care a bit about her family and rejected Darcy's help; she did not want to hear about leaving Wickham; she was convinced that they would marry someday and did not care when. In view of this, Darcy thought that the only thing to do was to facilitate and secure the marriage; in his first dialogue with Wickham, he saw that marriage was not in his plans. Wickham confessed that he had been forced to leave the regiment due to certain pressing debts of honor; he had no scruples in blaming Lydia's madness for all the unfortunate consequences of the elopement. He said he would immediately resign from his position, and as for the future, he did not know what would become of him; he had to go somewhere, but he did not know where and admitted that he did not have a penny to his name. Mr. Darcy asked him why he had not married your sister on the spot. Although Mr. Bennet might not be very wealthy, he could do something for him and his situation would improve with the marriage. But from Wickham's response, Darcy understood that he still harbored the hope of securing a more solid fortune by marrying another girl in some other country; nevertheless, given the circumstances he was in, he did not seem very averse to the temptation of obtaining an immediate solution. They met repeatedly because there were many things to discuss. Wickham, of course, needed much more than could be given to him, but in the end, he agreed to be reasonable. When everything was agreed upon between them, the first thing Mr. Darcy did was inform your uncle, for which he came to Gracechurch Street for the first time, the afternoon before my arrival. But he could not see Gardiner. Darcy found out that your father was still at our house, but that he was going to leave the next day. He did not believe that your father was a more suitable person than your uncle to handle the matter, and then postponed his visit until your father had left. He did not leave his name, and the next day we only knew that a gentleman had come on a business matter. He returned on Saturday. Your father had left and your uncle was at home. As I said before, the two of them talked for a long time. On Sunday they met again and then I saw him too. It wasn't until Monday that everything was decided, and then it was when the messenger was sent to Longbourn. But our visitor was very stubborn; I assure you, Elizabeth, that stubbornness is the true flaw in his character. He has been accused of many faults on various occasions, but that is the only true one. He wanted to do everything on his own, despite the fact that your uncle ––and I don't say this for you to thank me, so I beg you not to speak of it–– would have arranged everything instantly. They argued for a long time, much longer than the gentleman and the young lady in question deserved. But in the end, your uncle was forced to yield, and instead of allowing him to be useful to his niece, he reduced him to merely appearing to be so, much to your uncle's displeasure. So I imagine that your letter this morning has given him great pleasure by providing the opportunity to confess the truth and relinquish the credit that belongs to another. But I beg you not to disclose this and, at most, only tell Jane. I imagine you know what has been done for those young people. The debts of Wickham, which amount, I believe, to much more than a thousand pounds, have been paid; another thousand has been set aside to increase Lydia's dowry, and he has been secured a job. According to Darcy, the reasons for doing all this are solely the ones I mentioned before: because of his discretion, it was not known who Wickham was, and he was received and regarded in a way he did not deserve. There may be some truth in this, although I do not doubt that neither Darcy's discretion nor anyone else's has anything to do with the matter. But despite his nice words, my dear Elizabeth, you can be sure that your uncle would never have yielded had he not believed himself moved by another interest. When everything was resolved, Mr. Darcy returned to his friends who were still at Pemberley, but he promised to return to London for the wedding and to settle the financial arrangements. I think I have already told you everything. If what you say is true, this story will surprise you greatly, but I imagine it will not displease you. Lydia came to the house and Wickham had constant access to her. He was the same as I knew him in Hertfordshire, but I wouldn't tell you how much Lydia's behavior during her stay in our house displeased me, if it weren't for Jane's letter on Wednesday that made me understand that upon arriving at Longbourn she behaved exactly the same, so it shouldn't surprise you what I am now telling. I spoke to her many times with all seriousness, making her see the misfortune she had brought upon her family, but if she heard me it would be by chance, because I am convinced that she didn't even listen to me. There were times when she irritated me; but I remembered my dear Elizabeth and Jane and clothed myself with patience. Mr. Darcy returned punctually and, as Lydia told you, attended the wedding. He dined with us the next day. He was planning to leave London on Wednesday or Thursday. Will you be angry with me, dear Lizzy, if I take this opportunity to tell you what I never would have dared to say before, which is how much I like Darcy? His conduct with us has been as pleasant in every way as when we were in Derbyshire. His intelligence, his opinions, everything pleases me. He only lacks a bit of liveliness, and if he marries wisely, his wife will teach him that. It seems to me that he conceals it very well; he hardly mentioned your name. But it seems that concealment is in fashion. I beg you to forgive me if I have been too suspicious, or at least do not punish me to the point of excluding me from Pemberley. I will not be completely happy until I have taken a full tour of the estate. A low phaeton with a good pair of ponies would be ideal. I can't write to you anymore. The children have been calling me for half an hour.

en: “Yours, very sincerely,
vi: Your aunt,
tr: With my love,
es: Yours affectionately,

en: “M. Gardiner.”
vi: M. Gardiner
tr: M. Gardiner."
es: M. Gardiner

en: The contents of this letter threw Elizabeth into a flutter of spirits, in which it was difficult to determine whether pleasure or pain bore the greatest share.
