The vague and unsettled suspicions which uncertainty had produced, of what Mr. Darcy might have been doing to forward her sister’s match—which she had feared to encourage, as an exertion of goodness too great to be probable, and at the same time dreaded to be just, from the pain of obligation—were proved beyond their greatest extent to be true! He had followed them purposely to town, he had taken on himself all the trouble and mortification attendant on such a research; in which supplication had been necessary to a woman whom he must abominate and despise, and where he was reduced to meet, frequently meet, reason with, persuade, and finally bribe the man whom he always most wished to avoid, and whose very name it was punishment to him to pronounce. He had done all this for a girl whom he could neither regard nor esteem. Her heart did whisper that he had done it for her. But it was a hope shortly checked by other considerations; and she soon felt that even her vanity was insufficient, when required to depend on his affection for her, for a woman who had already refused him, as able to overcome a sentiment so natural as abhorrence against relationship with Wickham. Brother-in-law of Wickham! Every kind of pride must revolt from the connection. He had, to be sure, done much. She was ashamed to think how much. But he had given a reason for his interference, which asked no extraordinary stretch of belief. It was reasonable that he should feel he had been wrong; he had liberality, and he had the means of exercising it; and though she would not place herself as his principal inducement, she could perhaps believe, that remaining partiality for her might assist his endeavours in a cause where her peace of mind must be materially concerned. It was painful, exceedingly painful, to know that they were under obligations to a person who could never receive a return. They owed the restoration of Lydia, her character, everything to him. Oh, how heartily did she grieve over every ungracious sensation she had ever encouraged, every saucy speech she had ever directed towards him! For herself she was humbled; but she was proud of him,—proud that in a cause of compassion and honour he had been able to get the better of himself. She read over her aunt’s commendation of him again and again. It was hardly enough; but it pleased her. She was even sensible of some pleasure, though mixed with regret, on finding how steadfastly both she and her uncle had been persuaded that affection and confidence subsisted between Mr. Darcy and herself.
vi: The content of the letter caused Elizabeth's mind to be agitated with chaotic thoughts, in which it was difficult to discern whether joy or pain was more dominant. She had vague and confused speculations because she was unsure of what Mr. Darcy could have done with her sister's spouse, while she feared encouraging him to do something too good to be true. And at the same time, she dreaded having to be fair and then painfully thinking he had not done so. Now the speculations about the good deed had become too real! He had determined to track down the two people in the city, he had endured all difficulties and hardships in such a search, then had to plead with a woman he hated and despised terribly. He had to humble himself to meet a person he only wanted to avoid and whose name he did not want to mention, then had to meet this person repeatedly, reason with them, advise them, and finally spend money to bribe them. He had done all these things for a young girl he neither loved nor respected. Her heart whispered to her that he did all these things for her. But her hope was suppressed by other thoughts. She immediately thought that her vanity was still not enough to expect his feelings for her, for a woman who had once rejected him, now wanting him to overcome the natural disdain for a connection with Wickham. Wickham's brother-in-law! Every form of pride must oppose such a relationship. Surely he had helped a great deal. She felt ashamed when she thought of how much he had helped. But he had spoken about the reason for his intervention, and it was easy to see that this reason was legitimate. It was right that he believed he had been wrong; he had every right to act and every condition to act. Although she did not consider herself the main reason for his actions, perhaps she could believe that the remaining affection he had for her had supported his purpose to help her achieve peace of mind. It was painful, exceedingly painful, to know that those efforts were for someone who did not hope for any reciprocation. Her family owed him for Lydia's restoration, for Lydia's dignity, for everything. Oh! She was deeply grieved when she thought of every unkind thought she had harbored, every harsh word she had spoken to him. She felt ashamed for herself, but proud of him. Proud that in that goal of affection and honor, he had surpassed himself. She read and reread the part where her aunt praised him. Not much, but enough to make her happy. She also felt joy, though mixed with regret, when she saw that both her aunt and uncle firmly believed that there was always genuine affection and trust between her and Darcy.
tr: This letter's content threw Elizabeth into a tumultuous state of mind; it was difficult to decide whether joy or sorrow had the greater share. The disturbing doubts caused by not being sure of all the actions Mr. Darcy might have taken to hasten his sister's marriage, which Elizabeth feared to believe because they were impossibly kind, and at the same time was horrified by the obligation they implied, all turned out to be true in the end! He had deliberately followed them to the city, endured all the trouble and distress such an investigation could bring; he had to persuade a woman he despised, face, meet frequently, talk to, convince, and finally bribe a man he most wanted to avoid and couldn't even bear to hear the name of. He had done all this for a girl he wouldn't even consider a person. His heart told him he did it for Elizabeth. But this hope was immediately tested by other concerns; soon, when Elizabeth felt the need to trust in Darcy's love for her, a woman who had once rejected him, even his pride couldn't make him believe that this love could overcome a natural feeling like the disgust of being related to Wickham. Wickham's brother-in-law! Such a relationship would provoke every sense of pride. Of course, he had done a lot. Elizabeth felt ashamed when she thought of how much he had done. But he had given a reason for his intervention that was not so hard to believe. It was understandable for him to feel guilty; he was generous and had the means to be generous; Elizabeth did not see herself as Darcy's main reason, but she could believe that perhaps a lingering feeling of affection might have helped him strive for a goal that also concerned her peace of mind. They owed everything, including Lydia's regained respectability, to him. Oh! how she suffered for every ungrateful feeling she had harbored towards him, for every harsh word she had directed at him! For her part, she had learned her lesson; but she was proud of him. She was proud that he had managed to overcome himself for the sake of compassion and honor. She read over and over the parts where her aunt praised him. It wasn't enough, but it pleased her. When she saw how wholeheartedly her aunt and uncle believed in the love and affection between her and Mr. Darcy, she realized that she felt a certain pleasure, mixed with regret.
es: The content of this letter left Elizabeth in a state of shock where it was impossible to determine whether pleasure or pain took the greater part. The vague suspicions she had conceived in her uncertainty about Darcy's role in her sister's wedding, without daring to entertain them because they implied acts of kindness too great to be possible, and fearing they were true because of the humiliation that gratitude would impose, were thus confirmed. Darcy had gone after them expressly, had assumed all the trouble and mortification inherent in that search, implored a woman he must detest and was forced to deal with frequently, to persuade and ultimately bribe the man he most wished to avoid and whose very name horrified him to pronounce. He had done it all to save a girl who must mean nothing to him and for whom he could feel no esteem. Elizabeth's heart told her he had done it for her, but other considerations repressed this hope and she soon realized she was flattering her vanity by explaining the fact in this way, for Darcy could not feel any affection for a woman who had rejected him and, if he did, he would not be able to overcome such a natural feeling as that of being related to Wickham. Darcy, Wickham's brother-in-law! The most basic pride had to rebel against that bond. It was true that Darcy had done so much that Elizabeth was confused, but he gave a very plausible reason. It was not unreasonable to think that Darcy believed he had acted wrongly; he was generous and had the means to demonstrate it, and although Elizabeth resisted admitting that she had been the main motive, it was possible to suppose that a remnant of interest in her had contributed to his efforts in a matter that compromised his peace of mind. It was very painful to be so indebted to a person to whom they could never repay what he had done. They owed him Lydia's salvation and reputation. How much Elizabeth was hurt by her ingratitude and the insolent words she had addressed to him! She was ashamed of herself, but proud of him, proud that he had behaved so compassionately and nobly. She read over and over again the praises her aunt bestowed on him, and although they did not seem sufficient, they pleased her. It gave her great pleasure, though it also saddened her to think that her uncles believed that affection and trust still existed between Darcy and her.

en: She was roused from her seat and her reflections, by someone’s approach; and, before she could strike into another path, she was overtaken by Wickham.
vi: Someone came over, causing her to stand up and interrupting her train of thought. She intended to move to another place, but Wickham blocked her way.
tr: When she heard someone approaching, she got up from where she was sitting, shaking off her thoughts; before she could move to another path, Wickham caught up with her.
es: She rose from her seat and came out of her meditation upon noticing someone approaching; and before she could reach another path, Wickham accosted her.

en: “I am afraid I interrupt your solitary ramble, my dear sister?” said he, as he joined her.
vi: He said, as he approached her: - Dear sister, I fear I have intruded upon your solitary walk, haven't I?
tr: "I'm afraid I'm interrupting your walk, dear sister," he said as he came up to her.
es: ––I fear I am interrupting your solitary walk, dear sister ––he said as he walked up to her side.

en: “You certainly do,” she replied with a smile; “but it does not follow that the interruption must be unwelcome.”
vi: She replied with a smile: - That's right, but it doesn't mean that I welcome any further intrusion into my privacy.
tr: "Of course you are interrupting," replied Elizabeth, "but that doesn't mean you are being bothersome."
es: ––That's right, indeed ––he replied with a smile––, but it doesn't mean that the interruption bothers me.

en: “I should be sorry, indeed, if it were. We were always good friends, and now we are better.”
vi: - If that's the case, I sincerely apologize. We have always been good friends, and now even more so.
tr: "If that were the case, I would be truly sad. We have always been good friends, and now we are even closer."
es: ––I would feel bad bothering you. We have always been good friends. And now we are something more.

en: “True. Are the others coming out?”
vi: - Yes. Did anyone else leave the house?
tr: "Correct. Are the others coming too?"
es: ––True. And the others, have they left?

en: “I do not know. Mrs. Bennet and Lydia are going in the carriage to Meryton. And so, my dear sister, I find, from our uncle and aunt, that you have actually seen Pemberley.”
vi: - I don't know. Mrs. Bennet and Lydia are getting into the carriage to go to Meryton. Dear sister, I heard your uncle and aunt say you went to see Pemberley.
tr: "I don't know. Mrs. Bennet and Lydia are going to Meryton by carriage. In the meantime, my dear sister, from what I have learned from our uncle and aunt, you have indeed seen Pemberley."
es: ––I don't know. Mrs. Bennet and Lydia have gone by carriage to Meryton. My dear sister, your uncles have told me that you have been to Pemberley.

en: She replied in the affirmative.
vi: She accepted.
tr: Elizabeth said she saw it.
es: Elizabeth answered affirmatively.

en: “I almost envy you the pleasure, and yet I believe it would be too much for me, or else I could take it in my way to Newcastle. And you saw the old housekeeper, I suppose? Poor Reynolds, she was always very fond of me. But of course she did not mention my name to you.”
vi: - I am envious of you, but I believe this is too much for me; otherwise, I could have dropped by on my way to Newcastle. I guess you have met the old housekeeper, haven't you? Poor Reynolds, she always loved me. But of course, she didn't mention my name when talking to you.
tr: "I can't say I wasn't envious of his privilege, but still, I think it would have been too much for me, otherwise I would have passed through there on my way to Newcastle. You must have seen the old butler, right? Poor Reynolds, he was always very fond of me. But of course, he wouldn't have mentioned me to you."
es: ––I envy you that pleasure, and if it were possible, I would pass by there on my way to Newcastle. I suppose you would have seen the old housekeeper. Poor Mrs. Reynolds! How much she loved me! But I imagine she wouldn't have mentioned me in front of you.

en: “Yes, she did.”
vi: - Actually, she did mention it.
tr: "He mentioned it."
es: ––Yes, he mentioned you.

en: “And what did she say?”
vi: - And what did she say?
tr: "So, what did he say?""
es: ––And what did he say?

en: “That you were gone into the army, and she was afraid had—not turned out well. At such a distance as that, you know, things are strangely misrepresented.”
vi: - She said you had joined the military, and she feared it had not... not gone very well. With such a distance, you know, many things get misinterpreted.
tr: "He fears that you joined the army because things are not going well. You know, from afar, news is often strangely misrepresented."
es: ––That you had joined the army and that you were getting into trouble. You know that at such a distance things get distorted.

en: “Certainly,” he replied, biting his lips. Elizabeth hoped she had silenced him; but he soon afterwards said,—
vi: He replied, biting his lip: - That's right. Elizabeth hoped she had shut the guy up, but he continued:
tr: "Of course," she replied, biting her lips. Elizabeth hoped she had silenced him, but Wickham continued shortly after,
es: ––Sure ––he replied, biting his lips. Elizabeth thought she had silenced him, but Wickham immediately said:

en: “I was surprised to see Darcy in town last month. We passed each other several times. I wonder what he can be doing there.”
vi: - I was surprised to meet Darcy again in the city this month. We ran into each other a few times. I wondered what he was doing there.
tr: "I was surprised to see Darcy in the city last month. We passed by each other a few times. I wondered what he might be doing there."
es: I was surprised to see Darcy last month in the capital. We met several times. I would like to know what he was doing in London.

en: “Perhaps preparing for his marriage with Miss de Bourgh,” said Elizabeth. “It must be something particular to take him there at this time of year.”
vi: - Maybe he is preparing for Miss De Bourgh's wedding. There must be something special that requires him to go to the city at this time of year.
tr: "Maybe he is preparing for a marriage with Miss de Bourgh," said Elizabeth. "There must be a special reason for him to go there at this time of the year."
es: ––He might be preparing for his marriage to Miss de Bourgh ––said Elizabeth––. It must be something special for him to be in London at this time of year.

en: “Undoubtedly. Did you see him while you were at Lambton? I thought I understood from the Gardiners that you had.”
vi: - Certainly. Did you meet him at Lambton? I heard from the Gardiners that you did.
tr: "Undoubtedly. Did you see him while you were at Lambton? From what I understand from the Gardiners, you did."
es: ––Undoubtedly. Did you see him when you were in Lambton? I think the Gardiners told me that you did.

en: “Yes; he introduced us to his sister.”
vi: - Yes, he introduced us to his sister.
tr: "Yes; he introduced us to his sister.""
es: ––Indeed; he introduced us to his sister.

en: “And do you like her?”
vi: - And do you like her?
tr: "So, did you like him?"
es: ––And did you like it?

en: “Very much.”
vi: - Very fond.
tr: "Very much so."
es: ––A lot.

en: “I have heard, indeed, that she is uncommonly improved within this year or two. When I last saw her, she was not very promising. I am very glad you liked her. I hope she will turn out well.”
vi: - Actually, I heard that she has gotten better in the past one or two years. When I last met her, she didn't seem to have much promise. I'm very glad to know you like her. I hope she will become a really good person. - I'm sure she will be like that.
tr: "Indeed, I heard that he has made extraordinary progress in the last couple of years. When I last saw him, he didn't seem very promising. I'm very glad that you like him. I hope he continues to improve."
es: ––It is true that I have heard that in the last two years she has improved extraordinarily. The last time I saw her, she didn't promise much. I'm glad you liked her. I hope she does well. ––He will do well.

en: “I dare say she will; she has got over the most trying age.”
vi: She has gone through the most difficult age.
tr: "I'm sure he will improve; he has overcome the most difficult period.""
es: He has already passed the most difficult age.

en: “Did you go by the village of Kympton?”
vi: - Do you pass by the village of Kympton?
tr: "Did you go to the village of Kympton?"
es: ––Did you pass through the town of Kimpton?

en: “I do not recollect that we did.”
vi: - I don't remember us passing through.
tr: "I don't remember."
es: ––I don't remember.

en: “I mention it because it is the living which I ought to have had. A most delightful place! Excellent parsonage-house! It would have suited me in every respect.”
vi: - I mention this region because it is the parish that I was supposed to take charge of. A truly beautiful area! The Parish Priest's Residence is wonderful! It suits me in every way.
tr: "I am talking about it because that is the church I should have taken. A marvelous place! –A perfect parsonage! In every way, it suited me very well."
es: ––I tell you, because that is the rectory that I should have had. It's a delightful place! And what an excellent parsonage it has! It would have suited me from every point of view.

en: “How should you have liked making sermons?”
vi: - If you were a clergyman, would you enjoy preaching?
tr: "Would you like to give a sermon?"
es: ––Would you have liked to compose sermons?

en: “Exceedingly well. I should have considered it as part of my duty, and the exertion would soon have been nothing. One ought not to repine; but, to be sure, it would have been such a thing for me! The quiet, the retirement of such a life, would have answered all my ideas of happiness! But it was not to be. Did you ever hear Darcy mention the circumstance when you were in Kent?”
vi: - I liked it a lot. I should have considered this as part of my duty, and soon it would have meant nothing to me. One should not be troubled..., but surely, this should have been meant for me! A peaceful, secluded setting for such a life would have matched my idea of happiness. But it was not to be. Did you ever hear Darcy mention this situation when you were in Kent?
tr: "Indeed, how so. I would consider it part of my duty, and the fatigue would quickly pass. One should not complain; –but of course, it would be something important for me! The tranquility and silence of such a life would answer all my dreams of happiness! But it didn't happen. Did you ever hear Darcy mention the matter while in Kent?"
es: ––Very much. I would have taken it as part of my duties and soon it would have cost me no effort. I cannot complain, but there is no doubt that it would have been the best for me. The quiet and the retreat of such a life would have fulfilled all my desires. But it could not be! Did you hear Darcy mention that topic when you were in Kent?

en: “I have heard from authority, which I thought as good, that it was left you conditionally only, and at the will of the present patron.”
vi: - I heard from a knowledgeable person, whom I believe to be correct, that there are conditions set for you regarding this matter, depending on the person in charge of the property.
tr: "I heard it from an authoritative source, which is equally acceptable to me, that it was left to you conditionally, dependent on the current owner's will."
es: ––I learned from reliable sources that the parish was bequeathed to you only conditionally and at the will of the current master of Pemberley.

en: “You have! Yes, there was something in that; I told you so from the first, you may remember.”
vi: - She has heard. Yes, there are conditions set for that matter; I have told you about it, you probably remember.
tr: "Is that so? Yes, there was something like that; I told you right from the beginning, you remember."
es: ––Did he tell you that? Yes, there was something like that; that's how I told you the first time, do you remember?

en: “I did hear, too, that there was a time when sermon-making was not so palatable to you as it seems to be at present; that you actually declared your resolution of never taking orders, and that the business had been compromised accordingly.”
vi: - I heard that, at one time, you didn't like preaching as you do now, that in fact, you had declared you never wanted to be ordained, and all arrangements were made accordingly.
tr: "I have also heard that there was a time when preaching did not bring you as much joy as it does now, and you had clearly stated that you decided not to take your clerical appointment, and the matter was settled accordingly."
es: ––I also heard that there was a time when composing sermons did not seem as pleasant to you as it does now, that you then declared your intention never to be ordained, and that the matter was settled in accordance with your wishes.

en: “You did! and it was not wholly without foundation. You may remember what I told you on that point, when first we talked of it.”
vi: - She has heard! And it's not without foundation. You may remember I told you about this when we first talked about the case.
tr: "Is that so! It's not entirely baseless. You remember what I told you about that when we first talked."
es: ––Yes, it's true. You must remember what I told you about that when we talked about it the first time.

en: They were now almost at the door of the house, for she had walked fast to get rid of him; and unwilling, for her sister’s sake, to provoke him, she only said in reply, with a good-humoured smile,—
vi: They approached the main door of the house, as she had walked quickly in hopes of getting rid of him. Thinking of her sister, she didn't want to anger him. She only replied, with a slightly wry smile:
tr: They were now almost at the door of the house; Elizabeth had walked quickly to get rid of him; for the sake of her sister, she did not want to provoke him, so she replied with a meek smile and simply said,
es: She was already almost at the door of the house, for Elizabeth had continued walking to get rid of him. Out of consideration for her sister, she did not want to provoke him and only said with a smile:

en: “Come, Mr. Wickham, we are brother and sister, you know. Do not let us quarrel about the past. In future, I hope we shall be always of one mind.”
vi: - Hey, Mr. Wickham, we are brothers-in-law, you know. We should not argue about the past. In the future, I hope we always agree with each other.
tr: "Come on, Mr. Wickham, we are now like siblings. Let's not fight because of the past. I hope we will always agree in the future."
es: ––Come on, Wickham; we are brothers. Let's not argue about the past. I hope that from now on we won't have any reason to argue.

en: She held out her hand: he kissed it with affectionate gallantry, though he hardly knew how to look, and they entered the house.
vi: She extended her hand. He kissed her hand with a fond, flattering gesture, but he didn't know how to express it; and the two of them stepped into the house. Jane Austen Pride and Prejudice
tr: She extended her hand; although Wickham did not know how to look at her, he kissed her hand with warm eagerness, and they entered the house.
es: He shook her hand and he kissed it with affectionate gallantry, although he didn't know what expression to wear, and they entered the house.

en: CHAPTER LIII.
vi: Translator: Diệp Minh Tâm
tr: Chapter XI
es: CHAPTER LIII

en: MR. WICKHAM was so perfectly satisfied with this conversation, that he never again distressed himself, or provoked his dear sister Elizabeth, by introducing the subject of it; and she was pleased to find that she had said enough to keep him quiet.
vi: Chapter 53 Mr. Wickham was completely satisfied with this conversation, so much so that he never again felt the urge to provoke or upset his dear wife by bringing up old matters, and she was pleased to see that she had said enough to make him keep quiet.
tr: Chapter XI Mr. Wickham was so satisfied with this conversation that he never troubled himself again, nor did he provoke his dear sister Elizabeth by bringing up the subject; Elizabeth was pleased to see that he had spoken in a way that would shut his mouth.
es: CHAPTER LIII Wickham was so chastened by that conversation that he never again exposed himself, nor provoked his dear sister Elizabeth to resume it. And she was glad to have said enough to ensure that he would not mention the subject again.

en: The day of his and Lydia’s departure soon came; and Mrs. Bennet was forced to submit to a separation, which, as her husband by no means entered into her scheme of their all going to Newcastle, was likely to continue at least a twelvemonth.
vi: The day Mr. Wickham and Lydia were to depart had arrived, and Mrs. Bennet was forced to accept the separation. While her husband did not agree to the plan of the whole family going to Newcastle, the separation could last at least twelve months.
tr: The day they were to go with Lydia came quickly; since her husband did not agree to the plan of all going to Newcastle together, Mrs. Bennet had to resign herself to a separation that seemed to last at least twelve months.
es: The day of the young couple's departure arrived, and Mrs. Bennet found herself forced into a separation that seemed to be going to last at least a year, as it was in no way part of Mr. Bennet's plans for them all to go to Newcastle.

en: “Oh, my dear Lydia,” she cried, “when shall we meet again?”
vi: She exclaimed: - Oh! My dear Lydia, when will we meet again?
tr: "Oh my dear Lydia," he sighed, "when will we see each other again?"
es: ––Oh, sir!

en: “Oh, Lord! I don’t know. Not these two or three years, perhaps.”
vi: - My Lord! I don't know. Maybe two or three years.
tr: "Oh God, I don't know. Maybe we won't see each other for two or three years."
es: ––Oh, sir! I don't know! Perhaps it will take us two or three years!

en: “Write to me very often, my dear.”
vi: - My dear, remember to write letters to mom often.
tr: "Write to me often, my dear.""
es: ––Write to me very often, dear.

en: “As often as I can. But you know married women have never much time for writing. My sisters may write to me. They will have nothing else to do.”
vi: - I will try. But you know, a married woman never has time to write letters. My sisters can write to you. They will have nothing else to do.
tr: "I write at every opportunity. But you know, married women don't have much time to write letters. My sisters can write to me. They have no other work to do."
es: ––As often as I can. But you know that we married women don't have much time to write. My sisters will be able to write to me; they won't have anything else to do.

en: Mr. Wickham’s adieus were much more affectionate than his wife’s. He smiled, looked handsome, and said many pretty things.
vi: Mr. Wickham bid farewell with more affection than his wife. He smiled brightly, looked handsome, and said many nice things.
tr: Mr. Wickham's farewell was much more amiable than his wife's. He smiled, looked pleasant, and said many sweet words.
es: Wickham's farewell was much more affectionate than that of his wife. He smiled, was very pleasant, and said charming things.

en: “He is as fine a fellow,” said Mr. Bennet, as soon as they were out of the house, “as ever I saw. He simpers, and smirks, and makes love to us all. I am prodigiously proud of him. I defy even Sir William Lucas himself to produce a more valuable son-in-law.”
vi: As soon as the two people had left the house, Mr. Bennet said: - He is the man who has always been as good as I have ever seen. He is flashy, self-satisfied, and endears himself to all of us. I am extremely proud of him. I challenge even Sir William Lucas to see if he has such a fine son-in-law.
tr: "A charming man," said Mr. Bennet, as they left the house, "he lacks nothing. He smiles, grins, and wins us all over. I am exceedingly proud of him. I have even surpassed Sir William Lucas, for I have produced a more valuable son-in-law."
es: ––He is a very fine young man ––said Mr. Bennet as soon as they had left––; I have never seen another like him. He is a machine of smiles and flatters us all. I am extremely proud of him. I challenge even Sir William Lucas to find a more valuable son-in-law.

en: The loss of her daughter made Mrs. Bennet very dull for several days.
vi: The loss of a daughter left Mrs. Bennet in a daze for many days.
tr: Losing her daughter made Mrs. Bennet very sorrowful for a few days.
es: The loss of her daughter plunged Mrs. Bennet into sadness for several days.

en: “I often think,” said she, “that there is nothing so bad as parting with one’s friends. One seems so forlorn without them.”
vi: She said: - I often think there is nothing sadder than being away from a loved one. It is truly lonely when there is no loved one by your side.
tr: "I often think," he said, "there is nothing worse than being separated from the ones you love. When your loved ones are not with you, you feel very strange."
es: ––Many times I think ––he said–– that there is nothing worse than being separated from loved ones. One feels so helpless without them!

en: “This is the consequence, you see, madam, of marrying a daughter,” said Elizabeth. “It must make you better satisfied that your other four are single.”
vi: Elizabeth said: - Mom, you see, it's the inevitable result of marrying off a daughter. You should feel happier when you think that there are still four unmarried daughters.
tr: "This is the result of marrying off a daughter, Madam," said Elizabeth. "The fact that your other four daughters are single should comfort you."
es: ––Well, you see, that is a consequence of marrying off daughters ––observed Elizabeth––. It will make you happier if the other four of us remain single.

en: “It is no such thing. Lydia does not leave me because she is married; but only because her husband’s regiment happens to be so far off. If that had been nearer, she would not have gone so soon.”
vi: - It's not like that. Lydia is away from her mother not because she got married, but because her husband's regiment is stationed far away. If they were stationed closer, she wouldn't have to leave so soon.
tr: "It's not like that. Lydia didn't leave me because she got married; she left because her husband's regiment was far away. If it were nearby, she wouldn't have had to leave so quickly."
es: That's not it. Lydia doesn't leave me because she got married, but because her husband's regiment is far away. If it had been closer, she wouldn't have left so soon.

en: But the spiritless condition which this event threw her into was shortly relieved, and her mind opened again to the agitation of hope, by an article of news which then began to be in circulation. The housekeeper at Netherfield had received orders to prepare for the arrival of her master, who was coming down in a day or two, to shoot there for several weeks. Mrs. Bennet was quite in the fidgets. She looked at Jane, and smiled, and shook her head, by turns.
vi: But her unhappy situation was short-lived, and her mind again opened to a glimmer of hope. A new piece of news began to spread. The housekeeper at Netherfield had received orders to prepare for the master's return within a day or two, to go hunting for a few weeks. Mrs. Bennet was quite anxious. She looked at Jane, smiled, and shook her head:
tr: But the unpleasant mood that this event put her in passed quickly, and her mind was once again opened to the excitement of hope with news that had begun to circulate at that time. The housekeeper of Netherfield had received instructions to prepare for her master's arrival; he would be coming in a few days to hunt for a few weeks. Mrs. Bennet began to tremble with excitement. She looked at Jane, smiled, and kept nodding her head.
es: But the discouragement that this event caused him was quickly alleviated, and his mind began to function again with great agitation at the series of news circulating at that time. The housekeeper of Netherfield had received orders to prepare for the arrival of her master, which was to take place within two or three days, to engage in hunting for a few weeks. Mrs. Bennet was extremely nervous. She looked at Jane and alternately smiled and shook her head.

en: “Well, well, and so Mr. Bingley is coming down, sister,” (for Mrs. Philips first brought her the news). “Well, so much the better. Not that I care about it, though. He is nothing to us, you know, and I am sure I never want to see him again. But, however, he is very welcome to come to Netherfield, if he likes it. And who knows what may happen? But that is nothing to us. You know, sister, we agreed long ago never to mention a word about it. And so, it is quite certain he is coming?”
vi: - Ah, ah, so Mr. Bingley is coming back, isn't he? Ah, that's good. But it's not like I care. You know, he means nothing to our family, and I certainly never want to see him again. But still, if he wants to, he is welcome at Netherfield. And who knows what might happen? But this means nothing to us. You know, dear, we agreed long ago never to speak a word about this. By the way, are you sure he's coming back?
tr: "Oh my, so Mr. Bingley is coming, sister," (Mrs. Philips brought the news because.) "Well, that's very good. Not that I care, though. It doesn't mean anything to us, you know, I don't even think I want to see his face. However, it's a good thing he's coming to Netherfield, since he likes it. But who can know what will happen? But that doesn't concern us. You know, sister, we decided long ago not to talk about this again. So, is he definitely coming?"
es: ––Well, well, so Mr. Bingley is coming, sister? ––for it was Mrs. Philips who first gave her the news––. Well, that's better. Although I don't care. You know we have nothing to do with him and I don't want to see him again. If he wants to come to Netherfield, let him come. And who knows what might happen? But we don't care. You know that we agreed a long time ago not to say another word about this. Is it true that he's coming?

en: “You may depend on it,” replied the other, “for Mrs. Nichols was in Meryton last night: I saw her passing by, and went out myself on purpose to know the truth of it; and she told me that it was certainly true. He comes down on Thursday, at the latest, very likely on Wednesday. She was going to the butcher’s, she told me, on purpose to order in some meat on Wednesday, and she has got three couple of ducks just fit to be killed.”
vi: The other person replied: - You can believe it, because Mrs. Nicholls went to Meryton last night. I saw her passing by and went out to find out the truth; she told me that it was indeed true. At the latest, he will arrive on Thursday, but most likely on Wednesday. She said she was going to the butcher to buy some meat for Wednesday, and she had just bought three pairs of ducks at the right age for slaughtering.
tr: "You can be sure," the other replied, "because Mrs. Nicholls was in Meryton last night; I saw her passing by, and I went out myself to learn the truth; she told me it was definitely true. He is coming no later than Thursday, probably on Wednesday. The woman was going to town, she said, to order meat for Wednesday, and she bought three pairs of ducks, just ready to be slaughtered."
es: ––You can be sure of it ––replied the other––, because Mrs. Nicholls was in Meryton yesterday afternoon; I saw her pass by and went out determined to know the truth; she told me that yes, her master was coming. He will come by Thursday at the latest; he might arrive on Wednesday. Mrs. Nicholls told me she was going to the butcher's to order meat for Wednesday and was carrying three pairs of ducks ready to be slaughtered.

en: Miss Bennet had not been able to hear of his coming without changing colour. It was many months since she had mentioned his name to Elizabeth; but now, as soon as they were alone together, she said,—
vi: Miss Bennet could not hear the news of his arrival without blushing. For many months, she had not mentioned his name when conversing with Elizabeth, but now, as soon as they were alone together, she said:
tr: Miss Bennet's face blushed upon hearing of Mr. Bingley's arrival. It had been months since Elizabeth had spoken of him; but now, as soon as they were alone, she said,
es: Upon hearing the news, Jane changed color. It had been months since she and Elizabeth had spoken about Bingley, but now as soon as they were alone, she said to her:

en: “I saw you look at me to-day, Lizzy, when my aunt told us of the present report; and I know I appeared distressed; but don’t imagine it was from any silly cause. I was only confused for the moment, because I felt that I should be looked at. I do assure you that the news does not affect me either with pleasure or pain. I am glad of one thing, that he comes alone; because we shall see the less of him. Not that I am afraid of myself, but I dread other people’s remarks.”
vi: - Lizzy, I saw you scrutinizing me when our aunt announced the news, and I know I appeared distressed. But don't think this is due to some foolish reason. I was just momentarily confused because I thought I would be scrutinized. I want you to believe that I am neither happy nor sad about this news. I am only glad about one thing, which is that we will see him less, because he will return alone. It's not that I fear for myself, but I am tired of people's comments.
tr: "When my aunt gave this news today, I saw you looking at me, Lizzy; I know I seemed disturbed. But don't think it was for a foolish reason. I was just confused for a moment because I felt like I was being watched. Be assured that the news neither brought me joy nor sorrow. I'm only pleased about one thing, that he is coming alone; then we will see him less. It's not that I'm afraid of myself, but I'm horrified by what others might say."
es: ––I have noticed, Elizabeth, that when my aunt was commenting on the news of the day, you were looking at me. I know it seemed like I was embarrassed, but don't think it was for some silly reason. I was confused for a moment because I realized you all were watching me. I assure you that the news neither saddens nor pleases me. One thing I am glad about: that he is coming alone, because that way we will see him less. It's not that I'm afraid for myself, but I fear people's comments.

en: Elizabeth did not know what to make of it. Had she not seen him in Derbyshire, she might have supposed him capable of coming there with no other view than what was acknowledged; but she still thought him partial to Jane, and she wavered as to the greater probability of his coming there with his friend’s permission, or being bold enough to come without it.
vi: Elizabeth did not know what to think about this. If she had not met him at Derbyshire, she might have thought he dared to come here for the reason he stated. But she still did not think he had feelings for Jane, and she was torn between two possibilities: he returned because his friend permitted it, or because he had enough courage to defy the opposition.
tr: Elizabeth could not understand what to make of this. If she had not seen Bingley in Derbyshire, she might have believed that he came there with no other thought than what was said; but she still thought he was interested in Jane, and she was undecided between the possibility that he came there with his friend's permission, which was very likely, and the possibility that he came without his permission.
es: Elizabeth did not know what to think. If she had not seen him in Derbyshire, she might have believed that he came only for the mentioned reason, but she did not doubt that he still loved Jane, and she even ventured to think that he came with his friend's approval or that he had dared to come without it.

en: “Yet it is hard,” she sometimes thought, “that this poor man cannot come to a house, which he has legally hired, without raising all this speculation! I will leave him to himself.”
vi: Sometimes she thought: "But it is strange that this poor guy cannot return to the house, where he is legally renting, without causing so much speculation like this!" “I will leave him be.”
tr: "Still," he thought from time to time, "how unfortunate that this poor man cannot come to a house he has officially rented without arousing so much suspicion! I will leave him to his own devices."
es: "It's hard," he sometimes thought, "that this poor man can't come to a house he has legally rented without raising all these suspicions. I'll leave him alone."

en: In spite of what her sister declared, and really believed to be her feelings, in the expectation of his arrival, Elizabeth could easily perceive that her spirits were affected by it. They were more disturbed, more unequal, than she had often seen them.
vi: Although her sister had declared this and sincerely believed it to be her own feelings, Elizabeth could easily see that her sister's spirit was being affected. Her sister was disturbed, unbalanced, more so than Elizabeth had ever seen before.
tr: Despite what her sister had said about his arrival and what she believed to be her true feelings, Elizabeth could easily see that her mood was affected by it. Her mood became more uneasy, more changeable compared to before.
es: Despite what her sister said and believed in good faith, Elizabeth could notice that the expectation of Bingley's arrival affected her. She was different and more troubled than usual.

en: The subject which had been so warmly canvassed between their parents, about a twelvemonth ago, was now brought forward again.
vi: The topic had been discussed enthusiastically by the father and mother about twelve months ago, and now it was being brought up for discussion again.
tr: About twelve months ago, the topic that was heatedly discussed between his mother and father has now been brought up again.
es: The topic that their parents had heatedly discussed a year ago came up again now.

en: “As soon as ever Mr. Bingley comes, my dear,” said Mrs. Bennet, “you will wait on him, of course.”
vi: Mrs. Bennet said: - Dear, as soon as Mr. Bingley arrives here, of course you will go visit him.
tr: "As soon as Mr. Bingley arrives, my dear," said Mrs. Bennet, "you must go visit him."
es: ––My dear, I suppose that as soon as Mr. Bingley arrives, you will go visit him.

en: “No, no. You forced me into visiting him last year, and promised, if I went to see him, he should marry one of my daughters. But it ended in nothing, and I will not be sent on a fool’s errand again.”
vi: - No, no. She made me visit him last year, and promised that if I went, he would marry one of my daughters. But nothing happened, and I cannot be sent on the errands of a fool.
tr: "No, no. Last year you forced me to visit and promised that if I went, you would marry one of my daughters. But nothing came of it; I won't go anywhere falling for such lies."
es: ––No and no. You forced me to do it last year, promising me that he would marry one of my daughters. But it all came to nothing, and I don't want to make such a fool of myself again.

en: His wife represented to him how absolutely necessary such an attention would be from all the neighbouring gentlemen, on his returning to Netherfield.
vi: The wife explained to her husband that every polite neighborly man needed to show such concern when he returned to Netherfield.
tr: His wife explained to him that such an interest was absolutely necessary for the neighboring gentlemen if he were to return to Netherfield.
es: His wife pointed out to him how absolutely necessary that attention from all the gentlemen in the neighborhood would be as soon as Bingley arrived at Netherfield.

en: “’Tis an etiquette I despise,” said he. “If he wants our society, let him seek it. He knows where we live. I will not spend my hours in running after my neighbours every time they go away and come back again.”
vi: He replied: - I hate this kind of social nicety. If he wants to associate with us, let him come find us. He knows where we are. I will not waste my time chasing after neighbors every time they return after leaving.
tr: "A habit I despise," said Mr. Bennet. "If he wants our friendship, let him come and ask for it. Our place is well known. I will no longer waste my time running after my neighbors because they come and go."
es: ––It is a label that irritates me ––replied Mr. Bennet––. If he wants our company, let him seek it; he knows where we live. I cannot waste time running after the neighbors every time they leave and return.

en: “Well, all I know is, that it will be abominably rude if you do not wait on him. But, however, that shan’t prevent my asking him to dine here, I am determined. We must have Mrs. Long and the Gouldings soon. That will make thirteen with ourselves, so there will be just room at table for him.”
vi: - Ah, I just know it would be truly impolite if you didn't go meet him. But this doesn't stop me from inviting him to dinner, I have decided. We will soon invite Mrs. Long and the Gouldings. With us as well, that makes thirteen people, so there will be a place for him at the table.
tr: "Well, all I know is that if you don't visit, it will be terribly rude. However, that doesn't prevent me from inviting him to dinner. I'm determined, I mean. We must also get Mrs. Long and the Gouldings right away. If we include ourselves, we become thirteen people, and there's only one spot left at the table for him."
es: ––Well, it will be very rude of you not to visit him; but that won't stop me from inviting him to dinner. We will soon have Mrs. Long and the Gouldings at the table, and counting ourselves, we will be thirteen, so there will be just one place for him.

en: Consoled by this resolution, she was the better able to bear her husband’s incivility; though it was very mortifying to know that her neighbours might all see Mr. Bingley, in consequence of it, before they did. As the day of his arrival drew near,—
vi: Comforted by this resolve, she felt more at ease with her husband's rudeness, although it was somewhat embarrassing to know that her neighboring families might see Mr. Bingley again before her own family had the chance. As the day of Mr. Bingley's return approached, Jane said to her sister:
tr: "I start to feel sad when he is coming," said Jane to her sister.
es: Consoled by this decision, she was perfectly prepared to endure her husband's discourtesy, although it greatly bothered her that, because of this, all the neighbors would see Bingley before they did. As the day of the arrival approached, Jane said:

en: “I begin to be sorry that he comes at all,” said Jane to her sister. “It would be nothing; I could see him with perfect indifference; but I can hardly bear to hear it thus perpetually talked of. My mother means well; but she does not know, no one can know, how much I suffer from what she says. Happy shall I be when his stay at Netherfield is over!”
vi: - She began to feel sad that he would return. It was nothing at all; but she could not bear to hear this matter being discussed endlessly. Our mother was distressed by what she said. She could be at ease again when he no longer resided at Netherfield!
tr: "I start to feel sad when he is coming," said Jane to her sister. "It won't matter; I can remain quite indifferent to him, but I can't stand everyone talking about him. My mother is well-meaning, but she doesn't know, no one can know how much her words upset me. I will be genuinely happy when he leaves Netherfield!"
es: ––Despite everything, I am beginning to feel that he is coming. I wouldn't mind at all and I will see him with the greatest indifference, but I can't stand hearing about him perpetually. My mother does it with the best intentions, but she doesn't know, nor does anyone, the suffering it causes me. I won't be happy until Bingley has left Netherfield.

en: “I wish I could say anything to comfort you,” replied Elizabeth; “but it is wholly out of my power. You must feel it; and the usual satisfaction of preaching patience to a sufferer is denied me, because you have always so much.”
vi: Elizabeth replied: - I wish I could say something to comfort you, but it is completely beyond my ability. You must know this, and I can no longer be content to advise someone who is suffering to be patient, because you always have plenty of patience.
tr: "I wish I could say something to comfort you," Elizabeth replied; "but I can't. You must feel this; that familiar solace of urging patience to someone who is suffering has not been granted to me, because you already have so much of it."
es: ––I would like to say something to console you ––Elizabeth replied––, but I cannot. You must understand that. And the usual satisfaction of recommending patience to those who suffer is denied to me because you never lack it.

en: Mr. Bingley arrived. Mrs. Bennet, through the assistance of servants, contrived to have the earliest tidings of it, that the period of anxiety and fretfulness on her side be as long as it could. She counted the days that must intervene before their invitation could be sent—hopeless of seeing him before. But on the third morning after his arrival in Hertfordshire, she saw him from her dressing-room window enter the paddock, and ride towards the house.
vi: Mr. Bingley had returned. With the help of the servants, Mrs. Bennet devised ways to gather information as quickly as possible, to the extent that her time of anxiety and frustration was prolonged. She counted the days she would need to wait to send an invitation to him, and felt despair at the thought of wanting to see him sooner. But on the morning of the third day after he arrived in Hertfordshire, from the dressing room window, she saw him passing through the gate and approaching the house.
tr: Mr. Bingley arrived. Mrs. Bennet, with the help of the servants, managed to get the news as quickly as possible, regardless of how long her period of anxiety and distress would last. She counted the days that had to pass before the invitation could be sent, as she had no hope of seeing him earlier. But on the third morning of his arrival in Hertfordshire, she saw from her bedroom window that he was entering the lawn on his horse and approaching the house.
es: Bingley arrived. Mrs. Bennet tried to obtain the first news with the help of the maids, to increase the anxiety and bad mood that consumed her. She counted the days that had to pass to invite him, as she did not hope to see him before then. But on the third morning of Bingley's arrival in the county, she saw from her dressing room window that he was entering through the gate on horseback and heading towards the house.

en: Her daughters were eagerly called to partake of her joy. Jane resolutely kept her place at the table; but Elizabeth, to satisfy her mother, went to the window—she looked—she saw Mr. Darcy with him, and sat down again by her sister.
vi: She called the girls to share her joy. Jane resolutely sat still, but Elizabeth wanted to please her. She walked to the window, looked outside, saw Mr. Darcy walking along, then returned to sit down beside her sister.
tr: The girls were invited to join in a flurry of excitement. Jane remained resolutely at her place at the table; but Elizabeth, to please her mother, went to the window – looked out – saw Mr. Darcy beside her, and sat down again next to her sister.
es: He immediately called his daughters to share his joy. Jane refused to leave her place by the table. But Elizabeth, to please her mother, approached the window, looked out and saw that Bingley was entering with Darcy, and sat back down next to her sister.

en: “There is a gentleman with him, mamma,” said Kitty; “who can it be?”
vi: Kitty said: - Mom, there is a man going with Mr. Bingley. Who is he?
tr: "There is a gentleman with her, mother," said Kitty; "who could it be?"
es: ––Mom, another gentleman is coming with him ––said Catherine––. Who could it be?

en: “Some acquaintance or other, my dear, I suppose; I am sure I do not know.”
vi: - An acquaintance or something like that, my child, I guess; I'm sure I don't know.
tr: "He might be a friend, darling; I don't know."
es: ––I suppose some acquaintance of yours, dear; I don't know him. ––Oh! –– exclaimed Catherine––.

en: “La!” replied Kitty, “it looks just like that man that used to be with him before. Mr. what’s his name—that tall, proud man.”
vi: - There! It looks like the guy who used to go with Mr. Bingley before. What was his name! The tall, proud one.
tr: "Yo!" said Kitty, "he looks just like the man who used to be with you. Mr. something. That tall, proud man."
es: It looks like that gentleman who was with him before. The gentleman... what's his name? That tall and proud gentleman.

en: “Good gracious! Mr. Darcy!—and so it does, I vow. Well, any friend of Mr. Bingley’s will always be welcome here, to be sure; but else I must say that I hate the very sight of him.”
vi: - Good heavens! Mr. Darcy! That's right. Well, we can welcome any friend of Mr. Bingley who comes here, otherwise mother would have to say she doesn't want to see him.
tr: "Oh my God! Mr. Darcy! –I swear it's him. I mean, Mr. Bingley's friend is always welcome, but I must say I hate seeing this man."
es: ––Holy God! Mr. Darcy? Well, yes, it's him. Well; any friend of Mr. Bingley will always be welcome in this house; if it weren't for that... I can't stand the sight of him.

en: Jane looked at Elizabeth with surprise and concern. She knew but little of their meeting in Derbyshire, and therefore felt for the awkwardness which must attend her sister, in seeing him almost for the first time after receiving his explanatory letter. Both sisters were uncomfortable enough. Each felt for the other, and of course for themselves; and their mother talked on of her dislike of Mr. Darcy, and her resolution to be civil to him only as Mr. Bingley’s friend, without being heard by either of them. But Elizabeth had sources of uneasiness which could not yet be suspected by Jane, to whom she had never yet had courage to show Mrs. Gardiner’s letter, or to relate her own change of sentiment towards him. To Jane, he could be only a man whose proposals she had refused, and whose merits she had undervalued; but to her own more extensive information, he was the person to whom the whole family were indebted for the first of benefits, and whom she regarded herself with an interest, if not quite so tender, at least as reasonable and just, as what Jane felt for Bingley. Her astonishment at his coming—at his coming to Netherfield, to Longbourn, and voluntarily seeking her again, was almost equal to what she had known on first witnessing his altered behaviour in Derbyshire.
vi: Jane looked at Elizabeth with astonishment and concern. She knew little about their meeting in Derbyshire, so she felt embarrassed for her sister now meeting him for the first time since receiving his explanatory letter. Both sisters were confused. Each worried about the other, while they did not hear their mother rambling on about her dislike for Mr. Darcy and her intention to be polite to him only because he was Mr. Bingley's friend. But Elizabeth had another reason for her confusion that Jane did not know, as she had not yet had the courage to show her sister Mrs. Gardiner's letter or to recount the changes in her feelings towards Mr. Darcy. To Jane, he was merely the man who had proposed to her sister and been rejected; but to her, he was the man to whom the whole family owed a debt, the man she cared about, if not as passionately as Jane did for Mr. Bingley, then at least as reasonably and justifiably. Her astonishment at seeing him come – coming to Netherfield, to Longbourn, and voluntarily seeking her out again – was nearly equal to her astonishment at his changed demeanor in Derbyshire.
tr: Jane looked at Elizabeth with astonishment and concern. She didn't know much about their meeting in Derbyshire, so she felt the tension her sister must have experienced almost for the first time since receiving her explanatory letter. Both sisters were quite uncomfortable. They were excited both for each other and for themselves; meanwhile, their mother was berating Mr. Darcy, saying that the only reason she decided to be kind to him, without either of them hearing, was because he was Mr. Bingley's friend. But Elizabeth's discomfort had reasons that Jane could not guess; Elizabeth had not yet found the courage to show her Mrs. Gardiner's letter or to explain the change in her feelings towards Darcy. To Jane, he could only be a man whose proposal she had rejected and whose worth she had not appreciated; but Elizabeth knew well that he was the man to whom the whole family owed gratitude, and she felt a reasonable and justified affection for him, if not quite love, at least as much as Jane felt for Bingley. His arrival – his arrival at Netherfield, at Longbourn, and his voluntary search for her again – astonished her as much as when she first witnessed the change in his behavior in Derbyshire.
es: Jane looked at Elizabeth with astonishment and interest. She knew very little about her encounter in Derbyshire and, consequently, understood the horror that seeing Darcy almost for the first time after the clarifying letter must have caused her sister. The two sisters were quite uneasy; each suffered for the other, and naturally, for herself. Meanwhile, the mother continued to rant about her hatred for Darcy and her decision to be courteous to him only out of consideration for Bingley. None of the girls were listening to her. Elizabeth was troubled by something Jane could not suspect, as she had never dared to show her Mrs. Gardiner's letter, nor to reveal the change in her feelings for Darcy. To Jane, Darcy was nothing more than the man whose proposals Elizabeth had rejected and whose merits she had undervalued. But to Elizabeth, Darcy was the man to whom her family owed the greatest of favors, and whom she regarded with an interest, if not as tender, at least as reasonable and just as the one Jane felt for Bingley. Her astonishment at Darcy's coming to Netherfield, to Longbourn, seeking her again voluntarily, was almost equal to what she experienced upon seeing him so changed in Derbyshire.

en: The colour which had been driven from her face returned for half a minute with an additional glow, and a smile of delight added lustre to her eyes, as she thought for that space of time that his affection and wishes must still be unshaken; but she would not be secure.
vi: Her face turned pale for a moment, then became rosy again with a hint of blush, and a smile made her eyes sparkle even more as she thought of his feelings and wishes changing in Derbyshire.
tr: The color that had left her face returned half a minute later with an added brightness, and at that moment, thinking that Darcy's interest and dreams must still be alive, a smile of delight added a sparkle to her eyes. But she couldn't be sure.
es: The color, which had disappeared from her countenance, rushed violently to her cheeks, and a smile of pleasure brightened her eyes at the thought that Darcy's affection and desires remained the same. But she did not want to take it for granted.

en: “Let me first see how he behaves,” said she; “it will then be early enough for expectation.”
vi: She told herself: "First, let's see how he behaves, then there will still be time for wishes."
tr: "Let me first see how he behaves," he said; "it is still too early to hope for more."
es: "First, I will see how he behaves," he said to himself, "and then God will decide if I can have hopes."

en: She sat intently at work, striving to be composed, and without daring to lift up her eyes, till anxious curiosity carried them to the face of her sister as the servant was approaching the door. Jane looked a little paler than usual, but more sedate than Elizabeth had expected. On the gentlemen’s appearing, her colour increased; yet she received them with tolerable ease, and with a propriety of behaviour equally free from any symptom of resentment, or any unnecessary complaisance.
vi: She sat attentively continuing the work she was doing, trying to stay calm, not daring to look up, until out of curiosity she looked at her sister's face, while a servant was approaching the room. Jane appeared slightly pale, but calmer than she thought. When the two men entered, her face turned even redder, however, she greeted them with a moderate calmness, showing no signs of anger or excessive warmth.
tr: She resolutely set to her crochet work, trying to appear busy, not daring to lift her eyes, until, as the servant approached the door, a curiosity filled with unease carried her eyes to her sister's face. Jane looked paler than usual, but calmer than Elizabeth had expected. When the gentlemen appeared, her color heightened, yet she greeted them quite comfortably, with a dignified demeanor that showed neither any sign of resentment nor unnecessary joy.
es: He set to work attentively and strove to remain calm. He did not dare to raise his eyes until his growing curiosity made him look at his sister when the maid went to open the door. Jane was paler than usual, but calmer than Elizabeth had believed. When the two gentlemen entered, she blushed, but received them quite calmly, without showing any sign of resentment or unnecessary complacency.

en: Elizabeth said as little to either as civility would allow, and sat down again to her work, with an eagerness which it did not often command. She had ventured only one glance at Darcy. He looked serious as usual; and, she thought, more as he had been used to look in Hertfordshire, than as she had seen him at Pemberley. But, perhaps, he could not in her mother’s presence be what he was before her uncle and aunt. It was a painful, but not an improbable, conjecture.
vi: Elizabeth only spoke a few words to everyone as social etiquette required, then sat down to continue her unfinished work, with her usual unnecessary eagerness. She only glanced at Mr. Darcy once. He was as solemn as ever, and she thought, more solemn than when he first came to Hertfordshire rather than when she met him at Pemberley. But, perhaps with the presence of his mother, he could not be himself as he was when he faced his uncle and aunt. This was a painful speculation but not without basis.
tr: Elizabeth spoke to both of them only as much as politeness required and returned to her work with an attention that was not at all necessary for the task. She had dared to glance at Darcy only once. He looked as serious as ever; just as he appeared in Hertfordshire, she thought, rather than how he looked at Pemberley. But perhaps he couldn't be the same around his mother as he was around her uncle and aunt. It was a painful, but not impossible, conjecture.
es: Elizabeth spoke to the two young men as little as politeness allowed, and devoted herself to her embroidery with more application than ever. She only ventured to cast a glance at Darcy. He was as serious as always, and it seemed to her that he resembled more the Darcy she had known in Hertfordshire than the one she had seen at Pemberley. But perhaps in the presence of his mother, he did not feel the same as in the presence of her uncles. It was a painful supposition, but not an improbable one.

en: Bingley she had likewise seen for an instant, and in that short period saw him looking both pleased and embarrassed. He was received by Mrs. Bennet with a degree of civility which made her two daughters ashamed, especially when contrasted with the cold and ceremonious politeness of her courtesy and address of his friend.
vi: She also glanced at Bingley for a moment; seeing him display both joy and confusion. Mrs. Bennet received him with polite manners, which embarrassed her two daughters, especially when she adopted a cold and formal demeanor while conversing with his friend.
tr: She had also seen Bingley for a moment, and in that short time, she saw that he was both pleased and uncomfortable. They had been greeted by Mrs. Bennet with a politeness that embarrassed her two daughters, especially when compared to the cold and formal politeness in her curtsy and conversation with his friend.
es: He also glanced at Bingley for a moment, and it seemed to him that he was both happy and embarrassed at the same time. Mrs. Bennet received him with such fuss that it left her two daughters embarrassed, especially due to the contrast with her cold and ceremonious manner of greeting and treating Darcy.

en: Elizabeth particularly, who knew that her mother owed to the latter the preservation of her favourite daughter from irremediable infamy, was hurt and distressed to a most painful degree by a distinction so ill applied.
vi: Especially Elizabeth, because she knew her mother was grateful to Mr. Darcy for helping her beloved daughter avoid disgrace, felt sorrowful to the point of almost being in pain when she saw how clumsily her mother had shown favoritism.
tr: Elizabeth, knowing that her mother owed Darcy for protecting her favorite daughter from an irreparable disgrace, was deeply hurt and ashamed by such a grave misjudgment.
es: Particularly Elizabeth, knowing that her mother owed Darcy the salvation of her favorite daughter from such irremediable infamy, was deeply saddened by that rudeness.

en: Darcy, after inquiring of her how Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner did—a question which she could not answer without confusion—said scarcely anything. He was not seated by her: perhaps that was the reason of his silence; but it had not been so in Derbyshire. There he had talked to her friends when he could not to herself. But now several minutes elapsed, without bringing the sound of his voice; and when occasionally, unable to resist the impulse of curiosity, she raised her eyes to his face, she as often found him looking at Jane as at herself, and frequently on no object but the ground. More thoughtfulness and less anxiety to please, than when they last met, were plainly expressed. She was disappointed, and angry with herself for being so.
vi: Darcy inquired about Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner, a question which she could not answer fluently, and then he did not ask much more. He did not sit next to her, perhaps this was the reason for his silence, but in Derbyshire, he had not been like that. There, he could converse with her relatives when he did not know what to say to her. But a few minutes passed and he still did not say anything. A few times, unable to restrain her curiosity, she glanced up at him, sometimes seeing him looking at Jane or at her, often looking down at the ground. Clearly, he appeared thoughtful and unwilling to make a good impression as he had when they last met. She felt disappointed, and angry with herself for feeling disappointed.
tr: After Darcy asked her how Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner were and received a vague answer, he didn't say much. He wasn't sitting close to her; maybe that was the reason for his silence; but it hadn't been like this in Derbyshire. There, when he couldn't talk to her, he had talked to his friends. But now, a few minutes had passed without his voice being heard; occasionally, when she couldn't resist her curiosity and raised her eyes to his face, she found him looking at Jane as much as at herself, and often with his eyes cast down. It was clearly expressed that he was more thoughtful and less intent on pleasing than the last time they had met. Elizabeth was disappointed, and because she was disappointed, she was angry with herself.
es: Darcy asked how Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner were, and Elizabeth answered him with some unease. After that, she barely said anything. He was not seated next to Elizabeth, and perhaps this was the reason for his silence; but it was not like this in Derbyshire. There, when he couldn't talk to her, he spoke with his friends; but now several minutes passed without his voice being heard, and when Elizabeth, unable to contain her curiosity, looked up at him, she found him more frequently looking at Jane than at her, and often only looking at the ground. He seemed more pensive and less eager to please than in their last meeting. Elizabeth was disappointed and displeased with herself because of it.

en: “Could I expect it to be otherwise?” said she. “Yet why did he come?”
vi: She thought: "I can wish for the opposite!" But why did he come here?
tr: "Could I have expected it to be any different!" he said. "But then why did he come?"
es: "How could I imagine it would be any different?" he said to himself. "I don't even know why she came here."

en: She was in no humour for conversation with anyone but himself; and to him she had hardly courage to speak.
vi: She had no spirit to converse with anyone except him, and not much courage to start a conversation with him.
tr: He didn't feel like talking to anyone else, but he didn't have the courage to talk to him either.
es: She had no mood to talk to anyone except him, but she lacked the courage to speak to him.

en: She inquired after his sister, but could do no more.
vi: She inquired about your sister, but didn't know what else to say.
tr: He asked about his sister's well-being, but he couldn't do anything else.
es: She asked him about his sister, but then she didn't know what else to say.

en: “It is a long time, Mr. Bingley, since you went away,” said Mrs. Bennet.
vi: Mrs. Bennet said: - Mr. Bingley, you have been away for quite some time.
tr: "It's been a long time since you left, Mr. Bingley," said Mrs. Bennet.
es: ––A lot of time has passed, Mr. Bingley, since you left ––said Mrs. Bennet.

en: He readily agreed to it.
vi: He agreed with her.
tr: Mr. Bingley immediately accepted this.
es: ––Indeed ––said Bingley.

en: “I began to be afraid you would never come back again. People did say, you meant to quit the place entirely at Michaelmas; but, however, I hope it is not true. A great many changes have happened in the neighbourhood since you went away. Miss Lucas is married and settled: and one of my own daughters. I suppose you have heard of it; indeed, you must have seen it in the papers. It was in the ‘Times’ and the ‘Courier,’ I know; though it was not put in as it ought to be. It was only said, ‘Lately, George Wickham, Esq., to Miss Lydia Bennet,’ without there being a syllable said of her father, or the place where she lived, or anything. It was my brother Gardiner’s drawing up, too, and I wonder how he came to make such an awkward business of it. Did you see it?”
vi: - I began to worry that you would never return. People said you intended to leave for good around the time of Saint Michael's Day, but I still hoped it wasn't true. Many changes have taken place in this area since you left. Miss Lucas got married and has settled down. And one of my daughters. I think you have heard; in fact, you might have read the news in the papers. The news was published in the Times and the Courier, I know, though not in the right manner. The notice only stated “George Wickham, with Miss Lydia Bennet,” without mentioning her father, or her place of residence, or anything like that. My brother-in-law Gardiner handled this; I don't understand how he could be so clumsy. Did you read the news?
tr: "I was afraid you wouldn't come back again. Everyone said so, that you were going to leave the house altogether by Michaelmas; but, nevertheless, I hope that is not true. Since you left, there have been many changes in our neighborhood. Miss Lucas got married and left. One of my daughters as well. I assume you have heard; of course, you must have read it in the newspapers. It was written in the Times and the Courier, but of course, they didn't give it the space it deserved. It merely said, ‘Recently, George Wickham and Miss Lydia Bennet,' without a single word about her father or where she was from or anything else. It was my brother Gardiner's announcement, moreover; I don't understand how he managed to do such a clumsy job. Did you see it?"
es: ––I was beginning to fear ––she continued–– that you would not return. People say that by Saint Michael's day you plan to leave this region; but I hope that's not true. Many things have happened in the neighborhood since you left; Miss Lucas got married and is settled in Hunsford, and one of my daughters also got married. I suppose you must have known, surely you must have read it in the newspapers. It was in the Times and in the Courrier, only it wasn't well written. It only said: "Mr. George Wickham married Miss Lydia Bennet," without mentioning her father or where the bride lived or anything. The notice must have been the work of my brother Gardiner, and I don't understand how he could have done something so curt. Did you see it?

en: Bingley replied that he did, and made his congratulations. Elizabeth dared not lift up her eyes. How Mr. Darcy looked, therefore, she could not tell.
vi: - Mr. Bingley replied that he had read it and offered his congratulations. Elizabeth did not dare to look up, so she could not know Mr. Darcy's reaction.
tr: Bingley said he saw it and offered his congratulations. Elizabeth did not dare to lift her eyes. Therefore, she could not understand how Mr. Darcy looked.
es: Bingley replied that he did and congratulated her. Elizabeth did not dare to raise her eyes and could not see what expression Darcy had.

en: “It is a delightful thing, to be sure, to have a daughter well married,” continued her mother; “but at the same time, Mr. Bingley, it is very hard to have her taken away from me. They are gone down to Newcastle, a place quite northward it seems, and there they are to stay, I do not know how long. His regiment is there; for I suppose you have heard of his leaving the ——shire, and of his being gone into the Regulars. Thank heaven! he has some friends, though, perhaps, not so many as he deserves.”
vi: The mother continued: - It is truly joyful to see a daughter have a good marriage, but Mr. Bingley, at the same time, it is truly sad to see her have to live far from me. They are going to Newcastle, quite far to the North, and they will settle there, because I think you have heard about him leaving the militia to join the army. Thank God! He also has a few friends, though perhaps not many who are worthy of him.
tr: "It is a very nice thing for a girl to make a good marriage," her mother continued, "but at the same time, Mr. Bingley, it is very hard for me that she has to go so far away. They went to Newcastle, which I believe is quite far north, who knows how long they will stay there. His regiment is there; because I suppose you have heard that he left the --------shire regiment and joined the regular army. Thank God! he has some friends, perhaps not as many as he deserves."
es: ––It is delightful to have a well-married daughter ––she continued saying––, but at the same time, Mr. Bingley, it is very hard that she has gone so far away. They have moved to Newcastle, which is very far North, I believe, and they will be there for I don't know how long. My son-in-law's regiment is stationed there, because you may have heard that he has left the county garrison and has joined the regulars. Thank God he still has some friends, although perhaps not as many as he deserves.

en: Elizabeth, who knew this to be levelled at Mr. Darcy, was in such misery of shame that she could hardly keep her seat. It drew from her, however, the exertion of speaking, which nothing else had so effectually done before; and she asked Bingley whether he meant to make any stay in the country at present. A few weeks, he believed.
vi: Elizabeth understood that she was referring to Mr. Darcy, and she felt so miserable with embarrassment that she almost didn't want to sit back down. However, this made her try harder to continue the conversation, and she asked Bingley if he intended to stay here. He replied that he would stay for a few weeks.
tr: Knowing that this was directed at Mr. Darcy, Elizabeth was in such miserable shame that she could barely stay in her place. On the other hand, this forced her to speak, as nothing else could have had such an effect; she asked Bingley if he was planning to stay in the countryside for a long time. A few weeks, said Bingley.
es: Elizabeth, knowing that this was directed at Darcy, felt so embarrassed that she could barely stay in her chair. However, she made a supreme effort to speak and asked Bingley if he planned to stay in the countryside for long. He replied that a few weeks.

en: “When you have killed all your own birds, Mr. Bingley,” said her mother, “I beg you will come here and shoot as many as you please on Mr. Bennet’s manor. I am sure he will be vastly happy to oblige you, and will save all the best of the coveys for you.”
vi: The mother said: - When you have shot all your birds, I invite you to come here and shoot as much as you like in Mr. Bennet's estate. I am sure he will be very happy to accommodate you and will provide every convenience for you.
tr: "When you have killed all your own birds, Mr. Bingley," said his mother, "please come here and shoot as many birds as you like on Mr. Bennet's estate. I am sure he will be exceedingly happy to host you and will reserve all the best partridges for you."
es: ––When you have killed all your birds, Mr. Bingley ––said Mrs. Bennet––, come and kill all you want on my husband's property. I am sure he will be very pleased and will reserve his best nests for you.

en: Elizabeth’s misery increased at such unnecessary, such officious attention! Were the same fair prospect to arise at present, as had flattered them a year ago, everything, she was persuaded, would be hastening to the same vexatious conclusion. At that instant she felt, that years of happiness could not make Jane or herself amends for moments of such painful confusion.
vi: Elizabeth felt even more miserable because of such unnecessary and intrusive concern!
