She thought that now, even if she had as many desires as she did a year ago, which had made them proud, everything would still quickly lead to a sorrowful end. At that moment, she felt that many years of happiness could not compensate for Jane or herself for those moments of such painful endings.
tr: In the face of such unnecessary, such absurd interest, Elizabeth's embarrassment increased even more! She believed that if the same good chance that had come their way a year ago were to arise now, everything would quickly lead to the same painful outcome. At that moment, she felt that even years of happiness would not be able to erase these bitter moments of shame for Jane and herself.
es: Elizabeth's discomfort increased with such unnecessary and officious attention. She had no doubt that all those illusions that were reborn after a year would end again in the same way. She thought that entire years of happiness could not compensate her and Jane for those moments of painful confusion.

en: “The first wish of my heart,” said she to herself, “is never more to be in company with either of them. Their society can afford no pleasure that will atone for such wretchedness as this! Let me never see either one or the other again!”
vi: She whispered to herself: "The first desire of my heart is to never get close to either of these two people. Forming a relationship with them cannot create the joy that could soothe such restlessness. Please don't let me meet these two people again!"
tr: "My only wish," he said to himself, "is to no longer be near any of them. Their presence cannot provide the happiness to compensate for such shame! I don't want to see either of them ever again!"
es: “I desire only one thing,” he said to himself, “and that is to never see either of these two men again. All the pleasure their company might provide is not enough to compensate for this shame. I wish I never had to meet them again!”

en: Yet the misery, for which years of happiness were to offer no compensation, received soon afterwards material relief, from observing how much the beauty of her sister rekindled the admiration of her former lover. When first he came in, he had spoken to her but little, but every five minutes seemed to be giving her more of his attention. He found her as handsome as she had been last year; as good-natured, and as unaffected, though not quite so chatty. Jane was anxious that no difference should be perceived in her at all, and was really persuaded that she talked as much as ever; but her mind was so busily engaged, that she did not always know when she was silent.
vi: However, the distress, which many years of happiness could not compensate for, was soon alleviated when she saw that her sister's beauty had rekindled the affection of her former lover. When he first entered, he only had a brief conversation with Jane, but gradually he paid more and more attention to her. He found her as pretty as the previous year, still gentle, still calm, though she spoke less than before. Jane deliberately acted as if there were no changes in her, believing that she was still as lively in conversation as she used to be. But her mind was always in turmoil, to the point that sometimes she didn't realize she was being silent.
tr: Nevertheless, the feeling that years of happiness could not compensate was considerably alleviated when she saw that her sister's beauty rekindled the admiration of her former lover. When Bingley first entered, he had spoken very little with her; but every five minutes, he seemed to pay her more attention. He found her as beautiful as last year, as harmonious and at ease; though perhaps not as talkative. Jane feared that Bingley would find no change in her and truly believed she was talking as much as ever. But her mind was so full that she was not always aware of her silence.
es: But that misfortune, which years of happiness could not compensate for, was somewhat alleviated shortly after by noticing that her sister's beauty once again awakened the admiration of her former suitor. At first, Bingley spoke very little with Jane, but with each moment he seemed more captivated by her. He found her as beautiful as the previous year, as sensitive and as affable, though not as talkative. Jane wished that no change would be noticed in her and believed she spoke as always, but her mind was so occupied that sometimes she did not realize her silence.

en: When the gentlemen rose to go away, Mrs. Bennet was mindful of her intended civility, and they were invited and engaged to dine at Longbourn in a few days’ time.
vi: When the two gentlemen stood up to leave, Mrs. Bennet remembered the courtesy she had planned, so she invited them to dinner in a few days.
tr: When the gentlemen rose, Mrs. Bennet remembered the courtesy she had planned; they were invited to dine at Longbourn and agreed on a date a few days later.
es: When the gentlemen rose to leave, Mrs. Bennet did not forget her planned invitation. The two young men accepted, and it was agreed that they would dine at Longbourn in a few days.

en: “You are quite a visit in my debt, Mr. Bingley,” she added; “for when you went to town last winter, you promised to take a family dinner with us as soon as you returned. I have not forgot, you see; and I assure you I was very much disappointed that you did not come back and keep your engagement.”
vi: She added: Mr. Bingley, you still owe us a visit, because when you went to the city last winter, you promised to attend a family dinner with us as soon as you returned. You see, I haven't forgotten, and please believe that I will be very disappointed if you do not come back and keep your promise.
tr: "You owe me a visit, Mr. Bingley," she added, "because when you went to the city last winter, you promised to have a family dinner with us as soon as you returned. You see, I haven't forgotten; and believe me, I was very hurt that you didn't keep your word when you came back."
es: ––You owed me a visit, Mr. Bingley,–– added Mrs. Bennet––, for when you went to the capital last winter, you promised to dine with us as soon as you returned. You see, I have not forgotten. I was very upset that you did not come back to fulfill your commitment.

en: Bingley looked a little silly at this reflection, and said something of his concern at having been prevented by business. They then went away.
vi: Bingley looked a bit absent-minded with this recollection, and mentioned some concern, as he had to attend to business. Then they left.
tr: Bingley was a bit dumbfounded by these words and complained about being hindered by work and such. Then they left. Mrs.
es: Bingley seemed a little puzzled by that remark, and said he was very sorry, but that his affairs had detained him. Darcy and he left.

en: Mrs. Bennet had been strongly inclined to ask them to stay and dine there that day; but, though she always kept a very good table, she did not think anything less than two courses could be good enough for a man on whom she had such anxious designs, or satisfy the appetite and pride of one who had ten thousand a year.
vi: Mrs. Bennet was very eager to keep them and invite them to dinner that very day, but although she always prepared a decent table, she thought there should be at least two main courses to befit a person for whom she had such ardent designs, or to satisfy the appetite and pride of a person with an income of ten thousand a year.
tr: Bennet very much wanted to invite them to stay for dinner that day, but although her table was always quite good, she thought that less than two courses would not be enough to please a man about whom she had such enthusiastic plans or to satisfy the appetite and pride of another who earned ten thousand a year.
es: Mrs. Bennet had been on the verge of inviting them to dine that very day, but despite the fact that one always ate well in her house, she did not believe that two courses would in any way be sufficient for a man who inspired such ambitious projects in her, nor to satisfy the appetite and pride of another who had ten thousand pounds a year in income.

en: CHAPTER LIV.
vi: Chapter 54
tr: Chapter XII
es: CHAPTER LIV

en: AS soon as they were gone, Elizabeth walked out to recover her spirits; or, in other words, to dwell without interruption on those subjects which must deaden them more. Mr. Darcy’s behaviour astonished and vexed her.
vi: As soon as they left, Elizabeth walked out of the room to regain her composure, or in other words, to reflect on the events that had further clouded her mind. Mr. Darcy's attitude surprised and annoyed her.
tr: As soon as the guests left, Elizabeth went outside to lift her spirits, or in other words, to think uninterruptedly about matters that would further dampen her mood. Mr. Darcy's behavior had upset and distressed her.
es: As soon as they left, Elizabeth went for a walk to recover her spirits or, rather, to ponder the cause that had made her lose them. Darcy's behavior had her astonished and angry.

en: “Why, if he came only to be silent, grave, and indifferent,” said she, “did he come at all?”
vi: She thought: "If he comes only to remain silent, solemn, and aloof, then why come at all?"
tr: "If he only came to be silent, serious, indifferent," he said, "why did he come?"
es: Why did he come ––she asked herself–– to be silent, serious, and indifferent?

en: She could settle it in no way that gave her pleasure.
vi: She didn't find any explanation that made her happy.
tr: He couldn't give a response that would please him.
es: He couldn't explain it to her satisfactorily.

en: “He could be still amiable, still pleasing to my uncle and aunt, when he was in town; and why not to me? If he fears me, why come hither? If he no longer cares for me, why silent? Teasing, teasing man! I will think no more about him.”
vi: ”You are still charming, still able to win over your uncle and aunt when you are in the city, so why seek me out? If you no longer care about me, why remain silent? Teasing and teasing, this guy! I shouldn't think about him anymore.”
tr: "While in the city, he was still polite and warm towards my uncle and aunt, so why isn't he like that towards me? If he's afraid of me, why did he come here? If he doesn't care about me, why did he sit down and stay quiet? What an exasperating man! I won't think about him anymore."
es: “If he could be kind and accommodating with my uncles in London, why not with me? If he feared me, why did he come? And if he no longer cares about me, why was he so quiet? What an irritating man! I don't want to think about him anymore.”

en: Her resolution was for a short time involuntarily kept by the approach of her sister, who joined her with a cheerful look which showed her better satisfied with their visitors than Elizabeth.
vi: She could only maintain her intention for a moment, because her sister had approached with a cheerful demeanor, indicating that she was more pleased with the two guests than Elizabeth was.
tr: With her sister's arrival, she involuntarily adhered to her decision for a short while; Jane joined her with a cheerful demeanor that showed she was more pleased with the guests than Elizabeth.
es: Involuntarily, she maintained this resolution for a while, because her sister approached, whose cheerful appearance showed that she was more satisfied with the visit than she was.

en: “Now,” said she, “that this first meeting is over, I feel perfectly easy. I know my own strength, and I shall never be embarrassed again by his coming. I am glad he dines here on Tuesday. It will then be publicly seen, that on both sides we meet only as common and indifferent acquaintance.”
vi: She said: - Now that the first reunion is over, she feels completely relieved. She knows her own determination well, and she will never be flustered when he comes. She is happy that he accepted the invitation to dinner on Tuesday. At that time, everyone will see that they meet each other just like two ordinary and carefree acquaintances.
tr: "Now that I've gotten through this first encounter," he said, "I feel quite comfortable. I know my own strength; his arrival won't bother me anymore. I'm glad he's coming for dinner on Tuesday. Everyone will see, we both come together as ordinary, indifferent friends."
es: ––Now ––she said to him––, after this first encounter, I feel completely calm. I know that I am strong and that I will no longer be flustered in front of him. I'm glad he's coming to dinner on Tuesday, because that way it will be clear that we treat each other simply as indifferent friends.

en: “Yes, very indifferent, indeed,” said Elizabeth, laughingly. “Oh, Jane! take care.”
vi: Elizabeth smiled and said: - Yes, truly very carefree. Hey Jane, be cautious!
tr: "Yes, quite indifferent," said Elizabeth, laughing. "Oh Jane, be careful."
es: ––Yes, very indifferent ––replied Elizabeth, laughing––. Oh, Jane! Be careful!

en: “My dear Lizzy, you cannot think me so weak as to be in danger now.”
vi: - Dear Lizzy, you should not think that I am so weak as to be in danger.
tr: "My dear Lizzy, you can't think I'm that weak, the danger has passed for me."
es: ––Lizzy, dear, you are not going to believe that I am so weak as to be in any danger.

en: “I think you are in very great danger of making him as much in love with you as ever.”
vi: - I think there is a great risk that you will make him love you even more. *
tr: "I think you're in real danger now, you're making him fall in love with you again." -------------------------
es: ––I think you are in a very big one, because he loves you as always.

en: They did not see the gentlemen again till Tuesday; and Mrs. Bennet, in the meanwhile, was giving way to all the happy schemes which the good-humour and common politeness of Bingley, in half an hour’s visit, had revived.
vi: During the time until Tuesday, they did not see him again, and Mrs. Bennet was busy with all sorts of happy calculations, rekindled by Mr. Bingley's cheerful and polite demeanor during his half-hour visit.
tr: They did not see their gentlemen again until Tuesday; meanwhile, Mrs. Bennet once more indulged herself in all those happy dreams brought to life by Bingley's cheerfulness and indiscriminate politeness during his half-hour visit.
es: They did not see Bingley again until Tuesday, and in the meantime, Mrs. Bennet indulged in all the hopeful plans that the gentleman's joy and constant sweetness had revived in her during half an hour of visit.

en: On Tuesday there was a large party assembled at Longbourn; and the two who were most anxiously expected, to the credit of their punctuality as sportsmen, were in very good time. When they repaired to the dining-room, Elizabeth eagerly watched to see whether Bingley would take the place which, in all their former parties, had belonged to him, by her sister. Her prudent mother, occupied by the same ideas, forbore to invite him to sit by herself. On entering the room, he seemed to hesitate; but Jane happened to look round, and happened to smile: it was decided. He placed himself by her.
vi: On Tuesday, quite a few people were invited to Longbourn. The two young men, eagerly awaited, arrived on time like athletes. As they entered the dining room, Elizabeth anxiously observed whether Mr. Bingley would choose his usual seat next to her sister, as he had done in previous gatherings. The cautious mother, with the same thought in mind, patiently invited him to sit next to her. As he stepped in, he seemed hesitant, but Jane was looking around and smiling; thus, it was favorable. He sat down next to her.
tr: On Tuesday, a large gathering took place at Longbourn; the two most eagerly awaited individuals arrived right on time, not disappointing the confidence placed in their punctuality. As they moved to the dining room, Elizabeth watched with excitement to see if Bingley would sit in the place that used to be his during previous parties, next to her sister. Her shrewd mother, who had the same thought, restrained herself from inviting him to sit there. When Bingley entered the room, he seemed to hesitate; but Jane looked around and smiled: the decision was made. Bingley settled next to Jane.
es: On Tuesday, a large group of people gathered at Longbourn, and the gentlemen who were most eagerly awaited arrived with perfect punctuality. When they entered the dining room, Elizabeth watched Bingley closely to see if he would take the place that had always been his at previous meals next to her sister; her prudent mother, thinking the same, was very careful not to invite him to sit next to her. Bingley seemed to hesitate, but Jane happened to smile around the room, and the matter was settled: Bingley sat next to Jane.

en: Elizabeth, with a triumphant sensation, looked towards his friend. He bore it with noble indifference; and she would have imagined that Bingley had received his sanction to be happy, had she not seen his eyes likewise turned towards Mr. Darcy, with an expression of half-laughing alarm.
vi: Elizabeth felt triumphant and looked towards his friend. The gentleman displayed an air of indifference in a noble manner, and she would have thought he acknowledged that Bingley deserved happiness, if she had not seen his eyes also directed towards Mr. Darcy, with a look half anxious, half playful.
tr: Elizabeth looked at Bingley's friend with a sense of triumph. Darcy met this situation with noble indifference; Elizabeth would have thought that Bingley had received permission to be happy, but she saw that his eyes also turned towards Darcy, with an expression of semi-joking fear.
es: Elizabeth, with triumphant satisfaction, looked at Darcy. He met her gaze with noble indifference; Elizabeth would have imagined that Bingley had already obtained his friend's permission to enjoy his happiness if she had not caught his eyes also turned towards Darcy, with a smiling but alarmed expression.

en: His behaviour to her sister was such during dinnertime as showed an admiration of her, which, though more guarded than formerly, persuaded Elizabeth, that, if left wholly to himself, Jane’s happiness, and his own, would be speedily secured. Though she dared not depend upon the consequence, she yet received pleasure from observing his behaviour. It gave her all the animation that her spirits could boast; for she was in no cheerful humour. Mr. Darcy was almost as far from her as the table could divide them. He was on one side of her mother. She knew how little such a situation would give pleasure to either, or make either appear to advantage. She was not near enough to hear any of their discourse; but she could see how seldom they spoke to each other, and how formal and cold was their manner whenever they did. Her mother’s ungraciousness made the sense of what they owed him more painful to Elizabeth’s mind; and she would, at times, have given anything to be privileged to tell him, that his kindness was neither unknown nor unfelt by the whole of the family.
vi: During the meal, Bingley's demeanor showed that he had feelings for Jane, though he was more reserved than before; but Elizabeth still believed that if he were allowed to be natural, their happiness would quickly become solid. Although she did not dare to be certain about the future outcome, she was still pleased when observing his attitude. This lifted her spirits, as she had no other joy. Mr. Darcy sat far from her, next to her mother. She knew that in such a situation, no one would be happy and no one would benefit. She did not hear what they exchanged with each other, but she saw that they conversed little, and when they did, each had a serious and cold demeanor. Her mother's rudeness made her even more pained when she remembered how much her family owed him. Sometimes she wished to do anything to let him know that not the entire family was unaware or ungrateful for his kindness.
tr: Bingley's behavior towards his sister throughout the meal was so full of admiration that Elizabeth, although more cautious than before, felt that if Bingley were left entirely to his own devices, Jane's happiness, and consequently her own, would be swiftly secured. Even if she did not dare to be certain of the outcome, she took pleasure in observing Bingley's actions. This lifted her spirits somewhat; for she had no cheerfulness. Mr. Darcy was as far away from her as the table could separate them. He was beside her mother. Elizabeth knew that such a position would be unpleasant for both of them and would not even give them the opportunity to behave comfortably. She was not close enough to hear their conversation, but she could see that they rarely spoke, and when they did, their manner was formal and cold. Her mother's ingratitude made the sense of indebtedness to him even more painful for Elizabeth, and sometimes it seemed she would do anything to have the chance to say that not everyone in the family was unaware of or unappreciative of his kindness.
es: Bingley's behavior towards Jane during the meal revealed the admiration he felt for her, and although it was more circumspect than before, Elizabeth was convinced that if it depended solely on him, their happiness and Jane's would soon be assured. Despite not daring to trust the outcome, Elizabeth was very satisfied and felt as encouraged as her bad mood allowed. Darcy was on the other side of the table, seated next to Mrs. Bennet, and Elizabeth understood how unpleasant such an arrangement was for both of them, and how little advantageous it was for anyone. She was not close enough to hear what they were saying, but she could observe that they hardly spoke to each other and how cold and ceremonious their manners were when they did. This antipathy of her mother towards Darcy made the memory of what everyone owed him more painful for Elizabeth, and there were moments when she would have given anything to be able to say that his kindness was neither unknown nor unappreciated by the entire family.

en: She was in hopes that the evening would afford some opportunity of bringing them together; that the whole of the visit would not pass away without enabling them to enter into something more of conversation, than the mere ceremonious salutation attending his entrance. Anxious and uneasy, the period which passed in the drawing-room before the gentlemen came, was wearisome and dull to a degree that almost made her uncivil. She looked forward to their entrance as the point on which all her chance of pleasure for the evening must depend.
vi: She hoped that tonight she and he would have the opportunity to be close to each other, that they could talk more than just exchanging polite greetings when he first arrived. After the meal, while waiting for the young men to arrive, the time she spent anxiously and uneasily sitting in the living room dragged on in a tiring and tedious manner, to the point that it almost made her impolite. She longed for them to walk in, the decisive moment to determine whether she would have an enjoyable evening or not.
tr: He held the hope that the evening would give them the opportunity to come together, that the entire visit would not end without providing a chance for conversation beyond the solemn greetings at the entrance. He was anxious and uncomfortable; the time spent in the living room before the gentlemen arrived was filled with a dullness and tedium that almost led to rudeness. He eagerly awaited their arrival as the turning point for all the happiness of the evening.
es: She hoped that the afternoon would give her the opportunity to be by Darcy's side and that the visit would not end without exchanging more than just the simple greeting upon arrival. She was so anxious and uneasy that while waiting in the parlor for the gentlemen to enter, her unease almost put her in a bad mood. Her entire hope for pleasure that afternoon depended on Darcy's presence.

en: “If he does not come to me, then,” said she, “I shall give him up for ever.”
vi: She told herself, "If he doesn't come to me, then I will ignore him."
tr: "If he doesn't come to me then," she said, "I will give up on him forever."
es: "If he doesn't come towards me," she said to herself, "I will give up."

en: The gentlemen came; and she thought he looked as if he would have answered her hopes; but, alas! the ladies had crowded round the table, where Miss Bennet was making tea, and Elizabeth pouring out the coffee, in so close a confederacy, that there was not a single vacancy near her which would admit of a chair. And on the gentlemen’s approaching, one of the girls moved closer to her than ever, and said, in a whisper,—
vi: The young men came over, and she thought he looked as if he had met all her expectations, but, alas! The ladies had surrounded the table where Miss Bennet was making tea and Elizabeth stood beside her pouring coffee into the cups, leaving no space beside her for a chair. As the men approached, one of the girls moved closer to her, whispering: “They cannot come between us, I am determined on that.
tr: The gentlemen arrived; Elizabeth thought Darcy looked as if he might respond to her hopes; but where! The ladies had gathered so closely around the table where Miss Bennet was making tea and Elizabeth was serving coffee that there wasn't even enough space for a chair to fit around Elizabeth. Moreover, as the gentlemen approached, one of the girls moved even closer and whispered in her ear,
es: The gentlemen entered, and it seemed that Darcy was going to do what she longed for; but unfortunately, the ladies had gathered around the table where Mrs. Bennet was preparing tea and Elizabeth was serving coffee. They were all so crowded together that there was no free spot beside her nor room for another chair. As the gentlemen approached, one of the girls came up to Elizabeth and whispered in her ear:

en: “The men shan’t come and part us, I am determined. We want none of them; do we?”
vi: As the men approached, one of the girls moved closer to her, whispering: “They cannot come between us, I am determined on that. We don't want them here, do we?”
tr: "Men cannot come between us and separate us; I am determined." "We don't want any of them, right?""
es: ––The men will not come to separate us; I have already decided; we don't need them at all, do we?

en: Darcy had walked away to another part of the room. She followed him with her eyes, envied everyone to whom he spoke, had scarcely patience enough to help anybody to coffee, and then was enraged against herself for being so silly!
vi: Darcy separated himself, going to a corner of the room. She watched him, jealous of everyone he was talking to, almost losing patience to serve coffee to anyone, then angry with herself for acting ridiculous!
tr: Darcy had walked to another corner of the room. Elizabeth followed him with her eyes, envied everyone he spoke to, found it hard to muster the patience to offer coffee to everyone, and then got very angry with herself for being so foolish!
es: Darcy then went to another part of the room. Elizabeth watched him and envied everyone he talked to; she could barely muster the patience to serve the coffee, and she became furious with herself for being so foolish.

en: “A man who has once been refused! How could I ever be foolish enough to expect a renewal of his love? Is there one among the sex who would not protest against such a weakness as a second proposal to the same woman? There is no indignity so abhorrent to their feelings.”
vi: "A person who once refused!" How could I be so foolish as to expect him to confess his love again? Is there any man who would not reject the demeaning act of confessing love a second time to the same woman? According to their psychology, there is no humiliation more dreadful than that!”
tr: "A man who has been rejected once! How could I be so foolish as to expect him to repeat his love? Is there a single man who would not resist the weakness of proposing to the same woman a second time? There is no other indignity that would hurt their feelings so much!"
es: “A man whom I have rejected!” I must be crazy if I expect his love to be rekindled. There isn't a single man who wouldn't rebel against the weakness of making a second declaration to the same woman. There is no greater indignity for them.”

en: She was a little revived, however, by his bringing back his coffee-cup himself; and she seized the opportunity of saying,—
vi: However, she was a little excited when he returned his cup himself, and she seized this opportunity to ask him:
tr: Still, his face brightened a bit when he brought the empty coffee cup himself, and he immediately seized the opportunity to speak:
es: She perked up a bit upon seeing Darcy coming to return her coffee cup, and she seized the opportunity to ask him:

en: “Is your sister at Pemberley still?”
vi: - Is your sister still staying at Pembley?
tr: "Is your sister still at Pemberley?"
es: ––Is your sister still at Pemberley?

en: “Yes; she will remain there till Christmas.”
vi: - Yes, she will stay there until Christmas.
tr: "Yes; he will stay there until Christmas"
es: ––Yes, he will be there until Christmas.

en: “And quite alone? Have all her friends left her?”
vi: - And lonely? Have all your friends gone home?
tr: "All alone?" "Have all his friends left?""
es: ––And are you alone? Have all your friends left already?

en: “Mrs. Annesley is with her. The others have been gone on to Scarborough these three weeks.”
vi: - Mrs. Annesley is staying with her. The others have gone to Scarborough for these three weeks.
tr: "Mrs. Annesley is with her. The others have gone to Scarborough for three weeks."
es: ––Only Mrs. Annesley is accompanying her; the others have gone to Scarborough to spend these three weeks.

en: She could think of nothing more to say; but if he wished to converse with her, he might have better success. He stood by her, however, for some minutes, in silence; and, at last, on the young lady’s whispering to Elizabeth again, he walked away.
vi: She couldn't think of anything else to say, but if he wanted to talk to her, he could do better. But he stood by her for a moment in silence, and when the other girl whispered into Elizabeth's ear again, he walked away.
tr: Nothing else came to mind to say; but if Darcy had wanted to chat with him, he could have been more successful. However, he stood silently beside her for a few minutes and finally walked away when the young lady whispered something in Elizabeth's ear.
es: Elizabeth couldn't think of anything else to say, but if he had wanted to talk, how gladly she would have answered him! Nevertheless, he stayed by her side for a few minutes, in silence, until the girl from before started whispering to Elizabeth, and then he withdrew.

en: When the tea things were removed, and the card tables placed, the ladies all rose; and Elizabeth was then hoping to be soon joined by him, when all her views were overthrown, by seeing him fall a victim to her mother’s rapacity for whist players, and in a few moments after seated with the rest of the party. She now lost every expectation of pleasure. They were confined for the evening at different tables; and she had nothing to hope, but that his eyes were so often turned towards her side of the room, as to make him play as unsuccessfully as herself.
vi: When the tea table was cleared, they laid out the card games, and the ladies all stood up. Elizabeth hoped to be near him again, but all her wishes were overturned when he fell into the greed of his mother, who wanted another player. After a while, he had to sit with them. Now she had lost hope for an enjoyable evening. The two were entangled at two different tables, and she no longer had any expectations, except for the occasional glance he cast in her direction, as if to ensure that neither he nor she could fully concentrate on the card games they were playing.
tr: When the tea trays were cleared away and the game tables were set up, all the ladies stood up; Elizabeth was expecting that she would come to her side immediately, but then saw that her mother had fallen prey to the whist players' hunt and, a few minutes later, had sat down at the table with the rest of the group, shattering all her hopes. Now she had lost all hope of happiness. They were confined to different tables throughout the evening, and aside from the frequent glances he cast her way, as if he wished her to be as unsuccessful in the game as he was, there was nothing left for her to hope for.
es: Once the tea service was removed and the game tables were set up, all the ladies stood up. Elizabeth then thought she might be able to be with him, but her hopes were dashed when she saw her mother take hold of Darcy and force him to sit at her whist table. Elizabeth gave up all her illusions. They were confined to different tables all afternoon, but Darcy's eyes turned so often to where she was that both of them lost all their games.

en: Mrs. Bennet had designed to keep the two Netherfield gentlemen to supper; but their carriage was, unluckily, ordered before any of the others, and she had no opportunity of detaining them.
vi: Mrs. Bennet intended to invite the two gentlemen to stay for a late meal, but unfortunately their carriage was called before the others, and she had no opportunity to keep them.
tr: Mrs. Bennet had planned to detain the two gentlemen from Netherfield for dinner; but unfortunately, their carriage had been ordered earlier than the others, so she did not have the opportunity to keep them.
es: Mrs. Bennet had planned for the two gentlemen from Netherfield to stay for dinner, but they were the first to ask for their carriage and there was no way to detain them.

en: “Well, girls,” said she, as soon as they were left to themselves, “what say you to the day? I think everything has passed off uncommonly well, I assure you. The dinner was as well dressed as any I ever saw. The venison was roasted to a turn—and everybody said, they never saw so fat a haunch. The soup was fifty times better than what we had at the Lucases’ last week; and even Mr. Darcy acknowledged that the partridges were remarkably well done; and I suppose he has two or three French cooks at least. And, my dear Jane, I never saw you look in greater beauty. Mrs. Long said so too, for I asked her whether you did not. And what do you think she said besides? ‘Ah! Mrs. Bennet, we shall have her at Netherfield at last!’ She did, indeed. I do think Mrs. Long is as good a creature as ever lived—and her nieces are very pretty behaved girls, and not at all handsome: I like them prodigiously.”
vi: As soon as all the guests left, she said: - My children, how do you find this evening? Mother thinks everything is very beautiful. The dining table is set exactly as Mother wanted. The venison is roasted perfectly, everyone says they've never seen such a plump leg of venison. The soup is ten times better than the soup we had at Lucas's house last week, even Mr. Darcy admitted that the grouse was very delicious, and Mother thinks he has at least two or three French chefs. And, dear Jane, Mother has never seen you as beautiful as today. Mrs. Long said the same, because Mother asked her how you looked. And what do you think she said? "Ah! Mrs. Bennet, at last we shall see her settled at Netherfield." That's what she said. Mother thinks Mrs. Long is really a good person - and her nieces behave quite well, and are not beautiful at all.
tr: "Well, girls," she said as soon as they were alone. "What do you think of today? I think everything went extraordinarily well. The table was beautifully set. The venison was cooked to perfection – everyone said they had never seen such a well-fed leg. The soup was fifty times better than the one we had at the Lucases' last week; even Mr. Darcy said the partridges were marvelous, and he probably has two or three French chefs. Oh Jane, I have never seen you look so beautiful. Mrs. Long said the same, because I asked her how you looked. And do you know what else she said? ‘Oh Mrs. Bennet, we will finally see her at Netherfield.' She really said that. I think Mrs. Long is the best person in the world – her nieces are very well-mannered girls, though they are not at all pretty, but I like them very much."
es: ––Well, girls ––said the mother as soon as everyone had left––, what do you say? In my view, everything went perfectly today. The meal was as well presented as the best I've seen; the roasted venison was perfect, and everyone said the haunches were superb; the soup was fifty times better than the one we were served last week at the Lucas's; and even Mr. Darcy acknowledged that the partridges were very well done, and he must have two or three French cooks. And, besides, dear Jane, you have never looked prettier than this afternoon; Mrs. Long confirmed it when I asked her opinion. And what do you think she told me, moreover? "Oh, Mrs. Bennet, we will finally have her at Netherfield!" That's exactly what she said. I think Mrs. Long is the best person in the world, and her nieces are very well-mannered girls and not at all unattractive; I like them very much.

en: “Mrs. Long and her nieces.”
vi: Mother likes them very much.
tr: I think Mrs. Long is the best person in the world – her nieces are very well-mannered girls, though they are not at all pretty, but I like them very much."
es: I think Mrs. Long is the best person in the world, and her nieces are very well-mannered girls and not at all unattractive; I like them very much.

en: Mrs. Bennet, in short, was in very great spirits: she had seen enough of Bingley’s behaviour to Jane to be convinced that she would get him at last; and her expectations of advantage to her family, when in a happy humour, were so far beyond reason, that she was quite disappointed at not seeing him there again the next day, to make his proposals.
vi: Mrs. Bennet was completely elated. She had seen Bingley's demeanor towards Jane, enough to make her believe that in the end, she would win his affection. In her high spirits, her expectations far exceeded all reason, to the point where she was quite disappointed not to see him return the next day to propose.
tr: In short, Mrs. Bennet was extremely delighted; she had seen enough of Bingley's behavior towards Jane to be convinced that he would eventually win her over; her expectations regarding her family's happiness, especially when she was in high spirits, were so beyond reason that she was greatly disappointed when she saw that Bingley did not come to propose the next day.
es: All in all, Mrs. Bennet was in a splendid mood. She had observed Bingley's behavior towards Jane enough to convince herself that he was finally going to propose. She was so excited and her fantasies about the great future awaiting her family went so far beyond reason that she was extremely upset when Bingley did not show up the next day to propose.

en: “It has been a very agreeable day,” said Miss Bennet to Elizabeth. “The party seemed so well selected, so suitable one with the other. I hope we may often meet again.”
vi: Ms. Bennet said to Elizabeth: - What a pleasant day. Mother chose the guests correctly; everyone gets along with each other. She hopes to see them often.
tr: "It was quite a successful day," said Miss Bennet to Elizabeth. "The guests were well chosen, everyone was suitable for each other. I hope we gather often again."
es: ––It has been a very pleasant day ––said Jane to Elizabeth––. How select and cordial the party was! I hope it happens again.

en: Elizabeth smiled.
vi: Elizabeth smiled.
tr: Elizabeth smiled.
es: Elizabeth smiled.

en: “Lizzy, you must not do so. You must not suspect me. It mortifies me. I assure you that I have now learnt to enjoy his conversation as an agreeable and sensible young man without having a wish beyond it. I am perfectly satisfied, from what his manners now are, that he never had any design of engaging my affection. It is only that he is blessed with greater sweetness of address, and a stronger desire of generally pleasing, than any other man.”
vi: - Lizzy, don't do that. You shouldn't doubt me, making me suffer. I want you to believe that now I have learned to take pleasure in conversing with a pleasant and reasonable person without any further expectations. I am completely satisfied with his current attitude, seeing that he never intended to win my affection. It's just that compared to anyone else, he becomes more gentle in speech and has a more positive attitude in trying to please others.
tr: "Lizzy, you shouldn't do this. You shouldn't suspect me. It bothers me. I've learned to chat with Bingley like with a sensible young man, without imagining anything beyond that, believe me. I'm so pleased with his current behavior that he has never tried to win my love. It's just that he has a sweeter manner and a stronger desire to please others than anyone else."
es: ––Don't laugh. It hurts me that you are like this, Lizzy. I assure you that now I have learned to enjoy his conversation and that I see in him nothing but an intelligent and kind young man. I love his behavior and I don't care that he has never thought of me. I only find that his manner is sweet and more attentive than that of any other man.

en: “You are very cruel,” said her sister, “you will not let me smile, and are provoking me to it every moment.”
vi: The younger sister replied: - You are really cruel, you don't want me to laugh, and you keep trying to annoy me like that.
tr: "You are very cruel," said his sister, "you neither allow me to smile, nor do you stop provoking me to smile at every moment."
es: ––You're cruel! ––replied her sister––. You don't let me smile and you're provoking me to do so at every moment.

en: “How hard it is in some cases to be believed! And how impossible in others! But why should you wish to persuade me that I feel more than I acknowledge?”
vi: - In some cases, it is really difficult to get people to believe what you say. - And in other cases, it is unbelievable! - But why do you want to persuade me to feel more than what I have already said?
tr: "Sometimes it is so difficult to be convincing!" "Most of the time, how impossible it is!" "But why do you want to convince me that I feel more than I say?""
es: ––How difficult it is to be believed in some cases! ––And how impossible in others! ––Why do you insist on convincing me that I feel more than I confess?

en: “That is a question which I hardly know how to answer. We all love to instruct, though we can teach only what is not worth knowing. Forgive me; and if you persist in indifference, do not make me your confidante.”
vi: - This is a question I don't know how to answer. We all want to give advice, although we can only advise on things that are not worth knowing. Please forgive me, and if you insist on being distant, don't consider me your confidant anymore.
tr: "This is a question whose answer I do not know well either. We all love to give advice, but we can only manage to teach things that are not worth knowing. Forgive me; but if you insist on remaining indifferent, at least don't make me your confidant."
es: ––I wouldn't know what to tell you. We all like to give lessons, but we only teach what is not worth knowing. Forgive me, but if you persist in your indifference, it's better that I not be your confidant.

en: CHAPTER LV.
vi: Chapter 55
tr: Chapter XIII
es: CHAPTER LV

en: A FEW days after this visit, Mr. Bingley called again, and alone. His friend had left him that morning for London, but was to return home in ten days’ time. He sat with them above an hour, and was in remarkably good spirits. Mrs. Bennet invited him to dine with them; but, with many expressions of concern, he confessed himself engaged elsewhere.
vi: A few days later, Mr. Bingley came again, and he came alone. His friend was busy going to London and would return in ten days. He sat and chatted with them for over an hour, in a cheerful spirit. Mrs. Bennet invited him to have dinner with the family, but with a concerned look, he confessed that he was busy elsewhere.
tr: A few days after this visit, Mr. Bingley called again, alone. His friend had left him that morning to go to London, but he would return home within ten days. He sat with them for more than an hour; he was noticeably cheerful. Mrs. Bennet invited him to dinner, but with many expressions of regret, he confessed that he had another engagement.
es: A few days after that visit, Bingley returned to Longbourn, alone. His friend had gone to London in the morning, but was going to return within ten days. He spent an hour with them and was in excellent spirits. Mrs. Bennet invited him to dinner, Bingley said he was sorry, but he was already engaged elsewhere.

en: “Next time you call,” said she, “I hope we shall be more lucky.”
vi: She said: - When you come next time, I hope we will be luckier.
tr: "Next time you come," he said, "I hope we will be luckier."
es: ––Next time he comes ––replied Mrs. Bennet–– I hope we have better luck. ––I will be very pleased ––replied Bingley.

en: He should be particularly happy at any time, etc., etc.; and if she would give him leave, would take an early opportunity of waiting on them.
vi: He said he would be very pleased to accept at any other time, and if she allowed, he would seize the earliest opportunity to come and converse with them.
tr: Of course, he would be very happy, etc. etc.; but if he was allowed, he would come back to visit them at the first opportunity.
es: And he added that, if they allowed him, he would take any opportunity to visit them.

en: “Can you come to-morrow?”
vi: - Can you come tomorrow?
tr: "Can you come tomorrow?"
es: ––Can you come tomorrow?

en: Yes, he had no engagement at all for to-morrow; and her invitation was accepted with alacrity.
vi: Alright, he is not busy at all tomorrow and eagerly accepts her invitation.
tr: Yes, there was no promise for tomorrow; the invitation was accepted with pleasure.
es: Bingley said yes, as he had no commitments for the next day.

en: He came, and in such very good time, that the ladies were none of them dressed. In ran Mrs. Bennet to her daughters’ room, in her dressing-gown, and with her hair half finished, crying out,—
vi: He arrived, and arrived early, so early that the girls hadn't had time to dress properly. Mrs. Bennet rushed into her daughter's room, while she was still wearing her outer coat, her hair only half done.
tr: He arrived; and he arrived at such a good time that none of the ladies had dressed yet. Mrs. Bennet, in her dressing gown, with her hair half done, burst into her daughter's room, screaming.
es: He arrived so early that none of the ladies were dressed. Mrs. Bennet ran to her daughters' room, in her dressing gown and half-combed, exclaiming:

en: “My dear Jane, make haste and hurry down. He is come—Mr. Bingley is come. He is, indeed. Make haste, make haste. Here, Sarah, come to Miss Bennet this moment, and help her on with her gown. Never mind Miss Lizzy’s hair.”
vi: - Hey Jane, hurry up so we can go downstairs in time. He has arrived, Mr. Bingley has arrived. He really has arrived. Hurry up, hurry up. Hey, Sarah, come here right away to help Miss Bennet with her dress. Don't worry about Lizzy's hair.
tr: "My dear Jane, hurry up, come down quickly. He has arrived. –Mr. Bingley has arrived. –He has arrived, I swear. Quick, quick. Come on, Sarah, look after Miss Bennet, help with her dress. Forget about Miss Lizzy's hair."
es: ––Jane, dear, hurry up and go downstairs! Mr. Bingley has come! It's him, without a doubt. Come, Sara! Go immediately to help Miss Jane get dressed. Don't worry about Miss Elizabeth's hair.

en: “We will be down as soon as we can,” said Jane; “but I dare say Kitty is forwarder than either of us, for she went upstairs half an hour ago.”
vi: Jane said: - We will come down right away, but I am sure Kitty is ready, as she went upstairs half an hour ago.
tr: "We will go down when we are ready," said Jane; "but I am sure Kitty is ahead of us, she went up half an hour ago."
es: ––We will come down as soon as we can ––said Jane––, but it seems to me that Catherine is ahead of us, because she went up half an hour ago.

en: “Oh! hang Kitty! what has she to do with it? Come, be quick, be quick! where is your sash, my dear?”
vi: - Hmph, never mind Kitty! What does it have to do with anything! Hurry up, hurry up! Where's your shawl?
tr: "Aman, leave Kitty alone! What does she have to do with it? Hurry up, hurry up! Where is your belt, darling?"
es: ––Look at what you're coming up with! What does Catherine have to do with this? You are the one who should go down immediately. Where is your corset?

en: But when her mother was gone, Jane would not be prevailed on to go down without one of her sisters.
vi: But the mother had gone downstairs, Jane did not want to go downstairs without one of her sisters going down with her.
tr: But when her mother left, Jane was unwilling to go downstairs without one of her sisters.
es: But when her mother had gone out, Jane did not want to go downstairs without one of her sisters.

en: The same anxiety to get them by themselves was visible again in the evening. After tea, Mr. Bennet retired to the library, as was his custom, and Mary went upstairs to her instrument. Two obstacles of the five being thus removed, Mrs. Bennet sat looking and winking at Elizabeth and Catherine for a considerable time, without making any impression on them. Elizabeth would not observe her; and when at last Kitty did, she very innocently said, “What is the matter, mamma? What do you keep winking at me for? What am I to do?”
vi: The same anxious atmosphere was clearly present in the evening. After having tea, Mr. Bennet returned to the study as usual, and Mary went upstairs to practice music. Three of the five obstacles remained. Mrs. Bennet sat watching and winking at Elizabeth and Catherine for a long time without any response. Elizabeth did not want to look at her, and when Kitty finally noticed, she innocently asked: - Mom, what's going on? Why do you keep winking at me? What should I do?
tr: The effort to leave them alone became evident in the evening as well. After tea, Mr. Bennet withdrew to the library as was his custom, and Mary went upstairs to her piano. With two of the five obstacles thus removed, Mrs. Bennet began making facial gestures to Elizabeth and Catherine to seize the opportunity, but they did not notice. Elizabeth was not looking at her; finally, when Kitty saw her, she innocently said, "What is it, mother? Why do you keep winking at me? What am I supposed to do?"
es: In the afternoon, the mother again tried to get Bingley alone with Jane. After tea, Mr. Bennet retired to his library as usual, and Mary went upstairs to play the piano. With two of the five obstacles gone, Mrs. Bennet began to look around and make signs and winks at Elizabeth and Catherine without them noticing. Catherine noticed it before Elizabeth and asked quite innocently: ––What’s wrong, Mom? Why are you signaling to me? What do you want me to do?

en: “Nothing, child, nothing. I did not wink at you.” She then sat still five minutes longer; but unable to waste such a precious occasion, she suddenly got up, and saying to Kitty,—
vi: - There's nothing, my child, nothing. Mom didn't wink at you. Then she sat still for a moment, but not wanting to let such an opportunity go to waste, she suddenly stood up and said to Kitty:
tr: "Nothing, my child, nothing. I didn't wink at you." Then he sat motionless for another five minutes; but since he couldn't risk wasting such a valuable opportunity, he suddenly stood up and said to Kitty,
es: ––Nothing, girl, nothing. I wasn't signaling you at all. She remained seated for five more minutes, but she was unable to waste such a precious opportunity. She suddenly stood up and said to Catherine:

en: “Come here, my love, I want to speak to you,” took her out of the room. Jane instantly gave a look at Elizabeth which spoke her distress at such premeditation, and her entreaty that she would not give in to it. In a few minutes, Mrs. Bennet half opened the door and called out,—
vi: - Come here, my dear, I have something to tell you. Then she led Kitty out of the room. Jane immediately looked at Elizabeth, showing that she was extremely confused, and she wished her sister wouldn't leave. A moment later, she slightly opened the door and called in:
tr: "Come on, my dear, I want to talk to you," he said and took her out of the room. Jane immediately gave Elizabeth a look that showed her distress at such a plan and asked her not to allow it. A few minutes later, Mrs. Bennet partially opened the door and called out,
es: ––Come, darling. I need to talk to you. And he took her out of the room. Jane instantly looked at Elizabeth, showing her regret for such a premeditated departure and asking her not to leave. But a few minutes later, Mrs. Bennet opened the door and said to Elizabeth:

en: “Lizzy, my dear, I want to speak with you.”
vi: - Lizzy, my dear, I have something to tell you.
tr: "Lizzy, my dear, I want to talk to you."
es: ––Come, dear. I need to talk to you.

en: Elizabeth was forced to go.
vi: Elizabeth had to go out.
tr: Elizabeth had to leave.
es: Elizabeth had no choice but to leave.

en: “We may as well leave them by themselves, you know,” said her mother as soon as she was in the hall. “Kitty and I are going upstairs to sit in my dressing-room.”
vi: The mother said, as soon as she reached the hallway: - Of course I know, I need to give you two some privacy. Kitty and mother will sit in the dressing room upstairs.
tr: "We should leave them alone," said her mother as soon as she stepped into the hall. "Kitty and I are going upstairs, we'll be sitting in my dressing room."
es: ––Let's leave them alone, do you understand? ––her mother said to her in the hallway––. Catherine and I are going upstairs to my room.

en: Elizabeth made no attempt to reason with her mother, but remained quietly in the hall till she and Kitty were out of sight, then returned into the drawing-room.
vi: Elizabeth did not want to argue with her mother, but she still stood silently in the hallway until she and Kitty left, then returned to the living room.
tr: Elizabeth did not attempt to argue with her mother; she waited quietly in the hall until she and Kitty were out of sight, then returned to the sitting room.
es: Elizabeth did not dare to argue with her mother; but she stayed in the hall until she saw her disappear with Catherine, and then she returned to the drawing room.

en: Mrs. Bennet’s schemes for this day were ineffectual. Bingley was everything that was charming, except the professed lover of her daughter. His ease and cheerfulness rendered him a most agreeable addition to their evening party; and he bore with the ill-judged officiousness of the mother, and heard all her silly remarks with a forbearance and command of countenance particularly grateful to the daughter.
vi: Mrs. Bennet's intentions for the day did not succeed. Bingley was charming in every way except for proposing to her daughter. His easygoing and cheerful demeanor made the gathering very pleasant. He endured the mother's meddlesome and tactless behavior well, patiently listening to all her absurd remarks with a calm expression, which made the daughter appreciative.
tr: Mrs. Bennet's plans for that day were ineffective. Bingley was delightful in every way, except as a potential suitor for her daughter. With his ease and cheerfulness, he was a wonderful guest for evening gatherings; he endured the mother's tedious meddling, listened to all her foolish remarks with patience and a dignified expression, and earned her daughter's great admiration.
es: Mrs. Bennet's plans did not come to fruition that day. Bingley was a model of kindness, but not the declared suitor of her daughter. His ease and cheerfulness greatly contributed to the liveliness of the evening gathering; he endured all the mother's indiscretions and impertinences and listened to all her foolish warnings with a patience and serenity that left Jane very pleased.

en: He scarcely needed an invitation to stay supper; and before he went away an engagement was formed, chiefly through his own and Mrs. Bennet’s means, for his coming next morning to shoot with her husband.
vi: He did not need to be invited to stay for a late meal; before he left, he and Mrs. Bennet agreed that he would return the next morning to go hunting with her husband.
tr: He didn't even need to be invited to stay for dinner; before leaving, it was agreed, mostly through his and Mrs. Bennet's efforts, that he would come the next morning to go hunting with her husband.
es: He only needed to be invited to stay for dinner, and before he left, Mrs. Bennet extended a new invitation for him to come the next morning to hunt with her husband.

en: After this day, Jane said no more of her indifference. Not a word passed between the sisters concerning Bingley; but Elizabeth went to bed in the happy belief that all must speedily be concluded, unless Mr. Darcy returned within the stated time. Seriously, however, she felt tolerably persuaded that all this must have taken place with that gentleman’s concurrence.
vi: After this day, Jane no longer spoke of her coldness. The sisters did not say a word to each other about Bingley, but Elizabeth was pleased to think that everything would end well, except that Mr. Darcy would return at the time as announced. However, she seriously believed that all this must have happened with his consent.
tr: After that day, Jane never spoke of her indifference again. Among the sisters, Bingley's name was not even mentioned; but Elizabeth went to bed with a happy belief that everything would be swiftly resolved if Mr. Darcy did not return on the stated date. Seriously, it was as if she believed all this was happening with that gentleman's consent.
es: After this day, Jane no longer said that Bingley was indifferent to her. The two sisters did not speak a word about him, but Elizabeth went to bed with the happy conviction that everything would soon be resolved, if Darcy did not return before the indicated time. However, she was seriously convinced that all this would have happened just the same without the absence of said gentleman.

en: Bingley was punctual to his appointment; and he and Mr. Bennet spent the morning together, as had been agreed on. The latter was much more agreeable than his companion expected. There was nothing of presumption or folly in Bingley that could provoke his ridicule, or disgust him into silence; and he was more communicative, and less eccentric, than the other had ever seen him. Bingley of course returned with him to dinner; and in the evening Mrs. Bennet’s invention was again at work to get everybody away from him and her daughter. Elizabeth, who had a letter to write, went into the breakfast-room for that purpose soon after tea; for as the others were all going to sit down to cards, she could not be wanted to counteract her mother’s schemes.
vi: Bingley arrived on time, as both parties had promised, and he and Mr. Bennet spent the whole morning together. He appeared more agreeable than Mr. Bennet had thought. He showed no signs of boldness or recklessness that would provoke Mr. Bennet to mock him, or cause him to hold him in contempt and remain silent. He spoke more lively and maturely than Mr. Bennet had previously seen. Bingley returned with Mr. Bennet for dinner, after which Mrs. Bennet devised all sorts of ways to keep everyone away from him and Jane. Right after tea, Elizabeth went into the breakfast room because she needed to write a letter, and since the others had sat down around the card table, she did not want to go against her mother's intentions.
tr: Bingley arrived for his appointment right on time; he and Mr. Bennet spent the morning together as planned. Mr. Bennet was much more agreeable than his hunting companion had expected. In Bingley, there was not the slightest hint of arrogance or foolishness to provoke his sense of mockery or to disgust him into silence; the other was more talkative and less self-absorbed than he had seen him before. Bingley, of course, returned with him for dinner; in the evening, Mrs. Bennet's wit once again began to work to keep everyone away from Bingley and her daughter. Elizabeth, who had a letter to write, withdrew to the breakfast room right after tea for this purpose; since the others were going to sit down for a card game, her mother's plans could not be opposed.
es: Bingley arrived punctually at the appointment, and he and Mr. Bennet spent the morning together as agreed. Mr. Bennet was much more pleasant than his companion had expected. There was nothing in Bingley of presumption or foolishness that the other could ridicule or be internally displeased with, so he was more communicative and less surly than usual. Naturally, Bingley returned with Mr. Bennet to the house for lunch, and in the afternoon, Mrs. Bennet once again schemed to leave him alone with her daughter. Elizabeth had to write a letter, and for that purpose, she went to the small drawing room shortly after tea, for as the others had sat down to play, her presence was no longer necessary to thwart her mother's plots.

en: But on her returning to the drawing-room, when her letter was finished, she saw, to her infinite surprise, there was reason to fear that her mother had been too ingenious for her. On opening the door, she perceived her sister and Bingley standing together over the hearth, as if engaged in earnest conversation; and had this led to no suspicion, the faces of both, as they hastily turned round and moved away from each other, would have told it all. Their situation was awkward enough; but hers she thought was still worse. Not a syllable was uttered by either; and Elizabeth was on the point of going away again, when Bingley, who as well as the other had sat down, suddenly rose, and, whispering a few words to her sister, ran out of the room.
vi: But after finishing the letter, she returned to the living room and, to her utmost surprise, she found a reason to fear that her mother had been too shrewd. When she opened the door, she saw her sister and Mr. Bingley standing together by the fireplace, as if they were having an earnest conversation. If that wasn't enough, their expressions when they hurriedly turned away and moved apart to sit down said it all. Both looked embarrassed, but she seemed even more awkward. No one spoke a word, and Elizabeth was about to leave when Bingley suddenly stood up, whispered a few words into her sister's ear, and then rushed out.
tr: When the letter was finished and she returned to the living room, she saw with great astonishment that her mother had reason to fear she was too skillful for her. When she opened the door, she saw her sister and Bingley standing in front of the fireplace as if they were engaged in an excited conversation; even if this did not arouse suspicion, their faces as they hurriedly turned and moved away from each other would have been enough to tell everything. Their demeanor was quite strange; but Jane's condition seemed even worse. Neither of them said a word; Elizabeth was about to turn back and leave when Bingley, who was seated like the other, suddenly stood up, whispered a few words to her sister, and rushed out of the room.
es: But upon entering the room, after having finished the letter, she saw with infinite surprise that there was reason to fear that her mother had gotten her way. Indeed, upon opening the door, she spotted her sister and Bingley alone, leaning against the fireplace as if absorbed in the most interesting conversation; and if this had not already given rise to all suspicions, their faces, as they quickly turned and separated, would have said it all. The situation must have been very embarrassing for them, but Elizabeth was about to leave when Bingley, who, like Jane, had sat down, suddenly stood up, whispered a few words in Jane's ear, and left the room.

en: Jane could have no reserves from Elizabeth, where confidence would give pleasure; and, instantly embracing her, acknowledged, with the liveliest emotion, that she was the happiest creature in the world.
vi: Jane could not be reserved with Elizabeth when she felt such joy that she wanted to reveal it. She immediately embraced her sister and, in the most vivid emotion, confessed that she was the happiest creature in the world.
tr: She couldn't hide anything from Jane Elizabeth, especially when revealing her secret would bring joy; she immediately hugged her and, with vivid excitement, said that she was the happiest person in the world.
es: Jane could not keep secrets from Elizabeth, especially not a piece of news that she knew would make her happy. She hugged her tightly and confessed with the most vivid emotion that she was the happiest woman in the world.

en: “’Tis too much!” she added, “by far too much. I do not deserve it. Oh, why is not everybody as happy?”
vi: She added: - That's too much! You don't deserve that. Oh dear! Why can't others have such happiness?
tr: "This is too much!" he added, "really too much. I don't deserve this. Oh! why isn't everyone this happy?"
es: ––It's too much! ––he added. It's too much! I don't deserve it. Oh! Why can't everyone be as happy as I am?

en: Elizabeth’s congratulations were given with a sincerity, a warmth, a delight, which words could but poorly express. Every sentence of kindness was a fresh source of happiness to Jane. But she would not allow herself to stay with her sister, or say half that remained to be said, for the present.
vi: Elizabeth congratulated her with all the sincerity, warmth, and joy that no words could fully express. Every affectionate word was a new source of happiness for Jane. But at this moment, she did not want to stay close to her sister for long, nor say anything more that needed to be said.
tr: Elizabeth sincerely, warmly, and joyfully expressed her congratulations, even if words fell short. Every kind sentence became a new source of happiness for Jane. But at that moment, she was not willing to stay with her sister and recount things superficially.
es: Elizabeth's congratulations were so sincere and so fervent, and revealed so much pleasure that it cannot be expressed in words. Each of her affectionate phrases was a source of joy for Jane. But she couldn't stay with Elizabeth nor tell her half of the things she still had to communicate.

en: “I must go instantly to my mother,” she cried. “I would not on any account trifle with her affectionate solicitude, or allow her to hear it from anyone but myself. He is gone to my father already. Oh, Lizzy, to know that what I have to relate will give such pleasure to all my dear family! how shall I bear so much happiness?”
vi: She exclaimed: - I want to go to mother immediately. I don't want to belittle mother's worries and compassion, or let her receive the news through someone else. He has gone to meet father. Oh dear! Lizzy, just think about how the news I bring will make the whole family so happy! How can I endure such immense happiness!
tr: "I must go to my mother immediately;" she exclaimed. "I can never disregard her affectionate curiosity, nor can I allow her to hear the news from anyone but me. Bingley has already gone to my father. Oh, Lizzy, to know what great pleasure my news will bring to my dear family! How will I endure so much happiness?"
es: ––I'm going to see mom right away ––she said––. I can't ignore her affectionate concern nor allow her to find out from someone else. He just went to talk to dad. Oh, Lizzy! What I'm going to say will fill the whole family with joy. How will I be able to withstand so much happiness?

en: She then hastened away to her mother, who had purposely broken up the card-party, and was sitting upstairs with Kitty.
vi: Then she hurriedly ran to find her mother. Her mother had already decided to break up the card game and was sitting upstairs with Kitty.
tr: Then he hurried to his mother; his mother had deliberately disrupted the card game and was sitting upstairs with Kitty.
es: He went hurriedly in search of his mother who had deliberately suspended the card game and was upstairs with Catherine.

en: Elizabeth, who was left by herself, now smiled at the rapidity and ease with which an affair was finally settled, that had given them so many previous months of suspense and vexation.
vi: Sitting alone, Elizabeth now smiled at how their love story had quickly and easily reached a settled conclusion - a love story that had caused them tension and anxiety for many months.
tr: Elizabeth, left to herself, smiled as she thought about how quickly and easily the matter that had left them in months of curiosity and tension was finally resolved.
es: Elizabeth stood smiling at the ease and speed with which a matter that had caused so many months of uncertainty and pain had been resolved.

en: “And this,” said she, “is the end of all his friend’s anxious circumspection! of all his sister’s falsehood and contrivance! the happiest, wisest, and most reasonable end!”
vi: She thought: "And this is the outcome of all the careful worries in your friend! of all the deceit and tricks in your sister! The happiest, wisest, most reasonable outcome!
tr: "This," he said, "is the end of all those fear-filled objections of your friend, the end of all the lies and deceit of your sister! the happiest, the wisest, the most reasonable end!"
es: "Behold what it has come to," he said to himself, "the anxious circumspection of his friend and all the falseness and tricks of his sisters!" No happier, more prudent, or more reasonable outcome could have been given.

en: In a few minutes she was joined by Bingley, whose conference with her father had been short and to the purpose.
vi: In a moment, Mr. Bingley returned. The exchange between her father and him was brief and straight to the point.
tr: A few minutes later, Bingley came over; his meeting with his father had been short and to the point.
es: A few minutes later, Bingley entered, having finished his short conference with Mr. Bennet.

en: “Where is your sister?” said he hastily, as he opened the door.
vi: He hurriedly asked as he opened the door: - Where is your sister?
tr: "Where is your sister?" he said hurriedly, as he opened the door.
es: ––Where is your sister? ––he said as soon as he opened the door.

en: “With my mother upstairs. She will be down in a moment, I dare say.”
vi: - She went upstairs to meet her mother. She will come down right away, I am sure of it.
tr: "Upstairs, next to my mother. I think she'll come down right away."
es: ––Upstairs, with mom. I think she'll come down soon.

en: He then shut the door, and, coming up to her, claimed the good wishes and affection of a sister. Elizabeth honestly and heartily expressed her delight in the prospect of their relationship. They shook hands with great cordiality; and then, till her sister came down, she had to listen to all he had to say of his own happiness, and of Jane’s perfections; and in spite of his being a lover, Elizabeth really believed all his expectations of felicity to be rationally founded, because they had for basis the excellent understanding and super-excellent disposition of Jane, and a general similarity of feeling and taste between her and himself.
vi: Then he closed the door and approached her, receiving her congratulations and affection. Elizabeth expressed sincerely and warmly about the prospect between the two of them. They shook hands in utmost friendliness, and while waiting for her sister to come down, she had to listen to everything he wanted to say about his happiness. Even though he was in love, Elizabeth truly believed that all his expectations of happiness were based on reason, because there was a wonderful mutual understanding between them, Jane's extremely good character, along with the similarities in feelings and tastes between the two.
tr: Then he closed the door, came to her, and asked for her good wishes and support as a sister. Elizabeth expressed her sincere and enthusiastic happiness about their relationship. They shook hands warmly; then, until her sister came down, she had to listen to what Bingley said about his own happiness and Jane's superior qualities; she was truly convinced that despite being in love, all his expectations of happiness were based on reason, because they were founded on Jane's perfect understanding, extraordinary nature, and the similarity of feelings and tastes between them.
es: Then Bingley closed the door and asked for his congratulations, begging him to consider him as a brother. Elizabeth told him with all her heart how happy she was about this future relationship. They shook hands very cordially, and until Jane came down, Bingley talked about his happiness and the perfections of his beloved. Elizabeth did not believe his hopes for happiness were exaggerated, despite the love that blinded the young man, because Jane's good understanding and excellent heart were joined by the similarity of feelings and tastes with his fiancée.

en: It was an evening of no common delight to them all; the satisfaction of Miss Bennet’s mind gave such a glow of sweet animation to her face, as made her look handsomer than ever. Kitty simpered and smiled, and hoped her turn was coming soon. Mrs. Bennet could not give her consent, or speak her approbation in terms warm enough to satisfy her feelings, though she talked to Bingley of nothing else, for half an hour; and when Mr. Bennet joined them at supper, his voice and manner plainly showed how really happy he was.
vi: This is an evening where each person rejoices in their own way. The contentment on Miss Bennet's face cast a sweet lively glow, making her more beautiful than ever. Kitty, with her colorful smile, hoped that her turn would come soon. Mrs. Bennet could neither respond approvingly to her daughter's wishes nor express agreement with sweet words to satisfy her youngest daughter's heart, even though she spent half an hour talking only with Mr. Bingley about happiness. When Mr. Bennet came down to join them for supper, his words and demeanor showed that he was truly happy.
tr: It was an evening filled with exceptional happiness for all; the satisfaction in Miss Bennet's soul gave her face such a sweet glow of liveliness that it made her look more beautiful than ever. Kitty grinned, smiled, and wished for her turn to come quickly. Although Mrs. Bennet did not talk about anything else to Bingley for half an hour, she could not manage to give her consent or express her positive opinions in a manner warm enough to satisfy herself; when Mr. Bennet joined them at dinner, both his voice and actions showed how truly happy he was.
es: The afternoon passed amid general enchantment; Jane's satisfaction gave her face a light and an expression so sweet that it made her seem more beautiful than ever. Catherine smiled, thinking that her turn would come soon. Mrs. Bennet gave her consent and expressed her approval in the warmest terms, which, nevertheless, did not manage to describe the joy she felt, and for half an hour she could talk to Bingley about nothing else. When Mr. Bennet joined them for dinner, his voice and appearance revealed his joy.

en: Not a word, however, passed his lips in allusion to it, till their visitor took his leave for the night; but as soon as he was gone, he turned to his daughter and said,—
vi: However, he did not say a word about this joy until Bingley had left, but as soon as he had gone, he turned to his daughter and said:
tr: However, not a single hint about the matter came out of his mouth until the guests asked for permission to leave for the night; but when they left, he turned to his daughter and said,
es: But not a word escaped his lips that alluded to the matter until the guest took his leave. As soon as he had gone, Mr. Bennet turned to his daughter and said:

en: “Jane, I congratulate you. You will be a very happy woman.”
vi: - Jane, I congratulate you. You will become a very happy woman.
tr: "Jane, I congratulate you. You will be a very happy woman."
es: ––Congratulations, Jane. You will be a very happy woman.

en: Jane went to him instantly, kissed him, and thanked him for his goodness.
vi: Jane went straight to him, kissed him, and thanked him for his affection.
tr: Jane went right up to him, kissed him, and thanked him for his kindness.
es: Jane ran to her father, gave him a kiss, and thanked him for his kindness.

en: “You are a good girl,” he replied, “and I have great pleasure in thinking you will be so happily settled. I have not a doubt of your doing very well together. Your tempers are by no means unlike. You are each of you so complying, that nothing will ever be resolved on; so easy, that every servant will cheat you; and so generous, that you will always exceed your income.”
vi: He replied: - You are a good daughter, and I am very happy thinking you will be happy in your married life. I have no doubt that you two will get along well. Your temperaments do not clash at all. Each of you wants to indulge the other to the utmost, so there will be nothing that cannot be resolved; each of you is easygoing, so all the servants will deceive both of you; and each of you is generous, so you will always spend beyond your income.
tr: "You are a good girl," replied her father, "thinking that you will have such a happy marriage makes me very happy. I have no doubt that you will get along well. Your temperaments are not different. You are both so gentle that you will not insist on anything, so easygoing that every servant will deceive you, so generous that you will always spend more than your income."
es: ––You are a good girl ––added the father–– and you deserve the luck you have had. You will get along very well. Your characters are very similar. You are so accommodating to each other that you will never resolve anything, so trusting that any servant will deceive you, and so generous that you will always spend more than you have.

en: “I hope not so. Imprudence or thoughtlessness in money matters would be unpardonable in me.”
vi: - I hope that's not the case. Being wasteful or careless with money is unforgivable in your character.
tr: "I hope we don't spend it. In matters of money, recklessness or thoughtlessness would be unforgivable from my perspective."
es: ––That certainly not. Carelessness or negligence in financial matters would be unforgivable for me.

en: “Exceed their income! My dear Mr. Bennet,” cried his wife, “what are you talking of? Why, he has four or five thousand a year, and very likely more.” Then addressing her daughter, “Oh, my dear, dear Jane, I am so happy! I am sure I shan’t get a wink of sleep all night. I knew how it would be. I always said it must be so, at last. I was sure you could not be so beautiful for nothing! I remember, as soon as ever I saw him, when he first came into Hertfordshire last year, I thought how likely it was that you should come together. Oh, he is the handsomest young man that ever was seen!”
vi: The wife exclaimed: - The target exceeds the income! Sir, what are you saying? What, he has four or five thousand a year, maybe more. Then she said to her daughter: My dear, dear Jane, I am so happy! I surely won't be able to sleep tonight. I knew it would be like this. I was certain you couldn't be so beautiful without getting something in return. I still remember, right when I first met him, when he first came to Hertfordshire last year, I thought it was very likely the two of you would pair up. Oh! He is the most handsome young man I have ever seen!
tr: "Spending more than his income!" "Mr. Bennet, my dear," cried his wife, "what are you talking about? What do you mean, the child has four or five thousand a year, probably more."
