Then turning to her daughter, "Oh my dear Jane, I am so happy! I won't be able to sleep all night. I knew it would be like this. I always said it would end like this. You couldn't be this beautiful for nothing! I remember, when he first came to Hertfordshire last year, I knew as soon as I saw him that you would come together. Oh, the handsomest man that ever lived!"
es: ––Spending more than one has! ––exclaimed Mrs. Bennet––. What are you saying? Bingley has four or five thousand pounds a year, maybe more. Then, turning to her daughter, she added: Oh, Jane, dear, my life, I am so happy that I won't be able to close my eyes all night! I always knew this would happen; I always said that in the end everything would work out. I was sure that your beauty would not be in vain. I remember that as soon as I saw him the first time he arrived in Hertfordshire, I thought that you two had to get married. He is the most handsome man I have seen in my life!

en: Wickham, Lydia, were all forgotten. Jane was beyond competition her favourite child. At that moment she cared for no other. Her younger sisters soon began to make interest with her for objects of happiness which she might in future be able to dispense.
vi: Wickham and Lydia were both forgotten. Jane had surpassed all comparisons with the daughter she cherished the most. At this moment, she no longer cared about anyone else. The younger sisters began to pay attention to her because of the benefits she might bestow in the future.
tr: Wickham, Lydia, they were all forgotten. Jane was his indisputably favorite daughter. At that moment, no one else mattered to him. Soon, the youngest sisters began to coax him for the objects of happiness he could distribute in the future.
es: Wickham and Lydia were forgotten. Jane was now her favorite daughter, without any comparison; at that moment, the others did not matter to her at all. The younger sisters soon began to ask Jane for everything they wanted and that she would be able to provide them shortly.

en: Mary petitioned for the use of the library at Netherfield; and Kitty begged very hard for a few balls there every winter.
vi: Mary asked to use the reading room at Netherfield, and Kitty began to insist on having a few balls there each winter.
tr: Mary asked for permission to use the library at Netherfield; Kitty also begged a lot to have a few balls every winter.
es: Mary wanted to use the Netherfield library, and Catherine begged her to organize a few dances there in the winter.

en: Bingley, from this time, was of course a daily visitor at Longbourn; coming frequently before breakfast, and always remaining till after supper; unless when some barbarous neighbour, who could not be enough detested, had given him an invitation to dinner, which he thought himself obliged to accept.
vi: From that moment, of course, Bingley became a daily visitor to Longbourn. He often arrived before breakfast and always stayed until supper, unless some terribly disliked, rude neighbor invited him to dinner, which he felt obliged to accept.
tr: From that time on, Bingley naturally became a daily visitor at Longbourn; he often arrived before breakfast and always stayed until late at night, except on those few days when a merciless neighbor, whom it would be inadequate to call inconsiderate, invited him to dinner and he was obliged to accept.
es: Bingley, as was natural, went to Longbourn every day. He often arrived before lunch and stayed until after dinner, except when some barbaric neighbor, never detested enough, invited him to dine, and Bingley felt obliged to accept.

en: Elizabeth had now but little time for conversation with her sister; for while he was present Jane had no attention to bestow on anyone else: but she found herself considerably useful to both of them, in those hours of separation that must sometimes occur. In the absence of Jane, he always attached himself to Elizabeth for the pleasure of talking of her; and when Bingley was gone, Jane constantly sought the same means of relief.
vi: Elizabeth now had little time to converse with her sister, for when he was present, Jane paid attention to no one else, but Elizabeth found it very beneficial for both of them during the hours when the two were not together. In Jane's absence, he always paid attention to Elizabeth because he enjoyed talking to her; and when Bingley was away, Jane always sought solace in the same manner.
tr: Elizabeth no longer found much time to chat with her sister; with Bingley around, Jane had no inclination to pay attention to anyone else; but Elizabeth sometimes found that the hours of separation, which occasionally had to intervene, were quite beneficial to both of them. When Jane was not around, Bingley devoted himself to Elizabeth, because he enjoyed conversing with her; and when Bingley left, Jane felt the same need for relief.
es: Elizabeth had few opportunities to converse with her sister, for while Bingley was present, Jane had no eyes or ears for anyone else; but she was very useful to both of them during the hours of separation that were sometimes imposed. In Jane's absence, Bingley always sought out Elizabeth to indulge in talking about his beloved; and when Bingley left, Jane constantly turned to the same consolation.

en: “He has made me so happy,” said she, one evening, “by telling me that he was totally ignorant of my being in town last spring! I had not believed it possible.”
vi: One afternoon, she said: - He made you feel very happy when he told you that he had no idea you were in the city during the spring! You couldn't believe such a thing.
tr: "It made me so happy," said Jane one evening, "that he didn't know I was in the city last spring. It had never even occurred to me that this could be possible."
es: ––You don't know how happy he made me ––she told her sister one night–– by telling me that he was unaware I had been in London last spring! It seemed impossible to me!

en: “I suspected as much,” replied Elizabeth. “But how did he account for it?”
vi: - I think exactly like that. But how does he explain this?
tr: "I had suspected," replied Elizabeth. "But how did he explain it?"
es: ––I figured as much. But how do you explain it?

en: “It must have been his sisters’ doing. They were certainly no friends to his acquaintance with me, which I cannot wonder at, since he might have chosen so much more advantageously in many respects. But when they see, as I trust they will, that their brother is happy with me, they will learn to be contented, and we shall be on good terms again: though we can never be what we once were to each other.”
vi: - This must be because of your sister. Surely your sister doesn't like seeing you involved with me. I'm not surprised by this because there could have been more favorable choices, in many respects. But I believe that once they see their loved one happy with me, they will be content, and everything will return to a good relationship, even if it can never be exactly as it was before.
tr: "His sisters must have a job. Of course, they didn't like him being friends with me, which doesn't surprise me, because in many ways he could have made a more advantageous choice. But when his sisters see that he is happy with me, which I am sure they will, they will learn to accept it and things will be good between us again; but we can never be as close as we used to be."
es: ––It must have been the work of his sisters. The truth is that they didn't want anything to do with me, which doesn't surprise me, since Bingley could have found someone better from every point of view. But when they see, as I suppose they will, that their brother is happy by my side, they will be content, and we will be friends again, although never as before.

en: “That is the most unforgiving speech,” said Elizabeth, “that I ever heard you utter. Good girl! It would vex me, indeed, to see you again the dupe of Miss Bingley’s pretended regard.”
vi: - This is the most generous speech I have ever heard you utter. Good girl! Actually, it worries me to see you being deceived by Miss Bingley's feigned affection.
tr: "This is the most intolerant speech I've heard from you," said Elizabeth. "Well done! I don't want to see you fooled by Miss Bingley's false interest again."
es: ––This is the most unforgivable thing I have ever heard you say in my life ––exclaimed Elizabeth––. Wretch! It truly irritates me that you believe in Miss Bingley's supposed friendship.

en: “Would you believe it, Lizzy, that when he went to town last November he really loved me, and nothing but a persuasion of my being indifferent would have prevented his coming down again?”
vi: - Lizzy, do you believe it? When I went to the city last November, I truly loved her, and it was only because I thought she was indifferent to me that I didn't want to return, not for any other reason!
tr: "Would you believe it, Lizzy, when he went to the city last November, he really loved me; he just didn't come back because he believed I was indifferent!""
es: ––Do you believe, Elizabeth, that when he went to the capital last November, he truly loved me and only the certainty that I was indifferent to him prevented him from returning?

en: “He made a little mistake, to be sure; but it is to the credit of his modesty.”
vi: - Surely you have made a small mistake, but this is only because you are modest.
tr: "It seems he made a small mistake; but even this shows his humility.""
es: ––He made a small mistake, actually; but this speaks very well of his modesty.

en: This naturally introduced a panegyric from Jane on his diffidence, and the little value he put on his own good qualities.
vi: In a very natural way, this made Jane sing praises about his shyness, about how he did not deliberately flaunt his good qualities.
tr: This remark naturally led Jane to launch into a praise-filled speech about Bingley's modesty and his disregard for his own merits.
es: This naturally led Jane to praise her fiancé's lack of conceit and the little value he placed on his own qualities.

en: Elizabeth was pleased to find that he had not betrayed the interference of his friend; for, though Jane had the most generous and forgiving heart in the world, she knew it was a circumstance which must prejudice her against him.
vi: Elizabeth was pleased to see that he had not revealed anything about his friend's intervention, because although Jane had the most generous and open-hearted nature in the world, if she understood, she would have a prejudice against Darcy.
tr: Elizabeth was glad that Bingley's friend's intervention was not revealed, because although Jane had the most generous and forgiving heart in the world, she knew that this situation would make her prejudiced against Darcy.
es: Elizabeth was glad that she had not betrayed her friend by speaking of his interference, for although Jane possessed the most generous and forgiving heart in the world, this might have created some prejudice against Darcy in her.

en: “I am certainly the most fortunate creature that ever existed!” cried Jane. “Oh, Lizzy, why am I thus singled from my family, and blessed above them all? If I could but see you as happy! If there were but such another man for you!”
vi: Jane exclaimed: - Surely you are the luckiest creature! Oh Lizzy, why are you treated so specially in the whole family, more specially than anyone else! If only you could see me being as happy as this! If there were another young man like that for me!
tr: "I am the luckiest person in the world!" Jane exclaimed. "Oh, Lizzy, why was I chosen from my family, why did fortune smile upon me! If only I could see you this happy! If only there were such a man for you!"
es: ––I am undoubtedly the luckiest creature on earth, exclaimed Jane. Oh, Lizzy, I feel so sorry to be the happiest in the house! If only you were too! If only there were another man like Bingley for you!

en: “If you were to give me forty such men I never could be so happy as you. Till I have your disposition, your goodness, I never can have your happiness. No, no, let me shift for myself; and, perhaps, if I have very good luck, I may meet with another Mr. Collins in time.”
vi: - If you gave me forty young men like that, I would still never feel as happy as you. If I don't have the qualities you possess, the virtues you have, then I still wouldn't have happiness like yours. No, no, let me take care of it myself, and maybe if I'm really lucky, sooner or later I might meet another Mr. Collins.
tr: "Even if you give me forty men, I cannot be as happy as you. Until I have your nature, your goodness, I cannot possess your happiness. No, no, I will take care of myself; perhaps, if luck is on my side, I may encounter another Mr. Collins in time."
es: ––Even if you gave me forty like him, I would never be as happy as you. As long as I don't have your disposition, I will never be able to enjoy such happiness. No, no; leave me as I am. If I am lucky, I might find another Collins in time.

en: The situation of affairs in the Longbourn family could not be long a secret. Mrs. Bennet was privileged to whisper it to Mrs. Philips, and she ventured, without any permission, to do the same by all her neighbours in Meryton.
vi: The love story in the Longbourn family could not be kept secret for long. Mrs. Bennet had the privilege of whispering to Mrs. Philips, and without permission, the latter whispered to all her neighbors in Meryton.
tr: The development in the Longbourn family could not remain a secret for long. Mrs. Bennet hinted the news to Mrs. Philips, who, without any permission, spread it to all her neighbors in Meryton.
es: The state of the affairs of the Longbourn family could not remain a secret. Mrs. Bennet had the privilege of communicating it to Mrs. Philips, who then proceeded to broadcast it without prior permission to the houses of all the neighbors in Meryton.

en: The Bennets were speedily pronounced to be the luckiest family in the world; though only a few weeks before, when Lydia had first run away, they had been generally proved to be marked out for misfortune.
vi: Everyone quickly assumed that the Bennet family was the luckiest in the world, though just a few weeks earlier, when Lydia had run away from home, they were considered to be unfortunate.
tr: The Bennets were quickly declared the luckiest family in the world, whereas just a few weeks ago, when Lydia first eloped, they were seen by everyone as the epitome of misfortune.
es: The Bennets were soon proclaimed the luckiest family in the world, despite the fact that a few weeks earlier, on the occasion of Lydia's elopement, they had been regarded as the most unfortunate people on earth.

en: CHAPTER LVI.
vi: Chapter 56
tr: Chapter XIV
es: CHAPTER LVI

en: ONE morning, about a week after Bingley’s engagement with Jane had been formed, as he and the females of the family were sitting together in the dining-room, their attention was suddenly drawn to the window by the sound of a carriage; and they perceived a chaise and four driving up the lawn. It was too early in the morning for visitors; and besides, the equipage did not answer to that of any of their neighbours. The horses were post; and neither the carriage, nor the livery of the servant who preceded it, were familiar to them. As it was certain, however, that somebody was coming, Bingley instantly prevailed on Miss Bennet to avoid the confinement of such an intrusion, and walk away with him into the shrubbery. They both set off; and the conjectures of the remaining three continued, though with little satisfaction, till the door was thrown open, and their visitor entered. It was Lady Catherine de Bourgh.
vi: One morning, about a week after Bingley proposed to Jane, while he and the women of the family were conversing, they heard the sound of a carriage and saw a four-horse carriage driving into the grounds. It was too early for visitors to arrive, and moreover, none of the neighbors used such a carriage. The carriage was drawn by horses with harnesses, and both the body of the carriage and the attire of the coachman looked unusual. However, knowing for sure that someone was visiting, Bingley immediately signaled to Miss Bennet to avoid intruding on the family's privacy, and the two went out into the garden. The remaining three continued to speculate but could not find an answer, until the door opened, and the guest stepped in. It was Lady Catherine de Bourgh.
tr: One morning, about a week after Bingley and Jane's engagement was broken off, while Bingley and the ladies of the family were sitting in the dining room, their attention was suddenly drawn to the window by the sound of a carriage; they saw a four-horse carriage coming up the lawn. It was an early hour for a visitor, and the carriage did not resemble that of any of their neighbors. The horses were rented; neither the carriage nor the uniform of the footman in front looked familiar. But since it was certain that someone had arrived, Bingley immediately persuaded Miss Bennet to walk with him in the grove to avoid being taken captive by such an uninvited guest. The two of them left; the other three continued to speculate, but they were not very successful until the door opened and the guest entered. The visitor was Lady Catherine de Bourgh.
es: One morning, approximately a week after Bingley's declaration, while he was gathered in the sitting room with the ladies of Longbourn, they were drawn by the noise of a carriage and looked out the window, spotting a landau with four horses crossing the lawn in front of the house. It was too early for visits and besides, the carriage's team did not belong to any of the neighbors; the horses were post horses and neither the carriage nor the livery of the footmen were familiar to them. But it was evident that someone was coming to the house. Bingley proposed to Jane that they go for a walk in the shrubbery to avoid being separated by the intruder. The two of them left, and the three who stayed in the dining room continued their conjectures, though with little satisfaction, until the door opened and the visitor entered. It was Lady Catherine de Bourgh.

en: They were of course all intending to be surprised: but their astonishment was beyond their expectation; and on the part of Mrs. Bennet and Kitty, though she was perfectly unknown to them, even inferior to what Elizabeth felt.
vi: Of course, they thought there would be some surprise, but they were surprised beyond imagination; Elizabeth was more surprised than both Mrs. Bennet and Kitty, even though these two had not yet become acquainted with the guest.
tr: They were all ready to be surprised, of course; but they were astonished more than they had ever expected; even though they did not know the lady at all, the astonishment felt by Mrs. Bennet and Kitty was mild compared to Elizabeth's.
es: It is true that everyone was expecting some surprise, but this one exceeded all expectations. Although Mrs. Bennet and Catherine did not know that lady, they were no less astonished than Elizabeth.

en: She entered the room with an air more than usually ungracious, made no other reply to Elizabeth’s salutation than a slight inclination of the head, and sat down without saying a word. Elizabeth had mentioned her name to her mother on her Ladyship’s entrance, though no request of introduction had been made.
vi: Mrs. Catherine entered with more rudeness than usual, only slightly nodding in response to Elizabeth's greeting, then sitting down without saying a word. When she entered, Elizabeth had told her mother her name, though no one had asked for an introduction.
tr: He entered the room with a more arrogant air than usual, barely nodding in response to Elizabeth's greeting, and sat down without saying a word. Although no introduction had been requested, Elizabeth had mentioned her name to her mother upon the lady's entrance.
es: He entered the room with an even more unpleasant air than usual; he responded to Elizabeth's greeting with a simple nod of his head and sat down without saying a word. Elizabeth had mentioned his name to Mrs. Bennet when His Lordship entered, although she had not requested any introduction.

en: Mrs. Bennet, all amazement, though flattered by having a guest of such high importance, received her with the utmost politeness. After sitting for a moment in silence, she said, very stiffly, to Elizabeth,—
vi: Mrs. Bennet was extremely surprised, though somewhat self-satisfied, that such a respected person had come to visit, and she received the guest with utmost courtesy. After sitting for a moment in silence, the guest dryly said to Elizabeth:
tr: Mrs. Bennet, who was astonished, greeted the important guest with great courtesy, even though it flattered her pride to host such a significant visitor. After sitting in silence for a moment, she said to Elizabeth in a rather tense manner,
es: Mrs. Bennet, astonished yet very proud to have a person of such high rank in her home, received her with the utmost courtesy. They all sat in silence for a while, until at last Lady Catherine said to Elizabeth with great pomp:

en: “I hope you are well, Miss Bennet. That lady, I suppose, is your mother?”
vi: - I hope you are still well, Miss Bennet. I assume this lady is your mother.
tr: "I hope you are well, Miss Bennet. This lady must be your mother."
es: ––I suppose you are well, and I assume that lady is your mother.

en: Elizabeth replied very concisely that she was.
vi: Elizabeth replied affirmatively.
tr: Elizabeth briefly said that it was so.
es: Elizabeth answered concisely in the affirmative.

en: “And that, I suppose, is one of your sisters?”
vi: - And I think this is one of your sisters.
tr: "This must be one of your sisters, I suppose.""
es: ––And that other one I imagine must be one of his sisters.

en: “Yes, madam,” said Mrs. Bennet, delighted to speak to a Lady Catherine. “She is my youngest girl but one. My youngest of all is lately married, and my eldest is somewhere about the ground, walking with a young man, who, I believe, will soon become a part of the family.”
vi: Mrs. Bennet replied, delighted to converse with a lady named Catherine: - Yes, Madam. It is the second youngest. My youngest daughter is married, and the eldest one is walking somewhere in the garden with a young man, whom I believe will become a member of the family.
tr: "Yes, madam," said Mrs. Bennet, in the pleasure of speaking with the grand Lady Catherine. "The one just older than the youngest. My youngest just got married, and my eldest is somewhere around, on a walk with a young gentleman, who I believe will soon be part of the family."
es: ––Yes, ma'am ––Mrs. Bennet responded, very proud to be able to speak with Lady Catherine––. She is the second youngest; the youngest of all got married recently, and the eldest is in the garden walking with a gentleman who I believe will soon become part of our family.

en: “You have a very small park here,” returned Lady Catherine, after a short silence.
vi: Lady Catherine said, after a moment of silence. - She has a very small garden here.
tr: "You have a small garden here," replied Lady Catherine after a brief silence.
es: ––You have a very small farm ––said His Lordship after a short silence.

en: “It is nothing in comparison of Rosings, my Lady, I dare say; but, I assure you, it is much larger than Sir William Lucas’s.”
vi: - Madam, I dare say nothing can compare to Rosings, but I believe it is even larger than Sir William Lucas's garden.
tr: "Compared to Rosings, it is indeed so, madam, certainly; but rest assured, it is much larger than Sir William Lucas's.""
es: ––It is nothing compared to Rosings, madam; one must admit it; but I assure you it is much better than Sir William Lucas's.

en: “This must be a most inconvenient sitting-room for the evening in summer: the windows are full west.”
vi: - This must be the most inconvenient room in the evening, during the summer; all the windows face directly east.
tr: "This room is not suitable for sitting in on summer evenings; the windows face directly west."
es: ––This must be a very uncomfortable room in the summer afternoons; the windows face completely west.

en: Mrs. Bennet assured her that they never sat there after dinner; and then added,—
vi: Mrs. Bennet stated that the family never sat here after dinner, and added:
tr: Mrs. Bennet assured them that they did not sit there after dinner, then added,
es: Mrs. Bennet assured her that they were never there after dinner, and added:

en: “May I take the liberty of asking your Ladyship whether you left Mr. and Mrs. Collins well?”
vi: - May I ask, how are Mr. and Mrs. Collins?
tr: "May I ask Ladyship if Mr. and Mrs. Collins were well when they parted?"
es: ––May I take the liberty of asking Your Lordship how you left Mr. and Mrs. Collins?

en: “Yes, very well. I saw them the night before last.”
vi: - Very well. I met the two people the evening before last.
tr: "Yes, quite well. I saw them the previous night."
es: ––Very well; I saw them the night before last.

en: Elizabeth now expected that she would produce a letter for her from Charlotte, as it seemed the only probable motive for her calling. But no letter appeared, and she was completely puzzled.
vi: Now, Elizabeth thought she would hand over Charlotte's letter to be delivered to her, as this seemed to be the only reason for her visit here. But there was no letter, and she was utterly bewildered.
tr: Elizabeth must have brought a letter from Charlotte to her, she thought she would take it out and give it to her, because that could be the only possible reason for her visit. But when no letter came out, she became even more confused.
es: Elizabeth hoped that she would now give her some letter from Charlotte, as this seemed the only likely reason for her visit; but Lady Catherine did not take out any letter, and Elizabeth remained perplexed.

en: Mrs. Bennet, with great civility, begged her Ladyship to take some refreshment: but Lady Catherine very resolutely, and not very politely, declined eating anything; and then, rising up, said to Elizabeth,—
vi: With the utmost politeness, Mrs. Bennet earnestly invited the Lady to have some refreshments, but Lady Catherine firmly, and not very politely, refused all food and drink, then stood up and said to Elizabeth:
tr: Mrs. Bennet wanted to offer something to her ladyship with great politeness, but Lady Catherine very firmly and quite rudely refused to eat anything; then she stood up and said to Elizabeth,
es: Mrs. Bennet delicately entreated Her Ladyship to take something, but Lady Catherine firmly declined the offer without excessive politeness. Then, rising, she said to Elizabeth:

en: “Miss Bennet, there seemed to be a prettyish kind of a little wilderness on one side of your lawn. I should be glad to take a turn in it, if you will favour me with your company.”
vi: - Miss Bennet, there seems to be a beautiful patch of greenery on one side of the garden. I would be very pleased to take a walk, if you would kindly show me the way.
tr: "Miss Bennet, it seems you have a nice little wood on one side of your lawn. I would like to take a walk, if you would accompany me."
es: ––Miss Bennet, it seems to me that over there, beside the meadow, there is a beautiful and secluded spot. I would like to take a walk there if you would do me the honor of accompanying me.

en: “Go, my dear,” cried her mother, “and show her Ladyship about the different walks. I think she will be pleased with the hermitage.”
vi: The mother exclaimed: - Go, my child, so the Lady can see different scenery. I think the Lady will like the solitude here.
tr: "Go, darling," cried her mother, "show the lady our walking paths. I believe she will like the hermit's hut."
es: ––Come on, dear ––exclaimed the mother––, show His Lordship all the walks. I think he will like the hermitage.

en: Elizabeth obeyed; and, running into her own room for her parasol, attended her noble guest downstairs. As they passed through the hall, Lady Catherine opened the doors into the dining-parlour and drawing-room, and pronouncing them, after a short survey, to be decent-looking rooms, walked on.
vi: Elizabeth obeyed, ran to her room to get an umbrella, and then escorted the important guest downstairs. As they walked along the hallway, Lady Catherine opened all the doors leading to the dining room and the drawing room, looked around, complimented the elegant rooms, and then continued walking.
tr: Elizabeth agreed; she ran to her room, grabbed her umbrella, and accompanied the noble guest downstairs. As they walked through the corridor, Lady Catherine opened the doors of the dining room and the sitting room, and after a brief glance inside, declared them to be well-kept rooms and continued walking.
es: Elizabeth obeyed, ran to her room to fetch her umbrella, and waited downstairs for her noble visitor. As she passed through the hall, Lady Catherine opened the doors to the dining room and the drawing room, and after a brief inspection, declared that they were decent rooms, after which she continued walking.

en: Her carriage remained at the door, and Elizabeth saw that her waiting-woman was in it. They proceeded in silence along the gravel walk that led to the copse; Elizabeth was determined to make no effort for conversation with a woman who was now more than usually insolent and disagreeable.
vi: The lady's carriage was still standing at the door, and Elizabeth saw the maid sitting in the carriage. They walked along the gravel path to the grove; Elizabeth decided there was no need to attempt conversation with the woman who had now become more insolent and unpleasant than usual.
tr: Her carriage was waiting at the door; Elizabeth saw that her maid was in the carriage. They proceeded silently along the gravel path leading to the grove; Elizabeth was determined not to attempt to converse with the woman, who was now more arrogant and repulsive than usual.
es: The carriage was still at the door, and Elizabeth saw that Her Ladyship's maid was in it. They walked silently along the gravel path that led to the stables.

en: “After a short survey”
vi: They walked along the gravel path to the grove; Elizabeth decided there was no need to attempt conversation with the woman who had now become more insolent and unpleasant than usual.
tr: "How did I mistake him for my nephew?" he thought, while looking at his face.
es: Elizabeth was determined not to engage in conversation with that lady who seemed even more insolent and unpleasant than usual.

en: “How could I ever think her like her nephew?” said she, as she looked in her face.
vi: She thought to herself as she looked at the lady's face: "How could I ever have thought she was like her nephew?"
tr: "How did I mistake him for my nephew?" he thought, while looking at his face.
es: How could I ever say that she looked like her nephew?, he said to himself as he looked at her face.

en: As soon as they entered the copse, Lady Catherine began in the following manner:—
vi: As soon as they entered the orchard, Lady Catherine began:
tr: As soon as they entered the grove, Lady Catherine began to speak:-
es: When they entered a thicket, Lady Catherine said the following to him:

en: “You can be at no loss, Miss Bennet, to understand the reason of my journey hither. Your own heart, your own conscience, must tell you why I come.”
vi: - Miss Bennet, you can easily understand the reason for my visit. Your feelings, your conscience must tell you why I have come here.
tr: "You probably won't be surprised to learn why I came here, Miss Bennet. Your own heart, your own conscience should tell you why I came.""
es: ––Surely you must know, Miss Bennet, the reason for my journey here. Your own heart and conscience must tell you the motive for my visit.

en: Elizabeth looked with unaffected astonishment.
vi: Elizabeth appeared surprised in a calm manner.
tr: Elizabeth looked with emotionless astonishment.
es: Elizabeth regarded her with natural astonishment:

en: “Indeed, you are mistaken, madam; I have not been at all able to account for the honour of seeing you here.”
vi: - Madam, in fact, you are mistaken. I have no knowledge of the reason for your being received here.
tr: "Believe me, you are mistaken, madam. I did not understand what I owe the honor of seeing you here."
es: ––You are mistaken, madam. In no way can I explain the honor of your presence.

en: “Miss Bennet,” replied her Ladyship, in an angry tone, “you ought to know that I am not to be trifled with. But however insincere you may choose to be, you shall not find me so. My character has ever been celebrated for its sincerity and frankness; and in a cause of such moment as this, I shall certainly not depart from it. A report of a most alarming nature reached me two days ago. I was told, that not only your sister was on the point of being most advantageously married, but that you—that Miss Elizabeth Bennet would, in all likelihood, be soon afterwards united to my nephew—my own nephew, Mr. Darcy. Though I know it must be a scandalous falsehood, though I would not injure him so much as to suppose the truth of it possible, I instantly resolved on setting off for this place, that I might make my sentiments known to you.”
vi: The lady responded, with an angry tone: - Miss Bennet, you should know that I am not someone to be trifled with. But although you may wish to deceive, you will find that I am not like that. My character has always been expressed through honesty and straightforwardness, and for a purpose such as this, my character will certainly not change. Two days ago, I received very distressing news. I heard that not only is your sister about to marry advantageously, but also you, Miss Elizabeth Bennet, might very soon marry my nephew, Mr. Darcy. Although I know this is merely a scandalous falsehood, and although I do not wish to hurt my nephew by considering it might be true, I immediately set out to come here to let you know what I think about this matter.
tr: "Miss Bennet," replied her ladyship in an angry tone, "you must know that I am not to be trifled with. Even if you choose to be insincere, you will find that I am not. I am known for my frankness and honesty, and in a situation like this, I certainly will not abandon them. A very alarming rumor reached me two days ago. I was told that not only is your sister on the verge of making a very successful marriage, but you, Miss Elizabeth Bennet, are likely to follow her by uniting with my nephew, my only nephew, Mr. Darcy. Although I know this to be a dreadful falsehood, I would never wrong him by considering it possible, but I decided to come here immediately so that you may know my views."
es: ––Miss Bennet ––replied His Lordship in an angry tone––, you must know that I do not like jokes; no matter how insincere you wish to be, I am not like that. My character has always been celebrated for its loyalty and frankness, and in a matter of such importance as the one that brings me here, I will deviate much less from my way of being. It has come to my attention that not only is your sister about to marry very advantageously, but that you, Miss Bennet, may possibly unite with my nephew Darcy afterwards. Even knowing that this is a dreadful falsehood and although I do not wish to insult my nephew by admitting that there might be some hint of truth in it, I decided at once to come and communicate my feelings to you.

en: “If you believed it impossible to be true,” said Elizabeth, colouring with astonishment and disdain, “I wonder you took the trouble of coming so far. What could your Ladyship propose by it?”
vi: Elizabeth said, blushing with surprise and disdain: - If Madam believes that it is not the truth, I wonder why she took the trouble to come to such a distant place. What does Madam want to teach?
tr: "If you didn't believe it could be true," said Elizabeth, her face pale with astonishment and disgust, "I wonder why you bothered to come all this way. What is her ladyship trying to convey with this?"
es: ––If you truly believed that it was impossible –replied Elizabeth, red with astonishment and disdain–, I am amazed that you bothered to come so far. What is it that you intend?

en: “At once to insist upon having such a report universally contradicted.”
vi: - I want you to deny the news like that, right now.
tr: "Of course, to insist on denying such a rumor."
es: ––First of all, try to have that news corrected in all its parts.

en: “Your coming to Longbourn, to see me and my family,” said Elizabeth coolly, “will be rather a confirmation of it—if, indeed, such a report is in existence.”
vi: Elizabeth said coldly: - Your visit to Longbourn to see me and my family seems to confirm that news, if indeed there is such news.
tr: "Coming to Longbourn to see me and my family," said Elizabeth coldly, "will be more of a confirmation of this; that is, if such a rumor exists."
es: ––His coming to Longbourn to visit me and my family ––observed Elizabeth coldly––, will confirm it with more semblance of truth, if such news has circulated.

en: “If! do you then pretend to be ignorant of it? Has it not been industriously circulated by yourselves? Do you not know that such a report is spread abroad?”
vi: - If that's the case, are you pretending not to know this news? Weren't you the one who painstakingly spread this news? Do you know that this news has already spread widely?
tr: "So, you pretend as if you don't know. Wasn't this skillfully orchestrated by you? Don't you know that such a rumor has been spread around?"
es: ––Has it circulated? Do you intend to ignore it? Haven't you yourselves taken the trouble to spread it?

en: “I never heard that it was.”
vi: - I have never heard of such a thing.
tr: "I've never heard of it.""
es: ––I have never heard anything like it.

en: “And can you likewise declare, that there is no foundation for it?”
vi: - And you want to say that this news has no basis at all, right?
tr: "Can you also say that this is unfounded in the same way?"
es: ––And are you going to tell me as well that there is no basis for what I'm telling you?

en: “I do not pretend to possess equal frankness with your Ladyship. You may ask questions which I shall not choose to answer.”
vi: - I do not want to pretend to have the same frankness as Madam. She can ask questions that I have the right not to answer.
tr: "I will not pretend to have the same level of frankness as Her Ladyship. You may ask questions, but I will choose not to answer."
es: ––I do not presume to have as much frankness as Your Lordship. You may ask me questions that I may not want to answer.

en: “This is not to be borne. Miss Bennet, I insist on being satisfied. Has he, has my nephew, made you an offer of marriage?”
vi: - This is unacceptable. Miss Bennet, I want a satisfactory answer. Did he, my nephew, propose to you?
tr: "It's unbearable. Miss Bennet, I insist on getting an answer. Did my nephew propose to you?"
es: ––It's unbearable! Miss Bennet, I insist that you answer me. Has my nephew proposed to you?

en: “Your Ladyship has declared it to be impossible.”
vi: - The lady said that this matter could not possibly happen.
tr: "The Lady expressed that this was impossible."
es: ––Your Honor has already declared that it was impossible.

en: “It ought to be so; it must be so, while he retains the use of his reason. But your arts and allurements may, in a moment of infatuation, have made him forget what he owes to himself and to all his family. You may have drawn him in.”
vi: - It is indeed so, it must be so, when my nephew still knows how to use reason. But your art and allure can, in a moment of infatuation, make him forget that he owes a debt to himself and to everyone in his family. You may have seduced him into that infatuation.
tr: "It has to be that way; it must be that way, if he hasn't lost his mind. But your coquetries, your flirtations may have momentarily made him forget what he owes to himself and his entire family. You may have seduced him."
es: ––It must be so, it has to be so as long as Darcy retains the use of reason. But her arts and seductions may have made him forget in a moment of blindness what he owes to his entire family and to himself. Perhaps you have dragged him into doing it.

en: “If I have, I shall be the last person to confess it.”
vi: - If I were like that, I would be the last person to confess to you.
tr: "If I did it, I would be the last person to admit it.""
es: ––If I had done it, it wouldn't be me confessing it.

en: “Miss Bennet, do you know who I am? I have not been accustomed to such language as this. I am almost the nearest relation he has in the world, and am entitled to know all his dearest concerns.”
vi: - Miss Bennet, do you know who I am? I am not accustomed to hearing such language. I am almost the closest person to my niece in this world, I have the right to know about all her closest relationships.
tr: "Miss Bennet, do you know who I am? I am not accustomed to this kind of language. I am almost the closest relative she has in the world and am entitled to know all her important matters."
es: ––Miss Bennet, do you know who I am? I am not accustomed to that language. I am almost the closest relative my nephew has in the world, and I have reasons to know what his dearest interests are.

en: “But you are not entitled to know mine; nor will such behaviour as this ever induce me to be explicit.”
vi: - But you have no right to know about my relationships, and such an attitude will never make me confess.
tr: "But you are not authorized to know mine; moreover, you cannot persuade me to be open with such an attitude.""
es: ––But you do not have the right to know what mine are, nor is your behavior the most appropriate to induce me to be more explicit.

en: “Let me be rightly understood. This match, to which you have the presumption to aspire, can never take place. No, never. Mr. Darcy is engaged to my daughter. Now, what have you to say?”
vi: - I want you to understand me very clearly. This marriage, which you have impudently expected, will never happen. No, never. Mr. Darcy is engaged to my daughter. Now, what do you have to say? - Just like this!
tr: "I must ensure that I am understood correctly. The union you dare to imagine can never happen. No, never. Mr. Darcy is engaged to my daughter. Now, let's see what you have to say?"
es: ––But you do not have the right to know what mine are, nor is your behavior the most appropriate to induce me to be more explicit. ––Understand me well: that marriage to which you have the presumption to aspire can never take place, never. Mr. Darcy is engaged to my daughter. What do you have to say now?

en: “Only this,—that if he is so, you can have no reason to suppose he will make an offer to me.”
vi: If that's true, you have no reason to believe that he will confess his feelings to me.
tr: "I will just say this; therefore, you have no reason to think that he will propose to me."
es: ––Just this: that if it is so, you have no reason to suppose that you will make any proposition to me.

en: Lady Catherine hesitated for a moment, and then replied,—
vi: Madam Catherine hesitated for a moment, then replied:
tr: Lady Catherine hesitated for a moment, then replied,
es: Lady Catherine hesitated for a moment and then said:

en: “The engagement between them is of a peculiar kind. From their infancy, they have been intended for each other. It was the favourite wish of his mother, as well as of hers. While in their cradles we planned the union; and now, at the moment when the wishes of both sisters would be accomplished, is their marriage to be prevented by a young woman of inferior birth, of no importance in the world, and wholly unallied to the family? Do you pay no regard to the wishes of his friends—to his tacit engagement with Miss de Bourgh? Are you lost to every feeling of propriety and delicacy? Have you not heard me say, that from his earliest hours he was destined for his cousin?”
vi: - The engagement between the two of them is an unusual matter. Since they were young, they have been betrothed to each other. This is the earnest wish of his mother, as well as her mother. While the two were still in their cradles, we had planned their marriage, and now, as the wish of the two sisters is about to come true, their wedding is being hindered by a young woman of a lower class, of no importance in this world, completely unrelated to the family! Do you not care about the wishes of my niece's relatives? About the implicit engagement of Miss De Bourgh? Have you lost all sense of propriety and delicacy? Did you not hear me say that, since ancient times, my niece has been his intended?
tr: "Their engagement is of a special kind. They were promised to each other when they were still babies. That was the wish of his mother, and mine too. We planned this union while they were still in the cradle: but now, when the wishes of both families are about to be fulfilled, when both are about to marry, a young woman of lower status, with no importance in the world, and no family ties, is preventing this! Do you have no respect for the wishes of his relatives? What about his silent engagement to Miss de Bourgh? Have you lost all sense of shame and decency? Didn't you hear me say that he was promised to his cousin from birth?"
es: ––The commitment between them is peculiar. Since their childhood, they have been destined for each other. It was the greatest wish of his mother and hers. Since they were born, we have planned their union; and now, at the moment when the desires of the two sisters were about to be fulfilled, is it going to be thwarted by the intrusion of a girl of inferior birth, with no status, and completely unrelated to the family? Do the wishes of Darcy's friends, regarding his tacit engagement to Miss de Bourgh, mean nothing to you? Have you lost all sense of decency and delicacy? Did you not hear me say that from his earliest age he was destined for his cousin?

en: “Yes; and I had heard it before. But what is that to me? If there is no other objection to my marrying your nephew, I shall certainly not be kept from it by knowing that his mother and aunt wished him to marry Miss de Bourgh. You both did as much as you could in planning the marriage. Its completion depended on others. If Mr. Darcy is neither by honour nor inclination confined to his cousin, why is not he to make another choice? And if I am that choice, why may not I accept him?”
vi: - Yes, I have heard that before. But what does that mean to me? If no one else objects to my marrying your grandson, I certainly won't back down upon learning that his mother and aunt want him to marry Miss De Bourgh. Both of them have done what they could to arrange the marriage. Whether the marriage succeeds or not depends on others. If Mr. Darcy does not wish to marry his cousin out of honor or affection, why can't he have another choice? And if that choice is me, why can't I accept him?
tr: "Yes, I heard what you said. But what does that matter to me? If there is no other obstacle to marrying your nephew, of course, I will not give up just because his mother and aunt Miss de Bourgh want him to marry someone else. You have done your best by planning the marriage. Its realization depends on others. If Mr. Darcy is not bound by honor or affection to his cousin, why shouldn't he make another choice? If that choice is me, why shouldn't I accept him?"
es: ––Yes, I've heard it said; but, what does that have to do with me? If there were no other obstacle for me to marry your nephew, rest assured that our wedding would not be hindered by the assumption that his mother and aunt wished him to unite with Miss de Bourgh. You two did what you could by planning that marriage, but its realization depends on others. If Mr. Darcy does not feel bound to his cousin either by honor or inclination, why should he not choose another? And if I am the chosen one, why should I not accept him?

en: “Because honour, decorum, prudence—nay, interest—forbid it. Yes, Miss Bennet, interest; for do not expect to be noticed by his family or friends, if you wilfully act against the inclinations of all. You will be censured, slighted, and despised, by everyone connected with him. Your alliance will be a disgrace; your name will never even be mentioned by any of us.”
vi: - Because honor, etiquette, caution - no, this is a right - prohibit it. Yes, Miss Bennet, this is a right, for you should not expect my family and my nephew's acquaintances to acknowledge you if you deliberately act against everyone's wishes. All those related to him will condemn, disdain, and scorn you. The marriage will be a disgrace, and no one in my family will want to mention your name.
tr: "Because honor, decorum, common sense, and even interests forbid it. Yes, Miss Bennet, interests; because if you knowingly act against their preferences, do not expect to be accepted by his family and friends. You will be ostracized, scorned, and ignored by everyone associated with him. Your marriage will be a disgrace; your name will not be mentioned by any of us."
es: ––Because honor, decorum, prudence, and even interest prevent it. Yes, Miss Bennet, interest; because you should not expect to be recognized by Darcy's family or friends if you stubbornly act against everyone's will. You will be censured, slighted, and despised by all of Darcy's relations. Your union will be a calamity; your names will never be spoken by any of us.

en: “These are heavy misfortunes,” replied Elizabeth. “But the wife of Mr. Darcy must have such extraordinary sources of happiness necessarily attached to her situation, that she could, upon the whole, have no cause to repine.”
vi: Elizabeth replied: - These are the heavy misfortunes. But Mr. Darcy's wife will surely be connected to the most wonderful sources of happiness, so she will have no reason to complain.
tr: "These are grave misfortunes," replied Elizabeth. "But Mr. Darcy's wife would have such extraordinary sources of happiness from being with him that there would be no reason to be upset about these.""
es: ––Those are serious misfortunes ––replied Elizabeth––. But Mr. Darcy's wife will surely enjoy such blessings that she will still feel very satisfied.

en: “Obstinate, headstrong girl! I am ashamed of you! Is this your gratitude for my attentions to you last spring? Is nothing due to me on that score? Let us sit down. You are to understand, Miss Bennet, that I came here with the determined resolution of carrying my purpose; nor will I be dissuaded from it. I have not been used to submit to any person’s whims. I have not been in the habit of brooking disappointment.”
vi: - You stubborn, headstrong girl! I am ashamed of you! Is this how you repay the care I gave you last spring? Don't you feel you owe me something? Let's sit down. Miss Bennet, you should understand that I came here with the determination to achieve my goal, and nothing can sway me. I am not accustomed to submitting to anyone's whims. I am not in the habit of enduring disappointment.
tr: "Stubborn, headstrong girl! I am ashamed of you! Is this how you were going to thank me for the attention I showed you last spring? Don't you owe me since then? "Let's sit down. You will understand, Miss Bennet, I came here determined to achieve my purpose; I will not give up. I have never bowed to anyone's whims in my life. I have never tolerated a no as an answer in my life."
es: ––Ah, stubborn and obstinate creature! You make me ashamed! Is that your gratitude for my attentions last spring? Let us sit down. You must know, Miss Bennet, that I have come here with the firm resolution to achieve my purpose. I will not give up. I am not accustomed to submitting to anyone's whims; I am not made to endure disappointments.

en: “That will make your Ladyship’s situation at present more pitiable; but it will have no effect on me.”
vi: - This will make the current situation of the Lady even more pitiable, but it does not affect me.
tr: "This lady's current situation makes it even more pitiable, but it cannot affect me."
es: ––This may make His Lordship's current situation more distressing, but it does not affect me.

en: “I will not be interrupted! Hear me in silence. My daughter and my nephew are formed for each other. They are descended, on the maternal side, from the same noble line; and, on the father’s, from respectable, honourable, and ancient, though untitled, families. Their fortune on both sides is splendid. They are destined for each other by the voice of every member of their respective houses; and what is to divide them?—the upstart pretensions of a young woman without family, connections, or fortune! Is this to be endured? But it must not, shall not be! If you were sensible of your own good, you would not wish to quit the sphere in which you have been brought up.”
vi: - I do not want to be interrupted. Be quiet and listen to me. My daughter and my grandson were raised to live together. Both have maternal relations from the same noble lineage, and paternal relations from respectable, honorable families, though not titled. The wealth of both sides is abundant. They have been paired together by the voice of every family member, what could possibly prevent them? The arrogant expectations of a young girl not from a noble family, with no good connections, no wealth. And to endure this! But no, it cannot be. If she were sensitive to her value, she would not want to step away from the social standing in which she was raised.
tr: "Do not interrupt me. Listen to me quietly. My daughter and my niece were considered for each other. They come from the same noble lineage on their mother's side, and from respectable, honorable, and old families on their father's side, even if without titles. Their wealth on both sides is immense. In the eyes of every member of both families, they belong to each other; so what will separate them? The arrogant dreams of a young woman without family, relatives, or wealth. Is this something to be endured! Absolutely not, and it will not be. If you thought of your own good, you would not want to leave the environment in which you grew up."
es: ––I don't want you to interrupt me! Listen in silence. My daughter and my nephew have been made for each other. On their maternal side, they descend from the same illustrious branch, and on their paternal side, from respectable, honorable, and ancient families, though without title. The fortune on both sides is splendid. They are destined for each other by the vote of all the members of their respective houses; and what can separate them? The untimely pretensions of a girl of humble birth and without fortune. How can this be admitted? But it will not happen! If she looked out for her own good, she would not want to leave the sphere in which she was born.

en: “In marrying your nephew, I should not consider myself as quitting that sphere. He is a gentleman; I am a gentleman’s daughter; so far we are equal.”
vi: - If I were to marry your grandson, I think I wouldn't have to leave my position. He is a nobleman, I am the daughter of a nobleman. Up until now, we are equal.
tr: "I will not think that I have left that circle by marrying your nephew. He is a gentleman; I am also the daughter of a gentleman; in this respect, we are equal."
es: ––By marrying your nephew, I would not believe I am stepping out of my sphere. He is a gentleman, and I am the daughter of another gentleman; therefore, we are equals.

en: “True. You are a gentleman’s daughter. But what was your mother? Who are your uncles and aunts? Do not imagine me ignorant of their condition.”
vi: - Correct. You are the daughter of a noble father. But who is your mother? Who are your uncles and aunts? Don't think I know nothing about your circumstances.
tr: "Correct. You are a gentleman's daughter. But who is your mother? Who are your uncles and aunts? Don't think I'm unaware of them."
es: ––That's right; you are the daughter of a gentleman. But, who is your mother? Who are your uncles and aunts? Do you think I am unaware of your status?

en: “Whatever my connections may be,” said Elizabeth, “if your nephew does not object to them, they can be nothing to you.”
vi: - No matter what my relationships are, if your grandson doesn't care, then it has nothing to do with you.
tr: "Whoever my relatives may be," said Elizabeth, "if your nephew does not object to them, they are none of your concern."
es: ––Whatever my relatives may be, if your nephew has nothing to say about them, you have even less to say ––replied Elizabeth.

en: “Tell me, once for all, are you engaged to him?”
vi: - Tell me definitively, do you have a romantic relationship with him?
tr: "Tell me honestly, are you engaged to her?"
es: Tell me once and for all, are you engaged to him?

en: Though Elizabeth would not, for the mere purpose of obliging Lady Catherine, have answered this question, she could not but say, after a moment’s deliberation,—
vi: Although Elizabeth might not answer this question merely to oblige Lady Catherine; after a moment of thought, she had to say:
tr: Actually, Elizabeth would not have answered this question to please Lady Catherine, but after thinking for a moment, she couldn't help but respond,
es: Although merely out of the desire to be thanked by Lady Catherine, Elizabeth would not have answered her question; she could not help but say, after a moment of deliberation:

en: “I am not.”
vi: - I don't have it.
tr: "No."
es: ––I'm not.

en: Lady Catherine seemed pleased.
vi: Mrs. Catherine seemed pleased.
tr: Lady Catherine seemed pleased.
es: Lady Catherine seemed pleased.

en: “And will you promise me never to enter into such an engagement?”
vi: - And can you promise me that you will never have such a relationship, can you?
tr: "Well, will you promise me that you won't get engaged?""
es: ––And do you promise me never to make such a commitment?

en: “I will make no promise of the kind.”
vi: - I don't promise anything about this.
tr: "I cannot make such a promise."
es: ––I will not make any such promise.

en: “Miss Bennet, I am shocked and astonished. I expected to find a more reasonable young woman. But do not deceive yourself into a belief that I will ever recede. I shall not go away till you have given me the assurance I require.”
vi: - Miss Bennet, I am shocked and surprised. I had hoped to meet a more sensible young lady. But do not delude yourself that I will yield. I will not leave unless you assure me of what I request.
tr: "Miss Bennet, I am shocked, horrified. I thought I would find a more reasonable young woman. But do not deceive yourself into thinking I will give up. I will not leave here until you give me the guarantee I want."
es: Miss Bennet! I am horrified and astonished! I expected you to be more sensible. But do not delude yourself: I do not intend to yield. I will not leave until you have given me the assurance I demand.

en: “And I certainly never shall give it. I am not to be intimidated into anything so wholly unreasonable. Your Ladyship wants Mr. Darcy to marry your daughter; but would my giving you the wished-for promise make their marriage at all more probable? Supposing him to be attached to me, would my refusing to accept his hand make him wish to bestow it on his cousin? Allow me to say, Lady Catherine, that the arguments with which you have supported this extraordinary application have been as frivolous as the application was ill-judged. You have widely mistaken my character, if you think I can be worked on by such persuasions as these. How far your nephew might approve of your interference in his affairs, I cannot tell; but you have certainly no right to concern yourself in mine. I must beg, therefore, to be importuned no further on the subject.”
vi: - And certainly, I never guarantee anything about this matter. I am not easily threatened into accepting anything completely unreasonable like this. The lady wants Mr. Darcy to marry her daughter, but when I promise what she wants, will their marriage be more successful? Suppose he loves me, will my refusal make him declare his love for his cousin? Lady Catherine, allow me to say that the arguments you present to justify this extraordinary demand are as frivolous as the manner in which you make this ill-considered demand. You have mistaken my character if you think I can be persuaded by such means. How your nephew will think of you when you interfere in his love affairs, I cannot say, but surely you have no right to interfere in mine. Therefore, I ask you not to trouble me any further about this matter.
tr: "I will never give in. You cannot intimidate me into something so irrational. Lady, you want Mr. Darcy to marry your daughter; but will giving you the promise you seek make their marriage possible? Assuming he loves me, will my rejection of his proposal make him propose to your daughter? Let me tell you, Lady Catherine, the reasons supporting this extraordinary request are as absurd as the request itself. If you think I will be influenced by such words, you are greatly mistaken about my character. I do not know how much your nephew approves of your interference in his private affairs, but you have no right to interfere in mine. Therefore, I ask you, please do not prolong this matter any further."
es: ––Well, the truth is that I will never give it to her. Do not think that I will be intimidated by such a ridiculous thing. What Your Ladyship wants is for Darcy to marry your daughter; but if I made you the promise you desire, would that marriage be more likely? Suppose he is interested in me; if I refused to accept his hand, do you think he would offer it to his cousin? Allow me to tell you, Lady Catherine, that the arguments you have used to support your extraordinary demand have been as frivolous as the demand itself is thoughtless. You have greatly mistaken me if you think I can be convinced by such reasons. I do not know to what extent your nephew will approve of your interference in his affairs; but you certainly have no right to meddle in mine. Therefore, I beg you not to bother me any further on this matter.

en: “Not so hasty, if you please. I have by no means done. To all the objections I have already urged I have still another to add. I am no stranger to the particulars of your youngest sister’s infamous elopement. I know it all; that the young man’s marrying her was a patched-up business, at the expense of your father and uncle. And is such a girl to be my nephew’s sister? Is her husband, who is the son of his late father’s steward, to be his brother? Heaven and earth!—of what are you thinking? Are the shades of Pemberley to be thus polluted?”
vi: - Don't be hasty. I haven't finished speaking. With all the arguments I've made against you, I have one more thing. I know all the details about the scandal when your youngest sister ran away with a man. I know everything, I know that his marriage to the girl was just a patch-up measure, with the expenses borne by your father and your uncle. And can such a girl be the sister-in-law of my nephew? Can her husband, a son of a servant working for his grandfather, be the brother-in-law of my nephew? Good heavens! What do you think about this! Will the Pemberley estate be tainted like that?
tr: "Not so fast. I'm not finished. There is one more thing I want to add to all the objections I have made. I am not unaware of the details of your youngest brother's disgraceful escape. I know everything; the young man's marriage to her was a hastily arranged affair, orchestrated by your father and uncle. Will such a girl become my nephew's sister-in-law? Will her husband, the son of her late father's steward, become his brother-in-law? God forbid! –what do you say to that? Will the shades of Pemberley be thus polluted?"
es: ––Do not rush, please, I have not finished yet. To all the objections I have raised, I must add one more. I am not unaware of the details of the infamous abduction of your younger sister. I know everything. I know that the boy married her thanks to an arrangement made between his father and his uncle. And that woman is to be my nephew's sister? And her husband, the son of your father's former steward, is to become Darcy's brother? For heaven's sake! What do you think? Are the ancestors of Pemberley to be desecrated in this way?

en: “You can now have nothing further to say,” she resentfully answered. “You have insulted me, in every possible method. I must beg to return to the house.”
vi: She replied, annoyed: - Now you have nothing more to say. You have humiliated me in every possible way. I beg you to return home.
tr: "You can't say anything else now," he replied with distress. "You have insulted me in every possible way. With your permission, I am returning home."
es: ––You have already said it all ––replied Elizabeth indignantly––. You have insulted me in every possible way. I beg you, let us return home.

en: And she rose as she spoke. Lady Catherine rose also, and they turned back. Her Ladyship was highly incensed.
vi: And she spoke while standing up. Lady Catherine also stood up, and both of them turned back. Lady Catherine was very angry.
tr: He stood up while saying these words. Lady Catherine also stood up and they turned back. Her Ladyship was quite angry.
es: And upon saying this, he stood up. Lady Catherine stood up as well and they returned. Her Ladyship was in a rage.

en: “You have no regard, then, for the honour and credit of my nephew! Unfeeling, selfish girl! Do you not consider that a connection with you must disgrace him in the eyes of everybody?”
vi: - So, you don't care about my nephew's honor and reputation! You are an insensitive, selfish girl! Do you think your relationship with him is a disgrace in the eyes of everyone?
tr: "So, you have no respect for my nephew's honor and dignity! Heartless, selfish girl! Don't you ever think that being involved with you will ruin his reputation in everyone's eyes?"
es: ––So, you have no regard for the honor and reputation of my nephew? You insensitive and selfish creature! Don't you realize that if he marries you, he will be discredited in the eyes of everyone?

en: “Lady Catherine, I have nothing further to say. You know my sentiments.”
vi: - Mrs. Catherine, I have nothing more to say. You have understood my feelings.
tr: "Lady Catherine, I have nothing more to say. You know my thoughts."
es: Lady Catherine, I have nothing more to say. You already know what I think.

en: “You are then resolved to have him?”
vi: - So you are determined to take my grandchild??
tr: "So, you're going to marry him, is that right?"
es: ––Are you, then, determined to achieve it?

en: “I have said no such thing. I am only resolved to act in that manner, which will, in my own opinion, constitute my happiness, without reference to you, or to any person so wholly unconnected with me.”
vi: - I didn't say anything about such a matter. I just firmly decided to act in a way that I believe will create happiness for me without involving you, or anyone else who has no relation to me.
tr: "I didn't say such a thing. According to my own view, I am determined to act only in a way that will make me happy; I don't care what you or others who have nothing to do with me say."
es: ––I have not said such a thing. I am only determined to act in the way that I believe is most convenient for my happiness without taking you or anyone who has so little to do with me into account.

en: “It is well. You refuse, then, to oblige me. You refuse to obey the claims of duty, honour, and gratitude. You are determined to ruin him in the opinion of all his friends, and make him the contempt of the world.”
vi: - Alright. So you refused my request. You refused to comply with all the demands of duty, honor, and gratitude. You insist on ruining my nephew's life in the eyes of all his loved ones, causing him to be scorned by the world.
tr: "Alright. So you refuse. You refuse to fulfill the requirements of duty, honor, and gratitude. You are determined to ruin him in the eyes of all his friends, to disgrace him before the world."
es: ––Very well. Then you refuse to please me. You refuse to obey the command of duty, honor, and gratitude. You are determined to humiliate my nephew in front of all his friends and make him the laughingstock of everyone.

en: “Neither duty, nor honour, nor gratitude,” replied Elizabeth, “has any possible claim on me, in the present instance. No principle of either would be violated by my marriage with Mr. Darcy. And with regard to the resentment of his family, or the indignation of the world, if the former were excited by his marrying me, it would not give me one moment’s concern—and the world in general would have too much sense to join in the scorn.”
vi: - All duties, honors, and gratitude cannot have any plea in a situation like this. And my marriage to Mr. Darcy does not violate any principle at all. And speaking of his family's outrage, even if the family were delighted about his marrying me, I wouldn't care in the slightest. Or speaking of the world's disdain, generally, the world must have too much consciousness to interfere.
tr: "Neither duty, nor honor, nor gratitude," replied Elizabeth, "can influence me in such a situation. There is nothing in my marrying Mr. Darcy that violates these principles. As for offending the family or the world's disdain, if his family gets excited about marrying me, it wouldn't worry me for a moment – and the world knows better than to concern itself with such matters."
es: ––Neither duty, nor honor, nor gratitude ––replied Elizabeth––, can demand anything from me in the present circumstances. None of your principles would be violated by my marriage to Darcy. And as for the resentment of your family or the indignation of the world, if the former are enraged by my marriage to their nephew, I wouldn't care in the slightest; and the world would have enough good sense to join me in my disdain.

en: “And this is your real opinion! This is your final resolve! Very well. I shall now know how to act. Do not imagine, Miss Bennet, that your ambition will ever be gratified. I came to try you. I hoped to find you reasonable; but depend upon it I will carry my point.”
vi: - And that is her true opinion! This is your final decision?! Very well. Now I know how to act. Miss Bennet, don't think your ambition will come true. I came here to try to settle things with you. I had hoped you were reasonable, so that I could persuade you.
tr: "So this is your true opinion! This is your final decision! Very well. I know what I will do. Do not think that Miss Bennet will reap the rewards of ambition. I came here to test you. I hoped to find you reasonable; but be assured, I will do what I have set my mind to."
es: ––And this is your attitude, your final resolution? Very well; I know what I have to do. Do not imagine that your ambition, Miss Bennet, will ever be satisfied. I came to test you. I hoped you would be a reasonable person. But rest assured that I will have my way.

en: In this manner Lady Catherine talked on till they were at the door of the carriage, when, turning hastily round, she added,—
vi: In such a tone, Lady Catherine continued to speak until they reached the carriage, then suddenly turning back, she added:
tr: Lady Catherine kept talking like this until they reached the car door; then she turned hastily and added these words,
es: Lady Catherine said all this until they reached the carriage door. Then she turned and said:

en: “I take no leave of you, Miss Bennet. I send no compliments to your mother. You deserve no such attention. I am most seriously displeased.”
vi: - Miss Bennet, I am not saying goodbye to you. I do not wish to send my regards to your mother. You do not deserve such attention. I am extremely displeased.
tr: "I am not asking for your permission, Miss Bennet. I am not sending my regards to your mother either. You do not deserve such attention. You have seriously annoyed me."
es: ––I do not bid you farewell, Miss Bennet; I send no regards to your mother; you do not deserve such attention. You have gravely offended me.

en: Elizabeth made no answer; and without attempting to persuade her Ladyship to return into the house, walked quietly into it herself. She heard the carriage drive away as she proceeded upstairs. Her mother impatiently met her at the door of her dressing-room, to ask why Lady Catherine would not come in again and rest herself.
vi: Elizabeth did not answer and did not want to try to persuade her to come back into the house. She quickly turned away. She heard the sound of the carriage leaving as she ascended the steps. Her mother anxiously came out to meet her at the living room door, to ask why Lady Catherine did not come back into the house to rest.
tr: Elizabeth did not respond; without attempting to persuade her ladyship to return home, she quietly walked into the house on her own. As she was going upstairs, she heard the carriage driving away. Her mother impatiently met her at the door of the dressing room, asking why Lady Catherine had not come back in to rest.
es: Elizabeth did not respond nor did she try to persuade Her Ladyship to come into the house. She left alone and slowly. As she was going up the stairs, she heard the carriage depart. Her mother, impatient, met her at the door of the dressing room to ask her why Lady Catherine had not come back to rest.

en: “She did not choose it,” said her daughter; “she would go.”
vi: Her daughter replied: - She doesn't want to, she wants to go.
tr: "She didn't want to," said the girl. "She was going to leave.""
es: ––He didn't want to ––said his daughter––. He has left.

en: “She is a very fine-looking woman! and her calling here was prodigiously civil! for she only came, I suppose, to tell us the Collinses were well. She is on her road somewhere, I dare say; and so, passing through Meryton, thought she might as well call on you. I suppose she had nothing particular to say to you, Lizzy?”
vi: - She looks so beautiful! And she is so polite to visit us! Because mother thinks she came just to let us know that Mr. Collins' family is still doing well. I am sure she was on her way somewhere, and when passing through Meryton, she intended to visit you. I don't think she had anything special to say to you, did she, Lizzy?
tr: "What a pleasant woman! It was extremely kind of her to visit us! because surely she came just to tell us that the Collinses are well. Obviously, she was going somewhere else and thought of stopping by to see you while passing through Meryton. She didn't have anything special to tell you, did she, Lizzy?"
es: ––What a distinguished woman! And what courtesy on her part to come visit us! Because I suppose she has come to tell us that the Collinses are well. She must have been going somewhere and thought she could visit us while passing through Meryton. I suppose she didn't have anything particular to say to you, right, Lizzy?

en: Elizabeth was forced to give in to a little falsehood here; for to acknowledge the substance of their conversation was impossible.
vi: Elizabeth had to tell a little lie because she couldn't possibly reveal the content of the conversation between the two.
tr: Elizabeth had to resort to a bit of lying at this point; because it was impossible to explain the subject of their conversations.
es: Elizabeth was forced to tell a small lie, because uncovering the subject of her conversation was impossible.

en: CHAPTER LVII.
vi: Chapter 57
tr: Chapter XV
es: CHAPTER LVII

en: THE discomposure of spirits which this extraordinary visit threw Elizabeth into could not be easily overcome; nor could she for many hours learn to think of it less than incessantly. Lady Catherine, it appeared, had actually taken the trouble of this journey from Rosings for the sole purpose of breaking off her supposed engagement with Mr. Darcy. It was a rational scheme, to be sure! but from what the report of their engagement could originate, Elizabeth was at a loss to imagine; till she recollected that his being the intimate friend of Bingley, and her being the sister of Jane, was enough, at a time when the expectation of one wedding made everybody eager for another, to supply the idea. She had not herself forgotten to feel that the marriage of her sister must bring them more frequently together. And her neighbours at Lucas Lodge, therefore, (for through their communication with the Collinses, the report, she concluded, had reached Lady Catherine,) had only set that down as almost certain and immediate which she had looked forward to as possible at some future time.
vi: Elizabeth could not calm the turmoil in her mind caused by that unusual visit, and for many hours, she could not stop thinking about it. It seemed that Lady Catherine had taken the trouble to come from Rosings with the sole purpose of preventing her relationship with Mr. Darcy. Indeed, this was a reasonable assumption! But Elizabeth could not understand how news of their relationship had spread, and she recalled that he was a close friend of Bingley, while she was Jane's sister. That was enough to spark the idea, when the desire for a marriage made everyone excited about another wedding. She herself had not forgotten that her sister's marriage would certainly bring her and Darcy closer together more often. And thus, the neighbors at the Lucas house had concluded that this would surely and quickly happen, while she herself only hoped it could be possible in the future. She guessed that Lady Catherine had learned about it through the information exchanged between the Lucas and Collins households.
tr: It was not easy for Elizabeth to overcome the annoyance caused by this extraordinary visit; she could not manage to stop thinking about it for hours at a time. Lady Catherine had evidently gone to all the trouble of coming from Rosings to there just to break off her imaginary engagement with Mr. Darcy. It was indeed a clever plan! But Elizabeth had no idea where the rumor of their engagement could have originated; eventually, she thought that Darcy being Bingley's close friend, and him being Jane's brother, at a time when everyone was expecting one wedding, was enough to give rise to the idea of a second one. She had not forgotten that her sister's marriage would bring them together more frequently. So, their neighbors at Lucas Lodge (since they communicated with the Collinses, she concluded that the rumor had reached Lady Catherine through them) had conveyed what Elizabeth saw as a possibility for the future as if it were a done deal.
es: Not without difficulty did Elizabeth manage to overcome the agitation caused by that extraordinary visit. She spent many hours unable to think of anything else. Apparently, Lady Catherine had taken the trouble to travel from Rosings to Hertfordshire with the sole purpose of breaking her supposed engagement with Darcy. Although Lady Catherine was very capable of such a project, Elizabeth could not imagine where she had gotten the news of said engagement, until she remembered that his being such a good friend of Bingley and she being Jane's sister could have given rise to the idea, since the marriage of one couple predisposed to suppose the marriage of the other. Elizabeth had indeed thought that her sister's marriage would bring her and Darcy closer together. That must have been why the Lucases—through whose correspondence with the Collinses Elizabeth presumed the conjecture had reached Lady Catherine's ears—considered immediate what she had also believed possible for later.

en: In revolving Lady Catherine’s expressions, however, she could not help feeling some uneasiness as to the possible consequence of her persisting in this interference.
