From what she had said of her resolution to prevent the marriage, it occurred to Elizabeth that she must meditate an application to her nephew; and how he might take a similar representation of the evils attached to a connection with her she dared not pronounce. She knew not the exact degree of his affection for his aunt, or his dependence on her judgment, but it was natural to suppose that he thought much higher of her Ladyship than she could do; and it was certain, that in enumerating the miseries of a marriage with one whose immediate connections were so unequal to his own, his aunt would address him on his weakest side. With his notions of dignity, he would probably feel that the arguments, which to Elizabeth had appeared weak and ridiculous, contained much good sense and solid reasoning.
vi: However, upon reconsidering Lady Catherine's words, she couldn't help but feel some unease about the consequences of her insistence on intervening. From her determined words to prevent the wedding, Elizabeth suddenly thought that she would surely persuade her nephew, and she dared not think how he would react to arguments about the detrimental aspects of their relationship. She was not exactly sure of his feelings towards his aunt, but naturally, one could assume that he thought more highly of Lady Catherine than she could. It was certain that when listing the drawbacks of a marriage with someone of unequal social standing, his aunt would exploit his weakest points. With his notions of propriety, he might think that the arguments, which Elizabeth found weak and laughable, were reasonable and solid.
tr: However, while contemplating Lady Catherine's statements, she couldn't help but feel a bit uneasy about the likely outcome of her insistence on this intervention. From what she said about her decision to prevent their marriage, Elizabeth thought she might be planning to make a request to her nephew; if she conveyed the same negatives of being related to him, Elizabeth dared not think how Darcy would respond. She did not know the exact degree of his attachment to his aunt or how much he valued her opinions, but it was natural for him to hold Lady Catherine in higher regard than Elizabeth could; moreover, it was certain that while listing the troubles of marrying someone whose close relatives were so inferior to his own, his aunt would be appealing to his weakest point. Darcy, with his views on nobility that Elizabeth found weak and ridiculous, would probably feel that these claims were reasonable and thoroughly considered.
es: But upon reflecting on Lady Catherine's words, she could not avoid a certain uneasiness about the consequences that her interference might have. From what she said about her resolution to prevent the marriage, Elizabeth deduced that she intended to confront her nephew, and she did not know how Darcy would take the relation of the dangers that their union entailed. She was unaware of the extent of Darcy's affection for his aunt and how much he valued her opinion; but it was logical to suppose that he had more regard for Her Ladyship than she did, and she was sure that her aunt would touch a sore spot by enumerating the misfortunes of a marriage with a person from a family so unequal to his own. Given Darcy's ideas on that particular matter, Elizabeth believed it likely that the arguments that had seemed so weak and ridiculous to her might appear to him full of good sense and solid reasoning.

en: If he had been wavering before, as to what he should do, which had often seemed likely, the advice and entreaty of so near a relation might settle every doubt, and determine him at once to be as happy as dignity unblemished could make him. In that case he would return no more. Lady Catherine might see him in her way through town; and his engagement to Bingley of coming again to Netherfield must give way.
vi: If before he seemed to hesitate, not knowing what to do, now the advice and encouragement of such a close relative could dispel all doubts and determine that he immediately becomes happy in a way that an unblemished dignity can help him be happy. In this case, he would not return to her anymore. On the way, Lady Catherine might meet him in the city, and he would have to abandon the idea of returning to Netherfield with Bingley.
tr: If Darcy was undecided about what he should do until then, which often seemed to be the case, the suggestions and desires of such a close relative could dispel any doubt and lead him to happiness within the possibilities of unblemished nobility in an instant. In that case, he would not return. Lady Catherine could stop by to see him while going to the city; and the promise he made to Bingley to return to Netherfield would be forgotten.
es: So if Darcy had hesitated before about what he had to do, which he often seemed to, the warnings and urgings of such a close relative might dispel all his doubts and incline him once and for all to be as happy as an immaculate dignity would allow him. In that case, Darcy would not return to Hertfordshire. Lady Catherine would see him as he passed through London, and the young man would rescind his commitment to Bingley to return to Netherfield.

en: “If, therefore, an excuse for not keeping his promise should come to his friend within a few days,” she added, “I shall know how to understand it. I shall then give over every expectation, every wish of his constancy. If he is satisfied with only regretting me, when he might have obtained my affections and hand, I shall soon cease to regret him at all.”
vi: She thought further: "Therefore, if in the next few days he makes excuses to his friends about not keeping his promises, I will understand the situation. I will give up all hopes about his loyalty. If he is only complacent with feeling sorry for himself, when he could win my affection, soon I might not regret anything about him anymore."
tr: "So, if instead of keeping the promise he made to his friend to return in a few days, he sends an apology letter," she added, "I know how to interpret that. Then I will put an end to every hope, every wish related to his commitment. If missing me will suffice for him when he could have my love and my yes, I will immediately stop missing him." ------------------------
es: "Therefore," Elizabeth said to herself, "if in a few days Bingley receives an excuse from Darcy for not coming, I will know what to expect. And then I will have to rid myself of all hope and illusion about his constancy. If he is content to lament my loss when he could have obtained my love and my hand, I too will soon cease to lament losing him."

en: The surprise of the rest of the family, on hearing who their visitor had been, was very great: but they obligingly satisfied it with the same kind of supposition which had appeased Mrs. Bennet’s curiosity; and Elizabeth was spared from much teasing on the subject.
vi: When they heard the news about the visitor, the rest of the family were extremely surprised, but they accepted Mrs. Bennet's explanation, and Elizabeth escaped everyone's teasing.
tr: The other family members were greatly surprised to hear who had come to visit; but they dispelled it with the same kind of assumption that satisfied Mrs. Bennet's curiosity, thus sparing Elizabeth from being pressed on the matter.
es: The surprise of the rest of the family upon learning who the visitor had been was enormous; but they explained everything in the same way as Mrs. Bennet, and Elizabeth was spared having to mention her indignation.

en: The next morning, as she was going down stairs, she was met by her father, who came out of his library with a letter in his hand.
vi: The next morning, as she was walking down the stairs, just as her father was coming out of the study, holding a letter in his hand.
tr: The next morning, while coming down the stairs, he encountered his father coming out of the library with a letter in his hand.
es: The next morning, when coming down from his room, he met his father who was coming out of the library with a letter in his hand.

en: “Lizzy,” said he, “I was going to look for you: come into my room.”
vi: He said: - Lizzy, I'm looking for you. Come into my room.
tr: "Lizzy," said her father, "I was just about to look for you; come to my room.""
es: ––Elizabeth ––he said to her––, I was looking for you. Come with me.

en: She followed him thither; and her curiosity to know what he had to tell her was heightened by the supposition of its being in some manner connected with the letter he held. It suddenly struck her that it might be from Lady Catherine, and she anticipated with dismay all the consequent explanations.
vi: She followed him, increasingly curious about what he would say to her, which she guessed was related to the letter in his hand. Suddenly, she guessed this might be a letter from Lady Catherine, and she became disheartened thinking about the explanations that would follow.
tr: Elizabeth entered after her father; her curiosity about what he had to say increased even more when she thought it might somehow be related to the letter in her hand. Suddenly, she thought the letter might have come from Lady Catherine, and she anxiously considered all the explanations that would entail.
es: Elizabeth followed him and her curiosity to know what he had to communicate to her increased, thinking that it might be related to the previous day. Suddenly, it occurred to her that the letter could be from Lady Catherine, and she anticipated with dismay what it might be about.

en: She followed her father to the fireplace, and they both sat down. He then said,—
vi: The two people sat down near the fireplace, then he said:
tr: He followed his father to the fireplace; they sat together. His father began to speak,
es: He went with his father to the fireplace and they both sat down. Then Mr. Bennet said:

en: “I have received a letter this morning that has astonished me exceedingly. As it principally concerns yourself, you ought to know its contents. I did not know before that I had two daughters on the brink of matrimony. Let me congratulate you on a very important conquest.”
vi: - Dad received this letter this morning. Dad was extremely surprised. Since it mainly concerns you, you need to know the content. Previously, Dad did not know he had two daughters about to get married. Dad congratulates you on a very important conquest.
tr: "This morning, I received a letter that surprised me greatly. It actually concerns you, so you have the right to know its contents. I did not know before that my two daughters were on the verge of marriage. Allow me to congratulate you on this very important achievement."
es: ––I received a letter this morning that left me flabbergasted. Since it mainly concerns you, you should know its contents. Until now, I didn't know that you had two daughters about to get married. Allow me to congratulate you on such an achievement.

en: The colour now rushed into Elizabeth’s cheeks in the instantaneous conviction of its being a letter from the nephew, instead of the aunt; and she was undetermined whether most to be pleased that he explained himself at all, or offended that his letter was not rather addressed to herself, when her father continued,—
vi: Elizabeth's face turned red with joy when she immediately thought it was a letter from her nephew instead of her aunt. While she didn't know whether to be happy because he had calmed everything down, or upset because he didn't write to her directly, her father spoke up:
tr: The belief that the letter was not from her aunt but from her niece caused blood to rush to Elizabeth's cheeks; she could not decide whether to be pleased that Darcy had finally expressed himself or to be offended that he had not written the letter to her; her father continued,
es: Elizabeth was left stunned, believing that the letter was from the nephew instead of the aunt; and she wavered between being glad that Darcy was finally explaining himself, and being offended that he had not addressed the letter to her, when her father continued:

en: “You look conscious. Young ladies have great penetration in such matters as these; but I think I may defy even your sagacity to discover the name of your admirer. This letter is from Mr. Collins.”
vi: - You seem alert. Young girls have the ability to see through such matters, but I think I can even challenge your sharp intellect. This letter is from Mr. Collins.
tr: "It is understood that you know. Young ladies have strong intuitions about such matters; but I think I can even surpass your intelligence in discovering the name of your admirer. This letter is from Mr. Collins."
es: ––It seems like you can guess it. You girls have great intuition for these matters. But I think I can challenge your shrewdness by daring you to discover the name of your admirer. The letter is from Collins.

en: “From Mr. Collins! and what can he have to say?”
vi: - Mr. Collins! And what did he write?
tr: "From Mr. Collins! What could he possibly have to say?"
es: ––From Collins! And what does he have to say?

en: “Something very much to the purpose, of course. He begins with congratulations on the approaching nuptials of my eldest daughter, of which, it seems, he has been told by some of the good-natured, gossiping Lucases. I shall not sport with your impatience by reading what he says on that point. What relates to yourself is as follows:—‘Having thus offered you the sincere congratulations of Mrs. Collins and myself on this happy event, let me now add a short hint on the subject of another, of which we have been advertised by the same authority. Your daughter Elizabeth, it is presumed, will not long bear the name of Bennet, after her eldest sister has resigned it; and the chosen partner of her fate may be reasonably looked up to as one of the most illustrious personages in this land.’ Can you possibly guess, Lizzy, who is meant by this? ‘This young gentleman is blessed, in a peculiar way, with everything the heart of mortal can most desire,—splendid property, noble kindred, and extensive patronage. Yet, in spite of all these temptations, let me warn my cousin Elizabeth, and yourself, of what evils you may incur by a precipitate closure with this gentleman’s proposals, which, of course, you will be inclined to take immediate advantage of.’ Have you any idea, Lizzy, who this gentleman is? But now it comes out. ‘My motive for cautioning you is as follows:—We have reason to imagine that his aunt, Lady Catherine de Bourgh, does not look on the match with a friendly eye.’ Mr. Darcy, you see, is the man! Now, Lizzy, I think I have surprised you. Could he, or the Lucases, have pitched on any man, within the circle of our acquaintance, whose name would have given the lie more effectually to what they related? Mr. Darcy, who never looks at any woman but to see a blemish, and who probably never looked at you in his life! It is admirable!”
vi: - Of course, it's something that goes straight to the point. He began the letter with congratulations to Father on the upcoming wedding of his eldest daughter. It seems he heard the news from one of the kind-hearted, or gossiping, members of the Lucas family. Father didn't want to test your patience, so he didn't read this part. The part related to you is as follows: "After expressing the sincerest congratulations from Mrs. Collins and myself on that happy event, I now briefly address another matter. According to the same source, it is speculated that your daughter Elizabeth will soon no longer bear the Bennet surname. After the eldest daughter has taken another name, and the partner she has chosen is one of the most illustrious figures in this country." He spoke to Elizabeth while reading the letter: - Lizzy, can you guess who he is referring to? "This young man is strangely endowed with many blessings, with everything that a mortal heart could dream of the most - magnificent wealth, noble lineage, and extensive patronage." However, despite such temptations, I must warn my cousin Elizabeth, and warn you, about the calamities that may arise from hastily accepting his proposal, which with these advantages, of course, no one would want to overlook." Lizzy, do you know who he is? But here you will know: "The motivation that compels me to warn is this. We have reason to believe that his aunt, Lady Catherine de Bourgh, views the marriage with disfavor." He continued: - Mr. Darcy, my dear, it is him! Now, Lizzy, I think I have surprised you. Could he, or the Lucas family, lie more blatantly than that when mentioning his name? Mr. Darcy, who always looks at women through their flaws, and who probably would never have looked at you in his entire life! It's truly remarkable!
tr: "Something aimed at the purpose, of course. Obviously, he heard from the good-hearted, gossiping Lucases, starting by congratulating on my eldest daughter's upcoming wedding. I will not test your patience by reading what he said on that matter. Here's what he said about you. "After thus presenting the sincere congratulations of Mrs. Collins and myself on this happy event, let me add a brief word on another matter we learned from the same source. Your daughter Elizabeth, it is said, will not bear the Bennet name for long after her sister leaves; her chosen life partner also deserves to be admired as one of the most magnificent personalities in this land." "I suppose you can guess whom I mean, can't you, Lizzy?" "This young gentleman is specially blessed with everything mortal hearts might desire – a dazzling fortune, noble blood, and generous patronage. Yet despite all this charm, I must warn my cousin Elizabeth and yourself about the troubles you might face due to the sudden cancellation of this gentleman's proposals, which you would naturally wish to accept immediately." "Do you have any idea who this gentleman is, Lizzy? But it is coming to light." "The reason I am warning you is this. We have reasons to believe that his aunt, Lady Catherine de Bourgh, does not look favorably upon the marriage." "Mr. Darcy, yes, our man is him! Now I must have surprised you, Lizzy. Could Mr. Collins or the Lucases find another man among our acquaintances whose name would make their lies so obvious? Mr. Darcy, a man who looks at women only to find faults, and who probably has never even looked at you in his life! They are magnificent, indeed!"
es: ––As expected, something very timely. He begins with congratulations on the upcoming wedding of my eldest daughter, of which he seems to have been informed by one of the kind and talkative Lucases. I won't bore you by reading what he says about that point. What concerns you is the following: After having congratulated you on behalf of Mrs. Collins and myself for such a fortunate event, allow me to add a brief warning about another matter, of which we have been informed through the same channel. It is assumed that your daughter Elizabeth will not bear the name Bennet for much longer once her elder sister has left it, and that the partner she has been fortunate enough to secure can reasonably be considered one of our most illustrious personalities. ––Can you guess, Lizzy, what this means? That young man possesses everything one could desire in this world: superb properties, a distinguished family, and an extensive patronage. But despite all those temptations, allow me to warn my cousin Elizabeth and yourself of the dangers you may face with a hasty acceptance of the proposals of such a gentleman, which, naturally, you might be inclined to consider advantageous. ––Do you have no idea who the gentleman is, Elizabeth? He's coming now. The reasons I have for informing you are as follows: your aunt, Lady Catherine de Bourgh, does not look favorably upon this marriage. ––As you see, the gentleman in question is Mr. Darcy. I believe, Elizabeth, that you must be stunned. Neither Collins nor the Lucases could have chosen a name from our circle of friends that better reveals that what they are spreading is a falsehood. Mr. Darcy, who only looks at a woman to criticize her, and who probably has never looked at you in his life! It's phenomenal!

en: Elizabeth tried to join in her father’s pleasantry, but could only force one most reluctant smile. Never had his wit been directed in a manner so little agreeable to her.
vi: Elizabeth wanted to chime in with her father's joke, but could only manage a forced smile. Never before had his manner of joking become so unpleasant to her as it was now. He asked:
tr: Elizabeth wanted to join in her father's amusement, but she could only manage a very joyless smile. Her father's sarcasm had never seemed so unpleasant to her.
es: Elizabeth tried to joke with her father, but her effort resulted in nothing more than a very timid smile. Her father's mood had never taken a more unpleasant turn for her.

en: “Are you not diverted?”
vi: - Are you distracted?
tr: "Didn't you have fun?"
es: ––Didn't it amuse you?

en: “Oh, yes. Pray read on.”
vi: - Ah, yes. Please continue reading, Dad.
tr: "Ah yes. Please continue."
es: ––Of course! Keep reading.

en: “‘After mentioning the likelihood of this marriage to her Ladyship last night, she immediately, with her usual condescension, expressed what she felt on the occasion; when it became apparent, that, on the score of some family objections on the part of my cousin, she would never give her consent to what she termed so disgraceful a match. I thought it my duty to give the speediest intelligence of this to my cousin, that she and her noble admirer may be aware of what they are about, and not run hastily into a marriage which has not been properly sanctioned.’ Mr. Collins, moreover, adds, ‘I am truly rejoiced that my cousin Lydia’s sad business has been so well hushed up, and am only concerned that their living together before the marriage took place should be so generally known. I must not, however, neglect the duties of my station, or refrain from declaring my amazement, at hearing that you received the young couple into your house as soon as they were married. It was an encouragement of vice; and had I been the rector of Longbourn, I should very strenuously have opposed it. You ought certainly to forgive them as a Christian, but never to admit them in your sight, or allow their names to be mentioned in your hearing.’ That is his notion of Christian forgiveness! The rest of his letter is only about his dear Charlotte’s situation, and his expectation of a young olive-branch. But, Lizzy, you look as if you did not enjoy it. You are not going to be missish, I hope, and pretend to be affronted at an idle report. For what do we live, but to make sport for our neighbours, and laugh at them in our turn?”
vi: - "Last night, after mentioning the possibility of this wedding, she immediately humbled herself as usual to give her opinion, when it was obvious that, due to much opposition related to my cousin, she would never accept what she called a disgraceful marriage. I think I have a duty to quickly inform my cousin of this news, so that she and her noble suitor are aware of the situation and do not hastily proceed with the marriage without proper consent." He paused and then continued: - Mr. Collins continued writing like this: "I am truly delighted to see that Miss Lydia's unfortunate affair has been adequately covered up. I am only concerned that people will know they lived together before the wedding ceremony. However, I should not forget my duties in my position, and I do not want to restrain my expression of surprise upon hearing that you welcomed the two into your home immediately after they were married. This is an attitude that encourages sin, and if I were the clergyman in charge of the Longbourn parish, I would actively prevent this. As a Christian, you should certainly forgive, but you should never allow them to come near, nor permit others to mention their names to you." That is his view on the magnanimity of a Christian! The rest of the letter only talks about the situation of his dear Charlotte and his wish for an olive branch. But, Lizzy, it seems you are not happy. I hope you will not become a lady and pretend to be insulted by such trivial news. For what do we live, if not to endure our neighbors, and laugh with them in turn?
tr: "After informing her ladyship of this marriage possibility last night, she immediately, as usual, condescended to express her feelings on the matter; it became clear that she would never consent to what she called a disgraceful union due to some objections related to my cousin's family. I considered it my duty to immediately inform my cousin of this, so that he and his noble admirer would know what they were up against, and not rush into a marriage that had not been properly sanctioned. Mr. Collins then adds, "I was genuinely very pleased that my cousin Lydia's unfortunate affair had been so well resolved; my only concern is that it is widely known they lived together before the marriage. However, I will not neglect my professional duties and will not refrain from expressing how surprised I was to hear that you accepted the young couple into your home as soon as the marriage was solemnized. You have rewarded immorality; if I were the vicar of Longbourn, I would have strongly opposed this. Of course, you must forgive them as a Christian, but you should never look them in the face again, nor allow their names to be mentioned." This is his definition of Christian tolerance! The rest of his letter is about his dear Charlotte's condition; she is expecting a child. But Lizzy, you seem displeased. I hope you are not offended; do not pretend to be upset by a silly letter. Because why do we live? To amuse ourselves with our neighbors, and to laugh at them when it is our turn."
es: When last night I mentioned to His Lordship the possibility of that marriage, with his usual condescension he expressed his opinion on the matter. If it were true, Lady Catherine would never give her consent to what she considers a most imprudent union due to certain objections to my cousin's family. I felt it my duty to communicate this as soon as possible to my cousin, so that she and her noble admirer know what is happening and do not rush into a marriage that has not been duly authorized. And Mr. Collins, moreover, added: I sincerely rejoice that the matter of your daughter Lydia has been resolved so well, and I only regret that the news spread that they were living together before the marriage had taken place. I cannot forget what I owe to my position by refraining from expressing my astonishment upon learning that you received the young couple when they were married. That was encouraging vice; and if I had been the rector of Longbourn, I would have resolutely opposed it. It is true that you must forgive them as a Christian, but not admit them into your presence nor allow their names to be mentioned before you. ––This is his concept of Christian forgiveness! The rest of the letter refers only to the state of his dear Charlotte, and his hope of having an offspring. But, Elizabeth, it seems that you have not been amused. I suppose you wouldn't get angry and take offense at this foolishness. What do we live for if not to entertain our neighbors and laugh at them in turn?

en: “Oh,” cried Elizabeth, “I am exceedingly diverted. But it is so strange!”
vi: Elizabeth exclaimed: - Oh! I have been overly distracted. These things are really strange. - Right.
tr: "Yo," shouted Elizabeth, "I had a great time. But it's very strange."
es: ––Yes, I had a lot of fun ––exclaimed Elizabeth––. But it is so strange!

en: “Yes, that is what makes it amusing. Had they fixed on any other man it would have been nothing; but his perfect indifference and your pointed dislike make it so delightfully absurd! Much as I abominate writing, I would not give up Mr. Collins’s correspondence for any consideration. Nay, when I read a letter of his, I cannot help giving him the preference even over Wickham, much as I value the impudence and hypocrisy of my son-in-law. And pray, Lizzy, what said Lady Catherine about this report? Did she call to refuse her consent?”
vi: The interesting thing is right there. If they were talking about any other young man, it wouldn't matter at all; but while he is completely indifferent and she bitterly hates him, the matter has become amusingly absurd! Although I don't like writing, I wouldn't ignore Mr. Collins's letter for any reason. No, when I read his letter, I couldn't help but like him more than Wickham, considering how I judge the brazen and hypocritical character of my son-in-law. Lizzy, tell me what Lady Catherine said about this? Did she come here to object?
tr: "Yes, –that's why it's fun anyway. If they had chosen another man, it wouldn't have been effective; but his absolute indifference and your obvious hatred make the matter wonderfully absurd! I don't enjoy writing at all, but I wouldn't give up Mr. Collins' letters for any reason. In fact, when I read his letters, I can't help but find him more valuable than Wickham, even though I quite admire my son-in-law's baseness and deceitfulness. But please tell me, Lizzy, what did Lady Catherine say about this news? Did she come to withhold her consent?"
es: ––Well, that's what makes it funnier. If they had thought of another man, it wouldn't be anything special; but Darcy's absolute indifference and the deep grudge you hold against him is what makes the joke. As much as it bothers me to write, I cannot do without Collins' correspondence. The truth is that when I read one of his letters, he seems superior to Wickham, despite the fact that I consider my son-in-law the epitome of shamelessness and hypocrisy. And tell me, Eliza, how did Lady Catherine take it? Did she come to deny you her consent?

en: To this question his daughter replied only with a laugh; and as it had been asked without the least suspicion, she was not distressed by his repeating it. Elizabeth had never been more at a loss to make her feelings appear what they were not. It was necessary to laugh when she would rather have cried. Her father had most cruelly mortified her by what he said of Mr. Darcy’s indifference; and she could do nothing but wonder at such a want of penetration, or fear that, perhaps, instead of his seeing too little, she might have fancied too much.
vi: The daughter only responded to the question with a laugh, because he asked without any suspicion, she did not feel uncomfortable when he repeated the question. Elizabeth had never been so flustered to create an appearance contrary to her feelings. She needed to laugh out loud, when she actually wanted to cry. Her father almost made her faint when he mentioned Mr. Darcy's indifference, and she only wondered why he did not investigate further. Or perhaps she also feared that instead of him knowing too little, she might have been too delusional.
tr: Elizabeth answered this question with nothing but a laugh; she was not bothered by her father's repetition since the question had been asked without any doubt. She had never struggled so much to show her feelings differently before. She had to laugh, even though she preferred to cry. Her father had cruelly upset her with what he said about Mr. Darcy's indifference; faced with such a lack of understanding, she could do nothing but be surprised or perhaps fear the possibility that she was imagining too much rather than her father seeing too little.
es: To this question, Elizabeth responded with a laugh, and since her father had asked it without the slightest suspicion, she didn't mind ––that he repeated it. Elizabeth had never found herself in a situation where she had to pretend that her feelings were something they were not in reality. But now she had to laugh when she would have rather cried. Her father had cruelly hurt her by saying that about Darcy's indifference, and she couldn't help but marvel at her father's lack of intuition, or fear that instead of him having seen too little, she had seen too much.

en: CHAPTER LVIII.
vi: Chapter 58
tr: Chapter XVI
es: CHAPTER LVIII

en: INSTEAD of receiving any such letter of excuse from his friend, as Elizabeth half expected Mr. Bingley to do, he was able to bring Darcy with him to Longbourn before many days had passed after Lady Catherine’s visit. The gentlemen arrived early; and, before Mrs. Bennet had time to tell him of their having seen his aunt, of which her daughter sat in momentary dread, Bingley, who wanted to be alone with Jane, proposed their all walking out. It was agreed to. Mrs. Bennet was not in the habit of walking, Mary could never spare time, but the remaining five set off together. Bingley and Jane, however, soon allowed the others to outstrip them. They lagged behind, while Elizabeth, Kitty, and Darcy were to entertain each other. Very little was said by either; Kitty was too much afraid of him to talk; Elizabeth was secretly forming a desperate resolution; and, perhaps, he might be doing the same.
vi: Instead of bringing a letter from his friend explaining why he couldn't return, as Elizabeth had half-believed, Bingley brought Darcy to Longbourn a few days after Lady Catherine's visit. The two arrived early, and before Mrs. Bennet had time to recount their meeting with his aunt, while her daughter sat in stunned silence, Bingley suggested a walk because he wanted some privacy with Jane. Everyone agreed. Mrs. Bennet was not in the habit of walking, and Mary had no time, but the remaining five set off together. However, it wasn't long before Bingley and Jane let the others go ahead. The two slowed down at the back, allowing Elizabeth, Darcy, and Kitty to converse with each other. No one said much; Kitty was too shy to ask him anything, Elizabeth was silently preparing for a purpose, and perhaps Darcy was too.
tr: As Elizabeth more or less expected, instead of receiving an apology letter from his friend, Bingley brought Darcy to Longbourn a few days after Lady Catherine's visit. The gentlemen arrived early; under the fearful gaze of her daughter, Mrs. Bennet was about to tell Mr. Darcy that they had seen his aunt, but she didn't get the chance because Bingley, wanting to be alone with Jane, suggested they all go for a walk. The suggestion was accepted. Mrs. Bennet was not in the habit of walking, and Mary did not have the time, but the other five went out. Bingley and Jane allowed the others to pass them. The two of them lagged behind; Elizabeth, Kitty, and Darcy were to entertain each other. Neither of them spoke much; Kitty was too frightened of Darcy to speak; Elizabeth was inwardly reaching a hopeless conclusion, and perhaps Darcy was doing the same.
es: A few days after Lady Catherine's visit, Bingley not only did not receive any letter of excuse from his friend, but he also brought him to Longbourn in person. The gentlemen arrived early, and before Mrs. Bennet had time to tell Darcy that his aunt had come to visit them, which Elizabeth feared for a moment, Bingley, who wanted to be alone with Jane, proposed that they all go for a walk. It was agreed upon, but Mrs. Bennet was not in the habit of walking and Mary could not afford to waste time. So the remaining five went out. Bingley and Jane soon let the others go ahead and stayed behind. Elizabeth, Darcy, and Catherine walked together, but spoke very little. Catherine was too afraid of Darcy to chat; Elizabeth was making a desperate decision in her mind, and perhaps Darcy was doing the same.

en: They walked towards the Lucases’, because Kitty wished to call upon Maria; and as Elizabeth saw no occasion for making it a general concern, when Kitty left them she went boldly on with him alone. Now was the moment for her resolution to be executed; and while her courage was high, she immediately said,—
vi: They went to Lucas's house because Kitty wanted to visit Maria, and because Elizabeth thought there was nothing to fear when Kitty wasn't with her, she boldly walked beside him alone. Now was the time for her to carry out her intention, and while she still had enough courage, she immediately began:
tr: They walked towards the Lucases'; Kitty had wanted to visit Maria; without feeling the need to worry, Elizabeth continued to walk bravely alone with Darcy when Kitty left them. Now it was time to implement her decision, and while she still had her courage, she immediately said,
es: They headed towards the Lucas' house because Catherine wanted to see Maria, and since Elizabeth thought this might interest her, when Catherine left them, she boldly continued walking alone with Darcy. Then the moment came to put her decision into practice, and summoning her courage, she immediately said:

en: “Mr. Darcy, I am a very selfish creature, and for the sake of giving relief to my own feelings care not how much I may be wounding yours. I can no longer help thanking you for your unexampled kindness to my poor sister. Ever since I have known it I have been most anxious to acknowledge to you how gratefully I feel it. Were it known to the rest of my family I should not have merely my own gratitude to express.”
vi: - Mr. Darcy, I am a very selfish person, and while I tried to ease my own mind, I did not consider how I might hurt yours. I can no longer avoid thanking you for the unparalleled kindness you have shown to my wretched sister. Since I learned of this, I have been anxiously seeking a way to express to you how deeply grateful I am. If the rest of my family knew, I would not be speaking only of my own gratitude.
tr: "Mr. Darcy, I am a very selfish creature; I do not care how much I trouble you in order to ease my own feelings. I can no longer restrain myself; thank you for the unparalleled kindness you have shown to my poor sister. Since I learned of it, I have been eager to tell you how grateful I feel. If the other members of my family knew, I would not only express my own gratitude."
es: ––Mr. Darcy, I am a very selfish creature who cares only for my own feelings, without thinking that I might hurt yours. But I can no longer go on without thanking you for your unparalleled kindness towards my poor sister. Since I found out, I have been longing to express my gratitude to you. If my family knew, they would have done so as well.

en: “I am sorry, exceedingly sorry,” replied Darcy, in a tone of surprise and emotion, “that you have ever been informed of what may, in a mistaken light, have given you uneasiness. I did not think Mrs. Gardiner was so little to be trusted.”
vi: Darcy replied, surprised and moved: - I regret, deeply regret, that you have been informed about the matter, which in a way could be misunderstood, causing you to feel uneasy. I had thought I could trust Mrs. Gardiner to keep the matter confidential.
tr: "I'm sorry, extremely sorry," answered Darcy, with a voice full of astonishment and excitement, "I wouldn't have wanted you to learn something that might disturb you from a faulty perspective. I didn't think Mrs. Gardiner was so unreliable."
es: ––I am very sorry ––replied Darcy in a tone of surprise and emotion–– that you have been informed of something that, if misinterpreted, could have caused you some unease. I did not think Mrs. Gardiner would be so indiscreet.

en: “You must not blame my aunt. Lydia’s thoughtlessness first betrayed to me that you had been concerned in the matter; and, of course, I could not rest till I knew the particulars. Let me thank you again and again, in the name of all my family, for that generous compassion which induced you to take so much trouble, and bear so many mortifications, for the sake of discovering them.”
vi: - You should not blame my aunt. Lydia carelessly revealed to me that you were involved in this matter, and of course, I could not be at ease without knowing the details. On behalf of the entire family, I want to thank you, and thank you again, for the generous sentiment that made you go through such efforts and endure so much hardship to find the two people.
tr: "You must not blame my sister-in-law. It was Lydia's carelessness that first made me think you were involved in the matter; then, of course, I couldn't rest until I learned the details. On behalf of my entire family, I thank you again and again for your generous sacrifice, which caused you to go through so much trouble and endure so much hardship to find them."
es: ––Don't blame my aunt. Lydia's indiscretion was the first thing that revealed to me her involvement in the matter; and, naturally, I did not rest until I knew all the details. Let me thank you a thousand times, on behalf of my entire family, for the generous interest that led you to take so much trouble and endure so many mortifications to find the whereabouts of the two.

en: “If you will thank me,” he replied, “let it be for yourself alone. That the wish of giving happiness to you might add force to the other inducements which led me on, I shall not attempt to deny. But your family owe me nothing. Much as I respect them, I believe I thought only of you.”
vi: - If you want to thank me, your thanks alone are enough. I do not want to hide the fact that my desire to bring you happiness was an additional motivation among other reasons that compelled me to do it. But your family owes me nothing. While I still respect them, I only think of you.
tr: "If you are to thank me," replied Darcy, "let it be for your sake alone. I will not attempt to deny that other motives were added to the wish of pleasing you. But your family owes me nothing. Though I respect them, I thought only of you."
es: ––If you wish to thank me ––replied Darcy––, do so only in your own name. I will not deny that the desire to ease your mind was added to the other reasons that drove me to do what I did; but your family owes me nothing. I have great respect for them, but I thought only of you.

en: Elizabeth was too much embarrassed to say a word. After a short pause, her companion added, “You are too generous to trifle with me. If your feelings are still what they were last April, tell me so at once. My affections and wishes are unchanged; but one word from you will silence me on this subject for ever.”
vi: Elizabeth was too embarrassed to say a word. After a moment of silence, he added: - You have an open-hearted disposition, so I trust you won't make fun of me. If your feelings are still the same as they were last April, just let me know right away. My feelings and wishes remain unchanged, but just one word from you and I will never bring this up again.
tr: Elizabeth was too embarrassed to say a single word. After a short silence, her companion continued, "You are too kind to play games with me. If your feelings are still the same as they were last April, tell me so at once. My feelings and wishes have not changed, but a single word from you will silence me on this matter forever."
es: Elizabeth was so confused that she couldn't speak. After a short pause, her companion added: "You are too generous to mock me." If your feelings are still the same as last April, tell me at once. My affection and desires have not changed, but with a single word from you, I will not insist any further.

en: Elizabeth, feeling all the more than common awkwardness and anxiety of his situation, now forced herself to speak; and immediately, though not very fluently, gave him to understand that her sentiments had undergone so material a change since the period to which he alluded, as to make her receive with gratitude and pleasure his present assurances. The happiness which this reply produced was such as he had probably never felt before; and he expressed himself on the occasion as sensibly and as warmly as a man violently in love can be supposed to do. Had Elizabeth been able to encounter his eyes, she might have seen how well the expression of heartfelt delight diffused over his face became him: but though she could not look she could listen; and he told her of feelings which, in proving of what importance she was to him, made his affection every moment more valuable.
vi: The feelings in Elizabeth's mind had surpassed the usual awkwardness and worry for his situation. She felt compelled to confess. Though not very fluent, she immediately told him that her feelings had significantly changed from the moment he mentioned, so now she accepted his assertions with all respect and joy. Her answer created in him an immense happiness that he might never have felt in his life. He expressed to her the most sensitive and warm feelings that a person with intense love could articulate. If Elizabeth could look directly into his eyes, she could see the overflowing joy in his heart, spreading across his face, transforming his entire being. But although she couldn't see, she could hear, and he wanted her to understand how important a position she held in his heart. He revealed the thoughts that made his love grow stronger each moment.
tr: Feeling the unusual strangeness and anxiety in Darcy's demeanor, Elizabeth forced herself to speak; and immediately, though not very fluently, she made him understand that her feelings had undergone a great change since the time he mentioned, and that she accepted his recent words with gratitude and joy. The happiness created by this response was of a kind that Darcy had probably never felt before; he expressed himself sincerely and warmly, as might be expected from a man deeply in love. If Elizabeth had dared to look into his eyes, she could have seen how the expression of heartfelt joy spread across his face and how well it suited him; but, even though she couldn't look, she could listen, and while Darcy proved how important she was to him, he spoke of the feelings that made his love more precious with each passing moment.
es: Elizabeth, feeling clumsier and more distressed than ever in Darcy's presence, made an effort to speak immediately, though not quickly, and conveyed to him that her feelings had undergone such an absolute change since the time he referred to, that she now received his proposals with pleasure and gratitude. The happiness that this response brought to Darcy was the greatest of his life, and he expressed it with all the warmth and tenderness that can be expected from a man madly in love. If Elizabeth had been able to look him in the eyes, she would have seen how well the delight that flooded his heart was reflected in them; but she could listen to him, and the feelings that Darcy confessed to her, which demonstrated the importance she had for him, made her affection increasingly valuable.

en: They walked on without knowing in what direction. There was too much to be thought, and felt, and said, for attention to any other objects. She soon learnt that they were indebted for their present good understanding to the efforts of his aunt, who did call on him in her return through London, and there relate her journey to Longbourn, its motive, and the substance of her conversation with Elizabeth; dwelling emphatically on every expression of the latter, which, in her Ladyship’s apprehension, peculiarly denoted her perverseness and assurance, in the belief that such a relation must assist her endeavours to obtain that promise from her nephew which she had refused to give. But, unluckily for her Ladyship, its effect had been exactly contrariwise.
vi: The two continued walking without realizing which direction they were heading. There were too many things to ponder, to feel, to express. Now she knew that they owed his aunt for the mutual understanding between them at present. After returning, she had gone to see him, telling him about her trip to Longbourn, about her motives, and about the conversation between her and Elizabeth. Out of anxiety, she emphasized Elizabeth's stubborn and resolute attitude, believing that by doing so she would hear him promise what she had refused to promise. But, unfortunately for the Lady, the result was completely contrary to her wishes.
tr: They kept walking, not knowing which direction they were going. There were so many things to think about, to feel, to say that they couldn't pay attention to anything else. Elizabeth soon learned that they owed their current understanding to her aunt's efforts; her ladyship had visited while returning via London, where she had recounted her journey to Longbourn, her purpose, and the subject of her conversation with Elizabeth; her ladyship had insisted on every expression that, in her opinion, clearly demonstrated Elizabeth's perversity and impudence, thinking that such a complaint would help in her effort to obtain the promise that Elizabeth had refused to give. But, contrary to her ladyship's expectations, these had the opposite effect.
es: They continued walking without worrying about the direction they were taking. They had too much to think about, to feel, and to say to pay attention to anything else. Elizabeth immediately knew that they owed their closeness to Darcy's aunt's efforts, who visited him in London upon his return and told him about her trip to Longbourn, the motives behind it, and the substance of her conversation with the young woman, emphatically highlighting the expressions that, in Her Ladyship's opinion, denoted Elizabeth's perversity and brazenness, confident that this account would help her in her endeavor to extract from her nephew the promise that Elizabeth had refused to give her. But unfortunately for Her Ladyship, the effect was counterproductive.

en: “It taught me to hope,” said he, “as I had scarcely ever allowed myself to hope before. I knew enough of your disposition to be certain, that had you been absolutely, irrevocably decided against me, you would have acknowledged it to Lady Catherine frankly and openly.”
vi: He said: - This has given you hope that you previously did not dare to allow yourself to hope for much. You have known your feelings well enough to be sure that if you were determined not to accept his love, you would have said so frankly and clearly to Lady Catherine.
tr: "This taught me to hope," said Darcy; "I had not allowed myself to hope before. If you had been absolutely, irrevocably determined against me, I knew you well enough to be certain that you would have told Lady Catherine so openly and sincerely."
es: ––Thanks to that, I conceived hopes that I would hardly have dared to formulate before. I knew your character well enough to know that if you had been absolutely and irrevocably decided against me, you would have told Lady Catherine with complete clarity and frankness.

en: Elizabeth coloured and laughed as she replied, “Yes, you know enough of my frankness to believe me capable of that. After abusing you so abominably to your face, I could have no scruple in abusing you to all your relations.”
vi: Elizabeth blushed and laughed: - That's right, I know quite well how straightforward you are, so I believe you could say something like that. After having disgustingly insulted me to my face, you could unhesitatingly insult me in front of my loved ones.
tr: Elizabeth blushed; she laughed while replying, "Yes, you know my frankness well enough to believe that I could do this. After speaking so ill of you to your face, I would not hesitate to speak ill of you to your relatives."
es: Elizabeth blushed and laughed, replying: ––Yes, you knew my frankness well enough to believe me capable of that. After having rejected you so odiously to your face, I could have no qualms about saying the same to all your relatives.

en: “What did you say of me that I did not deserve? For though your accusations were ill-founded, formed on mistaken premises, my behaviour to you at the time had merited the severest reproof. It was unpardonable. I cannot think of it without abhorrence.”
vi: - How did you talk about me? Did you say I was undeserving? Because, although your accusations are unfounded and based on mistaken premises, my attitude towards you before was indeed deserving of the harshest criticism. It was unforgivable. I cannot think about my past behavior without feeling disgusted.
tr: "What did you say to me that I didn't deserve? Your accusations were baseless, built on faulty assumptions, but my behavior towards you at that time deserved the harshest condemnation. It was unforgivable. I can't remember it without feeling ashamed."
es: ––He didn't tell me anything I didn't deserve. His accusations were unfounded, but my conduct towards you deserved the most severe reproach. That was unforgivable; it horrifies me to think about it.

en: “We will not quarrel for the greater share of blame annexed to that evening,” said Elizabeth. “The conduct of neither, if strictly examined, will be irreproachable; but since then we have both, I hope, improved in civility.”
vi: Elizabeth said: - We should not argue about who was more to blame that evening. If we consider it strictly, each person's behavior was reprehensible, but since then, both of us have become more courteous - I hope so.
tr: "Let's not argue about who was more at fault that evening," said Elizabeth. "Neither of our behaviors was entirely blameless, if we think about it carefully; but since then, I hope, we have both made progress in terms of politeness."
es: ––We are not going to argue about who was worse that afternoon ––said Elizabeth––. Looking at it closely, we both had our faults. But it seems to me that we have both gained in courtesy since then.

en: “I cannot be so easily reconciled to myself. The recollection of what I then said, of my conduct, my manners, my expressions during the whole of it, is now, and has been many months, inexpressibly painful to me. Your reproof, so well applied, I shall never forget: ‘Had you behaved in a more gentlemanlike manner.’ Those were your words. You know not, you can scarcely conceive, how they have tortured me; though it was some time, I confess, before I was reasonable enough to allow their justice.”
vi: - I cannot easily be at ease about myself. For many months, even until now, whenever I think about what I said, my behavior, my attitude, my expressions throughout the incident, somehow I always feel pain. Your reproach was truly justified, I can never forget "if you had the manners of a gentleman." These are your words. You don't know, you can't understand, how these words have tormented me, though I must admit that it took some time for me to realize you were right.
tr: "I can't make peace with myself that easily. Recalling my words, actions, attitudes, and expressions from back then, which was months ago, gives me indescribable pain. I will never forget the very proper scolding I received from you: ‘if only you had behaved more gentlemanly.' Those were your words. You have no idea how they tortured me, you can't even imagine; –still, I admit, it took me some time to accept that they were right."
es: ––I cannot reconcile with myself so easily. The memory of what I said and did on that occasion is and will be very painful for me for a long time. I cannot forget her very accurate phrase: «If you had behaved more gentlemanly.» Those were her words. You don't know, you can't imagine how much they have tortured me, although I confess that it took me a while to be reasonable enough to recognize the truth they contained.

en: “I was certainly very far from expecting them to make so strong an impression. I had not the smallest idea of their being ever felt in such a way.”
vi: - I never thought my words would make such a strong impression. I completely didn't think you felt that way.
tr: "I really didn't expect them to have such a strong impact. It never even crossed my mind that you would feel that way."
es: ––Believe me, I was far from imagining that they could cause such a bad impression on you. I had no idea that they would distress you in that way.

en: “I can easily believe it. You thought me then devoid of every proper feeling, I am sure you did. The turn of your countenance I shall never forget, as you said that I could not have addressed you in any possible way that would induce you to accept me.”
vi: - You can easily trust me. At that time, I thought you weren't sensitive at all. You surely thought I felt that way. I'll never forget the look on your face when you said I couldn't confess my feelings to you in any other way to make you accept.
tr: "I believe this. At that time, you thought I was emotionless, I'm sure. I will never forget the look on your face when you said it was impossible for you to accept me even if I made my offer in a different way."
es: ––I don't doubt it. Then you assumed I was devoid of any elevated feelings, I'm sure. I will also never forget your expression when you told me that no matter how I had approached you, you would not have accepted me.

en: “Oh, do not repeat what I then said. These recollections will not do at all. I assure you that I have long been most heartily ashamed of it.”
vi: - Please don't bring up what I said back then. There is no use in remembering it forever. I hope you understand that I have long felt truly ashamed of my words.
tr: "Ah, then don't repeat what I said. Remembering these won't be of any use. Believe me, I've been ashamed of them for a long time too."
es: ––Do not repeat all my words from that day. We must erase that memory. I swear to you that I have been sincerely ashamed of that for a long time.

en: Darcy mentioned his letter. “Did it,” said he,—“did it soon make you think better of me? Did you, on reading it, give any credit to its contents?”
vi: Darcy talks about his letter. He asks: - Will my letter make you think better of me not long after? After reading it, do you believe what I wrote?
tr: Darcy mentioned his letter. "The letter," he said, "did it have a quick effect on you thinking better of me? Did you find the things described there believable when you read it?"
es: Darcy spoke to her about his letter: ––Did it make you change your opinion about me? Did you believe its content?

en: She explained what its effects on her had been, and how gradually all her former prejudices had been removed.
vi: She explained to him the effects that the letter had created in her mind, and how all her initial prejudices were gradually erased.
tr: Elizabeth explained the effect of the letter and how her old prejudices gradually faded away.
es: She explained to him the effect it had had on her and how her previous prejudices had gradually disappeared.

en: “I knew,” said he, “that what I wrote must give you pain, but it was necessary. I hope you have destroyed the letter. There was one part, especially the opening of it, which I should dread your having the power of reading again. I can remember some expressions which might justly make you hate me.”
vi: He said: - I know that what I write will cause you pain, but it is necessary to write it. I hope you have destroyed the letter. There is one part in particular, the beginning, that if you read again will terrify me. I can remember a few words in the letter that might make you rightfully hate me.
tr: "I knew," he said, "what I wrote would cause you pain, but it was necessary. I hope you have destroyed the letter. There was one part in particular, the introduction, that I would be horrified if you had the chance to read again. I recall some expressions that might justifiably cause you to hate me."
es: ––I already knew ––continued Darcy–– that what I wrote had to sadden you, but it was necessary. I suppose you have destroyed the letter. There was a part, especially at the beginning, that I would not want you to read again. I remember certain expressions that could make you hate me.

en: “The letter shall certainly be burnt, if you believe it essential to the preservation of my regard; but, though we have both reason to think my opinions not entirely unalterable, they are not, I hope, quite so easily changed as that implies.”
vi: - I will burn the letter if you believe this will preserve my feelings for you. However, although we both have reasons to believe that my sentiments are not entirely steadfast, I hope they are not easily changeable.
tr: "The letter will certainly be burned, if you deem it necessary for the preservation of my admiration; but, although we both have reasons to think that my views are not entirely unchangeable, I hope they do not change as easily as this statement claims.""
es: ––We will burn the letter if you believe it is necessary to preserve my affection, but although we both have reasons to think that my opinions are not entirely unchangeable, they do not change as easily as you suppose.

en: “When I wrote that letter,” replied Darcy, “I believed myself perfectly calm and cool; but I am since convinced that it was written in a dreadful bitterness of spirit.”
vi: Mr. Darcy replied: - When you wrote that letter, you believed you were completely calm and gentle, but then you realized that at that time you still harbored a terrible bitterness.
tr: "When I wrote that letter," replied Darcy, "I believed I was extremely calm and composed, but since then I think it was written in a feeling of terrible rebellion."
es: ––When I wrote that letter ––Darcy replied, I believed myself to be perfectly calm and composed; but later I realized that I had written it in a state of tremendous bitterness.

en: “The letter, perhaps, began in bitterness, but it did not end so. The adieu is charity itself. But think no more of the letter. The feelings of the person who wrote and the person who received it are now so widely different from what they were then, that every unpleasant circumstance attending it ought to be forgotten. You must learn some of my philosophy. Think only of the past as its remembrance gives you pleasure.”
vi: - Perhaps the letter began in bitterness, but the ending was not like that. The concluding sentence itself speaks of virtue. But we should not think about the letter anymore. The feelings of the writer and the recipient are now vastly different from back then, so it is necessary to forget all the unpleasant circumstances that created those feelings. You should follow my philosophy of life. Only think about the past if there is joy in remembering it.
tr: "The letter may have started with rebellion, but it didn't end that way. Your farewell itself was the epitome of magnanimity. But let's not think about the letter anymore. The feelings of the writer and the recipient are now so different from back then that all the unpleasant events associated with it need to be forgotten. You should learn a bit of my philosophy. Think only of as much of the past as you enjoy remembering."
es: ––It may have started with bitterness, but it didn't end the same way. The farewell was very affectionate. But don't think about the letter anymore. The feelings of the person who wrote it and those of the person who received it are now so different that all the unpleasant circumstances related to it should be forgotten. You must learn my philosophy. From the past, you only need to remember what was pleasant.

en: “I cannot give you credit for any philosophy of the kind. Your retrospections must be so totally void of reproach, that the contentment arising from them is not of philosophy, but, what is much better, of ignorance. But with me, it is not so. Painful recollections will intrude, which cannot, which ought not to be repelled. I have been a selfish being all my life, in practice, though not in principle. As a child I was taught what was right, but I was not taught to correct my temper. I was given good principles, but left to follow them in pride and conceit. Unfortunately an only son (for many years an only child), I was spoiled by my parents, who, though good themselves, (my father particularly, all that was benevolent and amiable,) allowed, encouraged, almost taught me to be selfish and overbearing, to care for none beyond my own family circle, to think meanly of all the rest of the world, to wish at least to think meanly of their sense and worth compared with my own. Such I was, from eight to eight-and-twenty; and such I might still have been but for you, dearest, loveliest Elizabeth! What do I not owe you! You taught me a lesson, hard indeed at first, but most advantageous. By you, I was properly humbled. I came to you without a doubt of my reception. You showed me how insufficient were all my pretensions to please a woman worthy of being pleased.”
vi: - You cannot judge me philosophically like that. When I recall what happened, I have no intention of blaming, and I think your satisfaction here is not due to philosophy, but rather because you are carefree. But for me, it is not like that. Painful memories still intrude, which I cannot and should not dismiss. All my life I have been selfish, in attitude rather than in principle. As a child, I was taught to know what was right, but I was not taught how to control my temper. I learned about principles, but I was left to pursue those principles in pride and arrogance. Unfortunately for me, being the only son, I was spoiled by my parents to the point of becoming spoiled. My parents, although very good people themselves, allowed, encouraged, and almost trained me to become selfish and self-important, caring for no one outside my own family, looking down on the rest of the world or at least wanting to disdain their perceptions and true values compared to my own. I was like that, from eight to twenty-eight years old, and I would still be like that if it were not for you, my dearest Elizabeth! What do I not owe you! You taught me a lesson, initially a hard one, but the most beneficial. You properly humbled me. You showed me that all my arrogant expectations were not enough to win the heart of a truly worthy woman.
tr: "I can't believe you have such a philosophy. Your view of the past is so far from the possibility of regret that the sense of peace arising from those memories can be explained not by philosophy, but even better, by ignorance. But it's not the same for me. Painful memories always remind themselves and it is not possible, nor should it be, to forget them. Though not in my principles, in my actions I have been a selfish person all my life. As a child, I was taught what was right, but I was not taught to correct my temperament. I acquired good principles, but I was left to follow them with pride and arrogance. Unfortunately, as the only son (and for years the only child), I was spoiled by my parents; they themselves were good (especially my father, a man full of love and care), but they gave me permission, encouragement, almost education to be selfish and domineering, to not care about anyone outside my family circle, to despise the rest of humanity, or at least to want to diminish their feelings and values compared to mine. I was like this from the age of eight to twenty-eight, and I might still be, my beautiful, dear Elizabeth, if it weren't for you! I owe you so much! You gave me a lesson that was hard at first, but then very beneficial. Thanks to you, my feet are on the ground. I came to you without doubting that I would be accepted. And you taught me how insufficient all my pride was to make a woman who deserves to be happy, happy."
es: ––I cannot believe in that philosophy of yours. Your memories must be so free from any reproach that the satisfaction they bring you does not come from philosophy, but from something better: the tranquility of conscience. But with me, it is different: I am confronted by painful memories that cannot and should not be driven away. I have been a selfish person all my life in practice, though not in principles. As a child, I was taught to think well, but not to correct my temperament. I was instilled with good norms, but they allowed me to follow them laden with pride and presumption. Unfortunately, I was an only child for several years, and my parents, who were good in themselves, particularly my father, who was the personification of kindness and love, allowed me, indulged me, and almost guided me towards selfishness and authoritarianism, towards indifference to everything that was not my own family, towards disdain for the rest of the world or, at least, to believe that the intelligence and merits of others were far inferior to mine. Thus, from the age of eight to twenty-eight, and it would still be so if it were not for you, dearest Elizabeth. I owe you everything. You gave me a lesson that was, indeed, very hard at first, but also very beneficial. You humbled me as was fitting, you showed me how insufficient my pretensions were to flatter a woman who deserves all the flattery.

en: “Had you then persuaded yourself that I should?”
vi: - So at that moment, did you believe that I should show you like that?
tr: "Did you believe I would accept it then?"
es: ––Did you think I was going to accept it?

en: “Indeed I had. What will you think of my vanity? I believed you to be wishing, expecting my addresses.”
vi: - Yes, I do. What do you think about my frivolity? - My attitude was wrong, but I didn't mean it that way, I hope you believe me.
tr: "Of course. What about my pride? I believed that you wanted and were waiting for me to make an offer to you."
es: ––Of course. What do you think of my vanity? I thought you were expecting and desiring my declaration.

en: “My manners must have been in fault, but not intentionally, I assure you. I never meant to deceive you, but my spirits might often lead me wrong. How you must have hated me after that evening!”
vi: - My attitude was wrong, but I didn't mean it that way, I hope you believe me. I never wanted to deceive you, but my state of mind might have led me astray. That night, how much did you hate me?
tr: "My actions may have been wrong, but believe me, they were not intentional. I never thought of deceiving you, but my impulsiveness often leads me astray. How much you must have hated me after that evening."
es: ––I behaved badly, but it was unintentional. I never meant to deceive him, and yet many times I mistake. How she must have hated me after that afternoon!

en: “Hate you! I was angry, perhaps, at first, but my anger soon began to take a proper direction.”
vi: - Hate you?! At first, he was angry, but gradually the anger shifted in the right direction.
tr: "Hate you! Maybe I was angry at first, but my anger soon began to take the right direction."
es: ––Hate her! Maybe I was resentful at first; but the resentment soon turned into something better.

en: “I am almost afraid of asking what you thought of me when we met at Pemberley. You blamed me for coming?”
vi: - I was almost too afraid to ask what you thought of me when we met again at Pemberley. Do you blame me?
tr: "I am a little hesitant to ask what you thought of me when we met at Pemberley. Did you blame me for coming?"
es: ––I hardly dare ask you what you thought upon finding me at Pemberley. Did you think it was wrong of me to have gone?

en: “No, indeed, I felt nothing but surprise.”
vi: - Actually, I don't blame you, I'm just surprised.
tr: "No, never; I was surprised, that's all."
es: ––None of that. I was just surprised.

en: “Your surprise could not be greater than mine in being noticed by you. My conscience told me that I deserved no extraordinary politeness, and I confess that I did not expect to receive more than my due.”
vi: - Your surprise cannot compare to mine, when you paid attention to me. My conscience tells me that I am not worthy of your utmost courtesy, I must confess that I did not expect to receive more than what I deserve.
tr: "You would have seen the real surprise on me when I got caught by you. My conscience was telling me that I had no right to expect any extraordinary kindness; I confess that I was not expecting to see more than I deserved."
es: ––Your surprise would not be greater than mine upon seeing you greet me. I did not believe I had the right to your attentions and I confess that I did not expect to receive more than what I deserved.

en: “My object then,” replied Darcy, “was to show you, by every civility in my power, that I was not so mean as to resent the past; and I hoped to obtain your forgiveness, to lessen your ill opinion, by letting you see that your reproofs had been attended to. How soon any other wishes introduced themselves, I can hardly tell, but I believe in about half an hour after I had seen you.”
vi: - My intention at that time was, through courteous behavior within my ability, to show you that I wasn't so narrow-minded as to be upset about the past, and by showing that I had responded to your reproaches, I hoped you would forgive me and think less badly of me. I am not sure when other aspirations came about, but I believe it was within half an hour after I met you again.
tr: "At that time my aim," answered Darcy, "was to show you with all my might that I was not narrow-minded enough to regret the past; to earn your forgiveness, to reduce your negative thoughts, and to make you see that your scoldings were taken into account. I'm not exactly sure when other dreams emerged, but I think it was about half an hour after I saw you."
es: ––I set out ––Darcy replied–– to demonstrate to you, with my utmost courtesy, that I was not so vile as to be hurt by the past, and I hoped to earn your forgiveness and mitigate the poor opinion you had of me by proving that I had not disregarded your reproaches. It is difficult for me to tell you how long it took for these other desires to mix in, but I believe it was about half an hour after having seen you.

en: He then told her of Georgiana’s delight in her acquaintance, and of her disappointment at its sudden interruption; which naturally leading to the cause of that interruption, she soon learnt that his resolution of following her from Derbyshire in quest of her sister had been formed before he quitted the inn, and that his gravity and thoughtfulness there had arisen from no other struggles than what such a purpose must comprehend.
vi: Then he mentioned that Georgiana was pleased to make her acquaintance, expressed disappointment when she had to hastily return home, and naturally, this led to the reason for her return. Now she knew that he had resolved to find her sister even before he left her inn, she also understood that his stern and contemplative demeanor at this moment was due to an internal struggle with the sole purpose of being understood.
tr: Then, she explained how happy Georgiana was to have met him and how saddened she was by his sudden departure, which naturally led to the reason for that departure; Elizabeth soon learned that Darcy had decided to follow him from Derbyshire to find his sister before leaving the inn, and that his distracted, thoughtful demeanor there was not due to any other struggle but solely to the obstacles in the way of such a purpose.
es: Then he explained to her how delighted Georgiana had been to meet her and how much she regretted the sudden interruption of their friendship. This naturally led them to discuss the cause of said interruption, and Elizabeth learned that Darcy had decided to leave Derbyshire in search of Lydia before leaving the inn, and that his seriousness and pensive appearance were due to no other thoughts than those inherent to the aforementioned project.

en: She expressed her gratitude again, but it was too painful a subject to each to be dwelt on farther.
vi: She expressed her gratitude once more, but both of them were still pained by the incident and did not want to say anything further.
tr: He expressed his gratitude again, but it was a subject too painful to be prolonged any further for both of them.
es: Elizabeth thanked him again, but the matter was too overwhelming for both of them, and they did not pursue it further.

en: After walking several miles in a leisurely manner, and too busy to know anything about it, they found at last, on examining their watches, that it was time to be at home.
vi: After leisurely walking a few miles and with their minds unburdened by other matters so they were unaware of the distance, they finally checked the time and thought they should head back.
tr: After walking a few miles aimlessly and preoccupied to the point of not noticing anything, they finally looked at their watches and saw that it was time to go home.
es: After walking several miles in complete abandonment and too busy to care about anything else, they looked at their watches and saw that it was time to go back home.

en: “What could have become of Mr. Bingley and Jane?” was a wonder which introduced the discussion of their affairs. Darcy was delighted with their engagement; his friend had given him the earliest information of it.
vi: "I wonder how Bingley and Jane are doing now?" was the pressing question for the discussion about that love story. Darcy was pleased to see them happy, his friend had previously told him.
tr: "What will Mr. Bingley and Jane do, I wonder!" This question brought their relationship to light. Darcy was quite pleased with their engagement; his friend had informed him of it immediately.
es: ––What could have become of Bingley and Jane? This exclamation led them to talk about each other's affairs. Darcy was very happy with his engagement, which Bingley had immediately informed him about.

en: “I must ask whether you were surprised?” said Elizabeth.
vi: Elizabeth asked: - Do you want to ask if I'm surprised?
tr: "May I ask if you were surprised?" said Elizabeth.
es: ––Can I ask you if it surprised you? ––said Elizabeth.

en: “Not at all. When I went away, I felt that it would soon happen.”
vi: - He is not surprised at all. When he left, he thought this would happen soon.
tr: "Not at all. I knew you would be close when you left."
es: ––By no means. When I left, I realized that the matter was imminent.

en: “That is to say, you had given your permission. I guessed as much.” And though he exclaimed at the term, she found that it had been pretty much the case.
vi: - This means you have allowed him to move forward. I guessed so. And although he did not admit it was true, she thought it really was. He said:
tr: "So you had given permission. That's what I had assumed." Although Darcy objected to this statement, Elizabeth understood that it was more or less the case.
es: ––That is to say, you gave him your permission. I already suspected it. And although he protested such terms, she found them to be very appropriate.

en: “On the evening before my going to London,” said he, “I made a confession to him, which I believe I ought to have made long ago. I told him of all that had occurred to make my former interference in his affairs absurd and impertinent. His surprise was great. He had never had the slightest suspicion. I told him, moreover, that I believed myself mistaken in supposing, as I had done, that your sister was indifferent to him; and as I could easily perceive that his attachment to her was unabated, I felt no doubt of their happiness together.”
vi: - On the evening before he went to London, he confessed to Mr. Bingley something he should have done long ago. He told him everything about his unreasonable interference. Mr. Bingley was extremely surprised. He also explained to him that he was mistaken in thinking that your sister was indifferent to him, and since he could easily see that Mr. Bingley's feelings for her had not diminished, he was confident they would be happy together.
tr: "The night before going to London," said Darcy, "I made a confession to her, which I should have done much earlier. I told her all those events that made my previous interference in her affairs seem unnecessary and foolish. She was very surprised. She hadn't had the slightest suspicion. I also told her that I believed I was wrong in saying that your sister was indifferent to her; it was very clear that her feelings for your sister had not changed, so I had no doubt they would be happy together."
