es: ––The evening before my trip to London ––said Darcy–– I made a confession to him that I should have made long before. I told him everything that had happened to make my interference absurd and impertinent. He was left speechless. He had never suspected anything. I also told him that I had been mistaken in assuming that Jane did not love him, and when I realized that Bingley still loved her, I no longer doubted that they would be happy.

en: Elizabeth could not help smiling at his easy manner of directing his friend.
vi: Elizabeth couldn't help but smile at the ease with which he steered his friend.
tr: Elizabeth couldn't help but smile at her friend's ease in giving directions.
es: Elizabeth couldn't help but smile upon seeing how easily she managed her friend.

en: “Did you speak from your own observation,” said she, “when you told him that my sister loved him, or merely from my information last spring?”
vi: She asked: - When you told him that my sister loves him, did you say it based on your own observation, or just because of what I said earlier?
tr: "When you said that my brother loved her," he said, "did you say it based on your own observation, or based on what I told you last spring?"
es: ––When you told him that my sister loved him, was it because you had observed it or because I had confessed it to you last spring?

en: “From the former. I had narrowly observed her, during the two visits which I had lately made her here; and I was convinced of her affection.”
vi: - From your observations. You have observed her very closely, from the two times you came later, and you believe that she truly loves Mr. Bingley.
tr: "The first one. During my two recent trips here, I observed him from a distance and believed in his love."
es: ––For the first part. I observed her carefully during the two visits I made to her recently, and I became convinced of her affection for Bingley.

en: “And your assurance of it, I suppose, carried immediate conviction to him.”
vi: - And I suppose when you believe so, Mr. Bingley also believes you.
tr: "Your certainty must have immediately instilled belief in him.""
es: ––And his conviction also left him convinced, right?

en: “It did. Bingley is most unaffectedly modest. His diffidence had prevented his depending on his own judgment in so anxious a case, but his reliance on mine made everything easy. I was obliged to confess one thing, which for a time, and not unjustly, offended him. I could not allow myself to conceal that your sister had been in town three months last winter, that I had known it, and purposely kept it from him. He was angry. But his anger, I am persuaded, lasted no longer than he remained in any doubt of your sister’s sentiments. He has heartily forgiven me now.”
vi: - That's right. Bingley is the most genuinely shy person. He lacks confidence and cannot rely on his own judgment, so he depends on you, making everything easier. You must admit that something else made him feel justifiably offended for a while. You could no longer hide the fact that you knew the sisters had been residing in the city for three months but still did not inform him. He was angry. But you believe he won't be angry with you for long once he has no doubts about the sisters' love. He has now fully forgiven you.
tr: "Indeed. Bingley is genuinely humble. His shyness prevented him from trusting his own instincts on such an important matter, but trusting me made things easier. However, there was something I had to admit that, for a while, and justifiably, upset him. It wouldn't have sat well with me not to tell him that I knew your sister stayed in the city for three months last winter and deliberately kept it from him. Of course, he was angry. But his anger didn't last longer than his doubt about your sister's feelings. He has now completely forgiven me."
es: ––That's right. Bingley is the most modest and least conceited man in the world. His timidity prevented him from trusting his own judgment in such an important matter; but his submission to mine settled everything. I had to tell him something that for a time, and quite rightly, had him very upset. I couldn't hide from him that his sister had been in London for three months last winter, that I knew it, and that I didn't tell him on purpose. He was very angry. But I'm sure he got over it when he was convinced that his sister still loved him. Now he has forgiven me wholeheartedly.

en: Elizabeth longed to observe that Mr. Bingley had been a most delightful friend; so easily guided that his worth was invaluable; but she checked herself. She remembered that he had yet to learn to be laughed at, and it was rather too early to begin. In anticipating the happiness of Bingley, which of course was to be inferior only to his own, he continued the conversation till they reached the house. In the hall they parted.
vi: Elizabeth wanted to remark that Mr. Bingley was the most charming and easily led friend, so her lover indeed had some talent. But she restrained herself. She remembered that he had not yet learned to endure jokes, and it was too soon to joke now. In the belief of Bingley's happiness, which of course was not equal to his current happiness, he continued the conversation until they reached home. They parted ways in the foyer.
tr: Elizabeth wanted to say that Mr. Bingley was a sweet friend, and that his being very easy to manage made him very valuable, but she restrained herself. She remembered that Darcy still needed to learn to be teased, but it was a bit early to start. Darcy continued the conversation until they got home, imagining Bingley's happiness as pale in comparison to his own. They parted in the hall.
es: Elizabeth would have liked to add that Bingley was the most wonderful of friends for the ease with which he could be brought and taken, and that he was truly invaluable. But she restrained herself. She remembered that Darcy still had to learn to laugh at these things, and that it was too soon to start. Speculating about Bingley's happiness which, of course, could only be inferior to theirs, Darcy kept talking until they reached the house. They said goodbye in the hall.

en: CHAPTER LIX.
vi: Chapter 59
tr: Chapter XVII
es: CHAPTER LIX

en: “MY dear Lizzy, where can you have been walking to?” was a question which Elizabeth received from Jane as soon as she entered the room, and from all the others when they sat down to table. She had only to say in reply, that they had wandered about till she was beyond her own knowledge. She coloured as she spoke; but neither that, nor anything else, awakened a suspicion of the truth.
vi: Everyone in the family asked her where she had been, but she only replied that the two of them had just wandered around here and there until she was no longer sure where she had gone. She blushed when she answered, but this or other things did not make anyone suspicious.
tr: "My dear Lizzy, where could you have walked?" This was the question Jane asked Elizabeth as soon as she entered the room, and the same question was posed by all the others when they sat down at the table. She could only say that they had been walking, without looking at where they were going. Her face turned red as she spoke; but neither this nor anything else raised any doubts about the truth.
es: Elizabeth, dear, where have you been walking? This is the question that Jane directed to Elizabeth as soon as they were in their room, and the one that everyone else asked when they sat down at the table. Elizabeth replied that they had been wandering until they reached the end of the path she knew. As she said this, she blushed, but neither this nor anything else aroused the slightest suspicion about the truth.

en: The evening passed quietly, unmarked by anything extraordinary. The acknowledged lovers talked and laughed; the unacknowledged were silent. Darcy was not of a disposition in which happiness overflows in mirth; and Elizabeth, agitated and confused, rather knew that she was happy than felt herself to be so; for, besides the immediate embarrassment, there were other evils before her. She anticipated what would be felt in the family when her situation became known: she was aware that no one liked him but Jane; and even feared that with the others it was a dislike which not all his fortune and consequence might do away.
vi: The evening passed peacefully without anything special. The couple who had publicly declared their love exchanged words and joked, while the couple who had not yet declared their love remained silent. Darcy did not have the temperament to express overwhelming happiness through jesting. Elizabeth was unsettled and confused; she recognized that she was happier than she felt; because besides the initial confusion, she also had unpleasant things ahead of her. She thought about her family's attitude when they learned about her love affair; she knew no one liked Darcy except Jane, and she feared that for the others, this was an aversion that even his wealth and status could not erase.
tr: The evening passed quietly, without anything unusual happening. The accepted lovers talked and laughed, while the unaccepted ones were silent. Darcy was not someone who overflowed with joy when he was happy; the excited and bewildered Elizabeth knew she was happy, more than she felt it; because in addition to the current anxiety, there were other obstacles ahead of her. She could predict what the family would feel when the situation was known; she knew that no one except Jane liked Darcy; she even feared that despite all his wealth and power, the others might hate him.
es: The evening passed quietly without anything extraordinary happening. The official couples chatted and laughed, while the unofficial ones remained silent. Darcy's happiness never overflowed into joy; Elizabeth, agitated and confused, knew she was happy more than she felt it, for besides her immediate bewilderment, other things worried her. She foresaw the commotion that would arise in the family when they learned what had happened. She knew that no one in her household liked Darcy more than Jane did, and she even feared that neither his fortune nor his position would be enough to satisfy them.

en: At night she opened her heart to Jane. Though suspicion was very far from Miss Bennet’s general habits, she was absolutely incredulous here.
vi: In the night, she confided her feelings to Jane. Although Miss Bennet was not in the habit of doubting anyone, she found it entirely hard to believe.
tr: He confided in Jane at night. Although doubt was not Miss Bennet's usual habit, she was definitely unwilling to believe it.
es: At night, she opened her heart to Jane, and although Jane was not naturally suspicious, she could not believe what her sister was telling her:

en: “You are joking, Lizzy. This cannot be! Engaged to Mr. Darcy! No, no, you shall not deceive me: I know it to be impossible.”
vi: - Lizzy, you're joking with me. It can't be! Loving Mr. Darcy! No, no, you can't deceive me. I know this can't happen.
tr: "You're joking, Lizzy. It can't be! –You're engaged to Mr. Darcy! No, no, you can't fool me. I know it's impossible."
es: ––You're joking, Eliza! That can't be! You, engaged to Darcy! No, no; you won't fool me. I know it's impossible.

en: “This is a wretched beginning, indeed! My sole dependence was on you; and I am sure nobody else will believe me, if you do not. Yet, indeed, I am in earnest. I speak nothing but the truth. He still loves me, and we are engaged.”
vi: - Indeed, this matter is starting to get troublesome! I only rely on you, and I am sure no one will believe me if you don't believe me. That's right, we love each other. I only know how to tell the truth. He still loves me, and we have made promises to each other.
tr: "It really was a terrible start! I only trusted you; if you don't believe me, no one will. Still, I'm telling the truth. I'm telling nothing but the truth. He still loves me; we got engaged."
es: ––Well, this is off to a bad start! I only trusted you, but if you don't believe me, others will believe me even less. I'm telling you the absolute truth. Darcy still loves me and we are engaged.

en: Jane looked at her doubtingly. “Oh, Lizzy! it cannot be. I know how much you dislike him.”
vi: Jane looked at her, suspiciously: - Oh dear, Lizzy, it can't be! I know how much you hate him.
tr: Jane looked at her with suspicion. "Oh Lizzy! It can't be. I know how much you hate him."
es: Jane looked at her hesitantly: ––Elizabeth, it is not possible. But I know you can't even stand him!

en: “You know nothing of the matter. That is all to be forgot. Perhaps I did not always love him so well as I do now; but in such cases as these a good memory is unpardonable. This is the last time I shall ever remember it myself.”
vi: - You don't know anything. The two of us have forgotten about that. Maybe I never loved him as much as I do now. But in situations like this, constantly remembering the past is unforgivable. This is the last time I want to remember it.
tr: "You know nothing. These things will be forgotten. Maybe I never loved him as much as I do now. But in such situations, having a good memory is not a forgivable thing. This will be my last remembrance as well."
es: ––You know nothing at all. We have to forget all that. Maybe I haven't always loved him as I do now; but in these cases, a good memory is unforgivable. This is the last time I remember it.

en: Miss Bennet still looked all amazement. Elizabeth again, and more seriously, assured her of its truth.
vi: Mrs. Bennet still showed signs of astonishment. Once again, Elizabeth solemnly confirmed that it was true. Jane exclaimed:
tr: Miss Bennet was still left in a state of astonishment. Elizabeth tried to convince her again, and this time more seriously.
es: Jane contemplated her sister with astonishment. Elizabeth reaffirmed with the utmost seriousness that what she was saying was true.

en: “Good heaven! can it be really so? Yet now I must believe you,” cried Jane. “My dear, dear Lizzy, I would, I do congratulate you; but are you certain—forgive the question—are you quite certain that you can be happy with him?”
vi: - Oh my God! How can that be possible! Now you have to believe me, but are you sure? I'm sorry, but are you sure you will be happy with him?
tr: "Oh my God! Could it really be true! But I have to believe you," cried Jane. "My dear Lizzy, I congratulate you – but are you sure? Forgive my question – I mean, are you absolutely sure you can be happy with him?"
es: ––Heavens! Is it possible? Really? But now I believe you ––exclaimed Jane––. Dear Elizabeth! I would congratulate you, I do congratulate you, but... are you sure, and forgive the question, completely sure that you will be happy with him?

en: “There can be no doubt of that. It is settled between us already that we are to be the happiest couple in the world. But are you pleased, Jane? Shall you like to have such a brother?”
vi: - There is no doubt anymore. Both of us think we are the happiest couple in the world. But Jane, are you happy? Do you want a brother-in-law like that?
tr: "I have no doubt. We have decided among ourselves, we will be the happiest couple in the world. Are you happy, Jane? Would you like to have such a brother-in-law?"
es: ––Without a doubt. We have already agreed that we will be the happiest couple on earth. Are you happy, Jane? Will you like having Darcy as a brother?

en: “Very, very much. Nothing could give either Bingley or myself more delight. But we considered it, we talked of it as impossible. And do you really love him quite well enough? Oh, Lizzy! do anything rather than marry without affection. Are you quite sure that you feel what you ought to do?”
vi: - Of course I want to. Nothing would make Mr. Bingley or me happier. But we have considered it before and said that it couldn't happen. And do you truly love him? Lizzy, you shouldn't marry without love! Are you sure you know what you are doing?
tr: "Indeed, very much. Nothing could make Bingley or me happier. But we thought about it and discussed that it was impossible. So do you really love him very much? Oh, Lizzy! Whatever you do, don't marry a man you don't love. Are you sure you love him enough?"
es: ––A lot, very much, it is what can give Bingley and me the most pleasure. And you, do you really love him enough? Oh, Elizabeth! Do anything but marry without love. Are you absolutely sure that you feel what you should feel?

en: “Oh, yes! You will only think I feel more than I ought to do when I tell you all.”
vi: - Of course! I just think you feel more than know what to do when you tell me all about this.
tr: "Ah yes! When I tell you everything, you will understand that I love you even more."
es: ––Oh, yes! And you will be convinced that I feel more than I should when I have told you everything.

en: “What do you mean?”
vi: - What do you mean? - What?
tr: "What do you mean?"
es: ––What do you mean?

en: “Why, I must confess that I love him better than I do Bingley. I am afraid you will be angry.”
vi: I just want to confess that I love him more than you love Mr. Bingley. I'm afraid you'll be angry.
tr: "I must confess that I love him more than Bingley. I fear you will be angry about this."
es: ––Well, I must confess to you that I love him more than you love Bingley. I fear that you will be upset.

en: “My dearest sister, now be, be serious. I want to talk very seriously. Let me know everything that I am to know without delay. Will you tell me how long you have loved him?”
vi: - Hey, it's time to be serious now. I want to have a serious conversation. Tell me everything I want to know, right now. How long have you been in love with him?
tr: "Dear brother, be serious though. I want to talk seriously. Tell me everything I need to know right away. Come on, since when have you been in love with her?"
es: ––Sister, dear, you can't be serious. Tell me one thing I need to know right now: since when have you loved him?

en: “It has been coming on so gradually, that I hardly know when it began; but I believe I must date it from my first seeing his beautiful grounds at Pemberley.”
vi: - It came gradually, to the point that I found it hard to know when it started. But I believe it was when I saw the beautiful scenery at Pemberley.
tr: "It happened so gradually that I don't even know exactly when it started. But I guess it dates back to the time when I first saw those magnificent gardens at Pemberley."
es: ––That love has come to me so gradually that I hardly know when it began; but I believe it dates back to the first time I saw his beautiful Pemberley estate.

en: Another entreaty that she would be serious, however, produced the desired effect; and she soon satisfied Jane by her solemn assurances of attachment. When convinced on that article, Miss Bennet had nothing further to wish.
vi: However, she had to assure Jane that she was serious, and eventually, Jane believed her. Mrs. Bennet wished for nothing more.
tr: The renewed request for seriousness had the desired effect; Elizabeth soon convinced Jane of the sincerity of her affection. Once convinced on this matter, Miss Bennet had no other wish.
es: Jane once again asked for formality and Elizabeth then spoke solemnly, affirming that she adored Darcy. Jane was convinced and was entirely satisfied.

en: “Now I am quite happy,” said she, “for you will be as happy as myself. I always had a value for him. Were it for nothing but his love of you, I must always have esteemed him; but now, as Bingley’s friend and your husband, there can be only Bingley and yourself more dear to me. But, Lizzy, you have been very sly, very reserved with me. How little did you tell me of what passed at Pemberley and Lambton! I owe all that I know of it to another, not to you.”
vi: She said: - Now I am so happy, because you will be as happy as I am. I have always held him in high regard. If for no other reason than his love for you, I would have already valued him; but now he is both Bingley's friend and your husband, only Bingley and you are the dearest people to me. But Lizzy, you have been too discreet, too reserved with me. You have told me very little about what happened at Pemberley and in London. I learned everything from others, not from you.
tr: "Now I am very happy," she said, "because you will be as happy as I am. I have always valued him. Even just because he loves you, I would always respect him; but now, as Bingley's friend and your husband, he is as valuable to me as both of you. But Lizzy, you have been very tight-lipped and very cautious with me. How little you told me about what happened at Pemberley and Lambton! All I know, I learned not from you, but from someone else."
es: ––Now I am completely happy ––he said––, because you are going to be as happy as I am. I have always had great esteem for Darcy. Even if it were only for his love for you, I would have to love him; but now that in addition to being Bingley's friend, he will be your husband, I will love only Bingley and you more than him. But how quiet and reserved you have been with me! Why didn't you tell me what happened at Pemberley and in Lambton? I had to learn everything from someone else and not from you.

en: Elizabeth told her the motives of her secrecy. She had been unwilling to mention Bingley; and the unsettled state of her own feelings had made her equally avoid the name of his friend: but now she would no longer conceal from her his share in Lydia’s marriage. All was acknowledged, and half the night spent in conversation.
vi: Elizabeth told her sister about the reasons why she had to be discreet. She could not mention Bingley, and while her mind was still in turmoil, she also wanted to avoid mentioning his friend’s name. But now she could not hide from her sister the fact that Mr. Darcy had helped with Lydia’s marriage. Everything was acknowledged, and they talked with each other until very late.
tr: Elizabeth explained the reasons for her secrecy. She was reluctant to talk about Bingley; the unsettled state of her own feelings similarly prevented her from mentioning her lover's name. But she would no longer hide her role in Lydia's marriage from him. Everything was told, and half the night was spent in conversation. ----------------------
es: Elizabeth explained to her the reasons for her secrecy. She had not wanted to mention Bingley, and the indecision of her own feelings made her avoid also mentioning the name of his friend. But now she did not want to hide Darcy's intervention in the matter of Lydia. Everything was clarified, and the two sisters spent half the night talking.

en: “Good gracious!” cried Mrs. Bennet, as she stood at a window the next morning, “if that disagreeable Mr. Darcy is not coming here again with our dear Bingley! What can he mean by being so tiresome as to be always coming here? I had no notion but he would go a-shooting, or something or other, and not disturb us with his company. What shall we do with him? Lizzy, you must walk out with him again, that he may not be in Bingley’s way.”
vi: The next morning, while standing by the window, Mrs. Bennet exclaimed: - My goodness! I hope that annoying Darcy doesn't come here anymore with dear Bingley! What does he mean by coming here and causing trouble like this? Mother just wants him to go hunting, or do something to keep from causing a disturbance. How are we going to deal with him? Lizzy, you must go for a walk with him again, so he doesn't bother Bingley.
tr: "My God!" cried Mrs. Bennet, as soon as she went to the window the next morning, "isn't that disagreeable Mr. Darcy coming here again with our dear Bingley! What could he mean by coming here so often? Wasn't he supposed to go hunting and leave us in peace? What are we going to do with him? Lizzy, go for a walk with him again, so he doesn't get in Bingley's way."
es: ––Oh, I hope that disagreeable Mr. Darcy doesn't come again with our dear Bingley! ––sighed Mrs. Bennet as she looked out the window the next day––. Why is he so bothersome and comes here continuously? He could go hunting or do anything else instead of coming to bother us. How could we get rid of him? Elizabeth, you'll have to go for a walk with him again so he doesn't bother Bingley.

en: Elizabeth could hardly help laughing at so convenient a proposal; yet was really vexed that her mother should be always giving him such an epithet.
vi: Elizabeth could hardly avoid bursting into laughter at this favorable suggestion, but she was still annoyed that her mother kept talking about him in such a manner.
tr: Elizabeth could hardly suppress her laughter in the face of such an appropriate offer; nevertheless, her mother's talking back and forth about her was truly upsetting.
es: Elizabeth almost burst into laughter upon hearing that interesting proposition, despite the fact that it hurt her that her mother was always insulting her.

en: As soon as they entered, Bingley looked at her so expressively, and shook hands with such warmth, as left no doubt of his good information; and he soon afterwards said aloud, “Mrs. Bennet, have you no more lanes hereabouts in which Lizzy may lose her way again to-day?”
vi: As soon as they entered, Bingley looked at her meaningfully and warmly shook her hand, as if to let her know he understood everything, then he said loudly: - Mrs. Bennet, do you have another path for walking so that Lizzy can get lost again today?
tr: The moment they entered the room, Bingley gave her a meaningful look and shook her hand so warmly that it was clear he knew; immediately after, he called out, "Mr. Bennet, is there no other path around here where Lizzy might lose her way today?""
es: As soon as the two gentlemen entered, Bingley looked at Elizabeth expressively and shook her hand with such ardor that the young woman understood that he already knew everything. Shortly after, Bingley said: Mr. Bennet, don't you have any other paths where Elizabeth might get lost again today?

en: “I advise Mr. Darcy, and Lizzy, and Kitty,” said Mrs. Bennet, “to walk to Oakham Mount this morning. It is a nice long walk, and Mr. Darcy has never seen the view.”
vi: Mrs. Bennet replied: - I advise Mr. Darcy, Lizzy, and Kitty to take the road to Oakham Mountain today. The road is truly beautiful; and Mr. Darcy has never seen the scenery of this place before.
tr: "Mr. Darcy, I recommend that Lizzy and Kitty walk to Oakham Mountain this morning," said Mrs. Bennet. "It is a long, pleasant road; and Mr. Darcy has never seen the view.""
es: ––I recommend Mr. Darcy, Lizzy, and Kitty ––said Mrs. Bennet–– to go this morning to Oagham Mountain. It is a long and beautiful walk, and Mr. Darcy has never seen that view.

en: “It may do very well for the others,” replied Mr. Bingley; “but I am sure it will be too much for Kitty. Won’t it, Kitty?”
vi: Mr. Bingley replied: - It might be suitable for the other two, but I believe it is too strenuous for Kitty. Is that right, Kitty?
tr: "It might be good for others," replied Mr. Bingley; "but I'm sure it will seem too long for Kitty. Isn't that right, Kitty?"
es: ––This might be fine for the other two ––explained Bingley––, but it seems to me that Catherine would get tired. Right?

en: Kitty owned that she had rather stay at home. Darcy professed a great curiosity to see the view from the Mount, and Elizabeth silently consented. As she went upstairs to get ready, Mrs. Bennet followed her, saying,—
vi: Kitty understood that she should stay at home. Darcy seemed eager to see the view from the mountain, while Elizabeth silently agreed. As she walked up the stairs to get ready, Mrs. Bennet followed, saying to her:
tr: Kitty said that she preferred to stay at home. Darcy said he was eager to see the view from the mountain, and Elizabeth silently agreed. As she went upstairs to get ready, Mrs. Bennet followed her and said,
es: The girl confessed that she would prefer to stay at home; Darcy expressed great curiosity to enjoy the view of that mountain, and Elizabeth agreed to accompany him. When she went up to get ready, Mrs. Bennet followed her to say:

en: “I am quite sorry, Lizzy, that you should be forced to have that disagreeable man all to yourself; but I hope you will not mind it. It is all for Jane’s sake, you know; and there is no occasion for talking to him except just now and then; so do not put yourself to inconvenience.”
vi: - Lizzy, I'm sorry for forcing you to go with that annoying guy. But I hope you don't mind, you know, this is for Jane, as she doesn't have many opportunities to talk to Bingley.
tr: "I'm very sorry, Lizzy, that I had to leave you alone with that grumpy man. But I hope you don't mind: it's all for Jane's sake, really; you don't need to engage in conversation, just say a few things now and then. So, don't stress yourself."
es: ––Lizzy, I'm very sorry that you are forced to be with such an unpleasant person; but I hope you do it for Jane. Besides, you only have to talk to her occasionally. Don't trouble yourself too much.

en: During their walk, it was resolved that Mr. Bennet’s consent should be asked in the course of the evening: Elizabeth reserved to herself the application for her mother’s. She could not determine how her mother would take it; sometimes doubting whether all his wealth and grandeur would be enough to overcome her abhorrence of the man; but whether she were violently set against the match, or violently delighted with it, it was certain that her manner would be equally ill adapted to do credit to her sense; and she could no more bear that Mr. Darcy should hear the first raptures of her joy, than the first vehemence of her disapprobation.
vi: While taking a walk, the two agreed that they would ask Mr. Bennet for permission this evening. Elizabeth wanted to take it upon herself to seek her mother's opinion. She was unsure how her mother would receive the news; at times she feared that his wealth and status would not be enough to stop her mother from detesting him. But whether her mother reacted with intense opposition or intense joy, her demeanor would certainly not align with Elizabeth's sensibilities, and she could no longer bear the thought of Mr. Darcy having to hear her mother's initial enthusiastic remarks from joy, though it would be better than her initial angry remarks from disapproval. **
tr: During the walk, it was decided to obtain Mr. Bennet's consent in the evening. Elizabeth reserved the task of seeking her mother's consent for herself. She couldn't decide how her mother would react; sometimes she doubted whether all his wealth and splendor would be enough to overcome her coldness towards the man. But whether she fiercely opposed the marriage or rejoiced intensely, it was certain that her actions would be equally far from common sense; she couldn't bear for Mr. Darcy to hear either the first excitement of her joy or the initial turmoil of her objection.
es: During the walk, they decided that that very afternoon they would ask for the father's consent. Elizabeth reserved for herself the task of informing the mother. She could not imagine how she would take it; sometimes she doubted whether all of Darcy's wealth and lineage would be enough to counteract the hatred she harbored for him; but whether she opposed the marriage violently or approved of it with equal vehemence, there was no doubt that her outbursts would not be any indication of good sense, and for that reason, she could not bear for Darcy to witness either the first raptures of joy or the initial expressions of disapproval.

en: In the evening, soon after Mr. Bennet withdrew to the library, she saw Mr. Darcy rise also and follow him, and her agitation on seeing it was extreme. She did not fear her father’s opposition, but he was going to be made unhappy, and that it should be through her means; that she, his favourite child, should be distressing him by her choice, should be filling him with fears and regrets in disposing of her, was a wretched reflection, and she sat in misery till Mr. Darcy appeared again, when, looking at him, she was a little relieved by his smile. In a few minutes he approached the table where she was sitting with Kitty; and, while pretending to admire her work, said in a whisper, “Go to your father; he wants you in the library.” She was gone directly.
vi: In the evening, right after Mr. Bennet returned to the study, she saw Darcy stand up and follow him, her mind in extreme turmoil. She did not fear her father’s refusal, but she was worried that he would be upset, and it was because of her, his beloved daughter, that he would be saddened by her choice, causing him to regret her. She sat there, thinking endlessly in misery, until Darcy returned, and seeing him, she felt somewhat relieved by his smile. He came to her, whispering: "You should go see your father; he wants to meet you in the study."
tr: -------------------------- In the evening, just after Mr. Bennet had withdrawn to the library, he saw Mr. Darcy get up and follow him, and at that moment he felt a great excitement. He was not afraid that his father would object, but the thought that his father's favorite daughter would upset him with her choice, that sending her off would leave him in tears and regret, was a painful one, and Elizabeth sat in agony until Mr. Darcy returned; seeing the smile on Mr. Darcy's face relieved her a little. A few minutes later, Mr. Darcy approached the table where Kitty was sitting; pretending to look at the crochet work in his hand, he whispered in her ear, "Go to your father, he wants you in the library." Elizabeth went immediately.
es: In the afternoon, shortly after Mr. Bennet had retired to his library, Elizabeth saw Darcy rise and follow him. Her heart began to beat strongly. She did not fear that her father would oppose, but it would grieve him greatly, and the fact that it was she, his favorite daughter, who was causing him such distress and who would inspire him with so much care and sorrow with her unfortunate choice, made Elizabeth very sad. She was very downcast until Darcy re-entered and, upon looking at him, his smile gave her encouragement. A few minutes later, Darcy approached the table where Elizabeth was sitting with Catherine, and pretending to look at her work, he whispered in her ear: ––Go see your father: he needs you in the library. Elizabeth dashed out.

en: Her father was walking about the room, looking grave and anxious. “Lizzy,” said he, “what are you doing? Are you out of your senses to be accepting this man? Have not you always hated him?”
vi: The father is walking around the room, showing a serious and anxious expression. He says: - Lizzy, what are you doing? Are you out of your mind, accepting a guy like that? Didn't you always hate him?
tr: Her father was pacing up and down the room, looking serious and worried. "Lizzy," he said, "what are you doing? Have you lost your mind to accept this man? Didn't you always hate him?"
es: His father was pacing around the room and seemed very serious and restless. ––Elizabeth ––he said––, what are you going to do? Are you in your right mind to accept that man? Didn't we agree that you hated him?

en: How earnestly did she then wish that her former opinions had been more reasonable, her expressions more moderate! It would have spared her from explanations and professions which it was exceedingly awkward to give; but they were now necessary, and she assured him, with some confusion, of her attachment to Mr. Darcy.
vi: Now she earnestly wished that her initial opinions had been more appropriate, and her initial words had been more gentle! If that had been the case, she wouldn't have to explain and confess in such embarrassment, but she still had to try. With a few stumbling words, she persuaded her father to believe in her love for Darcy. The father said:
tr: Oh, how sincerely Elizabeth wished that her previous views and statements had been more moderate! She wouldn't have had to make extremely disturbing explanations; but now they were necessary, and Elizabeth, albeit with some haste, convinced her father that she loved Mr. Darcy.
es: How Elizabeth regretted that her first impression of Darcy had been so unjust and her expressions so immoderate! Thus, she would have spared herself certain explanations and confessions that caused her great embarrassment, but which were unavoidable. Quite confused, Elizabeth assured her father that she loved Darcy deeply.

en: “Or, in other words, you are determined to have him. He is rich, to be sure, and you may have more fine clothes and fine carriages than Jane. But will they make you happy?”
vi: - Or in other words, you want to marry him. He is wealthy, of course, and you could have more luxurious clothes, more splendid carriages than Jane's. But would these things make you happier?
tr: "So, in other words, you are determined to accept it. Wealthy, of course; you will have more beautiful dresses and more luxurious cars than Jane. But will these make you happy?"
es: ––In other words, you are determined to marry him. He is rich, that's true; you will be able to have better clothes and better cars than Jane. But will all that make you happy?

en: “Have you any other objection,” said Elizabeth, “than your belief of my indifference?”
vi: Elizabeth asked: - Does Dad have any other reason to oppose besides believing that I'm indifferent towards him?
tr: "Do you have any objections other than thinking that I'm not interested?""
es: ––Is your only objection that you think I don't love him?

en: “None at all. We all know him to be a proud, unpleasant sort of man; but this would be nothing if you really liked him.”
vi: - Nothing else. We all know he is a proud, difficult person, but this doesn't mean anything if you love him.
tr: "Not at all. We all know that he is a proud, repulsive man; but if you really like him, it doesn't matter at all."
es: ––No more, no less. We all know he is a proud and unpleasant man; but this doesn't matter if you like him.

en: “I do, I do like him,” she replied, with tears in her eyes; “I love him. Indeed he has no improper pride. He is perfectly amiable. You do not know what he really is; then pray do not pain me by speaking of him in such terms.”
vi: She replied, with tears at the corner of her eyes: - I care about him, I love him. In fact, he has no undeserved pride. He is completely likable. You don't know what he is really like, so please don't make me suffer by using such words to talk about him.
tr: "Yes, I like him," she replied, with tears in her eyes, "I love him. In fact, he has no undue pride. He is quite friendly. You don't know him well; so please don't talk about him like that and upset me."
es: ––Well, yes, I like him ––replied Elizabeth with tears in her eyes––; I love him. Besides, he has no pride. He is the kindest person in the world. You do not know him. That is why I beg you not to hurt me by talking about him in that way.

en: “Lizzy,” said her father, “I have given him my consent. He is the kind of man, indeed, to whom I should never dare refuse anything, which he condescended to ask. I now give it to you, if you are resolved on having him. But let me advise you to think better of it. I know your disposition, Lizzy. I know that you could be neither happy nor respectable, unless you truly esteemed your husband, unless you looked up to him as a superior. Your lively talents would place you in the greatest danger in an unequal marriage. You could scarcely escape discredit and misery. My child, let me not have the grief of seeing you unable to respect your partner in life. You know not what you are about.”
vi: - Lizzy, I accept. In fact, he is the kind of person whom I cannot refuse anything he has humbly begged for. Now, I yield to your wishes, if you are determined to marry him. But I want to advise you to think it through carefully. Lizzy, I know your nature. I know you cannot be happy if you do not truly love your husband, especially when he is not your equal. Your lively talents will place you in the greatest danger in an unequal marriage. You will find it hard to avoid scandal and suffering. My dear, do not let me be heartbroken to see you unable to respect your life partner. Elizabeth was still emotional.
tr: "Lizzy," said her father, "I have given him my consent. He is not the kind of man I would dare to refuse anything he condescends to ask for. If you are determined to accept him, I now give you my consent as well. But I advise you to think carefully. I know your character, Lizzy. I know that if you do not truly love your husband, if you do not feel that he is superior to you, you can neither be happy nor at peace. Your cheerful disposition would put you in great danger in a marriage that is not conducive to it. You cannot avoid losing faith and becoming distressed. My child, do not cause me the pain of seeing that you do not respect your life partner. You do not know what awaits you."
es: ––Elizabeth ––added her father––, I have given my consent. He is one of those men, moreover, to whom you would never dare deny anything they condescended to ask of you. If you are determined to marry him, I also give you my consent. But let me warn you to think it over carefully. I know your character, Lizzy. I know that you will never be happy or prudent if you do not truly appreciate your husband, if you do not consider him as a superior. The liveliness of your talent would put you in the gravest of dangers if you made an unequal marriage. You could hardly save yourself from discredit and catastrophe. My daughter, do not give me the distress of seeing you incapable of respecting your life partner. You do not know what that is.

en: Elizabeth, still more affected, was earnest and solemn in her reply; and, at length, by repeated assurances that Mr. Darcy was really the object of her choice, by explaining the gradual change which her estimation of him had undergone, relating her absolute certainty that his affection was not the work of a day, but had stood the test of many months’ suspense, and enumerating with energy all his good qualities, she did conquer her father’s incredulity, and reconcile him to the match.
vi: She replied with the most earnest and solemn demeanor. She repeated that Mr. Darcy had always been the one she chose; she explained the gradual change in her assessment of him. She expressed her firm belief that his love was not fleeting, but had been tested through many challenging months. She passionately recounted his virtues. Finally, she managed to convince her father's doubts; he yielded to her.
tr: Now, feeling even more emotional, Elizabeth responded in a serious and dignified manner; in the end, by reiterating that she truly liked Mr. Darcy, explaining that her opinion of him had gradually changed, assuring that his love was not a matter of a single day but had been tested by months of waiting, and listing all his good qualities in one go, she dispelled her father's doubts and secured his approval of the marriage.
es: Elizabeth, more moved than her father, responded with vehemence and solemnity; and in the end, she managed to overcome her father's disbelief by reiterating the sincerity of her love for Darcy, explaining the gradual change that had occurred in her feelings for him, assuring him that Darcy's affection was not a fleeting thing, but had withstood the test of many months, and energetically listing all his good qualities. To the point that Mr. Bennet approved the marriage without reservations.

en: “Well, my dear,” said he, when she ceased speaking, “I have no more to say. If this be the case, he deserves you. I could not have parted with you, my Lizzy, to anyone less worthy.”
vi: He spoke when she finished: - Well then, my dear, I have nothing more to say. If that's true, he deserves you. Lizzy, I can't let you go with anyone less worthy than him.
tr: "Well, my dear," he said, when Elizabeth had finished her words, "I have nothing more to say. If that is the case, it means he deserves you. I wouldn't give you to someone less worthy, my dear Lizzy."
es: ––Well, dear ––he said to her when she finished speaking––, I have nothing more to say to you. In that case, it is worthy of you. My Lizzy, I would not have given you to anyone who was worth less.

en: To complete the favourable impression, she then told him what Mr. Darcy had voluntarily done for Lydia. He heard her with astonishment.
vi: Having been favorably impressed by him completely, she recounted what he had done for Lydia. He was utterly astonished:
tr: To complete the good impression he had created, he told his father about what Mr. Darcy had done for Lydia on his own. His father listened to these in astonishment.
es: To complete the favorable impression of her father, Elizabeth recounted to him what Darcy had spontaneously done for Lydia. ––This is truly an afternoon of astonishment!

en: “This is an evening of wonders, indeed! And so, Darcy did everything; made up the match, gave the money, paid the fellow’s debts, and got him his commission! So much the better. It will save me a world of trouble and economy. Had it been your uncle’s doing, I must and would have paid him; but these violent young lovers carry everything their own way. I shall offer to pay him to-morrow, he will rant and storm about his love for you, and there will be an end of the matter.”
vi: - Indeed, this is an evening filled with wonders! And so, Darcy did everything: arranged the marriage, provided the money, paid off his debts; helped him join the military! All the better. It saved father a lot of trouble and finances. If you do this, father will have to pay off his debts and he will, but the young lovers are determined to do things their way. Tomorrow, father will offer to pay off his debts; he will boast about his love for you, and that will be the end of it.
tr: "This evening is truly an evening of miracles! So Darcy did everything; arranged the wedding, paid the money, settled the man's debts, found a job! It couldn't have been better. He will save me from a world of trouble and expense. If my uncle had done it, I would have had to pay him and I would have; but these wild young lovers do everything as they know best. Tomorrow I will offer to pay him; he will fume, rage, talk about his love for you, and the matter will be closed like that."
es: ––This is truly an afternoon of astonishment! So Darcy did everything: arranged the marriage, gave the money, paid the young man's debts, and secured his position? Better: this way I'll be free from a sea of confusions and accounts. If your uncle had done it, I would have had to pay him; but these young and passionate lovers take care of everything. Tomorrow I will offer to pay him; he will protest and make a scene invoking his love for you, and the matter will be settled.

en: He then recollected her embarrassment a few days before on his reading Mr. Collins’s letter; and after laughing at her some time, allowed her at last to go, saying, as she quitted the room, “If any young men come for Mary or Kitty, send them in, for I am quite at leisure.”
vi: Then he recalled her embarrassment a few days earlier, when he read Collins' letter, and after teasing her for a moment, he allowed her to go outside - saying as she turned away: - If there is any young man who wants to marry Mary or Kitty, invite them in here, because father is very happy.
tr: Then, he remembered how uncomfortable Elizabeth was while reading Mr. Collins' letter a few days ago; after laughing at Elizabeth for a while, he finally allowed her to leave – and as she was leaving the room, he said, "If there are any young men coming for Mary and Kitty, send them in too, while I have nothing else to do.""
es: Then Mr. Bennet remembered how badly Elizabeth had felt while he was reading Collins' letter to her, and after joking with her for a while, he let her go and said as she was leaving the room: ––If any boy comes for Mary or Catherine, send him to me, as I am completely unoccupied.

en: Elizabeth’s mind was now relieved from a very heavy weight; and, after half an hour’s quiet reflection in her own room, she was able to join the others with tolerable composure. Everything was too recent for gaiety, but the evening passed tranquilly away; there was no longer anything material to be dreaded, and the comfort of ease and familiarity would come in time.
vi: Elizabeth's mind was now relieved of a burden. After contemplating for about half an hour in her private room, she was calm enough to rejoin the gathering. Everything was quite new, so there was nothing enjoyable. The evening passed peacefully; there was not much to fear, and before long, the comfort of ease and familiarity would return.
tr: A very heavy burden was thus lifted from Elizabeth; after calmly thinking in her room for about half an hour, she managed to join the others with a reasonable calmness. Everything was too new to be cheerful, but the evening passed quite peacefully; there was nothing significant left to worry about; the pleasure of comfort and familiarity would come with time.
es: Elizabeth felt as if a huge weight had been lifted off her shoulders, and after half an hour of quiet reflection in her room, she found herself ready to join the others, quite calm. Things were too recent to give in to joy, but the afternoon passed in the utmost serenity. She had nothing to fear, and the comfort of ease and familiarity would come in due time.

en: When her mother went up to her dressing-room at night, she followed her, and made the important communication. Its effect was most extraordinary; for, on first hearing it, Mrs. Bennet sat quite still, and unable to utter a syllable. Nor was it under many, many minutes, that she could comprehend what she heard, though not in general backward to credit what was for the advantage of her family, or that came in the shape of a lover to any of them. She began at length to recover, to fidget about in her chair, get up, sit down again, wonder, and bless herself.
vi: When her mother went up to the living room that night, she followed her, announcing an extremely special piece of news. The effect was extraordinarily unusual, for at first, her mother sat quietly listening, unable to utter a word. For a moment, she could not understand what Elizabeth was saying. Then she began to collect herself, fidgeting in her chair, standing up, then sitting down again, bewildered and wondering, then exclaimed:
tr: When her mother went up to the dressing room at night, Elizabeth followed her and gave her the important news. The effect of the news was extraordinary; at first, Mrs. Bennet sat motionless, unable to utter a single word. It took minutes for her to grasp what she had heard; nevertheless, she did not refrain from concluding that she had heard something beneficial for her family or that one of her daughters had received a proposal. Eventually, she began to recover, stirred in her chair, stood up, sat down again, marveled, and kept talking to herself.
es: When her mother retired to her room at night, Elizabeth went in with her and made the important communication. The effect was extraordinary, because at first Mrs. Bennet remained absolutely motionless, unable to articulate a word; and it was only after many minutes that she could comprehend what she had heard, despite the fact that she was usually not very reluctant to believe anything that meant some advantage for her family or a courtship for one of her daughters. Finally, she began to recover and become agitated. She would stand up and sit back down. She marveled and congratulated herself:

en: “Good gracious! Lord bless me! only think! dear me! Mr. Darcy! Who would have thought it? And is it really true? Oh, my sweetest Lizzy! how rich and how great you will be! What pin-money, what jewels, what carriages you will have! Jane’s is nothing to it—nothing at all. I am so pleased—so happy. Such a charming man! so handsome! so tall! Oh, my dear Lizzy! pray apologize for my having disliked him so much before. I hope he will overlook it. Dear, dear Lizzy. A house in town! Everything that is charming! Three daughters married! Ten thousand a year! Oh, Lord! what will become of me? I shall go distracted.”
vi: - Oh my! Thank my God! Just think about it! Oh dear! Mr. Darcy! Who could have imagined! Is it really true? Oh, my dear Lizzy! You will be rich and famous! You will have so much money, jewelry, and carriages. Compared to you, Jane is nothing - nothing at all. I am so happy, so joyful! What a charming young man, so handsome, so tall! Oh! Dear Lizzy! Forgive me for disliking him before! I hope he will forgive me. You, my dear Lizzy! A house in the city! Everything is so appealing! My God! What will become of me?! I am overwhelmed!
tr: "Oh my God! What has happened to me! Just think about it! Oh my! Mr. Darcy! Who would have thought! But seriously, is it true? Oh! My dearest Lizzy! How rich and powerful you will be! What allowance, what jewelry, what carriages you will have! Jane's are nothing in comparison –really nothing. How delighted I am –how happy I am. What a charming man! –so handsome! –so tall! –Oh my dearest Lizzy! Please apologize on my behalf for never liking him before. But I hope he doesn't mind. My sweet Lizzy. A house in the city! Everything is so classy! Three of my daughters are married! Ten thousand pounds a year! Oh God! Something is happening to me. I am going to lose my mind."
es: ––Heavens! God bless me! What are you saying, dear daughter? Mr. Darcy? Who would have thought! Oh, my dear Eliza! How rich and important you will be! What a fortune, what jewels, what carriages you will have! Jane's situation is nothing in comparison, truly nothing. How happy I am, how delighted! What a charming man, so handsome, so well-built! Lizzy, my dear, forgive me for finding him so disagreeable before! I hope he forgives me too. Elizabeth, my heart! A house in the capital! Everything desirable! Three daughters married! Ten thousand pounds a year! My goodness! What will become of me? I'm going to go mad!

en: This was enough to prove that her approbation need not be doubted; and Elizabeth, rejoicing that such an effusion was heard only by herself, soon went away. But before she had been three minutes in her own room, her mother followed her.
vi: That was enough to know that she had agreed. Elizabeth was glad to see that only she had to hear such words. But she was only alone in her room for a moment. She followed her, exclaiming:
tr: These were enough to prove that there could be no doubt about her consent: Elizabeth, who was happy just because she had heard such a storm herself, soon left the place. But she had not spent even three minutes in her own room when her mother came after her.
es: This was enough to prove that his approval was undeniable. Elizabeth, delighted that those effusions had been heard only by her, left immediately. But she had not been in her room for three minutes when her mother came in.

en: “My dearest child,” she cried, “I can think of nothing else. Ten thousand a year, and very likely more! ’Tis as good as a lord! And a special licence—you must and shall be married by a special licence. But, my dearest love, tell me what dish Mr. Darcy is particularly fond of, that I may have it to-morrow.”
vi: - My dearest child, I don't know what to think anymore! Ten thousand a year, maybe even more! It's like Heaven! And a special marriage license. You should marry with a special license. But my dearest child, tell me what Mr. Darcy likes the most so I can prepare it for tomorrow.
tr: "My dearest child," she exclaimed, "I can't think of anything else! Ten thousand a year, maybe even more! Worthy of lords! And a private wedding. You will have a marriage certificate from the Archbishop himself, as you should. But my dearest child, now tell me, what is Mr. Darcy's favorite dish, so we can prepare it for him tomorrow."
es: ––Daughter of my heart! ––he exclaimed. I can't think of anything else. Ten thousand pounds a year and maybe more! He's worth as much as a lord! And a special license, because you must get married with a special license. My dear, tell me what dish Darcy likes the most so I can prepare it for him tomorrow.

en: This was a sad omen of what her mother’s behaviour to the gentleman himself might be; and Elizabeth found that, though in the certain possession of his warmest affection, and secure of her relations’ consent, there was still something to be wished for. But the morrow passed off much better than she expected; for Mrs. Bennet luckily stood in such awe of her intended son-in-law, that she ventured not to speak to him, unless it was in her power to offer him any attention, or mark her deference for his opinion.
vi: This is a forewarning of the mother's attitude towards him. Although she had been loved passionately by him and accepted by his relatives, Elizabeth understood that she still longed for a few other things. But the next day passed better than she thought, because fortunately Mrs. Bennet still had too much respect for her future son-in-law to dare to start a conversation with him, unless she wanted to show care or express respect for his opinion.
tr: These words gave troubling hints about how her mother might behave towards the gentleman; although Elizabeth knew she had Darcy's sincere love and her family's consent, she still saw that something was missing. But the next morning went much better than expected; because Mrs. Bennet, thankfully, looked at her future son-in-law with such admiration that she did not attempt to speak to him, except to show as much interest as she could or to indicate her agreement with his views.
es: This was a bad omen for what Mrs. Bennet's behavior towards the gentleman in question was going to be, and Elizabeth understood that despite having Darcy's ardent love and the consent of her entire family, something was still missing. But the next morning went better than she had thought, because, fortunately, her future son-in-law instilled such fear in Mrs. Bennet that she did not dare speak to him except when she could pay him some attention or agree with what he said.

en: Elizabeth had the satisfaction of seeing her father taking pains to get acquainted with him; and Mr. Bennet soon assured her that he was rising every hour in his esteem.
vi: Elizabeth was delighted to see her father making an effort to be friendly with him, and before long, Mr. Bennet reassured her that he was growing to appreciate him more and more.
tr: Elizabeth was pleased to see that her father had taken the trouble to get to know him; soon after, Mr. Bennet reassured Elizabeth by saying that his esteem for him was increasing by the moment.
es: Elizabeth had the satisfaction of seeing that her father was making an effort to become close with him, and he assured her, to top it off, that he liked him more each day.

en: “I admire all my three sons-in-law highly,” said he. “Wickham, perhaps, is my favourite; but I think I shall like your husband quite as well as Jane’s.”
vi: He said: - Dad loves all three of his sons-in-law. Perhaps Dad loves Wickham the most, but he thinks he will love your husband as much as Jane's husband.
tr: "I like all three of my sons-in-law very much," she said. "Wickham, I think, is my favorite; but it seems I will love your husband as much as Jane's.""
es: Elizabeth had the satisfaction of seeing that her father was making an effort to become close with him, and he assured her, to top it off, that he liked him more each day.

en: CHAPTER LX.
vi: Chapter 60
tr: Chapter XVIII
es: CHAPTER LX

en: ELIZABETH’S spirits soon rising to playfulness again, she wanted Mr. Darcy to account for his having ever fallen in love with her. “How could you begin?” said she. “I can comprehend your going on charmingly, when you had once made a beginning; but what could set you off in the first place?”
vi: Elizabeth was in such high spirits that she felt like joking; she wanted Mr. Darcy to explain when he first began to love her. She asked: - How did this start? I can understand that you continued in an engaging way after you started, but when did you start?
tr: When Elizabeth's spirits quickly regained their former liveliness, she asked Mr. Darcy to tell her how he had fallen in love with her. "How did it begin?" she said. "I can imagine that once it started, it continued sweetly; but what first moved you?""
es: Elizabeth soon regained her cheerfulness, and she wanted Darcy to tell her how he had fallen in love with her: ––How did it all start? ––he said to her––. I understand that once you were on the path you kept going, but what was the first moment you liked me?

en: “I cannot fix on the hour, or the spot, or the look, or the words, which laid the foundation. It is too long ago. I was in the middle before I knew that I had begun.”
vi: - He cannot pinpoint the date, or the place, or the look, or the words that laid the foundation. It has been a long time. He was in the process of continuing before he knew he had started.
tr: "I cannot distinguish the hour, or the place, or the look, or the words that started it all. It was a long time ago. I found myself in the middle of it before I realized it had begun."
es: ––I cannot pinpoint the hour, nor the place, nor the look, nor the words that laid the foundations of my love. It was quite some time ago. I was already half in love with you before I knew that I wanted you.

en: “My beauty you had early withstood, and as for my manners—my behaviour to you was at least always bordering on the uncivil, and I never spoke to you without rather wishing to give you pain than not. Now, be sincere; did you admire me for my impertinence?”
vi: - You have accepted my appearance, and regarding my gestures and attitude towards you, they are at least close to rudeness, and I often talk to you with the intention of hurting you. Now be honest with me, did you still love me at that time when I was being insolent to you?
tr: "At first, you resisted my beauty, and as for my behavior – my attitude towards you was always on the edge of rudeness, and I never spoke to you without a desire to hurt you. Now let's be honest; did you love me for my arrogance?"
es: ––Well, my beauty hardly moved you. And as for my manners with you, they bordered on rudeness. I never spoke to you except to annoy you. Be honest: did you admire me for my impertinence?

en: “For the liveliness of your mind I did.”
vi: - Still, because of the liveliness of your soul.
tr: "I loved it for the vitality of its soul.""
es: ––For your vigor and your intelligence.

en: “You may as well call it impertinence at once. It was very little less. The fact is, that you were sick of civility, of deference, of officious attention. You were disgusted with the women who were always speaking, and looking, and thinking for your approbation alone. I roused and interested you, because I was so unlike them. Had you not been really amiable you would have hated me for it: but in spite of the pains you took to disguise yourself, your feelings were always noble and just; and in your heart you thoroughly despised the persons who so assiduously courted you. There—I have saved you the trouble of accounting for it; and really, all things considered, I begin to think it perfectly reasonable. To be sure you know no actual good of me—but nobody thinks of that when they fall in love.”
vi: - You can call it insolent right here. It's not much less than that. The truth is, you are fed up with politeness, respectful manners, or proper etiquette. You despise women who only speak, act, and think with the sole purpose of catching your attention. You noticed me because I am different from them. If you weren't genuinely charming, I would have hated you for this attitude. But despite the pain you want to hide, your feelings are always noble and just, and in your heart, you completely detest those who fawn over you. There, you have helped me save the trouble of explaining, and honestly, when considering everything, I think it is entirely reasonable. I did not know clearly about your goodness, that must be it. But no one thinks about this when they are in love.
tr: "You could also call this arrogance. It was on the verge of becoming so. The truth is, you were tired of politeness, meekness, and unpretentious closeness. You were fed up with women who spoke, looked, and thought just to please you. I warned you, I caught your interest, because I was nothing like them. If you weren't truly friendly, you would have hated me for this; but despite the troubles you went through to hide yourself, your feelings were always noble and fair; deep down, you despised those who courted you with such care. Look – I saved you the trouble of explaining; really, upon thorough reflection, I am starting to find this quite reasonable. In fact, you never saw any good in me – but when one is in love, no one thinks about that."
es: ––You can call it impertinence, for it was little less than that. The truth is that you were fed up with courtesies, deferences, attentions. You were annoyed by women who spoke only to attract you. I irritated and interested you because I didn't seem like them. That's why, if you hadn't actually been so affable, you would have hated me; but despite the effort you took to hide it, your feelings were noble and just, and deep down you completely despised the people who so assiduously courted you. See how I have spared you the trouble of explaining it to me. And, the truth is, after all, I'm beginning to think that it's perfectly reasonable. I'm sure that now you don't find any merit in me, but no one notices that when they fall in love.

en: “Was there no good in your affectionate behaviour to Jane, while she was ill at Netherfield?”
vi: - When Jane was ill at Netherfield, wasn't your affectionate attitude towards her a good thing?
tr: Was there no kindness in the attention you showed Jane while she was ill at Netherfield?"
es: ––Was there no merit in your affectionate behavior towards Jane when she fell ill at Netherfield?

en: “Dearest Jane! who could have done less for her? But make a virtue of it by all means. My good qualities are under your protection, and you are to exaggerate them as much as possible; and, in return, it belongs to me to find occasions for teasing and quarrelling with you as often as may be; and I shall begin directly, by asking you what made you so unwilling to come to the point at last? What made you so shy of me, when you first called, and afterwards dined here? Why, especially, when you called, did you look as if you did not care about me?”
vi: - Dearest Jane! Who could treat her so poorly?! But you can highlight this matter in every possible way. You defend all my virtues, and even try to exaggerate them as much as possible. In return, I find every opportunity to tease and argue with you as much as I can, and I will start right now by asking you what made you finally not want to get straight to the point. The first time you visited me and then stayed for dinner, what made you so shy with me? Especially when you arrived, why did you act as if you didn't care about me?
tr: "Dearest Jane! Who could have done less for her? But still, consider it a virtue. My good qualities are under your protection, and you exaggerate them as much as possible; it falls to me to find a reason to argue with you again, to make you angry; well, I will start by asking you directly, why were you so reluctant to get to the point? What was it that embarrassed you so much about me when you first came and dined here? Especially, why did you act as if you didn't care about me when you arrived?"
es: ––My dear Jane! Anyone would have done the same for her. But interpret it as a virtue, if you wish. My good qualities belong to you now, and you can exaggerate them as much as you like. On the other hand, it is my duty to find occasions to contradict you and argue with you as often as I can. So I am going to start right now. Why did you take so long to talk to me about your feelings again? Why were you so shy when you first came and then when you had dinner with us? Why, especially, while you were at home, did you behave as if I didn't matter to you at all?

en: “Because you were grave and silent, and gave me no encouragement.”
vi: - Because you are solemn and silent, and you do not encourage me to be bolder.
tr: "Because you were serious and silent; you did not give me courage."
es: ––Because I saw you serious and silent, and you didn't encourage me.

en: “But I was embarrassed.”
vi: - But because I was confused.
tr: "But I was tense."
es: ––She was very violent.

en: “And so was I.”
vi: - And you too.
tr: "Me too."
es: ––And me too.

en: “You might have talked to me more when you came to dinner.”
vi: - You should have talked more with me when you came for dinner.
tr: "When you came to dinner, you could have talked to me more.""
es: ––You could have talked to me more when you came to eat.

en: “A man who had felt less might.”
vi: - Someone who thinks less about you would do that.
tr: "Someone who feels less could have spoken.""
es: ––If I had been less moved, I would have done it.

en: “How unlucky that you should have a reasonable answer to give, and that I should be so reasonable as to admit it! But I wonder how long you would have gone on, if you had been left to yourself. I wonder when you would have spoken if I had not asked you! My resolution of thanking you for your kindness to Lydia had certainly great effect. Too much, I am afraid; for what becomes of the moral, if our comfort springs from a breach of promise, for I ought not to have mentioned the subject? This will never do.”
vi: - Perhaps you have a reasonable answer, and I have a reasonable reason to accept it! But I wonder how long you will continue like this, if everything is left to you? I wonder when you will be willing to speak, if I do not ask you. My intention to thank you for your kindness towards Lydia had a great effect. I fear it was too great, because I should not have mentioned that secret, and if we feel comfortable about breaking promises, what will become of morality? This way is not good.
tr: "What a misfortune to have a reasonable answer for everything; and it's another misfortune that I am reasonable enough to accept it! But, I wonder how much longer you would have continued if you were left on your own. When would you have spoken if I hadn't asked you? My decision to thank you for the kindness you showed to Lydia certainly had a great impact. Too great an impact, I'm afraid; but, if our happiness is born from the breaking of a promise, where is morality? because I had to avoid mentioning that subject. No, this won't do."
es: ––What a pity that you always have a reasonable answer, and that I am also so reasonable to accept it! But if you had had to decide, we would still be waiting. When would you have told me something, if it is not I who starts? My decision to thank you for what you did for Lydia had a good effect; too much: I am scared; because how does morality stand if our happiness sprang from the breach of a promise? I should not have spoken about that, I will not do it again.

en: “You need not distress yourself. The moral will be perfectly fair. Lady Catherine’s unjustifiable endeavours to separate us were the means of removing all my doubts. I am not indebted for my present happiness to your eager desire of expressing your gratitude. I was not in a humour to wait for an opening of yours. My aunt’s intelligence had given me hope, and I was determined at once to know everything.”
vi: - You shouldn't torment yourself. Morality will still be quite good. The indefensible efforts of Lady Catherine to prevent us are the means to dispel all doubts. With the happiness I have, I do not owe you gratitude for your earnest thanks. My feelings at that time did not await your open-heartedness. What my aunt told me gave me hope, and I wanted to know everything immediately.
tr: "There is no need for you to strain yourself. Morality is in its place. Lady Catherine's unacceptable actions to separate us helped dispel all my doubts. I do not owe my current happiness to your desire to express gratitude. I couldn't wait for you to bring up the subject. What my aunt told me gave me hope, so I decided to learn everything as soon as possible."
es: ––Don't torment yourself. Morality will remain completely intact. Lady Catherine's unclassifiable behavior to separate us was what dispelled all my doubts. I do not owe my current happiness to your vehement desire to express your gratitude to me. I did not need you to tell me anything. My aunt's account had given me hope and I was determined to know everything at once.

en: “Lady Catherine has been of infinite use, which ought to make her happy, for she loves to be of use. But tell me, what did you come down to Netherfield for? Was it merely to ride to Longbourn and be embarrassed? or had you intended any more serious consequences?”
vi: - Mrs. Catherine has contributed greatly, and this must make her happy if she likes to contribute. But, tell me, why did you come to Netherfield? Just to go to Longbourn and be confused? Or do you have a more serious intention?
tr: "Lady Catherine has been of great benefit, which is something to be glad about, because she loves to be useful. But tell me, why did you come to Netherfield? Was it to ride all the way to Longbourn and be inconvenienced, or did you have more serious intentions?"
es: ––Lady Catherine has been, therefore, infinitely useful to us, something that should delight her as she loves being useful to everyone. But tell me, why did you return to Netherfield? Was it only to come to Longbourn to torment yourself, or did you think of achieving a more serious outcome?

en: “My real purpose was to see you, and to judge, if I could, whether I might ever hope to make you love me. My avowed one, or what I avowed to myself, was to see whether your sister was still partial to Bingley, and if she were, to make the confession to him which I have since made.”
vi: - My main purpose is to meet you. And if possible, I hope to make you love me. The reason I gave, or the reason I created for myself, is to see if your sister still loves Mr. Bingley, and if she does, I will confess to Mr. Bingley about what I confessed afterward.
tr: "My true purpose was to see you, and of course, to understand if there could be any hope of making you love me. The purpose I expressed, or the one I expressed to myself, was to see if your sister still had feelings for Bingley and, if she did, to tell Bingley the truth, which I already did."
es: ––My true purpose was to see you and to find out if I could still hope that you loved me. What I was confessing or confessing to myself was to see if your sister still cared for Bingley, and, if so, to reiterate the confession I had already made to him once before.

en: “Shall you ever have courage to announce to Lady Catherine what is to befall her?”
vi: - If you have the courage to confess to Lady Catherine, how do you think she will react?
tr: "Do you have the courage to tell Lady Catherine what awaits her?""
es: ––Will you have the courage to inform Lady Catherine of what awaits her?

en: “I am more likely to want time than courage, Elizabeth. But it ought to be done; and if you will give me a sheet of paper it shall be done directly.”
vi: - Elizabeth, maybe you need more time than courage. But I will do this, and if you give me a piece of paper, I will write it immediately.
tr: "It seems like I need more time than courage, Elizabeth. On the other hand, it needs to be told; give me paper, I'll tell it right away."
es: ––Maybe I'm more short on time than courage. Let's do it right now. If you give me a sheet of paper, I'll do it immediately.

en: “And if I had not a letter to write myself, I might sit by you, and admire the evenness of your writing, as another young lady once did. But I have an aunt, too, who must not be longer neglected.”
vi: - And if I didn't have to write it myself, I would sit by your side to praise your straight lines, just as a woman once did. But I also have an aunt whom I must not forget.
tr: "Even if I didn't have a letter to write, I would sit beside you and admire the neatness of your writing, just like another young lady once did. But I also have an aunt who should not be neglected any longer."
es: ––And if I didn't have to write another letter, I could sit by your side and admire the uniformity of your handwriting, as a certain young lady did on another occasion. But I have an aunt whom I don't want to leave forgotten for any longer.

en: From an unwillingness to confess how much her intimacy with Mr. Darcy had been overrated, Elizabeth had never yet answered Mrs. Gardiner’s long letter; but now, having that to communicate which she knew would be most welcome, she was almost ashamed to find that her uncle and aunt had already lost three days of happiness, and immediately wrote as follows:—
vi: Elizabeth had not yet written a reply to Mrs. Gardiner's long letter because she did not want to admit her feelings for Mr. Darcy. But now, with this news to write about, which she knew the reader would be very happy to hear, she was ashamed to think that her uncle and aunt had lost three days of happiness. Immediately, she wrote to them:
tr: Due to her reluctance to admit how much her closeness with Mr. Darcy had been exaggerated, Elizabeth had not yet responded to Mrs. Gardiner's long letter, but now that she had something very pleasing to tell, she felt ashamed that her uncle and aunt had already lost three happy days and immediately wrote the following letter:
es: For not wanting to confess that they had exaggerated their intimacy with Darcy, Elizabeth had not yet replied to Mrs. Gardiner's long letter. But now, being able to announce to them what would be so well received, she almost felt ashamed that her uncles had missed out on three days of enjoying that news. Her letter was as follows:

en: “I would have thanked you before, my dear aunt, as I ought to have done, for your long, kind, satisfactory detail of particulars; but, to say the truth, I was too cross to write. You supposed more than really existed. But now suppose as much as you choose; give a loose to your fancy, indulge your imagination in every possible flight which the subject will afford, and unless you believe me actually married, you cannot greatly err. You must write again very soon, and praise him a great deal more than you did in your last. I thank you again and again, for not going to the Lakes. How could I be so silly as to wish it! Your idea of the ponies is delightful. We will go round the park every day. I am the happiest creature in the world. Perhaps other people have said so before, but no one with such justice. I am happier even than Jane; she only smiles, I laugh. Mr. Darcy sends you all the love in the world that can be spared from me. You are all to come to Pemberley at Christmas. Yours,” etc.
vi: " My dear aunt, I should have thanked you earlier for the long, heartfelt letter, detailing everything that you wrote to me. But I must confess, I was so overwhelmed that I couldn't respond. You guessed more things than what actually happened at that time. But now, you can speculate as much as you like, let your mind wander far, let your imagination illuminate every aspect related to the matter, and you will not be mistaken in anything unless you believe that I have gotten married. You should write more to me and praise him more warmly than in the letter. I thank you and uncle, I want to thank you forever, for the decision not to go to the Lake District.
