How foolish I was to want to go! Your idea about the little horses is really wonderful. The two of us will drive around the garden. I am the happiest creature in the world. I am happier than Jane, she only smiles, I often laugh out loud. Mr. Darcy sends to you the love that he can spare from me. I hope your whole family will visit Pemberley during the Christmas holiday. Your uncle and aunt's niece/nephew "
tr: "I should have thanked you earlier, my dear aunt, for enlightening me in such a long, understanding, and satisfactory manner about the details, but to be honest, I was too astonished to write. You have assumed more than what is actually the case. But now you can assume whatever you wish; let your dreams run wild; let your imagination soar as far as it can, and if you do not believe that I am truly married, you could not be more mistaken. Write again at the first opportunity and praise him even more than you did last time. Thank you repeatedly for not going to the Lake District. How could I have been so foolish as to want to go there! Your idea of a pony is marvelous. We will walk around the grove every day. I am the happiest person in the world. Perhaps others have said this before, but none have been so right. I am even happier than Jane; she merely smiles while I laugh out loud. Mr. Darcy sends you his endless love, of course, whatever he can spare from me. You will all come to Pemberley for Christmas. Yours..."
es: Dear Aunt, I would have thanked you earlier, as was my duty, for your extensive, kind, and satisfactory description of the event you know about; but you will understand that I was too distressed to do so. Your suppositions went beyond reality. But now you can suppose whatever you please, you can let your imagination run wild, you can allow your fancy to fly freely, and you will not be more mistaken than if you imagine that I am already married. You must write to me soon and praise Darcy much more than you did in your last letter. I thank God a thousand times over for not having gone to the Lakes. What folly on my part to have desired it! Your idea of the ponies is magnificent; every day we will tour the estate. I am the happiest creature in the world. Perhaps others have said it before, but no one with as much justice. I am even happier than Jane. She only smiles. I laugh out loud. Darcy sends you all the love he can spare from me. You will all come to Pemberley for Christmas. Darcy's letter to Lady Catherine was different.

en: Mr. Darcy’s letter to Lady Catherine was in a different style, and still different from either was what Mr. Bennet sent to Mr. Collins, in return for his last.
vi: Mr. Darcy's letter to Lady Catherine had a distinctly different style, and it was also different from Mr. Bennet's letter to Mr. Collins.
tr: The letter Mr. Darcy wrote to Lady Catherine had a different tone; but what was truly distinct was the letter Mr. Bennet wrote in response to Mr. Collins' last letter.
es: And even more different was the one Mr. Bennet sent to Mr. Collins in response to his last one:

en: “Dear Sir,
vi: " Sir,
tr: "Dear Sir,
es: Dear sir,

en: “I must trouble you once more for congratulations. Elizabeth will soon be the wife of Mr. Darcy. Console Lady Catherine as well as you can. But, if I were you, I would stand by the nephew. He has more to give.
vi: I will bother you, as you have to congratulate again. Elizabeth will soon become Mrs. Darcy. Please try to console Lady Catherine. But, if I were you, I would side with the nephew. He has more good things to offer.
tr: I have to once again offer my congratulations to you. Elizabeth will soon be Mr. Darcy's wife. Console Lady Catherine as much as you can. But, if I were you, I would get close to the nephew. He has much more to offer.
es: I have to trouble you once more with the matter of congratulations: Elizabeth will soon be Mr. Darcy's wife. Console Lady Catherine as best as you can; but if I were you, I would stick with the nephew. He has more to offer.

en: “Yours sincerely,” etc.
vi: Sincerely "
tr: Yours sincerely."
es: I greet you attentively.

en: Miss Bingley’s congratulations to her brother on his approaching marriage were all that was affectionate and insincere. She wrote even to Jane on the occasion, to express her delight, and repeat all her former professions of regard. Jane was not deceived, but she was affected; and though feeling no reliance on her, could not help writing her a much kinder answer than she knew was deserved.
vi: Miss Bingley's congratulations to her brother on his upcoming wedding were affectionate and insincere. She even wrote to Jane to express her joy and to repeat her previous expressions of affection. Jane was not deceived, but she was still touched; and although she did not trust her sister-in-law, she replied more kindly than what the sister-in-law deserved.
tr: Miss Bingley's congratulations to her brother on his impending marriage were full of sweetness and insincerity. She even wrote to Jane because of the marriage, expressed her joy, and repeated all her former displays of affection. Jane was not deceived, but she was affected; although she did not trust her, she could not help but write a much kinder response than she knew was deserved.
es: The congratulations from Miss Bingley to her brother on the occasion of his upcoming wedding were very affectionate, but not sincere. She also wrote to Jane to express her joy and to repeat her previous expressions of affection. Jane was not deceived, but she felt moved, and although she did not trust her, she could not help but send a reply much kinder than she thought she deserved.

en: The joy which Miss Darcy expressed on receiving similar information was as sincere as her brother’s in sending it. Four sides of paper were insufficient to contain all her delight, and all her earnest desire of being loved by her sister.
vi: After receiving similar news, Miss Darcy's joy in writing to her brother was as genuine as his own happiness. The four pages were not enough to express all her delight and her desire to be loved by her sister-in-law.
tr: The joy Miss Darcy expressed upon receiving the same news was as sincere as the joy of her brother who sent the news. Two pages, front and back, were not enough to convey her satisfaction and her desire to be loved by her sister-in-law.
es: The joy that Miss Darcy felt upon hearing the news was as genuine as her brother's when he communicated it to her. She sent a four-page letter that still seemed insufficient to express all her satisfaction and her strong desire to gain her sister's affection.

en: Before any answer could arrive from Mr. Collins, or any congratulations to Elizabeth from his wife, the Longbourn family heard that the Collinses were come themselves to Lucas Lodge. The reason of this sudden removal was soon evident. Lady Catherine had been rendered so exceedingly angry by the contents of her nephew’s letter, that Charlotte, really rejoicing in the match, was anxious to get away till the storm was blown over. At such a moment, the arrival of her friend was a sincere pleasure to Elizabeth, though in the course of their meetings she must sometimes think the pleasure dearly bought, when she saw Mr. Darcy exposed to all the parading and obsequious civility of her husband. He bore it, however, with admirable calmness. He could even listen to Sir William Lucas, when he complimented him on carrying away the brightest jewel of the country, and expressed his hopes of their all meeting frequently at St. James’s, with very decent composure. If he did shrug his shoulders, it was not till Sir William was out of sight.
vi: Before receiving a reply from Mr. Collins, or congratulations from his wife to Elizabeth, the Longbourn family received news that Mr. and Mrs. Collins would be returning to the Lucas household. It wasn't long before they realized the obvious reason for the trip. Lady Catherine had become extremely angry after receiving her nephew's letter, to the extent that Charlotte wanted to stay away until the storm passed, but she still shared in the couple's happiness. At a time like this, her friend's presence was indeed a joy for Elizabeth, although when they met again, she sometimes had to acknowledge that the joy came at a high price, seeing Mr. Darcy having to endure all the ostentatious and obsequious manners of her friend's husband. However, he endured it commendably. He could even listen to Sir William Lucas's words when he praised Collins for having taken away the brightest gem in the land, and with proper demeanor, expressed every hope that they would meet again at St. James's. Only when Sir William was out of sight did he shrug his shoulders.
tr: Before receiving a reply from Mr. Collins or congratulations from his wife to Elizabeth, the Longbourn family heard that the Collinses would personally come to Lucas Lodge. The reason for this sudden departure was soon understood. Lady Catherine was so enraged by the contents of her nephew's letter that Charlotte, who was genuinely happy about the marriage news, wanted to stay away until the storm passed. The arrival of her friend at such a moment sincerely delighted Elizabeth; however, when they came together, she must have thought that this joy came at a heavy price upon seeing Mr. Darcy subjected to all the noisy and slavish politeness of her friend's husband. Nevertheless, Mr. Darcy endured these with admirable calmness. He even listened with a very dignified manner to Sir William Lucas, who complimented him on taking away the brightest jewel of the neighborhood and expressed his hope of meeting frequently at St. James's. When he was about to shrug, he waited until Sir William was out of sight.
es: Before any response from Collins or congratulations from his wife to Elizabeth arrived, the Longbourn family learned that the Collinses were coming to the Lucas' house. The reason for such a sudden move was soon known. Lady Catherine had become so furious upon receiving her nephew's letter that Charlotte, who was genuinely happy about the wedding, wanted to leave until the storm subsided. The arrival of her friend at that moment was a great pleasure for Elizabeth; although during their meetings this pleasure diminished when she saw Darcy exposed to Collins' pompous courtesy. But Darcy endured it all with admirable serenity. He even attended to Sir William Lucas when he came to congratulate him on winning the brightest jewel of the county and expressed his hopes that they would all meet at St. James. Darcy shrugged, but only when Sir William could no longer see him.

en: Mrs. Philips’s vulgarity was another, and, perhaps, a greater tax on his forbearance; and though Mrs. Philips, as well as her sister, stood in too much awe of him to speak with the familiarity which Bingley’s good-humour encouraged; yet, whenever she did speak, she must be vulgar. Nor was her respect for him, though it made her more quiet, at all likely to make her more elegant. Elizabeth did all she could to shield him from the frequent notice of either, and was ever anxious to keep him to herself, and to those of her family with whom he might converse without mortification; and though the uncomfortable feelings arising from all this took from the season of courtship much of its pleasure, it added to the hope of the future; and she looked forward with delight to the time when they should be removed from society so little pleasing to either, to all the comfort and elegance of their family party at Pemberley.
vi: The rude demeanor of Mrs. Phillips was a torment, perhaps the greatest torment, for his endurance. Although Mrs. Phillips, like her sister, respected him too much to adopt the familiar attitude that Mr. Bingley cheerfully encouraged, whenever she spoke, she revealed her rudeness. Her respect for him only made her speak less, but did not help her become more elegant. Elizabeth did everything to ensure he was not overly noticed by the two ladies, always wanting him to stay close to her or with family members with whom he could converse comfortably. Although such feelings somewhat diminished the joy of a couple newly in love, this situation created hope for the future. She looked forward to the day when the two would break away from such unexciting relationships, to live together in comfort and elegance with his family at Pemberley.
tr: Mrs. Philips's wildness, however, became another source of distress that truly tested her patience; like her sister, Mrs. Philips was so intimidated by her that she couldn't speak to her with the ease they derived from Bingley's good nature, but when she did speak, she became even wilder. Although her respect for her led to speaking less, it did not make her more graceful. Elizabeth did her utmost to shield Mr. Darcy from the frequent attentions of both, staying vigilant to keep him reserved for herself and the family members who could be spoken of without shame; although the discomfort arising from all this took away much of the pleasure of the courting season, it contributed to the hope for the future; Elizabeth began to eagerly anticipate the time when they would escape that tedious company and enjoy the comfort and elegance of family life at Pemberley.
es: The vulgarity of Mrs. Philips was another and perhaps the greatest of the contributions imposed on her patience, for although this lady, like her sister, had too much respect for her to speak to her with the familiarity that Bingley's good humor allowed, she could not open her mouth without saying something vulgar. Not even that respect, which earned her a bit, managed to give her any elegance. Elizabeth did everything she could to protect him from everyone and always tried to keep him close to her or to the members of her family whose conversation did not mortify him. The annoyances that all this brought took away a good part of the pleasures of the courtship, but added greater hopes for the future. Elizabeth thought with delight about the future, when they would be away from that society so unpleasant for both of them and enjoying the comfort and elegance of their family gatherings at Pemberley.

en: CHAPTER LXI.
vi: Chapter 61
tr: Chapter XIX
es: CHAPTER LXI

en: HAPPY for all her maternal feelings was the day on which Mrs. Bennet got rid of her two most deserving daughters. With what delighted pride she afterwards visited Mrs. Bingley, and talked of Mrs. Darcy, may be guessed. I wish I could say, for the sake of her family, that the accomplishment of her earnest desire in the establishment of so many of her children produced so happy an effect as to make her a sensible, amiable, well-informed woman for the rest of her life; though, perhaps, it was lucky for her husband, who might not have relished domestic felicity in so unusual a form, that she still was occasionally nervous and invariably silly.
vi: All of Mrs. Bennet's feelings of happiness were about the day she got rid of her two most deserving daughters. After that, the pride she would feel when visiting Mrs. Bingley and what she would say to Mrs. Darcy could only be speculated. Her earnest desire to establish families for her daughters had come true, and this created such great happiness that she became a sensible, pleasant, and understanding woman for the rest of her life. Although her husband might not quite match the family's unusual decorum, he was fortunate that her nerves still occasionally became as tense and foolish as before.
tr: The happiest day of all maternal feelings was the day Mrs. Bennet got rid of her two most virtuous daughters. It can be imagined that she then visited Mrs. Bingley with delightful pride and spoke of Mrs. Darcy. I wish I could say that, for the sake of her family, the success she achieved in her passion for marrying off her children made her a reasonable, charming, and sensible woman for the rest of her life; yet, perhaps, her continuing to be occasionally nervous and always foolish was fortunate for her husband, who might not have appreciated an extraordinary familial happiness.
es: The day Mrs. Bennet parted with her two best daughters was of great bliss for all her maternal feelings. One can imagine with what delightful pride she later visited Mrs. Bingley and spoke of Mrs. Darcy. I would like to say, for the sake of her family, that the fulfillment of her most fervent desires in seeing so many of her daughters well married had the happy effect of turning her into a sensible, kind, and judicious woman for the rest of her life; but perhaps it was a blessing for her husband (who would not have been able to enjoy the happiness of home in such an unusual form) that she remained occasionally nervous and invariably foolish.

en: Mr. Bennet missed his second daughter exceedingly; his affection for her drew him oftener from home than anything else could do. He delighted in going to Pemberley, especially when he was least expected.
vi: Mr. Bennet missed his second daughter very much, so his affection for her drew him out of the house more often than other reasons. He felt happy whenever he went to Pemberley, especially when everyone was surprised.
tr: Mr. Bennet missed his second daughter immensely; his love for her caused him to be away from home more frequently than anything else could. He enjoyed going to Pemberley, especially at the most unexpected times.
es: Mr. Bennet missed his Elizabeth greatly; his affection for her drew him out of the house more frequently than anything else could have. He delighted in going to Pemberley, especially when they least expected him.

en: Mr. Bingley and Jane remained at Netherfield only a twelvemonth. So near a vicinity to her mother and Meryton relations was not desirable even to his easy temper, or her affectionate heart. The darling wish of his sisters was then gratified: he bought an estate in a neighbouring county to Derbyshire; and Jane and Elizabeth, in addition to every other source of happiness, were within thirty miles of each other.
vi: Mr. Bingley and Jane stayed at Netherfield for only twelve months. Even his easy-going nature or her affectionate heart did not much enjoy living close to her mother and Meryton. The earnest desire of his sisters was fulfilled; he bought an estate in the countryside near Derbyshire. Jane and Elizabeth, besides their sisterly bond, now lived only thirty miles apart.
tr: Mr. Bingley and Jane stayed at Netherfield for only twelve months. Living so close to Jane's mother and relatives in Meryton was too much for both Mr. Bingley's easy-going nature and Jane's loving heart. Then the greatest wish of the two sisters came true; Mr. Bingley purchased an estate in a county adjacent to Derbyshire, and Jane and Elizabeth, in addition to every other source of happiness, came within thirty miles of each other.
es: Bingley and Jane stayed in Netherfield for only a year. The proximity of her mother and the relatives from Meryton was not desirable even considering Bingley's easygoing nature and Jane's loving heart. Then the golden dream of Bingley's sisters came true; he bought an estate in a county near Derbyshire, and Jane and Elizabeth, to their utmost happiness, were only thirty miles away.

en: Kitty, to her very material advantage, spent the chief of her time with her two elder sisters. In society so superior to what she had generally known, her improvement was great. She was not of so ungovernable a temper as Lydia; and, removed from the influence of Lydia’s example, she became, by proper attention and management, less irritable, less ignorant, and less insipid. From the further disadvantage of Lydia’s society she was of course carefully kept; and though Mrs. Wickham frequently invited her to come and stay with her, with the promise of balls and young men, her father would never consent to her going.
vi: Kitty, with many material advantages, mainly spent her time staying with her two eldest sisters. Although her new familial connections were of a much higher class than her friendships, she made significant personal progress. She did not have the uncontrollable temperament of Lydia, and once she was out of Lydia's influence, with proper care and management, she became less irritable, less ignorant, and less insipid. Of course, she was carefully kept away from Lydia's connections, and although Mrs. Wickham occasionally invited her to stay with promises of balls and young men, her father never allowed her to go.
tr: Kitty wisely spent most of her time with her two elder sisters. She made great progress within a society far superior to the one she had previously known. Her nature was not as headstrong as Lydia's, and with Lydia's example removed from her view, and with the necessary attention and guidance, she became less troublesome, less ignorant, and less tiresome. She was carefully kept away from Lydia's companionship to avoid any harm; although Mrs. Wickham often invited her to stay with promises of balls and young men, her father did not allow her to go.
es: Catherine, solely for her material interest, spent most of her time with her two older sisters; and by frequenting a society far superior to what she had always known, she made remarkable progress. Her temperament was not as indomitable as Lydia's, and away from her influence, she became, thanks to proper attention and guidance, less irritable, less ignorant, and less insipid. As was natural, she was carefully kept away from the previous disadvantages of Lydia's company, and although Mrs. Wickham invited her many times to her house, with the promise of dances and suitors, her father never consented to her going.

en: Mary was the only daughter who remained at home; and she was necessarily drawn from the pursuit of accomplishments by Mrs. Bennet’s being quite unable to sit alone. Mary was obliged to mix more with the world, but she could still moralize over every morning visit; and as she was no longer mortified by comparisons between her sisters’ beauty and her own, it was suspected by her father that she submitted to the change without much reluctance.
vi: Mary is the only daughter still left in the house. Being drawn into the pursuit of Mrs. Bennet's achievements, she could not sit still by herself. Mary had to integrate more with the world, but she still preached morality on every morning outing. Since she no longer had to suffer from the comparisons of beauty between her sisters and herself, her father thought she submitted to the change without much resistance.
tr: Mary was the only girl left at home; she withdrew from the struggle for success because Mrs. Bennet could not be left alone. She had to be more involved with the world, but did not neglect to pontificate about her morning visits; her father thought she submitted to the change without much resistance since she was no longer vexed by the comparison of beauty among her sisters.
es: Mary was the only one who stayed in the house and was forced to stick close to Mrs. Bennet, who did not know how to be alone. For this reason, she had to mingle more with the world, but she could still moralize about all the morning visits, and since she was no longer mortified by comparisons between her beauty and that of her sisters, her father suspected that she had accepted the change without displeasure.

en: As for Wickham and Lydia, their characters suffered no revolution from the marriage of her sisters. He bore with philosophy the conviction that Elizabeth must now become acquainted with whatever of his ingratitude and falsehood had before been unknown to her; and, in spite of everything, was not wholly without hope that Darcy might yet be prevailed on to make his fortune. The congratulatory letter which Elizabeth received from Lydia on her marriage explained to her that, by his wife at least, if not by himself, such a hope was cherished. The letter was to this effect:—
vi: As for Wickham and Lydia, their status did not change due to the weddings of the two elder sisters. He calmly accepted that Elizabeth must now know all about his ingratitude and mistakes that she was unaware of before, and despite what had happened, still hoped to gain material benefits from Darcy. Lydia's congratulatory letter to Elizabeth showed her that at least his wife, if not he himself, still harbored such hopes.
tr: As for Wickham and Lydia, their characters underwent no change due to their sister's marriage. Wickham steadfastly endured the belief that Elizabeth must now have learned of his ingratitude and deceit, which she had previously been unaware of; but despite everything, he did not entirely lose hope that Darcy could be persuaded to give him his inheritance. The congratulatory letter Lydia sent to Elizabeth due to her marriage indicated that this hope, if not Wickham's own, was kept alive by his wife. The letter was as follows:
es: As for Wickham and Lydia, their sisters' weddings left them just as they were. He philosophically accepted the conviction that Elizabeth would now know all his falsehoods and all his ingratitude that she had previously ignored; but nevertheless, he still harbored the hope that Darcy would influence his fortune. The congratulatory letter for her marriage that Elizabeth received from Lydia implied that such hope was cherished, if not by him, at least by his wife. It read as follows:

en: “My dear Lizzy,
vi: “Dear Lizzy
tr: "My dear Lizzy,
es: My dear Lizzy,

en: “I wish you joy. If you love Mr. Darcy half so well as I do my dear Wickham, you must be very happy. It is a great comfort to have you so rich; and when you have nothing else to do, I hope you will think of us. I am sure Wickham would like a place at court very much; and I do not think we shall have quite money enough to live upon without some help. Any place would do of about three or four hundred a year; but, however, do not speak to Mr. Darcy about it, if you had rather not.
vi: I wish you happiness. If you love Mr. Darcy half as much as I love Wickham, you will be very happy. It is quite pleasant to have such a wealthy sister, and when you have nothing to do, I hope you will think of the two of us. I believe Wickham is very eager to have a position in the court, but I don't think we have enough money to live without assistance. Any amount will do, around three or four hundred a year. But don't say anything to Mr. Darcy if you don't want to.
tr: I wish you joy. If you love Mr. Darcy half as much as I love my Wickham, you must be very happy. It is a great comfort to think that you are so wealthy; I hope you will think of us when you have nothing else to do. I am sure Wickham would love to have a position at the palace; I don't think we will have enough money to live without some help. Any position with an annual income of three or four hundred would do; still, don't mention this to Mr. Darcy if you don't want to.
es: I wish you the greatest happiness. If you love Mr. Darcy half as much as I love my beloved Wickham, you will be very happy. It is a great comfort to think that you are so rich; and when you have nothing else to do, remember us. I am sure that Wickham would very much like a court appointment, and we will never have enough money to live there without some help. I mean a position of about three or four hundred pounds a year; but, in any case, do not mention this to Darcy if you do not think it appropriate.

en: “Yours,” etc.
vi: Your younger sibling
tr: With my love."
es: I mean a position of about three or four hundred pounds a year; but, in any case, do not mention this to Darcy if you do not think it appropriate.

en: As it happened that Elizabeth had much rather not, she endeavoured in her answer to put an end to every entreaty and expectation of the kind. Such relief, however, as it was in her power to afford, by the practice of what might be called economy in her own private expenses, she frequently sent them. It had always been evident to her that such an income as theirs, under the direction of two persons so extravagant in their wants, and heedless of the future, must be very insufficient to their support; and whenever they changed their quarters, either Jane or herself were sure of being applied to for some little assistance towards discharging their bills. Their manner of living, even when the restoration of peace dismissed them to a home, was unsettled in the extreme. They were always moving from place to place in quest of a cheap situation, and always spending more than they ought. His affection for her soon sunk into indifference: hers lasted a little longer; and, in spite of her youth and her manners, she retained all the claims to reputation which her marriage had given her. Though Darcy could never receive him at Pemberley, yet, for Elizabeth’s sake, he assisted him further in his profession. Lydia was occasionally a visitor there, when her husband was gone to enjoy himself in London or Bath; and with the Bingleys they both of them frequently stayed so long, that even Bingley’s good-humour was overcome, and he proceeded so far as to talk of giving them a hint to be gone.
vi: Because Elizabeth did not like it at all, when replying, she tried to put an end to all such pleas and expectations. However, she still assisted her sister within her means, by saving on her own expenses. She clearly saw that their combined income could never be enough for them to be wasteful in their destitution, and in a lifestyle that disregarded the future. Whenever they changed residences, they turned to Jane or Elizabeth for a little help in settling outstanding bills. Even when peace was restored, allowing them to return home, their way of life remained unstable. They always moved from place to place to find cheaper living arrangements, and always spent more than their income. His love for the youngest sister soon grew cold; her love lasted a little longer. Despite her youth and temperament, she bore all the gossip and slander that her marriage had caused. Although Darcy never wanted to welcome him at Pemberley, to help Elizabeth, he still supported him in advancing his career. Lydia occasionally visited when her husband was enjoying himself in London or Bath. With the Bingley family, both Lydia and her husband often stayed for quite a long time, to the point where even Bingley's easygoing nature was exhausted, and he eventually found a way to subtly hint to the two that it was time for them to leave.
tr: Since Elizabeth did not want it at all, she tried to cut off any such requests and expectations in her response. But the help she could afford, she saved up by economizing on her personal expenses and frequently sent it to them. She knew from the beginning that two people with such expensive desires, incapable of thinking about tomorrow, could not manage with such a small income; whenever they changed cities, they would either turn to Jane or her with a small request for help to pay the bills. Even when peace was signed and they were brought home, their lifestyle was extremely chaotic. They were always moving from place to place in search of a cheaper house and always spending more than they earned. Wickham's love for Lydia soon turned into indifference; Lydia's lasted a bit longer; despite her youth and temperament, she maintained all the privileges that her marriage provided her. Darcy never accepted Wickham at Pemberley; nevertheless, for Elizabeth's sake, he helped him advance in his profession. Lydia occasionally came to visit there when her husband went to London or Bath for pleasure; but the two of them stayed so long at the Bingleys' so often that even Bingley's patience ran out, and he went so far as to mention that he might hint at them to leave.
es: And as it happened that Elizabeth found it very inconvenient, in her reply she tried to put an end to all such pleas and dreams. But she often sent all the help that her practice of what she called economy in her private expenses allowed. It was always evident that the income managed by people as extravagant as the two of them and so careless about the future, would be insufficient to sustain themselves. Every time they moved, either Jane or she would receive some plea for help to pay their bills. Their life, even after peace confined them to a home, was extremely hectic. They were always moving from one place to another in search of a cheaper house and always spending more than they could afford. Wickham's affection for Lydia soon turned into indifference; Lydia's lasted a bit longer, and despite her youth and demeanor, she retained all the rights to the reputation that her marriage had given her. Although Darcy never received Wickham at Pemberley, he helped him progress in his career out of consideration for Elizabeth. Lydia paid them a visit now and then when her husband went to have fun in London or went to take baths. They often spent seasons with the Bingleys, to such an extent that they managed to ruin Bingley's good humor and he hinted that they should leave.

en: Miss Bingley was very deeply mortified by Darcy’s marriage; but as she thought it advisable to retain the right of visiting at Pemberley, she dropped all her resentment; was fonder than ever of Georgiana, almost as attentive to Darcy as heretofore, and paid off every arrear of civility to Elizabeth.
vi: Miss Bingley was very distressed when Mr. Darcy got married, but because she thought she should retain the right to visit Pemberley, she set aside all her resentment, became closer to Georgiana, and treated Elizabeth well, albeit belatedly.
tr: Miss Bingley was extremely upset about Darcy's marriage; but she wisely decided to forgo her resentment in order to retain the right to visit Pemberley, showed even more affection towards Georgiana, continued to behave as attentively as ever towards Darcy, and fulfilled all her duties of courtesy towards Elizabeth without fail.
es: Miss Bingley was very resentful of Darcy's marriage, but as soon as she felt entitled to visit Pemberley, her resentment passed: she was crazier than ever about Georgiana, almost as attentive to Darcy as before, and so courteous to Elizabeth that she paid her overdue respects.

en: Pemberley was now Georgiana’s home; and the attachment of the sisters was exactly what Darcy had hoped to see. They were able to love each other, even as well as they intended. Georgiana had the highest opinion in the world of Elizabeth; though at first she often listened with an astonishment bordering on alarm at her lively, sportive manner of talking to her brother. He, who had always inspired in herself a respect which almost overcame her affection, she now saw the object of open pleasantry. Her mind received knowledge which had never before fallen in her way. By Elizabeth’s instructions she began to comprehend that a woman may take liberties with her husband, which a brother will not always allow in a sister more than ten years younger than himself.
vi: Georgiana now lives permanently at Pemberley; the relationship between sister-in-law and brother-in-law is just as Mr. Darcy had hoped. They love each other, and they love each other as much as they had intended. Elizabeth has a very good opinion of Georgiana, though at first she often listened with astonishment, almost to the point of alarm, at the lively, spirited manner in which the younger sister spoke to her brother. Previously, he had instilled in his sister a respect that almost surpassed affection, but now she saw him become the object of jest. The younger sister had acquired new knowledge that she had never known before. Through Elizabeth's teachings, she gradually understood that a woman could be at ease with her husband, while a brother might never allow a sister more than ten years his junior to adopt such an attitude.
tr: Pemberley was now Georgiana's home; the sister-in-law and sisterly love was exactly as Darcy had hoped to see. They managed to love each other as much as they initially wanted. Georgiana was the person who admired Elizabeth the most in the world, even though at first she often listened to her lively, playful way of speaking with her brother with a surprise that bordered on fear. She now saw her brother, who had always inspired a respect that almost overwhelmed her affection, as an open object of jest. Her mind was filling with information she had never encountered before. Under Elizabeth's guidance, she was beginning to understand that a woman could behave comfortably with her husband, which was not always a comfort an older brother could grant to a sister ten years his junior.
es: Georgiana then stayed to live at Pemberley and grew fond of her sister as much as Darcy had anticipated. The two loved each other tenderly. Georgiana had the highest regard for Elizabeth, although at first she was astonished and almost frightened to see how playful she was with her brother; she saw that man who had always inspired in her a respect that almost surpassed affection, become the object of frank jokes. Her understanding received insights she had never encountered before. Enlightened by Elizabeth, she began to understand that a woman can take liberties with her husband that a brother can never tolerate from a sister ten years younger than him.

en: Lady Catherine was extremely indignant on the marriage of her nephew; and as she gave way to all the genuine frankness of her character, in her reply to the letter which announced its arrangement, she sent him language so very abusive, especially of Elizabeth, that for some time all intercourse was at an end. But at length, by Elizabeth’s persuasion, he was prevailed on to overlook the offence, and seek a reconciliation; and, after a little further resistance on the part of his aunt, her resentment gave way, either to her affection for him, or her curiosity to see how his wife conducted herself; and she condescended to wait on them at Pemberley, in spite of that pollution which its woods had received, not merely from the presence of such a mistress, but the visits of her uncle and aunt from the city.
vi: Lady Catherine was extremely outraged by her nephew's marriage. When responding to the letter announcing the marriage, she revealed her true blunt nature and used heavy insulting language, especially towards Elizabeth, to the extent that for a time the two sides did not communicate with each other. But eventually, through Elizabeth's persuasion, Mr. Darcy managed to overlook the offense and sought reconciliation. His aunt continued to oppose for a while, then her anger subsided, perhaps due to her affection for him, or out of curiosity to know what his wife was like. She humbled herself to visit the couple at Pemberley, even though the estate was tainted not only by the presence of such a mistress, but also by the uncle and aunt from the city who came to visit.
tr: Lady Catherine was extremely angry about her nephew's marriage; in response to the letter announcing the marriage, she unleashed the most genuine bluntness of her character and sent Darcy such an insulting letter, especially about Elizabeth, that all communication between them ceased for a while. But eventually, through Elizabeth's efforts, Darcy was persuaded to ignore the insult and seek reconciliation; after some resistance, his aunt, either due to her love for him or curiosity about how his wife was managing, set aside her resentment and graciously visited them at Pemberley, even though the woods were tainted not only by the presence of such a bride but also by the visits of her uncle and aunt from the city.
es: Lady Catherine became furious about her nephew's wedding, and as she unleashed all her genuine frankness in her reply to the letter in which he informed her of his engagement, she used such immoderate language, especially when referring to Elizabeth, that their relations were interrupted for some time. But, in the end, convinced by Elizabeth, Darcy agreed to forgive the offense and sought reconciliation. His aunt still resisted a little, but she yielded either to her affection for him or her curiosity to see how his wife behaved, so she deigned to visit them at Pemberley, despite the desecration her woods had suffered not only by the presence of such a mistress but also by the visits of her uncles from London.

en: With the Gardiners they were always on the most intimate terms. Darcy, as well as Elizabeth, really loved them; and they were both ever sensible of the warmest gratitude towards the persons who, by bringing her into Derbyshire, had been the means of uniting them.
vi: In the Gardiner family, the couple has the closest relationship. Darcy, like Elizabeth, truly admires the couple and feels deeply grateful to the people who brought her to Derbyshire and subsequently acted as a bridge for the two to come together.
tr: They were always very close with the Gardiners. Darcy loved them as much as Elizabeth did; both always felt a warm gratitude for the people who brought Elizabeth to Derbyshire and facilitated their union.
es: The Darcys were always in the most intimate relationship with the Gardiners. Darcy, like Elizabeth, truly cared for them; both felt the deepest gratitude towards the people who, by bringing Elizabeth to Derbyshire, had been the cause of their union.
